column2: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 11 -- Mrs. Donald Rede Carse entertained with a buffet supper and dance tonight at the Salembier cottage which she has leased for the season. Mrs. Carse will leave next week for a three weeks' trip to California. Her week-end house guests are Mr. and Mrs. William Sidley, Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Clarke and Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Fisher.

SMITHSONIAN Institution scientists, under the leadership of Dr. Frank H.H. Roberts, will this month begin the excavation of one of the most remarkable archaeological sites in the New World. The site is atop a low mesa overlooking the Puercos River in Arizona, and in it lies a large part of the story of the evolution of a civilization from the village to the apartment house, according to Dr. Roberts.

ENOUGH themes are provided by the Summer exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art to keep those of us who write about such matters profitably engaged for an indefinite period. It is a delightful exhibition; one that -- especially since Mr. Barr says the pictures will be changed from time to time -- merits repeated visits.

Bonds called last week for redemption in June and future months prior to their maturity dates were of small denominations and consisted of municipal, foreign, public utility and miscellaneous issues. The month's total is now $8,751,000, compared with $11,143,000 in May, and with $83,128,000 in June, 1931, at corresponding dates.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- With the battle lines between the wets and the drys drawn tighter as the Republican National Convention approaches, the belief prevailed today among the party leaders that the convention would reject a straight repeal plank, adopt a plank advocating resubmission of the prohibition amendment and that the main fight in the convention would be as to whether ratification of the "re-submitted" amendment should be by State conventions or by legislatures.

AURORA. N.Y., June 11 -- The cornerstone of a new Administration Building at Wells College for which a fund of $525,000 was recently completed will be laid Tuesday after the sixty-fourth annual commencement exercises.

BERLIN, June 11 -- Before the Langnamverein, an association of business men of the Rhineland and Westphalia, Dr. Hans Luther discussed today the Reichsbank's policy in a speech that was remarkable chiefly for its admission that a foreign debt moratorium might have to be declared if the German export surplus continued to shrink.

MADRID, June 10 -- There are distinct indications, which may or may not develop in importance, that Spain has gotten over the novelty of her new regime. After all, tradition is a strong thing and when a nation has followed one creed and set of customs for 400 years a complete break is diverting at first, but a reaction is likely to follow.

The report of the League of Nations' special committee is positive and convincing in its conclusion that the gold standard "remains the best available monetary mechanism," but it is equally impressive in pointing out the misuse which has been made of it.

WEST HILLS, L.I., June 11 -- Society and horse lovers took advantage of the first opportunity this afternoon to see the Spring races of the United Hunts Racing Association on the West Hills course, across the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White near Huntingdon.

NEW recognition will be given to the professional interior decorator by the opening on Tuesday at the Knoedler Galleries of the first annual exhibition of the work of members of the American Institute of Interior Decorators.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 11 -- John E. Rousmaniere's Lynx II sailed home first today in the Atlantic Class in the weekly regatta of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club.

Thirty-six prizes will be awarded in the intercollegiate and interscholastic outboard motor-boat regatta at Lake Skaneateles, near Syracuse, on Friday and Saturday. Twenty-one will go to the college drivers and the rest to the schoolboys.

BOGOTA, June 7 -- The alleged financial imperialism of the United States is considered the greatest danger to the independence of Latin American countries by the congress of students of the various States of Colombia which met recently in the legislative hall of Cundinamarco and passed rsrolutions opposing the invasion of North American capital to the impairment of sovereignty.

ON June 30 the government of the United States will end its fiscal year with the largest peace-time deficit in the history of the country, but with the promise of a new budget balanced in the sense that current expenditures can be brought into line with current income.

IN accord with the Covenant of the League of Nations, which is the fundamental chart for the future, and in the spirit of the Pact of Paris, we shall seek security not for ourselves alone, but for all nations, all of which, small and great, have equal claims in our eyes.
Recent leasing and building changes have focused attention of realty interests anew on the Fifth Avenue section north of Forty-second Street.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., June 11 -- Sandy Hook's dunes belched smoke and flame today and the little town of Highlands echoed to the roaring thunder of big guns as the Fifty-second Coast Artillery sent ten tons of steel screeching out into the Atlantic.

MICROPHONE fright among politicians is rare, especially among the seasoned speakers who invariably take leading parts in the national political conventions. The keynote speakers and commentators to be heard from Chicago during the Republican and Democratic conclaves have all had ample experience at the ethereal mouthpiece.

A BY-PRODUCT of hard times is the discovery, or the rediscovery, of the public libraries by their owners, the people. Never before have the libraries been so popular as they are now. All of them report increases of demand for their services, some as high as 50 per cent.

The phrase, "Vacancy Survey" is preferred to "Rental Survey," in New York City, John L. Curley told the members of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at the convention last week in Chicago.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11 -- Taking advantage of perfect rowing condition, oarsmen of four universities in training here for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20 put in busy sessions on the Hudson River today.

Signing by President Hoover of the new tax bill caused a flurry of excitement during the week in the merchandise lines affected, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fiseher. Many stores placed substantial orders for toiletries and some made conservative purchases of furs.

IN an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine for May 22, Mr. Olin Downes discussed the present perplexities and the possible future of the Metropolitan Opera House, the present perplexities being largely financial. Mr. Downes thinks, and I agree with him, that the opera will depend in future more and more upon the support of a growing public, perhaps of moderate means, but intelligently appreciative of what is best in art.

BERLIN OUR young German authors are the flower of blossoming youth, whose every fault we forgive because of their very youthfulness and because of the high hopes we cherish for their future. But as we glance through a number of books newly published by these young people we grow sad with disappointment.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Borah, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, is studying tonight the summary of the report by the League of Nations gold delegation printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES today and expects, he said, to speak on the subject in the Senate next week.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 -- Eleven new meet records were established and another was equaled in the third annual New Jersey A.A. U. track and field championships today at Essex Field. The meet took the form of Olympic try-outs, with the three winners of each event being eligible to compete in the semi-final try-outs at Cambridge, Mass.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11 -- The New Jersey State police suddenly decided today to make public three statements made by Violet Sharpe, the maid in the Morrow home who committed suicide yesterday, in order to show that the girl had not been ill-treated during her questioning by the authorities, as had been intimated in a statement made in England by her sister, Emily Sharpe, also known as Edna.
The revenue act of 1932 which goes into effect on July 1 adds just one more little tax to the heavy burden that real estate is staggering under.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., June 11 -- After literally burning up the long, arduous Timber Point Club course to gain the qualifying round medal with a scintillating 75, Tack Mackie Jr. of the Inwood Country Club was eliminated today by H.H. ("Tex") Newton of Lido. 2 and 1, in the first round of the seventh annual invitation tourney of the Timber Point Club.

A PLAN for a uniform system of naming streets and numbering houses has been proposed by J. P. Schwada, City Engineer of Milwaukee. At present, Mr. Schwada points out, each town and city uses its own method. Most of them have named their streets haphazardly.

Textile High School's baseball team, defending city P.S.A.L. senior high school champion, yesterday defeated Evander Childs High, 9 to 2, at the George Washington High School Stadium in an interborough semi-final game to gain the title final to be played at the Yankee Stadium next Saturday.

LISBON, Portugal, June 11. -- Stanislaus Felix Hausner, New Yorkto-Warsaw flier, was rescued from his floating plane tonight by the British freighter Circe Shell, according to a wireless message from Captain Wilson, in command of the vessel.

LOOKING ahead to the possibility of a great apartment house area in the East Thirty-fourth Street section bordering and near the East River, a proposal to rezone for residential use the blocks adjacent to St. Gabriel's Park was submitted to the Board of Estimate last week by Borough President Samuel Levy.

OMAHA, June 9. -- The downfall of Senator Smith Wildman Brookhart in the Iowa Republican primary this week was not entirely unexpected. There had been signs for quite a while that some of his supporters were losing a little of their taste for him.

After beating an 18-year-old girl in a Fifth Avenue office-building corridor y esterday morning to rob her of a purse believed to contain payroll money, Solomon Bloom, a convict on parole, ran north in the avenue followed by an angry, threatening crowd from which two policemen and a detective with some difficulty claimed their prisoner.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Taking cognizance of the nation's demand that Congress conclude its business and go home, Senator Robinson, of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, today told the Senate that action should be taken on pending unemployment relief bills, agriculture relief measures.

CARACAS, June 5 -- Evidence that Venezuela was the cradle of civilization is offered in a volume on his archeological discoveries which is being published by Dr. Rafael Requena, private secretary to President General Gomez. The publication of this book will lift the veil of secrecy which has shrouded Dr. Requena's discoveries since they were announced briefly a year ago.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, and one of the country's leading industrialists, announced yesterday his conversion to the belief that the best road toward temperance lies through repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

TAKING an old story that was told around Monte Carlo many years ago, Hanns Schwarz has fashioned a charming light entertainment. It bears the title of "Monte Carlo Madness" and is the Ufa edition with English dialogue of "Bomben auf Monte Carlo" (The Bombardment of Monte Carlo), a film that met with no mean success in Berlin and elsewhere in the German Republic.

The trend of municipal bonded debt continues steadily upward, the increase for the larger cities of the country more than offsetting the reductions accomplished by smaller communities, according to C.E. Rightor of the Detroit Bureau of Governmental Research.

Inaugurating their drive for representation in the Olympic Games at Los Angeles this Summer, the lacrosse teams of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and Rutgers University survived the quarter-final Olympic play-off for the United States championship at Baker Field yesterday.

LONDON. THE success of the Religious Book Week last October has encouraged the starting of a scheme for another book week next Fall. This time it will be a Boys' and Girls' Book Week, and the date of it has been fixed for November 6 to 12.

A sharp rally in sugar and gains in silk were the principal features of the price movements in local commodity markets last week. All other commodities, including coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides, silver and wool tops, closed with losses for the week.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 11 (AP) -- With the majority of its vote predicted for President Hoover and carrying at least three plans for amendment or repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the Pennsylvania delegation leaves for the Chicago National Convention tomorrow.

A request that Federal aid to large-scale, low-cost housing projects be safeguarded by administration through State housing boards, by the establishment of minimum standards of construction, and by subordination of land costs to building costs, has been made to President Hoover, to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to members of the Senate and House of Representatives by Mrs. Joseph M. Proskauer, chairman of the Housing Section of the Welfare Council.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- Test borings for a new subway system have revealed that there are about twelve underground rivers flowing beneath Moscow's streets. These streams were built over so long ago that the existence of most of them had been forgotten.

THE zoological-governmental dispute over monkeys in England has been settled satisfactorily and amicably, the settlement taking place, appropriately enough, during the week which marked the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Darwin, who had considerably to do with the point under discussion.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Dr. Eugene McCaulill of Yonkers, N.Y., won the men's singles tennis chpmpionship of Pennsylvnnia and the Middle States today when he decisively defeated Dr. Carl Fischer of Woodbury, N.J., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2. 6 -- 2, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The historic meeting at London in 1918 at which Secretary of War Newton D. Baker rejected the Allies' demands, presented by David Lloyd George, British Prime Minister, for the removal of General Pershing as Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force, was described in yesterday's issue of The Nassau (L.I.) Daily Star by its publisher, Colonel Lloyd C. Griscom, former diplomat, who was then General Pershing's representative at the British War Office.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 11 -- Exeter staged an uphil fight today to win the fifty-eighth annual baseball game from Andover, 7 -- 5. The Red and Grey was a heavy favorite to win, but after Andover pushed over four runs in the opening frame it looked as though the dope might again be upset in the classic series.

ALL the stirring events related in this novel occur in a house built by a madman, and they are-just such events as one might expect in such a place. Men are struck down by unseen hands, bodies disappear and reappear, and there are lesser phenomena which are equally inexplicable.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 9. -- The Republican party in Indiana after playing with the Anti-Saloon League for more than seventeen years, adopted a wet plank in its convention this week which has the whole State gasping.

As chairman of the board of the Consolidated Gas Company as well as of ths Hiagara Hudson Power Corporation. Mr. FLOVD L. CARLISLE speaks with a voice of peculiar authority. His address at the convention of the National Electric Light Association in Atlantic City last week will be discussed among utility executives throughout the country.

ROME, June 1 -- A recent article, authorship of which has been ascribed to Premier Mussolini, in II Popolo d'ltalia, journal of the Fascist party, discussed the world economic situation with particular reference to inflation of currency in Britain, the United States and Japan.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- As the tide of delegates flows into this city for the Republican National Convention, opening Tuesday, the renomination of Herbert Hoover for President of the United States appears to be the only outcome that is assured.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The army of ex-service men seeking immediate payment of their $2,400,000,000 bonus certificates had swollen to 15,000 tonight, and the District of Columbia authorities found themselves facing the question whether they could much longer shoulder a problem which they regard as one of the most serious ever to confront the District.

GENEVA, June 11 -- So far as the disarmament conference is concerned, the discussions between Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Herriot, which began in Paris today, mark a basic change in what some call tile British and others the American disarmament strategy.

HATS off to Frau Eisenmenger For hers was a martyrdom of war that deserves the honor and admiration of even the most embittered enemy of the Central Powers, a martyrdom that endured for the ten years covered by her diary and was still "going strong" at the last entry quoted here, January, 1924.

IT was just a year ago that James Dunn, featured in "Society Girl" at the Roxy this week, reported at the Fox studios in. Hollywood. An unknown, he had taken, a screen test for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer at the Fox studio in New York. Metro saw the test and was unimpressed.

Twenty-eight policemen and agents of the Department of Justice, equipped with gas masks, crowbars and blow-torches, set to work yesterday to dismantle a distillery found last Monday in a nine-story building at 296 South Street.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., June 11 -- Thousands of persons visited the Ramapo Riding Academy at Tallman, near here, today as the annual Rockland County flower show was concluded. It was opened yesterday by the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia. Rollo Peters acted as chairman.

Hindrance to the recovery of industrial production and employment at the present time lies in the absence of a profit margin for many industries, resulting in part from the tremendously uneven decline of prices rents and wages entering into costs, as compared with selling prices, Dr. Warren M. Persons, consulting economist and former president of the American Statistical Association, told THE TIMES yesterday.

LIKE the unification of Italy that of Rumania was accomplished by two steps: the first a cohesion of obviously identical nationals brought about by the complex rivalries of the members of the European concert; the second an adhesion of irridentist populations to the entities thus produced, brought about by the World War and the Paris Peace Conference.

A sudden twist in the raveled fabric of the Lindbergh baby kidnapping case, tending to clear Violet Sharpe, the Morrow servant who committed suicide on Friday, as well as Ernest Brinkert, the latest suspect in the mystery, was revealed at 7 o'clock last night by Inspector Harry Walsh at the State Police Headquarters at Alpine, N.J.

New York State's delegation to the Republican National Convention left for Chicago yesterday afternoon on a special train, with most of the leaders confident that a suitable wet plank would be adopted.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- Babe Ruth smote the first ball pitched to him in Cleveland this year over the local right-field fence today for his eighteenth home run of the season, but its beneficent effect was offset subsequently by a brisk Cleveland batting offensive which landed the Indians their first victory of the year over the Yankees, 6 to 3.
OWEN D. YOUNG has said in one sentence the challenging baccalaureate word to the young men graduating from college and university this year:

IF the current legends about the origin of the Stars and Stripes are taken at their face value next Tuesday is the 155th anniversary of the adoption of our present national flag. Every school child has heard the story that General Washington took the design for the flag to Betsy Ross in Philadelphia in July, 1777, and that the ingenious Mrs. Ross, after suggesting some slight changes, produced the first national flag.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 11 -- The American women's team won the Wightman Cup tennis series today, but with nothing like the clean sweep which yesterday's three straight victories foreshadowed.

PARIS, May 25 -- Spring is the season for fairs in Paris, and they are treading upon one another's heels these days. Like all the Old World countries, France has never lost the custom or the liking for these gatherings, where one can bargain for and buy everything from sausages to fire engines.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony concerts at Lewisohn Stadium this Summer will be microphoned by the WABC network, beginning July 2. The programs will be broadcast each Saturday night from 8:30 to 10 o'clock. The conductors are Willem van Hoogstraten and Albert Coates.

DONALD BARR CHIDSEY'S study of Sir Humphrey Gilbert is a biography of uncommon charm. "Written with graceful deftness and no little humor, we have as breezy a story as any one could wish to read. Mr. Chidsey has such a whole-hearted affection for his man that he is able to make him live vividly through the pages.

WHAT amounts to international news in the theatre, almost as stunning to Broad-way as to the Strand, is Charles B. Cochran's announcement of early closings for his three spectacular London productions, "Cavalcade," "Helen!" and "The Miracle."

MOSCOW, May 24 -- Moscow has its millions who live and work in the city, overflowing the houses and crowding the street cars to the bursting point. But like New York it has has its thousands of commuters who pour into the city every morning from suburbs and villages within a radius of about sixty miles.

JUPITER has a family of some fifty comets, all captives. It is commonly supposed that these comets rushed in from outer space, but were unable to return because they fell a prey to the powerful attraction of the largest of planets. Professor S. Vsessviatsky of the Astronomical Institute, Moscow, thinks otherwise.

Federal aid for large-scale model housing would play as effective a part in overcoming the business depression as expansion of the automobile industry did in 1921, in the opinion of Clarence S. Stein of the committee on the economics of site-planning and housing of the American Institute of Architects.

To the Editor of The New York Times Now that it is obvious, from the changing temper of the people, that we are about to rid ourselves of the unfortunate experiment of promoting temperance by the so-called national prohibition amendment, way we not hope that, in doing so, we may at the same time restore our Constitution to its true meaning?

Samuel Insull, who came to America fifty-one years ago as an alert, ambitious and confident young Englishman to become secretary and allround assistant to Thomas Alva Edison, now stands, at the age of 72, bereft of the great fortune created by his foresight and vision, shorn of his many offices and with no plans for the future.

HAVANA, June 11 -- On recommendation of the Sugar Institute, President Machado today signed a decree permitting the exportation during 1933 of sugar remaining unsold on Dec. 31, 1932, from the quota assigned to the United States out of the 1931-32 crop under the Chadbourne plan.

Carrying out his announced plan of familiarizing himself with the evidence against Mayor Walker as soon as possible, Governor Roosevelt spent nearly all of yesterday at his home in Hyde Park reading the voluminous testimony submitted by Samuel Seabury in support of removal charges.

ONE is fortunate whose Life is in the bands of Miss Tarbell -- that is, if one has lived an honest, useful and undaunted life. When Owen Young comes to read what she has written -- for I happen to know that he has not read a line of it -- he must feel that the Van Hornesville boy has already done a man's full life's work in the world.
NEW YORK. Anthony J. Drexel is at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. John C. King have left the Savoy-Plaza for Southampton, where they will pass the Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- As Congressional leaders who are considering economy measures left the White House after a conference with President Hoover late tonight it was stated that Mr. Hoover had not insisted upon specific means of further saving, but had left the details to Congress.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y June 11 -- Prince Charming II, the handsome bay gelding owned by the Warfield Farms of Port Chester, took premier honors at the thirty-ninth annual Westchester County horse show, which came to a close on the grounds of the Rye Turf and Polo Club today.

IBSEN, or one of the Ibsen characters most representative of Ibsen, spoke in a famous phrase of the New Generation knocking at the door. He did not foresee that the New Generation would be more likely to enter without knocking.

Breaking fifty straight targets, T. Bedell Jr. won the High Scratch Cup at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club in a field of fourteen gunners yesterday. There was a tie for the Handicap Cup, the trophy finally going to R. Haf.

LONDON. CURIOUS prohibitions arc laid uponits members by the famous Carlton Club, which has just celebrated its centenary. One of the Carlton's hard and fast rules is that no discussion of a murder may take place within its walls.

LONDON, June 11 -- Mrs. Gilbert Miller, the former Miss Kathryn Bache, wife of the New York theatrical producer, will be presented at the third court of the season on June 23. The presentations will be made by Mme. de Fleuriau, wife of the French Ambassador, at the request of Ambassador Mellon.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- Mouette, Horace Havemeyer's twelve-meter importation from England, continued her winning habits today in the Spring regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, held on Long Lsland Sound. She did not distance her competitors again, however.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 11. -- Warning that the new Junta would adopt vigorous measures against any subversive Communist activities, Col. Marmaduque Grove, the Minister of Defense, defined today for the first time the line dividing the Socialist program of the new government from communistic principles, which have been insistently brought to the fore by some of the government's supporters.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- With virtually the entire $750,000,000 obtained by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation obligated or actually lent out, new borrowing within a short time was indicated today at the Treasury.

EVER since some now forgotten courier came charging into town to arouse the citizenry with the report that the road was dead, plans to revive that ailing branch of the drama have bloomed in pleasant but notoriously ineffective clusters.

DETROIT MOTOR company executives will watch the next ten days' business with close attention. The interval is expected to bring a somewhat general acceleration of buying by those who want to get under the wire before the new Federal excise taxes become effective, on June 21.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., June 11 -- The Bellanca monoplane flown around the world, including a nonstop flight from Japan to Seattle, by Hugh Herndon Jr. and Clyde Pangborn last year is to start out again on its transoceanic travels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I present a phase of the prohibition problem that has been almost completely ignored -- namely, the effect on the consumption of alcohol resulting from the substitution of 50 per cent distilled spirits for 5 per cent beer?

Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain and Premier Herriot of France are spending today and tomorrow in an effort to frame a common program to be supported by London and Paris at the Lausanne Reparations Conference which opens on next Thursday.

A MID all the convincing hue and cry about the increasing criminality of the very young. Dr. J.B. Maller of Teachers College, Columbia University, has taken the trouble to find out the facts. His survey of the records of thirty years of the Children's Court of New York City goes to show that, however bad modern boys and girls may be, they were apparently twice as unruly in "the good old days."

A beautiful window unveiled the other day in the Guildhall, London, described as depicting the "historic scene of Sir Richard Whittington throwing into the flames, in the presence of King Henry V., bonds to the value of u60,000 given by the King," has brougth forth the criticism, supported by quoted authorities, that Whittington never was knighted and never did burn the bonds, as popular legend would have it.

LONDON, June 4. -- The breakdown of the gold standard is a direct consequence of the war debts and of the maldistribution of gold connected with their payment, Gustav Cassel, noted Swedish economist and member of the League of Nations gold delegation, said in his third and closing Rhodes lecture, delivered at Oxford.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 11 -- Tommy Tailer, born, so to speak, with a golf spoon in his hand, having had a links of his very own to play on ever since he was so big, today became the Metropolitan amateur golf champion, succeeding Leonard Martin.

THERE is no question about the carrying qualities of the voice of Senator Smith Wildman Brookhart of Iowa. But lungs cannot compete with wave lengths and loud-speakers; Senator Brookhart succumbed last week in the Iowa primaries to the Roxy of the Corn Belt, to the owner of a voice which is heard daily not only in the State where the tall corn grows, but in Nebraska, Minnesota, the Dakotas, Kansas and Missouri.

Inspired by the "confession" of Harry Elmer Barnes, professor at Smith College, who revealed in his recent publication, "Prohibition Versus Civilization," that he had been converted from a teetotaler to a user of alcoholic beverages, Burgoyne Hamilton, president of the Blue Cockade, a national anti-prohibition organization, called yesterday for confessions from other prominent people.

WHITE water ahead Placid, broad reaches of a wilderness river have suddenly narrowed. A cockleshell of a craft is tossed headlong into a turmoil of angry rapids. Can she ride it out? If she does not, the boat and its crew are in for a ruthless drenching and mauling.

HARTFORD, June 11. -- Deaf to the pleas of Governor Cross, who sought to cooperate with Washington police officials in restraining them, 135 World War veterans from this vicinity started this afternoon in fifteen cars and trucks for Washington.

Formation of an organization to be known as the Realty Relief-Reconstruction Committee "to foster immediate measures to meet today's realty problems on Long Island, particularly in the home mortgage field," was announced yesterday by the Long Island Real Estate Board.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended June 4 were higher than during the preceding week, hut continued well below a year ago, according to the weekly Survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

A foundation on which to test out the possibilities of a national economic plan for industry is provided in the recently concluded report by the New York State Advisory Committee on Prison Industries, A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers and a member of the advisory committee, pointed out yesterday.

VENICE. A MINOR thinker once called an exhibition a combat between the artist and the public. Any one wanting to have (metaphorically) the kick of his life -- and incidentally get an idea of the latest achievements and tendencies in contemporary art -- must come to Venice and see the Eighteenth International Exhibition of Modern Art, which was inaugurated a short time ago and is to remain open till the end of October.
A FRENCH airman, Lucien Coupet, is now making his final preparations for a great adventure into the stratosphere, twelve to fifteen miles above the earth.

WHEN the forces of protest against things as they are -- the forces which gave rise to the Soviet Republic, the Third International and many a lesser movement -- surveyed the world which they would conquer, South America offered both an invitation and a problem.

LONDON, which in 1928 saw Mary Wigman dance her "Monotonie -- Whirl Dance " at a benefit matinee, and applaud- ed it as a tour de force almost throughout its entire performance, has recently had its first opportunity to see her in formal recital.

PARLIAMENTS and Congresses are attracting increasing world scrutiny -- and criticism -- these days. France votes Left, but organizes a moderate, almost conservative, government. Germany turns Right, but dissolves the Reichstag and sets up an "Almanach de Gotha" Ministry answerable to no Parliament.

WHEN the authoritative, convincing life of Lee, comparable to Colonel Henderson's two volumes on Stonewall Jackson, is written -- if it ever is written -- artificers of the biographical craft will very likely consider it the eighth wonder of the world.

ABOUT twelve years ago Max Beerbohm began an essay on laughter with this equivocal sentence: "M. Bergson, in his well-known essay on this theme, says -- well, he says many things." Whereupon the inimitable Max went on to explain how a congenital form of procrastination had prevented his retting round to Bergson until nine years after the famous compendium on laughter had been published.
"Troilus and Cressida," The Playday and yesterday the cheaper seats at the Broadway Theatre, took in a gross sum of $11,500 during "its limited engagement of one week.

The movement of commodity prices was generally irregular yesterday, changes for the most part being slight and unimportant. Grains and rubber were up, cotton declined 6 to 7 points, while silk was firm. Other articles were steady.

With Melvin Ott exploding his twelfth home run of the season to produce half of their runs at one stroke, the Giants continued their amazing drive yesterday by upsetting the Pirates in the opening clash of a four-game series at the Polo Grounds.

SINCE the House of Representatives passed the Hare bill, which would pledge independence to the Philippines within eight years, much has been written about Filipino men and their fitness -- or lack of it -- for self-government. Yet so far little has been printed about the women of the islands, who are among the chief arguments for freedom.

PIE TRAYNOR cleared up one disputed point yesterday. It was before the boys went out to the Polo Grounds to see what the place looked like without John McGraw perched on the high chair at the inside corner of the Giant dugout.

EARLY rumblings of the Republican convention will be wafted across the land this afternoon at 3 o'clock when William Hard and Theodore C. Wallen, two political commentators already on the scene in Chicago, will broadcast over WJZ.

With victory already sealed in the first three matches, the United States Davis Cup team defeated Brazil in the remaining two contests of the American interzone final at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday to score a clear sweep and complete its campaign on this side of the Atlantic with a perfect record.

OF that most coveted of printed books, the Gutenberg Bible, there were probably issued 150 copies on paper and 35 on vellum, according to Dr. Paul Schwenke's calculations. Since the discovery in 1763 of the perfect copy in the Mazarin Library in Paris, various other examples have been "discovered," until today, barring fragments, scholars agree that there are forty-five survivors.

THE decision of the House of Commons against the demolitionof Waterloo Bridge brines to an end a heated controversy over the bridge's future. "The noblest bridge in the world" is apparently to stand. This must mean that the recommendations of Lord Lee's commission are to be adopted and that it is to be underpinned.

A new rapid transit unification plan, based on existing economic conditions and the present low price level of B.M.T. and Interborough securities, will be submitted to the Board of Estimate by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Senor Juan Carlos Zabala, the "hare of the Argentine pampas," dashed over the heavily traveled concrete highways of Chicago's South Shore today with such a burst of speed and stamina that he recorded the fastest fifteenmile marathon run in America's history.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee late today decided to extend the stock market investigation to Cleveland, seat of Continental Shares, Inc., an investment company controlled by Cyrus S. Eaton, whose operations are reported to have involved more than $100,000,000.

The State Banking Department yesterday announced the receipt of a certified copy of a certificate of merger, dated May 18, 1932, of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., with the Straus Securities Corporation. The merger was made in, accordance with provisions of Section 85 of the stock corporation law.
WASHINGTON, June 31. -- Business activity showed little change or a slight decline in most countries covered by the current weekly survey of conditions abroad by the Commerce Department.
Stanislaus Felix Hausner's rescue from the Atlantic caused aviation circles to recall last night that other fliers had been found after hope had been given up.

A NEW note in books about the Islands of the South Seas is struck by Loring Andrews in "Isles of Eden," and he has also hit upon a new method. Mostly, these books are written in a high and chanting register, so high that sometimes there is a break into falsetto.

SHANGHAI, May 18 -- At the same time that the Chinese Government is asking for the world's sympathy, professing reliance on the League of Nations, and declaring that it will wage no more civil wars with the object of uniting the country, the Legislative Yuan at Nanking has adopted the general principles for a conscription law which requires military service from all male citizens between the ages of 18 and 40 years.

PARIS FEMININITY is to be the sartorial ideal of the fashionable beaches this Summer, according to a number of Paris couturiers. It will no longer be amusingly chic to be mistaken for one's brother, from any angle or distance.

The Home Ownership and Construction Conference of Westchester County has been formed as a permanent organization as a result of the success of the "Westchester County Conference on Home Building and Home Ownership recently held in White Plains.

NO doubt it was never anything more than a very ordinary little suburban villa to those who would appraise it at its market value. But it was a great deal more to me, and that is the whole of possession and the home."
WORCESTER, Mass., June 11 -- Holy Cross evened matters with Providence College today defeating the Friers 8 to 4, in their second game of the season before a crowd of 4,500.

BLOOMSBURG, Pa., June 11 (AP). -- A novel extortion plot involving the use of an airplane was revealed today as police and foresters combed the woods of a lonely mountain for one or more persons who, they said, tried to get $15,000 from Harry Magee, carpet manufacturer.

BERLIN. THE zeal for sport and for bodily improvement aroused g throughout Germany since the armistice is strikingly shown in a new creation of its kind -- the sport park. All over the country sport parks have been laid out, either with or without the seating facilities of a stadium.

SEARCHING among the ancient archives of the . Parts secret police, Mr. H. Ashton-Wolfe has discovered many curious and interesting tales of crime, some of them still famous, others unknown or forgotten, and these he retells in slightly fictionized form.

In Chief Justice HUGHES'S address to the Judicial Conference of the Federal Judges of the Fourth Circuit last week many passages invite citation. We confine ourselves to his correction of a common and obnoxious error:

MOSUL, Iraq., May 18 -- Further details have just been reported in connection with the excavations at Tepe Gawra and Tell Billa, near here, which are being carried on by the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania and the American Schools of Oriental Research, with the cooperation of Drosie College, under the direction of Professor E. A. Speiser of the University of Pennsylvania.
THE National Republican Convention is the gala, event on the air this week. The broadcasters will give it the right of way as they do an SOS from a ship at sea.

BOOKS, we are wont to think, may be as freely consulted as the air is breathed in America. And any boy or girl whose schooling has been inadequate can at least, we assume, go to the public library and read his way to literacy, or even to the Presidency.

SOME figures on high altitude flying, aided by the wind, are disclosed in the official report covering the recent record flight of Captain Reuben C. Moffat, Air Corps, between Wright Field, Ohio, and Boiling Field, District of Columbia.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 11 -- As a part of the commencement activities of Colgate University, the alumni held in the Huntington Gymnasium this evening a five-century dinner in honor of fifteen veteran members of the university faculty whose terms of service aggregate 537 years.

Much is heard about a lack of planing. One explanation of our current troubles is that they are due to our having tolerated an economic system which is too much like a mighty maze without a plan. However that may have been in the past, it is no longer true.

"The Faith of the Irish" will undoubtedly be the outstanding feature of the Thirty-first International Eucharistic Congress, which will open in Dublin the week of June 19 and close on Sunday, June 26, with a religious demonstration in which it is expected that a million Catholics, representing all nations of the world, will participate.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 11 -- The flotation of a large Federal bond issue to finance a program of public works and the mobilization at relief wages of the unemployed engineers of the country to supervise its expenditure were urged as the only alternative to a "dole in its worst form" by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, at the Haverford College commencement today.

While prices of most commodities did not change greatly during the past week, July cotton sold for a time at 4.95 cents a pound, the lowest level reached for contracts in the history of the New York Cotton Exchange. A number of factors affecting the immediate trading outlook combined to produce this result.

STUDENTS from thirteen States and from Germany, Mexico and China, numbering in all 358, have been enrolled in the courses of the division of aeronautical education in the School of Education, New York University, established by the Daniel Guggenheim Fund committee on elementary and secondary aeronautical education and headed by Professor Roland H. Spaulding, which has recently concluded a busy year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 11 -- Yale today won a sensational twelveinning victory from Princeton in their 157th baseball meeting, a single by Charley Williamson with the bases filled bringing the Elis a 5-4 decision.

Back home again from their foreign invasion, the two metropolitan players. Miss Helen Hicks and Miss Maureen Orcutt, who were members of the women's United States golf team that triumphed against the British, will lose no time in playing competitive golf.

Flashing over the high hurdles with another of his flawless performances, Percy Beard of the New York A.C. equaled the accepted world's record of 0:14.4 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday to furnish the most brilliant performance of the fortieth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships.

LOS ANGELES, June 9. -- Slower than other sections to feel the full effect of retarded business this part of the country has at last come to realize the potency of the depression, but there are signs that the bottom scraping is nearly over.

LONDON, June 11 -- Except for adverse comment in today's Economist and Financial News the London press ignores the report on gold of the League of Nations committee. The Economist calls it a disappointing document.

IN his cogent and well-presented study Professor Hansen endeavors to prove that we live in an economic world whose characteristic state is and must be that of unbalance. To attempt to stabilize it by palliative measures is futile.

For the third time in the long history of the event a championship cup was retired from competition yesterday at the close of the thirty-sixth annual men's metropolitan clay court tennis championship tournament on the courts of the New York Tennis Club, when Julius Seligson, seeded No. 1, gained permanent possession of the singles trophy.

More than $2,225,000 for feeding and clothing needy children has been contributed by teachers and other employes of the public school system during the two academic years ending this month, Frederick D. Chambers, treasurer of the School Relief Fund, disclosed yesterday in a review of the operations of the fund since October, 1930.

The lowered income tax base, the evy to be paid by consumers on electrical energy and the manufacturrs' excise levies as provided for in he new tax measure signed by President Hoover during the week measrably add to retail problems, acording to views in retail circles here esterday.

Making a runAway victory of their initial contest with the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday, Max Carey's Robins advanced to fourth place in the National League race, their opponents dropping from fourth to fifth. The Robins have a margin of less than a percentage point.

IN an article in last Sunday's TIMES, comparing the cost of veteran's relief in the United States with that in other countries, a table was given listing the numbers of men mobilized during the World War, the numbers dead and wounded, and the estimated expenditures for veterans' aid in the year 1932-33.
PARIS, June 3 -- What is a snail? Neither fish nor fowl nor good red herring, is the reply of experts to the departmental council of the Cote d'Or at Dijon.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 11 -- On the sprawling lawns of the Lawrence Farms beneath a warm sun the North Westchester Kennel Club slaved its annual show today. A large gathering assembled and witnessed the fine turnout of 600 dogs. The proceeds went to the North Westchester Nursing Association.

Methods by which organized advertising can aid in the restoration of prosperity will be the principal topic of discussion at the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, which will open at the Waldorf-Astoria a week from today. More than 1,500 representatives of business communities throughout the nation will be present.

The New York Central Railroad, which has applied for a $13,600,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, reported yesterday a net loss of $4,019,328 in the first four months of this year, against net income of $1,411,669 in the same period of 1931.

PARIS, June 11 -- Even in wartime there seldom was such an atmosphere of discouragement at a meeting of the Premiers of Britain and France as marked today's first contact between Edouard Herriot and Ramsay MacDonald on the eve of the Lausanne conference.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 -- Play in the annual Meadow Brook Club early-season polo tournaments will get under way on Tuesday when three first round matches will Be played in the third Westbury challenge cup event, according to the draw which was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- A majority of the designated members of the platform and resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention have agreed to meet in Chicago on June 23, four days before the convention, to begin work on a tentative platform, the Democratic National Committee announced today.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Sunday, June 12. (AP). -- The voters of New South Wales recorded one of the most important political decisions in the history of their State by repudiating the Labor party headed by J.T. Lang, former Premier, in yesterday's election.
The United States revenue act makes income taxes a lien on all property of the person assessed.

CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP) -- Miss Stella Walsh of Cleveland equaled the Olympic record in the 100-meter dash, shattered the National A.A.U. record by a tenth of a second in the 50-meter dash and hurled the discus 127 feet 4 inches to establish a new A.A.U. record in the district Olympic tests today.

J. Edwin R. Carpenter, prominent New York architect, designer of the Lincoln Building in East Forty-second Street and other large modern office buildings and apartment houses, died suddenly at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his office at 598 Madison Avenue of an attack of heart disease from which he had suffered intermittently for some time.

SYDNEY, Sunday, June 12 (Canadian Press). -- Prime Minister Joseph Lyons, head of the Commonwealth United Australia party, expressed himself delighted at the overthrow of the Socialist majority in the New South Wales elections yesterday.

Formation of an enterprise similar in character to the recently organized American Securities Investing Corporation, but international in scope and comprising within its directorate men outside the United States as outstanding in the field of international finance as the members of the American corporation, was advocated here yesterday by Dr. Max Winkler, Associate Professor of Economics at the College of the City of New York.

Ralph Jonas, acting chairman of the board of trustees of Long Island University, announced yesterday the acceptance by the board of the resignation of Dr. George R. Hardie as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, to take effect Aug. 31, 1932, and the granting of a leave of absence to Dean Hardie until that date.

ENACTMENT last week of the government revenue measure incorporating Federal taxes on motor vehicles and automotive products was greeted with a salvo of protest by leaders of the industry, who saw in the new levies a threat alike to the manufacturers and the motoring public.

SHANGHAI, May 13 -- The disastrous effects of the flood which last Summer inundated the richest and most populous provinces in the Yangtse Valley, combined with severe frosts and droughts in the northwestern provinces of Shensi and Shansi, have brought on a severe state of famine, estimated to be the worst, in the areas affected, in more than 100 years.

AIR mail will come in for a test of its popularity and usefulness when, after July 6, the rate for the first ounce will become 8 cents instead of the present 5 cents, while ordinary first-class letters will require 3 cents in place of the long familiar 2 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The tax bill, agreed to by the House Saturday and by the Senate Monday, was signed at 5 o'clock Monday afternoon by the President. Estimated by the Treasury to yield $1,118,500,000, the bill required six months lacking a day to make its way through the legislative mill.

BERLIN, June 11 (AP) -- Chancellor von Papen's speech before the German Agricultural Council today brought forth considerable criticism from Leftists, who assailed it as reactionary. None of these critics, however, saw in it any implication of dictatorship, an interpretation set forth in reports published abroad.

LAUSANNE. THE deferred Reparations Conference will convene about the middle of June in Lausanne. The conferees and their retainers, that large body for whom conferences are becoming a career and who should be, by virtue of experience, discriminating, will like Lausanne.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Hoover approved today the bill recently passed by Congress for the transfer of juvenile delinquents now in Federal custodv to the juvenile courts of their own communities.

TOKYO, June 11. -- The opinion grows here that recognition of Manchukuo will be brought much nearer if Count Yasuya Uchida, president of the South Manchuria Railway, who arrives in Tokyo tomorrow, accepts the post of Foreign Minister, as it is generally believed he will.

Samuel Lesser, alias Harry Harvey, who was convicted on a kidnapping charge with two other men last March in General Sessions, was taken from the Tombs to Sing Sing at 10 o'clock yesterday morning to begin the fifty-year term imposed on him by Judge Nott.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The National Organization to Reduce Government Expenditures, with a task as formidable as its name, will face Republican platform makers here next week as part of its drive for a $750,000,000 tax reduction.

Yesterday's markets brought to its close a confused and perplexing week. The week-end movement of prices was mostly made up of readjustment from their movement of the day before, and there was no distinctive trend in any market. Stocks began by carrying a little further the impulsive advance of Friday, but before the two-hour trading was completed, most of the earlier advances had been canceled.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. IT was the lack of a suitable story that kept Ethel Barrymore away from the cinema all these years. This was revealed this week as she prepared for the filming of "Rasputin" with her two brothers, Lionel as the Mad Monk and John as Prince Yussupoff, the assassin.

THE Englishwoman who, as "Marjorte Bowmen," is probably the most prolific presentday writer of historical and modern romance and who, in 1928, and under the different pseudonym of "George Preedy," electrified the literary world by her remarkable historical novel "General Crack," has elected to send forth her latest book under the pen-name that made her internationally famous.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 11 -- Bob Kifnty Syracuse hurler, struck out fifteen batters and held Brown to four hits today, Syracuse winning by 8 to 0.

IDEALISM and practicality must be mixed if art is to be of vital aid in this period of financial uncertainty and conflicting counsels. We are beginning wisely to stress industrial art as the most promising avenue leading toward independence for the artist and reward for the public.

LONDON, June 11 -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, left London this morning for Paris, where they are having preliminary conversations with Premier Herriot, after which both will proceed to Geneva Tuesday and to Lausanne Thursday.

BUDAPEST, June 10 -- The Hungarian National Bank has received and paid into a special "closed account 50,000,000 pengoe [nominally $8,750,000] owed by State, provincial and municipal bodies and private individuals to creditors abroad, but is prohibited from tranferring it under Hungary's moratorium.

READING, Pa., June 11 (AP) -- Lester Bell went on a batting rampage today to give the Reading Keys the third and deciding game of a series with Buffalo by the score of 8 to 7. After getting two home runs, Bell broke up the contest in the ninth inning with a double.

The thirty-ninth annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association, which will begin tomorrow and continue on to Tuesday and Wednesday at the Westchester Country Club at Rye, will bring together several hundred bankers from all parts of the State to consider questions affecting banks.

Brazil's program of destruction of coffee to support the price of that commodity in all markets has now been in force exactly one year. In that time 7,103,000 bags of coffee beans have been burned or otherwise destroyed. They were valued at approximately $30,000,000.

The Farm Colony Horseshoe tossers of Four Corners, Staten Island, in their first major engagement laughed their way to not ignoble defeat yesterday. The fact that the Fort George Horseshoe Pitchers scored sixty-one points to their three meant nothing, they said, for they had "won" a full trip from Four Corners.

Formation of an independent security holders' committee by owners of the stock and notes of R. Hoe Co., Inc., was urged yesterday by Samuel Zirn, an attorney. He said in a letter to holders of securities of the company that he represented a group owning $85,000 par value of the 6 per cent notes and about 2,700 shares of the class A preferred stock of R. Hoe Co.

PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS is this month celebrating the third anniversary of its "blind flying school'' at Brownsville, Texas. This school was unique, since it was the first commercial blind flying school to be started in this country. Other airlines have made and are making a special study of blind flying and are making it possible for their pilots to take time for this training apart from their regular scheduled work.

Owners of non-seagoing motor craft have always wanted an inland route running north and south on the Atlantic seaboard. There is no doubt that a considerably greater number of motor boating devotees would make the trip if they were assured of a waterway where they would not be exposed to rough weather.

IRREGULAR weather conditions were responsible for rather spotty results in retail trade during the week. However; the demand on Summer apparel, sports and beach wear was fairly well maintained Home furnishings were active only in a few sections.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Speaker John N. Garner was ordered to bed at his suite at the Washington Hotel early today, after he suffered a chill at his office and his temperature rose to 102. Dr. George Calver, House physician, forbade Mr. Garner to receive visitors during the day, and soon after the House adjourned this afternoon he went again to the hotel to examine Mr. Garner.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. The sleek mahogany hull of the fastest rum-chaser in Federal service off Cape Cod, the CG819, formerly the rum-runner Peg, was beached by her crew at Provincetown recently in the darkness. There were two feet of water in her hold.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Joseph S. MacLaughlin, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Philadelphia area, died in Jefferson Hospital tonight in his sixty-first year. He was taken there two weeks ago, suffering from diabetes and erysipelas.

International tension arising from economic policies will be analyzed by authorities at the Columbia University Summer session which, will begin on July 5, it was announced yesterday by John J. Coss, the director.

BERLIN. THE American film is dead! Long live the American film! After a Winter which turned a very frigid shoulder to the product of Hollywood, Spring came for us with the weather. At one time five United States films are on view in the German capital.

Weetamoe and Vanitle, the two America's Cup yachts in commission, are to make their season's bow in Long Island Sound racing this week. The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay has arranged a special event for the large craft on Wednesday.
PARIS, June 10. -- The French police have greatly increased the strictness of their surveillance over all foreigners.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 -- The New Jersey National Bank and Trust Company, with main office at Broad and Market Streets, in the centre of the business district here, and four branches in the city, failed to open for business today. A notice on the door announced that a national bank examiner was in charge.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 11 -- Alleging that there has been a "flood of foreign artists" to the United States to paint the portraits of "Washington officials, Mrs. Florence T. Green, chairman of the arts division of the General Federation of "Women's Clubs in convention here, recommended today the passing of a law making obligatory the employment of American artists when the portraits are to be paid for out of public funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the wa traveling man has been more and more pushed aside as an important factor in the dirtribtition ot merchandise. In his place has arisen the powerful system of syndicate and resident office buying.

DR. AVRAM BARNETT of New York, since taking his degree in medicine at the Sorbonne University in Paris last year, has been working with Professor Raymond Thiberge of the Ecole Normale de Musique of Paris on the development of musical talent by science, writes a correspondent from Paris.
HAVANA, June 11 -- Dr. Pedro Herrera Sotolongo, noted oppositionist lawyer, was arrested this morning by the secret police and lodged in Principe Castle.

BECAUSE of its pioneering nature, as much as anything, one of the most highly competitive industries today is that of air transport. The pioneer, whatever his business, is essentially an individualist; he doesn't ask any odds and is determined not to give any.

WE stand on the eve of another opening of our quadrennial two-ringed circus. The epithet is not wholly cynical or flippant or inaccurate; for every thoughtful and observant person must admit that the Republican and Democratic national conventions are, at least in time of normality, amazingly amusing institutions of our democratic creation.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., June 11 -- George A. Sherwood, 48 years old, of 10 Arden Place, Yonkers, N.Y., was killed instantly when an automobile which he was instructing Mrs. John B. Clark, wife of the president of the Clark Thread Company, to drive skidded and overturned near Bedminister, about five miles from here.
PARIS, May 31 -- The presence of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody in Paris for the French International championship tennis matches always arouses great interest.

Tax collections in the city of New York are lagging approximately $18,000,000 behind those for the corresponding period last year. George S. Horton, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, declared yesterday in pointing out that this condition clearly indicates that the city officials must start retrenching at once.
MANLIUS, N.Y., June 11 -- Fifty students were graduated from the Manlius School today, with the Right Rev. Charles Fiske, Bishop of the diocese of Central New York, as the commencement speaker.

WHAT if you were a farmer and wanted to go modern by getting a whacking good road down the muddy lane past your place? What if you shopped around a bit and found that the current price on a first-class road was $40,000 a mile?

RECOGNIZING the urgent need of a real leader in America. Colonel Frederick Palmer, the well-known war correspondent and author, has undertaken to provide one in the hero of his forthcoming novel. "So a Leader Comes." which Ray Long Richard R. Smith will publish early in the Fall.

The listed bond market exhibited yesterday a steady tone during the two-hour trading period on the Stock Exchange. United States Government bonds showed strength, eight of the eleven active issues gaining 1-32 to 1/2 point, one showing a decline of 1-32 point and two holding unchanged.

The statistical position of the petroleum industry for April was less favorable than it had been in some time, largely because of excessive additions to stocks of gasoline and a markedly diminished demand for that product, according to statistics compiled by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

A request for direct action by President Hoover, heads of the Departments of State, Commerce and other branches of the Federal Government to end inequitable foreign exchange conditions which constitute a continual drain on the American, gold supply, was submitted by ten foreign trade associations here last week.

BERLIN, June 9 -- The abrupt disappearance of the Bruening Government continues to provoke lengthy post-mortem meditations over the nature of the political convictions that prompted President Hindenburg to part summarily with the man who for more than two years had been his guiding political confidant and to whom many feel that he directly owed his re-election.

SEATTLE, June 9 -- The Democrats of Washington expect to carry this State for the national ticket and to elect their candidates for United States Senator, Governor and for Representatives in Congress from most of the six districts. This expectation has a more substantial basis than mere hope, notwithstanding the fact that they were the first in years is rock-ribbed in its Republicanism.

Miss Alexandra Diodati Gardiner, daughter of Mrs. Robert Alexander Gardiner of 812 Park Avenue, was married to James Randall Creel, a lawyer, of 7 East Ninety-sixth Street, formerly Harvard prize debater and essayist, on Friday afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City, L.I.

THE Reo Motor Company of Lansing, Mich., has announced a new series of 1 1/2-ton Speed Wagons, powered with the Reo six-cylinder Gold Crown truck engine. The Wagons, which have a full line of standardized bodies designed to meet commercial haulage requirements, are also built as tractors for semi-trailer operation.

LONDON, June 4, 1932. THE season of important concerts is nearly over. The B.B.C. and the Philharmonic Orchestras will not be heard again before the Autumn; the London Symphony Orchestra concluded its series awhile ago and there is some doubt as to whether its activities are to be resumed.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 11 -- The police made public today a statement by Laura E. Hughes of 100 Palisade Avenue, private secretary in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, quoting Miss Hughes as saying that Violet Sharps "smiled and winked" at the end of one interview in the Morrow home in which the maid had identified a photograph of Ernest Brinkert.

BOSTON, June 9. -- At ten minutes before midnight Tuesday night the 147th Massachusetts General Court ended its second annual session. Only a few measures of outstanding importance were passed. The lack of team work between Governor Ely and the legislators was notable.
I KNOW few books which have stimulated me as much and so strongly impelled me to reflection as one which the young novelist, Jean Cassou, has just published on Tolstoy.

IN the history of Europe Don Alfonso of Spain is said to have been the only sovereign who, by the death of his royal sire, became actual king at the moment of birth. Never before had it happened, and when the 5-year-old Infanta asked where the new baby came from, the Queen Mother adroitly replied, "From your father in heaven."

PARIS, June 9 -- French Oaks brilliantly opened the big race month at Chantilly. Print frocks, short-sleeved cloth coats and big straw hats were the chic notes. The favorite color scale ranged from bronze to beige. Rose Descat's big beige felt picture hat trimmed with red and green ribbon created a sensation.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 11 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club baseball team rallied to tie the score in the ninth inning and then tallied the winning run in the tenth to defeat the New York A.C., 10 to 9, today in an Eastern Athletic Club League game.

WASHINGTON HERBERT HOOVER will enter the Presidential campaign of 1932 an entirely different man physically from the one nominated four years ago at Kansas City, and, according to his friends, with a considerably altered attitude toward the vexations of the Presidency.

WASHINGTON. IN national political conventions is the primal substance of excitement -- human conflict. The conflict is limited to a few principals, for the great mass of the delegates simply vote in conformity with instructions from their constituents and, when the instructions have been carried out, they follow the orders of their leaders.

IT has always been difficult to light upon an adequate definition for what Dr. Gerould calls "the ballad of tradition." The same thing was called by that greatest of all scholars in the field, Professor Child, "popular ballad." But because of the conventional connotation of the word "popular," the term required constant explanation.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 11 -- Awards of seventy-five varsity letters in track, baseball, fencing, lacrosse and tennis, ten rifle insignia and ninety-two class numerals were announced today by Romeyn Berry, graduate manager of the Athletic Association at Cornell University.

NEW YORK STATE so abounds in places of scenic and historic interest that motorists driving through it will always find plenty to occupy their attention. In these columns recently there was printed an article and map depicting the places worth visiting along the Hudson River valley, the eastern portion of the historic Cherry Valley Turnpike and in the Catskills.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Halcyon, winner of the $4,000 added Queens County Handicap last year, repeated his victory yesterday before 10,000 persons at the Aqueduct course, when he ran in front, almost from start to finish of the featured mile test.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his honest, courageons and weighty letter John D. Rockefeller Jr. sets forth (he thoughts which forced him in conclude that Federal prohibition is a failure and therefore, his support of Dr. Butler's demand for outright repeal.

THE broadcasters assert that the political parties are not charged for what goes through the microphones at the national conventions. But the campaign orators will pay for radio facilities and time on the air. And the rates are higher than in 1928.

With the opening of the bass season on Wednesday in New Jersey, the State Fish and Game Commission points out that many miles of good fishing, on the lower Delaware and its tributaries above and below Trenton, have been restored by anti-pollution campaigns that have been carried on both in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Western Pacific Railroad Company, in a supplemental application to the Interstate Commerce Commission today, increased from $759,000 to $2,264,554 the amount of the loan it is asking from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

UNLESS new circumstances suddenly dictate different tactics. President Hoover win direct his campaign for re-election from his Rapidan camp in the Blue Ridge Mountains. This will be a novelty in Presidential canvasses.

Reciprocal tariff reductions, an excise tax on 2.75 per cent beer and a universal manufacturers' sales tax were favored, and cancellation of the war debts was opposed by a majority of 4,200 bank presidents in 1,500 American cities in a questionnaire circulated by Remington Rand, Inc., it has been announced.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Citing the cost to the government of more than. $1,000,000,000 a year for socalled veterans' relief, Representative Douglas of Arizona in a radio address tonight appealed to the "unorganized majority" of the country to exert its influence for a revision of veterans' legislation to provide relief only for those whose injuries were attributable to war service.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 11 -- In a spectacular exhibition, George Lott, Chicago star, won the national clay courts championship today, defeating Bryan Grant of Atlanta, who threatened the tournament favorite at every turn of the match. The score was 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

MATRIARCHY, our more sensitive-or timid-literati have recently been telling us, is just around the corner in America. And for the first time in a century, when that recurrent threat has been made, the Main Streeter has failed to respond absently, "Oh, yeah?" It is an odd paradox.

WHAT a Summer it is going to be on the beaches! Never has there been so much undress or so much dress in the history of American seaside resorts as this season promises to bring forth. One of fashion's paradoxes!

BY MARCHING upon Washington to impress their desires upon the government, the contingents of World War veterans from many parts of the country have followed a precedent established nearly a century and a half ago.

PARIS, May 25 -- Once again an American with an eye to business has aroused the ire of the French press, especially the nationalistic element. The man in question had what he considers the foresight, but what the French consider the shocking bad taste, to buy a war relic and prepare to make money out of it.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The gathering of the advance guard of the Republican army that will occupy Chicago next week, when the party convention nominates a national ticket and adopts a platform, would ordinarily be a matter of interest dominating casual conversation, but locally it has been overshadowed by the almost unbelievable collapse of the career of one of this city's most notable, most powerful and, in many ways, most useful citizens -- Samuel Insull.

Ralph McA. Ingersoll of 135 East Forty-second Street, a friend of the late G. Grenville Hunter, New York advertising man, who died as the result of a shotgun wound last Saturday at the Summer home of a friend at Harvey Cedars, N.J., said yesterday that, contrary to newspaper reports and the findings of the coroner, he believed that Mr. Hunter had not taken his own life.

MR. WYNDHAM LEWIS wrote a few essays on Youth-written with a capital letter-became enamoured of his subject and decided there was a book in it. So, at least, it appears to the reviewer, who is repaid for struggling through pages of heavy repetition and vapid philosophizing by an occasional spark of brilliance.

PARIS, May 25 -- Once again an American with an eye to business has aroused the ire of the French press, especially the nationalistic element. The man in question had what he considers the foresight, but what the French consider the shocking bad taste, to buy a war relic and prepare to make money out of it.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The gathering of the advance guard of the Republican army that will occupy Chicago next week, when the party convention nominates a national ticket and adopts a platform, would ordinarily be a matter of interest dominating casual conversation, but locally it has been overshadowed by the almost unbelievable collapse of the career of one of this city's most notable, most powerful and, in many ways, most useful citizens -- Samuel Insull.

Ralph McA. Ingersoll of 135 East Forty-second Street, a friend of the late G. Grenville Hunter, New York advertising man, who died as the result of a shotgun wound last Saturday at the Summer home of a friend at Harvey Cedars, N.J., said yesterday that, contrary to newspaper reports and the findings of the coroner, he believed that Mr. Hunter had not taken his own life.

MR. WYNDHAM LEWIS wrote a few essays on Youth-written with a capital letter-became enamoured of his subject and decided there was a book in it. So, at least, it appears to the reviewer, who is repaid for struggling through pages of heavy repetition and vapid philosophizing by an occasional spark of brilliance.

JERUSALEM, May 22 -- A further discovery of great Biblical importance has just been made by the Tell en-Nasbeh expedition of the Pacific School of Religion of Berkeley, Cal., excavating under the direction of Dean William Frederick Bade. In a tomb of the west necropolis of Tell en-Nasbeh, near Ramallah, north of Jerusalem, was found a beautiful agate seal, finished as a human eye and bearing an inscription on the reverse.

THE early reappearance of the Cortot-Thibaud-Casals trio on Victor's list seems to indicate that the recent "Archduke" alm achieved the success it deserved. The new Masterworks Set, No. 126, ntains Mendelssohn's trio in D minor (Op. 49) on four records, the movements running in three, two, is and two sides respectively.

Loans to the Jobless. It seems to me that too much emphasis is being placed on the supposed merits of a public works program. A more effective plan would be to loan money to heads of families who are out of employment and without means; the loans to continue over a protracted period; the government to be reimbursed in small payments after the resumption of business.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Two signs and portents told the most casual observer today that Vox Populi was preparing to speak out in what the years have left of the old New England town meeting. One was the prodigal display of bunting which fluttered in the cool breezes from Lake Michigan above the city's principal thoroughfares and in the big Stadium, where on Tuesday the Republican National Convention will come to order.

E.R. Bradley's Burgoo King, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness and thus far the outstanding 3-year-old of the year, is definitely out of the $50,000 American Derby and the $70,000 Arlington Classic, it became known yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 9 -- The liquor question has been responsible for many political phenomena, and Alabama is adding to them with the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator which ends with the run-off primary here on June 14.

Moving at a speed of "25,000 kids an hour," as one observer put it, the annual June walk of the Monongahela Democratic Club passed colorfully, with the music of bands of every size, age and extraction, down Central Park West to 100th Street and into and across the park to the East Meadow from 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 yesterday.

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Summer exhibition, containing pictures and sculpture from the Bliss collection, the museum's miscellaneous treasury of acquisitions and numerous important loans. Opened privately on Tuesday and to the public Wednesday.

Sixteen major letters were awarded yeaterday to athletes of Hunter College at the anuual dinner of the Athletic Association of Hunter College in the Hotel Shelton. In the group were representatives of five sports activities, including basketball, swimming, tennis, fencing and horseback riding.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 11 (AP) -- Financial circles in this home of the Bank for International Settlements expressed the belief today that Germany would not maintain her flat refusal to pay further reparations when the Lausanne conference convenes on Thursday.

Many clergymen will refer in their sermons this morning to John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s statement in favor of a referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment. Today is "Children's Day" in all Presbyterian churches and those of a number of other denominations. Pastors will perform the rite of infant baptism.

PRINCESS DER LING in her earlier books has written of the older order in China in the days of the Manchu Dynasty and of the Empress Dowager Tzu Hai, to whom for three years she was first lady-in-waiting.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, in a statement issued tonight contrasted the prospects of the two major political conventions soon to meet at Chicago, asserting that the Republican gathering would be "more a lodge of sorrow than a ratification meeting" and that the Democratic Convention would be "an active coming together of every shade of Democracy."

GREAT RIVER, L.I., June 12. -- H.H. (Tex) Newton of Lido made short work of a clubmate, Charles H. Mayo Jr., Long Island interscholastic champion, in the final round of the seventh annual Timber Point Club invitation tournament today.

The Starlight supper dance to be given tomorrow night will mark the formal opening for the Summer of the Waldorf-Astoria roof garden. Proceeds from the event will be given to the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 12. -- Martin Deputy, alias Marshall Depew, accused ringleader of the gang that kidnapped Mrs. Nell Q. Donnelly, wealthy Kansas City woman, last December and held her for $75,000 ransom, admitted his implication in the plot as he arrived here this evening from South Africa aboard the steamer "West Cawthon.
