The world cannot be wholly extricated from its depression through any international economic conference that does not include the problems of tariffs and intergovernmental debts in its agenda, in the opinion of three leading American economists whose views were made public yesterday by the League of Nations Association at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A precipitous decline in American exports to Manchuria from about $20,000,000 in 1929 to $3,500,000 in 1931 was described today in a study of that country's foreign trade by John Carter Vincent, American Consul at Mukden, and made public by the Commerce Department.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., June 12. -- Major General Irving J. Carr, Chief Signal Officer of the Army, will present diplomas to twenty-eight officers and 193 enlisted men of the Army Signal School at Fort Monmouth at the eleventh annual commencement exercises, to be held here tomorrow in the War Department Theatre.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Four hundred and seventy-six prospective graduates at the Catholic University of America marched today in academic procession from the residence halls across the campus to the bascalaureate service, held in the crypt of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Concepttion.

TOKYO, June 12. -- Count Yasuya Uchida, who as president of the South Manchuria Railway has taken a prominent part in the events in Manchuria since last September, arrived here today and was invited by Premier Saito to take the post of Foreign Minister, which is now held temporarily by the chief of the Cabinet.

Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown announced yesterday his intention of resigning as chancellor of New York "University, in which capacity he has served for more than twenty years. His resignation is to become effective as soon as his successor is found and ready to be installed.

By voting to seat the old organization delegates from South Carolina and Mississippi the Republican National Committee has deliberately shown its contempt for Mr. HOOVER'S policy, begun early in his Administration, of ending the sale of Federal appointments in certain Southern States and "cleaning up" the malodorous oligarchy that has so long fattened on patronage.

BREST, France, June 12. -- The Italian salvage ship Artiglio returned here hurriedly today for coal with details of the discovery of bank notes in the bullion room of the sunken liner Egypt. The face value of the notes once may have been more than $500,000, but they are worthless now except for curios because the issue was canceled after the sinking of the Egypt ten years ago.

Describing the suspension of work in the building trades as the first experience for the industry of this kind in twenty-nine years, Alien E. Beals of the Dow Service estimates the loss to contractors, building supply firms, shops, mills, quarries and railroads at not less than $10,339,322.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12. -- Cornell and Pennsylvania arrived on the Hudson River today to bring to six the number of crew squads now in training here for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 20. M.I.T. and Washington are scheduled to arrive on Tuesday to complete the group.

LONDON, June 10. -- The week's news from Chile has caused anxiety, owing chiefly to fears of confiscation of the Cosach properties without reparation. This would entail heavy losses on British banking concerns and other interests.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- Radio, a fast seaplane, an ambulance and medical skill cooperated today in what appeared this evening to have been a successful attempt to save the lives of two men who were critically burned in an explosion aboard a tanker thirty-eight miles at sea.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., June 12. -- Diehard Faith, owned by the Scotsward Kennels of Mrs. C.B. Ward of this town, was judged best of breed as the Summer specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America came to a close today on Mrs. Ward's estate.

NEWPORT. R.I., June 12. -- Arleigh, at Bellevue and Parker Avenues, which in its day was one of the most interesting of Summer villas here and the scene of the marriage of the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt and Miss Kathleen Neilson, was destroyed by fire early today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12. -- The fiftieth year of Camp Smith, Summer headquarters of the New York National Guard, started today with the arrival of 1,800 guardsmen, constituting the Twenty-seventh Division Quartermaster train from Brooklyn under Major Robert E. Platz, and the Tenth Infantry, commanded by Colonel Charles E. Walsh, composed of units from Albany, Binghamton, Hudson, Oneonta, Rome, Utica and Walton.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- A declaration for maintenance of the soundness of American money, possibly to the extent of claiming the "gold standard" as the party's own project, was being drafted by Republican chiefs today on the eve of their convention.

Dr. J.C. Bloodgood, Professor of Surgery at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, and a noted authority on cancer, has just returned from a visit to Paris and London, where he delivered lectures on the activities in the United States for the control of cancer and studied the methods in use in those cities for the, prevention and cure of the disease.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 12. -- Carlos G. Davila resigned today from the week-old Socialist Government of Chile because of discord within the revolutionary junta.

The first steps have just been taken in reorganizing the educational work in New York State prisons, it was said yesterday by Sam A. Lewisohn, chairman of the Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction, which presented a program for the work in a special report to the Legislature last January.

WITH Max Schmeling and Jack Sharkey priming themselves for another world's heavyweight championship fight, there was added flavor in reading "Champions Off Guard," by William O. Inglis, a volume having to do with the careers and characters of former heavyweight champions from the great John Lawrence Sullivan down to Gene Tunney.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- After failing to get a man on base in the first three Innings today, the Yankees launched a batting barrage which landed them a 13-to-5 victory and dampened the enthusiasm of Cleveland's largest baseball crowd of the season so far, an overflow attendance of 23,000, part of which was parked behind ropes in left field, necessitating ground rules.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox took advantage of Red Sox errors today to win a pitching battle between Vic Frasier and Pete Jablonowski, 4 to 1.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Turngemeinde retained the eastern circuit championship of the American Gymnastic Union by amassing 858.7 points in a two-day meet which ended today. Other teams came from Brooklyn, Manhattan, Newark and Elizabeth, N.J.
CHICAGO, June 12. -- It's a beautiful Sunday afternoon here. Just the idea of Chicago having a Sunday strikes the rest of the country strange, don't it?

An article on "The War in the Far East," published today in the July number of Foreign Affairs, may lie taken, as the official Soviet view. It is written by KARL RADEK, editor of the Moscow Izvestia. It is partly historic, partly polemic. The steady advance of Japan into Manchuria is described as a policy of imperialism which has latent in it a determination to exercise control over a good part of North China.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES a correspondent asks for an answer to a question which has been asked throughout the ages and, as yet, has not been linked to any satisfactory response.

General activity in the wholesale apparel markets held up well during the week, as stores placed substantial reorders on Summer merchandise, following a period of fairly good retail business on these styles. Strictly warm weather dresses, such as eyelet batiste, lace cotton styles and printed silk chiffons, were outstanding in the dress division.

John N. Willys, retiring United States Ambassador to Poland, is due today from Warsaw on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Also on board are Count Rene de Chambrun and George P. Baker. Other passengers include:

NEWARK, N.J., June 12. -- Rain washed out the scheduled second game of a doubleheader today but 7,000 fans who sat through the constant drizzle of the first game were well rewarded by the great pitching of Don Brennan, who shut out Toronto with two hits.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 12. -- Those who opened their houses in the Berkshire Hills during the week-end included Mrs. Henry White, who is at Elm Court, Lenox, for her forty-seventh season; Miss Mildred M. Tytus at Ashintully in Tyringham; Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bigelow Jackson at the Field cottage, Lenox, and Dr. and Mrs. Warfield T. Long-cope of Baltimore at Cornhill Farm in Lee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Early in April the Women's Division inaugurated an active campaign raise a $100,000 relief fund for the Architects' Emergency Committee or unemployed architects and draftsmen. Of the 4,000 draftsmen in the metropolitan area estimated as the number unemployed, over 2,500 have already registered with the committee for jobs and aid.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Delegations from South, East and West trickled into Chicago today for the Republican National Convention, but they were so completely swallowed up by the city that a small gathering of Elks in Grant Park ran away with the show.

Mrs. Robert Alexander Gardiner, Park Avenue society matron, announced last night that she had forwarded by registered mail to the Long Island diocese of the Episcopal church charges against the Very Rev. G.T.P. Sargent, dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City, who, on Friday night last, officiated at the wedding of her daughter, Alexandra Diodati Gardiner, and James Randali Creel, lawyer, of 7 East Ninety-sixth Street.

Elaborate radio coverage of the Republican National Convention, opening tomorrow in Chicago, has been arranged by both the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company. Both systems have arranged for morning, afternoon and evening resumes of the news of the convention, the broadcasting of the principal speeches and the balloting.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- For the first time since 1912 a Republican convention assembled to renominate an incumbent of the White House is reflecting deep inner dissension. The arguments are now over the prohibition question and on the renomination of Vice President Charles Curtis.

A new issue or 5500,000 State of Kansas 4 1/4 per cent soldiers' compensation bonds, dated July 1, 1932, and due on July 1, 1954, will be formally placed on the market today by a syndicate comprising Barr Brothers Co., Inc.; the Mercantile Commerce Company, St. Louis, and First Securities Corporation, St. Paul and Minneapolis.

Plans to eliminate foreign exchange difficulties now experienced by export associations through the creation of a bank to hold foreign currency deposits, under the Edge act, have now been completed and are being submitted to President Hoover and the various departmental heads at Washington, according to an announcement yesterday made through the New York Board of Trade, Inc.

Playing in a heavy rain that fell throughout the contest, the Governors Island polo team defeated the Saddle River (N.J.) Polo Club, 14 to 8, yesterday at Governors Island. Several hundred persons, many in automobiles parked around the field, others huddled about near-by building's and some at windows of barracks, saw the game.

ELMONT, L.I., June 12. -- Gus Moore, competing unattached, retained his metropolitan A.A.U. championship in the ten-mile run today when he led home a field of forty starters, thirty of whom finished, in 54:45.

Patsy Palmira of the Mosholu golf course, with a 71, captured the low gross prize in the men's division of the New York Municipal Golf Association handicap tournament contested yesterday on the Mosholu links.
Exeter Estates, Inc., has surrendered to the Masro Realty Corporation a lease of 264 West Fortieth Street, which would have ended Jan. 31, 1949.
ROSLYN, L.I., June 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay were guests of honor today at a luncheon given by Arthur Williams at Brook Corners, his country home in Roslyn Harbor.

Magnificent mountain views of the Austrian Tyrol are blended expertly with Universal studio scenes in "The Doomed Battalion," a highly dramatic pictorial story of incidents in the fighting between the Italians and the Austrians on the snow-covered Alpine heights during the World War.

Mrs. Eise Thorenz Pettri of the German-American A.C. clipped the American long course record for 440 yards breast stroke, while George Fissler, George Kojac and Leonard Spence of the New York A.C. won scratch swimming events for men at a water carnival in the fifty-five-yard pool at Playland, Rockaway Beach, yesterday.

William H. Alien, director of the Institute for Public Service, yesterday announced figures on realty valuations for tax purposes in this city as compiled from the new annual report of the Department of Taxes and Assessments.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- In a letter sent to the White House today, Howard E. Coffin of Detroit replied to the criticism directed by President Hoover to the proposal put forward formally last week by thirty-six leading figures in the field of finance, industry and labor for the revival of the Council of National Defense as a means of getting the country out of the economic depression.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The Winter wheat harvest in the United States this year is to be one of the smallest since 1885. In that year production was 357,000,000 bushels of all wheat. The condition in June of that year was 82. The present condition as given by the government is 64.7 The Winter wheat crop this year on the present basis is 376,000,000 bushels less than the record harvested in 1931.

America's trouble is not lack of leadership but that its leaders as well as the masses are in a "mean and petty mood," lacking in greatness of spirit and largeness of outlook, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman asserted yesterday morning in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, at Sixtieth Street.

PITTSBURGH, June 12. -- Production of steel ingots last week was at About 17 per cent of capacity, against 20.11 per cent officially reported as the average for May. Production of all classes of steel ingots in May was at the rate of about 13,300,000 tons a year, or less than the actual production in any year since 1901, although one month in 1921, July, had a lower rate.

An artist who has, obviously been successful in satisfying the demands of book publishers has a brief account in The Publishers' Weekly of what he considers the artistic problems in designing book-jackets and in illustration. These are not matters of the artists' skill or inspiration.

Patrolman Joseph Burke, father of four children, was shot through the head, probably mortally, yesterday morning during a $16 hold-up in Harlem. His assailant, a 19-year-old youth, was captured after a short chase. Two of the gunman's confederates were seized during the hold-up in the Paradise Cafe and Restaurant at 2,320 Seventh Avenue.

The essence of religion is not in form and ceremony or in some system of church policy, but in being aware of the inward and vital presence of God, the Rev. Dr. Charles Reynolds Brown, Dean Emeritus of Yale Divinity School, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, where he was the guest preacher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the months roll by and there seems no indication that either individual initiative or government control is doing much to mitigate general suffering, I find that projects suggested by one here and another there are being put timidly to the test.

Everybody agrees that, in the end, public sentiment rules in this country. What the majority of the American people desire and demand they will finally get. But the preliminary and burning question always is how we are to find out, at any given time, the set of the popular will.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP). -- The Crowns won both games of a double-header from the Senators today, giving them a one-game lead in the series and their sixth victory in the last seven games against Washington.

The New Jersey State Police refused to regard as closed yesterday the phase of investigation in the Lindbergh. baby kidnapping and murder that centred on their suspicion of Violet Sharpe, maid in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, who committed suicide on Friday.

A city's chief weapon of defense against the forces of crime and corruption, is its children, the Rev. A. E. Keigwin said yesterday in his sermon celebrating Children's Day and the forty-fifth anniversary of the Sunday school at West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

John Galsworthy, Ernest Heming-way, Thomas Wolfe, James M. Barrie and James Truslow Adams are among the authors represented on the Scribner Fall and Winter book list. The book by James M. Barrie contains the first story from his pen in many years and goes back to the days of Prince Charlie for a love story of a Highland parson and a girl.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Increased interest developed here last week in wholesale and retail sales, and the aggregate was about the same as a year ago. It is becoming apparent that there is more disposition, particularly among wholesalers, to take on desirable lines that are quick sellers, and these lines will receive special attention this week, as many buyers will be attracted to the city by the Republican National Convention.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12. -- Yale's entire rowing squad, except the coaches and freshmen, enjoyed an outing today aboard Donald Brown's Diesel-powered yacht Oceania. The coaches spent the weekend at home. The oarsmen enjoyed an eight-hour sail along the Sound as far as Shelter Island.

ABOARD S.S. CIRCE SHELL, 600 Miles Off Portugal, June 12. -- This small British tanker was en route tonight to New Orleans with Stanislaus Felix Hausner, young New York-to-Warsaw flier, after picking him up yesterday in an exhausted condition.

There was something of visible improvement in financial sentiment last week. It was not strongly reflected in the markets, perhaps because both the definite adoption of the revenue bill and the bond-buying corporation's entry into business had been anticipated by the rise in Stock Exchange prices, before last week began.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The exservice men encamped here, pressing for immediate payment of the $2,400,000,000 bonus, were at a high pitch of expectation tonight as the House of Representatives prepared to take up the question tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12. -- A complete photographic record, both motion picture and still, from the air and from the ground, of the ascent of Mount 'Fairweather, the highest coastal mountain in the world and largest peak on the Fairweather peninsula in Southern Alaska, is the aim of Bradford Washburn, Harvard undergraduate, who has announced his plans to head an expedition made up of five other Harvard men leaving here the middle of this month.

CARLSTADT, N.J., June 12. -- Charles Cabot, the New Haven driver who sped down the Hudson to win the recent Albany-New York marathon, came home first in the tenmile feature free-for-all race at the third annual regatta of the North Jersey Outboard Association today.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx slammed his twenty-second home run of the season today, but the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 8 to 6, despite another Philadelphia homer by McNair. As a result Detroit advanced to fourth place as Cleveland dropped to fifth.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Influenced by the spread of sentiment for the adoption of a prohibition-repeal plank, friends of President Hoover went further today than they have gone heretofore and drafted a plank which would leave to Congress the decision as to whether an amendment to the Eighteenth Amendment to be submitted to the people should be for modification or repeal.

BERLIN, June 10. -- Unemployed working-men in Germany as of the first of June are stated to have numbered 5,583,000, which is 1,500,000 above the same date in 1931. There is no definite improvement in trade. The only better showing made in the steel branch is in joists and was occasioned by Russian orders.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12. -- The future success of America will be measured by its advance in social-mindedness, the graduating class of Vassar College was told this morning by the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Watson of Cairo, Egypt, who delivered the baccalaureate sermon.

PHILADELPHIA. June 12. -- Demanding that leaders of the national Republican organization take the initiative in meeting the prohibition issue and not shift the responsibility to the rank and file of the party, Pennsylvania delegates and alternates to the national convention left for Chicago on a special train this afternoon.
CHICAGO, June 12. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, upon his arrival here today for the Republican National Convention, immediately issued the following statement:
CHICAGO, June 12. -- The forces that have controlled the Republican party unchallenged since 1912 control this gathering today.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The condition of Speaker John N. Garner, who was seized with a severe chill and high fever while at his office In the Capitol yesterday, was so much improved today that he was permitted to take heavier nourishment. His temperature had subsided, Mrs. Garner said tonight, and he enjoyed two meals during the day.

The new $2,500,000 structure which will house the Bronx Hospital was dedicated yesterday afternoon at ceremonies held on the ninth floor solarium of the building. Rain prevented the exercises from being held on the front steps of the hospital, which is located in Fulton Avenue between 168th and 169th Street, the Bronx.

So wide is the ground covered in the report on the gold standard submitted by the League of Nations delegation, that it is possible here only to summarize its main conclusions. The committee consists of eleven eminent economists and financiers, representing ten different nations.

PARIS, June 12. -- Premier Herriot and Prime Minister MacDonald will leave Paris tomorrow morning for Geneya and thereafter Lausanne with the comforting knowledge that they think alike on most problems they are to tackle, however they must act.

LONDON, June 10. -- In general, the situation of the British export trade continues disappointing. In the iron and steel industry, which is usually quickest to reflect developments in foreign trade, many districts show no sign of expansion, and, in fact, manufacturers of all classes of commodities are working on short time.

DETROIT, Mich., June 12. -- G. Hall Roosevelt. City Controller, announced today an agreement by a Chicago, New York and Detroit banking group to renew $29,000,000 of Detroit's short-term notes that will fall due this month. Concern was expressed, however, over the tax delinquencies of approximately $19,500,000, which are greater by $1,500,000 than was expected.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- Two Federal prohibition agents from the Philadelphia area, whose names were not disclosed, were suspended today by Commander John D. Pennington, dry administrator here, after a surprise check-up at the Eureka Brewery at Paterson, N.J. where they had been on guard, revealed 850 barrels of "high-powered" beer to be missing.

LONDON, June 30. -- During the present week sentiment regarding dollar exchange has been influenced favorably by the balancing of the budget by the Congress at Washington and the passing of the economy bill. In the judgment of the banking community, these definite steps forward provided reason for natural recovery in the dollar relative to sterling.

Robert P. Lamont, Secretary of Commerce, sent a telegram to the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at Kearny, N.J., after the launching of the Santa Paula of the Grace Line on Saturday afternoon. It was made public yesterday by R. H. Patchin, vice president of W.R. Grace Co., and read in part:

In honor of the golden jubilee of the New York Archdiocesan Holy Name Union, 30,000 men paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the rain, which had turned to a steady down-pour before the procession was half over. Only three of the marchers carried umbrellas and they were elderly men.

PARIS, June 12. -- A difference of opinion between Feodor Chaliapin, Russian basso, and Michel Steiman, orchestra conductor, resulted in an unadvertised scene at a performance of the Russian opera season at the Opera Comique followed by M. Stelman's resignation.

A Dreadful Suspicion. Mayor WALKER is reported to be about to demand that the proceedings against him be postponed until after the November elections. Into his pure mind has come a horrid doubt that there may be "politics" in the proposal to remove him from office.

HONOLULU, June 12. -- Rikan Konishi, eighty-five-pound Japanese contractor, descended safely Into the Halemaumau firepit of Kilauea Volcano today and recovered the bodies of Sylvester Nunes and Margaret Enos.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 12. -- Nine star class yachts raced through rain today in a special event of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

A new plan for unification of the rapid transit lines of the B.M.T. and Interborough, under a Board of Rapid Transit Control, at a total purchase price of $400,683,990, was made public yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP). -- Speaking from the top of a taxicab, Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois today addressed a turbulent crowd of veterans at the "Bonus Expeditionary Force" camp and talked them down after facing a barrage of heckling.

Evil is one of the necessary things of life, for life must have shadow as well as sunshine to be interesting, according to the Rev. Dr. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Dean Gates advanced that theory in his sermon yesterday morning when he asserted also that Jesus taught the highest optimism, which is being construed today by many as the blackest pessimism.

CINCINNATI, June 12 (AP). -- The Phillies and Cincinnati Reds rushed down from Philadelphia last night, played a game today in which the Reds lost, 6 to 1, and took a train Tight back to the Pennsylvania city.

An analysis prepared by the research bureau of the Welfare Council and issued yesterday revealed that the public and private relief agencies of New York City had for several months been spending at the rate of 165,000,000 a year for direct aid to the destitute unemployed.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Beef eaters who had favored heavy steers for many months have changed to lighter weights, so that yearlings now have the preference and they commanded a premium at the close of last week. Early in the week choice heavy steers sold at $7.65 a hundredweight and $7.60 was the top for yearlings, with heifers at $6.75.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- A boom for James R. Garfield of Ohio to succeed Senator Fess as chairman of the Republican National Committee started among the convention delegates today, and by tonight it had grown to respectable proportions. Mr. Garfield will be chosen as chairman of the Resolutions Committee when it assembles, but the choice of the National Committee's new chief will not be made until the convention has adjourned.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 12. -- In delivering the baccalaureate sermon at the Colgate commencement exercises here this morning Dr. George B. Cutten, president of the university, pointed out to the 215 graduating seniors the necessity of the correct expression of instincts through the medium of intelligence.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Women propagandists, arriving in increasing numbers for the Republican National Convention, busily scurried about the numerous headquarters in the hotels along Michigan Boulevard today.

Another step that will eventually lead to added pleasure for the bass fisherman has been started by the New York State Conservation Department. One hundred and fifty acres of land have just been purchased at South Otselic in Chenango County, where a fish hatchery will soon be erected for the raising of bass.

Running with that boundless energy that is a characteristic of the Lermond brothers, Lieutenant George Lermond of the New York A.C. smashed the American 3,000-meter steeplechase record and came within a scant 2 seconds of the Olympic mark as the fortieth annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships came to a close yesterday on the vivid green turf at Travers Island.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Without debate or a dissenting vote and amid a burst of applause, the New York delegation to the Republican National Convention in caucus tonight approved a tentative prohibition plank calling for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment through the adoption by Congress of a concurrent resolution to repeal it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12. -- Professor Charles A. Dinsmore, in his sermon to the graduating class of the Yale Divinity School, which today opened its 110th anniversary celebration, said "man today thinks of the kingdom of heaven as the ideal State where every one has high wages, unemployment insurance and short hours of labor, whereas in the mind of Jesus it was an ideal glowing in a regenerated heart."

BERLIN, June 12. -- The German delegation to the Lausanne conference, consisting of Chancellor Franz von Papen, Baron Constantin von Neurath, Foreign Minister; Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, Finance Minister, and Professor Hermann Warmbold, Minister of Economics -- "all of the peerage," as their opponents scathingly comment -- will leave Berlin with a host of under-secretaries and attaches Tuesday night.

NEW ORLEANS, June 12. -- Last week on the Cotton Exchange here was one of spasmodic trading and lower prices. Near its end prices for contracts dropped to the lowest levels of the season, with the July option down to 4.92 cents a pound, October to 5.13 and December to 5.29.

Aroused by what they termed "the utter futility of protests, petitions and sporadic efforts to effect certain economies" in municipal expenditures, representatives of a group of leading merchants, tankers, real estate interests and civic associations announced plans yesterday for the formation of the Citizens Budget Commission, a permanent body designed to bring about reductions In the mounting costs of city government and to study possible sources of new revenue.

The Board of Transportation has asked the Board of Estimate to approve a contract for reconstruction of the Thirty-fourth Street terminal of the Hudson Manhattan Rail-road, at an estimated cost of $4,955,500 to facilitate construction of a four-track subway line in Sixth Avenue between Eighth and Forty-first Streets, it was disclosed yesterday.
ALBANY, June 12. -- Still busy with the reading of the evidence against Mayor Walker, Governor Roosevelt returned to the Capitol tonight prepared for an active program in the coming week.
MANILA, June 12. -- An unusual opportunity for rehabilitating the Philippines financially, and also probably preparing them for independence, faces the Governor General, Theodore Roosevelt.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 12. -- Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen gave a small luncheon today at Wakehurst and will give a similar party next Sunday. Mrs. Skirvin Adams entertained at Shady Lawn. Others having luncheon were Mr. and Mrs. Maximilian Agassiz and Mr. and Mrs. William F.H. Whitehouse.

The latest of the Summer theatres to announce its program is the Croton River Playhouse, which will open an eight weeks' season at Harmon, N.Y., on June 27. Ann Grosvenor Ayres will be general director; Ralph McBane, stage director; Charles Friedman, technical director, and Charles Walton, business manager.

Norman Thomas of New York and James H. Maurer of Pennsylvania were formally notified last night at a dinner of New York Socialists at the Park View Palace, Fifth Avenue and 110th Street, of their nomination for President and Vice President of the United States respectively by the recent Milwaukee convention of the Socialist party.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Walters, now at the Pierre, will sail on the Europa tomorrow with Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope to pass several weeks in England.

Gifts to the Salvation Army's united appeal for funds had reached a total of $276,513.91 at the close of the fourth week of solicitation, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the campaign. The appeal is for funds with which to continue emergency relief and institutional aid activities.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Governor Roosevelt may attend the Democratic National Convention, it became known today when it was disclosed that the Presidential suite now occupied by the Republican National Committee had been reserved by James A. Farley, New York State Democratic chairman and manager of Governor Roosevelt's campaign.

College professors are as derelict in the matter of attending chapel as students, according to the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. In his sermon last evening he asked whether our colleges and universities were turning out agnostics.

By creating the International Cancer Research. Association and endowing it with $2,000,000 Mr. WILLIAM H. DONNER may have taken a highly important step in checking a scourge that is exacting an alarmingly increasing toll of life. What distinguishes him from other philanthropists whose hearts have been similarly touched is his insistence upon a correlation of world-wide activities.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- While maintaining close contact with the Republican Convention, President Hoover is hopeful that no situation will develop which will call for his intervention, directly or indirectly. This attitude applies to the Vice Presidency and prohibition, just now the most troublesome of the problems awaiting solution by the convention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We shall not reach an era of prosperity and we shall not end the actual crisis until we stop lying to our-selves. There is no greater danger for the future of an individual than lying to himself. A man lying to him-self necessarily cannot see and understand the conditions under which he is living and therefore cannot act with common sense and in accordance with actual circumstances.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP). -- A two-run drive by the Cubs in the thirteenth inning broke up a pitchers' duel between Ben Cantwell and Guy Bush today and gave Chicago a 5 to 3 victory over the Braves. The triumph increased Chicago's lead in the National League race to a game and a half over the second-place Braves.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., June 12. -- The economic depression has placed emphasis on what a person is, rather than on what he has, Dr. Robert J. Trevorrow, president of the Centenary Junior College, in a baccalaureate address here today, told the students of Centenary Collegiate Institute who are to graduate tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Among early arrivals for the Republican convention is Godfrey G. Gloom, a prominent pawpaw planter and veteran Democrat of Amity, Ind., who was discovered this afternoon by a reporter sitting on a bench in Grant Park and watching the anti-prohibition yacht parade.

Announcement of the formation of a Citizens' Budget Commission carries high hopes for the future of New York and those who dwell therein -- and pay ever-mounting taxes on their dwellings. It will be a non-partisan, non-profit-making, permanent body, functioning under responsible auspices and designed to afford an independent check on municipal extravagance.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 12. -- Today was Baccalaureate Sunday at Lehigh. The Packer Memorial Church on the campus was filled by relatives and friends of the graduates to hear the annual sermon, preached by the Rev. Dr. Claude G. Beardslee, Professor of Moral and Religious Philosophy at Lehigh.

WARSAW, June 12. -- In an effort to aid business and labor, as well as to insure the payment of taxes, the Polish Government has undertaken to provide that incomes of private business shall not be dissipated through the payment of salaries that are considered too high.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- President Butler of Columbia University, leader of the wing demanding prohibition repeal, was photographed by a battery of camera men outside the Black-stone Hotel soon after his arrival with the New York delegation this morning.

BOSTON, June 12. -- Nathan Straus Jr. of New York came to Boston and vicinity today for the first time in connection with the Jewish Agency for Palestine, and made an appeal for financial support of the work that is going on in the homeland.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- A collection of paintings, furniture, tapestries and porcelains, supposed, to be valued at millions of dollars and never before on public display, has been lent to the Pennsylvania Museum of Art by Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury.
The All New York Selected Fifteen defeated the Mayo Provincial Gaelic football team for the third successive time at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, 8 to 5.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Headed by Dr. John Van Duyn of Syracuse, N.Y., sole surviving member of the class of 1862, alumni of Princeton University will return to the campus this week to hold their annual reunions. The gatherings of graduates are the opening events upon the program of the 185th commencement.

Governor Roosevelt announced yesterday that Kenneth Collins, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., had accepted the chairmanship of a general citizens' committee being formed to balance the 1932 budget of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

The Japanese policy of imperialistic expansion in Manchuria and China will, if persisted in, inevitably bring Japan into direct conflict with the United States and Soviet Russia, according to Karl Radek, editor of the official Soviet newspaper Izvestia and reputed to be the leading journalist of Soviet Russia.

It might seem that the heated disputes at Chicago over the exact phrasing of the prohibition plank were little more than a quarrel about words. But sometimes in public affairs a word becomes the equivalent of a thing. This now appears to have taken place with "repeal."

Archaeological finds in the vicinity of Jerusalem and in Samaria within the last few days bring fresh confirmation of certain passages in the Scripture record. They have more than ordinary human interest, whatever their scientific value, for they evoke from the earth fresh memories of personages with whom the Western world has had an acquaintance through the Bible.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 13 -- Revision of the constitution, making the terms of its officers three years and providing for a triennial convention hereafter was adopted today by the General Federation of Women's Clubs. No second term would be allowed the president.

BASLE, June 13 -- The appointment of a committee composed of representatives of central banks, including the United States Federal Reserve Board, to study monetary problems with the view to determining the role of the Bank for International Settlements in economic reconstruction was the principal decision at the shortest monthly board meeting at the World Bank headquarters here today.

Expressing the belief that Broadway, the symbol of the gaiety and bustle of city life, has been losing much of its prestige and glamour because of the dry laws, leading business interests of that thoroughfare as represented by the Broadway Association voted yesterday for prompt repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as the best means of reviving business and bringing back the "Great White Way" of other days.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The centre of Republican convention activity was invaded late tonight by about 200 members of a Chicago "bonus army," who trooped suddenly and unheralded into the Congress Hotel, where party leaders have headquarters.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 13 -- Traditional class-day exercises were held by the senior class at Lehigh University today. A new feature was the presentation of six athletic cups, five of which were formerly presented on Alumni Day, as follows:

Directors of the Adams Express Company voted yesterday to omit the quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share due at this time on the 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock. The investment trust issued this statement:

About 200 of the country's leading radio stations, spanning the continent from coast to coast, and extending into Canada, with allied shortwave transmitters to span the ocean, will be linked this morning with microphones at the National Republican Convention in Chicago, according to estimates of the National Broadcasting and Columbia systems.

RYE, N.Y., June 13 -- Urging members of the New York Bankers Association to crystallize public opinion in their respective communities toward the curtailment of governmental expenditures, J. Stewart Baker, vice chairman of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company and president of the association, in his address at the thirty-ninth annual convention here today, asserted that a country that was profligate of its citizens' money and credit could not hope to prosper.

AURORA, N.Y., June 13 -- Fifty-four young women, the largest class to be graduated since 1924, will receive the Bachelor of Arts degree from Wells College at the sixtyfourth annual commencement tomorrow.

The renewal for one year, subject to a reduction in principal amount from $50,000,000 to $45,000,000 of the credit to the Gold Discount Bank, an affiliate of the Reichsbank, which was announced in Berlin over the week-end, was confirmed here yesterday by the International Acceptance Bank, Inc., which headed the group of American banks extending the credit.

The annual observance of Flag Day, which was instituted on June 14, 1890, by the Sons of the American Revolution, will be general today throughout the city with services by various organizations, including a celebration for disabled veterans in the hospital at the Brooklyn Navy Yard under the auspices of the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

According to a cablegram received from London by Arch Selwyn. Charles B. Cochran's American associate, Mr. Cochran's productions of "Cavalcade" and "Helen" and his revival of "The Miracle" will close their London engagements on June 25.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 13 (AP) -- Francis J. O'Connor, Elmhurst, L.I., will receive a gold medal "for extraordinary loyalty, personality, character and success in studies in the senior class," at the annual commencement exercises of Niagara University tomorroy.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- Godfrey S. Gloom, the old-fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat from Indiana, was encountered by a reporter in the Congress Hotel lobby. Immediately Mr. Gloom drew the reporter aside.

Dr. Parke R. Kolbe, president of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, submitted his resignation to the corporation of the engineering college yesterday with the announcement that he had accepted an appointment as president of the Drexel Institute of Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- With the Republican convention opening tomorrow many important planks of the platform which will be presented to it were still uncertain. Farm relief and reduction of the cost of government were among the planks on which the Republican platform makers centred attention today, but overshadowing all others which the resolutions committee will consider tomorrow in open session was prohibition.

Dwight F. Davis, former Governor General of the Philippines, will sail tonight on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line, accompanied by Misses Alice and Helen Davis, his daughters, to see the tennis match played in Paris for the cup that he donated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I drive the streets of New York daily, starting from and finishing on East Forty-second Street. It would be difficult to conceive worse stop light regulations. They insure the slowest possible traffic and the greatest loss of time.

The daily report of gold transactions Issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed a net gain to the gold stocks of the country for the first time since May 5. A decrease of $6,000,000 in earmarked gold was reported and $6,001,400 gold, evidently including the metal released from earmark, was shipped to Switzerland.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The potted palms and rubber plants, the easy chairs and lounges which in calmer times adorn the hotel lobbies gave way today before the politicians who tomorrow will begin to whoop it up for Hoover, to resolve, to point with pride and perhaps view with alarm.

Twenty Negro workers, actors, students and writers will sail on the Europa at midnight tonight on the first lap of a journey to Moscow, where they are to appear in a Russian motion picture about the life of the Negro in the United States. The Meschrabpom Film Corporation of Moscow, producers of the film, is host to the party.
NEW YORK. Anthony J. Drexel gave a dinner Last night at the Central Park Casino. His guests were Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., Miss Edith Cram and Henry S. Cram.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Women prohibition organizations served notice on the two great parties today that they will not accept "a dry candidate for President or Vice President on a wet platform'' because, they declared, the sincerity of such a candidate could not be trusted.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 13 -- Matches scheduled for tomorrow in the Third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club have been postponed to Thursday because of today's heavy rain. It is not believed the turf will dry sufficiently to permit play tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on June 8 shows decreases for the week of $304,000,000 in loans and investments, $111,000,000 in net demand deposits, $40,000,000 in time deposits, $129,000,000 in government deposits and $19,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $10,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 13 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin believes the financiers are great comedians in the role of economists. The actor discussed economic conditions when he arrived here today from the Orient, nearing the end of his round-the-world tour.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Demands for a five-day work week, emergency and permanent unemployment relief and modification of the Volstead act to permit manufacture and sale of 2.75 per cent beer will be offered for the Republican party platform tomorrow night by representatives of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Under the silent gaze of 100 ex-service men, and with the corridors packed with 2,000 others unable to find places in the galleries, the House of Representatives took its first steps today toward the passage of the bill for the immediate payment of the $2,400,000,000 soldier bonus certificates.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Underlying the controversies over a prohibition plank and the renomination of Vice President Curtis, the chief point of difference in the Republican National Convention is the determination of the Old Guard to retain control of the national party organization and the organizations in the several States.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Just before midnight on the very eve of the opening of the Republican convention here tomorrow, a group composed of President Hoover's intimates and Cabinet associates agreed upon a resubmission plank on prohibition which they will offer in the committee on resolutions tomorrow.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has just increased his holdings in the Rockefeller Centre area by purchasing the former Dillingham residence at 8 West Forty-ninth Street, on a plot fronting 22 feet by 100 feet in depth The property was recently transferred to Cuthbert B. Caton by Harriet A. Dillingham and has now been conveyed by Mr. Caton to Mr. Rockefeller subject to a mortgage for $60,000 held by the Farmers Loan and Trust Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The current events club to which I belong has asked me to write to THE TIMES a suggestion which we believe might assist us in the effort we are making to keep open minds on a subject of great controversy, that subject being prohibition.
RYE, N.Y., June 13 -- Representatives of thirteen colleges will begin play at the Apawamis Club tomorrow in the annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13 -- Perry J. Fuller of 21 Morris Street, this city, New York lawyer, died in the Middlesex General Hospital here today, after an illness of five weeks. His age was 80. He had lived here for the last ten years, and until his final illness had gone daily to his office at 145 Nassau Street, New York, where he was in partnership with Friend L. Tuttle.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 13 (Canadian Press) -- Defeat of the Liberal Government of Sir Richard Anderson Squires was conceded tonight as results from Saturday's general election gave the United Newfoundland party twelve seats out of fourteen for which returns were complete.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- While Republican leaders wrangled over fine distinctions of phraseology in the party's prohibition plank, the delegates gathered here tonight for the national convention found the liquor problem chiefly academic. There was no reason why any Wet should go dry in Chicago.

Butter. Receipts, 13.844 packages. Some of the decided firmness noticeable at the close of last week was lost yesterday and while values were well supported during the early trading a rather uncertain feeling was in evidence. Arrivals for the week ended Saturday last, we believe, were the heaviest on record, totaling over 108,000 packages, and with heavy receipts expected this week some uneasiness was developing here and there.

TOKYO, June 13 -- A joint resolution urging the government to recognize the new State of Manchukuo will be introduced in the Diet tomorrow by the Seiyukai (majority party) and Minseito (chief minority party).
DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- Robert Moses Grove of the Philadelphia Athletics won his eleventh consecutive game today, beating Detroit, 8 to 1, and allowing only four scattered hits.

Business was at low ebb on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The share market was a languid, colorless affair, and the bond market only slightly less apathetic. The net results, except in a handful of issues, were unimportant.

The Presbyterian Church is run by a "machine" and the machine is "well oiled," according to several of the commissioners to the recent annual General Assembly in Denver. The commissioners made their official reports yesterday at a meeting of the Presbytery of New York in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

The squeeze of an overextended short interest in the stock of the Auburn Automobile Company, which resulted last week in a rise of 28 3/4 points, was transferred yesterday to the loan crowd of the New York Stock Exchange, where the shorts were compelled to pay a premium of 75 cents a share for borrowing the stock overnight.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- A move to just nine La Follette delegates from the Wisconsin convention group developed tonight at a delegation caucus.

PARIS, June 13 -- Although trading was not active on the Bourse today, the tendency was firmer, so that despite some weakness toward the closing, most of Friday's losses were effaced. After the Herriot-MacDonald talks at Lausanne, pessimism was somewhat reduced.

The adjusted index of automobile production has reached a new high mark for 1932. The index for the week ended June 11 stands at 51.5, as against 49.0 for the preceding week and 71.0 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, was 52,560 cars and trucks, as against 50,443 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 66.468 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 13 -- Reports that the firing of several shots had been heard near here led to the discovery by the police of the body of a man on the Allwood Road a short distance outside Clifton. Police said that the man had been shot in the head, evidently in a gang feud.

The Circuit Court of Appeals handed down a decision yesterday reversing the conviction of seven officers of the Long Island National Bank of Astoria, who in the United States District Court in Brooklyn in December, 1930, were found guilty of conspiracy to misapply the funds of the bank.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Reports that the supporters of Governor Roosevelt favored Melvin A. Traylor, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, for Vice President received partial confirmation today, when James A. Farley of New York, manager of the Roosevelt campaign, called on Mr. Traylor.

The Houston Post reveals him, Mr. HARVEY W. GILBERT, a Republican candidate for Congressman at large, has perfected a "sweeping program of unemployment relief." He would have the Government buy "vast areas of land in many States" and sell it on long-term loans to needy families, which it would furnish with funds to build small houses and for other purposes:

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- On the eve of the Republican National Convention leading Senate Democrats today used the economy program as a vehicle for one of the most bitter attacks on the Hoover Administration this session.

Martin Conboy, New York attorney, and former Supreme Court Justice John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie were announced by Governor Roosevelt yesterday as the two attorneys who will assist in analyzing the evidence on Mayor Walker submitted by Samuel Seabury, which the Governor has said he would treat as removal charges.

BERLIN, June 13 -- The Boerse anticipated today a favorable result from the Lausanne conference and business picked up after the recent stagnation. Prices moved slowly upward, the whole of the potash group advancing about 2 per cent. I.G. Farben, Siemens-Halske and Reichsbank benefited from, foreign investments.

Washington Square is moving uptown, piecemeal, it is true, but with a thoroughness and determination, sufficient to assure that the open-air art idea has sold itself right and left. Not that there is much open air left in the idea, for two of the sequel exhibitions opened yesterday in the restaurant at Gimbel Brothers and in Walter P. Chrysler Jr.'s Cheshire Gallery, 405 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Hundreds of protests are being received by the Radio Commission, against limiting the time of broadcasting station WLWL in New York City to two hours daily.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Former Senator France of Maryland, who is the only visible opponent to President Hoover for first place on the Republican ticket, hinted darkly today that some name would be brought before the party's national convention which would sweep that gathering off its feet when the order of nominations is reached.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Mr. Mitchell in THE TIMES commenting on a portion of Owen D. Young's address to the graduating class of Notre Dame is an able exposition of the conditions which have resulted in the economic collapse of agriculture.

Federal Judge "William Bondy. acting yesterday on a motion filed by De Forest Brothers, attorneys for the National Employment Exchange of 30 Church Street, dismissed a petition in bankruptcy entered on May 3 against the exchange by George J. Perpente, a former employe.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 13 -- The extension of social control is the program now being offered to the graduates of 1932 in commencement speeches everywhere. Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar, told the graduating class at the college commencement here today.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- The wets are trying to stampede the Republican Convention. Experience should teach them that the Republican Convention never stampedes on important matters.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- One man's influence dominates the attention of politically minded women who are arriving in Chicago by trainloads for the opening of the Republican national convention tomorrow. That man in John D. Rockefeller Jr.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Planks covering governmental economy, unemployment and international cooperation have been drafted by the National League of Women Voters for inclusion in the platforms of the Republican and Democratic parties. The texts of the planks were issued tonight by Miss Marguerite Wells of Minneapolis, chairman of the league.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The fight to prevent the re-election of Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, Representative in Congress, as one of New York's representatives on the Republican National Committee was assuming the dimensions tonight of a national conflict.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The turn of events in Chile signalized by the resignation of Senor Davila as head of the junta is regarded here with concern because of the possibility that disorders may result and lead to a greater demoralization in the economy of the country.

DETROIT, June 13 -- Henry Ford believes Herbert Hoover is better fitted to be President of the United States today than any other man who has been mentioned for nomination by either party. He believes that the country recognizes this and will reelect him.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., June 13 -- Fifty-three graduates of Blair Academy received diplomas from Dr. Charles H. Breed, headmaster, at commencement exercises held here this morning. The Rev. George A. Buttrick of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church of New York City delivered the address.

Production of new life insurance throughout the country dropped 22.5 per cent in May, bringing the average decrease for the first five months of the year down to 12.1 per cent, according to the report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce, based on figures from forty-four member companies having in force 82 per cent of the total insurance in force in all United States legal reserve companies.
MEDFORD, Mass., June 13 -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover received the honorary degree of Master of Arts from Tufts College at its seventy-sixth commencement today.

BERLIN, June 13 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's Nazi storm troops, which were dissolved by the Bruening Government April 13 on the ground they constituted a "private army" menacing the State, will be made legal again in a government decree to be issued tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Gaston B. Means was found guilty in the District of Columbia Court tonight of larceny of $104,000 from Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean in a fantastic plan to recover the kidnapped Lindbergh baby.

As sponsors of the Citizens' Budget Commission moved forward yesterday with their organization plans, Mayor Walker and Budget Director Charles L. Kohler said they would welcome any constructive suggestions toward solving the city's financial problems.

Trial of a suit brought by the Irving Trust Company as trustee in bankruptcy to recover about $3,000,000 from former officers of the Sonora Phonograph Company, Inc., drew to an end yesterday after its twenty-fourth day when both sides rested.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Two more days remain for payment of the last quarterly instalment of income taxes for the 1932 fiscal year. Judging from the payments of last June and March, about $150,000,000 will be received by the Treasury from income taxes this month, bringing the total for the year to around $1,050,000,000, the lowest since the war.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Making its third important trade in a week, the Boston Red Sox today sent Earl Webb, hard-hitting outfielder, to Detroit in exchange for Dale Alexander, the big first baseman, and outfielder Roy Johnson. President Bob Quinn said no cash was involved in the transaction.

New York City. The National City Bank, which, with the Chase National Bank, purchased from New York City last week an issue of $8,000,000 5 1/2 per cent special revenue bonds, due on June 10, 1933, will offer today through its affiliate, the National City Company, a portion of its share of the issue.

The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday offered to the oil producers of California an advance of 25 cents a barrel in the prices for crude oil. provided that the production of the State was held down to 476,700 barrels daily. This limit of production is that set by the Equitable Curtailment Committee of the State.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 13 -- James J. Corbett, former heavyweight champion of the world, was among those who saw Max Schmeling, the titleholder, lash his way through five rounds of fighting with three sparring partners today.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 13 (AP) -- Most of the favorites, including a number of college stars tuning up for next week's intercollegiates, passed safely through the first and second rounds of the Delaware State tennis championships on the rainsoaked courts of the Wilmington Country Club today.

The opening concert of the Goldman Band's Summer series took place as scheduled last night on the Mall in Central Park, despite lowering clouds and an ominous drop or two of rain early in the evening. A large crowd was present, filling most of the benches and warmly receptive to the music.

More than $4,000,000 in awards to Jamaica Bay property owners were handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Dunne in Brooklyn for land taken by the city in connection with the development of Jamaica Bay and its environs.

CINCINNATI, June 13 -- County Auditor Robert Heuck announced today to the Board of Revision a horizontal cut of 10 per cent on the tax value at all real estate in Hamilton County, to become effective in the December collection. So far as is known here, this is the first decrease in taxes in the country.

Mr. UNTERMYER'S latest transit unification plan is more advantageous to the city and the public than its predecessors, but less attractive to the companies, except in one important respect. To be feasible under present conditions, any plan must obviously " leave out of ac"count any contribution either in "cash or corporate stock or bonds "by the city, or the assumption by "it of any liability."

NEW ORLEANS, La., June 13 -- Stanislaus Felix Hausner formerly was a member of the Brothers of the Sacred Heart, a Catholic teaching order, and taught in St. Aloysius College in New Orleans. He was known as Brother Adolph and taught here from Nov. 1, 1918, until June, 1920.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 13 -- A municipality could not impose what amounted to a prohibitive tariff wall against merchants who have no stores within its borders under the guise of a peddler's license fee, Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief ruled today.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- Two home runs by Bill Dickey and Babe Ruth's fourth in the three games here were the high spots in the slugging which provided just enough runs for the Yankees to beat Cleveland today, 8 to 7, and take the lead in the series, two games to one.

LIMA, Peru, June 13 (AP) -- John Walter Gregory, 68 years old, Scottish geologist, died June 6 when his canoe capsized in the Urubamba River near Megantomi Falls, while he was making a private geological exploration trip through the Andes.

EASTON, Pa., June 13 -- With a registration that was encouraging in view of the fact that the alumni reunions were held nearly a month ago, the fourth annual session of the Lafayette College Alumni College opened this morning. After the regular lecture periods, the visiting speaker of the week, Professor Wilfred J. Hinton of England, delivered an address on "British Policy in the Pacific."

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 13 -- The Mansion House on the green in front of the Court House here where George Washington and his officers stopped after the evacuation of Fort Lee was raided yesterday by Federal prohibition agents, who arrested the proprietor and a bartender and confiscated about ten quarts of liquor and three barrels of beer.

The Bowery Savings Bank made a loan of $150,000, payable in five years at 5 per cent, to John F. Baudouine and others of his family on the southwest corner of Madison Av, and 61st St., and this has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one lien of $200.000 on the property.

The International Telephone and Telegraph System reduced its notes payable from S44,217,772 at the end of 1931 to $42,623,670 on March 31, 1932, according to the quarterly statement issued yesterday. These are notes of subsidiaries, of which $15,623,670 are principally local banking credits in favor of manufacturing companies.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- While reports from the Republican convention at Chicago concerning dissension over the selection of a Vice President and the form the prohibition plank will take evoked no official comment from the White House today, there were many indications that President Hoover was preparing to make a determined fight within the next twenty-four hours for a decision that will meet with his approval.

Rail Subsistence Gardens. The railroads are acceding to the request Subsistence of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief that their low-income and part-time employes be granted land to plant gardens.
The final detachment of the American expeditionary tennis forces for 1932 will sail at midnight tonight on board the Europa, bound for England.

By 226 to 175 the House of Representatives voted yesterday to discharge its Rules Committee from, further consideration of the Patman bonus bill. This was a parliamentary manoeuvre necessary to bring the measure before the House. The question of adoption or rejection will be raised today.
LONDON, June 13 -- Britain's unfavorable balance of trade is beginning to climb again despite the tariff arid the suspension of the gold standard.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 13 -- Cautioning the graduating class of Colgate University today not to take their business too seriously but to develop the cultural margins of their lives lest the pursuit of success leave them equipped with only uniform and sterile ideas, Stanley King, new president of Amherst College, added that a "disturbed world would test their characters and afford valuable experience."

GENEVA, N.Y., June 13 (AP) -- Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee investigating New York City's government, was cited by the Hobert College Alumni Council today for "distinguished service to the cause of good government."

By defeating the Hempstead Golf Club team, 4 to 1, in a match over the Pomonok Country Club course at Flushing, L.I., yesterday, the Women's National Golf Club took the title of the Class B division of the Long Island Women's Inter-Club Golf League.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13 -- The first of the series of garden days, under the auspices of the Newport Garden Association for the benefit of the Newport Civic League, will start tomorrow and continue each Tuesday afternoon until the end of August.

Rain and wet grounds, a combination that already has piled up an unprecedented number of doubleheaders for the Giants, again stood in the path of Manager Bill Terry's drive to get his team into the first division yesterday, when for the second successive afternoon the weather forced a postponement in the series with the Pirates at the Polo Grounds.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 13 (AP) -- Adobe Post conquered five other eligibles for the $50,000 American Derby today at one mile and seventy yards. Ridden by Jockey C. Landolt, the Chicago-owned horse ran the distance of the featured Niles Centre Purse in 1:41, one-fifth of a second off the track record.

ADDIS ABEBA, Abyssinia, June 13 -- Lij Yeassu, the former Emperor of Abyssinia, who escaped last week from the captivity in which Emperor Haile Selassie had kept him for fifteen years, has been recaptured.

Conditions being what they are in the theatre just now, a group of actors have organized themselves into the Broome Stagers, and they mounted their first play, "Back Fire," at the Vanderbilt last evening. Jerrold Robert, a Broome Stager (otherwise known as Robert Ober) wrote it; a Broome Stager directed it, and Broome Stagers, looking particularly comely, infested the aisles and directed the patrons to their seats.

LONDON, June 13 -- Leonard Goodhart Sutton, one of the world's greatest experts in flower growing, chairman of the famous seed firm of Sutton Sons, died in Reading today, at the age of 68. Four of his five sons were killed in the World War.

Buddy, the Bronx Zoo's 13-month-old chimpanzee, lay placidly on a small, glass-topped table in a corridor of the zoo's hospital yesterday, while it became obvious to every one present that something important was about to happen.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 13 -- When honorary degrees were conferred today by Colby College, in presenting the candidates Herbert E. Wadsworth, chairman of the board of trustees, made the following citations:

Directors of the New England Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the National Electric Power Company, voted yesterday to omit quarterly dividends on the $6 and $7 prior lien stocks, automatically forestaling payments in four other classes of preferred stock.

BOSTON, June 13 -- Class legislation must cease or the government will perish, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told the graduates of Boston University today as 1,401 degrees were conferred at Boston Arena.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Well, got some scandal for you today, for it wouldn't be a Republican convention without some sort of undercover "finagling." They are out now to throw poor old Injun Charley Curtis off and get another Vice President.

Democratic party leaders from all over the country joined yesterday in a statement that "whatever the result of the convention, the Democrats will get behind their nominee and support him loyally." The declaration was made to convince party members that the victory campaign fund of $1,500,000 should be raised regardless of a division of opinion as to who the Democratic candidate should be.

The money market was much the same in the matter of rates and conditions at the opening of business in the new week as it was during the preceding week. Virtually little demand was evident for any accommodation -- call, time or business money, while quotations for all were unchanged.

Price movement in commodities was mixed between a number of advances and declines, none of which ran to very great length, however. Grains were lower, but cotton showed improvement. Sugar was a feature in an advance of 2 to 4 points, rubber also showing a gain. Slight losses were found in coffee, cocoa and hides. Elsewhere prices were steady.

ASCOT, England, June 13 -- Royal Ascot, most aristocratic of British turf settings, opens tomorrow with the King and Queen heading the annual parade of English society to the country's most picturesque race course.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Displacement of the Glass banking reform bill as the pending business of the Senate was laid by Senator Glass in debate today to pressure from "special interests."

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- Near-exhaustion of consumer supplies points toward a possible early trend upward of prices and recovery of business, according to P.A. O'Connell of Boston, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, who addressed the opening session of the organization's convention today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Unemployment can best be aided by permitting the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to loan to private industry, it was contended today by Clarence M. Woolley, chairman of the board of the American Radiator Corporation, and Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the board of the United States Gypsum Corporation, in supporting the Barbour relief bill before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 13 -- More than ordinary interest in the annual village election June 21 is being evinced by voters of the millionaire municipality of Centre Island because of the filing of a designating petition for the office of Mayor by Mrs. Nelson B. Burr on the Citizens party ticket.
Radio appeals have brought many donations to the Salvation Army's united appeal for $1,090,000 and to the Block Community Organization, it was reported yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 13 -- Miss Eleanor Holm, national medley champion, broke the world's 200-yard backstroke record tonight in an exhibition by the Women's Swimming Association at the Westchester Country Club. Miss Holm was timed in 2:35.4 to shatter the old mark of 2:39.2, made by Miss Joan McSheehy in October, 1930.

GENEVA, June 13 -- Without a single cheer by a crowd that was a mere fraction of the enthusiastic throng that had welcomed them in 1924, Premier Edouard Herriot and Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald came back to Geneva tonight. They looked tired from their week-end conversations which had been continued on the train, but they were officially described as happy with the talks.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 13 -- Charles H. Mayo Jr., son of the Lido Club professional, who was put to rout yesterday in the Timber Point invitation by H.H. (Tex.) Newton, made amends today on the Rockwood Hall course.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., June 13 -- Governor A. Harry Moore addressed the graduating classes of the Centenary Collegiate Institute at the annual commencement in Whitney Hall here today. There were twenty-five graduates from the high school division and seventeen from the junior college.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- After being held scoreless for five innings today, the Chicago White Sox hit Eddie Durham freely and scored a 7-to-6 victory over Boston.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- With thinly veiled references to President Hoover and the administration group Who are here for the Republican National Convention, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared tonight that any individual, group or party that blocked progress toward repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment would pay the penalty of political disaster at the November election.
CANTON, N.Y., June 13 -- At the seventieth commencement of St. Lawrence University this morning 138 degrees and three honorary degrees were conferred by Dr. Sykes, the president.

Tax Spurs Advance Orders. Many orders for merchandise coming under the new excise levies featured the business placed in this market yesterday. Delivery was sought prior to the effect date of the taxes at midnight June 20. Orders for toilet goods were reported particularly numerous, covering in some cases from one to three months' normal needs.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The demand for curtailment of governmental expenditures should be an accomplished fact soon if party leaders take their cue from the wave of economy that apparently has hit the women folks of delegates and guests attending the Republican National Convention.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 13 -- Rolando Merino has been transferred from the Ministry of the Interior to take the place made vacant by the resignation of Carlos G. Davila, it was announced today, with no explanation of the move. Arturo Ruiz Mafei, Governor of the Port of Santiago, has been appointed Minister of the Interior.

After having been United States Ambassador to Poland for two and a half years, John N. Willys returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to resume his duties as chairman of the Board of the Willys-Overland Company of Toledo, Ohio.

The White Star liner Homeric, which sailed Saturday for Ireland and Channel ports, will not return here until next year, as the management in London has decided to base the ship at Southampton for short cruises around the British Isles and to Gibraltar.
The excellent pollack fishing in the waters off Montauk Point has caused considerable interest among Long Island as well as Connecticut saltwater fishermen this season.

Tammany Leader John F. Curry and Brooklyn Leader John H. McCooey met former Governor Alfred E. Smith over the week-end at Hampton Bays, L.I., it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Curry's meeting with Mr. Smith was at the latter's request, it was learned.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The fight of the Hoover Administration on two "black and tan" delegations from the South was practically dropped today when the threat was made by Negro leaders to use it as a pretext for raising the race issue on the floor of the coming Republican convention.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Akron reported tonight to the Navy Department her arrival at Parris Island, S.C., at 5:45 P.M. She was moored to a temporary mast at 6:30.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The executive branch of the government today took under advisement the plan proposed by ten New York export associations for bringing about a liquidation of American assets now "frozen" in foreign countries as a result of exchange restrictions.

Despite sloppy going and the fact that his mount was an outsider, George H. (Pete) Bostwick piloted his own Blind Bowboy to victory in the Old Rosebud Claiming Handicap, feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Leading from start to finish, the son of Epinard scored by a length at 8 to 1, with John McCambridge's Flaming second and the Brookmeade Stable's Helianthus, 7-to-5 favorite, third.
TRENTON, N.J., June 13 -- The State Highway Commission received bids today on three projects involving an outlay of more than $700,000. In each instance the competition was keen.

With Wall Street professionals supplying barely enough orders to keep the market in motion, prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday fluctuated within a narrow range and at the close showed little change from the final level of Saturday. Transactions on the Exchange made up a total of only 567,673 shares.

A gate of at least $400,000 seems assured for the world's heavyweight championshln ring battle between Max Schmeling, the titleholder, and Jack Sharkey, American challenger, to be held under the direction of Madison Square Garden in the organization's new bowl in Long Island City June 21.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The first open opposition to Secretary Mills's "gold standard" proposal for the Republican platform developed today when Ernest Bamberger of Utah offered a silver plank for the platform.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 13 -- Yale's oarsmen resumed rowing practice today and appeared to be in fine fettle after their day of rest. A heavy rain during last night had caused quite a freshet in the Thames River, a light northwest wind prevailed and conditions were excellent for fast times being made by crews pulling downstream over the course.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Bertrand H. Snell, permanent chairman of the convention, went to the Stadium for a voice test on the amplifiers. As he practiced his part Joseph Scott, who will nominate President Hoover, suggested: "You might whistle it, Bert."

BOSTON, June 13 -- A nation-wide survey of political sentiment just completed by the Babson statistical organization of Wellesley, indicates that there would be a Democratic victory if the Presidential election were held tomorrow, but that "offsetting this, however, is the fact that the tide has recently turned and is now clearly running toward President Hoover," whose renomination "is assured" at the National Republican Convention which opens tomorrow in Chicago.

After holding within a range of a few points for several hours yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply and closed 9 to 12 points higher than on Saturday.
