A loss of a cent a bushel in wheat influenced early trading, but weather details showing heavy rains over Sunday in sections that complained of too much moisture last week caused an improvement that left the list around the day's best figures.

BOSTON, June 13 -- Twenty-nine yachts will compete in the ocean race to Bermuda starting at Montauk Point on June 25, it was revealed today, when entries closed with Everett Morss Jr., chairman of the race committee of the Cruising Club of America, which will cooperate with the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club in conducting the event.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was dull and irregular yesterday, dealing's amounting to little more than $7,000,000. Public utility issues, notably New York rapid transit bonds, showed the best strength. A few major losses occurred in the railroad group, but in the infrequently traded issues.

LONDON, June 13 -- The stock markets were cheerful today, opening better generally on the week-end developments, which included Mr. Chamberlain's optimistic speech, an improved outlook at Lausanne, the new tariffs and the Australian election result.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A short time ago, in a letter to THE TIMES, I took occasion to reassert the impotence, as I saw it, of any international concert for the maintenance of world peace that is not reenforced by an adequate internaonal police-army.

PARIS, June 13 -- There is general contentment in France over the harmony of Anglo-French relations which resulted from the conversations of Premier Herriot and Prime Minister MacDonald and there is general acceptance of the fact that the Lausanne conference, to which they are going, will be very nearly, if not quite, the penultimate reperations conference.

Jack Zaroff, 29 years old, a former taxicab driver, took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday at his trial in General Sessions on a firstdegree murder indictment in the shooting of Patrolman Maurice O'Brien of the West 123d Street station, in West 113th Street, on the night of Jan. 30, 1930.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13 -- The crews of six universities worked out today on the broad reaches of the Hudson in preparation for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, and tomorrow, with the arrival of Washington and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the field for the greatest of the year's college boat races will be complete.

In his baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class at Vassar the Rev. Dr. CHARLES WATSON of Cairo said that " the young men and "women of our colleges shun the "political life, which English youth "enters upon naturally." Statements like this are familiar.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The New Jersey delegation at a caucus ending late tonight by unanimous vote adopted a tentative repeal plank sponsored by Walter E. Edge, Ambassador to France. The caucus also selected Ambassador Edge as the State's spokesman in the resolutions committee with instructions to press for the plank's acceptance.

Twelve Star Class fleets have named sixteen boats to sail in the Eastern Olympic semi-finals and Atlantic Coast championship races, which begin tomorrow at Warwick, R.I., and continue to Saturday, it was announced yesterday by George W. Elder.

VIENNA, June 13 -- After a fortnight's strained negotiations Sir Robert Kindersley of the Bank of England and Joseph R. Swan of the Guaranty Trust Company, representing American and English banks which lent $70,000,000 in short-term credits to the bankrupt Creditanstalt, left Vienna tonight without having reached a compromise with the Austrian Government.

The complaint of the City Affairs Committee against the "excessive" monthly charge of 25 cents for "French" telephone instruments was answered yesterday by the New York Telephone Company at a hearing before the Public Service Commission with the statement that a reduction of the charge could not be made unless other rates were increased.

MERION, Pa., June 13 -- Aided by unusual putting, Mrs. Clarence H. Vanderbeck, Philadelphia country club player, led the field in the opening of the Women's Eastern Golf Championship by shooting a 78 over the Merion Cricket Club's east course today.

Lee, Higginson Co. and the Guaranty Company of New York were served yesterday with notices of a suit brought in the Supreme Court here by Florence Bramson, represented by Victor House, attorney, of 11 Broadway, for the return of $4,808.33, with interest, which the plaintiff said she invested in $5,000 face value of ten-year 5 per cent collateral gold debentures of the International Match Corporation on or about Jan. 27, 1931.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey, after a conference yesterday with Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the State Police, defended the conduct of the Lindbergh investigators in their questioning of Miss Violet Sharpe, the English maid who committed suicide last Friday in the Englewood home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, Colonel Lindbergh's mother-in-law.

Cardinal Hayes sailed for Ireland yesterday noon on the French liner De Grasse, leading a pilgrimage of 825 men and women to the World Eucharistic Congress, which will be held in Dublin June 22 to 26. Among the pilgrims are several hundred priests.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14 -- That Harvard has an exceptionally fast varsity eight is proved by the time, 17 minutes 45 seconds, made by the crew this evening, when it pulled the shell over the four-mile course down stream.

It has been a frequent experience, said Mr. SHELBY M. HARRISON, general director of the Russell Sage Foundation, in his address at North-western University, to get the reply from foreign visitors when asked what impressed them most in America: "The large number and variety of your agencies and organizations instituted to deal with social problems."

CAMDEN, N.J., June 14 -- Three persons were injured here today during a Flag Day parade of 6,000 school children when, horses drawing a float bolted into a crowd of spectators. The horses, frightened by a shower of confetti, lunged toward the sidewalk a second time, but were held in check by the police.

An improvement in the tone of the stock market yesterday was cheering to Wall Street, although the net gains in leading issues were narrow on the average. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was larger by nearly 200,000 shares than on the day before.

The Commonwealth Theatre, a new producing organization which expects to put a subscription plan into operation next season, gave a party last night at Chanin's Theatre before an invited audience which virtually filled the house. Among those who appeared were Queena Mario, Vladimir Rosing, Natalie Hall, Agnes de Mille, Frank Chapman, Kathleen and Gene Lockhart, Lillian Taiz, Sam Jaffe, Miss Juliet, Gladys Swarthout, Rita Burgess Gould, Ray Knight and Elsie Mae Gordon.

A brisk rally in German loans, led by the issues of the government, featured an otherwise generally dull and irregular bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. German Government 7s closed with a net gain of 5 8/4 points and the 5 1/2S, with a gain of 3 3/8 points to the accompaniment of heavy trading.

Hunter College will award 913 degrees at its sixty-third commencement in Carnegie Hall at 10:30 o'clock this morning. The graduating class includes 319 seniors from the Bronx, 218 from Manhattan, 277 from Brooklyn, 67 from Queens and 15 from Staten Island.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, June 15 -- At 1:30 o'clock this morning the platform-drafting subcommittee of the resolutions committee, named late last night by Chairman James R. Garfield at the end of five hours of open hearings, began its work on the final shaping of the planks to be submitted to the Republican National Convention.

HAVRE, France, June 14 (AP) -- Three airplanes escorted the Ile de France to sea today and dropped flowers on the deck as France's farewell to Mrs. Putnam. With her husband Mrs. Putnam boarded the Ile de France after a reception held by municipal officials here.

DOVER, Del., June 14 -- Twenty-five charters were filed here today for Mangels, Inc., covering twenty-three States and one each for the East and the West. The corporation will manufacture, sell and deal in wearing apparel of all kinds. The capitalization of each company is 100 shares of no par value.

By unanimous vote of its executive committee, the Merchants' Association of New York called upon Congress yesterday to reduce by about $1,000,000,000 the operating expenses of the Federal Government. The association did not specify where these reductions were to be made, but after two hours of discussion members of the committee were convinced savings to that extent were not only possible but necessary to the country's welfare.
The following editorial is from this morning's New York Herald Tribune, Republican:

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Hoosier observer, was discovered by a reporter this evening in a grill room across from the hall where the Republican contention, had just adjourned, with the organ playing "Happy Days Are Here Again."
ABOARD S.S. CIRCE SHELL AT SEA, June 14 (AP) -- "I'm Stanley Hausner; save my ship."

Leo I. Levine. 27-year-old law student, who was discharged in 1928 from the Department of Labor, where he had been employed as a clerk at Ellis Island, pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment charging conspiracy and violation of the immigration law and then told Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury that Harold Van Riper, attorney of Washington, D.C., had used him as a go-between in the conspiracy.

AURORA, N.Y., June 14 -- There is an increasing demand for graduates of broad knowledge, in contradiction to the common saying that this is an age of specialization, according to Dean William E. Weld of the University of Rochester, who addressed the graduating class at the Wells College commencement and cornerstone laying here today.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Faced with the necessity of preventing the financial collapse of the municipalities and their institutions for unemployment relief, with resultant starvation for the army of 6,000,000 jobless, the von Papen Government issued a decree signed by President von Hindenburg today reorganizing the system of unemployment relief and cutting doles by about 20 per cent.

Edward White, president of New York Photo Engravers' Union, Local 1, was walking north in Nassau Street between Ann and Fulton Streets at 10:30 A.M. yesterday, carrying a brief-case containing $7,000 in cash, when he heard his name called.

ROME, June 6 (AP) (by Mail). -- The government has decided that high interest rates and risky business ventures are twin evils contributing to the present financial depression in Italy and has set out to remedy the situation.
Dwellings and small flats composed the built of realty trading in New Jersey reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Prices of wheat broke today around 1 1/2 cents a bushel to the lowest figures recorded on the Board of Trade here since 1852, with the exception of a brief period last Fall. The July delivery dropped below 49 cents for the first time this season, and at 48 3/4 cents was only 4 1/8 cents above the lowest figure at which any future ever has sold on the Exchange.

The Council for Tariff Reduction, in a letter sent yesterday to the chairman of the Republican National Convention in Chicago, urged that the Republican party incorporate in its platform a plank favoring immediate reduction of excessive duties in our own tariff laws and negotiations with foreign nations for tariff reductions on a basis of reciprocity, "thereby reviving the historical policy of the Republican party as exemplified by President McKinley."

While Republican, tradition runs against renomination of the Vice President, and disregard of the wishes of the head of the ticket as to its second name has flattered several times the importance of delegates, the movement or movements at Chicago for dropping Mr. CURTIS seem a little curious.

A warning to "all friends of the city's parks" to be on guard against the "ill-advised movement" to retain the reproduction of Mount Vernon in Prospect Park after the close of the Washington bicentennial celebration in November was sounded yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

About 3,000 arrests have been made since the first of this year in the Times Square zone in an effort by the police to rid the midtown section of panhandlers, peddlers and other undesirables, according to a statement yesterday by John B. Gratke, secretary of the Broadway Association.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In the midst of an impassioned plea for passage of the soldiers' bonus bill, Representative Edward E. Eslick of Tennessee fell dead on the floor of the House early this afternoon.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Al Van Camp's second double of the day, followed by a pair of sacrifices, today gave the Boston Red Sox an eleveninning 5-to-4 victory over Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Confusion surrounding relief and economy legislation, which grew apace today, forced the most optimistic of Senate leaders to conclude that adjournment will not take place on Saturday, but may be reached by the following week-end.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The only person who can stop the steadily growing opposition to the renomination of Vice President Curtis is President Hoover. This becomes more apparent every hour. The anti-Curtis forces are quietly at work, and tonight there is talk that more than twenty delegations are ready to join with Texas and Iowa in substituting General Charles G. Dawes for the man from Kansas.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Pennsylvania, one of the wet States, refused to join in the repeal stampede which swept many delegations last night while Cabinet and other platform makers were devising a submission plank to amend the Eighteenth Amendment to protect States which choose to remain dry.

Representatives of patriotic societies were joined yesterday by thousands of citizens in Flag Day exercises held throughout the city, marking the 155th anniversary of the adoption of the flag as the emblem of the Colonies during the Revolutionary War.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns defeated the Washington Senators, 17 -- 3, today to gain three straight victories in the four-game series. The Browns pounded three Washington pitchers for twenty-four hits, with a scoring offensive in the seventh that brought in six runs.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- The opening prayer for the Republican National Convention, delivered by the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of Washington, was as follows:

Supplementing the recent merger of Shubert, Erlanger and Theatre Guild booking interests and subscription audiences out of town, the receivers of the Shubert Theatre Corporation and its subsidiary companies announced yesterday that a separate plan had been agreed upon whereby other booking activities of the Shubert and Erlanger offices outside New York would be conducted by one company, soon to be formed.

An action to force stockholders of the closed Bank of United States to pay assessments of $25 a share will be brought by Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick on or about Aug. 1, it was disclosed yesterday in an affidavit in opposition to a motion by Abraham C. Weinfeld, a lawyer, for an order to examine Superintendent Broderick preliminary to a suit against the stockholders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For years the bugaboo of Tammany control of Westchester has been used to frighten any independent political thought in that county. Whenever criticism was directed at the strongly entrenched Ward organization the critic was condemned as a Tammany ally.

Plans for a new cooperative opera company, to be known as the Cosmopolitan Opera Association, of New York, will be discussed at a concert to be given June 24 in Madison Square Garden. Max Rabinoff, former impressario of the Boston Opera Company and head of the new association, announced yesterday.

The roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria was formally opened for the Summer season last night with an entertainment called the Starlight Supper Dance, the proceeds of which will benefit the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. Although inclement weather robbed the dance of the outdoor facilities of the roof, the "starlight" motif was maintained by virtue of fanciful decorations.

The liquidation sale of the Oliver Cromwell, a twenty-eight-story apartment hotel at 12-18 West Seventy-second Street, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed indefinitely by Thomas F. Burchill, auctioneer. Postponements have been ordered on several previous occasions.

PARIS, June 14 -- The new French Chamber of Deputies will include seventeen party groups, whose definitive formation will be officially announced tomorrow. "Under this new grouping there are four more than were registered in the last Parliament.

The money market was colorless, going through the same motions that have characterized it for weeks past in the matter of a minimum of business at no change in quotations. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent, Street trades at 1 and Federal funds 1/8@1/4.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A seemingly inevitable outcome of the depression is our increasing preoccupation with personal affairs. Because of this fact omens of great public danger may go unheaded. One phase of the current industrial situation appears to me fraught with possibilities of the gravest consequence.

An elaborate fashion show of the fur industry was staged in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last light with an attendance of more than 2,500 persons, including 500 fur retailers and buyers from various sections of the country.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- The text Of the keynote speech of Senator Dickinson at the opening session of the Republican National Convention was as follows:

To give its personnel "all practicable insurance of continued employment," and with the idea of providing occupation for a greater number of workers, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the largest oil company in the world, announced yesterday that, effective on July 1, it would adopt a forty-hour week for its entire domestic operations.

BERLIN, June 14 (AP). -- The heaviest tax burden ever carried by the German people was imposed today when President von Hindenburg signed a decree that also slashed the expenditures for unemployment relief and materially reduced the government's payments to wounded war veterans.

HAVANA, June 14 -- Wholesale arrests of hundreds of Cubans are being made in a drive against alleged terrorism, and President Machado confirmed today court-martial sentences of two youths accused of terrorism, although the Supreme Court recently declared unconstitutional the law under which they were tried by a military court.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld unanimously yesterday the District Court's decision denying minority interests in the New York Harlem Railroad an accounting of profits and interest under the 401-year lease dated April 1, 1873, through which the New York Central Railroad operates the terminal line.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- The brain of Dr. William W. Keen, eminent surgeon, who died a week ago in his ninety-sixth year, is being studied by fellow scientists in accordance with his wishes, which became publicly known today with the filing of his will, a twenty-six-page document including four codiciles.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- Amendment of the Volstead act to permit the manufacture and transportation of 4 per cent beer and submission to the people of the United States of an amendment to the Eighteenth Amendment were among the proposals advanced by Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an address at the convention dinner of the New York State Bankers' Association here tonight.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14 -- So far as the actors are concerned, the complete cast is assembled here for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta next Monday. The University of "Washington and Massachusetts Institute of Technology squads arrived today and tonight their crews were out on the river with the eights of the six other colleges which are entered.

There is a strong and ever-growing tendency among book publishers to maintain first edition book prices for at least two years after issue, rather than permit cheap reprints selling at approximately one-third of the original price to appear in the market within a few months after publication, W.W. Norton of W.W. Norton Co., chairman of the publishers' committee on the Cheney report, said yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 14 -- All the seeded players in the women's New Jersey State tennis championships, play in which started today, won their opening singles matches. The courts of the Oritani Field Club were still a trifle damp front the recent rains.

A committee was appointed by the board of managers of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States to draft a reply to the communication of the Lord's Day Alliance of New York State, which announced early last month a change of its name and its secession from the national body, it was said yesterday at the semiannual meeting of the board at 156 Fifth Avenue.

SANTIAGO, Chile. June 14 (AP). -- Chile's new Socialist government extended a helping hand to retail merchants today by decreeing a thirty-day moratorium on all their debts and by extending their loans at the national savings banks.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- A demand that the Republican party take a stand for outright repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment opened the first session of the Republican convention resolutions committee this evening.

GENEVA, June 14 -- The steering committee decided at the end of a day spent in important conversations to suspend further meetings of the disarmament conference until these talks were more advanced. This was done without serious opposition on a proposal by the president, Arthur Henderson, made with the double aim of bringing responsibilities home to the seven great powers and speeding the work of the conference.

Drop in Buyers' Registrations. A large drop in the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- With many of its leading figures busily engaged behind the scenes in working out formulae for the solution of problems, including prohibition, that will come before it for action, the twentieth Republican National Convention opened at the Stadium at 11 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The owned and used properties of the Pullman Company were tentatively valued for rate-making purposes at $174,200,000 by the Interstate Commerce Commission today. The new valuation brought the commission's accounting of the properties up to Dec. 31, 1931 and shows an increase of $54,450,000 over the final value assigned by the commission on its condition as of June 30, 1919.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during May was reported today by the Census Bureau to have been 332,439 bales of lint and 50,178 of linters, compared with 367,280 and 50,936 in April this year and 465,363 and 66,930 in May last year.

Dr. Gustav Arnold Carstensen, former rector of Holy Rood Episcopal Church, and now acting minister at Trinity Church, 166th Street and Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, sat in the Alpha Delta Phi Club, 136 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday and told his reminiscences of the last seventeen Presidential elections.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 14 -- The list of 147 candidates who will receive degrees tomorrow at the commencement of Adelphia College here was made public today, together with the awards of scholarships, honors and prizes. It follows:

An exhibition of 100 photographs of interiors, by members of the American Institute of Interior Decorators, opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries and will continue until the end of the month. After the metropolitan showing, the exhibition will be circulated through the United States by The American Federation of Arts.

BERLIN, June 14 -- In view of impending political decisions at home and abroad, the Boerse was extremely quiet today. The public was reserved and speculators also were hesitant. The more nervous ones exchanged mining stocks and certain bonds for Farbenindustrie and Reichsbank shares, which accordingly advanced slightly.

BALTIMORE, June 14 -- Independence of action, independence of thought and the courage to say what he believes are qualities which should still mark the university man long after most of the facts he learned in the classroom have passed out of his mind, President Joseph S. Ames of Johns Hopkins University impressed upon the 429 recipients of degrees this afternoon at the fifty-sixth commencement.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics unlimbered their heaviest artillery and shelled the Tigers into a 10-to-5 rout today, the barrage including Jimmy Foxx's twenty-fourth and twenty-fifth home runs of the season in successive times at bat.

A benefit performance of "Il Trovatore" for the Order of the Rose will be given by the Community Grand Opera Company under the direction of Stephen Forester, at Chanin's Forty-sixth Street Theatre tomorrow night. The cast includes Gina Pinnera, Edward Ransome, Dreda Aves, Mario Valle, Sigurd Nilssen, Maude von Steuben and George Chau, Gabrielle Simeoni will conduct and Rosita Leveque will head the ballet.

Democratic State Chairman James A. Farley returned yesterday from a week-end visit to Chicago, still confident that Governor Roosevelt will be nominated for the Presidency on the first ballot at the Democratic National Convention.

For the first time this season in the metropolitan district six favorites swept the card at Aqueduct yesterday. The occurrence is particularly rare in this district and caused wide comment among horsemen, who expected the continued rain and sloppy going to take its toll of the public choices.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 14 -- A doubt of national security was listed as one of the causes of political uneasiness today by James G. McDonald, chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, as he spoke to the Special Libraries Conference on world changes here.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In an effort to safeguard life and health land at the same time to contribute to more effective law enforcement, the Treasury and Justice Departments today published new regulations pertaining to the distribution of industrial alcohol.

When the highly paid stars and executives of the motion picture industry hear that "attendance has fallen from 10,000,000 a day in 1928 to 6,000,000 a day for the first four months of 1932" they may be willing to listen to some of the genuine leaders of the movie business.
BOSTON, June 14 -- A Boston committee was formed today to aid the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Federal Reserve System in promoting wider use of credit.

Senator DICKINSON of Iowa was assigned a hard job as "keynoter" at the opening of the Republican convention yesterday, and it must be said that he took it hard. Dutifully he entered upon a long laudation of President HOOVER, with which we have no quarrel, but which was shot through with occasional gleams of unconscious humor like the following:

Retail failures increased sharply during the week ended June 9, totaling 393, against 343 in the previous period, with an attendant slight rise in liabilities involved, Bradstreet's reported yesterday. The manufacturing group also showed a decided increase in insolvencies, while the total in the commercial service division dropped.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14 -- Reorganisation of Yale's sports program was continued today with the appointment of Malcolm Farmer, Hartford manufacturer and former Eli football player, as director of all the university's athletic activities.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Mrs. Mabel Walker Willebrandt, former champion of the "dry" cause within the administration, accepts as "inevitable" that the Republican party will enter the next campaign with some sort of "wet" plank.

LONDON, June 14 -- The stock markets generally were cheerful today, although the volume of business was small. British Government funds reacted slightly on profit-taking, but German bonds rose sharply on Continental buying.

Mrs. George Rudnick of Tibbetts Brook and Mrs. E.L. Beard of the home club tied for low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Pomonok Country Club at Flushing, L.I., yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- Herman H. Griswold, president of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Elmira, N.Y., will be nominated tomorrow for the presidency of the New York State Bankers Association, according to opinion generally voiced by various groups of delegates at the convention here today.

The results of an elaborate task of research just completed by More Game Birds in America, Inc., should be of special interest to all those studying the waterfowl situation and the establishing of open seasons for shooting.

The last of the Bank of France's dollar balances, amounting to $55,000,000, was withdrawn from this market yesterday, a part being converted into earmarked gold and part being exported in the form of gold bullion.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Appearing tonight before the Resolutions Committee in behalf of a world peace program, Miss Jane Addams, co-winner of the 1931 Nobel Peace Prize, received a sterling tribute from members of the committee and a crowded gallery.

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- After being held up for twenty-four hours by bad weather, the Eastern intercollegiate championship tennis tournament, the curtain-raiser to the national intercollegiates starting next Monday at Haverford, Pa., got under way today on the courts of the Apawamis Club.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 14 (AP). -- Senator Black of Birmingham, who announced recently that he would vote for a referendum on prohibition, apparently had been renominated tonight over former Governor Thomas E. Kilby of Anniston, also a referendum advocate, on the basis of unofficial returns from today's Democratic run-off primary.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Paul Thompson, once a vice president of the United Gas Improvement Company and former president of the Philadelphia Gas Works, was elected today President of the Corn Exchange National Bank and Trust Company to succeed the late Charles C. Calwell.

The Eastern railroad presidents' conference took steps yesterday to reply to a proposal by Joseph B. Eastman and Frank McManamy of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the railroads make a working test of the six-hour day. Although the nature of the decision was not officially disclosed, it was understood that the officials demurred at paying eight hours' wages to men working on a six-hour day in furtherance of the proposed tests.

The Summer show at the G.R.D. Studio, recruited from the gallery's permanent collection, has been placed on view and will continue until September. Contrary to the custom of past years, when the gallery was open to the public one weekday afternoon only, through the Summer, it will be opened this year at any time during the week, by appointment.

Concurrently with an announcement of the omission of dividends on its first preferred and preference shares, the American Superpower Corporation made public yesterday for the first time the details of its principal holdings of public utility securities.

Mrs. Tillie Leblang, widow of Joseph Leblang, cut-rate theatre ticket broker, was married last Thursday in East Rutherford, N.J., to William Jasie, an attorney of 521 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Leblang.

The continuing fall in the foreign exchanges was the outstanding movement on yesterday's markets. It was led by the rate on Paris, which moved sharply down to the lowest since the end of March. The day's decline brought Dutch exchange to the lowest in ten weeks; Swiss exchange to the lowest since the beginning of May.

CLEVELAND, June 14 -- Bill Dickey's third home run in two days and a triple steal, with Big Ben Chapman sliding safely across home plate, featured the Yankee offensive which landed the team a 7-to-6 victory in its Cleveland finale today, making three out of four for the series, six out of eight for the road trip to date and fifteen victories in seventen games played with Western clubs so far this year.

The foreman and the assistant foreman of the grand jury which investigated the Bank of United States testified yesterday at the trial of Isidor J. Kresel for perjury that the disputed passage in the grand jury minutes, for repudiating which Mr. Kresel was indicted, substantially expressed] the sense of Mr. Kresel's testimony.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 14 (AP). -- A warrant charging John R. Boyle, 37 years old, a prominent Birmingham attorney, with murdering his 66-year-old mother yesterday on Shades Mountain was ordered today by County Investigator G.M. Evans. Boyle was placed under arrest in a hospital.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP). -- A thirty-two page report was submitted in the Federal court today by the receivers for the United Public Service Company, the United Public Utilities Company and the Southern United Gas Company, subsidiaries of the Middle West Utilities System.

The general betterment in sugar conditions during the last week, resulting in a complete turnabout from the trend which has carried prices downward almost since the first of the year, was reflected yesterday in several developments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During our Civil War Artemus Ward declared that he was determined to put down the rebellion even if he had to send all his wife's relations to the front. Now we farmers are prepared to make no less a sacrifice in helping to balance the budget and in keeping it balanced.
PRAGUE, June 14 -- A Czechoslovak hydroplane towing an air target for anti-aircraft guns to shoot at crashed today in the Gulf of Cattaro.

Peter De Vito, former strike-breaking contractor, of 87-31 168th Place, Jamaica, pleaded guilty yesterday in United States District Court. Brooklyn, to an indictment charging conspiracy to violate the internal revenue laws and national prohibition act.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., June 14 (Canadian Press) -- Frederick Charles Alderdice, who pledged himself to appoint a committee to inquire into the desirability of placing Newfoundland under a form of commission government for a term of years, was swept into power on the avalanche of votes that buried the Liberal government of Sir Richard Squires.

Copies of the charges and the evidence on which the removal of Mayor Walker has been requested were delivered yesterday to Martin Conboy of New York and former Justice John E. Mack of Poughkeepsle, the two attorneys named by Governor Roosevelt to help study the data submitted by Samuel Seabury.

BERLIN, June 14 -- Headed by Chancellor von Papen, the German delegation left for Lausanne tonight to wage Germany's fight for an end to reparations. Both in numbers and calibre it suggested a more impressive official body than usually faces cameramen when a German delegation entrains for a parley with the nation's war creditors, and it was also observed that a more confident mood pervaded its ranks.

HOLLYWOOD, June 14 (AP) -- Ina Claire, stage and screen actress, has quit taking motion pictures seriously, she said today in announcing she had severed by mutual consent her contract with Samuel Goldwyn, producer.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 15 -- The Diet concluded its special session this morning after having passed all government bills, the principal ones being measures for controlling exchange rates, increasing the issue of currency, raising tariffs and sanctioning bond issues to meet the expenses of the campaign in Manchuria.

A Deserved Recognition. In the list of academic degrees conferred these days we may be excused for singling out with special pleasure that of honorary Master of Arts awarded by Colby to Mr. FREDERICK C. MORTIMER.

SOME local citizens are for Ignoring the outrage and turning to other matters, such as the approaching battle between Herr Max Schmeling and Jack Sharkey or the wet plank adopted by the local ball clubs: "No game today. Doubleheader tomorrow." But it can't be passed over that lightly. Chicago has made New York look like a slow town. At least the Board of Aldermen should take up the challenge.

In a decision scoring the "disregard of natural justice" in the union's handling of the case, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo yesterday ordered the reinstatement of Joseph A.L. Blek as a member of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Officers and directors of the Bel Canto Club of Huntington, L.I., winners of the choral contest of the Long Island music festival held last week, and the Morning Choral of Brooklyn, second-prize winners, were guests at a tea and musicals of Long Island compositions, which was given yesterday by Mrs. Oliver Harriman at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 14 -- Paraphrasing the warnings seen on signs at railroad crossings, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of Yale Divinity School, urged members of the graduating class of Lehigh. University in a commencement address today to "Stop, look, listen and think until they know something j about the meaning of life."
NEW YORK. Miss Elsie Celeste Hutton will leave the Beverly today for Shamrock Cliff, her place in Newport.

The defense and prosecution summed up yesterday at the trial in General Sessions of Jack Zaroff, 28 years old, former taxicab driver, on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Patrolman Maurice O'Brien in West 113th Street on the night of Jan. 30, 1930.

BOSTON, June 14 -- Other cities maintain breadlines in these perilous times, but Boston, as one might expect, is the first to open a book line. For that is what the free openair library, established by Mayor Curley at the Parkman Bandstand, had developed into within a scant half hour after the librarian was installed with her reading matter today.
Varied aspects of the handling of the new manufacturers' excise levies which go into effect next Tuesday were discussed yesterday at a number of trade meetings here.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The cost of the city government of Orange, N.J., in the fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1931, was $1,628,109, or $45.61 per capita, as compared with $44.34 in 1930 and $14.98 in 1917.

The Atlas Utilities Corporation made an offer yesterday for stock of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, promising to give in exchange threetenths of a share of its own common stock for each share of Goldman Sachs. Atlas is by far the largest stockholder in the other corporation, having acquired many shares by a private deal at the end of last year, and this offer may give it majority control.

The Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the new $5 par value common and class B stocks. E.G. McKeever, president, said at a stock-holders' meeting preceding the directors' meeting that the company might buy gasoline and crude oil in the open market or it might produce it, as the directors might determine.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- As a technologist, replying to the current accusation that invention has rashly multiplied the productivity of man and upset the economic equilibrium, Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president of Carnegie Institute of Technology, declared in a commencement address here today that science made to mankind a gift of leisure but that men blindly kept on worshiping a tradition of work.

Hoffman Philip, United States Minister to Norway; Lady Lindsay, wife of the British Ambassador; Viscount de Lantsheere, First Secretary of the Belgian Embassy in Washington, and Sir Thomas Robinson, will sail this afternoon for France and England on the White Star liner Olympic.

Memphis Bill Terry, the man who picked up the managerial scepter of the Giants laid down by the venerable John McGraw, is rapidly becoming acquainted with the numerous trials and tribulations that used to beset his predecessor, not the least of these being what to do with a smooth-working pitching staff that suddenly finds itself out of work because of the weather.

ALBANY, June 14 -- Governor Roosevelt called upon civic and business leaders of the State today to cooperate in a drive to bring about reduction of government costs. The taxpayer, he avowed, could not stand the burden of current imposts.

As Secretary of Commerce in the Wilson Administration, the late WILLIAM C. REDFIELD was not able to cut an important figure in wartime regulation of industry. That task was committed to special commissions with, large emergency powers, such as the War Industries Board.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The appearance tonight of the administration's steam-roller, the very existence of which had been denied, put pace and color into the opening day of the Republican National Convention of 1932, which had opened dully in a great hall, one-third empty, in which the rank and file of the delegates sat listlessly while Senator L.J. Dickinson of Iowa, the temporary chairman, delivered the keynote speech.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- A plea in behalf of labor was made tonight before the resolutions committee of the Republican convention by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor. The leader of organized workers laid before the committeemen twenty-two recommendations, including a demand for 2.75 per cent beer for inclusion in the Republican platform.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Representative Rainey. majority leader of the House, dwelt forcefully on the "enormous economic failures of Mr. Hoover" in a statement constituting an analysis, from the Democratic viewpoint, of Senator Dickinson's keynote speech before the Republican National Convention.

The New York Stock Exchange Institute, which provides employes of the Stock Exchange and of brokerage firms with opportunities to continue their educational studies, held its eleventh annual commencement dinner last evening at the Stock Exchange Luncheon Club.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Three-score Senators stood in the writing room of the Senate this morning to hear the radio broadcast of Senator Dickinson's keynote speech at the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The Hoover Administration group won a sweeping victory tonight when the convention's Committee on Credentials by a vote of 34 to 15 reversed the Republican National Committee and, in making up the permanent roll of the convention, voted to throw out the group of delegates brought here from South Carolina by Joseph W. Tolbert, veteran Republican leader of that State.

Municipal operation of the city's independent subway system by the Board of Transportation was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole, with Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, the sole dissenter.

CHICAGO, June 14 - The fight against Mrs. Ruth B. Pratt for reelection on the Republican National Committee from New York remained in abeyance today. The supporters of the State organization on the delegation are in the majority, and W. Kingsland Macy, the State chairman, was assured that he would have to vote to defeat Mrs. Pratt if a decision was reached to carry the fight against her to a conclusion.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, former world's wrestling champion, employed his famous headlock to pin Sam Stein in 47:05 in the feature finish wrestling exhibition at the New York Coliseum last nigrht. It was announced the attendance was 7,960.

Mrs. Gertrude Baker McEvoy defeated Mrs. Irene Hummel, 50 to 44, in the final block of the challenge match for the women's national pocket billiard title at Doyle's Academy last night to retain her crown. Inasmuch, as Mrs. McEvoy had captured the opening block, 50 to 41, the totals were 100 for the champion, to 85 for her opponent.

A 5 per cent cut in wages and salaries exceeding $300 monthly and reorganization of the traffic departments are to be included soon in a program of economy that already has resulted in greatly reduced clerical forces on the New York Central Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday.

Steamship agents said yesterday that the new cabin ships, Champlain, Georgic, Manhattan and Washington, have been built like their predecessors, the Lafayette and the Britannic because it had been recognized for a long time that the term "second class" is unpopular with Americans.

Yesterday was memorable in the history of rapid transit in New York. The vote in committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate in favor of direct municipal operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway came as the climax to a long series of developments which really began with the promulgation of the McAneny commission's "Plan of Readjustment for the New York City Street "Railroads" in the Fall of 1921.

ALBANY, June 14 -- Governor Roosevelt commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence imposed on John Resko, Bronx slayer and issued reprieves to Frank Giordano and Dominick Odierno, henchmen of the late Vincent Coll, who were to have been put to death in Sing Sing Thursday night for another Bronx murder.

Hard times, contrary to general belief, fail to help the pawnshop business, according to statements yesterday of several of the city's better-known pawnbrokers. The pawnshops are not doing well nowadays, it was said, because of the business depression.

The daily average gross crude oil production for the week ended on test Saturday was 2,183,450 barrels compared with 2,181,250 barrels for the preceding week, a gain of 2.200 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. For the four weeks ended with Saturday, production averaged 2,189,850 barrels daily.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- President Hoover was represented late today as standing firmly by his determination that no recommendation for repeal should appear in the plank on prohibition to be inserted in the Republican platform at the national convention.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The eight-day-old tax law was amended today in an effort to keep big users of goods subject to excise taxes from escaping levies totaling $40,000,000 to $50,000.000.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- In the theatrical business when a thing don't go, or it is a flop, we say that "it laid an egg." Well, the Republican convention "laid an egg" here today. The house wasn't near sold out. The loud-speaking system didn't work and half of 'em couldn't hear the "keynote" speech.

George J. Sklar, a 25-year-old art student, was announced yesterday by the Beaux-Art Institute of Design, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, as the winner of a prize of $1,200 for a year's study in Paris, for his composition, "Sculpture." Mr. Sklar has been a student in sculpture at the Beaux-Arts Institute for three years.
ALFRED, N.Y., June 14 -- Alfred University will award 100 degrees at its commencement exercises tomorrow. The class is the largest in the history of the school.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation's offer to the various committees representing bondholders and creditors of the Richfield Oil Company of California provides for the payment of $18,000,000 in the form of 6 per cent non-voting $100 par value preferred stock of the corporation, according to reports from Los Angeles.

ASCOT, England, June 14 -- A thrilling dead heat, the first in nearly a century of renewals of the famous Ascot Stakes, today accompanied the pageantry that annually marks the opening of Royal Ascot, most aristocratic of Britain's race courses.
Salvation Array officials reported yesterday a large increase in the number of women seeking shelter in emergency lodging houses.

Edward Henry Gerald Shepherd, acting consul general in New York for Great Britain, was instructed yesterday by the Foreign Office in London to submit a report on the death of Miss Violet Sharpe, maid, who committed suicide last Friday in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow in Englewood, N.J.

Continued rains in southeastern sections of the cotton belt caused a further advance yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange. Early trading was unsettled, due to a decline in the wheat market, but prices steadied when weather details showed heavy rainfall where showers had been persistent in the last fortnight.

An action for appointment of a receiver brought by Samuel Brooks and Richard A. Schoeler against the Majestic Hotel Corporation, owner of the Majestic Apartments at Central Park West, Seventy-first to Seventy-second Streets, was denied in Supreme Court yesterday by Justice John L. Walsh.

PARIS, June 14 -- The Bourse was steady today and this fact, together with a sharp recovery in Young Plan bonds, was interpreted by French writers as indicating greater confidence in definite accomplishments at Lausanne. The dollar continued to strengthen, closing at 25.41 1/2.

Lee, Higginson Co., for many years bankers for corporations in many parts of the world, and who have distributed upward of a billion dollars' worth of securities, and more recently in the public eye as bankers for the late Ivar Kreuger, announced yesterday that they plan soon to discontinue the issuance and distribution of securities.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Staffs trained in expert knowledge of style, types and quality today are being placed behind the retail counters as stores endeavor to provide greater service to their customers, it was pointed out today at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the William Penn Hotel here.

John J. Stiglin, 32 years old, formerly a plain-clothes patrolman in the vice squad, who was convicted May 23 of perjury for his testimony against two women following a raid in their East Seventy-fourth Street apartment in 1929, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions to a term of from two and one-half to five years in prison.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The intensive selling campaign in Anaconda Copper stock carried on by the National City Bank in 1929 was denounced by Senator Walcott today as Professor William Z. Ripley of Harvard appeared in the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's stock market investigation to demand searching publicity on the financial affairs of corporations with business of an interstate nature.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The administration board of strategy was in continuous contact with the White House today and tonight the position of the President on every issue in controversy is known to the convention leaders.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 14 -- Miss Electra Webb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Watson Webb of 740 Park Avenue, New York, and Shelburne, Vt., was honored by the sixty-five employes of Shelburne Farms, South Acres Farm and Shelburne House yesterday in recognition of her approaching marriage to Dunbar Bostwick on June 28 at the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of Incarnation, Garden City. L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- The Phillies scored three runs in the ninth inning to win the first game of today's double-header from the Cincinnati Heds, 6 to 5, but they couldn't beat Jack Ogden's seven-hit pitching and Jim Elliott's bad first inning in the second contest, and Cincinnati came through with a 5-to-2 triumph.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14 -- A decision was given at a meeting tonight at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club in regard to the Interclub race on June 4 when the skippers of competing boats refused to sail the prescribed course and raced instead on a course of their own choosing.

The current practice in the Federal court of making the Irving Trust Company the receiver in all equity and bankruptcy cases was attacked last night by Charles H. Hyde, former City Chamberlain, speaking at the organization dinner of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- The order of the Crown of Belgium has been presented to Dr. Alexander Russell, director of music and holder of the Frick Chair of Music at Princeton University, according to an announcement received here today by Dr. John Grier Hibben, president of the university.

Not a Bond or a mortgage in the State Fund's $17,000,000 investment list is in default either as to interest or principal, according to Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner, who made public yesterday a brief review of the condition of the State Insurance Fund.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- That women politicians can whoop it up for party and candidates was demonstrated at the opening session of the Republican National Convention.
MOSCOW, June 14 (AP). -- The Communist party organ Pravda today announced that production in all industries for the first four months of 1932 had increased by 20.3 per cent over the period of 1931.

Possibility of an imminent settlement of the building trades wage dispute, which, has hampered the industry since May 2 and has cost upward of $10,000,000, was indicated last night when Frank Feeney, president of the International Union of Elevator Constructors, announced that an agreement had been signed covering the members of Local No. 1 employed in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The so-called new American plan for limiting army effectives, which has been submitted informally to various delegations at the Geneva Disarmament Conference, was said today to have originated with President Hoover before the United States delegates left for Geneva last January.

On the eve of his appearance In court for pleading to indictments for the $300,000 jewelry hold-up in the home of Harry C. Glemby, manufacturer, at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, Sam Ippollto, 22 years old, was found fatally wounded last night under circumstances that pointed to suicide in the apartment of Miss Helen Smith, another suspect, at 161 West Fifty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Objection to the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is generally based on the fear of the return of the saloon. When the prohibitionist can think of no other argument he is bound to resort to the use of this bugaboo.

SEATTLE, June 14 -- A call for women to seek to progress was made today by Mrs. John F. Sippel, retiring president of the Federation of Women's Clubs, in a speech at the convention reviewing the federation's achievements for the last two years.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and William Allen White discussed the prohibition problem over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company tonight while the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention was wrestling with that troublesome problem.

In the multitude of prohibition planks submitted to the Republican convention, one point recurs frequently. It is the question whether added "protection" is to be promised the Dry States in case the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed, and, if so, in what form.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Blank forms for making returns of two forms of taxation provided in the 1932 revenue act were sent to collectors by the Internal Revenue Bureau today. They were for the tax on admissions and dues and for the tax on lubricating oils, brewers' wort, malt and grape products, matches and gasoline.

Weetamoe and Vanitie, the two America's Cup yachts in commission, will race on Long Island Sound today for the first time this season. They will take part in a special contest arranged for them by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay.

Babe Herman, Ernie Lombardi and Wally Gilbert, three of last year's Robins, came back to Ebbets Field yesterday in alien uniforms and just about ruined the day for Manager Max Carey, his team and 12,000 fans, forming one of the largest week-day crowds of the season.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Defeat caught up with Herb Pennock today for the first time this year and, sardonically enough, it made his best pitched game of the season the first entry on the losing side of his record. He allowed six hits, walked none, and saw the winning run score on an error behind him.

PITTSBURGH, June 15. -- Millions of drys will vote Democratic and millions of others will stay away from the polls in protest if President Hoover "goes back on prohibition," in the opinion of Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

OTTAWA, Ill., June 15. -- Five armed gangsters swooped down on the La Salle County jail here this afternoon and liberated three Chicago bank robbers being held for trial for the $52,000 robbery of the Union National Bank of Streator, Ill., on May 16.

Two members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, who were charged with assault by Michael C. Clohessy of 2,500 Hubbard Street, Brooklyn, were acquitted by a jury yesterday before County Judge Algerson I Nova In Brooklyn.
The Brooklyn Dodgers defeated the Boston Shamrocks, 7 to 3, last night at Ebbets Field in a box lacrosse game. Beckman, with three goals, and Aronowsky, with two, led the attack for the home sextet.

World-wide return to the gold standard as the best means of reducing uncertainty as to the value of currencies, restoring the basis for foreign loans and paying the road to world economic revival, was urged by Dr. Lewis Haney, director of the bureau of business research at New York University, in an address last night at a dinner meeting of the World Trade League of the United States in the Hotel Astor.

Details or recent transactions involving several scattered holdings in Manhattan were shown in papers recorded at the Register's Office yesterday. These constituted the bulk of the day's activity, which included a few sales of housing properties announced by brokers.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 15. -- The fifty-fourth commencement exercises of Smith College will begin tomorrow. Ralph Barton Ferry, Professor of Philosophy at Harvard, and formerly of the Smith faculty, will deliver the commencement address Monday, when about 350 students will receive diplomas from President Neilson.

Max D. Steuer, who investigated the failure of the Bank of United States and prosecuted cases arising out of it, appeared yesterday at the perjury trial of Isidor J. Kresel, director of and counsel to the bank, in a new role, that of prosecution witness.

Formation of Latin-American Associates, Inc., for the purpose of "supervising investment holdings of bonds representing approximately 144 different loans of fifteen nations, nine States, six provinces, six departments and fifteen cities in Latin America, on which, defaults amounting to 45 per cent have already occurred," was announced yesterday.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was so accelerated yesterday that the volume of the previous day was just about doubled. This, it appeared, rather accurately measured the increase in market interest. Stocks opened fractionally higher and continued to advance throughout the morning, showing at midday net gains of 1 to 2% points in many of the active issues.

A letter has been addressed to holders of stock and of voting-trust certificates for Class B stock of the American Utilities and General Corporation advising that 300,000 shares of the new American and Dominion Corporation, which has acquired the assets and assumed the liabilities of the former corporation, have been set aside for subscription before July 15 at $2.50 a share.

LONDON, June 8. -- The Lausanne conference cannot produce a final solution for the problem, of German reparations. If it succeeds at all, it can discover only a face-saving formula to put off the decision until the present economic depression has lifted from the world.

IT was just before noon yesterday and the Chicago Cubs were scattered about the lobby of the Commodore. A salesman of some sort had Manager Rogers Hornsby backed into a corner and was tapping him on the top vest-button. Manager Hornsby was showing great sales resistance. Charley Grimm was lounging in a big chair. Gabby Hartnett was chatting with an admiring fan. Kiki Cuyler came strolling along wearing a pinkish-orange tie.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The backbone of the anti-Curtis movement, which had assumed such menacing proportions that the renomination of the Vice President was seriously in doubt, appears to have been broken as a result of Charles G. Dawes's definite refusal to make the race.

Bond prices showed advancing tendencies in moderately active trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. under, the leadership of United States Government bonds, which advanced 1-32 point to 116-32 points. The movement in government securities was the most vigorous in several days.

The experience of the last three years has shown that large expenditures by the government have had little effect in minimizing the depression, hut have greatly increased taxation, it was said last night by Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago and North Western Railway, in a radio address.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -- The Harvard four met and conquered a powerful challenge in the intercollegiate polo championship tournament today at the Rye Turf and Polo Club when it defeated Army, 7 -- 6.

BERLIN, June 15 (AP). -- The Prussian Diet passed a Communist bill today demanding withdrawal of the Reich from the League of Nations, and rejected another that would have suspended further payments to the Hohenzollerns.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Gaston B. Means, former Department of Justice agent, stood again today in the shadow of prison walls.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Organization dry leaders were aroused in protest tonight as a result of the resubmission plank drawn up by the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention. Their future political course, it was stated, awaited both the action the Democrats would take on the question in their convention here this month and the annual meeting in August of the National Women's Christian Temperance Union.

LONDON, June 15 (Canadian Press). -- Nine centuries were recorded in the first day's play of cricket fixtures today, with Ernest Tyldesley scoring 225 not out for Lancashire against Worcester. John Iddon rolled an even 100 for the same county, helping the Red Rose to 482 for the lots of two wickets.

LONDON, June 15 (Canadian Press). -- The Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa should revolutionize the location of many industries and lead to a migration of industries among the United States, Canada and Great Britain, William Watson, assistant to the Minister of Labor and expert on industrial questions, declared today in an address at a luncheon of the Scottish National Development Board.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Republican women leaders held a large share of the limelight this morning in the tumultuous doings of the second session of the Republican National Convention in the Chicago Stadium.

ST. LOUTS, June 15 (AP). -- Three men were on, two were out and the score was tied In the last of the ninth today when Pitcher Leroy Mahaffey hit Jim Levey and forced in Rick Ferrell with the winning run in the St. Louis Browns' 9-to-8 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 15. -- A request that the United States cancel all war debts was being discussed tonight as the 600 delegates of thirteen nations assembled here for tomorrow's opening session of the conference on debts and reparations at which a way to world economic recovery will be sought.

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Consolidated Gas Company of New York to issue $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year 5 per cent gold debenture bonds, to be sold within sixty days at not less than 94 per cent of par and accrued interest. The proceeds of not less than $28,200,000 are to be applied to the discharge of the company's obligations.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 15. -- Mrs. John E. Craig won the Sweepstake's award this afternoon and the tri-color ribbon for the outstanding exhibit at the annual flower show of the garden committee of the Great Neck Woman's Club which closed tonight in the community house.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 15. -- The benefits of government publications for libraries were discussed at the Special Libraries Association conference here today by Ernest A. Tupper of the economic research division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
The complete text of Dr. Butler's speech at the Republican convention at Chicago, as heard over the radio here last night, was as follows:

David Dubinsky, general secretary treasurer of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, was unanimously elected president by the general executive board yesterday to succeed the late Benjamin Schlesinger, veteran leader who died last week.

The National City Bank of Hew York will celebrate today its one hundred and twentieth anniversary. On June 16, 1812, the New York State Legislature granted a charter to the City Bank of New York, authorizing a capital of $800,000. Today this bank stands as the second largest in the world, with capital of $124,000,000 and total resources of more than $1,671,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The two editorials on the prohibition problem that appeared in THE TIMES Tuesday and yesterday were excellent and in my judgment evidenced a statesmanlike comprehension of this constitutional problem.

RYE, N.Y., June 15. -- Harvard neld a seven-point lead over Princeton at the end of the first day's racing in the fifth annual Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, held on Long Island Sound by the American Yacht Club today.

BERLIN, June 15. -- Although the emergency decree concerning the liberty of the press and the lifting of the ban on Adolf Hitler's storm troops will be published tomorrow, it is believed that Bavaria, Baden and Wuerttemberg will resist the restoration of the storm detachments within their borders.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Under administration control, with Secretary Mills dominating the situation, the resolutions committee after long hours of argument agreed today on the prohibition plank and the party's declaration on other matters of vital interest for the twentieth Republican National Convention.

Funeral services were held yesterday for Violet Sharpe. the waitress in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow who committed suicide by taking poison last Friday rather than face for the fifth time police inquisitors working on the Lindbergh kidnapping.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 15 (AP). -- If Eddie Cantor, stage comedian, and Benjamin F. Holzman, New York, want to keep impounded upward of a million dollars in stock owned by defendants in Cantor's accounting suit against the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation they must file an indemnifying bond of half a million dollars or more.

The development of a social system based on scientific control of national resources and man-power, to replace the competitive phases of the existing price system in industry, was predicted yesterday by Howard Scott, consulting technologist, at meeting of the uptown branch of the American Statistical Association at the Fraternity Clubs Building, to East Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Allocations for the offering of government securities going on the market today amounted to $790,459,300, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Arthur A. Ballantine announced. The offering was for $750,000,000 and total subscriptions amounted to $2,797,377,400.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 16. -- Throughout the night battle over the prohibition plank a crowd of 15,000 men and women packing the galleries, jeered and booed the party leaders advocating adoption of the administration's proposal and wildly cheered the repealists pleading for the minority plank.

J.F. Schoellkopf has been elected chairman of Insuranshares Certificates, Inc., to succeed Edward B. Twombly. He is president of the Niagara Share Corporation, which has long had a substantial, though not controlling, stock interest in the investment trust.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15 (AP). -- The Greek freighter Artemis foundered off the Brazilian Coast opposite Southern Bahia today and her twenty-five men were picked up by the British motorship Eastern Prince, which responded to S O S calls.

Bidding at liquidation sales in the Vesey Street Exchange yesterday, plaintiffs in forced actions protected their liens on several large properties. Included in the offerings struck down by auctioneers were the Hotel Montclair, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street; the Nevada Apartments on upper Broadway and the fifteen-story apartment house at 10-12 West Eighty-sixth Street.

The Hebrew Association of the Deaf will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary next Saturday with a dinner at Temple Emanu-El. The association, organized in 1907 under the leadership of Marcus Kenner, was originally known as the Hebrew Congregation of the Deaf and was without a meeting place of its own, but through the aid of the Rev. Dr. H. Periera-Mendes, rabbi of the Portuguese-Jewish Congregation, permission was obtained to meet at the Y.M.H.A. Building.

RYE, N.Y., June 15. -- An appeal was made today at the closing session of the three-day convention of the New York State Bankers Association at the Westchester Country Club here for a cessation of the exchange of recriminations between the nation's political and financial leaders and for their adoption of a policy of mutual support in leading the nation to economic recovery.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The musical prelude to the Republican convention's tussle tonight over its stand on prohibition was convivial and such old totems as the mug of foaming ale, the shiny tin growler and the old charred cask were brought forth.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The babies born alive in 1930 in the birth registration area of the United States numbered 2,203,958, an increase over 1929 of 34,038, out of a total estimated population on July 1, 1930, of 116,644,000, or 94.7 per cent of the estimated population of the nation, according to statistics made public today by the Census Bureau.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Catholic University of America conferred 453 degrees in course and three honorary degrees at its forty-third annual convocation today under the chairmanship of the Most Rev. Pietro Fumasoni-Biondi, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 15. In his graduation address at Adelphi College today, Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, Professor of Homiletlcs at Drew University, urged the young women graduates to develop their individualism. Approximately 500 persons attended the commencement exercises, which were held in the gymnasium of the college.

A man and two young women, who on July 30 last tortured with matches and cigarettes George Van Vleck Brothers, 25 years old, son of George N. Brothers, retired Assistant District Attorney, until he wrote $850 in checks in a midtown apartment, three of which they cashed, were found guilty of extortion last evening by a jury in Judge Donnellan's part of General Sessions.

WARWICK, R.I., June 15. -- The two Peconic Bay fleet entries in the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship and Eastern Olympic elimination series, Harkness Kdwards's Winsome and Edmund Poor's Black and White, finished first and third in the opening race today.

Preservation of one American Indian dialect, the southern Caddoan, depends entirely upon the life of one old woman, the only living person who still speaks it, according to the annual report of the Committee on Research in Native American Languages of the American Council of Learned Societies, made public yesterday.

Politics in Newfoundland, where the Government of Sir RICHARD A. SQUIRES was overwhelmingly beaten in the election on Monday, has for twelve years been a history of the ups and downs of Sir RICHARD himself. He has always been in the thick of the fighting.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- Charley Whiteside, Harvard head coach, put his varsity crew through another hard workout today, especially this evening, when ten miles of paddling were recorded before the shell was stowed away.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The House today passed the Patman bill for the issuance of $2,400,000,000 additional currency to pay off the remaining half of the soldiers' bonus certificates, and sent the measure immediately to the Senate. The vote was 209 to 176.

Leading railroads in the East appeared yesterday to be virtually unanimous in holding the view that the Railway Express Agency should provide door-to-door freight service for the carriers, for Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, issued a statement approving the practice.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15. -- An ordinance reducing salaries of all city employes from 1 to 15 per cent, effective July 1, was adopted on first reading by the City Commission here today. A public hearing on the measure will be held June 29, when final passage of the ordinance la expected.

ASCOT, England, June 15. -- The American-owned silks of Victor Emanuel were flaunted to the breeze today when Totaig, quoted at 33 to 1, came romping home in front of a field of England's finest handicap horses to win the eighty-sixth running of the Royal Hunt Cup, feature event of the second day of racing at fashionable Royal Ascot.

Isadore Gastanaga, Spanish heavyweight, made a distinct success of his American ring debut last night at the Queensboro Stadium in Long Island City. Before a crowd of about 3,000 he hammered out a victory in ten rounds over Hans Birkie, Oakland, Cal., heavyweight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Mr. Coolidge on the Debts" interested me very much, and I entirely agree that it is an inauspicious moment for Mr. Coolidge to reiterate his opinions on this question, which are already well known to the world.

Each of 1,644 New York blocks has contributed $100 or more to the block-aid campaign for the unemployed, it was announced last night by Barklie McKee Henry, vice chairman of the Block Community Organization. Stamps sold to the residents of these blocks have a value of $806,436.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Leaders of the movement for an out-and-out wet plank, represented on the Allied Repeal Council, declared irrevocable opposition to the administration's Srohibition plank immediately after was made public today.

SCHENECTADY, June 15. -- A new application, of the cathode ray tube in X-ray spectroscopy and quantitative analysis, which not only detects the presence of very small quantities of an element but also "weighs" a particle as small as one three-millionth of anounce, was described here today by Dr. Forton R. Fonda of the General Electric Company before the twenty-fourth semi-annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
Having completed the conversion of their dollar balances into gold, Continental European central banks yesterday

LONDON, June 15. -- A prediction was made today by James M. Beck, former Solicitor General of the United States, that a lengthening of the present depression might subject the American Constitution to its severest strain. He was delivering the first of six lectures on "The United States Constitution as an Experiment in Democracy" at the University of London under the auspices of the Watson Chair Foundation.

Misunderstanding about the figures recently made public concerning city and private hospitals should be cleared up. It was semi-officially stated that the city hospitals are not overcrowded. A first glance at figures showing them operating at about 80 per cent capacity may seem encouraging, but the margin may be accounted for in ways which reveal the seriousness of the underlying facts.

Former State Senator Nathaniel A. Elsberg, who died of pneumonia at his home, 112 Central Park South, on June 4, left the residue of his estate to his brothers, Herman A. and Charles A. Elsberg, it was revealed yesterday when his win was offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court.

SEATTLE, WASH., June 15. -- The navy was host today to hundreds of delegates attending the biennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs. As part of a tour of Puget Sound, the visitors disembarked from the steamer Indianapolis and were shown through the Navy Yard.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP). -- Western leaders of the silver money movement today hailed as a partial victory a reported recognition by the Republican Platform Committee of the necessity for an international conference.

What is described in England as the story of "America in Defeat" will be published there shortly under the title "Stars and Stripes." It is the work of Shaw Desmond, who, it is said, spent thirteen years in this country. According to John O'London's Weekly, it tells "of lost money, gangsters, graft, the color question, dope, prohibition and 'crime and the churches'."
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A proposal to levy taxes of 33 1-3 per cent on the "surplus incomes" of corporations was made in a bill introduced today by Representative O'Connor of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad obtained today an additional three months in which to comply with conditions imposed by the Interstate Commerce Commission in authorizing it to acquire control through stock purchase of the Denver Salt Lake line.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 16. -- Under the pressure of the administration, a reluctant Republican National Convention shortly before 1:30 o'clock this morning voted down the minority's effort to have flat repeal of prohibition submitted to the American people.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 15. -- The charges made against the Very Rev. G.P.T. Sargent, dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City, L.I., by Mrs. Robert A. Gardiner, following the marriage of her daughter, Alexandria, to James R. Creel, are "absolutely without foundation," Jackson A. Dykman, counsel for the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, declared today.

Oak Park, Ill., a community of some 65,000 people, eight miles from Chicago, is an attractive, well-kept, residential suburb, "the largest village in the world," with a fine municipal building, an excellent public library and the usual governmental services.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CHICAGO, June 15. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the visiting Democratic observer, was encountered by a reporter wandering aimlessly around the Congress Hotel lobby.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The Republican National Convention marked time today while the committee on resolutions completed the platform draft on which it will pass tonight, but its second session this forenoon was enlivened by a spontaneous demonstration for President Hoover which lasted for twelve minutes before it subsided, after having been kept alive by band music for some five minutes more.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15. -- George J. Bassett, State Bank Commissioner, announced today that application will be made to the Superior Court before the end of the week for the appointment of a temporary receiver to take charge of the affairs of the Mechanics Bank, which a week ago closed its doors after a run.

PARIS, June 15. -- American and French financial circles greeted the news of the earmarking for the Bank of France of $50,000,000 in gold in New York with deep satisfaction. The dollar rose from 25.41 1/2 francs to 25.43 1/2, the feeling on all sides being that European withdrawals have virtually reached an end, with the Federal Reserve Bank still retaining a generous margin of free gold.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 15. -- Mrs. Herbert Lee Pratt won first honors this afternoon at the annual exhibit of the North Country Garden Club in the Oval on the Pratt estate. Showing outdoor blooms grown at the Braes, Mrs. Pratt won four blue ribbons and one red, her most notable entry being a collection of sweet peas of twenty-six varieties.
