POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15. -- The first really hot day that the crews, here for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on Monday, have encountered since training started, slowed work a bit today and held nearly all the eights off the water in the afternoon, until the sun had begun to drop behind the high-lands on the west bank.
GLASGOW, June 15. -- Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American educator, received today the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Glasgow University.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A class of fifty-one army officers will be graduated on Friday from the tank school at Fort George G. Meade, Md., the War Department announced today. The graduation address will be delivered by Major Gen. Paul B. Malone, commander of the Third Corps Area.

The operations of in-and-out short traders decreased sharply last month, according to the monthly bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange, issued yesterday. The ratio of in-and-out short sales, or transactions in which short commitments were made and covered on the same day, was 5.50 per cent last month, against 6.60 per cent in April.
COMMERCIAL TAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

LONDON, June 15. -- The cheerful tendency on the stock markets was maintained today following firmness in Wall Street and the more optimistic views regarding forthcoming conferences. British Government funds advanced.
CHICAGO, June 15 (NANA). -- Dr. Hubert Work held an impromptu reception today, leaning against the wall of a hallway in the Congress Hotel.

The sale of theatre tickets at cutrates will not exempt them in any way from the new 10 per cent admission tax, which will be figured according to the stamped, box-office value on tickets and collected in full from the theatre at which the performances are given, according to a statement made at the office of William Duggan, Collector of Internal Revenue of the Second District.

An additional contingent of eighty-three war veterans left this city yesterday to join the bonus force in Washington. The men assembled in Madison Square in the morning, under command of Clarence E. Norman of 359 West Forty-third Street, who served as Second Lieutenant in France.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The earnest hope expressed in your editorial "The Upset in Chile," that the new government's projects "will not prove to be so confiscatory and leveling as they sound," is doubtless characteristic of the speculation stimulated here by the recent coup.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- By a vote of 76 to 21, the New York delegation to the Republican convention, at a caucus this evening just before the night session of the convention, rejected the majority prohibition plank reported by the committee on resolutions and pledged the delegates to "adhere to the principles reflected" in a repeal resolution adopted by the delegation at its earlier caucus on Sunday night.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15. -- John Cunniff, public links golfer from the Branch Brook Club in Belleville, won the New Jersey State amateur championship qualifying medal for the second successive year today when he led a field of 162 players over the south and west courses of the Upper Montclair Country Club.

The First National Bank of New York headed syndicates that obtained yesterday the awards of the two principal State and municipal bond issues which were offered and which, totaled $6,000,000. The first issue was $4,000,000 city of Buffalo (N.Y.) relief and tax sale bonds, dated July 1, 1932, and due on July 1, 1937.

LONDON, June 15. -- Winston Churchill and Sir Robert Horne, both former Chancellors of the Exchequer, addressing the Royal Empire Society on the money problem today, said that increasing the world's commodity prices was the first essential.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15. -- The belief that President Hoover or some other President "could put our house in order to overcome difficulties of the economic depression if we could safely delegate the needed power" to the Chief Executive, was expressed here today by Dr. J.G. Lipman, dean and director of the New Jersey College of Agriculture and experiment station in addressing 2,500 persons at the annual field day of the institutions.

Dissension between members and executives of the Teachers' Union was revealed last night at the Muhlenberg Library with the circulation of petitions denouncing as "autocratic" the action of Mrs. Joanna Lindloff, a vice president of the union, in adjourning a scheduled meeting shortly after its opening because of lack of a constitutional quorum.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Shipping Board approved today an agreement between the New York Puerto Rico and the Panama Mail Steamship Companies covering through shipments of canned goods, canned salmon, dried fruit, beans and rice from Pacific Coast ports to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, with transshipment at New York.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The last of the major legislation program recommended by President Hoover, the Federal home loan bank bill, was passed by a viva, voce vote in the House late today without objection. It will be sent to the Senate tomorrow with the assurance of leaders that it will be speedily enacted into law.
NEW YORK. Colonel Henry May, now at the Plaza, will be joined today by his daughter, Mrs. William vom Rath.

Nearly all of the 1,500 men required for municipal operation of the Eighth Avenue subway have been chosen by the Board of Transportation, it was disclosed yesterday. Not only that, but for the past two weeks motormen, switchmen, signal men and other classes of specialized employes have been under training in the 207th Street yards and on the twelve-mile stretch of new subway.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The wheat market developed a much stronger undertone today, and while opinion on the Board of Trade here was divided as to whether the aggressive buying was for professional or Eastern account, the active deliveries advanced 2 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel after a small dip at the opening, and the close was 1 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents higher on the day.

A wage cut of approximately 15 per cent for journeymen and 17 per cent for helpers was agreed to yesterday on behalf of 130,000 building trades workers at a conference held at the headquarters of the Building Trades Employers' Association, and the 25,000 men who have been on strike or locked out since May 2 are at liberty to return to work this morning.

BUENOS AIRES, June 15. -- In the presence of overcrowded galleries the Minister of the Interior told Congress today, in answer to an interpellation, that recent rumors of unrest in Argentina had been circulated by trouble-makers and that the present government, elected by 70 per cent of the citizens, was fully able to prevent any attempt at disturbance.

In connection with the issuance of its monthly statement of earnings, which showed for May a net income of $1,346,851 available for common stock and reserves, against $1,504,275 a year before, the Cities Service Company announced yesterday a reduction in salaries ranging from 10 to 20 per cent, effective immediately.

The Brooklyn Museum will open today four exhibitions, all of which will remain through the Summer, closing Oct. 3. A group of one-man shows, constituting the museum's Summer exhibition proper, presents work by Alexander Altenburg, Mark Baum, Joseph Biel, James Chapin, Leon Croizat, Louis G. Ferstadt, Mordi Gassner, Oscar Grosch, Lena Gurr, Helen West Heller, Carl de Muralt, Clara Fairfield Perry, Georges Schreiber, David Silvette, Abram Tromka, Hans Weingaertner and James Lesesne Wells.

Expenditures totaling $6,700,837 to build a new municipal building for the Departments of Health, Hospitals and Sanitation and construct three new incinerators were approved by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 15. -- The text of the address of Representative Snell of New York as permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention was as follows:

Permanent Chairman SNELL at Chicago went back to the ancient custom of full-bodied political boasting and denunciation. The speech which, he delivered yesterday would have delighted Senator BENTON of Missouri who, a hundred years ago, took such pleasure in "going the whole hog."

A better tone in stocks and grain and persistent rains in sections where dry weather has been reported urgently needed advanced prices again yesterday on the Cotton Ex-change. Although pre-notice day liquidation of July contracts continued, that month touched 5 1/4 cents, the week's highest, and the list closed at the top, 12 to 14 points higher than on Tuesday.

SYRACUSE, June 15. -- Raising the price of milk to a point where the farmer will get a fair return on his investment and for his labor was urged this afternoon by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health for New York City, at the annual meeting of the home-making department of the Dairymen's League.

Catharine E. Smith of Montclair acquired the five-story Seville apartment house on a plot 50 by 144 feet at 131-33 Glenwood Avenue, Jersey City, from the Sevilla Holding Company. It is valued for taxation purposes at $110,000, the land value being $11,600 and that of the building $98,400.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 15. -- Notified today that President Hoover had signed the Kean-Wolverton resolution giving Federal sanction to the creation of the Delaware River Joint Commission toy the Pennsylvania and New Jersey Legislatures, the commission's finance committee decided to meet Friday afternoon to take up the matter of a proposed $42,000,000 bond issue.

Joseph B. Terbell Jr. of 145 East Fifty-fourth Street paid a customs fine of $15 at the Custom House yesterday and apologized publicly to a guard who accused Mr. Terbell of kicking him when the guard stopped him as he attempted to leave the pier of the North German Lloyd Line in Brooklyn the night before.

The Ruppert Realty Corporation, of which Colonel Jacob Ruppert is president, asked the Supreme Court yesterday for a review of the assessments on nine parcels of real estate and a total reduction in assessments of $1,344,000. The nine parcels included the Ruppert Building at 531 Fifth Avenue, formerly the Bank of United States Building.

The gold movement was watched with interest yesterday, after the virtually official announcement that credits of foreign central banks in cur market had been in substance extinguished, either through gold exports or "earmarkings." The day's gold engagements were $22,500,000 -- practically all released from previous earmarkings, which were reduced nearly $22,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 (AP). -- The Newark Bears defeated the Toronto Leafs in both games of a double-header today before 5,000 to make a clean sweep of the series. The Bears came from behind twice in the first game to win by 6-5.

DETROIT, June 15. -- Radically different from her famous predecessors, the hull of Miss America X, newest of Gar Wood's creations for the defense of the Harmsworth Trophy, today was a finished product.

Every fisherman remembers about "the big one that got away" sometime or other. Either he had a strike that stirred him to his boots (if he were trout fishing) or else he almost landed his catch, only to have the fish break away. For some reason or other the big fellows are always the ones that are lost, that disappear from view into the waters or the streams, tempting you to try again.

SEATTLE, WASH., June 15 -- With Dr. Robert A. Millikan, noted scientist and Nobel Prize winner as principal speaker, dedication ceremonies were held this afternoon at the University of Washington oceanographic laboratories. The building, on Lake Union Bay adjoining the campus, represents the major part of a $250,000 gift to the university by the Rockefeller Foundation.

Professor "William Lloyd Warner of the Feabody Museum of Harvard University will sail today for Ireland leading an archaeological expedition, accompanied by Mrs. Warner and Professor Russel R. Larmon of the department of international relations of Dartmouth College.
READING, Pa., June 15 (AP). -- Montreal and Reading split their double-header today, Reading taking the first game, 6 to 1, and losing the second, 4 to 2.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The downward trend of American foreign trade to pre-war levels continued uninterrupted during May, the decline being 517,812,000 below the April total, according to figures made public by the Commerce Department today.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Throwng farm relief legislation and the Glass banking bill into the discard, the Senate late today hopefully began to clear its program in order to adjourn before the Democratic invention. At the same time it was yarned by Senator Borah and Senator Lewis that all essential business must be dealt with first.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, announced yesterday that the organization had become affiliated with the Engineering Societies Employment Service to make available for its members the facilities of the service maintained by the principal engineering societies of the country.
CHICAGO, Thursday, June 16. -- The Republican platform declarations adopted by the convention follow:

PHILADELPHIA, Jue 15. -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. has been asked by the Rev. Dr. Hugh Thomson Kerr of Pittsburgh, president of the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, to state what, in his judgment, is the "next forward movement in the fight for temperance and the social control of the liquor traffic."

VIENNA, June 15. -- Silvester Matuschka, a Hungarian, who derailed a train at Bia-Torbagy, near Budapest, last September, sending twenty-eight persons to their death, and was the instigator of an earlier outrage of a similar kind that resulted in injuries to 109 passengers on the "Berlin-Vienna express at Jueterbog, Germany, was placed on trial In the Vienna District Court today.

RYE, N.Y., June 15. -- Sidney Berger of New York University, New York State intercollegiate tennis champion and second seeded player in the Eastern intercollegiates, was helped off the courts of the Apawamis Club with a badly sprained ankle today after apparently being headed toward unlooked-for defeat in his match with Harold C. Christensen of the Philadelphia College of Osteopathy.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP). -- The Phils won a shortened contest from St. Louis, 7 to 4, today, when a heavy rain washed out the game while the Cards were at bat in the seventh inning.

Disdainful, trained for Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney by the youthful Fred Hopkins, who also conditions Equipoise, showed gameness and stamina in high degree at Aqueduct yesterday to capture the Clover Stakes, which had its first running in 1888.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 15. -- Baroness Giacoma Levi of New York reached the semi-final round in the women's New Jersey State tennis championships on the Oritani Field Club courts today, defeating Mrs. Arthur Deane, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 15. -- The Akron, the navy's new air cruiser and the world's largest airship, returned tonight to her home dock here after an absence of thirty-eight days. During that time the big airship with a crew of eighty-two officers and men aboard had traveled 10,000 miles above a score of States, manoeuvred with the Pacific Fleet and had visited California and the Northwest.

This is Mr. HOOVER'S convention. He is entitled to control it. He does so at nig own risk. Submission of the majority of the delegates to the occupant of the White House when he is a candidate for re-election -- and sometimes when he isn't -- is familiar.

Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch, of the Appellate Division, it was disclosed yesterday, has refused to place on the court's calendar, for consideration before the Summer adjournment, the agreed statement of facts drawn by Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly and counsel for the Fifth Avenue Coach Company as the basis for testing the validity of the company's bus operation on most of its existing routes in Manhattan.

Ascribing the decline in revenues of the United Gas Corporation to the shrinkage in consumption of natural gas resulting from the depression and to the reduction in rates brought about by competition with low-cost crude oil in the South-western area served, Ralph B. Feagin, president of the company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday of the strides already accomplished in effecting operating economies and corporate simplification.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The prohibition plank agreed upon by the resolutions committee of the Republican convention is acceptable to President Hoover. It was framed along the lines which the White House felt was soundest in the present political situation, according to information received informally tonight.

Anders Jordahl, who was a personal friend of Ivar Kreuger for thirty years and who had been sought for questioning in connection with the latter's financial manipulations, appeared voluntarily yesterday before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee in the bankruptcy here of the International Match Corporation, and described "certain services" he had rendered to Mr. Kreuger in domestic affairs, in the organization of "inactive" Kreuger companies and in the conservation of assets.

Through an addition to section 119 of the Sanitary Code, adopted by the Board of Health, medical fakers with worthless nostrums and misinformation concerning disease and the human body will be barred from the streets of New York City after July 1, it was anounced yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 16. -- Following is the official vote on the motion to amend the majority report of the resolutions committee by adopting the Bingham report urging repeal, fractional votes being approximated:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Any good housekeeper has the right to scorn Congress in its dangerous, stupid, futile attempts to reduce the housekeeping expenses of the country and balance the budget.

A committee representing the Eastern railroad presidents' conference j drafted yesterday a plan for an actual test of the operation of a six-hour day. The outline will be submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Confirmation of the belief, general in political circles, that Governor Roosevelt will not take decisive action on the removal charges against Mayor "Walker before the Democratic National Convention was seen here yesterday in a statement made at the offices of Martin Conboy, one of the Governor's advisers in the case.
Crude but Necessary. Each day brings a political thinker to the front who demands that the national conventions of the political parties be abolished. HENRY FORD holds that they amount to nothing.

The most comprehensive manoeuvres ever held to test the aerial defenses of New York City will centre tomorrow on Fort Tilden, Rockaway Park, L.I., when the Sixty-second Anti-Aircraft Regiment of the regular army Coast Artillery will speed across Long Island from its base at Fort Totten, near Bayside, to "eagage" a fleet of raiding planes.
CHICAGO, June 15. -- The prohibition plank of the platform agreed upon late this afternoon by the Resolutions Committee and adopted tonight by the convention reads as follows:

The Citizens Budget Commission, announced on Monday, got a splendid reception. Press and public joined in welcoming this move to put a fan In the hand of Father Knickerbocker to winnow the wheat from the chaff of public expenditures. Some aspects of the welcome, however, must have seemed to the sponsors of the movement just a bit overwhelming.

MEXICO CITY, June 12. -- Exploring a ruined city in the jungles of Vera Cruz, Enrique Juan Palacios, Mexican Government archaeologist, has discovered that the Mayan system, of hieroglyphic writing was known to the Totonac Indians, who lived in this southeast region of Mexico.

Drawing attention to the further curtailment in steel production. The Iron Age in its weekly review points out that the inability of this industry "to maintain even its recent low operating rates" is due largely to "financial and political uncertainties that are throttling virtually every activity upon which the steel mills depend for business."

The St. John's High School base-ball team of Brooklyn defeated Iona Prep of Manhattan in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's city championship final at Mount St. Michael's Field yesterday, 7 to 5.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 15. -- Governor Roosevelt announced today the appointment of M. Maldwin Fertig of the Bronx as counsel to the Governor. Mr. Fertig has served for several years as Assistant Corporation Counsel of New York City.

A drastic revision of the regulations of the New York Stock Exchange with the apparent object of meeting criticisms that have been directed against the specialist system was announced yesterday. Under the new rules brokers are specifically prohibited from accepting stock offered or supplying stock wanted until they have made an effort to obtain in the open market more advantageous terms than those named in their orders.

S.S. ILE DE FRANCE, June 15 (AP). -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnana had traveled 350 miles on her return trip to America today in exactly the same elapsed time -- 13% hours -- that she spanned the entire Atlantic alone by airplane on May 20.

After deliberating for eleven hours without agreeing upon a verdict, the jury that heard the evidence in the trial of Jack Zaroff in General Sessions, where he was charged with the murder of Patrolman Maurice O'Brien in 113th Street, near Fifth Avenue, on the night of Jan. 30, 1930, was discharged by Judge Joseph E. Corrigan at 10:45 o'clock last night.

PARIS, June 15. -- Prices on the Bourse weakened today, indicating that the recent buying merely was covering in view of the settlements which took place today, with the official rate one-eight of 1 per cent. In practice, a large number of stocks was carried over at par or one-sixteenth of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Republican leaders here were satisfied today that Vice President Curtis would be renominated at the Republican convention after Charles G. Dawes, Vice President from 1924 to 1928, announced definitely today that he could not accept the nomination if it were offered to him.
LAUSANNE, June 15. -- It is on the attitude of Germany that the fate...

David Lamar, whose mysterious financial connections and stock market transactions won aim the sobriquet "The Wolf of Wall Street," was arrested yesterday afternoon in the office of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. on a charge of grand larceny.

ROME, June 15. -- Sentence of death by shooting in the back was passed late tonight by a special military tribunal on Domenico Bovone, bomb terrorist, who was arrested last September on a charge of exploding thirteen bombs in various Italian cities, killing a police sergeant and injuring several persons.

The second act of America's great quadrennial political drama, normally the business of naming a President and his running-mate, developed into a stirring debate on prohibition last night at the Chicago Stadium which kept the broadcasters on the air until 2:30 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time, and constituted perhaps the longest single political broadcast on record.

MERION, Pa., June 15. -- Shattering additional records, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare carried the Philadelphia Country Club colors to the front on the third and final day of the Women's Eastern Golf Association championship over the Merion cast course today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 15. -- Leo Kaufmann, Gedney Farrm representative, who has developed a penchant for leading fields in oneday tournaments, added another trophy to his fast-growing collection today by turning in the lowest score at the Leewood Golf Club, where the Westchester County Golf Association held one of its eighteen-hole outings.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Senator Borah is not satisfied with the prohibition plank agreed upon by the resolutions committee at Chicago, The Senator refused to comment on the plank tonight, even when informed that John W. Hart, chairman of the Idaho delegation, who had talked with Mr. Borah by telephone from Chicago, had stated that the plank did not satisfy the Senator.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The prayer delivered at the second session of the Republican convention by the Right Rev. Mgr. Thomas P. Bona of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary of Perpetual Help, Chicago, follows:

PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP). -- Present-day advertising was blamed for a large share of dullness in business, in the address of J.V. Thompson, store manager of the Strouss-Hirschberg Company of Youngs-town, Ohio, before the National Retail Dry Goods Association in convention today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 15. -- George H. (Pete) Bostwick, one of the leading gentleman riders, today won two of the six races on the opening day's program at the forty-second annual Eastern Horse Club meeting at the Brookline Country Club.
CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell kept pace with the two leftys, Grove and Gomez, today when he won his twelfth game of the season as the Indians routed Boston, 9 to 3.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 15. -- At Holy Cross College commencement exercises today degrees were conferred upon 215 seniors and seven post-graduate students by Governor Ely.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15.-- Yale defeated Brown, 10 to 4, today, a six-run rally in the eighth and ninth innings turning a close game into a virtual rout.

Headed for Cape York, on the bleak northwest coast of Greenland, 600 miles north of the Arctic Circle, the schooner Effie M. Morrissey, veteran of the ice floes, left West Brighton, S.I., at noon yesterday under command of Captain Bob Bartlett, with scientists, a crew of twenty-seven, and masons who will erect on the tip of Cape York a sixty-foot memorial to Admiral Robert E. Peary, discoverer of the North Pole.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Well, they met again today. There was no way of preventing it. They all had their tickets and their badges and the chairs was there, so they figured they had Just as well use all of 'em. Yes sir, everything was there but the performers.

VALETTA, Malta, June 15. -- The Maltese Nationalist party has held its majority in the Senate in the first general elections since 1927 and is expected to nave a majority of two or three members In the Legislative Assembly.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 15. -- Governor Roosevelt, finding it impossible to talk In person to all the Roosevelt-pledged delegats, has put his voice on many miniature phonograph records and mailed his talk to them.

BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP). -- Baltimore dropped the first game of today's double-header to Buffalo, 12 to 6. Rain resulted in the second game being called in the Orioles' half of the fifth inning with the score tied at 2 -- all.

PARIS, June 15 (AP). -- The loss of about $80,000,000 when Great Britain went off the gold standard was reported in American banking circles here today to be the basis for the French, gold policy that resulted in the removal of $50,000,000 in the metal from New York this week.
BOSTON, June 15 (AP). -- Tony Plet's triple in the eighth drove in two runs to break a 2-2 deadlock and help give Pittsburgh a 5-2 victory over the Braves in a series opener today.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- An argument that neither the National Broadcasting Company nor Station WGBB at Freeport, N.Y., was a common carrier engaged in the transmission of intelligence and that therefore the Interstate Commerce Commission had no jurisdiction over their rates was made today by Frederick H. Wood, counsel, before the full membership of the commission in its first case involving jurisdiction over broadcasting rates.
CHICAGO, June 15. -- The Republican party platform adopted at Kansas City in 1928 did not mention prohibition as such, but under the heading "Law Enforcement" it said:

DETROIT, June 15 (AP). -- Earl Webb, playing his first, game in a Tiger uniform, teamed with Gerald Walker today to figure in all of the scoring by which Detroit defeated the Washington Senators, 7 to 6, in the series opener. Webb and Walker each bagged two doubles.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 15. -- With her sails sheeted home in a rail-down breeze, Frederick H. Prince's America's Cup yacht Westamoe defeated Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie by one minute and five seconds over seventeen miles of Long Island Sound today.

Having been told by three speakers that they must go out and take an intense interest in the problems of the world and so contribute to the advancement of good citizenship and good government, 918 graduates of Hunter College received their degrees at commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall yesterday.

GENEVA, June 15. -- Some progress was made in the disarmament talks here today, especially on the American plan for limiting effectives. One thing deemed to reflect this progress was a statement Prime Minister MacDonald issued before going to Lausanne.

Twenty-eight years ago yesterday the excursion steamship General Slocum burned to the water's edge in the East River with the loss of 1,021 lives. The tragedy was recalled yesterday afternoon when 4,000 men and women assembled in the Lutheran Cemetery at Middle Village, Queens, for the annual services commemorating the disaster.

A six-point program, embodying knit goods manufacturers' ideas of the proper relationships between themselves and wholesale distributers, was adopted yesterday by members of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, at the annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP). -- George Earnshaw held the St. Louis Browns to eight hits and checked, temporarily at least, the St. Louis winning streak as Philadelphia won today's game, 5 to 1. The Athletics garnered fifteen hits off Fischer and Kimsey, who hurled the last two innings.

LEYTON, Essex, England, June 16. -- Percy Holmes and Herbert Sutcliffe, Yorkshiremen, today established a world's record for a first wicket stand, scoring 555 runs in a cricket match with Essex. The former record of 554 was made in 1898 by Brown and Tunnicliffe of Yorkshire.

The reparations conference heard at its first session, yesterday, a plea from Mr. MACDONALD addressed to the delegates of fourteen nations assembled at Lausanne. "My appeal "to you is to fear nothing out weak"ness; to issue bold proposals which "by their very character will com"mand the support of the world."

DESENZANO, Italy, June 16 (AP). -- The world seaplane speed record has been broken by Lieutenant Neri of the Italian Air Force with a speed of 430 miles an hour, but his trial was invalidated by a last minute accident. He beat the speed of 408.8 miles an hour set by Flight Lieutenant George H. Stainforth at Calshot, England, a year ago.

The Giants' winning streak of six straight crashed into Burleigh Grimes and came to grief at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the veteran spitball manipulator pitched the league-leading Cubs to victory in the second game of the series, 2 to 1.

General business activity continued to decline in May, dropping below the level of April by an amount which was greater than seasonal, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

ROME, June 16. -- Less than twelve hours after having sentenced Domenico Bovone to death for terrorist bombings the Special Military Tribunal for the Defense of the State sentenced Angelo Sbardellotto to death by shooting in the back for his attempt to kill Premier Mussolini.
CHICAGO, Ill., June 16. -- Well, the old Republican convention of 1932 went into either history or the ashcan at three thirty this afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Charles Curtis of Kansas won renomination as the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, but it was not an easy victory, and save for the fact that Pennsylvania swung its seventy-five votes to him after the roll-call of the States was concluded, he would have been 19 1/4 ballots short of the majority necessary for nomination.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new low point for the year.

The State of New Jersey awarded yesterday a new issue of $18,000,000 highway and institutional construction bonds, due on July 1, 1934 to 1967, at a price of 100.03 for the bonds to bear interest at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent. Thus, with a premium of $5,400 paid for the issue, the interest cost to the State was about 4.49 per cent.

E.G. Buckland, president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, who until now has announced month by month that with the aid of his organization all near-by railroad interest payments would be met, modified his usual statement yesterday by saying that all roads eligible to this aid might be expected to satisfy charges accruing after July 1.

MADRID, Spain, June 16 (AP). -- General Luis Orgaz, a former Monarchist commander with a brilliant army record, was added today to a list of prominent Spaniards under arrest on charges of plotting against the Republican Government of Spain.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- By one of those coincidences, not uncommon at a Republican National Convention, the "Hoover stampede," as some partisans called it, lasted today virtually as long as the leaders have been predicting it would ever since they began arriving here nearly a week ago.
LONDON, June 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

LAUSANNE, June 16. -- To a private plenary meeting of the Lausanne conference tomorrow will be presented a memorandum, to which Great Britain and France have already agreed, extending the suspension of all reparations payments, including the French unconditional annuities under the Young Plan, until a final settlement can be worked out.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Collection by banks and trust companies of the 2-cent tax on checks, drafts or orders for the payment of money, and the 10 per cent tax on safe deposit boxes will start on June 21, David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, stated today.
LAUSANNE, June 16. -- The text of Prime Minister MacDonald's opening address before the reparations conference here today was as follows:

ALBANY, June 16. -- Again calling upon taxpayers for intelligent investigation of possibilities for tax reduction, Governor Roosevelt pointed the way tonight for a prospective cut in the expenditures for the Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Changes in classes of ocean travel during the last few years have affected not only the swift liners carrying hundreds of passengers across the Atlantic in a few days, but have had a decidedly beneficial influence in the freight-ship class. Officials of companies operating freight lines said yesterday that the improved cargo-passenger services of today marked a new general mode of travel all over the world.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- In a study of the involved business of Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland capitalist, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today heard David Stock of its legal staff testify that Mr. Eaton had used the assets of Continental Shares, Inc., a $150,000,000 investment company organized by himself, in his own private business operations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is unfortunate that any one could have interpreted the figures showing increased use of supervised probation as an alternative to prison and of release from prison by parole as a more modern method of release, as indicating that these methods were beingused to empty Federal jails and prisons.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- The rift in the New York Republican delegation over the proposal to re-elect Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt to the Republican National Committee was healed today, and she and Committeeman Charles D. Hilles were unanimously renamed at a caucus of the delegation prior to the final convention session.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Gratified by the outcome of the Republican convention, President Hoover began preparations this afternoon for the campaign for his re-election.

Week's Reorder Activity Fair. Reorder activity on seasonal merchandise lines has been fairly well maintained this week, reflecting the improvement in retail sales which has been fairly general throughout the country, reports here yesterday indicated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16. -- The Medical Society of New Jersey in its annual convention held here today adopted plans to curb the use of the term "specialist" by physicians not scientifically qualified.

Shortly after the Great War a French Colonel wrote an article to faring out the mental attitude of the French general staff, wherein it differed from the German. The latter seemed to think only of army masses. At the French headquarters, personalities were deeply studied, especially those of the enemy commanders.
ROME, June 16 (AP). -- Cardinal Lorenzo Lauri, Legate of Pope Pius XI to the Eucharistic Congress at Dublin, left this morning for Ireland accompanied by a special pontifical mission.
CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP). -- Mary Garden is coming out of retirement to sing her favorite Carmen again.

Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, renewed last night his plea for unification of all of the city's rapid transit facilities at a fair price. He spoke over Radio Station WOR on behalf of the latest of his transit unification plans, sent to the Board of Estimate early this week.

The Eighth Street Gallery, which has been open only since last April and is the youngest exponent in the local exhibition field, has just opened its third group show of contemporary American painting and sculpture. This delightful little gallery is not so easy to find unless you know your way.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- The vote of the Republican National Convention by which President Hoover was renominated here today was as follows:

HALIFAX, N.S., June 16. -- Official protest was forwarded today by a Halifax legal firm on behalf of the crew of the Canadian motor vessel Mary F. Ruth to the Secretary of State, Ottawa, claiming molestation at the hands of United States revenue cutters fifty miles at sea.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Under the disclosed domination of the President, the Republican national convention at its closing session today renominated Herbert Hoover and gave a grudging but safe majority to Charles Curtis of Kansas, renominated as the party candidate for Vice President.

A free-hitting contest in which Dan Howley's Reds had the better of it sent the Robins down to their second straight defeat at Ebbets Field yesterday, with a gathering of 8,000 fans looking on in growing disapproval. The score was 8 to 6, the visitors overcoming a four-run Brooklyn rally against Larry Benton in the second inning.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Chicago's visitors to the Republican National Convention, estimated by trained observers around 10,000, left town tonight in droves. Their hurried departure immediately following the final session of the convention at the Chicago Stadium this afternoon was in accordance with the policy of economy evident among the delegates, alternates and friends throughout the five-day sojourn in the city.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Marriages performed in New York State during 1931 numbered 114,111, compared with 117,880 in the preceding-year, a reduction of 3,769 or 3.2 per cent, the Census Bureau announced today. In 1922, 98,357 marriages were performed.

To get at the real effect of the Republican prohibition plank, one bas to cut through, perhaps the worst jungle of verbiage that even platform-makers ever devised in order to conceal their thought. At the end we have it -- namely, a "proposed "amendment which shall allow "States to deal with the problem as "their citizens may determine."

Baldwin Locomotive Works -- Twelve months ended March 31: Consolidated net loss after depreciation, interest, taxes and other charges, $4,426,895. No comparison available on this basis, but for fiscal year ended Dec. 31 consolidated net loss after above deductions was $4,122,759.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 16. -- Eighteen-year-old Vanitie, America's cup yacht of 1914 vintage, came forth today in her new sail dress at the New York Yacht Club's special Glen Cove races and showed the way to modern Weetamoe over 25.7 miles by 7 minutes and 45 seconds.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16. -- Fellowships and graduate scholarships awarded at Harvard University for the academic year 1932-33 were announced today. They number 192 and carry a total value of $117,576.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- One hundred and twelve members of the Princeton unit of the Field Artillery Reserve Officers' Training Corps left here today for a six weeks' encampment at Madison Barracks, near Watertown, N.Y.

LOS ANGELES, June 16. -- Still the avowed pantomimist, and confident he has a cure for the world's financial ills, Charles Spencer Chaplin, film comedian, returned to his Beverly Hills home today after sixteen months of globe trotting, his "first real vacation in twenty years."

Following a brief spurt two weeks ago, bank clearings dropped back in the last week to only about half of the total for a year ago. The aggregate for twenty-two cities for the week ended on Wednesday night was $4,203,663,000, or 52.6 per cent below that of the corresponding period of 1931.

While many of the spokesmen for the wet and dry movements were in Chicago attending the Republican National Convention, those who remained here expressed different views on the effect of the prohibition plank adopted by the party. The drys hailed it as a defeat for the wets and the wets characterized it as a "rude shock" to those omptimistic repealists who have believed repeal to be just around the corner.

RED BANK, N.J., June 16. -- The annual June flower show of the Rumson Garden Club, held today in the carriage house of Mrs. Bertram H. Borden's estate at Rumson, attracted a large number of Summer residents of Rumson, Seabright and surrounding shore towns.

While thousands lined Seventh Avenue from Times Square to Thirty-eighth Street and others watched from the windows of neighboring office buildings, firemen rescued two girls and a man yesterday from a burning seven-story loft building at 566-568 Seventh Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Defending the prohibition plank in the Republican platform, Secretary of State Stimson declared over the radio tonight that instead of being a "straddle," the proposed method of dealing with the prohibition problem was "consistent, definite, logical and well-founded in law and fact."

WARWICK, R.I., June 16. -- Moonshine of the Narragansett Bay Fleet and Black and White of the Peconic Bay Fleet went into a tie for first place in the Star Class Eastern Olympic eliminations and Atlantic Coast championship today when Black and White led Moonshine over the finish line by 3 minutes and 21 seconds.

MEXICO CITY, June 16. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President and now Minister of War, left with his wife tonight for New York, where she will undergo a serious operation, reportedly for kidney trouble.
W.R. Coe's Pompeius, winner of three stakes in a row last Spring, and second last Saturday in the Queens County Handicap, captured the Broadway Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in a decisive manner.

For the twelfth consecutive day prices of sugar futures rose yesterday, making the widest one-day advance of the year. The upward trend was stimulated by continued improvement of consumer demand and by forced covering by a substantial short interest that had arisen in the belief that heavy profittaking would cut off the rally.

To the Editor at The New York Times: I desire to discuss two subjects, both, of which may be of interest to the many people who find themselves in a position similar to the one am in at the present time.
A few scattered housing deals featured mild trading in Manhattan yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 16. -- Five blue ribbons fell to the stable of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Tobey of Southold, L.I., during the first day of the twelfth annual Huntington Horse Show, which opened this morning on the grounds of the Huntington Bay Club.

SYRACUSE, June 16. -- More than 2,500 members of the Dairymen's League at its annual meeting this afternoon cheered a denunciation of "powerful and ruthless milk dealer organizations" by Governor Wilson of Vermont and heard Louis J. Taber of Ohio, master of the national grange, score "quibbling over prohibition while millions are in trouble."

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The House passed today by an overwhelming viva-voce vote, the Fulmar bill authorizing free distribution of 40,000,000 bushels of wheat held by the grain stabilization corporation, and 500,000 bales of cotton of the cotton stabilization corporation, both subsidiaries of the Federal Farm Board.

The American Council of Learned Societies announced yesterday the completion of the ninth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography, containing 673 sketches by 362 contributors. It opens with an article on Paxton Hibben, soldier and diplomat and the author of a much-discussed life of Henry Ward Beecher, and closes with a sketch of William Chapman Jarvis, pioneer laryngologist and rhinologist.

Copies of the exhibits received by the Hofstadter legislative committee during the testimony which, is now the basis of removal charges against Mayor Walker have been obtained by Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority member, it was revealed yesterday.

NEW YORK. Miss Elizabeth D. Campbell gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Prances Weeks and David Stone, who will be married tomorrow in East Hampton, L.I. The other guests were the Misses Rosamund Turner.

Hope for eventual use of Federal funds to encourage slum clearance is seen by Representative Fiorella H. La Guardia of New York despite the fact that a Senate committee struck from the Wagner bill a provision for housing loans.

PARIS, June 16. -- The market rallied on the Bourse today, with trading much more active. Both domestic and international stocks recovered, the gains in many cases being of considerable importance. Bank of France shares were up 5.90 francs, Generale Electricite, 100; Suez Canal, 355, and Rio Tinto Copper, 80.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Curiosity over the attitude of Senator Borah toward the prohibition plank adopted by the Republican National Convention dominated discussion of the platform here today.

In an article written for The American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune, published today, Dr. Cyrus Adler. president of the American Jewish Committee, takes sharp issue with the proposal of Dr. Stephen S. Wise. honorary president of the American Jewish Congress, for the convening of a world Jewish congress.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- A near-fight and a near-frolic marked the final session of the Republican National Convention, which came to a close at 3:55, Central Daylight Time, this afternoon, after renominating both Herbert Hoover and Charles Curtis for President and Vice President of the United States.
PARIS, June 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

ASCOT, England, June 16. -- For the tenth time since the famous Gold Cup was first run in 1807 the race was won two years in succession by the same horse when Trimdon, sporting the silks of Brig. Gen. Charles Lamton, accounted for today's renewal of the historic two and onehalf miles classic at Royal Ascot.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- When the twentieth Republican National Contion adjourned sine die this afternoon, leaving nearly 400 women delegates and alternates "all tired out," Mrs. Dolly Curtis Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, immediately was surrounded by friends, newspaper men and women and autograph seekers.

Building permits in the United States last month declined 19.3 per cent from April and 69.6 per cent from May, 1931, according to a survey by S.W. Straus Co., Inc., revealing a continuance of the general decline during the past two years. Permits in 577 cities and towns of the country last month totaled $42,994,477, against $53,268,724 in the preceding month, the survey shows.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A warning of the likelihood of disaster if the bonus payment bill was passed was issued today by Senators Copeland and Wagner of New York and Walsh and Coolidge of Massachusetts. It reads as follows:

To The Editor of The New York Times: Before leaving your wonderful country am glad to have this opportunity to express my appreciation of the charming hospitality which has been shown me by so many of your fellow-citizens.

ALBANY, June 16. -- The name of the man who will put Governor Roosevelt in nomination at the Democratic National Convention may be announced tomorrow, the Governor revealed today as he prepared for a three-day week-end trip through Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

DEAL, N.J., June 16. -- The first session of a contract bridge contest between the "Four Horsemen," holders of most of the championships in the game, and the Cavendish Club team, headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, will open here tomorrow night.

BERLIN, June 16. -- The rehabilita- tion of Adolf Hitler's brown shirt storm troops is permitted under a new emergency decree promulgated today, but the troops will be subject to supervision by the Reich's Minister of Interior. The decree abro- gates the ban on party uniforms.
Several apartment house deals were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

ALPINE, N.J., June 16. -- Miss Jessie Rosenberg, 19-year-old daughter of a prominent family in Hackensack, N.J., leaped to her death late this afternoon from Point Lookout here, the highest cliff of the Palisades, and in a suicide note revealed her secret marriage last September to a 21-year-old college student.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16. -- Elimination of the medalist and two former champions marked the first two rounds of match play for the New Jersey amateur golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club today, and only after a hard match that went three extra holes did the defending champion, F. Paul Anderson of Canoe Brook, survive to gain a place among the eight quarter-finalists.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- The text of the speech made by Charles F. Scott of Kansas, putting the name of Vice President Curtis into nomination at the Republican convention today follows :

LODON, June 16. -- The stock markets were more subdued today, due partly to a disinclination to enter fresh commitments in view of the Lausanne conference. British Government funds again were in good demand, with the 4 per cent consols Quoted above par, a new high record.

LONDON, June 16 (Canadian Press). -- The touring cricket team from India defeated the Eastern Counties by an Innings and 129 runs in a match concluded today at Lincoln. The score: Eastern Counties, 122 and 173 (Rhodes 90); All-India, 424 for seven wickets declared (Marshall 148, Limbdi 100, retired).

LONDON, Friday, June 17 (AP). -- The Daily Express printed an interview with Premier Mussolini of Italy today in which the Premier was quoted as criticizing caustically the United States and democracy generally, adding that he foresaw a long series of economic and military wars.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 16. -- Max Schmeling took off three and a half pounds in a five-round workout in a packed and stuffy indoor arena today. Warm sultry rain forced Schmeling to transfer the workout indoors at the last minute, and there was not enough space to accommodate half the crowd on hand to see the champion.

Decision on the petition for the appointment of a receiver in bankruptcy for Kreuger Toll was again held in abeyance yesterday by Federal Judge Mack, who granted an adjournment of the hearing until next Wednesday at 3 P.M. to permit time for a possible agreement among counsel as to the desirability of an independent proceeding here.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Two-day transatlantic flights in giant airships carrying fast air-mail between the United States and Europe, and eventually to the Orient and other fardistant points, came a step nearer to realization today when the House passed the Grosser airship bill authorizing the Postmaster General to enter into long-term contracts with airship builders for transatlantic airmail service.

RYE, N.Y., June 16. -- By capturing both races on today's final program, Harvard won the fifth annual Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, which was conducted on Long Island Sound by the American Yacht Club.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- The text of the address of Joseph S. Scott of Los Angeles, nominating President Hoover, was as follows:

Only one witness testified yesterday at Isidor J. Kresel's perjury trial before Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris of Buffalo and a jury in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. He was Nathan Behrin, a Supreme Court stenographer, called by the prosecution as an expert witness.

The tepid weather of the last few days probably has started trout fishermen thinking more than ever of thair favorite streams. Trout are usually anxious to feed when the flies hatch and the angler always expects to have his share of luck at these times.

Bankers of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System have virtually completed a plan for the repayment of $13,500,000 of short-term notes of the company due on Aug. 1, and the plan will be submitted to the directors of the company on next Monday, when the question of dividends on its preferred and common shares will come up for consideration:

Wall Street's interest in the stock market waned again yesterday. Not only was the business on the Stock Exchange slower, but fluctuations were confined to a narraw range and the net results failed to reflect any positive opinions on the part of speculators.

The body of the Rev. Dr. Caleb Rochford Stetson, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Parish, was taken yesterday morning to Trinity Church at Broadway, and Wall Street, and placed in All Saints' Chapel, adjoining the historic edifice, where it will rest until 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

One may imagine the spirit of PEARY sailing with Captain BARTLETT to Cape York, where a monument to the discoverer of the North Pole is to be erected this Summer. The explorer's daughter, born amid the snows, is on the Morrissey and with her two boys will be present at the ceremony.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 16. -- Determination to battle for vindication "until all legal remedies have been exhausted" was expressed here today by Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr., whose conviction for conspiracy to violate the North Carolina State banking laws was affirmed yesterday by the North Carolina State Supreme Court.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding at the end of May amounted to $787,414,750, a drop of $91,624,120 in the month and of more than $625,000,000 in the preceding year, according to the monthly survey of the American Acceptance Council.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., June, 16. -- Bernard Ernest, 19 years old son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ernest of East Hampton, was shot dead last night by an unknown assassin as he was riding with three friends in an automobile along Stony Hill Road between this village and Bridgehampton.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP). -- Allowing only one man to get past first base, Lloyd Brown turned back Detroit with five scattered hits today and pitched Washington to a 4-to-0 victory. The game ended the current series at 1-all.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, was 210,700,000 kilowatt-hours for the week ended June 11, as against 212,500,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 238,000,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.
A mortgage for $12,500, held by Elizabeth Schacht and Adolph Sauer from the Tozier Realty Co. on 928 Columbus Av., has been extended to July 1, 1935, at 6 per cent.

BERLIN, June 16. -- German imports declined in May by one-sixth, as compared with April. Largely because of this drop the surplus of exports over imports for the month was 87,000,000 marks (about $20,706,000), twice as large as that for April. The surplus, however, is by no means sufficient to cover Germany's payments abroad for the corresponding period, and it is expected to be considerably smaller in June.
The Blue Cockade, an anti-prohibition organization, sent a telegram to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler yesterday, asking him if he would consent to lead a new "liberal" party.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,245,000,000, an increase of $78,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,304,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Speyer Co. announced yesterday that the trustees of the Bulgarian 7 1/2 per cent stabilization loan of 1928 and 7 per cent settlement loan of 1926 would today publish notices here and in London that, for the period from April to September, 1932, the Bulgarian Government intended to remit one-half of the amount required for the payment of interest and sinking fund of the two loans.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- More than 2,000 Princeton alumni were on the campus here today for the annual class reunions tonight, tomorrow and Saturday. Forty-two classes have scheduled official reunion dinners or other activities. The graduates will march in costume to University Field Saturday afternoon to see the Princeton-Yale baseball game.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A continuation of the open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended yesterday increased holdings of government securities by $47,000,000 to $1,692,000,000, a gain of $1,093,000,000 in a year.

Gene Sarazen, who won the British open golf championship last week, will arrive today on the Cunard liner Mauretania, accompanied by Tommy Armour, defending champion, and Macdonald Smith, another American contender. Others on the Mauretania include:

RYE, N.Y., June 16. -- The Columbia University tennis team, which swept the Eastern intercollegiate championships last year, carrying off the singles and doubles titles and the team trophy, with a total of 40 points, was shut out of the current tournament in the quarter-finals today with an aggregate of 6 points at the Apawamis Club.

Yeshiva College held its first commencement exercises yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the college at 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Nineteen graduates received degrees of Bachelor of Arts and eight were graduated either magna cum laude or cum laude.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Friday, June 17. -- Colonel Marmaduque Grove was overthrown early today as provisional head of the Chilean Government, according to a manifesto by army leadera who launched a counter-revolt against him last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16. -- Miss Frances Snyder of the Apawamis Club, with an 85, won low gross, and Miss Betty Pietsch of the Tamarack Club took low net with a 79 in the weekly medal play handicap golf tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today at the Round Hill Club.

In the interval before the meeting of the Board of Estimate today, it is to be hoped that the members have given thought to the evidence presented on work and home relief by men whose knowledge of it is unquestioned. Commissioner of Public Welfare TAYLOR'S estimates of the sums necessary to keep the destitute from starvation have been remarkably accurate in the past.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's address at Lausanne today encouraged officials to hope that Europe would make a wise decision on German reparations and thereby lay a solid groundwork for the projected world economic conference.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Neither the wets nor the drys are satisfied with the "amphibian" prohibition plank, adopted last night under pressure of lieutenants of President Hoover by the Republican convention, and although the plank is wetter than would have seemed possible six months ago, the wets are more dissatisfied than the drys.

Indications of the proximity of the national open golf championship appeared yesterday when the U.S.G.A. released the pairings and starting times for the 1932 event, which will be held at the Fresh Meadow Country Club, just outside Flushing, L.I., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, June 23 to 25.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP). -- Brilliant pitching in the pinches by Jess Haines coupled with his home run into the left-field bleachers paved the way for a 2-to-0 St. Louis victory over the Phils today.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 16 (AP). -- Receivership suits were filed in Chancery Court today by groups of stockholders against the Hambleton Corporation and Hambleton Co., both of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Hanford MacNider is considering resigning as Minister to Canada, but it was said in administration circles today that he had not submitted his resignation, nor had he given any intimation that be would do so shortly.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Vice President Curtis received an ovation from Republicans and Democrats alike when news of his renomination was announced in the chamber this afternoon. Every Senator rose and applauded.

VILLANOVA, Pa., June 16 (AP). -- The Rev. Edward V. Stanford, formerly of Boston, was elected president of Villanova College today to succeed the Rev. James H. Griffin, who is being relieved on account of ill health.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Bill Dickey's fourth homer of the Western trip and his eleventh of the season, featured the Yankee attack, which, operating behind strong pitching by Charley Ruffing, won a 6-to-1 decision, over the White Sox today to even the series at one game apiece.

WILTON, Conn., June 16. -- There were fifty classes and more than 300 exhibits in the Spring flower show of the Wilton Garden Club, held in the Town Hall this afternoon and evening. The background for the exhibit was a classical setting on the stage of the hall, a "garden vert," arranged by G. Evans Hubbard with Houon's bust of Washington in the centre.

READING, Pa., June 16 (AP). -- Reading's Keystones took a double bill from Rochester today, winning the first contest, 8 to 7, in the ninth inning, and taking the second, also in the ninth, 5 to 4. The second game was scheduled for seven innings, but a tie forced two extra innings.

Business and quotations for the various classes of money showed no relaxation from the narrow groove in which both have held for weeks. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent, outside loans at 1, and Federals at 1/8@1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

Awards were voted to ninety-three members of five City College Spring sports teams at a meeting of the athletic association yesterday, with the varsity and junior varsity lacrosse units receiving the majority of the awards. The varsity and junior varsity baseball teams and the varsity tennis team also were honored.

MERION, Pa., June 16. -- New York's squad of women golfers started auspiciously in the Clement A. Griscom Cup intercity competition by easily defeating Boston, 13 to 2, over the Merion east course today.

Strength in the sugar market, futures rising 7 to 8 points, and raws 5 j points, stood out as the most important development in the local commodities markets yesterday. Coffee, cocoa, grains and cotton also moved higher. Hides, rubber and silk were irregular.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Are you quite sure that the last word has been said in the back-to-the-farm movement to cure distress and unemployment which so many of us advocate? You seem to so assume in your editorial "The Master Planner."
An Old-Timer of the Stock Exchange FRANK K. STURGIS, in the course of his long life, had been a member of the New York Stock Exchange from the panic of 1873 to the end of the great European war.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Everett Sanders of Indiana, former secretary to President Coolidge, was unanimously chosen chairman of the Republican National Committee at the organization meeting which followed adjournment of the party's convention here today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16. -- Miss Mary L. Alexander, manager of the library research department of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn of New York, was elected president of the Special Libraries Association today.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Senate vote on the Patman bill for the payment of $2,400,000,000 to World War veterans, which was passed by the House yesterday and was scheduled for action by the upper body today, was deferred until tomorrow after the Finance Committee had reported it adversely following a swift consideration this morning.

Mayor Walker appointed yesterday Charles L. Lawrance, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, chairman of the committee of honor, consisting of about 150 persons, which is to receive Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, the transatlantic flier, when she arrives here on Monday.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Former Senator Joseph I. France of Maryland was forcibly ejected by the police from the convention rostrum today as he was making an effort to withdraw as a candidate for President in favor of Calvin Coolidge. He pleaded with Chairman Snell to address the convention, but Mr. Snell refused to recognize him and finally the police escorted him from the platform.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Weighing the political aspects of the party's platform, prepared under administration influence, some Republican politicians indicated today that they believed the party leaders had acted too hastily in defining its attitude on prohibition, the regulation of public utilities and in denouncing the insurgents for party irregularity.

Persistent rains in eastern sections of the cotton belt, where dry weather is needed, caused a further recovery in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Active buying carried October at one time to 5.55 cents, which was 40 points above the low records made last week.

The Reading Company reported yesterday an increase in net income for April, but other roads, including the Santa Fe, Atlantic Coast Line, Delaware Hudson and Southern suffered net losses in the period. Net income after taxes and charges of sundry railroads for April and the first four months of the year, as announced yesterday, follows:

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Senate vote on the Patman bill for the payment of $2,400,000,000 to World War veterans, which was passed by the House yesterday and was scheduled for action by the upper body today, was deferred until tomorrow after the Finance Committee had reported it adversely following a swift consideration this morning.

Mayor Walker appointed yesterday Charles L. Lawrance, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, chairman of the committee of honor, consisting of about 150 persons, which is to receive Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, the transatlantic flier, when she arrives here on Monday.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Former Senator Joseph I. France of Maryland was forcibly ejected by the police from the convention rostrum today as he was making an effort to withdraw as a candidate for President in favor of Calvin Coolidge. He pleaded with Chairman Snell to address the convention, but Mr. Snell refused to recognize him and finally the police escorted him from the platform.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Weighing the political aspects of the party's platform, prepared under administration influence, some Republican politicians indicated today that they believed the party leaders had acted too hastily in defining its attitude on prohibition, the regulation of public utilities and in denouncing the insurgents for party irregularity.

Party platforms and funeral orations should be read with a certain tenderness. Monotony and excess of eulogy spring from the occasion. Still, the paid reader or the exceptional heroic soul who voluntarily paces over the acre of words cultivated at Chicago comes upon some queer spots.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 16. -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs, in convention here, today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to put motion pictures in the United States under Federal supervision.

The Reading Company reported yesterday an increase in net income for April, but other roads, including the Santa Fe, Atlantic Coast Line, Delaware Hudson and Southern suffered net losses in the period. Net income after taxes and charges of sundry railroads for April and the first four months of the year, as announced yesterday, follows:

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- In clusion in the Republican platform at Chicago of a plan for "enactment by Congress of a measure that will authorize our government to call or participate in an international conference in case of any threat of nonfulfillment of Article 2 of the treaty of Paris (Kellogg-Briand pact)" came as a surprise to officials here.

Gold transactions reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed a net gain of $5,164,100 to the gold stocks of the country. This was the second gain to be reported this week, prior to which there had been an unbroken series of daily losses since May 5.

NEW HAVEN, June 16. -- Dean Everett V. Meeks of the Yale School of Fine Arts paid tribute tonight to the part that the Mabel Brady Garvan collection in arts and crafts, established by Francis P. Garvan of New York, is playing in aiding popular instruction in early American art.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Committees representing railroads in the Castern, Southeastern and "Western sections of the country advised the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they were unwilling, even as an experiment, to put into effect a six-hour day on their respective roads.

LONDON, June 16. -- Stanley Bald- win, acting Prime Minister, who will head the British delegation to the Imperial economic conference at Ot- tawa next month, gave warning to the dominions tonight in the House of Commons that Great Britain would expect more trade reciprocity than she is now receiving from other parts of the empire.

The $1,000,000 appropriation for work and home relief which, the Board of Estimate is expected to approve today will care for a limited time for thousands of cases that have been turned away by family welfare agencies and the police, but, in the opinion of welfare workers, will still leave other thousands near the point of starvation.

Ward Summerfield, 19 years old, who admitted perpetrating eight chain-store hold-ups, and his 18-year-old bride, Elvira, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Levine in General Sessions to State prison terms of from three and one-half to five years each on guilty pleas to one of the robberies.

SCHENECTADY, June 16. -- The breaking down of a single globule of ordinary furnace oil, no bigger than the head of a safety match, into more than 100,000,000 particles, which promises to achieve great economies in oil burners, was announced today by engineers of the General Electric Company at the second session of the semi-annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Featuring prohibition enforcement in May was the seizure of fixtures of sixteen night clubs and road houses and the arrest of 1,380 persons in New York City, Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director, said today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16. -- When Coach Ed Leader took the Yale varsity crew down the Thames River course for along paddle at 7:30 o'clock this evening a heavy fog was encountered near the three-mile flag and the workout was not only interrupted but curtailed.

Governor Roosevelt declared yesterday that the nation's pressing need is "progressive leadership" which would recognize two parts of the problem before the country -- means of alleviating present dis- tress, and "a comprehensive plan covering all phases of our economic and social difficulties."
CHICAGO, June 16. -- The text of Mrs. Pratt'a address seconding Mr. Hoover's nomination follows:

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 17. -- Although intermittent showers made the track muddy, the Eastern Horse Club's second day of racing at the Brookline Country Club track today was more exciting than that of Wednesday.

LONDON, June 17 (AP). -- A British expedition will leave here tomorrow to back-track the seven-year-old trail of Colonel H.P. Fawcett, explorer and mystic, into the inner jungles of Brazil's vast Matto Grosso.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The "Welcome G.O.P." flags will come down tomorrow and up will go the "Welcome Democrats" banners. The Republican leaders had packed up overnight and the sign hangers were busy getting things ready to hoist the Democratic emblems.

SHANGHAI, June 17. -- The Portuguese port of Macao was terrified today when a fierce battle was waged across the entrance to the harbor, an army of 5,000 men under General Chen Chia-tang finally putting to flight a fleet of gunboats under Admiral Chan Chak, a Nanking supporter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published a dispatch from Seattle referring to a speed by Mrs. Florence T. Green, chairman of the arts division of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, recommending "the passing of a law making obligatory the employment of American artists when the portraits are to be paid out of public funds."
BERLIN, June 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 15 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

New bond financing this week totaled $30,480,983, with all except $4,000,000 in State and municipal loans. Last week's total was $7,180,673, that of two weeks ago $35,240,000, and that of a year ago $79,228,000. Most of the new issues were well received and in some cases oversubscribed.

In the presence of officers of the Park Association of New York City, a member of Controller Berry's staff and almost 100 bidders or their representatives, Park Commissioner Albert C. Benninger of Queens opened yesterday the bids for the operation of concessions in Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways.

Violet Sharpe, maid for Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, might not have committed suicide a week ago yesterday if a Department of Justice agent working on the Lindbergh case had accepted the offer of Ernest Brinkert of New Rochelle to go before the girl to prove that she had never seen him, according to a theory advanced last night by Brinkert.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 17. -- Rain fell today on the opening of the Pocono Mountains' second annual laurel blossom festival, but it failed to prevent the flight here from Philadelphia of the laurel queen, Miss Barbara Vincent of Beaver, Pa.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 17. -- Although all was gray gloom, with an occasional shower, on Long Island Sound today, the day was one of joyous brightness for Gerard B. Lambert, for his old America's Cup sloop Vanitie again showed a clean pair of heels to Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe, 1930 America's Cup creation, in the eighty-first annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club.

ELBERON, N.J., Saturday, June 18. -- In the first thirty-two boards of a 200-board contract bridge challenge match, the "Four Horsemen" piled up a lead of 1,625 points over a Cavendish Club team headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt at the Deal Club here last night and early this morning.
LITTLE BOAR'S HEAD, N.H., June 17. -- Reaching here on his weekend tour of New England, Governor Roosevelt disclosed tonight that he had completed the reading of the evidence against Mayor Walker.

BERLIN, June 17. -- The five-power declaration at Lausanne today has evoked no enthusiasm here, the best that can be seen in it being the fact that it involves the first formal acknowledgment by the creditor powers that the war debts and reparations are interrelated in the world crisis.

MONTREAL, June 17. -- Eleven men were killed and fourteen others, missing, are believed to have been killed today by a series of explosions and fire that wrecked the great Vickers dry dock and the interior of the oil tanker Cymbeline, on which 100 men were working.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 17. -- The third of four children of the same family who were striken suddenly by a disease that has baffled medical authorities lay near death in the Nassau County Hospital here tonight after two had died and the fourth child was being treated for a mild attack.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, declared yesterday on his return from the Republican convention that the prohibition plank adopted in Chicago must be regarded as more liberal than could have been expected.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Democrat who has been observing the Republican Convention, was discovered by a reporter alighting from a bus in front of a well-known lake-front hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Chief Examiner Yost today recommended to the Federal Radio Commission that Peter Goelet, son of Robert Goelet, New York City banker, be permitted to erect a new broadcasting station at the Goelet Summer estate at Chester, Orange County, N.Y.

Once again last night the horse, vanishing vestige of by-gone eras of chivalry and the brilliance of the mauve decade, bowed to the machine age when a taxicab, manoeuvred by its driver, halted the progress of a runaway white stallion and the delivery wagon careening behind him at Broadway near 126th Street after the animal had galloped madly down the hill from 116th Street.

The Teachers' Council, at a meeting yesterday at the Board of Education, adopted a report recommending that a fee be charged to applicants registering for examinations for all teaching positions except those in the elementary schools. The report mentioned no specific amount, but it has been estimated that the fee might reduce the cost of giving the examinations by $175,000 annually.

Asking the justices of the Appellate Division to consider whether the "sweetness and light" decision rendered by Supreme Court Justice Ford in connection with the Hofstadter inquiry was not an "unjudicial tirade," Samuel Seabury, the committee's counsel, sought yesterday to have affidavits admitted by Justice Ford stricken from the Supreme Court record.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The influence of unfavorable financial developments abroad upon business and credit conditions in the United States in 1931 were emphasized today by the Federal Reserve Board in its annual report for that year.

The restoration of City Hall Park to the appearance it had in Colonial times moved a step forward yesterday when the city received $2,440,640 from the Federal Government in payment for a new Federal court house site in the civic centre, which will permit the razing of the old postoffice building on Park Row so that its site may be added to the park.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Much interest and some speculation were evidenced by government officials today in regard to the warning by Acting Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin that Great Britain expected its dominions, at the coming Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, to offer more trade reciprocity than it now receives, if the present free entry of many dominion products into Britain was to be continued.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17. -- The charter of Local 825, International Union of Operating Engineers, was rescinded today by John Possehl, international union president, it was reported in building circles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- Sixty per cent of the graduating class of the Harvard Business School have already been placed in positions, it was announced today.
