Degrees were voted on Wednesday to 395 second-year men, and of this number 247 have obtained positions, about half of them through the efforts of the school.

Dr. Donald S. Wees, 33-year-old explorer of Elkins, W.Va., whose reports of the existence of "white Indians" in the grand desert of Northeastern Paraguay were discounted recently by the Museum of Comparative Zoology of Harvard University, returned yesterday from Buenos Aires on the Furness Prince liner Western Prince, with a collection of about 200 specimens of mammals and other native Paraguayan species for the Harvard museum.

Viewing this country's gold position as "impregnable" and domestic hoarding as virtually non-existent, Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson, economist of the Chase National Bank, in an address before the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents yesterday, predicted an early end to the outward flow of gold, with the possibility that before the year was over the United States might have more gold than he would care to see.

Patrick J. Commerford, prominent labor leader and vice president of the Building Trades Council, was named by the Federal grand jury yesterday in three indictments charging perjury and evasion of the income tax law.

Edward Miles had long held the idea that all the world was the same, that the "real people" of every nation were pretty much alike. So four years ago, being fifty years old, independent financially, and of a forward turn of mind, he set out to determine if his convictions were true.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Mrs. William H. Murray, wife of the Governor of Oklahoma, is the first wife of a Democratic Presidential candidate, outside of those in Chicago, to signify definitely her intention of coming here for the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Despite the opposition of Representative McFadden of Pennsylvania, the House today adopted, 235 to 24, the Somers resolution approving an international conference to discuss the world economic situation.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- When the New York delegation to the Republican convention entrained for home last night many of its members had distinct forebodings that the so-called Hoover group in the State organization, headed by Secretary Mills, might attempt to gain control and replace W. Kingsland Macy as chairman of the State committee with Richard W. Lawrence, erstwhile leader in the Bronx.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 17 (AP). -- The new junta headed by Carlos G. Davila continued the state of siege (martial law) under which the country has been functioning, and guards were stationed at strategic points, although the city was quiet after last night's harmless gunfire and other excitement.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- One hundred and ninety-five Princeton University seniors will graduate with, honors, according to the announcement made here today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university. There are about 450 members In the graduating class which will receive degrees Tuesday.

Renewed efforts to bring about unification of all rapid transit lines on terms mutually satisfactory to the city, the B.M.T. and the Interborough were being planned yesterday by the Transit Commission, even as the Board of Estimate, in ratification of committee action taken last Tuesday, was adopting a formal resolution for municipal operation of the city's independent subway system.
Acquisition by a religious order of a large plot adjoining a church featured the realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

CAIRO, June 2 (AP) (By Mail). -- A "funeral procession" of mummies of twenty kings and queens of Egypt recently passed at dawn through desarted streets of Cairo. They were being transferred from the Cairo museum to the new mausoleum, designed originally as the last resting place of Zaghloul Pasha, Nationalist leader, who died in 1927.

Cleaning up, modernizing and beautifying back yards are usual activities at this time of year. Inside work is shelved when warm weather gives people a chance to get out in the open with rakes and spades. But this year the community has not yet been organized for the back yard beautiful.

WARWICK, R.I., June 17. -- The New England Star boat Moonshine of the Narragansett Bay fleet of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association today won the Atlantic Coast championship by taking the final race of the series.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Friends of President Hoover, among them Postmaster General Brown and other administration leaders at the Republican National Convention, will have complete charge of the campaign for the re-election of the President and Vice President through an executive committee of fifteen, the creation of which was authorized last evening at the meeting of the new national committee.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- A resolution intended to clarify the attitude of Catholic youth on prohibition and temperance was adopted by 1,000 students of Catholic colleges today at the opening of a three-day concentration at the Palmer House.

With the support of Mayor WALKER and over the protest of President MCKEE of the Board of Aldermen, the Board of Estimate yesterday formally committed the city to municipal operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway. Mr. MCKEE'S dissent deserves to be spread on the record, where all citizens may read and ponder it.

ASCOT, England, June 17. -- Coyes cas, a son of the famous Gains borough, today won the $2,000 added Hardwicke Stakes over one and one half miles, the feature of the fina day of racing at Royal Ascot.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Allegations that William Fox, creator and for five years the dictator of the vast motion-picture enterprises bearing his name, participated in pool operations while issuing hundreds of thousands of shares of non-voting stock entered into the Senate stock market inquiry today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Attorneys for the Associated Gas and Electric Company moved today in the Federal Trade Commission's hearings on the company's affairs to amplify testimony of Charles Nodder, commission examiner. Mr. Nodder had testified to increases in connection with revaluations in transfers of common stocks of the Staten Island Edison Corporation and the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP). -- The $50,000 added American Derby will be raced at Washington Park tomorrow with Boatswain, 3-year-old son of Man o' War and winner of the Withers Stakes at Belmont Park, the ruling choice to capture the twentyfourth running.

Business conditions throughout the country are more favorable than for many weeks, according to the mercantile agencies. The gains are attributed in part to activities being carried on in anticipation of the increased taxes.
Gene Sarazen is back, Gene and e little jug that goes to the winner the British open championship.

In thirty-eight of the forty-two largest cities in the world the 1931 birth rate decreased as much as 26.9 per cent as compared with the rate for 1930, it was disclosed yesterday in a statistical bulletin published by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

GENEVA, June 17. -- "Commercial aviation so far has progressed on a basis of purely military considerations," Senator de Brouckere of Belgium, chairman of the League of Nations standing committee on air transit, told the disarmament conference air commission today when it began discussing the Spanish proposal to internationalize civil flying as a part of air disarmament.

HERR MAX SCHMELING knocked out a Kingston traffic cop in one of his training bouts. Max must be playing for the autoist vote. Jack Sharkey says he served four years under the American flag with honor, and five minutes under it at the Yankee Stadium brought him national disapproval. He says the mistake was forced on him and he knows now that the American flag is a banner and not a bathrobe.
CHICAGO, June 17. -- A clear-cut prohibition plank will be adopted by the Democratic National Convention, according to party leaders who are beginning to arrive.

No Haste on Summer Clearances. Indications are that a number of retailers will delay their clearances of Summer merchandise this year, in the belief that a considerable volume of business can be done in apparel and accessories until well into July. Additional support was given this stand by the adverse effect of bad weather this week on retail sales, the volume being considerably off as compared with the early part of this month.

Ten-ton army trucks hauling three-inch anti-aircraft guns raced across Long Island yesterday morning. Then puffing tractors nosed the guns into position amid the sand dunes around Fort Tilden and camouflage officers screened the guns against an "enemy" air raid which did not materialize.

While expressing sympathy with the difficulties the city is facing in connection with its public charities, officials of Catholic, Jewish and nonsectarian organizations furnishing free hospital service to the poor were united yesterday in suggesting that "justice" demanded that private hospitals caring for city patients receive at least the $4.50 a day it costs New York City to keep the patients in its public institutions.

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday to reverse the decision of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, and send Owen (Owney) Madden and three other former Sing Sing inmates back to prison for violation of their parole. The court reserved decision.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The bonus bill to issue $2,400,000,000 in new currency to pay World War veterans their certificates in cash was defeated in the Senate by a vote of 62 to 18 at 8:20 o'clock tonight.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 17. -- The text of the resolution adopted by the principal conferees here today follows:

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 17. -- An amazing display of speed by Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association in a 400-yard backstroke record trial featured an invitation water carnival for the benefit of Bellevue Hospital in the seventy-five-foot pool of the Lido Country Club today.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 17. -- The conference for the consideration of German reparations and European war debts took a notable step forward today. As a preliminary to taking up the general problems with which it will try to deal it wiped out some $45,000,000, comprising payments due in July from various European governments, including those due from Germany to other European governments, by "reserving" them "during the period of the conference."

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 17. -- For the second time in two weeks Carlos G. Davila, former Ambassador to the United States, presided over the government of Chile and extremists who had ousted him from the newSocialist regime a few days ago were prisoners.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- In spite of the stress through which the world Is passing, "we are really at the edge of an age of great promise if we but knew it," Dean Christtian Gauss of Princeton University told the members of the graduating class of the Hun School today in his commencement address.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- With the fiscal year rapidly drawing to a close and drastic reductions in Federal expenditures due to be placed in effect July 1, President Hoover moved today to break the deadlock between the Senate and House conferees on the special economy bill by appealing to them to accept the furlough plan for dealing with Federal employes.
PATERSON, N.J., June 17. -- Dr. Thomas E. Manly, Democratic Assemblyman from Passaic County, established today his right to the Democratic nomination for State Senator from Passaic County.

BULLAR NULLAH, Kashmir, June 14 (by runner to Astor). -- Our expedition to set a world record by climbing to the summit of Nanga Parbat, Kashmir's famous 26,630-foot peak, is encamped here in Bullar Nullah -- "nullah" means valley -- awaiting the return of two scouting parties sent out to examine alternative routes for the ascent.

The Public Service Commission issued yesterday a report on its investigation into the accounts and practices of twelve operating companies of the Associated Gas and Electric System serving Staten Island and extensive areas in Western, Central and Northeastern New York State, in which it finds, on the basis of facts disclosed, "that the letter as well as the spirit of the public service law has been violated."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17. -- Roger F. Murray 2d, '32, of New York City was announced by Yale University today as the winner of the John Addison Porter Prize of $500 for his essay "Biography of Thomas Chatterton." The prize is awarded for the best essay on a subject of human interest.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17. -- After yesterday's rush of action and time trials, the rowing colony spent a comparatively restful day today, with nobody going over the course.

LIVERPOOL, June 17 (AP). -- Liverpool's cotton statistics are as follows: British, stocks, 789,000 bales, against 799,000 a week ago, 836,000 two weeks ago, 824,000 three weeks ago and 983,000 a year ago, of which American 394,000 bales, against 399,000 a week ago, 420,000 two weeks ago, 417,000 three weeks ago and 452,000 a year ago.

LONDON, June 17. -- A republic of United Ireland, associated "in some circumstances and for some reasons" with the British Empire and with the King as the head of the association, was the proposal Eamon de Valera submitted to the British Ministers in last week's conferences.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 17 (Canadian Press). -- Sir John Quick, who was deputy president of the Commonwealth Court of Arbitration and Conciliation from 1922 to 1930 and originated in 1893 the plan for a Federal convention to frame the Federal Constitution of Australia, died today at the age of 80.

LAUSANNE, June 17. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's strong lead at the reparations conference yesterday and the successful negotiations which terminated in the drafting and acceptance of the creditors' resolution "reserving" all payments dominated the whole atmosphere of today's discussions.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Issuance by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of an additional $250,000,000 of six months notes to be subscribed by the Treasury was announced by the corporation late today. This brings the total subscribed by the Treasury to $1,000,000,000.

The Summer show at the Jumble Shop, 28 West Eighth Street, will continue until Aug. 1, when a new group will be installed. The pictures now on view have been selected from the four "first of the month" exhibitions held at this restaurant during the season.

The Rev. Edward Roche Hardy Jr., long known as "Columbia's infant prodigy" because he entered that university at the age of 12, will be advanced to the priesthood this morning at 10:30 o'clock at a special ordination service in St. Ansgarius's Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- A sharp disagreement among dry elements over the acceptability of the Republican prohibition plank came to the surface tonight with the statement of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement: "It is by no means a dry victory."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The circumstances under which the Lausanne Conference meets tell a story of opportunities lost and lack of vision on the part of the former Allies. In endeavoring to drain out of Germany the maximum amount of reparations the Allies have now practically forfeited all chances of receiving any reparations whatsoever in the future.

The closing of the Home Relief Bureau to new applicants for relief has compelled many families to turn their children over to private or public child-caring agencies, according to welfare workers, who declared yesterday that while the city is paying about $5 a week to relieve each family in need, it is paying $5 to $7.65 toward the support of each child.

The estate left by Edmund Roebling, who died Dec. 21, 1930, the last of the four sons of John A. Roebling, who drew the plans for Brooklyn Bridge, was appraised yesterday at $13,194,170 net in the transfer tax appraisal filed with the State Tax Commission.
PARIS, June 17. -- The news that has thus far been received from Lausanne has aroused general satisfaction in financial circles here.

Charles Monsolino, the cabinetworker sentenced under a little-used statute in Family Court by Magistrate Jonah Goldstein on June 2 to work at his trade on Welfare Island for six months, was released by Magistrate Goldstein yesterday on his promise to get a $15-a-week job in a dress factory and to pay $10 weekly toward the support of his wife and two children.

SEATTLE, June 17. -- Dr. Josephine L. Peirce of Lima, Ohio, was elected second vice president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at a second election held today following failure to obtain the required majority in yesterday's polling. She received 205 votes to 139 for Mrs. Clarence Fraim of Wilmington, Del.
LONDON, June 17. -- The stock markets finished the week firm, with British Government funds continuing buoyant. Otherwise business was light, but the tendency was favorable.

PARIS, June 17. -- Yesterday's improvement was maintained on the Bourse today, but the volume of trading decreased. Some domestic stocks made further gains, but irregularity developed among the electricals and rentes shortly before the closing. Advances in Wall Street yesterday made a good impression here.

The new 30,000-ton cabin steamship Champlain, said by the French Line, her owner, to be the largest, fastest and most luxurious of her type ever constructed, is to sail today from Havre via Plymouth on her maiden voyage to New York. She is due to arrive here next Saturday with a distinguished list of passengers on board.

One might feel more confidence in the Chilean "counter-revolution" if it were not the work of the army. Military domination has, however, long been not only the curse but the method of political change in too many Central and South American countries, so that it cannot be regarded as altogether irregular and disconcerting at Santiago.
Completing the boy And making a feathery trail for his heart to ride Alluring spaces impossible to shoes, Were thirty varicolored unpedigreed pigeons.

National committees never die. They are like the Senate; in their opinion, doubtless more important. Most of the members are "stayers." Of course, the chairman is personal to the candidate. Mr. HOOVER has had considerable experience in chairmen.

Brokers' reports yesterday indicated an increased activity in leases in the midtown section. The leading outright sale was of the five-story apartment house at 516 East Eightysecond Street in Yorkville. This house was sold by the Manhattan East River Development Corporation to a client of Malcolm E. Smith, broker in the deal.

After holding an advance for several hours, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined yesterday in sympathy with weakness in stocks and grains. An early rise, which followed an improvement in Liverpool, was stimulated by further rains in Georgia and Alabama, but the opening quotations were the best and the list closed at losses of 7 to 9 points.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- The Princeton Board of Athletic Control failed to name a successor to Dr. Charles W. Kennedy, chairman of the board, at its annual commencement meeting today.

RYE, N.Y., June 17. -- At the end of as protracted a semi-final round as the current tennis season has witnessed on metropolitan courts, Donald Frame of Harvard and Harold C. Christensen of the Philadelphia College of Osteopathy gained the final of the Eastern intercollegiate championship at the Apawamis club this evening.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Wholesale commodity prices in May fell 1 3/4 per cent under April's, and were about 12 per cent below those of May, 1931, the Department of Labor announced today.

Seldom can a platform declaration have met with such violent and contradictory comments as the utterance of the Republican convention on the subject of prohibition. This has been denounced as insincere and cowardly. Many hastened to assert that it was the most tricky and hypocritical statement ever drafted.

Although many "vile books" are being published and even some of the "so-called better publishers list them often enough," the "literary situation is improving," according to tie introduction to the current "white list" of books recommended by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee, made public yesterday.
HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 17 (AP). -- Two track records were shattered at Washington Park today as Polydorus and Burning Up captured the feature events.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. have left the Berkshire for Alder, the Thompson country place in Yonkers, and will go to Newport early next month.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 17. -- Lady Mary, the chestnut mare owned by Carleton Tobey of Southold, L.I., today captured the President's Cup, the leading prize offered during the second day of competition at the twelfth annual Huntingdon horse show on the grounds of the Huntington Bay Club.

Tomorrow will be Father's Day in most of the United States. The official slogan this year is "Show Dad You Remember." It was chosen on May 17 by a group of business men and advertising men headed by Sylvan Kronheim, president of the Retail Clothiers' and Furnishers' Association of New York State, Inc.

MERION, Pa., June 17. -- Headed by Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, the Philadelphia women's golf team opened its defense of the Clement A. Griscom Cup by defeating Boston, 11 to 4, over the Merion east course today.

Irving Klein, former Queens Highway Superintendent, was found guilty late yesterday afternoon by a jury in the Queens County Court of falsifying vouchers to authorize illegal claims against the city for payment of more than $6,000 in connection with a contract for 350,000 gallons of road oil.

John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Democratic leader in Brooklyn, conferred with Governor Roosevelt at the home of George Foster Peabody in Saratoga on Thursday, it was disclosed yesterday. National politics in general and the name of the man who is to place Governor Roosevelt in nomination at the Democratic National Convention were discussed at length.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 17. -- Brown University has received a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to finance a research project involving a comprehensive study of the gold standard, it was announced tonight by the president's office.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The decision of the powers at Lausanne to postpone the collection of reparations until a definite program has been evolved by the conference will result in no change in American policy toward the collection of debts owed the United States upon the expiration of the Hoover moratorium year, June 30, it was said here today.

All sections of the money market were quiet in tone and unchanged in quotation. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent, outside loans at 1 and Federal funds 1/8 @ 1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 17. -- T. Philip Parkins, who recently abandoned his amateur status, today returned the best score ever made on the Lido Country Club course. With a 32 on each nine, the former British amateur champion was around the course in 64 strokes, three less than the record held by Wiffy Cox and nine strokes below par.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The State Department said today it was not worried over the latest developments in Chile, where a new government of civilians headed by Carlos G. Davila has overthrown the military government of Colonel Marmaduque Grove.

Fresh liquidation appeared yesterday in the share market, but it failed to assume serious proportions. Indeed, the volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was smaller than in the uncommonly dull market of the day before. There were sharp losses in a dozen or so issues; elsewhere the declines were generally narrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- At the annual commencement of the Princeton Preparatory School held here today diplomas were presented to twenty-five students in the graduating class. The address to the seniors was delivered by Dr. Robert Clothier, president of Rutgers University.

A sharp advance in German Government loans featured dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. German Government 7s touched a high of 55 in the course of the day. closing at 54 3/4, with a net gain for the day of 2 3/4 points, while the 5 1/2s, attaining a peak of 38 1/4, finished at 35 1/2, up 7/8 point, reflecting developments regarding reparations and war debts at Lausanne.
More Passengers on Freighters. Styles in ocean travel have changed rapidly in recent years. De luxe first-class business has fallen off sharply. Second class has almost disappeared.

The Society of Woman Geographers, of which Harriet Chalmers Adams is president, has awarded its first medal to Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, an active fellow-member. Blair Niles, an explorer in the Orient and in South America, was appointed yesterday to bestow the citation of the medal, which reads:

G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, one of the country's leading steeplechase riders, who of late has been trying his luck with mounts on the flat, was accorded a tumultuous reception yesterday at Aqueduct when he won the featured Hanover Handicap astride his own Blind Bowboy.

Regional planning for the metropolitan district may present difficult problems, but is well worth the intensive study that must be given to it. The Regional Plan Association has no official authority and acts only in an advisory capacity. But as it includes many specialists, its publications have a great value.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Without a dissenting vote, the House today passed the Patterson kidnapping bill making the transportation of a kidnapped person across State borders, or to or from a foreign country a felony punishable by imprisonment for such terms as decided by the trial court.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 17. -- One man was killed and two others were injured by lightning this afternoon during a thunderstorm that flooded the streets of the resort, marooned employes of the City Hall and office buildings, and temporarily halted traffic.

Dr. Rivington D. Lord, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Brooklyn, will sail today for Liverpool on the White Star liner Baltic via Boston and Queenstown. Also leaving are Professor Dana C. Munro, Professor E.K. Rand, Dr. and Mrs. R.V. Smith, Mrs. W. Walker, Mr. and Mrs. J.F. Drake, J.C. Jackson, W. L. Peck, United States Consul at Queenstown; Mr. and Mrs. H. Lonsdale and Miss M. Weil.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Income taxes for the last payment of the fiscal year 1932 began to reach the Treasury Wednesday when $11,501,485.54 was received, increasing the total for the month to $34,191,687.92 as compared with $46,528,970.14 for the same period last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- The commencement exercises at Lawrenceville Preparatory School, in connection with the graduation of the 111 members of the class of '32, opened this evening with the annual declamation program in the auditorium of Memorial Hall.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 17. -- If F. Paul Anderson Jr. is to be thwarted in his attempt to win the amateur golf championship of New Jersey three successive years, the one to stop him will have to be Jack Sharkey of Crestmont, who held the title in 1929.

The merger of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation and the Armour Fertilizer Works has been arranged, it was announced yesterday. The assets of the two companies, which are in the fertilizer business, will be transferred to a corporation organized in Delaware and to be known as the Virginia-Carolina Fertilizer Corporation.

A comparative lull in new State and municipal financing is indicated for next week with only $18,867,359 of new issues scheduled for award, compared with $39,065,012 this week. The weekly average for the year to date is $23,006,534. Only four issues on next week's calendar are in amounts of $1,000,000 or more.

New York's "hard-boiled" policemen dug down into their pockets yesterday in response to Police Commissioner Mulrooney's appeal for contributions to the fund for the annual Summer outings given by the department to the city's poor.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 17. -- Gifts and bequests totaling $556,332.12 have been received by Mount Holyoke College from July 1, 1931, to May 31, 1932, according to the report of Miss Gertrude Bruyn, field secretary, details of which will be announced by Dr. Harriett M. Allyn, academic dean and acting president of the college, at the ninety-fifth commencement Monday.

The upward swing of prices for raw sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was brought to an abrupt halt through profit-taking yesterday afternoon, but this was largely offset by a sharp advance in raw sugar in the spot market and a general advance of one-tenth of a cent a pound in the price of refined sugar.

CORNING, N.Y., June 17. -- Members of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers inspected three plants of the Corning Glass Works today, the automatic bulb-blowing machine plant at Wellsboro and the tube-drawing and main plants in Corning.

WERNIGERODE, Germany, June 17. -- A group of eminent German and British investigators into psychic phenomena ascended tonight to the top of the Brocken, Germany's magic mountain, and, in accordance with, ancient rite, attempted to change a billygoat into a young man.

Without any apparent official efforts to check the movement, sterling exchange yesterday broke 3 1/2 cents to $3.61 1/2, the lowest price since March 8, severely punishing speculators and others who lately hastened to switch their funds from dollars into pounds.

GROTON, Mass., June 17. -- Groton School awarded diplomas to thirtytwo seniors at its annual Prize Day today. Professor Henry Fairfield Osborne, president of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, gave the address.
Engineering contracts reported for the month up to June 13 fail to follow the seasonal slump present last year at this time, according to Engineering News-Record.
BOSTON, June 17 (AP). -- Boston's Charlestown district was flag-bedecked today in observance of the "glorious seventeenth," the date of the Battle of Bunker Hill.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Plans for the reception of Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam when she comes to Washington to receive the special gold medal of the National Geographic Society from the hands of President Hoover were completed today.

Mr. and Mrs. David Hugh McCulloch of Harbor Acres, Port Washington, L.I., gave a dinner dance last night at the Central Park Casino to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Alice Fair McCulloch. The hostess and her daughter received in the Black and Gold Room, which had been transformed to represent a Spring garden of daisies, snapdragons and delphinium.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- With a mighty shove of his powerful right arm, Leo Sexton of the New York A.C. sent a sixteenpound shot spinning into the rainsoaked Harvard Stadium turf today for a new world's record of 52 feet 8 3/8 inches to provide the outstanding performance of the first day of the semi-final Olympic tryouts.

Jewelry, to most women, means tiaras, diamond bracelets and similar gewgaws, but to Mrs. Edith Ellis of Detroit, who came to New York yesterday to visit the golden anniversary exposition of the National Association of Master Plumbers of the United States, Inc., which will open June 20 at Madison Square Garden, jewelry means something else.

Despite the fact that some reports from Peconic Bay fishermen have been none too optimistic regarding catches of weakfish during the last few days as compared to ten days ago, the section, nevertheless, remains an excellent fishing centre throughout the Summer and in the Fall months as well.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17. -- Yale's varsity and junior crews had exceptionally light workous today, the morning practice of scarcely a half hour's duration being cut short by a rainstorm.

PRAGUE, June 17. -- Czechoslovakia's probable demands at Lausanne are outlined in the semi-official Frager Presse. In the event of the liquidation of reparations at Lausanne, Czechoslovakia will demand a proportional liberation of her liabilities under the "liberation debt," which calls for the payment of $50,000,000 yearly for thirty-seven years, and a proportional release of her liability to contribute to the funds created to end the optant-agrarian dispute between Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read but was much wearied by your editorial "A Multitude of Counselors." I guess I was just as wearied by editorials of this kind as you evidently are with the "wisdom" of the counselors, although you try to talk of them kindly.

PORTLAND, Me., June 17 (AP). -- The Yankee Division Veterans' Association at the business session today of its three-day convention here, after an hour's debate marked by cheers, jeers and the heckling of speakers, endorsed by a 2-to-1 vote a resolution for immediate cash payment of veterans' bonus certificates.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Plans for the political campaign occupied much of the attention of President Hoover today and practically all of the discussion at the regular Friday Cabinet meeting, which was attended by Secretaries Mills, Wilbur and Lamont, Attorney General Mitchell and Vice President Curtis.

BIRTH rates in most of the Occident are declining. In the United States birth registration area the Census finds that the 1930 rate was 18.9, the same as in 1929 but not up to the 1928 rate, which was 19.7.

The scenes made famous by Burns's poems were recalled yesterday as clans and Scottish organizations commemorated the anniversary of Robert Burns, who died July 21, 1796. Approximately 2,000 persons attended the exercises on Central Park Mall.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 18. -- Members of the Brazilian Davis Cup tennis team were guests of honor at a dinner dance held at Briarcliff Lodge here tonight. The team will participate in a tennis tournament tomorrow with an American team.

The Rev. Edward Roche Hardy Jr., who was graduated from Columbia University at the age of 15, ordained a deacon at 21 and who received his degree of Doctor of Philosophy at 22, was elevated to the Protestant Episcopal priesthood yesterday at the age of 24 at a special ordination service in St. Ansgarius's Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MEXICO CITY, June 18. -- President Ortiz Rubio sent a telegram to the Governors of all States last night asking their cooperation to prevent the adoption of laws for expropriating of private property by the States similar to those enacted by the Legislatures of Vera Cruz and Hidalgo.

HELSINGFORS, June 10, 1932. THE festival of contemporary Scandinavian music given during the last week of May at Helsingfors was the first of its kind which has taken place since the Stockholm festival of 1927. It marked the fiftieth anniversary of the foundation of the Helsingfors Conservatory and Stadsorkester.

HARBIN, May 21. -- All Eastern Manchuria is swept by terrorism. Bandits are overrunning the coun- try, murdering and pillaging without hindrance. Outside the railway zone the new Manchoukuo Government is absolutely without authority. Conditions have been aggravated instead of improved by Japanese military penetration.

No. 1, 437 Yards -- Par 4. Usually a drive and spoon. Bunkers along both sides of fairway. Slope off tee to about 260 yards out aids in getting a long drive. Gradual rise to green. Side-sloping fairway. Green bunkered in front.

MARY GARDEN will sing the title role in the Cleveland Stadium Opera Company's two performances of "Carmen," the first to open its eight-day season on June 29, the second to be given July 4, according to the organization's announcement and that of Miss Garden's concert managers, the Columbia Concert Corporation.

ISTANBUL, June 16. -- The Popular party, which is the sole political party in Turkey, was established by Mustapha Kemal Pasha for the defense of the Turkish Republic, and has for its most important principle State control of the country's chief industrial and commercial activities.

IN South Africa, which yields today more than half the gold of the world and nearly all of the diamonds, there has arisen a constitutional crisis which, if pressed to an issue, would be of far-reaching significance to the African Continent.

DETROIT. THE automobile industry began on 1933 today with the first announcement of a pre-dated model, the new Graham six. The car, a companion to the eight introduced last January, follows the same body design which made the latter one of the outstanding cars of the year.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics made better use of their nine hits today than did the Browns with an equal number, and won their second game of the series, 7 to 6. As a result the Mackmen took second place and the Senators fell to third.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 18. -- F. Paul Anderson Jr., champion of the Canoe Brook Country Club, won the New Jersey State amateur golf championship for the third straight year today, equaling A.F. Kammer's record in winning the title for the years of 1924, 1925 and 1926.
The following copyighted interview with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, by Forrest Davis, appeared yesterday in The World-Telegram:

UNDER capitalist society a man's experience is likely to be a thing he is worse for: it is sure to have been a melancholy and intimidating one. The whole aim of old men is to perpetuate tradition, and it is largely tradition that has landed this country in the position it is in today.

ALL aboard!" It is vacation time. The open spaces call. Time tables are being consulted, suitcases dusted and wardrobes checked. We, too, have been thinking of vacation time, and have scoured the town for suggestions. Here is the information gathered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial on Mr. Coolidge is as timely as you justly say his defense of our official attitude on the war debts was untimely. But it is more than untimely. It is, in important respects, misleading -- not to say untrue.

THE last four years have been marked by a series of momentous international meetings, and the most frequent attendant at these conferences is no single President, Premier or Secretary of State. He is a photographer whose camera lens has looked upon the foremost statesmen of the time in their hours of stress and strain as they struggle with the problems which the World War left in the world.

IT seems to have been a long time since the name of Alexander Scriabine was last brought to the attention of this department. There was a day when one judged that he was very much in demand, when none of the regular lists of unsolicited suggestions reaching us was without its Scriabine item.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 18. -- Harvard's heavy-hitting nine conquered Trinity, 10-3, today in a game marking the opening of commencement week at Trinity.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An econ- omy bill with theoretical reductions of about $65,000,000 in Federal expenditures for the fiscal year 1933, out of a budget in excess of $4,000,000,000, was reported today by Senate and House conferees.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 16. -- With one eye closed, but the other one open in more than usual expectation, Monroe County has altered its blase indifference toward possible political upsets and viewed with some interest the fight to unseat at least two veteran Western New York Congressmen and the latest attempt to wrest county jobs from Republican organization faithful.

High praise of the group of progressive Senators in Washington is contained in "Sons of the Wild Jack- ass," by Ray Tucker and Frederick R. Barkley, released for publication yesterday by L.C. Page Co. of Boston. The book takes its name from the characterization of the group made by Senator Moses of New Hampshire in a speech several years ago.

IN Russia, youth, it seems, is now the first estate. A force of artists lavish their skill on books to tickle his fancy; experts at poster propaganda remind him of the many rights and services for which he may hold his parents accountable; teachers from the kindergarten on consult him as to desirable programs for classes and accept his dictum as given by vote; the government translates its major plans into his language.

DUBLIN, June 18 (AP). -- Ireland looked forward today to next week's Eucharistic Congress. Dublin has been scrubbed and tidied. The streets are garlanded with flowers and gay with pennants and banners. Even the river Liffey, lazing through the city, has been cleansed.

TORONTO, Ont., June 18. -- Extensive geological mapping and exploring is to be carried out in the mineral districts in Northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba and in the Rouyn mineral belt of Quebec this season, according to announcement by the Department of Mines, Ottawa.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 18. -- Likening the present condition of the world to the seething crater of an active volcano, Newton D. Baker, speaking here today at the commencement exercises of Sarah Lawrence College, predicted that a higher type of life would result from the current state of flux.

Bonds to be redeemed in future months before their maturity dates featured the new calls announced last week. Only a few small lots of municipal issues were added for the remaining days of June. The month's total is now $8,851,000, compared with 515.904,000 last month and $86,339,000 in June, 1931, at corresponding dates.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York and Democratic nominee for President in 1938, has under consideration a plan to open his fight against the nomination of his Gubernatorial successor, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, for President, in a speech advocating the election of Jouett Shouse for permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention, in which he intends to charge the Governor with bad faith.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Caleb Rochford Stetson, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Parish, took place yesterday morning at 11 o'clock at Trinity Church, Broadway at "Wall Street, in the presence of more than a hundred clergy, and members of the vestry, lay leaders, members of old New York families, clergymen of other faiths and notable friends and associates of the minister.

Developments which might have been expected ordinarily to invigorate the security markets were passed over, yesterday without any sign of interest. Even the decisive defeat in the Senate of the soldiers' bonus bill failed to arouse any enthusiasm, to judge by the course of trading on the Stock Exchange.
LAUSANNE, June 18. -- Throughout this beautiful Summer day the Lausanne conference rested, took stock of the moiety that has been accomplished and surveyed the greater problems still to be met.

BOSTON, June 16. -- The liveliest political scramble in years is now coming to a close in Maine. On Monday candidates are to be nominated for Congress and for Governor. For the executive office the Republicans have five candidates, the Socialists one, and, mirabile dictu, the Democrats also have five.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 18. -- A mysterious explosion and fire tonight completely destroyed the private yacht of Walter Seligman, member of the New York banking firm of J. W. Seligman Co., and caused severe burns to its captain, John A. Watts, and a friend of his, Miss Audrey Cornwall, 20 years old, of Port Washington.

The executive committee of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners at a meeting in Chicago this week is expected to approve a three-point program which calls for the adoption of an emergency increase of 25 per cent in workmen's compensation rates throughout the country, reduced commissions to agents on premiums above $500 and a plan for retrospective rating through which careful employers will receive substantial rewards.

The average manufacturer in five of the country's leading industries spent a greater proportion of every sales dollar for materials going into his finished product during 1931 than in any other year of the last decade, according to a national survey of the financial and operating statements of 6,000 companies in the steel, iron, bronze, paper and lumber industries, released yesterday by W. Clement Moore, economist and cost specialist.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 18. -- Repeating their performances of four years ago, Johns Hopkins and the University of Maryland advanced to the final round of the American pre- olympic lacrosse play-off today.

TODAY. 1:00 P.M. -- WJZ -- Listeners from coast to coast can eavesdrop on this program which the broadcasters are sending to Switzerland as a sample of typical American radio entertainment. The performers include the Rollickers Quartet, McCravy Brothers, hill-billy songsters; Donald Novis, tenor; the Pickens Sisters, harmony singers; the Doerr saxophone octet, and organ melodies.

THE Board of Estimate's approval of municipal operation of the city's new independent Subway system by the Board of Transportaion brings nearer to conclusion a seven-year effort to relieve the congestion in rapid transit on the west side.

If disarmament conferences have made little progress in curtailing military and naval establishments, they have been all but stationary in prohibiting or limiting the use of gases. A battleship or a machine gun has its specific military uses, but there is no chemical compound which is not more essential in the pursuit of some peaceful art than in the waging of war.

In democracies such as ours and others it seems unavoidable that sometimes there must be, on the part of the governmental leaders, a certain amount of effort to bamboozle the public. Little is to be gained perhaps by assessing the blame for this circumstance.
MADRID, June 17. -- It is being recalled here that it was General Primo de Rivera's six-year dictatorship in Spain that set off by force of example the long-gathering revolutio'n in South America.

BEFORE the end of this fiscal year the airway network of the United States will comprise 19,500 miles. The aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce, under the leadership of Colonel Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary for Aeronautics, has already built and equipped 17,500 miles of airways.

PIRANDELLO has perhaps been taken a bit too seriously, at least in America. The reviewer is reminded of an incident during the run of "Six Characters in Search of an Author" a few years back. A young lady who met one of the cast at a tea said to him:

Legal assistants and associates of Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, began preparing yesterday analyses and summaries of the mass of testimony which has been taken by the committee looking toward the time when the members of the body will begin writing their report to the Legislature.

Those who are classed among the tennis devotees of the Metropolitan District, and especially those who follow with interest the action in many at the West Side Club at Forest Hills, L.I., are still talking about the superb play of Miss Eleanor Goss in the recent Sears Cup matches.

The ports toward which the slim prows of their shells have been pointing all through the season and evei since the start of training last Fall loom just ahead for the oarsmen of all except three of the colleges in this country which sponsor rowing.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 18. -- Mrs. Charles F. Hubbs's Chestnut mare Clover Leaf captured the rosette in the class for grand champion horse or pony at the Huntington show today. The class was one of the features of the last program of the three-day show, which was held on the grounds of the Huntington Bay Club.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 18. -- The annual Ivy Day program at Smith College opened with the alumnae parade this morning, reviewed from the steps of the library by President and Mrs. Neilson and Dean Marjorie Hope Nicolson.

SHANGHAI, May 21. -- Japanese Legation and consular officials are complaining bitterly because of the renewal of anti-Japanese agitation, a revival of the boycott, and charge that the Nanking Ministry of Education is openly propagating hatred of Japan in Chinese schools and colleges.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Testimony that William Fox profited secretly by $322,960 in one of several pools involving shares of Fox Thestres. Inc., was put today before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, which at the conclusion of the hearing unexpectedly brought its examination of his stock operations to an end.

With less rain throughout the South than at any other time in the last three weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost further ground yesterday and closed at losses of 2 to 3 points. July opened at 5.08 cents, or more than 20 points under the high levels of the week, but week-end covering reduced the loss.

George V. Van Tubergen, 43 years old, for the last twenty years a purchasing agent for twenty International Standard Electric Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself in the right temple in the washroom on the fourteenth floor of the company's building at 67 Broad Street.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 19. -- Mes- sages from Changchun, the capital of Manchukuo, announced that the government today had issued a statement declaring its intention to take over all customs revenues collected in Manchuria, including those received in Dairen.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18. -- Goweil Claset of Montreal shut out the Bears, 1 to 0, today to even the series and stop Newark's winning streak of four straight. He allowed only five hits and struck out six men. Don Brennan allowed the Royals eight hits.
COPENHAGEN. WITH his new volume of "Myths," the fifth in the series, Johannes V. Jensen once more vindicates the art form, the modern myth, which he has made happily and distinctively his own.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- The Penn Athletic Club Rowing Association won the championship in the seventy-ninth annual Schuykill Navy Day regatta on the Schuylkill course in Fairmount Park today. The Undine Barge Club, last year's titleholder, took second honors, with the Malta Boat Club third.

The reorganization of Copper Exporters, Inc., the single selling agency outside of the United States for copper producers both in this and foreign countries, is imminent because of changing marketing conditions created by the enactment of the 4-cent import duty on copper into this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once more the season has arrived when agriculturists as well as amateur gardeners wage war against cutworms and other pests of all descriptions. How is it that our country is hit by certain insect pests which hold no terror for European countries?

The Institute of International Education announced yesterday the names of forty-six American students who have been chosen to receive fellowships for graduate study in Germany during the next academic year by the American German Student Exchange.

Now that the great rush for reentry permits made by resident aliens wanting to go to Dublin for the Eucharistic Congress is over, the Department of Labor in Washington is trying to clear up the long list of similar applications of other aliens, which have been delayed in some cases for weeks.

THE Little Kingdom of Gilpin County is athrob with new life. Ghosts, haunting the gulches, are disturbed by unfamiliar activity in the long-deserted tunnels of famous gold mines. There is a smell of new boards; steam plumes into the cool, late Spring air, and the pulse of machinery beats an efficient rhythm.

STRONG support for those who maintain that security for any nation lies in powerful aerial arms is to be found in the failure of the air commission of the world disarmament conference at Geneva to agree on what are the most dangerous of the new air weapons now at hand.

George Mapother, 18 years old, who would have teen graduated this month from the Brooklyn Vocational Training School, was found dead last night, hanging by a clothes line from a steam pipe in the cellar of his home at 105-15 Farmers Avenue, Hollis, Queens.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. THE week saw the beginning of the Summer cinema doldrums. Warner Brothers prepared to close entirely until Aug. 1; others indicated less active schedules for the next few weeks; a few made a brave effort to be "as busy as usual."

MOUNTAIN LAKES. N. J., June 18. -- Esten Boiling, engineer and authority on heating and ventilation. was found dead from a self-inflicted gun-shot wound here yesterday, in the living room of his Yorke Village home. One of three letters he had left bore the caption, "Thoughts of a Man About to Commit Suicide."

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Bank debits outside New York during the week ended June 11 were higher than in the two preceding weeks, but continued below those of the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

Asserting that welfare organizations knew that certain defects in the Senate Democrats' relief bill would defeat the purpose of the measure to provide loans to States for relief of distress arising from unemployment. Allen T. Burns, executive director of the Association of Community Chests and Councils, sent a letter yesterday to Chairman Henry B. Steagall of the House Banking and Currency Committee and submitted several suggestions to improve the bill.

BISHOP HALL, who died two years ago, gave long and devoted service, thirty-six years, to the episcopate of Vermont. And before that he had been for almost a quarter of a century an equally devoted Mission Priest of the Society of St. John the Evangelist.

First steps in the formation of a State budget survey committee, to operate on a plan similar to that worked out for the Citizens Budget Commission for New York City, were taken yesterday by J. Irving Walsh as president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards.

The illustrated catalogue of American Historical Prints from the Phelps Stokes and other collections, consisting chiefly of views of American cities, which has just been published by the New York Public Library, appears appropriately in this bicentennial year. The frontispiece in colors shows New York as WASHINGTON knew it from the North River

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Seeking to expedite provision of funds for immediate relief of the unemployed, President Hoover tonight summoned to the White House four leading members of the House Banking and Currency Committee for conference on the Senate Democrats' relief bill recently passed in the upper branch.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 18. -- Mistaken identity was said by the police today to have caused the shotgun murder Wednesday night of Bernard Ernest. 19 years old, of East Hampton. Two witnesses were held in bail in connection with the crime this afternoon and tonight Justice of the Peace William Vaughn of Sag Harbor issued a warrant, charging homicide, for the arrest of Matteo D. Greggorio, operator of Matty's, a bathing pavilion near Sag Harbor.
About 200 persons will attend the dinner in honor of Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam to be given at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

LONDON, June 18 (AP). -- Mrs. Eivira Dolores Barney, socially prominent defendant in the "cocktail shooting case," collapsed at her arraignment today during the reading of love letters exchanged by herself and Thomas William Scott Stephen, whom she is accused of murdering.

Credits and collections in LatinAmerican countries continued to improve through the second quarter of the year, according to the current analysis of conditions in twenty-one South American nations completed yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

BERLIN, June 6. -- The occupational complexion of the new Frussian Diet shows as the most outstanding change a great increase in the number of agricultural representatives. There are sixty-two of them, forming the largest occupational group with the sole exception of the "Beamtenschaft" -- the civil servants -- which has seventy representatives in the Diet.

OTTAWA, June 16. -- The next eight or ten weeks will show whether the British Empire is to set the world an example in economic recovery through the Imperial Economic Conference which opens here on July 21 or whether this meeting, carrying so many high hopes, is doomed to failure through the conflicting interests it represents.

THE country most famous for its arts maintained upon a high plane for several centuries is also the country in which physical development was a constant and supreme interest, and the athletic sports making special demands upon such development achieved a fame that has continued undiminished.

BURNS has been singularly unfortunate in his editors, his biographers and his critics, and particularly in those who immediately after his death assumed the guardianship of his fame. It is almost ludicrous to watch so essentially masculine a genius in the hands of the timorous, respectable mediocrities who had the first shaping of his "legend."

DALLAS, June 16. -- Unless legal steps are taken to prevent it, Texas Democrats will vote on resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment in the July 23 primaries. Until then the already intense Summer heat will be accentuated, by wet and dry campaigning.

Summer dresses in cottons, sheers and prints in the lower price ranges continued fairly active, although comparatively little general buying developed in the wholesale markets during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

The properties of the Midland Natural Gas Company and the Twin States Natural Gas Company will be offered for sale at public auction in Charleston, W. Va., on July 2 at 10 A.M. and 10:30 A.M., pursuant to final decrees of the Chancellor of the State of Delaware and of the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, W. Va., entered in the cases of both companies.

Long reviled as the author of all of the troubles which may overtake an unwary customer in the stock market, the specialist finds himself at last deprived of valued privileges. By the action of the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange his market activities are sharply circumscribed.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities of the United States showed a further average decline of 2 1-3 per cent during the month ended April 15 and were 16 1/4 per cent below their average on the corresponding date last year, according to the monthly survey of the Department of Labor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18. -- The Sarah Wey Tompkins Memorial Pavilion was officially opened today at the New Haven Hospital. The new unit provides 139 beds for surgical and obstetrical patients. Funds for the new pavilion, were provided in a bequest to Yale University by Mrs. Sarah Wey Tompkins, whose father, Dr. William C. Wey, for a half century served the community of Elmira, N.Y., as a physician and surgeon.

PARIS. ATER having gone in for rainbow color schemes, Paris seems to be returning to her old loves -- black and white. At the opening of the Ambassadeurs, always one of the sartorial big nights of the Spring season, the best dressed women appeared in either black or white, or a combination of the two.

VIENNA, June 4, 1932. FORTY THOUSAND Viennese watched Mme. Jeritza make her debut on the football field tonight, when, to open the Vienna Festival Fortnight, she sang for the first time in the open air on the Hohe Warte, a sports stadium on the hills overlooking Vienna.

SPEAKING to an Anglo-American conference of historians, J. Ramsay MacDonald, the British Prime Minister, said: "There are great misunderstandings regarding British colonial policy in North America in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, because our historians have had a Whig bias.

WHEN Senator Hattle W. Caraway presided over the august upper house of the United States Congress the other day she broke an old tradition and established a new one. She became the "first woman who" had ever presided over the Senate, and almost immediately thereafter she surprised her constituents by announcing that she would run for re-election.

PARIS, June 11, 1932. THE music of Igor Markevitch, aged 19, will figure on the programs of at least three of the leading orchestras of America next season. The composer, a Russian born in Kiev July 19, 1912, heard the music of Mussorgsky at the age of 7 and, as he told us, was impressed.

MOSCOW, June 17. -- The decree allowing collective farm members and individual peasants to trade freely at the bazaars has been in effect more than a month, but the general supply of foodstuffs and other goods has not increased appreciably.
CHICAGO, June 18. -- Gusto, a thoroughbred by every right, today won the $50,000-added American Darby, to the astonishment of 30,000 spectators at Washington Park.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 18. -- Savanola, owned by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark of Westbury, L.I., ran a great race to win the Raceland Cup Steeplechase, which featured the Eastern Horse Club's annual visit to the Raceland track today.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Four major struggles, the results of all of which are in the balance, will be fought out behind closed doors and on the floor of the Democratic National Convention which will assemble here one week from tomorrow. They are:

WEATHER conditions reduced retail trade again for the week and slowed down activity quite materially from the level attained earlier in the month. Summer apparel and accessories were bought, but the demand was of an immediate character and values were shopped very closely.

A NEW opera, "Tom-Tom," is scheduled for its world premiere with the Cleveland Stadium Opera Company June 30. According to Denoe Leedy of The Cleveland Press, the composer, Miss Shirley Graham, is a young Negro musician who has directed intimate opera in Howard University and is now doing graduate work at Oberlin College.

OF all the regions within easy motoring distance of New York City few are more interesting historically than the New England coast line, especially that portion of it that lies in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

LAKELAND, Fla., June 16. -- Because Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen has represented Florida with such gracious dignity there is tremendous disappointment that she must step aside as a member of the House of Representatives. Many of her thousands of outspoken admirers have gone so far as to describe her defeat as a calamity.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18, -- Candidates endorsed by the Socialist party for Congress, the Assembly and county offices, were announced here today by the Westchester County Committee of the Socialist party. Morris Berman of Pleasantville, who was a delegate from WestChester County to the recent National Socialist Convention, reported the proceedings at a meeting of the county committee on Thursday night.

Conservationists have watched with increasing concern the growth of a new public domain. The areas which compose it might be called second-hand lands, or, in more modern parlance, "used" lands. The latest figures, compiled by the Federal Bureau of Agricultural Economics, show the rapid acceleration of this back-to-the-States movement in the West.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- President Hoover announced today that he would limit his part in the Presidential campaign to a few addresses and that the conduct of the campaign would be entrusted entirely to Chairman Everett Sanders and the Republican National Committee.

Proposals that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation engineer a scheme whereby railroad bonds would be bought at current low levels, thereby stabilizing a class of investment constituting large holdings by savings banks and life insurance companies, have been, discussed favorably in Federal Reserve and other banking circles in the last few days.

With "Profitable Volume by Maintaining Quality Standards" as its theme, the joint convention of the sales promotion and merchandise managers' divisions of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will be held here on Tuesday and Wednesday in the Hotel Commodore.

Seventy-eight contestants, included among them some of the leading players in the metropolitan area, will tee off tomorrow at the Tamarack Country Club, Port Chester, in the qualifying round of the annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association championship.

An unofficial battle between the food and drug trades over which group should distribute alcoholic liquors, if, as and when the Volstead act is modified or the Eighteenth Amendment repealed, provided a hot weather topic in those lines last week.

The Merchants' Association of New York, a pioneer among those organizations dedicated to the upbuilding of the business of the community, will celebrate its thirty-fifth anniversary on Tuesday. It was founded on June 21, 1897, when a group of nine men met at 108 Leonard Street to frame its organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- The East's Olympic stalwarts went on parade again in the Harvard Stadium today in the semi-final track and field tryouts, and in a series of brilliant performances completed the meet with world's, American and Olympic records to their credit in eleven of the eighteen events.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP). -- A fight against the confirmation of the reappointment of T.V. O'Connor as chairman of the Shipping Board was opened in the Senate today by Senator McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee.

Berkeley Bell of New York opened defense of his Eastern clay courts crown yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club and defeated Winthrop Emmet of Forest Hills in the second, round after drawing a bye in the first. The former Texan won by 6-2, 6-2.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- While the sale of tickets of the Republican National Convention failed to meet the expectations of the citizens' committee, which guaranteed a fund of $150,000 for it, the committee expects the Democratic National Convention to be a "sell-out."
Time's hands are now pointing toward another national open golf championship, this one the thirtysixth under U.S.G.A. auspices, proving that the game has gone a long way in this country.

The protective committee as an institution in the field of municipal finance, although well known for generations to holders of foreign loans and domestic corporation bonds, has now assumed a role of major importance, particularly in the case of over-bonded communities in the State of Florida.

Frederick J. Lyke, an attorney, was appointed receiver by Supreme Court Justice Humphrey in Brooklyn yesterday to conserve the assets of Michael T. Watts of 65 Central Park West, Manhattan, who is affiliated with M.T. Watts, Inc., operators of a chain of gasoline stations.

More than 300 "amateur skippers," ranging in age from 6 to 16 years, rigged their craft in a sailboat contest of the Bureau of Recreation of the Department of Parks, held yesterday on the conservatory lake in Central Park. This was the feature event of the annual children's day program.

Clergymen in their sermons today will discuss the religious and moral aspects of the National Republican Convention in Chicago last week. Prayers will be offered today for a blessing upon the Democratic Convention, which opens June 27. In Roman Catholic churches there will be prayers for a blessing on the International Eucharistic Congress, which will be held in Dublin, Ireland, beginning Wednesday and continuing four days.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The House passed an amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation act today providing that $50,000,000 be made immediately available to the Secretary of Agriculture for loans to farmers who suffered crop failures in 1931, and for live-stock production, poultry and dairy farming, or crop planting or cultivation.

BERLIN, June 17. -- Chile's leap into State socialism is being watched in Germany with the alertness natural to a people who themselves live atop a volcano. It is wondered where next in Latin America the tension will reach the bursting point. The Chilean upheaval is regarded here as notice to the industrial world that its stubbornness and lack of cooperation are paving the way for bolshevism.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18. -- After long deliberation over six splendid canine specimens, Alva Rosenberg of Brooklyn this evening awarded to Check Von Hunenstein the ribbon signifying the highest honors at the third annual bench show of the Greenwich Kennel Club held on the grounds of the Greenwich Polo Club.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 18 (AP). -- The Standard Oil Company of Indiana sued in Federal court here today to enjoin the Standard Oil Company of Kansas from directly or indirectly using the name Standard Oil Company of Kansas or any other similar to that of the complainant in thirteen States.

THE bathroom and the kitchen are experiencing a radical change in appearance. This is due mainly to the beauty and convenience of the new sinks, bathtubs and other fixtures which are appearing, glorified by entrancing colors and smart designs.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- By a viva voce vote, the House today approved the Carley bill authorizing the Postoffice Department to acquire the present temporary postoffice site at 452 Lexington Avenue, New York City, for a permanent office building.

HELPING the pedestrian "step on the gas and apply the brakes" -- the new thought in traffic regulation -- became more than a gesture when the city of Philadelphia recently introduced a safety innovation known as the pedestrian signal.

Generally steady prices and quiet trading characterized the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the two-hour trading period. German Government bonds continued their upward movement, the 7s gaining 1 1/4, points and the 5 1/2s, 1 1/2 points. German bank issues closed up a halfpoint to 1 7/8 points, but German State and corporation issues showed irregularity.

Manufacturers enjoying established contacts with chain store organizations have suffered less in the depression than those catering to other types of distributers, Harold Everts, Eastern district sales manager for the A. J. Kitchen Tool Co., said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- James C. White, a close friend of Calvin Coolidge and for many years political writer on The Boston Herald, died today at the Chastleton apartment of Major James F. Coupal, who was White House physician under President Coolidge. His age was 56.

LONDON, Sunday, June 19. -- Nothing that Eamon de Valera has done in the last four months has irritated the British public so much as his refusal to accept arbitration in an empire court on the disputed land annuities which the Irish Free State refuses to pay.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 18 (AP). -- A rebellion in the Chilean air force, intended to restore Col. Marmaduque Grove to the governing power from which he was ousted yesterday, broke out today, but the government declined to acknowledge its existence.

BERLIN, May 26. AT such a time as this it is doubly hard to produce plays with a political tendency, for they will appeal only to a part of the audience and will arouse the rest to indignant protest. But the young author Eugen Gurster seems to have found the right mixture.

THE theme of the following chapters" says the author in his introduction, "is the background of nineteenth-century expansion which has placed America in a position whereby it is vitally concerned in the issues now at stake in the Far East.

PARIS, June 17. -- Once again the French press is attacking the United States as if the country were an enemy of mankind generally and France particularly. Choice words, such as usury, hypocrisy and stupidity, are being thrown out by the dozens in editorials seeking adequately to describe for French readers the American attitude on disarmament and reparations.

BROOKLYN MUSEUM -- Four exhibitions opened last Thursday and will remain through the Summer, closing Oct. 3. These are: A miscellaneous group; a selected group of Chicago painters; a memorial exhibition of drawings and masks by Edward I.R. Jerinings and water-colors by Signer and Signora Carlandi.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18. -- Action as a taxpayer by Mrs. Dorothy D. Furry, a Republican county committeewoman here, for a permanent injunction in the Supreme Court in White Plains restraining John P. Nestler, City Treasurer of New Rochelle, from paying the salaries of City Manager John F. Donovan and three other officials was commenced today with the service of complaint and summons upon Mr. Donovan.

ANDRE STEEMAN is a young Frenchman who was the winner of the Prix du Roman d'Adventures of 1931. In this novel, competently translated by Rosemary Benet, he tells a tale of six young men who have made a pact that each of them will go abroad to seek his fortune and that all will share equally, at the end of five years, in the results of this quest.

AMHERST, Mass., June 18. -- Portraits of President Arthur Stanley Pease and the late Senator Morrow were presented to Amherst College at the annual alumni dinner today. Edward T. Esty, '97, of Worcester, on behalf of a group of alumni presented the portrait of President Pease.

SHANGHAI, May 22. -- Amazement is being expressed in all foreign circles here over the fact that the Chinese municipal authorities of Greater Shanghai have lodged formal and bitter complaints because the International Settlement and the French Concession spent considerable money repairing roads outside the foreign-controlled area, damaged when the Chinese and Japanese were fighting early last Spring.

PROBABLY even in this country the name of Walter Wilkinson is not unknown to readers who like happy-golucky, gossipy chronicles of "the open road." Impresario of marionettes in extraordinary, wandering chaperon of Judy and her Punch, Mr. Wilkinson has contributed two friendly and enticing books in "The Peep Show" and "Vagabonds and Puppets."

Thomas H. Dowd, a veteran Democrat of Salamanca, Cattaraugus County, has been selected by Governor Roosevelt as the man to place him in nomination before the Chicago convention, according to reports current in local political quarters yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- A delegation of a score or more, headed by Mayor A.J. Cermak, D.F. Kelly, Fred W. Sargent and Ernest R. Graham of the Citizens' Committee, will appeal to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation next Tuesday for millions with which to keep the local governments operating.

SUMMER promises this year to offer more than the customary quota of warm-weather art entertainment in New York. As previously noted in these columns, several galleries that usually close when the "regular" season is over are keeping open.

THE loftiest object in New York City, as compared with surrounding street levels, is the weather vane lately installed at the top of the Empire State Building, 1,265 feet above the pavement. In the same comparative sense it is the highest-placed weather vane in the world, and it is likewise one of the least conspicuous.

MR. CARHART knows his Colorado, knows it and loves it, knows it thoroughly and loves it enthusiastically. And so he has written a book about it that is far and away different from any ordinary guide book, or history, or description.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- The issue of Tammany corruption, as revealed by the investigation of the government of New York City by the Hofstadter legislative committee, may be raised here by Samuel Seabury, whose reservation of a suite at the Drake Hotel, beginning Sunday, June 26, became known today.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A twoyear loan of $10,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company was conditionally approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company has made greater progress in the last two years of depression than in the preceding two years, according to A.Y. Tuel, operating vice president, and developments are being pushed so that the company will be ready to handle a larger proportion of business when conditions improve.

The New York Stock Exchange has announced the receipt of notice from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, depository for the issuance of American shares of capital stock of the Rhine-Westphalia Electric Power Corporation, that it has been advised by the Dresdner Bank, its agent in Berlin under the deposit agreement, that Article I of the Eleventh Decree of the German Government relating to foreign exchange regulations provides as follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., June 18. -- Trinity College's new chapel, costing more than a million dollars, largely contributed by William G. Mather, '77, of Cleveland, was dedicated today with impressive ceremonies attended by an audience that included Governor Cross, eight Episcopal Bishops and hundreds of alumni here for commencement week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to the letter of Edward Peale, I would say that "Davy and the Goblin" is not forgotten.

THE Ford Motor Company's "truck week" opened yesterday at Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street and will continue through June 25. A new line of trucks and commercial cars designed to meet the transportation requirements of merchants, manufacturers, contractors, farmers and others is on display.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Operations in manufacturing establishments of the country were on a curtailed basis during May, according to the monthly bulletin of the United States Employment Service.

WITH an orderly bonus army bivouacked in the shadow of the Capitol and reinforcements putting hot and dusty miles behind them in every section of the country, no class of men are watching these events with a sharper interest than the national and local leaders of the American Legion.

MEXICO CITY, June 18 (AP). -- At least three persons were reported killed and more were feared dead in a heavy earthquake that shook Central Mexico from coast to coast early this morning causing severe damage.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Politics held the centre of the stage this week, particularly as to the part the wet and dry issue will play in the approaching election. Meeting at Chicago to renominate President Hoover and Vice President Curtis, the Republican National Convention adopted a resubmission plank which, although widely assailed as a straddle, marked the erection of another milestone in the retreat from nation-wide prohibition.

AS a test of the progress of the American Republic in the century's span which separates the celebration of George Washington's one hundredth birthday from the celebration of his two hundredth birthday, it is interesting, and it may be instructive, to try to dust off the picture of New York in the '30s of the nineteenth century.

DESPITE provocative speeches and inspired press stories from both Moscow and Tokyo, Soviet Russia and Japan are still at peace. Their armies face each other on the Manchurian-Siberian border in the direction of Pogranitchnaya.

With the announcement last week of new regulations governing the specialist system, and of a reduction in commissions on low-priced bonds, the New York Stock Exchange has continued its policy of making improvements and reforms in its trading machinery, as called for by changing conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- With the prohibition plank in the Republican platform continuing to be the major subject of political discussion in the lull before the Democratic convention, dry leaders are for the most part reserving their opinions until after the Democrats act.
