The city has been forced into the policy of municipal operation of its new subway system because the Board of Estimate has done nothing, in the last five and a half years, to promote rapid-transit unification, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, declared yesterday.

THE tiny lapel microphone introduced at the Republican National Convention eliminates all need for the heralded microphone technique on the part of speakers, according to the Columbia Broadcasting System. Speakers unfamiliar with the technique of the conventional stationary microphone often mar the broadcast by turning their heads away from the instrument or by straying a few feet from the electrical ear.

Textile High School's baseball team retained the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship by defeating James Madison High of Brooklyn, 2 to 1, yesterday before 20,000 at the Yankee Stadium. The Manhattan nine annexed the title for the sceond successive season to give Textile its third city P.S.A.L. crown of the 1931-32 school year.

WHERE should the child receive his sex education -- at home, school, church or in camp? Probably at all of these, says the latest pronouncement on the subject by the White House conference on child health and protection, with the fundamental responsibility shared by home and school.

LONDON, June 18. -- Declaring that no workable plan can be framed at the Lausanne reparations and debts conference without help from the Geneva arms parley, Wickham Steed, British publicist, suggests a way of furthering the disarmament proceedings by substituting a new agreement in place of Article XVI of the League of Nations covenant, which he declares is impractical.

PARIS, June 3. -- The cool weather and the month of official mourning for President Doumer somewhat retarded the usually brilliant Paris social season. But now the calendar is filled with mundane and sporting events until the Grand Prix, which is the climax of the season and falls on June 26, after which the usual Summer dispersion takes place.

The third annual Eastern intercollegiate outboard championship regatta to be held at Skaneateles, N.Y., on Friday and Saturday has attracted an entry of forty drivers from about twenty-six colleges and schools.

ELBERON, N.J., June 18. -- Adding 620 points today to the lead of 2,095 they had built up last night, the "Four Horsemen" contract bridge team reached the halfway mark in their duplicate match at the Deal Club here with a Cavendish Club quartet headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt with a total advantage of 2,715 points.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. de Forest Grant have gone to Whileaway, Bar Harbor, for the Summer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- The New York A.C. could do little with Billy Reynolds, formerly of Dayton University, today and lost to the Penn A.C. in an Eastern Athletic Club Baseball League game 8 to 1.

To the accompanying roars of a gallery of 25,000, the Giants tried mightily yesterday to continue their recent spectacular drive toward the top in the National League pennant race, but at the end of a long afternoon at the Polo Grounds they found themselves in fifth place with absolutely no gain to report.

RICHMOND, June 16. -- Virginia has just witnessed the most astonishing State Democratic Convention held within its borders in a quarter of a century. It was a convention which probably would have gone for repeal if loyalty to former Governor Harry F. Byrd had not led many wet delegates to favor his referendum plan instead.

NEW YORK STATE is progressing with its plan, initiated two years ago, of placing a living wall instead of bricks and mortar around its paroled prisoners. When a convict passes out through the prison gates, having served his minimum sentence and received time off for good behavior, he is no longer alone in the world with a railroad ticket, a suit of clothes, and a $10 bill.

In the Canadian Summer resort literature the Magdalen Islands, midway between New Brunswick and Newfoundland, where the Gulf of St. Lawrence is broadest, are almost unnoticed. They have a bad record for shipwrecks. Rev. EDWIN SMITH, who writes about them in the June Canadian Geographical Journal, states that "the death toll amounts to thousands."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18. -- About 450 seniors will receive diplomas at the 185th commencement exercises of Princeton University here Tuesday. The graduation will climax the annual commencement and alumni festivities, which began on Thursday.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 18. -- The hard-riding, hard-hitting Yale four, with its brilliant mallet wielders in excellent form, defeated Harvard, 13 -- 9, today at the Rye Turf and Polo Club to capture the intercollegiate polo championship.

Savings of from 20 to 50 per cent are possible in expense reduction of printing and packing supplies by department stores and other users, according to R.W. Greve, president of R.W. Greve Company, Inc., supply consultants. The process starts, he said yesterday, with the determination of the minimum utility requirements of each item and includes the origination of complete purchase specifications and a cost pre-determined on the basis of thorough knowledge of costs involved.

MERION, Pa., June 18. -- New York's team of women golfers today recaptured the Clement A. Griscom Cup, symbolic of tri-city supremacy, by defeating Philadelphia, 9 to 6, in the final matches. Boston was eliminated in earlier rounds of the play over the Merion links.

IT will surprise the gentle reader to be told that the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, is in truth an innocuous as well as ancient fraternity, more concerned with patriotism and pane- gyrics than with politics, patronage or plunder. Yet such, paradoxically, is the fact.

A nurse and four young women employes of the Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital, Cumberland Street and Greene Avenue, were menaced by pistols yesterday morning while three young hold-up men ransacked the main office of the institution and escaped with a strong box containing valueless papers.
RYE, N.Y., June 18. -- All the honors in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships went to Harvard today.

PREPARATIONS for filming "Island of Lost Souls," from H.G. Wells's fantastic adventure story, "The Island of Dr. Moreau," were initiated at Paramount last week. Charles Laughton, the English stage player who was recently won over to Hollywood, will have the weird role of the doctor who discovers how to make animals talk.

NO MORE gratifying example of the combining of the camera and the microphone has been revealed on the screen than in "The Doomed Battalion," the present film at the Rivoli. And in addition to the impressive views and sound effects, there are also the much-desired elements of restraint and truth in the story.

PARIS, June 18. -- Premier Edouard Herriot returned to Paris this morning and within a few hours got unanimous approval of his actions at Lausanne from his cabinet. The press and the public generally are equally satisfied, for as M. Herriot, who talked freely to newspaper men after the cabinet meeting, emphasized more than once, France has "preserved full liberty for further action without any pledge or commitment."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 18. -- Dr. John Livingston Lowes, Francis Lee Higginson Professor of English Literature at Harvard University, delivered the address at the annual convocation of the Graduate School of Brown University in Sayles Hall here today.

Declines in security prices have compelled the Pennsylvania Railroad to pledge almost three-fourths, or about 73 per cent of its control in the Long Island Railroad to bolster the collateral behind Pennsylvania Company 4 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1963, according to an announcement by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP). -- A proposal that the Federal Government issue currency to cities in exchange for municipal bonds as an aid in dissipating strained money conditions has been approved by the city Board of Estimates.

LOS ANGELES. A DOZEN miles southwest of the business centre of Los Angeles, overshadowing the vast motion picture factories of Culver City, rises a cluster of grass-grown hills. In Summer their treeless slopes are sun-baked a deep brown, but their round tops, looking down to the Pacific, five miles away, are cooled by morning fog and afternoon trade winds.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 18. -- Funeral services were held today for William R. Huntington of Rutherford, who died suddenly yesterday in his sixty-seventh year.

TWENTY-SEVEN lecturers will be heard in the course on contemporary literature to be given this year in the Columbia University Summer Session. John Erskine, Joseph Auslander, Professor Horace A. Eaton and Professor Allan Abbott will lecture on contemporary poetry; Zona Gale, Will Irwin and Hamlin Garland on contemporary fiction, and John Golden, Professor Hatcher Hughes, S.L. Rothafel and Clayton Hamilton on the present-day theatre.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 14. -- The first Communist riot took place here recently after a meeting in the offices of the General Union of Workmen and Communist Club. It soon became apparent that there would not be room enough for the large crowd which quickly gathered, and those who could not get in the club remained in the adjacent streets.

NEWARK. N.J., June 18. -- Marching Peter, gray pacer owned by Ed Mansfield of Hoboken and driven by John Lawrence, and Wilbur D. Blood's great 3-year-old trotter, Del Hanover, romped off with the feature events at Weequahic Park today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18. -- Yale defeated Princeton by 6 to 3 in ten innings today to win the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. Johnny Broaca kept the Princeton hits well scattered and struck out twelve Tiger batsmen.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 16. -- Skirmishes between wet and dry forces in Oregon are now furnishing plenty of interest and keeping the public keyed up during the hiatus between the primary campaigns and the general melee this fall.

NO record of the season would be complete without a review of the accomplishments of the Dance Centre in its first year of activity. Just when that year will come to its formal conclusion it is difficult to tell; for, like all young organizations that have not quickly floundered into premature obscurity, it is a little obstreperous when it conies to abiding by schedule.

ALL his long life Sir J. Arthur Thomson has lived in intimate association with the things of which he writes. They have been the objects of his daily observation, the constant subjects of his thoughts, the matters of which he wrote and talked, the themes of his years upon years of teaching.

The country with its institutions, belongs to the people who inhabit it. Whenever they shall grow weary of existing government, they can exercise their constitutional right of amending it, or their revolutionary right to dismember it and overthrow it."

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Eastern longs were credited in trade gossip with having sold out lines of wheat at the opening today on the Board of Trade, but the pressure so much in evidence on Friday was lacking. Lowest figures of the day and for the season were made around the start, but they ran into short covering and buying against weekly bids.

PITTSBURGH, June 16. -- Proposed by John M. Phillips of this city, former chairman of the State Game Commission and noted conservationist, and backed by two former Governors, John S. Fisher and John K. Tener; newspapers and a number of civic and welfare bodies, a back-to-land plan for Pennsylvania is being prepared for presentation to the expected special session of the Legislature as one of the measures for dealing with unemployment.

SINCE its inception in 1914, the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee has carried on, through agencies estabished in Poland, Latvia, Rumania, Austria and other districts in Central and Eastern Europe, reconstruction work which has met with impressive success.

One for All. MR. ROY H. FAULKNER, vice president of the Studebaker Sales Corporation, has the floor. This platform is yielded to him this week. For he has something to say. He wouldn't pretend that his message is original in its thought.

WHEN in the brief compass of fifteen thousand words a novelette gathers to itself all the richness and force of a fullbodied novel, and adds to that a delicacy entirely its own, a high point in the development of the short narrative form has been attained.

Blenheim, the Wheatley Stable racer which last year ran second to Twenty Grand in the Dwyer Stakes, captured the famous $10,000 added Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday at odds of 4 to 1. The result was something of a surprise, but the disappointment was the dull showing of the Fox-Catcher Farm's White Clover II, which ran last in a field of seven.

PELHAM, N.Y., June 18. -- Brig. Gen. William Dorrance Beach, U.S. A., retired, a veteran of the Spanish-American War, who commanded the Eighty-eighth Division in France during the World War from May to August, 1918, died tonight in the Mount Vernon Hospital of a heart attack with which he had been stricken in the afternoon while out motoring with a sister, Miss Sarah E. Beach of 141 Loring Avenue, Pelham.

WHEN New York's charter was drafted, government by political machines had to be taken for granted as an unavoidable feature of the American scene. Since then, however, many American cities have seemingly found escape from machine rule by the adoption of a new schema of government so simple in its mechanism that the voters can and do perform their function at elections unaided by machines.
LONDON. THE Times Literary Supplement takes Edward J. O'Brien's collection of "Modern American Short Stories" as the text for some interesting comments on recent developments in this field.

PARIS, June 17. -- Close on repudiation of the government's proposed quotas for Hollywood films by the French movie theatre owners, those very industrialists whose interests the recent restrictions upon foreign imports were intended to protect now are condemning this policy as ruinous to France's export trade.

NEGRO children in New York, living in greater congestion than children of their color anywhere else, have been made the subject of a special study by Owen H. Lovejoy, secretary of the Children's Aid Society. In a report issued not long ago Mr. Lovejoy described them as the greatest sufferers today from the effects of unemployment, and set forth some things the city can do to make their lot easier.

BYRON'S quip can still provoke a smile, after more than a century. But, like much other debunking, it matters little after all. For its only consequence is that it gives something to smile at, while many things that Bishop Berkeley said and did were of such vital importance that the power of them lives to this day and is likely to last for many centuries to come.

The first semester of the Institute for Adult Education of the De Witt Clinton High School, Mosholu Parkway and Navy Avenue, the Bronx, was concluded Friday with exercises at the school's auditorium at which certificates were presented to 105 women who finished 147 courses.

The annual meeting of the Advertising Federation of America, bring- ing several thousand leading figures in the advertising world from every part of the United States and foreign countries, will open officially this morning with the registration of delegates at the Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16. -- A retrospect of the political events in the days preceding the arrival of California's delegation at Chicago shows how large the prohibition question looms in President Hoover's own State. Sentiment here is like that in every other State -- divided.

PANAMA, R.P., June 13. -- Changes in the Cabinet of President Olaya Herrera before the opening of the regular session of the Colombian Congress on July 20 are suggested by newspapers and reports brought here from Bogota and other cities. Colombian editors have been discussing this subject for several weeks, although it may be that such discussions are based largely on political rumor.

Without comment Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh accepted a subpoena yesterday morning in the Morrow home at Englewood, N.J., directing him to appear as a witness for the defense in the trial of John H. Curtis, scheduled to start a week from tomorrow at a session of the Common Pleas Court at Flemington, N.J.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA. Inc. LONDON, June 18. -- The questions of policy and principle propounded in the recent speeches of the principal delegates to the international conference on disarmament at Geneva raise far greater issues than were at first contemplated.

THE sense of impending calamity which must dominate the scenes of a murder mystery story on the screen may be created in the furniture and settings, says Lloyd Bacon, who recently completed the new Warner mystery, "Miss Pinkerton," which follows "Winner Take All" at the Strand.
AMHERST, Mass., June 18. -- Effective hitting in the pinches and sensational fielding gave Amherst a 5-3 victory over Dartmouth today before a colorful commencement crowd.

ROME, June 17. -- Any one who may be seeking arguments in favor of private enterprise as against the nationalization of industrial activities should examine the figures in recent years of the progress of the telephone services in Italy.
LONDON'S safe deposit vaults, in one of which Queen Mary recently stored her valuables. are often used for odd treasures.

Many, young Americans arrive in France, fresh from one to eight years studying French, only to find themselves completely baffled by the most commonplace remarks of porters, taxi drivers, waiters and policemen. And their own carefully thought out questions are equally unintelligible to the French.

GENEVA, June 17. -- Only cursory interest in party conventions in the United States is being shown among the foreign diplomats, financiers and journalists whom the Arms Limitation and Reparations Conferences have brought to Lake Leman -- less than might be expected from the class of men who specialize in foreign affairs.

THE rise of musical activity in Yugoslavia since the war, and the turning of its composers and younger musicians to national material, is commented upon in the Central European Observer in the following article:

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Republican reaction, here to Dr. Butler's reported drive to repudiate the Republican prohibition resubmission plank was just what might have been expected. Drys and conservatives of the party jeered at the proposal, while the wringing wets hailed it with glee.

INVESTED capital in broadcasting ranges from $15,000 for a ten-watt station to $200,000 for a fifty-kilowatt installation, according to the Federal Radio Commission's statistics. Reports submitted by 558 stations show an invested capital of $36,845,045.

Wall Street took scant interest in yesterday's sluggish share market, as the extremely small volume of trading on the Stock Exchange indicated. In point of total turnover, it was the second slowest market of the year, involving a total of only 341,000 shares.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., June 18. -- If there is such a thing as the law of averages Jack Sharkey is counting upon it to win for him the world's heavyweight championship from Max Schmeling in their fifteen-round bout Tuesday night at the new Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 18. -- After a farewell review of the Tenth Coast Artillery and the Second Battalion of the Thirteenth Infantry at Fort Adams this morning, Lieut. Col. John Scott, U.S.A., who has been in command of the post and the Narragansett Bay defenses, but will leave soon for new duties in Chicago, had a busy social program.
HANOVER, N.H., June 18. -- The senior class at Dartmouth College occupied the spotlight today as the group of 424 carried out its commencement ceremonies.

THE prohibition question in the United States is entering upon a new phase. This has been clearly indicated by recent events -- notably in the adoption of a modification-resubmission plan, by the Republican National Convention, following close upon unofficial polls which showed an unmistakable wet drift and upon the conversion to the anti-prohibition cause of a number of leading former drys, including John D. Rockefeller Jr.

FOR every student who went to college in the United States in 1890 there are now more than ten. The college population, that is to say, has increased five times as fast as the total population. If education responded to the law of supply and demand as other commodities do the purveyors of it in its collegiate form might well congratulate themselves, for their goods have maintained a market even during these present troubled times.

TRENTON, N.J., June 18. -- Branded by former Governor Edward C. Stokes as "unworthy of the great party of Abraham Lincoln and Theo- dore Roosevelt," the prohibition plank written into the Republican platform at Chicago this week is regarded by political observers here as having materially weakened whatever chance President Hoover may have had of carrying New Jersey next November in his fight for reelection.

BERLIN, June 18. -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler has relinquished his post of musical director of the Baireuth Wagner Festival performances. The reasons which have been, made public, as governing his retirement, are "fundamental differences with Frau Winifred Wagner, who, in contradiction to the agreement reached last year, demands a deciding, voice also in matters artistic."

FROM a casual traveler who recently encountered Gilbert Miller not too far from his St. James's Theatre in London comes the information that Mr. Miller's opening production over here in the Fall probably will be "While Parents Sleep!" Despite that early A.H. Woods title, the play is a light farce with some diverting complications, and is attracting its share of business in London, where Leon M. Lion, is its producer.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Held to two singles by the veteran Ted Lyons in the first six innings today, the Yankees resorted to strategic baseball in the seventh, sending home one run with a bunt and scoring another on a double steal to account for the margin of their 4-to-2 victory over the White Sox in the third game of the series.
READING, Pa., June 18 (AP) -- Emery Zumbro's pitching gave the Reading Keys a fourth straight victory over the Rochester Red Wings today, 7 to 3.

WITH the enclosure on May 28 of the famous old Zuyder Zee, a new chapter in Holland's national life began. The face of the country has changed, and when the project of draining the great body of water shall have been completed 500,000 acres of arable land will be thrown open, causing agriculture to supplant the prosperous fishing industry which was the livelihood of many coast dwellers.

Four armed young men, who had overpowered a watchman by a ruse, held up eleven employes in the cashier's office of Drake's Bakeries, Inc., at 71 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, one block from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, at 6 o'clock last night, obtained all available cash, amounting to about $8,500, and escaped in a gray sedan driven by a confederate.
CLEVELAND, June 18 (AP). -- Mel Harder limited the Boston Red Sox to four hits today as the Indians pounded the offerings of Andrews and Jablonowski to take the second game of the series, 9 to 2.

Butter. Receipts, 12,889 packages. Friday's decline did not bring out much buying support and the market declined another 1/2c Saturday morning. Offerings pretty free and distributing trade light. Some speculative buying on the basis of 16 1/2c for extras; the long attractive lines command 1/2c more.

ALMOST since man was man one lure above all others has made him abandon his own hearthside, plunge into deserts and jungles, cross unknown seas and mountains, and brave human enemies, wild beasts and death by hunger and thirst.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 18. -- The 265 members of the graduating class joined this morning with 500 Mount Holyoke alumnae, including the classes of '71, '72, '07, '22 and '30, in the first alumnae-senior parade and fete of the college, combining the events held separately in previous years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In perusing the "Life of Samuel J. Tilden," by Theodore P. Cook, I ran across a letter written by Mr. Tilden when he was a candidate for Attorney General of New York. At the time the letter was written the prohibitionists were in power, the Know-Nothings were steadily gaining strength and the Democrats were divided and appeared to be losing ground rapidly.

BERLIN, June 18. -- The Boerse firmer but inactive today, with the public still holding back from the market. The liveliest trading was in the mining section. Bonds were dull and weak, except the Young loan, which was stronger. Money, rates were unchanged.

The Census Bureau statistics relating to births and deaths in 1930 show a slight actual increase in the number of babies born alive, the birth rate remaining practically the same as in 1929 (18.9 per thousand), though lower than the 1928 rate. The deaths for the same period were fewer than the births by more than a million (1,321,367), representing a death rate of 11.3 per thousand as compared with the birth rate of 18.9.

SECONDARY education appears to be at the end of an era. The National Survey of Secondary Education, which completes its three-year comprehensive study of American high schools on June 30, discloses that many important developments in this field of education are rapidly coming to a climax.

The expense of maintaining Ivy Hall, the Jericho (Long Island) es- tate of the later Elbert H. Gary, who was head of the United States Steel Corporation, must be paid from the widow's share of his estate instead of from his estate as a whole, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday in reversing a decision by Surrogate Howell of Nassau County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eliot Tuckerman continues bravely in his crusade to change the construction of the "two-thirds rule," so that two-thirds of the members elected to each House of Congress would be required to propose amendments to the Constitution or override a veto, instead of only two-thirds of the members present.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP). -- A machine that measures the ravages of erosion, which already has ruined 21,000,000 acres of once productive American farm land, has been developed by the Department of Agriculture.
HELSINGFORS, June 6. -- The system of "restricted liberty" provided by the new Finnish drinking law came into operation early in April, but it is not working very smoothly.

THE radio industry is more jubilant. June, the month that presents diplomas, wedding rings and perfect days, has added a championship prizefight and two national political conventions as good measure this year. And radio is delighted because few events stir greater interest and enlarge the invisible audience more than a fistic encounter or political oratory in a Presidential arena.

Perhaps the Connecticut fishing mystery will be solved today. Some of the clues which can be used by anxious anglers who have been "seeking" three six to seven pound brown trout released in the waters of the State on April 4 were furnished to the public at large by Eben Cobb, field superintendent of the State Board of Fisheries and Game yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP). -- As the keynote statement of his personal activities during coming months, President Hoover's words today carried with them wide implications. Barring unforeseen developments, they limited the radius of his movements largely to the White House grounds and the comparatively brief distance to his camp in the Virginia mountains.

A TEXAS ECONOMIST. IF there exists any unanimity of opinion concerning the Hon. Wright Patman, LL. B., of Texarkana, Texas, and Representative from the First District of Texas, the common ground of understanding would be agreement that Mr. Patman is unlike many a Congressman in that every one knows where he stands.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 18 (AP). -- Suit to recover $29,266 of the $34,000 salary and bonus paid Jerre L. Dowling of New York, who became president of the People's State Bank of South Carolina six weeks before it closed on Jan. 2, has been filed by the receivers in Federal court here.

POUGKKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 18. -- With the big crews of the colleges entered for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on Monday more or less resting on their oars, today's excitement turned to the substitute boats, which are called "pickle boats" and which have been holding races of their own before the big race in recent years.

CAMERIDGE, Mass. CAPITAL and labor, art and industry, human relations and market analysis, in fact most of the antitheses which are generally accepted in the world of business, are finding new, correlated niches in the field of business education.
BALTIMORK, June 18(AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles defeated Toronto in both ends of a double-header today, 5 to 4 and 5 to 0. The first game went ten innings, the Orioles winning on Rothrock's error.
GROTON, Mass., June 18. -- Heading back through New England, Governor Roosevelt stopped over here tonight to greet his sons after conferences with Colonel Edward M. House and Mayor Curley of Boston.

THERE is a merry battle wagin between the great transcontinental airway systems of the country for business. The airlines are offering faster schedules, particularly mall and express schedules, than was thought possible five years ago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16. -- Unless something comes along to spoil the picture between now and the time when the Democratic National Convention gets to the business of choosing a candidate for President, Ohio is in the position of offering four men and maybe five as possibilities.

BERLIN, June 18. -- Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, new German Chancellor, spoke to his country for the first time tonight over the radio from Lausanne. He appealed to all Germans to support the government's stand at Lausanne and pledged himself to insist on all points vital to the national existence of Germany.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 18 (AP). -- An opinion in Federal court today dismissed the bill of complaint filed several months ago by the Moffat Tunnel League of Colorado and the Uintah Basin Railroad League of Utah against the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company.
WASHINGTON. WHEELS are turning in two great factories night and day while more than 2,000 persons work overtime to produce one of the smallest articles manufactured -- postage stamps.

CARACAS, June 13. -- President General Gomez has issued a decree ordering officials to take energetic action against inordinately high prices of foodstuffs. The decree, which is characteristic of the General's method of dealing with otherwise impossible problems, is addressed to Presidents of States and Governors of Territories and reads:

THIS author has the gift of writing historical tales that hold the attention of boys and girls. Filling in his background accurately, he nevertheless understands how to keep from overburdening his story with too many descriptive details.

PRINCETON, N.J. June 18. -- Confidence that the international crisis would be solved, and that one of the most hopeful signs in that direction was the increasing number of "sober and responsible young men" of the new generation, was expressed this afternoon by Bainbridge Colby of New York City, Secretary of State under President Wilson, in the founders' day address at the annual commencement today of Lawrenceville School.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- For whomever may have a little lively imagination, Washington today recalls ancient Carthage. Beyond the city, on the banks of the Potomac, in the immense marshy field of the tributary, Anacostia, 17,000 men are encamped just as, in ancient times, were the mercenaries of Hasdrubal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tonight after supper while drying the chinaware which my sparrin' pardner washed, I says to myself I'll write a piece to THE TIMES calling Henry Ford, who says one can make a living at farming, by offering a section of my 300-acre farm to any city slicker who's impressed with that idea, first injecting a few observations as to past and present-day farm conditions.

LONDON, June 3. IS it not exceedingly strange that the poorer we become the more plays are brought to the theatre and the more expensively they are produced? On a Sunday in the near future -- Sunday being a day of theatrical rest -- five new pieces are announced for production in London; here is abundant proof that the theatre is not dead.

LET us look at the younger Rockefeller as he is to be seen in New York any day of an ordinary week. At the usual hour of 9:30, or thereabout, an automobile stops at 26 Broadway and a man steps briskly onto the sidewalk.

THIS author has the gift of writing historical tales that hold the attention of boys and girls. Filling in his background accurately, he nevertheless understands how to keep from overburdening his story with too many descriptive details.

PRINCETON, N.J. June 18. -- Confidence that the international crisis would be solved, and that one of the most hopeful signs in that direction was the increasing number of "sober and responsible young men" of the new generation, was expressed this afternoon by Bainbridge Colby of New York City, Secretary of State under President Wilson, in the founders' day address at the annual commencement today of Lawrenceville School.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- For whomever may have a little lively imagination, Washington today recalls ancient Carthage. Beyond the city, on the banks of the Potomac, in the immense marshy field of the tributary, Anacostia, 17,000 men are encamped just as, in ancient times, were the mercenaries of Hasdrubal.

LOS ANGELES, June 18 (AP). -- Prank Wykoff returned to the cinder paths today after a siege of illness and, with the old-time fire of his sprinting career, ran the 100 meters in the world's record-equaling time of 10.4 seconds.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A belief that the Irish Free State, because of business considerations, eventually will accede to the demands of Great Britain for preservation of the oath of allegiance to the Crown and for continued payment of the land annuities is held by many economically minded officials in Washington.

THIS novel follows a more or less familiar pattern, but it is written with so much beauty and freshness that it seems, while one is reading it, to be alone of its kind. It is primarily a novel of locale, and nothing in it is so important as the feeling of a particular place that it conveys -- the atmosphere, the color and activity, the sights and sounds of an Irish home.

Arundel Corporation -- Five months ended May 31: Net profit, after depreciation. Federal taxes and other charges, $600,593, equivalent to $1.22 a share on 492,556 no par capital shares, against $871,106, or $1.76 a share, in first five months of 1931.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18. -- For the third time in three days Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup creation Vanitie today defeated Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe, the sloop that many times took the measure of the cup defender Enterprise.

Shifting Purchasing Power. Now that the difficult job of increasing taxes has been accomplished I trust that the statesmen are enlighted enough to realize that these taxes will not restore jobs to the millions of unemployed. What they will accomplish, is to feed the army of government workers.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Elvin Seibert of New York City, now on duty in the State Department, has been assigned as Vice Consul at Southampton, England.

Except for its plank on prohibition and it apologia for hard times, replacing a claim to Republican-guaranteed prosperity, the platform adopted last week at Chicago will not seem to many-readers to differ greatly from that of four years ago. The promise to establish agriculture on a "parity" with industry is repeated in the same vague language used at Kansas City.

LAUSANNE, June 18 (AP). -- A final reparations settlement, without any guarantee from the United States that war debts would be canceled or revised, was being prepared today by the great powers represented at the Lausanne conference. This information was obtained from quarters well informed about what the leading European nations are planning.

WE meet under the shadow of the most ominous economic crisis which has ever afflicted the world in time of peace. The whole world looks to us as it has never looked to an international conference before. The world looks on not only in need but in impatience.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Business conditions improved little if any in most of our foreign markets covered in the current weekly analysis by the Commerce Department.

Morris Hillquit, national chairman of the Socialist Party, last week assailed the Republican, platform adopted at the Chicago convention as a declaration of political bankruptcy" which deprives President Hoover and his party of any claim to the support of the American people.

UNDER the terms of a local bill recently laid before the Board of Estimate for consideration, it is proposed to reduce the age limit for policewomen recruits to 29. The present admission age for policewomen is between 30 and 40 years, and for patrolwomen between 21 and 35 years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Everybody knows that some kinds of dust may explode, but how many know that this is the case with practically all dust except that of earth or stone? Ordinary household sugar would seem to be a safe commodity, but an explosion of sugar dust in a factory not long ago killed twelve men, injuring twenty-seven, and did more than $1,000,000 damage to the property.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The economies in Federal expenditures for the fiscal year 1933, beginning on July 1, as contained in the bill reported out by House and Senate conferees today, compared with the savings in the bill as passed by the House and the Senate, are listed unofficially as follows:

IN the heavyweight realm Herr Max Schmeling calmly considers himself the Man of Destiny, and Jack Sharkey has the sullen belief that he is the Man of Misfortune. As a heavyweight championship bout approaches, usually the talk is all of the champion. He is the magic figure in the "fierce light that beats about a throne." The challenger, the coming conqueror, lingers in the shadow as the great event is neared.

BEVERLY, Mass., June 18. -- Miss Gertrude Binney Smith, 59, of Amesbury, an artist well known for her landscape and marine work, was instantly killed here today when she jumped or fell from a train which she had boarded by mistake.

HOLDERS of prize-winning tickets in the Argentine State lottery who have failed to collect their winnings are responsible for making the Club Gimnasia y Esgrima of Buenos Aires one of the best equipped sports organizations in the world.
DETROIT, June 18 (AP). -- Detroit got the best of a battle of hits today and defeated Washington, 14 to 11, in the third game of the series. Washington used five pitchers and Detroit three.

IT is unfortunate for his book that Mr. Freeman was persuaded to use so misleading a title. For what he has written is no dithyrambic chant of the carnal and conventional order about brown princesses and South Sea Edens. but a pithy, entertaining and vigorous book about his experiences in Siam as editor of the Bangkok Daily Mail, King Prajadhipok's own paper and organ.

Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, on Tuesday night will defend his title against the man he defeated for the crown two short years ago on a foul. The German is to battle Jack Sharkey, Boston exsailor, in a fifteen-round bout in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City.

Importers of lame, metal thread, metal cloth, articles made of bronze, vitriol and any other goods containing 4 per cent of copper, will be affected by the new copper tariff and should make an immediate study of Section 601 of the new revenue act. James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., Inc., customs brokers, warned here yesterday.

PROHIBITION Commissioner Woodcock's recent statement that there are 3,844 places in New York City where intoxicants can be obtained, in contrast to the 32,000 estimate made by former Police Commissioner Whalen a few years ago, emphasizes the difficulty in reconciling the various figures put out dealing with the liquor question.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Charges that President Hoover objected to calling an international conference on silver and that that was the reason why the monetary plank adopted at the Republican National Conference did not frankly urge such a step by this government, were made by Senator Pittman, Democrat, of Nevada, on the Senate floor today.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- With the bonus army shaken by the Senate's overwhelming defeat last night of the proposal for the payments of $2,400,000,000 on their compensation certificates, but with its morale still unexpectedly high, the communistic elements opened a determined campaign today to enlist the disappointed veterans under their own banner.

AMHERST, Mass., June 18. -- The report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that a new public domain is being created in the United States by the growing tax delinquencies of the last two years does not apply to Massachusetts.

Claims of support for Jouett Shouse for the post of permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention from the Garner forces are being made here by friends of the executive chairman of the national committee. In addition delegates from States pledged to Governor Roosevelt, but not bound on other questions, are being claimed.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Lack of leadership on the part of President Hoover, not "wicked stubbornness of Democrats in Congress" was responsible for the delay and lack of performance incidental to the balancing of the national budget, according to Jouett Shouse, executive chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who in a radio speech tonight, broadcast over the Columbia network, presented a critical survey of the Republican National Convention and the platform it adopted.

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, notorious Brooklyn racketeer, and his 7-year-old daughter, Jean, were shot shortly after 1 o'clock this morning when gangsters attempted to wipe out the entire Higgins family as they were leaving the Knights of Columbus Clubhouse, Prospect Park West and Union Street, Brooklyn, where the little girl had taken part in a school entertainment.

RECENT excavations near modern Nablus have resurrected an old biblical city, Sichem, and the greatest Canaanite stronghold ever unearthed in Palestine. In the chain of ancient fortresses -- Jericho, Beisan, Ta'anach, Megiddo -- Sichem was the most formidable.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 18. -- If Max Schmeling loses the heavyweight championship of the world in his fight with Jack Sharkey in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on Tuesday night, it will not be because of any flaw in the champion's physical condition or make-up.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 16. -- Announcement of the tentative program for the sixth Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia, to be held July 4 to 16, is receiving, especially in Virginia, a good deal more attention for what it does not contain than for its customarily variegated menu of thought-food.

VIENNA, June 17. -- The English and American bankers and bond buyers who have invested in one way or another the equivalent of about $1,000,000,000 in Southeastern Europe have been brought, by events of the past week, nearer realization if not admission that a good part of this money is lost.

THE Alpine war setting in "The Doomed Battalion" at the Rivoli is taken almost completely out of the experience of Luis Trenker, who wrote the story and acts in it. He was born in the little town of St. Ulrich, in Austrian Tyrol, just two hours away from where the mountain war scenes in the film were filmed and which he directed.

LIMA, Peru, June 18. -- The cruiser Durban, flagship of the British South American squadron, which has its headquarters at Bermuda, arrived in Callao Bay early this morning. After official visits were made the cruiser refueled and is standing by pending orders to proceed southward to protect British interests and lives in Chile.

Activity in the sugar market was the outstanding feature of the local commodity exchanges last week. It was the most active week in a year, with the raw product swinging higher than the futures. There was a better sentiment in coffee, cocoa and rubber.

Dr. Butler's interview on the Republican dry-wet plank, page 19. Republican leaders of the States along the Eastern seaboard, home yesterday after the Chicago convention, privately admitted that the plank on prohibition contained in the Republican national platform would prove a handicap in their wet constituencies, particularly if a more definite and wetter plank is adopted by the Democrats at their national convention.

Frank K. Sturgis, former Stock Exchange president, president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and a former chairman of the New York Jockey Club, who died on June 15, left $55,000 in cash bequests to four public institutions and the residue of his estate of several million dollars to the "Winifred Masterson Burke Relief Foundation.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 19 -- Matteo D. Greggorio, proprietor of "Marty's", a bathing pavilion near Sag Harbor, was arrested today on a charge of murder in the first degree for the killing of Bernard Ernest, 19 years old, of East Hampton as Ernest was driving an automobile along the Old Castle Road near Sag Harbor.

Nearly 10,000 constituents of "His Honor, the Mayor of Borough Park," Morris Morrison, the first "Locality Mayor" of Brooklyn, cheered yesterday morning as Louis Zeltner, "Lord Mayor" of Manhattan and the Bronx and the founder of the League of Locality Mayors, presented to Morrison his badge of office on the steps of the Borough Park Talmud Torah, Forty-fifth Street and Ninth Avenue, after a parade.

LONDON, June 19 -- Thousands knelt on the floor of one of London's grimiest railway stations today to greet Cardinal Lorenzo Lauri, Papal Legate, on his way from Rome to the Eucharistic Congress in Dublin.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 -- Rufus (Lefty) Meadows pitched a no-hit, no-run game as the Bears defeated Montreal, 8 to 0, in the second game of the double-header today before 15,000. Newark also won the first game, 4 to 2. The contest lasted seven innings, in accordance with the International League rule covering second games of double-headers.

Having captured three second places to two for the Salem Crescent A.C., the Millrose A.A. yesterday won the team trophy in the second annual Manhattan Athletic League outdoor track and field championship meet held at Macombs Dam Park.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Wheat prices are so low that only the pit traders are selling it short, except cash handlers in the Southwest, who are the only ones furnishing moderate selling -- against purchases of the grain in the interior. At the same time prospects for good profits for a good advance in the near future are too uncertain to invite buying.

A six-point program, designed to remedy the evils at the roots of modern American democracy, was proposed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman in his sermon at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary of New York City, speaking at the baccalaureate services in the Wellesley College Memorial Chapel today, urged the seniors to make the most of the adversity that awaits them outside the campus gates.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- While Congressional leaders laid plans to renew the struggle for relief legislation the Joint Committee on Unemployment announced tonight that seventeen organizations with a total membership of 6,000,000 would formally demand tomorrow that a relief program be written into law before Congress adjourned.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- Declaring that the prosperity enjoyed by the United States in other years had collapsed because it was "structurally unsound," Dr. John Grier Hibben, president of Princeton, said in his baccalaureate sermon here today that he felt serious concern for the members of this year's graduating class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prohibition is no longer a liquor issue. It has become a menace to good government and good morals and threatens to undermine goodwill among our people and between the several States. It has been clearly demonstrated during twelve years of trial that beer, wine and liquor for beverage purposes cannot be eliminated.

Pointing out that the steel industry is taxed to maintain its present operating rate of about 17 per cent, the magazine Steel, in its weekly, review of the industry, says prices on finished steel are holding remarkably well and not in years has the industry been making so determined a stand.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- What the world needs now "more than anything else" is the "reinforcement of young and generous souls." the Rev. Frederick M. Eliot of Unity Church, St. Paul, declared today in the baccalaureate services of Radcliffe College in the First Church, Congregational, of Cambridge.

Seldom in the history of public service regulation in this State has any utility been arraigned so severely as the Associated Gas and Electric system in the latest order and report of the Public Service Commission. Fortunately, the excesses complained of are not typical of holding companies generally.
An exciting finish marked the soccer game at Hawthorne Field yesterday when the Hakoah All-Stars and the German-American League team played for the Good-Will Trophy donated by Nathan Straus Jr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your leading article today captioned "Hoover and the Democrats" you state the necessity for the Democrats to nominate a stronger man, or, as you put it, "the Republican convention at Chicago played a high trump in nominating Mr. Hoover.
HANOVER, June 19 -- At the second reunion here of veterans of German cavalry regiments good-will message was received from the ex-Kaiser. It was signed "Wilhelm I.R."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- By the time the graduates now emerging from colleges have worked their way to positions of authority in the public service, in business, in the professions, better conditions will have come back, President Abbott Lawrence Lowell predicted in his baccalaureate address at Harvard University today.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Harvesting of Winter wheat in the Southwest moved northward at a normal rate during the past week. Threshing returns in parts of Texas exceeded early expectations and Oklahoma yields are said to be of fair average.

PARIS, June 19 -- Premier Herriot entrained for Lausanne tonight, satisfied that as far as he has gone France is overwhelmingly behind him. Joseph Paul-Boncour, who preceded him, was delayed by a train wreck on the line and reached Geneva by automobile to resume the disarmament negotiations which, ac- cording to opinion here, are becoming linked ever more closely to the debts problem.

As a member of the Administration Secretary MILLS accepted and carried through with his usual vigor the prohibition plank, though it didn't represent fully his personal views and was stoutly opposed by the great majority of the New York delegation.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 19 -- Following tradition, only the seniors of Smith College heard the baccalaureate address delivered today by President William A. Neilson and the text of it was for them alone.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 19 -- The opening of the Maidstone Beach Club for the season attracted many Summer residents and their weekend guests. More than 100 had luncheon in the club's newly decorated lounge.

LONDON, June 17 -- An interesting development of the week was the Bank of England's step appointing protective bondholders' committees for loans issued under the auspices of the League of Nations. The difficulties encountered by those borrowing countries have been due either to the raising of loans disproportionate to their economic status or to the fall in world prices, which has increased the burden of the debt payments to an extent unforeseen.

Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Forces for Prohibition, issued a statement yesterday on the attitude of the organization toward the plank on the prohibition question adopted by the Republican National Convention.

Two man-eating blue sharks, which are usually found in tropical seas, were sighted just west of the Grand Banks by Captain O. Scharf, master of the North German Lloyd liner Stuttgart, which arrived yesterday afternoon from the Channel ports. He said the sharks were fully 25 feet long and their fins were two and a half feet above the surface of the water.
Plans for the reception by the city, ncluding the greeting at City Hall by Mayor Walker and the confetti-showered parade up Broadway, of Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam were completed last night.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Earle Combs, first batter in today's game at Comiskey's Park, scored the only run of a keen pitching duel between Young John Alien of the Yankees and the veteran Sam Jones. Combs walked, took second on a pass to Ruth, and scored after two out, on Chapman's single to left centre.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 (AP) -- A move to put the "fair play" rules of sport into the conduct of big business was sponsored here today by Francis P. Garvan of New York, a Yale alumnus and a leader in the American chemical industry.

LONDON, June 17 -- London financial markets have displayed an undertone of quiet confidence throughout the week. This was based on reviving hopes that something would be accomplished at the Lausanne conference; but public interest is still restricted.

FRANKLIN, Pa., June 19 -- The greatest recent spurt in business here, with scores of orders likely to remain unfilled before the time limit expires, will end for local refineries tomorrow. Every refinery in this section worked through the week-end with extra shifts and overtime forces trying to keep pace with last-minute telegrams and telephone calls.

The North Baptist Church in Greenwich Village, so named because it was once the most northerly church of that denomination in New York City, celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of its present building in West Eleventh Street between Waveriy Place and West Fourth Street.

The 3,500 volunteer workers in the Salvation Army's United Appeal for funds will open the sixth week of their campaign today, encouraged by the financial report of James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the drive.

BALTIMORE, June 19 (AP) -- Baltimore moved into first place in the International League by taking both ends of today's double-header from Toronto, 8 to 2 and 10 to 1. The batting of Buzz Arlett was the feature, the Orioles' big left-fielder driving two home runs in the first game and adding another in the nightcap, giving him thirty-one for the season.

A turning to God is the prime need today in the world depression, the Rev. Dr. Clifton Macon declared in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, of which he is the senior assistant rector.

A scientific analysis of New York City's real estate and taxation structure is to be made for the Equitable Assessment Association by the Institute for Economic Research, it was announced yesterday by R.V. Calder, president of the association.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- With the bonus army still standing its ground here and admitting few defections, notwithstanding the Senate's defeat of its $2,400,000,000 demands on Friday, Federal authorities tried today to devise some peaceable strategy to get the ex-service men out of town.

BERLIN, June 17 -- Business circles on the whole have received favorably the financial reform proposals of the Papen Cabinet, that no new direct tariff should be imposed and that social benefits should be reduced. The program was sharply attacked as "anti-social" by opposition politicians, but their criticism was hampered by the fact that Papen's measures were in principle identical with those which Bruening himself had proposed immediately before his resignation.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics and the St. Louis Browns broke even in a doubly header today, giving the Mackmen three victories in the five-game series. The Browns won the first game today, 3 to 2, then lost the second, 6 to 3.

PARIS, June 17 -- The index number of prices during May on the Paris Bourse, as published this week, is 220, comparing with 250 in April and 322 in May of 1931. Separate groups of securities make the following comparisons:

GENEVA, June 19 -- In an effort to force action at the Geneva Disarmament Conference, Senator Claude A. Swanson, United States spokesman, is understood to have made it very clear to British and French leaders today that Washington would not easily abandon its plan for limiting arms effectives, especially when being asked to cancel war debts.

Professor Albert Einstein, Dr. John Dewey, Edward Arlington Robinson, Aldous Huxley and United States Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis tell what they believe are the necessary qualifications for success in the world today in the current issue of Youth, publication of the Young Israel of Williamsburg, which is edited by Albert Bassuk, a student at St. John's College, Brooklyn.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 19 -- Man is an amphibian who needs must live in the two diverse worlds of work and of worship, and on his solution of this paradox depends his spiritual maturity, according to the Rev. Frank Gavin, Cornell University baccalaureate speaker.

John E. Mack, who will nominate Governor Roosevelt at Chicago is not a member of the State's delegation to the convention, but under the Governor's plans will be elected to fill the vacancy that will be created by the resignation of Thomas F. Conway of Clinton County, former Lieutenant Governor, either as delegate from his own Congressional District or as a delegate at large.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., June 19 -- Squadrons of military airplanes, a formation of police fliers and individual racing planes droned over the heads of more than 7,500 persons at Curtiss Airport here today in an exhibition for the benefit of the Convalescent Relief Fund of Bellevue Hospital.

Heine Meine came to Ebbets Field with the Pirates yesterday and gave 18,000 fans an exhibition of his very best pitching by holding the Carey clan to five hits in seven innings as Pittsburgh won, 2 to 1.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation:
ALBANY, N.Y., June 19 -- Governor Roosevelt conferred for many hours tonight with Martin Conboy and John E. Mack on the evidence against Mayor Walker.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- An active day in the affairs of the Republican party is expected tomorrow, with Everett Sanders, the new chairman of the national committee, due at the White House from Chicago for a conference with President Hoover on campaign strategy, and Senator Borah scheduled to make an address in the Senate giving his views on the prohibition plank adopted by the national convention.

WASHTNGTON, June 19 -- Internal revenue officials have set up the machinery necessary for the collection of the manufacturers' excise and miscellaneous taxes, designed to yield $654,000,000 in additional revenue, which go into effect Tuesday and are hastening the promulgation of regulations for the enforcement of these provisions of the new tax law.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I had a dream that the American Ambassador wrote asking me to write on a postcard the best thing that could be done for the world commercially.

READING, Pa., June 19 (AP) -- Reading won both games of today's double-header, 8 to 2 and 2 to 0, to make a clean sweep of the six-game series with Rochester and advance to seventh place in the International League.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 19 (AP) -- The Communists today nominated Israel Amter, veteran organizer of the party, for Governor of New York. The candidate for Lieutenant Governor is Henry Shepard, Harlem Negro.

The clamor that arose from the lawn in front of the Bronx Maternity Hospital at 166th Street and the Grand Concourse gave proof early yesterday afternoon that the fourth annual baby pageant of the institution was in progress. From the 350 members of the youngest set of the Bronx and Upper Manhattan came shrill and prolonged expressions of disapproval, approbation and general bewilderment.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 19 -- World's champions, past and present, were in the crowd of 3,000 fight fans who watched Max Schmeling go through the final workout today for his fight with Jack Sharkey. Benny Leonard, Jack Britton and Tony Canzoneri sat in different parts of the arena and studied the heavyweight titleholder at close range.
When James J. Walker was in his twenties, he wrote a song. Its sentiments were sweet and the tune was catchy, and its name was "Will You Love Me in December as You Did in May?"

Fear as the bugbear preventing recovery from the throes of misery and depression was the topic of a sermon preached yesterday in St. Thomas's Lutheran Church, Topping Avenue at 176th Street, the Bronx, by the Rev. Alien Clay Lambert, recently chosen pastor.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 19 -- There were fifty-four starters heade by the three twelve-meter sloops in the second regatta of the Larchmon Yacht Club's Sunday series held out in Long Island Sound off here today.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 19 -- The appliances of life have caused the significant things to be subordinated, the Rev. Halford Luccock, Professor of Homeletics of the Yale University Divinity School, declared in the baccalaureate address at Mount Holyoke College today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in the June 17 issue entitled "Hoover and the Democrats" made an indelible impression upon me.

In at least twelve cities outside of New York there is to be a sensible arrangement of theatrical entertainment next season. Beginningthe first of August, the Guild, the Shubert and the Erlanger interests will attempt a businesslike presentation of their most promising offerings to the cities where the Guild has built up subscription audiences in the past five years, and probably to many more.

Simon Schuster will introduce soon what they call "Novel Novels," fiction selected and bound particularly for use in rental libraries. The sole purpose of these books, the publishers say, will be to entertain, their celophane wrappers will be sealed to the binding and they will be specially bound, with reinforced backs.

Illustrating the Children's Charter. In the July Atlantic an article by VERNON KELLOGG on "The President as I Know Him" gives an engaging picture of some of Mr. HOOVER'S personal traits little known to the public.

At the Palace, where the vaudeville is continuous and the free orangeade is playing an extended return date, the ten -- count 'em -- acts are headed by Al Trahan, a variety performer of long and honorable service, and Charles (Buddy) Rogers, a young man whom you used to read about in the motion picture news.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 19 -- The crews of eight colleges came in from the river today and racked their shells for the last time during the collegiate training season.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- Shamsi Batredinoff, formerly a member of the Communist party and chief prosecutor for the Supreme Court of Uzbekistan at Tashkent, was sentenced to death today at the end of a six-week trial, but the sentence was commuted to ten years' imprisonment.

BOSTON, June 19 -- Fifty-six athletes today were recommended to participate in the final tryouts for the American Olympic track and field team at Palo Alto. Cal., July 15 and 16, as a result of the Eastern tryouts in the Harvard Stadium Friday and yesterday.

Wilfred Seagram will take over Osgood Perkins's role tonight in "A Thousand Summers," the play at the Selwyn starring Jane Cowl. Before his appearance here in the Fall in "The Pure in Heart," Mr. Perkins will act in productions of the New York Repertory Company in Westport, Conn.

ROCHESTER, June 19 -- Age-long traditions of national self-will must be put aside for that saner national self-interest which finds priceless good, ideal and practical, in international understanding and sympathy, the graduating class of the University of Rochester was told today by President Rush Rhees in his baccalaureate address.

With the appearance of the ninth volume of the "Dictionary of American Biography" another cross-sectional view of our national personality is presented. It is not the life of the moment (for the living are not included), but of the United States as a people, from the first settlements down to the death-roll of last year.

Seven men and a woman, alleged to be members of a band of professional incendiaries that has caused more than twenty-five fires in New York City since 1919, were locked up yesterday at Manhattan Police Headquarters charged with conspiracy and attempted arson in a plot to set fire to the Plaza Hotel at 145 Beach Eighty-fourth Street, Rockaway Beach, a three-story frame building.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- James A. Farley, campaign manager for Governor Roosevelt, arrived here today, opened headquarters in the Congress Hotel, announced the selection of Arthur F. Mullen of Nebraska as floor leader of the Governor's forces for the convention and repeated his prediction that the New York Executive would be nominated on the first ballot.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Convention week brought buyers of seasonal merchandise in large numbers from all parts of the country, who took liberal supplies of goods, particularly cotton piece goods, women's underwear and hosiery for Immediate shipment.

Organization of a national federation of Orthodox Jewish congregation of orthodox Jewish congregavention in the auditorium of the Yashiva, College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which was atattended by delegates representing 200 Orthodox Jewish congregations in twenty-four States and Canada.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Prospects are that there will be a closer adjustment of supplies to consumptive requirements of dressed beef later in the year than has been known for several years. Despite the decline in market prices for beef steers claims are made by farmers that they have made $1 to $2 over feed costs.

The first Eastern invasion of the Western track and field stronghold in the fifty-six-year history of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. started yesterday as the athletes entrained for the championship games of the association at Berkeley, Cal., on July 1 and 2.

At the ninth annual presentation of awards to contestants of the New York Music Week Association yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the season's highest rating in any class was awarded to David Johnson Jr. of 36 West 139th Street. His grade was 97 1/2 per cent in the junior violin class.

Last week's abrupt fall in the foreign exchanges was a natural sequel to the news that return of the redeposited reserves of European central banks had been completed. The market's action would have attracted less attention but for the prophecies of inevitable disaster, as a result of the recent gold exports, with which the neurasthenic part of Wall Street had favored its fellow-citizens.

Proceedings and proposals at Lausanne have caused some people in this country to he resentful or alarmed. They speak of a "United Europe" deliberately plotting to injure the United States. In the very agreement between France, Germany and England, with the approval of Italy, they think they see European nations, for the first time since the war, uniting for a common object, and that object is to em- tarrass and weaken the American Government.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 19 -- June operations of mid-Western iron and steel companies are being well supported at current levels, production schedules for the week of June 20 reveal, with advances in some finishing mill directions.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Unemployment among all classes of workers in the United States now ranges between 9,000,000 and 11,000,000, according to the most reliable estimates. Official, up-to-date information as to the exact figure is lacking, however.
HANOVER, N.H., June 19 -- "The greatest lack of the present day is the lack of faith," said President E. M. Hopkins, of Dartmouth College in his baccalaureate sermon today in Roilins chapel.
DUBLIN, June 19 -- Candles gleamed from thousands of altars in Dublin tonight on the eve of the eucharistic congress. As night fell the whole city became one vast shrine.

The harm done to our national life by the tendency of political conventions and platforms to praise themselves and call all others blackguards was stressed by the Rev. Dr. H. Percy Silver, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 19 -- In the baccalaureate address this morning at Union College, Bishop Irving P. Johnson of Colorado told the graduates that "we live in an age of half-educated specialists who know more and more about less and less until they know nothing at all."

BERLIN, June 19 -- Increasing skepticism is plainly reflected in today's comment here on the progress of the Lausanne reparations discussions. There is an increasing conviction in political circles that the conference not only got away to a bad start but that the German delegation may even have been left at the post.
New transactions reported by brokers over the week-end indicate a demand for small housing properties. New Jersey buyers were especially active in this type of trading.

PARIS, June 17 -- The increase of 803,000,000 francs in the Bank of France's gold holdings, shown in the bank's report for the week ended June 10, was accompanied by reduction for the same week of 1,053,000,000 francs in the bank's foreign balances.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- With House insurgents again in revolt against salary cuts for Federal workers, indications tonight were that President Hoover's furlough plan, possibly with modifications, would be accepted tomorrow when the conference report on the economy bill is considered by the House for concurrence with the Senate amendments.
DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Continuing their batting attack where they left off yesterday, the Tigers defeated the Senators, 8 to 5, today to take the series, three games to one.

ALBANY, June 19 -- Governor Roosevelt announced tonight that John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie, former Supreme Court justice, would place him in nomination as a Presidential candidate at the Chicago convention.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert gave a dinner at Anglesea this evening.
WHILE waiting for the big explosions that are coming this week, there's time to put on record a few baseball stories the Cubs left behind them when they departed this vicinity.

After forty-three years, Yale has its first formal baseball championship since 1889, and Johnny Broaca, sophomore pitcher, who hurled the Elis to a 6-to-3 ten-inning triumph over Princeton on Saturday, holds four Eastern Intercollegiate League records and shares two others.
NEW YORK. Prince and Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst 1,130 Park Avenue will sail Wednesday on the Bremen.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 -- President Angell in his baccalaureate address today to the seniors of Yale College and the Sheffield Scientific School, who are to be graduated Tuesday, urged their generation to give active support to every measure that has reasonable promise of com posing international differences.

Some time In the next two decades television will emerge from the research laboratories to take the centre of the stage for the next act of the machine age drama and to reveal "incalculable possibilities and countless opportunities," Orin E. Dunlap Jr., radio editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and author of several books on radio, writes in "The Outlook for Television," published today by Harper Brothers.

A report made public yesterday by Joseph A Brady, executive secretary of the Home Relief Bureau, dealing with the work of the bureau's division of special investigation, reveals that the number of delinquencies among the personnel of the bureau, numbering 2,300 men and women, has been "gratifyingly limited," and that effective action resulted in every case investigated.

LONDON, June 19 -- The apparent attempt to assassinate Lord Lloyd, former Governor of Bombay and former High Commissioner for Egypt, was discovered by two schoolboys at St. Bees School, near Whitehaven, Cumberland, just after he had distributed the school prizes last night.

Mr. Everyman, interested in railroads, cannot but be impressed by the advertisements of feats in long-distance carriage on the highways -- of cotton to Gulf ports, of Idaho wool to the Pacific Coast, of coal by truck from the Pennsylvania mines, all cutting into rail transportation.

A tribute to the memory of the late Rev. Dr. Caleb Rockford Stetson, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, was paid by the Right Rev. Frank W. Creighton, S.T.D., Bishop of Mexico, in his sermon preached at memorial services held in the church yesterday.

The world's champion Cardinals, the team that overthrew the powerful Athletics last Fall, made their first appearance of the year at the Polo Grounds yesterday and beat the Giants decisively, thanks to a masterful pitching performance.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 19 -- Carlos Davila, head of the Socialist junta of Chile, emphatically declared today that all armed forces and a "united country" stood behind his government, despite reports of another counter-revolt on behalf of Colonel Marmaduque Grove, former head of the country's air service.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 19 -- America's mightiest assault on the British tennis championship begins tomorrow when Ellsworth Vines walks to the centre court for his first match in the Wimbledon international tournament.

The Merchants' Association made public yesterday a letter to President Hoover, members of the New York delegation in Congress and to leaders in the Senate and House, calling for a revision of the entire Federal program for relief to war veterans along lines designed to effect a saving of $400,000,000.

Construction of the second link of the west side express highway, extending from Twenty-second Street to Thirty-eighth Street, will be started this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock, when Borough President Samuel Levy will pet in place the first girder of the steel superstructure.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The estimated cost pf building construction for which permits were issued in 352 cities increased 24 per cent in May over the preceding month to a total of $67,501,025. The development was regarded as significant by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which stated in its announcement of the May total that "permits issued during May ordinarily show a decrease as compared with April."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19 -- "The issue confronting the youth of America today is cynicism or Christianity," said the Rev. Samuel V.V. Holmes in delivering the baccalaureate sermon at Williams College today. "The world is where it is today because of the accursed thirst for gold and the egotism of society, and the need of this society at present is men who will attack burning issues with diligence and sincerity," he said.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- Production of steel ingots last week was at about 16 per cent of plant capacity, representing one point decline from the preceding week and continuing the four-month recession. The rate was approximately seven-tenths of that of last December, which remained the low mark until April.

An uproar of encouraging shouts and unrestrained laughter resounded in narrow Elizabeth Street between Broome and Grand Streets yesterday as several hundred residents of Little Italy watched or participated in the games which are part of the annual celebration in honor of St. Charles the Hermit of Sciacca.

At the end of the long training trail, and happy that the grind is over, Jack Sharkey arrived in this city last night to await the bell which will send him on a scheduled fifteen-round journey against Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, tomorrow night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City.

Substantial reorders for Summer merchandise, particularly bathing suits and beach accessories, featured the activity in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. Retailers were confident that a large volume of business will be done on seasonal goods for the July Fourth holiday week-end and are making preparations to take care of the demand.
MADRID, June 19 -- Former King Alfonso's private fortune was declared confiscated today by the director of the republic's Treasury.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 19 -- Fred A. Victor, State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New York, speaking in the First Methodist Episcopal Church here today, said that the drys approved some parts of the prohibition plank in the Republican national platform.
With the opening of the bass season in the Province of Quebec Thursday, additional numbers of sportsmen will fish the waters within reach of Montreal and Ottawa, says a Canadian dispatch.

The impression left by the recital of Fjola Marine soprano, which took place last night in the Cort Theatre, was that of a big, dramatic voice not thoroughly groomed for public utterance. Occasionally the tone was round, full and of fine quality.

A reconsideration of intergovernmental debts, reparations, tariffs and other trade barriers is essential to the success of any international economic conference, in the opinion of a large majority of the fifty-three leaders of finance and business who have replied to a questionnaire sent out by the League of Nations Association, it was disclosed yesterday.

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, rum runner, night-club owner and most powerful underworld leader in Brooklyn since the death of Frankie Uale, died at Methodist Episcopal Hospital yesterday afternoon, fifteen hours after he ran into a crossfire of gangster bullets at 1:25 A.M. in Union Street between Prospect Park West and Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, June 18 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 59.3, which compares with 59.6 a week ago, 60.2 two weeks ago, 60.2 three weeks ago and 61.1 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; this week's average is the lowest.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Unable to obtain sufficient exchange for carrying on normal trade relations and finding similar conditions in several other countries, many German merchants are turning to the ancient method of barter trade.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians passed Washington to take third place in the American League race today by winning both games of a double-header with the Red Sox as the new Boston manager, Marty McManus, took over the reins from John (Shano) Collins.
