The country has been very patient with the "Bonus Expeditionary Force" at Washington. Something could Be said for the delusion of men who had been led to believe that the way to get what they wanted was to march on Washington and demand it of Congress.
BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Si Johnson held the Braves to five hits today as Cincinnati shut out Boston, 5 to 0, in a series opener to make it five straight over the Tribe this season.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 19 -- Its strong rally in the last period of play just falling short of tying the score, Winston Guest's Templeton quartet bowed to the Sands Point team, 13 to 12, in a thrilling polo contest at the Sands Points club today.

The New York Central Railroad moved 113,945,000 tons of freight in 1931, compared with 150,046,000 in 1930, a drop of 24 per cent, it is shown in the annual report for last year. As a result, freight revenue declined to $245,897,087 from $307,177,575, or 19.9 per cent.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 19 -- Indiana Democrats were converging on Indianapolis from all parts of the State today in preparation for the convention Tuesday and Wednesday, when candidates will be selected for Senatorial, Gubernatorial and other offices.
Investment deals in Manhattan housing properties were announced over the week-end.

Appearing as incongruous among the craft in Gravesend Bay as a barekneed and bearded viking would appear in crowded Times Square, the sixty-foot Norwegian bark Roald Amundsen, modeled after an ancient viking ship, in which Captain Gehard Folgero has sailed some 23,000 miles over the routes of the early American explorers, put out for Norway and home yesterday afternoon from Larson's pier at the foot of Bay Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 19 -- Belgium, Luxembourg, Holland, Denmark, Sweden and Norway, the six States which signed the Oslo protocol of 1930, are moving toward a reduction in customs tariffs. Their Foreign Ministers, meeting here, passed a resolution declaring it to be of the "greatest importance" that a general tariff reduction should be brought about very soon.

Three new plays are scheduled for production by a stock company which is being organized by Herbert Ranson and Barlowe Borland to give a ten weeks' season, opening on June 30, at the Old Red Barn Theatre in Locust Valley, L.I. Paul D. Cravath, Mrs. Joseph B. Vanderbilt, Arthur Hopkins and Mrs. E. Mortimer Ward comprise the advisory committee.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,453,000 Town of Montclair (N.J.) 6 per cent improvement bonds, dated July 1, 1932, and due from 1933 to 1964, at prices to yield 5 to 5.70 per cent. The offering group will consist of B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., J.S. Rippel Co., Newark; H. L. Alien Co., and M.F. Schlater Co., Inc.

Jersey City broke even with Buffalo in a double-header in Jersey City yesterday and captured the series, three games out of five. Cascarella pitched fine ball in the opener to limit the Bisons to one hit, Jersey City winning, 1 to 0.

The Montreal Royals turned back Jersey City, 5 to 2, yesterday in the opening game of their series at West Side Park, Jersey City. LeRoy Parmelee, property of the New York Giants, hurling for the Royals, was in excellent form.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 -- The congratulations of the crew that gave California its hardest fight over the four-mile regatta course today were carried to the Golden Bears tonight by Coach Jim Wray of Cornell in a meeting with Coach Ky Ebright of California at the Vassar Alumnae House, headquarters of the victorious oarsmen.

BERLIN, June 20 -- The Boerse displayed some optimism today, which was reflected chiefly in strengh in bonds, some of which advanced 2 per cent. Stocks remained quiet, with a few exceptions. Gelsenkirchener was active, due to reports of the impending purchase of a controlling interest in the corporation by the Reich.

TRENTON, N.J., June 20 -- Despite a statement today by Governor A. Harry Moore that he would rather be Chief Executive of New Jersey than Vice President of the United States, speculation continues in political circles here as to his chance of being nominated.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Legislation authorizing President Hoover to present a Distinguished Service Medal to Amelia Earhart Putnam for her transatlantic flight was passed tonight by the House and returned to the Senate with an amendment.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 20. -- Colonel E. St. John Greble, prominent Republican of this city, declared today that he saw no hope for Republican Presidential success in either New Jersey or the country as a whole. He predicted a bolt of wet Republicans to "either a third party or the Democratic ticket."

Wall Street found yesterday's markets on the Stock Exchange interesting statistically because of the extremely small volume. In stocks the turnover was the smallest for a full five-hour day since June, 1924. It involved a total of only 388,000 shares.

Noteworthy chiefly because of their remarkable lethargy, the security markets failed yesterday to mark out a definite course and did little to illuminate the financial picture. The machinery of the Stock Exchange was motionless a good part of the day.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, who have been at the Ritz-Carlton, will sail for England tomorrow.

Absorb Tax on Two Cosmetic Lines. Two cosmetic producers yesterday announced they will absorb the excise tax of 10 per cent on this merchandise which takes effect today. The makers taking this step are Dorothy Gray and Marie Earle. Other manufacturers have either not taken action as yet or have decided to pass the tax on to the retailer, reports in the trade indicated.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Regulations "42," under which provisions of the revenue act of 1932, pertaining to the taxation of telegraph, telephone, radio, cable facilities, transportation of oil by pipe line, safety deposit boxes, checks and electrical energy will be administered, were issued today by David Burnet, Internal Revenue Commissioner.

General Sessions Judge Levine, after listening to argument by State and defense lawyers, announced yesterday he would take under advisement an application by Albert B. Unger, Assistant District Attorney, for permission to resubmit to the grand jury manslaughter charges against John C. Flinn and Henry F. Lalley in connection with the Pathe Sound Studios fire at Park Avenue and 134th Street on Dec. 10, 1929.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 20. -- Early this evening Ed Salisbury, stroke of California's varsity crew, and his mates took the second of the steps along the trail blazed for them in 1928 by Peter Donlon and another great California crew. Shortly after 7:30 they had placed the Poughkeepsie championship with the victory over Washington in the Pacific Coast regatta.

A demand that the United States insist that European nations acknowledge their debts to this country is made by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in a three-point indictment of the Administration of President Hoover contained in an article in the June 25 issue of Liberty Magazine.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- New demands for prompt Federal aid for the jobless were raised today as the Senate pushed ahead with debate on the $2,000,000,000 unemployment relief bill sponsored by the Senate Democratic leadership.

A sharp rally in German loans featured an otherwise prosaic market in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Bonds of the German General Electric Company led the rise with net gains for the day of 2 to 5 1/2 points. German Government 7s advanced a point, while the 5 1/2s closed unchanged in heavy trading.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Pittman silver-purqhase bill went on the Senate calendar today accompanied by a favorable report voted 6 to 4 by the Banking and Currency Committee.

THE heavyweight champion of the world and the challenger are ready to don the gloves and fight for the crown in the new Garden Bowl. It seems to be agreed on all sides that Herr Max Sehmeling is a good fighter and will put up a good fight.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 20 (AP). -- Vice President Charles Curtis, commencement speaker at the University of Vermont, today urged upon the university's graduating class the need for self-reliance, "by far the most important single factor in success, whether in business or otherwise."

A new combination of fuel oil and coal dust for firing boilers is being experimented with on the Cunard liner Scythia, which arrived here last night from Liverpool. If successful the plan is expected to save considerable money for the steamship company.

Conferees representing the Senate and the House have at last reached partial agreement on a program of economy. The sum to be saved in the various items acceptable to both sides amounts on paper to $65,674,106, But even this small saving, about 1 1/2 per cent of next year's budget, is in part fictitious.

Members of the Hampton Players have begun rehearsals in Southampton, L.I., of "Good-bye Again," a new comedy by Alien Scott and Harry Selby, their first production there for this season. The date of the opening is July 6. Henry Codman Potter is the founder and director of the group, and George Haight manager.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 20. -- The annual alumnae parade by classes on Tower Court Green, followed by the dramatic presentation of the Alumnae Fund drive, in Alumnae Hall in the form of the final run-off of the "Wellesley Derby" -- a motion-picture race-track scene -- marked the day's activities at Wellesley College, preceding commencement exercises tomorrow.

BOSTON, June 20 -- Governor Roosevelt of New York will deliver a last-minute personal message to his New England supporters as they pass through Albany Saturday on their way to the convention. Roosevelt headquarters here made the announcement today of this feature of the trip of the Curley special.

The baccalaureate addresses, to which, much space was given in yesterday's news, deserve it, because they had to do with matters of public interest. Those who made them, university and college presidents and preachers alike, walked not "the studious cloister's pale," but out in the open highways of the world's affairs, discussing its woes and its welfare, and inciting the young graduates to battle for the "prosperity that a man findeth in misfortune."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A new rule of the Federal Radio Commission whereby broadcasting stations of the country can deviate only 50 cycles from their assigned frequencies, which was adopted a year ago, becomes effective on Wednesday. At present stations may deviate as much as 500 cycles.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 -- Three American tennis stars advanced safely into the second round of the British championships, which opened on the Wimbledon courts today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 20. -- The seniors of Williams College were told today by Benjamin Nathan Cardozo, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, that every life was miraculous, but that each must find the miracle for himself in his own soul.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 20. -- Sir Francis James Wyle, who was executive secretary of the Rhodes trust and resident host to all Rhodes scholars at Oxford University from 1903 to last Summer, delivered the honorary chancellor's address at the 165th commencement of Union College today, describing the life and ideals of Cecil Rhodes, who established the scholarships in order to assure "Anglo-Saxon unity" and world peace.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 20 -- Clifford Sutter, Tulane University captain; Bryan Grant, University of North Carolina ace, and all the other seeded stars came through their first and second round tests today as play got under way in the forty-seventh annual national intercollegiate tennis championships at the Merlon Cricket Club.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 20 -- Alongside the reparations conference, although strictly no part of it except in the wider sense which empowers the conference to consider any economic and financial measures which would tend to bring the world back to normal, there arose today a movement of modest beginnings and limited aims which may develop into world-wide importance.

"The Cheshire cat might well grin at the present theory that the more money the government can wring from an overtaxed people the greater will be their prosperity," James M. Beck, former Solicitor General of the United States and now a member of Congress, writes in "Our Wonderland of Bureaucracy," published today by Macmillan.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 20. -- Professor Ralph Barton Perry of the Department of Philosophy at Harvard University, told the graduating class at the Smith College commencement today that "there is among you a certain lack of deference to your elders which is sometimes annoying, but on the whole a good sign, perhaps a sign of precisely that for which I wish to plead today."

The Non-Partisan Committee of One Thousand of Forest Hills, formed to further the nomination of former Governor Alfred E. Smith at the forthcoming Democratic convention at Chicago, made public yesterday a letter to Queens County Leader John Theofel urging him to support Mr. Smith.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- About 57,000 depositors of the Franklin Trust Company, which closed on Oct. 6, may expect finally to receive 50.9 per cent of their money, according to an inventory and appraisal filed today by Dr. William D. Gordon, State Secretary of Banking.

With practically the whole list of entries on hand, the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Flushing, L.I., which is to be the scene of the national open golf tournament, starting Thursday, began to take on a real championship aspect yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, June 21. -- From "Green Grow the Lilacs," which the Theatre Guild was playing two years ago, Lynn Riggs has passed bravely on to "The Cherokee Night," which was played this evening at the Hedgerow Theatre in Moyland-Rose Valley.

WASHINGTON. June 20 (AP). -- Although vigorously opposed by Senator McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, the renomination of T.V O'Connor of Buffalo as chairman of the Shipping Board was confirmed by a vote of 35 to 16 in the Senate today.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP). -- The Athletics let loose with all their heavy guns today to win a slugging match from the White Sox, 18 to 11.

The Country Club of Brookline has attained the age of fifty years. Its history is deserving of notice, because it was "the first-born of a "huge family which spread from "Maine to California and from "Alaska to Florida." When it was organized, sportsmen and sports-loving people were not conspicuous in the United States.

There were fewer railroad accidents in this country, fatal and non-fatal, last year than in any preceding year since their downward trend began in 1923, and the Class I railroads spent $299,994,990 for accident prevention during the year. Arthur W. Williams, president of the American Museum of Safety, announced yesterday.

Donald Durant, a partner in the banking firm of Lee, Higginson Co., testified yesterday before Henry K Davis. Federal referee, sitting as special master, that although he had been a director of the Kreuger Toll Company since 1929, he never attended a directors' meeting until a short time after Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish financier, had committed suicide.

ALBANY, June 20 -- A new ruling promulgated by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles holds that unless an automobile, insurance policy is drawn so as specifically to insure the driver of a taxicab or omnibus he cannot successfully claim protection from the policy that covers the car and its owner.
BOSTON, June 20 (AP). -- The Braves gained their first victory of the year over the Reds today as they took an eleven-inning pitchers' battle, 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON. June 20. -- Plans of the New York Central Railroad to issue $75,000,000 of refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, Series C, were approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The issue will be dated Oct. 1, 1921, and mature Oct. 1, 2013.

All sections of the money market kept the quiet restraint in the matter of business and quotations which has governed sessions of the month past. On the Stock Exchange day loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent., with outside trades at 1, and Federals at 1/3 @ 1/4.

The National Alliance of Art and Industry opened yesterday at the Art Centre its "Designer and Industry" exhibition, which will continue until Oct. 1. As a matter of fact, most of the present week will probably be required for completing the installation.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP). -- Charges of murder and driving while intoxicated were filed today against Harold L. Menjou, 20-year-old adopted son of Adolphe Menjou, screen star, as an outcome of an automobile accident yesterday in which young Menjou's girl companion was killed.

With action by Governor Roosevelt on the removal charges against Mayor Walker expected soon, Samuel Seabury began yesterday breaking up the legal staff of the Hofstadter legislative committee, which gathered the evidence against the Mayor and other Tammany officeholders.

The prevalence of Illness among families whose members need the support of welfare agencies was emphasized in a report submitted yesterday at an executive session of the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The golden anniversary plumbing and heating exposition sponsored by the National Association of Master Plumbers opened at Madison Square Garden yesterday. From 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. a steady stream of members of the organization and its friends and guests filled the corridors of the garden basement, where the gleaming multi-colored products of more than 100 manufacturers were on exhibition.

Jimmy Martin, national amateur bantamweight champion, won the decision from Johnny Whittier of the Salem-Crescent Club in an 118pound special bout at the semimonthly amateur boxing card at the New York Athletic Club, Travers Island, last night.

Peter Grimm, former president of the Real Estate Board of New York and president of William A. White Co., was elected chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission at the board's first meeting yesterday. Mr. Grimm will act as the commission's spokesman, and will proceed immediately with the work of organizing the staff of experts which it is to have at its command.

Van Lingle Mungo and Bill Harris engaged in a pitching duel at Ebbets Field yesterday and the Broooklyn youth won the decision, a single from his own bat paving the way for Joe Stripp to drive in the winning run. The Robins triumphed over the Pirates, 2 to 1, just reversing Sunday's score when they were defeated.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 20. -- The salvation of the world rests with international cooperation, an important aspect of which should be cancellation of war debts, Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman told the sixty-fourth graduating class of Cornell University today.

READING, June 20 (AP). -- Reading took two games from Toronto tonight to make it eight in a row. The Keys won the first contest, 6 to 4, and the second, 11 to 3. Lester Bell, Keys' third sacker, hit a homer in each game.

BREST, France, June 20. -- Tomorrow, weather permitting, the salvage ship Artiglio sails hoping to complete the work of lifting $5,000,000 from the sunken liner Egypt, a task which was delayed by the unexpected presence in the bullion room of a miscellaneous cargo of guns, ammunition and silk.
Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam returned to the city yesterday one month and a day after leaving New York to fly alone across the North Atlantic.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 (AP) -- The Poughkeepsie regatta may be the alpha and omega of the rowing season for many college crews, but it was only the second stop in any alphabet for the California stalwarts who won the intercollegiate classic today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The District of Columbia, through General Pelham D. Glassford, superintendent of police, attempted today to wash its hands of the bonus army, which has been encamped here and growing steadily for three weeks.
ALBANY, June 20 -- With his managers laboring vigorously in the political vineyards at Chicago, Governor Roosevelt shook off official cares today to attend the annual college regatta at Poughkeepsie.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20 -- Five-players, including E.R. Elliott Fleming. Princeton freshman, seeded No. 1, gained the quarter-finals of the annual Essex County junior tennis" championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

W. Irving Glover, Assistant Postmaster General, warned leaders of the aviation Industry last night that the proposal now before Congress to reduce the appropriations for air mail contracts from $20,000,000 to $9,000,000 would ruin commercial aviation in this country if it is approved.

SHANGHAI, June 20 -- The League of Nations inquiry commission, under the Earl of Lytton, is being urged by representatives of the Nanking Government to initiate direct Chino-Japanese negotiations to seek a compromise on the status of Manchuria.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP). -- Detroit defeated the Red Sox in a series opener, 6 to 4, today. Marty McManus, new Sox manager, argued a close decision at first base so fiercely that Umpire Owens sent him from the coaching box to the showers, and in the inning Warstler, Sox shortstop, followed him for a similar offense.

ST. LOUIS, June 20. -- After resting a little longer than usual between jobs because of a blister on the palm of his pitching hand, Vernon Gomez, kingpin pitcher of the American League, stepped into the box today and held the Browns to three singles in the opener of a four-game series, the Yankees winning, 3 to 1, for their fourth straight victory.

BERLIN, June 20. -- A controlling bare in the Vereinigte Stahlwerke, Germany's huge coal, iron and steel trust, is about to pass to the Reich, marking another important step toward socialization of private business.

OTTAWA, June 20 (Canadian Press) -- The total Dominion revenue derived from the manufacture and sale of liquor last year amounted to $43,263,871, according to a report issued today. This was a decline of $13,000,000 from the previous year, and of $16,000,000 from the peak year of 1929.

Copyright, 1032, by The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved. ON THE RIVER AMAZON, In Brazil, June 10 -- In my last story, sent from Iquitos, Peru,I told of the very definite, if possibly temporary, wave of prosperity which had covered that place in the shape of a lucrative business in mahogany logs.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 -- After being put off three times last week because of inclement weather, play in the third Westbury Challenge Cup twenty-goal polo tournament got under way today at the Meadow Brook Club, with two matches being played.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP). -- Charlie Root was wild and ineffective today and the Phillies scored six runs in the first two innings to defeat the leading Chicago Cubs, 7 to 5. Smith and Tinning, who followed Root, kept the locals well in hand the rest of the way, but the damage had been done.

A little old lady observed wandering aimlessly about the Times Square subway station last night was taken to Bellevue Hospital in an ambulance. It was found there that she was suffering from amnesia and was unable to talk, but after she had rested for a time she spoke a few words in German.

A young blonde woman, about 30 years old, smartly dressed and armed with what John Benkler, manager of the Knickerbocker Ice Company office at 1 Lombardy Street, Brooklyn, described as an "enormous revolver," pointed, the weapon at his head with a steady hand and departed calmly through the office door with $400, which Mr. Benkler was preparing to deposit in the bank shortly after 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

Lovett and Harriman. ROBERT S. LOVETT'S official career represented. much as did that of his contemporary, Judge GARY, the desire of the "promotion period" of two or three decades ago to couple a daring leader in an industrial enterprise with a co-executive of conservative ideas.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- William Fox, who made millions in the movie and theatre business, quietly checked out at his hotel today and was believed to have returned to New York, although still under subpoena to testify in the Senate stock market investigation concerning his financial operations.

The golf course of the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Creedmoor, Queens, where the National Open Championship is scheduled to start on Thursday, was being guarded by police yesterday and roads in the vicinity were patrolled by radio cars as a result of an alleged plot to damage the greens.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Debts and armament reduction are not being linked in the present effort at Geneva to produce results at the Disarmament Conference, it was said today on high authority at the State Department.

Four members of the visiting Brazilian Davis Cup team were included among the casualties in the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, leaving only Ricardo Pernambuco, the No. 1 singles player for the South Americans, and Captain Ignacio Nogueira in the running at the end of the third day of competition.

WARSAW, June 20 -- Strong objections are being raised here against the proposed visit to Danzig of several units of the German Navy, which is expected about the end of June in celebration of the 500th anniversary of St. Anne Hospital of Danzig.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20. -- Practice today of the Yale and Harvard crews was considerably lighter and the coaches plan to gradually cut down on the stretches and long-distance paddles to keep the oarsmen in shape.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20. -- Men prominent in politics and education paid tribute today to Dr. John Grier Hibben, retiring president of Princeton University, in a special "Hibben supplement" edition of The Dally Princetonian, campus newspaper.

John M. Callahan, member of the Democratic National Committee from Wisconsin, has sent to all of the delegates of the Democratic National Convention photostatic copies of what purports to be correspondence between Governor Roosevelt and his campaign manager, James A. Farley, and the organizers of the Roosevelt Southern clubs, intended to show that the Roosevelt movement in the South received aid from the Ku Klux Klan.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Machine gun threats prompted Cook County officials today to dismiss a bank robbery charge against Danny Mc Geoghegan, beer hustler.

Although Charles M. Schwab persuaded some bankers in 1927 to agree to pay $3.000.000 above the market price for his holdings of stock of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, he became impatient about a month later because he had not received the money and sought to call the deal off.

GENEVA, June 20. -- Great Britain, France and the United States settled down here today to a three-power disarmament conference in which Washington had an active part by transatlantic telephone. Both Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Britain and Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson, head of the American delegation to the disarmament conference, talked directly to President Hoover as part of these conversations.

Mrs. James J. Walker, wife of the Mayor, entered the Polyclinic Hospital yesterday for an abdominal operation which will he performed at 8 o'clock this morning by Dr. William Schroeder Jr., Commissioner of the Sanitation Department and the Mayor's personal physician, for the removal of a fibroid tumor.

LAUSANNE, June 20 -- For three hours this morning Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain tried to persuade Premier Herriot of France that cancellation of Europe's bad debts was the only road out of the financial morass and that all "buts" and "ifs" with which M. Herriot was seeking to condition the surrender would mean only so many more impediments to recovery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We discovered a few days ago an old cemetery with headstones dating from pre-Revolutionary days. This landmark is fast falling into decay through the vandalism of picnickers and others who have chipped off pieces of the gravestones and carried them away.

The adjusted index of automobile production shows a further slight gain. For the week ended June 18 it stands at 51.7, as against 51.5 for the preceding week and 64.2 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, amounted to 53,158 cars and trucks, as against 52,560 cars and trucks in the preceding week and 62,752 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

Although the striped-bass fishing could be described as "spotty" during recent weeks at Nlantic Inlet, Conn., some good-sized fish were caught over the past week-end. R.B., who spends most of his fishing days on trout streams, decided to try the stripers for a change.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP). -- The mercurial Cleveland Indians bobbed into fifth place in the American League standing today when Alvin Crowder of the Senators bested Wes Ferrell in a pitching duel, 3 to 2. The Senators resumed their third-place position, while the Tigers moved into fourth place.
The text of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's address, "The International Mind," before the Advertising Federation of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria, last night follows:

The belief that the Democratic National Convention will adopt a plank calling for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, with modification of the Volstead act pending repeal, was expressed yesterday by Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago. Mayor Cermak stopped here on his way to Washington, where he will press the demands of his city for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

ROCHESTER, June 20. -- Before a crowd of nearly 3,500 the University of Rochester today graduated 394 seniors and graduate students, the largest class in its history. Eleven men received honorary degrees.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several days ago THE TIMES published an editorial about the flood of "plans" pouring into your office. It would seem that every economist, professional and amateur, has one to offer. However, I am afraid it is a waste of time and energy to present them -- the meritorious ones call for too great a sacrifice and the others, naturally, cannot pass the test.

HOLLYWOOD, June 20 (AP). -- Lita Grey Chaplin, former wife of Charles Chaplin, movie comedian, signed a contract today by which she and their two young sons are to appear in five pictures for the Fox Film Company.

LONDON, June 20 -- James M. Beck, former Solicitor General of the United States, charged today that the United States Constitution had been a failure in not preventing Congress from virtually unlimited spending of public moneys.

Assailing the position of the Hoover Administration and of Congress on the international debt question, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, decried last night the "political paralysis" Which, he said, seizes the politician in office when a general election Impends.

Following a setback of more than $1 a bale late last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and ended with gains of 6 to 8 points. At one time July sold at 5.22 cents a pound, an improvement of about 15 points from recent low figures, despite steady liquidation in the near month prior to notices on June 28.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 20 -- A field of seventy-five golfers started play today in the qualifying round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield championship over the links of the Tamarack Country Club. Tied for the medal with cards of 86, Miss Catherine Singer of the WestChester Country Club and Miss Betty Pietsch of Tamarack led in qualifying for the first flight of sixteen.

President Hoover, in a message of greeting to the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, asserted that advertising had become such vital force in our economic life that it was important it should have "leaders in courage and enterprise."

Having considered in my first article the peace-time indispensability of American railroads, the take-off for sound public policy stands starkly revealed. As highways, waterways and rails must co-exist, does not the task reduce itself to a wise apportionment of the national transportation load among these agencies?

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Senator Borah, who threw his eloquence and power behind President Hoover in the 1928 campaign, announced in the Senate today that he will not support the President for re-election on the platform adopted by the Chicago Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Growth in sentiment for adoption of a repeal plank by the Democratic convention, increasing confidence expressed by James A. Farley, Roosevelt campaign manager, of Governor Roosevelt's nomination for President on the first ballot and an admission by those opposed to the nomination of Mr. Roosevelt that his supporters would control the convention committees were the principal developments today as the party leaders continued to gather here for next week's convention.

Miss Sarah Schuyler Butler, vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, daughter of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and herself one of the leaders for a repeal plank at the Republican convention at Chicago, assailed yesterday the wet-dry prohibition plank.

Retail consumers of electricity supplied by the four companies of the Edison System saved $6,495,722 from Sept. 1, 1931, until May 1, 1932, under the new rates which became effective last July, according to testimony before the Public Service Commission yesterday.

It is good to think of " JIM " FARLEY filling something over sixty rooms in the Congress Hotel in Chicago with his seventy-four inches, his 215 pounds, his expansive smile and speech. He covers an immensely greater territory than that. See his map of delegates.

BERLIN, June 20 -- Germany is backing Max Schmellng to win tomorrow's fight -- a multitude for reasons much like those that prompted the champion's mother to tell THE NEW YORK TIMES, "My boy is sure to win and remain the world's champion."

Remain Rolland, French author and publicist, from his home in Villeneuve, Switzerland, issued an appeal yesterday to the American people to appoint representatives to an anti-war congress and to work out a plan for common action against what he terms the "imminent" danger of another world conflict.

LONDON, June 20 -- The stock markets opened cheerful today, with some slight increase in business. Strong support for British Government funds continued, the 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan touching 90 1-16, a new high record. Market conditions were favorable in view of the prospects at Lausanne.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 20. -- Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut, former dean of the Yale Graduate School, was one of eight persons who received honorary degrees at the 100th commencement exercises of Wesleyan University today.

PARIS, June 20 -- Trading lagged on the Bourse today and a large portion of the recent gains were effaced. The wholes list was dull and steadily declined throughout the session, which closed at the day's lows, although apparently, there were no new factors affecting the situation.

LOS ANGELES, June 20. -- Jean Harlow, platinum blonde star of the screen, and Paul Bern, Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer executive, today filed intention to wed here. The date for the ceremony has not been set, they declared.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is highly important that Mr. Average Citizen be importuned to tighten his belt and resolve here and now to meet the coming tax burdens honorably, if not cheerfully. It will have done no good for Congress to have balanced the budget on tax estimates if every one forthwith schemes to evade their imposition.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Concern over reports that the present regime in Manchuria contemplates taking over the Chinese customs administration in Manchuria was expressed informally to Katsuji Debuchi, the Japanese Ambassador, by Secretary Stimson on June 10, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- A very minor portion of the new stamp taxes -- that expected from counter checks -- will be lost to the government if all banking institutions in the country follow the lead of a Kokomo, Ind., bank.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A treatment for the American type of typhus fever, which has been found to act also as a preventive, was announced by the Public Health Service today by inoculation of a serum extracted from ground-up fleas taken from typhus-infected rats and mice.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 20. -- A warning that America is in danger of race degeneration unless steps are taken to provide for the eugenic sterilization of the large numbers of the mentally defective who are likely to produce children which they could not care for and who would be "incapable of becoming self-sustaining good citizens" was sounded today at the opening of the Summer session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Last week the Salvation Army was forced to turn away thousands of deserving applicants for relief because of the exhaustion of its $900,000 emergency relief fund, Brigadier Thomas Seaver of the Army's Family Welfare Department declared yesterday in a statement in which he called the week "the worst seven days" in his experience.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- President Hoover's staggered furlough plan for all Federal employes was passed by the House late today by the overwhelming vote of 326 to 45 after it had adopted the conference report on the economy bill.
PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP). -- James Francis Burke, general counsel for the Republican National Committee, tonight defended the prohibition plank adopted by the national conventioin in Chicago.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 20 -- Miss Helen Hicks of Lido, winner of four major women's golf titles last year, including the national championship, won the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Long Island title competition, which started today at the Cherry Valley Club.

George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company, made the principal address at the graduation exercises of the New York Edison Company Educational Bureau held last night at 4 Irving Place. Frank W. Smith, president of the New York Edison Company, presided, and Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board, presented the diplomas and certificates.

The United States Securities Corporation has been formed as a bond-holding fixed trust by Wellington Bull Co., Inc., and associates. It will issue its own collateral trust 7 per cent income bonds through a country-wide syndicate against collateral in the form of bonds purchased and deposited with trustees.

STAMFORD, Conn. June 20. -- On the eve of his departure for Chicago, where he will attend the Democratic National Convention as delegate at large, Homer S. Cummings, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today again predicted the nomination of Governor Roosevelt and came out strongly for abolishing the two-thirds rule governing Presidential nominations in Democratic conventions.

THE HAGUE, June 20. -- The first photographs of the so-called orang letjo or ape man have arrived in Holland. Some time ago the District Governor of Sumatra offered a reward for a specimen, dead or alive, of the orang letjo, supposed to live in the Rokan Mountains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask, through THE TIMES, for two grand pianos for use in the two high schools of the Virgin Islands? At a time when so many people are finding their pianos taking up room and not in use, there probably would he two persons who would like these instruments to find the very excellent use that we could put them to in the Virgin Islands.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20. -- A merger of the Westchester County Children's Association and the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children was planned for the near future, the association, announced today. The merger will be "in line with the modern trend in industrial and welfare work" and "to effect an economy in administrative costs," according to the announcement.

Boston, Mass. The city of Boston plans to open sealed bids at noon today on an issue of $3,000,000 of temporary notes. The issue will be dated June 22 and will mature on Oct. 6. Thus far this year the city has borrowed $17,000,000 on short-term obligations, while its legal limit is $30,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Work on the organization of the Republican campaign plans got under way today after Everett Sanders, the new national chairman, held a short conference with President Hoover.

LONDON, June 20. -- The Salvage Association established contact yesterday with the Egypt's former second officer, named Cameron, who was responsible for stowing the cargo. The gold and silver aboard the Egypt were in the bullion room when it sank, he said, having been transferred from the baggage room, where he counted it.

TOKYO, June 20 -- The serious anxiety with which the powers regard the plan of Manchukuo to take over from China the customs houses in Manchuria, including those in the Japanese leased territory, is indicated in an inquiry directed to the Tokyo Foreign Office by Sir Francis Lindley, the British Ambassador, and one made of Ambassador Debuchi in Washington by Secretary of State Stimson.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20. -- Harvard commencement week activities today included Phi Beta Kappa exercises, the award of six fellowships, including two to Cambridge, England; the time honored senior spread and the first exercises in the twenty-fifth year reunion of the class of 1907.

Now that Europe's central banks have called home that part of their reserve which had long been carried in the American market, it is possible to see more clearly how certain economic influences have operated, before and since 1929. No criticism of the economic position has been more familiar than insistence on the inexcusable "hoarding" or "sterilizing" of the world's gold in America.

Thorough blanketing of the United States and Canada by the nationwide networks of the National Broadcasting Company will enable countless radio listeners to participate vicariously in the developments of tonight's championship bout between Max Schmeling and Jack Sharkey.

MONTREAL, June 20 -- Toe Dance, R. Leslie's speedy filly, won the Jacques Cartier Purse, feature at the Blue Bonnets track today. Under good handling by Jockey W. Cleverly the Leslie racer maintained a safe lead throughout the six furlongs of the race to win by half a length from Roselys, with H.T. MacFarlane's Wee Toddler II in third place.

Objections to the accounting in the estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical man, were filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by Edmund D. Codman and John R. Lazenby, trustees under the will of Maria P. Codman. Mr. Lazenby sued in his own name as trustee and also as counsel for Martha C. Karolik of Washington, D. C.

A plant for the refining of copper produced in Northern Rhodesia will be built near Liverpool, England, according to information received here yesterday. British Insulated Cables, Ltd., jt is understood, will start at once construction of the plant, which will have a initial monthly capacity of 2,500 to 3,000 tons of fire-refined copper and be in operation early nest year.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP). -- On the witness stand under the gaze of the man from whom she demands $200,000 in a breach of promise action, Myrtle St. Pierre today described her introduction to David Hutton before he became the husband of Aimee Semple McPherson, the evangelist.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 -- Fighting a determined California crew for supremacy in the junior varsity race and coasting into a comparatively easy victory in the freshman test, Syracuse swept both minor events of the Poughkeepsie regatta on the calm waters of the Hudson today.

The apprentice jockeys, Silvio Coucci and Hank Mills, who scored respectively last Saturday on Gusto in the American Derby and on Blenheim in the Brooklyn Handicap, divided the honors yesterday at Aqueduct.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 20 -- John O'Donnell, minority county commissioner and chairman of the Democratic City Committee, asserted today that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City had offered him "anything you want" to desert Governor Roosevelt and join with the forces of Alfred E. Smith in the fight for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The board of directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation took no action yesterday on the common dividend, but declared the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the preferred stock, payable on July 15 to stock of record of July 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 20 (AP). -- Builders of the Democratic State platform started their work tonight with a prohibition plank, prepared by an advisory committee, recommending a submission to the States of a proposal for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, and repeal of the Wright "bone dry" law, State enforcement act.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 20 -- Governor Pinchot announced tonight at the conclusion of a four-hour conference with Republican leaders that the Legislature would convene here on Monday evening in special session to act on a fourteen-point program for unemployment relief agreed upon by the conferees.

PORTLAND. Me., June 30 (AP). -- The fight between State Senate President Burleigh Martin of Augusta and Lewis O. Barrows of Newport for the Republican nomination for Governor was overshadowed late tonight by the nip-and-tuck struggle between, former Governor Ralph O. Brewster of Dexter and Clarence C. Stetson of Bangor for the party's nomination in the Third Congressional District.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 20. -- Gifts to Brown University totaling $1,000,000, including $300,000 from an alumnus for the construction of an infirmary as a memorial to a former president, Dr. E.B. Andrews, were announced by President Barbour today.

AMHERST, Mass., June 20. -- Secretary Adams of the Navy Department, Representative Rainey, '83, majority leader of the House, and Mrs. Emily C. Folger, widow of the donor of the Folger Memorial Library in Washington, were among the eight persons to receive honorary degrees at the commencement exercises of Amherst College today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 20 (AP). -- Ambassador William S. Culbertson formally requested the new Socialist Government tonight to protect American lives and property at the Braden copper mines at Teniente against threatened anti-foreign disorders.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The text of Senator Borah's address today in the Senate follows:

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, Brooklyn gangster, who was shot down Sunday morning in the presence of his entire family, had so many enemies that the police were at a loss yesterday where to concentrate their search for the murderers.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20. -- Class-day exercises in which the campus activities of the senior class of Princeton University were concluded with ceremony and festivities were held today, the last day before graduation. Degrees will be bestowed upon 461 members of the graduating class by Dr. John Grier Hibben, retiring president of the university, at commencement exercise tomorrow.

Four players reached the quarter-final round in the Eastern junior singles tennis championships as the annual tourney got under way at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday. Play in the boys' championships also started.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: It is to be hoped that the Democratic prohibition plank will be more satisfactory than the splintered one so laboriously carpentered by the Republicans.

DUBLIN, June 20 -- Cardinal Lauri the Papal Legate to the Eucharistic Congress, was welcomed to Dublin today with all the enthusiasm that the Pope himself might have received if he had come in person.

Copyright, 1932. by NANA, Inc. I am ready. It is with, confidence that I await the signal that will start my battle with Jack Sharkey in the Madison Square Garden Bowl, which will prove to the world my fitness for the title I hold.

DETROIT, June 20 -- An appeal to American business to end "billions of dollars in economic waste" was made by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men in opening the association's convention here today. He said that the country's fraud loss was four times the sum of the net income of the 1,500 biggest industrial, utility and railroad companies of the nation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20. -- Several hundred bizarrely clad Yale graduates, representing twenty-two classes, returned here for their class reunions today. Scotsmen in kilties represented the class of 1929; Breton sailors, 1912; blue-coated sailors in white ducks, 1912 Sheffield; convict garb. 1922, and straw-hatted farmers, 1926.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 20. -- The graduating class of Mount Holyoke College was addressed via Transatlantic telephone today by President Mary E. Woolley, who spoke in Geneva, Switzerland, where she is one of the American delegates o the disarmament conference, and vas heard in South Hadley through, a large amplifier set on the stage in Chapin Auditorium.

According to our State Department, the American Government is willing to join in an international conference on finance and trade provided reparations and war debts are kept out of the discussion. But according to many of our leading bankers, industrialists and economists, the thing cannot be done.
Jack Sharkey gets his third chance at the world's heavyweight championship tonight.
BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP). -- Frank Packard's single in the ninth, sent home the winning run to give Baltimore an 8-to-7 victory over Rochester in the opening game of the series tonight.

BERLIN, June 20. -- In a pointed statement today Wilhelm Furtwaengler, conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, who last year was appointed general musical director of the Baireuth festival, announced he had decided to sever his connection with the Festspielhaus because he refused to submit to "the dictation and interference" of Frau Winifred Wagner.

Speaking over the radio yesterday from Station WABC, W.A. Warn of the convention staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, now in Chicago, asserted that, with the Democratic National Convention just a week off, the relationship between Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and Tammany Hall occupied the foreground of public interest in that city.

Prizes, medals and academic honors to be conferred tomorrow evening at the eighty-sixth annual commencement exercises of City College in the Lewisohn Stadium were announced yesterday, by Dr. Morton Gottschall, registrar. The awards will be distributed by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, who also will deliver the commencement address.
CHICAGO, June 20. -- The lobbies and various headquarters in Michigan Boulevard's "political" hotels assumed a brightened atmosphere today as nearly 200 Democratic women gave it the "feminine touch."
LOS ANGELES, June 20. -- William Gibbs McAdoo, former Secretary of the Treasury, filed today as a candidate for Senator from California.

HOMEWOOD, Ill ., June 20 (AP) -- Scores of women who were delegates to the Republican National Conention were among the 14,000 spectators who enjoyed the racing at Washington Park today, and several of the events were named after women prominent in Illinois politics.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Evening-up operations were under way in the grain markets today in preparation for the new government tax on transactions on commodity exchanges, which will go into effect tomorrow. In some quarters it was said these operations had been going on several days on the Board of Trade here.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Reversing its former position to comply with a decision by the Supreme Court, the Interstate Commerce Commission today found that carload freight rates on fresh deciduous fruits, other than apples, from California to transcontinental destinations were not unreasonably high.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- After a stormy session behind closed doors, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee decided today not to question William Fox regarding his operations in Fox Films and Fox Theatres stock for the time being, but refused by unanimous vote to release him from a subpoena.

ST. PAUL, June 20 (AP). -- Earle Brown, Minneapolis millionaire horseroan, held a substantial lead over Franklin F. Ellsworth, Minneapolis attorney, for the Republican nomination for Governor in Minnesota's State wide primaries today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- Eight honorary degrees and eighty-five degrees in course were conferred by President Remsen B. Ogilby at the commencement exercises today of Trinity College's largest class. The exercises were held for the first time in the new chapel given, by William Gwinn Mather, '87, of Cleveland, for many years a trustee.
NEWARK, June 21 (AP). -- The Bears took both ends of a double-header from the Buffalo Bisons today, 6 -- 2, and 6 -- 4, advancing to within a half game of second place.
Charley Retzlaff, Duluth (Minn.) heavyweight, outpointed Hans Birkie, Oakland, Cal., in the five-round bout preceding the championship in the bowl last night.

Although the annual steel-ingot producing capacity of the nation was increased 1,401,860 tons last year to 68,298,956 tons, a new high record, the pig iron and ferro-alloy capacity was reduced for the first time in many years, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron, and Steel Institute showing production capacities as of Dec. 31, 1931.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris will rule this morning on a plea to direct the jury to acquit Isidor J. Kresel of a charge of perjury.
CHICAGO, June 21. -- With delegates to the Democratic convention now arriving by every train, head quarters for various Presidential candidates began to operate today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Hopes to adjourn Congress on Saturday evaporated this evening when they became entangled with debate on unemployment relief in the Senate and that body decisively, by a vote of 38 to 32, reversed plans of its leaders to hold night sessions.

At the eighty-sixth annual commencement exercises of the College of the City of New York, in the stadium at 8:30 o'clock this evening, 1.577 degrees and diplomas will be conferred by the College of Liberal Arts and Science, the School of Technology, the School of Business and Civic Administration and the School of Education.

Buyers' Registrations Fell. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the number registered in the previous week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 21. -- A resolution calling upon "the recognized outstanding Jews of the country to formulate a program and platform which will bring together all shades of Jewish opinion in favor of Jewish objectives and bring about harmonious action of American Jewry in all things affecting local and international relations relating to our people" was adopted here today at the concluding session of the annual convention of the Order of B'rith Sholom.
WELLESLEY, Mass., June 21 -- "There was never a time when clear thinking was more needed," M. Roy Ridley of Oxford University told the alumnae and graduating class at Wellesley College this morning.

The advisory board of the Association of Railway Executives reinforced yesterday a movement to improve railroad credit by authorizing the appointment of a committee to supplement one already active in the bituation. Each committee will study one of what the executives believe to be the two major aspects of the problem.

The Board of Taxicab Control, at a special executive meeting in City Hall yesterday, took a hand in an investigation now being carried on by three State departments regarding the sufficiency of the insurance carried by 2,300 taxicabs operated by three subsidiaries of the Parmelee Transportation System.

The sincerity of Mayor Walker's repeated avowals in favor of rapid transit unification, was questioned yesterday by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., in a letter challenging the Mayor to fix the date for the first of a series of unity conferences in which city officials and spokesmen, for the B.M.T., Interborough and civic groups would participate.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 21. -- The human eye, peering through a powerful telescope at the Lowell Observatory in Arizona, has at last penetrated the thick clouds that surround our neighboring planet Venus and had its first glimpse of what is believed to be the surface of the planet, it was revealed here today during the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
READING, Pa., June 21 (AP). -- Reading and Toronto split a doubleheader tonight, the Maple Leafs winning the twilight game of seven innings, 12 to 1. while the Keye snatched the night game, 9 to 8.

A smiling and democratic young prince registered at a midtown hotel yesterday afternoon, and soon afterward opened the door of his suite to a reported inquiring for His Highness, Prince Subba Svasti of Siam.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 21 -- An ovation was given Alfred E. Smith, Democratic Presidential possibility, when the Twentieth Century Limited pulled in here tonight bearing the former Governor and party on their way to the Democratic convention at Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Contrary to reports from Lausanne and Geneva that the American arms delegation was discussing cancellation or modification of debts, Secretary Stimson in a formal statement today denied that this question had entered into the discussions.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 21 (AP). -- The remedy for depression already exists on a small scale in American factories, the American Association for the Advancement of Science was informed today.
Charles Sarka, a well-known illustrator for fiction magazines, is having an exhibition of his work in water-color at his newly leased gallery, 696 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- The same Philadelphia Athletics who batted out twenty-six hits yesterday made just six off Milton Gaston today and the Chicago White Sox defeated the American League champions, 3 to 1, to even the series.

By expensive autos, by ancient rattletrap machines, by subway, street car and on foot, the spectators arrived at the Madison Square Garden bowl for the world's championship fight last night. And so great was the jamming by any method of conveyance that there was some difficulty experienced in reaching the bowl.

A warning that China Is rapidly becoming a serious menace to the cotton and cotton goods industries of this country through her ability to undersell in the markets of the world was sounded yesterday at an informal meeting of twenty-five representatives of various Cotton Exchange houses at the Downtown Association.

John Markle, in behalf of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, has donated $100,000 to the Salvation Army United Appeal, it was announced yesterday, increasing total contributions in the campaign for $1,090,000 to $425,000.

PARIS, June 21. -- The French are giving evidence today of being worried at the turn affairs at Lausanne have taken. When Premier Herriot returned Saturday ana announced that France had not yielded, and that Germany was joining the test of Europe in placing the ultimate burden of the solution on American cancellation of war debts, France was obviously satisfied.

Debts ranging from a few dollars to nearly $1,000,000 against the estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical producer, who died on March 6, 1930, Were presented yesterday at a hearing before Surrogate John P. O'Brien on objections to an accounting of the estate filed by Saul Baron, temporary administrator.

ALBANY, June 21. -- Outlining his plans for the period of the Democratic National Convention, Governor Roosevelt said today that he intended to follow his normal routine in Albany as Chief Executive and leave his nomination drive to his aides in Chicago.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 21. -- Scoring five goals in the first period and holding the opposition scoreless, Winston Guest's Templeton quartet opened its drive for the third Westbury challenge cup at the Meadow Brook Club today by downing the United States Army polo team, 14 to in a second-round match, both teams having drawn byes in the first round.

HAVANA, June 21. -- Authorization to continue military rule until the end of his term in 1935 was granted to President Machado in a secret session of the House of Representatives early this morning. When approved by the Senate, where no opposition is expected, the action will maintain in effect the martial law that has existed in the entire island since Aug. 10, 1931.

An investigation of the investments of New York fire and casualty insurance companies by the Republican Advisory Committee of New York County has shown the need for legislation to prevent investments by these companies in common stocks, and to protect assets which have been depleted through speculative ventures, according to a tentative report of the committee.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 21. -- In view of Speaker Garner's open pronouncement in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, a bolter movement in Texas is likely, should he be chosen as the Presidential nominee of the Democratic party, according to observers of politics in this State.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 21. -- More than twenty women golfers were entered today in the flag tournament arranged by Mrs. Clifford H. McCall. This is the first tournament play of the season on the Maidstone Club links. The annual women's ringer tournament for best score up to Sept. 15 also begins this week.
STURBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -- Close races, two of them necessitating extra heats, featured the Bay State circuit racing opening before 1,500 spectators today.

Japan's Manchurian campaign was defended as only a measure of self-protection against a Chinese policy of systematic economic aggression and violation of treaty rights by Viscount Kikujiro Ishii in an article on "The League and the Japanese Problem" in a new international review, Contemporary Japan, copies of which arrived here yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times : I read with interest your editorial "Learning to Speak French" and agree it is a stupid method to teach only reading and translating.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP). -- Steady pitching by Pat Malone, coupled with timely and heavy hitting by his mates, gave the Cubs a 12-to-3 triumph over the Phillies today.

Accusing Dr. Cyrua Adler, president of the American Jewish Committee, of disrupting Jewish unity at a critical time, the American Jewish Congress announced yesterday its determination to go ahead with plans for the convening of a preliminary conference in Geneva this Summer to consider calling a world Jewish Congress.

The concentration and control of the world's gold supply in the hands of bankers operating through the central banks of the respective nations is the primary cause of the depression, and unless remedied it will lead to revolution, former Mayor John F. Hylan declares in a book, "Gold: Its Control Over Nations and Men," just published by the Prosperity Publishing Company.

In a further effort to stabilize the petroleum markets outside the United States, Charles E. Arnott, president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, and Harold F. Sheets, its vice president, sailed last midnight on the Ile de France to meet the principal oil producing interests of Rumania with a view to arranging orderly marketing of oil exports from that country.

Humaneness is still appreciated and in some instances rewarded, as it was in the case of Joseph Krankoff veteran B.M.T. motorman, who risked incurring the wrath of his superiors by bringing in his train six minutes behind schedule during the rush hour last Thursday morning and thereby prevented killing a small Pomeranian which ran down the right-of-way in front of the train.

SEATTLE, June 21 -- Clinton P. Anderson, a 36-year-old insurance man of Albuquerque, N.M., was elected president of Rotary International oday to succeed Sydney W. Pascall, an English confectioner. He was the only nominee.

Having received assurance of necessary support from the Railroad Credit Corporation, the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway forwarded to Washington yesterday an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of about $4,000,000 to cover taxes and interest on its 4 and 5 per cent prior lien bonds due on July 1.

LONDON, June 21 (Canadian Press). -- The British taxpayer cannot indefinitely shoulder most of the burden of defense and other empire services unless greater facilities for trade within the empire are accorded, declares the report on empire trade adopted by the British Association of Chambers of Commerce, made public today.

Despite the depression, a large volume of business still is carried on throughout the country and it can be increased by intelligent sales effort, largely through advertising, according to business leaders who addressed the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Behind the excellent pitching and the terrific hitting of Freddy Heimach the Robins yesterday overpowered the Pirates, 9 to 2, to go into a tie with the Buccaneers for third place and place themselves within two games of the second-place Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- John Nance Garner of Texas today made his first direct gesture as an aspirant for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency with the statement that he had never believed the prohibition amendment sound or workable, "and it should be repealed."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- General Pelham D. Glassford, Superintendent of Police, began negotiating with railroads today for the return of the bonus marchers to their home States and said arrangements would be completed tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, June 21 (AP). -- Morris F. Freund, a salesman, of 212 Fifth Avenue, New York City, was injured fatally when catapulted from his speeding car as it rounded a curve near here late this afternoon. He died before two ambulances from this city reached the scene.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 21 (AP). -- In a State convention dominated by younger members of the party, Paul V. McNutt, former National Commander of the American Legion, was nominated today by acclamation as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Indiana.

Cass Gilbert, New Tork architect, and Mrs. Gilbert are among those departing today for France and England on the White Star liner Majestic. Others sailing include Eugene Goossens, orchestra conductor; Dr. Royal Whitman, T.F. Whitmarsh and Mrs. Whitmarsh. New Yorkers include:

MOSCOW, June 21 -- The president of the Supreme Economic Council, Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, today threatened severe discipline for the heads of factories supplying material for automobile trucks unless they delivered their quotas not later than July 5.

A series of twelve free orchestral concerts, to be known as the Toscanini fund concerts, will be presented during July and August for students enrolled in the Summer sessions of the colleges of New York, it was announced yesterday by Harry Harkness Flagler, chairman of the committee of the Musicians Emergency Aid, which is administering the special fund raised by the benefit concert conducted by Arturo Toscanini at Carnegie Hall on April 28.

The heavyweight boxing championship of the world came back to America last night. Jack Sharkey, disappointed in his quest of the title heretofore, won the crown when he received a fifteen-round decision over Max Schmeling, the methodical German, who entered the ring as the pugilistic king of the universe and left it an ex-champion.

Eugene F. Moran, chairman, of the Committee of the Marine Industries of the United States, representing twenty organizations allied to shipping, made public yesterday a resolution adopted by the committee last week urging the Secretary of Commerce to appoint Dickerson N. Hoover, Supervising Inspector General of the Steamboat Inspection Service, as head of the proposed consolidated Inspection Bureau and the Bureau of Navigation.

Sunset in the bowl. Wind southeast. Track fast. Weather partly cloudy. A blimp sailing overhead. Another blimp was reported to the eastward but it turned out to be primo Camera approaching the ringside. First bulletin on the big fight came from underneath the ring.

Copies of three letters, two bearing the name and office address of Abraham Wilson, attorney for William J. Flynn, Bronx Public Works Commissioner, were handed to reporters at City Hall yesterday in what appeared to be a further move in the legal controversy between Mr. Wilson and Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Amid the stir and bustle of setting the stage for the big Democratic national show the advance guard of leaders, engaged in conferences in which the strategy of the various factions is being formulated, tonight were eagerly awaiting the arrival of two of the principal figures, Alfred E. Smith, titular national leader of the party, and John F. Curry, chieftain of Tammany Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times. As I have received a copy of the letter forwarded to you by Dr. Futrall, I am anxious to explain my reactions to certain comments made, by him to the end of establishing a better understanding.

BERLIN, June 21 (AP). -- The brown shirts of Adolf Hitler's followers provoked disorders throughout the Reich today that took two lives and resulted in injuries to many on the eve of an apparently inevitable showdown between the Federal and State Governments over display of the Fascist uniforms.

Dr. Ernest H. Lines, chief medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, pointed out yesterday that more than 60 per cent of drownings take place from the beginning of May to the end of August and that nearly half of them are men and boys under 25 years of age.

The four men who control a majority of the New York State delegation to the Democratic National Convention, left for Chicago at 12:05 A.M. today, declaring that their choice of a nominee would be determined at the scene of action, and that no decision had been made as yet.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 21. -- Mrs. R.C. Lake of the Old Country Club and Miss Helen Hicks of Lido, winner and runner-up, respectively, in the women's Long Island championship golf tourney last year, triumphed in the first-round matches today at the Cherry Valley Club and will oppose each other tomorrow.

GLEN COVE, N.Y., June 21. -- Mrs. Herbert Lee Pratt won fifteen first awards and seven seconds this afternoon on the first of the two-day annual rose and sweet pea show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society on the Pratt estate.

Helen Wice, 17 years old, of 467 West Forty-sixth Street, fainted in the court room and her mother screamed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Edward Dore dismissed a suit for $25,000 damages brought by her against Edward W. Browning, real estate operator, and the Edbro and the Broadway and Sixty-first Street Corporations for injuries she received while entering the building to attend a children's Christmas party given by Mr. Browning on Dec. 22, 1928.

A fast start and a game race won The Woodhaven Claiming Stakes for Mrs. George M. Seglin's Cutie Face at Aqueduct yesterday in one of the closest finishes of the meeting. The daughter of Chilhowee just lasted to win by a nose from H.C. Phipps's Balios, which was a length before Mrs. W.T. Andersen's Merry Caroline.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 21 -- At a simple ceremony under the long silver side of the United States airship Akron tomorrow one of the most experienced lighter-than-air officers of the navy, Lieut. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, will turn over command of the giant dirigible to Commander Algar H. Dresel, who has been skipper of the Los Angeles, and begin a tour of sea duty aboard the battleship West Virginia.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 21 -- More than 3,000 taxpayers of the town of Greenburgh, which includes Irvington, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings, Ardsley and Elmsford, filed written protests against increased property assessments at the Town Hall here today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 21. -- David N. Jones, Columbia University basketball and tennis star, advanced to the fourth round of the national intercollegiate tournament by easily beating Joseph Coughlin of Stanford University at the Merion Cricket Club courts today.

A predominantly hostile audience of 200 men. and women walked out on their speaker, A.J. Muste, chairman of the Conference for Progressive Labor Action, at a mass meeting last night in the Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street. The meeting had been called to permit members of a supposedly impartial committee to appeal for a fair election Friday night in Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

ATHENS, June 21 (AP). -- The daring of a Levantine beauty in entering a monastery on Mount Athos, where nothing female is allowed -- not even a cow, goat, dog or chicken -- was understood today to have brought a pronouncement of "public anathema" upon her head.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of all the great business men called to Washington by the Council of National Defense during the upheaval of the World War, none bore himself with more dignity and fineness than did Judge Robert S. Lovett, who died on Sunday.

HANOVER, N.H., June 21. -- With the evergreen background of College Park as a setting, Dartmouth brought its commencement exercises to a close today with the graduation of 424 men from the class of 1932.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 11 totaled 501,670 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 54,373 cars more than in the preceding week, when loadings were somewhat reduced owing to the observance of Decoration Day; 230,649 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 424,306 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Although the turnover on the Stock Exchange was greater by about 100,000 shares than on the day before, Wall Street continued to complain yesterday of the lack of interest in the market. The day's trading involved a total of 491,000 shares.
Small flats again comprised the bulk of realty conveyances in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

Among the paintings in the Summer exhibition at Kraushaar's, which opened yesterday, you will find "Head Waiter," by Guy Pene du Bois. The lady who is asking him to give her his very best table might never get into the "Follies" or "Vanities," but head waiters subscribe to codes of their own, and the lady, who seems admirably to know her way about, will doubtless have no cause for complaint in his restaurant.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- As the Democratic women arrived today in increasing numbers for the national convention, two outstanding convictions were discerned among them. They were confident of the choice of Governor Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination and appeared to be almost 100 per cent in favor of a repeal plank in the platform.

Emanuel Neumann, member of the Executive of the World Zionist Organization and of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, returned from Palestine yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and reported that Palestine was one of few countries not in the throes of the economic depression.

Home-going office workers descending in the elevators of the south wing of the Hudson Terminal Building at 30 Church Street at 5:30 P.M. yesterday unconsciously rubbed elbows with four armed men whose pockets were bulging with about $20,000 worth of platinum and gold stolen from an office on the eighth floor after binding and gagging three men and a woman.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 21 (AP). -- Carlos G. Davila, president of the ruling junta, was taken ill tonight with a severe attack of grip in the midst of a critical political situation involving the safety of American lives and property.

GENEVA, Wednesday, June 22 -- The rapidly moving situation in the disarmament conference reached a climax at 2 o'clock this morning when this League of Nations rushed out notices convoking a public meeting of the general commission for this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- For losses incurred as a result of a Navy Department order in 1918 which commandeered the Bush Terminal Buildings in New York, the United States Court of Claims has awarded $40,979 to the William Wrigley Jr. Company.
GENEVA, June 21 (AP) -- The United States informed the governments of Europe today that so long as they continued heavy expenditures for armaments they need expect no revision of war debts.

According to the Human Betterment Foundation of Pasadena, Cal., 18,000,000 of us are either actually or potentially so weak in the head that we will coat the community one billion a year because of our crimes and our inability to fend for ourselves. The figures are preposterous on their very face.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- Ruth, Gehrig and Lazzeri knocked home nine runs for the Yankees today, but the scoring play that decided the battle with the Browns was a wild throw past first base by Chad Kimsey in fielding Dickey's bunt in the ninth with the score tied at 8 -- all.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21 -- Starvation of the nation would follow the abandonment of mechanized agriculture and a return to the hand tools of a century ago, Leonard J. Fletcher of Peoria, Ill., president of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers, declared in an address before the society's annual meeting at Ohio State University today.

Two more perfectly conditioned athletes never weighed in for a ring battle, according to Commissioner William Muldoon, who yesterday supervised the weighing of Max Schmeling and Jack Sharkey in the basement of the State Office Building, at Worth and Centre Streets.

The war of contract bridge is at least temporarily over, it was anounced yesterday by the two most belligerent factions represented in the battle last Winter between Sidney S. Lenz, a sponsor of the "official sysem," and Ely Culbertson, sponsor of the Culbertson system of bidding.

ALBANY, June 21 -- New rules of calendar practice were promulgated today by the Court of Appeals to go into effect in the Fall. They are expected to speed up the work of the court, giving it greater control of its business by putting cases on the calendar as soon as the returns are filed.

The government of the United States, which almost two years ago began an action to padlock the Central Park Casino, fashionable restaurant which has enjoyed the patronage of Mayor Walker, has decided not to press its original suit, and will be content instead if the defendant posts a bond to guarantee future compliance with the law.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 21. -- A suit believed to involve nearly $5,000,000 was filed here today by Henry A. Uterhart, an attorney of New York City, in behalf of the Fox Theatres Corporation against William Fox, Jack G. Leo, Eva Fox, Carolyn Lean Tauszig, Mr. Fox's daughter; John Zanft, Jacob Rubenstein and Bessie Livingstone.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21 -- Radcliffe College will graduate 222 at its commencement exercises tomorrow and in the afternoon will dedicate, the John Chipman Gray Memorial Gate. The gate is the gift of the late Mrs. Gray in memory of her husband, who espoused the cause of Radcliffe College while he was Royall Professor of Law in Harvard Law School and suggested the relationship with Harvard which was later incorporated in the Radcliffe charter.

Definite conviction that Senator Samuel H.
