Hofstadter will be nominated for one of the posts on the Republican State-wide ticket this Fall in the event that before that time he is not named a Federal district judge was expressed last night as the Republicans of the Fifteenth Assembly District met and endorsed Walter S. Mack Jr. for the State Senate post which Mr. Hofstadter now holds.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 21. -- Mrs. George Rudnick, representing the Tibbetts Brook Golf Club of Van Cortlandt Park, tied for low gross and second net prizes and lost both awards by matching cards in a women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

BOSTON, June 21 -- Senora Calles, wife of Plutarco Elias Calles, War Minister and former President of Mexico, arrived in Boston tonight by train to be taken immediately to the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, where it was expected that Dr. Harvey Cushing would perform an operation to remove a brain tumor.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 21. -- On the fiftieth anniversary of his graduation and the twentieth of his presidency, Dr. John Grier Hibben retired as president of Princetqn University here today after having reeived the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the 185th commencement.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 21. -- Play at Longwood as the fourth annual college girls' invitation tennis tournament got under way today was featured by the ease in which the four seeded girls, Charlotte Miller, New York University; Helen Marlowe, University of Southern California, and Marjorie Sachs and Dorrance Chase of Simmons, won their matches to advance into the third rouffd.

CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP). -- The third-place Washington Senators got revenge on Jack Russell today for six victories he had won over them as a member of the Red Sox, as they defeated Cleveland, 8-to 3.
DUBLIN, June 21 (AP). -- Ireland has never before witnessed such a celebration as that which opens in her capital tomorrow, the Eucharistic Congress.

LONDON, June 21. -- The stock markets opened uncertain today, business declining following receipt of Lausanne news, but in the afternoon prices rallied. There was considerable profit-taking in British Government funds as the dollar continued to improve.

Senator Carter Glass, who voted for the Eighteenth Amendment and always has been a total abstainer, declared yesterday that prohibition was not a party question and that the issue of repeal should be resubmitted to the States for determination through State conventions rather than by the State Legislatures.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- High officials and scientific honors were accorded today to Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam for her solo flight across the Atlantic.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21. -- Governor White sent a letter to former Senator Pomerene today committing himself to submission of the question of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to State conventions. The letter was in response to requests for the Governor's position to guide Mr. Pomerene in nominating him as a candidate for President at the Democratic National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Speculative interest in the grain markets was at a low ebb the greater part of today, the pit element on the Board of Trade here refusing to trade as the result of the increased commodity exchange tax. This caused wheat to hold within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel most of the day with little attention paid to the news.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Borah, a central figure in the wet-dry controversy, threw new fuel on the flames by attacking the administration's prohibition platform from two different angles today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States for the week ended on Saturday was 2,197,550 barrels, compared with 2,183,450 barrels for the preceding week, a gain of 14,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 19,200 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma and a decline of 6,100 barrels in that of California were the most important changes.

Daniel Carter Beard, National Commissioner of the Boy Scouts of America and father of the Scouting movement in America, celebrated his eighty - second birthday yesterday while congratulations and friendly messages poured in upon him from all over the United States.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I,. June 21. -- Sam Freeth of Salisbury and Mack Fisher of Old Westbury tied with John Hines of Old Westbury and George Hale of Hempstead for the low gross honors in a best-ball tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Wheatley Hills Club today.

Dizzy Dean, the tall and eccentric right-hander who decided a few days ago he would pitch no more baseballs for the world's champion Cardinals, only to change his mind on the matter, appeared at the Polo Grounds yesterday and at once made the Giants regret he had not stuck to his first decision.

City Hall Park Sometimes a step backward is a step forward. City Hall Park once extended all the way south to St. Paul's Church, and people walking up Broadway got a pleasant glimpse of the City Hall in the background, with shade trees and grass plots in between.
With practically every golfer of consequence in this country playing the course in practice, the Fresh Meadow Country Club's par of 70 still remains inviolate.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21. -- A home run by Albie Booth in the first inning with the bases filled, plus the effective pitching of Johnny Broaca, gave Yale a 4-2 victory over Harvard in the 158th baseball game between the Blue and the Crimson before a commencement crowd of 7,500 today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21. -- The first part of the two-day program which comprises the 231st commencement of Yale University was carried out today with the graduation of 704 seniors from Yale College and the Sheffield Scientific School.

In the presence of city officials and delegates from 227 colleges, universities, learned societies and associations. Dr. William A. Boylan was formally inaugurated as first president of Brooklyn College last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Following the installation ceremonies eighty-nine young men and women received degrees at the college's first commencement exercises.
Fishermen and boatmen spend a great deal of time in preparing for their respective expeditions, the angler going over his lines and lures, the skipper inspecting, painting, cleaning his craft.

Irving Klein, former Queens Highway Superintendent, was sentenced yesterday by County Judge Thomas Downs, of Queens, in the Long Island City Court to serve from one year and three months to two years and six months in prison for falsifying vouchers containing fraudulent claims against the city, but received a stay of execution.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In all good faith the Y.W.C.A. of the City of New York announced a beach club on Long Island Sound as one of the chief features of the citywide program of Summer sports and recreation for its members.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Criticizing hospital expansion of the past decade as "far beyond immediate needs," Dr. Nathan B. Van Etten, medical director of the Morrisania Hospital in New York, declared at Villanova College today that "financially unsound rivalries between cities and educational institutions have led to piling up of bricks and mortar into lasting memorials of monumental folly."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The two editorials in THE TIMES, one on President Hoover, his record and personality, the other warning the Democratic party to name its ablest, man as its nominee for the Presidency, stand out like twin beacons for those sailing our political seas.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- When the National Democratic Committee meets Friday it must begin action to determine whether a delegation dominated by Senator Huey P. Long or a delegation headed by former Governors John M. Parker, Jared Y. Sanders and Ruffin G. Pleasant shall cast Louisiana's twenty votes on the floor of the convention.

PORTLAND, Me., June 21 (AP). -- A wet Democratic nominee for Governor and a Republican generally considered to be favorable to his party's traditional support of prohibition in Maine will face each other in September's Slate election as a result of the vote in yesterday's primaries.

A greenish-yellow cloud sizzled out of a broken pipe yesterday in front of the Washine National Sands, Inc., a laundry supplies factory at Baldwin and Bradley Streets, the Bronx, on the edge of Mount Vernon. It was a cloud of chlorine gas that might have brought a whole battlefront to the qui vive during the World War.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 21 -- The Board of Assessors of the town of Oyster Bay, assisted by Charles I. Wood, township counsel, and Leonard W. Hall, special counsel, was besieged today by a stream of taxpayers and their attorneys who filed complaints on their 1933 assessments.

There was little definite trend to yesterday's movement of prices on any market; the general attitude was one of apathy. In stocks, the day's transactions hardly changed from the very small aggregate of the day before. A business of 500,000 shares or less on two successive five-hour markets brings Stock, Exchange activities to an abnormally low ebb.

Eugene J. Buffinaton will retire on July 1 as president of the Illinois Steel Company after serving thirty-four years in that office. He will leave the active service of the company at his own request under the pension plan of the United States Steel Corporation, of which Illinois Steel is a subsidiary.

PARIS, June 21. -- A sharp rally by Young Plan bonds, which, after falling to 462. jumped to 500 before closing, featured today's session of the Paris Bourse. The market was swept by rumors concerning the Lausanne conference, none of which was confirmed before the session ended.
BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP). -- Baltimore lost to Rochester, 14 to 5, today, the Red Wings breaking their losing streak with a 15-hit attack on three pitchers.

SYDNEY, N.S., June 21 -- Vainly sought by antiquarians and historians for nearly a century, what is believed to be the body of the illfated Due d'Anville, High Admiral of France and commander of the armada which crossed the North Atlantic to relieve Louisburg in 1745, was discovered today by government engineers who are excavating the ruins of Louisburg Fortress.

With Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin protesting against the extravagance of city appropriations for Independence Day celebrations, the Board of Aldermen authorized an expenditure of $6,000 yesterday for badges, medals and other accessories to be used in celebrating the day.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -- With three days of practice left before the renewal of the Yale-Harvard regatta on Friday, the crews of both went through a hard day's work along the Thames today.

Dramatic critics on a busman's holiday in Europe are already beginning to send back reports of the drama abroad. The stay-at-homes are glad enough to have the news. They have the left-over successes of last season, which they have probably seen already, and the tryouts of next season to amuse them in resort towns all the way from Maine down the coast and in the hills.

Alfred E. Smith left on the Twentieth Century Limited yesterday afernoon for Chicago to attend the Democratic National Convention, where his name will be presented as candidate for the nomination, for the Presidency for the fourth successive time.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont, who will sail today on the Majestic after a three months' stay in Washington, will return in September.
Max Schmeling weighed 188 pounds and Jack Sharkey tipped the scales at 205 pounds when they entered the ring for their championship battle last night.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -- With three days of practice left before the renewal of the Yale-Harvard regatta on Friday, the crews of both went through a hard day's work along the Thames today.

Dramatic critics on a busman's holiday in Europe are already beginning to send back reports of the drama abroad. The stay-at-homes are glad enough to have the news. They have the left-over successes of last season, which they have probably seen already, and the tryouts of next season to amuse them in resort towns all the way from Maine down the coast and in the hills.

Although more active than on the previous day, the listed bond market failed to how any definite trend yesterday except United States Govemenent long-term issues, which were strong. Closing prices for the government issues were unchanged to 15-32 point higher with the exception of the infrequently traded first Liberty 4s, which sold off 1-32 point.

Samuel Unlermyer, as counsel with Siegfried Hartman of the independent protective committee of Kreuger Toll debenture holders, issued last night an appeal to holders of the debentures to deposit them with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- France tonight seems to block the way to a realization of the plan to link the disarmament conference at Geneva and the reparations and debts parley at Lausanne.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- The University of Pennsylvania will award degrees in course to 1,595 graduates tomorrow morning af commencement exercises which will bring to a close the university's 192d academic year. Ten honorary degrees also will be conferred.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 21. -- Miss Helen Silleck, representing the Greenwich Country Club, triumphed over an old rival today when she defeated Miss Jane Evans of Siwanoy 1 up, at the Tamarack Country Club, to gain the second round of the women's Westchester and Fairfield golf championship.

Governor Roosevelt paid a high tribute to Daniel D. Tompkins, Vice President of the United States under President James Monroe and Governor of New York for four terms, whose 158th birthday anniversary was observed on Staten Island yesterday with the unveiling of a bronze tablet to his memory in Tompkins Park, at Tompkinsville, as part of Staten Island's Washington bicentennial celebration.
This little matter of howling beasts in the Central Park Zoo is assuming the proportions of an issue -- at least, in the minds of those who live in the vicinity thereof.

Carl Joeken, a Berlin operatic tenor, and Gretl Theimer, who is best known over here for her performance in "Zwei Herzen im Drei-Viertel Takt," are the principals in "Schubert's Fruhlingstraum" (Schubert's Dream of Spring), the new German-language picture at the Europa.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21 -- Sullen skies brightened over the Harvard Stadium late this afternoon as the sons of John Harvard rose to meet their challenge in song and cheer.

DUBLIN, June 21 -- Although, the formal opening of the Eucharistic Congress will not take place until tomorrow afternoon, Dublin buzzed with activity today. The welcome to the Papal Legate yesterday has been acknowledged as one of the most impressive displays of popular enthusiasm ever seen in this country, and Cardinal Lauri expressed delighted surprise at the warmth of the reception.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES publishes a letter frost M. Reni-Mel regarding a movement by the arts division of the General Federation of Women's Clubs for a law making obligatory the employment of American artists when the portraits are to be paid for out of public funds.
LONDON, June 21 (Canadian Press). -- Kent defeated Hampshire by 90 runs in a first-class county cricket game which was concluded today at Portsmouth.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 21 (AP). -- Gallant Knight, the Audley Farm Stable's handicap star, raced a mile in 1:35 3-5 today to set a new Washington Park record for the distance, in winning the Great Northern Handicap.

Spending almost as much energy to fight off the mob that stormed his dressing room as he did in the ring, Jack Sharkey, newly crowned world's heavyweight champion, last night paid tribute to Max Schmeling and promised him a return bout "if there is enough money."

The Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., and its subsidiary report for the fifty-three weeks ended April 28 net income, before deducting write-offs and reserves in respect of accounts and notes receivable, mortgages and sundry investments charged to surplus, of $578,423.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, romping through her match with Fraulein M.R. Couquerque of Holland with the loss of only two games, at 6-1, 6-1, went into the second round today together with Miss Helen Jacobs, No. 2 ranking American player, who eliminated Miss Southwell of England by the same score.

Less favorable weather in extreme northwestern and southeastern sections of the cotton belt caused a further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. An advance of about 10 points carried July fn within 2 points of the high levels of last week, but a decline in the stock market In the last hour caused reselling and the list closed 3 to 4 points higher on the day.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 21 (AP). -- The statement that white paper can be made from virtually all of the South's pine forests was made here today. White paper chemical pulp, made for the first time from long leaf and loblolly pines, was prepared for exhibition at a meeting of the Georgia Forestry Association tomorrow at Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Provision for administration of the manufacturers' excise taxes, estimated to yield $450,500,000 in revenue to the government, was made in new regulations issued today by David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue. These taxes went into effect today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 21 -- The legitimate sale of liquor is not profitable to drug stores and the "saloon drug store" is harmful to the trade, Albert A. Muench of Syracuse, president of the State Pharmaceutical Association, told 400 delegates at the association's annual convention here today.

Assurance, most economically, of a total transportation adequate for national needs should be the lode star of public railroad policy. Neither sympathy nor justice for employes or owners, essential as that may be, must give way to this fundamental social requirement.

THAT war-worn veteran Sergeant Gabby Street could hardly talk when he came into town with his Cardinals the other day. As they were closing out what was intended to be a pleasant stay in, Philadelphia, the City of Brotherly Love, the Phillies leaped upon his world's champions and throttled them twice in an afternoon.

Sympathy with proposals to modify the prohibition law was expressed yesterday by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. Discussing economic trends, Mr. Willard asserted that there are some authorities "who hold that before we can have an entirely satisfactory condition, some modification must be made of our prohibition law, and I am inclined to be sympathetic with that thought.
Senator BOKAH'S speech is rightly regarded as a political event of firstclass importance. It contains nonessentials that may be passed by.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 21 (AP). -- Returns today revealed that new forces had won control of the Demoratic party in Minnesota's Statewide primaries of Monday, and tonight the nominal head of the movement hailed the result as "repudiation" of the Democratic Stata Contention's prior indorsement of Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination.

What three months ago was a barren stretch of Long Island terrain, nestling, as inconspicuously as fair Auburn, in the backyard of a railroad siding, stood transformed last night into the crossroads of the sports world.

The directors of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey voted yesterday to make a 6 per cent reduction applicable to both its payroll and to dividends payable to holders of its common stock to meet conditions due to reduced earnings and to additional costs imposed by the new Federal budget-balancing tax law.

Millions of listeners-in last night heard the radio broadcast of the Schmeling-Sharkey fight over the National Broadcasting Company, network that reached all over the United States, Canada and by short-wave stations to Germany and South America.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. I believe I won. I never was so surprised in all my life as I was when Joe Humphries announced: "Winner and new champion, Jack Sharkey." I think there was only one person more amazed than I and that person was Sharkey.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- An order allowing the receivers of the Middle West Utilities Company to discontinue twelve life insurance policies of Samuel Insull and associates and to collect the cash surrender value on them was granted today by Judge Walter C. Lindley of the Federal court.

BERLIN, June 21. -- The Boerse was in the doldrums today, prices fluctuating feebly in listless trading, the market closing weak. There was liquidation in Gelsenkirchen following yesterday's announcement of the reorganization, the stock declining 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP). -- Told of alleged tax evasions mounting into the millions, the Senate today authorized its Banking Committee to continue its investigation of the stock market until the expiration of the present Congress, March 4.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 21. -- Henri Cochet of France was tumbled to defeat today in the first major upset of the Wimbledon tennis tourney.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds made sixteen hits off Ed Brandt and Bruce Cunningham of the Braves to win, 9 to 3, today, and make it two out of three in the series.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- References of Viscount Kikujiro Ishii before the Japan-America Society in Tokyo to fears that the United States might attempt to dominate the Asiatic continent and prevent Japan "from her pacific and natural expansion in this part of the world" aroused no adverse reaction here because of the pacific tone of the address.

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, Brooklyn racketeer, had returned from an airplane visit to the Great Meadows prison at Comstock, N. Y., where he was an overnight guest of Warden Joseph H. Wilson, only a few hours before he was fatally shot last Sunday morning, it became known last night.

Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, has advised State-chartered banks and trust companies that for purposes of examination by the Banking Department the principle of disregarding market prices of bonds in cases in which these figures are below intrinsic value, which has applied to bond Investments, will be extended to collateral held by banks against loans.

Jack Sharkey rose from the obscure position of a $30-a-month sailor in the United States Navy to a position of independent wealth and world-wide fame in the amazingly short period of eight years and as a consequence of fewer than fifty ring struggles.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 21. -- Until late in the day the best gross score in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Shackamaxon Country Club today was a 76 by Franklin P. Russell Jr. of Canoe Brook, a former Princeton golfer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing could be further from the truth than to state, as Charles Morrow Wilson, does in your issue of June 12, that Arkansas is turning away from the great progress that she has made in education in the last twenty years and is looking back toward primitive conditions.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 22 -- A call to participate more in world and community affairs was sounded today at the annual Rotary international convention in the Civic Auditorium here by David J. Keese, Governor of the Second District at Ventura, Cal.

Making another one of those astonishing about turns which has kept them bounding from one extreme to the other all season, the Giants rallied with a grand display of magnificence around a brilliant two-hit pitching effort by Carl Hubbell at the Polo Grounds yesterday to trounce the Cardinals, 9 to 1.

The need for a more equitable distribution of property assessments in New York and "constant study of tax problems by the Tax Department" was stressed by William H. Alien of the Institute for Public Service in a statement yesterday in which he defended land values against "bearish talk," which, he said, was based in large measure on failure to recognize changes in the dollar's value.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 22 (AP) -- Denial that unless a receiver is appointed its assets will be subjected to "vexatious litigation" was made today in an answer by the Southwest Gas Utilities Corporation of Chicago to a receivership suit filed against it recently by Jennie Fox of New York, owner of a $500 bond of the corporation.

LONDON, June 22 -- The annual meeting of the General Electric Company, Ltd., will be held on June 30, when Sir Hugo Hirst, chairman is expected to give the shareholders a satisfactory report. Profits for the year amount to u1,957,657, and after making provision for the addition of u130,000 to reserves the directors will recommend a dividend of 8 per cent.

After reading in the House of Commons last week a dispatch from Mr. DE VALERA, the Secretary for Dominions, Mr. THOMAS, said that it left the situation of the Anglo-Irish dispute worse than it was before. The Irish President maintained his intransigent position with regard to the oath of allegiance, which he didn't even take the trouble to mention.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Lou Gehrig arched homers over the local right field pavilion in the seventh and eighth innings today, his sixteenth and seventeenth of the season, driving home five runs; but instead of saddening the 2,000 fans in the stands, Lou's two explosions merely made them laugh.

HOMEWOOD, Ill., June 22 (AP) -- Aba Barteistein's California 4-year-old Polydorus today took his final warm-up for the Peabody Memorial Handicap on Saturday by defeating Gold Step and Don Leon in the best event at Washington Park.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 22 -- Chambers Field of the Bronxville schools was the scene tonight of an outdoor sport and theatrical show arranged by the Leonard S. Morange Post of the American Legion, assisted by the Bronxville League for Service and the Bronxville Boy Scouts, for the benefit of the unemployed.

MAX SCHMELING won the heavyweight championship of the world sitting down. Jack Sharkey of Boston won it backing up. Other times, other customs. John L. Sullivan was on the floor in New Orleans when Gentleman Jim Corbett was crowned king of the heavyweights in 1892. Gentleman Jim was down in the dust when Bob Fitzsimmons, the Freckled Ccrnishman, was hailed as the new champion at Carson City.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- Germany presented to the conference on war debts and reparations today the suggestion that in return for the cancellation of reparations she would be ready to engage in close economic cooperation in the interest of general recovery, with frequent meetings among the nations' Ministers of Industry and Trade that would help to establish a common policy.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity is practically unchanged at 20.6 for the week ended June 18, as against 20.4 for the preceding week and 43.1 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output this week is 2 points lower than last, according to The Iron Age, which estimates the current operating rate at 16 per cent of capacity.

Steel houses, to be marketed like automobiles, even to the extent of agency dealers, time payments and trade-in value, were envisioned yesterday in the announcement of General Houses, Inc., a corporation as yet in the formative stage.

SHANGHAI, June 22 -- Settlement of the controversy in Manchukuo over the interview of A.T. Steele, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and a Swiss correspondent named Lindt with General Ma Chenshan, the insurgent leader, is believed to be near.

It is refreshing in these days of pussyfooting to hear Governor SMITH declare that now, as in the days when the movement against prohibition had gathered little of its present strength, he is "for the un"conditional repeal of the Eigh"teenth Amendment."

PARIS, June 22 -- Although the text of the Hoover disarmament proposal had not been published in Paris today, the news that Hugh S. Gibson was reading it at Geneva was received and created a great sensation, dominating all the discussions of political groups assembled in Parliament and commanding the predominant attention of the press and public.

PARIS, June 22 -- Uncertainty over the Lausanne negotiations weighed against the market today and trading lapsed into inactivity. During the first half of the session, prices held steady, but during the latter half a general decline developed. Young Plan bonds, which reached 500 yesterday, fell to 482.

The last remaining member of the Brazilian Davis Cup team was eliminated from the Eastern clay court championship yesterday when Ricardo Pernambuco was defeated by Edward Tarangioli of New York at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Closing their series with the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday before 6,000 fans with a near "Garrison finish" that didn't quite come off, the Robins dropped the final game, 7 to 8, and tumbled from third to fifth place as the Pirates supplanted them in the fourth position and the Phillies rose from fifth to fourth, which they hold by a fraction of a point.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Should his paper strength materialize in the convention committee meetings, Franklin D. Roosevelt will outline personally, a straightforward repeal plank for the Democratic platform, and also give his specific views on the economic pronouncements.

The nineteen-story Starrett-Lehigh Building, occupying the site bounded by Eleventh and Thirteenth Avenues, Twenty-sixth to Twenty-seventh Street, has been purchased by the Lehigh Valley Railroad from the Starrett Investing Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Arthur B. Walsh, vice president of the corporation.

BUDAPEST, June 22 -- The Hungarian Government has at last succeeded in persuading Hungary's American creditors to accept a standstill agreement similar to that of English creditors. As a result of yesterday's signatures to this standstill agreement.

Sixteen years ago William Collins escaped from San Quentin prison in California after serving two years of a twenty-five-year sentence for a street car hold-up. Yesterday he was in the line-up at Police Headquarters here facing return to San Quentin.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A decline of 1.5 per cent in ownership of automobiles through the world from 35,805,632 in 1930 to 35,263,397 in 1931 was shown in an international census compiled by C.F. Baldwin and made public today by the Commerce Department.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- All the American entrants came through successfully on the third day of the Wimbledon tennis tourney in uneventful matches all played on outer courts except the match in which Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, Wimbledon doubles champions of 1929 and 1930, were extended to win.

William Faulkner's "Sanctuary," "Bubu of Montparnasse," by Charles Louis Philippe, and "Strange Women," by an anonymous author, were banned from Canada last week by the Canadian Department of National Revenue.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Senate wants Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, the first woman to fly the Atlantic alone, to receive the same award bestowed upon Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh -- the Distinguished Flying Cross -- instead of the Distinguished Service Medal voted by the House.
NEWARK, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- The Newark Bears moved into second place, a game behind the pace-making Baltimore Orioles, when they defeated Buffalo tonight before 10,000 fans, 6 to 4.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S action in the matter of the charges against Mayor WALKER is entirely, if somewhat coldly, correct. He calls upon the Mayor to reply to the accusations. No time limit is fixed, but there seems to be no doubt that Mr. WALKER will be allowed to wait until after the Chicago convention before making his defense.

SYRACUSE, June 22 -- The "ghosts of murdered molecules," "shot" by "guns" of radium constantly being fired in the air we breathe, were made to dance tonight in weird macabre rhythm upon an elaborate stage set of most intricate and delicate gadgets devised by ultramodern science before a large and spellbound audience of scientists and laymen attending the Summer meeting here of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

TOKYO, June 22 -- The Japanese Charge d'Affaires in Peiping is suggesting to the representatives of the other powers there an arrangement whereby the Manchurian proportion of Chinese debt services would be met out of the Manchurian maritime customs revenues and the surplus turned over to the new State of Manchukuo.
DUBLIN, June 22 -- Nine scarlet-robed Cardinals walked slowly down the aisle of Dublin's pro-cathedral today, opening the Eucharistic Congress.

New York City. According to present plans New York City will borrow on Monday $40,000,000 under the revolving fund arrangement entered into last January with a city-wide group of banking houses and commercial banks. As usual, the borrowing will take the form of the sale of revenue bills issued against revenues and taxes.

LONDON, June 22 -- While there was a quieter tone in evidence in British Government funds today, business among the industrials displayed signs of broadening on the Stock Exchange. British funds opened at around last night's closing, but in the absence of fresh support they became irregular.

MIAMI, Fla., June 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller, Australian aviatrix and prominent figure in the recent mysterious shooting of her fiance, Haden Clark, was arrested by Federal immigration authorities and placed in jail tonight on a charge of illegal entry into the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- A verbal message from Pope Pius XI urging that Catholic hospitals in this country pay greater attention to the neglected field of medical missions was transmitted by the Rev. Edward P. Garesche of New York, director of the Catholic Medical Mission Board, to the annual conference of the Catholic Hospital Association of the United States and Canada today at Villanova College.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A cooperative arrangement for booking and transporting passengers to, from and via North American Pacific Coast ports and Hawaii, and to, from and via Dutch East Indies ports, with interchange at Shanghai, Hongkong and Manila, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- The Tigers moved up from fourth to second place in the American League race today by beating Boston, 6 to 5, for the third straight time of the series. The Athletics dropped from second to third and the Senators from third to fourth as Detroit advanced.

Almost on the eve of the Democratic National Convention, and in the face of reports that his Presidential candidacy may be opposed there by the Tammany delegation, Governor Roosevelt notified Mayor Walker yesterday to reply to charges filed against him in removal proceedings based on evidence presented by Samuel Seabury to the Hofstadter committee.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Federal Government's deficit took an upward bound on Monday for the first time since income tax receipts for the June quarter started to reach the Treasury.

Except for a recovery in wheat and firmness in other grains, there was a decline in most other commodities yesterday. Cotton, coffee, cocoa, silk, rubber and hides all lost ground. Sugar was off 1 point to 2 points higher, with raw down 10 points at the close to 2.80 cents. Other articles were steady.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 23 -- The Senate recessed soon after midnight after failing to reach a vote on the second Wagner unemployment relief bill despite a thirteenhour session.

Dullness persisted in the money market, and rates for all classes of accommodation remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent. Street trades 1 and Federal 1/8 @ 1/4. Time money was quoted 1 1/2 per cent. Business money markets were steady.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds continued their winning ways at the expense of the Braves by taking a free-hitting game today, 14 to 8.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The Roosevelt forces laid claim today to at least twenty-five of the thirty Indiana delegates to the Democratic National Convention, bringing the New York Governor's instructed, pledged and claimed strength for the Presidential nomination to 588.

An arrangement whereby the 350,00 shares of Diamond Match Comany stock involved in the bankruptcy case of the International Match Company are likely to be sold at slightly above the market price or a total return of about $5,300,000 is being worked out and may be confirmed today by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 22 -- The co-medalists, Miss Catherine Singer of the Westechester Country Club and Miss Betty Pietsch of Tamarack, reached the semi-final round today in the women's Westchester and Fairfield championship golf tournament at the Tamarack Country Club.
The leading golfers of the nation, supplemented by one Argentine, Jose Jurado, and one Japanese, Tom Miyamoto, start out today in quest of the greatest honor that the game of golf can bestow.

On the petition of the Chicago rule and Trust Company, a creditor claiming $410,190, the Fox Theatres Corporation passed yesterday into the hands of William E. Atkinson, its president, and John F. Sherman by appointment of Judge Martin T. Manton, who named them equity receivers.

Formation in Switzerland of the International Commodities Trading Corporation to deal in commodities whose movement has been impeded by foreign exchange rates was announced yesterday by Neidecker Cie. B. Coles Neidecker of the firm, with offices in Paris and other European points and Buenos Aires, organized the corporation.

The first double of the season for Owner James Butler was scored at Aqueduct yesterday, when Apprentice captured the featured Myrtle Claiming Stakes after Forewarned had gotten home first in the third race.

Louis Lipsky, national chairman of the American Palestine Campaign, announced last night that the nationwide drive, which will continue until the end of the year, had so far yielded $609,293.98. The figure was made public at a dinner at the Hotel Astor, attended by officials of various Zionist organizations and several hundred of their members.

ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Roosevelt's personal campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination is over and from now on his case rests in the hands of his managers in Chicago, it was indicated here today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- An appeal for university graduates to venture off the beaten trails of knowledge and boldly attempt to seek out the unknowns was voiced by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, in a commencement address today before 1,596 members of the University of Pennsylvania graduating class, who received their degrees.

Emil Lederer, senior director of the Hamburg-American Line in charge of passenger traffic, announced yesterday that he had accepted the invitation of the associated transatlantic passenger lines to become a "sole arbiter" for settling disputes and otherwise promoting harmony among the lines.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A sweeping proposal for all-round armament reductions by nearly one-third the present strength of the world's armies, navies and air forces was made by President Hoover today to the general disarmament conference at Geneva.

The Board of Estimate, sitting yesterday in committee of the whole, voted to readvertise for bids for the new municipal building to house the Departments of Health. Hospitals and Sanitation, upon which a low bid of $3,232,747 has been submitted by Caldwell, Wingate Co.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The full text of President Hoover's proposal for cutting the arms of the world nearly one-third in an effort to lift a burden of from $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 from the shoulders of the world's taxpayers in the next decade, is as follows:

Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam returned to New York yesterday by airplane from Washington and spent the afternoon and evening receiving another round of honors for her flight alone across the Atlantic Ocean.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 22 -- Nine members of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association were elected to membership on the State Board of Pharmacy at today's session of the association's convention here. They were Arthur S. Wardle, Hudson; William Manfield, Albany; T. Bruce Furnival, Albert A. Muench and Edmund L. Weston, Syracuse; Frank S. Houck, Gloversville; C.H. Gauger and Michael Strozzi, Buffalo, and Elmer E. Chilson, Rochester.

The controversy between the Culbertson and official system headquarters, which was settled on Tuesday with the formation of the United States Bridge Association, supported by both factions, raised new storm clouds yesterday when Baron Waldemar von Zedtwitz, president of the American Bridge League, took exception to the duties assumed by the new organization.
Several New Yorkers figured in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

An agreement reached earlier in the day between Harry G. Kosch, president and equity receiver of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, and a committee of first mortgage bondholders, to close the Roxy Theatre after tonight's performance and reopen it in the middle of July or on Labor Day, alter a thorough reorganization, was upset yesterday when Federal Judge Caffey objected to conditions of the proposal.
OMAHA, Neb., June 22 -- William G. McAdoo stopped here long enough today to dictate a statement on the political situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On May 8 THE TIMES published a letter in which I outlined, from my experience, why I believe we should encourage new, small business enterprises as a means leading to improved conditions.

LONDON, June 22 -- As far as British opinion, and interest are concerned, President Hoover's proposal has restored Geneva to the map and made disarmament again worth talking about. With Ramsay MacDonald, Sir John Simon and Neville Chamberlain absent in Switzerland, lesser members of the Cabinet are wary of expressing an opinion, but the spontaneous comment in the lobbies of non-Cabinet members of Parliament is most favorable.

LONDON, June 22 -- Members of the North Atlantic conference and the Mediterranean conference meeting here today under chairmanship of Director A. Stadtlander of the Norddeutscher Lloyd ratified the appointment of Emil Lederer as sole arbiter in New York.
The directors of the Electric Power and Light Corporation at a meeting yesterday took no action on the declaration of the dividends due at this time on the second preferred and common stocks.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- As the greater factional leaders began to arrive today, the last to come being New York City's two major bosses, John F. Curry and John H. McCooey, the preconvention scene took on the aspect of the first round of a scientific boxing match between two principals who had never measured blows before.
ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Roosevelt today freed Walter Bannigan. Sing Sing prisoner who gave himself up almost twenty-two years after an escape.

County Register Arthur S. Mauldin reports 105 foreclosures in Westchester County last month, as compared with seventy-seven for May, 1931. In May, 1930, there were ninety-four foreclosures and in May, 1929, only fifty-seven.

GENEVA, June 22 -- The international control of civil aviation, especially in Europe, received a substantial push from France in the air commission of the disarmament conference today, with Britain and the United States supporting it.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Stoutly defending the Republican party prohibition plank as "the fairest method possible," James R. Garfield, chairman of the resolutions committee which drew the plank at the Chicago convention, today denied Senator Boran's accusation that Federal officeholding delegates supported the plan through political expediency.

Widespread popular ownership of railroad securities was never more significant than at this climax of unparalleled depression. There are said to be nearly 1,000,000 individual stockholdings in American roads, with an ever-increasing proportion in small lots.

PEIPING, June 22 -- Missionary reports received here today told of the alleged slaying of a German Catholic missionary. Father Conrad Rapp, by a Japanese soldier in the area of Chientao on the Korean border in Kirin Province, Manchuria.
At a meeting of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday the following regular memberships were transferred:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 22 (AP) -- A. statement of Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. that Governor Roosevelt's future in New York State depends upon his decision in the case of Mayor Walker of New York led to widespread gossip in political circles here today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- How the navies of the three largest naval powers and the armies of the chief powers would be affected by the proposals of President Hoover is shown in the tables below. Present budgetary allowances for military purposes are also given.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- Yale University received $3,192,297.18 in gifts and bequests for endowment in the fiscal year ending June 30, President Angell announced today at the alumni luncheon following commencement exercises.
CHICAGO June 22 -- Gangsters and habitual criminals are persona non grata in Chicago these days.

With total transactions only slightly larger, yesterday's stock market moved mostly within narrow fractional limits; it might to all practical purposes have stood motionless. Under ordinary circumstances, it would doubtless have been said that the market was awaiting the adjournment of Congress and the determination of the Democratic party's platform and candidate.

BATES and WALLACE, the English naturalists who spent years on the Amazon and its tributaries, reported the towns and villages as ill-planned and unkempt. Sanitation was almost unknown, and the jungle sometimes invaded a street. Neglect and decay oppressed the visitor from happier lands.

The President's program for disarmament, submitted yesterday to the conference and the world, did not meet with immediate acceptance abroad. The French instantly declared that they could not favor it. Sir JOHN SIMON, for England, held that it was too much of a "unilateral" plan.

Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, sailed last night on the Bremen to attend in London about July 1 a conference of Germany's creditors under the standstill agreement. The meeting will be the first of those scheduled for the so-called consultative or advisory committee to determine from time, to time, in consultation with the German authorities, the possible repayments of the principal covered by the agreement.

BOSTON, Mass., June 22 (AP) -- Professor Felix Frankfurter, champion of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Van zetti, radicals, whose death sentences and executions for murder had reverberations throughout the world, was nominated today by Governor Ely for a place on the Massachusetts Supreme Court bench.

A meeting of the Board of Education was nearly thrown into confusion yesterday when a large group of unemployed teachers, to whom a hearing had been at first denied, shouted their protests against the ruling of the chair and then continued the interruptions while the board, with difficulty, concluded its calendar.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 -- Yacht bound for New London for the annual Yale-Harvard boat race arrived today in Newport Harbor. They ineluded Mrs. William L. Harkness's Cythera, Mr. and Mrs. R.M. Robson's Janelburn and Robert Jenks's Trefor.

Following the lead taken by the American League two years ago, the National League, at its annual June meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, decided, to number the uniforms of its players in order to make it more convenient for the fans to identify the men.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The Chicago Civic Opera Company decided today to abandon plans for performances next Fall and Winter. Announcement that the city's new $20,000,000 Grand Opera House would be dark throughout the 1932-33 season was made this afternoon after a fifteen-minuta meeting of the board of trustees of the opera at the ofifces of Stanley Field, the secretary.

Fluctuations of only about 5 points in range on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the smallest in some time and the list closed 4 to 6 points lower than on Tuesday. Less rain in the cotton belt and predictions of generally fair weather offset a far from favorable weekly weather report.

ABOARD THE SALVAGE SHIP ARTIGLIO, OFF BREST, France, June 22 -- "The gold, the gold, the Egypt's gold at last!" the begrimed members of the Artiglio's crew, hoarse with emotion, suddenly shouted, almost hysterically, to each other this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The annual convention of the Advertising Federation is in town and we are hearing a little more than usual about advertising as a cure for business depression. The inference seems to be that all advertising pays, whereas those of us who have had the most experience in advertising know that it does not.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, who with Mayor Walker of New York City control a majority of New York's ninety-four votes in the Democratic National Convention, arrived at 10 P.M. today' uncommitted to any candidate, but favoring adoption of a straight-out repeal plank, with the party pledged for ratification.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the present situation of the country there is just one paramount issue. The recovery of prosperity for the United States, and through the United States for the world, transcends infinitely all other objects.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Roosevelt delegations from Louisiana, Minnesota and Puerto Rico today flatly challenged the authority of a subcommittee of the Democratic National Committee to hold scheduled hearings tomorrow on seatings contests in which all three are involved.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22 -- Intellectual, leadership is greatly needed by our country in the situation under which she is now laboring, Newton D. Baker declared in a speech at the Yale alumni luncheon after he had received an honorary degree at commencement exercises.

The semi-final bracket in the Eastern junior singles tennis championship tournament was filled yesterday when three seeded stars accounted for quarter-final triumphs at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The other semi-finalist, Ernest Koslan, seeded No. 1,. reached the semi-final round on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Census Bureau said today that deaths from alcoholism per 100,000 population decreased slightly in 1929 and again in 1930, the last year for which figures are available.

Without evidencing any change in its general characteristics, the share market showed some slight signs of a revival of interest yesterday. This was encouraging to the brokerage section of Wall Street. The turnover on the Stock Exchange ran a little above 600,000 shares, compared with 492,000 shares on the day before.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22 -- Alfred Post Coburn, 57 years old, a retired insurance broker, was killed by monoxide gas this afternoon in the garape of his home here at 7 Riehey Place. Both doors of the garage were closed, the ignition switch of his automobile was turned on, but an empty gas tank accounted for the fact that the motor was not running when Mr. Coburn's body was found.

MIAMI, Fla., June 22 -- Stanislaus Hausner landed on American soil at 11:35 P.M. today and described his experiences during the eight days he clung to his plane before he was rescued June 11 by the British tanker Circe Shell.

RENO, Nev., June 22 (AP) -- William Leonard Nicoll of New York filed suit here today to divorce Mrs. Marion Rutgers Nicoll on grounds of extreme cruelty. He asked approval of an agreement settling property rights and arranging for the custody of a 19-year-old son, William Jr., who is a student at Princetom.

American women, on whom retailers count as candidates count on delegates, are just now the subject of earnest discussion by manufacturers, wholesalers, advertising people and department stores. It has been pressed upon them that the buying public, meaning women, is not making the expected response to the single inducement of lowered prices.

BERLIN, June 22 (AP) -- The question of the right of German States to control the activity of militant groups such as Adolf Hitler's storm troops went unanswered today when the Reich failed, as politicians put it, to "impose its will."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am wondering whether I do not typify the tremendous number of young men and women who will cast their first Presidential ballots in the coming elections.

Although Harry Langewisch, Junior High School 125 twirler, struck out twenty-three batters and yielded only nine scattered blows, his team lost to Galvani Junior High School, 1 to 0, in a seventeen-inning play-off for the City P.S.A.L. Junior High School championship yesterday at the Astoria P.S.A.L. Field.

In a speech, addressed to "all the citizens of the city" as well as to the 15,000 persons who attended the eighty-sixth annual commencement exercises of City College in the Lewisohn Stadium last night, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, defended the city's policy of public higher education, and assailed its critics as being motivated by "ignorance, jealousy or cupidity."

CHICAGO, June 22 -- An action which may prove of great importance to insurance companies was taken by the valuation of securities committee of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners at the Edgwater Beach Hotel today when it adopted a resolution recommending that amply secured bonds held by companies be treated on an investment basis so as to reflect par at maturity rather than the present deflated values.

In the wake of a storm of criticism of the decision which gave Jack Sharkey the world's heavyweight championship in his fifteen-round bout with Max Schmeling last Tuesday night, the State Athletic Commission, through its secretary, Bert Stand, announced yesterday that it would stand solidly behind the verdict and that no investigation was planned.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- New low levels for wheat futures were established in the world's leading markets early today as the result of scattered liquidation and Hedging pressure. Prices on the Board of Trade here dropped 1 1/3 cents from yesterday's finish, the July falling fractionally below 47 cents a bushel, and at the inside being only 2 1/4 cents above the low figure established by the December future in October, 1931.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) -- The Examiner publishes a copyrighted statement by Eleanor Boardman, Him actress, that she and her husband. King Vidor, director, have separated and that a divorce is imminent. Miss Boardman said she would ask custody of their two small daughters.

QUINCY, Mass., June 22 (AP) -- The building shed of the $7,000,000 Victory Shipbuilding plant was swept early tonight by fire which destroyed luxurious yachts and caused property damage of approximately $2,000,000.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 22 -- Three Eastern players, including David N. Jones of Columbia, four from the South and one Coast representative reached the quarter-final round in the national intercollegiate tennis singles tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today.

The depression made its way into the animal kingdom at the Central Park zoo yesterday. In the annual auction of "surplus animals" held by the Department of Parks, the net result of the brief session was $28.60 in return for "approximately 260 pounds of sheep's wool.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22 -- Business recovery based on an unprecedented era of scientific discovery and utilization of inventions was predicted tonight by Dr. F.O. Clements of Detroit, technical director of the American Society for Testing Materials, at the organization's annual dinner here tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22 -- Marshall Field's goal after receiving a pass from J.C. Rathborne soon after the sudden-death period began enabled the Hurricanes to score a thrilling 9-to-8 triumph over Earle W. Hopping's Sands Point polo team in a second-round match of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Character is the ingredient that business in this country seems to back today, Kenneth Collins, excutive vice president and publicity director of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., aid last night in an address at the closing session of the joint convention of the merchandise managers' and sales promotion divisions of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Estimating that the steel industry generally is operating at an average rate of 16 per cent of ingot capacity, The Iron Age, in its midweek review, reports that there has been thus far no sign of the long-expected revival of consumer demand. Operations have declined in Pittsburgh, Chicago, Buffalo and Detroit and in the Valley region.

Josef Stalin, head of the Communist State, was the "undertaker" of the second Chinese revolution and is now preparing to "strangle the third Chinese revolution at its inception," Leon Trotsky, exiled Communist leader, writes in "Problems of the Chinese Revolution," a collection of his speeches and articles just published by the Pioneer Press.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy and one of the delegrates at large from North Carolina, said today the Democrats would make a mistake if they decided to "paramount the prohibition question" in the campaign.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22 -- Harvard's nine made a run-away of the second game of its series with Yale today before a happy commencement crowd of 7,500, winning 17 to 4.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 22 -- Creation of an official Westchester County planning board which would bring into being a "comprehensive master plan" to coordinate the county's park system, sewer system, water supply system, building projects and transit system was advocated tonight by Wayne B. Heydecker, consultant to the Regional Plan Association.

Miss Susan Robertson of the Women's Swimming Association, holder of several Metropolitan A.A.U. titles, who was so unexpectedly defeated in a 200-yard free-style match by Miss Dorothea Dickinson last week, conclusively turned the tables on her clubmate at an invitation water carnival for the benefit of the Olympic Fund in the 75-foot pool of the Bronx Union Y.M.C.A. last night.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Recognition of three committees organized to represent holders of common stock of the Middle West Utilities Company in the receivership litigation was refused today by Judge W.C. Lindley in the Federal District Court. After hearing the pleas of their attorneys, the judge remarked that there was no necessity "for the entire population of Chicago and the Middle West to join in the litigation."

The modified Byrne plan for curtailment of production of tin has been approved by the signatory governments and will be put into effect on July 1, it was announced yesterday by the New York office of the International Tin Committee.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 22 -- Lieut. Commander Charleg E. Rosendahl formally relinquished command of the United States airship Akron to Commander Alger H. Dresel in a brief ceremony in the Akron's hanger here today. Lieut, Commander Rosendahl has been ordered to report aboard the battleship West Virginia for a tour of sea duty.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22 -- The new Federal amusement tax might result in reduction of box office prices, Sidney E. Samuelson, president of the Allied Theatre Owners of New Jersey, asserted in an address today at the organization's annual convention here.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Retail sales on credit constitute 34 per cent of the total sales of all stores in the United States, which in 1929 amounted to nearly $50,000,000,000, John Guernsey, in charge of the government's census of distribution, said today in addressing delegates to the convention of the National Retail Credit Association.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- The Railway Executives' Association today called upon Congress to stay in session to see the country through its ills and at the same time vigorously attacked the "prevailing propaganda" against Congress as "atrociously unfair."

BALTIMORE, June 22 (AP) -- Rochester defeated Baltimore, 9 to 8, in a wild game today to take the lead in the series, two games to one. Buzz Arlett hit his thirty-third home run in the ninth with one on base.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman will entertain a party of twenty Friday evening, July 1, at the John Drew Memorial Theatre, when Carola Goya, Spanish dancer, will appear in a recital, assisted by Beatrice Burford, harpist.

Though the "bonus army" is apparently losing strength, police officials estimate that 19,000 veterans are still maintaining a fruitless vigil in the capital. The District of Columbia has never been equipped to take care of these men. Accordingly, it has been suggested that before adjournment Congress accept responsibility for them.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Connie Mack employed seventeen men and Jimmie Foxx hit his twenty-eighth home run of the season today, but the Chicago White Sox walloped three Philadelphia pitchers for thirteen hits and a 9-to-4 victory.
Blaise Noto crammed more excitement into the space of ten or fifteen minutes last night than he had ever experienced in all his thirteen years.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Authority to issue $25,516,000 of first and refunding mortgage forty-year gold bonds of its 1932 series was sought by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in an application filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Creation of a Fascist military dictatorship in Tokyo was predicted by T.A. Bisson, research expert on Far Eastern affairs, in a special report on "Japan and Manchukuo" issued today by the Foreign Policy Association.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- The Indians celebrated "Joe Vosmik Day" today with rare gusto, battering Washington into submission, 11 to 2, for their first victory over the Senators this season. Harder was effective for Cleveland.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 22 -- The efforts of Miss Helen Hicks of Lido to regain the women's Long Island golf championship, which she last won in 1929, came to naught for the third straight year today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 22 -- The strictest application, of martial law with scant notice plunged the city into unusual repose at 10 o'clock tonight, with all traffic suspended. Citizens are not allowed on the streets on any account unless bearing special permits from the authorities, who have warned that drastic steps will be taken against disorderly persons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Notwithstanding the many just criticisms that can be leveled at governmental management during the last decade, it is fair to say that on the whole many social services have been rendered with increasing efficiency.

BOSTON, Mass., June 22 -- "The demand is for insight, tolerance, magnanimity and imagination in international relations," declared Georve E. Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, in his address at the Radcliffe Commencement this morning at the Sanders Theatre.

A "jocular" offer by James Speyer to lend $5,000,000 to Charles M. Schwab was an incident in the negotiations for the purchase from Mr. Schwab of stock of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, Morgan Belmont, a partner in the banking firm of August Belmont Co., testified yesterday at the continuation of the trial of the suit for $140,000 commissions brought against Belmont Co. and Speyer Co. by two intermediaries.

OYSTER BAY, June 22 -- Representative Ruth Baker Pratt exhibiting blooms from the gardens of the Manor House, her estate at Glen Cove, won ten first awards and one second this afternoon at the opening of the twenty-first annual rose and sweet pea show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society in the parish house of Christ Church.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. Now that it is all over, I find it difficult to analyze my feelings. There is no regret, for I have nothing to regret. If I had to fight over again, I would fight the same way. I think it was a winning way. I have not the feelings of a loser.
GENEVA, June 22 -- The statement to the arms conference of Dino Grandi, the Italian Foreign Minister, on President Hoover's plan for arms reduction was as follows:

BERLIN, June 22 -- The United States Government's bold move for armament reduction at Geneva comes as a surprise in Germany and affects political opinion like a fresh breeze in a stagnant atmosphere. It tends to lessen the recurrent feeling of depression that comes with the anniversary of the Treaty of Versailles on the twenty-eighth day of this month.

PATERSON, N. J., June 22 -- Seventy-three diplomas will be awarded tomorrow night at the annual commencement of the New Jersey State Normal School at Paterson. The exercises will be held at the East Side High School.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Progressive Republican Senators have been informally discussing the possibility of supporting Franklin D. Roosevelt against President Hoover, if Mr. Roosevelt is nominated at Chicago, but have not yet agreed upon any concert of action.

MONTREAL, June 22 -- Exports of newsprint from Canada in May show a moderate advance in value over the previous month, but a decrease of nearly $3,000,000 in comparison with the same month of last year, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

Isidor J. Kresel's perjury trial was brought to an abrupt close yesterday morning when the jury which had been hearing evidence in the case since June 8 returned a verdict of not guilty by direction of Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Porter Morgan has left 10 Park Avenue for her Summer home in Stamford, Conn.

Investment in capital goods in anticipation of future needs, including the modernization and overhauling of existing facilities, has started economic recovery in the past and is likely to revive business again George H. Houston of Philadelphia president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, declared yesterday in an ad dress at the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America at the Waldorf-Astoria.

TRENTON, N.J., June 22 -- Leaving a note for his wife and son in which he said he was a "wreck" and was "taking this way out so you can collect the insurance," former State Senator Harry D. Leavitt, prominent in banking and business circles here, attempted to commit suicide with gas at his Parkside Avenue home today.

One Ready to Go In. Several commencement orators have this year lamented the fact that there is no place in politics for young college graduates. That depends upon who they are and how they set about it.

ALBANY, June 22 -- Judge Simon W. Rosendale received many letters of congratulation today in anticipation of his ninetieth birthday, which he will observe tomorrow with a dinner party for immediate members of the family.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 -- Reported to be faced with legal action and despondent over a series of financial difficulties, Edward Schoen, 51 years old, banker, lawyer and a member of the Newark Board of Education, committed suicide in his home here today by inhaling gas.

BERLIN, June 22 -- The Boerse was weaker today, the Lausanne uncertainties and the Gelsenkirchen deal both producing depressing effects. Gelsenkirchen lost 6 per cent. The general list partly recovered toward the close. Bonds sagged under rumors of fresh interest in the conversion issues.

RICHMOND. Va., June 22 (AP) -- Grandsons of Lee and Grant, in person and bearing the names of their grandfathers, today were greeted with resounding rebel yells from the throats of 1,000 Confederate veterans gathered at Frazier's Farm for the dedication of the Richmond Battlefields Park.

It's disconcerting enough to lose a fish after it has been hooked, but to have one taken right out of your hands is perhaps worse. A story forwarded from Fort Frances, Ont., describes the experience of William Bergman and Alfred Crawley of Fort Frances, who were, making their camp for the night on the shore of Nora Lake, north of Mine Centre.

NEW LONDON, June 22 -- With the crews of both camps going through their drills again today, the main rowing activity of Yale and Harvard nevertheless was that of the officials in charge of the preparations for the four races which comprise this regatta.

WARSAW, June 22 -- In the opinion of the Polish Government the Germans have acted tactlessly in insisting on their navy's visit to Danzig "at this particular moment," according to a semi-official communique issued to the foreign press today after conversation of Marshal Pilsudski with Lieut. Col. Josef Beck, Under-Secretary of State in the Foreign Office.

Thirty-five business men, including two city officials, met yesterday at a luncheon at the Yale Club to lay plans for an intensive campaign to raise $100,000 to balance the budget of the Boy Scouts Federation of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The reaction on Capitol Hill to President Hoover's proposal at Geneva for arms reductions was generally favorable. There was some dissent as to details, but for the most part the comment was commendatory.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 22 -- The quarter-final round of the fourth annual college girls' invitation tennis tournament was reached at the Longwood Cricket Club today, with all four seeded players among the survivers.

The book and job printing plants in New York City are fast reaching the point where bankruptcy can be avoided only by financial relief in the form of reduced wage scales, according to the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association, which sent a letter to Typographical Union 6 yesterday giving the union the required notice of an intention to amend or abrogate the existing contract, which expires on Sept. 30.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Alfred E. Smith arrived this morning. He was acclaimed by thousands at the La Salle Street Station and in the streets and tonight he is in the centre of the Democratic National Convention picture.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Expressing himself as greatly pleased at the public response to the views on prohibition, war debts and tariffs he announced yesterday, Speaker Garner sought a way today to absent himself long enough from the Capitol next week to attend the national convention, where his name is to be offered for the Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- The ranks of the Smith-for-President rooters encamped in the Congress Hotel for the Democratic convention were augmented today by the stanchest of all the former New York Governor's supporters, Mrs. Alfred E. Smith.

Applications for the listing of new stock of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, the National Surety Company and International Carriers, Inc., were approved yesterday by the governing committee of the Stock Exchange. In each instance the new stock is of a lower par value and will be exchanged share for share for the old stock.

ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Roosevelt demanded today an explanation from Joseph A. Wilson, warden of Great Meadow Prison, of the visit of Vannie Higgins, Brooklyn gangster, the night before he was shot down by enemies.
DETROIT, June 23 (AP). -- Detroit defeated Boston, 6 to 3, today, making a clean sweep of the four-grame series with the Red Sox.

STURBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Invader, with Lyman Bnisie driving, won the feature event, the trot for 3-year-olds, in the final day's racing of the Bay State circuit meeting at the Pair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The business picture for May and the first half of June was without encouraging factors, except for increased production and employment in the automobile and food products industries, according to the Federal Reserve Board's analysis made public today.
NEWARK, N.J., June 23. -- The list of graduates who will receive diplomas tomorrow morning at the commencement of the New Jersey State Normal School here was made public today as follows:

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- Clint Brown, one of Cleveland's star pitchers, was just another ball player to the Senators today and they found him for eleven hits and a 6-to-1 victory that included a pair of home runs by Judge and Manush.

CHICAGO, June 23. Seven banks. Including the three South Side institutions controlled by John A. Car- roll failed to open their doors today. The Carroll banks were the South Shore State, 2,633 East Seventy-fifth Street of which Mr. Carroll was president the Hyde Park-Kenwood National, 1,525 East Fifty-fifth Street, and the Jackson Park National, 1,960 East Seventy-first Street, of which he was chairman of the executive committee.

It will be well worth your while to make a special trip to the Metropolitan Museum, where, in one of the several Egyptian rooms, Herbert E. Winlock has just placed on view the newly assembled and arranged jewelry of Princess Sat-Hathor-Iunut, daughter of King Senusert II of the Twelfth Dynasty.

BOSTON, June 23. -- A bitter dispute between Umpire George Barr and Manager Max Carey, which resulted in the Brooklyn pilot being banished from the field, marked today's game, which the Braves won, 8 to 7, in the tenth inning. The result dropped the Robins to sixth place.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- An unsuccessful ten-year struggle to have the New York Stock Exchange discipline Hayden, Stone Co. for alleged misconduct was described to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Miss Grace Van Bramm Roberts of New York City.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 23. -- Degrees were awarded to 113 persons at the 127th commencement day exercises at Bowdoin College today. Of that number seventy-three were degrees of Bachelor of Arts in course and forty were degrees of Bachelor of Science in course.

BERLIN, June 23 (AP). -- Clashes between Adolf Hitler's National Socialists and Communists, raging throughout the nation, took a toll of four dead today, making a total of ten persons killed since last week-end.

LAUSANNE, June 23. -- Being host to two international conferences is not such an easy task, and even the Swiss, accustomed as they are to having their mountains and hotels trampled over by crowds of visitors, are not altogether enjoying themselves.

ANeither the wind nor the fact that he was playing In the national open golf championship weighed too heavily on the massive shoulders of Olin Dutra, California professional, as he led the field in the opening eighteenhole round of the 1932 classic at the Fresh Meadow Country Club yesterday.

The only development of financial importance yesterday was the reduction from 3 per cent to 2 1/2 in the Reserve bank rate. Aside from the fact that this accommodates the official rate more closely to rates on the open Wall Street market, the reduction doubtless recognizes the change in the gold-export situation.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- In an appeal to delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Frank Hague. Democratic National Committeeman from New Jersey, vice chairman of the national committee and prospective leader of the Smith forces on the floor of the convention, declared tonight that Governor Roosevelt, in the event of his nomination could not be elected President of the United States.

LONDON, June 23. -- The American theatre figured in the third royal court of the King and Queen, held in Buckingham Palace tonight. The former Adele Astaire, musical comedy dancer, now Lady Charles Cavendish, was presented by the dowager Countess of Airlie, and Mrs. Gilbert Miller, wife of the New York theatrical producer, was among ten American women presented by Mme. de Fleuriau, doyen of the diplomatic corps, at Ambassador Mellon's request.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although it is true that a tie exists between the municipal government and the people, yet it is strange that citizens have given so little attention to the affairs of their city. This might be expected in the larger cities where people are crowded together, and in civic affairs are drawn further apart; yet the problem of the citizen in the smaller community is just as complex.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Representatives of the Radio Corporation of America and the Mackay Radio Telegraph Company conferred today with officials of the Federal Radio Commission in connection with the allocation of the forty frequencies recaptured by the commission from the Universal Wireless Communications Company, Inc., and used for domestic point-to-point communication.

The Commerce Department's classified statement on origin and destination of gold imported and exported during May, in which month the exports stood second only to those of last October, shows that last month's shipments of $212,228,820 went to ten separate countries, of which six took $7,000,000 or more.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 23. -- Mrs. Robert C. Lake of the Old Country Club, the defending title-holder, and Miss Marion Hollins of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, former women's national and metropolitan champion, today triumphed in semi-final round, matches of the annual women's Long Island golf championship tourney at the Cherry Valley Club.

The sixty-sixth annual report of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, covering the society's activity for 1931, will be issued today. It is published in a twenty-four-page illustrated booklet.

David May, retired member of the law firm of May Jacobson and an authority on divorce law who had participated in many celebrated legal battles in New York in the last forty years, was killed yesterday when he fell from a window of his apartment on the fifth floor of 215 West Ninety-first Street.

Two upsets were recorded yesterday in the Eastern junior championship tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, the first and second seeded players being turned back in semi-final matches.

The Stamford (Conn.) Playhouse, Inc., under the management of Gladys Burch and Edith Gresham will open on July 4 with Edwin Burke's comedy. "This Thing Called Love." In a nine weeks' season it is planned to try out three new plays, "Crawley's." a comedy by Marius Charles Underwood; "Shadows on Glass," by Miss Burch and John Wolcott, and "The Red Swan," a play about present-day Russia by Boris de Tanko.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Contrary to the constantly downward trend of American foreign trade during the first quarter of 1932, shipments of wheat and cotton showed marked increases over the corresponding period last year and were considerably larger than the preceding five-year average, according to an analysis today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2.295,000,000, an increase of $50,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,339,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Millions of dollars have been wrung from the people of New York City through a political despotism controlled by "political organizations whose fixed purpose is to commercialize the processes of government," Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, declared in an address today before the Harvard Alumni Association after receiving an honorary degree at the university commencement exercises.

GENEVA, June 23. -- More swiftly than it had flamed up yesterday, the disarmament conference seemed to sink down today to where the only spark of life in it appeared to be again the secret triangular parley of the British, French and American delegates.
