MADRID, June 23. -- The Cortes by a vote of 191 to 112 passed tonight the second article of the Catalan statute establishing equality of the Castilian and Catalan tongues in Catalonia. By that majority, with fewer than half the Deputies voting, was Spanish national unity preserved.

Three State witnesses testified yesterday in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions at the beginning of the trial of Cornelius McNerney, 46 years old, who described himself as an "enforcement agent," on an indictment charging he attempted to extort money from an official of the Theatre Owners' Chamber of Commerce by promising to suppress complaints received by the Lord's Day Alliance against motion-picture theatres.
LONDON, June 23. -- The Duke of Cornwall, whose title originated in 1337 and pays him more than $200,000 annually, observed his thirty-eighth birthday today as a bachelor.

The Sobol Holding Corporation, which last week transferred twenty-three gas stations in Manhattan to the Standard Oil Company of New York, yesterday conveyed twenty-nine Bronx gas stations to the same company. Ira J. Sobol is president of the holding corporation.

HAVANA, June 23. -- A bill suspending constitutional guarantees throughout Cuba for a year and granting authority to the Chief Executive to prolong the period for another two years was signed by President Machado today.

MIAMI, Fla., June 23 (AP). -- A brinestained diary -- written during the eight days he tossed perilously on the floating plane that failed him in flying toward Poland -- is the potential nest-egg for Stanislaus Hausner's next attempt to span the Atlantic by air.

The Reading Company reported yesterday an increased net operating income for May and the first five months of the year despite reduced gross revenues, but this result was not general among the statements issued. The Lackawanna reported a net operating income of $563 in May.

ST. LOUIS, June 23. -- Headed by Goose Goslin's three homers over the right-field pavilion, the Browns' heavy blasting prevailed over the Yankees today. The Western trip of the McCarthymen ended with a 14-to-10 defeat. The result brought an even break for the series, after the Yanks had won three out of four in each of the other Western cities.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader and chief ally of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, was picked today by the majority of the New York delegation to succeed Norman E. Mack of Buffalo as national committeeman.

The Society of Beaux-Arts Architects last night, awarded its twentyfirtli annual Paris Prize in Architecture, having an estimated value of $4,050, to Richard H. Granelli, 25 years old, of 3,035 Radcliffe Avenue, the Bronx.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 23. -- The twenty-third annual exhibition of the New Canaan Garden Club this afternoon and evening in the Henry W. Sage Junior High School proved to be the largest and most successful in the history of the club.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 23. -- Threat of a serious dispute in the ranks of Rotary International wag avoided today when the annual convention adopted a resolution which postponed until next year in Boston a proposal to increase the number of Rotary Clubs in a city.

A rise in German bonds featured yesterday an otherwise colorless bond market. Domestic corporation bonds were irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange, while United States Government issues were irregularly higher. Of the corporation issues, the industrials were weaker than rails and utilities, as a rule.

Joseph Pellerito, 21 years old, of 1,972 Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn, climbed up a main cable to the Brooklyn tower of the Brooklyn Bridge late yesterday afternoon. When sighted by Patrolmen John McGonigle and James Rock of Traffic L from their police car, he was cavorting about the top of the tower, 150 feet above the bridga pavement, skipping from cable to cable and swinging from the guy ropes.

The New York Stock Exchange in an order yesterday forbade its members to be associated with so-called unit or group plans of stock selling unless special requirements are met. Reasons for the order were given by the governing committee.

William Woodward's Faireno, the son of Chatterton and Minerva, which won the Belmont Stakes in decisive style, scored an equally impressive victory in the $4,000 added Shevlin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday and as a result will make his next start in the Dwyer, a week from tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Assuming the success of its plan for a reduction in its fixed interest charges as required recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, in a supplemental application filed with the commission today, reduced from $9,364,808 to $4,390,086, the amount it has requested be made available to it on or before July by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 23. -- Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club, one of the low handicap players in the metropolitan district, and Miss Frances Snyder of Apawamis today reached the final round of the annual women's Westchester and Fairfield championship golf tournament at the Tamarack Country Club.

With Wall Street awaiting developments in Lausanne, Washington and Chicago, the stock market continued yesterday its irregular fluctuations in extremely dull trading. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange was smaller by 125,000 shares than on the day before.
ALBANY, June 23. -- Governor Roosevelt conferred tonight at the Executive Mansion with John E. Mack of Foughkeepsie, who will place him in nomination at the Democratic convention next week.

The most important development in the money market happened after the close of trading hours when the Reserve Bank announced a cut in the rediscount rate to 2 1/2 per cent from 3. While the downward revision was not unexpected, the possibility having been discussed over the last several weeks, it will have no particular influence toward easier money, as this condition has prevailed in the call loan, maturity money and bill market for months.

The emergence of the Summer art show as an integral part of the year's program rather than as a mere filler-in is one of the striking phenomena of 1932. Many of the New York galleries, as well as the museums, are presenting for the delectation of visitors and residents exhibitions that do not differ radically in quality from the exhibitions of the season proper.
LONDON, June 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. -- The tendency of the Westchester County Children's Court to rely more on probation and less on commitment in recent years is shown in the court's annual report to the Board of Supervisors. The report, made public yesterday, was signed by Judge George W. Smyth.

A controversy over whether the Park Department's efforts to make a modern park of Inwood Park were "defacing" the park and "laying waste to its natural beauty" or "making a natural woodland" of the area broke out yesterday between Arthur Schwieder, a member of Inwood Park Local Park Board 250 and Walter R. Herrick, Commissioner of Parks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Conceding that the peroration of Senator Borah's speech in which he bolted the Republican party was a magnificent burst of oratory, is it not pertinent to inquire whether Mr. Borah ever studied the political career and utterances of the "strange figure" who came out of the prairies of Illinois?

LAUSANNE, June 23. -- Out of yesterday's situation there developed today such satisfactory progress at the Lausanne reparations conference that tomorrow the French and German delegations will sit down alone to begin to try to work out what the Reich is willing to give and what France is willing to accept instead of reparations.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- The resolution introduced by George S. Van Schaick, New York Insurance Commissioner, recommending that sound bonds held by insurance companies be valued on their maturity basis rather than on their present depreciated market price, was adopted today by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners at their meeting here.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 23. -- Several small luncheons and dinners were given at the Devon Yacht Club today. Mrs. Louis Connick had a dinner for eight persons. Mrs. E. R. Perry had five guests.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 23. -- All four of the seeded players gained the semi-final round in the college girls' fourth annual invitation tennis tournament, at the Longwood Cricket Club today, while the doubles play, which reached the final, also found the two top seeded teams winning.

Mrs. Vilma Hill, 28 years old, widow of Detective Thomas E. Hill, who was murdered by gunmen two years ago, was shot In the forehead yesterday afternoon on the roof of her horns at 1.370 Merriam Avenue, the Bronx, by an unsuccessful suitor, Edward P. O'Connell, 27, who then fired three bullets into his own body.

The imperative demand for housing for the "white-collar" man and for the rebuilding of the slum sections of Manhattan is emphasized in the annual report made public yesterday of the State Board of Housing, composed of Darwin R. James, chairman; Aaron Rabinowitz, vice chairman; John Halkett, Louis H. Pink and Oliver Cabana Jr.

Fourscore and Ten. On June 25, 1922, there appeared in THE TIMES an account of the life of SIMON W. ROSENDALE under the heading "After Eighty Good Years." Ten years have now been added to the eighty and have been kind to him, for at 90 "his mind is clear, his hearing is good and his eyes have lost none of their keenness."

Mayor Walker left for Chicago at 8 o'clock yesterday afternoon to assume his duties as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention. He is due to arrive there about noon today. Soon afterward he is expected to confer with John F. Curry, Tammany chieftain; John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, and other members of the New York City Democratic board of strategy.

OTTAWA, June 23 (Canadian Press). -- Establishment of a quota on importations of syndicated matter published by Canadian newspapers, so as to include a necessary proportion of 20 per cent Canadian material being used, was suggested to the convention of the Canadian Authors Association here today by J. Murray Gibbon, director of publicity for the Canadian Pacific Railway.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- It was asserted on authority today that the United States would consider under no circumstances entering a security pact, a thesis that France is urging at Geneva as a condition of accepting the American arms reduction program.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23. -- Miss Margaret Mayo, playwright, of Harmon, near here, sought today through her attorney, Florence J. Sullivan, to obtain a temporary injunction from the Supreme Court here restraining New York City from using its new pumping station at the Cornell Dam on the Croton River to divert water from the dam's spillway to the Catskill system.

The purchase by John D. Rockefeller Jr. of two plots of land on Washington Heights, at the southerly end of Fort Tryon Park, from the Metropolitan Museum of Art was indicated in the passing of title yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- A charge that Congress is "busting up homes in the name of economy" was made in the Senate today as It approached a vote on the controversial measure reducing Federal expenditures.

THE early birds were checking up on the early birdies in the first round of the national open golf championship at Fresh Meadow yesterday, finding them rather few and far between compared to the abundance in some open championships. Just when all hands had decided that the high wind was to blame along came big Olin Dutra with a card of 69, which is good scoring, wind or no wind.

PARIS, June 23. -- Though a full day has passed, Paris has not recovered from what is being called President. Hoover's "thunderbolt," but crystalizing opinion merely emphasizes yesterday's cleavage of Left support and Moderate and Right opposition.

Such is a characterization of Harvard's Professor PALMER. He is as much a part of the university as its best-known buildings, even though he is nominally "emeritus." A graduate student looking forward to teaching sought an interview with him a few days ago and got so much of reminiscent wisdom that it ought not to be kept within the circle of the readers of The Harvard Teachers' Record.

Surrogate James A. Foley announced yesterday that he would hear the claims of twenty-nine alleged close relatives and claimants to the fortune of the late Ella V. von E. Wendel on July 25. The twenty-nine claim relationship in the third, fourth and fifth degree of kinship to the late spinster.

It is impossible that the delegates in session at these two cities are insensitive to the unuttered but moving appeal going to them from all nations. One conference is debating reparations and war debts and economic plans. The other is still seeking ways to reduce the burden and the menace of great armaments.

The interpretation of two words in the will of Mrs. Hannah M. Lydig, who died on Dec. 29, 1930, in a decision handed down yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley, will enable twenty-one institutions to share in the residue of the estate. The residue is valued at nearly $1,000,000.

A settlement with the Turkish Government which eventually will produce $14,250,000 for the creditors of the International Match Corporation, now in bankruptcy, has been completed by the Irving Trust Company, trustee for International Match, it was announced yesterday at a hearing before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee.

On an application of the Jacob Ruppert Realty Corporation, 535 Fifth Avenue, to which the defendant corporation consented, Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente yesterday appointed Philip J. Dunn as temporary receiver of the Empire Bond and Mortgage Company of the same address.
ROME, June 23. -- The Pope's Vicar General published today a regulation forbidding the sale of votive candles in all churches of the Diocese of Rome.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- Big George Earnshaw restricted the White Sox to four hits today, but the Philadelphia Athletics had quite a tussle before winning the final game of the series, 4 to 3.

A distinguished appearing man of suave address, who, the police say, has taken part in swindles aggregating $4,000,000 in the past ten years, was arrested yesterday on charges of perpetrating a classic confidence game and robbing Miss Kathryn K. Beeson of New York and Uniontown, Pa., of $177,000 of the $2,000,000 in a steel fortune which she inherited.
PARIS, June 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

TOKYO, June 23. -- The first official reactions to President Hoover's arms reduction plan may be summarized by saying that Japan is prepared to contribute something to disarmament, though less than 331-3 per cent of her arms.

The timely intervention of a detective saved Peter Buchet, a pushcart peddler, from serious injuries at the hands of a mob in Harlem last evening. Leaving his cart at Lenox Avenue and 129th Street for a few minutes. Buchet returned to find that it had been overturned and its load of fruit scattered in the gutter.

BERKELEY, Cal., June 23. -- That the vegetable world may be near the era often visioned for man, when food will consist of highly concentrated nourishment in pill form, is suggested, by achievements in soilless agriculture at the University of California.

A clearly thought out and earnest defense of instalment buying was recently made by Mr. J. GIBSON JARVIE, chairman and managing director of the United Dominions Trust, an industrial finance bank, in an address before the Royal Society of Arts.

Members of the old Intercoastal Steamship Conference met yesterday at 44 Whitehall Street and attempted to establish a new agreement to go into effect when the current temporary agreement terminates in August.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Authority to Issue $10,000,000 of 6 per cent mortgage bonds to be dated June 1, 1932, and maturing June 1, 1962, was sought by the Boston Maine Rail- road today in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 23. -- David N. Jones, Columbia University tennis star, passed out of the national intercollegiate tournament today by losing his quarter-final round singles match to Clifford Sutter of Tulane University on the Merion Courts. 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.
The Eastern clay court championship came down to the semi-final round at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday with only one seeded player left in the running.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 23. -- The copyrights of a dozen plays, in eluding "Beware of the Doss."

ALBANY, June 23. -- Stressing the necessity of adequate care for wards of the State, Governor Roosevelt indicated tonight in his third radio address on State finances that he did not believe the Mental Hygiene Department offered many opportunities for drastic cuts.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Purchases of government securities by Federal Reserve banks in the open market are gradually glowing down, acquisitions in the week ended yesterday having amounted to $38,000,000, compared with $47,000,000 the week before and $70,000,000 in the week ended on June 8.

The price movement in commodities was forward, reversing the sagging tendency of Wednesday. Wheat lost a fraction, but corn, oats and rye were up, as were cotton, coffee, sugar and cocoa. Silk was firm, but hides and rubber were irregular. Other articles remained steady.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 23. -- Mrs. Beverly Bogert gave a small luncheon at Anglesea today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23. -- For the seventieth time since the August day in New Hampshire eighty years ago when Yale and Harvard crews first met each other on Lake Winnipesaukee, the varsity crews of these ancient universities will fight it out tomorrow evening over the same four miles of blue water where they have been settling their aquatic differences, with few exceptions, since 1878.

ABOARD THE SALVAGE SHIP ARTIGLIO, off Brest, France, June 23. -- One shot of the Artiglio'a grab this afternoon produced more than 1,000 sovereigns and five bars of gold from the liner Egypt's bullion room to be added to the twenty-eight gold bars of various sizes recovered yesterday, when the haul totaled 254 pounds of gold and 173 sovereigns.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 23. -- William L. Ward, veteran chairman of the Westchester County Republican committee, told 600 delegates at the annual county convention In Grace Church Parish House here today to Ignore talk of the depression.

Admitting that he had hopes of a profit of $1,500,000 to $1,900,000 in a deal to buy 95,000 shares of Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company stock from Charles M. Schwab for $16,000,000. Morgan Belmont of August Belmont Co. testified yesterday in Supreme Court that the deal never had been carried through.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- Nine State and regional winners will display their best forensic talents in the new Commerce Building auditorium tomorrow night as finalists in the bicentennial oratorical contest.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- After ten years of litigation, the estate of John Wanamaker, merchant, was adjudicated today by Judge John M. Gest, in Orphans Court here. The adjudication shows a balance for distribution of $2,066,343.

PARIS, June 23. -- With the public galleries overflowing and the area around the Luxembourg Palace under redoubled surveillance by the police and Republican guardsmen, the Senate opened general debate today on the bill for women's suffrage.

DUBLIN, June 23. -- An American churchman delivered to the Irish people tonight the strongest appeal for peace and reconciliation that Catholicism has made to them since the latest political crisis with the British began.

Archibald B. Roosevelt, son of the former President and secretary of the National Economy League, yesterday denied the statement made in Congress on May 15 by Representative Patman of Texas that "a shipping company with which Mr. Roosevelt was associated received a gift from the government of $779,004."

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Convention headquarters of all Democratic candidates for President hummed busily today as interest centred in the efforts of various camps to build up machines which will hold together indefinitely when the balloting begins next week.
LAUSANNE, June 23. -- The twin conferences on disarmament and debts almost marked time today. The solitary progress that could be recorded was at Lausanne, and that was almost imperceptible.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Protection" for dry States, which as assumed so much importance in the prohibition discussion, has two distinct legal aspects. One concerns the power of Congress to furnish exernal protection; the other the power of the States to protect themelves.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- Newton D. Baker returned from a trip East today and announced that he will have nothing to say about the course of the Democratic National Convention.

RYE, N.Y., June 23. -- Walter Rothenberg of Winged Foot today won the medal in the Westchester amateur golf championship tournament being staged at the Westchester Country Club, carding a 77 to lead a field of 110.

Perfect weather was on hand for the golfers at the start of the national open championship at Fresh Meadow yesterday. The day broke clear and cool, reminding one of the difference between this year's championship and last, when it was torrid at Toledo.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23. -- A brilliant five-goal rally in the final period enabled the United States Army quartet to come from behind and upset the Aiken Knights, 13 to 10, in one of the practice games staged at the Meadow Brook Club today.

The recent shrinkage of actual transactions on the Stock Exchange to 400,000 or 500,000 shares for a full day's business, bringing the daily total, down to the average at this season in such years as 1921 and 1908, and to a figure barely twice that of the Summer of 1896, is not the least interesting of sidelights on the present situation.

A large group of "literary racketeers" is prospering despite the depression, Arthur McKeogh, managing editor of Good Housekeeping Magazine, said yesterday. Most of this group represent themselves as "literary consultants" and specialize in making contact with untrained, inexperienced persons who have an idea that they would like to write for profit and persuading them to pay for reading and criticism.

Borough President Harvey of Queens will ask the Board of Estimate to investigate the activities of the Board of Higher Education, which has jurisdiction over New York's free colleges. Mr. Harvey made this announcement yesterday before leaving for Schenectady to attend the State convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Efforts made today on the Board of Trade to get the wheat market out of the rut met little success. Black stem rust was reported found at several points in the Dakotas and all leading Minneapolis line elevator houses fear infestation.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- A three-year loan of $10,398,925 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company, with which to complete the construction of its Union passenger station and equipment terminal, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Amid but intellectually apart from the proclamations and the enthusiasms of managers and boomers, two deep-revolving statesmen move with impenetrable calm. They may be compared to judges in a crowded court room. Without prejudice, without opinion, they sit and hear.

Although weather in the South proved the most favorable for the cotton crop so far this month, prices on the Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and in light trading ended 2 to 3 points higher than on Wednesday.

The policy of government economy in matters pertaining to education was decried yesterday by Dr. John P. Conroy, a former District Superintendent of Schools in this city, in an address to the members of the graduating class of the New York Teacher Training College in the auditorium of the building at Convent Avenue and 135th Street.

LONDON, June 23. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, arrived in London by airplane this afternoon and spent a short time in the House of Commons where, in reply to a question, he said the Hoover armament proposals would be thoroughly examined by the British Cabinet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23. -- M. Pierpont Warner, a member of the Yale golf team, who this Spring won the North and South amateur golf title at Pinehurst, today won the Paul Haviland Cup in the second annual tournament held on the Yale course.
LONDON, June 23. -- Here is what the American women presented at the third royal court tonight wore:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Harvard University received $7,887,111.97 in gifts and legacies during the past year, President Lowell announced today during the 269th commencement exercises at which 2,205 degrees were awarded.

NEW HAVEN, June 23. -- Dr. K. T. Bainbridge of the Bartol Research Foundation at Swarthmore, Pa., maintained by the Franklin Institute, revealed here today that he had succeeded In measuring to an extraordinary degree of accurary the weight of the recently discovered hydrogen or the heavy hydrogen atom.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Alfred E. Smith and William G. McAdoo, whose bitter rivalry over the Presidential nomination and wide divergencies on the prohibition question in 1924 kept the Democratic National Convention of that year at the old Madison Square Garden deadlocked for three long weeks, met this afternoon in a prolonged and secluded huddle at Smith headquarters in the Congress Hotel.
RICHMOND, Va., June 23 (AP). -- With rebel yells, the United Confederate Veterans today rejected a resolution calling for a joint reunion with the Grand Army of the Republic.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Advised of reported plans of some public utility companies and other large users of postal facilities to evade payment of the higher postage rates becoming effective July 6 by collecting monthly bills and distributing matter usually sent through the mails by other means, the Postoffice Department has taken measures to prevent such steps.

A transport pilot was instantly killed last evening when his plane, caught in a sudden gust of cross wind, went into a tailspin over the Jamaica Sea Airport and crashed three hundred feet to the ground.
NEWARK, N.J., June 23 (AP). -- The Newark Bears were unable to hold a five-run lead today and lost to the Buffalo Bisons, 10 to 7, when Pitchers Weaver and Miner gave twelve passes and eleven hits.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Democratic leaders in the House saw their chances of attending the national convention in Chicago next week grow brighter today when it became apparent that the Senate would not be able to send back to the House the routine appropriation or "supply" bills, in time for enactment before the beginning of the next fiscal year on July 1.

BERLIN, June 23 (AP). -- A Franco-German military alliance, such as suggested by Chancellor Franz von Papen today at Lausanne, doubtless would arouse the opposition of organized labor, Adolf Hitler's National Socialists, the Nationalist party and the German Communists.

MEXICO CITY, June 23. -- Thirty bodies have been recovered and more than a hundred lives are believed to have been lost in the tidal wave that virtually swept the fashionable Summer resort of Cuyutian off the map Wednesday.

LAUSANNE, June 23. -- A proposal that France and Germany join together in a military alliance was advanced today by Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany, and a few hours later representatives of the two governments met for direct negotiations in which the suggestion was expected to play a part.

GARFIELD, N.J., June 23. -- Leo Breda, 23 years old, owner of a gasoline station at Ray Street and Lanza Avenue, and William Schlegel, 20, his helper, were riddled by machine-gun bullets in front of the filling station late this afternoon by a gunman who mistook them for a pair of local beer hi-jackers he was hunting.
ALBANY, June 23. -- Governor Roosevelt and the members of his Cabinet gave a farewell fete today to a Republican member, Berne A. Pyrke, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

With the outflow of gold to Europe halted, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday reduced its rediscount rate to 2 1/2 per cent from 3 per cent, the rate which had been in effect since Feb. 26.

Major Francis Yeats-Brown, who created a literary stir with "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer," has just completed a new book of history and adventures called "Bloody years." The book deals with war years in Stamboul, of captures and escapes and oplum smoking.
NEW YORK. Anthony J. Drexel, who has been, at the Savoy-Plaza, will depart next Thursday for his home in Paris.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- The authority challenged by supporters of Governor Roosevelt, namely, a subcommittee of the Democratic National Committee, today heard testimony by contesting delegations from Minnesota and Puerto Rico and adjourned to write its report to the full committee, which meets tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If we are to find the reason for our distressing condition we must first put out of our minds one theory so often advanced. That is the idea that war must necessarily be followed by depression. The World War was fought on foreign soil, and our loss of life was a small percentage of our population.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Economic Issues seem likely to dominate the Democratic platform. Party leaders, including three former members in the Wilson Cabinet, A. Mitchell Palmer, Carter Glass and William G. McAdoo, with half a dozen Senators, are insistent that the party write a concise and explicit platform on proposed measures to end the depression.

Japanese yen exchange broke 1 1/8 cents yesterday to a record low of 27.87 cents as Japanese importers hastened to place orders in advance of the imposition of Japan's new and stringent exchange restrictions. The exchange had fallen steadily since Monday when the rate was 30.44.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 23. -- Mrs. Albert G. Milbank of Huntington won two blue and one red ribbon in the final day's judging of the twenty-first annual rose and sweetpea, show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the parish house of Christ Church.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Representatives of every State and territory, pledged to the Presidential candidacy of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, agreed unanimously tonight to "do all within our power to bring about abolition of the two-thirds rule and the adoption of the majority rule in this convention."

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 23. -- The second of a series of four oneday golf tournaments to be conducted this season by the New York Advertising Club Golf Association was held today over the Lido Beach Country Club course, with fifty-nine members taking part.

BOSTON, June 23. -- An operation for the removal of a tumor from the brain was performed today by Dr. Harvey Cushing on Senora Leonor Lorente Calles, wife of former President Calles of Mexico. The operation took place at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, where Senora Calles was brought on Tuesday night after a trip from Mexico.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23. -- Running, wind searching and finally reaching her way here from Scotch Caps on the American Yacht Club's annual "boat-race" run, Bayard S. Litchfield's 12-meter Cantitoe led a fleet of fourteen yachts past New London Ledge Light today.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- The State, which dropped bank robbery charges against Danny McGeorgheghan last week, sought him again today.

Works of art of the kind that adorn the walls of speakeasies -- the whiskery old gentleman sipping beer, the gilt-framed painting of the Ace of Hearts, expensive tapestries and much red plush -- are to be offered for sale in a series of auctions of property seized in speakeasies and night clubs, the first sale of its kind ever conducted by the government, Raymond J. Mulligan, United States Marshal, announced yesterday.

Although the results of the work carried on at the Noank lobster hatchery by the Connecticut States Board of Fisheries and Game may have a special meaning to commercial fishermen, yet there is much from the standpoint of scientific experimentation that will be of consequence to the average salt-water fisherman.

Thumping along once more on all cylinders, the Giants wound up their first home stand of the year against the West at the Polo Grounds yesterday by flattening the Cardinals for the second successive afternoon.

Prompted by lessons learned while broadcasting the sessions of the Republican convention a few days ago, radio engineers of two coast-to-coast networks are at work in the Chicago Stadium to complete preparations by Monday which will enable even more realistic and dramatic presentations from the Democratic conclave than was possible from the other meeting.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23. -- Three research associates were appointed for the Sterling Foundation today by Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale Law School. The appointees are Jerome Frank of New York City, George E. Bates, a professor in the Harvard School of Business Administration, and Edson R. Sunderland, Research Professor at the University of Michigan Law School.
LONDON, June 23. -- The tone again was cheerful on the Stock Exchange today. British Government funds advanced and interest in the industrials increased, dealers reporting more active trading.

BALTIMORE, June 23 (AP). -- Rochester closed the series today by defeating the Orioles, 18 to 7. The Red Wings battered four Baltimore pitchers for sixteen hits, among which were homers by Puccinelli, Wilson, Kauffmann and Heath. McGowan and Hinkle hit four-baggers for the Birds.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- President Hoover sent to the Senate today the nomination of Gardner Cowles Sr., publisher of The Des Moines (Ia.) Register and Tribune, to become a member of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. His appointment, however, threw no light on the matter of a successor to Charles G. Dawes as president of the corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP). -- The Phillies made it three out of four today by hammering Bush and May for sixteen hits and a 16-10 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

Bank clearings last week were somewhat improved. The total of $4,788,749,000 for twenty-two leading cities in the United States was 31.2 per rent less than a year ago. At New York City clearings were $3,289,747,000, a decline of 35.1 per cent, while the total for the cities outside New York was $1,499,002,000, or 31.5 per rent smaller than a year ago.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23. -- The first real sensation of the Wimbledon tennis tourney occurred today when, after a terrific three-hour struggle on the centre court, Frank Shields of the United States defeated the young New Zealander, E.D. (Buster) Andrews, 4 -- 6, 13 -- 15, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, to gain the fourth round.

Teasie came down to earth again in a laundry bag yesterday. Then it and Eugene McKernan, the retired police captain of Riverdale, turned in for a good sleep. All Wednesday night the Capitan had stared from a window of his home at 551 West 235th Street at John Haelen's giant oak tree on the corner of Oxford Street.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Senate passed the $2,300,000,000 Wagner relief bill without a roll-call this afternoon and sent it to the House, where it must be compromised with the Garner bill, carrying about the same total.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- A medal similar to that given to Colonel Lindbergh will be given to Mrs. Putnam on June 29 when she comes to Boston, the Governor's office announced today.
Max Schmeling is willing to end the controversy resulting from the decision in Jack Sharkey's favor in the world's heavyweight championship fight on Tuesday night. The German boxer yesterday said:
BERLIN, June 23. -- The impression is deepening here that Lausanne will produce absolutely nothing and Geneva, despite President Hoover's frontal attack, little more.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 2 3/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The Advertising Federation of America endorsed President Hoover's proposed armament cut of onethird yesterday at the closing session of its twenty-eighth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria. It also went on record as reaffirming its stand for the highest principles of truth, honesty and integrity in advertising as well as in all other lines of business.

The Public Service Commission authorized yesterday the issuance of $IO,000,000 first lien and refunding mortgage 5 per cent series B bonds due in 1957 by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company. The commission allowed the company until Sept. 1 to sell the bonds, although the usual interval is thirty days.

Owen Madden and Salvatore Spitale visited Brooklyn yesterday to tell the police that they were friends of Charles (Vannie) Higgins, the rum-runner who was shot last Sunday in Eighth Street, Brooklyn, and that they had no idea who had killed him.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- The Railway Labor Executives' Association decided today to get behind a plan for a new kind of reconstruction corporation to finance the "common man."

PARIS, June 23. -- The Bourse was inactive today, hut without important fluctuations. The list was about equally divided between gains and losses, but the general tendency indicated abstention among traders. In the foreign exchange market sterling weakened slightly, while the dollar was quiet, but registered a small advance to 25.42.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production is down sharply to 59.0 for the week ended June 18 from 68.0 for the preceding week and 90.3 for the corresponding, week last year. Sales of goods were nearly equal to the low output, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service, and shipments were fully equal to it.
The Philadelphia Church Cup team, led by Samuel B. Gilpin, defeated Boston on the opening day of play in the annual intercity matches at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- American banking conditions during May continued to be favorable with seventy-seven failures, including fourteen national, six State member and fifty-seven non-member institutions, according to Federal Reserve figures made public today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate stock market inquiry ended today. The question whether it will is resumed when Congress convenes in December was left, open by the Banking and Currency Committee, which has been conducting the investigation, but no further action will be taken during the Summer or Fall.

State and defense lawyers finished presenting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Cornelius MoNerney, law enforcement agent for the Lord's Day Alliance, on an indictment charging he attempted to extort $100 from the president of the Theatre Owners' Chamber of Commerce to suppress Sabbath law complaints against its members.

Through the American Association for Adult Education, the Carnegie Corporation has made a grant to the newly formed National Theatre Conference. The purpose, "to serve collectively the interest of the American theatre," lies in the field of dramatic education.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Johnny Risko, Cleveland heavy-weight, won a decision tonight from Mickey Walker, former middle-weight champion, in a twelve-round fight. Risko weighed 198 1/2 and Walker 171 1/2.
NEWARK, N.J., June 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles dropped from the top of the International League race today when the Bears won, 4 -- 3.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Alfred E. Smith announced tonight that he would take the floor at the Democratic convention and fight against the proposal from the Roosevelt camp for abrogation of the century-old rule under which a two-thirds vote is required to nominate candidates.

LYNBROOK, L.I., June 24 -- Seven persons were injured here today when an eastbound Long Island train crashed into a five-ton cinder truck at the Wright Avenue grade crossing. More than 100 passengers in the train were hurled from their seats by the impact, which crushed the truck against a telegraph pole.

The Polo Grounds provided a setting for "Aida" last night when a cast of 250 grand opera artists cooperated to present the open-air charity performance under the auspices of the Girls' Service League and the camp of the Boys' Club of New York.

CHICAGO, June, 24 -- The Roosevelt forces will control the writing of the tentative draft of the platform which is being prepared by the provisional resolutions committee in advance of the Democratic National Convention Monday. On motion of William G. McAdoo, a supporter of Speaker Garner, a subcommittee was appointed by Gilbert M. Hitchcock, chairman of the unofficial committee, to prepare a draft.
Instead of going down to the sea in a ship to fish, Dr. Werner Philipp of the Bay Ridge Rod and Gun Club decided to do so by seaplane last Wednesday.

Following up the reduction of its rediscount rate on Thursday from 3 to 2 1/2 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday lowered the rates at which it will buy bankers' acceptances. The new rates are 1 per cent for bills having a maturity up to ninety days, 1 1/3 per cent for bills of from ninety-one to 120 days' maturity and 1 1/2 per cent for longer bills.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24 -- Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Charles Curtis, was guest of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons at their borne this evening. Later, Mrs. Gann was the principal speaker at a meeting at Newport Beach, over which Mrs. Fitz Simons presided as Republican National Committeewoman from Rhode Island and president of the Newport County Women's Republican Club.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A program of intensive effort to effect economic improvement, calling foi action by both government, and business and cooperation between the two, was approved by the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in session here today.

Men's Suit Promotions Aid Stores. The widespread number of promotions by department stores on men's low-priced clothing during the week caused a sharp spurt in demand for such goods, but specialty chains and independents did not show much improvement over last week, store executives reported yesterday.

SKANEATELES, N.Y., June 24 -- The schoolboy racers stole the thunder from the collegians today in the opening program of the third annual Eastern intercollegiate outboard championships on Lake Skaneateles.
"What We Live By," a new book by the Abbe Ernest Dimnet, is published today by Simon Schuster.

The United States Shipping Board made the first move toward reclaiming the fleet of seven Dimon Line ships yesterday when the freighter Pacific Fir was bid in at Newark for $10,000. While the line has been in the hands of receivers for several months and has for a longer period been attempting to reorganize under the direction of creditors, the Shipping Board's steps toward regaining the fleet was not known in shipping circles.

The speakeasies are taking restaurant trade away from hotels, "first, because the food is rather good, and second, because you can get something to drink," said Murray Rappaport, hotel accountant, in reporting the results of an investigation of the hotels' prohibition problems at a meeting of the Hotel Accountants' Association of New York City, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, issued a warning yesterday dealers in securities who market-called "unit," or "pocket trusts," against the use of colored facsimiles stocks offered to the public. He id ignorant investors might be iped by unscrupulous dealers into lying these imitations in the belief at they were genuine stock certifcates.

Locating Ambassador Mellon. Thanks to our "regular subscriber and admiring reader'" Mr. SAMUEL HARDEN CHURCH, we are able to inform other admiring readers who wish to communicate with Ambassador MELLON that he is "at the Court of St. James" and not "at the Court of St. James's," as hitherto indicated in publications of high authority.

The cold snap which suddenly thrust the mercury to a record low mark of 52 degrees in New York yesterday morning, aroused residents of the metropolitan area from their sleep with a chill and sent them to work shivering, was traced to its lair last night by the Weather Bureau.

The Aqueduct meeting added another long-priced winner to its list yesterday when Mrs. J.E. Nagle's The Crane won the fourth race at 50 to 1. In some places 100 to 1 was to be had. The 3-year-old son of Ballot and Mammy was so lightly regarded that he was almost ignored in the betting.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A survey of the delegations on the ground in the convention city by THE NEW YORK TIMES indicates the following line-up on the question of abolishing the two-thirds rule of the Democratic convention.

The need for a national movement to back a definite moral code that will offset changing standards in the social order was urged by leaders in religious education before the National Council of Women yesterday after a discussion of various phases of the subject.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Supporters and opponents of the candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic Presidential nomination were agreed tonight that he will win or lose on the single issue, raised suddenly at midnight Thursday, of the abrogation of the two thirds rule.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Reaction to the Roosevelt move for abolition of the two-thirds rule was so pronounced tonight in the ranks of those opposing the Governor's nomination and to a lesser extent in parts of his own camp that the party was facing one of the bitterest convention fights in its history.

LONDON, June 24 (Canadian Press) -- Essex easily defeated Warwickshire in a first-class county cricket match concluding today while Lancashire won on the first innings over Hampshire. Oxford defeated M.C.C. by 111 runs at Lords.
BERLIN, June 24 (AP) -- Political clashes that have cost ten lives within the week brought a public declaration from Adolf Hitler today demanding martial law throughout Germany.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Politics attracted more attention today on the Board of Trade here than did reports regarding the progress of the grain crops. A large delegation of brokers left the Exchange early in the session to meet Albert C. Ritchle of Maryland, a Democratic aspirant for President, who arrived here from the East.

GENEVA, June 24 -- The ice between the Japanese and United States delegations to the disarmament conference was broken by Ambassadors Gibson and Wilson calling on Ambassador Matsudaira and Nao-take Sato in what both sides stressed was merely a courtesy visit to clarify the reasons why President Hoover's arms reduction statement was made so suddenly and to discuss some of its contents.

What will be known as the New York Summer School of Theology will open Monday in the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, and continue three weeks. Sessions will be held daily from Monday through Friday. The classes will be from 8:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. and from 8 to 9 o'clock at night.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Mayor James J. Walker, the New York member of the resolutions committee, arrived here today for the Democratic National Convention with whiskers on his chin and a repeal plank -- only slightly used -- up his sleeve.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The revolution in Siam today, it was recalled here, coincided strangely with an ancient prophecy that has been woven into the folklore of the nation, that the present dynasty would last 150 years. The sesquicentennial of the dynasty was celebrated last April, with touches of superstitutious awe as a result of that prophecy.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Governor Roosevelt, speaking from Albany, addressed a group of twenty of his leading supporters, assembled tonight in the Presidential suite in the Congress Hotel, and asked that none of them make any personal attack on any other candidate.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Net profits of member banks of the Federal Reserve System for 1931 amounted to $12,261,000 as compared with $306,502,000 in the previous year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

SYRACUSE, June 24 -- The "evil eye" of ancient superstition has been found by scientific experiment to have a definite basis in fact, it was reported here today during the closing sessions of the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. Otto Rahn, Professor of Bacteriology at Cornell University.

Ten State and municipal issues comprised the new bond financing done in the New York market this week, the total being $15,900,000. Last week's new financing amounted to $30,480,983, of which $4,000,000 was public utility and the remainder State and municipal issues.

Several pre-convention talks by Democratic leaders will be carried on extensive networks today. Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will be heard at 7:15 P.M., Eastern Daylight Time, over WEAF's chain on "The Prospective Policies of the Democratic Party," and at 10:15 P.M. overs WABC's facilities former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri will talk on "What the Democrats Should Accomplish."

King Prajadhipok of Siam, who with his Queen and other members of the family and a considerable entourage visited the United States last year, ascended the throne in 1925, succeeding his brother, Rama VI. He was the seventh ruler of the Chakkri dynasty and, until the revolution of yesterday, the last remaining absolute monarch of an independent country in the world.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 22:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 24 (AP) -- Deputy City Treasurer J.P. Winn took a lead pencil here today and figured out how to solve the nation's economic ills through a special government issue of twenty-five one-dollar bills to every citizen. Here's how he says it can be done:

To the Editor of The New York Times : The most important and realistic fact to be noted in considering President Hoover's suggestion for a mutual 30 per cent armament cut is that the effecting of such a proposal would do more than any other single thing, except a cut of even greater proportions, to promote the safety and security of the United States.

GENEVA, June 24 -- The nineteenpower commission of the League of Nations decided today to recommend that the Assembly prolong the six months' period in which the League Council, under Article 12 of the Covenant, must report on the Chino-Japanese conflict.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The decision of the supporters of Governor Roosevelt to make a fight for the abrogation of the two-thirds rule, the most sensational single development in a national convention since 1912, was made without the knowledge of Governor Roosevelt and without any intention of his convention managers to have any decision on the question at this time.

Among new and recorded leaseholds announced yesterday was one covering the four-story English basement house at 608 Park Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, which was leased to Mrs. Evelyn Stuart. The owner is Mrs. Clara A. Bowron, and the brokers in the deal were Pease Elliman.

The formation of a new Stock Exchange partnership, Bernard, Winkler Co., and the proposed organization of two other firms, Bywater Leary of 50 Broadway and Clark, Childs Keech of 11 Broadway, were announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24 -- An all-day golf match, a contract bridge tournament, a tea dance with professional entertainment and water sports for juniors were the features of a fete held here today at the Century Club by the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

The players again, had a high wind to contend against in the open championship at Fresh Meadow yesterday, except that it had shifted a trifle more into the north. It was blowing fully as strong in the morning as it did on Thursday, but it died considerably as the day wore on.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- A challenge of President Hoover's authority to name the president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, made in the Senate today by Democratic leader Robinson, promptly drew from high administration quarters the reply that such action was not planned.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt will leave next Tuesday for Beaulieu, Newport, where she will be joined later by Brig. Gen. Vanderbilt who will go to Camp Dix that day.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A further loan of $2,264,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Western Pacific Railroad was conditionally approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Loans of $1,303,000 and $799,000, maturning in one and three years, respectively, already have been made to the road.

Today is the fifty-sixth anniversary of the Battle of Little Big Horn, Mont., in which General George A. Custer and 207 comrades were massacred by the Indians, Custer's widow, Mrs. Elizabeth Custer, who was 90 years old last April, will spend the day quietly in her apartment at 71 Park Avenue, with memories revived as she moves among her war relics.

The financial stability of Venezuela, attested by an increase in its treasury surplus, while other countries have struggled to balance their budgets, and Venezuela's freedom from political strife, were noted yesterday by Domingo M. Navarro, special representative of President Juan Vicente Gomez, as he added his country's flag to the Advertising Club's collection of foreign emblems.

BANGKOK, Siam, June 24 -- The army and navy in Bangkok, combining as a new people's party, started a successful "peaceful" revolution early this morning against the traditional absolute monarchy, which for more than sixty years has been conducted on the lines of a benevolent paternal despotism.

LEAVE it to Leo Diegel to do something odd and interesting. There were all sorts of stunts performed In the second round of the national open golf championship at Fresh Meadow yesterday, but Leo put over a trick that sounds impossible, but was really easy of performance. On the second hole, 395 yards, he drove a ball to the green without ever letting the ball touch the grass between the tee and the green.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The nomination of ex-Governor Smith was urged over the radio this evening by former Senator Peter Goelet Gerry of Rhode Island. The address was broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Julius Rosenwald left an estate worth about $50,000,000, according to estimates today by attorneys when they filed an inventory before Probate Judge Horner. The inventory was approved.

BERLIN, June 24 -- Chancellor Franz von Papen will exchange the sluggish conference atmosphere of Lausanne tomorrow for the livelier domestic political breezes that have been blowing in on Berlin from the Bavarian highlands for the last forty-eight hours.

As a sequel to the cut in the rediscount rats by the Reserve Bank, open market operations in the bill market were thrown into a state of confusion in an attempt to adjust rates. Three houses marked down discounts 1/8, two others made no change whatever, and one made concessions on choice names and maturity.

TOKYO, June 24 -- As Japanese public and official opinion is engrossed by objections to President Hoover's arms cut plan, certain inherent factors favorable to at least partial acceptance have not yet been fully realized here.

BERLIN, June 24 -- Although the volume of business continued small on the Boerse today, the tone was firm, with some public demand and covering by professional traders. The chief gainers included bituminous coal and potash stocks. The electrics also were higher.

The rank and file of the city's delegation to the Democratic National Convention will entrain for Chicago today on board "convention specials" of the New York Central and the Pennsylvania railroads. About 700 delegates, alternates and guests make up the roster, which includes the names of virtually all the city's minor Democratic leaders and many of the party's local officeholders.

The attitude of the American business world is now showing a decided improvement, and that in itself is a hopeful augury for the future, in the opinion of Jean Pouyer and Andre Grandpierre, French industrialists, now visiting in this country for pleasure and to acquaint themselves with conditions here.
MONTREAL, June 24 -- J.G. Weir of Toronto was elected president of the Investment Bankers Association of Canada at its annual meeting today at Lucerne-in-Quebec.

New Yorkers will have an opportunity to see how their city functions without an official Mayor for a week or so, it became evident at City Hall yesterday with the news that all three officials eligible for the post would attend the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

Public financing of all new construction is foreseen by L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, who says that the present rate of fostering construction at the expense of public treasuries is creating an abnormally large ratio between public and private work.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. RAKIOT NULLAH, Kashmir, June 19 (by runner to Astor) -- The point of this expedition's attack on Nanga Pargat has at last been definitely decided.

The privilege of operating all concessions at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways, Queens, for the next five years, including the management of the new $530,000 bathing pavilion, which probably will be opened about midsummer, has been awarded to Max Fuchs of 975 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by Albert C. Benninger, Queens Park Commissioner.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 24 (AP) -- J.M. Gardenhire, a delegate to the Democratic National Convention, announced today he would sponsor a resolution to deny former Governor Alfred E. Smith the privileges of the convention floor and to declare him ineligible as a Presidential candidate "unless and until he assures the delegates that he will abide the action of the convention and support its nominee."

Purchases made to avoid the new taxes imposed by Congress have tended to swell the general volume of trade, according to the week-end reviews of the commercial agencies. Business generally is described as spotty.

RYE, N.Y., June 24 -- Walter Rothenberg, a junior at Lafayette College and representing Winged Foot, who won the medal with a 77, continued his steady golf to go through two rounds today and enter the semi-finals of the Westchester amateur championship tourney at the Westchester Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Completing the purchase of the $125,000,000 of capital stock of the Federal Land Banks, authorized by Congress, the Treasury acquired 550,756,260 of these securities so far in June, the Federal Farm Loan Board announced today.

Ruling unanimously, the Appellate Division upheld Samuel Seabury yesterday in his appeal from the "sweetness and light" decision in the Flynn case by which Supreme Court Justice Ford recently admitted affidavits accusing Mr. Seabury and some of his Hofstadter committee aides of subornation of perjury.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Ellsworth Vines, American champion; Bunny Austin, English ace, and Jiroh Satoh, Japan's leading player, won their way today into the quarter-finals of the men's singles at the Wimbledon tennis tournament.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- From the standpoint of the usual marine spectacle, the flotilla of yachts at the Yale-Harvard crew races today was a sad disappointment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- Thomas A. Logne, one of the leaders of the Alfred E. Smith forces in Philadelphia, left for Chicago today predicting that Mr. Smith would have thirty-four Pennsylvania votes on the first ballot for the Presidential nomination.

With only 58,176,562 of new municipal issues listed for award next week, he market will have a breathing spell in which dealers plan to concentrate on moving several old blocks of bonds offered during recent weeks. The revised total of new bonds up for award this week was $22,802,339, compared with the weekly average for the year to date of $22,998,367.

Disguised as delivery men for Saks Co., two detectives greeted two hold-up men with blazing pistols, killing one and seriously wounding the other late yesterday afternoon, when the would-be robbers tried to hold up a delivery truck at East Eighteenth Street and Avenue T. Brooklyn, a residential neighborhood.
BANGKOK, June 24 (AP) -- One of the world's few remaining absolute monarchies toppled today when the army and navy of this picturesque land suddenly revolted and set up a "constitutional monarchy."

TRENTON, N.J., June 24 -- Although he has not submitted a formal resignation. Major Gen. Quincy A. Gillmore of Rumson has made known to Governor Moore his desire to be relieved of command of the New Jersey National Guard. Impaired health is said to be the reason for the request.

PARIS, June 24 -- With a rally affecting nearly every group of stocks, the Bourse ended the week today considerably firmer. More hopeful prospects of the Lausanne conference were credited with causing the improvement, for trading remained more or less dormant.

Irregularly lower prices were again the order yesterday in most sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Aside from a few infrequently traded issues, the principal losses were not more than a point or two, while at the same time a fair-sized list of issues advanced about these amounts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Rattling base hits off their convenient right-field wall until the affair took on the aspect of a spirited handball encounter, the strangely revitalized Phillles gave the Giants a drubbing today, 11 to 6. The outcome dropped Manager Bill Terry's club back, into sixth place.

Officers of the International Union of Operating Engineers and of its Local 125 in this city were accused yesterday of attempting to circumvent a recent important decision by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer, aimed against despotic control of labor organizations, by issuing a charter for a new local to supersede Local 125 and by entering into agreements with builders before the court had had lime to act on its own decision.

The Cosmopolitan Opera Association of New York, a cooperative project for artists and musicians to present opera at popular prices, announced its formation last night with a concert in Madison Square Garden. Several thousand persons heard a program of music and addresses by Frederick B. Robinson, president of the College of the City of New York, and De Wolf Hopper, well-known actor.

Attention was sharply focused on the relation, of civil to military aviation by the statement of Senator DE BROUCKERE of Belgium to the disarmament conference at Geneva the other day that "commercial aviation so far has progressed on a basis of purely military considerations."

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. If for no other reason, the two-thirds rule of Democratic National Conventions is entitled to some of the respect always due to age. It was just one hundred years ago, at the party's first convention, that the rule was adopted.

Sprayed with flaming gasoline exploded from a gallon container, Grace Perezzi, 4 years old, was burned fatally yesterday afternoon and her mother, Mrs. Frances Perezzi, 23, was critically burned while the family were having lunch in their apartment at 215 East 106th Street.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Republican liquor plank is expected by Joseph R. Nutt, treasurer of the national committee, to help the party's campaign chest.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Secretary Stimson in a letter today to Senator Jones, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, denied a charge made on the floor last Monday by Senator McKellar that the State Department had been spending $400,000 a year for liquors to be served at embassies and legations abroad.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Wagner $2,300,000,000 relief bill passed by the Senate yesterday and sent to conference by the House today met the approval today of President Hoover on "the principle of generous relief to unemployment," but he criticized the provision of the bill in general as "pork barrel" gestures that would ultimately ruin the accomplishments of those who have struggled to bring about a balanced budget.
RENO, Nev., June 24 -- John Wanamaker 2d of Philadelphia, son of the late Rodman Wanamaker, filed suit for divorce here today from Mrs. Pauline Disston Wanamaker.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 (AP) -- A crowd of 12,000 watched Miss Sarah Palfrey's losing battle against Miss Betty Nuthall on the Wimbledon Centre Court today.
Coney Island's famous Bowery, trod day and night by milling hordes of amusement seekers, is a private road and not a public street, Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

A chemical analysis, made yesterday, established that Raymond H. Alien of 299 Park Avenue was intoxicated when he fell into a bathtub on Wednesday night in the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Van Riper at 1,060 Fifth Avenue and received scalding burns that resulted in his death.

The Congregation Khal Chasidie Skwere, now at 231 South Third Street, Brooklyn, has bought for a new home the two-story building at 1,337 Forty-seventh Street, near Fourteenth Avenue, from the Manufacturers Trust Company.
LONDON, June 24 -- Mme. de Fleuriau, the wife of the French Ambassador, presented eight American women at the fourth and final court of the season, which was held at Buckingham Palace tonight.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 24 -- Wilson Charles Jr., a brawny young brave from the Oneida tribe, today took the lead in the battle for the honor of representing the United States in the decathlon, most trying test on the Olympic program.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- A fighting spirit among the 500 women officially here to attend the Democratic National Convention became apparent today in the lobbies and headquarters of the Congress Hotel and other "political" hotels along Michigan Avenue. Each feminine committee member or alternate appeared ready to battle for her choice among the Presidential and Vice Presidential aspirants.

The Board of Taxicab Control announced yesterday that it would hold a public hearing next Tuesday, in response to a widespread demand from members of the taxicab industry, to discuss methods of reducing the number of cabs now in operation on the city streets.

After waiting more than a month for her re-entry permit, Mrs. G. Mercer Adam, an Englishwoman, who has resided in New York City since 1892, succeeded in obtaining the document and sailed yesterday on the Cunarder Franconia for London.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A frank statement of the authorship and genesis of the railroad bond purchase plan, now under serious consideration in Washington, seems desirable in view of the published implication that some concealed and possibly sinister interest may be behind the idea.

A copy of the so-called "Breeches Bible," one of twenty curious editions of the Scriptures which collectors throughout the world have prized for hundreds of years, has been uncovered in the vaults of the Winter Memorial Library at the Staten Island Academy in St. George by that private school's headmaster, Thomas G. Burton, it was announced yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24 -- After a lapse of five years Miss Marion Hollins of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club won the women's Long Island golf championship today, wresting the title from the defending champion, Mrs. Robert C. Lake of the Old Country Club, 5 and 3, in the scheduled thirty-six-hole final at the Cherry Valley Club.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The licenses of broadcasting stations WMBQ and WMIL, Brooklyn, and WWRL, Woodside, N.Y., were temporarily renewed today by the Federal Radio Commission, subject to the commission's decision on their pending applications for renewal, which are designated for hearing.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- Opposing a proposal to change the two-thirds rule at the Democratic National Convention, former Governor James M. Cox, the party's Presidential candidate in 1920, issued the following statement tonight:

Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Churchill signed yesterday an order declaring Louis Waldman, attorney and former Socialist candidate for Governor, in contempt of court for "disorderly, contemptuous and insolent behavior" in court, and fining him $250, with the provision that if the fine was not paid in five days, Mr. Waldman should be sent to jail for ten days.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 (AP) -- Lloyd Waner poled a long home run into centre field In the seventh inning today with the score tied at 3 -- all and the Pirates took the first game of the series from the Reds, 4 to 3.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- Three national and two State banks in Chicago were closed today by action of their boards of directors.

FAR HILLS, N.J., June 24 -- New Jersey's hunting set gathered at the Far Hills Fair Grounds this afternoon for the opening session of the annual Bedminster Hunter Show staged by the Misses Virginia Brice and Emily Stevens.

Why in this great hour are Mr. CURRY and Mr. McCOOEY turning their backs upon New York? Themselves among its glories, why are they neglecting this opportunity to exalt its horn? With surprise and pain, its citizens must see them careless of their duty to it, apparently making no efforts in behalf of a New York candidate for President, though two are in the field.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What an excellent letter appears in THE TIMES today over the signature of Fabian Franklin! His remarks anent Mr. Hoover may carry a modicum of justice tempered with mercy, but he "damns with faint praise" in trying to refrain from wounding the President or his advocates.

A study of the stars and celestial spaces as a cure for depression and "the blues" was recommended yesterday by Dr. Robert G. Aitken, director of the Lick Observatory, who returned on the United States liner Leviathan from a trip to London, where he was honored for his work in astronomy.

Embittered by a long-standing quarrel with 22-year-old wife, Julia, which had twice resulted in his arrest, George Glendenning, 30, a bakery wagon driver living at Asbury Park, N.J., armed himself with a pistol and went yesterday to 474 Central Avenue, Jersey City, where his wife lived with her mother and stepfather.

BOSTON, June 24 -- Hollis Thurston, backed by five Brooklyn double plays and a far-flung home run by Hack Wilson, pitched a neat shutout against the Braves today, the Robing winning, 3 to 0, and supplanting the Giants in fifth place. It was Thurston's fifth consecutive victory.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Hoover's statement on unemployment relief and the Wagner and Garner bills was as follows:

ALBANY, June 24 -- With the ad-, vance guard of Democratic leaders it Chicago striving to prevent his nomination, Governor Roosevelt appeared today unperturbed by the latest reported developments and more confident than ever.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 24 (AP) -- Richard Bennett, manager of the Binghamton Airport, was killed today in the plunge of his flaming plane as he was rounding the second pylon in an event for small-motored machines, a feature of the opening program of the international air races.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Fabian Franklin is right in saying that economic issues are of paramount importance at the present time. Prohibition problems are secondary in the minds of most of us to the nightmare task of keeping afloat and maintaining a modicum of morale and self-respect in this bog of depression that threatens to engulf us all.

Acute weakness cropped out in many sections of the Stock Exchange list yesterday. A considerable number of the prominent issues broke through previous lows. Transactions involved a total of 772,000 shares, against 472,000 shares on the day before.

The three Silinsky brothers, Al (alias Abe), William and Frank, whose activities in bucket shops in the financial district for more than ten years had been under almost constant investigation by the Attorney General's staff and the District Attorney's office, were found guilty by a jury in General Sessions yesterday afternoon of second-degree grand larceny in a bogus stock transaction.

RICHMOND, Va., June 24 (AP) -- A feeble remnant of the once magnificent armies of the Confederacy today passed in review before the bronze statues of Lee, Jackson and Stuart mounted on stone pedestals, high above Richmond's famed avenue of heroes.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Governor Roosevelt, who has repeatedly declared for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and twice has run on a wet platform, has no need to state his view on this issue, James A. Farley, his campaign manager, declared tonight in a radio speech from Station WENR.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Secretary Stimson has sent a message of appreciation to Premier Mussolini for Italy's quick acceptance of President Hoover's disarmament proposal, but is not making it public here or commenting on it.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The Democratic National Committee, after a good old-fashioned wrangle, voted tonight to seat two Roosevelt delegations whose right to vote in the convention was contested by rival groups claiming to represent the true will of the people their States.

MEXICO CITY, June 24. -- The American Smelting and Refining Company won a victory over striking employes today, and the Cananea Consolidated Copper Company, which has the largest plant in Mexico, applied for permission for an indefinite suspension that would throw out of work the bread winners among 10,000 men, women and children.

An expedition headed by Sherman Pratt, son of George Fratt of the Standard Oil Company, returned yesterday from Spanish Honduras on the United Fruit liner Musa. The party brought back about fifty jungle snakes, a number of birds and animals and about 15,000 feet of film taken in the jungle.

The Pennsylvania and the Lehigh Valley Railroads were among those that reported yesterday decreased net operating incomes for May. The Chicago Great Western incurred a net loss in the same month. The New York. Ontario Western reported a small decrease in net operating income for the month, although its net operating income for the five months ended with May was ahead of that of a year ago.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Need for an economical campaign as well as more money with which to finance the party's activities during the coming year was stressed by leaders at a Democratic "Victory Fund" caucus held today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 24 -- A novel study of the movement of elections through watching X-rays that had been shot at them and had bounded away was described here this morning at the second day's session of the 179th meeting of the American Physical Society.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 24 -- Louis Waldman, New York attorney and Socialist candidate for Governor in the last Gubernatorial campaign, told the delegates attending the eighteenth Summer conference of the League for Industrial Democracy today that "economic planning is as popular a phrase with financiers, politicians and liberal economists today as was reconstruction, immediately after the war, but with a revival of business they will forget economic planning as they have forgotten reconstruction.
DUBLIN, June 24 -- A hundred thousand Catholic women knelt throughout a drizzling rain in Phoenix Park tonight, oblivious of everything except the mystery and wonder of their faith.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 24 -- Rising to brilliant heights of tennis, Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, University of North Carolina star, furnished the greatest upset of the national inter-collegiate championship tournament by beating the titleholder, Keith Gledhill of Stanford University, on the grass courts of the Merion Cricket Club today.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Amelia Earhart skimmed into the Curtiss-Reynolds airport today and did not flinch from the cameras as she did four years ago when Chicago welcomed her as "a home town girl" who had blazed a trail for women filers across the Atlantic.

Leaving out the question of SMITH, McADOO or any other candidate, I doubt if any rules of the convention should be changed after the delegates are elected. But if, after the convention has met, it should appear that the old rules are working a hardship on the party, that might be a reason for a change next year.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- Rowing against the tide on the windroughened waters of the Thames this morning, the Yale freshman crew and the Harvard junior varsity eight triumphed in the minor races that opened the seventieth annual regatta.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- Back from the ruck of an early season marred by disappointments, a brilliant Harvard crew raced to victory over Yale on the Thames River this evening.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 24 -- This is the first year in a quarter of a century when the onward development of our American system of education had been seriously interrupted J.W. Crabtree, secretary of the National Education Association, told delegates gathered here for the meeting of the National Council on Education prior to the opening of the annual convention of the National Education Association tomorrow.

By playing the best round of golf produced over the testing, trying Fresh Meadow Country Club links yesterday, Phil Perkins, bespectacled British-born golfer who recently deserted the amateur ranks, catapulted himself right into the thick of the fight for the national open championship of 1932.
Small flats continue to provide the bulk of realty transactions in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- A $302, 000 trust fund created twenty-nine years ago by the late Rodman Wanamaker for the benefit of his three children, who were to share the income upon his death, has grown to $856,863,09, it was shown today in an adjudication in Orphans Court of the first accounting of the trustees.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: If it is wise to invest at today's low market prices, and to buy commodities at today's low costs, is it not equally wise for employers to take advantage of the present opportunity to strengthen their staffs with men and women whose training and experience they could not have bought three years ago for twice the salary of today?

Unsettlement on the Stock Exchange yesterday was ascribed to a number of developments, among them the closing of several small banking institutions in the Chicago district which aggravated a situation that already has been causing some concern.

LONDON, June 24 -- A special Cabinet meeting was called today by Stanley Baldwin, Deputy Premier, to hear the report of Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, on the Hoover disarmament proposal. Sir John, had planned to return to Lausanne tomorrow, but will remain here until Monday or Tuesday.

LONDON, June 24 -- A special Cabinet meeting was called today by Stanley Baldwin, Deputy Premier, to hear the report of Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, on the Hoover disarmament proposal. Sir John, had planned to return to Lausanne tomorrow, but will remain here until Monday or Tuesday.

LAUSANNE, June 24 -- Nothing tangible has come from today's first effort of the French and German delegations to the reparations conference here to find some substitute for reparations or to cancel them.
