It is becoming obvious that Prime Minister MacDonald's great effort on behalf of the world's business to get rid of Europe's political bad debts and try to make a fresh start has little chance of success.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 24 -- Undaunted by a heavy wind which swept the course throughout the day, Miss Frances Snyder of the Apawamis Club triumphed over Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club, 6 and 5, in the final round of the annual Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Tamarack Country Club today.

The Manufacturers Trust Company Has been appointed registrar for 2,500,000 shares of $3 common stock of the American and Dominion Corporation and depository for the 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold debentures and certificates of deposit therefor of the American Natural Gas Corporation.

The Railroad Credit Corporation has agreed to release to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway the $2,014,000 of its consolidated mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds that the railroad pledged for a loan of $2,805,175. These bonds the Frisco would repledge, together with $4,390,000 of new prior mortgage bonds for a $4,390,086 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Unsettled by a weak stock market and favorable weather in most southern sections, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased a few points yesterday and closed 3 to 5 points lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A proposal that the President and Vice President of the United States be elected by popular vote was made to the Senate today by Senator Coolidge. Introducing a joint resolution to amend the Constitution to that effect, he also stated that he would ask the resolution committee of the Democratic National Convention to consider the matter favorably.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Reduction of the rediscount rate of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank from 3 1/2 to 2 1/2 per cent, effective tomorrow, was announced today by the Federal Reserve Board.

A few figures from the annual report of the State Housing Board give a picture of the housing problem, as it exists today on the lower east ide. Thirty years ago we set out to banish old-law tenements and do away with slums. Both are with us yet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- Supplementiag his recent pronouncement in favor of "good beer" and submission of an amendment to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment, Governor George White today declared that Federal prohibition could not be enforced "at the present time."

As a result of the new Federal taxes, the Durium Products Company, makers of the paper phonograph records which have had wide sale in this country since 1930, will transfer most of its manufacturing operations from the United States to England, it became known yesterday.

SEATTLE, June 24 -- Delegates at the final session today of the convention of Rotary International were urgrd to assist in promoting international understanding in solving world economic problems and aiding in overcoming the "moral, psychological and financial depression of the world."

The Consolidated Gas Company increased its sales of electricity in the three months and the twelve months ended on March 31, but derived less revenue from them than in the comparable periods a year before. The figures are contained in reports to the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.

Colored wood-cuts by Gustave Baumann, a member of the Taos colony, are on view at the Grand Central Galleries and will remain there until Aug. 1. This work is pleasantly ornamental. The flat tones, all keyed to the same intensity, and the easily comprehensible composition contribute to the effect of nature as seen through an interior decorator's eye.

Official confirmation that the theatrical producing firm of Schwab Mandel bad separated "for the present" was obtained yesterday from Laurence Schwab, when he announced that he and B.G. De Sylva would present a musical show next season.

Increasing pressure on the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare has compelled the organization to double the size of its headquarters in anticipation of an expenditure In the Fall of about $100,000 a day for relief, as compared with approximately $50,000 at present, it was reported yesterday at the bureau offices, 10 East Thirty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland, aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination, reached Chicago with a trainload of Maryland delegates and supporters and on a parade through part of the business district was cheered by probably 100,000 people, who packed sidewalks and office windows and showered the visitors with ticker tape, confetti and torn telephone books.

Twenty-six organizations, chiefly Catholic charitable and religious institutions, share the residue of the estate of Mrs. Clara A. Baab, who died Oct. 8, 1931, and whose estate was valued yesterday in the transfer tax appraisal at $258,837 gross and $218,240 net.

Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion of the world, was suspended indefinitely as a manager and a second yesterday by the State Athletic Commission "for conduct and actions in the ring considered detrimental to boxing."

MUCH of the excitement of trapping big game in the jungle, without any of the dangers or inconveniences, is to be had by a visit to the Mayfair, where Frank Buck's remarkable picture, "Bring 'Em Back Alive," is attracting unusual throngs.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The American Jewish Congress opened tonight with a meeting of the national executive committee under the chairmanship of Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum of New York. Dr. Tenenbaum will review the conditions facing European Jewry at the first general session tomorrow morning.

WITH the discovery by Dr. Walter S. Adams and Dr. Theodore Dunham of the famous Mount Wilson Observatory that carbon dioxide is present in the atmosphere of the planet Venus, the old question of the habitabllity of other worlds than our own assumes a new importance.

The transatlantic steamship companies are practicing rigid economy in every department in their efforts to make enough money from passengers and freight to pay operating expenses and keep down their deficits.

It appears that there is no lack of activity among yacht brokers of New York City and vicinity. At any rate, reports gathered from them over the past few weeks reveal a sizable turnover of pleasure craft included in the so-called "documented" class, i.e., those displacing over sixteen gross tons.

To the Dramatic Editor: I was gratified to see that you considered the letter of F.G.M. of sufficient value to give it publication in your issue of May 22. Let me join F.G.M. in her fine suggestions. Needless to state, the first one, regarding the foul air in many Broadway playhouses, is undebatable.

Retail business during the week was good and reorders wets fairly heavy for timely items. Many stores are planning special departmental promotions for immediately after July 4, instead of the usual clearances, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

THAT popular pen-and-ink hero, Mickey Mouse, has become a producer-member of United Artists, joining Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks, Charlie Chaplin, Gloria Swanson and the other members of the Joseph M. Schenck organization. With him goes Walt Disney's companion feature, the Silly Symphony.

Moscow. THE Bolsheviki realize that the cinema is one of the best instruments for pounding new ideas into stubborn heads. Past masters of the art of propaganda in writing and speech, they are making full use of the screen to teach their people what's what in the Communist lexicon.

Asserting that business activity here can be accelerated only by the introduction of new industries, H.W. Bennett, president of the American Tung Growers' Association, said yesterday that the production of tungoil is one of this country's new basic industries and will aid in initiating recovery.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- On the same stag's which the Republicans used for their recent extravaganza, "press on with Hoover," the Democrats were preparing today to open on Monday a revival of that old American favorite, "E pluribus unum," or "One out of many."

New York school teachers attending the annual meeting of the American Federation of Teachers, which opens in Chicago today, have pledged their "utmost strength" to members of the profession in the Middle West in their "demands for financial justice."

BOGOTA, June 22. -- The most Important question facing the 1932 National Congress, which meets in special session on June 27, is whether the emergency legislative powers, amounting virtually to a fiscal and financial dictatorship, conferred on the President of the republic, shall be continued beyond July 31 of this year.

In the midst of other vehicles stopped by a traffic light on Broad-way at 176th Street, Philip Bessise, 25 years old, driver of a delivery truck for the Eagle Fur Corporation of Yonkers which contained pelts valued at more than $6,000, and his helper, Oriofrio Lugattoile, 24, were held up at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a youth, who held a pistol partly concealed under his coat.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, June 26. -- The controversy over the interview of A.T. Steele, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and a Swiss correspondent named Lindt with General Ma Chen-shan, the insurgent leader, was settled satisfactorily at Harbin late yesterday.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, May 28. -- "Not enough money and too many relatives." That is the trouble with the new state of Manohoukuo, in the words of a high official in the government. As he spoke, he withdrew a packet of $100 in local currency, worth about $20 American money, from his pocket and threw it on a table.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an out and out gold standard man and approving all the varied acts of reconstruction of Congress and President Hoover, I am constrained to say, as I have heretofore said, there will be no great relief from this frightful depression until something has been done to restore the purchasing power of silver.

WINDSOR, Ont., June 25 (Canadian Press). -- Weakened through medicine which he had taken to reduce his weight and disappointed because a heart condition would not permit an extended airplane flight which he proposed, Wilbert Clayton Hyatt, 26, hanged himself today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- All New York lost to All-Philadelphia in the men's field hockey final trials for the Olympics at St. Martin's today, 4 to 2.

SINCE talking big about theatrical productions always has been a favorite hot-weather sport, many are the musical shows being announced these days for late August or early September production. A lot of them, of course, will never reach the stage (some already have been postponed indefinitely), but among those which should be fairly certain is a new George White's "Scandals."
PITTSBURGH, June 25 (AP). -- The hustling Pittsburgh Pirates climbed into second place in the National League race today by beating the Cincinnati Reds in a double-header, 5 to 4 and 8 to 5.

OF all the problems raised by national conventions, that of nominating a Vice President is perhaps the most curious. IN comparison, Presidential nominees and platforms are almost simple. People begin talking about them weeks ahead of time.

The annual scholarships, medals and other awards of the School Art League will be presented to high school students at exercises tomorrow afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum. Dr. Herbert Spinden, director of education at the museum, will preside, and John S. Roberts, assistant to the Superintendent of Schools, will be the principal speaker.

Never in the thirty-six years of its history has the open championship seen such a demonstration as was made at the home green at Fresh Meadow yesterday, when Gene Sarazen and Willie Klein, his playing partner, smashed their seconds shots to the green.

MR. DENNIS has written a quotable book, noted for close thinking and plain speaking. Its chapters are even more intriguing than its title, being charged with a spirit of frank inquiry into the gravest questions of the hour.

The wide use of the typewriter, not only in business but in private life, has caused some to fear that handwriting may soon become as obsolete as beautifully illuminated manuscripts. Mid-Victorian ladies, shocked to find grand-daughters at college writing them neatly typed notes, wonder what the world is coming to.

DETROIT, June 23. -- The Department of Public Welfare, after an uneven career of attempting to give the city's unemployed men care which would maintain their morale until such time as conditions became normal, is at length faced with the situation of being unable to provide even groceries for a bare sustenance diet to the families under its care without the most complex planning.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- The first wide breach in the "favorite-son" entrenchments appeared swiftly and dramatically today when a telegram to an Illinois editor from Senator James Hamilton Lewis, withdrawing is a Presidential candidate, was issued from Roosevelt headquarters.

JERUSALEM, June 8. -- Whoever it was that said that the youth of a country must be reckoned with as an influential force was right so far as Palestine is concerned. In this country the youth is an active factor in racial politics. The majority of the youthful politicians are students at the high schools, colleges and universities of the Near East; and they are probably the greatest irritant in an already complex situation.

IT may be only a bewildered impression, but these open golf championship seem to get wilder year by year. A player, after digging His own grave at 10 A.M. or so, is decently interred and forgotten. Less than an hour later the miscreant is discovered holing a long putt for a birdie on the sixteenth and right back in the tournament again. There ought to be a law.

LONDON. THE annual conference of the Associated Booksellers. just held at Chester, spent the greater part of its four sessions in dealing with technical matters. The discussion of moat general interest was on a proposal for closer cooperation with the Publishers' Association by means of a joint committee.

Armament Reduction. Why did the Senate, on June 16, 1932, pass a bill appropriating $319,000,000 for naval purposes when this nation professes to want disarmament, and is insistent that economy measures be observed in carrying on all departments of the government?

TODAY. 3:00 P.M. -- WABC -- The "D Minor Symphony" by Cesar Franck will be performed in full during the symphonic broadcast under the direction of Howard Barlow. Selections from the works of Humperdinck and Sinigalia will complete the program.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- Ralph Kress came out of his batting slump with three singles and a double to help the White Sox stop the fast-flying Tigers, 10 to 5. It was Detroit's first setback in seven games.
NEWARK, N.J., June 25. -- Arbiter, 2-year-old bay colt owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange and driven by Paul Vineyard, trotted off with the feature event of the matinee today.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The new gift tax law was interpreted today by David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, as being intended by Congress not only to be a "revenue-raiser" but also to supplement the estate tax, which has been to a considerable extent evaded by transfers made during life.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 25. -- Championship honors in the first annual horse show of the Plainfield Riding Club at Vinebrook Farm, today went to Golden Robin, a chestnut mare owned and ridden by Miss Doris M. Blondell of MontclairGolden Robin, a saddle, horse, previously had won two blues in the morning classes.

ONE of the most interesting developments in the field of aeronautics comes into being today with the dedication at Akron, Ohio, of the Daniel Guggenheim Airship Institute. For years the United States Navy and private capital, furnished for the most part by the Goodyear Zeppelin Company of Akron, have provided the hacking for lighter-than-air research.

RECENT conferences of directors of Summer camps in al parts of the country reveal un precedented difficulty in securing enrolments and support. Many private camps have reduced they rates, but still find it hard to bring parents to the point of signing contracts.

WASHINGTON. THE comparative silence that hung over the various prohibition camps during the between-conventions week spoke, more eloquently than volumes, of the new quandary in which these organizations find themselves.

In what was doubtless the most sensational finish of the season, the Wheatley Stable's Blenheim charged through the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday with a show of speed and tenacity which could not be matched by his rivals, and won the Brookdale Handicap before 10,000 cheering spectators who were left breathless by the drive.

The cooperation in government movement, which at the end of each school term presents tokens to selected high school graduates, again assembled its new recruits in the hall of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon to administer the Ephebic Oath that was taken 2,000 years ago by the young men of Athens on their becoming citizens.

PARIS, June 25. -- A proposed new-film quota, approved by the French Superior Cinema Council and forwarded to the Minister of Public Instruction today, would drastically limit the importation of American dialogue pictures.

BIRMINGHAM, June 23. -- When the roll is called at the Democratic National Convention next week, the first responding voice will come from Alabama. It will belong to the same Alabamian who led off on 103 ballots at the Madison Square Garden convention in 1924 with "Ala-b-a-a-a-ma, twenty-four votes for Un-der-w-o-oo-o-d."

Nineteen-year-old Albert Law of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, who had played so impressively throughout the week, was defeated by Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, in their semi-final round match in the Eastern clay-court tournament at Jackson Heights yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The railroads can do much to put an end to the present economic depression. If they want to do so. The method is very simple, and practically painless, so far as they are concerned.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Aroused by a press association report from London yesterday that the United States and Great Britain had made a "gentlemen's agreement" on debts and disarmament, Secretary Stimson issued a formal denial today of a sweeping character.
NEW YORK CITY has a pattern of family names peculiar to itself, and some of its most popular surnames are little known elsewhere in the nation.

THE leading article in the June issue of The American Magazine of Art is "Washington and His Associates," by Katherine McCook Knox. This is followed by the second of a series of three articles by Thomas Munro -- "How the Artist Looks at Nature" -- much too excellent to be missed.

KAY FRANCIS hag abandoned her plans for a European jaunt in order to appear in a leading role in the next Ernst Lubitsch venture, which bears the tentative title of "The Honest Finder." Paramount borrowed Miss Francis from the Warners, where she had just completed "One Way Passage" with William Powell.

Reconciliation of Mr. McAdoo and Governor Smith at Chicago offered a great but unused opportunity to those opposing their plans. They should at once have got out a big poster reading. "See St. Luke, xxiii, 12." Delegates who scurried around to the bookstores would have found that it read: "And the same day Pilate and Herod were made friends together."

MOSCOW, June 12. -- Private trade has almost disappeared in Russia; some time ago the government figured that it represented 1 per cent of the total. One of the first things that a visitor in Moscow notices is the absence of private stores. There are no little shops with the owners' names written on the outside.

A large delegation representing English nobility and important business interests of that nation sailed for New York yesterday from Southampton on the Cunaro liner Berengaria to take part in the ceremonies here next Saturday to mark the laying of the cornerstone of the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Centre.

ROME, June 12. -- This year again the "National Fascist Federation for the Fight Against Tuberculosis" is holding a propaganda week, throughout the length and breadth of Italy, to intensify the relentless war waged by the Fascist Government against this disease, which ranks among the most dreadful scourges of the present age.

THE HAGUI. AN attempt to give international support to the various national efforts to improve history teaching will be made at an international conference on the subject to be held here from June 30 to July 2, under the presidency of Professor R. Altamira, Spanish judge in the Permanent Court of International Justice.

WILL ROGERS reported from Chicago the other day that box seats at the Republican convention were being bartered for standing room at the Democratic convention. The foregone conclusions of the earlier gathering and the prospect of a contest between Alfred E. Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt only partly account for the difference in the popular attitude.

PARIS, June 25. -- Premier Herriot returned here this morning from Lausanne for a second week-end trip to Paris and as swiftly as last Saturday got a unanimous Cabinet agreement to his and Joseph Paul-Boncour's negotiations. However, his support this time is not for a constructive accomplishment such as a five-power declaration but for virtually destroying the hope of making President Hoover's arms plan a genuine basis for discussion.

DETROIT. ADVANCE word indicates that the most radical automobile of the entire depression period is within a month of its formal debut. And even should present advices relating to the new model prove to be overstatements, the principles involved in design still will command wide attention, because the projected new car will have high performance, derived from a material reduction in weight rather than Increased engine power.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Paul Shoup of San Francisco, president of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company, discussed the railroad situation generally with President Hoover at the White House today. Their conference lasted nearly an hour and one phase of the situation discussed with the President, Mr. Shoup said afterward, was the assistance rendered to the roads by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Railroad Credit Corporation.

RESEARCH incidental to the restoration of Colonial or early Republic mansions has disclosed a stronger French influence than was formerly realized Popular opinion has generally conceived the homes of this period as being entirely English in spirit, as were most of those of pre-Revolutionary days.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Reaction to the Roosevelt proposal to abrogate the Democratic two-thirds rule continues to indicate opposition to the change in quarters where the Roosevelt managers had been counting on solid support.

The adventures of Mme, de Littke, who recently, within forty-eight hours, brought to a climax two separate plots of treason, one against the Magyar Regency and the other against the Republic of Poland, surpass those of the Dutch Mata-Hari, even when related by that executed spy's most sensational biographer.

TORONTO, Ont., June 25. -- Production of gold from mines in Ontario in May amounted to $4,079,320, a high record for the Province, which compares with the previous record of $3,847,635 made in March. The largest gain was made by the Porcupine Camp, where the output rose from $1,624,241 in April to $1,810,009 in May.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Politics lines of cleavage etched themselves deeply into the political map during he past week. While a Democratic covention was in the throes of preliminary skirmishing in Chicago, a Congressional session drew near a discordant close and Senator Borah, almost a dry institution in himself, noted President Hoover.
LONDON, June 11. -- An important increase is shown by the Home Office figures in the number of tourists visiting the United Kingdom during the first three months of 1932 as compared with 1931.

Recent decisions of the United States Supreme Court upholding laws of Texas and Kansas regulating the operation of commercial motor vehicles are said to vindicate contentions put forward by railroads in their plea for equality of regulation among all forms of transportation.

CHICAGO. THE tenth annual No-Jury exhibition, a flower show by Chicago artists and a one-painter exhibition of work by Mrs. Amy Irwin McCormick, wife of Colonel R.R. McCormick, publisher of the Chicago Tribune and one of the owners of the New York Daily News -- these are three first-rate art events in Chicago, prolonging the season through June, in the teeth of the calendar and of tradition.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25. -- John Hay Whitney's Greentree quartet and Winston Guest's Templeton polo team gained the final round of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament by registering victories in semi-final matches today at the Meadow Brook club.

The downward revision of rayon prices during the last two months, amounting to about 30 per cent, is definitely insuring the position of the rayon trade among the textile industries of this country, a position which was not clear up to the present time, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by leaders in the textile fields.

Bobby Jones, four times winner of the national open-golf championship will pair with Tommy Armour against Gene Sarazen, British open and newly-crowned national title-holder, and Billy Burke, 1931, national open champion, in an exhibition benefit match at the Fresh Meadow course in Flushing today.

Prohibition agents of the staff of Administrator Andrew McCampbell went to the Federal Building yesterday to complain about the way they had been treated Friday night at an establishment in West Fifty-second Street which the agents said was a speakeasy, but this allegation they were unable to prove.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. The Bangkok revolution has fulfilled at least part of the old mystic prophecy, well known in Siam, that the Chakri dynasty would end in 1932. However, the dynasty has not really ended, since present plans appear to be for a constitutional monarchy, but at least the absolutism of the reigning house has ended, and now the people have been taken into partnership with the dynasty.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- The subcommittee of the unofficial Democratic platform committee this afternoon began consideration of a tentative prohibition plank of unprecedented brevity, which will be reported to the committee on resolutions when that body has been appointed by the national convention on Monday.

LONDON, June 25 (Canadian Press). -- The All-India cricket team, in one of the most creditable performances seen at Lord's, today dismissed the All-English team for 259 in the first innings of the only test match, scheduled this season.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 25. -- Judge A.O. Robbins denied today an application of Lloyd Fisher, counsel for John Hughes Curtis, for a bill of particulars in the indictment against the Norfolk boat builder, whose trial on a charge of impeding justice in the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby will begin on Monday.

ST. LOUIS. June 25 (AP). -- Jake Flowers, playing his first game for the Cardinals, bunted for a squeeze play in the ninth inning with the score tied and allowed Gelbert to fcore from third, St. Louis defeating the Cubs 7 to 6.
LONDON, June 25 (AP). -- The eleven-year-old romance of Paul Robeson, Negro singer, has gone on the rocks of sheer ennui, his wife divulged tonight.

TRYING to record contemporary history in the making, I have had a strange life and a busy one in the last four years. It I ever had time to philosophize, I might venture to hope that my photographs of the statesmen of the world at their work would somehow help to bring about a better understanding among nations.

THIS poem, a series of lyrics really, but so composed as to form a narrative, is the record of one woman's life and of all the influences, social and ancestral, which go to make up that life. The poem is autobiographical and representative of the mind of the author as that mind is the focus of the passions and actions of her forebears.

William Jerome, who wrote "Bedelia," and "Mr. Dooley" and other great song hits of thirty years ago, died yesterday afternoon of pneumonia at his residence, 600 West 165th Street, at the age of 67. He suffered a stroke last Fall and spent three months in the Neurological Hospital before returning home in February.

BENEFITS RECEIVED" is a novel more serious in its import than anything Alice Grant Rosman has yet given us; but it sacrifices nothing of the charm and delicacy which have made her previous books so pleasantly memorable.

Owing to the accumulation in this country of large stocks of copper and to the low rate of consumption, the imposition recently of a tariff of 4 cents a pound on the metal is not likely to cause an early appreciable increase in the price of copper, according to Walter Lyman Brown, mining engineer.

LOOKING back, it seems inevitable to Irene Beasley that she should eventually find her way to the microphone. Miss Beasley traces her origin to below the Mason-Dixon line. But the quiet contentment and shaded streets of Whitehaven, Tenn., where she was born, were no proper setting for "the long, tall girl from Dixie."

PARIS, June 16, 1932. BETWEEN the orchestral concerts spoken of last month and the Russian ballets and operas constituting this year the "grande saison" of Paris, there has occurred an interesting series of recitals.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 25. -- Many members of the Summer colony entertained house guests this week-end, which promises to be the gayest of the season so far.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. GEORGE M. COHAN shocked Hollywood. For years New York actors, directors and executives have alighted from the train to begin telling the local boys how pi tures should be made Recently Mr. Cohan arrived to make "The Phantom President," shooting of which will commence July 5.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 25. -- A sweeping arraignment of the inferior courts of New York City as Tammany selected and controlled, low in standard and inefficient, resulting often in "gross denial of justice," was made by Samuel Seabury in an address here today.

Granting of college entrance credits for music is urged by the music committee of the General Committee on the Secondary Curriculum of the Secondary Education Board in a final report made public yesterday by Frank S. Hackett, headmaster of the Riverdale Country School and adviser on administration problems to the music committee.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange at one time yesterday touched low levels of the week, but active covering left the list at the highest figures of the day and unchanged to 2 points higher than on Friday.

AONG with the forward-looking "modernists" in music whose efforts are exclusively directed toward the discovery and establishment of new ways and novel devices, there has arisen in recent years a group of students and scholars who are directing their attention to rediscovering and expounding the principles that governed the musicians of past epochs.

NOT much change was reported in retail business during the week, although certain promotions drew results above the ordinary. Thus the response to a sale of high-grade merchandise at attractive prices was understood to have been very satisfactory.
NEW YORK. Otto Wadsted, the Danish Minister, is at the Ritz-Carlton.
MUSIC alone is not sufficient for the majority of American concertgoers at the present time.

SUCCESSFUL business men 40 years old and older have had little or no opportunity to get training in a business school. Consequently, they prescribe the same training for young men that they had. Yet when they are actually employing a young man and paying for his training they do not include Latin, Greek or calculus, however much they may believe those studies contributed to their own development.

CONFISCATION last week of former King Alfonso's private fortune by the Spanish Republic revives Interest in that subject of persistent curiosity, the wealth of royalty. "Rich as a king" goes the saying, but the exact figures are not given often.

Moscow. ALL sorts of people who had believed themselves shockproof have been shocked by the production here of "Hamlet" at the Theatre Vakhtangov. Criticism has been on the whole disapproving, but packed audiences register violent enthusiasm nightly.

Slowly but surely, getting closer every two or three days, according to the length of their engagements In the western part of Canada, where they landed on June 17, the Australian cricketers, making a goodwill tour of North America, are advancing upon New York to play three exhibition matches between July 14 and July 19.

FAR HILLS, N.J., June 25. -- The annual Bedminster Horse Show closed its two-day session at the Far Hills Fair Grounds today when Miss Emily Stovens, one of the directors of the show, saw her brown gelding Ben G. win the hunter championship. Reserve went to Mrs. R.D. McGrath's Flying Ebb, a horse which Miss Stevens rode in several events.

PARIS. HAVING seen M. Harriot, a Premier of the Left, succeed M. Tardieu, a Premier of the Right, in charge of the French. Government, foreigners have manifested curiosity as to the signifcance of this change for the foreign policy of France.

GLACIERS nowadays keep out of the way of progress, hiding at the ends of the earth or among the highest mountains, yet they make the first page often and figure in some of the most stirring news of the time. Adventurous souls, exploring the world for the rest of us, travel upon them and always find them highways of peril.
SKANEATELES, N.Y., June 25. -- By the narrow margin of 13 points, Yale won the 1932 Eastern intercollegiate outboard championship on Lake Skaneateles today, beating Princeton, 5,459 points to 5,446.
BANGKOK, Siam, Sunday, June 26. -- King Prajadhipok cordially accepted today the end of his absolute power and the establishment of a constitutional monarchy by leaders of the People's party.

Depressed business conditions have forced material changes in vacation policies followed by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers In this city, according to a survey which was completed yesterday by the inlustrial bureau of the Merchants' association.

HENDON, England, June 25. -- With the world considering President Hoover's disarmament proposals, including the abolition of airplane bombers, Great Britain's newest secret fighting aircraft, including a day bomber capable of 200 miles an hour at 20,000 feet, were seen in action for the first time by a record throng at the thirteenth Royal Air Force display here today.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Federal Farm Board suffered a reverse when the Senate by a viva voce vote cut an appropriation of $1,000,000 for the board from the independent offices bill, today and substituted permission to use up to $600,000 of the surplus remaining for the current fiscal year.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- In preparation for the bitter convention fight in prospect over the proposal of the Roosevelt forces for abrogation of the two-thirds rule, John F. Curry, Tammany leader, who will be chosen chairman of the State delegation, will place that question and the permanent chairmanship of Senator Walsh of Montana or Jouett Shouse before a meeting of the New York delegates tomorrow evening.

NO man can feel anything but the most poignant apprehension and anxiety. I do not wish to create a pessimistic feeling. Among the nations of the world we are, I believe, in the best position, but if the world is going down, if civilization is going in crack.

In none of the financial markets was there any incident yesterday to break the monotony of an uneventful week. Stocks marked time and the bond market was only a trifle less apathetic. There was an irregular decline in the foreign exchanges, with the exception of sterling, which rose 3/8 cent to $3.61 1/2.

THE Mr. Craig to whom words like "suave" and "ingratiating" recently have been applied barely missed being a hoofer. At the moment, as a matter of fact, he can be found nightly lapsing into a dance as he presides as master of ceremonies and monologist for "Hey, Nonny, Nonny!" the new goings-on at the Shubert.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI has developed something of a tradition. After crowning his local season to good purpose, he hies himself across New Jersey and performs the same service for New York. Thus it has become a habit, as our activities are on the ebb, to look toward Philadelphia to learn what the mercurial maestro has up his sleeve wherewith to reopen the Metropolitan Opera House for a night.

SEIZING the opportunity presented by the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Human Betterment Foundation of Pasadena, Cal., spread abroad the results of what it calls "careful studies" of our terrible mental state.
President Hoover's arms plan has given Europe something to think about.

OMAHA, June 23. -- Grasshoppers are hopping all over the corn belt and beyond. Reports of their presence in noticeably large numbers come from an extensive area in eight of the North Central agricultural States, from Iowa and Minnesota on the east, through Nebraska and the Dakotas to Montana, Wyoming and Colorado on the west.

The Appellate Division will be asked tomorrow or Tuesday to permit an appeal from its decision Friday sustaining Samuel Seabury in his contention that Supreme Court Justice Ford erred in his "sweetness and light ruling", and should have rejected from the records of a contempt case the affidavits of William J. Flynn.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat from Amity, Ind., was discovered by a reporter trying to keep his balance in the pushing crowd in the Congress Hotel corridors.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 25. -- Pounding out fourteen hits, the New York Athletic Club nine beat Fort Slocum, 5-3, on the losers' diamond today. Jess Sawyer, former Yale twirler, hurled effectively for the winners. Although he granted nine hits, he kept them well scattered.

To The Editor of The New York Times. We hear from various sources, such as Dr. Butler, the cry for a real national leader, for a statesman like Lincoln, who can fearlessly disregard immediate political preferment and maintain a consistent principle to lead us out of our difficulties.

With two smashing finishing rounds, unquestionably the greatest ever played in any golf championship. Gene Sarazen yesterday added the United States open title to the crown he annexed only a few weeks ago in Great Britain.

BOSTON, June 25. -- Primed for what they expect to be the political "battle of the century," Massachusetts supporters of former Governor Smith and Governor Roosevelt left for Chicago today and will arrive there tomorrow.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 25 (AP). -- The Davila Socialist Government made a gesture for foreign approval today by restoring all its former functions to the Central Bank of Chile, which had been placed under government control as a State bank by the short-lived junta headed by Colonel Marmaduque Grove.

SHANGHAI, May 28. -- Having decided to stop wasting its revenues and resources on indecisive civil wars, the Nanking Government is now working out the details of elaborate schemes for the rehabilitation and development of that portion of the country which is securely held by General ChiangKai-shek's armies.

A conscience-stricken 18-year-old boy surrendered to the police in Queens late Friday night and confessed his connection with a gang which, in the last eighteen months, is alleged to have been responsible for a large number of chain-store and delivery wagon hold-ups in that borough and Brooklyn which netted more than $75,000.

THIS little book comes from England and presents an interesting collection of the convictions on certain aspects of religion in its relation to science of a large group of leading men of scientific attainment. The British Christian Evidence Society, which made the investigation, did so because it thought that to get at first hand the personal expression of men of science on these matters would be highly desirable.

Despite rumors that disturbances might attend the biennial election of officers by Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, held yesterday in the Central Opera House, East Sixty-seventh Street, near Third Avenue, uneventful voting returned to office the administration ticket headed by Frank Wilson.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 25. -- The home of Ercules Molea, known to the police as a man of wealth and several professions, was destroyed here In a mysterious explosion early this morning a few hours after Molea and his wife had sailed for Italy.

In His Arms-Cut Proposal to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva. THE time has come when we should cut through the brush and adopt some broad and definite method of reducing the overwhelming burden of armament which now lies upon the toilers of the world.

A TRANSCONTINENTAL, motor tour is well worth while at any time, but especially so this year, because it will enable those who visit Los Angeles between July 30 and Aug. 14 to witness the Olympic Games. That this added attraction will draw thousands of motorists from all parts of the country is evidenced by the number of inquiries received at the principal motor-touring bureaus in New York.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 25. -- Gus Scharfenberg of Lynbrook, driving Honest Napoleon in the 2:15 pace in the Nassau Driving Club races at the fair grounds today beat three sterling side wheelers in Lady Lucy, Hollyrood Devereaux and Short o' Cash, former Grand Circuit stars.

HARTFORD, June 25. -- Connecticut's thirty-four delegates and thirty-four alternates, carrying the State's sixteen Smith votes to the Democratic convention, left for Chicago this afternoon with mixed feelings and hopes.

BERLIN, June 25. -- The Boerse opened weak today, the first hours producing declines as much as 3 per cent, mainly due to profit-taking sales consequent on the non-materialization of yesterday's better expectations from Lausanne and nervousness over the South German situation.

THE gay '90s are coming to life again in the world of fashion. Is it just a midsummer fancy? Perhaps, but here they are -- the feathers and frills that reigned supreme during those years when the waltz was at its dizzy best. May there not be some subtle bond between the early 1890s and the youthful 1930s?

LAUSANNE, June 25 (AP). -- One of the many proposals delegates to the reparations conference are considering over the week-end is an idea for a general pool whose resources would support the public credit by guaranteeing the debts of nations on the verge of financial ruin.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- In presenting platform suggestions of organized labor at a morning session of the Democratic Resolutions Committee today, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared that industrial conditions were growing worse, with the largest unemployed total in history.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 25. -- A field of 121 began play in the fortieth annual New Jersey State men's tennis singles championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club, with two of the eight seeded players advancing to the third round.

FOR many years the mind of the United States has been interested in the Near East, in Russia, in China and, latterly, in India. It is now the turn of Africa to emerge, how slowly yet how surely, out of the shadows into the limelight.

Firing will open on three fronts this Friday and Saturday in the battle for places on the American Olympic track and field team. Three semi-final try-outs will be held and foremost of these will be the fifty-sixth annual Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. championships at Berkeley.

Plans for stabilizing business, advanced recently by numerous organizations and business men, are unworthy of serious consideration because they centre on modification of anti-trust laws, methods for artificial maintenance of prices and curtailing competition, and avoid recognition of the need for getting supply into a proper relationship with demand, George A. Renard, secretarytreasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, charged here yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 18. -- It is estimated that at least 500,000 persons are suffering from famine and disease in the drought section of North Brazil and the cooperation of the entire nation is urged by the press. The president of the Brazilian Red-Cross, General Dr. Alvaro Tourinho, likens the present situation in the afflicted sector to Dante's Inferno.

LOS ANGELES, June 23. -- California, as a political entity in its relation to a national election, is in a new and Intriguing role just before the delegates to the Democratic Convention depart for Chicago. It is a peculiarly mixed and interesting situation.

ST. LOUIS, June 23. -- When Missouri voters go to the polls next August to name party nominees for the United States Senate, the lower house of Congress, Governor and some lesser State offices, they will be confronted by the most formidable list of candidates within the memory of veteran politicians in the State.

OTTAWA, June 23. -- The project for an imperial quota scheme for wheat which came to the forefront at the Imperial Conference of 1930 remains a vital subject in Canada, particularly in the three Prairie Provinces.

Attacked and overpowered by two men. apparently intoxicated, who were in an argument over the Sharkey-Schmeling prizefight on a crowded B.M.T. train on the Fourteenth Street Line train pulling into the station at Fourteenth Street and Fourth Avenue early today.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- It's a woman-feud, open and bitter, against Huey Long now, with two of his home-State feminine leaders chief combatants and the Democratic convention floor the probable arena.

Lou Gehrig, by driving home the first two Yankee runs with his nineteenth homer of the season and by breaking a 4-4 tie with a seventhinning single, played the major role in the 7-to-4 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics before 20,000 fans at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
BERLIN. THE novels to be discussed today are distinguished more by the position and personality of their authors than by any particular merit from the artistic point of View.

IT is only a little more than twenty years since John W. Gates died, at the end of one of the most spectacular and flamboyant careers lo which Wall Street has ever given birth. The golden tides had piled up at his feet in less than a decade some $30.000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Judge Max Isaac of New York, editor of The American Bankruptcy Review, today characterized as both "important and far-reaching" two bills introduced yesterday by Representative La Guardia. One would prohibit the appointment of corporations as trustees in bankruptcy and the other would forbid their appointment as receivers.

Under this caption ALBERT G. MIL-BANK, lawyer, bank director, chairman of the board of a great industry and philanthropist, sets forth foundation principles on which "to build an improved economic and social order." Socialism in its extreme form "destroys some of the finest and most useful qualities in the individual."

IDAHO'S LONE LION. LAST Monday Senator Borah picked to pieces the Republican, platform plank on the Eighteenth Amendment. At the end of the performance Senator James Hamilton Lewis raised his chromatic voice in a question almost as involved as the plank itself.

With the commissioning of eighty cadets of the Salvation Army's training school tomorrow the institution will be closed for a year, in accordance with an order of the Army's national war council, and the organization's activities will be concern traced solely on relief work among the destitute.

BERLIN, June 23. -- The question of whether German citizens of voting age have a constitutional right to dress themselves in a manner to identify them as belonging to closed political formations has become a burning issue in the Reich and the federated States as a result of President von Hindenburg's revocation of the decree proscribing Adolf Hitler's "brown army" and its uniform.

LOUISVILLE, June 23. -- On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, Kentucky politicians are on tenterhooks over many complicating factors threatening to afect the coming campaign. It is learned from a reliable source that former Governor Edwin P. Morrow is all set to announce for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, and that he will declare for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
HERE is a battery of scholars noted for research who have at length discovered a very small rusty needle In a very large and dubious haystack.

THE fact that this translation is made from the fifth Russian edition would Indicate that Dr. Nemilov's exposition of his theory had had a very considerable success in Soviet Russia. That it should arouse interest is understandable, since the Russians are trying to establish a new evaluation of woman and to set her in the proletarian State on a basis of equality with man.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The subject of corporation finance, particularly railroad finance, is a live topic right now. As I understand it, two theories or policies are applicable to corporation debt. One contemplates constant refunding as indebtedness matures and the other contemplates payment of indebtedness out of earnings over a period of years.
For the fourth year in succession and the ninth time in the fifteen years that the trophy has been in competition, New York won the Church Cup yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club. Forest Hills.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 24. -- Signs of recovery are seen in the farm regions of the Tenth Federal Reserve District. Another advance in fat hogs and fed cattle this week carried prices $1 above the May lows, representing an increase in the net return to producers on live stock marketed at Kansas City of about $10 a head on a 1,000-pound steer and $2 a head on a 200-pound hog.

BUFFALO, June 23. -- Buffalo was first incorporated as a city in 1832. Preparations have been made for a memorable observance of its centennial this year. A new centennial park has been developed on the Niagara River front, and a stadium has been built.

THAT familiar ghost of this season of the year, the announcement that the young hopeful has failed in a study and will be taking it over in Summer school or next year, does not walk any more at the Columbus School in New Rochelle, despite the fact that the presence of a large foreign group among its pupils presented some educational difficulties and "repeaters" used to be a major problem.

WITH the support of leaders of both political parties, the House of Representatives last week passed H. R. 8681, a bill to encourage the conctruction in the United States by American private capital of airships for use in foreign commerce.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 23. -- With the rout of his party at the election, former Premier J.T. Lang practically disappeared from the public stage. Almost the only mention of him in the newspapers is when he testifies before or is mentioned by the royal commission that is inquiring into the scandals arising from his administration.

A university professor hearing a colored laborer singing expressed his pleasures that any one was happy enough to sing in these days, but got the answer that there was such a thing as singing to make one's self happy. Hearing Major MOTON speaking in his melodious prose, about conditions among his own people, one wonders whether it is his own naturally, radiant happiness that is expressing itself or his exuberant hope.

ROME, June 12. -- A census of the native population in the Italian colony of Tripoli has just been completed. It shows that the resident native population numbers 522,914, including 7,750 soldiers. This compares with a resident native population of about 400,000 in 1929 and of 569,000 in 1911, when Tripoli was still under Turkish domination.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Customs Bureau today ruled that the recently imposed revenue duties on imported lumber would not apply in the case of imports from the Philippine Islands.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- As a result of negotiations involving milk dealers, interested labor unions and dairy farmers, the price of milk in Chicago recently dropped from 12 to 11 cents a quart and from 8 to 7 cents a pint.

LAUSANNE, June 25. -- By the German delegation and by the British, who are Germany's second biggest private creditor, emphatic denial was given today to the suggestion that there would be proposed or discussed here any reduction in Germany's private debts.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- The Pierrette Club of New York held the first of a series of Summer dinner dances tonight at the Rye Bath and Tennis Club. The clubhouse and grounds were decorated to represent a night at Cannes. Varicolored lights were suspended from the trees which form part of the gardens of the club, overlooking the Sound, and used to illuminate the outdoor dancing pavilion and dining terrace.

ROME, Ga., June 22. -- A revolutionizing of the methods employed by the paper industry of the South in the production of white paper and news-print was predicted here today by Dr. Charles N. Herty of New York, in an address before the annual convention of the Georgia Forestry Association.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Bread lines and party lines were the chief concern of Democratic women at a breakfast given this morning by former Governor Nellie Tayloe Ross, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, for her lieutenants, the national committeewomen here to attend the party's convention.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 25. -- For the second time in the last three years, Clifford Sutter, Tulane University star, today won the national intercollegiate tennis championship, beating Bryan Grant of North Carolina in the final round on the grass courts at the Merion Cricket Club.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 25. -- Three all-around track and field stars from the same collegiate neighborhood, headed by James A. Bausch, the Jarring Jim of Kansas football fame, will represent the United States in the decathlon of the tenth Olympiad.

A DECENT admonition by Viscount Kikujiro Ishii against American interference with Japan's "pacific and natural expansion" in the Far East is notable not only for its directness but also because it marks a further stage in the relations of the two countries with respect to Asiatic affairs.

ART CENTRE -- "Designer and Industry" exhibition, which opened last Monday and is to be on until Oct. 1. It was summarized June 21 and will be discussed in more detail by Walter Rendell Storey in next Sunday's TIMES Magazine.

ALTHOUGH sales of automobiles for the first five months of 1932 were less than one-third of those in the corresponding period of 1929, there has been an increase in the number of buyers paying cash for their purchases in both 1932 and 1931, according to Motor Magazine.

PARIS, June 24. -- The Grande Semaine is just ending -- the culminating week of the racing year as well as the very height of the season, artistically and socially. Ordinarily one could not interest Parisians in anything else, but Frenchmen today are talking more about disarmament, reparations and war debts than about who is going to win the Grand Prix at Longchamps Sunday.
