The Rev. Francis P. Duffy, World War chaplain of the 165th (the Fighting Sixty-ninth) Infantry, was in a coma early this morning at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was taken nine days ago suffering from colitis. Little hope was held out that he would survive the night.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Tammany, led by John F. Curry, is in danger of being "left out on a limb" after convention as it was after the 1912 convention in Baltimore, if the supporters of Governor Roosevelt win their fight to abrogate the two-thirds rule, elect Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana as permanant chairman, and nominate Mr. Roosevelt for President.

Some of the pastors will devote their sermons this morning to a discussion of the moral issues before the country, and a number will speak of the National Democratic Convention which opens tomorrow in Chicago, and prayers will be offered for divine guidance there.

What Are You Going to Do? IT WAS remarked here recently that many drivers in New York seemed to be blankly ignorant of the fact that hand signals to indicate turns and stops had been established by law, and it was reported that the Police Department had undertaken the rather hopeless task of enforcing the unknown statute.

Governor ELY'S appointment of Professor FELIX FRANKFURTER of the Harvard Law School as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts has stirred up a curious little storm. Mr. FRANKFURTER'S position among teachers of and writers on the law is of the highest.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23. -- Just as for centuries the ring of a coin has been accepted as a test of its worth, wo today research engineers are utilizing and measuring with the most delicate instruments the ring of metals to find out their fundamental properties, which it is especially necessary to know in the development of new alloys.

BOGOTA, June 22. -- President Olaya Herrera will recommend some kind of control of the sale of intoxicating liquors to the Congress which he has called into special session June 27. The measure will probably follow the lines of his suspended decree on the same subject.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25. -- Frederick Perry won a smashing victory for Great Britain today over Wilmer Allison, United States Davis, Cup player, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, the winner gaining the quarter finals.

Details of a new corporate voting shares trust. United States Electric Light and Power Shares, Inc., were made public yesterday by Calvin Bullock, Inc., the sponsoring firm. They show that the shares represent twenty-eight public utilities, 80 per cent of which are operating.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 25. -- Starting with a fairly strong breeze and then almost becalmed in the middle stages of the races before the wind returned, eighty-five yachts competed today in the sixtieth annual regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, held in Long Island Sound under the auspices of the Long Island Yacht Racing Association.

THE Chicago Stadium, the 1932 citadel of national politics, it frequently used for boxing bouts. On both sides of the massive arena is a large sign reading, "Next Fight --" the date being blank. One of the radio technicians attending the Republican convention filled in the date, "June 27."

What some of the women swimmers of the country do in competition this season, of course, will have added significance because of the Olympics. But there is one young lady, in fact, one very young lady, who has gained much attention because of her record performances of last season and who in the normal trend of sporting events would ordinarily warrant added consideration, even though there were no international competitions to think about.

Mr. HOOVER'S proposals to the disarmament conference illustrate at once the possibilities and the limitations of the President an a leader. In foreign affairs he has an almost exclusive privilege conferred upon him by the Constitution. He can receive or refuse to receive diplomatic representatives of other countries, which implies that he may recognize or decline to recognize any given, government.

THIS combination of hard times, higher taxes and a swiftly mounting public debt has caused many Americans to look with fresh Interest at the vast machinery of Federal government which now employs three-quarters of a million people.

LONDON, June 18. -- A new race of fossil man is believed to have been found in the raves of Wady el-Muphara, which lie at the foot of the western slope of Mount Carmel, forming one of the most remarkable groups of Stone Age sites discovered in recent years.

At Syracuse last week Dr. W.F.G. SWANN set up a strange fifteen-foot instrument to count atoms which had been wrecked by cosmic rays or radium emanations and thus reduced to ions. Clicks came from a loud-speaker, each the salute of a passing ion. Only the wrecks due to cosmic rays were made to announce themselves.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange showed considerable irregularity again yesterday in the two-hour trading period. United States Government bonds, in which dealings amounted to only $543,000, recouped part of the previous day's losses. Eight of the eleven issues traded moved up 1-32 to 6-32 point, one issue sold off 1-32 point and two held unchanged.

LONDON. UPON reading the Treaty of Versailles In 1919 Max Weber, the German scholar and republican, remarked to a friend: "In ten years we shall all be nationalists." This prophecy has very nearly come true.

IT was at the end of 1930 that Carleton Washburne set out on the quest of which this book is the outcome. It was a globe-girdliag quest, made possible by the Julius Rosenwald Fund, to seek out what is being done and thought in other lands by those whose thinking and doing will influence educational theory and practice during the coming years.

ABOARD TAMMANY SPECIAL TRAIN, Albany, N.Y., June 25. -- Battles may rage on the Chicago front, but Tammany's sole worry is that the fun may be over by the time it gets there. The trains that left New York today carried the rank and file of the organization, and the rank and file is going in a carnival spirit.
The annual fishing rodeo in which "only nets, trout lines, hand lines and dynamite are barred" will be held under the auspices of the Izaak Walton League chapter of Foley, Ala.

Tim Brooks, a photographer of 859 Van Nest Avenue, the Bronx, started out from Great Kills Beach, on the south shore of Staten Island, yesterday afternoon in an open canoe on a voyage to the Bahama Islands. He was accompanied by his young wife. Mrs. Stella Brooks, and their 1-year-old daughter, Stella Marie.
NEWARK, N.J., June 25. -- The Newark Bears made a desperate uphill fight today, but fell one run short of overcoming an early Baltimore lead and lost to the Orioles by 5 to 4.

ONE of the non-fiction headliners on the Fall list of Ray Long Richard R. Smith is a book entitled "Not to Be Repeated." It is described as an "Inside Survey of the Merry-Go-Round of Europe," and its authors, one for each country, prefer, for obvious reasons, to remain anonymous.

Members of patriotic and civic organizations in Washington Heights participated yesterday in ceremonies held at points made historic by Washington in that area. The ceremonies were part of the George Washington bicentennial celebration.

Mgr. James B. Curry, for the last fifteen years pastor of Holy Name Catholic Church at Ninety-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, died yesterday at the rectory, 207 West Ninety-sixth Street, from arterial sclerosis and uremic poisoning. He had been ill three months.

WASHINGTON. June 25. -- Aroused by the President's criticism of his unemployment relief bill because of the $500,000,000 appropriated in it for public works. Senator Wagner today delivered a final plea for the measure as it was taken up by a conference of members of the House and Senate.

It is not Colonel Powell's inention, of course, to convey he idea that there is literally any undiscovered country in Europe, though the parts he describes are little frequented by tourists. It must be admitted that he very ingeniously justifies his title.

ON the surface this is the story of the murder of two American boys traveling through a small Balkan State and of the efforts of an American newspaper correspondent to find the murderer. But beneath the surface it is much more than that.

IT seems difficult for a master printer to design a monumental book without becoming, well. expansive. The idea that the proper testimonial to a typographer's talent must be something that bulks large is a very old and popular one.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Under the influence of the Roosevelt forces, the control of important posts in the Democratic National Convention has been shifted from the South and the populous Eastern cities to the rural West.
BOSTON, June 23. -- Can the Suffolk County grand jury compel the Governor of Massachusetts to appear before it to testify in connection with its investigation of a closed bank?

TORONTO, June 25. -- Either the Ontario Government or the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission will take over the Abitibi Canyon power development project, according to a statement made by Premier Henry. This is a result of financial difficulties of the Ontario Power Service Corporation, which finds it impossible to obtain about $50,000,000.

ATLANTA, June 23. -- If the stop-Roosevelters would take a day off and analyze the Democratic situation they might be able to understand the hopelessness of the task they have set for themselves. At least that is the opinion here. Georgians and many Democrats in other Southern States find amusement in the anomaly of McAdoo.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- With at least fifty members of the House certain to be absent and about half that number of Senators attending the Democratic National Convention at Chicago, Congress will enter the new week in a bitter and dilatory frame of mind although confronted by the twist important and urgent legislation of the session.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Garvan pave a large dance last night at Roslyn House, their estate in Roslyn, L.I., to introduce to society their elder daughter, Miss Flora Brady Garvan. It was the first debutante party of the Summer on Long Island. The grounds were beautifully illuminated.

WASHINGTON. June 25 (AP).--The Red Sox won their twelfth game in sixty-two starts this season today when, they drove Al Crowder from the hill with a six-run rally in the fourth and defeated the Senators, 7 to 6.

DUBLIN, June 25. -- The religious exaltation of the Irish Catholics mounted hourly tonight as the climax of the Eucharistic Congress, with a solemn pontifical high mass and profession for almost 1,000,000 worshipers, drew near.

Complying with its recent offer to advance prices of crude oil when certain conditions limiting production had been met by the oil producers of California, the Standard Oil Company of California yesterday announced an increase of 25 cents a barrel, effective today.
BALTIMORE, Md., June 25. -- The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team rallied strongly to score a 7-to-5 triumph over the University of Maryland today and captured the United States title.

ALBANY, June 25. -- With the Chicago scene surcharged with the tension of convention eve, Governor Roosevelt altered his plans tonight to be close to his direct telephone wire to his convention headquarters. The Governor had planned to remain overnight at his Hyde Park home, but, after motoring there in the morning, he changed his schedule and returned here after a visit to Newburgh to dedicate a swimming pool as a memorial to an aunt.

TORONTO, June 25 (Canadian Press). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs broke even with the Montreal Royals today as Russell Blackburne assumed the management of the Leafs. The Royals won the opener, 11 to 1, and the Leafs captured the second 10-8.

LONDON, Sunday, June 26. -- President Hoover's arms reduction proppsals were hailed in some Sunday papers; a Sunday Times editorial declaring, "It comes as a blast of fresh air into the fetid atmosphere of expertism which Geneva has been breathing too long."

PLANS are being considered and worked out for opera in London this Fall. The success of the four-week Wagner festival at Covent Garden recently has stimulated increased activity in the planning of opera for the coming season.

HITHERTO the publications of the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, which was organized to study in a five-year program the economic aspects of the prevention and care of sickness, have been devoted to phases and subjects of the general theme in their relation to the medical profession.

PARIS, June 14. -- Underconsumption of French wines, which in recent years has coincided, unfortunately, with increased vineyard production, might be remedied if hotel proprietors and restaurant keepers would lower prices on their entire wine list.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- Playing a brilliant, well-balanced game, Leonard Martin of Apawamis, 1931 metropolitan amateur champion, captured the Westchester amateur golf crown today, defeating V. Theodore Lowenstein Jr. of the Century Country Club, 7 and 6, in the scheduled eighteen-hole final, over the West Chester Country Club's west course.

THE new tax on bank checks, which went into effect last week, will put an added book-keeping burden on banking institutions throughout the country. Up to this time few of the large New York banks have kept any tally of the number of checks that were drawn by their depositors, only the amount in dollars they represented being considered of importance.

AMERICAN in aspect, manner, and work, Ernest Haskell nevertheless owed something to his descent on his mother's side from the Norman French. The mingling in his character and in his art of strength and a delicacy amounting to daintiness was unusual and rewarding.

MOSCOW, June 23. -- For a long time the Soviet press has been crying out against dangers besetting the Soviet Union from the outside, such as the risk of an attack, but whereas now there is a lull in this direction there are important internal problems.

A SAVING of "from ten to fifteen billions of wasted dollars to the peoples of the world during the next ten years," while still "maintaining an adequate self-defense among all nations," was held possible by President Hoover in his statement of last Wednesday recommending a reduction of about one-third in the world's armaments.

DUBLIN, June 25 (AP). -- A signal honor was conferred upon American Catholicism today when Archbishop Michael J. Curley of Baltimore was selected to celebrate the solemn pontifical high mass that will conclude the Eucharistic Congress tomorrow.

LONDON, June 24. -- The members of the British Parliament are going on the warpath in an effort to reduce government expenditures and when the House of Commons adjourns next month it will leave at work a whole brood of voluntary committees determined to find new ways to economy.

Men's clothing and furnishings, with the $15 price point emphasized for suit promotions by many stores, attracted steady customer interest in local stores during the week, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer Both Retail Reporting Bureau. The development of special merchandise and the offering of clothing reduced from stock to this point were the two methods followed by the stores.

RUMSON, N.J., June 25. -- One more grand canine specimen that has been knocking at the door of fame for some time gained entrance today when the chow dog Champion Far Land Thvmdergust, bred and owned by the Far Land Kennels of William Macfarland of Camden, N. J., was awarded the title of best in show at the annual exhibition of the Monmouth Kennel Club, held on the Harding estate.

MUCH has happened up at the Metropolitan Museum Since one year ago today. It has been truly a Wunderjahr. As a matter of fact, the year has witnessed, all over the country, museun developments and changes, many of which are of great significance.

Indiana, once thought to be the stanchest of all prohibition States north of the Mason-Dixon Line, has twice deserted the Eighteenth Amendment during the last three weeks. Early this month the Republican State Convention adopted a platform spurning the compromise Hoover-Garfield-Brown-Moses-Mills plank then in process of evolution, and substituting for it a plank favoring a direct vote on repeal.

LATONIA, Ky., June 25. -- After an absence of little more than a month, the thoroughbreds returned to Kentucky today as Latonia swung open its gates for a 31-day Summer meeting. Despite a cloudy sky, track and weather conditions were ideal and a crowd well in keeping with previous inaugurals was on hand.

WHAT WE LIVE BY" is a philosophic handbook of conduct, ethical and spiritual; but a handbook conceived with such clarity of thought, and written with such clarity of diction, the reader does not realize he has been lured into the pursuit of philosophy!

THE Graham six for 1933, announced last week, is reported to be now in production and to be available in the five-passenger sedan and convertible coupe types. To these will shortly be added a standard coupe and a rumble-seat coupe.

LONG ago the romance of the old oaken bucket faded, in real life at least, before its sanitary terrors. And now the tender associations of the little red schoolhouse bid fair to vanish in the face of its rapidly increasing toll of educational sins.

THE recent unsuccessful efforts in Germany to break up Adolf Hitler's "Brown Army" directs attention to the number of military and semi-military organizations that have been active in the affairs of the Reich. The Treaty of Versailles limited the republic's official standing army to 100,000 men, but the German States maintain efficient police forces which may be moved about like a militia.

To most persons, the new ruling of the State Superintendent of Banks relating to the evaluation of securities held by State-chartered banks and trust companies will appear to be a radical departure from ordinary banking practice. As a matter of fact it is, but the ruling has the endorsement of the best minds in the banking world and was suggested by the newly formed State Banking Board as one of its first official acts.

In conformity with a new policy of making public its results from time to time, the Consolidated Gas Company notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday of earnings of the New York Edison Company and the Brooklyn Edison Company, its two leading subsidiaries, for the three months and the twelve months ended on March 31.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 25. -- Heading out to sea past Great Eastern Rock buoy off Montauk Point, twenty-seven yachts started this afternoon on their race to Bermuda. Craft that are more than fifty-three feet long sailed at 4:10 P.M., and the smaller boats followed ten minutes later.

CINCINNATI, June 25. -- George Simpson, former Ohio State University flash, bettered the Olympic record for 200 meters today in the Allegheny district tryouts by going the distance in 21.2 seconds. The present mark is 0:21.6.

VENICE. THE traveler who, soon after leaving Mestre. looks out of the train window, eager to enjoy the vision, always new and always enchanting, of Venice which, through the vague mist, seems to float gently on the waves like a white seabird, is today suddenly surprised and disturbed by an ugly and unexpected sight.

TO an ever-increasing extent aviation is making its influence felt in the field of education. The relation of aeronautics to education, especially to sociology, psychology and economics, is to be the subject of a new course in the Summer sessions of the School of Education, New York University.

WASHINGTON. FROM the time of the enactment of the first income tax law of the United States the Federal Government has treated the incomes of the legitimate business man and the criminal alike. The federal tax gatherer sits down with the honest man and the felon alike and counts up their profits and divides with them upon the same basis -- no discrimination is made against the criminal, none in favor of the decent man.

ALTHOUGH the theatre is basically a city enterprise, country theatres have a place in the artistic scheme of things, and some plays belong to country theatres alone. One of these plays is Lynn Riggs's "The Cherokee Night," which had its first performances last week at the Hedgerow Theatre in Moylan-Rose Valley, near Philadelphia.

SHANGHAI, May 29. -- Leaders of the Nanking Government are watching events along the Manchurian-Siberian border with grave apprehensions, for they feel that if Russia and Japan become involved in a war, Manchuria will not only be the principal scene of conflict, but will be permanently lost to China no matter which side wins.

VIENNA, June 24. -- Preliminary estimates of the wheat crop of the Danubian basin indicate that the Winter wheat acreage sown has been reduced 3 to 5 per cent as a result of the Spring floods in Yugoslavia and Rumania, and the acreage of Spring wheat is something like half of normal.

TOKYO, June 25. -- The dismissal yesterday by the Chinese Government of Commissioner Fukumoto, a Japanese, from the Chinese Maritime Customs in Dairen, in the Japanese leased territory of Kwantung, brought a vigorous protest today from the Tokyo Government to Nanking.

With the exception of part of an issue of foreign bonds called for redemption in June before the maturity date, the only additions last week to the list called for retirement, for the remaining days of the month, were small lots of State and municipal securities.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Gallant Knight, heavily played favorite, won the $10,000 added Peabody Memorial Handicap, closing-day feature of Washington Park's thirty-day meeting today, with Spanish Play second and Pittsburgher third.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25. -- Arguing that "the great American tradition" has lost its potency, and that we are experiencing a beginning of national disintegration. Dr. Fred J. Kelly of the United States Office of Education, speaking here today before the National Council on Education, urged the calling of a congress of social and economic leaders to formulate the essential social-economic goals of America to be taught in public schools.

BOSTON, June 25. -- The Dodgers bade farewell to Boston tonight with no reluctance. They dropped the third and final game of the series to the Braves, 6 to 5, after young Van Mungo had gone into the eighth inning with a 5-to-3 lead.
TOKYO, June 25. -- Disagreement with the method of uniform arms reduction suggested by President Hoover was expressed today by General Sadao Araki, the Minister of War.
NEWBURGH, June 25. -- Governor Roosevelt dedicated the new Annie Delano Hitch Memorial swimming pool here today. It was constructed honor of his aunt, who was noted for her philanthropy.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 25. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club retained its lead in the Eastern Athletic Club League by defeating the Penn A.C., 4-3, before 2,500 persons today.

DEPRESSION has knocked on the door of romance, and Cupid, sitting inside adjusting his arrows for the rush season, has been forced to telephone the arrow factory to cut down on the usual order. June does not beckon us quite so alluringly as of yore to the spots where romance flourishes.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Having in mind the numerous legislative proposals to be considered at the next session of Congress that affect the banking system of the country, the United States Chamber of Commerce announced today that it would take a referendum among its members to determine what, in their opinion, should be the character of remedial measures adopted.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 25. -- Combining a fast-passing attack with an alert defense the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club la crosse team brought its season to a close by routing the Montelair A.C., 9-1, today. It marked the tenth victory in twelve starts for the Crescents.

LONDON. QUEEN MARY, who has just celebrated her sixty-fifth birthday, possesses some curious and little known rights and distinctions. She is, among other things, practically regarded by the Constitution as a single woman.

A RADIO preview of the new opera, "Tom Tom," to receive its world premiere on June 30 in Cleveland, will be broadcast over WJZ's network at 7 o'clock tonight. The opera, which traces Negro life from Africa to Harlem, is the work of a young Negro composer, Shirley Graham, who has directed intimate opera.

GENEVA, June 25. -- Organized support, from the small powers, which earlier this year forced the adoption by the great powers of the Stimson doctrine of non-recognition of results gained by breach of peace treaties, is now developing here for the Hoover disarmament plan.

Hounding out the dullest week on the Stock Exchange since August, 1923, the share market continued yesterday to reflect the current mood of hesitancy in Wall Street. The day's volume was only about 310,000 shares; the total for the week was a trifle more than 3,000,000 shares, or what would have represented a normal day's business in 1928 or 1929.

Frederick Brown, real estate operator and philanthropist, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court. The petition, which was entered by Ernst, Gale, Bernays Falk, his attorneys, contains no estimate of liabilities or assets.

The new French Line cabin steamship Champlain arrived yesterday from Havre via Plymouth and was received with salutes from the various craft in the harbor from Quaranine to the pier at the foot of West fifteenth Street. The liner responded with deep toots from her siren.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25. -- Newton D. Baker, declaring himself today against abrogation of the Democratic two-thirds rule for Presidential nomination, said that a candidate chosen by such an expedient would have "a moral flaw in his title" and would find it "deeply embarrassing" to himself and to the party.

DES MOINES, June 25 (AP). -- Henry L. Doherty Co. must stand trial in Iowa courts on actions brought by buyers of Cities Service stock to recover on shares sold before the company was licensed in Iowa, the Supreme Court held in a ruling handed down yesterday.

The Treasury Department's monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of June 1 shows the following principal changes during May. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

WHEN Stuart Erwin, as the screen - struck enthusiast of "Make Me a Star," paid what was supposed to be his first visit to a Hollywood studio, scarcely one of the several score departments on the Paramount lot escaped the prying lenses of the cameras.

If air-conditioning could be applied to apartments and dwelling houses, pure cool air would be breathed by the occupants. Conditioning simply means regulating by artificial means the air in the interior of office building, theatre, factory, skyscraper, hotel, public library and the home.

PARIS. A the moment of writing, Paris couturiers are very busy turning out chic travel clothes. The fashionable woman leaves nothing to the last moment: and so, as soon as the Grand Prix is run, she is ready to dash to Deauvllle or Le Teuquet, and, later on, from there to points north or south, according to the dictates of fashion or fancy.

Two firemen were overcome by smoke at 10:30 o'clock last night and traffic in lower Fifth Avenue was diverted three-quarters of an hour while fire companies, summoned on three alarms, fought a stubborn, smoky blaze in the first-floor showrooms of Ezra Mallen Son, tapestry and rug importers, at 3 West Thirtieth Street, and in the basement of the five-story loft building.

MADRID, June 24. -- The difficulty of breaking the political crisis has been brought to the fore this week by the furor over the Catalan statute. The Catalans have stood firm for the type of autonomy they desire, while the rest of the country has made it impossible for the Azana Government to give it to them even if it wanted to.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- There was no substantial change in foreign markets covered in the weekly survey of conditions abroad issued today by the Commerce Department. Activity was reported at lower levels in several countries, but Australia and Canada had some gains.

THIS is a story in two parts. The first is written in the Middle West, home address of America and generalizes the talk to be heard almost anywhere in the United States during this highly conversational, politically heated and financially frigid campaign year of 1932.

Formation of a Canadian counterpart of the Corporation of Foreign Bondholders, founded in London in 1873, under license from the Board of Trade, to be known as the Coporation of Canadian Bondholders, was made known here yesterday on receipt of prospectuses outlining the scope of the new organization.

Golf -- Gene Sarazen added the national open championship to the British open title which he won recently by scoring 70 and 66 for the last two rounds at Fresh Meadow, giving him a 72-hole total of 286. His score equaled the record for this event.

THERE is a fallacy concerning air travel which seems to persist no matter how frequently the facts are made public. It is that Europe leads the United States in commercial flying. The other day cables were busied with a dispatch to the effect that a record for air travel had been set at Le Bourget, the famous airdrome which serves Paris.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 25 (AP). Isaac Rosner, living at 47 South Windsor Avenue, dropped dead of heart disease tonight at the age of 55. His daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Cooper, and son, Philip, have been staying here with him.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 25. -- Charley Devens pitched Harvard to a 6-to-0 victory over Yale today in the play-off of the series between the rival baseball teams.

TAMMANY HALL will hold a pivotal position in the Democratle Convention which opens tomorrow in Chicago. This fact, coupled with the recent disclosures brought out by the Hofstadter legislative investigation, centres interest more than ever upon the organization and its leader.
CHICAGO, June 25. -- The forces of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, seemed to hold firm all along the line today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 25. -- Three hundred members of the Theta Delta Chi college fraternity of this country and Canada are holding a four-day assembly here at Briarcliff Lodge. The assembly opened this morning with a business meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended June 18 were lower than in the preceding week, but were still larger than during the first week of the month, according to the weekly survey of the domestic business situation made public today by the Commerce Department.

LONDON, June 25. -- Andrew W. Mellon, standing erect and dignified with his back to the wall of the great throne room of Buckingham Palace for two solid hours on each of the "court nights" this week, experienced again the rigors of the pageantry of royal courts.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Authority to establish lower rates on freight shipped in steel containers over its lines east of Buffalo was requested by the New York Central Railroad today in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

FOR many years copper tubing of .035-inch wall thickness for aircraft fuel systems has been the recognized standard of the Air Corps, but a program of research has been kept in effect at the materiel division, Wright Field, in which the vibration machine has been kept going day after day, testing materials other than copper, in an effort to obtain a tubing of greater desirability and offering greater resistance to the destructive action of vibration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Southeastern Pennsylvania delegates to the Democratic National Convention, badly split on a Presidential nominee, but evidently united for prohibition repeal, left Philadelphia on a special train this afternoon for Chicago, amid cries of "bring back beer" and "bring back prosperity."

SOUTHAMPTON. L. I., June 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins gave a dinner tonight at Ashton Moor, their place in First Neck Lane, for Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, who are spending a few days with them. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. William H. Woodin of East Hampton and Mrs. Frederic Van Lennep, who is passing several weeks with Mr. and Mrs. Higgins.

PRAIRIE CHRONICLE" is presumably a first novel but It is a first novel of marked vigor and originality. In spite of some moments of awkward and rather amateurish writing, it has a fine swing in its narrative and a salty savor in its speech.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 25 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons defeated the Red Wings in the opening game of the series today, 11 to 4, shelling Wetherell and Smith for sixteen hits. Fussell pitched airtight ball for five innings and then collapsed, but was rescued by Wilson.

PARIS, June 16. -- The Petite Semaine, or Little Week, which precedes the Grande Semalne, marking the close of the big Paris social season, usually sees around of private entertainments as well as charity and other public functions. One of the most notable and distinguished affairs was given, by Mrs. Burke Roche.

THE fifteenth season of Summer concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium of the College of the City of New York will open Tuesday evening under the direction of Willem van Hoogstraten. Again there will be eight weeks of nightly concerts, with Mr. van Hoogstraten presiding over the first half of the season and Albert Coates over the second half.

FEDERAL, credit has eased the financial strain on the country's producing machinery -- large-scale industry, commerce and agriculture. But the home owner still struggles unaided with the cash commitments of high-income days.

PARIS. PAUL. VALERY baa said that the usefulness and the true function of the critic could be expressed In the advice offered by the following admonition: "I urge people of such-and-such intelligence and such-and-such temperament to read such-and-such a book."

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- Several hundred women prohibitionists jokingly agreed today to a proposal by Mrs. Henry W. Peabody of Beverly, Mass., that New York be allowed to "prove itself the perfectly model wet State" to demonstrate to the rest of the States what conditions would be without prohibition.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I assume it is hardly necessary to defend Eliot Tuckerman against the criticism of William A. Platz in your issue of June 19, but the question of the qualified negative of the President, with thousands of ex-soldiers storming the citadel of government, is one of importance, and it may justify a reference to historical matters more relevant than those suggested by Mr. Platz.

LONDON, June 15. -- A unification of the economic and industrial interests of the British Empire and the United States was envisioned here today by William Watson, chairman of the New Industries Home and Overseas Committee, who spoke at the Savoy Hotel before a gathering which included municipal authorities, home and overseas manufacturers, foreign, consuls and representatives of industrial organizations.

Developments in the controversy over the administration of the manufacturers' excise taxes yesterday in eluded a statement from retail in terests, insisting on the absorption of the tax by producers, and a three hour discussion between furriers and apparel manufacturers, which ended in a deadlock.

ROME, June 24. -- The death penalties recently inflicted on the bomb terrorist, Domenico Bovone, Mussolini's would-be assassin, and Angelo Sbardellotto caused a far deeper impression in Italy than would have been the case in a majority of other countries, because Italy is one of the few States wherein capital punishment had been nonexistent for the latter half of the nineteenth century.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- The Chicago Bank of Commerce did not open for business today. The closing was ascribed to heavy withdrawals which have reduced the deposits from more than $10,000,000 to $5,200,000. Assets are understood to be sufficient to pay all depositors upon eventual liquidation, according to bankers well informed regarding current conditions, and there may even be a small surplus for the stockholders.

Liberalisation of anti-trust rules to permit groups of producers to agree that none of them shall sell below the cost of production la urged by Ernst Ernst, accountants, In their weekly bulletin. They assert that the present laws tend to establish a roof or a top for prices, but do not provide for any limits to a decline.

BERLIN, June 25. -- Premier Heinrich Held of Bavaria sent an appeal to President von Hindenburg today invoking his intercession in connection with the State's refusal to raise the ban against Adolf Hitler's storm troops and their uniforms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: German pre-war national wealth was estimated at 330,000,000,000 marks. Therefore she most certainly is capable of paying off a debt of $10,000,000,000 in fifty-eight years.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 (AP). -- British tennis observers believe that Ellsworth Vines and Sidney B. Wood of the American forces have the best chance to win the Wimbledon title. While Wood, the defending titleholder, has been playing the best all-around game of the tournament.
WASHINGTON. June 25. -- Prince Subba Svasti, brother of the Queen of Siam, who is traveling incognito in this country as Major Svasti, arrived here tonight from New York

Gifts and bequests totaling $175,462,82 had been received in the past year by New York University, William M. Kingsley, treasurer, announced yesterday. Of that sum $100,000 was received under the will of Mrs. Frances R. Biggs, widow of Herman M. Biggs, former State Health Commissioner.

CHARLES WILLIAMS is an English scholar with a very live interest in poetry, a wide and profound knowledge of the Engllsh poets, and a trenchant pen when writing of poets and of poetry. Including his latest book. "The English Poetic Mind," Mr. Williams has published a round half-dozen volumes, including not only studies in poetry but poetry of his own, and plays.

In few conventions have the problems facing retailers been treated with more "brutal yet constructive frankness" than the one held during the week by the National Retail Dry Goods Associations at the Hotel Commodore. Any decline in attendance was more than made up in the out-spoken declarations made by leaders of the business at the joint gathering of the sales promotion and merchandise managers' divisions of the association.

An appeal for more generous support and endowment of women's colleges together with a statement setting forth the urgent needs of seven institutions, approximating $30.000,000, is contained in a report of the advisory council of the colleges made public yesterday.

BERLIN, June 26. -- Chancellor von Papen left for Lausanne this afternoon equipped with amplified authority to expand the scope of his conversations with Premier Harriot over Franco-German economic cooperation in a last effort to break the impasse now deadlocking the reparations conference.
CHICAGO, June 26. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the unterrified but frequently disgusted Democrat from Amity, Ind., was encountered by a reporter on his way to the planetarium.

Priest and Patriot. Probably the Rev. FRANCIS P. DUFFY was the best-known Catholic priest in NeW York. He was undoubtedly the most loved. His engaging personality, his breadth of sympathy, his public spirit, in addition to his exceptional services as war chaplain for the "Fighting Sixty-ninth," made him a familiar and winning figure in our community life.

THE old story was that the first man in with a good, score would win the open championship; it stood the test of time. But at Fresh Meadow a stocky, swarthy, confident player wrote a new version. Gene Sarazen came in late in the day and won under pressure. He knew what he had to do and he did it with something to spare.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- A number of cabana and terrace luncheons were given at the Maidstone Club after noontime swimming. Mr. and Mrs. Dickson Bayard Potter gave a luncheon for ten persons in honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. H. Adams Ashforth.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26. -- Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York officially shattered the American short tank record for 100 yards back stroke and unofficially clipped the world's standard for the event at an invitation A.A.U. water carnival conducted by her organization in the sixty-foot outdoor pool of the Stewart Manor Country Club today.

A list of fourteen principles the adoption of which would cut the city's budget, including increased subway and ferry fares and water rates, to make these services self-sustaining, and a pay cut for city employes, was made public yesterday by the Merchants' Association in a letter to the Citizens' Budget Commission.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Harvesting of Winter wheat in the Southwest has been interrupted by rains in Kansas, Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle. The early grains were followed by favorable weather and cutting was resumed. A large percentage of the crop is being harvested by the old-time binders and put in stacks.

A State-wide Summer work relief program, involving an expenditure of $6,546,784, of which $5,062,604 is to be for wages, has been launched by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, it was announced yesterday. The program will be carried out in cooperation with city and country work bureaus which receive a share of the State's unemployment relief fund.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Excavation of a palace 4,000 years old at Tepe Hissar, a few miles from Damghan in Northwestern Persia, was reported today by the University of Pennsylvania Museum, which with the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology has an expedition at work there.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., June 26. -- The eighteenth annual Summer conference of the League for Industrial Democracy came to a close today at Camp Tamiment, near here, with a general discussion of "Roads to Social Planning" as the culmination of a general conference on "A Socialist Plan for America."

The Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, war-time chaplain of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" Regiment, whom Cardinal Hayes once described as "the ideal army chaplain and the ideal parish priest," died at 5:30 A. M. yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He had been ill for three months, suffering from colitis and an infection of the liver.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorial entitled "International Cancer Research" voices your appreciation of the endowment for that purpose by William H. Donner. Mankind is already deeply indebted for other benefactions, however, which your editorial somewhat undervalues.

PARIS, June 24. -- The virtual completion of the recall of foreign balances by the Bank of France was indicated by the reduction in that account for the week covered in Thursday's bank statement by 1,411,000,000 francs. The gold reserve rose only 669,000,000, or less than half as much as the foreign credit fund was reduced.

DUBLIN, June 26 (AP). -- A solemn pontifical high mass before a million worshippers and a great religious procession climaxed and closed the thirty-first Eucharistic Congress, which ended here today. Archbishop Curley of Baltimore celebrated the pontifical high mass in Phoenix Park, just outside the city boundary

BELFAST, Nortnern Ireland, June 26 (AP). -- Catholic pilgrims on their way to and from the Eucharistic Congress at Dublin were stoned today in various parts of Northern Ireland in an outburst of anti-Cathoic attacks which caused many injuries.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Live stock raisers have had better markets of late. Cattle prices were up 25 to 40 cents last week, and within a month steers have advanced $1 to $1.50 a hundredweight. The top on choice fed steers at the close was $8.25, with most sales $6.35 to $7.65, while the average was $6.90, the highest since the week ended Jan. 9.

Every New Yorker should take the time to read the report of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee published in the newspapers this morning. Here, in the midst of the depression and the uncertainties of the time, the alarums of the politicians and the nostrums of the quacks, is the record of something accomplished in this community on the grand scale.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 26. -- The annual meeting and luncheon of the Berkshire Industrial Farm took place at Canaan, N.Y., yesterday. The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Diocese of New York, was the speaker. Guests included:

PARIS, June 26. -- Premier Herriot spent this morning discussing the question of a loan to Austria with the heads of the Senate and Chamber Finance and Foreign Affairs Commissions, but there is still no indication of a definite French stand.

President HOOVER urged the abolition of bombing planes, yet, according to one English editor, his proposals for a cut in armaments fell upon Geneva like a benevolent bombshell. In England his bold initiative meets a daily growing favor, though the Government continues to hold its opinion in reserve.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Folicies for the furtherance of world peace which she suggested to the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention and the informal resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention were discussed tonight by Jane Addams, noted social worker and founder of Hull House, in an interview here with William Hard, which was broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.

The United States Department of Commerce has offered to cooperate in a plan presented by a group of export associations providing for the elimination of foreign exchange restrictions. The plan was presented to President Hoover, Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson and Secretary of Commerce Robert P. Lament.

Predicting the nomination of Governor Roosevelt "in the very early balloting" at Chicago, Senator Harrison of Mississippi, in a radio address made over the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, voiced opposition to the plan of the Roosevelt forces to abrogate the two-thirds rule.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP). -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President of Mexico, today for the first time since Friday was allowed to see his wife. Senora Elonor Llorente Calles, critically ill since the removal of a tumor from her brain last Thursday.

Activity in the wholesale apparel trades here last week slackened considerably due to the cool weather and to the close of the current buying season. The dress market was at a standstill and manufacturers in some cases discontinued production temporarily, except for actual orders.

VATICAN CITY, June 26. -- Pope Pius this afternoon listened by wireless to the closing ceremony of the Dublin Eucharistic Congress and then broadcast a short message in Latin which was reverently listened to by the huge throng assembled in Phoenix Park, Dublin.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- The battle to defeat the move of the Roosevelt organization to abolish the two-thirds rule in the Democratic convention assumed new impetus tonight as the result of unexpected losses of the pro-Roosevelt forces in the New York and Pennsylvania delegations.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation:

The seven colleges for women, a statement of whose specific needs, signed by NEWTON D. BAKER, BERNARD BARUCH, JAMES BYRNE, THOMAS W. LAMONT, Bishop LAWRENCE and OWEN D. YOUNG, appears today, are asking not alone for themselves. They are championing the general cause of the higher education of women.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- Washington returned to third place today by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 8 to 4. They supplanted the Athletics in that position.

Trading in sugar continued to be the centre of attraction last week in the local commodity markets. Activity spread to virtually all positions, but profit-taking late in the week wiped out the earlier grains. Wool top futures and hides resisted the downward trend, while coffee, rubber, cocoa and silver were lower.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 26. -- Richard Murphy of Utica, defending champion, and two other strong contenders for the title, Herbert L. Bowman and Jerry Lang, both of New York, were among ten players to reach the fourth round of the fortieth annual New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship today on the courts of the Montclair A.C.
IRVINGTON, N.J., June 26. -- For the fourteenth time since she started her show career on this side of the Atlantic, champion Nancolleth Beryl of Giralda today was named best in show.

Yesterday was the first Sunday after the first Saturday after the official beginning of Summer in these parts and, as such, upheld the tradition of the season in an orthodox fashion. The life-guards at local beaches -- to which many journeyed -- put in a busy day.

Unless the nations of the world discontinue their adherence to a materialistic philosophy and a nationalistic religion, they were certain to find themselves standing on the brink of disaster, the Rev. Harold L. Gibbs said in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Rodgers gave a luncheon today at the Meadow Club Tea House, their residence. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Louis du Pont Irving, Mr. and Mrs. James N. Wallace and Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Gensler.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Firms doing foreign business have run into situations in which the present state of the law in New York does not give adequate protection. For instance, in one case a firm in India owed several thousand dollars. A partner of that firm came into this jurisdiction, was duly served, defaulted in appearance, and judgment by default was taken against him.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 26. -- The Italian salvage ship Artiglio brought her first cargo of the liner Egypt's gold, valued at u180,000 [$875,160], to Plymouth today, only to suffer a blow that at first seemed staggering, although it will soon be reduced to its true proportions.

Bobby Jones and Tommy Armour defeated Gene Sarazen, new national open champion, and his predecessor, Billy Burke, 3 and 2, in an exhibition match played yesterday at the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Flushing for the benefit of the unemployed of New York.

The burden carried by New York City real estate for city and school purposes is analyzed on a per capita basis by William H. Alien of the Institute for Public Service, who computes comparisons with the tax figures of other near-by cities from the tax rate and assessment tables for 300 cities issued by C.R. Rightor of the Detroit Bureau of Governmental Research.

GENEVA, June 26. -- While the British, French and Japanese arms delegations were consulting their capitals today on how to meet President Hoover's move, the United States delegation was considering what would be the best tactics for pushing it on, the work of consolidating the position gained having already begun yesterday with the aid of the small powers.

ROME, June 26 (AP). -- Pope Plus gave his benedicition to the Eucharistic Congress at Dublin today over his own radio station, after a brief address congratulating the congress for its display of religious faith. The Pope had intended to speak earlier at the start of the ceremony, but transmission became so faulty he delayed, and it was not until the close that technicians announced conditions were favorable.
CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP). -- The Indians and Browns split a doubleheader today, St. Louis dropping the first, 10 to 5, against Wes Ferrell and then taking the second game, 6 to 5.
BRUSSELS, June 26. -- Violent demonstrations against former soldiers took place today in Antwerp, where various veterans' associations are holding a conference. More than 100 persons were injured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to Borough President Harvey's criticism of the City College, If he had been present at the commencement last Wednesday evening at the Lewisohn Stadium he would have heard the 1,553 graduates in the presence of an audience of 17,000 take the Ephebic oath, which is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Club and college oarsmen from all parts of the country make up the list of 105 entries for the combined National People's Day and Olympic trials regatta to be held on the Schuylkill next Friday, Saturday and Monday.

What the current non-stop bill at the Palace chiefly needs is an outstanding act. While there are several turns in the continuous program that supply the requisite amount of entertainment, they are definitely secondary turns. Along with the rest of the world, the country's premier vaudeville house temporarily lacks leadership.

The prohibition plank of the Republican party is neither fish, flesh nor fowl, the Rev. Dr. John Logan Davis declared yesterday at the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 135 West Fourth Street. In his opinion, he said, "it is the work of scheming, planning, evading politicians, given to us with the express purpose of confusion.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Prospects of serious damage to the Spring wheat crop in the American and Canadian Northwest from grasshoppers and discovery of black rust in the Dakotas and Nebraska, particularly in the northwest, brought late last week a moderate return of confidence among holders of wheat contracts and a rally in prices.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Nearly a hundred school teachers of the country, from kindergarten to university, will send a petition to Congress tomorrow from the opening session of the American Federation of Teachers asking Federal aid to the educational system.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Adjournment of Congress this week now appears improbable in view of a complicated legislative situation which leaders have little hope of unraveling quickly.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Tammany and its allies, riding rough-shod over the Roosevelt forces on the New York State delegation, forced the passage, at the delegation's caucus tonight, of a resolution putting the delegation on record as favoring the retention of the two-thirds rule.

Great Britain's action in putting India on the gold standard in 1926 and demonetizing the silver which had always been Indians wealth was characterized yesterday by Colonel Francis L. Harden, until recently editor of The China Press in Shanghai, as one of the greatest blunders in history.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 26. -- Miss Evelyn T. Leonard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Leonard of Jericho, headed the committee in charge of the annual gymkakna this afternoon on the polo field on Old Acres, the estate of Mrs. Robert Bacon on the Jericho Turnpike.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Cowboys from the Texas plains, elderly statesmen from the South and heavy-jowled Tammany braves from New York swarmed into Chicago today in holiday mood for the Democratic National Convention which opens tomorrow.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., June 26. -- A family feud which had begun last Fall is reported to have flared up last night at the poultry farm of Joseph Vitolo in Swezeytown, near here, causing the death of James Morello, 27 years old, of 104 Jackson Street, Brooklyn, and the murder of Rose Marino, 22, of 145 East Forty-sixth Street, Manhattan.

Christianity must be interpreted as an attitude of heart and a mode of living if it is to rise above the charges of being a mere acceptance of dogmatic truths, the Rev. Dr. Minot C. Morgan said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

ATLANTA, June 26 (AP). -- After sixteen years, Dixie's hopes for a huge memorial of heroes of the Confederacy have been revived again. A new and bigger monument on the face of Stone Mountain, Georgia's massive monolith, sixteen miles from Atlanta, has been outlined by Gutzon Borglum here during a leave of absence from his Mount Rushmore memorial job in South Dakota.

Accused by passers-by of having fired a shotgun charge from the window of his furnished room on the top floor of 73 West Ninetieth Street at Columbus Avenue, Patrick Scott, 37 years old, was shot and seriously wounded last night by Patrolman John McConnell when he attempted to shoot the policeman to escape arrest.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 26. -- It is the general opinion here that the reparations conference will enter tomorrow upon its crucial week. Within the next six days its success or failure will be assured.

Clergymen of all faiths and military men who came in contact with Father Duffy, in war and peace, were saddened when they heard of his death yesterday. All paid high tribute to his widespread spiritual influence and to his humane qualities in dealing with the recreant and unfortunate.

aTo the Editor of The New York Times: I am much Interested in the well-considered explanation of the necessity for a change in the interstate commerce clause of the Constitution, to give the dry States adequate legal protection, contained in the letter of Noel T. Cowling, published in your paper today.

The body of Abraham J. Greenberg, 43 years old, of 1,953 East Third Street, Brooklyn, was recovered from the Gowanus Canal, at Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, after emergency crews had worked more than four hours in finding and raising Greenberg's sedan which had plunged through the bridge into about twenty feet of muddy water.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 26. -- The public school teachers of the United States should voluntarily remit a percentage of their salaries to the public treasury in cases where their communities are seriously embarrassed financially, declared Miss Florence Hale, president of the National Education Association, in an interview at the association's annual convention in session here today.

A preliminary report on its activities, made public yesterday by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Harvey D. Gibson is chairman, revealed that New York's citizens contributed to the committee a net total of $19.635,509.29, including money, food clothing and other aid.

No one can read the reports from Chicago without that "extreme solicitude" with which General GARFIELD said that he had observed the bitter debates and factional wrangles in the Republican National Convention of 1880. It is not a case of partisan sympathies one way or the other.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs split a double-header with the St. Louis Cardinals today and lost the National League leadership to Pittsburgh. A crowd of 31,000, setting a season's record at St. Louis, saw the games.

TORONTO, June 26. -- Lieut. Col. Clarence A. Denison, who retired in 1919 as chief accountant of the Standard Bank of Canada after forty-one years' service, died today at his home, Rusholme, in his eighty-third year.
HEW YORK. Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge will return from Paris next week and will be at the Madison before going to Bretton Woods, N.H., for the Summer.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Declaring that platform generalities about "economical administration" will not suffice, Bernard M. Baruch, in a statement Issued here tonight, called for reduction of $1,000,000,000 in governmental expenditures.
BANGKOK, Siam, June 26 (AP). -- A new Siam, with a Constitution and a political party, was born today of last week's revolution and King Prajadhipok remained as the Monarch.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 26. -- Accounting for seven goals in the first three periods, Roslyn held off the late attack of Sands Point in the weekly polo game at the Sands Point Club today to win, 16 to 11.

BANGKOK, June 26. -- King Prajadhipok returned here today as head of the new constitutional monarchy. He was accompanied by the Queen, Prince Svasti and Prince Purachatra, Minister of Communications, and drove to Sukodaya Palace. The two Princes were not seized as hostages by the leaders of the People's party, but Prince Paribatra, heir to the throne, and Prince Damrong are still held.

BARNEGAT CITY, N.J., June 26. -- Fire of undetermined origin destroyed the Sunset Hotel, an old landmark on a high bluff overlooking Barnegat Bay, here today, and endangered the functioning of Barnegat Light a short distance away. Flying embers, fanned by a twenty-five-mile wind, spread to the Jetties protecting the lighthouse and covered the light.

A special session of the Legislature to appropriate $25,000,000 more for unemployment relief and increase to $75,000,000 the $30,000,000 bond issue authorized for that purpose, is demanded in a memorandum sent to Governor Roosevelt by Socialist leaders and made public yesterday.

Legalization of 2.75 per cent beer as a source of governmental revenue, and a $5,000,000,000 Federal bond issue to finance public works and provide jobs for the unemployed were urged as a combined project yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a broadcast from the Columbia studio at the scene of the Democratic National Convention.

PITTSBURGH, June 26. -- Decreases in steel demand in the last few weeks have been confined almost entirely to bars, shapes, plates and sheets, while rail production has dropped to virtually nothing by the completion of deliveries against orders placed for the season and releases against old contracts.
BOSTON, June 26 (AP). -- The Braves and Phillies split a double-header today before 25,000 fans. The Braves won the first game, 5-4, but dropped the nightcap, 5-1, as Holley pitched effectively.

SALEM, N.H., June 26 (AP). -- Al Gordon of South Bend, Ind., was declared the winner of the Roekingham Speedway 50-mile sweepstakes automobile race today when A.A.A. officials called the race off at the end of the fifteenth mile because three cars had crashed through the rail.

In a normal period, the approach of this week's Democratic convention, with the existing tension of feeling in regard to candidate and platform, would have found some reflection in financial markets. Last week's absence of any such display of interest probably went to show that the present markets have other things to occupy their mind.

BERLIN, June 25. -- The Reichsbank's view, regarding the relative standing of Germany's foreign debt, is that if dwindling reserves of gold and foreign exchange were to compel curtailment of the debt service, then the Dawes and Young Plan loans would probably get priority.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26. -- The Bears and Orioles concluded their crucial series today by splitting a double-header before a crowd of more than 15,000. Newark won the first game, 3 to 1. while Baltimore scored seven runs in the seventh and final inning to win the second, 10 to 6.

More than 6,000 children attending Jewish religious schools in this city, 200 Boy Scouts and a detail of 150 Jewish World War veterans participated yesterday morning in George Washington bicentennial anniversary exercises in front of the Federal Hall reproduction in Bryant Park.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- A prediction that at the present rate of increase there would be 13,000,000 unemployed in this country next Winter was made in a statement issued today in behalf of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 26. -- Nearly 15,000 devotees of St. Therese, the "Little Flower of Jesus," attended this afternoon the two dedicatory services at the new shrine at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church here, Eastern headquarters of the Little Flower Society.

RUMSON, N.J., June 26. -- Champion Blue Dan of Happy Valley, the consistent performer owned by the Happy Valley Kennels of Roxborough, Pa., added another triumph to his list by being named best of breed at the specialty-show of the English Setter Association today.

Officials of the State of South Carolina are expected to reach agreements this week with New York bankers for the renewal of loans held here. Next Friday an issue of $5,000,000 of the State's revenue notes will mature, and on July 15 a like amount of highway notes.
RYE. N.Y., June 26. -- Two daughters of Gaorge V. Smith took out their father's Atlantic Class racing sloop Naiad this afternoon and gave no quarter to Kingsley Kunhardt and his champion Noiram.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 26. -- The tiny cabin in the town of Malden, near here, that was the West Virginia home of Booker T. Washington, Negro educator and emancipator, this afternoon became a national shrine as his people and members of the white race met to dedicate his homesite.

A more hopeful attitude on the part of business generally and positive indications of improvement in certain directions are emphasized in a summary by the Journal of the American Bankers Association and in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company.

Westchester and Putnam County trout fishermen no doubt will be pleased to hear that additional plantings of brown and rainbow trout have been made in the streams of the counties during the past week and will continue for the next few days.

Recommendations for drastic retrenchment for the city's public schools during the coming year, preposing to levy fees in evening high schools, fill vacancies in the teaching of certain subjects only with substitutes, eliminate certain examinations and curtail extension activities, are included in a report made to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, by a special committee of representatives of teachers' organizations from all over the city.

Presenting a patched-up line-up, with Freddy Lindstrom back at third base and Eddie Moore replacing the injured Jackson at short, Manager Bill Terry and his Giants fell before the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field, 5 to 2. A gathering of 28,000 saw the contest.

Criticism of the church by persons who are not participants in religious activity was characterized by the Rev. Dr. Frank Gavin of the General Theological Seminary as "careless generalization." in his sermon yesterday at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

LONDON, June 24. -- The reduction in the New York bank rate, which brings it to the same level as the Bank of England rate, came as a surprise to the London market. Owing to the recent weakness of dollar exchange and the heavy loss of gold by the United States, London had not looked for such action at the present time.

Because the world had become out of harmony with the good and lost in deception and avarice it was subjected to the purifying ordeal of an economic crisis, the Rev. John W. Wetzel said yesterday, preaching in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 26. -- County government, its functions and cost, and the possibilities of betterment through reorganization, consolidation or separation will be studied during the sixth Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 26 (AP). -- Sending his low-winged Gee Bee speedster over the five-mile course at an average speed of 199.53 miles an hour, Russell Boardman of Springfield, Mass., today won the fifty-mile free-for-all feature race of the Niagara Falls air race meet.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- A charge that big business interests" and the power trust" and the "big international bankers" were trying to block the nomination of Governor Roosevelt by the Democratic National Convention was made today by his supporters and his headquarters made public some of these statements.
DUBLIN, June 26. -- The largest congregation in the history of Christendom crowded the wide spaces of Phoenix Park today for the solemn Pontifical high mass ending Dublin's Eucharistic Congress.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 26. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club baseball team today registered its twelfth victory in sixteen games this season when it defeated the New York Stock Exchange nine, 10 to 3.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Melvin A. Traylor, Chicago banker and possible Democratic candidate, told the Illinois contingent tonight that "the question before us is whether we can save this country's conservative civilization."

An obscure village in Ohio, New Rumley, with a population of less than 200, was the scene last week of the unveiling of a memorial to its most famous son, General GEORGE A. CUSTER. A report of the ceremony was broadcast. His widow, Mrs. ELIZABETH CUSTER, is still residing in New York at the age of 90.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Prominence of Senator Huey P. Long of Louisiana among the leaders in the Roosevelt camp threatened today to add still another hurdle to obstruct the way of the New York Governor to victory in the Democratic convention.

The difficulties and dangers of the world temporarily vanished during the Eucharistic Congress in Dublin last week, Cardinal O'Connell of Boston said yesterday in a radio broadcast from Dublin, which was heard here over the National Broadcasting Company's network in the weekly Catholic hour.
OTTAWA, June 26 (Canadian Press). -- Sean T. O'Kelly, Vice President

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Jews today are facing the gravest crisis in their history as a result of an anti-Semitic movement in Europe, aimed at the destruction of the race and so malign and far-reaching as to threaten the peace of the world, according to Dr. Joseph Tanenbaum of New York, who spoke today before, the American Jewish Congress, calling upon Jews everywhere to fight for their lives and battle for their rights.
BERLIN, June 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

BERLIN, June 25. -- Financial sentiment on this market during the past week has been unfavorably affected by various international political developments and, as a consequence, movement of prices on the Boerse was steadily downward. Business circles were badly impressed by the street war between Hitlerites and Communists, and by the differences between the Reich and the South German States over questions of uniforms and demonstrations.
Besides the Summer theatres already operating, at least thirteen others will swing into action this week in New York State, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

High officials of nearly a score of national church bodies affiliated with the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America joined yesterday in a message to President Hoover expressing "hearty approval" of what they termed his "courageous proposal" for the reduction of armaments.

MADRID, June 26. -- Plans for one of the greatest engineering feats of all time -- the construction of a tunnel under the Straits of Gibraltar -- have been revived with the naming of a committee of eighteen leading scientists, politicians and diplomats, who will present a proposal to the League of Nations after preparing their report.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 26. -- Impressive ceremonies marked the breaking of ground for the American Legion Cathedral of the Air at the entrance to the naval air station here this afternoon. The actual construction of the building, which is being erected as a memorial to the aviators of the army and navy who died in service, will begin tomorrow.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- Flew all night by plane from California and arrived here this morning in air charged with true democracy and the good feeling of every candidate for his own delegates.

A "fearless" report on conditions in China and India, based on a nine-month investigation by the Commission of Appraisal of the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry, probably will be ready early in September, according to the Rev. Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University and a member of the commission, who preached the morning sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Total contributions of $481,258 to the Salvation Army's United Appeal were announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign. Mr. Blaine expressed confidence that the appeal quota of $600,000 for the Army's emergency relief and institutional aid activities in New York would be attained.

Consistent newspaper advertising has resulted in maintaining or increasing the earnings of many companies despite the depression, according to a survey made by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association, the result of which was made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- The subcommittee of nine controlled by the Roosevelt forces tonight agreed upon most of the essential planks for the Democratic platforms except prohibition, unemployment relief and farm relief. Public hearings will be held tomorrow to permit advocates of various farm and unemployment relief measures to be heard before the drafting committee completes the platform for submission to the resolutions committee tomorrow night.

Frederick Brown, real estate operator and philanthropist, who has just filed a petition in bankruptcy, explaining that he is free of personal debt and that he does not wish to be discharged from committments representing his voluntary contributions to religious, charitable and educational organizations, has been described as one of the most helpful factors toward the upbuilding of New York City.

Leon H. Hoag of 28 Sherman Avenue, East Orange, has been awarded first prize In the small library competition for unemployed architects and draftsmen conducted by the Architects' Emergency Committee, 115 East Fortieth Street, it was announced yesterdgy by Chester H. Aldrich, chairman of the jury of award.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 26. -- Preparations were completed here today for the trial tomorrow of John H. Curtis, Norfolk boatbuilder, who is charged with interfering with the orderly process of justice in the police hunt for the kidnapers and murderers of the Lindbergh baby.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 26. -- A case that had puzzled New England police for six months was closed today with the finding of the body of Floyd J. Stewart of Kansas City, Harvard Business School student, who disappeared Jan. 31.

AKRON, Ohio, June 26. -- With an impressive group representing scientific, army and navy circles assembled for the event, the Daniel Guggenheim Airship Institute, embracing the world's largest vertical wind tunnel for testing airship models, was dedicated here today.

LONDON, June 26. -- Although currency and monetary questions are confidently expected to have a place in the long-delayed agenda or the Imperial Economic Conference in Ottawa, they are receiving little advance consideration of a constructive character.

Comparing Lenin to Peter the Great and characterizing bolshevism as a specific Russian phenomenon which, despite the negative features of its philosophy, methods and morals, has played a constructive part in Russia in shaking the country from its old political and social lethargy, Waldemar Gurian presents an exhaustive study of the subject in his book, "Bolshevism -- Theory and Practice," published by the Macmillan Company.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Two women of prominence in national Democratic circles today joined the feminine contingent here for their party's national convention opening tomorrow. They were Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, widow of the war-time president, and Mrs. William H. Murray, wife of the Governor of Oklahoma.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June26 (AP). -- Buffalo increased its lead in the International League by taking both ends of a double-header from the Rochester Red Wings, 4 to 3 and 8 to 2, today. Ollie Carnegie's home run in the tenth inning broke up the first contest.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Campaign managers for Alfred E. Smith and what may be termed contenders of the second line for the Presidential nomination were at work all today in last-minute efforts to strengthen their positions against the apparent strong onrush of support for Governor Roosevelt.

Widely divergent views on plans proposed to replace the dual banking system of State and national charters with a unified system under Federal supervision are expressed in surveys conducted under auspices of the American Bankers' Association and the National Industrial Conference Board, which were issued yesterday.
VIIPURI, Finland, June 26. -- Paavo Nurmi made his debut as a marathon runner today and promptly smashed to bits all previous records for the classic grind.
ALBANY, June 26. -- On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, Governor Roosevelt was in a jovial mood and apparently confident that his managers in Chicago would "put him over" safely.
CHICAGO, June 26. -- Samuel Seabury, foe of Tammany, arrived in Chicago tonight amid an atmosphere of mystery to attend the Democratic National Convention.

ELBERON, N.J., Monday, June 27. -- The "Four Horsemen" of contract bridge turned what had been a closely contested duplicate match into a runaway at the third session of their four-day match with Harold S. Vanderhilt's Cavendish Club team and when play closed at the Deal Club here early this morning they were 6,260 points ahead.

NEW HAVEN, June 24. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 59.5, which compares with 59.3 a week ago, 59.6 two weeks ago 60.2 three weeks ago and 60.2 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; last week's average was the lowest.

LONDON. Ky., June 26 (AP). -- A detachment of Kentucky National Guard troops sent into the new Salem section of Laurel County this afternoon after a fight in which one man was slain was ordered withdrawn tonight by Adjt. Gen. H.H. Denhardt.

Robust doubles by Ben Chapman and Tony Lazzeri in the first inning at the Yankee Stadium yesterday drove home enough Yankee runs to defeat the Athletics and make a clean sweep of the two-game series between the league leaders and league champions.

William A. Brady, who, accompanied by his wife, Grace George, returned from Europe Friday on the Aquitania, has acquired the rights in London to Ivor Novello's "I Lived With You," now running there. Mr. Novello, who acted here two seasons ago in two plays of his authorship, "Symphony in Two Flats" and "The Truth Game," will return in December to appear in "I Lived With You."

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Brighter spots were apparent in most lines of trade last week, with increased distribution by wholesalers, retailers, and mail order houses, especially of drygoods, women's undergarments and silk hosiery. The large influx to the Democratic convention is looked upon by merchants as likely to result in a sharp pickup this week, with sales equaling those of a year ago and in some instances exceeding them.

NEW ORLEANS, June 26. -- The cotton market here was narrow last week, with little business from the outside reported by brokers. Trading was confined largely to professional scalping and straddle transactions between markets, and as a result prices fluctuated narrowly, the extreme spread between the high and low points being about 22 points, and the net gain about 10 points, or a half dollar a bale.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- With Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt seeming to be the probable Presidential nominee of the Democratic party, the leaders in his camp began today serious discussion of a candidate for Vice President, without, however, reaching any definite conclusion.
