CHICAGO, June 26. -- Refusing to "surrender to any underworld," Evangeline Booth, commander-in-chief of the Salvation Army in America, told a meeting of the Women's Prohibition Movement in Orchestra Hall tonight that the Salvationists would resist efforts to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment and would fight for its enforcement.

Rockefeller Centre, Inc., announced yesterday that it had awarded to Donald Deskey, noted modernist, the contract for the interior decoration of the International Music Hall and its thirty-one auxiliary rooms now being hurried to completion in the north block of Rockefeller Centre.

It would be an illusion to conclude that the various measures enacted by Congress for the relief of the financial situation are capable of furnishing a permanent solution of the American banking problem, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.

Accidents are becoming so rare in the transatlantic trade that ship surgeons have very little to occupy their time either with passengers or crew, according to E.C.F. Moore, senior purser of the Cunard fleet, who sailed Saturday on the Scythia.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Speculative interests have dropped out of the corn market, even cash handlers are doing comparatively little, and the farmers in the Corn Belt are showing no disposition to rush their holdings to market. Crop conditions in the main are favorable, growth being normal the only complaints coming from Northwestern Iowa and Central Illinois, where there has been too much rain, which is retarding cultivation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems that every time the subject to taxes is under discussion the first thought that comes to the minds of our lawmakers is everything connected with an automobile, such as gasoline, oil and tires. They assume that every one that driver, a car does so for pleasure.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The third running of the $5,000 added Arlington Inaugural Handicap, which featured the opening of the thirty-day meeting at Arlington Park today, resulted in an upset when Mrs. S.H. Fairbanks's Gold Step scored over Polydorus, Jamestown and other fast handicap performers.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- An important step toward solving the deadlock on the special economy bill was taken tonight, when the Senate, by a vote of 29 to 17, requested the House to return the bill which the Senate had rejected as a conference report.
NEW YORK. The French Ambassador and Mlle. Claudel are at the Sherry-Netherland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article by Professor William Z. Ripley in THE NEW YORK TIMES, estimating the individual stockholdings in American railroads to be nearly 1,000,000, is very interesting for more reasons than its evidence of a widespread ownership.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The Boerse was listless with a downward tendency today, but the average of losses was not large, the maximum not exceeding 2 per cent. An outstanding exception was Rheinische Brown Coal, which advanced 3 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Despite the more immediate problems confronting the Democratic National Convention today, delegates continued to cast about for a suitable candidate for the Vice Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Mrs. Ellis A. Yost of Huntington, W. Va., was reappointed today by Chairman Everett Sanders as director of the women's division of the Republican National Committee, a post she has held for two years. She will direct the work of Republican women in the Presidential campaign from national committee headquarters in Chicago.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27 -- Henry L. Wilson, 34 years old, of Germantown, Pa., a Professor of English at Temple University, Philadelphia, died in McKinley Hospital here tonight of injuries received in an automobile accident at Dean's Lane on the New Brunswick road between Princeton and New Brunswick.
Realty trading reported yesterday in the metropolitan area was light and scattered. Housing properties provided the bulk of the turnover.

Riis Park Rights The outcome of the prolonged controversy over Park concessions in Riis Park is satisfactory. Mr. FUCRS runs a good restaurant off Times Square; he ought to be able to run a good restaurant on the beach in the Rockaways.
The race committee of the Riverside Yacht Club announced yesterday that five additional auxiliary cruisers had been named for the Riverside-Stratford Shoal overnight sailing race on July 16.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 27 -- Four youngsters from Princeton, Southern California, Colgate and Michigan today tied for leadership in the first qualifying round of the national intercollegiate golf championship. They scored 72s.

Advocating the enactment of laws to keep production of crude oil reasonably hear to market demand, W. S. Farish, president of the Humble Oil and Refining Company, expresses the opinion in the current issue of The Lamp, that this would avoid rather than involve greater interference of government in business.

Dividend uncertainties were again uppermost in the Wall Street mind yesterday and there was a resultant extension of last week's declines in a long list of stocks. Business on the Stock Exchange ran to about 767,000 shares. About seventy issues reached new low territory for the bear market.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The United States does not intend to bargain for acceptance of President Hoover's disarmament proposal at Geneva in terms of consultative pacts or other political concessions, but solely in terms of ships, military equipment and personnel.

ALBANY, June 27 -- Governor Roosevelt acted suddenly today Then he called a dramatic halt to the fight to abrogate the two-thirds rule as the Democratic convention in Chicago formally began its sessions.

Governor ROOSEVELT has called off a fight in Chicago which should never have been, begun. To start it was almost the crowning mismanagement of his mismanaged campaign. Rightly or wrongly, his telegram of yesterday asking his supporters at the convention to stop trying to abolish the two-thirds rule will be everywhere taken as a retreat forced upon him.

Three seeded players advanced to the third round in the Staten Island junior tennis championship yesterday at the Clifton Tennis Club in Arrochar. Bernard Cohen. captain of the Port Richmond High School team, top-ranking player, eliminated George Steiniger, 6-0, 6-1, in the second round, after a bye in the opening session.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- While virtually admitting defeat in their effort to put through a rule abolishing the Jacksonian two-thirds rule, which has controlled the nominations for President and Vice President in Democratic conventions since 1832, the Roosevelt forces embarked on another campaign tonight to put the Democratic convention under a compromise majority rule and on that they are facing as hard a fight as was the losing one Governor Roosevelt halted this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ogden L. Mills, in his speech before the Republican convention, stated that the exponents of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment had no substitute to offer in its place. May I suggest a plan which, I believe, would not only eliminate the evils now existing under the Eighteenth Amendment but do what that piece of legislation tried to do and failed-prevent drunkenness and bring about real temperance?

SKYTOP, Pa., June 27 -- Miss Abigale Vare, sister-in-law of Mrs. Glenna Gollett Vare, and Miss Jane McCullough, both of the Huntington Valley Country Club, tied at 89 for the best score in the first round of the women's invitation golf tourney at the Skytop Country Club today.

The city got along nicely yesterday without an official Mayor, operating under an amiable duumvirate composed of Assistant Mayor Charles F. Kerrigan and Alderman Frank Cunningham, chairman of the Aldermanic finance committee.

The decision by which the Appellate Division reversed Supreme Court Justice Ford on the latter's ruling permitting affidavits attack- ing Samuel Seabury to remain in a Supreme Court record was filed with the County Clerk yesterday by the clerk of the higher court.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 27 -- Warden Lawes of Sing Sing prison startled teachers from all parts of the country gathered here for the annual convention of the National Education Association when he told them today that our "splendid and costly educational program" through a century "has done nothing -- and I say this advisedly -- nothing to mold the character of our people."

William R. Rose of the law firm of Proskauer, Rose Paskus left an estate valued at $2,709,006 net when he died on Nov. 19, 1930, according to the valuation in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. He left $100,000 to charities, but these legacies are deferred until the death of his sister, the life beneficiary of a trust fund of $100,000.

Eighty cadets, graduates of the Salvation Army's training school. West Tremont and Andrews Avenues, the Bronx, were commissioned as probationary lieutenants last night at exercises at the Salvation Army Auditorium, 120 West Fourteenth Street. Commissioner John McMillan, Eastern Territorial Commander, presented the commissions before an assemblage of 2,200 persons.

LONDON, June 27 -- The present reaction against parliamentarism and the necessary conditions under which democratic institutions are maintained under the complex conditions of a mechanistic civilization were discussed by Representative James M. Beck of Pennsylvania, former Solicitor General of the United States, at Kings College, Cambridge University, tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- The Athletics leveled their big guns on five Boston pitchers today and battered the Red Sox into submission in both games of a double-header, 15 to 8 and 9 to 4. The victories gave the Athletics third place in the league standing, displacing the Senators, who were idle.

LONDON, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- Ten thousand spectators at Lord's today saw England dismiss All-India for 189 runs in the first innings of the only test match of the season, giving England a first-innings margin of 70 runs.

The executive board of Theatrical Protective Union 1 has been authorized to negotiate a new wage-scale agreement with the theatrical managers to supersede the present two-year agreement which expires on Sept. 1. The authorization was given at a meeting of more than 700 members of the union on Sunday afternoon.

BERLIN, June 27 (AP) -- Return of the Hohenzollerns to the throne of Germany was called for today by the Nationalist party, in the midst of a three-cornered, continuing strife among the South German States, the von Papen Government and Adolf Hitler.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27 (AP) -- Miss Ames was a member of the staff of the Harvard College Observatory and noted for the surveys of external universes, in which she collaborated with Dr. Harlow Shapley.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- Testimony that Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church, represented by a dummy, was one of the three original stockholders in the Vertex Realty Company, headed by Harry G. Hendricks, marked the opening hearing here today of the investigation of Chancery Court receiverships before Charles L. Carrick as Special Master.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Repeal of prohibition would keep the sight in the American eye, Dr. Julius Neumiller, chief of the clinic of Pennsylvania State College of Optometry, said today at the annual congress of the American Optometric Association.

Kentucky has long been a fruitful mother of full-bodied orators and daring rhetoricians. Senator BARKLEY'S speech at the Chicago convention yesterday shows that in him the noble lineage is continued. Take an inspiring sentence from his exordium.

In The American Federationist is a list of thirty local unions in Philadelphia with statements showing what each has done for the relief of unemployed members. The measures described were studied and collected by the Department of Local Economy and Local Research of Bryn Mawr College, cooperating with the Central Labor Union.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- With the Roosevelt band wagon checked in what twenty-four hours ago seemed to be a triumphant progress by a revolt among its passengers, Newton D. Baker loomed tonight as the most probable dark horse to draw the Democratic chariot in what his supporters hope will be a march to victory in November.

A plan of reorganization has been completed for the Michigan Fuel and Light Company, an affiliate of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, and its subsidiaries, the Northern Indiana Fuel and Light Company and the Wisconsin Fuel and Light Company.
HAVANA, June 27 -- For the first time in Cuban history a woman, Senora Mariana de la Torre, went on trial today before a military court.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 27 -- Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam, the only woman who has flown alone across the Atlantic Ocean, was welcomed home today by the residents of two townships in which her husband's home is situated. After a celebration here, which included the unveiling of a memorial monument, the flier motored to Rye for another celebration.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 27 -- Keenan Morrow of Malba, L.I., a student at Choate School, led the field today in the opening qualifying round of the annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship, on the course of the Greenwich Country Club. Morrow scored a 78.

The fiftieth anniversary edition of the Wall Street Journal, comprising eighty pages, was printed yesterday by Dow, Jones Co., its publishers. Messages of congratulations from outstanding financial leaders, including J.P. Morgan, Andrew W. Mellon, Richard Whitney, Myron C. Taylor, Walter S. Gifford, Henry Ford, Gerard Swope and Charles M. Schwab, were sent to the Journal in connection with its anniversary.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- A survey to- night by THE NEW YORK TIMES on the probable convention vote on the compiomise Democratic two-thirds rule, providing for a change to a majority rule if the sixth ballot is reached without result, indicated the following:

ELBERON, N.J., Tuesday, June 28 -- The Deal Club contract bridge team headed by P. Hal Sims defeated the Cavendish Club team led by Harold S. Vanderbilt by 4,910 points when their four-day challenge match came to a close at the Deal Club here early this morning.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 27 -- James P. Mellon, Pittsburgh financier and brother of Ambassador Mellon, defended tonight the aims of prohibition, expressed the opinion that the present law should be ratified and declared "the United States as a whole could get along without liquor and would have, but for the foreign element which introduced bootlegging and racketeering on a wholesale scale."

The Banking and Industrial Committee, headed by Owen D. Young, which was formed last month to help make effective the credit expansion program of the Federal Reserve System, issued yesterday a statement endorsing the proposal for using trade acceptances as a substitute for open book accounts.

The church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, which has been involved in recent years in many internal and diocesan disputes, is now having another controversy. It concerns the so-called Body and Soul Medical and Mental Clinic, through which more than 400,000 persons have been treated for various ills during the last ten years.

A jury in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions, after taking only one ballot, returned a verdict of guilty in less than twenty minutes yesterday against Cornelius McNerney, agent for the Lord's Day Alliance, at his trial for attempting to extort $100 from an officer of the Theatre Owners' Chamber of Commerce to suppress Sabbath law complaints against theatres.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The prayer delivered by Commander Evangeline Booth at the opening session of the Democratic National Convention today was as follows:

Evidence that the depression had hit some of New York's speakeasies came to light yesterday when 116 petty offenders in prohibition cases elected to go to jail for two days each instead of paying the customary $25 fine, which is usually imposed on small violators of the dry law who plead guilty.
Weakness in securities and grains operated against active buying on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but prices improved slightly and ended with gains of 3 to 6 points.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Newspapers are industrial enterprises, and therefore are exempt from the 3 per cent tax on electric energy, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.
CLEVELAND, June 27 -- Mrs. Liberty Emery Holden, widow of the late founder and editor of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, died Saturday at Pasadena, Cal., relatives and friends were notified today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Wormser, in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, asserts that "genuine law reform cannot be brought about by lawyers and judges but must come from the layman," and that in England "law reform was brought about by laymen."

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CHICAGO, June 27 -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-fashioned Hoosier Democrat, was detected in the act of slipping out of the convention hall before Senator Barkley's remarks were concluded.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 27 -- The holders of the treasure that the salvage ship Artiglio has recovered from the liner Egypt's bullion rooms off the coast of France having given an undertaking to appear in court, the Admiralty Marshal today allowed twenty-one boxes of the gold, constituting the Artiglio's first cargo, to be brought ashore.
BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., June 27 (AP) -- Charles Chaplin says a shortage of money and not of supply and demand is the prime cause of the world's economic situation.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The text of the keynote spech delivered today by Senator Alben W. Barkley at the Democratic Rational Convention follows:

Among the properties sold in foreclosure proceedings at auction yesterday was a portion of the large vacant plot on the southwest corner of Union Square and Sixteenth Street which was assembled by Henry Mandel about six years ago with the intention of erecting a forty-one story commercial building.

Orders were issued at Governors Island yesterday giving the names of New York State residents who are to report for Citizens Military Training Camp duty at Camp Dix, N.J., on July 1. Among them are the following residents of New York City:

MINEOLA, L.I., June 27 -- A sealed verdict was returned by a jury here today to Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink as the result of damage suits involving five litigants in connection with an airplane crash about 800 feet above Mitchel Field on Oct. 2, 1928.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Roosevelt forces at the Democratic National Convetion were busy tonight repairing them shattered battle lines, which had been badly broken by their fight against the two-third's rule.

Joseph Indelicato, 23 years old, an undertaker of 123 Elizabeth Street, about to be called for trial in General Sessions yesterday for participation in the $290,000 jewelry hold-up last January in the home of Harry C. Glemby, hair net manufacturer, at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street, pleaded guilty before Judge Corrigan to second-degree robbery and was remanded to the Tombs for sentence Thursday.

The Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare has opened its doors for the registration of new applicants after having been closed since April 6, it was reported yesterday after the removal of the headquarters from 10 East Thirty-fourth Street to the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.
The Kerr Steamship Company, Inc., announced yesterday a new freight service from California and Gulf ports to South Africa and India, to be operated jointly with the Pacific-Java-Bengal Line.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 27 -- Congress convened in special session today and heard a ninety-two page message from President Olaya in which he asked it to express its will as to the continuance of emergency powers granted to the President to deal with the depression, which expire on July 31.

President Hoover paid tribute yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" Regiment and pastor of Holy Cross Church, 331 West Forty-second Street, who died early Sunday morning in St. Vincent's Hospital.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler listened yesterday to attorneys and experts in the laws of Czarist Russia who expounded to him the meanings of the short Russian word "isk." Upon his determination of its meaning and his interpretation of the old Russian law involyed will depend the decision in a suit by a Russian policyholder against the Equitable Life Assurance Society, a test case involving, with other similar cases, about $7,000,000 in claims.

A defense of the Republican prohibition plank by a speaker yesterday at the last of the season's meetings of the School of Politics of the Women's National Republican Club ended in a mild burst of laughter from the audience, in which the speaker joined, when persistent questioning from the floor had forced him to admit that according to the plank the wetness of State's desiring to be wet would depend on Congress.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 27 -- When an angler on pleasure bent catches a shark instead of a bass, that's one thing, but when a fisherman out to make a living catches a shark that fractures his leg and that he didn't want anyhow, that's another thing.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Bamford won the Distinguished Service Medal for his command of American troops from June to October, 1918.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 27 (AP) -- Allegations that an obligation involving the payment of $2,550,000 was unlawfully placed upon the Balaban Katz Corporation, which operates theatres in Chicago, are made in an accounting suit filed in Chancery Court today by Max Kirchheimer of Chicago, owner of fifty shares of preferred stock of the concern.

Hearings were opened here yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission to receive evidence concerning the warehousing and storage of freight by the eighteen trunk lines and connecting railroads which serve the port of New York.

Although many educators have held that adults acquire knowledge less easily than children or adolescents, William R. Barnes, dean of educational-booksellers and publishers in the United States, disputes this statement, insisting on the basis of his fifty years in the educational-book field, that the contrary is true.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- An extraordinary general meeting of officials of the Anglo-South American Bank today unanimously approved a scheme for an increase in capital to L11,000,000 (currently about $40,150,000). This was a sequel to an arrangement announced on May 19 whereby the Bank of England and associates would take over certain assets of the Anglo-South, American Bank amounting to more than L7,000,000, presumably nitrate securities, which at present cannot be liquidated.

The Luke McLuke gelding, Mr. Sponge, which has scored some notable victories for his breeder and owner, Joseph E. Widener, added the featured Primer Handicap to his list at Aqueduct yesterday, winning in a decisive manner. The test was at six furlongs with Mr. Sponge winning from Ella De T. Simpson's Commuter by a length and a half.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Jane Addams and her "Peace Paraders," seeking a "definite statement on international policy" from the Democratic National Convention, rode through the city streets today from the Congress Hotel to the Stadium, to register personally their demands at the convention.

Adolph Lewisohn, founder and honorary chairman of the Stadium Concerts Committee, will give his annual dinner before the first concert of the stadium season at Claremont tonight. About a hundred persons will be his guests and will attend the concert with him afterwards.

Aside from uniform strength in United States Government bonds and moderate gains by a fair-sized section of the foreign loan group, the bond market on the Stock Exchange drifted generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. United States Government issues finished unchanged to 10-32 point higher, while the foreign list was led by a 10-point recovery in Czechoslovak 8s, due in 1952.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 27 -- Following is a transcript of the testimony today of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh at the trial of John Hughes Curtis:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27 -- Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close granted three applications today for certiorari reviews of Scarsdale assessments asking reductions in assessed valuation totaling $725,481.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 27 -- Muttering thunder and fitful lightning flashes provided a gloomy background in the ancient county court house here this afternoon during the half hour that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh testified as the first witness for the State in the trial of John Hughes Curtis, Norfolk shipbuilder.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 27 -- It should be well understood in the United States that the tale of a proposed Franco-German military agreement is entirely without solid substance, no matter how far the echoes of it may penetrate.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Charles G. Dawes, who on Sunday night was elected chairman and a member of the board of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company, late this afternoon gave out the following statement over his signature.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 27 -- James H. Ottley Jr., owner of the yacht Adriana, and his brother, Gilbert, returned to their homes near here today after a thrilling escape from their burning schooner at sea about eighty miles south by east of Montauk during a race to Bermuda.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The anti-Roosevelt forces tonight are preparing to take the aggressive in the convention when it meets at noon tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Democratic National Convention came to what was foolishly called order today, and it was apparent that there still is a difference among the followers of Thomas Jefferson and their Republican brethren.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27 -- How nickels and dimes gathered in the business of blacking boots built up a fortune of $175,000 for a man who had come to this country as a penniless Italian immigrant was disclosed here today when Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close appointed a committee of relatives to look after the property of Pietro A. Ierardi.
LONDON, June 27 -- Lord Kilbracken died at Malvern today at the age of 85. He was once private secretary to the Jate William E. Gladstone, who described him as the best secretary he ever had.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- A plank committing Democrats in Congress to take steps for repeal was urged by Chairman John J. Raskob in opening the Democratic convention. In making his plea, the chairman said that the plank should pledge Federal assistance to dry States in repelling "liquor invasions" and that new laws to "restore tolerance and temperance" should also guard against the "evils of the old-time saloon."
PARIS, June 27 -- Inactive during the early part of the session today, the Bourse became more animated in the latter part and the majority of the list improved.

FAIRMONT, W.Va., June 27 -- Tension increased all over the Northern West Virginia strike zone tonight as a result of the killing of one striker and the serious wounding of seven others when three guards of the Kelley's Creek Colliery Company stationed at the Maidsville mine, near Morgantown, fired into a group of union sympathizers at noon.

Buying for July Promotions. Orders for promotional merchandise for selling after July 4 were received in fair volume in the market here yesterday. Many stores are relying on new merchandise to provide stimulus in what threatens to be the most difficult month of the year.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, jumped into, the political arena tonight with an address to 600 members of guests of the Young Democratic Club of America in which he outlined a 500-word platform for the party.
CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 28 -- The fight over the seating of two Roosevelt delegations will be carried to the floor of the Democratic National Convention today.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- As certified to Temporary Chairman Barkley today by the various State delegations, the committees of the convention are as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Notice that he will press for a vote on his Philippine independence bill before the present session ends was given by Senator Hawes on the floor today. He said that a majority of the Senate favors the measure.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Attention at the Democratic convention today turned on the women who are married to the men who want to be President and those who are campaigning for the candidates. The campaigners received the largest share.

The Olympic team of the Republic of Haiti, which will compete in the games at Los Angeles, arrived in New York yesterday on the Dutch Line steamship Stuyvesant, and will hasten on to California in the next day or two.

The New York Central Railroad reported for May the first monthly operating loss in many years. Gross decreased $8,771.000 compared with May, 1931 and the operating deficit of $226,000 reported for the month contrasted with income of $2,852,461 in May, 1931.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 27 -- Charles H. Mayo Sr., professional at the Lido Country Club at Long Beach, was a dual winner today in a one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association at the Cold Stream Country Club.

Possibly even Wall Street was more interested yesterday in the extraordinary developments at the Democratic convention than in its own affairs; but the day's stock market moved in accordance with the general financial picture, which was not cheerful. The highly unfavorable series of railway reports for May brought no surprise; they had been abundantly foreshadowed by the decrease of a fraction more than 29 per cent in the month's car loadings, reported several weeks ago.

A mid-Victorian burglar with a Raffles complex, who has terrorized the proprietors of small shops and games of chance at Coney Island for the last month, was captured without a struggle yesterday by two patrolmen who found him following his profession in the Palace of Penny-Heart on the boardwalk near West Twelfth Street.

LONDON, June 27 -- The stock markets were quiet and irregular today, dealers awaiting further news from Lausanne before making fresh commitments. British Government funds were supported, but prices did not respond to any great extent. Shipping stocks were firm, with support for Cunard.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- No convention today. The Democrats met, talked, agreed and adjourned. So the day was a total loss. The convention officially opens tomorrow.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Helen Jacobs reached the semi-finals of the women's singles in the British tennis championships today. They were joined by the young English girl, Miss Mary Heeley, and the French woman, Mme. Rene Mathieu.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The American Jewish Congress, at its closing meeting here today, approved the measures taken to convene a world Jewish conference at Geneva on Aug. 14, and elected thirty-five delegates to attend, all but three of whom are from New York City.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Abandonment of two long-standing rules of Democratic conventions was voted by the rules committee tonight. For the traditional two-thirds rule, the subject of bitter controversy, the committee adopted a compromise regulaion which would provide for nomination by a simple majority if the first six ballots failed to choose the nominee.

A "tear-gas billy" bought by Seymour H. Knox, banker and polo player of Buffalo, at the titme that the manhunt in the Lindbergh baby kidnapping was at its height caused the arrest of the banker's chauffeur yesterday. Since he did not have a permit for the weapon he is charged with a misdemeanor under Section 1897 of the penal law.

A plea to the textile industry for more appreciation of the consumers' desire for native styles was made last night by Meycr Bloomfield. industrial consultant, speaking at the graduation exercises of the Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Detroit's Tigers combined eight hits, five of them, for extra bases, with five Chicago errors today to take the final game of the series, 9-to-3.

LAUSANNE, June 27 -- Both Premier Herriot of France and Chancellor von Papen of Germany came back from their week-end consultations in their respective capitals todays in a stiffer frame of mind, with the result that the Lausanne Reparations Conference has reached its first real deadlock.

HAVANA, June 25 -- Despite the fact that the Cuban budget is expected to show a deficit of approximately $10,000,000 at the end of the current fiscal year, June 30, all payments due on Cuba's foreign obligations on that date will be met. The law just passed by the Cuban Congress gives President Machado authority to contract a temporary loan of $2,278,215 with American bankers.

A fourth consignment of Washington Square art is about to achieve aftermath uptown. On July 5 work by about sixteen artists will be displayed in Wesley Hall of the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Forty-eighth Street, which, according to the minister, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner, is located just "ninety-nine steps west of Broadway."

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Tammany will cast its vote 67 to 27 for the election of Jouett Shouse to the post of permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention in opposition to Senator Walsh of Montana, the Roosevelt selection.

Although Queen Victoria was hotly enlisted on the side of Spain during the Spanish-American War, she was unable to influence the course of British foreign policy because of the strength of her own ministers, the final volume of "The Letters of Queen Victoria," published here today by Longmans, Green indicate.

BUCHAREST, June 27 -- Five days of rain which has swollen every stream and flooded streets in every low-lying city and village, has taken a heavy toll of life and property in the northern part of Moldavia, Bukovina and Bessarabia. The rain is continuing and the water is rising every hour, and a catastrophe is feared.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Communism was again routed from the bonus army today.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Pulled out of one hole by a message from Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt today, directing abandonment of the effort to change the ancient two-thirds rule to a simple majority requirement for the Presidential nominations, it appeared possible that his managers might have fallen into another pit tonight.

A high order of broadcasting, comparable at times to the general clarity of programs offered daily from scientifically constructed studios of the major radio organizations of the country, was effected yesterday by engineers in charge of putting the Democratic convention on the air from the Chicago Stadium.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27 -- The Driggs family, long associated with Long Island golf, added more laurels to its record today when Eddie Driggs Jr. from Cherry Valley teamed with his 13-year-old son, E. H. Driggs 3d. and led the field in the seventeenth annual Father and Son Golf Association championship tournament with a gross score of 80 and a net of 69 at the Garden City Golf Club.

Dr. Herbert Spencer Dickey's "dude" exploring expedition, which retraced the trail of the Spanish conquistadores through 4,500 miles of South American jungle, returned to New York yesterday aboard the freighter Haiti of the Ocean Dominion Line.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 27 -- A strong field of fifty-three players, leaded by Baroness Giacomo Levi and recruited from New York, New Jersey, Westchester and Long Island, started out in quest of the women's metropolitan clay-court tennis championship today at the Lido Country Club.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here reversed today its action of Saturday, advancing early and breaking later, all deliveries selling within fractions of the lowest figures of the season and closing with net losses of 5/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

WITH his panama tilted back on his head, a sandwich in one hand and a glass of milk in the other, Al Simmons was standing at the Stevens lunch counter at the Yankee Stadium. Between bites and swallows, he was sounding off on baseball topics.
On his first deep-sea trip of the season on his boat Alibi, Charles L. Lehmann of New York needed to offer no excuse when he came back to Montauk, L.I., Sunday evening.

Despite the offer of the contestants to wrestle in the rain yesterday, the start of the forty-fourth annual national A.A.U. championship mat tournament, also a semi-final Olympic tryout, was postponed. An extra session was ordered for this afternoon in addition to the regular schedule for tonight.

NICE, France, June 27 -- Fear is entertained here that Borrah Minevitch, a Russian-American musician known to Broadway as the creator of a mouth-organ symphony orchestra, has been lost at sea with his wife, Betty. They chartered a two-masted schooner, the Lydia Ellen, and sailed with a crew of four men for Calvi, Corsica, intending to proceed thence to Tunis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that when the Treasury estimates of the revenue from corporation and individual income taxes were placed before Congress at the beginning of the session, they were based on an improvement of 15 per cent in business over the calendar year 1931.

The Merchants' Association is more outspoken than some of its contemporaries in the "Fifth Estate." It gets right up in open meeting and proposes an increased subway fare. "All city services which are financed "by bonds on the assumption that "they are self-sustaining should be "made actually self-sustaining where "possible," says the association's letter to the newly formed Citizens' Budget Commission.

A torrential thunderstorm swept over the city last evening after a day of intense heat and high humidity which caused one death and much suffering. The storm, however, brought death to an army corporal and probably mortal injuries to a reserve lieutenant when their plane, lost in the bad visibility, crashed on the beach at Port Washington, L.I.
ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- The veteran Burleigh Grimes gave way before the youngster Paul Derringer as the St. Louis Cardinals won today's game, 4 to 1, to take three out of the four-game series.

Thomas F. Curran, 41 years old, bank director and former controller for the Worcester Salt Company, 71 Hurray Street, who defrauded five tanks and three brokerage firms of $493,000 through forging stock certificates of his corporation, which he used as security for brokerage accounts, was sentenced by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday to three and one-half to ten years in Sing Sing.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Under the impetus of the convention demonstration in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, ultra-wets among the members of the resolutions committee conferred and tonight agreed to submit a prohibition plank committing the party not only to repeal but binding its members of Congress to support submission of the amendment.

The Fokker Aircraft Corporation was sufficiently interested in the transatlantic flight of Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith in June, 1930, to back the adventure to the extent of $5,000 but the company was not so enthusiastic when it came to buying $1,229.40 worth of razors, combs, toothbrushes and clothes for Kingsford-Smith and his three flight companions after they reached New York, it was disclosed yesterday in the City Court.

Virtually the same conditions prevailed in the money market at the opening of the new week as those which governed business last night. Demand for accommodation in every section was light with a resultant small turnover and quotations unchanged for call, time and business money.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- The New York Giants put on a home-run act for the edification of some 1,500 fans today when, they trimmed the Newark Bears of the International League in an exhibition game, 8 to 1.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- A petition for Federal aid was addressed to the Senate and the House by 100 delegates to the sixteenth convention of the American Federation of Teachers today.

Dr. Adolf Scheurer, member of the New York board of directors of the Hamburg-American Line, was advised in a cablegram from Germany yesterday that he had been appointed director of passenger traffic of the line in the United States and Canada, to succeed Emil Lederer, who will leave the line on Friday to take his new office as arbiter of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference.

Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the National Collegiate A.A. committee on swimming records, yesterday issued the list of intercollegiate and interscholastic standards approved during the past year. It is an unusually short list, disclosing the shattering of only five varsity and four high school marks for the regulatioir championship events.

President HOOVER credits the Senate with adopting "the major provisions" for which he has been contending, in the matter of Federal relief, but raises two objections to the Wagner bill, passed last week and now in conference. Its proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for public works seems to him to smack of the "pork barrel" no less than the $1,190,000,000 Garner plan adopted by the House.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 27 -- Criticism of overlapping functions in the New Jersey State Government as a hindrance to economy and charges of political extravagance in the spending of public money, was contained in an address here tonight by Herman B. Walker, secretary of the North Jersey Metropolitan Regional League, at St. Paul's Lutheran Church.

One of the issues on which candidates for the Democratic nomination disagree is the question of war debts. Governor SMITH has advocated a plan to scale them down in return for the purchase of American goods. But Governor ROOSEVELT apparently believes that it is both possible and desirable to exact full payment.

VAN HORNESVILLE, N.Y., June 27 -- Owen D. Young declared today at the commencement exercises of the centralized Rural School of Van Hornesville, which he founded, that the spirit of children in the schools was a heartening factor amid the gloom of a depression.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (AP) -- Play continued in the women's doubles today, with Miss Jacobs pairing with Miss Elizabeth Ryan to win from Mrs. J. Lycett and Mrs. G. Peacock of England, 6-2, 7-5.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- House and Senate Democrats held in Washington by official duties "listened in" to the radio broadcast of Senator Barkley's keynote' speech at the Democratic convention in Chicago today and accorded it almost universal approval.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Further government assistance to the New York Central Railroad, amounting to $13,600,000, in a second loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ROSEDALE, Miss., June 27 (AP) -- John Hunter, one of four brothers who achieved fame at Chicago two years ago by setting a world's airplane endurance record, was killed here today by the propeller of his ship.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- For twelve minutes of stir and action the Democratic National Convention at its opening session today gave vent to new enthusiasms aroused by a reference in the keynote speech to repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

BROOKFIELD CENTRE, Conn., June 27 -- Efforts were being made here today to suppress any further performances of Virgil Geddes's comedy, "In the Tradition," which was presented by the Brookfield Players for the first time on Friday evening at the Haybarn Theatre in New Milford, Conn.

Disbursements of dividends and interest on July 1 will aggregate about $1,000,000,000 this year, but will probably be the smallest in at least five years. Dividends on shares of domestic corporations will be the smallest in many years, aggregating possibly $250,000,000.

King PRAJADHIPOK went out of office, so to speak, on Friday, and came back on Sunday as a constitutional monarch in the making. Nobody has any objection to him, but the royal family, the multitudinous broods of princelings, wants and costs too much and is always asking for more.

In the hope of increasing gate receipts at football games next Autumn, the Eastern Intercollegiate Association decided yesterday to prohibit radio broadcasting of any game played on the home grounds or under the jurisdiction of any of the members of the association.

CINCINNATI, June 28. -- Declaring that high financing costs and an unfair proportion of the tax burden have made home ownership difficult for the person of small means, the board of directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards today sent an appeal for aid to the resolutions committee of the Democratic convention in Chicago.
PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics made a clean sweep of the three-game series with the Boston Red Sox today by putting on a two-run rally in the eighth inning to win, 5 to 4.

Splitting a double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday kept the Giants and dodgers extremely busy for nearly five hours, but none of the 28,000 spectators walked out on the absorbing show. Terry's men took the opener, 7 to 3, and Carey's men retaliated in the nightcap, 5 to 3.

HORICON, N.Y., June 28. -- Philetus Smith, proprietor of the Pueblo Hotel at Brant Lake and senior member of the firm of Philetus Smith Son of this place, died this morning at his home here after an illness of two months. He was 68 years old.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange received yesterday a letter from the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation explaining that the reduction in collateral securing the company's 6 pet cent gold bonds due in 1968, which was announced by the exchange, had been accompanied by an even greater decline in the amount of bonds outstanding, so that there had been an actual increase in the collateral securing the issue.

LOS ANGELES, Tune 28. -- William Z. Foster, Presidential candidate of the Communist party, was arrested here today when he attempted to address assembled followers in the plaza shortly after noon. His arrest precipitated skirmishes between Foster's sympathizers and a hundred police officers detailed to prevent a Communist demonstration.

LONDON, June 28. -- George Lansbury, leader of the Opposition in Parliament, declared tonight in the House of Commons that President Hoover had made a magnificent proposal for disarmament and he demanded to know what the policy of the British Government was going to be in response to Washington.

BERLIN, June 28. -- Today's thirteenth anniversary of the signing of the Versailles Treaty, yearly a day of mourning and protest for Germany, was more tense than other anniversaries because of the conferences at Lausanne and Geneva. How the whole nation feels was indicated by the fact that newspaper editorials, ranging from the extreme Nationalist Right to the extreme Red Left, all sound the same note:

Geography, bargain, the insubordination of delegates upon whom the head of the ticket has been forced -- so many contingencies, sudden enthusiasms are mixed up with the nomination of a candidate for Vice President that almost every four years there is a fat waiting list of aspirants.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- Ah! They was Democrats today, and we was all proud of 'em. They fought, they fit, they split, and adjourned in a dandy wave of dissension.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 28. -- Declaring the property taxpayer was bearing an unfair proportion of the costs of government, Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the School of Education of Columbia University, told a luncheon meeting of the chamber of commerce and joint service clubs today of plans whereby New Jersey communities might be able to save from 30 to 40 per cent of their school costs without injuring the educational system.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June. 28. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, during his cross-examination by defense counsel on the second day of the trial of John H. Curtis, self-styled intermediary in the hunt for the Lindbergh baby, declared this afternoon that he did not believe "at this time" that Curtis was ever in touch with the kidnappers or in touch with persons who had possession of the baby.

In its forty-four years of service the Babies' Hospital of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre has given hospital care to more than 50,000 children and has had 480,000 visits to its out-patient department, according to its annual report, made public yesterday through the United Hospital Fund.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- Liqueur, 2-year-old son of Supremus and ridden by Jockey T.P. Martin, won the top race today by a half length from Old Hillside at Arlington Park. Llandaff finished third in the five and one-half furlong sprint.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Following the somewhat belated leadership of their candidate on this issue, the Roosevelt supporters made a half face-about in their attack on the two-thirds rule late last night, beat a hurried retreat this morning and finally retired from an untenable position by an agreement for a report of the rules committee with the two-thirds rule unchanged and nothing much damaged but their prestige.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 28. -- Five players entered the quarter-final round of the New Jersey State championship tennis tournament at the Montclair Athletic Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The new Senatorial Campaign Funds Committee, successor to the Nye committee, met today and laid plans for any inquiries it may have to make in connection with expenditures for Senatorial campaigns in thirty-four Stales in the Fall.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 28. -- The Army Air Corps Reserve units stationed here engaged in sham war today during the annual inspection of tactics by the Second Corps Area Commander, Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan. The "war" lasted ten minutes, during which an enemy force advancing on New York from Riverhead and Freeport was repulsed, enemy aircraft were destroyed and Mitchel Field abandoned.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 28. -- The thirty-four-foot yawl-rigged sloop Key Walthim, which has been missing from Amityville since Saturday night and for which a general Coast Guard alarm was sent out this morning, returned safely to port in Montauk today with the six men and women, who made up a yachting party aboard.

In an effort to extricate themselves from the "financial strait-jacket," forced on them by the custom of collecting taxes annually or semiannually, a movement is now under way in municipal official circles throughout the country to work out plans for monthly or quarterly payments of taxes.

Important dividend meetings kept the share market agitated yesterday, but the net result, measured by final quotations, was a standoff. It was a trying day for Wall Street nerves. So far as dividends were concerned, industrials fared better than the railway issues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of June 12 printed a statement by Colonel Lloyd C. Griscom concerning what you call "the historic meeting at London in 1918 at which Secretary of War Newton D. Baker rejected the Allies' demands, presented by David Lloyd George, British Prime Minister, for the removal of General Pershing as Commander-in-Chief of the American expeditionary force."

Joseph J. Cohen, the juror who caused a mistrial in the first perjury trial of Isidor J. Kresel, the lawyer, on May 31, because he visited the defendant at his Summer home at Mamaroneck, N.Y., for aid in obtaining a bank loan, was discharged from custody in the Tombs Court yesterday.

The Board of Taxicab Control took under consideration yesterday, after a public hearing at City Hall, the advisability of compulsory "lay-ups" of from 33 to 50 per cent of the city's taxicabs during the Summer. Strenuous opposition to the proposal was voiced by representatives of independent owner-operators, while operators of large fleets appeared to welcome the suggestion.

MONTREAL, Que., June 28. -- That the Beatty committee for stabilization of the Canadian newsprint industry, also known as the bankers' committee, is continuing its work with consolidation of various companies as its objective and is receiving cooperation from those interested, was announced tonight by E. W. Beatty, president of the Canadian Pacific Railways, who is chairman of the committee.

DUBLIN, June 28 (Canadian Press). -- A referendum in which the people of the Irish Free State would indicate whether they wished to form part of the British Commonwealth of Nations is asked in a motion tabled in the Dail Eireann today by Frank MacDermot, Republican, and seconded by Sean maCein.

Flanked by a group of children wearing wooden shoes and French peasant costumes, Lieut. Col. H.E. Lavigueur, Mayor of Quebec, and Mrs. Lavigueur were formally received at City Hall yesterday by Assistant Mayor Charles F. Kerrigan, acting for Mayor Walker.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, June 28. -- The absence of American oarsmen for the first time in some years from the Henley regatta, starting tomorrow, is generally regretted. Crews which might have come over are entered for the California Olympic regatta, making participation in the Henley as well out of the question.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- The developments of the second day of the Democratic National Convention, in the course of which Roosevelt's forces won three victories, were as follows:

CHICAGO, June 28. -- As Chairman Walsh's gavel fell at the adjournment of the second day's session of the Democratic National Convention it became evident that the Presidential candidacy of Alfred E. Smith, a small candidacy with less than 150 votes, stands between some State's favorite son and a possible nomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28. -- Governor Rolph has stepped between Frank Melville, alias William Collins, who escaped from San Quentin prison in 1913, and any official action to bring him back from New York to complete his term here.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 28. -- The Garden Club of East Hampton opened its annual flower show today at Guild Hall. The brick terrace and entrance hall were decorated as a Spanish market. Painted Andalusian carts for potted plants stood outside, and indoors Spanish shawls were a background for artistically arranged fruit and vegetable baskets and a Spanish pottery market.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The resolutions committee was still divided by prohibition when it adjourned tonight, and it will go into session again at 10 A.M. tomorrow in the expectation of adopting a platform for submission to the Democratic convention later in the day.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 28. -- Warden Joseph H. Wilson of Great Meadow prison was severely reprimanded today for acting as host at the prison to Charles (Vannie) Higgins, Brooklyn gangster, only a short time before he was slain.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Two more days remain of the Federal Government's fiscal year 1932, which will be marked by a deficit of nearly $3,000,000,000, a loss in receipts of about $1,177,000,000 and an increase in expenditures by nearly $800,000,000. The year will be marked by an increase to about $19,500,000,000 in the public debt.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 28. -- Five rebels were killed yesterday when National Guardsmen attacked a rebel camp east of San Juan.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Major Walker is staying out of the limelight as much as possible at the Democratic National Convention. The delegates and visitors to the convention see him only during the day when he enters the convention hall, accompainied by his secretary, George Colling and, at night, his only public appearances have been at the ammany caucuses.

ORADELL, N.J., June 29. -- Tommy Goodwill, 19-year-old son of Bud Goodwin, one-time aquatic star of the New York A.C., was the medalist in the metropolitan Junior golf championship qualifying round played today over the Hackensack Golf Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP). -- The Senate today extended a helping hand to bonus-seeking war veterans, who wish to return home from the capital. It passed and sent to the House a resolution providing that the government lend the former service men sufficient money for transportation and subsistence.

State of South Carolina. Virtual agreement has been reached between holders of State of South Carolina 6 per cent revenue notes, due on July 15, outstanding in the amount of $5,000,000, for an extension of the loan for six months at the same rate of interest.

BUTLER, Pa., June 28. -- A wet bathing suit and an electric wire near the upper end of a fire escape chute on a schoolhouse were believed today to be the combination that killed an 8-year-old schoolboy last night.

MONTREAL, Que., June 28 (Canadian Press). -- Canadian lake steamship companies decided today to take drastic measures to stem the decline in revenue from the commerce of the Great Lakes. A company will be incorporated to act for all Canadian lake steamship owners in arranging charters for the carriage of grain.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The text of the communique on import quotas issued yesterday by the French Ministry of Commerce was received by the State Department today from the Paris Embassy. It provides for general increases of from 10 to 30 per cent and reads as follows:

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 28. -- Eight hundred exhibitors, representing thirty-three garden clubs of the Second District Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, took part in the annual district flower show, which opened in the Community Building here today.

Notices for about 41,000 bales were circulated yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, of which 14,000 were taken by a firm reported as operating for German interests. For a time prices eased, influenced by weakness in outside markets and by less general rainfall in the South than in the preceding three days.

AVON, Conn., June 28. -- Two of the three races at the opening of the second week in the Bay State Circuit today were split-heat events. Great Atlantic, favorite for the 2:12 trot at $20 to $15 each for Capital Stock and Volo Yorke, finally came through after four stiff heats.

"There is nothing heroic about big-game hunting," says CARVETH WELLS, the English explorer and collector. The beasts of the jungle and the plain have not a sporting chance for their lives against a hunter using modern high-powered rifles. In Africa he travels with bearers in caravan fashion, who act as a bodyguard and protect him from danger.

Approximately $150,000 from the estate of Charles V. Nellany, for merly special counsel in the New York City Law Department, will ultimately go to charitable institutions it was shown yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal was filed with Deputy State Tax Commissioner Maurice A. Stephenson. The estate of Mr. Nellany, who died on Sept. 23 1931, was appraised at $484,933 gross and $248,581 net.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange failed to hold its early gains yesterday and finished irregularly lower. Railroad bonds lost the most ground, with a long list in this group declining one to six points, several touching new lows. Leading foreign loans, as a rule, displayed better resistance to the decline than did domestic corporation issues.

CLEVELAND, June 28. -- The Grand Circuit season of light-harness racing opened at the North Randall track today. The initial card, postponed from yesterday because of rain, was marked by close competition.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 28. -- Henry Kowal, 20-year-old Colgate University captain, today won the 36-hole qualifying round medal in the national intercollegiate golf championship with a score of 149, as Yale captured the team trophy for the second year.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A three-year loan of $8,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. A total of $10,996,331 had been applied for, but the commission noted in its decision that the road expected $2,996,331 to be supplied by the Railroad Credit Corporation and other sources.

LONDON, June 28. -- Britain's newest submarine, the Rainbow, rising suddenly out of the water this afternoon, had a collision with a pleasure steamboat that endangered 150 persons aside from her own crew. There were no casualties, however, and both vessels returned to port with no serious injuries.

The large ground floor store and basement at the southwest corner of New Street and Exchange Place, in the Continental Bank Building, has been leased for a long term by the Walgreen Company for a unit in its drug-store chain.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Reversing its former action, the Senate accepted the conference report on the economy bill by a vote of 35 to 11 late this evening and thereby placed the measure, which is designed to save $150,000,000 in the coming fiscal year, in a position to be signed by the President.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, sailed with Mrs. Robinson and their two children on the American export liner Exeter yesterday. Dr. Robinson said they would spend the Summer in Italy and at the end of their vacation go to Vienna and Trieste.

The Roxy Theatre, which was recently petitioned into an equity recevership, will close for four weeks following the last performance tomorrow night, Harry K. Kosch. receiver and president of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, announced yesterday.
A bond issue of 5,000,000 gold pesos ($5,000,000) intended to "finance the fight for Puerto Rican independence" was announced yesterday in local Spanish-language newspapers.
NEW YORK. Mrs. George Thompson has left 162 East Sixty-first Street for Kinder Rook, her Summer place in Onteora Park, Tannersville, N. Y.
LATONIA, Ky., June 28 (AP). -- The racing strip was deep and holding today and only the stoutest of thoroughbreds could negotiate the footing with any degree of success.

Four deaths, two attributed to the heat and two of drowning, and three heat prostrations were recorded yesterday as the mercury rose to 84 degrees, within 2 degrees of Monday's high mark, and an overcast sky kept the atmosphere sticky, without promise of the temporary coolness of a shower.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- About 500 Democratic women delegates and alternates returned from the national convention to their hotel rooms tonight with aching muscles and hoarse vocal cords. They had spent long hours in the Chicago Stadium parading the aisles, yelling, cheering, clapping and wildly waving banners in behalf of their favorite candidates for the Presidential nomination and the permanent chairmanship of the convention.

PEIPING, June 28 (AP). -- A creature with man's hands, but seemingly some other kind of feet, lived in China 1,000,000 years ago. A wristbone and a toe-bone to prove this were described today by Dr. Davidson Black, world-famous Canadian anatomist, attached to the Rockefeller Hospital here.

The fighting Petrolle family maintained its superiority over Christopher (Bat) Battalino, former world's featherweight champion, again last night. Fighting as a welterweight, the Hartford Italian went down to defeat before Frankie Pettrolle of Schenectady, younger brother of Billy, who twice vanquished Battalino last Winter.
MADRID, June 28. -- Spain's Chief of Staff General Godet, and two other high Generals were removed from office today by Premier Azana after a Cabinet meeting.

H. de Aleida Filho, chairman of he Brazilian Loans Redemption, Committee, issued a statement yesterday from the Brazilian Consulate, 17 Battery Place, saying that the committee has sent reports of a surrey of the Brazilian debt situation to members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives, asking favorable consideration of legislation to make the banker and investment banker jointly liable, as comakers, with any country floating a loan in the United States.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The stock of Governor Ritchie of Maryland as a contender for the Presidential nomiation is on the rise as the time for balloting on candidates is approaching. Tonight it is regarded as only thirty-six hours off, since the convention at its session today adopted a report from the committee on rules under which action on the platform will precede nominations as the order of business.

ALBANY, June 28. -- Governor Roosevelt was elated tonight over the success of his forces in the national convention in electing Senator Walsh as permanent chairman over Jouett Shouse. The Governor's advisers here said that, as a result of the day's events, he looked with Confidence toward the time for balloting on the nomination.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28. -- Donald S. Wees, just back from the Paraguayan, jungles, is absolved by Dr. Thomas Barbour, director of the Museum of Comparative Zoology of Harvard University, of all responsibility for tales of "white Indians."
CHICAGO, June 28. -- The address of Senator Walsh as permanent chairman of the Democratic National convention was as follows:

At the Lewisohn Stadium last night more than 15,000 persons, a capacity audience, attended the opening of the fifteenth season. Willem van Hoogstraten, beginning his eleventh stadium season, was the conductor, and the orchestra was the Philharmonic-Symphony of New York.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 28. -- Frank C. Paine's Class A cutter Highland Light crossed the finish line at 3:50 this afternoon, less than three days out of Montauk Point, and the first yacht in the ocean race to arrive at the destination.

In response to country-wide appeals prompted by the wet-dry plank adopted by the Republican National Convention and the repeal plank which the Democratic National Convention is expected to adopt, the Crusaders, national repeal organization, announced yesterday that it would move today for immediate action in Congress looking toward repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment and also for modification of the Volstead act to legalize 275 per cent beer pending a referendum on repeal.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 28. -- Ellsworth Vines will be the only man in the semi-finals out of the powerful contingent the United States sent to Wimbledon this year.

LONDON, June 28 (Canadian Press). -- While his audience of prominent Conservatives cheered, Stanley Baldwin, Acting Prime Minister, made it quite clear in an address at a dinner of the 1900 Club this evening that Britain would not negotiate with the Irish Free State at the Ottawa imperial economic conference or anywhere else.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 28 (AP). -- Mrs. Ethel Borch Wright of West Orange, N.J., has filed in the Registry of Deeds here a $100,000 attachment against Muriel N.L. Bourgeois of Atlantic City, N.J., and Northboro, Mass., in an action to recover for the alleged alienation of affections of the plaintiff's husband, Dr. Paul Wright of Atlantic City and New York.

Buyers' Arrivals Showed Gain. Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the figures for the previous week, the total still remained well under the number listed for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Hogs continued today to be in urgent demand and prices advanced 10 to 20 cents, the top moving up to $4.90 a hundred pounds on the sale of a part load, or 20 cents above yesterday and $1.60 above the recent low. The average was advanced 15 cents to $4.45 and showed $1.30 above the low of June 4.

QUEBEC, June 28(Canadian Press). -- A revised set of by-laws for Price Brothers Co., newsprint manufacturers, was approved today without dissent at a formal meeting of common and preferred stock shareholders. Allan A. Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook's brother and newly elected president, was in the chair.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The fight over the permanent chairmanship of the Democratic National Convention resulted today in a complete victory for the friends of Governor Roosevelt when Senator Walsh, veteran pilot of the Madison Square Garden convention of 1924.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway passed its common dividend yesterday and the Norfolk Western Railway reduced its annual rate of disbursement on common from $10 to $3. As "standard dividend-payers," both roads continued their regular distributions until long after the onset of the depression and held above par while most other issues were sinking to record low levels.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 28. -- Barclay Kingman of Orange, seeded fifth, was the first of the seeded players to be defeated in the Northern New Jersey junior tennis championships at the East Orange Tennis Club today.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The late Annie Swan Coburn left most ot her fine art collection and much of her $500,000 fortune to Chicago institutions, including the Art Institute, the Field Museum of Natural History and Northwestern University. Harvard University and Smith College also share under her will, which was filed today.

Miss Margaret Roulston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Charles Roulston of Wykagyl Park, New Rochelle, N.Y., and Paul D. Outerbridge of Hamilton, Bermuda, nephew of Sir Joseph Outerbridge and Lady Outerbridge of London and Bermuda, whose marriage was set for last Monday in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, were married in Baltimore last Saturday, two days before the scheduled time, it was disclosed yesterday.

Albert Hirschfeld, New York artist, returned to his studio yesterday with thirty-eight pictures he painted when on a nine months' tour of the South Sea Islands and the East Indies. He still wears the short-clipped Vandyke beard that he cultivated as a student in the Quartier Latin in Paris.

LAUSANNE, June 28. -- Between France's insistence on a promise from Germany to resume reparations payments at some indefinite future date and the stubbornness of the German refusal to make any such engagement or advance any really effective scheme of cooperation instead of reparations payment, the Lausanne Conference seems tonight likely to end inconclusively in the near future without having realized the hopes that were entertained for it.

GENEVA, June 28. -- The French delegates to the disarmament conference who are working to get France to accept the Hoover plan for a one-third cut in armaments are cheered by the progress they consider they are making. One of them said today:

MANCHESTER, Vt, June 28. -- Six of the eight matches in the first lound of match play in the twenty-eighth annual golf competition of the Summer Advertising Golf Association went to the seventeenth green at Equinox Links Club today.
LONDON, June 28 (Canadian Press). -- England today decisively defeated India in the only test cricket match scheduled this season, ending the three-day struggle at Lord's with a victory by 158 runs.

A series of Important announcements of dividends, which on the whole were more favorable than Wall Street had expected, caused yesterday wide fluctuations and a fairly general rise in leading industrial securities, while railroad stocks declined moderately.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 28. -- A man who said he was an escaped inmate of an insane asylum shot two women and a man with a revolver here tonight. The assailant, who was captured by the police, gave his name as Peter Tierponio and said he lived on Glen Street here.

The familiar picture of the barefoot youngster going fishing with a pole over his shoulder and carrying a can of worms may be partially destroyed in Connecticut next year. Up until the present time the State has allowed those under 14 years of age to fish in the trout streams of the State without a license.

An Ultimatum to 30,000 retail cleaners in New York to join retail groups fostered by the Metropolitan Cleaners and Dyers' Association, the wholesale plants, was sent out yesterday by the Trade Association Management Company, 570 Seventh Avenue, of which former Sheriff Thomas M. Farley was manager until two weeks ago.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Brought into unified control after four days of syndicate leadership, the Roosevelt convention organization today won a series of essential victories in the second session of the Democratic National Convention and put the Governor of New York firmly back into the forefront of the contest for the Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The ballot rejecting the minority report of the committee on permanent organization and electing Senator Walsh as permanent chairman of the convention over Jouett Shouse was as follows:

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- A newly born national Democratic war veterans' organization was ready today to fight for the cash bonus payment and other platform demands of exsoldiers in the Democratic National Convention.

"Talking books" for the blind, as substitute for Braille, have been made possible through recent developments in sound reproduction, and experiments are now being conducted for their production in the near future, it was announced yesterday by Robert B. Irwin, executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind, before the convention of the Anerican Association of Instructors for the Blind, composed of school superintendents from all over the country.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Tammany decided tonight to remain on the fence for at least another day. Immediately after the election of Senator Walsh as permanent chairman of the convention, John F. Curry, chairman of the New York State delegation, told his lieutenants to inform the delegates and the press that there would be no caucus of the delegation tonight.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Some one in the delegation hurt the feelings of W.L. Rea of Texas at Monday's session by "pushing" him around and demanding that he parade when he didn't want to. An old-time ranger, Rea said little, but today he took his seat in the hall, called the attention of his fellow-Texans and while they watched, drew a thick .45-calibre pistol from a hip holster.

A Kings County Court jury in the trial of Jack Weinstein, former note teller in the Joralemon Street branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company in Brooklyn, was ordered yesterday by County Judge McLaughlin to be locked up for the night. It was the first occurrence of the kind in seven years in that court.

An afternoon of political fireworks, done in the best Democratic style, echoed and re-echoed from the Chicago Stadium yesterday over two coast-to-coast radio networks to form the longest sustained broadcast from a national convention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Republican convention closed with a disappointing platform to both the wets and the drys. There were many others who were sadly disillusioned by their party's actions. It was very evident that the party leaders had been playing a game of bluff.

Jack (Kid) Berg, English boxer, and Kid Chocolate, Cuban lightweight, are to undertake a repetition of their hurricane ring struggle of two years ago. They were signed yesterday for a fifteen-round contest in the Madison Square Garden Bowl Long Island City, on the night of July 11.

MARION, Mass., June 28. -- The Tabor Academy crew, with 15-year-old Frank B. Jewett Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., as skipper, took a decisive lead in the preliminary races of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association championships which began today.
The army found itself in another prodicament yesterday, and among the "Captains and the Generals and the corps of engineers" it was no laughing matter.

Michael B. Eisenstein, Manhattan and Brooklyn bail bondsman, who was a witness in the trial of former County Judge Bernard W. Vause, filed a petition in bankruptcy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, listing liabilities of $243,791 and no assets.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- Telegrams from Democratic organizations in New Jersey attacking Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and urging the nomination of Governor Roosevelt were received today at Roosevelt headquarters.

Sir Oliver Lodge, British scientist, in a book, "The Eighteen-Sixties," just published by the Macmillan Company, advises caution in accepting as true some of the forecasts and philosophic speculations of present-day prophets. Sir Oliver cites "the doctrine of relativity" as one of the theories deserving cautious acceptance wherever it has not been confirmed by experiment.

When the team of United States golfers answers the challenge of the British players in the Walker Cup series in September Captain Francis Ouimet will be able to rely not only upon veterans of other years but upon a number of the youthful stars who have forged their way to the top lank in golf during the last few seasons.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 28. -- Head of the seeded list, the Baroness Giacomo Levi was halted in her quest of the metropolitan clay court title today when she met Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch on the courts of the Lido Country Club.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- The delegates were all wired for sound today and the second session of the Democratic National Convention was a humdinger from start to finish.

Jack Van Bebber of the Los Angeles A.C., twice national 165-pound champion, scored an impressive victory yesterday as the forty-fourth annual National Amateur Athletic Union title wrestling tournament got under way in the new Madison Square Garden bowl.

A sharp gain in the number of banking suspensions and a small decline in the number of retail failures featured business defaults for the week ended June 23, according to Bradstreet's. There was an increase of over 100 per cent in the liabilities involved for the period, this being largely due to the bank closings, particularly in the Chicago area.

More than 2,000,000 families and individuals have been helped directly by the health and welfare agencies in New York City in the last fifty years, according to a report made to the directors of the Welfare Council yesterday by Solomon Lowenstein, chairman of the council's committee on social service exchange.

The Transit Commission moved yesterday to give new life to unification proceedings, which have lain practically dormant since last December, when the commission's tentative $474,500,000 plan was published. As a prelude to the official reception of the recent $400,000,000 unity plan proposed by its former special counsel, Samuel Untermyer, the commission conferred for two hours with A.M. Williams and Clarence J. Shearn of counsel for the B.M.T.

TRENTON, N.J., June 28. -- Certificates designating them registered pharmacists were presented by Governor Moore today to seventy-two of 114 candidates who took the May examination. The new druggists are:

Jules Sauerwein, noted French journalist and correspondent of the Paris Soir, will sail tonight for France on the Paris of the French Line after studying the political situation in Chicago, Washington and New York.

HONGKONG, June 28 (AP). -- Chinese reports said today military leaders in Kwangsi Province had applied to the Cantonese Government for permission to send 5.000 men through Kwangtung to fight Communists, but the permission was refused by General Chen Chia-tang, who feared it was a "trick" to capture Canton for General Chiang Kai-shek.

Norman T. Whitaker, 42 years old, a suave and smiling prisoner identified in a police line-up here as the mysterious "Fox No. 19" who assisted Gaston B. Means in obtaining $104,000 from Mrs. Evalyn McLean on promise to return the Lindbergh baby, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Francis O'Neill as a fugitive from justice.

Personal, Not Official. When the announcement came that VON PAPEN was to be made German Chancellor, even friends of his confessed their astonishment. He was a fine fellow, but what did he, as a military man, know about diplomacy?
CHICAGO, June 28. -- The invocation at the Democratic National Convention today was delivered by the Right Rev. Mgr. F.G. Ostrowski of St. Joseph's Church, Chicago. The prayer follows:
