FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 28. -- The principal parts of the cross-examination yesterday of Colonel Lindbergh by Lloyd Fisher of counsel for the defense of John B. Curtis follows:

Three fillies which finished at the heels of Top Flight in the recently run Coaching Club American Oaks were defeated at Aqueduct yesterday by Selby Burch's Playfole, lightly regarded outsider at 12 to 1 in a fourhorse field.

A first glance at the still unfinished business of Congress discourages hope of early adjournment Only two of the eleven routine appropriation bills have been sent to the President for his signature, though a new fiscal year begins on Friday and the Government will need funds to cover expenditures.

One objective of the delegates opposed to Governor ROOSEVELT at Chicago is overlooked by many. It was not to "stop ROOSEVELT," or any other candidate, so much as to stop an apparent effort to override and intimidate the convention from the first hour of its meeting.

Financial attentions yesterday was directed in advance to dividends; the rate being fixed by four important companies, in all of which the action had been in doubt. Of these the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway passed its common stock dividend, as had been generally expected and as, in fact, the company itself had intimated to its shareholders when making the last previous quarterly payment.

Through the action of the New York Stock Exchange's governing committee in ordering yesterday that trading be suspended on Saturday, a large part of the Wall Street community got assurance of a three-day vacation at the week-end.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once more our kind paternalistic Congress proposes to reconstruct the private affairs of the sovereign people by imposing on them a $2,500,000,000 tax liability for loans for every conceivable purpose. The people of Boston and New York are to have their depleted incomes drawn on to make up the losses incurred by a recent administration in Chicago.

About 1,200,000 school children will be set free tomorrow when classes are dismissed until Sept. 12, but, after a week's respite, more than 65,000 who have failed of promotion will enter Summer schoolrooms in an attempt to catch up with their classmates before the end of vacation.

Continued irregularity in price movements was noted in commodities yesterday. In the foodstuffs, wheat improved, while corn, rye and oats were steady. Provisions were higher. Cotton was lower, as was sugar, which broke 6 to 8 points after getting up to new highs for this movement. Silk and hides showed improvement. Other articles remained firm.

BOSTON, June 28 (AP). -- Young Bobby Brown pitched the Braves into a virtual second-place tie with Chicago today when he turned back the hard-hitting Phillies, 5-3. It was the youngster's seventh victory in ten starts and he Rave the Phils only four hits, striking out six and walking five.

The Rumanians, like most other peoples of Southeastern Europe, are a nation of craftsmen rather than of artists. The exhibition of arts and crafts now on at the Rumanian Consulate, 1,819 Broadway, emphasizes this interesting endemic trait. From the vestees elaborately embroidered in many colors to the landscapes in oil, the painstaking quality of technique commands admiration.

LONDON, June 28. -- Trading was light on the Stock Exchange today, although there was more activity in British Government funds, which were stimulated of revival of rumors of the imminence of the treasury's bond-conversion scheme. Dealers were also discussing the likelihood of the Bank of England reducing the Bank rate on Thursday to 2 per cent.
LONDON, June 28 (Canadian Press). -- Essex defeated Leicestershire by seven wickets in a first-class county cricket match concluding today at Chelmsford.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Three convention victories, one of them, the election of Senator Walsh as permanent chairman in a major contest, were received tonight by the Roosevelt supporters as an omen of victory in the big battle, that for the nomination for President.

The members of the Intercoastal Steamship Conference will meet at 44 Whitehall Street tomorrow and try to reach agreements which will permit an extension of the existing rate schedule or establish a new agreement to run for another six months. The conference, which disbanded several years ago after disagreement among members and reformed last Winter temporarily, met last week and failed to establish terms agreeable to all operators.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 28. -- Charles Mayo Jr. of St. Paul's School, Garden City, today won the qualifying medal in the Eastern Interscholastic golf championship for the third consecutive year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial, "Vacationing at Home," was quite timely and suggestive, although I do not know what hopes were raised in the minds of thousands of children to whom the prospect of happy days in camp or travel are thwarted by economic conditions.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the Democrat of purest ray serene from Amity, Ind., was discovered by a reporter in the act of having a sore finger bound up at the emergency hospital in the Stadium.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., June 28. -- Kar Lee, 22 years old, a Chinese student of aviation, deliberately nosed his plane into the ground here today to avoid striking a 10-year-old girl playing with a rubber ball in a driveway along her home, according to witnesses of the accident.

The money market was without feature as it coursed through another of its idle sessions. Business was light and quotations unchanged for all accommodations. Stock Exchange call loans ruled at 2 1/2 per cent. Street trades at 1 and Federals 1/8 @ 1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is ample reason to believe that if the consuming public were fully aware of the real significance of the new manufacturers' excise tax on furs there would be a widespread protest against the measure. As it now stands it is actually a luxury tax upon a necessity.

CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP). -- Pepper Martin bobbed up again to contribute to the Reds' downfall today, his triple in the fourth starting a series of Cincinnati misplays that gave the Cardinals the game, 6 to 2. Hallahan held the Reds to four hits.

PARIS, June 28. -- That a serious movement in favor of President Hoover's arms proposal and for a definitive settlement at the Lausanne reparations conference has developed within the ranks of the French parties was evidenced today in a long discussion on these questions at a Radical Socialist party meeting which ended in an undecisive vote.

READING, Pa., June 28 (AP). -- The Reading Keys took both games of tonight's double-header from Newark, the first, a seven-inning affair, 4 to 1, and the second, 9 to 8. In each contest the Keys came from behind to win.

BERLIN, June 28 (AP). -- Political disorders in various parts of Germany in the last twenty-four hours piled up a casualty list of four dead and more than thirty-seven injured. Forty-four persons were arrested.

Optimism in the face of prevailing conditions and a moratorium on foreclosures were advocated by Harry Hall, chairman of the board of William A. White Sons, in an address "Real Estate -- In Retrospect and Prospect" before the June luncheon meeting of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board in the Brooklyn Elks clubhouse yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The Roosevelt forces in the national convention won their first tests in the contests affecting Louisiana and Minnesota. Both were carried to the floor of the convention today on appeals from adverse decisions in the committee on credentials and resulted in Roosevelt victories.

PARIS, June 28. -- In view of the unfavorable situation at Lausanne. the Pang Bourse exhibited surprising strength today. Instead of an expected sharp decline, there was great firmness in prices during most of the session, and at one time there was even improvement over yesterday's levels. Toward the close of trading, however, further pessimistic reports from Lausanne caused a reversal of tendency and the market finished with moderate losses.

Banks and lending institutions, acting as plaintiffs in realty liquidation sales yesterday, bid in numerous Bronx and Manhattan propertics. The auction list contained some large holdings, including an office building at Madison Avenue had Thirty-fourth Street and the Hotel Narragansett at Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- The flow of dimes from traffic on the elevated railways has fallen off to such an extent that the Chicago Rapid Transit Company went into receivership today.
BERLIN, June 28 (AP). -- The Reichsrat today approved the 1932-33 budget, which will be promulgated in an emergency decree as quickly as possible.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28. -- Dr. Frank Fell Underbill, Professor of Pharmacology and Toxicology in the Yale School of Medicine, died today in his home here after an illness of two months from nephritis. He was in his fifty-fifth year.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 28. -- Miss Jane McCullough, one of the low handicap stars of the Philadelphia district, was leading in gross scoring at the end of thirty-six holes of the women's three-day invitation tournament at the Skytop Club today. She carded another 89 for a two-day total of 178 giving her a lead of six strokes.

Results of his trip through Russia and the Caucasus in a search for new music forms were outlined by Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a broadcast from Berlin, last night. Mr. Downes, who declared that he "went to the Caucasus to find primitive music in the semi-Oriental city of Tiflis," admitted that the most startling thing he encountered was American jazz.

When a prominent advertising agent declares that products of American industry are sold "by means at once insincere and misleading and offensive to good taste," manufacturers, retailers, advertisers and customers must alike wonder.

A story was revealed here yesterday of a retired police lieutenant who flew from Montreal to Los Angeles and back to get his life savings, only to lose them to a "confidence man." The details became known, at Police Headquarters when Kent Marshall, 63 years old, of 235 West 108th Street, appeared in the line-up charged with being a fugitive from justice in Montreal.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 28. -- The old Red Barn Theatre, which was to have opened tomorrow night with "Elizabeth Sleeps Out" before a notable audience of North Shore society folk, will be dark.

From Jan, 1 to June 18 the sugar melt of fourteen refineries in the United States totaled 1,685,000 long tons, compared with 1,530,000 in the corresponding period of 1931. Deliveries totaled 1,500,000 tons, against 1,735,000 a year before.

Harry and Sadie Schanbam of Bayonne conveyed to the Fifth Ward Savings Bank of Jersey City four two-family frame dwellings at 319, 329, 333 and 335 Columbia Avenue, near the Secaucus Road, Jersey City, subject to four mortgages totaling $24,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28. -- The National Education Association, in business session at its annual convention here today, refused the plea of the New York State delegation to elect by acclamation the veteran educator and philosopher, John Dewey, as honorary president, an office heretofore lacking in the organization.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The demand for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment recently made by John D. Rockefeller Jr. was answered today by Colonel Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director, with the assertion that "it seems obvious to us that he has based his conclusions to some extent upon misinformation."

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Changing and spreading operations furnished most of the transactions in wheat today on the Board of Trade here, but scattered liquidation and hedging pressure were sufficient to cause a lower range, with the finish within a fraction of the bottom at net losses of 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 29 (AP). -- The Socalist provisional government of Carlos G. Davila took its first definite step today toward constitutionality when it was announced that a constitutional assembly would be called to meet the first Sunday in October.
MANY brave hearts are asleep in the deep, including the Giants. But there may be a good time coming. It's odd how the visiting ball players of both leagues, when they come to town, start asking:

Washington, the only American League team with a victory over Vernon Gomez this year, yesterday knocked him out of the box in the eighth inning, thereby preventing him from scoring his fifteenth victory of the season and his twelfth straight.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 30. -- Following is the vote in detail as taken by the Democratic convention early this morning on the question of substituting the minority for the majority (wet) report on the prohibition plank in the platform, the "no" votes standing for outright repeal and legalized beer, the "yes" votes for resubmission:

The need for remodeling many of the older buildings in the west side district below Thirty-fourth Street to improve the general appearance of the loft and office sections and to attract more tenants was emphasized by speakers at the meeting of the Penn Zone Property Owners Association yesterday in the Hotel Governor Clinton.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 29. -- The first meeting of the East Hampton Emergency Sewing and Knitting Guild, organized to aid the unemployed by Mrs. Frederick K. Hollister, will be held tomorrow morning and every Monday and Thursday morning thereafter through the Summer.

Celebrating his golden jubilee as a priest of the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. Henry C. Longo, S.J., was honored yesterday by hundreds of parishioners and his fellow-clergymen at a solemn high mass yesterday morning at a testimonial dinner given in his honor last night.

A marked decrease in the number of families of social prominence who have left the city for the Summer is shown by the Summer Social Register for 1932, just issued by the Social Register Association of 381 Fourth Avenue.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee has appropriated $411,000 for July, it was announced yesterday. The Emergency Work and Relief Bureau will receive $396,000 for emergency wages, while $15,000 will be spent for direct relief in Harlem.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Mayor Walker, it was learned today, has told friends in the New York delegation that he did not want his own political fortunes, now resting with Governor Roosevelt, to influence in any way the vote of any member of the New York delegation.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed co-agent with the Industrial Trust Company of Pawtucket, R.I., for payment of city of Pawtucket 5 1/2 per cent funding, 5 per cent water, 5 per cent sewer, 5 per cent sidewalk, 5 per cent highway and 5 per cent school bond coupons.

Willie and Eugene Howard, now appearing in the stage show at the Paramount Theatre, have been engaged to be the featured comedians of "Ballyhoo," the revue in the preparation of which Bobby Connolly, Lewis E. Gensler, Russell Patterson and Norman Anthony will be associated.

Irregularity marked the trend of prices in commodities markets yesterday. Grains sagged, but cotton turned higher. Provisions were firm, with continued strength in hog prices. Rubber and hides improved, but coffee, sugar and cocoa were slightly lower. Silk remained steady. Other staples were unchanged.

With the drama on Broadway taking its Summer siesta, it was not to be expected that last night's new play in MacDougal Street would be anything exceptional. But without being anything exceptional, it still could have been a good deal better than it was. "The Lingering Past" was its title; Leonard J. Tynan, a newcomer, its author, and Ed-win Hopkins, a play doctor and student of theatrical copyright, its director.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The form Federal relief of unemployment is to take constituted tonight the only serious obstacle to adjournment of Congress this week.

MEXICO CITY, June 29 (AP). -- Foreign banking institutions doing business in Mexico must submit themselves exclusively to the laws of Mexico under a general credit and banking law promulgated today by President Ortiz Rubio under special powers granted by Congress.
CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP). -- Detroit pummelled the Cleveland Indians' pitchers almost at will today, netting 16 hits from three hurlers and finishing on the long end of a 13 to 4 score.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- A drive to obtain action at this session on the Goldsborough dollar stabilization bill or the Senate substitute was opened today by Senator Borah and others.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 29. -- Jack (Kid) Berg of England received the decision over Mike Sarko of Boston in a hard-fought six-round bout, the main event on the boxing card tonight at the Island Park Stadium at Island Park near here.

CINCINNATI, June 29. -- Our educational system is honeycombed with atheists, agnostics, rationalists, naturalists and Communists, Archbishop McNicholas declared at the national conference of the Catholic Educational Association here today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 29. -- Three of the favorites survived the league round-robin tournament play in the annual national marbles tournament here today and advanced to the semi-final round, which will be played tomorrow morning.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, June 29 (Canadian Press). -- "Canadians were frankly amazed that we should seriously have asked a general reduction of the Canadian duties on British cotton goods and free entry in the case of specified lines," declared John H. Grey, chairman of the British cotton trade delegation, on his return today with members of the party that conferred with the Canadian textile industry.

An effort to obtain information concerning a mysterious transaction involving 29,000,000 kroner. put through by the late Ivar Kreuger in December, 1931. when he was in New York, was begun yesterday before Henry K. Davis, sitting at 140 Nassau Street as a special master in connection with the American petition for a receivership for the Kreuger Toll Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29. -- The New York State delegation at the annual convention of the National Education Association attained todoy the objective which yesterday it had given up for lost, and Dr. John Dewey was elected by the delegate assembly as honorary life president of the association.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 (AP). -- William Z. Foster, Communist party Presidential nominee, charged with "suspicion of criminal syndicalism," was released from the city jail today on orders of Captain William F. Hynes, head of the police Red squad. Captain Hynes said he had no evidence that Foster was engaged in the "practice of criminal syndicalism."

The clearing house banks have reached an understanding that for the time being they will place their facilities and those of the clearing house at the disposal of their large corporation customers in acting as paying agents for dividend and salary checks drawn by these corporations upon themselves so as to avoid the 2-cent tax on checks.

The Park Association expressed disapproval yesterday of the suggestion of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens that part of Raymond M. O'Connor Park in Bayside be utilized as a site for a new high school. Lawrence M. Craner, executive secretary, explained that this disapproval was only in line with the traditional policy of the association of opposing the use of park lands for any other purpose.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 30. -- A tumultuous night session of almost five hours in which the repeal champions of the Democratic party debated with the advocates of moderation, while packed galleries cheered or jeered or laughed and delegates broke into two impromptu parades, led up to the convention's rejection of the minority report on its prohibition plank early today.
CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored a 10-to-9 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- President Hoover's request for a $40,000 appropriation to pay the expenses of an American delegation to the proposed international economic conference at London was rejected today by the Senate, which by a vote of 45 to 8 decided that the money should go to pay the expenses of a delegation to a "monetary conference" which is apparently not even in the offing.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- A prompt disavowal came from Roosevelt head-quarters today of any connection with an effort Frank Schofield, manager for Melvin Traylor, said had been made by a man claiming to be a Roosevelt supporter to have the Chicagoan withdraw from the race for the Presidential nomination.
WILDWOOD, N.J., June 29. -- W. H. Billbee of Post 23, Trenton, was elected Commander of the New Jersey Department of the Grand Army of the Republic at today's session of the State encampment here.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 (AP). -- The youthful American team of Sidney B. Wood and Gregory Mangin fell today before the splendid play of Fred Perry and George Hughes, British pair, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3. Wood dropped two important service games and wildness cost the Americans a chance to come from behind in the third set.

BUENOS AIRES, June 29. -- Brown Brothers Harriman Co. of New York have renewed $9,000,000 of the $10,000,000 Argentine Government loan expiring on July 1. The new loan is issued in four series of $2,500,000 each, expiring on Jan. 15. next, Feb. 15, March 15 and April 15.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- The text of the platform as adopted by the majority of the resolutions committee and presented tonight to the Democratic convention reads:

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Following is the text of the address of Alfred E. Smith to the Democratic Convention favoring the adoption of the majority report on prohibition, as transcribed by the Columbia Broadcasting system:

PARIS, June 23 (by mail). -- The extent to which France's export trade has been hit by the depression is illustrated by a "cry of distress" that powerful exporting firms have addressed to Premier Herriot.

LONDON, June 29. -- As reprisal for the refusal of the Free State to pay the half-yearly land annuities amounting to u1,500,000 (the pound was quoted at $3.60 yesterday) which are now due, Britain proposes to impose a sweeping tax on Free State goods entering Britain.

Port officers supervising the entry of a Pan American Airways flying boat at Miami Tuesday night discovered a stowaway hiding in the rear stow hold of the ship, the New York office reported yesterday. Weak and exhausted from a two-day foodless flight from Panama, the man.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29. -- In a hard-riding, exciting game in which play swung one way and then the other, the Greentree polo team shaded Roslyn on Cochran Field at the Meadowbrook Club today, 10 to 9, and reached the second round of the Meadow Brook Cup tournament.

James Di Salvio, 49 years old, of 204 Hester Street, better known as Jimmy Kelly, night-club operator, politician, former pugilist and proprietor of a resort at 181 Sullivan Street, was held in $1,000 bail yesterday by Magistrate Smith in Essex Market Court for examination Friday on a chargeof taking $20 from the pocket of a customer.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- After a week of internal dissension, which rent its ranks almost to the point of disintegration, the bonus army was under a virtual dictatorship tonight.

The American woman who intends to follow the dictates of Paris fashion lot the coming year might better "save her breath" if she wants her silhouette to conform, it was indicated yesterday at the last of the Spring luncheon meetings of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Ambassador.

A machine that does the "seeing" for the blind, enabling them to read books and newspapers or study maps and diagrams, was demonstrated yesterday at the third day's session of the thirty-first blennial convention of the American Association of Instructors of the Blind in the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.
CINCINNATI, June 29. -- Litigation again has broken about the heads of trustees of the country's only railroad owned by a city, the Cincinnati Southern.

Formal opening, as it might be termed, of the out-of-town Summer season, when citizens of the New York art world estivate happily among green hills will be marked by the opening on July 5, of "Americana Week" at Camp Tamiment, Forest Park, Pennsylvania.
Small homes comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 29. -- Two patrolmen of the Westchester County parkway police will leave here at dawn tomorrow on an expedition along the jungles of the Bronx River to capture alligators for the Bronx Zoo. The police explorers plan to fight their way down the river to Crestwood Lake, where native boys reported recently that the reptiles had been seen sporting in the water.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 29. -- William D.B. Ainey, 68-year-old chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, was accused today in a 7,000-word statement, dictated and sworn to by a former employe of Thomas E. Mitten, late head of Philadelphia's transit system, of receiving upward of $150,000 from Mr. Mitten over a six-year period.

LAUSANNE, Thursday, June 30. -- Pulling with all his strength and throwing overboard all unnecessary cargo in his effort to save the ship. Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain drew the Lausanne conference once more off rocks into quieter waters yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 29. -- Yale came through individually today almost as well as it did as a team yesterday in the national intercollegiate golf championship. Sidney F. Noyes Jr. of Dobbs Ferry had difficult going in both his matches, but John E. Parker of Orange, N.J., breezed through the first and second rounds.

BERLIN, June 29. -- The Boerse was more animated today, with an upward tendency in prices, the market being stimulated by a feeling that the late developments at Lausanne may yet produce some favorable results. The advance was led by the electrical stocks, some gaining as much as 4 per cent.

The reason why keynote speeches leave no impress on the political mind and memory is obvious. Their framework and purpose are necessarily always the same; the delegates always know beforehand what is to be said, and they know also that the platform will say the same things more authoritatively.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20. -- The black 58-foot schooner Malabar X, owned jointly by John G. Alden of Boston and R.I. Gale of Cleveland, Ohio, made the best time of the Class A craft, and the yawl Dorade, winner of the transatlantic race last Summer, appears to be the winner among the Class B racers.

Railroad earnings already reported indicate that the Class I railroads had net operating incomes of about $12,200,000 in May, against $41,263,000 in May, 1931. This would bring their net for five months to about $99,750,000, against $188,387,000 in the same period last year.

The New York Stock Exchange has stricken from the list Barnet Leather Company, Inc., common stock; F W. Grand-Silver Stores, Inc., common stock, and New York Railways Company bonds. The Exchange has also suspended dealings in Rudolph Karstadt, Inc., American shares.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Here is the indicated first battle line-up for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as forecast by instructions, pledges and statements of State leaders to date.

Both in financial markets and in general industry the approach of the midsummer holiday usually causes increased inactivity, and surrounding circumstances at the present juncture are not such as to break the rule. Yesterday's stock market, however, was firmer, with numerous advances of a point or more which were pretty well maintained up to the close.

Efficient operation of its commutation service out of Grand Central Terminal would net the New York Central Railroad a substantial profit, instead of the alleged loss upon which it bases its demand for a 40 per cent rate rise, according to testimony given yesterday by John C. Brackenridge, engineer, of 95 Liberty Street, at a joint hearing of the Public Service and Transit Commissions.

GENEVA, June 29. -- The disarmament negotiations were resumed at a swift pace here today, with the Lausanne reparations conference difficulties stimulating the French and their allies to consider more favorably the idea of accepting the Hoover arms reduction plan about as it stands.

The major radio networks of the country watched part of an evening's profits vanish in the "smoke" of battle that curled up over the political arena at Chicago last night, when several commercial hours on the air were ruthlessly sidetracked for the first after-dinner session of the Democratic convention.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- When Hollis Thurston had finished blanking the Phillies today, Manager Max Carey and his Dodgers found themselves tied with their opponents for fifth place, half a game out of fourth place and the first division.

The Necessary "Mystery Man." A political dispatch from Chicago at last reveals the welcome news that a mysterious stranger is really behind the scenes, pulling the strings that move the puppets in the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Federal Radio Commission expects to call upon radio communication companies to file with it copies of their contracts with foreign governments. The commission will investigate these contracts as the result of the filing with it by the State Department of an arbitration decision in connection with an exclusive contract which the Radio Corporation of America has with the Czechoslovak Government.

BERLIN, June 29 (AP). -- A controversy between the von Papen Ministry and the two strongest opposition parties developed today when the government requested the Prussian Interior Ministry to suppress two party organs that have been lampooning it in cartoons and articles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The entire country seems to be befogged and panicky about the dreadful things that will happen should the Eighteenth Amendment be repealed. People do not seem to realize that nothing could be much worse than present conditions.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the unterrified Hoosier Democrat, was discovered by a reporter sitting in the Congress Hotel lobby, with his Prince Albert coat wrapped tightly about him and his arms folded across his chest.

PARIS, June 29. -- French cinema producers and theatre owners, the former favoring a reduction in American films and the latter opposing restrictions, today conferred at length with government officials who are preparing to issue new contingent schedules.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- The most-talked-of woman in the National Democratic Convention today was Mrs. Isabella Greenway of Arizona, appearing in the dual role of Roosevelt seconder and the woman to be nominated for Vice President.

HORTA, The Azores, June 29. -- Our little thirty-six foot sloop, the Ochito, with my wife and I and a boy as officers, crew and passengers, slipped into Horta harbor today twenty-two days out from Bermuda.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The extreme wets crushed the moderate submissionist group and the chief spokesmen for Governor Roosevelt in the Democratic convention's resolutions committee late today, and by a vote of 35 to 17 forced the insertion of a wringing wet and modification plank into the platform, which was submitted to the convention tonight.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Hundreds of persons, many of them carrying $40 tickets, milied around them Chicago Stadium tonight, unable to obtain entrance to the Democratic National Convention. Police reserves were called out, but there were no disorders.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29. -- Governor Rolph's economy plan for a five-day week had the State Building here in a quandary today and caused open revolt in Sacramento from the offices of Secretary of State Jordan State Treasurer Johnson, State Controller Riley and Fred E. Stewart, chairman of the State Board of Equalization.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Reports of defections in the Roosevelt ranks were denied today by James A. Farley, campaign manager for the Governor, Mr. Farley declared that the contrary was the case and that Mr. Roosevelt would pick up votes when the test comes on the first ballot.

Before sailing last night on the French liner Paris for France, Jules Sauerwein, French journalist, lecturer and author, said he had been deeply interested during his month's stay in this country watching the great crisis through which the American people were passing.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Two years of enforcement of the prohibition laws under the Department of Justice will end tomorrow.

Economies in Federal court expenditures, which include the laying off of judges' messengers, fourteen in Manhattan and five in Brooklyn, and the cutting of jurors' pay, will go into effect tomorrow on the order of Charles P. Sisson, Assistant Attorney General in charge of personnel.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP). -- Irving Hadley held his old team-mates to four hits in six innings today as the Browns won from the White Sox, 6 to 1, in the series opener. Sam Gray, pitching the last three innings, did not allow the Chicagoans a hit.
READING, Pa., June. 29 (AP). -- The Newark Bears defeated the Heading Keys twice tonight by scores of 5 to 4 and 13 to 7, to reverse the double defeat which they suffered in yesterday's twin bill.

Coast Buyers Here Next Week. Buyers from the Pacific Coast are expected to figure prominently in the arrivals of buyers here next week to view Fall lines of dresses and other merchandise, it was reported here yesterday. Decision to delay Fall openings of dresses until after July 4 served to postpone the arrivals of these buyers here and they are counted on to place a good volume of business for immediate delivery.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Injunction proceedings were filed in the Federal court at Lynchburg, Va., today by the government against 136 bituminous coal mining companies, headed by Appalachian Coals, Inc., to test the legality of the regional sales agency plan.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- Tonight's session of the Democratic National Convention provided the first spontaneous mob scene of the current political season. The promise of beer was the touchstone.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- The invocation delivered at the opening of the fourth session of the Democratic National Convention tonight by Rabbi Louis L. Mann of Sinai Temple, Chicago, follows:

ST. JOHN'S, Nfid., June 29 (Canadian Press). -- The new Government of Newfoundland, formed by F.C. Alderdice, who was sworn into office last night as Prime Minister, was completed today, so far as may be until a session of the Legislature is held.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- Another Bryan with her father's gift of oratory is rising into the spotlight of the nation's Democratic leadership.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange has passed a ruling which prohibits members from dealing in, or having anything to do with sales of, groups or units of stocks, termed "packages." Overcharging, waste and misleading statements are given as reasons for the ruling.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- Amos and Andy won the nomination at ten minutes to two this afternoon.

Three underprivileged children, two suffering from defective eyesight and one from deafness, received the M. Samuel Stern Memorial prizes of $200 each yesterday as pupils "found by the Superintendent of Schools to be most worthy of assistance and most likely to profit by such assistance."
PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- Staging a remarkable comeback, Tommy Loughran, former world's light heavyweight champion, defeated Steve Hamas of Passaic, N.J., in ten rounds at Shibe Park tonight.

Modest gains in the general list on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated to most observers that Wall Street was recovering from the attack of nerves brought on by recent dividend uncertainties. The dividend news of the day was mixed, but the share market chose to look on the bright side. Trading was somewhat slower than on the day before, transactions amounting to 630,000 shares.

The Board of Taxicab Control is considering a proposal to order one-third or one-half the city's taxicabs off the streets for the rest of the Summer. Though suggested as a temporary expedient, this rough and ready means of dealing with the admitted surplus of cabs has been brought forward from time to time ever since it was first officially advocated by the committee headed by the late Chief Magistrate WILLIAM MCADOO nearly ten years ago.

MARION, Mass., June 29. -- Completing the preliminary races for the interscholastic yacht racing championship today, five schools earned positions in the final series which will be sailed tomorrow off the Beverly Yacht Club.

Department of Commerce figures reveal certain facts with respect to American export trade overlooked by the keynote orators at Chicago. Losses have not been evenly distributed among all products, as might be inferred from criticism of Republican policy, but have been scattered among different groups in striking disproportion.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- With political eyes turning to all points of the compass, with rumblings heard in at least four of the Roosevelt delegations and with echoes audible in four or five others in the same column, the strategy of the Roosevelt managers is centred tonight in a last-minute drive to win the nomination for Governor Roosevelt on the first two ballots.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 29. -- A brilliant 71, par for the course, enabled young Joe Gagliardi from Winged Foot to take low gross prize in the one-day tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Green Meadow Country Club today.

NEW YORK. Miss Mollie Cullum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Barlow Cullum, gave a supper last night at the Central Park Casino for Miss Margaret Tyner of Washington. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Harding Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Allen M. Cullum, Mr. and Mrs. Alien Milliken, Miss Martha Reading, Miss Cornelia Prime, Joseph Sawyer, Donald McWillie. Clement Harts and Robert Sullivan.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- One day more, and the last financial entry of this nation, will be written -- in red. Tomorrow at midnight the United States will close its fiscal year and embark on a brand new period with additional revenue-producing machinery, together with an auxiliary economic program, which is hoped to produce sufficient income to keep the Treasury in order.

Railroads operating in the West have agreed, in principle, to the formation of a mutually supported commission which will act as arbitrator to eliminate destructive competition, it was disclosed yesterday. Duplication of passenger-train services where adequate traffic is not offered, reduction in the number of surplus fast freights and reform of some methods of freight solicitation were subjects said to be within the purview of the commission.

No sign of the firmness in money normally due at the end of the month and half-year was in evidence. Funds were in good supply for all classes, but demand continued light. Quotations for call, time and business money were all unchanged.

The Brookmeade Stable's Okapi. which was a surprise winner of the Bouquet at Belmont Park, sustained the followers of form at Aqueduct yesterday when he captured the featured Canarsie Claiming Stakes at 4 to 5. At the end of the five furlongs Okapi was driving hard to win by a head from H.C. Phipps's Balios, which led Mrs. W.T. Anderson's Merry Caroline by five lengths.

ORADELL, N.J., June 29. -- Celestin Durand of Lido supplied the best golf in the metropolitan junior golf championship today by going out in 33 at the Hackensack Golf Club. His flying start of four birdies and a par on the first five holes gave him a commanding lead over Wallace Manion of Bloomfield.

Mr. WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE loves the virtuous countryside and shudders at the wickedness of cities, where he spends so much of his time for sociological and other good purposes. To him the divisions at the Chicago convention are between burgher and farmer. It is true that the great populous States of the East and the mid-West are opposed to the nomination of Governor ROOSEVELT.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Senator Copeland's hat was tossed into the ring here tonight for the Democratic Presidential nomination by Dr. Arthur MacDonald, the anthropologist, who is noted for his studies in psychology and related subjects. It was Dr. MacDonald who recently measured the beads of many members of the Senate and House to determine their characteristics.

Charles Achlobin, 52 years old, living at Grand Central Parkway and Pinto Street, Hollis, Queens, telephoned the Queens Village police station at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning and complained that while he was sleeping his wife had struck him on the head with a shoe tree.

ALBANY, June 29. -- With an airplane poised for a flight to Chicago if he is nominated, Governor Roosevelt gathered the members of his family about him in the Executive Mansion tonight to listen to the session of the Democratic National Convention over the radio.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 29. -- President Hoover has awarded the Navy Cross to Second Lieutenant Samuel S. Jack, U.S.M.C., of Glendale, Ariz., for distinguished service as an aviator with the marine brigade when on April 12, 1931, he successfully bombed a rebel camp in the face of machine-gun and rifle fire near Puerto Cabezas and the following day assisted in effecting the crossing of Snaki bridge by a ground patrol.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 29. -- Following her victory over Baroness Levi on Tuesday, Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch of Scarsdale defeated Mrs. William V. Hester Jr. of Glen Cove today to reach the semi-final round in the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championship at the Lido Country Club.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Sixty-five votes from New York and about 200 in all for Alfred E. Smith on the opening ballot at the Democratic National Convention is the expectation of supporters of the former Governor now here doing missionary work for him.

LONDON, June 29. -- A boom in British Government funds developed on the Stock Exchange this afternoon, the strong buying being encouraged by a growing belief that a preliminary Treasury conversion scheme is imminent and by hopes of a reduction in the bank rate tomorrow.

The Republican party has always stood and stands today for obedience to and enforcement of the law as the very foundation of orderly government and civilization. There can be no national security otherwise. The duty of the President of the United States and the officers of the law is clear. The law must be enforced as they find it enacted by the people. To these courses of action we pledge our nominees.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Shipping Board today authorized the Merchant Fleet Corporation to negotiate with the various contending Boston factions to ascertain whether they can agree on specifications for a lease of the Boston army base pier property for private operation in the interest of the community.

Raw steel was produced in the last week at a national average of 15 per pent of capacity, compared with 16 per cent in the week before, and indications are that operations will be reduced still further by the Independence Day shutdown, according to The Iron Age.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 29. -- The New Jersey State Department of Banking and Insurance was asked to make an investigation of the Bank-italia Company of this city following the arrest here today of Edward Yuliano, 39 years old, of 131 Hudson Street, on a charge of failing to account for money said to have been entrusted to his care by Italian residents of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Cantonese offensive against the insurgent stronghold on the large island of Hainan, southwest of Canton and east of French Indo-China, was ordered after negotiations had failed for a reconciliation between the Cantonese and Admiral Chan.

AVON, Conn., June 29. -- A surprise was staged today at the second day of the Avon (Conn.) Bay State meeting when Signal Spier, 2:041/4, star of the Shamrock Stable of Pueblo, Col., defeated the 2-1 favorite Azure Volo, 2:03, in the 2:12 pace.

CRAMERTON, N.C., June 29 (AP). -- Stuart W. Cramer, textile manufacturer and a leader in the National Republican party, and Mrs. Cramer today announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Katherine Cramer Woodman of Ardmore, Pa., to Dr. James Rowland Angell, of New Haven, Conn., president of Yale University.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The statesmen surrendered the platform to professional entertainers at this morning's session of the Democratic National Convention, but the crowd in the galleries roared repeated demands for Jimmy Walker and Huey P. Long, the junior Senator from Louisiana and the only "Kingfish" at this solemn conclave.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The wet plank adopted by the Democratic platform committee at Chicago caused a buzz of comment in the Senate corridors this afternoon.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29. -- Miss Helen Jacobs swept into the women's final of the British tennis championships today with a clear-cut victory over Mme. Rene Mathieu of France, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1.

Count Lazlo Szechenyi, Hungarian Minister to the United States, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, accompanied by his daughter, Miss Cornelia Szechenyi, for his annual vacation.

PARIS, June 29. -- The Bourse remained uninfluenced today by news from Lausanne, although trading was extremely restricted. Suez Canal, Royal Dutch Oil and the gold mining shares were active and high, but most of the domestic stocks declined slightly.

CHICAGO, Thursday, June 30. -- Early this morning the Democratic party went as wet as the seven seas at the fourth session of its national convention in the Stadium. By an overwhelming majority the delegates sustained the majority plank in the platform which puts the party on record as favoring outright repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and immediate modification or the Volstead act to permit the manufacture and sale of beer.

To the unfortunate person who has almost forgotten the feel of cold cash, talk about an international barter system must sound remote and unhelpful. When he reads that thirty thousand tons of coal have been exchanged for forty thousand pairs of boots, he sees himself no nearer to a new pair of shoes for his own feet or means of paying for the Winter's fuel.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP). -- Josedale, driven by Dr. H.M. Parshall, Urbana, Ohio, upset auction speculators today by trotting a straight-heat victory in the twenty-second renewal of the Old Tavern Steak classic at North Randall.

Patrolman David Fay, a member of the fledgling police sanitation squad, stole the show from Police Commissioner Mulrooney, Sanitation Commissioner Schroeder and others at a meeting yesterday afternoon of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association in the trial room at Police Headquarters.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 29. -- Miss Jane McCullough of Huntingdon Valley won the women's invitation golf tournament at the Skytop Club today by finishing the fifty-four holes with a medal total of 266. Her scores by rounds were 89, 89, 88.

LATONIA, Ky., June 29 (AP). -- Brownell Combs's 5-year-old mare Manta showed a return to form which carried her to triumphs in renewals of the Independence and Enquirer Handicaps here last Summer, when she accounted for the Highland Stock Farm Purse, today's principal offering.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will issue forty-eight feature films during the 1932-33 production season, acccording to the schedule Issued by the company yesterday. Among the outstanding items on the list is Eugene O'Neill's "Strange Interlude," which retains the asides used in the play.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 29. -- Harold Schein of Newark and Richard Hebard of White Plains gained the semi-finals of the Northern New Jersey junior tennis championship today at the East Orange Tennis Club.

One of the few leasehold deals announced in Manhattan yesterday was of a Lenox Hill house which was rented furnished to Alexander P. Morgan, who is connected with the firm of Shreve, Lamb Harmon, architects. The property consists of a five-story American basement dwelling at 111 East Seventy-first Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Reading THE TIMES editorial on the problem of the slum, and answering your final question, "Is it possible that out of our adversity may come new hope for the healing of this chronic sore?" I say, emphatically, yes!

MEXICO CITY, June 29. -- Governor Adalberto Tejeda of the State of Vera Cruz is convinced that the Federal Government eventually will agree with him as to the soundness of the recently authorized policy in his State of expropriation of private property by decree of the Governor.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 29. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr. of St. Paul's School, who won the medal in the qualifying round of the Eastern interscholastic golf championship yesterday, reached the semi-finals of the tourney today. After defeating Frank McClintock of Choate in the first round, 1 up, this morning, he then won his match against Jack Malloy of Andover this affternoon, 4 and 2, in the quarter-final round.

HAVANA, June 29. -- Cuba made today full interest and amortization payments falling due on June 30 on all outstanding foreign obligations, in the amount of approximately $9,500,000, thus liquidating these obligations for the fiscal year 1931-32.

Captain Henry A.T. Candy, commander of the liner Pennsylvania of the Panama Pacific Line, will retire after forty-five years at sea in sail and steam when his ship arrives here on Aug. 1 from California.

Americans were long solemnly urged never to let prohibition get into politics. Those who themselves got it enacted by adroit political means were almost tearful when urging that it be not allowed to become an issue between parties or within parties.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, in its third supplemental application to the Interstate Commerce Commission, today reduced by another $1,000,000 the loan it has requested by July 1, from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Jersey City gained a 2-1 advantage in the current five-game series with Baltimore by turning back the Orioles, 14 to 5 and 5 to 4, in a double-header at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

With rains again general in Southern States, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose sharply yesterday on the heaviest turn-over in some time. July contracts, which early this month sold at 4.91 cents a pound, reached 5.41 cents, or an improvement of a half-cent.

TRENTON, N.J., June 29. -- Once the leading agricultural county in New Jersey, Hunterdon County now has 300 abandoned farms covering a total area of 24,000 acres, it was pointed out by the State Department of Agriculture today, in a report in which it attributed this condition to the movement of farm youths to cities, lack of agricultural equipment, high mortgages, poor roads and inexperienced farmers.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the heaviest thus far this month, but it failed to develop any pronounced trend in prices, except in the case of United States Government securities, which turned weak. Losses for the Liberty Loans and Treasury issues ranged from 1-32 to 29-32 point, the Liberty first 4 1/4s and the Treasury 3 3/8s, due in 1943, and callable in 1940, representing the extremes.

LONDON, June 29 (Canadian Press). -- With few exceptions, bowlers had the whip-hand as a series of first-class cricket matches got under way today throughout England. Freeman of Kent took eight Warwickshire wickets for 31 runs at Folkestone, Warwickshire being dismissed for 129 runs.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 30. -- Instructions to oppose the proposal of President Hoover for reduction of armaments were sent today by the navy office to the Japanese naval delegation at the arms conference in Geneva.

PARIS, June 29. -- France is trying hard not to believe tonight that the negotiations at Lausanne will collapse, but without much success. The press is restrained editorially, but the news items do not disguise the facts and official circles are deeply discouraged.
In the vicinity of Ambrose Lightship last week Francis Low of Woodmere, L.I., sighted a marlin, but was unable to fulfill an ambition of hooking into one of these big fish.

No other three men are doing more to build "the New Asia" than are those "pioneers of a better world," Gandhi in India, Hu-shin in China and Kagawa in Japan, Dr. Kenneth Saunders asserts in his book, "The Heritage of Asia," just published by the Macmillan Company.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 29. -- Continuing his drive in defense of his title, Richard Murphy, Hamilton College star of Utica, N.Y., won handily from Harold MacGuffin of Philadelphia in the quarter-final of the fortieth annual New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 29. -- Robert W. Whitlow, 17-year-old graduate of the Tulsa Central High School, Tulsa, Okla., who won first prize in the essay contest conducted by the League of Nations Association, arrived here today for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Thomas, members of the association.

RYE. N.Y., June 29. -- More than 400 employes of railroads and transit lines in the vicinity of New York City sat down with railroad presidenis to a cornedbeef and cabbage dinner tonight in the dining room of the Westchester Country Club.

About 2,400 young men were designated yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, United States Army, to attend the basic and infantry course of the citizens' military training camp at Plattsburg Barracks, Plattsburg, N.Y.

A new drive to enlist 250,000 more women in New York State against prohibition to adduce proof of repeal sentiment in "dry" districts was mapped yesterday at the first general Meeting of the newly formed Women's Hotel Committee of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, in the Hotel Vanderbilt.

The Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, World War chaplain of the "Fighting Sixty-ninth" Regiment, was buried yesterday afternoon in St. Raymond's Cemetery, the Bronx, while the Ninth Observation Squadron of twenty-eight army planes circled in tribute overhead and a rifle salute was fired at the grave.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The committee on resolutions of the Democratic party has accepted the challenge of the Republican convention. A dripping wet plank demanding beer and straight, immediate repeal came surging out of the committee room to the floor of the convention.

Two members of the Los Angeles Athletic Club, Conrad Caldwell and Jack Van Bebber, advanced a step further toward the retention of national wrestling championships which they won a year ago by scoring victories in their matches at the National A.A.U. tournament at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night.

With field deputies of the Department of Taxes and Assessments winding up today their final first three months' work on the 1933 property valuations for New York's five boroughs, realty interests predicted that for the first time in many years the aggregate value of taxable realty would show a decrease when the final figures for next year were compiled.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 29. -- The classic rowing festival, the Royal Henley regatta, began brilliantly today with the largest first day attendance in years.

TOKYO, June 29. -- The Japanese Government will advise Manchukuo and China to accept a compromise on their customs dispute, whereby the Chinese customs office in Dairen in the Japanese leased territory of Kwantung would remain in Chinese control, while all the other ports of entry in Manchuria would be taken over by Manchukuo.

Three important members of Copper Exporters, Inc., the single sailing agency abroad for copper producers, announced yesterday that, beginning today, they would sell their product outside of the organization. The imposition by the United States of a tariff on copper of 4 cents a pound, which went into effect on June 21, was given as the reason for their decision.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., June 29. -- With a record-breaking 69, Johnny Farrell of Mamaroneck, N.Y., took the lead at the end or the opening eighteen holes of play in the Massachusetts State open golf championship at the Oyster Harbors Club today.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Stepenfetchit, one of the favorites for the $70,000 added American Classic, disappointed his followers in the Garfield Handicap today, losing to Evergold, an outsider, by a head at Arlington Park.

TORONTO, June 29. (Canadian Press). -- Rain brought the first game played in Eastern Canada by the touring Australian cricketers to an abrupt conclusion today with the visiting players in a good position to score a decisive victory over an all-star Toronto team. The match was declared drawn.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Production of automobiles increased 36,823 cars throughout the United States during May over the preceding month to a total of 185,149, the Commerce Department announced today on the basis of reported factory sales by 144 manufacturers.

State of Arkansas. The Supreme Court of Arkansas has sustained laws passed by the State Legislature providing for the refunding of bonds of various road districts through the exchange of State revenue bonds, according to word received here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Today's session of the Democratic convention was opened with an invocation delivered by the Rev. Duncan Hodge Browne, rector of St. James's Episcopal Cathedral of Chicago. It was as follows:

LONDON, June 29. -- The New Jersey police were cleared of a thirddegree charge in the report of the British Consul at New York in the recent suicide of Miss Violet Sharpe, who was a maid in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, mother-in-law of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- Federal Trade Commission hearings over the financial structure of the Associated Gas and Electric Company drew to the close of another phase today as Chief Council Robert E. Healy questioned Examiner Charles Nodder upon the long-term indebtedness of the company.

CINCINNATI, June 29. -- What has been criticized as the extravagance of local governmnts is not the exravagance of governments as such but of the American people, transferred out of private life to State and nunicipal budgets, said Clarence A. Dykstra, Cincinnati City Manager, peaking at the first general session of the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

BOSTON, June 29. -- Amelia Earhart Putnam, once social settlement worker in Boston, came home today for a welcome from the city whence she started on her first flight to fame. Thousands hailed her as the first woman to fly the Atlantic, the only woman to fly it alone and the only aviator of either sex to make the hazardous flight twice in a heavier-than-air machine.

GENEVA, June 29. -- Mrs. Robert Pell, wife of the American delegation's press attache at the disarmament conference, was saved from drowning today by Ernest Schelling, American pianist, when she was exhausted from a courageous fight for her life.

The only way to reduce the cost of government is to abolish every governmental activity which is not actually essential to the well-being of the people and to discontinue every governmental service which citizens can and should provide for themselves, John M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman of the committee on public relations of the Eastern Railroad President's Conference, said last night in a radio address.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 29. -- The first two seeded players, Miss Sally Childress and Miss Wynfred Fox, respectively, today gained the final round of the girls' Westchester County championship tennis singles tournament at the County Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Federal Judge Walter C. Lindley today instructed the receivers of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., to discontinue operation of the company and to proceed with the liquidation of its assets for the benefit of creditors.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- An upward revision of fees for registration of domestic mail matter, and other innovations provided in a bill signed last night by President Hoover, which are expected to result in savings by the government of $7,000,000 annually, were announced today by the Postoffice Department.

VIENNA, June 29. -- How the growth of the nationalistic spirit in Europe has added to the miseries of racial minorities in all countries was described at today's opening sitting of the eighth European Congress of Nationalities.

Bank clearings this week at twenty-two leading cities in the United States, as reported to Dun's Review, were $3,782,960,000, a decline of 56.5 per cent from the same week in 1931. Clearings at New York City were $2,433,063,000, a decrease of 61.3 per cent, while the total for the cities outside of New York was $1,349,897,000, which was 44.0 per cent smaller than a year ago.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 30. -- The "country fair," sponsored by about 300 prominent women, was opened this afternoon, the proceeds to be devoted to three charities, the Boys' Club, the Social Service League, Inc., and the Greenwich Day Nursery.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June 30. -- The Summer season here will open on Saturday with festivals at the Thousand Islands Yacht Club and the Thousand Islands Country Club.

Owen D. Young, who announced recently that he would not be a candidate for Presidential nomination, is quoted in an interview in the July 9 issue of Colliers as maintaining that his record in the past has made him "immune" to such candidacy. Parts of the interview were released by the publishers yesterday.

An estate of $3,256,458 gross, reduced to $3,026,157 by debts and expenses, was left by William Lawrence Saunders, chairman of the board of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, when he died on June 25, 1931, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday with the State Tax Commission here.

Holders of 5 per cent serial gold notes of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, due on Aug. 15, have received offers of a par for par exchange of first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds of the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company, due in 1962, as a result of arrangements made between the General company and the Associated Gas and Electric Securities Company.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 30. -- Two soldiers of the Bolivian Army were put to death on June 14 and two others were imprisoned for life as Paraguayan spies, it was revealed today.

BERLIN, June 30. -- The chief task of the German delegation at the conference of the foreign private creditors under the standstill agreement that is scheduled to begin in London tomorrow will be to get interest rates, now averaging 6 to 7 per cent, reduced to 2 to 3 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- The City Commission and business men of Chicago Heights today declared a business moratorium, to extend until Wednesday, as a means of restoring business confidence in the community.

More than $1,000,000,000 in gold now held in the United States Assay Office in Wall Street will be transported in the next few weeks to the new Assay Office at South "Street and Old Slip. There will be from 350 to 400 truckloads of the precious metal, the largest shipment of gold aver made.

The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices advanced sharply again to 90.6 on Tuesday, in the second week of recovery. The June monthly average declined slightly to 88.6, a. new low for that compilation.

Block-aiders reported new cash contributions of $32,279.48 for the thirteenth week of the campaign, it was announced yesterday by Wilton LloydSmith, chairman of the Block Community Organization. The total to date amounts to $1.115.101.33.

Gold in the amount of $4,447,600 was removed from earmark here yesterday by the Bank of France and shipped to Paris. The transfer, which was the only gold transaction of the day, followed a similar one of $4,546,000 made by the Bank of France on Wednesday.

William H. Collins, who was arrested on June 21 as a fugitive from a California prison from which he escaped in 1913, succeeded yesterday in winning at least temporary freedom from the Tombs prison here on $1,000 bail set by Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh in habeas corpus proceedings.
Two sales of residential properties by estates were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

One question to which frequent reference appears in dispatches from Lausanne is whether Germany, relieved of reparations, would enjoy an unfair advantage in competition for world trade. The argument is that extreme Inflation in 1922 and 1923 wiped out Germany's internal debt.

Another score for Trainer James Fitzsimmons and Jockey Hank Mills was chalked up at Aqueduct yesterday when the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret got home first in the featured Speculation Claiming Handicap, which had a value of $3,150 to the winner.

Predictions of better things in store are heavily discounted these days. But when they come from persons able to deliver the goods, they are entitled to a respectful and even grateful hearing. Mr. RICHARD J. DELEHANTY is chief deputy of real estate in the Department of Taxes and Assessments.

Whether it Is in Forty-fifth Street, in Greenwich Village or high above Forty-second Street, the Summer drama remains hopeless. Last night's little dandy, presented, for no apparent reason, in the Chanin Auditorium on the fiftieth floor of the like-named building, was "Destruction," a play attacking communism.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending June 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,354,000,000, an increase of $59,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,400,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

CLEVELAND, June 30. -- Alfred Sargent remembered all of his famous golfing father's lessons at Canterbury today and responded with a record-equaling 69 that shoved him ahead of a tightly bunched field in the opening eighteen-hole skirmish for the Western open championship.
CHICAGO, June 30. -- The following prayer at the night session of the Democratic convention was made by the Rev. Dr. Paul Wolfe, of the First Presbyterian Church of Evanston. Ill.:

A reduction of 12 per cent In the wages of photo-engravers employed by the Publishers' Association of New York was announced last night by the arbitration board which had considered the demand of the publishers for a 20 per cent decrease.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- All the gains made in the reduction of money circulation since the anti-hoarding drive was started early in February were wiped out in the week ended yesterday, when circulation bounded upward by $144,000,000, chiefly as a result of the troubled banking situation in Chicago, according to the report of the Federal Reserve Board.

The first large group of foreign invaders for the Olympic Games at Los Angeles arrived in the United States yesterday when an advance guard of eighteen Swedish athletes reached New York on the M.S. Gripsholm. An even larger number of Swedish competitors is due in another fortnight, thus bringing their total representation close to the fifty mark.

Fluctuations in the commodity markets were mixed, advances and declines being distributed irregularly through the list. Grains were easier, as were coffee, rubber and cocoa. Improvement was noted in cotton, silk and hides. Other articles were steady.

OSSININO, N.Y., June 30. -- Twelve minutes after they were to have been put to death at Sing Sing tonight, Frank Giordano, 32 years old, and Dominick Odierno, 20, Bronx gangsters, received a twenty-four-hour reprieve from Governor Roosevelt. The two men were dressed for the electric chair and waiting in the pre-execution cells when the Executive postponement was conveyed by telephone to Warden Lewis E. Lawes.

The prohibition plank of the Democratic platform, with the sensation attending its drafting and adoption, naturally "stole the show" from all the rest of it. But the achievement of writing a platform within so narrow a frame and with so sparing a use of words to conceal thought is itself noteworthy in our political annals.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 30. -- C.J. Rockwood, receiver for the W.B. Foshay Company, who intervened in two actions brought in Hennepin County District Court by minority stockholders of the company against W.B. Foshay, H.H. Henley, C.W. Salisbury and H.E. McGinty as officers and directors, is entitled to judgment of $540,969.93 against the defendants, under terms of an order filed Thursday by Judge W.C. Leary.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The long-debated and frequently amended economy bill, passed by the House and Senate after two months' consideration and a week's deadlock on the conference report, was signed by President Hoover today, in his own words with "limited satisfaction."

The Grand Central Galleries have established the custom of exhibiting a fresh group of prints each month. The show that opens today and that will be continued until Aug. 1 contains work by Childe Hassam, Gustave Baumann, John Sloan, Abbo Ostrowsky, William C. McNulty, R. W. Woiceske and the famous tennis star, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, whose graphic work was for several years been familiar to the art public.

LAUSANNE, June 30. -- Throughout an ideal Summer day, in an inner room at the Hotel Beau Rivage, shut away from the beauties of Lac Leman, a historic meeting was in progress today. It was the struggle of experts of five of the inviting powers of this conference to devise a plan for getting rid of reparation payments and substituting something else that can be submitted to Germany and that Germany will accept.
CHICAGO, Friday, July 1. -- After a double session, the second of which lasted into the morning hours, nine candidates for the Presidency were placed in nomination at the Democratic convention.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30. -- Favorites came through today in both singles matches played in the New Jersey State championship tennis tourney at the Montclalr Athletic Club.

Because some of the so-called pivotal stocks were sold somewhat aggressively at times it was assumed that this was the cause of the general heaviness on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The market was higher at the opening than at the previous close, but reactionary influences were felt before the end of the first hour.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- The Board of City Trusts vetoed a request from Mayor Moore today for a $10,000,000 gift from the residuary estate of Stephen Girard to aid the city in its fiscal troubles. The board agreed, however, to consider the purchase of $5,000,000 or more of municipal bonds.

BOXING. There's a rough sport. In a recent fight for the world's heavyweight championship, one of the bold bruisers actually got a black eye. Yachting. That's a "sissy" sport for rich fellows who like to wear white pants. Certainly it is. All you have to know is a thousand things about running and standing gear, sheets and spars, canvas and calking, charts and chronometers, wind, weather and water.

The annual exodus of holiday makers from the city over the Fourth of July, combined with the departure of Summer vacationists including thousands of boy and girl campers, was in full swing last night and is expected to reach its peak this afternoon.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30 (AP). -- The 20-year-old son of a wealthy manufacturer was held tonight by kidnappers, who threaten death unless $35,000 ransom is paid

The decision of the vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie was made public yesterday requesting the withdrawal of the clinic which was Installed in the church ten years ago by Dr. William Norman Guthrie, as rector, in the hope of reaching many troubled souls by religion after their bodily ills had been repaired by medicine.

As women will when they get together, Mrs. James J. Walker and Miss Theresa McGinity got to discussing illnesses yesterday afternoon at the Polyclinlc Hospital, where the former Is rapidly recovering from an abdominal operation while her husband, the Mayor; is In Chicago on important political business.

BERLIN, June 30. -- The Boerse displayed strength today, stimulated by a demand for bonds. Although bonds did not advance, due to the large amount of orders still unexecuted, the recent decline was interrupted. Stocks advanced in early trading as much as 2 per cent in some instances.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday . .2 1/2, per cent for the best names. Wednesday . . 2 1/3 per cent for the beat names. The quotations are for three-four, months' paper.

Testimony that the late Ivar Kreuger withdrew $60,000 from his bank accounts In this country shortly before he left New York for Paris, where he committed suicide early this year, was introduced yesterday before Henry K. Davis, sitting as a special master in the Federal Court proceedings to determine whether an American receiver shall be appointed for the Krueger Toll Company.

Two women, one in Brooklyn and the other on the lower east side of Manhattan, were wounded yesterday by the bullets of gangsters fired presumably at other persons. Both women were on streets in front of their homes when shot.
PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's first-place Pirates celebrated the twenty-third anniversary of the opening of Forbes Field today by winning a see-saw slugfest from, the Cardinals, 9 do 6.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Mrs. Isabella Greenway, who came all the way from Arizona to second the Presidential nomination of Governor Roosevelt, ably fulfilled her task before the Democratic National Convention, today and was rewarded with the plaudits of the 20,000 delegates, alternates and spectators who jammed the hall.

Interest payments aggregating $47,435,347 will be available today to the 5,777,737 depositors in mutual savings banks in New York State, bringing the total of such disbursements up to $577,761,597 since Oct. 1, 1929, the approximate time from which the depression dates.

LONDON, June 30 (Canadian Press). -- The Prince of Wales, in an address read by his brother, Prince George, at a dinner tonight bidding farewell to the British delegation to the imperial conference at Ottawa called for cooperation of the empire In leading the world back to a sound economic base.

DUBLIN, June 30. -- Although it was not unexpected here, the British Government's decision to obtain by tariffs the Irish land annuities has aroused deep, widespread alarm throughout the Free State. It was the principal subject of talk in Dublin today.

MEXICO CITY, June 30. -- A strike of Pullman car and sleeping car employes began at 1:30 P.M. today on all lines of the Mexican National Railway. Leaders of the Alliance of Mexican Railway Employes met representatives of the railroads at noon, but were unable to reach an agreement on wages and other issues.

GENEVA, June 30. -- With a brief resumption of the Anglo-Franco-American talks today, preceded by a meeting of the French and American delegations the issues and line-up in this stage of the manoeuvres over President Hoover's disarmament proposals became clearer.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 30. -- The odyssey of John H. Curtis, self-styled "negotiator" for the return of the Lindbergh baby, was related here by three police witnesses during the fourth day of his trial for deliberately hindering the search for the kidnappers of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30. -- Ellsworth Vines flashed through to the Wimbledon tennis final today and instantly proved himself one of the greatest players England has known.

The one event of importance in the markets yesterday was the Bank of England's reduction of its rate to 2 per cent, the lowest in its history and not reached since 1897. In a measure, this reduction was doubtless forced by the decline in open-market London discounts to the neighborhood of 1 per cent, but it was also accepted as a sign that London high finance sees quiet weather ahead in international finance.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30. -- The London Rowing Club's first eight gained an easy victory over the French crew, Societe Nautique de la Marne, in the first heat of the Grand Challenge Cup event today at the Henley regatta.

Cornelius D. McNerney, 48 years old, unsaliried enforcement agent for the Lord's Day Alliance, which for years has actively engaged in suppressing violations of the Sunday closing law, was sentenced to prison for from two to five years by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday.

The coast-tocoast networks of the countryset a new record last night for continous broadcasting from a national political convention. WEAF and WJZ facilities signed on the air from the Chicago Stadium at 10:26 and 10:45 o'clock, respectively. WABC's chain went on at 10:30 P.M.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter headed "Chance in Small Business" that recently appeared in THE TIMES had real substance to it.

CHICAGO. June 30. -- The Democratic National Convention, with one loud vote of "aye," adopted the report of its resolutions committee early this afternoon and thus defined the issues upon which in the November elections it will seek the trust of administering the Federal Government.
Elaborate festivities are being prepared at Long Island beach clubs for the July 4 week-end holiday.

LONDON, June 30. -- The stock markets were cheerful today following the reduction of the bank rate to 2 per cent and better news from Lausanne. Strong buying of British Government funds was resumed at the opening, although profit-taking caused a setback.
Realty trading in Manhattan yesterday was about equally divided between leasehold deals and changes in fee ownerships.

Last Summer several hundred towns and counties carried out successful food-conservation programs for the benefit of both the unemployed and families of low income. Many more are planning similar "preserving bees" this year. To show them what has already been done and to help them avoid mistakes, the President's organization on unemployment relief has published the story of a few typical community kitchens.

HAMILTON, Ohio, June 30 (AP). -- Seven persons were killed and five injured in the head-on collision today of a fast electric passenger car and a heavily-loaded freight car of the Cincinnati Lake Erie Railroad.

Negotiations looking to a renewal for one year of acceptance credits of the Nitrate Corporation of Chile, or Cosach, the $350,000,000 Chilean nitrate monopoly, which are held by bankers here and in London, are being carried on, and are expected to be concluded successfully soon.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 30. -- House guests of Summer residents are arriving for the holiday weekend. On the Maidstone Club courts the tennis season will open with the playing of the mixed doubles on Saturday and on Tuesday the women's singles tournament for the John Drew Memorial Cup will be played.

Yesterday's reduction of the Bank of England's official discount-rate to 2 per cent is in its way historic. Perhaps for the first time since prewar days it is now lower than any other bank rate in the world. No lower rate has ever been fixed in the history of the bank itself, and it is nearly thirty-five years since a 2 per cent bank rate last existed at London.
