PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- Four agents of the Internal Revenue Bureau, acting on orders from Acting Collector William E. Brown, are investigating the bank accounts, financial dealings and income tax returns of William D.B. Ainey, chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission.

Applications for reductions in assessments on real estate broke all records yesterday, when the County Clerk's office in the basement of the County Court House at 60 Centre Street received twice as many applications as had ever been received in one day. Yesterday was the last day allowed for filing applications for Supreme Court writs of certiorari to obtain a judicial review of the 1932 assessments imposed by the Board of Taxes and Assessments.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Rear Admiral William F. MacDougall today relinquished command of the Fifth Naval District at Norfolk and of the Hampton Roads Naval Operating Base. He will retire from the navy tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The very real dilemma in which proponents of the Republican plan of Federal protection to dry States inevitably find themselves is illustrated by the able letters, printed In your columns, of Noel T. Cowling and John W. Hutchlnson.
ALBANY, N.Y., Friday, July 1. -- Governor Roosevelt spent a happy and confident afternoon in the Executive Mansion yesterday listening to his cohorts in Chicago presenting his Presidential candidacy.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP). -- Testifying Mervyn Le Roy, film director, packed his belongings and told her he would never return, Edna Murphy, stage and screen actress, received a divorce from him today on grounds of desertion.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 30. -- Miss Sally Childress won the girls' Westchester County tennis singles championship today, defeating Miss Wynfred Fox in the final at the County Tennis Club. 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1. Miss Childress was the runner-up last year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- Falling before one of the Phillies' famous assaults, during which base hits rattled off the tall right field barrier like shrapnel, the Dodgers lost today's closing engagement, 9 to 3, and tumbled into sixth place. The Phillies, meanwhile, rose to fourth, supplanting the Cardinals, who fell to fifth.

PARIS, June 30. -- Premier Herriot is returning from Lausanne tomorrow to examine financial projects which, according to declarations made by Budget Minister Maurice Palmade before the Chamber Finance Committee today, require urgent attention because of the rapidly growing deficit.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- Details of receiverships handled by Harry G. Hendricks and C. Wallace Vail, two men often appointed by Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church, and accounts of his efforts to save them from difficulties, occupied a large part of the third day of the chancery receivership investigation.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP). -- A six-run rally in the fourth, opened with a homer by Elias Funk, tied the White Sox with the Browns, who had amassed an early lead, but St. Louis added a run in its half of the frame for a 7-6 victory today.

Continued rains over a large section of the South had more influence yesterday than earlier in the week on prices on the Cotton Exchange, and under the largest volume of business in several months, all deliveries advanced more than $1 a bale. The final quotations were 20 to 25 points higher than on Wednesday and nearly 3/4 cent above the low levels of the month.
Bass fishermen who do not find time to greet the opening of the season in New York today no doubt will take an opportunity to do so during the holiday week-end.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Evening up by July longs in wheat and spreading between deliveries furnished most of the trading again today on the Board of Trade here. Demonstrations of buying by local professionals failed to have much effect except briefly at the opening, when fairly general purchases carried the December to around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.

AVON, Conn., June 30. -- Three favorites lost in the Bay State circuit harness races at Cherry Park today, Calumet Calling, The Bloomer Girl and Ninety-Three being defeated by Turney English, Toll Gate and Hollyrood Brown, respectively.

A substantial rally in United States Government bonds and leading foreign loans and about an even distribution of gains and losses throughout the domestic corporation list, characterized dealings in those issues yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Trading totaled $9,081,000, compared with $14,245,000 on the previous day, the turnover in the Federal Government's issues amounting to only $2,373,000, against $7,129,000 on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Friday, July 1. -- The first ballot on the Presidential nomination, taken by the Democratic National Convention at 7:15 o'clock, Eastern daylight time, this morning gave Governor Roosevelt of New York 666 1/4 votes, 103 3/4 votes short of the two-thirds, 770 necessary for nomination.

CHICAGO, Friday, July 1. -- With the Democratic National Convention approaching its hour of decision on candidates, former Governor Smith found it necessary yesterday to deny rumors that he was going to quit the race and release his delegates.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Anti-prohibition leaders attending the Democratic convention and the wets generally were outspoken today in approval of the convention's action in incorporating in the party's platform a pledge to repeal the dry law and bring about quick modification of the Volstead act to legalize the sale of beer.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Wet leaders in the House and Senate were planning tonight to force a vote on modification of the Volstead act if Congress could be held in session after the conclusion of the Democratic National Convention. Elated over the dripping wet plank adopted at Chicago, the wets of both parties were consolidating their forces for an immediate grand assault on prohibition.

Dividends declared in June were much smaller than a year ago. The total for 1,382 corporations was $268,778,528, the smallest amount for any June in five years. It compared with $280,545,315 for 688 corporations in May and with $485,136,043 for 1,945 corporations in June, 1931.

A list of seventy-eight successful candidates selected to attend the cavalry course of the Citizens' Military Training Camp at Fort Myer, Va., was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, United States Army.

The Phlegmatic English. The old tradition that the English people are never swept away by waves of excitement or international suspicion is harder than ever to believe in view of the recent flurry in the House of Commons and in the London press over the suicide here of an English maid connected, or supposed to be, with the Lindbergh kidnapping.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CHICAGO, June 30. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-fashioned Indiana Democrat, was discovered slipping out into the lobby of the convention hall Just as Senator Connally arose to nominate Garner.

Among the passengers sailing tonight on the Holland-America liner Rotterdam are Margaret Sanger, exponent of the birth control movement; John M. Tierney, justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York; Hendrik Willem van Loon, author and historian, with Mrs. Loon, and Tytus Filipowicz, Polish Ambassador to the United States, who will be accompanied by his secretary, Thaddeus Zazulinski.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Receivership for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company was averted today through an eleventh-hour decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission, approving a further loan of $3,390,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

BERKELEY, Cal., June 30 (AP). -- Stars of the collegiate track and field world will assemble here tomorrow in an attack on times and distances, with prospects that the fifty-sixth annual I.C.A.A.A.A. championships will be of the greatest in the history of this old-time rivalry.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Stephen G. Williams have gone to Doublebrook, their place in Westport, Conn., and probably will make it their permanent home.

Two suits in the Supreme Court were filed yesterday against William Fox, former motion-picture executive whose financial operations recently engaged the attention of the Senate committee on banking and currency. One, begun in Mineola by the Fox Film Corporation, involves an undetermined amount estimated variously between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Dry leaders, after their severest defeat in the twelve years of controversy over national prohibition by the adoption of the repeal plank by the Democratic convention, declared today that millions of Democrats would refuse to follow a dripping wet banner next Fall and that the party would be doomed to defeat.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30. -- Contending that thousands of schools have already been seriously injured by unwise and often unnecessary curtailments and that many school systems are now being threatened with financial starvation, the resolutions committee of the National Education Association announced today the text of a resolution to be offered tomorrow to the annual convention.

Emmet J. McCormack, president of the New York Maritime Exchange and vice president of Moore McCormack, shipping agents and operators, made a statement yesterday advocating conversion of the site of old Fort Schuyler, on Throgs Neck, the Bronx, for the use of the New York Merchant Marine Academy.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- Charlie Grimm led an extra-base hit barrage on Red Lucas, and Guy Bush pitched shutout baseball today to give the Cubs a 7-to-0 victory over Cincinnati in the series opener.

NUTLEY, N.J., June 30. -- For the second successive year the mother and daughter championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was won today by Mrs. Joseph Millang and Miss Dorothy Millang of the Old Country Club in Flushing, L.I.

PARIS, June 30. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, who fought for a prohibition repeal plank in the Republican convention, was emphatic in his praise of the Democratic repeal plank when interviewed here today. Although he predicted that "the Hoover straddle plank is doomed to the fate which it invites and deserves," he refused to commit himself as to whether it would induce him to vote for the Democratic candidate in November.

State and local Republican leaders declined yesterday to comment on the "wringing wet" repeal plank adopted by the Democratic National Convention at Chicago. But they admitted unofficially their concern over its probable effect upon Republican rotors throughout the State who are dissatisfied with the liquor plank adopted by their party two weeks ago.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 30. -- Firm opposition to Federal control of the nation's schools was expressed in a resolution by the National Catholic Educational Association today as it closed its convention here.

Many changes in Stock Exchange firms and other organizations operating in the financial district will become effective today, at the beginning of the second half of the year. Among the changes are mergers of brokerage firms, and reorganizations of investment houses.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- State legislation to compel the establishment by industries of unemployment insurance reserves was advocated today by a Senate committee.

LONDON, June 30 (Canadian Press). -- Kent defeated Warwickshire by 74 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluding today at Folkstone. Kent scored 174 and 169, Warwickshire 129 and 148. Freeman, crack Kent bowler, took eight Warwickshire wickets for 31 in the first innings and nine for 61 in the second.

LONDON, June 30. -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons tonight announced the long-awaited conversion of the 5 per cent war loan of 1929-47 into a 3 1/2 per cent loan. [The amount of bonds to be converted is about $7,490,194,808 at yesterday's exchange rate.]

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Expiration of the Hoover holiday year on intergovernmental debts at midnight tonight was preceded a few hours by notification to the Treasury today by Greece that she would not make payment of $130,000 on account of principal of her debt of $30,292,000 to the United States, which falls due tomorrow, but would postpone it for two and one-half years under the moratorium provision of her debt-funding agreement.

CINCINNATI, June 30. -- "A militant minority" of publicity men, lobbyists and membership secretaries were charged with defeating the program of the New York State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws by State Senator Seabury C. Mastick of Pleasantville, N.Y.

BOSTON, June 30. -- Danny MacFayden, facing his former team-mates today for the first time, did his best pitching since joining the Yankees last month and with almost unanimous batting support from his teammates and little competition from the local aces had no trouble attaching his second victory as a McCarthy man-at-arms in the opener of a five-game series.

Factors "closely akin to subsidies" operating in favor of competitive forms of transportation adversely affected the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in 1931, Daniel Willard, president, said in his annual report, issued yesterday. The report shows that the average distance of movement of both passengers and freight on railways is increasing, which, conversely, shows that competitors are gaining more short-distance traffic.

MARION, Mass., June 30. -- The crew from St. Mark's School of Southboro, captained by E. Dwight Fullerton Jr., today won the interscholastic yacht racing championship and captured the Mallory Trophy for 1932.

One of the pettiest of extortion schemes yet known in the city was uncovered yesterday when more than fifty teachers, awaiting public school appointments, appeared at the Board of Education after receiving fake telegrams, which were delivered "collect" containing instructions to call at the office of the Board of Examiners for verification of "assignments."

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The United States, Great Britain and France, through their Ambassadors at Tokyo, have made representations to the Japanese Foreign Office urging that the Chinese customs administration be maintained intact, it was learned at the State Department today.

With Manager Bill Terry embellishing the proceedings with his fifteenth home run of the campaign, along with a couple of singles, and Freddy Lindstrom contributing another circuit clout, the Giants brought down the Braves in the opening encounter of a four-game series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Arlie Tomlinson, a graduate of Oklahoma A. and M. and holder of the National A.A.U. wrestling championship in the 145-pound class for 1929 and 1931, continued in the running for his third championship by winning his bout at the Madison Square Garden Bowl last night.

The State of Florida, which can issue bonds only for the purpose of "repelling invasion or suppressing insurrection," is now faced with the dilemma of owning more than one-fifth of the acreage of the State formerly in private hands, acquired when the former owners failed to pay their taxes.

The four bill dealers who had maintained the scale of open market discounts prevailing prior to the reduction of the rediscount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York last week yesterday fell into line with the three dealers who bad previously cut rates, establishing a uniform schedule at the lowest levels ever quoted.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 30. -- Edward H. Schmierer of Philadelphia, gunnery sergeant in the United States Marine Corps and Second Lieutenant in the Nicaraguan National Guard, was murdered in his sleep early this morning at San Isidro, in the central part of Nicaragua.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Economic issues will be supreme in the Presidential campaign, in the opinion of the conservative Democratic leaders. They observed today that while their party has taken a decisive position on the Eighteenth Amendment, its declarations on economic problems and its pledges to reduce governmental expenses by $1,000,000,000 will appeal more to the taxpayers than the repeal and modification plank.

To the Editor of The New York Times. The depression has forced smaller communities to close schools, and this will retard the educational progress of our future citizens. Teachers are doing their best to remedy the situation -- not only do they teach without being paid for it, but they also feed and comfort children in numerous places.

TOKYO, June 30. -- The objections of the Japanese Navy to President Hoover's disarmament proposals were detailed to your correspondent today following the dispatch of instructions to the Japanese naval delegate to the arms conference in Geneva.

Receivers were appointed yesterday for the National Electric Power Company, with assets approximating $600,000,000, and the National Public Service Corporation, its principal subsidiary. The two control all properties of the Middle West Utilities System in Eastern States, from Florida to Maine.

CHICAGO, Friday, July 1. -- Flags waved, bands played, whistles shrilled and the crowd roared all yesterday afternoon and last night and way into the early hours of this morning as the Democrats, in national convention assembled, began in their quiet way to get two-thirds of their number to agree upon a Presidential nominee.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Alien observed their fortieth wedding anniversary this afternoon at their Summer home. The Mount, with a reception and tea for seventy or eighty guests. Mr. and Mrs. Alien were later joined by their son.

If agreements between Governments are good for anything, Great Britain has a perfect case in respect to the land annuities. In 1923 and again in 1926 the Free State Government undertook to pay the frill amount due from time to time at agreed intervals.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 30. -- Cool and resolute in the face of a more experienced player, Miss Helen Germaine of New York today upset Mrs. Agnes Sherwood Lamme of Rye, seeded fourth, to achieve the semifinal bracket of the women's metropolitan clay-court championship tourney at the Lido Country Club.

Hendrik Willem van Loon, who is sailing tonight for Europe on the Rotterdam, thinks that within the next few months "the Junker element will get hold of things in Germany" and that "they will make the usual mistakes, for that class never learns anything."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 30. -- William Dear of Great Neck, L.I., won the annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship over the course of the Greenwich Country Club today by defeating Charley Mayo Jr. of Flushing, L.I., 2 and 1.

To reduce the number of accidents which result in the loss of eyesight, the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, at 450 Seventh Avenue, recommended yesterday the prohibition of the manufacture and sale of dangerous toys such as air rifles, cap pistols, slingshots, bows and arrows, darts, toy guns and other devices for projecting missiles, as well as the sale of firecrackers and torpedoes.

CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell did a good job of pitching and a better job of hitting as he turned in his fourteenth victory today as the Indians beat the Tigers, 7 to 4, to gain an even break in the two-game series.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CHICAGO, June 30. -- A long, hot day of gabble, clack, racket, tumult and the mechanical simulations of passions marked the fourth day's session of the great National Democratic Convention far into the night.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Congres has much work still to do and may sit throughout next week, it became apparent today when conferees on relief legislation announced that they would not report before Tuesday.

The Chrysler Corporation in the last seven years has paid in taxes an amount equal to 35 per cent of its net profits, and more than half of the total distributed on dividends to stockholders, said a statement sent to stockholders yesterday with the dividend checks for the second quarter of the year.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- A world's record was set at Arlington Park today when Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Equipoise, famous son of Pennant and Swinging, which has not been defeated this season, raced a mile in 1:342-5 for his fifth consecutive victory of the year.
CHICAGO, Friday, July 1. -- The New York delegates, on the first ballot at the Democratic convention early today, voted 65 1/2 for Smith to 28 1/2 for Roosevelt. The poll follows:

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Why in the world didn't they have that fellow Ely, Governor of Massachusetts, not only nominate Al Smith but nominate all of 'em. He was good. Chairman Walsh tried to stop him and give a Gunboat Smith decision, but the audience wouldn't let him.

Judge Corrigan in General Sessions dismissed yesterday the $75,000 bail on which Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, reputed beer-runner, had been at liberty on two indictments charging felonious assault on a detective and violation of the Sullivan law.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30. -- One of the strongest fields of the year, headed by Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers and Manuel Alonso, formerly of the Spanish Davis Cup team, started today at the Nassau Country Club in quest of the oldest grass court tennis trophy in competition in the United States.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 30. -- An old-time farmers' dance will be held at Mrs. Molly Govington Hanna's barn at Stoekbridge on Saturday. It is to be a subscription affair, and guests are asked to wear overalls with broad-brimmed straw hats or farmerette costumes.

Two former medical students were held in $500 bail each in Brooklyn and a graduate student of Leland Stanford Jr. University was held by the police of Palo Alto, Cal., yesterday on charges of forging certificates of two of this city's leading institutions of higher learning.

GENEVA, June 30. -- Unemployment in the six major industrial nations of Europe this month was almost 50 per cent more than in June, 1931, according to figures of the International Labor Office here which have just been published. The report also shows that though unemployment normally declines substantially in the Spring, it has either Increased or remained about the same this Spring throughout the world compared with last Winter.

CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP). -- The $1,500 Buckeye Stake for 2:17 class pacers, today's Grand Circuit feature at North Randall, was a straight-heat victory for Rose Marie Abbe and marked a new record for the stake.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- The Senate today passed and sent to the House a bill reducing from 4 1/2 to 3 per cent the rate of Interest on loans to veterans on World War adjusted service certificates. There was no record vote.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month continued on a small scale. Sales as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES totaled 22,997,862 shares, slightly less than the preceding month's total of 23,151,047 shares and the smallest since October, 1924.

PARIS, June 30. -- The stock market was firm through most of today's session, with prices easing slightly in late trading. The money rate on the Bourse floor was one-eighth of 1 per cent for the final June settlements, but on many stocks the carry-over was considerably below the official rate.
TORONTO, - June 30 (Canadian Press). -- Displaying marked superiority, the Australian cricketers defeated a selected Toronto team today, 191 to 94.

In addition to the nineteen Federal court messengers who were notified Wednesday that their jobs would terminate today, 169 Federal employes in Manhattan and the Bronx learned yesterday that they were to be laid off at the same time in line with the economy bill passed by the Senate last Tuesday.
ALBANY, Friday, July 1. -- In his study in the Executive Mansion Governor Roosevelt settled down last night for long hours of radio listening.

Replying to the contention of George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queans, that the need for educational facilities in the Bayside district of Queens was greater than for added recreational areas, M. Lawrence Craner, executive secretary of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., said his organization insisted on "hands off the parks," whatever the city's financial needs might be.
CHICAGO, June 30. -- Following are the addresses made in putting the names of candidates for the Presidential nomination before the Democratic convention today:

Encouraged by the progress of its United Appeal for funds with which to continue emergency relief work in New York, the Salvation Army announced yesterday that it was making new appropriations for its Family Welfare Department, the work of which had to be curtailed for lack of funds.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The estate of William K. Vanderbilt of New York, of which Harold S. Vanderbilt and others are executors, has received an income tax refund of $353,987 for 1924 and 1925, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

Frank Hogan, the massive catcher who has been, striving to crack a home run all season, finally made his first one of the championship campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday and could scarcely have chosen' a more auspicious moment. He unveiled it in the sixth inning against the upper left balcony with two comrades aboard, and with this one shot enabled the Giants to gain their second straight victory over the Braves, 5 to 4.
LONDON, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- Yorkshire defeated Northhamptonshire by an innings and 49 runs in a first class county cricket match concluded today at Northampton.
The tragedy of royalty in exile is pictured by Edith O'Shaughnessy in her biography of Marie Adelaide, Grand Duchess of Luxemburg, recently published by Harrison Smith, Inc.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps gave a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza for her sister, the Countess of Granard, who has just arrived from London.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1 -- Declaring that education is the "chief bulwark of the nation against the destructive forces of extreme radicalism," the National Education Association at the final sesilon of its annual convention here today unanimously adopted a resolution calling upon the Federal Government, through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to "make available to the several States sufficient funds to safeguard public educatlon against retrenchment.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 1 -- A card of 41 -- 36 -- 77 grave Miss Maureen Orcutt and Sinclair Orcutt the metropolitan brother and sister golf championship today in the annual foursomes competition of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Essex Fells Country Club.

DUBLIN, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- Strong hopes that the disputed question of land annuities would yet be arbitrated were held tonight following indications that President Eamon de Valera was backing down from his decision that if they are to be arbitrated it should be by an international tribunal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democratic plank on liquor is as bad as the Republican, since both contain a stupid declaration against the return of the saloon. The open saloon is precisely what we need to cure the worst evils that prohibition has brought upon us to date.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The Democrats, assembled in the great Stadium here for their national convention, started their campaign to put Governor Roosevelt in the White House like a medieval army embarking on a holy war.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., July 1 -- The home of William L. Bass, retired business man, who had devoted himself to the study of literature and science, was destroyed here today by fire caused by lightning. The house was unoccupied and the whereabouts of Mr. Bass were undetermined by the police.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- After two years of investigating postoffice leases a special Senate committee today recommended immediate legislation to provide a $45,000,000 postal building program.

SEA GIRT N.J., July 1 -- With a score of 892 out of a possible 900, the Bear Rock Rifle Team No. 2 won the Palma small-bore team match of the eleventh annual small-bore rifle tournament, which opened today.

TORONTO, July 1 (AP) -- After losing eight straight games to Buffalo this season, the Toronto Leafs turned today and won both games of the Dominion Day double-header from the Bisons, 5 to 0 and 7 to 1. Freddy Maguire, former New York Giants and Boston second baseman, made his debut with the Leafs and played impressively.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Thatcher's letter to THE TIMES will be appreciated by many silent possessors of creative minds. He has done them, industry and society a good service.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Lonnie Warneke became the first National League pitcher to win ten games this season when the Cubs defeated the Reds, 8 -- 4, today and returned to first place, supplanting the Pirates. It was Cincinnati's ninth straight setback.

A brisk rally yesterday in virtually all sections of the bond market of the New York Stock Exchange enabled many issues to erase losses of the last few days. Foreign loans were the strongest, led by German, issues and United Kingdom 5%s. Railroad and utility bonds made better gains than did most of the industrials, and United States Government loans extended their recovery.
GENEVA, July 1 -- The inside fight going on over President Hoover's plan for a one-third reduction in armaments broke through the surface momentarily today in a way illustrative of its intensity.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 (AP) -- The defeat of Allison and Van, Ryn today was a blow to British, tennis critics, who had labeled the Americans the world's leading doubles pair.
The police are looking for Owen Madden, former convict, and three of his associates, former Sing Sing inmates.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate late today approved a conference report on the $1,056,247,833 Postoffice-Treasury Department bill and thus, with the exception of two bills deadlocked, wiped clean the slate of departmental supply measures for the fiscal year that began today.

Samuel Seabury, counsel in the Hofstadter inquiry, has made arrangements to sail for Europe on July 16, it was learned yesterday. The news was taken to indicate that he does not expect to act as prosecutor of the removal charges against Mayor Walker now pending before Governor Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The greatest field ever assembled for an American regatta, comprising 105 entries, today started a three-day program of rowing which is to decide national championships and the Olympic entries in six of the events on the Olympic program.

When the American Merchant liner American Trader sailed for Plymouth and London yesterday afternoon, Captain Theodore Van Beek, master, told of a strange experience when the ship was steaming westward on her last crossing. The ship arrived a week ago from London.
LAKE GENEVA, Wis., July 1 (AP) -- Blind and snow-haired, Dr. Edwin Grant Frost retired today at 65 as director of the University of Chicago's Yerkes Observatory.

BERLIN, July 1 -- The Boerse continued to advance today, the pace being even livelier than that of yesterday, stocks gaining between 1 and 3 per cent, although the turnover was still small. The upward movement was attributed to news from Lausanne, which was interpreted optimistically and also to a rise in German bonds abroad.

ALBANY, N.Y., Saturday, July 2 -- Wreathed in smiles, Governor Roosevelt sat in his armchair in the Executive Mansion early this morning, jubilant at his nomination and all ready with plans for an intensive campaign to win his way to the White House.

The first official act of the city's new Acting Mayor. Alderman Frank Cunningham, resulted yesterday in a perfect afternoon of swimming and wading in the Civic Virtue fountain in City Hall Park for poor children of the neighborhood who sought relief from the heat.
CHICAGO, July 1 -- The detailed vote on the fourth ballot of the Democratic National Convention nominating Franklin D. Roosevelt for President follows:

EXECUTIVE MANSION, Albany, N.Y., July 1 (AP) -- From the ballroom, where she had been posing under photographers lights, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt hurried to the kitchen of the Executive Mansion tonight, tied the trailing sleeves of her green chiffon hostess gown behind her and proceeded to scramble some eggs for the Democratic candidate for President of the United States.

The National Electric Power Company, a 5600,000,000 corporation for which equity receivers were appointed on Thursday in actions begun in Maine, was named a defendant yesterday in a petition in bankruptcy filed in this district for Ellen D. Cholerton. Louis D. Merry and George W. Boland, who presented claims of $200, $1,000 and $3,000, respectively.

The Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, a Belgian company, which is the owner of the largest copper mine in the world, situated in Africa, has announced its withdrawal from Copper Exporters, Inc., the cooperative selling agency abroad for copper producers.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1 -- After a trying afternoon with his disabled sloop, Siboney, on Long Island Sound, Dr. Eugene H. McCauliff of Yonkers, whose fame as a navigator is second only to his reputation on the tennis courts and in the chemistry laboratories, arrived at the Nassau Country Club today to undergo another ordeal in the annual invitation tournament here.

PARIS, July 1 -- The Bourse was irregular or dull during the greater part of today's session, but rallied toward the closing when considerable trading took place. A good many stocks advanced and the week ended on a note of optimism. This was attributed partly to continued hopefulness regarding Lausanne and partly to the good impression in Lombard Street concerning the British conversion proposal.

A sharp reaction in sterling exchange, coinciding with the British Government's active preparations to refund the L2,000,000,000 5 per cent War Loan, was the overshadowing development in yesterday's financial markets. The British currency was under pressure all day and at one time it was 2 1/8 cents below the previous close; the final quotation of $3.57 1/4 disclosed a net decline of 1 3/4 cents.

WATERTOWN, Conn., July 1 -- One of the most prized trophies of the horse show held under the auspices of the Watertown Riding and Hunt Club was permanently retired today at the first session of the sixth annual exhibition, which opened this morning to continue through, tomorrow.

The announcement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer that the British Government had determined to refund the L2,000,000,000 5 per cent war loan, combined with the Bank of England's reduction in its rate to 2 per cent, the lowest point in thirty-five years, precipitated yesterday heavy withdrawals of Continental European balances from London, driving sterling exchange down to a new low price on the current reaction.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., July 1 While the United States Is the greatest producer of leaf tobacco in the world, other countries are increasing their crops and coming more and more in competition with the American tobacco trade abroad, A.B. Carrington of Danville, president of the Tobacco Association of the United States, warned that body today at the opening of its annual convention.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Texas was reluctant to the last to haul down the Garner colors. The delegation was in caucus when the word came from the Speaker's office in Washington that he was ready to quit and in quitting to let the votes go as each individual saw fit.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- William Gibbs McAdoo, tall, courtly and dignified, stepped out tonight on the platform at the Democratic National Convention to announce to a gathering that had already sensed what was happening that in the interests of party unity and majority rule, the votes pledged to John N. Garner would go to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Democratic leaders in the capital appeared well pleased with the nomination of Governor Roosevelt as the Democratic party's standard-bearer. Their comment was as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES S.N. Ferris Luboshez takes exception to my statement that "In England, law reform was brought about by laymen." Mr. Luboshez omits the following sentence in my statement: "All the English commissions which achieved such substantial results were composed mainly of laymen; the chairman was generally a layman."

New York City borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday from the National City Bank and the Chase National Bank through the sale of 6 per cent corporate stock notes due on March 15, 1933. The respective security affiliates of the banks, the National City Company and the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, will offer the notes today at a price to yield 5 per cent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 1 -- Buffalo's life through 100 years passed before the eyes of her citizens Friday afternoon as the civc parade, formal opening feature of the city's centennial, wound through the downtown area.

New public financing here in June was slightly above the total for May, but the increase did not herald any change of consequence in the virtually dormant state existing in the market for new securities. The month's total was $106.363,000, comprising $105,863,000 in bonds and $500,000 in stocks, compared with $79,028,000 of offerings in May, which were all bonds, and $353.211,000 for June, 1931, when $351,611,000 in bonds and $1,600,000 in stocks were marketed.

The outstanding development in the financial situation in June, says the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, published yesterday, was the virtual completion of the repatriation of the funds of foreign central banks which accumulated in this country a few years ago.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Delivery of 6,024,000 bushels of wheat on July contracts today was well in excess of the trade's expectations and led on the Board of Trade to free selling in the current delivery by scattered longs, the price dropping 7/8 cents a bushel from yesterday's close to 46 7/8 cents and equalling the season's inside figure.

BERLIN, July 1 -- The Federal Supreme Court at Leipzig today adjudged the Berlin Vorwaerts, Germany's best-known Socialist and labor organ, guilty of contempt in that it had slandered the von Papen Government in a cartoon, thereby confirming the five-day suspension demanded of the Prussian Interior Ministry by Baron Wilhelm von Gayl, Federal Minister of the Interior.

Marion Talley, the Kansas City girl who came out of the West in 1926 at the age of 19 to join the Metropolitan Opera Company and suddenly ended her operatic career after four seasons as prima donna to retire to her Kansas farm, was secretly married on Thursday in White Plains, N.Y., to Michael Raucheisen, German pianist.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Ending a twelve-month period of unprecedented depression, with its demoralizing effect on official finances, the Federal Government showed a deficit of $2,885,000,000 at the end yesterday of the fiscal year 1932, Secretary Mill announced today.

WITH the college athletes bent on breaking track and field records at Berkeley, it's odd to turn over the pages of an old record book and read some of the queer marks on the pages. There has come to hand a bound copy of Spalding's Official Athletic Almanac for 1911 from the library of the late Sam Miles, the Bristol Harrier of old days.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- "Detroit mules," fed on Texas gasoline; Minneapolis flour Vermont syrup. Pittsburgh tin pans and Cincinnati soap are the principal reasons for the economic distress in Nebraska, Representative Morehead said in the Congressional Record today.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union disclaims any part in a third party "dry" movement at this time, Mrs. Ella A. Boole, national president of the organization, announced today, indicating a division of strength among the ultra drys.

Louis Waldman, attorney and former Socialist candidate for Governor, won yesterday from the Appellate Division a stay of the order of Supreme Court Justice Churchill fining him $250 for contempt of court. The Appellate Division issued a certiorari order requiring Justice Churchill to turn over within twenty days to the higher court his "proceedings, decisions and actions" and all the records of the case so that the higher court might review the contempt order.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Cheering their throats hoarse to down "boos" behind them, the five young "Roosevelts," excitedly watched tonight as the Democratic convention made their father its Presidential nominee.

Twenty-one athletes from Argentina and three from Uruguar reached the last lap of their 10,000-mile trip to Los Angeles for the Olympic games when they arrived in New York yesterday on the M.S. Northern Prince. Sun-bronzed track and field athletes, boxers, rifle-shooters and a sculler were in the party.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England July 1 -- The Leander Club's powerful Cambridge boat-race eight maintained its supremacy today by the winning of the semi-final heat of the Grand Challenge Cup competition from the London Rowing Club's first crew on the third day of the Henley regatta.

COBH, Irish Free State, July 1 -- Eleven of the crew were drowned when the four-masted Finnish bark Melbourne, one of the windjammers in the annual Australian grain race, sank off Fastnet early today after a collision with the Anglo-American Oil Company's tanker Seminole.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1 -- Allegiance to "financial adventures" and practices of men supposed to be their leaders had resulted in lost prestige for the legal profession during the last two years, Professor Calvert Magruder of Harvard Law School, told the Maryland State Bar Association in annual convention here today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- New Jersey Republicans in Congress failed in a caucus today to agree on their prohibition stand.

Once a week for the last three months there has been provided gratuitously a "country-wide hookup" making available for millions a program of addresses by men and women of authority on subjects within the scope of the general title "You and Your Government."
MADRID, July 1 (AP) -- Ruth Chatterton, American stage and screen actress today confirmed reports from Hollywood that she and Ralph Forbes, her actor-husband, would be divorced.

The first evidence tending to support the widely held theory that the late Ivar Kreuger, Swedish match monopolist, incurred financial ruin by market operations designed to support his own securities was adduced yesterday at a hearing in the office of Henry K. Davis, special master in the application to appoint an American receiver for the Kreuger Toll Company.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Had it not been for timely payment of $1,019,000 in inheritance taxes by the estate of United States Senator Dwight W. Morrow, New Jersey's new fiscal year would have begun today with the treasury "in the red" about $400,000. As it turned out, the net free balance at the beginning of the year today was $596,014,70.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The extreme outsider in a field of eight, the Mereworth Stud's Waylayer staged a spectacular stretch drive to score by a head in the $2,500-added Shoreland, Claiming Stakes, feature at Arlington Park today. C.V. Whitney's Fall Apple was second, three lengths ahead of Prince Tokalon.
CHICAGO, July 1 -- The invocation of Dr. John Thompson of the First Methodist Church, Chicago Temple, Chicago, follows:

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Up to within half an hour of the reconvening of the Democratic convention this evening, gloomy prophecies were heard on all sides about a repetition of the Madison Square Garden deadlock in 1924. of desertions, in some instances wholesale, from one camp to another, of deals involving the vice Presidential nomination, and other wire-pulling activities by leaders of opposing factions to hold their lines intact.

To the Editor of The New York Times: D.F.B., in a letter to THE TIMES, suggests that criminals be sentenced to terms of service in the army. Military training and discipline probably would benefit most offenders, and they could get it in civilian prisons and training camps.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 1 -- Both sides rested and summed up their arguments tonight in the trial of John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boat builder, who for weeks upheld the hopes of the Lindbergh family that he and he alone could effect the return of their child.

LONDON, July 1 -- World-wide recovery and that "far-reaching uplift in industry and commerce for which all civilized nations are praying" are held to be among the benefits that in due course are expected to result from Great Britain's gigantic war loan conversion.

PARIS, July 1 (AP) -- Borrah Minnevitch, leader of a harmonica orchestra, who embarked from Nice last Friday for an African lion hunt, found himself in the hands of racketeering sailors and wound up at Bandol, France, minus his sloop, money and sailing togs.

Samuel Untermyer, who went to the Democratic National Convention as a Tammany district delegate, after his return by airplane last night acclaimed the nomination of Governor Roosevelt despite what he termed a concerted drive of powerful financial groups to block his march to the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Federal prohibition forces will be reduced by sixty-five to seventy men. Colonel Amos W.W. Woodcock, chief of the bureau, announced today.

North of the Seventy-second Street express stop, where the cinema is not always immune to the heat, nature is waging an unhappy war with art and the scenario writers for the soul of "The Midnight Lady." After the first twenty minutes the fight is not even close, and yesterday was an uncomfortably warm day indeed.

"With but limited satisfaction" the President has signed the omnibus economy bill, ending a controversy which has been in progress since Congress met last December. It is estimated that this measure will reduce Federal expenditures during the next twelve months by $150,000,000, or about 3 1/2 per cent of the budget.

The good fortune of Joseph Friedman, 25 years old, of 133 Clarke Avenue, the Bronx, in obtaining a job as rent collector yesterday after he had been out of work for more than a month, stood him in good stead during a first day of turmoil in which he was robbed of $110 of his employer's money, kidnapped and assaulted by two hold-up men.

BOSTON, July 1 -- By way of beginning the new fiscal year in memorable fashion, the Yanks and Red Sox traded roles today, the tailenders slapping the American League pacemakers all over Fenway Park for an 11-to-6 victory to the huge delight of a ladies' day crowd of about 7,000.

CHICAGO, Saturday, July 2 -- James A. Farley, the Roosevelt campaign manager, predicted early this morning that Governor Roosevelt would be elected by the greatest majority ever received by a Democratic nominee for President.

PARIS, July 1 -- The publication today of the financial measures by which the government intends to cover next year's budgetary deficit to the extent of 4,500,000,000 francs (about $180,000,000) has created a situation in France that promises an agitated session in the Chamber of Deputies when the projects come under discussion Monday.

GARFIELD, N.J., July 1 -- Four young men who had stolen a payroll of $1,000 from a cemetery superintendent near Rochelle Park today ran down Mrs. Rose Congialosi, 41 years old, of this city, as they were speeding down Harrison Avenue. Nicholas Grimm, their victim, who had followed them from the scene of the hold-up a few miles away, abandoned his pursuit to take the woman to a hospital in Passaic.
Copyright, 1932, by NAKA, Inc. TEMPORARY BASE CAMP, Nanga Parbat, Kashmir, June 26 (by runner to Astor, July 1) -- Things have been moving fast with our expedition the last few days.

Under the auspices of the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools 269 schools will open on Tuesday morning in this city and vicinity. They will be in session for four weeks from Mondays through Fridays, closing on Aug. 5. The morning sessions will begin at 9 and the afternoon sessions at 2 o'clock.

New duties, double those now imposed on typewriters, speedometers and toys, will be put into effect by Switzerland on Tuesday, according to the weekly summary of tariff changes made public yesterday by the Department of Commerce. The tax on imported typewriters is increased from 250 to 500 francs a 100 kilos, that on speedometers from 170 to 500 francs and on toys from 40 to 100 francs.

Following five months of steadily mounting withdrawals of gold by European countries, the movement on a large scale was halted at the middle of June, and although the month's total showed a huge loss, the culmination of such a movement without the United States being forced to abandon the gold standard helped remove much of the gloom in financial markets.

All the security markets and most of the commodity exchanges will be closed today, not to reopen until Tuesday. This means that, while the banks and the New York Cotton Exchange will be open as usual today, business otherwise will be sharply curtailed in all financial centres.
Fifteen steamships will sail today for foreign ports carrying more than 8,000 passengers, of whom threefourths are bound for Europe.

Reports filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by 164 Class I steam railways, including seventeen switching and terminal companies, showed a net loss of $20,682,727, after taxes and charges, in April, against a net income of $2,623,005 earned in April, 1931.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary Stimson, in a radio address today, congratulated the people of Canada on the celebration of Dominion Day. The address was sent over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 1 -- The State Department of Education today announced the award of twenty-five industrial teacher scholarships at the State Teachers College, Buffalo. In addition to the scholarships, seven alternates were named. Tile competition this year bad the greatest number of applicants since the Legislature first made provision for the scholarships in 1920.

The Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game is ready to issue instructions on the building of turtle traps and it will also forward recipes on how turtle soup and turtle food dishes may be prepared.
NORTH WESTPORT, Mass., July 1 (AP) -- A 3-year-old boy slept in his crib today while his uncle broke into the house to find the child's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pelletier, shot to death.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "An emergency * * * second only to that of the great war," in which "human suffering occasioned may well exceed that of a period of actual conflict," pronounces the Republican platform.

New York stifled again yesterday in baking temperatures and high humidity that caused thousands to flee to the beaches in search of comfort and killed one man in Brooklyn and caused several prostrations.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Weary but stubborn delegates, equally weary and persistent spectators in the balconies, and all the rest who, because of their duties, were still awake at dawn, were stirred from their mental lethargy when the State of New York was reached on the first ballot this morning.
MONTREAL, July 1 (AP) -- Rochester won both games of a double-header from the Royals today with a pair of last-inning rallies. The scores were 10 to 7 and 7 to 5. A crowd of 6,000 was present.

HERRNHUT, Germany, July 1 -- Fifty-six representatives of more than a score of national Christian councils on every continent assembled here today for a committee meeting of the International Missionary Council, presided over by Dr. John R. Mott, the president of the International Young Men's Christian Association.

The receivership order against the Roerich Museum, granted last April by Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan in Bronx County on the application of a committee representing holders of bonds secured by mortgages on the building, was vacated yesterday by the Appellate Division.

The $2,850,000 condemnation award set by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook on the Libby Hotel was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division in a three-to-two decision denying the application of the city to reverse the valuations placed by the Supreme Court on this and other property condemned for the Chrystie Forsyth Street widening and improvement project
Housing deals constituted the outstanding feature of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

Two policemen and a woman clerk were slightly burned yesterday in extinguishing a fire in the record and license room of the Public Markets Department in the Manhattan Municipal Building, which destroyed between 20,000 and 30,000 records bearing the names of peddlers at public markets.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The text of the statement issued, today by Secretary Mills concerning government finances at the end of the fiscal year 1932 follows:
Michael Ricciardelli sold to Patrick J. Hayes the four-story eight-family brick-flat, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, at 227 Bay Street, near Erie Street, Jersey City. It is valued for taxation at $16,000.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Agreement on relief legislation, the most important subject before Congress, was reached by the conferees tonight just after the Senate and House recessed until Tuesday, when they will take up the conference report.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the New York of the Hamburg-American Line was Mrs. Amalta H. Schlegel, 92 years old, who came here first in 1858 and has made sixty crossings between this port and Hamburg.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 1 -- Billy Howell of Washington and Lee, and Johnny Fischer of Michigan blasted Yale's hopes in the national intercollegiate golf championships today by turning back Sidney Noyes and John Parker, Eli stars, in the smartest exhibitions of golf ever seen at the Cascades Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- Charges that the late Thomas E. Mitten, head of Philadelphia's transit system, paid $150,000 to William D.B. Ainey, chairman of the Public Service Commission, prior to, during and after proceedings which resulted in the commission's granting a fare increase to the transit company, were declared entirely false today by Dr. Arthur A. Mitten.

Although freed on $1,000 bail Thursday night by Supreme Court Justice Valente, William H. Collins, the fugitive from San Quentin prison is California who was recaptured here last week after nineteen years of freedom, spent another five and a half hours in the Tombs yesterday because Magistrate Overton Harris felt that Justice Valente's action had no bearing on the fugitive charge pending in the Tombs Court.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- The Cardinals turned on the Pirates today, defeating them, 5 to 3, and knocking them out of first place in the National League. The Pirates, in second place, now trail the Cubs by four points.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 1 -- In a jump of water such as Long Island Sound can kick up when the wind blows, twenty-two yachts started tonight in the Stamford Yacht Club's race of 232 miles out around Vineyard Sound Lightship, this siide of Martha's Vineyard, and back.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -- Calumet Crusader, a first starter and owned by the Arden Homestead Farms, and driven by Will Dickerson, won the nineteenth renewal of the $1,500 Fasig Stake for 3-year-old trotters today in straight heats at North Randall.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The request of the Illinois Central Railroad for a $11,000,000 loan from the Reronstruction Finance Corporation with which to meet interest and equipment trust obligations was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Frank Giordano, 32 years old, and Dominic Odierno, 20, members of the disrupted Vincent Coll gang of beer-runners and gunmen, were put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing last night. They had been convicted in the Bronx about six weeks ago of the killing of Joseph Mullins, a member of the Dutch Schultz gang.

William E. Walsh, former chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, who has been under State and Federal inquiry concerning his conduct in office when William F. Doyle, the veterinarian, enjoyed a lucrative practice before that body, was cleared yesterday of the only charge remaining against him in connection with the investigations.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production has dropped to a new low, the figure for the week ended June 25 being 56.6, as against 59.0 for the preceding week and 89.4 for the corresponding week last year. "Sales were smaller than during previous weeks," according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service, "and undoubtedly below the current rate of output in the aggregate.

Queens Needs All Its Parks. Some days ago Borough President HARVEY of Queens suggested to the Board of Education that part of Raymond M. O'Connor Park in Bayside be used as a site for a new high school.

PARIS, July 1 (AP) -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and his associates in the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace revealed today a plan to call a conference of signatories of the Briand-Kellogg peace pact "to put teeth into the instrument."

Interest charges for call loan funds in June, on both of the local Stock Exchanges, were the same as in the previous four months -- 2 1/2 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 3 per cent on the New York Curb Exchange. They compared with 1 1/2 per cent and 2 per cent, respectively, in June, 1931.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Comment, jubilant or resigned, came tonight from Democratic leaders after Franklin D. Roosevelt was nominated.

PARIS, July 1 -- "The fate of the Lausanne conference is in the hands of the German Government," Premier Herriot said today on his third trip to Paris since the parley opened. Asserting that France had the complete support of Britain regarding a united front toward both Germany and the United States, the Premier intimated that no matter what attitude the Reich might take the French would gain by the new understanding with the British.

A record political broadcast was established Thursday night and yesterday morning when for eleven hours and fifty minutes 158 stations scattered from coast to coast in the United States were attached to microphones in the Chicago Stadium. For the major portion of that time the combined stations associated with the WEAF-WJZ and WABC networks reached a total of 184 transmitters.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- California and Texas, which came to Chicago pledged to Speaker John N. Garner, broke the deadlock on the Presidential nomination in the Democratic National Convention on the fourth ballot tonight by casting their ninety votes for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York.

Arriving yesterday from England one the Cunarder Berengaria was a delegation of British nobility who have come to attend the laying of the cornerstone of the British Empire Building, in the Rockefeller Centre. They were met at Pier 4, Hoboken, by Nelson Rockefeller, son of John D. Rockefeller Jr.; Hugh S. Robertson and Dr. H.H. Stevens, Canadian Minister of Commerce in New York.

The rise of Franklin D. Roosevelt to national prominence has been comparatively slow but steady. He first appeared on the national political stage as Assistant Secretary of the Nevy in the administration of Woodrow Wilson. In 1920 he was the Vice Presidential nominee of the Democratic party when James M. Cox of Ohio headed the ticket, which was defeated under the avalanche of votes that swept Warren G. Harding into the White House.

E.N. Brown, chairman of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, was elected chairman of the readjustment management committee of the railway yesterday. Clarence W. Michel, vice president of the road, was elected secretary. The committee was organized to manage the road as part of the recapitalization plan announced Thursday.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 1 -- Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch defeated Miss Helen Germaine today in a semi-final round match of the metropolitan clay- court championship tourney at the Lido Country Club. The score was 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 1 -- Charles A. Waters, Auditor General, announced today a plan by which bonds for refinancing the Delaware River Bridge might be sold without disturbing the bond market. He suggested that the Pennsylvania and New Jersey State Governments buy the bond with sinking funds and other custodial funds, releasing the money from the bridge for general use at once.

GENEVA, July 1 -- A special session of the League of Nations Assembly extended today, with the consent of the parties concerned, the time limit under the covenant for decision on the Chino-Japanese conflict until receipt of the report of the Lytton commission enables the committee of nineteen to determine how much more time will be needed.

PARIS, July 1 -- With a view toward more freedom in international trade the French Government today announced renewals of the quotas for imports from the United States, many of which represent increases ranging from 10 to 30 per cent in the contingent limitations.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Only two families have sent more than one member to the Presidency of the United States, the Adamses and the Harrisons. If Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected the Roosevelts will be the third as Theodore Roosevelt, the twenty-sixth President, was a fifth cousin of the Democratic candidate this year.

The work of the Democratic National Convention must be judged as a whole. There were at Chicago several candidates for the Presidency in a furious and long-drawn-out battle. But there was also a preliminary struggle which was collective, not individual.

VIENNA, July 1 -- The inability of Austria and Hungary to continue paying service on the loans with which the League of Nations rehabilitated their finances eight years ago has involved the governments of both countries in a bitter dispute with the League's representatives over the disposal of the securities on which the loana were granted.

TORONTO, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- Australia and Eastern Canada battled on even terms today in the first of three cricket test matches to be played in Canada during the Australian tour. At the end of the first day's play a team representative of Eastern Canada had scored 176 runs for eight wickets, declared, their famous opponents replying with 143 for six when play was called for the day. The match will be concluded tomorrow.

BELGRADE, July 1 -- Signs are multiplying that the reply of the "Yugoslax dictatorship to the ever-growing unrest throughout the country will be to reject any attempt to seek a solution through agreement with the leaders of the political parties and treat all opposition with redoubled severity.

NEWARK, N.J., July 1 -- A search was started here today for three armed men who entered the office of the Motor Vehicle Underwriters, Inc., at 830 Broad Street, last night, bound the manager, Harry Farhash of 9,302 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, and two employes of the office, and escaped with $2,000.

FORLI, Italy, July 1 -- One hundred and eight athletes, comprising the Italian team that will compete in the Olympic games at Los Angeles, received farewells in this city this morning from Premier Mussolini, who, after reminding them that they were "ambassadors extraordinary of Italy to the United States," urged them to fight hard for the triumph of Italian sport.

RYE. N.Y., July 1 -- Canvasback, owned by Robert McC. Shields and sailed by Gordon Raymond, was the winner today of the first yacht race in the July series of the interclub class on Long Island Sound on a windward and leeward course. Canvasback edged out Corny Shields's Aileen, winner of the June series, by the slim margin of seventeen seconds.
CLEVELAND, July 1 -- The Western Open Golf championship saw a four-man deadlock today as the 72hole struggle reached the halfway mark.

LATONIA, Ky., July 1 (AP) -- A mild surprise marked the running of today's feature, the Queen City Jubilee Purse, when Max Hirsch's Swift and True drove home in advance of several good sprinters, aa the 3-year-old son of Swift and Sure had graduated from the maiden ranks only last Wednesday.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Fifteen thousand persons who crowded the Stadium for the Democratic convention session tonight expecting drama were not disappointed in the spectacle they saw when Franklin D. Roosevelt was nominated, amid the cheers of delegates, and groans and boos from those in the galleries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 1 -- Faculty members and other employes of Rutgers University would receive salary reductions ranging up to 15 per cent and certain members of the staff would have to be released to enable the university to meet the $200,000 cut in the State appropriation imposed by the Legislature, it was announced today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers.

Hard times are bad for the big gambling resorts like Deauville and Monte Carlo. The get-poor-quick millionaires who frequent them have been relieved of their surplus cash by other means. The professionals find few of the old-time plungers against whom to match their wits.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the Democratic candidate for President, has been variously described as a democratic aristocrat and an aristocratic Democrat.

In the rush of news from Chicago a highly important dispatch from Tokyo published in yesterday's TIMES should not be overlooked. It presents an authorized and official view of the Japanese naval authorities, and presumably of the Japanese Government, respecting President HOOVER'S proposal of a general cut of one-third in all armaments.

MEXICO CITY, July 1 -- Answering union criticism of his recent attack on street-car and steam railway strikes as unpatriotic and uneconomic at this time, Abelardo Rodriguez. Minister of Industry, has issued a statement saying that the plain truth from a public official had taken the public by surprise.

The $526,812 suit brought against Gene Tunney, retired heavyweight boxer, by Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, must go to trial again, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in reversing the verdict of the Supreme Court jury, which, late in 1930 returned a verdict in favor of Tunney.

BERKELEY, Cal., July 1 -- The University of Southern California's track and field team, seeking its third successive Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. title, today qualified seventeen men for nineteen places to take the lead in the annual championship meet.

Export Trade Improved. June export business will show a noticeable improvement over May in the machine tool, packaged food and specialties branches, according to opinion expressed by executives of export trade organizations yesterday. In addition to the improvement in actual sales, the number of inquiries on general export lines was the best since the start of the year.

LONDON, July 1 -- The financial markets were ablaze with activity today following the government's conversion proposals, and scarcely a stock failed to gain. Gilt-edge securities bounded upward in the most striking movements in the history of the Stock Exchange.

Three 1931 champions triumphed in bouts yesterday in the fourth day's competition in the annual national A.A.U. wrestling championships at the Madison Square Garden bowl. The night events were halted midway by a heavy thunder shower.

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 1 -- Hector Dyer, former Stanford sprint star, running for the Los Angeles A.C., equaled the world's accepted 100-meter dash record today, running the distance during the Olympic tryout in 10.4 seconds. Charles Paddock and Eddie Tolan are co-holders of the mark.

Holders of Republic Gas Corporation first lien collateral 6 per cent convertible bonds, series A, and certificates for such bonds issued under the deposit agreement dated Jan. 20, have been advised by the bondholders' protective committee headed by James R. Buck that the committee has approved reorganizing the Kansas properties of the corporation "as an initial and necessary step in the reorganization of the Republic Gas Corporation."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1 Many members of the Summer colony attended the first in a series of dances in aid of the Southampton Unemployment Relief Fund, which was held tonight at the George Warrington Curtis House. Several dinners were given in advance.

C. Leroy King's Roan Antelope, a gelded son of Man of War, broke a sequence of three winning favorites when he captured the "fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday at 8 to 1. Silvio Coucci, the meeting's leading apprentice, brought Roan Antelope home to complete a consecutive double.

The money market was quiet and unchanged, except for commercial paper, where there was a good demand for ninety-day paper at 2 1/4 per cent, a slight decline from the previous day. Stock Exchange money ruled at 2 1/2 per cent, against 1 per cent on the outside and Federal funds 1/4 @ 1.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 1 -- Four art exhibitions opened at Guild Hall this afternoon. A performance was given there this evening by Carola Goya, Spanish dancer. Many dinner parties' were given before the Goya recital.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Mile Suzanne Lenglen sat in the stands today watching Mrs. Helen Wills Moody win her fifth Wimbiedon singles championship. The once incomparable Suzanne saw the American champion defeat Miss Helen Jacobs, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, and prove that there is only one incomparable queen of the courts today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Bunching eight hits in two innings, the Senators took the opening contest of a two-game series with the Athletics today, 7 to 5.

With some producing sections reporting the heaviest rainfalls of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued upward in most of yesterday's session. At one time July sold at 5 3/4 cents a pound, compared with a recent low mark of 4.91 cents, or an improvement of more than $4 a bale.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- After forcing two unsuccessful ballots in an attempt to bring about the nomination of Governor Roosevelt for President at the all-night session of the Democratic National Convention, the Roosevelt forces suffered a minor defeat in failing to get an adjournment early today, but successfully met the counter-attack of the Smith and anti-Roosevelt combination on the third ballot, after which adjournment came by mutual agreement.

Outbound holiday travel, starting with a rush at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, reached its peak in the afternoon and evening, according to reports from many transportation lines. Railroad, bus, steamship and air lines reported that business, while not quite as large as that of the last Fourth of July period, compared favorably with it.

The total of new municipal financing scheduled for next week is the smallest for any week so far this year, amounting to $4,949,575. In large measure, this is due to the holiday on Monday and the quiet demand for municipal bonds which has ruled this week. The revised total of new issues up for award this week is S10,826,562, compared with the weekly average of $22,530,220 for the year.

Preliminary statements for the six months ended on June 30, which were issued yesterday by the Second National, Third National and Fourth National Investors Corporation, showed that the trusts had increased their holdings of cash almost to 50 per cent of their net assets through the sale of investments.

Indications of a more hopeful attitude on the part of merchants and industrialists throughout the country are noted by Bradstreet's weekend trade review, based upon reports from fifty-five leading cities.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 1 -- In his first competitive test since the annexation of the national amateur championship at Chicago last Summer, Francis Ouimet of Woodland, Mass., today won the Massachusetts open golf championship by a stroke, defeating Herman Barren of Port Chester, N.Y., in a dramatic finish at the Oyster Harbor's Club.

LAUSANNE, July 1 -- Chancellor von Papen tonight received the plan for a final capital payment by Germany in place of reparations which has been worked out by incessant labor during the past few days.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 -- Winning three matches with the loss of only seven games, J. Gilbert Hall, South Orange, and Fritz Mercur, Bethlehem, Pa., advanced to the semi-final round of the New Jersey State men's doubles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1 -- Clifford Sutler, the newly crowned intercollegiate champion, reached the finals of the men's singles in the Atlantic City invitation tournament to- day by defeating Martin Buxby, Texas University star, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3. Sutter will meet Sam Gilpin, who beat Karl Kamrath in the other semi-final round match, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the finals tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Politics ain't on the level. I was only in 'em for an hour but In that short space of time somebody stole 22 votes from me. I was sitting there in the press stand asleep and wasn't bothering a soul when they woke me up and said Oklahoma had started me on the way to the White House with 22 votes.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Denying he had any part in the Lindbergh kidnapping, Norman T. Whitaker, alias The Fox, indicted by the District of Columbia grand jury on charges "of conspiracy to defraud" in connection with the Gaston B. Means ransom hoax, arrived here at 12:15 P.M. today from New York in custody of two United States deputy marshals.
BUDAPEST, June 20. -- The present troubles of Hungary may be traced to two main causes: the difficulty of selling her agricultural produce abroad and the general crisis in credit conditions.

LONDON, July 1. -- The present week has been a banner one for British aviation. Half a million spectators, of whom nearly halt paid admission, at the annual Royal Air Force display at Hendon last Saturday left no doubt as to the airmindedness of this nation.

THE Sam H. Harris office has received the finished manuscript of the new KaufmanFerber play, "Dinner at Eight," and is more than a little excited over the event. Almost nothing is known of the play, as the authors are determined at all costs to keep its contents a secret.

SO far out of the ordinary is this novel that one is puzzled at finding an approach. Shall one begin with the pigeons, Conquistador, Daphnis and Butter-cup? That will not do for these three feathery messengers are more nearly a chorus as used by the Greeks than direct participants in the action.

THE best proportion of teachers to pupils is still a vexing problem. However, research has been patiently nibbling around the edges for nearly forty years, and it has lately made several important discoveries.

Following the holiday tomorrow initial operations for the Fall season will be started by retailers. Tentative merchandising and expense bud gets for the new season have been set up by many stores and the stage is set for a season which may prove better than the unsettling period through which both retailers and manufacturers passed during the Spring.

ONE brisk morning in mid-January, 1932, Broadway woke with more than its customary yawn. The trial of Mayor Walker had not yet begun. Mr. Rockefeller, to all intents and purposes, still was numbered among the drys. The Atlantic was unconquered by a loneflying Amazon.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated in an unusually wide range yesterday and ended at the highest figures of the week, 15 to 18 points above Friday's closing quotations.

DETROIT. DUE to the relatively strong de- mand for small cars and the considerable stimulus imparted to production and sales by the desire to beat the new Federal excise taxes, the automotive industry has just emerged from an unusual June.
WIMBLEDON, England. July 2. -- Ellsworth Vines Jr., not yet 21, climbed to the pinnacle of tennis greatness on Wimbledon's centre court today.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass. -- Yacht racing and cruising, as usual, take precedence over all other events as the 1932 season gets under way in this "yachting capital of America," with the Eastern Tacht Club starting the official season with its Puritan Cup race, annual regatta and cruise starting on Monday.

TO most of Shakespeare's present-day admirers, who accept without question the idea that the bard of Avon was the supreme poet and dramatist of all time, the thought that Shakespeare was not always venerated presents itself with something of a shock.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Several hundred delegates, including outstanding leaders of Zionism in this country, were arriving here tonight to attend the convention of the Zionist Organization of America, which opens tomorrow.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 2. -- Twenty-five yachts capsized, were dismasted or in some other manner disabled today in the second championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association as a westerly gale provided the most strenuous Seaside Park Yacht Club racing seen here in years.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 2. -- Flashing a steady, often brilliant, game of golf, Johnny Fischer of the University of Michigan and Cincinnati defeated Billy Howell of Washington and Lee University, 2 and 1, to win the national intercollegiate golf title for 1932 at the Cascades Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Memorial plaques honoring the memory of Stephen Tyng Mather, founder and first director of the National Parks Service, will be dedicated Monday on his sixty-fifth birthday anniversary, in ten of the national parks and monuments in the United States, and in the Indiana Dunes State Park near Chicago.

THE colleges are up in arms against broadcasting. The wholesale microphoning of football will be stopped in the Autumn if the Eastern Intercollegiate Association has its way. And the Big Ten in the West reports that a ban on gridiron broadcasting is also favored in that area.

RYE, N.Y., July 2. -- Plowing through a water-blown northwester that puffed from twenty to thirty knots, sixty-four crafts engaged this afternoon in the American Yacht Club's forty-ninth annual regatta, which was the seventh season's championship of the sound.

LATONIA, Ky., July 2. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Stepenfetchit, disappointing favorite in the recent renewal of the American Derby, atoned for that defeat today when he accounted for the golden jubilee running of the $15,000 added Latonia Derby, W.R. Coe's Osculator, which finished second in the Belmont Stakes.

WILL LEVINGTON COMFORT displays great skill and a the artistic imagination of in ease with which he handles widely diverse literary material in his novel. "Apache." published last year, he chronicled the life of an Indian chief, Mangus Colorado.

Preparations being made for Fall business by manufacturers of home furnishings products are founded on the belief that price liquidation has come to an end in that field and a general firming in quotations is certain, according to opinions expressed by producers in key lines yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Senator Norris gave his support to Governor Roosevelt in the coming Presidential contest today. In a statement he said:
"When the warm sun beats down upon the fisherman as it had during the last few days, his thoughts usually turn to the sea, especially if he lives close to the coast.

BOSTON, July 2. -- William Wheeler, for many years a hydraulic and consulting engineer with offices in Boston and one-time president of the Sapporo Agricultural College in Japan, died late last night at his home in Concord, after several years of failing health.

BERLIN, July 1. -- The Reich's new balanced budget, appropriating 8,200,000,000 marks (about $1,951,600,000) -- 1,200,000,000 marks (about $285,600,000) less than its predecessor and carrying nothing for reparations -- has just been passed by the Reichsrat (federal council) and made provisional law by a Presidential emergency decree.
