Declines in the adjusted indices of freight car loadings, electric power production and carded cotton cloth production more than offset advances in the adjusted indices of automobile production and steel mill activity, and the combined NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index has consequently fallen to a new low record.

GUAYAQUIL, June 26. -- Dr. Alfredo Baquerizo Moreno, who became Chief Executive of Ecuador after Provisional President Lanea Alba had been forced to resign because of his attempt to become dictator, says he will be pleased when he can turn the presidency over next August to his successor, President-elect Neptali Bonifaz, and there is no doubt of his sincerity, for this is not the first time he has held this high office.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Governor Roosevelt was warmly welcomed by Chicago today during a quick trip through the streets from the Municipal Airport to the Democratic convention stadium, where he was form ally notified of his nomination for President.

WALTER P. CHRYSLUR, chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation, has written a letter addressed to all distributer, dealer and field organizations announcing July 6 as the first anniversary of the introduction of "floating power" la the Plymouth.

HENDAYE, France, June 20. -- The Basques of France are watching sympathetically the efforts of their brothers in Spain to regain the autonomous government which their united race enjoyed hundreds of years before they knew either Spanish or French rule.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- An early and vigorous Democratic campaign throughout the country was urged by Governor Roosevelt tonight as he established himself in the Presidential suite at the Congress Hotel for a brief stay in the convention city.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The Stadium was slow in filling up for the last session. Tired delegates dragged themselves to their places; visitors, too, had slept late to make up for the all-night session of two nights before and the busy day yesterday in which the nominee finally was chosen.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 2. -- Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers, Manuel Alonso of Spain and New York and two representatives of the University of California at Los Angeles reached the semi-final round of the annual invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- Owen Carroll hurled the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-to-3 trriumph over the league-leading Cubs today, and thus broke the Reds' losing streak of nine straight. The visitors pounded Charley Root hard in the first and fourth frames. Bob Smith and Jakie May finished the game.

MUCH historical research went into the making of this book, and the author has treated his surprisingly large collection of material with scholarly methods and in the historical spirit. His study of his theme brought him to the conclusion that a strongly religious spirit has Inspired what we symbolize by "the White House" all through our history, and that this spirit has furnished the background for our national development.

Charges that Russia fomented the Shanghai conflict between Japan and China, in an effort to cause another world war which would bring about the self-destruction of capitalistic civilization, are made by the Intelligence Office of the Council Board of the new Manchukuo Government in its "Report on Plots to Disturb North Manchuria," which has just reached here.

Aided by Rood fortune and a pair of home runs by Don Hurst and Virgil Davis, the ambitious Phillies made it two straight over the luckless Dodders at Ebbets Field yesterday, 6 to 3, and remained close behind the fourth-place Cardinals.

WHEN Dr. Diana Saffron is found dead from gas in her room at the Women's City Club, Inspector Boot Is inclined to suspect young Dr. Freda Carter or her fiance, Sebastian Thurlow. Dr. Carter is Dr. Saffron's heir, and, furthermore, Dr. Saffron has opposed her protegee's marriage on the ground that it would ruin Freda's career as a physician.

ATLANTIC CITY. ASIDE from the immediate problem of whether our democracy can keep the schools going during the financial depression, no question, apparently, looms larger in the minds of the country's school men and women, as represented at the seventieth annual convention of the National Education Association just closed here, than whether the schools can keep democracy going.

EXHIBITIONS of every-day objects of household utility are gaining the increasing interest of the public because of the rapidly improving design of such articles. During the past season thousands of persons visited displays in museums in New York and other cities to view the latest styles of chairs, fabrics and chinaware.

The thousands of New Yorkers who prefer shining sands to concrete pavements and whispering winds to exploding firecrackers as the background for their Fourth of July celebrations continued their exodus from the metropolitan area yesterday by rail, water, road and air.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Robert Gardiner has returned to the Carlyle from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

SHANGHAI, July 2. -- Japanese police and Manchukuo troops, led by a Japanese adviser, entered the private residence of Robert M. Talbot, the commissioner in charge of the Chinese customs office at Antung, Manchuria, last Thursday, and at the point of a revolver compelled him to surrender his archives and documents.
HARBIN, May 29. -- Although Manchuria's door of trade may be wide open in theory, it will never be open in fact as long as the Chinese merchant continues to mistrust Japanese intentions."

PARIS, July 1. -- Any French Premier who wrote a book on the trials and tribulations of his entrance into office could make a very harrowing tale. Of course, that is true enough of any governmental leader anywhere, but somehow French politics seeing to be an extra hard school, and of all Premiers since the war M. Herriot managed to have the bumpiest road to travel.

SHANGHAI, June 3. -- A storm of indignant protest and a howl of ribald amusement has been aroused by Chang Chi, a veteran Kuomintang politician, and a pillar of the Nanking Government, who declared at Loyang that the Chinese universities should for the next twenty years abandon all courses in law, political science, philosophy and literature, and confine themselves to training technical and scientific experts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published an editorial, "Learning to Speak French" -- a subject to which I have given some time and thought. The pronunciation of French is more difficult for English than for German-speaking people.

Bernard Cohen, Port Richmond High School net captain, won the Staten Island junior tennis singles championship by defeating Gerald McCarthy, 6-1, 6-2, in the title final at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, yesterday. Finals in the doubles and in the mixed doubles are slated for today.

BEAR, MOUNTAIN, N.Y. July 2. -- Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York won the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 220-yard back-stroke championship in world's record time at a water carnival conducted over a fifty-five-yard stretch in the sylvan lagoon at Palisades Interstate Park today.

LINDEN, N.J., July 2. -- Stanislaus Felix Hausner, Polish-American aviator who was picked up at sea eight days after he had been forced down on an unsuccessful attempt to fly from New York City to Warsaw, Poland, will be the guest of honor here next Saturday at the fifth demonstration in honor of his return to safety.

A FEW ANNE MORGANISMS. THE rank of Commander in the Lesion of Honor -- the second highest grade In the Napoleonic decoration of the French Republic -- is now held by two women, the Countess de Noailles and Miss Anne Morgan.

Moscow. IT is necessary to travel to Tiflis to make the acquaintance of Niro Phirosmanishvill, a genuine phenomenon in the line of painting. And an unforeseen incident almost robbed me of this experience. For just when I arrived a general housecleaning was going on in the National Museum in Tiflis.

Recent developments indicate the possibility that the American Railway Association, which in one form or another has existed for about fifty years, may within a short time be expanded and made the instrument for correcting many of the conditions now considered handicaps to railroad operation.
A COMMUNITY should support its music as a matter of course; it should subsidize its orchestra just as it subsidizes the safety, health and transportation of its citizens.

When the cornerstone of the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Centre was laid yesterday morning by Lord Southborough, chairman of the syndicate sponsoring the structure, John D. Rockefeller Jr. announced that it was a profound belief "in the growing spirit of internationalism throughout the world" that had moved him to set up "a practical example of cooperation among nations."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial, "Birth and Death," has been read with interest and appreciation. As you say, the birth rate in this country in 1930 was the same as that for 1929 (18.9 per 1,000 population), while the death rate decreased from 11.9 to 11.3 per 1,000 population.
Joe Fickel of Kansas State College won the National Amateur Athletic Union 134-pound wrestling championship in Madison Square Garden last night on the Olympic scoring system.

AN out-of-town version of the open art market idea, which was tried out with such conspicuous success in Washington Square recently, has been inaugurated at Nash'a Corner, Westport. Conn. This venture, staged by twenty-two artists, including several craft workers, is being run on a strictly cooperative basis.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 2. -- F. Dickerson annexed the high scratch cup in the registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club's traps today. He returned a card of 91 out of a possible 100 targets.

Butter. Receipts, 7,020 packages. The market cleaned up pretty well Friday afternoon in most stores, but on Saturday, with a good deal of stock being unloaded and trade pretty well over for the week, increased selling pressure was noticeable, and part of the recent advance was lost.

TORONTO, July 2 (Canadain Press). -- Australia today defeated Eastern Canada in the first test match of the tour of Canada and the United States by ten wickets. Set 55 runs to win, the Antipodeans made the Canadian bowling look easy and knocked off the necesary runs for the loss of one wicket.
PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP). -- Bombarding Ray Kremer for three runs in the first inning, the St. Louis Cardinals handed the Pittsburgh Pirates another setback today, 5 to 4.

MOSUL, June 15. -- During the last two and a half months the army of Iraq and the British Royal Air Force have been fighting a small but interesting war in one of the wildest countries of the world, the mountainous district of the Turkish border, which forms part of what is loosely known as Kurdistan.

BERLIN. THE writings of Count Hermann Keyserling usually take a personal impression as to the point of departure for an extension of the individual self of a distinguished mind into the broad universality of philosophic thought.

WARSAW, July 1. -- President Hoover's disarmament proposal met a decidedly bad reception here, being called too simple to be good and a new American bull in the European china shop. It is held that his program, if adopted in its entirety, would lead inevitably to war in Europe.
A year ago a friend gave William Dorhman a home-made dinghy, a crazily built craft with a beam almost half its length.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2. -- The forty-second congress of the American Whist League, in progress here, has completed its five-day schedule of the venerable game of whist and turned to bridge.

SUMTER, S.C., June 30. -- Dry sentiment, since the advent of prohibition, has been as strongly entrenched in South Carolina as the Democratic party itself -- and let it be recalled that, despite the big hullabaloo in the presidential year of 1928, it returned about its usual Democratic majority.

Speaker GARNER remarked philosophically late on Friday: "Politics is funny." This he could not have meant as a mere comment on the part which he had played prior to and in the Chicago convention. But if his sudden throwing over of his delegates to Governor ROOSEVELT was fun for him, it was death to the alliance of which he was supposed to be an unyielding member.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2. -- The United States Army polo team, consisting of Lieutenants McFarland, Jones and Read on the forward line and Major Smith at back, advanced to the second round of the Meadow, Brook Club Cup tournament by defeating Cyril Harrison's Hurricane quartet, 12 to 9, today at Cochran Field.

An analysis of the trend of steel prices during the last twelve years shows that the industry has been thoroughly deflated, according to the National Association of Flat Rolled Steel Manufacturers. The average price of steel has declined 54.9 per cent from the 1920 post-par price level, compared with a decline of 45.5 per cent for all commodities during the period, the survey shows.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 2. -- Tale's varsity crew, which remained at Gales Ferry after its defeat by Harvard, this morning had its last practice on the Thames River for this season.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- The text of the address of Representative John McDuffie of Alabama nominating Speaker John Nance Garner for the Vice Presidency follows:

"POLITICS," said Ambassador Mellon recently, "next to baseball, is perhaps our favorite national pastime." It is only once every four years that the interest in this national game rises to absorption, but the game is always with us.

In preparation for the international matches with the touring Australian cricketers, due here on July 14, two teams composed of players who will oppose the invaders engaged in another trial contest yesterday at Dycktnan Oval.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 2. -- Twenty-nine boats in three classes of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, namely the Atlantic, Beach Club and Fish classes, raced over courses varying in length from eight to ten miles in Cold Spring Harbor and Long Island Sound today.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The opinion that Tammany Hall's last-ditch stand against the nomination of Governor Roosevelt, including the reputed opposition of Mayor Walker to a shift from former Governor Smith, will help rather than hurt the party's nominee in many sections of the country was expressed by leading Democrats at the convention hall this afternoon.

BERLIN. USUALLY the Berlin Summer is marked by a series of revivals of past successes. This was formerly a pleasant characteristic: it gave us the chance to renew our acquaintanceship with the masterpieces of preceding years.

HARBIN, May 29. -- The influx of Korean refugees into Harbin from the eastern zone of the Chinese Eastern Railway continues unabated, with the spread of military unrest. A serious social problem has been created.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2. -- Sheriff Bernard M. Cannon of Middlesex County, who telegraphed Roosevelt leaders at the Democratic convention to dispute Frank Hague's claim that the New York Governor could not defeat President Hoover in New Jersey or "any State east of the Mississippi," predicted today here that Roosevelt "will sweep New Jersey by at least 100,000 majority, and Middlesex County by a 20,000 to 25,000 majority."
UTICA, N.Y., July 2. -- An insurgent group called the "militants" developed in the State convention of the Socialist party, which opened here today.

CHARLES F. BRABIN, who has several worthy films to his credit. is responsible for the Intelligent and generally restrained direction of "New Morals for Old," an adaptation of John Van Druten's play "After All." In the picture, which was at the Capitol.

CINCINNATI. RECALLING the Cincinnati Art Museum of ten years or more ago, it is less the matter of its collections that one remembers than the matter of its mental and, if you like, its spiritual atmosphere.

GERTRUDE LAWRENCE'S last appearance on these shores was with Noel Coward in the stage production of the latter's "Private Lives." Now, a sufficiently rare phenomenon, she is at the Rivoli in a film version of Lonsdale's "Aren't We All?" which Paramount produced in England.

At midnight tonight when the ninety-second year of the Cunard Line closes, every ship of the fleet with one exception will be plying the seas with passengers, H.P. Borer, general passenger manager of the line announced yesterday. The one exception is the Andanla, which will be at Liverpool over the holidays.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- Alfred E. Smith was described today by those who had breakfast with him as being exceptionally cheerful and looking forward to spending a quiet Summer.
LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP). -- Aimee Semple McPherson Hutton, the evangelist, expressed faith today in her husband, David Hutton, defendant in a love suit filed by Myrtle St. Pierre.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 2. -- A big batch of mid-West track and field athletes and a few from the South took a few wallops at records today as they concluded the section's Olympic trials at Dyche Stadium.

Prints by John Sloan, William C. McNulty, Abbo Ostrowsky, W. Woiseeke and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody are on view, during July, at the Grand Central Gallery. Few new plates are included in the show and its value is largely retrospective. This very quality of "deja vue" confers upon the group much of the interest it possesses.

WITH the closing of schools for the Summer more than 500,000 girls in Greater New York, it has been found, will be seeking recreation. While some will spend part or all of the Summer months in camps or out of town with their parents, the great majority will be "on their own" without any organized recreation.
BABYLON, L.I., July 2. -- The first races of a three-day meet under the auspices of the Babylon Yacht Club were held today with twenty-seven boats competing in ten classes.

WESTPORT ON CHAMPLAIN, N.Y. -- A novelty in Fourth of July celebrations in this part of the Adirondacks has been made possible this year by the opening of the new Aviation Club on Lake Champlain, Inc., which is another link in the chain of such clubs being spread across the country.

Thirty-eight matches have been planned for the racing season in the waters of the British Isles among the large racing yachts Britannia, which is the King's own; Shamrock V, the last America's Cup challenger, now owned by T.O.M. Sopwith; Candida, White Heather and Astra. They will follow the coast from Harwich to Plymouth.

BUSHIRE, Persia, June 12. -- At this port and along the Persian littoral of the gulf no Winter or Spring rains fell and in consequence there has been not only a total crop failure but famine and actual lack of drinking water. Almost the whole population is dependent on agriculture and thus, suddenly, finds itself penniless and deprived of every means of support.

DUBLIN, July 1. -- Great Britain's decision to tax Irish goods and President de Valera's intention to retaliate are regarded here as the first shots in a struggle which will determine whether the Free State shall remain in the British Empire. It is felt that within the next six months the struggle should be settled one way or the other by a general election.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, who opposed the nomination of Governor Roosevelt and voted to the last for former Governor Smith, indicated clearly today that they would support the Democratic national ticket.

EVERYWHERE the need for quicker traffic facilities between airports and the hearts of the cities they serve is being felt. From Newark Metropolitan Airport, the busiest by far in the world, the impressive elevated highway, to cost $22,500,000, is fast nearing completion.

Fluctuations in commodity markets last week were mostly narrow. In some instances, however, prices showed better resistance to selling pressure than in several weeks. This was attributed partly to the low level at which those commodities are selling. As a whole, trading was slightly more active than in the several preceding weeks, although the turnover of wool tops, cocoa and coffee was moderately less than in the week before.

NEWPORT -- The coming of July finds everybody in the Summer colony here ready for a busy time that will continue through the Summer. Today they seem to be facing one of the busiest weeks of the season, judging from the number of events that have been crowded upon the program for the next six days.

With the Stock Exchange closed yesterday for an extra holiday, financial developments were few. In the present condition of the markets, this adjournment for a day hardly changed the aspect of things from what it would have been with that market open.

To the Dramatic Editor: To E.J. Carstens, whose letter, printed in last Sunday's dramatic section of THE TIMES, voices a most troubling regret at being unable to see the "great" of the New York stage, I would like to Bay a few words, founded on my own.

ROME, July 1. -- Two gigantic enterprises recently have attracted wide interest in Europe. First is that of Holland for drying up the Zuider Zee and second is that of Italy for the reclamation of the Pontine marshes. Holland, needing apace for a dense population of seventy-seven to the square mile, seeks to recover lands from the sea which engulfed it seven centuries ago.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended June 25 were higher than at any time during the month, and increased 5 per cent over the preceding week, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

CHICACO, July 2. -- John J. Raskob, retiring chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who financed the Smith 1928 campaign and liberally supported the expenses of the committee in the last four years, was a silent and disappointed spectator at the Democratic convention in the last day, after the Smith allied forces had failed to stop the nomination of Governor Roosevelt.

HAVANA, July 2. -- Despite the announcement of the Sugar Institute on June 28 of a project for forming an 800,000-ton sugar pool, it has been abandoned and negotiations during the last few days between Cuban and American sugar holders paved the way for the obligatory formation off the 700,000-ton pool by a decree signed by President Machado today.

In an office building near Madison Square, the address of which was not revealed, Federal agents under Major Joseph A. Manning, district supervisor of the narcotic bureau, made a raid Friday night and discovered a chemical laboratory which had been used, they said, to turn out fake morphine mainly composed of quinine.

TORONTO, Ont., July 2. -- W.A. Mackenzie, Minister of Mines of British Columbia, says in his report for 1931 that Placer Mining had a busy and successful year, production amounting to $291,922, compared with $125,315 in 1930. Furthermore, the work done indicated that Placer-gold production would increase in the future.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 2. -- The growing importance, nationally and internationally, of institutes for the discussion of public affairs was emphasized in addresses delivered by Stanislaw Massalski, secretary of the Polish Embassy, and others at the institute on institutes held here today.

THE plan for paying for injuries caused by motor vehicles, recentJy set forth by the Committee to Study Compensation for Automobile Accidents, has engendered considerable interest and debate among the groups concerned with the problem.

MOSCOW, July 1. -- The Soviet Union views political and economic manoeuvres of the capitalist world with a suspicious eye and is never slow in predicting failures for such things as the Geneva and Lausanne conferences.

Veteran steamship men said yesterday that the peak of the eastbound transatlantic travel had been reached last week with the sailing of the North German Lloyd liner Europa with 2,054 passengers, of whom 571 were in the first class, and that this peak would continue until the end of the month.

ISTANBUL, July 1. -- The National Assembly is still discussing the budget for the financial year that opened today. It is expected that revenue and expenditures will balance at 169,000,000 Turkish, lire or about $80,000,000. Last year expenditures totaled 194,000 lire and the previous year 232,000,000 lire.

The British trawler-built vessel William Scoresby, designed for study of oceanographic conditions, has returned to London after eighteen months of research in Antarctic waters and the Pacific. From South Georgia she sailed as far as the Weddell Sea, on the side of the polar continent opposite to the Bay of Whales.

SEATTLE, June 30. -- Two powerful forces are operating to extinguish the salmon-packing industry in the Pacific Northwest -- overfishing without proper provision for replenishing the supply and the damming of streams for the storage of water for irrigation or for the production of electrical energy.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The prayer delivered at the closing session today of the Democratic National Convention by the Rev. Rolland W. Schloerb, pastor of the Hyde Park Baptist Church of Chicago, reads as follows:

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Before it adjourned tonight, after unanimously nominating Speaker John N. Garner of Texas for Vice President, the Democratic National Convention saw and heard its Presidential choice of yesterday, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- To Philadelphia oarsmen went the honor of being the first chosen to represent this country at the "Olympic games when the Penn Athletic Club four with coxswain and the veteran Bachelors Barge Club double of Ken Myers and W.E. Garrett-Gilmore raced over a windswept course on the Schuylkill River today to triumph in their events.

SOMETHING ought to be done about booksellers' catalogues. They are growing too numerous and their technical and literary contents have developed along such interesting lines that we cannot afford to overlook them. We should hardly suggest curtailing the output, for the bibliographical and linguistic talents shown, especially in some of the more recent brochures, are too rich and various to be denied so harmless an outlet.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Speaker John Nance Garner of the House, with only two State delegations at his command, has carried out the role of "king maker" of the Democratic National Convention.

FOR twice 200 years -- lacking a trifling round dozen of revolutions of the sun -- William Byrd 2d has lain beneath the sod of his garden beside his mansion of Westover with its high-peaked roof and tall chimneys. Above the grave stands a monument celebrating his accomplishments and the exalted company he kept.

In The Harvard Graduates' Magazine the widow of Professor MUENSTERBERG revives memories of her first years in America, where she wag to stay. For the most part they are pleasant memories. The outbreak of the great war, which brought so unreasonable a persecution, of her husband, is but lightly touched.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 2. -- Robert Rice Reynolds, a militant wet, won an overwhelming victory in today's Democratic primary, when he was nominated over Senator Cameron Morrison upholder of the dry cause by a majority far in excess of the 50,000 plurality Mr. Reynolds received in the first primary on June 4.

SIGNOR MALAPARTE is no parlor-Fascist. He is the real article. He took an active part in the seizure of Florence in 1922 and accompanied Mussolini on the march to Rome. He has been advertised as a poet, diplomat and close associate of II Duce.
LONDON, July 2 (AP). -- Former King Manoel's secretary said he was stricken while preparing to go as usual to the Wimbledon tennis championships.

IN spite of the Summer season, when dance events are generally supposed to go into a fallow period, there is considerable activity to be noted here and there. Mention has already been made of the several events to be held in the immediate vicinity.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Platforms of the two national parties adopted here in the last fortnight have offered no panaceas for the solution of the agricultural problem, said F.E. Murphy, publisher of The Minneapolis Tribune, who offered a farm program to the platform makers of both parties.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- With a fleet of forty-one yachts, the yacht racing season on Moriches Bay started today off the West Hapmton Country Club on the Speonk Shore. The wind was exceptionally strong. At the start it was from the south-west, moving into the northwest and again backing into the southwest as the afternoon advanced.

IN ALL the current discussion of the uncertain future of opera in New York there is one group of operagoers from which little has been heard-those whom Olin Downes in his recent article in THE TIMES MAGAZINE described as "the people of plain lives and moderate means or less."

WHAT are schools doing to help out in the unemployment emergency? A recent canvass of superintendents in cities large and small by the Fedtral Office of Education discloses that school systems throughout the country are marshaling their resources to meet the unusual conditions produced by the depression.

PUBLISHED by authority of King George, we have here the ninth and final volume of those letters, that journal which, for all time, will be the one authentic and enduring monument of Queen Victoria as she really was.
FOR the first time since the issue was raised in the hallowed past, the American public is promised in 1932 an opportunity to vote on national prohibition.

CINCINNATI, July 2. -- James Norris Gamble, vice president of the Procter Gamble Company and one of Cincinnati's most charitable and beloved citizens, died in his sleep early today at his home here. He would have been 96 years old on Aug. 9.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- When Governor Pinchot and the State Legislature are within the Harrisburg city limits at the same time, Pennsylvania folk usually can look forward to a few weeks of entertainment. They are accustomed to watching the Governor present a program, tailing the legislators with, a crack of the whip that he wants it adopted and finally seeing it scrapped, all or in part.

Faced with a city order to vacate the rectory of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, at Duane Street and City Hall Place, by Aug. 1, Mgr. William E. Cashin, pastor of the church, declared yesterday that he and his staff would remain until the "marshal puts us on the street," because the city had failed to carry out its share of an agreement to exchange other land for the rectory site.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30. -- Without deluding itself with what may be just around the corner, this commercial and industrial area is cheered by signs which give hope that at least the trough of the depression has been reached. Confidence that the outlook is for better things is indicated in the new businesses opened during May.

BOSTON, June 30. -- The State of Maine is waiting to see what may be the fate of the bill sponsored by its junior Senator, Wallace H. White Jr., and matched by another measure sponsored by Representative John E. Nelson, "for the conservation of lobsters."

Resisting four armed men who confronted him and his brother in the corridor of the apartment house in which they live at 2,363 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, Enrico Taddeo, 32 years old, was shot and critically wounded in the right side early this morning.

The stifling mugginess that oppressed New York most of last week was broken yesterday by a wave of cool weather and northwest winds blowing as high as fifty-one miles an hour that followed on the heels of a storm which struck the metropolitan area late Friday night, leaving a trail of crop and property damage and causing one death in Westchester County and one serious casualty in New Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP). -- George Earnshaw and Rube Walberg pitched the Athletics to victory in a double-header with Washington today, the league champions taking the first contest in eleven innings, 2 to 1, and the second, 5 to 4, before 10,000.

CHICAGO. THE most dramatic contrast suggested by the political Olympics in Chicago is not the wellknown contrast between the official behavior of Democrats and Republicans. They do behave differ- ently, of course.

THE great mystic poets have one intensity in common, their ability to feel and convey a sense of unity. But they differ in the ways in which they arrive at this sense of unity, and, in the image or symbol or Idea which they name unity.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Alfred E. Smith departed for New York City this afternoon, leaving unanswered that question asked repeatedly by interviewers: whether or not he would support the Democratic national ticket in November.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Benjamin S. Dean, in a letter to THE TIMES, "assumes it is hardly necessary to defend Eliot Tuckerman" against my criticism of his stand on the constitutional requirement of a two-thirds vote in Congress for the proposal of amendments and for overriding vetoes.

BOSTON, July 2. -- Outbatted in both games of the double-header today by the lowly Red Sox, the Yanks won the first game, 8 to 5, on a collapse of the local keystone defense in the sixth inning, but lost the second, 6 to 5, making the series stand even, two games to two, with one to play.

MANY things have happened since that Black Thursday in October, 1929, when Richard Whitney in a strenuous endeavor to stem the falling prices of stocks stalked onto the floor of the New York Stock Exchange and bid in steel at 205.

NEW ORLEANS, June 30. -- The remainder of the United States can find in the current session of the Louisiana Legislature much which will enable it to understand Senator Huey P. Long. Here it is an old story, but those who have been amazed by the self-styled Kingfish's actions and utterances in Washington and Chicago may find the key to his conduct in the proceedings at Baton Rouge.

THE New York Orchestra, under the direction of Modest Altschuler, is scheduled to give the first of a projected series of Summer concerts in the George Washington Stadium, 194th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, next Tuesday evening.

Views ranging from hope to confidence in the progressive growth of Governor Roosevelt as a champion of the people were expresed in many newspaper editorials over the country commenting upon the Democratic nominee for the Presidency. There was a tendency to await proof of this strength.

MAGDEBURG, Germany, June 23 (By mail). -- So long as strained relations remain between Germany and Poland there is grave danger that Russian bolshevism may overrun Europe, according to Franz Seldte, chief commander of Steel Helmets, the ex-service men's organization.

Arthur Perina of Port Richmond, former Curtis High School track captain, made his first appearance in Staten Island competition since 1929 and captured the men's individual scoring honors with 13 points in the annual Richmond County A.A.U. track and field championships at Curtis Field, New Brighton, yesterday.

SOLOISTS for the Toscanini Fund concerts by the Musicians' Emergency Aid at Columbia University and at Hunter and City Colleges during July and August include Ivan Ivantzoff, tenor; Mary and Virginia Drane, violinists, and Edward Weiss, pianist, Sandor Harmati, Theophil Wendt, Jaffrey Harris and Paul Eisler will conduct.

TRENTON, N.J., July 2. -- The effect in New Jersey of the nomination of Governor Roosevelt, along with the adoption by his party of a plank pledging repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, is being closely watched by observers here.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- An amazing situation whereby fourteen States received from the Federal Treasury in the fiscal year 1931 $24,040,501 more than they paid toward the national tax burden has grown out of the steadily expanding program of direct Federal aid to States, it is revealed by figures compiled in the office of Representative Robert L. Bacon, Republican, of New York.

EVER since the Summer of 1918, when I skirted the northern fringe of the Great South Desert of Arabia on my way down to Wadi Dawasir and heard from my companions the strange story of a buried city in those sands, the discovery of that city and the exploration of the Rub al Khali have been the goal of my ambition.

EVERY one is captivated by General Washington." Such is the sincere tribute of Major Carl von Baurmeister. Adjutant General to the force of German mercenaries who were hired by King George III of England to beat his American subjects into submission in 1776.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Counsel for A.A. Chapman, former confidential secretary to the late Thomas E. Mitten, head of Philadelphia's transit system, declared today that David Ainey, son of William D.B. Ainey, chairman, of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, had been employed as an engineering assistant by the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company during Mr. Mitten's regime.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 2. -- Miss Grace Surber, 39-year-old star from the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, won the women's metropolitan clay court title today by defeating Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch, former champion, 6-1, 6-1, in the final round at the Lido Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 1. LEW LESLIE has come to the rescue of this city's theatrical reputation with a revue called "Clowns in Clover," which made a fairly satisfactory start at the Apollo Theatre last Sunday night. This show falls into the neutral zone between the "intimate" revues and the copious extravaganzas of the Broadway ring-masters.

STOCKHOLM. ATTACHED to the notices of Ivar Kreuger's death in the obituary columns of the Stockholm papers last March were the words "No flowers by request: remember the Flower Fund." Familiar though these words have long been to Stock holmers, to foreigners they are a clue to a charity which is probably unique.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2. -- Richard Murphy of Utica, N.Y., and Hamilton College, the defending champion, gained the final round of the New Jersey State Men's Singles tennis championship today by capturing a three-set battle from Berkeley Bell of New York at the Montclair A.C.

LONDON, July 2 (Canadian Press). -- British Cabinet members completing preparations for attending the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa on July 21 had before them today a report of leaders of the British cotton industry declaring that reduction of the Canadian tariffs on cottons was essential if the British industry was to obtain an equitable share of the Canadian market.

T.S. STRIBLING has chosen a staggering theme for "The Store," the second volume of his projected trilogy of the South from pre-Civil War days to the present. In comparison with this incisive, vigorous and salty chronicle of the era of the first Cleveland democracy in the country laid waste by reconstruction, the initial volume of Mr. Stribling's novelized social history seems dwarfed.

IT is asserted by ordnance officers that anti-aircraft guns are nearly eight times as efficient today as they were during the World "War. At that time it was estimated that for every 20,000 shells fired by the anti-craft Runs there was one direct hit.

With all the security markets and most of the commodity exchanges closed, business in the financial centres was sharply curtailed yesterday. Only the Cotton Exchange among those in New York remained open. However, the banks did business as usual and dealings took place in foreign exchange.

WESTCHESTER -- Under the personal direction of Alexander Brook a three-months' Summer course will be given at the artist's home at Cross River, in Westchester County. The school will be conducted by Mme. Winifred Negulesco. An exhibition of the paintings by Alexander Brook is current, until July 4, at the Westchester County Centre, White Plains.

GLUCKEL of Hameln lived her long and busy life and wrote her memoirs in the second half of the seventeenth century and the first quarter or the eighteenth, 1646-1724. She wrote the seven little books that told the story of her life for her children out of the depths of her heart, and she produced a classic.

DESPITE alarming announcements about pending changes in policy and rumors of radical alterations to take place in the immediate future, Columbia's periodical lists continue to be published, and the selections still give evidence of the good Judgment which has been behind them these many years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What is the price we pay for second or third terms in our Senate and House? Or for any of our governmental jobs, Federal, State or local? A pretty stiff figure, one may be sure.

VIENNA, June 21. -- In a local court here the magistrate was called upon today to decide whether a box on the ears was administered at a seance by a disembodied spirit or by a corporate Viennese plumber. The latter was charged by the plaintiff, Herr Franz, with hitting him in the face during a conversation with the spirit world.

MR. GEORGE ADE never saw the inside of a modern speak-easy and never will, unless, as he phrases it. "some one blindfolds me and backs me in." He gave a great deal of attention to the study of saloons, however, when he was younger and drinking was constitutional, and he writes the present little volume as an expert who knows all the kinds of saloons there used to be.

AFRESH onslaught against certain expenditures by the Federal Government for war veterans has been prepared by the National Economy League, an organization of former service men which recently mustered 200,000 signatures to a petition to Congress charging that $450,000,000 of the veterans' relief program is waste or needless expense.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Ethelbert Stewart, Commissioner of Labor Statistics and widely recognized as the foremost analyst of labor conditions in the United States, arose today to find himself without a job. He is resting up a bit, he says, before starting out on his "job hunt."

THE first book to bear the joint imprint of Frederick A. Stokes Company and Yale University Press will be "Man's Rough Road," by Professor A.G. Keller of Yale. It is described as the life story of human society for the general reader, giving backgrounds and bearings from mankind's experience.

One of the mysterious areas of the world the great southern desert of Arabia. Rub' al Khali, is giving up its secrets. Last year Bertram Thomas traversed its eastern section; early this year H.St. John Philby made a zigzag journey through the heart of the desert, crossing the Empty Quarter from west to east for the first time, and finally disposing of the myth of the legendary city of Wabar.

George de Ghika, Hungarian consul general here, announced yesterday that he had just received from the Hungarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Budapest the following message relative to the Hungarian State loan of 1924:

ROME, June 21, 1932. THE program has Just been published for an important music festival to be held in Florence next Spring, under the title of "Maggio Musicals Florentino," an initiative sponsored by Premier Mussolini himself.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Speaker Garner took his nomination with modesty. He left his own office a few minutes before he was nominated and for more than four hours played hide and seek with a group of photographers and reporters.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Thousands of members of the bonus expeditionary force assembled on the steps of the Capitol this morning to protest against the adjournment of Congress without passing a bonus bill and left in bitter disappointment when they found that both houses had recessed until Tuesday.

More than at any time except at the first of the year, the beginning of July is traditionally a turning point at which financial experts attempt to sum up the significance of the period just ended and to pierce the veil obscuring the events to come.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to compliment Maurice Wertheim for his article in THE TIMES last Sunday, "As Europe Sees Us."

The major monetary problem now facing the world, in the view of many bankers and economists, is the future of the pound sterling and the policy to be pursued by Great Britain, pending a return to the gold standard.

ALTHOUGH this year's boat-race between the crews of Harvard and Yale was not the eightieth meeting of oarsmen from the two colleges, eighty years have elapsed since crews from the two institutions first tried conclusions at the sweeps.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2. -- Alta, the sprightly bay mare owned by Fred Tejan, took the rosette in the polo pony championship, one of the feature classes at the third annual Saxon Woods horse show, held on the club grounds by the Saxon Woods Hunt Club today.

ON a ''clear, cold evening in February. 1865," as Herr Iltis tells us, the members of the Brunn Society for the Study of Natural Science met in their little Moravian city to hear a paper by one of their members, Pater Gregor Mendel, an Augustinian monk and professor of the Modern School, on "Experiments in Plant Hybridization."

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Last night's sensational break in the balloting for President by the delegates to the Democratic National Convention, by which Texas and California furnished ninety votes and started the stampede which resulted in the nomination of Roosevelt, furnished revenge on Alfred E. Smith for William Randolph Hearst as well as for William G. McAdoo.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., July 2. -- Cadets of the first class from the Military Academy brought to a close three weeks of intensive training with the Coast Artillery Corps Area, the Field Artillery at Fort Bragg, N.C., and the Air Corps at Langley Field today.

WHEN a theatre performance celebrates its premiere the showmen are usually aware of every detail in the acts from beginning to end. But when radio begins a new year of broadcasting, its program planners never know at what moment in the day or night some scene may be lifted from the actual drama of life to add realism, to broadcasting.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- The first in a series of supper dances was held tonight at the Meadow Club Lines of colored lights silhouetted the clubhouse and colored lights and lanterns illuminated the gardens. The guests were seated at small tables placed in cabaret fashion along the walls of the Colonial ballroom and Japanese room, leaving an open space for dancing.

There is no more astute and skillful practical politician than John Nance Garner in Washington, and there are few men in high position in the national capital who are more completely the builders of their own eminence than the present Speaker of the House and Democratic candidate for the Vice Presidency.
Although the tournament calendar is already rather well crowded, the women golfers of Long Island are scheduling another tournament this season.

HISTORY to satisfy boys and girls must be presented in terms of pictures and people, though it is not only youthful readars who enjoy historical writing that la picturesque and vivid and that emphasizes personalities.

HAVANA, July 2. -- General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba, who had been protected in the Brazilian Legation here since May 23, when he sought refuge after a warrant had been issued for his arrest as a leader in a revolutionary plot, left Havana this afternoon aboard the German liner Karlsruhe for France.

OTTAWA, July 1. -- The eyes of the world are turning toward the capital of Canada, where the sessions of the Economic Conference of the British Empire will begin on July 21, and continue, it is believed, until about Sept. 1, with virtually a quarter of the population of the world and about the same proportion of its land surface represented.

Substantial gains in retail sales of men's clothing were registered during June over the previous months of this year and the dollar volume was said to have exceeded that of the corresponding period of last year, according to reports yesterday. Most of the increases, however, were confined to department stores that featured special promotions of men's suits at low prices, as, with few exceptions, specialty chains and independents snowed decreases in dollar figures.

American fanciers of the shepherd dog will be interested in the results of the annual Sieger show, held at Dortmund, Germany, which have just been received on this side. It is notable that in these times the entry reached a total of 300. The senior dogs were judged by Captain Max von Staphanitz, "father of the German shepherd dog," while the bitches were in the very capable hands of Dr. Curt Roesebeck.

PARIS, June 23. -- As the Grand Prix approaches and the Grande Semaine, Paris's big week, draws to at close, certain families of the ancient nobility always entertain their friends at large receptions in accordance with long-standing tradition.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- Top Flight, the entry of C.V. Whitney of New York, won the $15,000-added Arlington Oaks by two lengths today at Arlington Park, with Evening second and Parry third.

A special plea in behalf of the Negro, who, in times of stress, is "among the first to reach the end of his resources," was made yesterday by William Church Osborn in urging support of the Salvation Army's United Appeal for $600,000, the minimum required for the immediate needs of the Army's emergency relief activities in the five boroughs.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 2. -- Manufacturing is still very quiet, but factory stocks are low and a sustained demand is expected to bring resumption of operations on a small scale in some lines.

The Empire City Racing Association's meeting of twenty-two days, which is expected to see the return to competition of the famous son of Sting, Questionnaire, will get under way on Wednesday. James Butler is the president of the Empire City Association and he also is the owner and breeder of Questionnaire so that it is reasonably certain that the champion of the Butler string will be seen in action at the home course.

NEW series of the Willys-Overland sixes and eights and the Willys-Knight sixes, characterized by streamline body design, have been introduced as the advanced 1932 line of the company. The announcement follows the return of John N. Willys to active duty as chairman of the board.

A gradual but distinct change in the viewpoint of American business toward Soviet Russia is reported in a memorandum made public yesterday by the American-Russian Chamber or Commerce, which comments on the ability of the Soviet Governent to meet its financial obligations and on opportunities for economic relief through increased trade relations between the two countries.

THE extended holiday, coupled with fine weather, brought quite a fair increase in trade activity for the week. Summer apparel and accessories, sporting goods and travel equipment enjoyed brisk demand. Low-price promotions on men's clothing continued to draw gpod response, but there was some shifting of the demand to Summer suits.

A GLANCE at what might be called the alcoholic map of the world shows that the United States would have a variety of liquor-control systems to choose from if it decided to abandon national prohibition. Practically every government has interfered with the liquor traffic to the extent of taxing it heavily, largely on the ground that those who did not like to pay the taxes could go without the liquor.

THE week-end orgy is on. July 4 gets in full swing. From now until Labor Day more or less officially closes the city dweller's hunting season for sunshine and fresh air, suitcases are continuously in action.

The annual field training for Army Reserve officers and C.M.T.C. students in the Second Corps Area will get under way this week at eight army posts, it was announced yesterday. The largest single contingent to leave New York for camp will start Tuesday at 8:50 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, when 1,100 C.M.T. C. youths will board a train for Plattsburg at the Grand Central Terminal.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 30. -- Prohibition has caused a sudden and unexpected upturn in Arizona politics and may prove the vital Issue in the coming elections. The issue had been smoldering. Now it has flared out with the announcement of Harlow Akers, Phoenix lawyer, that he is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator against Carl Hayden.

PARIS, July 1. -- The memory of Dom Perignon, Benedictine, the monk who put the sparkle into champagne wines just 250 years ago, was honored this week with the dedication of his statue and appropriate fetes at Epernay, Rheims and Hautevillers.

MARY PICKFORD'S new picture will have Frank Barzage for its director and M.C. Levee, president of the Screen Guild, for its production manager. This does not mean that Mr. Levee's toddling guild is to be left to shift for itself.

LOS ANGELES, July 2. -- Norman B. Sawyer, Stanford honor graduate and son of E.W. Sawyer, an assistant secretary in the Department of the Interior, took his own life here today at the home of an uncle, Arthur J. Davis, a contractor.

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 2. -- Hector Dyer, who led the sprint parade in preliminaries yesterday, showed the way today to Far Western track and field athletes aspiring to the American Olympic team. Winners of the first three places go to the final United States team trials at Palo Alto, Cal., July 15 and 16.

BOXING put it all over golf at the Democratic convention. Jim Farley's fighter, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, won in the fourth round from Ritchie, Garner, Traylor et al. (short for Alfred Emanuel Smith) at a late hour Friday night. The handlers of Ritchie, Garner and Traylor threw towels into the ring to save their men from unnecessary punishment, but Al Smith stayed in there fighting until they counted him out.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 2. -- Bay Constable James B. Ott reported today that the yacht The Penguin, which figured last September in the murder of its owner, Benjamin Collings, had been sold and had been taken to Bridgeport, Conn The sale was made through the attorney for Mrs. Collings.

STEPS in the progress of blind flying which, in a few months, will be part of the equipment of all army as well as commercial transport pilots, were outlined last week by the Army Air Corps. Research activities in this field were intensified in 1918, when Captain (then Lieutenant) Albert F. Hegenberger, took charge of the newly organized instrument unit at McCook Field.

Urging Universal Free Trade. Trade ought to be free. Every human being ought to have the legal right to buy and sell where he can do the best for himself. Let each individual be his own judge in this matter. In other words, tear down all trade walls, all tariffs; give the World absolute free trade.

HANKOW, June 3. -- Secret Communist agents now living in Hankow are making a practice of pasting up numerous posters every night or so declaring that the Communist armies occupying the Red Lake district nearby are mainly anti-Kuomintang in their policies.

Bonds called for payment in June before their maturity dates totaled $9,102,000, the smallest amount in more than five years. The total compared with $15,904,000 retired in May and $86,339,000 in June, 1931. A large part of the calls consisted of partial retirements of issues in which sinking fund requirements made redemptions mandatory in June.

PARIS, June 22. -- Count Serge de Fleury of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who recently visited the United States, delivered an address at the Press Club here on the subject of the depression in America.

To the itinerant citizen the hillside country appears to be outside the depression precincts. Although the early season drought has left the grass thinner than in ideal years and retarded the progress of kitchen gardens, only the practiced eye can make such distinctions.

LAUSANNE, July 2. -- Final agreement was reached today among Germany's governmental creditors on the terms of a reparations settlement. The plan will be officially communicated to the German delegation tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ended June 25 stands at 64.0 as compared with 63.7 for the week ended June 18.

POSTMEN in Europe not only delivet mail but collect radio license fees from set owners along their route. The tax averages about 25 cents a month per set and is the main support of broadcasting in nearly every country in the world except the United States, according to a report on "Broadcasting Abroad," issued by the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education.

THE ninth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography, which carries us from Paxton Hibben, diplomat, radical and biographer, to William Chapman Jarvis, a pioneer taryngologist, is as rich and variegated as any of the volumes that have gone before.

Few changes were noted in general business conditions last month, according to the regular report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Scanning developments throughout the United States and Canada, members of the committe pointed out that encouraging factor in the business picture are lacking.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Governor Roosevelt and his supporters lost no time in taking control of the new Democratic National Committee, which met tonight in the Gold Room of the Congress Hotel and elected as chairman James A. Farley, who successfully conducted Governor Roosevelt's campaign for the nomination.

William Woodward's Faireno, winner of the Belmont and Shevlin Stakes, established the best claim to the 3-year-old championship this year when he won the Dwyer Stakes before 10,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday.

For most of the European governments indebted to the United States the end of the "Hoover year" last Thursday did not raise an immediate difficulty. From all but one of these nations payments are not due until Dec. 15. They have five and a half months' leeway in which to observe the result of efforts to settle the reparations question and then to determine their policy regarding debts owed this country.

IN all the national feting of Amelia Earhart Putnam, no honors perhaps have come to her more gratefully than those which have been given to her as increasing the prestige of her sex. For her flight, in her own view at least, was intended to advance the conquest, not so much of the air as of the lingering prejudice against woman, and to add an incontestable laurel to her brow.

More than 11,000 students, compared with 14,000 a year before, registered in the three-day registration period in the thirty-third Summer session of Columbia University, which will open on Tuesday, it was announced last night. The decline can be explained partly by the Fourth of July coming on the day before opening, said Edward J. Grant, registrar.

Quietly and unostentatiously there were inserted in the platforms of both the Republican and Democratic parties planks providing that the United States would consult with other powers in the event of danger to the peace of the world. This is the more interesting because these planks, very similar in nature, represent the work of both Republican and Democratic leaders over some months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial, "The Next Decimal Point," you showed how the recent invention of the wrecked-atom counter once again verified Lord Kelvin's statement that science is measurement. As other proofs of that dictum, you mentioned Professor Rowland's ingenious diffraction grating, Dr. Coblentz's thermocouple for measuring verious temperatures on Mars and Millikan's electroscope for measuring cosmic rays.

NO one can deny that the Adirondacks are sufficient in themselves to make any motor tour through Northern New York a decided success. When to this region of mountains and lakes are added the attractions of the Thousand Islands, Lake George and Lake Champlain, superlatives are necessary to express the enthusiasm of vacationists.

WATERTOWN, Conn., July 2. -- Championship competitions in the various divisions brought to a successful conclusion the sixth annual horse show of the Watertown Riding and Hunt Club today. Conditions were ideal, heavy rains having settled the dust and brought cool breezes.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- President Hoover, who recently presented Amelia Earhart with a National Geographic Medal for her solo transatlantic flight, today signed a joint resolution authorizing presentation to her of the Distinguished Flying Cross.

Bringing into play an effective block movement, the Braves deftly tripped the Giants in the third game of the current series at the Polo Grounds yesterday, thereby making it necesary for Manager Bill Terry and all his New York delegates to capture the final encounter today if they are to show any majority at all, with or without the two-thirds rule.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2. -- The Harvard Summer School will open on Wednesday and plans for the six-week session are complete. The last examinations will be held on Aug. 16. Arrangements for the session correspond closely to those of last year.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 2. -- The Leander Club's eight, which was victorious as the Cambridge crew in the varsity boat race, won the Grand Challenge Cup today, winning the final by rowing a superb race against the Thames Rowing Club.

Belief that the depression is at its lowest point and that by Fall consumers will be in a position to increase their purchases prompted executives of the country's largest chain shoe store organization last week to schedule a 5 per cent increase in September unit sales for all stores which have been in operation more than a year.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- A row broke out among members of the national prohibition board of strategy tonight over the language to be used in a statement condemning the repeal plank in the Democratic platform and Governor Roosevelt's speech. Issuance of the statement was postponed until tomorrow.

EUREKA, Nev., June 30. -- Last of the States to feel the depression, and still feeling it less than others, Nevada finds itself confronted with an acute taxation tangle. There 16 need of a thorough overhauling of the tax structure, accompanied by stern economies in State, county and city government in the face of falling revenues.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Events of varied character have been planned for Independence Day, which usually marks the beginning of social activity in Southampton. In addition to the many house parties at estates throughout the colony and their attendant round of entertainment, there are several big community undertakings which will claim attention.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Trade Improved little in most foreign countries covered by the current weekly survey made public today by the Commerce Department. A summary follows:

GEORGE ARLISS, who now is playing the country squire at his English home, informs the local Warner office by letter that he expects to return to the United States about Oct. 1 to map "The Adopted Father." This one from a novel by Edgar Franklin, but what has not been announced is that Mr. Arliss is working on the script himself and that he will write a good deal of the dialogue.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The first of a series of ten chamber music concerts is to be given this afternoon at Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music, South Mountain, Pittsfield, with Willem Willeke, violoncellist, again director of the South Mountain String Quartet and Elshuco Trio.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 2. -- Fort Necessity, where George Washington began his military career, will be dedicated as a national shrine tomorrow and Monday on the one-hundred and seventy-eighth anniversary of the mountain wilderness battle of the English colonists against the French and Indians.
RYE, N.Y., July 2. -- Many dinner dances were held tonight at the beach clubs, yacht clubs and country clubs in Westchester County in celebration of the holiday week-end.

SHANGHAI, June 4. -- During peace times in Shanghai about 120 human bodies are picked up and buried in the Potter's Field every day. Ninety per cent of these are infants abandoned by their parents, who are usually too poor to give them decent burial.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2. -- Restoration of hydraulic mining in California, which was virtually wiped out overnight forty-eight years ago by adverse judicial decisions, is the object of a concerted movement of interested mining organizations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover's proposal for world disarmament has brought a storm of criticism based upon the assumption that reduction of armaments must necessarily mean increased unemployment; that such unemployment is just one part of the price which we must pay for the achievement of a great end.

RICHMOND, June 30 -- The more level-headed delegates to the recent convention of United Confederate Veterans, Sons of Confederate Veterans and members of Confederate memorial associations strongly deplored the intemperate utterances of certain groups during the course of the proceedings.

Promotion of reforms in the electric light and power industry, which has been going on in some companies and groups for several years, was speeded when such changes were signified publicly as the aim of the industry as a whole in the "keynote speech" of Floyd L. Carlisle at the annual convention of the National Electric Light Association three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Hiram Bingham Jr. of New Haven, son of Senator Bingham, who is in the foreign service and at present stationed at Tokyo as Third Secretary of the Embassy, has been assigned as Vice Consul at Warsaw.

RALEIGH, N.C. -- June 30. -- Two recent discoveries of "forgotten men," sentenced to be electrocuted at the State Prison here but who have remained alive long after the dates set for their executions, have puzzled authorities.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- John Nance Garner of Texas, Speaker of the House of Representatives, of which he has been a member nearly thirty years, was nominated at 3:40 P.M. today as the Democratic candidate for Vice President of the United States.

READING, Pa., July 2 (AP). -- A six-run rally off Carroll Yerkes in the first inning was top much of a handicap for the Reading Keys to overcome and they dropped the fifth and deciding game of the series to Newark today 10 to 7.

BAR HARBOR. -- Summer is fast bringing to Bar Harbor, by train and car and boat, the season's residents and guests, who, like the original Americans, find this island a happy hunting ground for Summer pleasure.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- The text of Senator Thomas J. Walsh's address of notification to Governor Roosevelt was as follows:

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 2. -- Hog prices and spirits are rising in Iowa. Hogs that on June 1 brought a $3.40 top price are now selling as high as $5.15 on the Chicago market. The average price was $4.70 a hundred-weight.

BERLIN, July 2. -- German political leaders see in the nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt by the Democrats a bad augury for settlement of the reparations and debts problem because he stands for full payment of war debts and wants the United States to stay away from European affairs.

LISBON. AVIATION in Portugal has received intense interest from every government which, has been in power, and, though it would seem that the country was not in any real need of a heavy third arm of defense, the fact remains that it has eighty-five airplanes of different types and seventy pilots, all belonging to the army or navy.

When Dr. H.J. MULLER in the course of his classic experiments turned the X-rays on the fruit-fly and obtained monstrosities that startled experimental evolutionists, and when still more recently X-rayed grapefruit were exhibited in Schenectady, N.Y., which had flowered in five weeks instead of the usual five years, we beheld what was in effect a transmutation of life comparable with the transmutation of the elements.

ON the hot second day of July, 1776 -- the day which John Adams wrote to his wife, Abigail, would be celebrated by later generations with speeches, ringing of bells and firing of cannon the Continental Congress was in session as a committee of the whole in the rebel capital of Philadelphia.
BERLIN, July 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of June 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The major radio networks of the country signed off last night from Chicago Stadium microphones following the address of acceptance of Governor Roosevelt, and another National Democratic Convention passed into history, so far as the radio listener is concerned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of published statements relative to the economic debacle in Siam, it may be interesting to have pointed out how the situation there is of vital importance to the world in general.
The Canadian and Mexican authorities were asked yesterday to help the police here find Owen Madden and three other former Sing Sing inmates wanted for violation of their parole.
Funds held by the City Chamberlain for the benefit of minors must not be invested in securities that mature after the minors come of age, Justice Brower ruled yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

SPY stories enliven a half hour on WEAF Saturday nights at 8:30 o'clock. "K-7," former star operative in an intelligence branch of the United States Government, conceals his name, and goes on the air as a man of mystery. The acting and realism injected into the ethereal tales of this secret agent reveal the possibilities and effectiveness of radio dramatizations.

COMPUTED by feet, which is always an impressive method to compute anything cinematic, the film in the Warner library of sound effects would reach from here to Albany, with enough left over for a minor excursion to Trenton. More specifically, there are a little less than 1,000,000 feet of sound effects in the library to help frantic directors over the rough spots.

Awards totaling about $650,000 to property owners whose land was taken in connection with the extension of Neptune Avenue, Brooklyn, were handed down by Supreme Court Justice Fawcett in Brooklyn yesterday. But the city saved nearly $2,000,000 on other claims by property owners for filled-in and "made" land along Gravesend Bay.

Owners of pleasure boats coming under the new Federal boat users' tax, which went into effect last Friday, have until the last day of the month to pay the levy, according to instructions issued by the Treasury Department.

LONDON. WHY do we not get more autobiographies from newspaper men? Many of them see a great deal more of the world than most authors of volumes of reminiscences, and their training has taught them how to tell a story effectively.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- President Hoover, accompanied by Mrs. Hoover and a party of friends, left Washington this afternoon for his camp in the Virginia mountains, where he will spend the week-end and part of the Fourth of July. The others in the group are Secretary and Mrs. Hurley, Secretary Hyde, Representative Snell and Captain Boone, the President's physician.

EDMONTON, Alta., June 30. -- Dominion Government officials have selected two Pacific coast islands, Piers and D'Arcy -- the latter a former leper colony 20 miles from Victoria, B.C. -- as the most suitable places to put the Doukhobors, recently sentenced for parading in the nude.

BERKELEY, Cal., July 2. -- Marked by the defeat of Ben Eastman and the point winning rush of a powerful University of Southern California team, the fifty-sixth Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships were concluded today before 15,000 persons in Edwards Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD, CAL. WHEN Katharine Cornell refused to consider the cinema during her recent appearance here in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," she started a discussion that has almost reached the proportions of an undercover feud. As a result of her disinterest, United Artists, having bought the piece, have agreed to sell it to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

The coat market for Fall is fairly well organized and many lines have been seen, but very little buying has been done to date, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Several leading retail organizations placed orders for August sale merchandise last week and, while purchases were greatly under last year, the values are appreciably greater and favorable consumer response is expected.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- James A. Farley, manager of the Roosevelt campaign, said today that he was "satisfied" Tammany Hall and the leaders of those States which held out against Roosevelt would rally to the support of the party in this campaign.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 2. -- John Hughes Curtis, the Norfolk boat builder and self-styled "intermediary" for the return of the Lindbergh baby, was found guilty here today of deliberately giving false information for the purpose of preventing the arrest of the kidnappers.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 1. -- Completion of Glockner Road, Austria's great Alpine highway above the eternal snows, and the third highest in Europe, has been assured by Parliamentary approval after overcoming big political, financial and international obstacles.

PARIS. IN Paris, these nights, fete follows fete. The Petite Semaine, as the week before last of the big season is called, is booked to the limit with those brilliant charity affairs in which society manages to combine pleasure with benovolence.

TOKYO, July 2. -- Torrential rains at the close of the rainy season have caused widespread floods throughout Western and Southern Japan and a number of lives have been lost in the destruction of embankments and bridges.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 2. -- With the largest entry in its history, the Bergen County tennis championship started today on the Oritani Field Club courts.

THIS Summer has brought to many people the pleasing discovery that nature has suffered not at all from the depression. Business as usual is evident along every stream and in every flower-strewn meadow. Building activities are going on with undiminished volume among beavers, birds, hornets and field-mice.

HAVING written (according to his own count) some forty Western novels, each of which had a historic background, Dane Coolidge has now turned his attention to biography and has gathered between the covers of his latest book vivid sketches of the lives of twelve "famous fighting men."

THE great importance at this Juncture of the Ottawa conference [Empire Trade Conference which meets July 18] - is that it comes at a time when we are definitely at the parting on the ways. It will be impossible for things to drift any longer.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's speech of acceptance of the nomination for President of the United States before the Democratic National Convention here today was as follows:

CLEVELAND, July 2. -- Back on his happy hunting ground of golf where he first rose to national fame, Walter Hagen fought the battle of his life today to ascend the Western open throne for the fifth time.

BELGRADE, July 2. -- Dr. Milan Srskitch, Minister of the Interior in the Marinkovitch Government, succeeded tonight in forming a new Cabinet to succeed that which resigned two days ago. It consists of nine Serbs, four Croats and three Slovenes.

MADRID, July 1. -- No one believes Spain could ever finance a tunnel under the Straits of Gibraltar, but it is not too rash to state that the chances are very good that some day one may be constructed.
LIMA, Peru, July 2. -- A revolt, supposedly of communistic origin, broke out here tonight, but was meeting with stern resistance and was believed late tonight to have been put down.
THE Cunard Steamship Company has announced that the expeclments which have been made with colloidal fuel on board the liner Scythia have been eminently successful.

THE Blumenthal Prize of 20,000 francs was won recently by the French composer Marcel Delannoy. The committee which named him the winner included Joseph Bonnet, Paul Dukas, George Hug, Henry Malherbe, Guy Ropartz, Henri Rabaud, Maurice Ravel, Florent Schmltt, Charles Wider and Andre Dezarrois.

MANILA, May 30. -- The Philippine Legislature assembling in July will be confronted with, the most serious problems in its history, steadily declining revenues have wiped out the government's surplus and left a deficit for this year of 17,000,000 pesos. Estimates of revenue for next year are optimistically placed at this year's level, and even that is only 53,000,000 pesos, with which to operate a government organized upon a much more costly basis.

BERLIN, June 18, 1932. THERE are those in America who regret that we have not government subsidy of musical institutions, although they admit that it would be dangerous for art if the Metropolitan Opera Company and the Philharmonic-Symphony Society were run from Washington or Tammany Hall.

According to a radio message received yesterday at the office of the White Star Line from Captain F.F. Summers, master of the new cabin motorship Georgic, on her maiden voyage to New York from Liverpool, the vessel will dock this afternoon at pier 60, West Nineteenth Street, sixteen hours ahead of the schedule.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Presidential row was a deserted village tonight. The delegates to the Democratic National Convention deserted it as though it were a plague spot as soon as they had heard the acceptance speech of Governor Roosevelt, their nominee for President.

TORONTO, July 2 (Canadian Press). -- Breaking up even with the Buffalo Bisons in today's double leader, Toronto won the five-game series, three to two. The Leafs won the second game today 3 -- 0, after losing the opening affair, 8 -- 4.

IN May, addressing the annual meeting of the American Association of Museums, Laurence Vall Coleman, director, called our museum growth "amazing." It certainly is if borrowing phraseology associated with "you, Mr. Citizen," and government census schools of thought, one pause to realize, that "a new museum is established every fortnight and a new museum building' or wing, erected every fifteen days."

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Launching his campaign for the Presidency with the first utilization of the airplane in national politics, Governor Roosevelt sped here from Albany today through squalls and bumpy air to make his address to the convention.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Independence Day will be celebrated with many small events in the White Mountains. The season is just getting well started, the last of the biff hotels having opened only yesterday. Many householders are expected to arrive this week.

As tomorrow is Independence Day virtually all the sermons today will be of a patriotic nature. Many clergymen will weave in moral issues as dealt with in the Democratic and Republican national conventions not a few commenting on the prohibition planks in the platforms of the two major parties.

Analysis of the account of the Kreuger Toll Company with the Chase National Bank, showing payments of almost $3,000,000 to brokererage houses here in December, 1930, and in the first three months of last year, was begun yesterday by Jacob K. Javits, counsel for creditors petitioning for the appointment of an American receiver for the company.

In sharp contrast to the great amount of "window dressing" done by banks during the closing weeks of 1931 in preparation for the year-end statements of conditions, with the consequent severe decline in bond prices in December, activity on the part of banks prior to the mid-year statements now being issued had comparatively little effect on the bond market in general.
