Work by six young artists, one of them a talented sculptress, has just been placed on view in two of the local galleries -- the Caz-Delbo, at 561 Madison Avenue, and the Balzac at 149 Park Avenue. The Balzac group will remain through the month, the others only until July 10.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Speaker Garner made known today that he had no present intention of withdrawing his application filed several weeks ago for re-election to the House from his Texas Congressional district. The primary is late this month.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 3 -- The barn dance at Mrs. Molly Covington kanna's farm, west shore of Maheenac Lake, Stockbridge, attracted list night most of the Lenox and Stockbridge younger set. The women wore gingham and wash dresses and the men overalls and broad-brimmed straw hats.

New York's pack of police dogs, which nightly help to guard homes in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, is about to be augmented by a recruit. A new animal, as yet unnamed, is undergoing the careful training prescribed for the members of the pack and will soon join Rex, Nogi, Pup, Boots, Florrie and Skipper in the task of routing skulkers from shrubbery.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 3. -- Dr. John A. Mackay, secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States and former director of the International Council of the Young Men's Christian Association in Mexico City, spoke tonight on "The Spiritual Spectrum of Hispanic America" at the opening vesper service of Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP). -- Detroit dropped to third place in the American League today when Cleveland took a 7-to-4 decision in the series final played in a drizzling rain. The victory enabled the Indians to take fourth place.
LONDON, July 3. -- A strong track team that includes four British Empire athletic titleholders was chosen today to represent Great Britain in the Olympic games at Los Angeles.

LONDON July 3 -- The British press gives friendly welcome to Franklin D. Roosevelt as the Democratic nominee for the Presidency and an even more friendly one to his demand yesterday for tariff reductions and a liberal foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The overwhelming defeat of Senator Cameron Morrison, militant dry, by Robert Rice Reynolds in North Carolina yesterday gave impetus to the movement toward modifying the Volstead Act and amending the Constitution before Congress adjourns.

The motor ship Georgia arrived yesterday on her maiden voyage from Queenstown and Liverpool. Her entry into the New York passenger trade brings the gross tonnage of the White Star Line in that service to 238,600. The newcomer to the great Atlantic merchant fleet was decorated with the International code flags from the bow over the tops of the masts to the taff rail aft.

The congregations at all eight masses in St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, 20 City Hall Place, were asked from the altar yesterday by Mgr. William E. Cashin to pray for "the proper conduct of the negotiations with the city" which led him the previous day to announce that he would not obey an order to vacate his rectory until "the marshal puts us in the street."

Convention promises made by both parties at Chicago were just "so much piffle," in the opinion of the Right Rev. Dr. Elmer N. Schmuck, Bishop of Wyoming, preaching yesterday morning in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. Hard work and nothing else will restore prosperity, he said, urging Americans to recall some of the accomplishments of the nation's founders.

LONDON, July 3 (Canadian Press). -- George Lansbury, Parliamentary Labor leader in the British House of Commons, and William Norton, Labor leader in the Irish Free State Dail whose support is essential to the de Valera Government, believed tonight that good-will on both sides and willingness to continue negotiations would bring a settlement of the dispute over the Irish stand on the oath of allegiance and withholding of land annuities.

SEAFORD, L.I., July 3. -- Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York shattered another record, while George Fissler of the New York A.C. and Miss Constance Hanf of the W.S.A. won Metropolitan A.A.U. senior championships at a water carnival sponsored by the Seaford Chamber of Commerce, conducted over a fiftyfive-yard course at Seaford Harbor today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senate's prohibition champion, Senator Borah of Idaho, conferred today with two strategists of the organized drys, and at one of the meetings, at Ieast, the Senator said there was no talk of a third party. About the other he was silent.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Tilney have left the Carlyle for Oyster Bay, where they will remain until the Autumn.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Promising efforts are being made to start a prosperity boom in agriculture. Hogs and cattle have advanced surprisingly in the last four months, and accumulation of wheat is under way at 50 cents a bushel and under for the September and December deliveries.

Building as a business must be made safe for investors before the industry can embark on a resumption of trade prosperity, writes Allen E. Beals in a current Dow Service release in which he declares that New York City's construction and allied trades are preparing in their own way to protect their interests, pending a general attempt to avoid the trade errors and financial disasters during the building boom of recent years.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 3. -- John H. Curtis, the Norfolk boatbuilder who was convicted in Quarter Sessions Court here yesterday of knowingly giving false information to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and the New Jersey State Police to prevent the arrest of the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby, conferred today with attorneys on the question of an appeal to the Supreme Court.

PRINCETON, July 3. -- A project for the development along new lines of a generator capable of producing millions of volts of static electricity, to obtain high potentials with which to penetrate the nuclei of atoms, is announced here by Princeton University as part of its new research program in fundamental physics.

COCHEREL, France, July 3. -- The body of Aristide Briand was brought here today to rest in this little Norman town where, alone during the last turbulent years of his life, he knew peace and relaxation.

In one of many Indepedence Day sermons preached in New York City pulpits yesterday, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of King's College, Halifax, N.S., told the congregation at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Sixty-ninth Street east of Broadway, that the century-long cordiality between Canada and the United States should be an example to the world.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- With the Democratic nomination for President in his possession, the next serious problem confronting Governor Roosevelt concerns his disposition of the charges against Mayor Walker.

The New York Athletic Club, amateur wrestling stronghold of the Kast, gained major honors as the forty-fourth annual National A.A. U. title tournament was concluded yesterday morning, three Winged Foot stars emerging with individual crowns -- Joe Sapora, 123 pounds; Joe Schutt, 174 pounds, and Louis Putrin, 191 pounds.

At a time when science and economics have remade the world into a unit there is a "recrudescence of narrow nationalism which bids fair to rob mankind" of the blessings of scientific and economic progress, according to the Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Albany, who preached on "The Signs of the Times" yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Morning-side Heights.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. CHICAGO, July 3. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the old - fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat, was discovered by a reporter in the act of redeeming his car from a parking space, and preparing to start back home to Amity, Ind.

Former Governor John H. Trumbull of Connecticut, president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, said yesterday that the electrical industry had charted a new course for labor and industry in adopting the proposals made by Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, known as , the Nema mutual unemployment benefit plan.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP).-- Pittsburgh reglined the lead in the National League race today by winning a six-inning game from the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 4. A double-header wag scheduled, but a drizzling rain that suddenly became a heavy shower ended matters after six innings of the scheduled opener.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Irreconcilable prohibitionists, through their national board of strategy, declared war today against the platforms of both major parties and urged all friends of the Eighteenth Amendment to "devote their best efforts to the election of dry candidates to both houses of Congress and to State Legislatures."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A cheery figure familiar for two decades to most of the Presidents, all the Vice Presidents and ail the Senators, Robert C. Perkins, will disappear this week from Senatorial haunts. He was cut down by the economy program.

UTICA, N.Y., July 3. -- Opposition of Tammany and the recent renouncement of his belief in the League of Nations, virtually at the behest of William Randolph Hearst, gained Franklin D. Roosevelt his reward in the form of the Presidential nomination at Chicago, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate, declared here tonight at the State convention of his party.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- The steel industry is at the lowest stage of activity in Its history, the last touch having been given by the seasonal drop. By tradition, the first half of July is expected to be the lightest period of the year in steel production and shipments.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 3. -- Joseph Paterno, aged 16, of Riverdale-on-the-Hudson narrowly escaped death from drowning or bleeding when thrown from a speed boat and cut by its propeller in upper Saranac Lake this afternoon.

Governor ROOSEVELT put into his appearance and his address before the Chicago Convention something of the breeziness that went naturally with his flight through the air. The dash and vigor which he had shown by setting out for Chicago in an airplane also marked his speech.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A return to the moral valor of George Washington was pictured as the need of the hour by the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of New York, who delivered the sermon at the national patriotic service this afternoon in the National Cathedral.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 3. -- All of the major classes of boats raced today in the first general Sunday regatta held on Barnegat Bay and brisk westerly breezes provided plenty of excitement as the craft covered the long windward and leeward course in fast time.
BERLIN, July 3 -- The front pages of all the newspapers in Germany are filled with editorials on developments at the Lausanne conference.

THE theory that the ball clubs leading the major leagues on the Fourth of July are due to meet in the world's series has been badly dented from time to time. The classic clout at the ancient theory, of course, was the victory of the Braves in 1914. That team was in last place on the Fourth of July and swept to four straight over the great Athletics in the world's series In October.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Add an Inch to the tail of the shirt of every Chinese and our surplus cotton, problem is solved. Increase by a penny a day the income of each Chinese, and there would probably be no unemployment in the United States, all of which is not idle speculation.

NEW HAVEN, July 2 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 59.6, which compares with 59.5 a week ago, 59.3 two weeks ago, 59.6 three weeks ago and 60.2 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; the average of two weeks ago was the lowest.
BERKELEY, Cal., July 3. -- University of Southern California athletes swept through the fifty-sixth annual intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field meet yesterday for their fifth national title.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 3. -- Two world's records were bettered, one of them twice, in the opening events of the Albany Yacht Club's annual motor-boat regatta on the Hudson today.

PARIS, July 1 -- It is coming to be recognized with increasing clearness that the psychological depression is exerting an enormous influence on the economic depression. In the reactionary conditions of Europe the moat important factor is anxiety concerning international politics.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3. -- Morgan Memorial Park, the thirty-acre shorefront recreation ground and bathing beach dedicated to Glen Cove and Locust Valley by J. Pierpont Morgan in memory of his wife, will be formally opened tomorrow with a joint celebration of Independence Day and the George Washington Bicentennial.

MADRID, July 3 -- With the names of most of Spam's great men on Its roll, Including those of Premier Azana, Minister of Education De Los Rios and the opposition leader, Alejandro Lerroux, a League for World Peace has been organized here to establish world-wide propaganda forpeace.

Like every other transportation facility, the Panama Canal has been hard hit by the depression. The figures for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1932, are already in hand. They show that transits dropped from 5,529 in 1931, when conditions were none too favorable, to 4,506 in 1932.

EN ROUTE WITH GOVERNOR ROOSEVELT IN MICHIGAN, July 3 -- The Democratic nominee for President was speeding borne tonight from the party's national convention, ready to make a vigorous contest for election.
ANAMOSA, Iowa, July 3. -- The career of "52 per cent" George Earl Huckins came to an end today when he was found dead of heart disease in his cell in the county jail here. He was 43 years old.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- Agricultural America tomorrow will unite in its greatest Independence Day celebration since the founding of the Republic, officials of the American Farm Bureau Federation said tonight.

Two persons were killed and six others hurt yesterday afternoon to an automobile collision involving three machines on the Montauk Highway, half a mile west of Bridgehampton, L.I. The accident was one of many on the congested highways throughout the metropolitan area which resulted in an additional death, that of a motorcyclist, who was the victim of a hit-and-run driver, and injuryy to at least twenty-orie other persons.

Combining most of their finer qualities and leaving their darker moments well in the background, the Giants bounded smartly off the ropes at the Polo Grounds yesterday to flatten the Braves in the final engagment of the four-game series, 5 to 2.

Forty-two snakes were liberated yesterday from the glass-enclosed prisons in the snakehouse at the Bronx Zoo in which they had dozed for many a day and were put to work to earn their keep in an outdoor Island near by.

FRANKFORT, Ky.. July 3 -- Ancient grudges flared up in several Kentucky counties during the weekend, and a compilation tonight showed nine men had been killed and a woman and nearly a dozen men seriously wounded in shooting affrays.

ABOARD THE TWENTIETH CENTURY LIMITED, TOLEDO, Ohio, July 3 (AP). -- Whether Alfred E. Smith will campaign for Governor Roosevelt, the man whose nomination for the Presidency he was unable to block, probably will be determined at a conference which James A. Farley, new chairman of the national committee, will hold with him this week.

Enumerating three causes of decline in national solidarity, the Rev. Henry Burnham Kirkland, pastor of the North Presbyterian Church, I55th Street, east of Broadway, declared yesterday that the greatest force for unity in nationalism was righteousness.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Senator Walsh of Massachusetts, a State that clung stanchily to Alfred E. Smith in the fight over the Presidential nomination, issued a statement tonight calling upon the Massachusetts Democrats to support Franklin D. Roosevelt.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3. -- Hitting with, blinding speed, Jack Tidball of the University of California, at Los Angeles, defeated Manuel Alonso of Barcelona and New York today in the invitation turf court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 3. -- Additional returns today emphasized the crushing defeat of Senator Cameron Morrison, a prohibitionist, by Robert R. Reynolds, a wet, in yesterday primary for the Democratic nomination for Senator.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Replying to the letter of C. Gill of London published recently in THE TIMES: The United States Government owes no debts to the British on account of the Civil War. If the British chose to invest their money hi Confederate bonds -- the bonds of States in rebellion against the United States Federal Government -- they did so at their own risk.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP). -- The Detroit Boat Club withdrew its senior eight-oared shell today from the final Olympic tryouts for the eights at Lake Quinsigamond, Worcester, Mass., this week, just as the American Olympic rowing committee met to announce the draw for the trials.

Voluntary dissolution of the Lackawanna Securities Company, formed in 1927 in connection with the segregation of the coal properties of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company, will be voted by stockholders of the company at a special meeting called for July 25 at the offices of the company in Hoboken.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 3. -- Rallying strongly in the final periods, after being held even during the first half of the contest, Stewart Iglehart's Aiken polo team conquered the Sands Point quartet, 12 to 9, in the weekly high goal exhibition match at the Sands Point Club today.

Tammany Hall, which he termed "a highly organized minority plunderbund," was cited yesterday by Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, in his sermon in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, as an example of the power an organized minority can exert in determining human policies.
PARIS, July 3. -- Premier Herriot tonight faces a serious political crisis with his financial program slashed to pieces by the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

VIENNA, July 3. -- Serious Hitlerite rioting occurred today at Eisenstadt, capital of the Province of Burgrenland, when storm troops of the National Socialists rushed the Social Democratic secretariat, destroying furniture and generally wrecking the premises.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Loans to railroads from the Railroad Credit Corporation with which to meet interest requirements were larger during June than in any month since the establishment of the corporation, and totaled $8,717,116, due to unusually heavy July 1 maturities.

Pinkey Whitney, the quiet but highly competent third baseman of the surprising Phillies, knocked a ball game right out of Dazzy Vance's hands on one of the veteran's best days at Ebbets Field yesterday, and the Shotton men beat the Dodgers in the eleventh inning.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 3 -- Harvesting of Winter wheat in the Southwest was delayed by rains early last week, but made good progress toward the close. Yields in many parts of Kansas and Eastern Nebraska were better than earlier expectations, estimates on Eastern Nebraska alone being raised 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 bushels from the low private returns of ten days ago.
A handicap of two goals aided the Governors Island polo four to victory over the All-Army team yesterday in a game at Governors Island that went to an overtime period.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- John N. Garner was unofficially "notified" of his choice as Democratic candidate for Vice President today by Governor O. Max Gardner of North Carolina and Representative Lindsay Warren, an active leader in the nomination of Mr. Garner at Chicago.
CLAREMORE, Okla., July 3. -- Flew down here to recuperate from one straight month of speeches. Heard a mule braying a while ago at the farm and for a minute I couldn't tell who he was nominating.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Army and navy officers were perturbed today when it became known that a literal interpretation of a clause in the $150,000,000 economy act would suspend the execution of transfer orders during the next fiscal year, regardless of the date of issue of the order so long as it applied to removal after July 1.

LONDON, July 1 -- In consequence both of its boldness and of its magnitude the government's war loan conversion plan has left the city somewhat breathless. For some time past efforts had been shaping favorably for this conversion operation, but the most that had been generally expected on the market was a plan to deal with only a part of this huge debt of more than 2,000,000,000.

Perfect weather yesterday turned all New York outdoors. Those who could -- and there were thousands of them -- trailed in the wake of the holiday rush to the seashore, swelling throngs already there, crowding the highways, packing bathhouses, jamming boardwalks, taxing all accommodations to the utmost.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hungary is occupying only a modest place in the world today and therefore few realize what a keen struggle for life this nation had to fight, partly by social efforts and partly by the activity of its government ever since the conclusion of the peace treaty.

The Democrats in action at Chicago provide the Trans-Lux Theatre on Broadway with its outstanding newsreels this week. There is also a Paramount subject of the recent disturbances in Siam. Some of the other scenes show Colonel Lindbergh testifying at the Curtis trial, two unique types of airplanes, Gene Sarazen winning the United States open, girl swimming champions training for the Olympics and the Eucharlstic congress in Dublin.

BERLIN, July 2 -- Although complete details and data of the Allies' new plan for reparations adjustment at Lausanne have not yet been divulged, German business circles at the end of the week regarded the situation more hopefully. Aside from the political extremists.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 3. -- After being buffeted by the lashing of a gale, fourteen of the twenty-two yachts that started from here on Friday night in the Stamford Yacht Club's 232-mile race out around Vineyard Sound Lightship and back reported today they had been forcecd out of the contest and made scattered ports to the eastward.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- A dinner was given this evening at Beauliew by Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt in honor of their guests, the Marchioness of Crewe of London, who was with them at the beach today, and M. Paul Claudel. BRIDES IN RECENT WEDDINGS HERE AND IN GREENWICH, CONN. M. Rives, Albert Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.L. Hoffman; Dr. and Mrs. George Boiling Lee and their son. Robert Lee.

LONDON, July 1 -- Issues of new capital in Great Britain during June aggregate u17,500,000. In May they were u12,250,000 and in 1931 they were u12,750,000. The aggregate for the completed half-year, which is u74,750,000, compared with u71,000,000 during the first half of 1931.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 3 -- Although last week opened with the cotton market here rather quiet and with traders disposed to await developments in the crop and in both domestic and foreign politics, activity appeared as the week advanced, and finally there was an upward trend of prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There seems to be no doubt about the growing Interest in gold mining as an investment, but one is amazed at the lack of knowledge concerning gold mines and the lack of organized business methods for obtaining them. Apparently, capital expects to find them wrapped in cellophane and on sale at any grocery or drug store -- all in running order and ready to pay dividends.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Fortified by optimistic reports of economic conditions in Palestine and by a belief that the spirit of defeatism had been banished by Zionism, leaders of the Zionist Organization of America at the opening of its annual convention here today appealed for continued support to the upbuilding of a Jewish national home in spite of the world-wide depression.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Farmers who use cattle, hogs and sheep as side lines, as well as those who specialize in feeding those animals, have had a change of luck for the better in an increased demand, a smaller supply and one of the best advances in prices in recent years.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 3 (AP). -- A naval tug was sent out today to search for the ketch Curlew of Throggs Neck, N.Y., and the Bermuda fishing boat Spanish Rose, missing for five days.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 3. -- Aileen, piloted by Cornelius Shields, sailed home to victory in the Sound Inter-club class, which was one of the feature divisions of the special regatta, conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Races were held in twelve classes, and the fine weather attracted an entry of sixty yachts.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Browns, 7 to 4, today in the concluding game of their series, in which they broke even with two victories each. Only one same of today's scheduled double-header was played, the second event being postponed in order to allow St. Louis to catch a train.

LONDON, July 3 (AP). -- Old Bailey will be the scene tomorrow of a trial which will be of wide interest here when Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, estranged wife of a New York cabaret singer, faces the bar of justice to answer a charge of murdering Thomas Scott Stephen, a young man about town.

A seven-goal handicap proved too much for the First Division quartet of Fort Hamilton to overcome, and it dropped a 11-9 decision to the Central Park Hunt Club polo team of Long Island yesterday before a crowd of 2,000 at the Fort Hamilton Reservation.

LONDON, July 1 -- The two noteworthy eveats on this week's London markets were Thursday's reduction in the Bank of England rate to 2 per cent, the lowest since 1897 and the minimum rate of its history, and the announcement of the war loan conversion scheme which immediately followed.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The tremendous industrial changes wrought in the United States during the 1920-1930 era of motorization, mechanization and mass production are reflected in an abstract of occupational statistics just compiled by the Bureau of Census.

MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- In Congressional elections today, which are reported to have been without vlolence throughout the country, the dominant National Revolutionary party is understood to have won every Senatorship and Deputyship for which it contended.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 3. -- Future strategy of some dry groups will be determined in conventions here this week.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 3 -- Pledging his absolute support to the Democratic ticket, Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland told a welcomehome audience of 20,000 here tonight that he was going to exert his undivided energy for the success of the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.

Speaking yesterday afternoon on the topic of "Great Britain and America's Independence Day" over Station WOR, Gerald Shephard, acting British Consul General in New York, urged cooperation between the two nations to vanquish the economic depression.
Newark defeated Jersey City In both games of a double-header at West Side Park in Jersey City yesterday, winning the first game, 8 to 2, and the second, 9 to 6, before a crowd of 14,000.

Although capturing only two first places in the seven events contested, the German-American Athletic Club athletes amassed a total of twenty-one points to take the team title at the annual Bronx County A.A.U. track championships held before a crowd of 1,000 spectators at Pelham Bay Park yesterday.

Two well-known fishermen, R.D. Williams and Otto Peters, the flycaster, of Buffalo recently spent six days fishing at St. Ignace Island, Nipigon. Ont., and have returned with interesting stories concerning their expedition.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Basking today in the restful Hours of a Sabbath, the United States will pause tomorrow to renew her pledge of fealty to the ideals proclaimed in Philadelphia 156 yeays ago.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 3 -- Business in Chicago for June, as indicated by the bank clearings, suggests a decrease of $804,685,788, the aggregate clearings being $990,490,071, compared with $1,795,175,859 for the same period of 1931. For the six months ended June 30, with $6,212,946,613, business was the lightest in recent years.

Michael S. Koumen, 45 years old, a dealer in diamonds and watches, whose business address is 2,033 Eighth Avenue, was arrested on a charge of felonious assault yesterday morning and locked up in the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital after a fist fight with eight policemen and a passerby on Park Avenue near 112th Street.

A Distinguished Convert. Great masses of ordinary people are evidently preparing to surrender to the irresistible anti-prohibition tide. This leads to some curious paradoxes, as when the new United States Senator from Georgia assured Governor ROOSEVELT that he need have no fears about the South, since, though it was dry, it would vote enthusiastically for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

BALTIMORE, July 3 (AP). -- Reading broke even with Baltimore in a double-header today, winning the first game, 7 to 5, and losing the nightcap, 2 to 1. Beryl Richmond, who defeated George Milstead in a ]eft-handed duel in the second game, allowed only one hit a scratch safety.

BERLIN, July 1 -- The suggestion of reduction in the interest rate on Germany's external bonds does not elicit general approval here. The view is taken that such reduction would make relatively small savings, and that it would, morever, finally close the foreign capital market to Germany.

PRAGUE, July 3 (AP). -- Frank Walsh of Chicago, a member of the American delegation to the Sokol Congress here, presented a Washington bust to the Sokol organization today. Later President Masaryk received him and Jan Zeman of New York and thanked them for their efforts to bring a large number of American Czechs to the homeland.

Several more Summer theatres this week will join the ranks of those already operating in the Eastern States. As the first bill of its season, the Stamford (Conn.) Playhouse tonight will present "This Thing Called Love," with Jean May and Walter Abel heading the cast.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- The Senators slipped to fifth place today by losing again to the Athletics, 4 to 3. It was the third successive victory over Washington for the Mackmen, who advanced to second place in the American League standing.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3 -- Grain markets here were weak and inactive last week under decreased demand of importing markets on the eve of the 'harvest in the Northern Hemisphere, wheat especially feeling the pressure, reports on the Canadian crop being that it is larger than last year.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Unemployment relief legislation and proposals to modify the Volstead act loomed tonight as possible obstacles to an early adjournment of the present session of Congress. While some Congressional leaders have not abandoned hope that Congress can adjourn next Saturday, all were agreed that, if the conference agreement upon a $2,100,000,000 relief measure and the proposed Bingham amendment to the Home Loan Bank bill develop much discussion, the session will be prolonged.

Mario Piras thought he had killed his former employer, Francesco De Achilles, in the Westchester Macaroni Company plant at 4,817 Baldwin Street, the Bronx, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. He hurled the knife away, set fire to the plant in five places and was preparing to leave by a side door when he saw firemen and policemen surround the building.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- Reaching its climax with the selection of the country's Olympic single scull representative in the thirty-fifth event, scheduled to be rowed late in the afternoon, the three-day regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen will close tomorrow on the famous Schuylkill River course.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith came back from Chicago yesterday morning as silent regarding his attitude toward the Democratic national ticket as when he quietly left the convention city on Saturday without sending a word of greeting to Governor Roosevelt, the party's Presidential nominee.

SCARBOROUGH. N.Y., July 3. -- An eagle 3 by Jess Sweetser on the eighteenth hole gave him and Bobby Jones a 1-up victory over Billy Burke and Johnny Farrell in an eighteen-hole best-ball exhibition golf match played today at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club for the benefit of St. Faith's House, Tarrytown, and the Thursday Club Charities.

Last week, though for a time turbid with anxiety and fear, was fat with happiness for Mr. WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE, head philosopher of the Bucolic School. For days and nights he watched the struggle between the urban and the "rural" blocs.
HONGKONG, China, July 3 -- Desertion of most of the Cantonese air force brought hope today of a truce in Canton's civil strife, involving the rebellious navy of Admiral Chan Ohak.

An exchange of Hoboken vacant lots valued at $150,000 was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey yesterday. The deal was between the Erie Land and Improvement Company and the Hoboken Land Improvement Company. Under the trade the Erie conveyed the block of thirty-two lots bounded by Ninth, Tenth, Madison and Monroe Streets, eight lots on Madison Street and ten on Monroe Street, corner of Tenth Street.

A little woman, so crippled by rheumatism and age that she had been unable to walk for more than six months, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday in a fourth-floor tenement apartment at 414 First Avenue. She was Nettie Burk, once famous bareback and trick rider for the P. T. Barnum circus.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 3 (AP). -- A time machine of the type designed to ignite explosives was found in the main unit of West Virginia's new $10,000,000 Capitol today. No explosives were located.

Scholars and artists are cooperating in the preparation of a portfolio, to be called "The Bicentennial Pageant of George Washington," which is to be published early in the Fall by the George Washington Memorial Association, Inc., and issued in cooperation with the United States George Washington Bicentennial Commission.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 3 -- Belief that the bottom of the business depression had been reached was expressed today by Charles Edison, son of Thomas A. Edison and head of Edison Industries, Inc., following the return to his home here from a six weeks' tour of the United States.

On the eve of Independence Day Secretary STIMSON, on behalf of the people of the United States, sent broadcast through the air of the whole continent a message of congratulation to Canada celebrating Dominion Day. It was more than a formal greeting.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The news of the sudden death of Dr. George F. Kunz is a shock to this entire community, exceeded only by our sense of the great loss which this city and the entire country has sustained. Others may recall through the press his world-wide services and importance to science in his chosen field.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Smilingly confident of his election to the Presidency of the United States, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, whose sensational arrival by airplane and his speech to the Democratic National Conventional just before adjournment yesterday put his campaign under full headway within less than twenty-four hours after his nomination, devoted today to political conferences in the Presidential suite of the Congress Hotel.

LAUSANNE, July 3. -- Despite every effort to keep all mention of Europe's debts to the United States out of the Lausanne settlement they will keep bobbing up. Today Germany mentioned them. She could not take the risk, Chancellor von Papen informed Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain, that this settlement might not be final.

SEAGIRT, N.J., July 4 -- Scoring 189 of a possible 200, W.B. Woodring of Bethlehem, Pa., won the long range individual match, fired at 200 yards, which today brought to a close the eleventh annual small bore rifle tournament on the State ranges.

Miss Grace Surber, 19-year-old girl who won the Metropolitan clay-court championship at the Lido Country Club on Saturday, made an auspicious debut in the New York State clay courts tournament, which started at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4 -- In a battle of services marked by scintillating shot-making but almost barren of rallies of any lengthy Dr. Eugene H. McCauliff of Yonkers defeated Jack Tidball of Hollywood, Cal., today to win the invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- President Hoover will call an extra session of Congress to enact unemployment relief measures if the present Congress fails to pass a bill acceptable to him, Representative Snell, minority leader, predicted tonight after dinner at the White House.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Washington made a clean sweep of the holiday double-header with the Yankees today, coming from behind for a 5-to-3 victory which broke the winning streak of Vernon Gomez in the first game and leading all the way to take the second, 12 to 6.

Total contributions to the Salvation Army's United Appeal for funds at the beginning of the eighth week of solicitation have reached $530,340.60, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the campaign. More than $50,000 was added during last week, and it is now hoped that the campaign's minimum goal of $600,000 will be exceeded.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- Bradford Norman Jr. was re-elected president of the Clambake Club at the annual meeting today. A luncheon clambake followed. Gustave J.S. White was elected secretary and treasurer, while the board of governors will be made up of Marion Eppley, Dr. Harry J. Knapp, Charles P. Williams, Michael M. Van Beuren, Colonel Francis L.V. Hoppin and C. Oliver O'Donnell, the latter the only new member.

PARIS, July 4 -- After one of the most difficult days in his political career Premier Herriot entrained for Lausanne tonight with his government still in power, though badly shaken by dissension over the financial program.

LONDON, July 4 (AP). -- Dramatic evidence about "the other woman" was projected today into the murder trial of beautiful Mrs. Dolores Barney of West End society, who stands accused of shooting her close friend, Thomas William Scott Stephen, after a night of revelry May 31.

Their enthusiasm undimmed by a steady rain yesterday morning, 10,000 athletes -- most of them athletes for just a day -- competed in the annual safe and sane Independence Day celebration in city parks and playgrounds under the auspices of Mayor Walker's committee.

LAUSANNE, July 4 -- The Italian delegation to the Lausanne reparations conference today demanded a final settlement at the parley and urged that "cancellation be applied equally to all European powers, creditors and debtors, of reparations and war debts."

BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- Buzz Arlett, Oriole left fielder, hit five home runs in a double-header with Reading today, helping bring victory to Baltimore in both games and sending his total of home runs for the season to forty-one. The scores were 21 to 10 and 9 to 8.
The text of the address of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler at the Fourth of July celebration of the American Society in London yesterday, as heard in New York by radio, follows:

Rain, marring yesterday's holiday, started a homeward rush of traffic early in the afternoon, and though the skies cleared later and the clouds dispersed, the rush continued with augmented volume, pouring like a tide-race into the half-deserted city. Boats, trains, ferries and subways were jammed with human cargoes, while in from the highways came equally crowded buses and endless thousands of automobiles.

It seems likely that a call may go up to the Arctic wastes to page Jar Welzl, for there is much that the literary world would like to learn about him. He is the author of "Thirty Years in the Golden North," published today by the Macmillan Company after several postponements and selected by the Book-of-the-Month Club as its July choice.
LONDON, July 4 -- The time has come for a world-wide "declaration of interdependence," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler told the American Society in London tonight at a Fourth of July dinner.

Controller Charles W. Berry sent a telegram yesterday to Mgr. William E, Cashin, pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, 20 City Hall Place, inviting the clergyman to confer with him today regarding the city order to vacate the rectory of the church by Aug. 1.

Two persons were killed and thirteen taken to hospitals with various injuries, in the metropolitan area yesterday as a result of automobile accidents. Of the fatalities one was in Brooklyn and one in Atlantic City. Many others were treated for minor injuries and sent home.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 4 -- Robert Emmet Sherwood's comedy, "The Queen's Husband," was produced at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge tonight by F. Cowles Strickland for the opening of the filth season. The leading roles were taken by Claude Rains, Claude Meek, Leo Carroll, the Misses Nedda Harrigan and Florida Friebus.

From the Prohibition Board of Strategy comes a mingled confession and lamentation. Its tone is pathetically in contrast with that held for years by the Anti-Saloon League and its congeners. Once both parties heeled after them meekly. Now both have broken away, one absolutely, the other in effect, though it still spreads honeyed fly-catching pretenses to pacify the Drys.

REBILD PARK, Jutland, July 4 (AP). -- The American Minister to Denmark, F.W.B. Coleman, in an Independence Day address here today departed from his subject, "George Washington," and attacked those people who are representing that Americans "are the Shylocks of the world."

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 4 -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., speaking at the Independence Day observance in the Ocean Grove Auditorium today, told 3,000 Methodists that John D. Rockefeller Jr. had developed an "inferiority complex" on the question of prohibition.

The low rate of consumption of cotton textiles during the last two years has resulted in extreme demolition of plant equipment and a sharp increase in the total of idle spindles, according to a survey of operations in the industry during the last ten years released yesterday by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of Naw York.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 4 -- The second Summer conference course in industrial relations which will be attended by fifty executives and personnel staff men of American industries will be held at the Graduate College of Princeton University Sept. 19 to 24, it was announced here today by the industrial relations section, under whose auspices the conferences will be held.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- Price-cutting in large and small cities of Southern California, leading to profitless operation of stores, is declared to be one of the principal factors now retarding the recovery of retail business in a summary of recent investigations carried on in cooperation with merchants by the field bureau, Journalism Department, University of Southern California.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., July 4. -- The Zionist Organization of America, recognizing an "urgent need for the consideration of and common action on the grave problems facing the Jewish people," voted unanimously at its annual convention here today to participate next month in the preliminary world Jewish conference in Geneva, which is to consider the question of a World Jewish Congress.

MORRISTOWN, N,J., July 4 -- A pageant of the life of George Washington in fifteen scenes, with about 1,000 participants, was postponed for the second time here tonight, when a sudden downpour of rain routed about 4,000 spectators who had been waiting in the grand stands at the athletic field for the performance to begin.

The protective committee for holders of Fisk Rubber Company bonds and notes, headed by Ferdinand Eberstadt, has announced that in view of the improvement of the company's financial position it now favors a cash distribution by the receivers of about 40 per cent to the security holders.

PARIS. July 4 -- Frank B. Kellogg, co-author with Aristide Briand of the Pact of Paris to outlaw war, today condemned armed alliances to maintain a balance of power. He spoke at the Fourth of July dinner of the American Chamber of Commerce here.

While several thousand residents, of the neighborhood crowded the sidewalks and pavement of St. Ann's Avenue and leaned from the rooftops and windows of flag-draped apartment houses, a marble monument to Gouverneur Morris, whose hand wrote the Constitution of the United States, was unveiled yesterday afternoon in the yard of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, St. Ann's Avenue and 140th Street.

RENO, Nev., July 4 -- Rangy Max. Baer of California established himself as a leading contender for heavyweight honors in pounding out a twenty-round decision over King Levinsky, former fish peddler of Chicago, in a furiously fought battle featuring Reno's annual Independence Day celebration today.

The driving rain yesterday forced a great many of the bass fishermen in Westchester and Putnam Counties to beat a hasty retreat. Along the edges of the watershed lakes were many in oilskins during the morning, but even these had to give way after a while when the downpour was at its height.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The 1932 national champions and American Olympic rowing representatives decided in the three-day regatta which ended today on the Schuylkill River follow:

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- Condemning what he interpreted as "a cry throughout the land for some benevolent despot to appear, not to lead us, but to drive us, to prosperity," Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, described President Hoover in an address at Independence Hall today as "the master statesman of the future," who would lead the world to compose its economic differences.

BERLIN, July 4 -- For the first time since the parties split after the World War, the Socialists and Communists of Berlin joined today in a demonstration. They made common cause over the suppression by the von Papen Government of Vorwaerts, official organ of the Socialist party, on the ground that it had slandered the government and President of the Reich.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 4. -- The final round for the all-auction-pair championship was concluded here this afternoon in the first event of the bridge program of the American Whist League Congress.

Secretary MILLS'S review of the fiscal year which ended June 30 confirmed the estimate of a national deficit in the neighborhood of $3,000,000,000. Several new expenditures unforeseen twelve months ago carried the total to $5,006,000,000, compared with $4,220,000,000 last year.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds and the St. Louis Cardinals battled to a 3-3 deadlock in the second game of their holiday double-header here today which went thirteen innings and then was called because of darkness.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The new three-cent stamp which will go into nation-wide service Wednesday will be printed in the purple of royalty and bear the familiar Stuart portrait of Washington.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4 -- Several luncheons were given today for holiday guests. Mrs. John E. Berwind entertained at the Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. James Imbrie Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Rogers C. Dunn and Captain Ross Cuthbert of London, who are visiting her.

HAVANA, July 4. -- Many Americans here celebrated Independence Day at a luncheon sponsored by the American Club at the National Hotel and the American Legion gave its annual picnic for American children.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied forces for Prohibition, representing, it is claimed, a membership of 1,500,000, in a statement issued today, delounced the prohibition planks of both major political parties and sledged his organization to support candidates who would fight repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

A call for help which should not go unheeded is issued today by the Visiting Nurse Service, Mr. FELIX WARBURG, president of the association, and Miss LILLIAN WALD, director of the service under the Henry Street Settlement, realized over a year ago that more patients than the normal number would ask for treatment in 1931 and 1932.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- Ambassador Claudel of France, an honorary member of the Virginia Society of the Cincinnati, spoke at the exercises of the Rhode Island society here today in commemoration of the 156th anniversary of American independence.

An average of 18,453 needy families is cared for each month by leading family welfare agencies in New York City on funds raised by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, of which Harvey D. Gibson is chairman, it is announced today by Baily B. Burritt, chairman of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, through which the funds, totaling $4,690,000, were disbursed.

GUELPH, Ont., July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Don Bradman, world's premier batter, knocked up 260 runs, a new Canadian record, as the touring Australian cricket team defeated a Western Ontario team today by a one-sided margin.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 4 (AP) -- Flood waters in the hilly ranch and resort country west and south of here toward the Mexican border today have taken at least nine lives and caused an undetermined amount of property damage.

Police strategists who take the negative in the debate on the value of police dogs in these days of electrical Sherlock Holmeses -- a debate which has largely supplanted Presidential possibilities and probabilities as a topic of conversation in departmental circles in Flatbush -- were quick to hail a case that came up in the local magistrates' court yesterday as a proof of their contentions.

TRENTON, N.J., July 4 -- A crowd estimated at 30,000 persons this afternoon thronged the shores of the Delaware River near the new Trenton marine terminals to salute the arrival of the Bristol City from Fewey, England, the first transatlantic ship to bring a cargo to the new port of Trenton.

NEW BRUNSWICK, New Jersey, July 4 -- Though the equities held by the New Jersey farmers in their properties have been sharply impaired in the last two years, there is as yet no serious dislocation in the ownership of farm property. Tax delinquencies are growing and in some districts have reached disquieting proportions of the total tax, but the State and local governments have made no attempts to sell farm properties or to force collection.

Artie Nissen, one of Nettie Burt's neighbors at 414 First Avenue, put the heavy old family Bible on the chair, displacing two bright-eyed kittens that had been making passes at each other. They hopped on the window sill and stared out at the courtyard, basking in the sun.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Equipoise proved himself the greatest 4-year-old thoroughbred in America today when he galloped to victory in the featured $20,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap before a holiday throng of 25,000 at Arlington Park.

PARIS, July 4. -- The fifth international electrical congress, which has attracted scientists from all over the world, will open here tomorrow. Many Americans will read papers at the congress and other scientists of the United States, who were unable to come here, have sent their papers.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 4 -- Burglars early today made a rich haul of silver and linens when they ransacked several of the 100 rooms in Hearthstone Hall, home of Walter B. Lashar, wealthy manufacturer.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 4 (Canadian Press Cable) -- Famous shots of the British Isles captured the honors at the great empire meeting of the National Rifle Association got under way today, with Canadians well up in the biggest shoot on the opening program.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 4. -- Mrs. Rose Klafter, whose husband maintains a drapery shop at 92 Carman Avenue here, said last night that she had not heard from her brother, Samuel Lehrmann, for months. He left his home in Corona for California in January, she said, on a trip for his health and with the intention of seeking employment on the West Coast.

TOKYO, July 4 -- The League Inquiry Commission arrived here today and will remain in Japan about a fortnight. The Earl of Lytton, chairman of the commission, is indisposed, with a slight temperature, and is resting in bed at the British Embassy.

The late STEPHEN T. MATHER, Director of the National Parks Service for fourteen years, would have been 65 on the Fourth of July if he had not worn himself out in devotion to the cause of developing the national park system for the American people.

Concerted international embargoes against a nation which goes to war in violation of the pact of Paris (the Kellogg-Briand treaty) are advocated as the most practicable means of preserving world peace in "Boycotts and Peace," a book published this week by Harper Bros.

JOCKEYS up! Before the last notes of the bugle die away over the treetops in the paddock the silk-clad riders are being tossed lightly into the saddle. In the colorful history of the turf there have been some great little fellows in silks.
LONDON, July 4 (AP). -- Closing prices here today were as follow, with American stocks quoted in dollars at 4 shillings to the dollar:

A policeman was seriously wounded early yesterday when he surprised two petty thieves engaged in pilfering nickels from an automatic piano in the London Restaurant, 664 Eighth Avenue. One of the thieves, an escaped convict from Great Meadows prison, was captured after being wounded twice by pursuing policemen.

MONTREAL, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Couched in emphatic terms, a statement was issued today by Canadian cotton mill owners respecting the recently concluded conferences with representatives of the British cotton industry. The statement is in reply to the report made to J.H. Thomas. Secretary of State for the Dominions, by members of the British delegation on their return to England from Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- Twelve New York residents, guests of Moore and McCormack, Inc., operators of the American Scantic Line, were among those marooned several hours this afternoon and tonight in the Delaware River below Chester when the liner Scantates ran aground in the mud flats off Hook's Creek.

New public financing done in the United States in the first half of 1932, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal issues, amounted to only $242,427,000, according to figures announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of National Statistical Service, Inc.

BABYLON, L.I., July 4 -- Despite a steady downpour of rain the three-day regatta of the local yacht club was concluded today, with an entry list of twenty-four boats. The wind, was milder than that which prevailed Saturday and yesterday, but the rain kept dozens of boats riding at anchor.
WASHINGTON, Kan., July 4 -- At least three persons were killed and more than twenty others were injured by a tornado that ripped through this Washington County-seat town late today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP). -- Speculation over the role Senator Johnson will play in the Presidential campaign was heightened by his statement praising Franklin D. Roosevelt's conduct in accepting the Democratic nomination. The Senator would not discuss his plans.

The Pendleton Canoe Club of New York City, national team champions, captured the metropolitan crown for the fifth straight year in the sixth annual title competition held yesterday over the short three-eighth-mile course on the Central Park Lake.
BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- President Agustin P. Justo radiophoned greetings to the people of the United States over a short-wave broadcast at 7 o'clock tonight.

Evidences of Democratic harmony in New York, or more specifically Tammany support for the Presidential campaign of Franklin D. Roosevelt, and confidence in victory in November marked the celebration of the 156th anniversary of American independence yesterday by the Society of Tammany in Tammany Hall, Union Square.

BAYSIDE, L.I., July 4 -- Regardless of the overcast sky, the rain and a strong southwest breeze, the members of the Bayside Yacht Club held their annual Independence Day Regatta on Little Neck Bay today. Three classes raced, Bayside Gulls and senior and junior Snipe class skippers, sailing practically the same boats.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Harry Dove, Canadian World War ace, was fatally injured tonight when an airplane in which he was instructing a student passenger in night flying crashed 100 feet at the Rising Sun airport near here. His passenger, Donovan Griffith, was seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Among the 1,344 executives of Class 1 railroads of the United States with annual salaries of $10,000 or more on March 1, 1932, two were receiving $135,000 a year, according to a recent report to the Senate by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As has been the custom, the conventions of both of our great political parties were opened with prayer, calling for Divine guidance in the selection of candidates for the Presidency. And now that the nominations have been made, what do we have?

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 4 (AP). -- Catching the spirit of early America, 20,000 persons from half a dozen States, civil and military leaders and representatives of the French and British Governments assembled today for the dedication of Fort Necessity, the scene of Washington's first battle.

MINEOLA, L.I., July -- Four medals of the Order of the Purple Heart were presented to veterans of the World War at an Independence Day celebration In the village of Southampton. The medals were presented by Colonel Theo Mornell, a Summer resident of the village, to Captain William P. Nugent, Captain David H. Hallock, M.D., Lieutenant Harold B. Morris and Private Leon Bass.

The boom for Colonel William J. Donovan for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination came out in the open yesterday with the announcement of the formation of the "Win With Donovan" Committee, organized to work in his behalf. The chairman of the committee is Melvin C. Eaton, Republican leader of the Chenango County.

LONDON, July 4 -- Prospect of settling the Anglo-Irish dispute became suddenly brighter tonight than at any time since President Eamon de Valera first announced the Free State's intention not to pay land annuities.

A continued deadlock between the fur and cloak trades with respect to the billing of the excise levy on furs, condemnation by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association of the "dictatorial method attempted by fur groups in passing on their tax to retailers" and the passing on of the tax by a majority of toilet goods producers featured the latest developments in the tax situation in the wholesale markets.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- With American grain markets closed in observance of Independence Day, grain men in Winnipeg had a quiet day, there being no business from the outside in either futures or cash grain. Liverpool was strong early, opening unchanged to 1/4d a bushel higher than Saturday's closing level and advancing 5/8d to 3/4d up to 2:15 P.M.

All the financial and commodity markets will reopen this morning after what was, for most of them, a three-day suspension incident to the Independence Day holiday. The banks as well as the Exchanges and business houses generally were closed yesterday.

With the Tammany hosts home from Chicago, unhappy warriors all, the local political spotlight turns again on Mayor WALKER and the fate that awaits him at the hands of the Governor. The delegation did not make a very impressive showing at Chicago.
Mayor Walker, on his return from the Democratic National Convention yesterday, announced, in response to questions, that he would support the party's ticket in the coming campaign.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 4 -- His own world's record -- set twenty-four hours before -- fell today before Jack Woods of Detroit at the annual Fourth of July regatta of the Albany Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- A movement to persuade Speaker Garner to make a campaign tour of the country, to begin late this Summer, has been started by friends of the Texan. who are certain the suggestion will meet with the approval of Governor Roosevelt and other leaders, it was learned today.

The press both in Germany and England seems to be disturbed by Governor ROOSEVELT'S declaration that the war debts must not be canceled. It is feared that this will unfavorably affect the negotiations going on at Lausanne. There the new German Chancellor is insisting that the agreement about future reparations payments, if any accord can be raached, must be without regard to the attitude of the United States.

Confirmation of reports that Governor Roosevelt would have both sides of the Mayor Walker removal case before him for decision some time next week was seen here yesterday when Mr. Walker, back from the Democratic National Convention at Chicago, said that he planned to start drafting his reply to the Governor today.

Federal Intermediate Credit Banks. The Federal Intermediate Credit Banks System will offer today through its fiscal agent, Charles R. Dunn, a new issue of approximately $16,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent collateral trust debentures, due in three, six and nine months.

Unless substantial financial assistance is soon provided by the city or is received from some other source, the Visiting Nurse Service administered by the Henry Street Settlement will, for the first time in the nearly forty years it has been functioning, be compelled to restrict its free service to the sick.
NEW YORK. Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge is returning from Paris tomorrow and will be at the Madison.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 4 (AP) -- Thousands of office-seekers closed Oklahoma's initial primary election campaign tonight in a State-wide burst of oratorical fireworks.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- The Tigers recaptured second place in the American League today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Browns, 2 to 0 and 12 to 7, while the Athletics were held idle by rain.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. MELBOURNE, Victoria, July 4 -- The two German fliers, Captain Hans Bertram and his mechanic, Herr Clausmann, missing since May 17 on a flight from Kupang, Timor Island, to Darwin, Australia, were in a pitiable condition when found. They had subsisted on snails, kangaroo flesh and lizards for forty-five days.

LAHCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Only sixty-eight racing craft competed in the fifty-first annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today on the Sound. It was less than half the usual number for the Independence Day turnout. The reason was a driving rain in a stiff west-southwest wind.

Foundation work for the new thirty-eight-story Federal court house to be erected on the property east of Foley Square, between Pearl and Duane Streets, in the heart of the downtown civic centre, will be started in a week or ten days. The contract for the work has been awarded by the United States Treasury Department to the George Atwell Foundation Corporation of New York at 5387,267, the work to be completed in 240 days.
The New Friendship's Garland. If politics sometimes makes new friends -- witness SMITH and McADOO temporarily bedfellows at Chicago -- it seems to have a way of suddenly reviving old friendships.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Appointment of the Rev. James E. Kearney, pastor of the Church of St. Francis Xavier in the Bronx, New York City, as Bishop of Salt Lake, Utah, by the Holy See at Vatican City was announced today in messages received here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The Oberlaender Trust of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation announced today awards and grants for special research work in Germany and Austria. Gustave Oberlaender established the trust fund to enable American citizens to discover how the German people have dealt with problems that confront the American people.

On the farther slopes of the Alleghany Mountains, among the Laurel Hills of Western Pennsylvania, an appropriate contribution has been made to the celebration of the Washington Bicentennial. The discovery of the outline of Fort Necessity, hastily built by WASHINGTON at Great Meadows, has led to the reconstruction of the fort as a memorial.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 4 -- For the first time in many years the village of Bronxville abandoned a program of fireworks in celebration of Independence Day and turned over money allotted for fireworks to the unemployed. A band concert was held on the high school grounds, with the music furnished by unemployed musicians organized by the New York City emergency relief committee.
CATSKILL, N.Y., July 4 -- One man was killed instantly and four others were injured, one probably fatally, in an automobile accident near the top of Jefferson Hill early this morning.

CLEMENTON, N.J., July 4. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, addressing 3,500 persons at Clementon Park this afternoon in his first South Jersey speech since his nomination, charged both major parties with gross negligence in the matter of unemployment relief and offered socialism as "the only salvation from catastrophe or fascism, which is disaster itself and only postpones catastrophe."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -- The Lovatt Pipe Band of New York, of which Angus Fraser is leader, won first prize in the pipe-band competition open, which featured the annual Scottish games held under the auspices of the Round Hill Scottish Games Association on the estate of Charles Arthur Moore, Round Hill, Greenwich, this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES account of the reading machine for the blind mentions the fact that investigation showed that the children could not read the regular type of the visagraph as rapidly as they could read Braille.

Trapped in the bedroom of their burning apartment on the ground floor of a six-story building at Newport Street and Rockaway Parkway, in the Canarsie district of Brooklyn, a young mother and her 2-year-old baby were rescued last night by two patrolmen.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Wesley Ferrell won his fifteenth victory of the season for Cleveland, and Ted Lyons gave a flash of his old form today as the Indians and the White Sox divided a double-header. The split dropped Cleveland from fourth to fifth place.
Quietly and with restraint, city, State and nation celebrated yesterday the anniversary of the birth of the Republic.

Hampered by overcast skies and intermittent rains, more than 100 units of the Coast Guard fleet from New London to Norfolk swept the Atlantic yesterday in vain search for the missing 49-foot Ketch Curlew of New York, long overdue in the 628mile yacht race from Montauk Point to Bermuda that started June 25.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 -- The two major parties, particularly the Republican party and President Hoover, were scathingly denounced by speakers at tonight's mass meeting on the eve of the national convention of the Prohibition party.

Louisville, Ky. Offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,000,000 city of Louisville (Ky.) 4 1/2 per cent sewer bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1969, at a price to yield 4.40 per cent. The bonds will be marketed by a group headed by the Guaranty Company of New York and including the First National Old Colony Corporation, Hannahs, Ballin Lee and the Fidelity and Columbia Trust Company of Louisville.

WARSAW, July 4 -- Thanks to Ignace Paderewski, donor of the Wilson monument unveiled a year ago, today, at Poznan, Poland again celebrated the Fourth of July by unveiling a monument of a prominent American who is looked on as Poland's friend.
LATONIA, Ky., July 4 (AP) -- Play-time, an outsider belonging to the Southland Stable, led all the way today to win the mile and one-eighth Independence Handicap from Mania and Pittsburgher.

A rapid rise in municipal expenditures, including a sharp gain in debt service, is indicated in a survey of the fiscal problems of municipalities of New York State, with particular reference ,to second and third class communities, completed by Meech, Harmon, Lytle Blackmore of Buffalo.

By scoring his first victory in the featured $4,000 added Carter Handicap, which goes back to 1895, Admiral Gary T. Grayson prevented Joseph E. Widener from tallying his fourth triumph in the stake yesterday at Aqueduct.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Reggie McNamara, known as the Iron Man of bicycle racing, fractured his left collar bone in a bad spill tonight.
ALBANY, July 4 -- To the acclaim of Capitol crowds, Governor Roosevelt came home from the Democratic convention city late this afternoon.
All markets in this country were closed yesterday for the Independence Day holiday, and there were no prices quoted on the financial or commercial exchanges.

POSITANO, Italy, June 25 (by mail). -- An Italo-Venezuelan expedition will set out near the end of the year on an attempt to reach the source of the Orinoco River and augment the geographical data collected by such explorers as Dias de la Fuente, Humboldt and Dr. Herbert Spencer Dickey.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- The Pirates' artillery dropped the Chicago Cubs twice today, 9 to 6 and 6 to 5, tightening Pittsburgh's hold on first place in the National League.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- To the oarsmen of Philadelphia's famous Boathpuse Row went all the Olympic honors that the sixtieth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen had to offer. In the three-day regatta which ended today, six places on the United States Olympic rowing squad were decided, along with national champions in all classes, and all six of these places went to men of Philadelphia clubs.

CAIRO, July 4 -- It is understood that a decision in the Salem case has been given in favor of Egypt. Thus the United States on behalf of George T. Salem, a naturalized American citizen and former resident of Egypt, loses in the arbitration to which she agreed after the case had been pending for more than ten years.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The economic problem in the Philippines was described as more important at this time than the political problem by former Governor General Dwight F. Davis in his annual report, which was made public today by the War Department.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, July 4 -- Congress and the conventions have shown a calloused and even defiant indifference to the welfare of agriculture, Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, declared in a Fourth of July address here today.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 4 -- Despite severe wind and rain squalls, sixty yachts in seven classes sailed in the third championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association at the Island Heights Yacht Club today.
New York City celebrated what was apparently one of its safest and sanest Independence Days, according to incomplete reports received from police precincts and hospitals last night.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 4 -- Due to an unusual mix-up in the annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club today, the Class J sloops sailed a different course from that sailed by the fourteen other yachts in the race, and as a result no award was made of the club's famous trophy, the Puritan Cup.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So long as human nature is what it is, resulting in family differences, differences within the community and within the State, there must arise from time to time international differences.

The West Point Officers polo team defeated the First Division four at Fort Hamilton yestherday, 13 to 5. The winners, favored with a handicap of three goals, carried the play to their rivals from the start and never were headed. Because of the threatening weather the start of the game was delayed an hour.
REMSCHEID, Prussia, July 4 -- Early this morning the parents of Hans Bertram were aroused by a cablegram from Australia saying:

Mr. and Mrs. Gamaliel C. St. John of Greenwich, Conn., grave a dinner dance at the Lake Placid Club in the Adirondacks last night for their daughter, Miss Marie Louise St. John, and Dr. Tibor de Cholnoky of Budapest, Hungary, who will be married this afternoon in the Memorial Chapel at the club.

LONDON, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Cambridge University batsmen put up a great stand against the Oxford bowlers when the annual inter-varsity cricket classic got under way at Lord's today. When stumps were drawn the Light Blues had rolled up 356 runs for seven wickets.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senator Hiram Johnson, choosing Independence Day, issued a statement this afternoon so complimentary to Franklin D. Roosevelt that observers wondered if the Californian proposes to throw his active support behind the Democratic Presidential nominee.

Two cricket elevens, most of the members of which will be pitted against the Australians when they play here July 14 to 19, met in a trial match at Dyckman Oval yesterday. The team of the West Indian Cricketers of New York, captained by E.H. Margetson, won easily from L.C.K. Wood's team, made up of players from clubs in the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association and the Metropolitan District Cricket League.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 4 -- All of the racers in the Stamford Yacht Club's 232-mile contest out around Vineyard Sound Lightship were accounted for tonight with the exception of Frederick J. Wells's new sloop Cyclone.

Merchandise for promotion sales this month and in August was sought here last week in an effort to obtain Summer business rather than push early Fall, lines which has been the case in other years. Many retailers have featured in their promotions special groups of cotton frocks, sheer costumes and evening dresses.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons and Montreal Royals halved their holiday twin bill today. The first went to the Royals, 11 to 4, and the Bisons captured the second session, 8 to 1.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Fifth of a famous family of astronomers to win such a post, Dr. Otto Struve, professor of astrophysics at the University of Chicago, this week assumes the directorship of the university's Yerkes Observatory at Williams Bay, Wis.

Jack Sherry, 225, of Onto, threw Reginald Siki, 208-pound Abyssinian, in the feature wrestling bout at the Coney Island Stadium last night. Sherry pinned his rivalwith a bodyhold, following an airplane spin, in nine minutes and 42 seconds.
CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- North Randall's track, heavy from the recent rains, forced postponement until tomorrow of the two featured events today -- the Stallion Stakes and the Free-For-All Pace.

PRIDDIS, Alberta, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- Back again in the Rocky Mountain foothills, where he spent his early boyhood, the youthful Earl of Egmont is fast settling down to the life he left with his father to claim a fortune and title.

CATSKILL, N.Y., July 4 -- Five miles from the old-time Greene County headquarters of Legs Diamond, a man was slain today in what police believe was another gang murder. The victim, an unidentified man, was beaten to death with a sledge-like implement called a "godevil."

MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- A bas-relief tablet in memory of Ambassador Dwight W. Morrow "was unveiled in the chancellory of the United States Embassy here today by Javier Sanchez Mejorada, managing director of the National Railways of Mexico, who was an Intimate friend of Mr. Morrow.

A definite plan for applying the City Manager form of government to New York City, with a city council, which is to select the manager, to be elected in borough rather than city-wide elections, has been drafted by Richard S. Childs, generally considered America's foremost authority on this form of municipal government, and published in pamphlet form by the City Club of New York, of which he is president.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- The Boston Braves defeated the Phillies twice today by the scores of 8-6 and 9-0, and succeeded the Cubs in second place in the National League race.

LAUSANNE, July 5 -- Reparations are dying hard. All day long in the British Prime Minister's room at the Hotel Beau Rivage the debate went on, first with one country, then with another, and this evening Germany's offer for a final settlement stands at 2,600,000,000 marks ($618,800,000).

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- To commemorate the maiden voyage of the steamship Manhattan, the largest ship ever built in America, the Post-office Department has prepared a special cachet for use on letters to be carried by the vessel when she sails from New York on Aug. 10 for Queenstown, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg.

Directors of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company voted yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend on the common stock from 62 1/2 cents a share to 25 cents a share, rather than curtail national advertising of its products. They said it would be the policy of the company to conserve its resources and maintain a liquid position so long as present economic conditions continue.

The net asset value of capital stock of the Lehman Corporation was $47.34 a share on 686,900 shares on June 30, according to the annual report for the year ended on that date, issued yesterday. This compares with net asset values of $56.64 a share on 782,100 shares on Dec. 31 and $74.17 on 873,400 shares at the end of the preceding fiscal year.

General Orders 18 of the New York Police Department, issued yesterday at "headquarters, lists the names of policemen who have been singled out for personal heroism and other exceptionally efficient work. A posthumous award of honorable mention is made to Patrolman John Walsh of Traffic C, who was killed on the night of last Jan. 21 while attempting to frustrate a hold-up at 206 East Eighty-eighth Street.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 5 -- The story of a fight by two patrolmen with two women and a man on the dance floor of the Woodlands Park Casino was told to Police Judge James J. Lyden in court here today. Patrolman Michael Erdley of the park police said that the assistance of Sergeant George Glintenkamp was required before the disturbance could be quieted.
MOSCOW, July 5. -- Tentative and unofficial moves are being made to reopen the question of formal diplomatic relations between the United States and Soviet Russia.

Circumstances may lead an Empress to transgress just as they may incite the modern underprivileged youth into criminality, it appears from "The Comedy of Catherine the Great," by Francis Gribble, just published by E.P. Button Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Democratic party platform and Presidential nominee were commended today by Representative Paul J. Kvale, Farmer-Laborite, of Minnesota, who indicated a readiness to join the opposition to President Hoover headed by Senator Norris of Nebraska and silently supported by the twelve independent Republican Senators.

Cincinnati is famous for many things. It is proud of having got rid of boss control and substituted a form of government which has been hailed by reformers the country over, among them our own Judge SEABURY. It has in the person of Mr. DYKSTRA a competent city manager, whose abilities are shown not only in the administration of the affairs of the city but in his clear and illuminating reports.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 5 -- A challenge to wet forces in both Republican and Democratic parties that "we are ready to meet them on the prohibition issue in constitutional form at the polls" was sounded here today at the opening of the national convention of the Prohibition party by Clinton N. Howard of Rochester, N.Y., keynote speaker and chairman of the National United Committee for Law Enforcement.
