BERLIN, July 5. -- The Koelnische [Cologne] Volkszeitung, the leading organ of the Centrist party in the Rhineland, was forbidden to publish for three days by a verdict of the Federal Supreme Court today.

Miss Grace Surber of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, who scored a notable victory over Mrs. Carolyn Schwartz Hirsch last week to win the metropolitan crown, advanced to the quarter-finals of the New York State clay-court championship yesterday with the loss of only two games in as many matches.

While grain markets sagged yesterday, there were sharp price advances elsewhere in commodities. Sugar futures rose 1 to 6 points, and one contract of raws was reported sold as high as 2.97 cents, an advance of 17 points over last Friday. Coffee, cocoa, provisions, silk, hides and rubber also were higher. Other articles were steady.

The booming of the army's saluting guns that helped to usher another Independence Day into history Monday was the most warlike sound the garrisons at Fort Hamilton and Fort Wadsworth have heard for more than twenty years.

The sum of only $48,000 stands between the American Olympic committee and complete American representation in this year's great international extravaganza at Los Angeles. This was learned yesterday when the committee gathered in its final meeting at the New York Athletic Club.

A "demonstration of merchandising courage" by stores through more liberal purchasing policies was called for yesterday by George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, who asserted that continued delay in buying of cotton goods "will necessarily mean continued shrinkage in purchasing power and a prolongation of the depression."

The State Athletic Commission yesterday adopted a resolution designed to give the board direct control over the time for starting broadcasts of bouts, the assignment of the commentators who broadcast and the use of the ringside microphone by others than those assigned for the purpose.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of May 30 there appeared a letter from Mrs. S.M. Farrell, president of the Vivisection Investigation League, Inc., in which she condemns vivisection and questions the correctness of the assertions of the medical profession that insulin has been of tremendous benefit in the treatment of diabetes and has prolonged the life of diabetic patients.

The American Legion's unemployment campaign for 1,000,000 jobs has gone "over the top," It was announced yesterday by the Legion's national unemployment commission. At the same time Mark T. McKee, executive director of the commission, laid new plans to increase employment were being formulated and would be made public later.

"The greatest convention in the history of any party in the United States and the greatest platform," was the verdict of Francis P. Garvan, head of the Chemical Foundation, on the Democratic National Convention which came to a close in Chicago on Saturday, in announcing hia support of the ticket headed by Governor Roosevelt.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 -- A large gathering was present at the Casino Theatre tonight for the first performance of the sixth season when "June Moon," by George Kaufman and Ring Lardner was presented, with Lee Patrick, Edith Van Cleve and Harry Ellerbe in the leading roles.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The move at Geneva to adjourn the general disarmament conference until Fall and utilize the intervening time for study of the proposal of President Hoover was said on high authority this afternoon to be welcomed by the United States.

By his hurried trip from Lausanne to Paris, Premier HERRIOT seems to have won a respite rather than a reprieve at the hands of the French Chamber. His difficulties are financial. The French Government faces an estimated deficit of about $215,000,000 for the current fiscal year.

MONTREAL, July 5. -- The Canadian International Paper Company and subsidiary companies report that their consolidated net revenue in 1931 available for interest and depreciation was $4,530,869, compared with $5,612,082 in 1930.

LONDON, July 5. -- London bankers are skeptical of ideas for an empire currency system which have been advanced in discussions of the plans for the empire economic conference at Ottawa this month. Practical financiers in the City admit that the return of the gold standard is out of the question for the present, but they are equally convinced that this international metallic monetary standard must be eventually re-established.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The first gun of the administration aimed at the policies proclaimed by Governor Roosevelt in his speech accepting the Democratic nomination was fired today. Secretary Hyde was the gunner and that part of the speech in which Governor Roosevelt suggested reforestation as one of the ways to relieve unemployment was his target.

Tax collections on account of the first half of this year's tax levy have failed off $19,173,497.84, with the city's large business enterprises responsible for moat of the deficiency, City Collector William Held Jr. said yesterday.

LONDON, July 5 -- The Stock Exchange was quieter today, with most of the industrials affected adversely by profit-taking. British Government funds again were easier following further weakening of sterling.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting will give a dinner dance on Sept. 14 at Hamilton Farm, Gladstone, N.J., for Miss Victoria Brady, who will make her debut next Winter.

As detectives were searching vainly for Owen Madden and three of his associates, all wanted for violation of parole, attorneys for the four notified State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of their intention to carry the case to the Court of Appeals.

BILL DICKEY of the Yankees landed one punch and the victim was carted to the hospital with his jaw fractured in two places. This strengthens the conviction that Sharkey and Sehmeling were playing pat-a-cake or something that fine evening in the new Garden Bowl on Long Island.

Harry J. Koerper, former managing director of the twenty-six story building at Riverside Drive and 103d Street in which the Roerich Museum and its affiliated art activities are housed, committed suicide there Monday night or yesterday morning by firing three bullets under his heart.

WASHINGTON, July B -- Speaker Garner will follow the example set by Governor Roosevelt and receive formal notice of his nomination for the Vies Presidency with as little ceremony and expense as possible. He expects Senators Barkley and Walsh to visit his office in the near future and briefly express the choice of the Democratic National Convention.

GENEVA, July 5 -- The disarmament conference headed today toward taking an early vacation of indefinite length. In a secret meeting its steering committee decided that the conference, before dispersing should issue a declaration for a triple purpose:

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., July 5 (AP). -- Two American aviators, James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, fought their way through what sailors call a "pea soup" fog today to reach their first goal on a round-the-world flight.

Two steamships arrived yesterday from Europe, bringing back the first crowd of pilgrims who had attended the Eucharistic Congress in Dublin last month. They said the streets of the Irish capital had been so crowded it was difficult to walk about.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP). -- Catcher Bill Dickey of the Yankees today was indefinitely suspended by President William Harridge of the American League for assaulting Carl Reynolds, Washington outfielder.

James J. Mattern, whose home is in Port Worth, Texas, and Bennett Griffin of Oklahoma City, who started their world flight yesterday, are former army Lieutenants, and both have had a good deal of flying experience since entering civil life. Mattern has flown in several races and derbies, including the Gardner Trophy race at St. Louis in May, 1929.

BERLIN, July 5 -- Well-informed political circles in Berlin now look for Germany's acceptance of the plan of Sir Walter Thomas Layton for liquidating reparations pressed by the British at Lausanne. While it is expected Premier Herriot of France will demand certain modifications before offering it to his chamber, its fundamental implications impress political leaders close to the present government as suggesting an acceptable final solution to the long deadlocked negotiations.

LONDON, July 5 -- The government went full speed ahead with its anti-Irish tariff proposals today despite yesterday's revelation that President de Valera was putting the unpaid annuities into a special fund.

With rain over much of the South on the Independence Day holiday, making ten days of almost continuous moisture in some sections, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose yesterday into new high ground for the present movement, October selling within 2 points of the 6-cent level, while July touched 5.84 cents a pound, contrasted with its recent mark of 4.91, which is the lowest on record.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP). -- The Senate today adopted a proposal to reduce from twelve to four the number of banks authorized under the home loan bank bill sponsored by the administration.

Gradual disintegration of the National Electric Power group, the two principal holding companies of which went into receivership on Thursday, is impending as a result of the offering for sale at public auction a week from today of securities of operating companies pledged with the New York Trust Company as collateral for a loan of $3,000,000 to the National Electric Power Company.

"Tanks" will be used to collect the nickels dropped into the turnstiles of the new city subway system and transport them to the auditing bureau of the Board of Transportation, at 250 Hudson Street, it was disclosed yesterday.

Nothing could inspire greater confidence in the future of the United States than a study of its geography as presented in an atlas published jointly by the Carnegie Institution of Washington and the American Geographical Society of New York. It opens with a series of plates illustrating the world of nature in which the American nation came into being and has grown to maturity within 300 years.

St. Luke's Hospital opened yesterday its first appeal to the public for funds in its seventy-four years of existence, explaining that unless the estimated deficit of $150,000 in the 1932 budget is made up it will have to curtail free service in its clinic, ward and convalescent branches.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- President Hoover in a message to Congress today requested a special appropriation of $120,000 to continue the work of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief.

The annual exhibition of work by students in the Summer classes of the Art Students' League also opened yesterday and will receive critical comment later. The work will remain on view through Saturday in the league galleries, at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BERLIN, July 5. -- German sports enthusiasts, who will be hosts to the next Olympic Games in 1936, have duff deep into their pockets to finance the sending of a team of seventy-seven athletes to this year's games at Los Angeles.

Twelve juniors from as many women's colleges began yesterday the annual "Junior Month" sociological course given by the Charity Organization Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street. A preliminary session was held on Monday.

The weakness in sterling that developed late last week, following the announcement of the British Government's plan for converting the $2,000,000,000 of 5 per cent War Loan bonds, was renewed yesterday with the opening of trading in the foreign exchange market here.

A special statutory court which, had been convened to settle the dispute between the State of New York and the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads in connection with the proposed payment by the latter railroad of an additional $1,000,000 a year rent for the use of trackage facilities of the Pennsylvania reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments from both sides.

Patrick F. Dwyer, widely known for years as a colleague of Tom Healey's when both conditioned the horses of the late Richard T. Wilson, and more recently trainer for Walter J. Salmon, scored in the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday with his own Panax, a gelded son of Axenstein, the test holding the feature position on the closing day card.

LONDON, July 5 -- On the return of the Cunarder Scythia after an experimental voyage from New York using a new mixture of oil and coal in certain boilers, the owners report the test was a success. Isaac Foot, Secretary of Mines, in the House of Commons tonight congratulated the company, but asked the House to remember that the experiment was only in the early stages.
OTTAWA, Ont., July 5 (Canadian Press). -- The draw for the Canadian open golf championship, opening Thursday over the wind-swept Ottawa Hunt and Golf Club links, was released tonight.
Small homes comprised the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area, reported yesterday.

NEWARK, July 5 (AP). -- The Newark Bears today took both ends of a double-header from Jersey City at the Ruppert Stadium by scores of 5 -- 3 and 5 -- 0, to close their home stay on top of the International League, a game and a half in front of the Baltimore Orioles.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- President Hoover, in an eleventh-hour move, halted the $2,100,000,000 unemployment relief bill tonight until some arrangement more satisfactory to the administration could be worked out.

Were Governor ROOSEVELT to believe what some of his supporters at Chicago are saying to crowds of homefolk, he would not be continuing the "harmonizing" efforts he began as soon as the nomination was made. He would not be planning the "short trips" to various parts of the country, the six or seven -- which will probably turn into twelve -- brief addresses, each concerned with a single issue.

The Wheatley Stable's Blenheim, winner of the Brooklyn and Brookdale Handicaps in big last two starts, will be the star performer today when the Empire City Racing Association begins its twenty-two-day meeting at the Yonkers oval. The Empire City Handicap, at a mile and a quarter with $5,000 in added money, is the feature and in it Blenheim is counted a surs winner by many admirers.

PLATTSBURG BARRICKS, N.Y., July 5 -- With many high-ranking army officers, including Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, extending a welcome, the last detachment of 1,237 of the 2,300 young men who will attend the 1932 Citizens' Military Training Camp here arrived tonight aboard a nineteen-car special train which left New York City this morning.

Additional statements of condition, issued yesterday by national banks and State banks and trust companies in response to calls by the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banks for reports as of the close of business on June 30, showed a high degree of liquidity.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 5. -- Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup sloop Vanitie today beat her rival, Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe by 14 minutes and 33 seconds in the first run of the annual cruise of the Eastern Yacht Club. On corrected time the Vanitie won by 8:33.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 5 -- Mme. Symnove Johanna Waaler, radio broadcaster of New York, well known in Hollywood, Cal., was married on Friday to Edward Leiter, an actor of New York, in the parsonage of the Baptist Church at North Egremont by the Rev. Elmer S. Allen.

SHANGHAI, July 5 -- Alarmist reports, charging that Japan was intending to attack Peiping and Tientain by sending Manchukuo armies through the Jehol Mountain passes, were received in Nanking today from Chang Hsiao-liang, ousted Governor of Manchuria, who is in Peiping.

Estimates submitted to the Shippers' Regional Advisory Boards indicate that carload shipments of the twenty-nine chief commodities in July, August and September will, be 21.1 per cent below those in the same months last year. Current car loadings are running 30 per cent under those of last year.

BERKELEY, Cal., July 5. -- Joe McCluskey of Fordham University raced to victory today in the 3,000-meter steeplechase, one of the five post-In-tercollegiate A.A.A.A. semi-final Olympic tryouts in Edwards Stadium, and won the right to compete in the final trials at Palo Alto July 15 and 16.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Congress must either immediately pass laws expanding the currency and further extending credit, or return here in the Autumn "facing the proposition of devaluating the dollar," Senator Borah asserted this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jdly 5 (AP) -- C.C. Van Meter's Red Whisk came back in his best form at Arlington Park today and easily captured the River Forest purse by three and a half lengths. Clarify was second and Poppyman finished third in the five and one-half furlong dash.

The Police Department resumed yesterday the Summer excursions instituted two years ago and entirely supported since then by the uniformed force as its contribution to the relief of mothers and children in the city.

In many instances the new Federal tax on borrowed stock, which must be paid by the lender and in turn collected from the borrower or short seller, is being evaded by failure to deliver the stock sold short, according to information in brokerage circles yesterday.

Long Petitions and Short Memories. Washington is a State where petitions flourish. At Present there are between fifteen and twenty going the rounds. Statutory measures may be initiated by the people, the law requiring 50,000 signatures to place a measure on the ballot.

Barring the "pinch" in Federal funds, which sold at 1 per cent compared with a recent 1/5@1/4, and which was due to reserve deficiencies because of the payment of the first-of-the-month checks, there was little else of account recorded in the day's money market.

German bonds of all classifications rose sensationally on the Stock Exchange yesterday, rallying practically the entire foreign list and imparting a strong tone to domestic corporation issue. United States Government bonds continued moderately higher.

Declaring that the New York City Government was from three to six months in arrears in redeeming food checks issued by the Department of Public Welfare and honored by grocers, the Grocers' Protective Committee, with a membership of 150 independent store owners, met last night in the Broadway Central Hotel to discuss plans for compelling the city to act.

BOSTON, July 5 (AP). -- Mayor James M. Curley, Roosevelt chieftain and a hitherto political enemy of Governor Joseph B. Ely, Smith partisan, today said he would support Mr. Ely for re-election. Mayor Curley said it was Governor Ely's duty as a Democrat to run for the Governorship again.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July, 5. -- With the field reduced from fifty-eight pairs to sixteen, the second round of the contract bridge pair championship of the American Whist League was concluded here this afternoon with Charles Lochridge and Sam Fry Jr. of the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York in the lead with 206 match points.

The daily average gross crude oil production of the United States for the week ended last Saturday was 2,104,800 barrels, as compared with 2,156,000 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 51,300 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

PARIS, July 5 -- Optimism persists on the Bourse and today's prices again were higher. Logdingr the upward movement were Pechiney Oilmen, Suez Cnnal, Rio Tinlo Copper Campanie Generale d'Electricile. The pound sterling was slightly weaker, but the dollar was stronger.

Five judges instead of the customary nine were sitting yesterday in Federal Court at the beginning of a heavy July calendar and the generally accepted explanation for this at the Federal Building was that the economy order issued by the Attorney General last month, had influenced many jurists from other districts not to accept invitations to sit here.

LONDON, July 5 (AP). -- Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, young society woman, declared in cool, calm tones on the witness stand today that for almost two years she had supported Thomas William Scott Stephen, whom she is accused of having murdered.

Settlement of the dispute between the city and St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Duane Street, over the transfer of property, seemed assured yesterday when Controller Charles W. Berry said that he would ask the Sinking Fund Commission at its next meeting to Brant the land desired by the church in exchange for land it has already given the city.
ALBANY, July 5. -- Governor Roosevelt revealed today that he would take a cruise with his four sons in New England waters next week, using a forty-foot yawl.

LONDON, July 5 (Canadian Press). -- With six wickets in hand, Oxford was 295 runs behind Cambridge when stumps were drawn at Lord's at the close of the second day's play in the annual varsity cricket match.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the wife of a physician I would like to answer a letter appearing in "Excerpts From Letters" in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Sunday, asking that the professional class -- doctors particularly -- lower their fees. The writer seems to think they should come down in proportion to the cuts the general public has taken.

The Knoedler Galleries opened yesterday "a selected group of fine prints of six centuries," which will remain on view through this month and August. Emphasis is laid on the prints themselves rather than on the centuries; that is to say, no effort has been made to give anything approaching a comprehensive picture of the progress of graphic art through this long period.

The list of the Cunarder Berengaria, leaving tonight for Southampton via Cherbourg, includes a large group of the Business and Professional Women's League headed by Miss Lena Madesin Phillips. Others leaving are:

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 5. -- The first race of the July dinghy series was held today at the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and was won by Jimmie Rousmaniere in his Lynx, the boat crossing the finish line three minutes ahead of Susan, sailed by John Cross.

NEWARK, July 5 -- Axlee, bay colt owned by J.B. Gillipan of South Orange, and Joan Bunter, brown filly owned by Wilbur D. Blood of Rutherford, carried off the purses in the colt stakes at the special matinee today at Weequahic Park.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- The Giants first public appearance here this year under any management was a hotly contested ten-inning struggle ending in a 4-to-3 victory for the league-leading Pirates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That estimable practitioner of fiction, Thomas McMorrow, must have been unusually genial when he dashed off his plea [in a letter to THE TIMES] for the return of the open saloon. In fact, before deciding upon comment I puzzled forty-eight hours to determine, if possible, whether Mr. McMorrow was joking.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 5 -- Residents of Main Avenue here were startled early today at the sight of a "human torch," darting from a building across several vacant lots and through an alleyway into Harrison Street. An investigation indicated, the police said, that Joseph Gash, 69 years old, a baker, had set fire to his clothing while attempting to burn down his shop at 889 Main Avenue.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July S. -- Martin Buxby of the University of Texas became the first quarter-finalist in the Rhode Island State men's tennis championships on the turf courts at Agawam Hunt as today's opening matches reduced the field of sixty-four to nineteen.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia extended to July 14 the time in which Radio Corporation of America and Mackay Radio Telegraph Company can answer to the Federal Radio Commission's plea for a rehearing on the reallocation of certain domestic short wave frequencies.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- President Hoover again used his veto power today, sending back to the Senate without his approval a bill which proposed to extend the Bacon-Davis law relative to the wages paid laborers and mechanics on public buildings.

LONDON, July 5 -- The German delegates at the first of the quarterly conferences on the working of the standstill agreement covering Germany's private foreign credits have succeeded in winning a reduction of the rates of interest.

A strike of nearly 30,000 workers in the cloak and suit industry was brought one step nearer yesterday when a conference between the jobbers and union spokesmen reached" an impasse on the question of "limitation of contractors."

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Catching the Democratic side without enough votes to control the House early this afternoon, the Republicans went on a rampage that for more than an hour turned the House into anything but a dignified and sedate group of legislators earning $10,000 a year.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. MILWAUKEE, July 5. -- A 12 1/2 per cent reduction in local rates of the 102 exchanges operated by the Wisconsin Telephone Company, ordered by the State Public Service Commission, is a bold stroke in public utility regulation the outcome of whlch will attract the attention of regulatory bodies and utility managements all over the country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 5 (AP). -- With three homers featuring their batting attack, the Montreal Royals made it three out of four over the Bisons today by taking the final game of the series, 6 to 3. The defeat sent the Bisons tumbling into third place, Baltimore gaining second place.

CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) -- Although forced to the limit in an extra-heat race, The Marchioness, owned by Mrs. Will F. Caton of Syracuse, N.T., and driven by Will Caton, outran the field in the third and extra heat at North Randall today to win the $12,500 Stallion Stake for 3-yaar-old Trotters, feature of today's Grand Circuit racing.

Out on hail on a charge of grand larceny in connection with the "sale" of the Union Square Hotel to a man he met in Union Square Park, George Sauer, 39 years old, a sandhog, of 441 Sixth Street, was arrested early yesterday morning at Sixth Street and First Avenue on a charge of grand larceny.

MONTREAL, Que., July 5 (Canadian Press). -- A possibility that the party system of government in Great Britain is a thing of the past is seen by Anthony Vickers of the firm of Vickers, Ltd., armament manufacturers. Mr. Vickers is here with nine other steel industrialists who are conferring with Canadian steel men preliminary to the imperial conference.

The future of secondary education including a central planning commission and "varying so that it will be appropriate to the abilities, interests and probable needs of each individual," was outlined last night by Professor Thomas H. Briggs of Teachers College, Columbia University, in an address at the Secondary Education Conference, in the Horace Mann Auditorium, Teachers College.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., July 5. -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, the American fliers who left New York early this morning on an attempt to shatter the round-the-world record, arrived here this afternoon after a grueling trip, hurriedly refueled their plane and then took off for Berlin.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- New low prices for July and September wheat, also for July corn and oats, were made today on the Board of Trade. Liquidating pressure was responsible for the weakness and it was said at the last that practically all the July trades had been closed out or would be within a few days.
To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the worst phases of street congestion is that resulting1 from the unrestrieted parking ol motor cars all night.

No word came yesterday from former Governor Alfred E. Smith as to whether or not he would support Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, but intimate friends indicated that he would not maintain much longer the silence in which he has persisted since Roosevelt's nomination, but would fall into line in support of his party ticket today or tomorrow.

Yesterday's markets presented indications of exactly contradictory trends, under varying influences which had nothing to do with one another. Stocks declined at the start, regaining something like half at the early loss before the close. For the initial weakness, Franklin Roosevelt's nomination by the Democratic convention was commonly assigned.

Whatever believers in the integrity and discipline of parties may think of Senator NORRIS'S practice of being nominated and elected as a Republican and then heartily opposing Republican policies and Presidents in the Senate, Nebraska is satisfied with it.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 5 (AP). -- Awakened at daylight by the news that her husband had started from New York on the first lap of a round-the-world flight, Mrs. Jimmie Mattern began a vigil of prayerful waiting here today that will last until he returns.
ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP). -- Red Lucas pitched Cincinnati to a 12-to-4 victory over St. Louis today in the final game of the series.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 5 -- Following is the balance statements of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of June 30, as made public here today. Figures are in Swiss francs at par, 19.3 cents:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5 -- Members of the executive committee of the Garden Club of Southampton, of which Mrs. Robert Waller is president, met this morning at Sound o' Sea, the home of Mrs. Tillman Martin. Mrs. Waller presided. Plans were made for the next meeting of the club, which will take place on July 13 at Lenoir, the home of Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson.
Details of recent leasing deals were shown in contracts recorded yesterday at the Register's Office.

Up six flights of stairs at 129 East Ninety-seventh Street, turn right in the gloomy hall and ring the bell on John Costen's door. You hear the soft, brushing movement of a hand on the inside panel, a fumbling on the knob and the door opens. John Costen has been blind eight years.

The airship Akron took off from the naval air station at Lakehurst, N.J., at 8:30 o'clock last night to assist more than 100 Coast Guard vessels, as well as private craft, in the search for the missing ketch Curlew and her crew of six amateur seamen.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. MELBOURNE, Victoria, July 5 -- Leaving Kupang, Timor Island, at midnight on May 14, we were blown off our course and had to fly blind for several hours, although we thought we could make Melville Island.

DUBLIN, July 5 -- The debate in the House of Commons yesterday on the land annuities has had the effect of relieving public anxiety here. The disclosure that the money collected here has been lodged in a suspense account pending arbitration is accepted in political circles as denoting that the Free State Government prefers settlement by negotiation.

WINDSOR, Conn., July 5 -- Volo Yorke won the 2:12 class trot at Sage Park today with heats of 2:07 and 2:08 1/2 in a day of high-class racing in which only one mile was timed as slow at 2:10. Invader took the 3-year-old trot and April Symbol carried off the pacing event. Mr. Hanover, 2-year-old pacer, was given a record of 2:12 in an impressive exhibition.

The hearing on the complaint of the New York Warehousemen's Protective Committee and other warehousemen's organizations, which allege that the railroads operating at the Port of New York are fostering unfair competition to warehouse owners by warehousing and storing freight, was continued yesterday before William K. Bartel, director of the Bureau of Service of the Interstate Commerce Commission, at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

Half the counties of this State have been organized or are being organized by the New York State Economic Council in an effort to force the Legislature to reduce expenditures and thus cut taxation. This was announced by George W. Wickersham, the council's chairman, in an address broadcast last evening over WJZ and a National Broadcasting network.

A. Graham Miles, who once was a polo player, an army reserve officer and a son-in-law of a lessee of the old Waldorf-Astoria, was returned yesterday to a private sanitarium in Beacon, N.Y., from which he had escaped on Saturday.

An auction sale of articles seized by the police or left unclaimed in their custody was held yesterday in the basement of Police Headquarters in accordance with the practice of emptying the storeroom of the property clerk whenever it gets too full.

Weakness in a handful of market leaders seemed to Wall Street to account for the moderate decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday. There were no striking declines, but some of the popular trading stocks lost as much as 2 or 3 points. The average price of fifty selected stocks showed a net loss of 94 cents.

Victory for the Democratic party in the national campaign and a Democratic sweep in his home State of California, where he is seeking the United States Senatorial nomination, were predicted here yesterday by William G. McAdoo. Mr. McAdoo, with a small party, arrived yesterday from Chicago and is staying at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5. -- "Ambitious" proposals to amend the anti-trust laws, which reflect little if any knowledge of economics or the legal history of the subject, were denounced tonight by Gilbert H. Montague of New York at the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

The sport of taming deep sea game fish has an especial appeal for most fishermen. And with the developing of the art of taking swordfish on rod and reel there are some who are willing to set out year after year in the hope that sometime they will get their fish.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The bonus expeditionary forces paraded Pennsylvania Avenue again today, swarmed about the Senate end of the Capitol for two hours listening to speeches fiery and sometimes bordering on the radical, sang "America" and "The Star-Spangled Banner" and then straggled back to their respective camps to eat wheat, which, according to police, was the only rations left.

Clement Lista, a painter of 36 Berpenline Avenue, Guttenburg, N.J., was held without bail yesterday on a charge of having shot and killed Salvatore Arena, a painter and decorator of 1,550 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, at the St. George Terminal of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad on Monday night.

PARIS, July 5 -- A decision was handed down today against the National City Bank in litigation over an account with the Franco-Asiatic Bank, and a a result 10,000,000 francs I about $393,000} has been attached by the French Bank.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 5 -- In a hard-fought, interesting match the first title of the 1932 Meadow Brook Club polo tournaments went to Greentree tonight when the team led by Thomas Hitchcock Jr. turned back Templeton in the final of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup event 11 to 9.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 5 -- Reports received today said treasure hunters on Cocoa Island, off the coast of Costa Rica, with the aid of a new metal diviner had located a spot in the bed of Wafer,Creek under which they believed lay the famous Devonshire treasure, burled by Captain Graham of the British warship Devonshire after that adventurous seaman turned pirate.

BUENOS AIRES, July 5. -- "Social and moral questions will lead the Foreign Office to continue to refuse diplomatic recognition to the Soviet Government," says a note that the Foreign Minister sent to the Chamber of Deputies today in response to a request for information on the possibillty of the government recognizing the Soviet or canceling the late Provisional President Urlburu's decree banishing luyamlorg, tha Russian trade agency, from Argentina.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on June 29 shows decreases for the week of $65,000,000 in loans and investments, $26,000,000 in time deposits, $54,000,000 in government deposits, $22,000,000 in horrowings from Federal Reserve Banks and $27,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

Borrowings by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange declined $56,822,927 in June, or from $300,397,222 at the end of May to $243,574,295 on June 30, according to the monthly compilation by the Exchange, made public yesterday. The loan account now stands at the lowest figure since compilation of the figures was started and contrasts with the high record of $8,549,383,979 made at the end of September, 1929.

DETROIT, Mich., July 5. -- Before a meeting of many city officials and industrial and business leaders today, Mayor Frank Murphy outlined a program designed to save at least $7,000,000 from the $72,000,000 tax budget and enable the city through banking cooperation to escape defaulting on its bond.

CATSKILL, N.Y., July 5 (AP). -- The Sheriff of Greene County today was looking for Salvatore Spitale, New York underworld character, for questioning regarding the murder of an unidentified man slain last night in a farmhouse near the former headquarters of "Jack" Diamond, who was murdered in Albany.

American observers have Been noting during the past year or two that the young people of this country are showing a serious side, a purposeful tendency toward the good life that was sadly lacking in those of their age immediately after the war.

President BUTLER'S Fourth of July address in London may not have contained novel ideas, but it did enforce one point with fresh emphasis. Others have spoken of the need of a "declaration of interdependence." The close-knit world of today which must coordinate one part with the other unless it is to fly into discordant pieces has been the theme of other orators and writers.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The drive to change the prohibition laws began this afternoon in the Senate, in the ears of whose members loudly rang the declarations on that subject by the recent political conventions.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 5 (AP) -- Senator Elmer Thomas, a leader in the legislative fight for payment of the soldiers' bonus and an oil tariff, held a commanding lead over three opponents in his race for Democratic renomination as returns from today's primary election were tabulated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of tens of thousands of Republicans who, putting country above party, principle above policy and present needs above past accomplishments, will vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt. May I, therefore, set forth seven seasons why for the first time in my life I intend to vote for a Democrat?
WINDSOR, Conn., July 6. -- Toll Gate triumphed today in the free-for-all pace at Sage Park. The son of Peter G., owned by J.M. Roddy of Kingston, Ont., won in three straight heats.

MOSCOW, July 6. -- To reap the biggest crop in the history of Russia, the Soviet Government will launch the biggest harvest campaign in its history. Two days ago Soviet statisticians said there would be a bumper crop through an increased yield per acre despite the fact that the total acreage sown was less than last year.

RYE, N.Y., July 6. -- Three American records were shattered by candidates for the women's Olympic swimming team at a water carnival conducted by the Women's Swimming Association of New York in the 50-yard pool at Playland tonight.

Led by sterling, which was supported by the Bank of England for the first time in several days, foreign exchanges yesterday recovered nearly all of their heavy losses of the previous day. Sterling rallied 2 1/4 cents to $3.57 1/4, the franc was up 1/4 point to 3.93 cents, belgas rose 1/2 point to 13.91 cents, guilders 1 point to 40.38 cents and Swiss francs 1 1/2 points to 19.51 cents.

Emphasis on novelty-textured fabrics, combination jacket styles, velvet for evening wear and wide use of fur trimmings featured the models shown yesterday at additional openings by members of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America. Showrooms were again crowded, in several cases to capacity.

TOKYO, July 6. -- Count Uchida accepted the post of Foreign Minister this morning and was installed in the presence of the Emperor. Later he made a brief statement which gratified the newspapers though it left their curiosity unsatisfied regarding the burning question of recognition of Manchukuo.

Fall Buying Attendance Good. The attendance of buyers here to view Fall lines and to analyze major trends for the new season has been better than was expected for this period, comments in the dress and coat trades indicated yesterday. While the store representatives will be cautious in their early operations, they are disposed to give buying attention to styles which emphasize salability.

A member of President Hoover's emergency committee for employment in 1930-31 has turned to fiction to express some of his views on the present world economic situation. Dr. James C. Lawrence, dean of the University of Minnesota, under the pseudonym of Calvin Quincy Cabot, is the author of "The Year of Regeneration," just published by Harper Brothers.

Citing the great saving the city could effect by using the existing organized Visiting Nurse Service administered by the Henry Street Settlement, Felix M. Warburg, president of the service, requested the city yesterday to appropriate $250,000 for home nursing to the destitute unemployed.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 6. -- Zachary Smith Reynolds, 20 years old, one of the heirs to the vast estate amassed by the late R.J. Reynolds, fatally shot himself early today at his country home here. Dr. W.N. Dalton, Forsyth County Coroner, after an investigation said he would record the death as a suicide.

TORONTO, July 6 (AP). -- Losing the first game, 6 -- 4, in thirteen innings, the Toronto Leafs broke even with Reading in a double-header today by taking the second game, 3 -- 2, scoring the tying and winning runs in the seventh and last inning.

Playing in the best form she has shown since the Sears Cup matches, Baroness Maud Levi defeated Miss Florence Le Boutillier of Westbury, L.I., yesterday, to reach the semifinal round of the Women's New York State Clay Court Championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

LONDON, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- Oxford and Cambridge played to a draw in the annual varsity cricket match concluded at Lord's today. The scores were: Cambridge 431 and 163 for nine wickets, Oxford 368.

The Republican Scout. No one can be more pleased with Governor ROOSEVELT'S decision to start the campaign early than Senator MOSES. The longer the period of purely political activity, the happier he is.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I suppose any intelligent American would gladly do his small part in any plan to lessen this business depression. I know I would. But I want to point out some results, which I know all about, certainly following on the proposed blind cut in wages of all government employes or any other employes.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP). -- Homers by Art Shires and Walter Berger were the only runs made by the Boston Braves today as they lost to the Cardinals, 4 to 2, in the series opener. Bill Hallahan, southpaw, holding the Braves to five hits, gained his tenth victory of the year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 6. -- A large audience filled Parish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players opened their sixth season by presenting "Goodbye Again." The play, a new comedy by Allan Scott and Harry Selby, was directed by Henry Codman Potter, founder of the group.

After obtaining an indictment yesterday against two officers of the Knickerbocker Fur Coat Company, Inc., which did business at 134 West Twenty-ninth Street, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, denounced creditors who "come to terms with crooked debtors."

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., July 6. -- Charles Journal, remembered for his Montmartre Club in New York, and Vivian Johnson jointly will open the Montmartre Friday Supper Club here Friday night as a weekly rendezvous for society and celebrities of the theatrical profession.
Every agency of the government augmented private enterprise in searching the waters of the Atlantic for the missing ketch Curlew yesterday as hope for the craft and her amateur crew of six men waned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to enter disagreement to the obiter dictum you pronounce under the caption, "Walker's Case Next": "The [New York] delegation did not make a very impressive showing at Chicago."

Aaron Sapiro, who drew up the papers of organization for the Metropolitan Cleaners and Dyers Association and for the various regional associations of retail cleaners and tailors, has resigned as counsel for the Metropolitan Association, it was learned yesterday.

Three young hold-up men, trapped on the fifth floor of Stratton Hall at 342 West Eighty-fifth Street, near Riverside Drive, at 3 A.M. yesterday, dropped one by one to the window ledge of the floor below in an attempt to escape, but were caught by six detectives who had followed them from Long Island City, where they had held up a bartender and nine customers at 35-54 Steinway Avenue.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 6. -- In the opening races of the July series of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today all three classes sailed triangular courses, getting off at intervals of five minutes to a fair start with a moderate wind out of the souhwest, which increased considerably before the boats came home.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 6. -- Fire and an explosion in the bow of the $20,000 yacht Daphne, moored off Southport harbor, today ravaged the interior of the vessel and sent two men to a hospital with possibly fatal burns.

Raw steel production has fallen in the last week to a national average of not more than 12 per cant of capacity, the lowest level of which there is any record, according to the review of The Iron Age. This publication notes that the June output of pig iron, amounting to 20.935 gross tons a day, was the smallest since December. 1896.

Speaker GARNER went back to an old bad manner of his when he exclaimed in the House yesterday that if the pending relief bill were not passed in a certain form there would be "riots." On the particular point at issue between him and the President we would not be dogmatic.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6. -- A grandmother who campaigned as a vigorous foe of Governor Murray tonight had outdistanced more than a score of men opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for Oklahoma's new Representative at large.

MOSCOW, July 6 (AP). -- Joseph Stalin and Vyacheslaff Molotoff, chairman of the Council of People's Commissars, issued a joint decree today calling for mobilization of the nation's agricultural resources to insure the success of the harvest of all crops.

Charges that warehouse concerns in the United States with investments estimated at $1,000,000,000 would be threatened with ultimate failure if railroads were not prohibited from competing with them were made yesterday at a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission by representatives of the New York Warehousemen's Protective Committee at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

From a relative position of more than four hours behind the Post and Gatty record at Harbor Grace, Mattern and Griffin moved to a point 10 hours and 43 minutes ahead of the record holders when they left Berlin on their flight around the world yesterday.

LATONIA, Ky., July 6 (AP). -- Showing suddenly improved form, Octave Viau's veteran campaigner Agapanthus accounted for the Allendale Purse today at Latonia. The Dixiana Stud's Lady Dean, heavily backed favorite, finished second and M.M. Riddle's Stop Gap third.

PITTSBURGH, July 6. -- The Pirates continued their smartly stepping pennant march by sweeping today's double-header with the Giants, 4 to 2 and 3 to 1. The determined local attacks broke through in the closing innings of both games against the stubborn pitching defense offered by Bill Terry's hurlers.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange decreased $507.581.503 during June to $15.633.479.577, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The total represented a new low record since the Exchange began publishing the figures.

Evidence that the late Ivar Kreuger speculated secretly in his own securities for at least a year preceding his suicide in Paris was adduced here yesterday at one of the many hearings that have followed the collapse of his attempt to found a world-wide match monopoly.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- Lon Warneke, Cub rookie pitcher, mowed down the hard-hitting Philadelphia Nationals today to register a 6-to-1 victory in the opening game of the series. The victory advanced the Cubs to second place.

A substantial increase in retail insolvencies accounted for most of the rise in failures during last week reported by Bradstreet's yesterday. While the dwindling in large banking suspensions created a sharp decline of 40.8 per cent in total liabilities, the actual number of failures rose from 587 to 625 for the week ended June 30, of which retail failures were 419, a gain of 35.

New fabrics rate first in importance for the early Fall season, Mrs. Dessie M. Barr, Paris representative of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, said yesterday at the fashion forecast session of the buying organization attended by more than 100 store executives and buyers.

Foreclosure of mortgages on the Hippodrome, on Sixth Avenue between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, sale of the property, and the appointment of a receiver were asked yesterday in an action filed in Supreme Court by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP). -- The $4,000 Rainy Day Sweepstakes for 2-year-old trotters was won in two straight heats today by Spencer McElwyn, whose illustrious sire, Spencer, set the Grand Circuit record of 2:05 1/4 for the stake in 1927.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 6 (AP). -- The name of Senator Borah was placed before the Prohibition party's national convention here tonight as it began selection of a Presidential candidate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6. -- The five-man team, with alternates, which will be the first United States weight-lifting squad to enter in Olympic competition, was announced today by Mark H. Berry, coach of the American Olympic weight-lifting team.

Mayor CURLEY, who got into the Chicago convention by way of Puerto Rico, re-entered his home town, on the Fourth and made the holiday his own. A triumphal procession recompensed him for his disaster in the primaries. To a crowd on the Common whose numbers were estimated at from 25,000 to 100,000 his Street Commissioner introduced him as "the greatest Roman of them all."

Communism cannot prosper in Uruguay and that country's institutions and people "constitute a healthy organism in which anarchist and dis- rupting germs cannot thrive," according to Dr. Juan Carlos Blanco, Uruguayan Minister of Foreign Affairs.
OTTAWA, July 6. -- Headed by Walter Hagen, defending champion, and a field of crack American professionals, 105 players today awaited the start of the annual Canadian open golf championship tomorrow.

Among new and recorded leases that figured in mild real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday was a contract just concluded for an entire blockfront in the Chelsea section. These leases constituted the bulk of the day's trading.

A proposal that a survey be made of the need for concessions in all Brooklyn parks and that the large number of small concessions be con- solidated into a few large ones "strategically located according to this survey" was advanced yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

In the belief that the stock market has ceased to be a reliable yardstick of values, some business leaders are discussing the advisability of establishing minimum prices for securities as a means of re-establishing confidence in industry, Philip D. Wagoner, president of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company, said yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 6. -- The award of 6-inch varsity P's to seventeen members of the Princeton baseball team for 1932 wag announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- President Hoover today submitted to Congress a supplemental estimate for $100,000 to be spent in returning as many of the 14,000 "bonus marchers" encamped here as might indicate a willingness to go home. The Senate has already passed such a resolution, and the House Ways and Means Committee today reported the measure favorably.

A people "without pride in their form of government is politically dyspeptic," Major General Smedley D. Butler, United States Marine Corps, retired, told 300 members and guests of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen last night at the Mechanics' Institute, 20 West Fortyfourth Street.

BERLIN, July 6. -- After flying from Harbor Grace, Nfld., to this city without a stop, in the sensational time of 18 hours 41 minutes, James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, American round-the-world fliers, tarried here only 3 hours and 20 minutes before taking off for Moscow.

With heavy rains reported from several cotton-growing States, prices on the Cotton Exchange here rose sharply yesterday. After starting at about the previous day's closing levels, all positions advanced above 6 cents a pound and the list closed at the top, 27 to 30 points higher than on Tuesday.

TRENTON, N.J., July 6. -- Condemning the prohibition plank in his own party's national platform as a "cowardly straddle," Senator Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic County, Republican leader in the Legislature, today asserted he could see no reason, either morally or legally, why the Hobart State enforcement act should not be repealed, as proposed in a referendum to be submitted to the voters of New Jersey at the general election in November.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6. -- James R. Garfield, who was chairman of the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention, went on record today as opposed to the prohibitory features of the antitrust laws and joined, the ranks of those urging changes to meet the present needs of industry and business.
CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP). -- The parents of Libby Holman today said they knew of no reason why Smith Reynolds should have ended his own life.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 6. -- "The Ticket-of-Leave Man," a revival of Tom Taylor's melodrama, was presented tonight by the Scarborough Players in the Beechwood Theatre here, on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, as the first of a series of plays to be given this Summer.

KITTERY, Me., July 6. -- The Weetamoe. Class J sloop owned by Frederick H. Prince and sailed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, today defeated Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie by 3 minutes 3 seconds, corrected time, in the racing run of the Eastern Yacht Club to this port from Gloucester, Mass.

LAUSANNE, July 6. -- With the same obstinancy that has marked all their relations in war and peace, France and Germany stand tonight both unwilling to make the final move that will bring the Lausanne conference to a successful end.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP). -- Two hundred golfers, effectively wielding putter and mashie, interrupted their game long enough late today to rescue Joseph Myda, 45, from what was intended to be his last ride.

Ex-Governor SMITH has done the expected thing in announcing his intention to support the Democratic party and platform, but it cannot be said that he has done it in the expected terms. If he were to make any statement at all, people looked to him to do it in a mood of large generosity.

BERLIN, July 6 (AP). -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, two young Americans who were itching to girdle the globe by air faster than any one ever has, brought their red, white and blue monoplane down at Tempelhof Airdrome this afternoon after a record-breaking transatlantic crossing, and three hours and twenty minutes later they roared into the air again, en route to Moscow.

BOSTON, July 6 (AP). -- Governor Ely and Mayor Curley, leaders of the Massachusetts forces of Alfred E. Smith and Governor Roosevelt, gave their approval tonight to Smith's announcement that he would "support the Democratic party."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6. -- Urging that Herbert Hoover be re-elected President in "the interest of the prohibition cause," officers of the Flying Squadron Foundation today offered an analysis of the Republican and Democratic planks on the Eighteenth Amendment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- Jersey City kept the crippled Bisons in the throes of a losing streak today by taking the opening game of the series by a score of 9 to 4. The Buffalo string of losses was extended to five in six starts as Bill Gould was thumped hard for his first defeat of the season.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 6. -- A team from the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York, made up of Baron Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Edward Hymes, Charles Lookridge and Sam Fry Jr., was leading at the end of the first round in the contract bridge team-of-four championship of the American Whist League, which was contested here today.

What is said to be the largest book ever put into Braille, the type used in printing for the blind, is Albert J. Beveridge's "Life of John Marshal," published by Houghton Mifflin. It will require approximately 4,800 Braille pages, bound in twentyfour large volumes, four more than required for the Braille reproduction of the text of the Bible.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The market for hogs was buoyant again today here, making the twenty-eighth consecutive day on which swine have advanced in value. Prices now are $1.80 to $2.05 a hundredweight above the low levels of a little more than a month ago and are the highest since last October.

Mayor Walker, at the request of the Transit Commission, has called a conference on rapid-transit unification, to be held at City Hall tomorrow with the Board of Estimate, the Transit Commission and the Board of Transportation participating.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several weeks ago I wrote a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES calling attention to the fact that Dr. Daniel A. Poling had been quoted as having said that every family in America would have to drink twelve gallons of beer a day in order that the Federal Government might raise $1,000,000,000 a year from taxes thereon.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 6. -- Confident that he will see his prediction come true that he will live to be 100 years old, John D. Rockefeller plans to celebrate his ninety-third birthday on Friday quietly on his estate in Pocantico Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Secretary Hyde's attack on Governor Roosevelt's reforestation program drew return fire today from Ovid Butler, executive secretary of the American Forestry Association, in a letter accusing the Secretary of Agriculture of a "narrow" and "negative" attitude on the subject of forestry.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Alfred E. Smith's statement pledging support for the Democratic national ticket and declaring that the prohibition plank was a forward step by the party elicited approval generally today from Democratic Senators, who had expected such a declaration from the 1928 stnadard-bearer.

LONDON, July 6 -- (Canadian Press) -- A picture of the imperial economic conference at Ottawa as the 'most shameless thieves' kitchen the world has ever known' was conjured up by R.D. Holt, shipowner and former member of Parliament, addressing the Liberal free trade committee at luncheon today.

Admitting that he had been in this city during the five days detectives were searching for him as a violator of parole, Owen Madden, convicted slayer and reputedly one of Broadway's racketeers, surrendered late yesterday afternoon at the gates of Sing Sing prison.

Rising prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon, following an irregular market in the morning, reflected the more cheerful sentiment in Wall Street. The reports of a promising turn of events at Lausanne were largely responsible for the reversal of attitude on the part of the financial community.

A strike referendum of members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union will be taken next Tuesday at a mass meeting to be held at the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, it was announced yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the union.

GENEVA, July 6. -- Turkey was invited to join the League of Nations at a special session of the Assembly this morning that accidentally began with a gentle reminder that the country whose President founded the League was still in the narrowing circle of non-League members.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., July 6. -- The annual meeting of the Pleasant Valley bird and wild-flower sanctuary at Lenox was held in the museum this afternoon. Bishop Thomas Frederick Dayies, president of the association, in his annual report, announced an anonymous gift of six acres of land, with a house and barn, adjoining the sanctuary property on the south.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 6. -- Haskell Bohn, 20-year-old son of a manufacturer, who was kidnapped Thursday morning, was found safe tonight at Medicine Lake, seven miles from Minneapolis.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Speaker Garner, speaking on the relief question, said in part:

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- C.V. Whitney's Fall Apple, confidently ridden by Sonny Workman, won the featured Oak Park Purse at one mile by three lengths today. Dyak was second and Swift and True finished third.

President HOOVER'S request for a special appropriation to make possible the continued work of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief -- or, as it is generally known, the "Gifford Committee" -- deserves prompt response. This committee gives practical recognition to the principle which informs our social order that voluntary neighborly aid is at the foundation of all human relief.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 6. -- A man believed to Nikolai Semenoff, noted as a dancer in the Russian ballet under the Imperial regime in Moscow and later in the troupes of Fokine and Diaghileff in Europe and the United States, committed suicide early this morning by leaping into the upper rapids above the Table Rock House on the Canadian side.

LONDON, July 6. -- The stock markets were considerably less active today, most sections becoming irregular on nervousness regarding the outcome at Lausanne. Although on a smaller scale, profit taking again was in evidence, and was not unwelcome to brokers, who inclined to the view that conditions were thereby improved.

The exhibition of work by members of the Summer classes of the Art Students' League will continue through Saturday. All in all, the show runs true to form: beautiful charcoal drawings from the antique and the nude by students in the Bridgman classes; Brackmanesque oils by followers of Brackman; "free-style" painting from the studio course.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Revolutions in Latin America in the past three depression years were said to be "fundamentally a social struggle" by Dr. Samuel Guy Inman of Columbia University in a lecture today before the Conference on Hispanic American Affairs of George Washington University.

Fishing tackle manufacturers have been somewhat uncertain concerning the application of the 10 per cent Federal tax on sporting goods as applied to their industry. It was announced a short time ago that the tax would be placed on all fishing tackle equipment with the exception of lines.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Secretary Stimson maintained close contact by cable and transatlantic telephone today with Ambassador Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation to the general disarmament conference at Geneva, as plans were being completed for an adjournment of the conference for several months in order that the disarmament proposal of President Hoover might be studied in detail by experts and the governments directly.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- Rochester and Baltimore split a hard-fought twin bill today, the Red Wings winning the first, 2 to 1, and the Orioles the second, 4 to 3.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6. -- If Bennett Griffin and James Mattern kept on at the rate they were going, they would make it around the world in five days, and power to them, Wiley Post, record-holder with Harold Gatty for the round-the-world flight, said tonight.

CINCINNATI, July 6. -- No appre- ciable progress was made by the Dodgers as their Western tour opened today with a divided double-header with the Reds. Hollis Thurston had his winning streak ended at six games when he lost the opener to Owen Carroll, 6 to 4.

The Wheatley Stable's Blenheim made it four straight victories and three stakes in a row when he captured the $5,000 guaranteed Empire City Handicap, feature of the opening-day card at James Butler's hilltop course at Yonkers yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 6. -- Harris B. Fenn, who won the amateur golf championship of Maine when he was 15 years old, and his 20-year-old son, William, captured the father and son championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association by scoring 83, 84 -- 167, in the annual tournament played today over the Echo Lake Country Club course.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- A woman scorned almost took the life of Bill Jurges, star shortstop of the Chicago National Baseball Club, today.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- The Republicans established national campaign headquarters in the Palmer House today and Everett Sanders conferred on plans with the publicity diiertor, former Governor Allen of Kansas.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 6 (AP). -- Habeas corpus proceedings were begun here today seeking release on bond for George P. Courson, a prison camp captain, and Solomon Higginbotham, a guard, charged with first degree murder in the death of Arthur Maillefert, a youthful convict from Westfield, N.J.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I must regretfully agree with the recent statement of my distinguished classmate, Professor Wormser, to the effect that reform of the law cannot be left to the lawyers alone but that "lay support on a large scale is necessary."

Steel-mill activity has fallen to 18.3 per cent of estimated normal, which is beyond any reasonable doubt a new low record in the history of modern steel-making. The adjusted index of 18.3 for the week ended July 2 compares with 21.0 for the preceding week and 41.2 for the corresponding week last year.
THE Detroit Tigers are in town and in second place, but, to the best of deponent's knowledge and belief, the 12-pound shot is reposing heavily in some secret nook in a cozy apartment in Detroit.

Thousands of correspondents forgot all about that three-cent stamp innovation of the government yesterday, ignoring passage of the revenue bill by their representatives in Congress, the reiterated warnings of the Postoffice Department and the columns of newspaper space announcing the change.

Senator BORAH'S demand for arbitrary increase in the paper currency occurs under circumstances which illustrate his habitual position of political isolation. He would not consider himself bound by the plank in the Republican platform which asserts that "relief by currency infla"tion is unsound in principle and "dishonest in results."

The male population of New York and its environs has suddenly decided that white duck caps at 25 cents each are a bargain and as a result the local cap industry centred around lower Broadway is enjoying a boom unprecedented since the hatless fad gathered momentum.

The New York City track and field athletes who will leave tomorrow night for California and the final tryouts in preparation for the Olympic Games at Los Angeles, are to be honored by Mayor Walker at a City Hall reception at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, it was announced yesterday by the American Olympic Committee.

OKLAHOMA, CITY, July 6. -- Like a person sickened by some bitter experience, Bennett Griffin, my older brother, who with Jimmy Mattern is attempting a globe-circling flight, returned from the World War determined to forget he ever had flawn an airplane.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- By a vote of 34 to 32 the Senate this afternoon adopted Senator Couzens's amendment to the administration's home loan bank bill, virtually displacing its essential structure.

The First of Boston Corporation, previously the First National Old Colony Corporation, and Estabrook Co. will offer today a new issue of $600,000 city of St. Paul (Minn.) 4 1/2 per cent general improvement bonds, due on July 1, 1933 to 1962.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Militant preparations to press for a decision on legislation to bring back beer were made on both sides of the Capitol today as the House Republican wets agreed to petition for an early vote, and Senate anti-prohibitionists mapped their strategy for roll-calls on amendments tomorrow.
ALBANY, July 6. -- A conference on economy in State Government on July 19 was called today by Governor Roosevelt in letters to civic, business and farm organizations throughout the State.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP). -- Michael Semenoff was being hunted by Cleveland police early today at the request of Michael Fokine at the same hour he was believed to have gone over Niagara Falls to his death.

In the first official classification which it has made of its common stockholders, the United States Steel Corporation showed, in a statement issued yesterday, that 80,309 of its 187,409 holders of common stock own less than ten shares each. The figures cover the closing of the stockholders' books for the annual meeting in April, but they are believed to be reasonably close to the records at this time.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Due to the record outflow of $765,000,000 in short-term capital from the United States in 1931, this country's credits abroad were reduced during the year by $472,000,000, according to an analysis of America's balance of international payments for 1931 by Dr. Amos E. Taylor of the Commerce Department's finance division made public today.

ALBANY, July 6. -- Governor Roosevelt hailed today the increasing party unity marked by Governor Smith's promise of support and a statement that Jouett Shouse was expected to be back on the active firing line for the Democratic national ticket.

Requests for the establishment of a department of city housing and a loan of $25,000,000 to be obtained by the city from the Federal Government to construct housing at $8 per month per room were sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Public Housing Conference of 112 East Nineteenth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am greatly concerned that the contemplated economies of the Board of Education seem to be entirely at the expense of unemployed teachers and children. There are, I think, savings that could be made in the educational bureaucracy of New York City.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The text of President Hoover's statement on the failure of the White House conferences to agree on a workable relief bill, issued shortly before 5 o'clock this afternoon, read:

Endorsement of the Democratic platform on prohibition and of the Democratic nominee for the Presidency by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Repeal is expected today at the meeting of the executive committee of the organization at the home of Mrs. Edward S. Moore at Roslyn, L.I.

The foreign bond department was again the focus of activity and strength yesterday on the Stock Exchange. German bonds led the advance, as they have done for a week or more, but securities of half a dozen other Continental States moved up along with them.

PARIS, July 6. The tone continued firm on the Bourse today notwithstanding pessimistic reports of the negotiations at Lausanne and the disquieting French budgetary situation. Young Plan bonds advanced slightly and all the leading stocks made gains.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 6. -- Playing one of the finest rounds of her career, Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks today clipped four strokes off the record for the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course by negotiating the short but exacting layout in 75 strokes.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Shipping Board approved today an agreement for the establishment of a conference of carriers in the trade from Santos and Rio de Janeiro to New York, the member lines of which agree to maintain uniform rates, with two exceptions, on general cargo and coffee.

LONDON, July 6. -- The British Government tonight offered President de Valera his choice of any kind of arbitral tribunal he liked to settle the dispute over the payment of land annuities by the Irish Free State -- with, however, "the final, definite qualification" that its members must be citizens of the British Commonwealth of Nations.
MONTREAL, July 6 (AP). -- The Newark Bears took the opener of a four-game series from the Royals today when Meadows, Newark southpaw, outpitched three Royal hurlers, 7 -- 3.

St. CATHARINES, Ont., July 6 (Canadian Press). -- Antipodean bats rang out with vim today as the touring Australian cricketers piled up 309 runs for the loss of six wickets to defeat decisively a team composed of Ridley College players, past and present.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6. -- Two-thirds of the $134,000 estate of Lewis R. Hardenbergh, a vice president of the Carnation Milk Company, who died in New York on Dec. 15, will pass to Terry Hardenbergh of 67 Warwick Road, Bronxville, his 8year-old adopted son, according to a decision handed down here today by Surrogate George A. Slater.

The First National Old Colony Corporation, formed in December, 1929, as the security affiliate of the First National Bank of Boston, will henceforth be known as the First of Boston Corporation, with the exception of five of the New England offices, which will operate under the name the First of Boston Corporation of Massachusetts, according to a resolution adopted yesterday by the directors of the present corporation.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- Norma Talmadge, screen star preparing here for her stage debut next week, denied today a report from Nogales, Mexico, that she planned to divorce Joseph Schenck, film producer.

LONDON, July 6 (AP). -- A jury of ten men and two women found today that Mrs. Elvira Dolores Barney, 26-year-old daughter of a wealthy baronet, was not guilty of the murder of Thomas William Scott Stephen, who was shot to death in her bizarre apartment after a smart cocktail party May 31.

The sharp advance of German bond prices continued unabated yesterday, lifting prices half a point to more than 6 points with few exceptions. More than a dozen of the German loans were pushed into new high ground for the year, including the Government 7s at 67 and the 5 1/2s at 47 3/4.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 6. -- The field of nine contending crews for the Olympic eight-oared honors was completed early today with the arrival of the Harvard contingent. The Crimson oarsmen got into action soon after their arrival, working on some starts and taking a long easy paddle.

Five women swimmers from Los Angeles, the Misses Josephine McKim, Norene Forbes, Georgia Coleman, Jennie Cramer and Marjorie Lowe, arrived here early yesterday by airplane to compete in the Olympic trials, July 15 and 16. They also will take part in the special events to be held in conjunction with the international swimming meet at the Jerome Cascades pool Saturday and Sunday.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- Chinese palates, whetted by 15,000,000 bushels of Federal Farm Board wheat, may furnish American farmers with a new market larger than any they have ever had.

KANSAS CITY, July 6 (AP). -- Two suits asking damages aggregating $42,000,000 were filed today against The Kansas City Star and its executives by Henry L. Doherty personally and by the Cities Service Gas Company.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Confusion reigned today in Federal departments as to how, when and where the pay-reduction provisions of the economy act shall be applied. The law, estimated to save between $150,000,000 and $175,000,000, took effect Friday.

The money market was quiet and featureless. Tuesday's temporary flurry in Federal funds disappeared and the rate dropped to 14@ 1/2, from 1. On the Stock Exchange call loans were unchanged at 2 1/2 per cent, time money was quoted at 1 1/2 all maturities, with commercial paper and acceptances steady.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Differnces over the unemployment relief bill flared into open conflict today between President Hoover and Speaker Garner, Democratic nominee or the Vice Presidency.
NEW YORK. Countess Ferdinand ColloredoMannsfeld, who is arriving on the Bremen, will be at the Ritz Tower.
Conventions brought $70,000,000 to the city last year, according to an estimate in the annual report of the Merchants' Association's convention bureau.

"Chic" Sale, cornet soloist and litterateur, went in last night for Old Settlers in much the same manner he uses in the portrayal of Old Soldiers. The picture which loaned him a postmaster's hat instead of the blue was "Stranger in Town." During its initial showing at the Winter Garden it drew forth considerable laughter by its bumptiousness, and a bit of restlessness during the occasional periods when nothing very much was happening.

On the same day in the widely separated Rhineland and Kansas, Federal power put gags upon newspapers. The German Supreme Court, following the five-day suspension of Vorwarts in Berlin, banned for three days the publication of the Kolnische Volkszeitung.

Though the process is obscured by the millions of transactions entering into the account, nations, like governments and private corporations, balance their books with a profit or a loss. The nearest approach we have to an audit of our national ledger is the annual report on the balance of international payments of the United States.

The establishment of vocational schools throughout the country at which farmers with a high school education could be trained as intelligent leaders in the agricultural field would do much to remedy the present agricultural crisis, Dr. James E. Russell, dean emeritus of Teachers College, declared yesterday afternoon at the conference on secondary education in the Horace Mann Auditorium of Teachers College.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 6. -- Ten crews from the United States and Canada were entered as the second annual Prince of Wales junior international sailing series started at the Lakeside Yacht Club on Lake Milo today. Crews were present from seven United States clubs and three Canadian clubs.
Three purchases by New Yorkers were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The inexorable power of economics over war hatreds and nationalistic ambitions has never been exhibited more strongly than in the shifting status of reparations during the thirteen years between the Treaty of Versailles and the international conference now under way at Lausanne.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Cobb of 140 West Fifty-eighth Street, June 25 at the Alice Fuller LeRoy Sanitarium. Mrs. Cobb is the former Miss Ida Bostleman of this city. The child will be named Joan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6. -- An intermittent rainfall failed to mar the seventh annual father and son golf tourney of the Westchester Golf Association today. Robert Elmer Baker, teamed with his 17-year-old son, Robert Alien, led a field of thirty pairs to capture the championship and low gross honors with an 80 at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

BOSTON, July 6. -- Adolph B. Benesch of New York came to Boston today under a writ of protection against civil suits to be arraigned for conspiracy to make bucketshop contracts, "bucketing" stock orders, conspiracy to steal and Jarceny in 102 counts.

GENEVA, July 6. -- Negotiations over the declaration with which to adjourn the first phase of the disarmament conference began today with the United States among those working to prevent the vacation being for an indefinite period. The Americans want a definite date fixed for the next session to begin, preferably in the middle of November.
