An exhibition of water-colors priced at less than $50 has been arranged by the Midtown Gallery. While a water-color at $50 may not be the prodigious bargain it must surely have seemed a couple of years ago, when prices were up, this is an extremely modest fee for a work of art.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 (AP). -- The Federal District Government today forbade the exhibition of the American motion picture film "The Broken Wing," featuring Lupe Velez, Mexican actress, and voted to censure Senorita Velez for allowing herself to be featured in the picture.

Payment of city bills about two months after services have been rendered is the normal procedure, according to I. James Brody, secretary of the Department of Public Welfare, who denied yesterday that the city was many months behind in payments to grocers for food checks issued to needy families by the Home Relief Bureau.

BOSTON, July 6. -- The Boston Elevated Railway has instituted operating economies which will save $1,660,000 during the trustee year begun July 1. without including permanent discharges of employes or abandonment of service or lines, according to a statement issued today by Edward Dana, general manager.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who had maintained silence as to his political intentions since the Democratic National Convention, broke it yesterday by issuing a statement that he would support the Democratic party at the November election.

DUBLIN, July 6. -- President de Valera assured the Dail Eireann to- day that neither to his knowledge nor his government's were any arms being landed in the Irish Free State or crossing the Northern Ireland frontier.

CLEVELAND, July 7. -- The team of the "Four Horsemen" won the contract team-of-four event, the third contest of the American Whist League Congress, late last night. This league has never had a contract team event before, therefore, there was no defending championship team.
Apartment house and taxpayer deals comprised a large part of the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The action of the grain markets was a great disappointment today to those who had expected a continuation of yesterday's upward movement in prices. Liverpool failed to follow the advance, and this led to selling on the Board of Trade here and a decline in prices followed a bulge and a late recession.
LIMA, Peru, July 7. -- An Aprista-Communistic rising in Trujillo, the third city of the republic, was reported in the official bulletin this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A depressed gentleman stopped me in the subway. He said: "I am one of Wall Street's 17,000 dropped assistant secretaries. I have nervous prostration. Do you think I shall ever get well?"

To the Editor of The New York Times: Richard Kolb is unjust in criticizing the city teachers in his letter to THE TIMES, and it is very evident he is not familiar with the work they are doing besides teaching.

Men still make mysterious trips across the sea, converse in low tones with others over the cabalistic technique of safe-cracking and crawl down musty palace cellars to tamper with dust-covered strong boxes.
LONDON, July 7. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said today that June 30 probably would go down in history as the beginning of the end of the world crisis.

A plea for emergency remedial measures which would check the dumping of foreign steel in this country has been submitted to members of Congress by the National Association of Flat Rolled Steel Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP). -- The Washington Senators slipped down into the second division today by dropping two games of a doubleheader to the Cleveland Indians by one-run margins. The scores were 3 to 2 and 4 to 3. The Indians took fourth place, while the Senators dropped to fifth.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 7. -- By pulling back the tee markers a bit, the powers that have authority over such things at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today put a stop to all the record-breaking business that went on in the opening round of the first annual Long Island Women's Golf Association closed championship.

The upward trend in sugar prices continued yesterday, all three classes of the commodity -- raws, refined and futures -- reaching new high ground for the movement and close to the highs for the year. These advances took place following a day of profittaking which left the market in a buoyant condition.

Heroin valued at $25,000 was found in baggage brought to New York on the Cosmopolitan freighter Vincent, it was disclosed yesterday when customs agents brought the narcotics to the United States Barge Office and filed an official report with Thomas W. Whittle, surveyor of customs.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The advance in prices of hogs was halted today, ending, a twenty-eight-day upturn, the longest rise in recent years. Some grades fell back 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight, but reports from the wholesale trade were encouraging and the larger packers bought aggressively when weakness appeared.

The Republic of Turkey enters the League of Nations as fifty-sixth member by invitation. The virtual pledge to accept it was given in the Treaty of Lausanne, by which she agreed to follow the direction of the Council of the League in repairing any infractions of the treaty.

Plans for opening the Republican campaign in the East and for the establishment of headquarters of the national committee in New York City will be discussed today when Everett Sanders, the new national chairman, and J.R. Nutt, treasurer of the national committee, arrive for conferences with the local Republican leaders.
"Stay home, young woman," was the plea made yesterday over the National Broadcasting network by Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement and of the Visiting Nurses Service.

Representatives of commercial warehouses declined yesterday at a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, to consider a proposal to put railroad storage rates on a parity with commercial rates as a solution of allegedly unfair competition by the carriers with the cold storage industry.

Robert F. Mahoney, a new York lawyer and president of the New York State board of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic, sailed yesterday afternoon on the North German Lloyd liner Dresden for Ireland. He booked passage on the liner after receeiving an urgent cablegram from President de Valera, asking him to come to Ireland at once.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 7. -- Officials at Sing Sing said this afternoon, that Owney Madden had with him a physician's prescription for a stomach disorder, and that his health appeared to be none too good. Two years ago, Madden was operated on for an old gunshot wound at the Ossining Hospital here.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 7. -- J.P. Morgan has been hobbling on crutches about his estate at Matinecock Point, East Island, for the past few days following an injury to his ankle suffered during the Independence Day week-end.

Campaign headquarters were opened yesterday in the Biltmore for Colonel William J. Donovan, wartime commander of the 165th Infantry, the old Sixty-ninth, and former Assistant Attorney General of the United States, whose friends are backing him for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- William G. McAdoo, candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Senate from California, today approved Speaker Garner's unemployment relief position and his speech yesterday defending the Democratic program.

Refusal of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union yesterday to agree to change the system of payment of cloak workers from the week work to payment by the piece resulted in the breaking off of negotiations for a new agreement between the union and the American Cloak and Suit Manufacturers Association, the contractors' organization.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 7 (AP). -- Convicts told Judge George Couper Gibbs today of floggings and "sweat boxes" as he investigated the death of Arthur Maillefert, 19-year-old New Jersey youth, in a prison camp.

After a fruitless forty-eight-hour search of the Atlantic for the missing yacht Curlew, the naval airship Akron was back at her hangar at Lakehurst, N.J., last night. Commander A.H. Dresel reported that nothing had been seen of the missing craft, which left Montauk Point on June 25 with six men to compete in the sailing race to Bermuda.

WINDSOR, Conn., July 7. -- Harry Brusie triumphed at Sage Park today with the 3-year-old Calumet Calling, which led a field of pacers. Among the defeated horses was Turney English, heretofore unbeaten on the Bay State Circuit and naturally the favorite.

Alfred Damon Runyon, newspaper man and maagazine writer, of 224 West Forty-ninth Street, and Miss Patrice Amati Del Grande, an actress of the same address, were married by Mayor James J. Walker yesterday afternoon at the home of Ed Frayne, sports editor of The New York American, at 200 West Sixteenth Street.

PARIS, July 7. -- An unexpected wave of selling today weakened the stock market and sent prices tumbling on the Bourse. Most of the gains made earlier in the week were lost. Apparently the optimism that had prevailed regarding the outcome of the Lausanne conference has disappeared.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 7 (AP). -- Proving there is plenty in a name, Will Rogers, rural schoolmaster, perched at the top of the ticket for the Democratic nomination as Congressman at Large tonight, put there by a rush of late-counted ballots.
LONDON, July 7. -- Following is the full text of the declaration of British disarmament policy as read in the House of Commons today by Stanley Baldwin:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 7. -- Seventeen-year-old Willie Turnesa, youngest of golfdom's Turnesa brothers, competing for the first time in the Westchester County junior golf championship tourney, today captured the qualifying medal and then gained the semi-final round at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The issuance today of figures by the Department of Commerce showing that American exports to Great Britain had increased during May by $2,000,000 over those of April, reaching a total of $23,120,611, coincided with reports of a lessening of the "Buy British" campaign.

Fourteen educational, religious and charitable institutions will receive the income from trust funds totaling $40,000 under the will of Benjamin Altschul, who died May 27, last, it was disclosed yesterday when the testament was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- False representations by merchants that price increases are attributable to the new manufacturers' excise taxes are violations of the law, punishable by maximum fines of $1,000 and imprisonment for one year, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

With Civic Virtue, the unhappy warrior, apparently doomed to banishment from his commanding place in City Hall Park, Coney Island and Queens both put in bids for him yesterday and promised him a happy home for the rest of his days.

The editors of fifteen of the twenty-two publications against which the Citizens' Committee on Civic Decency, headed by Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney, began a campaign last Winter on the ground that they were objectionable in the meaning of Section 1,141 of the penal law, agreed yesterday to stop publication, while the other seven consented to "tone down" their articles and caricatures.

Declaring that despotism exists in Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union of Greater New York, three members of the union filed yesterday in Supreme Court an order requiring union officers to show cause on Monday why Sam Kaplan, president, should not be restrained from conducting the union's business, and why the officers should not be restrained from using union funds for advertising and for counsel fees.
Real estate and civic organizations will be allowed to take an active part in forming the 1933 budget, Mayor Walker announced at City Hall yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt in his speech at Chicago made a perfectly concrete and sensible suggestion anent employing the unemployed on reforestation areas. This contemplated working-over of logged-off lands, the clearing of brush acreage, sapling planting, and so forth, would not only insure lumber of varieties already extinct in this country, but might well be extended to plantations of nut and fruit orchards on the public domains.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 7. -- The scarcity of facts on the sinking of the submarine Promethee makes me hesitate at this point to give a definite opinion as to the cause of the accident or the possibility of the crew being saved.

Quotations for Over-the-Counter Securities are unofficial. Those included in these tables are obtained from many brokers and dealers. The source which supplied any quotations in this list will be given upon request.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The British disarmament proposals announced in the House of Commons today were welcomed here as in line with the spirit of President Hoover's proposal of June 22 to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva for a reduction of almost one-third in the land, air and naval forces of the world.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP). -- On the historic Plaza, Louis Byrens, philanthropist, today opened his "slave market" to relieve unemployment.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP). -- Two home runs gave today's contest to Boston, the Braves winning, 5 to 4, although outhit by St. Louis. Hargrave's circuit clout in the second inning drove in a run ahead of him and in the eighth, with his team behind, Shires's homer came with two on bases.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP). -- Pat Malone stooped the slugging Phillies with five singles today and the Chicago Cubs won their second straight game of the series, 7 to 0, to pick up a full game on the Pittsburgh Pirates, leaders of the National League.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP). -- Leading from start to finish, Timorous led home a band of good 2-year-old fillies in the $2,500 added Geneva Claiming Stakes, five and one-half furlong feature of the Arlington Park program today.

Strength in sugar market featured trading in commodities yesterday. Refined was marked up 10 points to 4 cents, the futures market rose 2 to 4 points, with a sale of spot raw at 3.05 cents. In provisions, mess pork reached a new high at 19 1/4 cents. Hides, rubber and cocoa were others to show improvement. The grains, cotton, coffee and silk were lower.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Carley bill, authorizing the purchase by the government of the building housing the Grand Central Postoffice at 452 Lexington Avenue, New York City, was before President Hoover today for his signature.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 8 (AP). -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, the American round-the-world fliers who started out so bravely by crossing the Atlantic in record time, were unreported and nearly twenty-four hours overdue here this morning. They had disappeared as completely as if their red, white and blue monoplane had gone Bailing off into space.

MONTREAL, July 7 (Canadian Press) . -- The Associated Lake Freighters, Ltd., is to be established and incorporated by all the Canadian steamship companies on the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River. An agreement of that affect has been signed here, following a series of meetings.

PITTSBURGH, July 7. -- Scarcely had the Giants crashed through the Pirate bulwarks in a late-inning drive to gain a 4-to-3 victory in the first game of today's scheduled double-header when a thunderstorm broke over Forbes Field and raged with such fury for half an hour that hostilities were called off for the day, leaving Bill Terry's band in possession of all the honors.

MONTREAL, July 7 (AP). -- Newark made it two straight over the Royals today, beating a former team-mate, Bill McAfee, 6 te 3. Three doubles by Saltzgaver featured the eleven-hit Newark attack. Shiver hit a homer with one on in the sixth for Montreal.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the exhibition of etchings and paintings by Southampton artists, which wad opened this afternoon with a reception and tea at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.

Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch of Scarsdale, member of the Sears Cup team and runner-up for the metropolitan title, joined Baroness Maud Levi in the semi-finals of the women's New York State clay court championship singles yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 7. -- Finland today became the first Baltic State to conclude a definite nonaggression pact with Soviet Russia when President Svinhufvud signed the treaty with an appended arbitration treaty, which Parliament had sanctioned in April.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President Hoover's request for an appropriation of $100,000 to pay railroad fare home for the several thousand "bonus marchers" encamped here met with quick response in the House today, when, without a dissenting vote, a resolution appropriating the money was passed.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7. -- Indica- tions late this afternoon were that the handsome exhibit of fuchias and lilies in a garden display presented by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Curtiss James at the annual flower show of the Newport Garden Association and the Horticultural Society that closed this evening would receive the prize offered by Mrs. T. Shaw Safe for the most popular entry.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 7. -- Mrs. Nadine Ruth Gilmore, daughter of Tom Mix, cowboy actor, has obtained an annulment of her marriage to Douglas Gilmore, another Hollywood actor, in Sullivan County, it was learend today through papers filed in the County Clerk's office at Monticello.

CHERBOURG, France, July 7. -- While her commander was on deck beside the conning tower the new French submarine Promethee suddenly sank just outside Cherbourg harbor this afternoon, carrying sixty-three men down with her to the bottom of the sea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is still a distinct possibility that before the Senate adjourns it will be called upon to vote on the Dies bill, which allows the ejection of aliens from the United States if they can be implicated as advocates of communism or communistic ideas.

Fresh liquidation, for which Wall Street found it difficult to account in the light of the day's various developments, produced a further moderate reaction on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon. The pressure was directed particularly against a few specialties.
LONDON, July 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
LONDON, July 7 -- The British Government announced to the world today what steps it was willing to take in the direction of reduction of world armaments by one-third as proposed by President Hoover.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- With the aid of thirty-five Republican votes, House Democrats today forced the adoption of the conference report on the highly controversial Wagner-Garner unemployment relief bill, which the President has indicated that he will veto.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- A public works program coordinated in accordance with the suggestions of President Hoover "would undoubtedly prove to be a stimulating effect upon all business," Charles F. Abbott of New York, executive director of the American Institute of Steel Construction, told the President today.
ROME, July 7 (AP). -- The Most Rev. Bernard J. Mahoney of Sioux Falls, S.D., had a twenty-minute audience with Premier Mussolini today, the first American Bishop to be received by II Duce.

BERLIN, Friday, July 8. -- Up to last midnight no word had been received here of Bennett Griffin and James Mattern, American fliers, who were due in Moscow early yesterday morning. A Polish landing field near the Lithuanian border reported that an unidentified plane passed there at 11:40 o'clock Wednesday night, and from Minsk, White Russia, came word of a plane sighted at dawn yesterday and heading East.

NEW HAVEN, July 7. -- "The New Year Shooter," a painting by George Luks, has been presented to the Yale Art School by the National Academy of Design. This is the third canvas by Mr. Luks to be included in the Yale gallery.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 7 (AP). -- Twenty-nine aspirants for places on the American Olympic wrestling team were eliminated tonight in the first and second rounds of the Olympic finals. The matches will continue tomorrow and Saturday when seven first-place men and a like number of alternates will be selected.

THe vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie made public last night correspondence revealing that the Rev. Dr. William N. Guthrie, rector, is standing with the vestry in its request on June 27 to Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, to remove the body-and-soul clinic installed in the church at Dr. Guthrie's invitation ten years ago to treat mental disorders under the auspices of religion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not know why the institutions which have made loans on real estate cannot see the advisability of reducing the interest-rate and waiving amortization on properties where incomes have been very greatly reduced.

The theory of Dr. Robert A. Millikan that the cosmic rays are "the birth cries of newly born atoms is interstellar space" and that they furnish "some experimental evidence that the Creator is still on the job's is given a setback by Dr. Arthur H. Compton, fellow Nobel Prize winner in physics with Dr. Millikan in the forthcoming number of The Physical Review, it was revealed here yesterday by the American Institute of Physics.

LONDON, July 7 (Canadian Press). -- Sussex defeated Glamorgan by an innings and 66 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluded today at Hove, the Sussex bowlers playing-havoc with the Glamorgan wickets. Nottinghamshire defeated Worcestershire at Worcester by nine wickets.

ROCKPORT, Mass., July 7. -- The America's Cup yacht Weetamoe today evened her score for the season's racing with Vanitic, veteran of cup competition, by defeating the older boat by 6 minutes and 37 seconds on corrected time on the third run of the Eastern Yacht Club cruise, a thrash from Kittery, Me., here, a distance of 22% miles.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 7. -- Albert H. Hake, 22 years old, son of a wealthy resident here, was accidentally shot and killed tonight by his older brother, William, 24. The tragedy occurred in their home at 18 Forrest Lane as the two youths were preparing to attend a party.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The purchase of government securities in the open market by the Federal Reserve Banks was virtually halted in the week ended yesterday, the holdings being increased only $94,000, according to the Reserve Board's condition statement issued today.

Bayonne, N.J. A new issue of $1,016,000 city of Bayonne (N.J.) 6 per cent school and improvement bonds, date May 1, 932, and due serially from 1934 to 1962, will be placed on the market today by Adams Mueller of Newark.

Samuel Scabury, counsel for the Hofstadter legislative investigating committee, will return to his law practice this Fall, it was disclosed last night, and his first private undertaking since September, 1930, will be as counsel for the General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders.

PARIS, July 7. -- France has no direct interest in how much money Germany agrees to pay, Leon Blum, Socialist leader, said today, since whatever it is two-thirds will be passed on to the United States, while what little France would collect of the rest would be too insignificant to bother about.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP). -- The Athletics and White Sox started their marathon of three doubleheaders in three successive days by dividing honors today. The White Sox won the first game, 13 to 3, and the Mackmen the second, 9 to 3.

For what is believed to be the first time on record, two of the three groups into which the Class I railroads are divided operated at a loss in May, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics. Both the Western and Southern groups had operating deficits in May, while the net operating income of the Eastern lines dropped 47 per cent to $13,003,000, the low record for any month.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP). -- John B. Elliott, a political associate of William Gibbs McAdoo, said today that from Mr. McAdoo, in Washington, a telegram had been received that read as follows:

President HOOVER states that it has been "possible to reach a fair adjustment" with the House and Senate leaders regarding the proposed public works program in the Federal relief bill. But he vigorously objects to the proposal, now incorporated, authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to "make loans to any individual, any "private corporation, any partner"ship, any State or any municipal"ity."
NEW YORK. Pierre Cartier will give a luncheon for Pierre Lyautey of Paris, next Thursday at the Metropolitan Club.

CHERBOURG, July 7 (AP). -- Efforts to locate and salvage the sunken submarine Promethee with its impris- oned occupants were begun immediately but were impeded by violent currents. Search for the sunken craft by naval planes was handicapped by bad flying conditions, which made their job dangerous.

Judge Donnellan in General Sessions imposed yesterday sentences of from fifteen to thirty months each in Sing Sing on AI, Frank and William Silinsky, brothers, who were convicted two weeks ago of defrauding a West Thirty-second Street speakeasy owner of about $475 in a bogus stock transaction.

Etienne De Hedry, Hungarian Minister to Belgium, is among the passengers on the Cunard liner Mauretania, due today. The ship is also bringing the Finnish Olympic team of fifteen track men, including Paavo Nurmi. The Polish runner Janusz Kusocinski is another passenger.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 7 (AP). -- All of the favorites in both the men's and women's divisions came through the quarter-finals of the Southern tennis tournament singles today in strictly regulation fashion.

Senator BORAH was amiably or ironically polite in advising the national convention of the Prohibition party at Indianapolis not to nominate him for President. To tell the truth, so small a party could not hope to be led by so great a man. The National Prohibition party, founded in 1869, has been casting a handful of votes in Presidential elections ever since 1872.

Is the Iowa hog leading us out of the sandy fields of depression back to the acorn-strewn plains of prosperity? According to dispatches from Chicago, the meat-packing industry is inclined to believe that this is so. Ever since the peak of the hog crop receded at the end of May the prices of pigs and cattle have risen in more than a seasonal curve.

THE eight-oared shell that wins on Lake Quinsigamond will probably be pulling down the Olympic stretch in company with the Leander crew that is coming over from England. The Leander crew is the Cambridge crew that outrowed Oxford on the Thames this Spring. This will be the first time in rowing history that an English university crew came over to this country all in one piece.

James Butler, owner of the Empire City track, won the race yesterday which had the place of honor on the Hilltop card. His Thoughts, a daughter of Sting from Wistful, was first in the fourth race, which was at a mile and seventy yards. It was Mr. Butter's first victory of the meeting.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7. -- President Carlos Ibanez, who flew back from his Chilean exile yesterday, denied rumors today that he intends to take over the government.

Entered for the New York Athletic Club's annual sail and motorboat races to Block Island, which will start tomorrow, are sixteen sailing and five motor craft. The getaway will be off Execution light at noon. The motor craft should reach Block Island tomorrow night, and the canvassed ones on Sunday.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 7. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the Democratic nominee for 'President, in an address today at the Chautauqua Institution, criticized overcentralization of big business as a factor in the economic depression and asserted that one of the lessons learned was realization of the interdependence of agriculture and urban industry and trade in this country and of all nations in world commerce.

The first unit in the acquisition of hunting and fishing grounds for the public in New Jersey has been obtained. In making the announcement the New Jersey State Fish and Game Commission declared that the sector of 138 acres selected in Sussex County will be suitable for the angler, as it contains a mile of the Flatbrook stream, and that the land is also "particularly suited for rabbit, partridge and woodcock hunting."

ALBANY, July 7. -- Replying today to Secretary Hyde's criticism of Governor Roosevelt's program linking unemployment relief to reforestation, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner, invited Mr. Hyde to come here to get information on the subject.

LONDON, July 7. -- The stock markets opened firm today, with fairly heavy buying, but the activity quickly decreased and an easier tendency developed. British Government funds however, were in demand and rises were general.

OTTAWA, July 7. -- Lighthorse Harry Cooper of Chicago toured the 6,770yard layout of the Ottawa Hunt and Golf Club in 69 strokes today to gain a one-stroke lead on his rivals in the opening round of the Canadian open golf championship.

A foreign central bank, believed to be the Bank of England, earmarked yesterday $5,250,400 of gold at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, with the result that the daily gold statement showed a loss for the first time in several weeks. There were no exports or imports of gold here, but $875,000 was received at San Francisco from China, reducing the day's net loss to $4,375,400.

ALBANY, July 7. -- Hailed by more than 15,000 supporters of the powerful Democratic organization of Albany in an "official welcome" to the Presidential nominee, Governor Roossvelt tonight predicted success for the party's national ticket and linked its program to restoration of economic justice over the country.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 7. -- Richard Murphy of Utica, N.Y., defeated Fritz Mercur of Williamsport, Pa., 6-3, 6-3, 6-1 to furnish the first major upset of the Rhode Island turf court singles championship at the Agawam Hunt today as play in this division reached the semi-finals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have heard many political speeches, but the acceptance speech that Governor Roosevelt made last Saturday will be remembered long after the drums of the campaign have died down. I was never so thrilled by anything in my life as I was by that speech.

Strikingly attired in red flannel coats and white trousers, twenty-five members of the Hungarian Olympic parly -- seventeen swimmers and water polo players, five modern pentation stars and three officials -- arrived in New York yesterday on the S.S. Bremen.
ALBANY, July 7. -- Governor Roosevelt heard pleas for clemency today for six men who are in the death house at Sing Sing.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,377,000,000, an increase of $23,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,407,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

With steel operations for the country at large averaging 15.96 per cent of capacity, the production of ingots in June aggregated 897,275 tons, the lowest total for any month of which there is a comparable record. As compared with the previous month, June showed a decrease of 208,755 tons, while the drop from June, 1931, amounted to 1,230,487 tons.

The renewal rate for call money, which had been "pegged" at 2 1/2 per cent at the money desk of the Stock Exchange for six months, was reduced yesterday to 2 per cent, terminating the longest stretch of unchanged call money quotations on record.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7. -- Discussions of proposed amendments to the anti-trust laws, our relations with Latin America, and the country church and the rural ministry were continued at the University of Virginia today, while the two-day conference on regulation of women's work by law was concluded.

LATONIA, Ky., July 7 (AP). -- The colors of Charles T. Fisher, who races under the nom de course of Dixiana, were conspicuous today when In High and Pre War, coupled in the betting, finished in one-two order in the Locust Corner Purse, feature offering.

WINSTON SALEM, N.C., July 7. -- R.E. Lasater, vice president of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and one of the guardians of Zachary Smith Reynolds, 20, who was found fatally shot yesterday, said tonight that all evidence pointed to the fact that young Reynolds committed suicide.

Aside from the profit taking which forced German bonds down slightly during the last hour of trading, the bond market on the Stock Exchange generally continued its advance yesterday, with some notable gains scored in the foreign list. Utility issues showed the best average strength among domestic corporation bonds, and United States Government bonds finished 1-32 to 15-32 point higher, with the exception of the first Liberty 4 1/4s, which eased 1-32 point.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- A statement that President Hoover had favored features of the relief bill passed by Congress today which he now opposes was made by Senator Thomas J. Walsh tonight as he left Chicago for his home in Montana. He was permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention last week.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 7. -- The Columbia graduates and California, the Penn Athletic Club and Yale, will meet tomorrow in that order to decide the finalists for Saturday's race which will determine America's eight-oared crew for the Olympic Games.

The grand jury will hear the case against Bernard G. Guerney, author, publisher and bookseller, charged with criminal libel by John S. Sumner, secretary of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, who believes a cartoon and poem in the first issue of the magazine called "Jack Ketch, the Hangman," of which Guerney is "chief executioner," alludes to him and to his predecessor, Anthony Comstock.

The national executive committee of the Women's Organization for national Prohibition Reform voted yesterday to support Governor Roosevelt for President. The organization which is headed by Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, a Republican, now numbers more than a million members and has divisions in forty-two States.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 7. -- After graduating from a New York evening high school last month with highest honors, Frank Houston, 27 years old, of 1,368 Sixth Avenue, New York, who says he is descended from General Samuel Houston, embarked upon a career of crime to earn money for college, according to a confession Acting Police Chief James E. Burnett asserts Houston made to him.

While rains have continued this week over a large portion of the South, they were not so heavy as those of last week, and with predictions yesterday of fair weather in six States, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back $1 a bale at the low prices of the day.

Still in the Field. Students of political rivalries will be interested to note that ALFRED E. SMITH'S Field, campaign manager during the California Presidential primaries, P.M. ABBOTT, remains a candidate for the Democratic Senatorial nomination against WILLIAM G. McADoo.
Details of recent leasehold deals were shown in contracts recorded at the Register's Office yesterday. These comprised almost all of yesterday's realty activity in Manhattan.

Two young hold-up men from Raleigh, N.C., held up the National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street last night, herded two of the members and several employes into a grill room in the rear and fled with $196 from the cash drawer.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The intensified continuance of the Polish boycott against Danzig, propagated especially by the League of Western Marches, has prompted the government of Danzig to address a new note to Dr. Papee, Poland's diplomatic representative there, emphatically protesting against what is characterized as disloyal conduct on the Polish side and demanding the prompt initiation of measures to stop the agitation.

Harold Gatty, round-the-world flier with Wiley Post in 1931, returned from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday expressing concern over the lack of word from James Mattern and Bennett Griffin.

The Detroit Tigers, who have been doing a number of very remarkable things in the American League the past few weeks, brought their pennant pretensions to the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yankees opened their second home stand of the year against the West and gave a gathering of 10,000 another surprising jolt.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Republican party will stand squarely on its prohibition plank and will not attempt to make that plank appear wetter than it is, James R. Garfield indicated today after a conference with President Hoover. Mr. Garfield, who was chairman of the resolutions committee at the national convention, also intimated that there would be no "effort by party leaders to commit the party to modification of the Volstead act.

RYE, N.Y., July 7. -- Record performances by Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women's Swimming Association of New York and Miss Katherine Rawls of Miami Beach, Fla., featured the second evening of aquatic sports in the 50-yard pool at Playland tonight.

The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., issued yesterday its report for 1931 and a report covering the twelve months ended on March 31, in which reference is made to contracts made in April giving the company the right to extend to Oct. 26, 1933, the maturity date of its $50,000,000 bank loans originally due on Oct. 26, this year.

Retail cleaners and dyers notified the Joint Board of Retail Cleaners and Dyers at 55 West Forty-second Street yesterday that they would resist efforts of the Metropolitan Association of Cleaners and Dyers to compel them to join the "company unions" fostered by the Metropolitan, an organization of wholesalers.

The order of the Wisconsin Public Service Commission calling for a 12 1/2 per cent reduction in local telephone rates is certain to attract wide attention. Utilities are a shining mark, especially during political campaigns. Governor ROOSEVELT has more than once leveled shafts at them.

GENEVA, July 7. -- In the midst of a meeting of the disarmament conference's general commission here today called expressly to hear views on the Hoover arms reduction plan of only those secondary States that had not yet had a chance to give them, Sir John Simon, with his inseparable colleague, Sir Herbert Samuel, left the room.

The bond market, especially foreign securities, continued to command the greater interest yesterday. In the foreign list, German Republic bonds reacted 1 1/2 to 3 1/2 points. Apparently, this reflected speculative profit-taking; for other external bonds on Germany advanced, and a rise of 12 or 15 points in a week would naturally invite pressure of realizing.

Universal official praise of Mr. HOOVER'S proposals for cutting down armaments continues, but also universal official explanation that they cannot be adopted. The Japanese Government has set forth at Geneva its objections. Yesterday the British Government, after consulting with the Dominions, made its position clear.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A salesman who has listened to the heartbreaking stories of more than 500 pharmacists cannot help commenting on THE TIMES editorial "The Evolution of a Drug Store." I can still hear their voices ringing in my ears: "When will they take the restaurant out of the drug store?"

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President Hoover issued an executive order today setting the rates for subsistence allowance of army, navy, marine and Coast Guard officers and Geodetic Survey and Public Health Service officials at 52 cents a ration and the rental allowance for one room at $18 a month during the present fiscal year.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The Boerse to- day reflected the suspense at Lausanne with a sharp recession in the volume of trading and rapid fluctuations in prices. The general list of stocks, however, showed considerable resistance and the losses were limited to 1 to 2 per cent.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in a formal announcement endorsed yesterday the plan for increased use of trade acceptances that Irenee du Pont, vice chairman of the company, was active in sponsoring and that recently received the approval of the Young committee of bankers and industrialists.

KANSAS CITY, July 7 (AP). -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, told the Kansas City Branch of the Federation of American Business today that "the Reds on Capitol Hill" were speeding American civilization to an inevitable end.
BOSTON, July 7 (AP). -- The Browns whacked out seventeen hits in their game today with the Red Sox to win 8 to 2.

PARIS, July 7. -- A paper read by Mine. Marie Curie on the progress made recently in the study of the electron through observing the rays of radioactive substances was the high spot of today's session of the International Electrical Congress. It had been hoped Mme. Curie would discuss her reported discovery of a new radioactive material.

The Board of Superintendents of the Board of Education has approved the proposal of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens to utilize part of Raymond M. O'Connor Park in Bayside, Queens, as a site for the new Bayside High School, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president, of the Board of Education.

Edward N. Brown, chairman of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, together with the readjustment managers and security committees, issued yesterday a call for deposits of bonds under the recapitalization plan announced last week. The notice said prompt and practically unanimous assent to the plan was essential to avoid a receivership for the railroad.

The Repeal Ball, the first event sponsored by society as a demonstration in favor of the repeal movement, was given at the Hotel Roosevelt last night under the auspices of the Blue Cockade, a national anti-prohibition organization.
Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt's campaign for the Presidency will be at sea next week.
LAUSANNE, Friday, July 8. -- New hopes that a reparations agreement can be reached here were raised as a result of long and earnest conversations that continued until early this morning.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 7. -- The Greentree quartet was eliminated from the Meadow Brook Club Cups tournament, which it won last year, when it bowed to the United States Army polo team, 18 to 10, on Whitley Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (AP). -- Former Representative William D. Upshaw of Georgia, a stalwart dry, was nominated today for the Presidency by the Prohibition party, and he quickly pledged himself to withdraw if Senator Borah of Idaho or some other outstanding figure should agree to lead a third party dry campaign.

In furtherance of a general move by all the railroads to eliminate practices which are said to be undermining the revenues of the industry, a committee of Eastern railroad officials has been appointed to consider the problem of competitive rate-cutting, it was disclosed yesterday.

Fascist comrades answered roll-call for Salvatore Arena yesterday as the body of the victim of Monday's rioting on Staten Island was carried down the steps of the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, and raised the Fascist battle cry "A Noi" as the coffin was lifted into the hearse.

Martin T. Manton, presiding judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, publicly Joined sides yesterday with New York attorneys who recently expressed dissatisfaction with the current practice in Federal court of appointing the Irving Trust Company receiver in all bankruptcy cases -- posts which, prior to the bankruptcy scandal of 1929 had been reserved for lawyers.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 7. -- Ray Knowles, captain-elect of the golf team at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, won the medal in the New Jersey junior golf championship at the Echo Lake Country Club today, his card of 77 leading thirty-five starters over the 6,800-yard-course.

A Better showing in bank clearings for the last week is reported by R. G. Dun Co. The aggregate for twenty-two cities of the country is put at $4,624,527,000, a decline of 89.0 per cent from the corresponding period last year, whereas the decrease the week before from the like pariod of 1931 was 56.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Challenges for immediate modification of the prohibition laws were flung back and forth across the Senate chamber today as Democrats and Republicans engaged in a debate on the Bingham 3.2 per cent beer amendment to the home loan bank bill.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7. -- New York City will receive $6,900,000, the bulk of the $10,360,970.65 personal income tax money this year, it was announced today at the State Department of Taxation and Finance, of which Thomas M. Lynch is commissioner.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 7. -- A proposal to merge the Corrigan-McKinney Steel Company of Cleveland and the Newton Steel Company of Newton Falls, Ohio, and Monroe, Mich., was announced here today.
PARIS, July 7 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

OGDENSBURG, N. T., July 7.Mrs. Rhoda Fox Graves of Gouverneur, only woman member of the Assembly, announced her candidacy today for the Republican nomination for State Senator from the Thirtyfourth District in opposition to Senator Warren T. Thayer of Chateaugay, and declared she would stand firmly behind President Hoover and the Republican national platform.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As to your remarks in Topics of the Times of today on the proposal to put a new high school in the Raymond O'Connor Park in Bayside. Such an action is sure to be vicious and a dangerous precedent for other mistakes of the same kind.

On the eve of his ninety-third birthday, John D. Rockefeller, who has lived through depressions and prosperities that most persons now alive can review only on charts, declared in his annual message to the public yesterday that "prosperity has always returned, and will again."

A picture of life at the court of an Indian Maharajah is provided in "Hindu Holiday," by J.R. Ackarley, published today by the Viking Press. The picture -- an informal one -- was written by the young English author in the form of day-by-day sketches in his diary.

Several hundred members and their friends thronged the Atlantic Beach Club yesterday afternoon and last night for a beach fiesta and extensive program of entertainment arranged in behalf of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. Guest privileges extended by the club enabled many subscribers to participate in beach diversions during the afternoon, although the main program did not begin until 6 o'clock.
Mayor Walker said yesterday that he would attend the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this Summer if he could possibly catch up on his schedule by the time the finals occur.

Bernard Wagenaar's "Divertimento," with the composer conducting, was played for the first time at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. The work, which was first performed in New York last Winter by the National Orchestral Association, is in four movements: Cortege, Paspy, Pastorale and Rondo.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- The retirement of Paraguay from the conference of neutrals in Washington trying to settle the Chaco dispute between Paraguay and Bolivia was announced today. Paraguay charged a new Bolivian offensive had begun against the Paraguayan positions in Chaco.
BALTIMORE, July 8 -- Executors of the estate of Isaac E. Emerson today filed a first administration account of $12,767,329 personalty in the Orphans' Court.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- The Baltimore Club, one of the oldest social organizations of Baltimore, will soon close. Its officials said today, regardless whether informal discussions of a merger with the Maryland Club materialize.

LAUSANNE, July 8 -- What Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald described today as the most difficult task of his life has been brought to success. After thirteen years of effort and failure and suffering, payment by Germany to the victorious allies of that tribute that was to serve for restoration and reparation has been brought to an end.

With the final settlement of the reparations problem, announced at Lausanne yesterday, one of the major obstacles to world-wide recovery from the depression, has been removed, in the view of bankers here.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 8 (AP) -- Richard Washburn Child, former American Ambassador to Italy, announced today that he had called a conference for Sunday afternoon at his home to formulate plans for a permanent international conference here.

There was an expansion in the volumo of checks exchanged at the principal clearing houses of the country for June, the total of $21,948,930,796, for the month, being 6 per cent in excess of the May turnover. Compared with a year ago, however, the total showed a decline of 44.1 per cent.

The newspaper should share in the interest and study that bibliographers and collectors have long lavished on the manuscript codex and the printed book, Stanley Morison declares in "The English Newspaper," published in England by the Cambridge University Press and just issued here by the Macmillan Company.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 8 -- Governor Roosevelt came here to his birthplace tonight to greet his mother for the first time since his nomination and to receive an impromptu reception from his neighbors in a rural setting.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James W. Gerard have joined Mrs. Marcus Daly in Hamilton, Mont.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8 -- Two of the Turnesa brothers. Joe of Elmsford Country Club and Mike of the Fairview Country Club, captured the best-ball honors in the one-day metropolitan P.G.A. tournament contested over the Fenimore Country Club links today.

Somewhere in Tin Mountain, the four-acre jungle on the Red Hook waterfront in Brooklyn, Louis Bringmann put down his old sea chest last night and looked about him for a place to sleep. He was 60 years old, penniless, friendless and jobless.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Jumping into the lead at the rise of the barrier, Max Hirsch's Swift and True ran away from his field to win the featured $2,500 added Crystal Lake Purse at Arlington Park today.

Five issues of debentures and bonds, aggregating $28,616,000, constituted the new offerings of senior securities this week. In addition, one stock offering was made in the amount of $1,000,000. Last week $7,288,500 of new bonds was placed on the market, while a year ago this week the new offerings reached $57,082,000.

The United States had the beat set of sprinters in the world in 1928, and yet an unknown Canadian schoolboy, Percy Williams, won both Olympic dashes. Never have American shortdistance stars been so numerous or so close to world's record speed as this year.

This year's campaign for the reelection of President Hoover will be run less expensively than that of 1928, when Mr. Hoover was first a candidate, Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared yesterday in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Fluttering so thickly that they resembled a snow storm, enormous swarms of moths swept down over the Bronx in the middle of last evening and by 1 o'clock this morning had beset many of the more brightly lighted sections of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

Miss Grace Surber, winner of the metropolitan crown last week, passed out of the women's New York State clay court singles championship on her home courts at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

Dr. John Grier Hibben, former president of Princeton University, will sail today for England on the White Star motorship Georgic on the vessel's maiden eastward voyage to Liverpool, accompanied by Mrs. Hibben. Others who will leave on the liner include Dr. F.L. Babbett Jr. and Mrs. Babbett, Henry W. Farham.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Senator Hatfield, Republican, of West Virginia, who is chairman of a subcommittee considering the Davis-Kelly bill for Federal regulation of the bituminous coal industry, said today in a formal report that he could not support the measure.

Following the comparative dearth of new State and municipal loan awards this week, with a total of only $6,691,975, according to revised figures, next week's schedule of issues aggregates $16,401,279, representing the requirements of thirty-six communities throughout the country.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Bob Smith, making his first start in five weeks today, was hit safely in every inning, but the Cubs, with the aid of five Philadelphia errors, took the final game of the series, 6 to 4.

Looking not a day older than when he last left the United States, Paavo Nurmi arrived in New York yesterday on the Cunarder Mauretania in company with nine other Finnish stars en route to the Olympic Games. As phlegmatic as ever, Nurmi refused to make any comments on his suspension by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, a bar which may keep from him his present ambition, to win the Olympic marathon.

Horse armor attributed to Kunz Lochner, foremost Nuremberg armorer of the Renaissance, made in 1548 for Johann Ernst, Duke of Saxony, is an important new acquisition by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, just placed in, the room of recent accessions.

Returning to their old-fashioned steam, roller tactics with which they have attained no little success in the past, the Yankees went brusquely about the business of putting the Tigers back in their place at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Speaker Garner held the centre of the stage in the Capitol today. He stood adamant against his fellow party members in the Senate who favor acceding to President Hoover's wishes in the unemployment relief bill controversy.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Government assistance to banks, other financial institutions and railroads for weathering the emergency amounted to $1,054,814,486 at the close of business June 30, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today in its second quarterly report to Congress.

An oversupply of public school teachers and an overload of high school pupils have brought a decision from the budget, committee of the Board of Education to discontinue the Maxwell College for Teachers, one of the three teacher-training institutions, and to use the building at 801 Park Place, Brooklyn, to relieve overcrowding in the high schools.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If you were a stockholder in an industrial corporation, and you learned that through, the wastefulness of its managers the enterprise was brought dangerously near insolvency, what would you do? Would you sign a proxy enabling the management to retain control, or would you use your proxy in the interest of a new management?
PARIS, July 8 -- The general satisfaction with the Lausanne settlement is reflected in the press comment here.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Franco-German agreement at the Lausanne Conference for a sharp revision of reparations was hailed by Congressional leaders in Washington as a long step toward solution of the economic problems in Europe, but was discounted as a force for further revision of interallied obligations to this country.

LONDON, July 8 -- Lady Louis Mountbatten, wife of the King's second cousin and one of the most prominent English society women, was the plaintiff today in a libel action described as "most atrocious and most abominable."

It those who plan a deep sea'trip in quest of broadbill swordfish have been the least hesitant, perhaps the fact that two more catches have been reported taken on rod and reel during the last two days should dispel their doubts.

Acting for the Port of New York Authority, the Badger Realty Company yesterday bid in at auction the three five-story tenement houses at 433-7 West Thirty-eighth Street. The Port Authority was in possession of title to the houses, which were acquired some time ago in connection with the Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel project.

MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- District Judge Florencio Araiza at Pachuca yesterday granted an injunction against expropriation by the State of Hidalgo of the Cruz Azul cement factory. The State will appeal to the Federal Supreme Court here to pass on the constitutionality of the expropriation law.

The Fault Not June's. The meteorologist of the Central Park observatory reports that June was the dirtiest month of the year so far. This is a surprise to those ready to hail June of 1932 as one of the fairest months ever known, bright in the morning, filled with sunshine during the day, and usually ending with an amber glow in the west.

Dewey Bentham's Martis, winner only once in seventeen 1932 starts, previous to yesterday, was the surprise victor in the featured Morrisania Handicap at Empire City. Getting the best of the racing luck he slipped along the rail under a strong ride by Buddy Ensor and won by a nose at 6 to 1.

The insurance plan inaugurated by the electrical industry in this city two years ago at the request of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers has run on the rocks, it was learned yesterday, when announcements were received by members of the local union that premiums for July could not be paid.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Christian P. Paschen, former City Building Com- missioner, was sentenced to serve two years in Leavenworth penitentiary and fined $10,000 by Federal Judge Barnes today for evading pay- ment of $43,000 in income tax in 1927.

GENEVA, July 8. -- The Germans began talks here today with the French in an effort to get disarmament as compensation for their withdrawal of their Lausanne demand for suppression of the Versailles Treaty's war guilt clause.

Effective operation of twenty-seven Salvation Army Corps, backbone of the organization's social service and evangelical activities in New York, is dependent upon success of the $600,000 United Appeal, it was announced by Army officials yesterday.

TORONTO, July 8 (AP) -- Reading defeated Toronto twice today. The Keys took the opener, 8 -- 3, as they combed three Toronto pitchers, Abberboch. Cook and Liebhardt, for eleven hits; and won the second, 1 -- 0, in the tenth.

Store-door delivery by the railroads serving New York City will be discussed at a meeting of representatives of shippers' organizations and the carriers at the Pennsylvania station on Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock, it was announced yesterday.
BISLEY CAMP, England, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- Canada flashed into the winning column as intensive competition opened today in the empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., July 8 -- Theodore Dreiser, author, escaped injury this afternoon when the car he was driving sidewipe a house, wrecked a rock garden, tore down a fence, displaced a four-ton concrete block and finally wrecked itself against a tree.

Mrs. Helen Pabon, 31 years old, rushed to a window of her fifthfloor apartment at 908 Kelly Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon and hurled her 5-year-old daughter Edna into a courtyard. Then, amid the cries of neighbors, she climbed onto the sill and leaped to the pavement.

The American secondary schools throughout the country, faced with the "widespread break-down of local machinery for taxation," must reduce their expenses and make fundamental changes in their curriculum, Professor A.K. Loomis of the University of Chicago declared yesterday afternoon in an address before the Secondary Education Conference in the Horace Mann auditorium of Teachers College, Columbia University.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 8 -- A permanent trust fund of $500,000 to the Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N.H., and other bequests totaling $980,000 were provided in the will of James Norman Hill, son of James Jerome Hill, founder of the Great Northern Railroad, which was filed today for probate with Surrogate Howell.

When he added up the figures early this week, City Collector REID discovered that tax collections on account of the first half of this year's tax levy had fallen off more than $19,000,000. That is not surprising; nor is it unduly alarming, since that sum represents only a small part of the total, and many more accounts will be closed before the year is over.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The total amount of the war debts of fifteen nations to the United States as funded amounted to $11,565,093,885. Their present indebtedness to the United States is $11,261,176,719.57, and the total that the fifteen were scheduled to pay during the fiscal year 1933, which began July 1, 1932, is $269,976,571, in principal and interest combined.

Stock Exchange call loans again renewed at 2 per cent, which was posted on Thursday for the first time since last January. Outside trades, however, were arranged at 1 and Federals at 1/4. Supply was good but demand light. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull and unchanged.

KELVINGTON, Sask., July 8 (Canadian Press) -- Trapped in a circle of armed police and farmers marshaled into the strongest criminalhunting force in the history of Saskatchewan, William Miller shot himself to death near here late today. He faced arrest and trial with two companions for the murder of Corporal Leonard V. Rails, a Royal Canadian Mounted policeman.

LONDON, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- With the veteran slow leg-break bowler, Alfred Freeman, mowing down the wickets, Kent defeated Northamptonshire by an innings and 188 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluded today at Tunbridge Wells.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Cotton under cultivation July 1 was reported today by the Department of Agriculture to total 37,290,000 acres or 9.5 per cent less than a year ago, when 41,189,000 acres were in cultivation.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 8 -- Several greens on the Lido Country Club golf course, where the Metropolitan open tournament will be played next week, have been damaged by some corrosive believed to have been scattered deliberately, it was learned today. The greens border on the Lido Road and a special guard has been posted there by the club to prevent further damage.

Havana cigars, like Swiss cheese, soon will be made in the United States, it became known yesterday when it was disclosed that the cigar manufacturing subsidiary of the American, Tobacco Company is preparing to transfer its plant from Havana to Trenton, N.J.

The August selection of the Literary Guild is "The London Omnibus," to be published by Doubleday, Doran Co. This thick volume will contain two complete novels, plays by Somerset Maugham and Noel Coward stories by Aldous Huxley and Max Beerbohm, and essays and poems. Virginia Woolf, H.G. Wells and Julian Huxley are among the other contributors.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 8 -- A keen rivalry has developed already among the thirteen companies of the Citizens Military Training Camp here to win the coveted honor of being adjudged the best marching company in the daily regimental parade on the post parade grounds.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8 -- "Pork barrel prosperity" as he dubbed the Garner bill, was denounced tonight at the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs by Henry J. Allen of Kansas, former Governor and Senator, who is to be publicity director of the Republican National Committee in the Presidential campaign.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP) -- Bob Brown, whose pitching has been a great help in keeping the Braves in the upper division of the National League race, allowed the Cardinals only four hits today and was all set for a shut-out when Jimmy Wilson singled in the ninth to drive in the only run for the Cards in a 6-to-1 contest.

Fears for the safety of the forty-nine-foot ketch Curlew and her crew of six New York yachtsmen, long overdue in the 628-mile race from Montauk Point to Bermuda, which started June 25, were dissipated last night when the Coast Guard cutter Marion reported sighting the tiny craft off Nantucket.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Representatives of Illinois mine unions and coal operators reached an agreement today on a new wage scale. More than 40,000 miners have been on strike since the expiration of the old contract on April 1, and the agreement is expected to put thousands back to work.

BERLIN, July 8 -- Prices on the Boerse were irregularly lower today and trading was in reduced volume. Uncertainty concerning Lausanne and how the reported settlement will affect the domestic situation produced general reserve. The electrics were most in demand, Berlin Light and Power touching 88 3/4.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons unleashed a heavyhitting attack against Jersey City today for a 12-to-7 triumph. The Bison barrage of sixteen safeties against four pitchers included Ollie Carnegie's twenty-third homer of the season with two mates on in the third inning.

Efforts to keep intact the $600,000,000 Eastern properties brought together by Samuel Insull in the last five years came suddenly to a halt yesterday when receivers appointed only eight days ago for the National Electric Power Company and the National Public Service Corporation resigned and petitions in bankruptcy were filed for the latter company and for the Seaboard Public Service Company, a subsidiary holding company.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 8 -- Timothy O'Sullivan, 31 years old, of 1,032 Laura Street, here, was shot and wounded fatally tonight by one of two hold-up men, Negroes, who encountered O'Sullivan while he was sitting with a girl companion in his automobile parked near State Highway route 25, on the northern city line.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 -- The Giants made a great up-hill fight today to overcome the Pirates' 7-to-O lead, only to lose in the ninth, 8 to 7. The New Yorkers left for Cincinnati tonight with four defeats and only one victory to show for their invasion of the league leaders' citadel.

SHANGHAI, July 8 -- Coincident with the raising of funds to finance a six months' anti-Communist campaign under General Chiang Kaishek, the Nanking Government has notified all foreign legations that large areas in Hunan and Hupeh Provinces are dangerous because of increasing Communist activity and that large-scale warfare is imminent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This letter carries one more proposal with reference to the already overdiscussed wet and dry question. It is a proposal to modify the Eighteenth Amendment by a provision for State option to suspend its prohibitory provisions for a limited time -- say ten years -- at the end of which period the prohibitory provisions would again be in effect, unless again suspended by the State.

The elimination of assistant vice presidents from the traffic departments of the New York Central Railroad, was disclosed in changes made public yesterday. For some time the highest officer in the passenger traffic department has been L.W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 8 -- John D. Rockefeller passed his ninety-third birthday today without any special birthday program, because the excitement would consume some of the energy which he wishes to use in reaching the age of 100.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- The globecircling adventure of James Mattern and Bennett Griffin has come to an abrupt end in Western Russia with only one-third of the flight behind them.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The German aviation world expresses deep sympathy with Bennett Griffin and James Mattern in their misfortune. Germans generally are keenly disappointed over the failure of the American fliers, whose record trip from Newfoundland to Berlin held out such promise for the establishment of a new round-the-world record.
MONTREAL, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- Don Bradman of Australia today showed Montreal cricket enthusiasts why he is regarded as one of the best batsmen the ancient game has produced.

THE Yankees were playing the Detroit Tigers at the Stadium. A big, blond-haired, broad-shouldered fellow sat in the grand stand and watched the proceedings with a melancholy air. Hits rang out; fine fielding plays were made; from time to time the spectators rose up with roars of approval or disapproval.The big, blond-haired fellow sat there unmoved.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- Baltimore beat Rochester in two games today, dropping the champions by scores of 7 to 2 and 4 to 2 as Harry Smythe and Harry Gumbert pitched fine ball.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 8 -- State drys will support President Hoover in the November election instead of a third party candidate, Harvey F. Remington, president of the New York Anti-Saloon League and Law Preservation party State committee member, declared here today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 8 -- The anticipated stretch duel between Miss Helen Hicks, the national champion, and Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks for the Long Island Golf Association medal play championship failed, to materialize today at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Radio remains a problem. It is true that superb music, and more rarely a good speech, occasionally rewards us; but most of the time the air is made hideous with advertisement-dominated inanities. Literally it is a racket.

Samuel Untermyer, sponsor of a proposal for liquidating the assets of the defunct Bank of United States and paying the depositors in full within three years after the plan went into effect, issued a statement yesterday saying that those interested in the project had obtained an additional thirty days in which to raise the funds necessary to put the plan into effect.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- One Kansas Representative charged in the House today that another Kansas Representative exhibited at the State Fair "a bull whose hide was filled with paraffin at eight different places."

A formal announcement giving the purposes of the General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders, for which Samuel Seabury is to be counsel in an investigation of real estate financing in New York City, is to be issued on Monday, simultaneously with the first appearance of the committee's advertisements.

LIMA, Peru, July 8 -- The "unimportant riots" yesterday in and around the important commercial centre of Trujillo in Northern Peru turned out to have been a ten-hour engagement between troops and police and Communists and Apristas. Late this afternoon the issue apparently was still undecided, although the government was predicting a quick victory for the loyal forces.

The Daily Graphic, Inc., publisher of The Evening Graphic, tabloid newspaper, which, suspended publication on Thursday, has liabilities of $3,132,521, of which $2,908,479 is owed to Macfadden Publications, Inc., according to schedules in bankruptcy filed yesterday in behalf of the company by Joseph. Schultz Jr., attorney.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The Young Plan is extinct -- the burden of 34,000,000,000 marks in reparations annuities that was to be carried until 1988 has been lifted from the shoulders of the German people -- that was the message that all Germany received over the radio from Chancellor Franz von Papen in Lausanne early this evening.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 8 -- In two blazing races, the fastest 2,000 meter sprints that the historic waters of Lake Quinsigamond ever have seen, the University of California and Rann Athletic Club crews today Flashed into the final round of the sight-oared Olympic rowing eliminations.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- Locked in a pen with an ordinarily docile. Russian brown bear, Thomas Earl, 56, was torn to death today a few minutes after he was dismissed as an animal keeper at the Brookside Zoo.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The contest for a Senate vote on beer resolved itself into a battle of parliamentary strategy today, with Senator Bingham, champion of the beer forces, matching wits with Senator Borah.

The Lee Higginson Corporation, formed recently with capital from sources outside the partnership of Lee, Higginson Co., announced yesterday that its business, which will be confined to New York, Boston and Chicago, will be under the general direction of N. Penrose Hallowell, executive vice president, with headquarters in banking offices of Lee, Higginson Co. here.

Colonel WILLIAM J. DONOVAN is an able and brilliant citizen as he was a gallant and dashing soldier. He is a thoroughly sympathetic figure and worthy of all the high office which he ought to have had. All the same, it is our unexpected and most painful duty to give him a public admonition.

The annual government report on the acreage planted to cotton, which was issued yesterday, proved to be about as foreshadowed by private agencies, and prices on the Cotton Exchange here, after rising to marks near their recent high levels, closed 4 to 6 points higher than on Thursday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 9 -- Ab Walker, close friend of Z. Smith Reynolds, who was shot to death Wednesday in his home here, supposedly by his own hand, was in the custody of the police tonight, following a secret inquiry held this afternoon at Reynolda after the funeral of the heir to some of the Reynolds tobacco millions.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Representative Celler charged in the House today that the Irving Trust Company had been given a monopoly in bankruptcy and receivership cases by the Federal district judges in New York City.

A man facing possible life imprisonment under the Baumes laws, an escaped inmate of the House of Refuge and a former inmate of the same place walked out of West Farms Court to the freedom of the city's streets yesterday afternoon, after Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky had decided to hold the three of them for the grand jury on charges of burglary and grand larceny.

LONDON, July 8. -- "There will be no more reparations." This, in the opinion of a wide and influential section of the British press, is the best news the world has had since Nov. 11, 1918. Of course, the difficult question of war debts still remains, but the fact that the first of the great international conferences has ended with decisive success is held to be a happy omen for others.

Seamen have had troubles peculiar to their calling in addition to those commonly endured for the past two years. While Federal, State and municipal funds were provided to care for the unemployed ashore, the merchant seamen were denied such relief as being transients.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, inc. BASE CAMP, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir, July 3 (By Runner to Astor, July 9) -- Nanga Parbat has begun to counter-attack!

Frank B. Laughlin, a customs agent who is an expert on the dumping of foreign, goods, has been brought from his regular station in Philadelphia to the New York division to investigate charges of dumping at the Port of New York, customs authorities revealed yesterday.

The announcement of the Lausanne agreement, the full and technical details of which are published this morning, is a great event, rich in promise of good. It bids fair to quicken hope not only in Europe but throughout the whole world. A persistent disturber of the peace is removed.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Gains of 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight were recorded in the hog market today. Yesterday's weakness which interrupted the long upswing was gone and buyers were again searching the yards for good grades at new high prices. The top reached $5.50 and the average went up 10 cents to $5, the highest since Oct. 23.
OTTAWA, July 8 -- Al Watrous, pro from Birmingham, Mich., shot his way into the lead in the second 18-hole round of the 72-hole Canadian open golf championship today.

Mayor Walker's decision to give business and civic groups a voice in formulating the 1933 city budget was approved by the League of Women Voters and the Citizens Budget Commission yesterday. At the same time the women's organization reminded the Mayor it expected him to produce his own economy program.

While early strength on the Stock Exchange yesterday was ascribed to the accord on reparations reached at the Lausanne conference, the later reaction suggested to Wall Street that other matters, such as reduced company earnings and a lower rate of industrial activity, were being regarded as of greater moment, from the speculative viewpoint.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Grain, markets on the Board of Trade here were inclined to easiness this morning, but became active in the last hour and prices advanced under short covering and professional buying. Hedging pressure was largest at the last, but was well absorbed, and the market closed with a fairly good tone.

Acceptance of an offer made by Jacob M. Kaplan of 292 Madison Avenue, whereby he would purchase for cash the unpaid balances of the claims of creditors of James A. Hearn Son, Inc., Fourteenth Street department store, and acquire the capital stock of the store, has been recommended in a letter sent to creditors by the creditors' committee, headed by Henry C. Taylor of Taylor, Clapp Beall, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 8 -- By a smashing majority of 222 to 30 the House of Commons today passed the final reading of the Irish duties bill, empowering the Treasury to impose tariffs up to 100 per cent if necessary to recover the unpaid land annuities of L1,500,000 from the Free State.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Refunds of $127,372 each to the trust for Waldorf Astor and the trust for John Jacob Astor of New York were announced today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Crude petroleum production throughout the United States in May totalled 68,523,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,210000 barrels, the Commerce Department announced today. This was a reduction of 47,000 barrels from the daily average output of the preceding month, and was 263,000 barrels or 11 per cent below that of the corresponding month last year.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The thirty-day furlough imposed on more than 500,000 of the government's employes by the economy bill will result in deduction of 2 1/2 days pay from each monthly pay envelope, effective July 1. This ruling was made today by Comptroller General McCarl.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 8 -- The Richard S. Greenough prize for the most notable painting or piece of sculpture in the annual exhibition of the Art Association at the opening today of the yearly exhibit was awarded to an Indian woman, Anne Elizabeth Prophet, a native of West Warwick, R.I., who this morning was elected a member of the association in order that she might compete under the rules.

TOKYO, July 8 (AP) -- Officials of the Japanese Fisheries Bureau said today they probably would ask the Foreign Office to protest to Moscow against the imprisonment of 400 Japanese fishermen employed at a Russian crab-canning plant on Ptchichi Island, off the west coast of Kamchatka.

Men's Wear Sales Again Fair. In the face of rather unfavorable weather, department stores continued to make a good showing in their promotions of men's low-price clothing during the week, store executives reported yesterday. The specialty chains also received a fair response from their clearance sales.
LAUSANKE, July 8 (AP) -- The text of the Lausanne reparations treaty, agreed upon yesterday by the delegates of Germany and her creditors, follwos:

Spokesmen for the B.M.T. and Interborough will be invited to attend a rapid transit unification conference to be held at City Hall next Tuesday, Mayor Walker announced yesterday at the end of a two-hour conference attended by members of the Transit Commission, Board of Transportation and Board of Estimate.
