Although, real estate activity in Manhattan was mild yesterday, brokers reported a few new transactions, indicating a demand for residential properties. Dwellings and apartment houses in the borough passed to new control as the result of scattering sales and leases.

In a spanking breeze from the west, one-half south, twelve Interclub Class yachts went through their regular Friday afternoon race yesterday on Long Island Sound, thoroughly demonstrating their wind-eating qualities.

The last straight vaudeville theatre in the country will pass out of existence next Saturday, July 16, when the Palace, for almost twenty years the leading variety hall of Broadway, will add feature films to its stage entertainments.

Part of the deal whereby the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company is building a factory in Hoboken for the Hinde Dauch Paper Company was recorded yesterday. The latter company, headed by Sidney Frohman of Sandusky, Ohio, transferred to the improvement company an unimproved block of thirty-two lots, 400 by 100 feet, bounded by Eighth,Ninth, Adams and Jefferson Streets, Hoboken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a certain Agustino Sandino, a Nicaraguan guerrilla, who has for nearly four years thrown, into complete disorder and terror the inhabitants of the mountain districts of Nicaragua and the residents of the little villages in that region.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 8 -- Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., today defeated Jack Tidball of Los Angeles in five sets, 6 -- 3, 10 -- 8, 2 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, to gain the final bracket of the Rhode Island turf court singles championship, where tomorrow he will defend his title against Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas.

Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the fur industry, announced yesterday that a conference to consider complaints of the Furriers' Joint Council that collective labor agreements in the New York fur industry were being violated by fur manufacturers would be held at the offices of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- Forty chambers of commerce, comprising the Finger Lakes Association of Central New York, today wired to John D. Rockefeller felicitations on his ninety-third birthday. Mr. Rockefeller was born and spent his early youth in the area.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 -- Twentythree wrestlers, nearly all of them holders of some championship or other, remained in the running tonight for places on the American Olympic team at the close of the fourth round matches.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- As a means of aiding the merchant marine in weathering the depression, the Shipping Board is considering a proposal to declare a moratorium of one year on construction loans due the board from American owned and operated steamship lines. These loans on June 30.amounted to $111,135,544, and under the law are to be repaid in annual instalments over a period of twenty years.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Wesley Ferrell was hit hard today, but he outlasted two Washington pitchers as Cleveland took its third straight from the Senators, 6 to 5.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- Miss Stella Walsh, 21-year-old world's women sprint champion, today declined the citizenship papers that would have made her eligible to race for the United States in next month's Olympic' Games.

A suit charging that the plan for financial reorganization of the Hotel Delmonico at 502 Park Avenue is "unjust, unlawful and fraudulent" was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by minority bondholders acting with the recently formed Protective Committee for Defaulted Real Estate Bonds, of which Edward C. Delafield, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, is head.
BOSTON, July 8 (AP) -- A six-run drive by the St. Louis Browns in the second inning enabled them to win from the Red Sox, 8-to-4 today.

MOSCOW, July 8 -- MOSCOW officials learned at 11 A.M. today, after a thirty-one-hour vigil at the Moscow airport, that James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, American round-the-world fliers, had crashed in a forced landing at Borisov, near Minsk, in White Russia, at 4 A.M. yesterday.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 8 -- Professor Thomas N. Carver of Harvard University told a general conference of the Society of Friends meeting here today that the nation's wet crusaders had exaggerated the economic benefits which might result from repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment.

The committee that recently was formed to represent investors in securities of leading rubber manufacturing companies "plans to investigate various trade practices and to consider the elimination of those which are unsound and may be legally abolished," according to a statement yesterday by George T. Bishop, chairman.

LONDON, July 8 -- Stocks became Irregular after a strong opening today. Sharp reactions occurred in German bonds and the Anglo-Americans despite the long-awaited accord at Lausanne. British Government funds continued to boom, the 2 1/2 per cent consols rising 1 1/2 to L72 1/2 and the funding loan jumping 1 1/3 to L107 3/4.

A thoroughgoing discussion of secondary schools in our educational system is in progress at Teachers College. The growth of high schools has been the most significant social as well as educational movement in the present century. But as Dr. THOMAS BRIGGS said in opening the conference, there has been no fundamental thinking "that has materially affected secondary education."

KANSAS CITY, July 8 (AP) -- Three high-living, knicker-clad golf players arrested on a public links here were identified today as notorious criminals sought in connection with half a dozen major crimes in the midWest, including bank robberies and the smuggling of firearms Into Leavenworth Federal prison.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 8 (AP) -- A fugitive gunman, who was involved in the slaying of Marshal Jay Davis at North Baltimore today, shot and seriously wounded Dr. Martin Larkin, 34, a Toledo physician, in a wild attempt tonight to escape from this city, where he had fled after the killing of Davis.

Judge SEABURY has let it be known that he intends to return to the private practice of the law in the Autumn. Though he had been expecting to sail on July 16 for a vacation in Europe, he has postponed that plan, the reason being that Governor ROOSEVELT may not be able until after that date to hold a public hearing on the charges against Mayor WALKER.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Eric W. McDonald gave a dinner tonight at Penrhyn for Miss Carola de Peyster Kip, Lord Carew of London and Daniel E. Pomeroy, who are passing several days with them.

The rise in prices of foreign bonds on the New York Stock Exchange has lately become of outstanding: interest; not less so in that it has occurred while discouragement and pessimism seemed to govern the movement of other securities. Because of the negotiations at Lausanne, the recovery of some 25 points in the German Republic's external bonds has attracted most attention; but the readjustment of values has not been confined to German securities.

ALBANY, July 8 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. handed down an opinion today that the State, cities and counties of New York are exempt from virtually all prpvisions of the new Federal revenue act.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- The constitutionality of the grain futures act was upheld by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson in a long decision made public today.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- An attack made upon Judge David Jenkins by Newton D. Baker before the referee in the million dollar suit for attorney fees in the proposed Youngs-town Sheet and Tube merger was read into the record by Attorney H. J. Crawford at the conclusion of arguments before the Court of Appeals here today.

CHERBOURG July 8 -- A telephone buoy floating in the middle of a large patch of oil-coated water led to the discovery today of the exact spot where the French submarine Promethee rests on the bottom of the English Channel, probably with the bodies of sixty-two men.

Denial of a report that Colonel William J. Donovan, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, was the candidate of either the so-called Hooverite group or of the "water-power interests," was made yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton of Norwich at the Donovan headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel.

SYRACUSE, July 8 -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Fine Arts has been conferred upon Mrs. Anna Hyatt Huntingdon, outstanding American sculptress, by Syracuse University at her home in New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment on Governor Smith's statement regarding his support of the Democratic party was not altogether fair. His statement impressed me as further evidence of Al Smith's honesty, frankness and good judgment.

A week's study of the Scriptures at sea will be made under the auspices of the American Bible Conference Association. On Thursday the Cunard liner Transylvania will sail for a seven-day cruise with 800 Bible students aboard. The ship will make stops at Nova Scotia and Bermuda.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- One hundred thousand dollars was available tonight to take members of the bonus army back home.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 8 -- Abandonment of its utility venture by the Standard Oil Company of California was made known today in an announcement of the sale of the Pacific Public Service Company, a $32,000,000 subsidiary, to the Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation, subject to the approval of the State Railroad Commission.

"Mr. Green," with the blue serge suit, the panama and the cigar dangling from his contented face, did most of the buying yesterday at the first government auction of furnishings seized in speakeasy raids. Without removing the cigar he outbid all the other perspiring and wise-cracking customers in the Knickerbocker Warehouse at 28 Second Avenue.

While the share market gave a singularly apathetic response yesterday to the conclusion at Lausanne of an agreement on the reparations problem, bonds reflected in a measure the evident satisfaction of the financial community here over the Franco-German understanding.

ALBANY, July 8 -- W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, and other party leaders came to Albany today for the third of a series of conferences on Republican plans for the coming campaign. The object of these meetings, Mr. Macy said, was to discuss possible candidates for Governor and other State officers.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Looking to the saving of about $150,000,000 to bring the 1933 budget into balance with the exception of the statutory debt retirement, President Hoover will soon begin a new economy drive.

A sharp difference in opinion between two groups of the late Ivar Kreuger's financial advisers as to whether publicity should have been given to his financial affairs in the period just before his suicide in Paris was made known yesterday at a hearing before Henry K. Davis on the affairs of the Kreuger Toll Company.

DALLAS, Texas, July 19. -- Militant opposition to any weakening of the Eighteenth Amendment and national prohibition was avowed by a group of 250 ultra-drys led by Alvin Moody of Houston who met here today and formed the Texas League of Dry Democrats.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- At the end of a three-hour conference today, it was announced by Publicity Director Henry J. Allen of the Republican National Committee that steps will immediately be taken to counteract the effect on American youth of Franklin D. Roosevelt's airplane trip to the Chicago convention and his proposed sea trip in a yawl with his four sons.

THERE is no slackening in the procession of books dealing with Soviet Russia. They range in kind from the impressionistic reports of casual travelers to careful studies made on the ground by writers with some special equipment for appraising the results of the Bolshevist regime.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 9. -- Scotch grit plus an unflinching crusading spirit won for Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain a great personal victory when he steered the Lausanne conference to success against heavy odds.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 9. -- The papers today foreshadowed important amendments to the drinking restrictions as a result of much criticism of the monopoly company's present rigid policy.
If Franklin D. Roosevelt goes to the White House he will be the ninth Protestant Episcopal President of the United States.

DALLAS, July 8. -- Certain political prognostications about Texas, as foolish usually as predicting the weather in this State, may be made rather safely even at this early date. In November Texas will not again startle the nation by deserting its traditional Democratic stand for a strange Republicanism.

BERLIN July 9 -- Almost two years ago I had the honor of addressing the people of the United States over the radio. I assured them that "the noble endeavor to build the peace of the world on a solid and lasting foundation which the United States has been pursuing for many years can find nowhere a heartier response than in this country.

NEW ORLEANS has been justly celebrated for many different things: her carnivals, her architecture, her port, her pirates and her picturesqueness, as well as her creole gumbo and her crawfish bisque -- not to mention those gone and regretted mitlgators of human unhappiness, the Ramos gin-fizz and the Sazarac cocktail.

HAVANA, July 4. -- Further increases of customs duties and the creation of sales taxes to be levied on domestic production of various articles, at present protected by high tariff, has been recommended by President Machado in a recent message to Congress as a measure to increase general revenue sufficiently to take care of the estimated $10,000,000 deficit already apparent in the 1932-33 budget, which went into effect July 1.

LONDON, July 8. -- Although the British delegates are leaving for Ottawa next week, no agenda for the imperial economic conference has been received here from Canada, where it is being formulated, and London is still much in the dark concerning details except that in a general way it knows the representatives of the dominions are going to discuss imperial trade and possibly monetary problems.

THE still unfinished process of discovering the world and reconstructing it pictorially had its origins long before Columbus. An important obstacle to the orderly development of ideas was the question of the status of what we now know to be South America.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 9. -- Company I of the Citizens' Military Training Camp regiment here, composed principally of young men from Manhattan and Brooklyn, was adjudged the best marching company in the Third Battalion in the daily regimental review this morning on the post parade ground.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended July 2 were lower than those of the preceding week and were about 40 per cent lower than in the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 5. -- The "ultimate Statehood for Puerto Rico" clause in the Democratic platform places both major parties on record as favoring closer relations between island and mainland. Brief as the statement is, it could scarcely be more specific.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Sydney Thayer, chemical manufacturer, clubman and member of an old Pennsylvania family, died of heart disease today at his home, Thornbury, at Haverford, after a long illness. He was in his sixty-sixth year.

FROM Bali, in the Dutch East Indies, comes the latest of the photographing Marco Polos, bringing with him some 18,000 feet of film and a well-developed case of adjectival fever. Charles Trego is a young amateur photographer who went to Ball because that seemed like a good place for a young man to go when he times of punching time clocks in New York offices.

NEWPORT. -- Trap shooting is becoming a popular diversion for the men of the Summer colony and they are apparently going in for it stronger this season than ever before. Since a trap was installed at the Clambake Club on Easton's Point a few Summers ago. there have been a number of informal but interesting matches.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 9. -- Miss Justine V.R. Townsend gave a reception tonight at the studio of Mrs. Newell W. Tilton for Mr. and Mrs. C. Kenneth Clinton, who are passing several days with her at The Nook. Later supper was served.

AN exceedingly rare instance of an airplane pilot being overcome by monoxide poisoning during flight culminated the other day in a rather trying experience for his companion in his endeavor to take over the control of the plane to avert a serious disaster.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 9. -- John Rourke, one of Savannah's most picturesque characters, died suddenly late this afternoon at his country home near the city. He was a veteran marine foundryman known for his resemblance to the mythical figure of "Uncle Sam."

The British colonial area has too great a stake in this country's markets to support any radical measures for tariff discrimination, against the United States which may be proposed at the British imperial economic conference convening in Ottawa July 21, George E. Quisenberry, export authority, said here yesterday.

An expenditure of more than $500,000 in government money and the employment of a staff of 150 investigators for sixteen months by the United States Tariff Commission has resulted in a report which demonstrates the impossibility of substituting domestic value for a foreign value basis in levying tariffs on imported merchandise, C.T. Riotte, secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., said here yesterday.

About $75,000,000 will be needed for the care of the needy in this city in the next twelve months, and probably not less than $55,000,000 of this amount will have to be provided by the city's treasury, according to William Hodson, executive director of the Welfare Council.

No zealot is so intense a believer as one who has been converted at the eleventh hour. This is why it is appropriate that Mississippi Democrats should have called upon ALFRED E. SMITH for "unqualified support of Governor ROOSEVELT." When the procession of the saved began in the Chicago Stadium Mississippi almost missed the parade.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9 (AP). -- One run scored by Jersey City in the ninth inning provided the margin of victory over Buffalo today, 7 -- 6, although the Bisons tallied three in their half of the final session.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., July 8. -- Arkansas' credit morale shows definite symptoms of being on the upgrade. With an unexcelled crop season as general background, the State is further cheered by a satisfactory report on the status of its highway bonds, which constitute the major part of its direct obligations.
CHICAGO, July 9. -- Catcher Bill Dickey of the New York Yankees was suspended until Aug. 4 and fined $1,000 for striking Carl Reynolds, Washington outfielder.

THOSE whor have been reading Olav Duun's great saga. "The People of Juvik." as the successive volumes have appeared here in translation, will on no account wish to miss this fourth instalment -- while looking forward to the two which are to follow.

With the wholesale market turning its attention to Fall merchandise, practically all coat lines and many of the better dress lines were opened during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

GENEVA, July 9. -- The broad lines of the draft declaration upon which Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, is now consulting the delegations with a view to having the disarmament conference adopt it unanimously before adjourning became known today.

SOUTHAMPTON -- Sports events of varied character will claim the interest of members of the Summer colony during the coming weeks. Entries in the annual Meadow Club tournament for the Cameron, Babcock, Fox and Stafford Cups, which were posted early last week, will close on Friday, and actual play is certain to get well under way on Saturday and Sunday.

WASHINGTON. THE prohibition planks recently adopted by the national conventions of both the major political parties, the part that the issue is certain to play in the Congressional elections in the Fall and the renewed raising of the question in Congress during the past week have made the prohibition fight, as seen from Capitol Hill, hotter than at any other time since the passage of the Volstead act.
The Bermuda ocean race this year called for less sail handling and navigation than any of the previous ones over the twenty-five years of the contest.

THE publishers offer this poem, which has been inspired by the economic crisis, as pamphleteering as well as poetry. It is doubtful that it is good pamphleteering, for reasons that will be made plain later, but as poetry it has its merits.

LOS ANGELES, July 8. -- Southern California, from a national political standpoint, is considerably upset. The play at Chicago proved a bit fast for some of the folk accustomed to taking their politics at a slower tempo.

ROME, July 8. -- Italy this week celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of her entrance among the world's colonial powers. It was on July 5, 1883, that the Italian Government purchased from the Rubattino Steamship Company the coaling station of Assab, on the western coast of the Bed Sea, declaring that small city and 250 square miles surrounding it Italian territory.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 9. -- The Eastern football team made up of Yale, Harvard and Princeton players which will meet a team of players from the University of Southern California, University of California and Stanford University in a demonstration game Aug. 8 in Los Angeles, will leave New York at 1 A.M. Monday for the Pacific Coast.
DUBLIN, July 9. -- An appeal by the "army council" of the Irish Republican Army to Orangemen to join in a movement "for a free and united Irish republic" was made today.

LAUSANNE, July 9. -- With the ancient seal of the city of Lausanne, which was first used in 1525 at the signing of the pact of alliance and fraternity between the cities of Lausanne, Berne and Fribourg, there was sealed here today the new treaty of Lausanne which puts an end to reparations payments by Germany and will begin, it is hoped, a new era of business prosperity and real international cooperation.

IN addition to direct assistance in their homes and aid through "created work" the State of New York has begun to sponsor a new form of relief for city unemployed by putting some of them on what are known as "subsistence farms."

This is the tourist season. People cross continents and oceans to see strange sights and hear strange sounds. So has Helen Keller, who can neither see nor hear; yet she "sees" far more than even most discerning tourists. She is in Great Britain, and in a letter to a friend in this country she recorded the following impressions of Cornwall and a visit to the Thomas Hardy country.

WITHIN a few short hours Mayor James J. Walker waved farewell to the New York A.C. contingent heading westward for the final Olympic trials, greeted the Hungarian (Swimming) Rhapsodies, Barany and Halassy, and extended a friendly hand to Peerless Paavo, the great Nurmi, with his comrades from Finland.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9. -- The ketch Curlew of New York, the missing Bermuda racer that started from Montauk two weeks ago today with the other craft and then disappeared until Friday night, when she was reported by the Coast Guard cutter Marion off Vineyard Haven, was safely tied up at the head of one of the wharves here tonight.
A LITTLE checking up reveals that the various announced musical shows are taking shape about as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Mrs. May Conyers, aged 32, a Philadelphia divorcee, was shot and killed this evening by her suitor during a quarrel aboard a yacht of which they were joint owners and which lay anchored in the Delaware River just off the Essington Yacht Club at Essington about fifteen miles below this city.

MOSCOW, June 22. -- Soviet funerals are one of the oldest of the customs that still hang on in a land of new styles and Ideals. One would think that the Soviets, who believe neither in the soul, life after death, or Heaven and hell, would consider the pomp of a funeral ceremony a left-over of "paganism" and the religion which held sway under the Czar.

Nikola Tesla, dean of American in venters, either was 76 years old yesterday or will be today (he does not know which because he was born on the stroke of midnight), and in a self-deprecatory interview last nigh at a midtown hotel, where he lives, he told a little of his activities of the last year and his hopes for the future.

PARIS. PARIS, the debonnaire, continues to launch gay modes at midsummer festivities. Last week an account was given on this page of the glamourous white ball. Close on top of it followed the pink ball; it was held at the Ambassadeurs in the middle of the Petite Semiane.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Chairman Stone of the Farm Board has promised a "statement" soon, calling upon the private grain and cotton trade "to go to it" on its promise to raise prices once stabilization stocks were wiped out.

ALBANY, July 9. -- The assessed valuation of taxable real estate in few York State for 1931 was $29,91,105,905, according to an announcement by the Department of Taxation and Finance. This is an increase of about $39,300,000 over 1930.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 9. -- With hog, cattle and sheep prices steadily climbing, Kansas farmers are optimistic once more and are forgetting the low prices of grain and the poor wheat crop.

FORT SMITH, Ark. A LITTLE woman at Fort Smith, who dwells at the meeting place of the Romany trails of the world, feels the pulse of the gypsy tribes wherever they may be. She is Mrs. W.H. Cole, postmistress for the Gypsy tribes of America.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Equipoise, America's big wonder horse, made it seven in a row today. The sensational 4-year-old son of Pennant and Swinging, pride of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney of New York, easily galloped off with the honors in the $20,000 added Arlington Gold Cup to the cheers of 20,000 spectators at Arlington Park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a devotee of opera and patron of the Metropolitan Opera House, may I say a few words concerning the future of the Metropolitan and put forth a few suggestions for the enhancing of the program usually undertaken by this same company?

WEST HAMPTON BEACH. L.I., July 9. -- The bay mare, Arnoldean, owned by Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton, captured the premier honors in the two jumpers' events, which featured the second annual horse show of the West Hampton Country Club at Pratt Field, adjacent to the clubhouse today.

BERLIN, June 28, 1932. THE Verdi epidemic in Germany shows no sigs of abating. The public appetite seems to grow by what it feeds on, and in the name of the old wizard of Sant' Agata the opera houses of the country are willing to go the limit of exhumation.

OMAHA, July 8. -- The echoes of convention oratory, the bawling of the galleries and the peal of the stadium organ are still ringing in Corn Belt ears. For the moment this section is very much politically minded. It is agog with interest and in a questioning mood.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Sunday July 10. -- The Wahneta III, owned by Dr. George E. Rice of Bay Shore, and representing the New York A.C. pulled into the West Harbor here early this morning, the winner of the powerboat division of the New York Athletic Club's annual race to Block Island.

THE second release of the International Collectors' Club gives one food for thought, to say nothing of a certain satisfaction. Some time ago a suggestion was made to the effect that an album comprising a representative selection from the recordings of Melba, most of which have long since been with-drawn from current catalogues, be issued.
NEW YORK. The Netherlands Minister and Mrs. J. Herman van Royen are at the Barclay.

A student of the theatre who is obviously familiar with the drama as it has been presented in London, Paris, Berlin, Moscow and other European theatrical centres, and fairly well informed about New York's contributions, has an article in The London Times Literary Supplement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A press dispatch from London regarding Major de Spencer Robertson, M.P., and his straw hat is inaccurate. Major Robertson is not the first man to appear in the House of Commons wearing a straw hat; that honor belonged to a Mr. Joyce, member for Limerick City, back in 1897.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 9. -- Thirteen varsity letter winners are among the seventy-three undergraduates who have been declared eligible to compete for positions on the Harvard varsity football team next Fall, it was announced today. The list includes those athletes who have signified they will return to college Sept. 15 for the first varsity practice.

We had already been a nonth in the desert and ny companions were beginning to be restive, while the long fast of Ramadan, now very near its end, had served to reduce the common stock of vitality and optimism.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- An invitation for Calvin Coolidge to represent President Hoover at the opening of the Olympic Games in Los Angeles July 31 has been rejected by the former Chief Executive.

JAMES A. FITZPATRICK, the "Traveltalk" man, is busily carving a second series of his two-reelers out of the jumble of film which he shot earlier in the year during a two months' location trip along the Spanish Main. These new travel subjects will be released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer during the 1932-33 season, and will include sections on Mexico, Central America, South America and the West Indies.
METROPOLITAN MUSEUM -- Exhibition of old masters, designated as the gods of our younger generation. Opens today in D 6, remaining through Oct. 2. Reviewed on this page.

PARIS, July 7. -- Events at Lausanne and Geneva in the past few weeks and the efforts to balance the budget have taught the French once again the old lessor, that the ruling class has little choice, no matter what it represents.

In a recent address in Montreal, according to a Canadian Pacific Railway bulletin, E.J. Carlyle, general secretary of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, predicted that the mineral industry of the Dominion has far from reached its zenith of production and that great opportunities lie ahead for the products of Canada's mines and quarries.
HATS are going to give us lots to think about from now on. Marked new tendencies are already noticeable in them. Crowns, for instance, are being lowered in a very jaunty fashion.
ST. PAUL, July 9 (AP). -- A ransom of $12,000 was paid by Haskell Bohn's father for the youth's release from those who kidnapped him, police disclosed today.

The renewal of unification parleys by the Transit Commission, the Board of Estimate and the rapid transit companies, it was reported yesterday, would be followed shortly by important changes in the B.M.T. directorate and the creation of a committee, representing various classes of security holders, to do the "trading" with, public officials and boards.
HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The next major event on the Summer, sport calendar is the annual Virginia State open tennis championship, which is now the centre of interest in the Homestead colony.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- All except 8,548,110 bushels of the 40,000,000 bushels of Farm Board wheat voted by Congress for alleviating distress has been distributed throughout the country by the Red Cross in flour for needy families and feed for live stock, records of that organization disclosed today.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 8. -- North Carolina has not yet recovered from the amazement occasioned by the enormous majority by which Robert R. Reynolds, a militant wet, was nominated to the United States Senate in last Saturday's Democratic primary.

Tree-Planting Extraordinary. With ponderoup sarcasm Secretary Hyde pointed out that Governor Roosevelt's reforestation measure would relieve unemployment for less than a day. It is his contention that one reasonably efficient man can plant one acre or 1,000 trees in a day.

TORONTO, Ont., July 9. -- Returns received by the Ontario Department of Mines from the metalliferous mines, smelters and refinery works of the Province for the three months ended on March 31 are tabulated below. For purposes of comparison the values are Riven for the corresponding period of 1931.

BRETTON, WOODS, N.H. -- The Barnstormers, organized last season by Francis Grover Cleveland, will open their second season in the White Mountains on July 12 at Tamworth, with an evening performance by a large cast of semi-professional players.

With a record of ten victories, two draws and a single defeat behind them, the Australian cricketers, on a good-will tour of North America and due to arrive in New York on Wednesday evening, to all intents purposes appear invincible. The game they lost was not to eleven opponents, but to a team of fifteen representing the Mainland in a return match at Vancouver after they had beaten another Mainland fifteen the day before.

SHANGHAI, June 10. -- When considering the future of China most people have taken into consideration mainly the internal situation and the probable trend of events arising from it. Foreign interference was not expected, because the interested Powers under the Washington Treaty undertook to give China every encouragement to reorganize, and pledged themselves to consult each other before taking any action calculated to affect the process.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 9 (AP). Cliff Sutter of New Orleans won the men's singles championship of the Southern Tennis Tournament today, but Bryan Grant of Atlanta went down to an honorable defeat.

ALL who like to make literary pilgrimages will be glad to know that The Wayside, Hawthorne's home in Concord, Mass., has been opened to the public. The house, which is situated nineteen miles out from Boston, on the Lexington road, has other literary associations in addition to its prime interest as the home of the author of "The Scarlet Letter."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 9. -- Officers of the Devon Yacht Club held open house today in honor of visiting yachtsmen and their guests from the Sebonac Yacht Club of Southampton, the North Fork Yacht Club of Cutchogue, L.I., and the Shelter Island Yacht Club.

With the weather throughout the cotton-producing sections the most favorable for the crop that it had been in several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined nearly $1 a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 14 to 18 points. Virtually no rain had fallen for a day in the cotton belt, and predictions were for fair weather over Sunday in all parts except western portions of Texas.

PARIS, June 30. -- To gay that Paris does not feel the pinch in these days of world-wide disturbance would be to blink the truth. Nevertheless, few signs of crisis or depression were apparent to the onlooker at the events of the Grande Semaine, or Big Week, as the seven-day period culminating in the Grand Prix late in June is called.

LAUSANNE, July 9 (AP). -- The reparations agreement was initialed today by delegates of the leading powers, and almost before the ink was dry preparations were started for the world economic conference authorized in the treaty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am writing in Italy, where the depression pervading Europe is not so marked. This gives one the opportunity to moralize but without detachment from the universal bleakness. People should be taught to be less selfish, less crazy about money making, more altruistic and less disposed to acquire luxuries.

LONDON. IT is an inflexible rule of the British royal family that its members shall not accept presents from strangers. And one of the most difficult of the problems that face King George and Queen Mary and their sons is how to refuse gifts -- some very valuable -- offered to them in ignorance of this rule, without hurting the feelings of the donors.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 9. -- R.H. Helsel won the regular scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club's traps today. He took the trophy by breaking 49 targets.

ORIGINAL ROOSEVELT MAN. WHO made Franklin D. Roosevelt Democratic nominee for President of the United States. Nine hundred and forty-five delegates at Chicago? James A. Farley? John Nance Garner? William Gibbs McAdoo?
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 9. -- With a lively breeze blowing out of the west, twenty-seven sloops took part in the third race of the July series off the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

GENEVA, July 8. -- Turkey's entry into the League of Nations, which now is certain, is noteworthy from several viewpoints. To begin with, it is a forcible reminder that the only peace treaty that was negotiated instead of dictated proved to be the only one that has led to genuine peace.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 9. -- In a brisk racing breeze that swept the yachts of the Eastern Yacht Club over the last run of their annual cruise today in last time, Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe defeated Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie by 16 minutes 52 seconds on corrected time, and thus broke the tie that bad existed between the America's Cup craft on their season's records.

Premier Edouard Herrlot of France appealed yesterday to "the people themselves of every nation to help us continue our work" so "the new spirit" of international relations might prevail, in a radio address from Lausanne over a nation-wide Columbia network.

DETROIT, July 8. -- A special election has been called for Aug. 9 on a proposed amendment to the City Charter which would limit the budget for the current fiscal year to $61,000,000, that of next year to $60,000,000, and so on, cutting $1,000,000 a year until a limit of $57,000,000 is reached.

Three cigar companies in addition to Henry Clay, Bock Co., Ltd., have moved their factories from Havana, Cuba, to Trenton, N.J., with a view to reducing retail prices in the American market approximately 50 per cent, it was announced yesterday by L.S. Houston, chairman of the company named, which markets the output of the group.

AIR mail operators and their employer, the Postoffice Department, are watching with interest the load records on air mail. Last Wednesday the new rate of 8 cents for the first ounce or fraction thereof and 13 cents for each additional ounce or fraction of an ounce went into effect.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Dr. Henry Hadley, American composer who conducted the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra for three years, will be guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra's outdoor Summer concerts in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, from next Tuesday evening until July 19.

FREDERICK II, Holy Roman Emperor, could not help being constantly in the limelight. His actions, even when seemingly trifle, were potentially of a gigantic conception. To his contemporaries he was the "stupor mundi," the marvel of the world, and to the later Middle Ages he was a legendary figure.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The reiteration by the State Department that President Hoover thought there was no relation between German reparations and debts owed the United States served to recall today the general interpretation placed in interested circles on the communique issued by Mr. Hoover and Premier Laval of France after their conversations here last October.

VIENNA, July 8. -- While Austria's elder statesmen have been appearing before representatives of the allied powers at Lausanne as supplicants for a new loan, Austria's Hitler-minded youths have appeared before some of the Ministers to Vienna -- not to plead, however, but to beat them with oxwhips and bludgeons.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 9. -- Governor Roosevelt asked President Hoover by telegraph today for a personal conference to settle the controversy between the State and the Federal Administration on the proposed St. Lawrence River development.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Official intimations that the United States was willing to consider further war debt cuts in view of the new agreement sharply curtailing German reparation payments met with protests today on Capitol Hill.

Congress is still in session at Washington, doing what President Hoover in May used to speak of with dread -- "legislating the political platforms." In May the President often said that he wouldd do everything to save the country from the post-convention activity of Congress.

Governor Mike S. Connor of Mississippi is no pessimist. As a Democrat, he believes Roosevelt will carry all the Southern States the party lost in 1928, and as a legislator, he believes that his pet sales tax will pull the State out of any slough of depression.

ANOTHER electoral battle impends in Germany. This time the issue will be Hitlerism. The result of the election will show whether the Reich will continue under a constitutional government or openly join the dictatorships.

IT should be noted immediately that all the essays in "Revaluations" were first broached as lectures and that they necessarily possess all the flaws common to lectures, hasty arrivals at conclusions, a paring down of argumentation and cursory presentation.

THERE was a time, not so very far in the past, when most of our museums lay under the stigma of functioning only as repositories of past art. Accumulating material, they omitted to put it to use. Buying and receiving, installing and preserving, was the chief of their diet.

GENEVA. ARE international matters solely the province of men, or do they also fall within the woman's sphere? Do the women of the world have any voice in them at the present time? How can they exert such influence in the future?
WINSTON-SALEM, July 9 (AP). -- The former Libby Holman, Broad-

At about twenty stations distributed over six continents, and in all zones but the Antarctic, identically calibrated instruments have been set up to measure the intensity of the cosmic rays. Never before has anything like this been done. The plan is one conceived and carried out by Professor A.H. COMPTON under the auspices of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

MISS ROSS'S story has for its theme the various complications created in the lives of a group of people who are thrown together for the four months' duration of one of those luxurious round-the-world cruises which seem to have taken a definite place in American life.

WESTPORT - ON-CHAMPLATN N.Y. -- Now that Governor Roosevelt has become the Democratic candidate for President, Essex County's celebration of the Washington bicentenary, scheduled to take place at historic Crown Point, a few miles south of Westport, on Sunday, July 24, has taken on added interest as he and Governor Stanley C. Wilson of Vermont are among the honor guests expected for the celebration.

PITTSBURGH, July 9. -- An error of omission by Dazzy Vance enabled the Pirates to tie the acore in the eighth inning of today's game with the Dodgers, but an error of commission by Billy Harris started the Dodgers on their way to seven runs in the ninth and the league leaders lost, 9 to 3, before a crowd of 10,000.
CARACAS, July 6. -- Publication of the budget for the fiscal year 1932-33 shows that the Venezuelan Government continues to be one country which is living within its income.

BUDAPEST, June 30. -- According to reiterated statements in the Hungarian Parliament and the Budapest press, the minute Principality of Liechtenstein has become an Eden for nervous capitalists in Central Europe.

JUST how a Newton discovers the role of gravitation in the cosmos or how an Edison happens to invent the phonograph are mysteries that psychology has not yet succeeded in explaining. Indeed, before M. Montmasaon brought out this book no one had written a thoroughgoing psychology of invention.

UNTIL a few years ago it was considered quite a perilous undertaking to traverse extensive desert areas in an automobile. If you ventured from Cairo into the Northeast, toward the Holy Land, for example, there was always danger that you might run into smugglers or bandits who infested the country and, mounted on swift camels, were able to maintain themselves despite the activity of the border police patrols.

THE name "fathometer" has been given to a new instrument devised by Dr. Herbert G. Dorsey of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey. The instrument makes it possible to drive a ship at full speed safely through a fog when nearing shore.
BERLIN, July 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

BERLIN, July 9. -- No prophecy can be made as to how the Lausanne reparations settlement will affect the balloting for the new Reichstag on July 31. For that a battle is being waged around the one internal issue agitating the electorate -- Hitlerism versus democracy.
Ellen Marjorie Garner died yesterday morning in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, as the result of burns she received on Friday when the candles on her mud-pie birthday cake set fire to her dress.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP). -- Effective pitching by Guy Bush and some timely hitting gave the Chicago Cubs a 5-to-2 victory over Boston today and enabled them to gain a full game on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

AROUSED by mounting taxes on automobiles and allied products, representatives of about fifty national groups of industrial, agricultural and private motor vehicle users, following a meeting in Washington recently, have decided to organize a highway users' conference with the aim of stiffening resistance to further levies.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9. -- With Tommy Hitchcock Jr. giving one of his customary brilliant performances, the Sands Point four today rode to a 17-to-7 triumph over the Meadowbrook Club in a polo match played for the benefit of the Nassau County Unemployment Relief Fund at the Meadowbrook Club.

In his speech of acceptance at Chicago, Governor ROOSEVELT referred to what he called the "Tory theory" of government. It is, according to his condemnatory account of it, first to see to it that "a favored few are helped, with "hopes that some of their prosperity "will leak through, sift through, to "labor, to the farmer, to the small business man."

Under the leadership or German loans, foreign dollar bonds last week recovered more of their lost ground than in any slmilar period since the decline began in 1929. Theie also was a moderate decree of strength manifest in domestic corporation bonds and in United States Government issues.

Exploding six home runs, three of them by Ben Chapman, the Yankees sent the Tigers out of the Stadium yesterday a sadly disillusioned array of young men by trampling the Detroiters down in both ends of a double-header that concluded the four-game series.

PARIS. THE great series of biographies, started here five or six years ago by many of the publishing houses, seem almost to have reached an end. But now and again on isolated biography is still issued.

IT was a Jolly little bomb that Professor Frank Jevrett Mather Jr. tossed into the Valentiner-Bode-de Groote camp last February. Like the world. Rembrandt "is too much with us." or "too many," according to Professor Mather of Princeton, who contended in his good-tempered yet sufficiently drastic Creative Art rebuke that the "official" Rembrandt list should be pared down from more than 700 to an average of "something less than 400."

More than seventy girl swimmers and fancy divers, representatives of a dozen States, have reported in this city for the women's Olympic aquatic trials, to be held at the State Park, Jones Beach, Long Island, on Friday and Saturday. The entry is the largest ever received for the tests.

TOKYO, Sunday, July 10. -- General Ma Chen-shan, who was driven away from Harbin and the district north and northwest of that city by Japanese expeditionary forces, has again come into a serious clash with the Japanese far to the westward.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Supported by fourteen Republican votes, the conference report on the Garner-Wagner $2,100,000,000 relief bill was adopted in the Senate today and Congressional action on the measure was thus completed. The vote was 43 to 31.

LAKE JUNALUSKA, N.C., July 9 (AP) -- Motion pictures are condemned as a "social menace" in the annual report of the Board of Temperance of the Methodist Episcopal Church, made public here tonight by Bishop James Cannon Jr.

FEAR is the great negative motif of the Soviet, as of every other dictatorship. It is a threefold fear. Facing outward, there is the fear, which the rulers feel, of international intervention. Inwardly they have a fear of the specialists.

With dollar volume and gross margin slipping badly, and promotions at the $15 level or under establishing new low-price points, the merchandising of men's clothing during recent months has presented one of the major difficulties in department store retailing.

Recalling the ebullient stock market that developed when President Hoover proposed in June of last year a one-year moratorium on inter-governmental debts, Wall Street was sorely disappointed by the languid response yesterday and the day before to the news of the Lausanne agreement to discontinue reparations payments.

CHERBOURG, France, July 9. -- The patented diving bell that ia part of the Italian salvage ship Artiglio's equipment descended to a depth of 230 feet today and located the sunken French submarine Promethee eight miles off Cap Levi.

Baroness Maud Levi of New York and Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch of Scarsdale gained the final round of the New York State clay-court championship tournament yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club and will meet for the title at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

It was in the bond market that the financial community again expressed its interest yesterday in the reparations agreement reached at Lausanne. As on the day before, the share market was inert and indifferent. There was an irregular decline in the foreign exchanges.

Cuts of 10 per cent or more in the salaries of presidents and higher offiaries of presidents and higher officials of the railroads were disclosed in the report sent by Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission to Senator James Couzens, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

A SCHOOL which started out to meet primarily the real life needs of youth, with preparation for college a decidedly secondary consideration, and which has succeeded in doing both -- that is the story of the Walden High School, which celebrates this year the graduation of the first group of its students from several leading colleges.

BROADWAY in the Summer sees license plates trout every commonwealth between Baffin Bay and the Torrid Zone. California rubs hubs with Quebec, Ohio parks with Oregon, and the solid South lines up with New Hampshire and Nebraska at the air pump.

LONDON, July 9 (Canadian Press). -- The annual cricket match between Eton and Harrow, famous old public schools, was drawn at Lord's today. Eton scored 238 and 216 for five (Hotchkin 109 and 96); and Harrow 349 (Pulbrook 104, Turnbull five for 75).

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- A tour of gardens, under the auspices of the Rumson Garden Club and for the benefit of the Monmouth County organization for social service, on Tuesday, heads the list of events in an active social week on the North Jersey coast.

MRS. IVES introduces a new pastime for leisure hours and names it "Headquartering as a Hobby" Her book, the outcome of her own long pursuit of her special avocation, is ample proof of the interest and the fascination she found in "headquartering."

PARIS, July 9. -- The French Government does not regard the Lausanne accord as having the nature of an ultimatum to the United States to reduce the war debts, it was stated in authoritative quarters today despite the press and public understanding that now it is up to America to take action, France intends to exert no pressure, it was said, and no responsible official expects real negotiations to begin before the Presidential elections.

MANILA, May 18. -- Governor General Theodore Roosevelt is making a determined drive on behalf of the small farmers of the Philippines. He has devoted more than half the time since he has been in the islands to a systematic survey of rural conditions, and he expects by the opening of the Legislature in July to have obtained first-hand reports of agricultural conditions in at least three-fourths of the provinces.

The cruLtlon of a new industry, through the establishment of plantations throughout the country for the scientific production of flowers from which will be extracted the essential oils for the manufacture of cosmetics, perfumes and allied products was proposed here yesterday by John V. Klochkov, former assistant professor of chemistry at the Empress Katharine Institute in Petrograd and now chief chemist of the Emyl Rajah Perfumery Company, Seattle, and the Belgian Trading Company, New York.

BROADCASTING stations are strengthening their voices. Old devices are being cast aside in the march of progress. Radio is preparing for better times ahead, and in so doing is spending thousands of dollars for new equipment.

The great moth mystery was partly solved yesterday. On Friday night millions of white insects with wingspreads of about two inches invaded the city, swarming over electric-light signs, motorists and pedestrians. The moths, coming from no one knew where, also swept over part of Northern New Jersey.

LONDON, June 20. NEWS from the theatres during the past fortnight has not been encouraging. In the height of the London season the Haymarket Theatre is without a play and its stage has been temporarily occupied by Cornelia Otis Skinner.

CINCINNATI, July 9. -- Babe Herman, the long, limber lumber-swinger imported by the Reds from Flatbush, cracked his season's eleventh homer into the right-field bleachers with two on base in the first inning today and the Giants began their visit here with a reverse, dropping the opener of a four-game series by the score of 3 to 1.

THE season of the Royal Hungarian Opera House has come to an end, showing remarkable results from the financial as well as from the artistic point of view, acaccording to a resume of the season, published recently in The London Times.

PITTSBURGH, July 7. -- No matter what the traditional Republicanism of Pennsylvania, a real Democratic Roosevelt-Garner campaign is promised in this State, with the expectation that the liberal elements which nearly brought about the election of a Democratic Governor two years ago will again cooperate.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP). -- Joseph M. Dixon, Acting Secretary of the Interior Department, announced today that the contract for furnishing the 30-foot pipes for the Hoover Dam tunnels at Boulder Canyon had been awarded to the Babcock Wilcox Company of New York.

MORE is heard about silver in this country today than at any time since the historic currency battle of a generation ago. For a long period silver had seemed of small consequence to the people of the United States, who forgot that it was the monetary standard of countries like Mexico and China and practically the sole purchasing medium possessed by a large proportion of the human race.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Waldo Warner's $1,000 prize-winning composition for piano, violin and violoncello is to be played by the Elshuco Trio at Mrs. Elizabeth S. Coolidge's Temple of Music in Pittsfield this afternoon. The performers are to be Willem Willeke, violoncello and conductor; Karl Kraeuter, violin, and Aurelio Giorni, piano.
The metropolitan open champion ship, one of golf's oldest and most distinguished events, will centre the spot-light on the famous Lido links this week.

WHEN Summer is in mid-swing, when every one has thought in terms of prints -- flowered and polka-dotted -- the colors-black and white, solid or as a combination, come as an immense relief to the well-dressed woman.

IF moral courage and broad scholarship still have any meaning in this age of machinemade universities and standardized political thinking, then let us honor the memory of Luyo Brentano. No German of his time did more to advance the cause of peace and good-will among nations; no man more deserved the prize that should be bestowed on one who sought the truth in the face of public opinion, official stupidity and religious autocracy.

Third-class travel to Europe is keeping up to capacity fairly well, as the rush of laborers to their native lands to wait until the depression passes shows no diminishing at present, it was said in shipping circles yesterday. Four steamships carried 2,300 third-class passengers yesterday and another 2,000 left on Friday for Germany, France, England and Northern Europe.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP). -- A fire which smoldered for six days in the hold of the North German Lloyd freighter Hannover was extinguished today, but only after twenty-seven firemen and a member of the crew had suffered injuries or had been overcome by smoke and gas.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9. -- International consultation and action to meet the demands of a new economic era in which trade, finance and credit have become part of a world system was advocated in an address tonight before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia by Eric H. Louw, Minister at Washington of the Union of South Africa.

WHILE the outbursts of convention oratory were still re-echoing through the air, a retiring, slowspoken, silver-haired college professor sat in his library and discussed political theories. No flood of imagery swept away the simplicity of his words, nor did eloquence or emotion enter into his arguments.

THE society pages are keeping it dark, but Mr. and Mrs. Thayer Outerfunds of Park Avenue, their niece, Miss Vera Lowensilver of Gramercy Park and the Formly Hadrocks of Riverside Drive will spend the vacation season this year at Manhattan Island.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 2 amounted to 489,273 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 9,526 cars fewer than in the preceding week, 178,357 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 302,780 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

GUAYAQUIL, July 3. -- Ecuador's revolutions of the last few years have been bloodless, but bandits and moonshiners do not fight according to the rules observed in these disturbances, where the guns were seemingly used principally to announce the positions occupied by the opposing forces and the tide of battle was decided by comparison of the strength of the positions each force occupied.

In the slowest trading for a Saturday since September, 1924, the share market continued yesterday to ignore the reparations agreement at Lausanne. Only about 235,000 shares were dealt in on the Stock Exchange. Dealings were confined to 341 separate issues, which made the market the narrowest in about seven years.

The Democratic National Committee will run its campaign for the election of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Presidency with the same economy that characterized his campaign for the nomination, James A. Farley, national chairman and Roosevelt pre-convention campaign manager, declared yesterday.

ATER a matter of a year and a half in Hollywood. George Brent -- at the Strand this week with Joan Blondell in "Miss Pinkerton" -- is being groomed by the Warners for big things. His next part will be the lead in the film version of Warden Lawes's "Twenty Thousand Years in Sing Sing."

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 142,394 tons in June to 2,034,768 tons, the corporation announced yesterday. This was the fifteenth consecutive monthly decrease in the corporation's unfilled orders and brought them to the lowest level yet reached.

VERY much of a man was Colonel James Buckner Barry, whose modest story of his experiences in the pioneer days of Texas makes this book. That story makes it evident that he well deserves the tribute the editor of his reminiscences pays him at the end in these words:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 9. -- The Montctair A.C. remained in the race for the Eastern Athletic Club baseball championship by defeating the New York A.C., 12 -- 8 today. Montclair will have to defeat the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club to gain a tie with the Crescents.

PARIS. JUDGING from all the plans which the producing companies here are announcing, France is not going to be so devoid of new French pictures as one would suppose from the gloomy prophecies of recent months. Of course, there is likely to be something of a hiatus between the exhaustion of the films produced in 1931 and the new crop, but it will not be for long.

THE luxuriant green growth of the tropics, the ruthless sun, the brilliant blue of the sky, the ripple of pahn trees in the wind, the rush and sparkle of the sea, make a ricb background for Alec Waugh's really splendid picture of a spirit aa luxuriant, as ruthless and uncalculating.

Europe has taken our advice for once. For some years we have been advising the Old World to settle reparations and now a treaty has been written settling reparations with a liberality and finality on the part of the former Allies which exceeded the expectations of Washington hy many degrees.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 9. -- An intensive man-hunt radiating from this city throughout the Middle West was under way tonight for the desperado who released a Toledo man and his nephew, whom he had forced to drive him to South Bend, Ind., early this morning, in an attempt to escape after killing Marshal Jay N. Davis of North Baltimore and seriously wounding a Toledo physician.

OTTAWA, July 9. -- Idealism versus materialism! Perhaps the greatest struggle between these two forces in the history of the British Empire will occur in this city when leading statesmen of empire countries gather July 21 at an Imperial Economic Conference at the call of Prime Minister Bennett of Canada, in an attempt to bind approximately one-fourth of the world's population into a single economic unit.

WHEN one contemplates the remarkable diversity of our magnificent country, including Alaska and the farflung dependencies, it is remarkable that the secondary schools are so thoroughly standardized. It can hardly be assumed that the needs of all youth in all of our high schools -- in Sulu, Guam, Santa Barbara, Abilene, Chicago, Mount Mariah, Brookline and Montclair -- are so nearly the same as our standards seem to indicate.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 9. -- Blowing from the northwest with a slight northerly variance, a fresh breeze that ranged from 20 to 35 knots' strength today swept seventy-two craft through the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's forty-fourth annual regatta.

BORISOV, Russia, July 9 (AP). -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, American round-the-world fliers who had expected by this time to be winging their way above the Pacific Ocean, spent today in the mud of the peat bos where their plane was damaged in landing Thursday morning.

VENEZUELA has a distinction not shared by any other country today. Her government is working on a budget that has been normally balanced without the aid of income taxes or loans. Moreover, though her estimated income is 110,000,000 bolivares ($21,230,000) less than last year, she has laid aside money for her gold reserve.

IT IS a curious, interesting and provocative Summer exhibition that opens today at the Metropolitan Museum. Apparently they found it no easy matter to find a concise explanatory title, finally deciding upon "The Taste of Today in Masterpieces of Painting Before 1900."

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Beer, which has occupied the attention of the Senate several days, was pushed into the background today while debate proceeded with the Glass temporary currency expansion plan, which Senator Borah offered yesterday as a substitute for the Bingham beer rider.

HAVANA, July 9. -- Captain Miguel Calvo, chief of the Cuban secret police, and two policemen riding in the auto with him were shot dead this morning opposite the Maine monument on Malecon Ocean Drive.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass. -- A fishermen's chorus program presenting the best voices of the Provincetown fishing fleet, assisted by Enid Romaney, a leading player of the Wharf Theatre, and led by William McCaffrey, the town's Selectman-orchestra leader, is a novelty scheduled for tomorow evening at the Wharf Theatre.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 9. -- Memories of a young Democrat, fresh from Harvard and seeking election as State Senator from Dutchess, Columbia and Putnam Counties, were evoked today as 4,000 residents of those areas crowded about Governor Roosevelt's home to welcome him as the Presidential candidate of his party.

LIMA, Peru, July 9 (AP). -- Government forces recaptured the city of Trujillo today from civilian rebels who had slain the Mayor, looted homes and banks and set fire to several buildings in a reign of terror, according to reports received here. Peru remained in a state of siege.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 9. -- The text of the report of the Power Authority of New York on its negotiations toward development of the St. Lawrence was as follows:

A recommendation that cotton mills discontinue productive night operations entirely, beginning on Oct. 15, has been made to the industry by the Cotton-Textile Institute, George A. Sloan, president of the organization, announced yesterday.

The agreement signed at Lausanne last week for a final settlement of the reparations problem was regarded in Wall Street as accomplishing the first half of the great task of clearing up the obstacle to world economic recovery presented by the burden of international indebtedness left as a legacy of the World War.

A definite ruling is being sought from the Treasury Department by the National Retail Dry Goods Association as to whether certain forms for the payment of money are taxable under the new excise levies, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director.
A SOCIETY OF NATIONS. By NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER, President Columbia University, at the Fourth of July Celebration of the American Society in London.

Frank Bowden, seeded first and former Columbia University captain, advanced to the fourth round of the fifth annual Richmond County clay courts singles championship by defeating Robert J. McKay of New York, 6 0, 6 3, as the tournament got under way at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I., yesterday.
OTTAWA, Ont., July 9. -- Lighthorse Harry Cooper, slim, bespectacled star from Chicago, put on a galloping finish today to win the Canadian open golf championship with a score of 290.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The strange customs of the Tlingit Indians of Southwestern Alaska, among whom a man's wealth is rated by what he has given away rather than by what he has, were described today by Kalervo Oberg, graduate student in anthropology at the University of Chicago, who has just returned from a year's visit to the tribe.

WHILE Times Square dozes in the heat of July, while on only a handful of local stages do actors, dripping beneath their costumes and make-up, run through their roles for the benefit of such audiences of stay-at-homes and visitors as may be attracted by the meager playbills, while, in brief, the New York stage hits the low-water mark, the Summer theatres are more active than ever before in communities beyond the city's gates.
CHERBOURG, July 9 (AP). -- When the news came today that the divers had failed to get any response from the sunken submarine Promethee, fifty-six hours had passed since she trent down.

Neither of the platforms of the two leading parties can be considered satisfactory to labor either from the point of view of an emergency policy or of a long-term program, according to the July issue of Facts for Workers, published by the Labor Bureau, Inc., 2 West Forty-third Street.

The sustained upward trend in sugar prices of all classifications has been the most noteworthy development in local commodity markets in several weeks, one which parallels the rally in hog prices in the Middle West. Local traders are enthusiastic and are inclined to regard the advance as one of the most hopeful signs in many months.

Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley Jr., socially prominent daughter-in-law of the chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company, separated recently from her youthful husband and is on her way to Reno, it became known yesterday. Her attorney, George G. Zabriskie of Zabriske, Sage, Gray Todd admitted that he had drawn a separation agreement about ten days ago.

Moscow, June 18, 1932. THERE once was a city named Tiflis, and once a dweller in this city -- a musician -- came to America and listened in one of our concert halls to the justly popular symphonic suite, "Scheherazade," of Nicholas Rimsky-Korsakoff.
THE thirty-eighth season ot Promenade concerts will open at Queen's Hall in London on Aug. 6. They will continue for eight weeks.
LONDON, July 8. -- On top of all its other troubles at Lausanne, Ottawa and Irpland, the British Government suddenly finds itself facing a fresh source of anxiety in India.

Many secondary school and college graduates use their education chiefly to assist them in rationalizing their prejudices. Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Secondary Education Conference in the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University.

CLEVELAND, July 9. -- The Crusaders, in closing their national convention here tonight, commended the Democratic party for espousing repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and called upon President Hoover to clarify the Republican plank on prohibition.
I BELIEVE the city manager form of government is suitable and desirable for large cities. I went through several stages of opinion before reaching this conclusion.

HAVANA, July 4. -- Henry Clay and Bock Co., Ltd., subsidiary of the American Tobacco Company and head of a combine of several companies in Cuba, who recently closed their cigar factories and stated they would indefinitely suspend manufacture in Cuba, plan greatly to increase their tobacco acreage in the Province of Pinar del Rio.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 9. -- After finding blood and finger-prints on a door between a bathroom and the sleeping porch in which Z. Smith Reynolds was shot fatally Wednesday, a coroner's jury today ordered that Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, widow of the dead youth, and Albert Walker, his life-long chum, be held in custody until the secret inquest begun yesterday is resumed Monday afternoon.

Reserve officers representing the commissioned personnel of fourteen units of the Air Corps, Tanks, Ordnance, Medical Department and Quartermaster Corps will leave their homes in the metropolitan area today for two weeks of field service at regular army posts, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area on Governors Island.

TOKYO, May 10. -- Depression, which in America flaunts itself in breadlines of the unemployed, in Japan hides itself in the farmer's cottages, and the comparative absence of urban unemployment officially estimated at between 300,000 and 400,000 - masks its real extent, so long as the farmer is quiet.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP). -- If there is a Congressional investigation of the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board, it will be into the $3,730,000,000 in tax refunds, rebates and credits made by the Treasury since 1922 up to the present time, including the $96,000,000 tax refund to the United States Steel Corporation and particularly a $6,000,000 item.

The moral, if any, of this tale is that nice little girls should not run away to the big wicked city in search of excitement. They are likely to find more than they have bargained for. That is what happens to Tevis Calvert, who finds herself involved in a gang war with no one to help her but a newspaper reporter named Jasper Graves.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Guy Irving Burch, whose letter you published under the caption "Drop in Birth Rate Natural During Times of Depression," would perhaps be far from admitting in so many words that what he calls the poverty-stricken class is congenitally and innately inferior to the "intelligent" and "responsible" portion of the population.

THERE is no unemployment in our community -- West Buffalo, northwest of Buffalo, Kan. And the folks are going ahead with their day-by-day tasks in practically a normal manner. Every one has plenty to eat, and an abundance of such other human essentials as shelter, fuel and water is available.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the United States shall have the finest mercantile marine in the world is the ardent desire of every patriotic American citizen. In spite of this fact, an astonishing number of Americans continually and consistently patronize vessels sailing under foreign flags.

THE retirement of Pinto has been one of the major tragedies of the modern screen. For many years he galloped across the Western plains, carrying Texas Rangers as they rescued the blondes of a pre-platinum age. No mountain was too steep for him to climb, no chasm too wide for a mighty leap in defense of virtue.

ONE factor which adds mystery to broadcasting is that the speaker never knows who is listening or where his words are picked up. While the thousands of words were flowing out of the Chicago Stadium during the political conventions John S. Carlile, production manager of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was eavesdropping and making a study of the voices.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 9. -- The first glider of the national gliding and soaring contest will float out Monday morning over the valley up which Sullivan's ragged soldiers stumbled in 1779, and the ridge on which they broke the power of the Six Nations.

Henry Lippmann, an Assistant Superintendent of Delivery in the New York Postoffice, who had been an employe in the postal service for almost fifty-two years, was the guest of honor at a testimonial luncheon given yesterday by his friends and associates upon his retirement from active service.

HERE in New York critics sometimes carp at the unwieldiness of our huge high schools -- cities often in themselves. But out in the wide open spaces, undersize, high schools constitute apparently a far more serious educational hazard.

Some cynical politician compared a party platform to that of a street car -- a convenience for jumping on and jumping off. Such a coarse expression must be regretted by all who appreciate the ritual fervor of these quadrennial statements of party orthodoxy, but the vigor with which Republicans and Democrats are leaping from their respective prohibition planks gives point to the old definition.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Chicago, approaching its own hundredth anniversary of incorporation as a village, views with more than passing interest Buffalo's celebration of its century as a city. The interest is largely historical. Chicago's manner of observance in 1933 will be on a vaster scale, proportioned to its grpatpr size, and emulating its earlier triumph in the Columbian Exposition.

NEW LONDON. THE United States Coast Guard ship Ponchartrain arrived at the State pier here last week after traveling continually from the northern ice fields, a distance of 1,250 miles. The ship is in command of Captain William Stromberg and carries a crew of 100.

PANAMA, R.P., July 4. -- President Ricardo Alfaro will send to the National Assembly for approval next month an amendment to the Liquor-Smuggling Treaty between Panama and the United States that will relieve this country from application of the Volstead act that bottled up the port of Colon and prevented the transportation of intoxicants from one part of the republic to the other through the arid Canal Zone.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9. -- Because his only two competitors eliminated each other in the semi-finals of the 145-pound division, Melvin Clodfelter of Stillwater, Okla., tonight won a place on the United States Olympic wrestling team without going to the mat.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., July 9. -- A strong northwest breeze again caused considerable trouble among the smaller classes of the fleet of the yachting department of the West Hampton Country Club today off the Speonk shore.
MONTREAL, July 9 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal took the final of a three-game series from the Newark Bears today, 7 to 4, before a slim crowd.

BERLIN. ON the table in THE NEW YORK TIMES bureau as this is written is a three-day-old copy of a London newspaper of large circulation. Across its front page in heavy type are headlines which read: "German crises: Amazing rumors.

WASHINGTON. FOR nearly a quarter of a century members of Congress have been able to proceed swiftly and safely underground from the Capitol to the Senate and House office buildings, but now the completion of a large sunken garage in the extended Capitol grounds provides a new and important link for this subterranean system.

LATONIA, Ky., July 9. -- Invaders irom the Chicago sector showed the way in the Quickstep Handicap, which was renewed today after a lapse of one year. The Superior Stable's Supreme Sweet took down the major portion of the $5,000 added purse, with the minor awards going to Mrs. Fairbanks's Gold Step and J. W.Y. Martin's Con Amore.

In an edition limited to 500 copies. Harold Vinal again comes forth with a volume of his cameo poems. This time the book is labeled "Hymn to Chaos," but it makes little difference what this poet selects for a title. His verse is ever of the same carefully carved sort, something to give a very peculiar pleasure to the few, although perhaps not of distinct appeal to the many.

The growing movement on the part of buyers to break down standard terms in the selling of merchandise, which has been under way for several months, reached its peak during the week and caused serious concert to credit executives of manufacturing companies and trade associations, according to expressions of opinion here yesterday.

NON-PROMOTION will again spoil the vacation for many a child. There will be those who will have to go to Summer school throughout the hot Summer months. There will be others whose vacation joys will be blighted by the knowledge that the next school term will find them back in the grade where they have already spent ten months.

A six-ton chandelier, said to be the largest single lighting fixture of its kind ever planned, will be installed in the auditorium of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Photoplay Theatre in the Radio City section of Rockefeller Center, according to the terms of a contract announced yesterday by the Rockefeller interests.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., July 9. -- Two men were fatally injured and two others were burned following a collision early today between two trucks at the intersection of State Highway 29 and Thompson Avenue. In another accident three boys were injured when a motorcycle on which they were riding skidded off the River Road in Piscataway Township near here.

BAR HARBOR. -- The Northeast Harbor Fleet, that association of hardy mariners which is now in the second decade of its existence as an organization, will sail the first race of the season on Tuesday, when fifty of its member yachts will take to the water in the first of the July series of championship races.

Several churches will hold an open-air service this evening and will continue to do so until Fall. Many visiting clergymen will preach this morning, the majority of the pastors having gone on their vacations. In some of the churches the associate or assistant pastor will preach.
