After six efforts, during which she could not win, The Beasel, a daughter of Sunspot and Antipodes, owned by J.P. Smith, won her initial victory of the year at Empire City yesterday when she was first in the featured $3,000 guaranteed Fleetwing Handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A rapid and favorable settlement by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the investigation it undertook in 1928 into newsprint freight rates in Eastern, Southern and Western trunk line territories was demanded by railroads in those sections today in a petition filed with the commission.

Last-minute revisions in Mayor Walker's formal answer to Samuel Seabury's aliegations, it became known yesterday, will delay its filing until after Governor Roosevelt's return from his cruise off the New England coast.
DETROIT. THE rough and rutted road over which the automotive industry has been traveling for some time is now beginning to smooch out. The belief is gaining ground here in Detroit.

In the past the verse of Angela Morgan has been so thoroughly disseminated that her work is well known. It is-in the present volume at least -- that sort of verge which gives pleasure to those who look to their poets for daily aid in living.

In the list of judges licensed by the American Kennel Club as competent to officiate at dog shows in the United States as of July 1 and just announced by the governing body there appear the names of a thousand men and women, their addresses and the breeds which they are permitted to pass upon.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 9. -- Complaints that bank funds had been lent without collateral by directors of the closed Bank of North Hempstead at Port Washington are being investigated, District Attorney Edwards admitted here today. He also admitted that three officers of the closed institution had been questioned before the grand jury and required to sign waivers of immunity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest THE TIMES editorial, "Railway and Motor Truck." Of course, Professor Ripley is right in saying that tha railroads are here to stay and that it would be impossible for motor trucks to supplant them.

HOLLYWOOD. THE road of the independent and free lance player is becoming increasingly hard. Studios which once operated on the theory that all featured players and stars should be under contract now have fewer artists on the payroll than ever before.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 9. -- Reserving his best brand of tennis for today's finals, Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., retained his Rhode Island singles crown and his balf share in the New England sectional men's doubles title on the turf courts at Agawam Hunt.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- A boom has come to the live stock industry, with the rapid rise in hog and cattle prices for the last few weeks causing the Western farmer to smile again and the nation in general to feel that beef and pork may be leading the way upward from the depression.

Mrs. E. Garfield Gifford, an active Republican organization worker of South Orange, N.J., announced yesterday her resignation from the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform because the executive committee of the organization last Thursday voted to support Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidency.
PARIS, July 9. -- A new method of lighting which promises to revolutionize illumination in houses was described today by Professor Georges Claude before the International Electrical Congress.

WASHINGTON. OPERATING under the new postal rate of three cents an ounce for letters, which went into effect on last Wednesday, the Postoffice Department expects to lose about 8 per cent in volume of first-class business but to profit by more than $130,000,000 in the present year.

The first step toward the return of national prosperity hinges on the divorce of politics and business, in the opinion of E.R. Thomas, 81-year-old pioneer of the automobile industry, who paused between trains here last week long enough to express himself on the doldrums of the times and their proposed cures.

WHY do superstitious people cross the road at the approach of a black cat? Do poets who write of beautiful women with snakes' bodies invent the monstrous idea? In what century did the cult of the Virgin first assume a dominant place in the development of Christian doctrine?

DARIEN, Conn., July 9. -- Flowing Gold, the brilliant chestnut gelding owned by the Oldtown Hill Farm of Mrs. Florence F. Dibble of Newbury, Mass., added one more championship rosette to the almost innumerable collection of trophies he has captured in the show ring when he carried off the leading honors in the saddle division of the sixth annual horse show of the Oxridge Hunt Club today on the club grounds.

THE recovery of $875,160 in gold from the sunken liner Egypt will be numbered among the few successful attempts to salvage the treasure that lies in Davy Jones's locker. Many millions have gone down in ships since man first ventured out into the open sea; some spots on the ocean's bed are no doubt paved with Spanish pieces of eight, but comparatively little of it has j been recovered.
LONDON, July 9. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, returned from Lausanne this evening. Mr. Chamberlain said:

BORISOV, Russia, July 9. -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, American fliers, were seeking a suitable landing spot Thursday morning when the magneto of their engine failed. They sighted what they thought was pasture land, but unfortunately it was a peat swamp, and it wrecked their effort to beat Wiley Post and Harold Gatty's round-the-world record after a brilliant start.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Business conditions remain generally unfavorable in our markets abroad covered in the current weekly survey by the Commerce Department. Some improvements were reported, however, from Canada, China and the Philippines.

THE Chicago Symphony Orchestra under Frederick Stock will give a week of concerts at the Stadium of Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio, beginning next Thursday. The fact that there is m Ravinia opera season in Chicago this year frees the Chicago orchestra for out-of-town engagements for the first time in many Summers.

FARMERS are jealous of their radio time, according to C.A. Herndon of the Department of Agriculture. The rural listeners demand that agricultural or informational programs be easy to listen to; easy to understand and remember. They want the subject matter concise and definite, concrete and specific.
PARIS, July 7. -- An amusing new beach necklace, launched at Monte Carlo, is made of elongated glau beads filled with real water in which tiny gayly colored glass fish swim. It it made by Anne Marie.

Mayor Walker and Count Laszlo Szechenyi, Hungarian Minister to the United States, were among the 2,300 aquatic sports enthusiasts who last night saw the crack New York A.C. relay quartet conquer the Hungarian Olympic four in the opening session of the two-night international swim carnival at the Jerome Cascades Pool.

SO many mystery stories are being published from day to day that few devotees of that type of fiction ever find time to read the boohs written by tbe pioneers in that field. One reason for this neglect may be that the older writers did their work at a time when both writing and reading were leisurely occupations.

TOKYO, July 9. -- Preliminary comment of naval officials on the British formula for reduction of navies, the text of which was received here today, showed that Japan's thesis is fundamentally similar to Britain's and fundamentally different from that of the United States.

It hag been a pleasant surprise for tennis fans to watch the steady play of a new star in the metropolitan district. Although she already had won a place for herself in the junior ranks, it was not until Miss Grace Surber triumphed in the metropolitan clay court event a littla over a week ago at the Lido Country Club that she gained her first distinctive success in major competition.

SAVED from the Australian bush after a desperate six weeks' search, the German airmen, Captain Hans Bertram and his mechanic, Herr Clausemann, sent back last week a strange tale of the country in which they had been trapped. For forty-five days they wandered timorously along the northwestern coast of Australia, fearing at every step that they were advancing into the hands of hostile aborigines.

George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, said yesterday that butter prices were "shockingly low" and that, despite light storage holdings and barely normal production, they continue dropping.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 9. -- A National Guard patrol, led by Lieutenant Michael M. Mahoney of the United States Marine Corps, engaged a group of about 200 rebels Thursday night at Guancastillo, near Jicaro, in the northern area.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Disappointing cable messages from foreign markets in the face of a satisfactory adjustment of affairs between France and Germany at Lausanne, with wheat in Liverpool 1 to 1 1/8d lower at the start, brought today a selling movement on the Board of Trade here that carried prices down sharply, although there were moderate rallies.

SAVED from the Australian bush after a desperate six weeks' search, the German airmen, Captain Hans Bertram and his mechanic, Herr Clausemann, sent back last week a strange tale of the country in which they had been trapped. For forty-five days they wandered timorously along the northwestern coast of Australia, fearing at every step that they were advancing into the hands of hostile aborigines.

George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, said yesterday that butter prices were "shockingly low" and that, despite light storage holdings and barely normal production, they continue dropping.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 9. -- A National Guard patrol, led by Lieutenant Michael M. Mahoney of the United States Marine Corps, engaged a group of about 200 rebels Thursday night at Guancastillo, near Jicaro, in the northern area.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Disappointing cable messages from foreign markets in the face of a satisfactory adjustment of affairs between France and Germany at Lausanne, with wheat in Liverpool 1 to 1 1/8d lower at the start, brought today a selling movement on the Board of Trade here that carried prices down sharply, although there were moderate rallies.

IT is a matter upon which the British dancers and their London public should be heartily congratulated that the Camargo Society has recently completed successfully what The Dancing Times calls "the first serious British attempt to produce a season of ballet in the West End."

EDGARTOWN, Mass. -- Summer activities on Martha's Vineyard have begun earlier than usual, and more events are scheduled than last year -- most of them of a salty nature. The new East Chop Beach Club, which has just been formally opened, is to be an outdoor and social centre for the island.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP). -- Monte Weaver won the nightcap in a double-header with Cleveland today, 14 to 4, the only victory for the Senators in a five-game series with the Indians. Cleveland took the first game of the twin bill, 4 to 1.

THE many who have watched with pleasure the increasing poetic mastery of Frances Frost will feel in the book "These Acres" that they were not misled in their earlier entausiasms. Not perhaps a bulging sheaf, although not a meager one.

RECENT news dispatches have drawn attention to Iceland as a base for transatlantic flights over the northern route. The Icelandic Parliament has just passed a bill granting a seventy-five-year concession to the Trans-American Airlines Corporation to conduct flights via Iceland.

THERE is a quality of Victorianism in the novels of Lady Eleanor Smith which tempts one to say. In a phrase which has become rather meaningless with misuse, that they are in the best tradition of the English novel. They are purely chronicle novels, and the emphasis is always on the narrative, on action in its external and physical aspects.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9. -- Gray Craig, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Van Beuren in Middletown, was the setting this afternoon for the annual round-up of the Newport County Boy Scouts. An entertaining program was presented. The guest of honor was Governor Norman S. Case, who with Mrs. Case and a member of his staff had come from Providence on invitation of William F.H. Whitehouse, chairman of the County Boy Scout Council.

In a phrase which has become rather meaningless with misuse, that they are in the best tradition of the English novel. They are purely chronicle novels, and the emphasis is always on the narrative, on action in its external and physical aspects.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9. -- Gray Craig, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Van Beuren in Middletown, was the setting this afternoon for the annual round-up of the Newport County Boy Scouts. An entertaining program was presented. The guest of honor was Governor Norman S. Case, who with Mrs. Case and a member of his staff had come from Providence on invitation of William F.H. Whitehouse, chairman of the County Boy Scout Council.
BOSTON, July 6. -- William Gibbs McAdoo may have lost Franklin D. Roosevelt the electoral votes of three New England States.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- If money talks, then Philadelphia's City Government figuratively is in excellent voice. And it has proved conclusively that advertising pays!

Two additional Summer schools for unemployed adults, increasing the centres during July and August to five instead of three, will open tomorrow in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24. -- One of the greatest steps taken by the present administration in the reconstruction of the Brazilian finances came about with the enactment of the law creating the Caixa de Mobilizacao Bancaria or Banking Mobilization Department.

Tom Keane of Syracuse, track veteran, remarked recently that in the Olympic Games athletes are looking for pace-setters like Ben Eastman. For several months past Eastman's amazing achievements at the quarter and the half have had the track world agog.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 9. -- Two dinner dances were held tonight in Larchmont. One was at the Larchmont Shore Club. The hosts included:

PARIS. PARIS couturiers are having a great success this season with those little Summer frocks that are neither distinctly for ports nor in the morning or afternoon class. One would not be shocked at meeting them anywhere, from the pesage at Auteuil to the beach at Biarritz.

MADRID, July 8. -- For seven years Portugal had practically a stable government under the rule of a widely representative group of generals who thought it better to cooperate for results than to instigate the individual revolutions that characterized Portugal's early twentieth century existence.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The House Rules Committee, beginning hearings on the McFadden resolution authorizing an investigation of the Treasury Department, voted today to invite Secretary Mills and Eugene Meyer, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, to appear Monday and express their views on the proposed inquiry.

The break-up of the Instill utility group, which will make many banks the involuntary owners of operating companies, with little opportunity for resale of the properties urtil the recovery from the depression is well under way, is attributed directly to persistent overexpansion carried over from the boom years into two years of receding business.

RETAIL trade suffered its usual post-holiday slump during the week. However, there was fair activity on women's Summer apparel, which was offered at lower prices. Sporting goods drew response on several lines and men's wear promotions brought some demand, though not up to the former level.

ESTES PARK, Col., July 9. -- The seventeen-year mystery of the disappearance of the Rev. Dr. Thornton R. Sampson, nationally known as a Presbyterian educator, of Austin, Texas, was believed solved today with the finding of a skeleton near here.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP). -- Frogs are taking up aviation. A Mexican branch of the frog family, actually is learning to "fly."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP). -- William D. Upshaw, Presidential nominee of the Prohibition, party, issued a challenge tonight to debate the prohibition issue with Governor Roosevelt or President Hoover.

Reconsideration of the whole system of inheritance taxation in the United States is called for because estate taxes are running as high as 45 per cent on estates in excess of $10,000,000, according to Walter Ewing Hope of the law firm of Mil-bank, Tweed, Hope Webb, who has analyzed a symposium in the law and practice of taxation conducted in the Summer session by the Law School of Columbia University.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9. -- Argentina would not participate in any negotiations looking toward concerted Latin - American reprisals against the United States' tariffs nor was she interested in the proposed Latin-American customs union, said a high authority of the Foreign Office today, when asked the Argentine attitude on Peru's recent move for a Latin-American bloc against the high tariffs of the United States.

LONDON, July 9. -- A further advance by British Government funds featured the close of an active week on the Stock Exchange. The Lausanne settlement was received with satisfaction, and cheerfulness pervaded today's trading.

Two elevens, composed of players who will meet the Australian cricketers at Innisfail Park on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, met in the first innings of a two-day match under the auspices of the West Indian Cricketers of New York at Dyckman Oval yesterday.

The sudden starting of a boom for Colonel William J. Donovan for the Republican nomination for Governor by Melvin C. Eaton, Chenango County chairman, has stimulated the friends of former Supreme Court Justice Daniel J. Kenefick of Buffalo to action, it was revealed yesterday.

WHEN the first one and two lunged "horseless carriages" began their rattling rambles along the byways of New England the White Mountains of New Hampshire were already widely known as a hot-weather playground, and each Summer the railroads carried happy vacationists into that beautiful highland region.

The Fourth of July was not nearly so deadly this year as had been expected. Only a few days before, the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters had gloomily forecast at least 600 deaths throughout the country as a result of avoidable holiday accidents. Actually there were only 243 fatalities, about half last year's total.

ENTHUSIASTS and experts in the comparatively new art of powerless flight are gathering today at Elmira, N.Y., for the third annual national soaring meet, held under the auspices of the Soaring Society of America, Inc. Twenty-eight pilots have already filled their blanks and have signified their intention of being present.

VOICES "paint" character on the radio. Now the time has come when politicians and broadcasters alike are studying the microphone technique of Hoover, Roosevelt, Curtis and Garner. They are weighing radio's part in the campaign. They realize that voice personalities overspreading the nation, within range of millions of voters, can play an important role in the fortunes of politics in this electrical age.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 9. -- Addressing the 1,000 delegates to the general conference here of the Society of Friends, Professor Jesse H. Holmes of Swarthmore College lamented today the condition to which the society had fallen.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 9. -- More than 500 residents of Purchase were guests today at Ophir Hall, the former Whitelaw Reid estate, where the annual Purchase Community Day was held. Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Reid present owners of the estate and publishers of The New York Herald-Tribune, were hosts with Mr. and Mrs. William A. Reed Jr., prominent Purchase residents.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9. -- Gavolo, 13-year-old black gelding trotter owned by Doc Bodenwelser of Newark, made his first appearance in a regular race at the local matinees after a lapse of ten years and scored an impressive victory at Weequahio Park today.

PRAGUE, July 28. -- A great nobleman of a past age a close friend of King Edward VII and of King Milan of Serbia, and a familiar figure at the court of the last Napoleon, died in poverty at Tavarnok, Slovakia, yesterday in the person of Count Siegmund Csaky-Pallavicini.

The short interest on the New York York Stock Exchange was increased 71,150 shares last month to 2,131,783 shares, according to statistics issued by the Exchange after the close of the market yesterday. This is the smallest change in the size of the short interest for any month since May, 1931, when the Exchange began to make these figures public.
BERLIN, June 29. -- The restoration of the monarchy is a question that few in Germany take any interest in these days; not even the monarchists, because at heart they know there is no chance for it.

RECKLESS speeding on highways is about the most dangerous of driving practices. Inconsiderate crawling is probably the most annoying. And ordinary people in automobiles have a right to demand freedom from annoyance as well as danger when they use the public roads.

PINEVILLE, Ky., July 9 (AP). -- Damage suits for a total of $112,500 were filed today in Bell County Circuit Court here on behalf of five representatives of an Arkansas labor college who were ejected from Kentucky last April and said they were beaten by vigilantes.

BERLIN, July 8. -- The meetings of the International Missionary Council's committee at Herrnhut and the World's Alliance of Young Men's Christian Associations and Young Women's Christian Associations at Dassel, with delegates from twenty-five nations and all the continents, were held under the sign of "Christianity meeting the challenge of the world crisis," in the phrasing of Professor Basil Mathews of Boston University, one of the delegates.

Judging from the accumulative reports from salient fishing points both in Long Island and New Jersey, the week-end should be one of the best of the season for anglers. With both striped and sea bass, bluefish, weaks, bonito, fluke, blackfish and porgies among the species that are running, the salt-water fishermen are now awaiting the tuna.

The impressive strength in the bond market on the Stock Exchange that had characterized dealings all week was unabated yesterday, and foreign loans, notably the German issue, continued to make striking gains. Transactions amounted to $6,382,000, of which foreign issues accounted for $3,076,000.

DENVER, July 8. -- Denver, apparently wearied of national politics and the long-drawn-out efforts of the Federal Government to balance the budget by multifarious additional taxes and economies, has decided that its paramount interest is first to set its own house in order.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the recent article in THE TIMES describing the burning of a composite coal-oil fuel under the boilers of the Cunard liner Scythia, it may be of interest to readers to know that on Nov. 11, 1920, while attached to the invention section of the Army War College.

TAKING another step to safeguard the airworthiness of American airplanes, the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce, headed by Colonel Clarence M. Young, has announced an amendment to the air commerce regulations which limits the validity of an approved type certificate to two years.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 9. -- A new political party, with a program to regulate the economic system in the United States to save the country from complete collapse or dictatorship, is the project of the League for Independent Political Action, which opened its annual conference here today.

THIS little book is concerned with the automobile and what the horseless carriage has done to civilization, the difficulties it has encountered and how it has conquered them. Of its two authors. Mr. Kettering is vice president and Mr. Orth is engineer of General Motors Corporation.

Louis Bringmann, penniless and homeless former hotel chef, became the child of fortune yesterday and also the victim of a double paradox. His eviction from the corrugated cardboard "resting place" on the fire escape of the Atlantic Theatre, Brooklyn, attracted the attention of a prospective employer but it sent him on his way, unaware, into obscurity.

It is an unusual request which Governor ROOSEVELT made of the President in connection with the pending treaty with the Dominion of Canada, relating to navigation and the development of hydroelectric power on the St. Lawrence. The Governor was well aware that the treaty itself must be negotiated between Washington and Ottawa.

The church has her part in the battle to end unemployment and the depression, the Rev. Alien Clay Lambert, pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in St. Thomas's Lutheran Church. Topping Avenue and 175th Street, the Bronx. It is her duty to see that the Spirit of Jesus is spread broadcast so that charity and justice will prevail.

The finest exhibition of volleying the local women's season has witnessed and an unflagging defense that consistently turned back apparent winners carried Baroness Giacomo Levi of this city to the New York State clay-court tennis championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Marriages, births and deaths in New York City all decreased in the first six months of 1932 from the number reported in the corresponding period last year, according to figures made public yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health.

A school of sociology similar to schools of this type in various universities is to be established in the probation department of the Court of General Sessions, it became known yesterday through an announcement that the judges of the court have adopted a general court rule creating the "Institute of Probation."
WEST POINT, N.Y., July 10. -- The West Point Officers remained undefeated on their home field when they routed a team from Governors Island, 24 to 4, in a polo game on Howze Field today.
BERLIN, July 10. -- That 75 cents is about all the pact of Lausanne will be worth six months hence was the prediction made by Adolf Hitler at a campaign meeting at Berchtesgaden, Bavaria, today.

The city's intention to honor the memory of 417 persons whose bodies were moved to Woodlawn Cemetery after the historic old Nagel Cemetery on West 212th Street had been condemned to make way for the $10,000,000 shops and yards of the city's new subway system, was made known yesterday by the Board of Transportation.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Manton of London have left the Barclay for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark in Cooperstown, N.Y.

Active participation by the city in public hearings of the Transit Commission on rapid-transit unification may be one of the results of the conference to be held tomorrow between the Board of Estimate, the Board of Transportation and the Transit Commission and spokesmen for the B. M.T. and the Interborough, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The reaction today in Congressional circles to the secret agreement entered into by the reparations creditors at Lausanne, under which reparations would be virtually wiped out only if the United States scaled down the war debt, was mcst unfavorable.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- Harry Cooper, who won the Canadian open golf title yesterday, hopped back to Chicago in time to pair off with Horton Smith today and defeat Gene Sarazen, United States and British open champion, and Tommy Armour, 7 and 6, in an Olympic fund exhibition at the Glen Oak Country Club.

CLEVELAND, July 10. -- The Indians and the Athletics battled wildly and stubbornly today for eighteen innings before Jimmy Foxx crossed the plate with the run that gave the Athletics a hard-earned 18-to-17 victory.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 10. -- Almost on soon as the ink has dried on the signatures to the Lausanne treaty for ending German reparations and readjusting European war debts, the machinery for effectuating it will have been set in motion.

MOSCOW, July 10 (AP). -- Dirty, weary and disappointed, James Mattern and Bennett Griffin stepped off a train here today, shook hands with a few fellow countrymen and hastened for a bathtub. A little later, with most of the grime scrubbed off, they told of the wreck of their round-the-world flight ambition in a Russian peat bog, and of their determination to try it again.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Internal revenue collections from all sources during the fiscal year 1932, ending June 30, amounted to $1,554,233,363.11, a drop of $873,995,391.11 from the total collection of $2,428,228,754.22 in the previous fiscal year.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 10. -- Libby Holman and Z. Smith Reynolds were married at Monroe, Mien., on Nov. 29, 1931, officials investigating the death of Reynolds announced here today. Mrs. Reynolds testified to this fact while she was being examined by the coroner Friday at the secret inquest at which efforts are being made to solve the mystery surrounding the fatal shooting.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 10. -- For the second year in a row, Golliwog, a cutter owned by Ernest Ratsey of the Larchmont Yacht Club, annexed first honors in the sailing boat division of the twenty-seventh annual race sponsored by the New York Athletic Club, which was completed off here today.

One question ought to be kept out of this Presidential campaign, even though prohibition could not be. No party issue should be made of the attitude of this country toward readjustment of the war debts. Apparently some Democrats think that they can win votes by pointing to their platform against cancellation.

Dr. Stephen Barany of the Hungarian Olympic team, European 100 and 400 meter champion, defeated George Kojas of the New York A.C. and Walter Spence of the Canadian Olympic team in a 100-yard free-style swim for men, one of the features of the second session of the two-night international swim carnival at the Jerome Cascades pool last night.

The United States should be prepared to accept a new settlement of the war debts, but such a settlement should be coupled with reduction of armaments, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America has replied to the manifesto by fifty British religious leaders appealing to the churchmen of the United States and other countries "to press for the cancellation of reparation payments and of international war debts."

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Cutler, who reached the nineteenth green, were winners of the week-end tombstone tournament at the Newport Country Club for prizes offered by Countess Szechenyi. Mrs. George Boiling Lee and I. Townsend Burden were close seconds.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 10 (Canadian Press). -- The belief was expressed here tonight that a body found by Nascopie Indians on the upper reaches of George's River, Labrador, was that of either Herman J. Koehler or Fred Connell Jr., Americans who started a canoe trip into the barren Labrador-Quebec peninsula last July and have been reported only once since.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Hoover today declined the suggestion of Governor Roosevelt of New York for a personal conference at this time on the St. Lawrence waterway development.
BOSTON, July 10 (AP). -- The Tigers and Red Sox divided a double-header today, Detroit winning the first, 7 to 5, and Boston taking the second, 13 to 2.

MARSEILLES, France, July 10. -- Dr. James Sparks, commander of the American Legion in France, who acted as one of the three judges in the boxing match tonight between Al Brown of Panama, bantam-weight champion of the world, and Kid Francis, a native of Marseilles, was badly beaten after the fight by ringside spectators who disagreed with his decision that Brown was the winner.

After almost twenty years of straight vaudeville, the Palace is saying good-bye to all that with its current show. On Saturday a program combining variety acts and feature motion pictures will take over the stage of what until recently was the proudest and most empurpled of all the country's former big-time music halls, the goal of vaudevillians everywhere.

In the Senate last week there was a passage at scholarship between Mr. ASHURST and Mr. JAMES HAMILTON LEWIS. With sadness it must be said that he who should have been the worthy representative of the University of Chicago and all the colleges and arts of Illinois didn't shine.

There is cause for cynicism in the spectacle of the national conventions of both major parties, meeting at a time when thousands are begging for bread, to focus their attention upon "beer and booze," the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

Led by the hard-hitting Lieutenant Harry Collins, the Governors Island four defeated the First Division team from Fort Hamilton, 11 to 6, in a polo game at Governors Island yesterday before a crowd of 3,000. Lieutenant Collins tallied six goals, three of them being on drives of more than 100 yards.

Thirty-nine working girls, representing ten major industries, have seen enrolled in the Barnard Summer School for Women. Workers in Industry, it was announced yesterday by Miss Ernestine Friedmann, director of the school.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP). -- The world's champion St. Louis Cardinals batted their way back into the first division from sixth place today by winning a double-header from the Phillies, 7 -- 5 and 3 -- 1.

The first of the two granite piers which will support the towers of the Tri-Borough Bridge over Hell Gate will be completed today, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Plant and Structures. The pier is in Astoria, and the one on the other side, on Ward's Island, will be completed in a few days, the announcement said.

STERLING, Ill., July 10 (AP). -- Dodging a terrific electrical storm, a tri-motored United Air Lines plane with five men and three women aboard struck a high tension line at an emergency landing field here this morning, catapulted to the ground and was wrecked.
To the Editor of The New York Times. I was pleased, the other day, to read your editorial with respect to the plan of Governor Paul M. Pearson of the Virgin Islands.

PARIS, July 8. -- Friday's announcement, showing that the German reparations question had been settled, is recognized as having immense importance in the financial situation from the psychological viewpoint. It is still asked whether it can be depended on that America will be as conciliatory toward her war debtors as the European creditor states have been toward Germany, and uncertainty on this aspect of the question may still hold back the markets.

CHERBOURG, France, July 10. -- Having established beyond reasonable doubt that none of the sixty-two victims of the mysterious sinking of the French submarine Promethee was still alive in their steel coffin on the bottom of the English Channel, divers went down again today to ascertain if possible what had caused the accident and study how the craft might be raised.
LONDON, July 10. -- Prime Minisister MacDonald received a warm welcome from a large crowd when he returned from Lausanne this afternoon.

A protest against the action of the executive committee of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, of which Mrs. Charles H. Sabin is chairman, in endorsing the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt for President was voiced yesterday by sixty-two of its members, including a number of women prominent in society.

If stock markets in this country persist in the "traditional attitude o ignoring the existence of pool opera tions," public intervention is inevitable Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Professor of Political Economy at Johns Hopkins University, asserts in his book, '"Want and Plenty," published recently by the Houghton Mifflin Company.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- About 7,000 State troops figured in changes of units at Camp Smith and other training grounds today. The Fifty-fourth Infantry Brigade, which arrived at Camp Smith, is made up of 2,200 men, including the 107th Infantry of Manhattan and the 108th Infantry with units from Syracuse, Rochester, Oswego, Watertown, Geneva, Auburn, Hornell, Elmira and Ogdensburg.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- Lonnie Warneke again pitched great ball today, shutting out the Braves, 4 to 0, to give the Chicago Cubs their fifth straight victory over Eastern clubs. The triumph was Warneke's twelfth of the National League campaign, his fifth straight and gave him his second shutout of the season.
OTTAWA, July 10 (Canadian Press). -- Canada will lay before the Imperial Economic Conference a list of well over 8,000 items which it is prepared to admit free of duty from empire countries.

A warm sun greeted the Manhattan Athletic League's annual safe and sane track and field games yesterday at Macombs Dam Park. They had been postponed on Independence Day because of rain. A large crowd was present to witness the performances of the local athletes, all of whom had never won a medal in these games previously.

Examinations for public school teaching licenses during 1933 and promotion license examination scheduled for this Fall will be omitted, except in the "most necessary" cases, in an effort to stem the tide of excess teachers being added to the eligible lists of the Board of Education.

THAT was a great three-day regatta on Lake Quinsigamond, possibly the finest college and club competition on the water this country ever has seen. It was something approaching a real "American Henley."

The Salvation Army's United Appeal for $600,000 to continue emergency and institutional activities in New York has raised $545,287.35 so far it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the campaign, who said the sum represented 9,928 subscriptions from 103,595 individual donors.

When the Europa and the Bremen of the North German Lloyd are made fast next March to the new Pier 32, foot of Canal Street, it will be the first time in twenty years that any transatlantic liner has docked below Christopher Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An interesting letter written by Donald M. Liddell appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES. One wonders why Mr. Liddell's bent for mathematics did not take him a little further.
Three boys, between the ages of 8 and 10, were caught yesterday afternoon after a three-month series of raids on the kitchens of Park Avenue apartments.

DUBLIN, July 10. -- Governor General James McNeill has demanded an apology from Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Frea State Executive Council, for affronts by the President and members of the Council. He has called for the apology "as an alternative to my removal from office."

The leader who uses "the big stick" method to clean up morals and politics was classed with the autocrat by the Rev. C. Lloyd Lee, assistant pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, at 174th Street, yesterday morning when he challenged the wisdom of those who are praying for a mighty leader to effect reforms.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 10 -- Eleven Interclub Class and twelve Atlantic Class racing craft had spirited contests today in special events arranged by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, and the Atlantics clearly beat out the Interclubs on time.
Some 15,000 Flatbush fans welcomed the Dodgers home for a single game at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- The heavy hitting which the Washington Senators showed in their last game yesterday against Cleveland was still to the fore today, and they pounded out a 13-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

BERLIN, July 9. -- Friday's news of the agreement at Lausanne was received in German business circles and banking circles with profound relief. The markets had not indicated anticipation of the settlement, and it had been believed that any breakdown of the negotiations would dangerously aggravate the crisis in international confidence.

BERLIN, July 9. -- The news of the settlement at Lausanne led to a sharp advance in stocks and bonds on the night Boerse at Frankfort on Friday, but the effect on security markets in general is not yet determined. There was some feeling that the German and other European stock exchanges might have discounted the agreement by the advances of recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The United States is approaching steadily a position of "associated membership" in the League of Nations, according to a lengthy study of "The Society of Nations; Its Organization and Constitutional Development" by Felix Morley, to be published tomorrow by the Brookings Institution of this city.

BOMBAY, July 10 (Canadian Press). -- The Indian members of the continuing round-table committee have all decided that they cannot cooperate further in the work of constitutional reform in view of the fundamental change, as they describe it, in the British policy on the method of progress toward Indian self-government.

PITTSBURGH, July 10. -- Steel production since July 1 is not regarded as indicative of underlying conditions as to demand, as the holiday interrupted operations in varying degrees in steel-consuming lines. This week will furnish a measure of the mid-summer demand.

Europe unmistakably held the centre of the financial stage last week. There was perhaps some logic in the fact that the first clear brightening of the horizon should occur in financial communities which had indulged in the paroxysm of despair last Autumn, and whose action at that time had introduced the most disturbing stage of our own reaction.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 10. -- A new conception of the writings and character of George Eliot is declared by The Yale University Library Gazette to be presented by the letters and journals of the novelist which were purchased recently by the Tale library from Miss Elsie Druce, her niece.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 10. -- Former President Carlos Ibanez, who flew homo from exile in Argentina last week, was a refugee again today after what appears to have been a vain attempt to seize power yesterday.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 10. -- About sixty taxpayers of School District 4, which includes the villages of Mill Neck, Mattinnecock.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 10. -- Several luncheons were given today. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner entertained at North Cottage for Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe of Planting Fields, Oyster Bay, L.I.

A leap from the roof of a six-story tenement to the platform of the elevated station at 110th Street, between Columbus and Manhattan Avenues -- the highest station in the city-enabled two men who held up the Briarcliff Dairy at 331 Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday morning to get away from a cordon of patrolmen and detectives summoned by radio to trap them.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 10. -- Paul B. Sawyer Jr. of Pocono Lake, Pa., an amateur, and Tommy Estlick of Waukegan, Ill., a professional, scored heavily in their respective divisions today to share top honors in the Buffalo centennial outboard regatta held inside the harbor breakwall on Lake Erie.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 10. -- In a substitution program for the Independence Day regatta, which was postponed on account of the weather, twenty-five sloops started in the competition of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 30. -- Two goals in the final period by John R. Fell carried the Sands Point team through to victory over Roslyn in the weekly polo game at the Sands Point Club today, 11 to 9.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 10. -- A silver spade, wielded by the Rev. Adolf F. Meyer, pastor of St. Mark's Lutheran Church, overturned the first bit of earth today on the site of the proposed new church edifice here. The church building is expected to be completed in the Fall at a cost of $125,000.

The Yankees astounded a gathering of 31,000 sweltering fans at the Stadium yesterday by losing not once but twice to the Browns, who in the course of five and three-quarter hours, pummeled Joe Mc-Carthy's pitchers for a grand total of thirty-three hits.

WASHINGTON. July 10. -- The belief that "sentiment" would play a small part in the settlement of problems confronting the British Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa on July 21, and that the issues involved would be dealt with according to "cold economic facts" was expressed by Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 10 (AP). -- Slugging by Ray Pepper, with four hits and four runs batted in and by Jimmy Shevlin, with three hits and two runs batted in gave Rochester a 9-to-5 victory over Jersey City today. Pepper had a triple, double and two singles to lead a 13-hit barrage off Jones and Ogden.

MOSCOW, July 10. -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin, whose world flight ended early Thursday in a crash on a Russian bog, arrived in Moscow this morning on the Paris-Moscow express and were met at the Alexandrovsky station by representatives of the Foreign Office, the Civil Aviation Department, Amtorg [American trading agency], Osoaviakhim [aviation society] and reporters and camera men.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, floor leader for former Governor Alfred E. Smith at the Democratic National Convention and head of the group that tried unsuccessfully to block the nomination of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President, will give Governor Roosevelt active and loyal support.

The Oxford English Dictionary, more than fifty years in the making, is now to have a supplement. Six or seven hundred pages will be required to present new words and new meanings for old words that have come into use in the last half century.

LONDON, July 8. -- Quite apart from the influence of the agreement on reparations at Lausanne, financial sentiment in all circles of this country has undergone a marked change for the better since the government launched its plan for conversion of the war loan.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The United States is credited by the Federal census with having had 3,964 centenarians on April 1, 1930.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., July 10 AP). --The fleur de lis waved again over Fort Ticonderoga today, commemorating the building on that site of old Fort Carillon 177 years ago by the French engineer, Marquis de Chartier de Lotbiniere.

Frank Bowden and E. Ralph Martin ranked No. 1 and No. 3, respectively, in the tourney's American seeded list, gained the quarter-final round yesterday in the fifth annual Richmond County open clay court tennis tournament at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, Staten Island.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 10. -- That white face powder was produced in ancient Greece 400 years before Christ by methods identical with contemporary processes has been established here by a chemical analysis of the first white cosmetics ever recorded

CLEVELAND, July 10 (AP). -- A platform making the liquor question subservient to economic issues and supporting Norman Thomas for the Presidency on the Socialist ticket was advanced to the voters today by the national convention of the League for Independent Political Action.

READING, Pa., June 10. -- Assailing President Hoover's threat to veto the Garner-Wagner relief measure, Louis Waldman, Socialist party candidate for Governor of New York, declared today that the bill itself was wholly inadequate for the purpose for which it is designed.

God cannot be legislated out of the universe by the vote of any conferences, the Right Rev. Elmer M. Schmuck, Bishop of Wyoming, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- New Winter wheat is beginning to move in larger volume after having been delayed by heavy rains in the Southwest. This week will see greatly enlarged receipts at Kansas City and other Southwestern markets, as well as from the Middle West district.
BUENOS AIRES, July 10. -- The grain, wool, hide and security markets here showed slight but firm improvement last week over the previous week, with a sustained demand not experienced in recent weeks.

As a result of twenty or more conferences by representatives of the Merchants' Association's building code committee and representatives of the Building Superintendents, the Merchants' Association expects to make a final report on the new building code to Mayor Walker in August.

More than half of the district captains in the borough of Richmond are on the city payroll, according to a further analysis of the political distribution of exempt positions, made public yesterday by H. Kliot Kaplan, secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association.

The Olympic Games at Los Angeles, the tenth Olympiad of the modern revival, should produce new champions and be a great success as a spectacle. In the preliminary trials everywhere there have been sterling performances. Almost every land will be represented when the parade of nations occurs on July 30 and President HOOVER proclaims the games open.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 (AP). -- A tentative organization to promote peace and prosperity through better international trade relations was formed today at the home of Richard Washburn Child, former Ambassador to Italy. The meeting was called by Newport and New York businessmen to consider holding here regular Summer conferences on international affairs as seen by business interests rather than through the eyes of political and collegiate "idealists."

Party lines are all tangled up in New Jersey, and four months of oratory and organization may be needed to get them straight again. The Republicans are dissatisfied with their national platform. The Democrats are not pleased with their Presidential candidate.

A young people's crusade for law and order is called for in a resolution adopted after the morning service yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, Fourth Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn. The action followed a sermon preached for young people by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William F. Sunday, on the Lindbergh baby kidnapping.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 30. -- An excellent performance on the homeward trip gave victory to Howard McMichael's star class craft Grey Fox today in the annual Captain Island race.

The Rev. William Pierson Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, arrived in New York yesterday from San Francisco, after a ten-month tour of Japan, China and India as clergy member of a commission of lay representatives of Protestant churches which agreed to "appraise the foreign missionary enterprise" with funds provided by John D. Rockefeller Jr. and others.

LAKE JUNALUSKA, N.C., July 30 (AP). -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., who called the dry conference leading to the organized anti-Smith movement of 1928, indicated here today that he would oppose Franklin D. Roosevelt for President.

Miss Elsie Copp, 23 years old, a resident employe of the Creedmore Hospital, Queens, died at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in Jamaica Hospital, an hour after having been injured in a collision on a "whoopee auto ride" at 157th Street and Cross Bay Boulevard, Howard Beach.

BERLIN, July 8. -- Now that the Lausanne conference has acted on reparations, the official view is that the general question of the period of international debts will play an important role at the coming London conference. It is felt, therefore, that no action by Germany on its external obligations would be advisable, unless or until the position of the Reichsbank's reserves should itself become impossible.

AKRON, Ohio, July 10 (AP). -- Wind-storms struck Summit County with the force of tornadoes late today, laying waste the residential section of Mogadore, a village of 2,500 inhabitants, seven miles east of here, and doing widespread property damage in Goodyear Heights, an eastern Akron suburb.
Several reports received from the New York State Conservation Department, which at first glance seem solely of technical nature, are nevertheless relevant to the welfare of fish and game interests.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The $2,100,000,000 unemployment relief bill is expected to arrive at the White House tomorrow afternoon for President Hoover's immediate veto, and on the following day Congress will probably begin framing a revised measure eliminating loans to private individuals, the proposal most objectionable to the President.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The declaration of John D. Rockefeller Jr. against prohibition will be answered by the Women's Christian Temperance Union all over the country this Summer, particularly in county fairs, where the women will exhibit a series of six posters briefly answering his charges, the organization announced today.

A Bird's-Eye Prophet. Mr. McADOO, following his customary mode of travel, flew back to California. On his arrival there he told the reporters that from "indications gathered across the country," he was confident that the Democratic party would be successful in November "by one of the greatest majorities ever recorded."

A two-day conference on municipal planning and government and administration in metropolitan regions is to be held on Oct. 18 and 19 in the auditorium of New York University, 37-41 West Fourth Street, it was announced jointly yesterday by Dean Frank H. Sommer of the New York University School of Law, Dean John T. Madden of the university's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, and Dean Rufus D. Smith of the university's Washington Square College.

With the sinking of the Promethee the number of submarines that have met disaster since 1904 totals twenty-one. Over 800 men have lost their lives under circumstances as heroic as any that distinguish war service. Are engineers so helpless that submarine duty must always be regarded as the most perilous to which officers and crew can be assigned?

Sound banking will never be achieved through legislation which would provide a governmental guarantee of bank deposits, in the opinion of Henry H. Heinmann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, who, in his monthly analysis of business trends, vigorously attacks the proposed legislation.

LONDON, July 10. -- Sir Richard Threlfall, who became famous in the World War for his services as a chemist, died in Birmingham today at the age of 70. His wide scientific knowledge was employed by the Allies in one secret technical problem after another.

VATICAN CITY, July 10. -- "We should be failing in our duty if we did not thank Divine Goodness for the faint dawn of better days that we appear to see on the horizon," said the Pope today, referring to the Lausanne settlement. He was speaking to the Sacred Congregation of Rites on the occasion of the reading of a decree proclaiming the heroic virtues of Maria Crocefissa Dirosa of Brescia, who died in 1855.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived in New York City last night for the first time since his nomination for the Presidency. He came late in the evening, accompanied by three of his sons, James, Franklin Jr. and John, who will start with him today on his cruise up the New England coast in the yawl Myth II.
BREMERHAVEN, Germany, July 10. -- When the Europa sailed for New York today the rail of the tourist deck was lined with Germany's Olympic team waving goodbyes to the cheering crowd on the wharf.

The take-off of James Mattern and Bennett Griffin on their round-the-world flight forms the principal subject at the Embassy newsreel theatre this week. There is also an illustrated map showing the route of the flight as planned by the two adventurers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Developments at the Lausanne conference indicate that the time is approaching when the European nations which owe war debts to the United States will approach this country with a plea for reduction or cancellation.

LONDON, July 8. -- The City's view of the final agreement on reparations at Lausanne is somewhat modified by the fact that markets had fully realized beforehand that reparation payments on the old basis were dead beyond all hope of resuscitation. Today business men are asking whether the Lausanne conference has really settled the war-debt problem, considered as a whole.

PARIS, July 10. -- With the statement, "Everything depends on agreement with America," Premier Herriot of France returned to Paris today from the Lausanne conference on the same train with Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 10. -- The cotton market here was more active last week than it had been in some time, and prices developed a fair upward movement, governed by influences within the market itself rather than by fluctuations in stocks and wheat.
Sunday, Summer heat and dazzling sunshine combined yesterday to jam the neighboring coast resorts with the largest crowds in their histories.

A warning that people are becoming "excessively problem-conscious," with consequent increases in insanity, suicide and nervous breakdown, was sounded by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, at 122d Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- The economic significance of the rural half of the population, municipal problems of unemployment relief and conclusions based on a week of round-table discussion of the anti-trust laws today engaged the attention of members of the Institute of Public Affairs, at the University of Virginia.
BERLIN, July 8. -- The Prussian crops improved further in June, the index number of conditions for wheat, rye and barley on June 1 being better than in July, 1931.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 10. -- Five hundred members of the Berkshire Summer colony filled Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's temple of music on South Mountain, Pittsfield, this afternoon at the second chamber music concert of the Summer.

The General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders, of which Samuel Seabury is to be counsel, revealed in a formal announcement of its plans yesterday that of twenty-seven issues of securities which it at present plans to investigate twenty-three were distributed by one firm.

Although one of the smallest of all the competing nations, Holland presented yesterday the most diversified Olympic squad yet to reach New York when twenty athletes, competitors in seven different sports, arrived on the S.S. Statendam of the Holland-America Line.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 10. -- Twenty-four yachts today competed on Long Island Sound in the second special regatta for members and guests of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club. The craft in the eight classes sailed over triangular courses in a southwest breeze that was light at the start and fresh at the finish.
Nicholas Perrotti of Split Rock led the field to take the medal in the New York Municipal Golf Association championship over the Pelham Bay Park links yesterday.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 11. -- John Hughes Curtis, Norfolk boat-builder and self-appointed "negotiator" with the kidnappers of the Lindbergh baby, was sentenced here today to serve one year in State's prison and pay a fine of $1,000. On July 2 Curtis was convicted in Quarter Sessions before Judge Adam O. Robbins of having given false information to the authorities for the purpose of preventing the arrest of the Kidnappers

Influenced by the most favorable over-Sunday weather so far this season, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost ground yesterday and closed 6 to 11 points lower than on Saturday. Virtually no rain fell in producing sections, while temperatures of 100 degrees were reported both east and west of the Mississippi River, while showers were predicted for only a few sections.

BOSTON, July 11. -- Nathaniel W. Niles, for ten years a member of the first ten in national tennis ranking, nine times the national figure-skating champion and a memher of three American Olympic Winter sports teams, died at the Baker Memorial Hospital today after undergoing an operation two and a half weeks agro.

The Amtorg Trading Corporation, agents for the Soviet Union, in the United States, announced yesterday that its purchases here during the first half of 1932 amounted to only $5,549,000, compared with $40,593,000 for the first six months of last year, a decline of 86 per cent and with $42,099,000 for the first half of 1930, a decline of 87 per cent.

George Bernard Shaw gave his recipe for success yesterday in an international broadcast from London which was rebroadcast here by WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System. "When in Rome do as the Romans do," quoted the dramatist as the surest road to success.

SHANGHAI, July 11 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The British Consular Court of the First Instance ruled today against the contestants for a share in the estate of Silas Aaron Hardoon, who died on June 18, 1931, and dismissed the case. The validity of the will, which left the entire estate, estimated at $50,000,000, to his Chinese widow, was recognized.
Details of the Regatta. 1. The yawl Myth II, manned by FRANKLIN, JAMES, JOHN and FRANKLIN (Junior).

Curiosities of the United States Patent Office provided material for a book, "Beware of Imitations," recently published by the Viking Press. A.E. Brown and H.A. Jeffcott Jr. have searched the records of the Patent Office and compiled a descriptive list of such oddities as a device to reshape the upper lip into a "Cupid's bow," a balloon propelled by eagles or vultures, an edible stickpin and a chewing-gum preserver.

American colleges, failing in their attempt to make proper contributions to national life, have developed an "aloofness from the central social struggle rather than to constructive social participation in that struggle," Dr. E.H. Wilkins, president of Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio, declared yesterday in an address before Columbia Summer Session students in the Main Hall of Teachers College, Columbia University.

College students always set the pace in dancing, and their ballroom novelties are watched and studied by dancing teachers doing the highest type of work, according to Miss Lucille Stoddart, chairman of the second annual Dancing Teachers' Congress, which opened a four weeks' session yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

In a Maryland county court a Negro was convicted of murder in the first degree and sentenced to death. The State Court of Appeals has granted him a new trial on the ground that the practice in that county for the last twenty-six years of excluding Negroes from juries is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The President was urged today by officers of the Farm Bureau Federation to exert his influence to bring about the enactment of pending farm relief legislation before the adjqurnment of Congress, Those who conferred with the President were President Edward A. O'Neil, Vice President Charles Hearst and Earl C. Smith of the federation's board of directors.

WEYMOUTH, England, July 11. -- Wearing the uniform of Admiral of the fleet, King George V stood on the upper bridge as the royal yacht Victoria and Albert steamed between the lines of warships of the home fleet this afternoon. Just below him were the Prince of Wales in a Vice Admiral's uniform and Prince George in a Lieutenant's uniform.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11. -- Many entries have been received in the annual Meadow Club tennis tournament for the Fox, Babcock, Cameron and Stafford cups, which will begin next Saturday and continue until Labor Day. Entering the competition for the Fox Cup are Mrs. William Palmer Dixon, the Misses Cathleen Fox, Gertrude Vander Poel, Mildred Lee, Mary Alice Waller, Anne Schuyler Richardson and Edith G. Betts.

While Governor Roosevelt is sailing along the New England coast, a collection of his articles on current topics is being prepared for early publication in book form by Covici-Friede, under the title "Government: Not Politics." The book is to contain twenty-four articles by the Governor, all but two of which have appeared separately during the last twelve months.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP). -- Four men were shot and more than a score injured by flying missiles today when police used tear gas to disperse a crowd of 3,000 unemployed gathered on the City Hall lawn under auspices of the Unemployed Councils of St. Louis, a Communist organization.

The Rev. Dr. William N. Guthrle, speaking as rector of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerle, and Coran Capshaw, as clerk speaking for the vestry, made public a letter yesterday notifying Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, that they would not reconsider their corporate decision of June 27 requesting his body-and-soul clinic to vacate the church by July 31.

The Standard Oil Cqmpany of New Jersey announced yesterday that employes may buy stock under its stock acquisition plan at $23.60 a share in the last six months of 1932. This is the first time that the company has offered stock to its employes at less than the par value of $25 a share.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 11 (AP). -- James Storey, 22-year-old St. Paul, Minn., youth wanted in Ohio for murder, robberies and kidnappings, died in a hospital here tonight a little more than twelve hours after he was shot down by police who arrested him here early today.

Simultaneously with a fair-sized recovery in prices, trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell off sharply as compared with the business done on Friday, the last five-hour day of the week before. The advance occurred in the last two hours; in fact, most of it was recorded in the final thirty minutes of trading.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The "gentlemen's agreement,"upon which the Lausanne reparations accord is conditioned, to the effect that the reparations settlement will not become operative unless the United States scales down Europe's war-time debt, has solidified opposition in Congress to any modification of the debt agreements made with this country.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 11. -- Mrs. Daniel A. Murdock, owner of the cottage on Sagamore Hill Drive which. Libby Holman rented last year near a cottage occupied by Smith Reynolds, said today that after Miss Holman had given up the cottage she found that an antique table which she valued greatly and which stood in the dining room bore what apparently was the mark of a bullet.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., July 11 (AP). -- President Hoover, in a message today to the second annual conference on smaller industries held here, declared these little units of the economic system were "vitally important in the human sense," employing half of the workers of the nation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The difference between the statement that lay support for the proposed bankruptcy reforms is needed, and the charge that lawyers shirk their responsibility in not remedying the bankruptcy evils, is apparent

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 11. -- Trapped in their homes before daylight, with all avenue of escape cut off, more than a score of persons were thought to have been drowned early today in a flood which followed a series of small cloudbursts on Paint and Armstrong Creeks, twenty miles from Charleston.

Two armed robbers, posing as deliverymen, gained admittance to the auditor's office in the Hotel Roosevelt last night. They trussed two employes and locked them in a vault, emptied a $3,000 payroll into a sack they had brought for the purpose and fled by way of the stairway and corridor leading into Vanderbilt Avenue near Forty-fifth Street.

Beginning yesterday the pay of structural steel workers was increased from $12 a day to $13.20 to conform to the wage rate fixed recently for the highest paid group in the unionized building trades in the city.
CLEVELAND, July 11. -- Bill Dickey, New York Yankee catcher who swings as mean a fist as he does a bat, will have to do his thirty days off the ball field and dig up his $1,000 fine.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP). -- Los Angeles, through its City Council, went on record today as opposed to allowing its Olympiad visitors to have a fling at the night life in Mexico.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 11. -- Two of Bernard Shaw's comedies, "Great Catherine" and "The Man of Destiny," attracted a full house tonight for the start of the second week at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge. F. Cowles Strickland, director, has cast Miss Violet Kemble Cooper and Claude Rains in the title roles.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 11. -- Walter Rothenberg, a junior at Lafayette and a member of Winged Foot, won the medal in the qualifying round of the second annual New York State junior championship at the Siwanoy Golf Club today, but only by a narrow margin.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11. -- A police statement today says a rebel movement began in Sao Paulo yesterday backed only by two army units. The movement is declared confined to Sao Paulo City, with the balance of the country perfectly calm and the government dominating the situation.

OTTAWA, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Australian cricket team scored 418 runs for nine wickets in its match against a team from the Ottawa Valley Cricket Council today. Ottawa was all out for 55 runs.

With an exceedingly small business done, prices on the stock market recovered yesterday, advances of 1 or 2 points being predominant in the more active shares. German bonds sold off again; which was not unexpected, both because of the recent recovery of 25 points or more and because the actual effecting of such an achievement as that at Lausanne gives occasion for the other side of the situation to be considered.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 11. -- The negotiations in Washington for a non-aggression treaty between Paraguay and Bolivia were broken up by Paraguay because she feared an unwanted agreement was imminent, your correspondent was told today by high Bolivian officials.

BERLIN, July 11. -- Chancellor Von Papen in a press conference today expained the terms obtained by Germany in the Lausanne reparations settlement which he said had been distorted in the German press as a result of the domestic political struggle.
Flats and dwellings and an industrial plot comprised the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Cattle and hogs of all classes sold today at new high prices for the season. Hogs ruled steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than on last Saturday but finished a little slow. Top sales reached $5.55. with the general average up 6 cents at $5.

The National Electric Power Company and subsidiary holding companies yesterday again became the objects of a "stand-still" agreement between banking creditors until the situation arising from the appointment of the Irving Trust Company as receiver in bankruptcy for the National Public Service Corporation and the Seaboard Public Service Company has been fully canvassed and the prospects have been received.

NEW HAVEN, July 11. -- Beating across Long Island Sound in a stiff breeze that whipped the salt spume into his face, Governor Roosevelt guided his forty-foot yawl into Morris Cove here this evening for an overnight rest on his New England cruise with his sons.

A rise in the suicide rate does not always accompany an economic depression, although in 1930 and 1931 the male rate rose sharply and the female one slightly in New York City, according to the current Health Department "Weekly Bulletin, which presents the city's suicide statistics for 1900 to 1931 inclusive.
COMMERCIAL PAFEE. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Following announcement last Saturday by Deputy Public Welfare Commissioner James W. Kelly that he would bar any attempt to sell tickets here for the benefit of the Bonus Expeditionary Force in Washington, Ernest M. High, representing himself as an official of the Universal Production Company of 489 Fifth Avenue, called yesterday at Mr. Kelly's office and argued for permission to stage the performance.

MADRID, July 11. -- Alejandro Lerroux, at a meeting today, told an audience what he will do "when I get in power" and declared that the Azana Government had failed. The speech has reacted strongly in political circles in the Capital and, although the fall of the government may not be considered imminent, the number of persons predicting its early collapse is increasing.
Captain Bill Fagen, aboard the Alibi, returned to Montauk on Sunday night with another broadbill swordfish, the third taken on rod and reel from this boat thus far this season.

PARIS, July 11. -- The publication in the United States of what is described as an "inaccurate version" of the gentlemen's agreement made at Lausanne has caused some uneasiness here in regard to the effect that may be produced on American opinion.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Federal Reserve Bank's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on July 6 shows decreases for the week of $222,000,000 in loans and investments, $126,000,000 in net demand deposits, $139,000,000 in government deposits and $74,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and an increase of $30,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

Testimony purporting to show that the Pennsylvania Company, a holding company of the Pennsylvania Railroad, guaranteed a loan of $1,000,000 for the Federated Fruit and Vegetable Growers, Inc., and subsequently made good the loan when the corporation failed for 52,000,000 was introduced yesterday into the Interstate Commerce Commission hearing at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 11. -- After deliberating for three hours and fifteen minutes on the death early last Wednesday morning of Z. Smith Reynolds, 20-year-old husband of the former Libby Holman, Broadway musical comedy star, a coroner's jury returned a verdict at 11:45 o'clock tonight that young Reynolds met his death "from a bullet wound inflicted by a party or parties unknown."

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A commission headed by Lieut. Col. Joseph I. McMullen of the Judge Advocate General's Department of the Army will sail for London from New York next Monday to adjust claims of British inventors for use of their devices by the United States during the World War.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The text of the special message of President Hoover vetoing the $2,100,000,000 Wagner-Garner unemployment relief bin follows:

OTTAWA, Ont., July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Official announcement of the provisional agenda for the imperial economic conference was made tonight by Prime Minister R.B. Bennett. Tariff and trade matters and monetary and financial questions, broadly speaking, will constitute the program of empire discussions opening in Ottawa on July 21.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City who as leader of the Smith forces at the Democratic National Convention declared that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, if nominated for President, could not carry New Jersey, last night pledged his support to Mr. Roosevelt's election in a formal statement at a meeting of more than 600 members of the Hudson County Democratic Committee, held at the Grotto Auditorium in Jersey City.

BUENOS AIRES, July 11. -- Conflicting and highly censored news reaching here tonight from Southern Brazil indicates the Sau Paulo revolt is more serious than is admitted in the Rio de Janeiro Government's official statements.

A woman skipper, Mrs. Joyce Borden Balokovic, the wife of Zlatko Balokovic, Croatian violinist, brought her two - masted schooner yacht Northern Light neatly through the swirling tides of the East River yesterday afternoon, ending a 35,000-mile world cruise which started from San Francisco in, April, 1931.

Consolidated net profit of the Crown Willamette Paper Company, a division of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, amounted to $2,233,926 for the fiscal year ended on April 30, comparing with $1,893,630 for the preceding year. The profit includes earnings of Pacific Mills, Ltd., after deducting proportionate interest of minority stockholders.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 11. -- Another monolith, about five feet high, has been discovered at Tiahuanaco by the Wendell Bennett-John C. Phillips archaeological expedition for the American Museum of Natural History of New York. Although smaller than the others unearthed, this monolith is characterized by exceptional artistry.

KEWANEE, Ill., July 11 (AP). -- E. E. Robinson of Kewanee, general supervisor of the Illinois Power and Light Corporation, has received word of his appointment by Hugh L. Cooper of New York, engineer, to go to Russia for work on the new hydroelectric development on the Dnieper River in Ukrainia.

TRENTON, N.J., July 11. -- The State Highway Commission appealed today to officials of Fort Lee to enact zoning ordinances which would prevent advertisers from placing billboards near the approaches to the George Washington Bridge.

As it came to him, after eight weeks' tug-and-pull between the Senate and the House, the Federal relief bill which Mr. HOOVER vetoed yesterday had three main purposes. It provided for loans up to $300,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to State Governments for direct relief of distress.
BOSTON, July 11. -- The text of the speech of Secretary Mills at Faneuil Hall tonight was as follows:

The New York Central reported yesterday for May a net loss of $3,963,796 after taxes and charges, bringing its loss for the first five months of the year to $7,983,124. The statement was regarded in financial circles as throwing light on the recent announcement of a further reduction of 5 per cent in wages on the system.

LIMA, Peru, July 11 (AP). -- Trujillo, northern city seized last week by rebels described as civilian extremists, was captured by the government today, a communique said, after a fierce attack by land, sea and air, with numerous lives list on both sides.
Budget Director Charles L. Rohler declared yesterday that he would resign if the 1933 budget did not show decrease substantially more than 15,000,000 from the current budget.

THIS country has had its Black Fridays, but Savage Sunday is something new in the calendar. July 10 was the dolorous date, and the dead and wounded are still lying about the fields. It appears to have been an almost world-wide wave of brutality.

LONDON, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Sussex defeated Worcestershire by nine wickets in a first-class cricket match concluded today at Kidderminster. Worcestershire scored 192 and 111 (Tate five for 51 and four for 49) and Sussex 191 and 113 for one wicket (Bowley 66 not out, Hoot four for 32).

LONDON, July 11. -- A bitter attack on the Lausanne settlement by Winston Churchill in the House of Commons tonight brought a statement from Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain that reassuring talks had been held between British and United States representatives during the recent conference.

PARIS, Tuesday, July 12. -- President Hoover's proposal for a one-third cut in armaments hung heavily on the Chamber of Deputies during a discussion of ways and means of balancing the budget, which Minister of the Budget Falmade admitted was in deficit for 1931-32 4,470,000,000 francs [$175,671,000].
"No more poker for Dickie," was the edict laid down at the Costen home at 129 East Ninety-seventh Street yesterday when Dickie came back from his operation.
