WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Garner-Wagner $2,100,000,000 unemployment relief bill today received its expected veto from President Hoover, but his message, instead of creating dissension in Congress, obviously cleared the way for swift passage of legislation acceptable to both Congress and the administration.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Unmatured Liberty bonds, issued in 1917 and 1918 to provide for cash advances to the Allies and for American prosecution of the World War, were outstanding in the volume of $8,201,314,550 on June 30, according to Treasury Department figures.

The money market remained at a standstill in the matter of turnover and rate changes. The easy undertone for Stock Exchange call loans continued, the quotation being continued at 2 per cent, while Street trades went on at 1 and Federal funds 1/4 @ 1/2.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Department store Sales again declined by more than the estimated seasonal amount from May to June according to figures made public by the Federal Reserve Board today.

Ross L. Freeman, who has been in charge of the United States Rubber Company's factory in Sumatra for several years, brought a miscellaneous cargo of wild animal life to New York yesterday on the Furness freighter Javanese Prince.

Reactionary tendencies in German loans, which finished the day with losses ranging up to 5 1/2 points, did not unsettle the foreign list in general on the Stock Exchange yesterday and did not prevent a forward movement in United States Government bonds and in domestic corporation issues, where the rails showed the best strength.

New York State, outside the bounds of its principal cities, probably has as good opportunities for healthful outdoor recreation as any other equally thickly populated area anywhere in the world. The Conservation Department has sought to make those opportunities ever more widely available.

Jurors in Kings, Queens and Richmond Counties, who, unwittingly, have been serving without pay in the city and State courts for the past month or so because of lack of funds for the regular Jury fees, will have their compensation assured today, when the Board of Estimate acts on a celandar item designed to provide $85,000 for the purpose.

ALBANY, July 11. -- Edward (Fats) McCarthy, Coll gang veteran and quarry in one of the most determined manhunts in the history of the New York City Police Department since he killed one detective and wounded two others there last Fall, was cornered and killed early tonight outside his hiding place on the Dorlyn Road near here.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- President Hoover today recommended a partial reorganization of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, eliminating from its board of directors Eugene Meyer, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and Paul Bestor, Farm Loan Commissioner, and increasing the membership of the board from seven to eight.

BERLIN, July 11. -- Stocks were generally weaker on the Eoerse today, while bonds were unusually firm even small buying orders sufficing to send up prices. The Young loan was up 1 per cent. The expected public interest in stocks following the Lausanne settlement failing to materialize, prices sagged under realizing sales for speculative accounts, but losses did not exceed 2 per cent.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 11. -- Society on the North Shore is lending a hand in plans for a garden dinner and dance to be given on Saturday evening by Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field at their estate, Caumsett, at Lloyds Neck, near Huntington, for the benefit of the Long Island Biological Society.

A group of paintings by six living American artists replaced yesterday the "Washington Square Show" at the Gotham Outdoor Gallery. This exhibition is the first of a series which Robert Ulrich Godsoe plans to present in hotels, bookshops, restaurants and theatre lobbies throughout New York.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Grain traders spent most of today on the Board of Trade here in evening up for the government report, which was due after the close of the market. Fluctuations were the narrowest known in a long time, being less than 1 cent a bushel in wheat, with the close 3/8 to 5/8 cent lower than on Saturday.

TOKYO, July 11. -- Count Uchida, Foreign Minister, in his first interview with foreign correspondents this afternoon declared himself hopeful that Manchukuo would attain stability and suppress banditry both of the political type financed from the outside and the kind produced by native poverty.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11. -- Resenting the invarion of westchester County's parks by residents of New York City, the Board of Supervision referrea to the Park Commission today a resolution giving preference in the use of the parks to residents of this county.

LONDON, July 11. -- The "gentlemen's agreement" at Lausanne was described in diplomatic circles here today as merely a memorandum, which was nothing more than the transcript of certain conversations held behind the scene. It is said to have no binding force on any one, for it is one of the niceties of secret diplomacy that a memorandum cannot bind Parliaments while formal secret agreements can.

MADISON, Wis., July 11. -- Dr. Carl Russell Fish, a member of the University of Wisconsin faculty for the last thirty-two years and one of the best-known teachers of American history, died last night of septic pneumonia at his home. He would have been 56 on Oct. 13.

Of the two billion people on the face of the earth, at least one billion are directly dependent upon agriculture for a living. A majority of them, according to KENYON L. BUTTERFIELD, who has become a student of rural conditions throughout the world, live close to the economic margin.

LONDON, July 11. -- The stock markets were subdued today. British Government funds were firm, but less active and the industrials mostly were easier. Courtaulds was lower on fears of a reduced dividend. Furriest-Witny was supported in the shipping section on expectations of a favorable report by the company.

In support of its contention that the Federal Government, through the State Department, has not acted in good faith toward the State of New York with respect to pending plans for the Improvement of the St. Lawrence waterway and the St. Lawrence power development, the Power Authority made public yesterday an unanswered letter addressed to Secretary of State Stimson on June 8, 1932.

Records of banking transactions of the Kreuger Toll Company with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company were made yesterday part of the record in the proceedings in which Henry K. Davis of 140 Nassau Street is sitting as a special master.

A repetition of last Summer's serious outbreak of poliomyelitis, or infantile paralysis, is unlikely this year in the opinion of Dr. William H. Park, director of the bureau of laboratories of the Department of Health, who said yesterday he did not expect a severe recurrence of tho disease here for another five or ten years.

Representatives of national, State and-local industrial and trade associations met yesterday in executive session at the Waldorf-Astoria in a conference called by the National Association of Manufacturers to discuss "extravagance in Federal costs and the failure of the national legislators to readjust the government's budget to a level conformable with general business."

BIOOMFIELD, N.J., July 11. -- Craig Wood, Hollywood Golf Club professional, and his assistant, Dick Metz, former Texan, who is spending his first year in the New York district, tied at 71 for low individual score in a one-day tournament of the New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association over the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

The biggest European contingent to reach these shores en route to the Olympic Games at Los Angeles arrived yesterday, when the Italia team, numbering 106 athletes and 26 officials and coaches, disembarked from the S.S. Conte Biancamano.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 11. -- Mrs. John H. Prentice was a dinner hostess at Belmead tonight.

PITTSBURGH, July 11. -- Fred Heimach suffered his first defeat of the season and the Dodgers their second of the current series with the Pirates today, much to the delight of 2,500 youngsters who attended as guests of the management and shrilled approval of their heroes throughout the contest.

Ignacio Nogueira, Brazilian Davis Cup captain, advanced to the quarterfinal round of the annual Richmond County open clay championship court tournament by eliminating Stanley W. Povey of Brooklyn, seeded fifth on the American list, 3-6, 7-5, 7-5, on the Clifton Tennis Club's courts at Arrochar, S.I., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A temporary currency expansion of nearly $1,000,000,000 was approved by a vote of 53 to 18 this afternoon in the Senate. A few hours later It was voted, 50 to 25, to bury the Bingham beer proposal in the Judiciary Committee.

There is an even chance that Hope Montana, one of two pumas born yesterday at the Central Park Zoo, will live. Twice before babies have been born to the puma couple, but each time they killed their offspring. Zoologists believe pumas don't think much of zoo life and don't want it inflicted on their infants.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11 (AP). -- Jersey City evened the series with Rochester by winning the second game, 12 to 6, today.

Dr. Getulio Vargas, Liberal, became Provisional President of Brazil on Oct. 30, 1930, after the triumph of the revolution which began on Oct. 3, 1930, under his leadership and that of Oswaldo Aranho. There were several engagements in which hundreds of Federal and rebel troops were killed.
TORONTO, July 11 (AP). -- Don Brennan held the Toronto Maple Leafs to four hits, struck out nine batsmen, passed only one, and Newark won the opening game of the series, 5-1, today.

LONDON, July 11 (AP). -- Winston Churchill told the House of Commons tonight that, knowing American public opinion thoroughly, he was convinced that "no more unfortunate approach toward debt can- cellation could have been made than the procedure adopted at Lausanne."

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP). -- Marooned, a 2-year-old colt owned by Leo J. Marks of Lexington, Ky., staged a brilliant stretch run to win the Wilmette Purse, $2,500 feature today at Arlington Park. Marooned beat Cap-sheaf by five lengths with Liqueur third.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- With aggregates of 69 out of a possible 70, two crack English marksmen. Armorer Sergeant French of the Hertfordshire Regiment and Sergeant Bolton of the tank corps, today earned the right to shoot off for the bronze cross for leadership in the first stage of the St. George's Challenge Vase shoot.

Details of the new French superliner, T-6, now building at Saint Nazaire, France, were received yesterday by cable at offices of the French Line, 17 State Street, announcing that the liner, the largest ever built, would slide down the ways on Oct. 29, and be commissioned for service early in 1934.

Reluctance of the Soviet oil interests to participate in another international oil conference, such as that which is being held in Paris, has made necessary the changing of the program of the international oil companies in their attempt to stabilize the oil markets outside the United States.

We pick up the telephone and ask for a number in Piccadilly. Fifteen minutes later the operator announces: "All ready for London." Talking through the ether over the sea is still so novel that it is a Historical event for most of us. What if there is sometimes a grinding, hissing and sputtering which tells of electrical disturbances far out at sea, and what if service is now and then interrupted?

BOSTON, July 11. -- Political uncertainty, biennially in greater or lesser degree a deterrent to forward-looking business planning, and intensified in Presidential years, is now the chief deterrent to better trade conditions in this country, Harvey S. Firestone, the tire manufacturer, said here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11. -- A.A. Chapman issued a statement tonight througrh his attorney, Lawrence Hickman, denying Mr. Ainey's assertion that Chapman had tried to "sell" his story to Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company officials for $50.000 and later reduced his price to $20.000.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP). -- The Indians gave the Athletics' hopes of gaining on the Yankees a severe jolt today when they took both ends of a double-header, 9 to 8, and 12 to 7.

BERLIN, July 11. -- Reports from Paris and London that Germany's major creditor powers had concluded a so-called "gentlemen's agreement" which would definitely nullify the Lausanne accord if the United States refused adequate revision of the allied debts were met in official quarters with the statement that no such agreement had been brought to the attention, of Germany at Lausanne, nor did she at any time identify herself with such a line of thought.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A telegram of sympathy from President Hoover to President Lebrun of France on the disaster to the submarine Promethee was made public by the State Department today as follows:
BALTIMORE, July 11. -- Henry L. Hobby, sportsman, died last night in a hospital here at the age of 46. He underwent an appendix operation about two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- Representative Mary T. Norton, who strongly seconded Alfred E, Smith for the Presidency and who might have had 190 votes herself as Vice President, returned to Congress today a Roosevelt-Garner campaigner.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., July 11. -- Play opened today in the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club's annual invitation July tournament, and Jerome Lang, last ypar's winner, easily disposed of Dr. Frank K. Meeske, 6-1, 6-0, in his first-round match.

Plans of the Board of Transportation for recapture of the Culver line of the B.M.T. and its connection with the city's new transit system to make possible a five-cent ride from Spuyten Duyvil to Coney Island have been virtually completed, it was indicated yesterday.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., July 11 (AP). -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's Presidential campaign will begin next Sunday in New Hampshire, where his drive for the Democratic nomination first received the backing of the voters of his party.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers made it two out of three in their present five-game series with the Red Sox by scoring a 5-to-3 victory today behind smart pitching on the part of George Uhle, Jablonowski, Boston starting pitcher, was replaced by Moore with none out in the sixth.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 11. -- Philip Mostrom, manager of Sound Airways, and Philip S. Powell, a New Bedford undertaker, were drowned, and Commander A.W.S. Agar of the British warship Scarborough, which has been visiting in this port, is at St. Luke's Hospital, on the danger list, following a plane crash in the harbor early this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A Congressional investigation of the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board would seriously disturb the confidence and faith of the American public at this time, despite the fact that neither unit of the Federal Government has nothing to hide, and would, result in no ultimate good, two ranking members of these organizations told the House Rules Committee today.

New York City borrowed yesterday an additional $6,000,000 from the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank. This was the last instalment under the $25,000,000 credit which it obtained from these banks under a tentative arrangement last April.

BOSTON, July 11. -- Opening the Republican Presidential campaign here tonight, Ogden L. Mills charged that Franklin D. Roosevelt had no program to meet the present economic situation and that his acceptance speech as Democratic nominee could not stand "the acid test of careful analysis."

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP). -- Huck Betts and his Braves' mates stopped the Cub winning streak at five straight today, 8 to 2, and shoved the Chicago entry in the heated National League flag race two and one-half games behind the pace-setting Pirates.
A popular victory was scored at Empire City yesterday when Earl Sande got home first with Concord, owned by Mrs. Al Jolson, in the fourth race, which had the place of honor on the card.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Lausanne is the complement of Locarno. The economic agreements of the former make more secure the political agreements of the latter. That clearly Is the deep meaning of this great news of the settlement of reparations.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 11. -- Seventeen players, including all of the eight in the seeded list, were left after the opening day's play in the fortieth annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament on the Long-wood Cricket Club courts today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 11. -- In the face of denials by William D.B. Ainey, chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, that he had received $150,000 from the late Thomas E. Mitten, Philadelphia transit operator, Governor Pinchot tonight ordered Attorney General Schnader to make an investigation of graft charges preferred against Mr. Ainey by A.A. Chapman, who was Mr. Mitten's confidential banking secretary for several years.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Henry Herman Harjes of Paris and her sons, the Messrs. Harjes, have returned to the Pierre after a visit with J. Pierpont Morgan in Glen Cove. They will leave today for Boston and later go to Bar BC Ranch in Wyoming.

Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, head of the Women's Organization of National Prohibition Reform, linked Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills yesterday with the statement issued Sunday night by sixty-four Republican women, in which they declared they would support President Hoover even though the executive committee of the organization of which they are members had endorsed Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The cost of administering prohibition in New York State during the fiscal year ended June 30 exceeded the money collected in fines or obtained from the sale of seized cars, it was indicated yesterday in figures made public by Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator.

TOLEDO, July 11 (AP). -- Hollyrood Dennis trotted to a decisive victory in the Peninsular Farm stake for 3-year-old trotters at the Fort Miami track tonight in the feature event of Toledo's opening program of a two-week Grand Circuit harness race meeting.

The paintings and art objects owned by the late Lizzie P. Bliss, art patron and daughter of President McKinley's Secretary of the Interior, were valued at more than $1,100,000 yesterday in the transfer tax appraisal filed with Deputy State Tax Commissioner Maurice A. Stephenson.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 11. -- A meeting of the Ladies' Village Improvement Society was held at the Dune residence of Mrs. Robert Appleton today, with Mrs. Clifford H. McCall presiding. After the business meeting tea was served. Mrs. Norman W. Barnes and Mrs. Nathan H. Dayton poured.

There may be such a place as Bermuda, but you can't prove it by the crew of the good ship Curlew. The Curlew came home from the seas yesterday after finding the briny deep a region curiously complicated by politics, restless waves, the vagaries of nature and other unkind things.

Still smarting under the sting of the two defeats that had been heaped upon them Sunday, the Yankees made swift reprisal on the Browns at the Stadium yesterday by flailing two of Bill Killefer's pitchers for a total of fifteen hits, including a pair of homers by Joey Sewell and Arndt Jorgens, to romp off with the game by a score of 15 to 4.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 11. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia scored a 79 today to win the medal in the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament for the Griswold Trophy at the Shenecossett Country Club.

DETROIT, July 11. -- The City Council was informed today that if outstanding notes were to be renewed by New York and Detroit banks it must adopt Mayor Murphy's plan for budget cuts totaling $7,000,000 and put into force the five-day week for city employes.

DUBLIN, July 11 -- President Eamon de Valera rescinded this afternoon his ban on the publication of letters from Governor General James McNeill complaining of the "discourtesy" of Free State Ministers -- letters that are expected to throw Ireland tomorrow into another turmoil.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- Police today guarded members of the bonus army who applied at the Veterans Administration for train fare home.

Jacob Lieberman went home to Yonkers yesterday noon to start, at the age of 87 years, to relearn his trade as cabinet maker, dropped twenty years ago when blindness overcame him. "Home" to him is the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, at St. Johns and Crotty Avenues, Yonkers.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11. -- The "negative" policies of President Hoover were criticized by Paul Mazur, investment banker of New York, and defended by M.C. Rorty, also of New York, who is the statistician of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in discussions of unemployment and economic recovery which opened today at the University of Virginia.

Store-door delivery and pick-up of freight in the metropolitan district will be started by all railroads serving New York City and its environs on Sept. 15. Announcement of the new service was made at a conference of carriers and shippers yesterday afternoon in the Y.M.C.A. auditorium of the Pennsylvania Station.

Irma Duncan and her group of Isadora Duncan Dancers will present their program at the Lewlsohn Stadium tomorrow evening on a platform which has been built and extended into the field so that they will be visible from every angle of the great amphitheatre.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 11. -- Individual and company prizes and trophies in citizenship, military profioieney and athletics, which will be awarded at the close of the citizens' military training camp, supervised by Colonel George A. Herbst, commander of Plattsburg barracks, were announced today by Captain Ralph B. Watkins, the post adjutant.

Why anybody should wish to turn on campaign oratory so soon and in such weather remains a mystery. But if anybody had to do it Secretary MILLS was indicated for the job. He is a vigorous and effective speaker, with a good command of his material, and not without humor.

The Lambs, who never even had a "Ladies' Day" at their home in New York, set aside an old tradition yesterday to admit the presence of Lois Moran, stage star, who became the first woman ever to pass the portals of the famous club.

A man to be accounted a hero by some of us has sent to the bookman of The Manchester Guardian Weekly a list of books which he and his wife have read aloud to one another during the last ten years. His wife must be a heroine, too. There is pleasure in talking over a book with a friend who has read it.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11. -- Six guest conductors, including Walter Damrosch, will direct concerts of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra during the 1932-33 season, Simon N. Stein, president of the Rochester Civic Music Association, announced today.

If the United States does not win the 110-meter hurdles event at Los Angeles, form charts have not the slightest value. It seems inconceivable that an American will not snap the tape first in this event, past performances even going so far as to make a one-two-three procession by wearers of the shield a certainty.

BERLIN, July 12. -- Many eyes are turned toward Neudeck in East Prussia, where President von Hindenburg is now vacationing and whither Chancellor von Papen and Baron von Gayl, Minister of the Interior, will repair tomorrow. The Chancellor will report on the Lausanne conference, but what more engrosses public attention is that the head of the Interior Ministry is going along, for the internal party warfare is urgently demanding some check.

LONDON, July 12. -- The stock markets showed signs of recovery in late trading today. Early losses in British Government funds were overcome and most of the declines among the industrials also were canceled, although the textiles and cables and wireless remained outstandingly weak on profit taking.

Colleges throughout the country have developed an "institutional inertia, a 'take it or leave it' attitude" in the presentation of their curricula. Dr. E.H. Wilkens, president of Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio, asserted yesterday in an address to the Columbia Summer sessions students in the Horace Mann auditorium of Teachers College.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Detectives today frustrated a $50,000 kidnapping plot directed against the 2-year-old daughter of Jack Durand, foster son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Durand of Lake Bluff, a Chicago suburb. They arrested two alleged members of the gang at Mrs. Durand's Crab Tree Farm.
VENICE, Italy, July 2 (by Mail). -- Venice has just had to make one of the most delicate decisions in her history, what to do when the automobile reaches the city of lagoons.

The Attorney General's office was asked yesterday to start an immediate investigation into alleged racketeering in the cleaning and dyeing industry and into the activities of the Metropolitan Trade Association of Master Cleaners and Dyers.

PARIS, July 12. -- The International Electrical Congress closed today. It meets twice in a century. The last meeting was held in Paris in 1881. This meeting was to have been held in 1931 but was a year late. The next meeting will be held in 1981, probably in Paris.

Louis Bringmann was busy yesterday buying a new suit and carefully shining his worn shoes. Over in Tin Mountain, along the Red Hook waterfront of Brooklyn and in all the jungles of the unemployed where bitter men with hopeless faces loiter, blue-coated policemen had searched for him ever since the tragedy of his eviction from his cardboard fire-escape "home" had turned into a somewhat paradoxical drama of regeneration.
Esttimating With Ease The United States Sen ate has produced many extraordinary statistclans, tossing figures about with delightful abandon. One of the chief "estimators" is Senator BROOKHART.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 12. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia, Miss Edith Quier of Reading, Pa.; Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd of Philadelphia and Mrs. Leo Federman of Flushing, L.I., four of the outstanding stars in the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Country Club, all advanced into the second round of match play today.

The storm which centred about the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform after its endorsement of the Roosevelt-Garner ticket appeared to have died down yesterday. No more Republican members resigned from the organization, as many had done on Sunday and Monday because they refused to support the Democratic candidates.
LONDON. July 12. -- Passages dealing with the United States from Prime Minister MacDonald's speech in 1he House of Commons today follow:

LONDON, July 12 (AP). -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in June are as follows Exports of British products, u29,720,000; re-exports, foreign goods, u4,170,000; total exports, u33,890,000; imports. u57,510,000; excess of imports, u23.620.000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Beyond question, radio has the opportunity and the ability to be the greatest and best educational institution in the United States. Literally, from the cradle to the grave we listen in, expecting and hoping that we shall be instructed as well as entertained by our teachers, the announcers.

The demands upon the Salvation Army Nursery and Infants' Hospital, 396 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, are now greater than ever in the institution's history, according to a report of the Department of Public Welfare made public yesterday by the Salvation Army.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 12. -- W.W. Waters, Commander-in-chief of the Bonus Expeditionary Forces, after a day spent in seeking funds in this city so that the veterans encamped outside of Washington might not miss tonight's meal, boarded a plane with his wife and $96 at 5:40 P.M. to return to the National Capital.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 12. -- Bankruptcy threatens the city of Long Beach, one of Long Island's most popular Summer resorts, it became known here today.
Pairings and starting times were announced yesterday for the metropolitan open golf championship, which starts tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP). -- Putting on a two-run rally in the ninth inning today, the Indians captured their third straight game from the Athletics, 7 to 6. A home run by Eddie Morgan tied the score, and successive doubles by Sewell and Cissell gave Cleveland the deciding run in the final round.

John J. Robinson made it two in a row in the Frivolity Claiming Stakes, feature at Empire City yesterday, when his Little Lad was first at the end of the five and one-half furlongs, duplicating the feat of Mr. Robinson's Renaissance in the stake last year.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 12 (AP). -- Peace overtures were made to rebels holding the State of Sao Paulo tonight as Provisional President Getulio Vargas ordered seven States of Brazil to lay down their arms.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 12. -- The Rajah of Kolapore's Imperial Challenge Cup, one of the two historic and highly valued team trophies of the National Rifle Association, was captured for Canada today by a team of eight picked marksmen.
OSLO, July 12 (AP). -- The government decided today to occupy a strip of Southeastern Greenland two miles wide between 60:30 degrees and 60:40 degrees N.L.

After a wild session in which the chairman was overruled, the views of a former national commander were voted down and fist-fights threatened, the fourteenth annual convention of the New York County Organization of the American Legion, representing ninety-five posts with a membership of more than 11,000, went on record in favor of immediate payment of the soldiers' adjusted service certificates.

Whenever a group of responsible financial experts has pronounced this year on the merits of the gold standard, as against " bimetalism," " managed currencies," or other devices, it has declared for world-wide gold resumption. The latest and most emphatic of these statements was Monday's unanimous resolution by the Bank for International Settlements.

MUKDEN, July 12. -- The new Manchukuo Government is indignant because the world powers continue to take up all diplomatic entanglements in Manchuria through Japanese Consulates, ignoring the Changchun Government. Diplomatically phrasing his indignation, the Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs today sent a telegram to Senior Consul Hanson at Harbin as follows:

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 12. -- With the collapse of federal authority in the State of Sao Paulo, the revolutionary movement inaugurated Sunday emerged today as an attempt to seize control of the entire nation, rather than to set up a separatist government.

OTTAWA, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- Scoring 369 runs for the loss of seven wickets, the touring Australian cricketers easily defeated a team from the Ottawa Valley Cricket Council in their second one-day match today. The local players were able to make only 82 runs with eighteen men batting.

Prime Minister MACDONALD in the House of Commons yesterday made short work of the charge that France and England, Belgium and Italy, had entered into a secret and sinister plot to undo the Lausanne agreement. He was able to point out that their attitude had been publicly made known throughout the whole negotiations.
To the Editor at The New York Times: The letter of Arthur Ross published in THE TIMES today seems to strike the right chord.

The New York Central is putting into effect a plan for reduced days of work or for lay-offs which will affect 14,000 clerical employes. The five-day week will be offered wherever possible to unorganized employes as an alternative to a 13 per cent reduction in working forces.

Plans for promoting the wider use of trade acceptances as a substitute for open book accounts, whereby it is hoped to bring about an expansion of bank credit, were advanced yesterday by the appointment of a local and a national committee to cam- paign for the proposal.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., July 12. -- Proving himself as capable outdoors as indoors, George Spitz, New York Athletic Club high jumper, cleared the bar set at 6 feet 8 inches today in his first high jumping workout preparatory to the final Olympic trials Friday and Saturday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 12 (AP). -- Another record was broken at Fort Miami tonight as Rose Marie Abbe, in winning the second heat of The Toledo Times's seventeen pace, feature of the second evening's Grand Circuit program, stepped the mile in 2:01.

With Los Angeles as their destination, ninety-one members of the French Olympic delegation, including sixty-four athletes and twenty-seven officials, coaches and trainers, arrived in New York yesterday aboare the M.S. Lafayette. Contestants in eleven sports make up the French group, which was met at the pier by Count Charles de Fontnouville, French Consul General in New York.

Details of the plan announced in May by the Young committee of bankers and industrialists whereby arrangements were made for a group of New York banks to supply funds to be used by the saving's and loan associations of New York State in refinancing maturing mortgages of small home owners have been completed, it was announced yesterday by David B. Hutton, managing director of the Savings and Loan Bank of the State of New York.
Small housing properties comprised practically the entire realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 12 (AP). -- The Examiner in a copyrighted article tonight said that "amazing charges of petty graft and charity racketeering in Aimee Semple McPherson Hutton's Angelus Temple will be presented to the City Social Service Commission at the City Hall tomorrow."

The reptile house at the New York Zoological Park in the Bronx was the scene of a reception late yesterday in honor of two king cobras, a score of pythons, mangrove snakes and other serpents arriving from Sumatra. Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator, and Head Keeper John Toomey officiated at the formal presntation of the cobras to the other 250 squirming sinuous occupants of the big glass cases.

BELFAST, July 12. -- Ulster Orangemen today celebrated the 242d anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne by demonstrations in various parts of the province. The largest was at Belfast, where nearly 50,000 Orangemen marched to Finaghy Park along a five-mile route from the centre of the city lined with thousands of spectators.

The two final volumes of the revised edition of Everyman's Encyclopedia, the original edition of which has been out of print, have been issued here by E.P. Dutton Co. This twelve-volume reference work, enlarged and brought up to date, is a part of the Everyman Library.

Spurred by efforts of an outside group to gain control of the organization, the directors of the Phoenix Securities Corporation are asking stockholders to establish a ten-year voting trust to keep the investment trust under its present management.

Protracted negotiations between the city and St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Duane Street over the transfer of land owned by both parties were closed yesterday when the Sinking Fund Commission voted to transfer a city parcel to the church in exchange for church property located in the bed of new City Hall Place.

Stockholders and former directors of the Bank of United States have subscribed more than $6,200,000 of the $8,000,000 required under the plan sponsored by Samuel Untermyer for the formation of a Liquidation Corporation to take over and distribute the assets of the closed bank, it was announced yesterday.

Scoring an 80, one over women's par, Mrs. Henry March of the North Shore Country Club led a field of ninety-five women in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Old Country Club course in Flushing yesterday.

LONDON, July 12. -- The memory of George Washington was honored in London tonight at a brilliant Pilgrims dinner at which Winston Churchill for Britain and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler for the United States praised him as one of the glories of the English-speaking race.

The solution of the problem of rapid transit unification seemed as far distant as ever at the close yesterday of a two-hour conference at City Hall, in which the Transit Commission, Board of Estimate, Board of Transportation and spokesmen of various bond and stockholding groups of the B.M.T. and Interborough sought to find a common ground for agreement.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 12 (AP). -- The Grand Lodge of Elks in annual meeting here today elected Floyd E. Thompson of Chicago Grand Exalted Ruler and chose Milwaukee for the 1933 convention.

In the opinion of The Chapel Hill Weekly, that sprightly journal of unconcealed opinion published within the shadow of the University of North Carolina, a companion issue to prohibition was responsible for the defeat of Senator MORRISON by over 100,000 majority.

SHANGHAI, July 12. -- The longenduring state of civil warfare existing between the two Cantonese factions was terminated favorably for General Chen Chia-tang, the military commander holding Canton, today.
PRAGUE, July 12. -- Thomas Bata, the shoe king of Czechoslovakia, was killed at 6:30 this morning immediately after having left his private airport at Zlin to fly to Switzerland.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Appointment of an equity receiver for the Associated Telephone and Telegraph Company was asked in a bill filed in the Federal District Court here today on behalf of Claude H. Dunlap of Kansas City, who alleged mismanagement.

Thomas Bata, the man who was known, as "Europe's Henry Ford" and "the Flying Shoemaker," was the son of an obscure cobbler, who taught him the rudiments of shoemaking by hand. He was born at Zlin, Moravia, then a hamlet, now called the Detroit of Czechoslovakia, in 1876, and went to work for his father in his early 'teens.

DUBLIN, July 12. -- President Eamon de Valera told questioners in the Dail today that in the event of an agreement being reached in the recess regarding the composition of an arbitration tribunal to settle the financial dispute with the British both the Dail and the Senate would be summoned to obtain the necessary approval.
BOSTON, July 12. -- Professor Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School has declined to accept an appointment to a place on the State supreme bench, succeeding Judge George A. Sanderson.
MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., July 12. -- Singles play advanced to the third round today in the annual invitation tournament of the Mohonk Lake Tennis Club.

Two trophies have been offered for the best batting and bowling performances against the Australian cricketers, expected to arrive here from Ottawa tonight, and will be awarded to the members of the two teams representing the West Indian Cricketers of New York who distinguish themselves against the famous tourists.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 12. -- Fifteen persons, mostly women and children, were rescued this afternoon from the sailboat Cinco when it struck a submerged piling off Longport Inlet and began to sink. The excited passengers were picked up by the thirty-foot power boat Spirit of Ocean City II, which was cruising near by.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Leaders of both parties in the Senate blocked an effort by Senator Bingham today to reintroduce discussion of a beer bill and postponed consideration of a resolution he offered calling on Surgeon General Cumming of the Public Health Service to ascertain and report how much alcohol a non-intoxicating drink could contain.

DON BRADMAN, the Wild Man of the Wicket, famous from the lonely coast of New South Wales to Piccadilly Circus and back again, is to lead his Australian cohort of cricketers into town this evening from a northerly direction. Within the next week we will have big-time cricket on the hearth, or words to that effect.

Plans for reforms within and without the railroad industry will be laid before the advisory committee and the general membership of the Association of Railway Executives at meetings to be held here next Tuesday and Wednesday. The twofold plan will provide for a declaration of policy in respect to regulation of competitive forms of transportation.

If the motion picture industry and the theatre are to survive the present depression, they must give to the public "fine, wholesome, clean entertainment, beautifully done," S.L. Rothafel (Roxy) asserted yesterday afternoon in an address to Columbia University Summer Session students at the McMillin Academic Theatre.

LATONIA, Ky., July 12 (AP). -- The Dixiana's Spartan Lady showed a smart performance today to account for the Tiger Lily Purse, feature offering at Latonia. F.C. McAtee's Billies Orphan finished second and the Audley Farm's Codetta third. Billies Orphan cut out the early pace and Codetta was closest in attendance to the far turn.

A large glass mosaic will be executed on the walls of the loggia at the western entrance of the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Centre as one of the most important units in the decorative scheme for the $250,000,000 office and amusement project, the developers announced yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Kellogg are returning on the Leviathan and will be at the Ritz-Carlton.

VIENNA, July 12. -- Fashionable Vienna crowded today into a court hearing the cases of two members of the Viennese aristocracy and two club servants charged with cheating at baccarat and chemin de fer at two of the smartest of Vienna clubs. The titled defendants are Baron Otto Guttman and Baron Henry Menasse.

GEORGE FRED WILLIAMS has gone at 80. He was a strong and salient character, touched in politics with a kind of romanticism which his puzzled opponents called instability. He had almost every gift that should command success. His presence was dignified and distinguished.

The protective committee for holders of bonds of the city of Coral Gables, Fla., announced yesterday that it had approved a plan for the refinancing of approximately 50,000,000 of the city's funded and floating debt, representing the work of a year and a half by the committee.

The Italian Olympic team, on its second day in New York, received an official greeting from Mayor Walker at City Hall. The team, which arrived in this city on Monday aboard the S.S. Conte Biancamano, met the Mayor in the large room opposite his office at 3:15 yesterday afternoon, following a luncheon at which the European athletes were the guests of Generoso Pope, New York contractor and publisher.
FOR the fourth consecutive day excellent weather prevailed yesterday throughout the South, and prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved lower again, closing with losses of 14 to 15 points.
MONTREAL, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- The Montreal Royals made it three straight over the Baltimore Orioles today, winning 5 -- 4 in a thrilling finish. The losers dropped to third place.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Charging that the "consultative pact" plank in the Republican platform was inserted by Secretary Stimson in "a surreptitious attempt to have the United States join to meet the demands of France, thereby hopelessly involving the United States in the political affairs of Europe."

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,152,550 barrels, compared with 2,104,800 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 47,750 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Rises of 37,150 barrels in the average daily of Oklahoma and 14,650 barrels in that of California were the most important changes for the week.

Stocks lost ground negligibly yesterday in a market that was almost a duplicate of the slow, draggy affair of the day before. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was about 700,000 shares; the price of fifty selected stocks averaged 17 cents net lower at the close than at the end of the day before, after the usual calculations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12. -- The pressing problem of unemployment and unemployment relief was tackled today as soon as the first session of the semi-annual meeting of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor got under way.

There are approximately a million children in the city of New York between the ages of 4 and 16, at least half of whom, it is estimated, depend upon public playgrounds for recreation. For only 200,000 is provision now made by the combined contributions of the city and private givers.

The animal kingdom, it appears, was swept by a great wave of emotion when the fourth ballot was taken at the Democratic National Convention and Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt was pronounced the party nominee for President of the United States.

Captain Henry L. Stevens Jr. of Chattanooga, Tenn., national commander of the American Legion, returned yesterday on the motorship Lafayette of he French Line, after visiting France, Belgium and England. He was the guest of King Albert in Brussels and was entertained in Paris by President Le Brun, head of the French Republic.
CHICAGO, July 12. -- War to the finish against tax dodgers was declared today by Chicago's impoverished and embattled army of school teachers.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Requests of domestic sugar refining interests for an increase in import duty on refined sugar from Cuba were rejected by the Tariff Commission in a decision made public today. It held that Cuban and American refining costs were not of sufficient difference as to warrant a change in duty at this time.
CHICAGO, July 12. -- The Republican campaign to re-elect President Hoover this Fall will be so conducted by party leaders that he will be left unhampered to perform his White House duties.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12. -- The United States Army polo team, which is preparing for the national junior championship tournament which starts Saturday at Rumson, and the Sands Point team rode through to the final of the Meadow Brook Club Cups tournament today at the Meadow Brook Club.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP). -- George D. Widener's Evening, held as a powerful contender for the $70,000 added Arlington classic to be run Saturday, wound up ninth in a ten-horse field today as S.W. Labrot's Springsteel won the featured $2,500 added Sheridan Stakes at Arlington Park.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Fire, believed to have been of incendiary origin, broke out in the basement of the furniture shop in Stateville (Ill.) Penitentiary today and sent dense clouds of smoke rolling over the prison walls. Firemen from Joliet assisted the prison department in extinguishing the blaze, which caused $3,000 damage.
TORONTO, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- The Newark Bears extended the Leafs' losing streak to seven straight games by winning both ends of today's double-header, 4 to 1 and 4 to 2.
LOS ANGELES, July 12. -- Amelia Earhart, transatlantic filer, took off from the Municipal Airport at 5:11:25 M. (New York Daylight Time) today on an attempted non-stop flight to Newark.

Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney, on his return yesterday from Albany, announced that Detectives Harold Moore and Thomas Riggs would receive promotions for their part in the killing of Edward (Fats) McCarthy, Coll gang desperado, and the capture of two of his confederates.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP). -- Pat Malone, who failed to get a man out in the first inning yesterday, redeemed himself today by outpitching two Boston hurlers and starting the rally that accounted for a 4-to-3 victory for the Cubs.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Large local packers became aggressive today in the hog market here when prices received the first serious setback recorded in thirty-four days ending one of the longest uninterrupted advances on record. The top fell 15 cents a hundredweight to $5.40, while the average was off 10 cents at $4.90.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The bill authorizing the Treasury Department to appraise and negotiate for a Grand Central postoffice site in New York City was signed this afternoon by President Hoover. He stated that the act is not a commitment by the government to purchase the building.

Fred Kohler, former Mayor of Cleveland, will arrive today from Europe on the French liner Paris. Mr. Kohler left here on the French liner Champlain, but suffered a stroke of paralysis and was transferred to the Paris at Plymouth for the return voyage.

Alfred J. Neve, former president of the Neve Drug Stores, Inc., which went into bankruptcy in 1930, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday for $41,000 damages against United States Marshal Raymond J. Mulligan and the Irving Trust Company, trustees in bankruptcy for the drug store company.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 12. -- Favorites went down like ten pins in the second match play round of the second annual New York State junlors championship at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

BERLIN, July 12. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's eagerly awaited speech in the House of Commons, which it had been honed would clear up what the "gentlemen's agreement" amounted to, leaves German political opinion unsatisfied on that score.

Pending an agreement among the various protective committees on acceptable terms, the overtures being made for the acquisition of the Richfield Oil Company of California, now in receivership, are being held more or less in abeyance. The offer of the Consolidated Oil Corporation is understood to be the only definite one that has been made.

PITTSBURGH, July 12. -- Losing the services of Lloyd Waner in the first inning and those of his brother Paul in the fifth, the league-leading pirates overcame the handicap of their scrambled line-up, battled the Dodgers to a standstill today and triumphed in the twelfth inning of the final game of the series, 8 to 7.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Campaign issues for 1932, in so far as the politicians can make them, have begun to take on definite outlines, particularly since Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills set up his easel in Boston Monday night.

Helping hands grabbed at Otto Griesel, 28 years old, of 821 Kast 173d Street, the Bronx, last night when the 6 o'clock rush-hour crowd on the uptown platform of the Bowling Green I.R.T. subway station, surging into position for the customary onslaught into the entrances of an arriving train, pushed him into the eighteen-inch space between the train and the platform.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 12. -- Surrogate George A. Slater signed today a final decree disposing of an accounting in a trust fund left by Richard Harding Davis, writer, to his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Genevieve McAvoy Davis, known on the stage as Bessie McCoy, who died in Paris last Aug. 16.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 12. -- Reorganization of the Federal Reserve System to enable it to play a more important part in the financial activity of the country through the stimulation of consumption as well as production was urged in an address tonight at the University of Virginia by Paul Mazur of New York.

Four prohibition agents apparently with faulty memories failed yesterday in Federal court to identify Frank Ahearn, reputed lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Fleggenheimer, Bronx beer runner, as the man, who on the night of Aug. 30, shot and wounded Russell H. Whited, one of their number, during a raid on Braacker's Casino, 139 City Island Avenue, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed in the eleven-month period, Aug. 1 to June 30, was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 5,234,155 tons, compared with 4,693,724 tons in the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills June 30 totaled 353.935 tons, compared with 32,921 tons a year ago.

World production of merchant vessels is at the lowest point in fifty years, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping, in a report for the quarter ending June 30 covering returns from all maritime countries excepting Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The House Rules Committee voted today to defer action on the proposed investigation of the Treasury Department, the Controller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board until next December, at least.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- Christianity has not failed, but "a pseudo practice of Christianity is poisoning the springs of salvation." Mattison B. Jones of Glendale declared in an address at the opening session of the Northern Baptist convention here today.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12. -- Republican candidates for election to the Legislature met at the State House today at the call of Senator Emerson L. Richards, to consider campaign strategy. By virtue of his post of majority leader at the 1932 session. Senator Richards is in line for the Senate presidency if the Republicans continue in control, and it is believed he is ambitious to run for the Gubernatorial nomination two years hence.

The action of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, in executive session at Los Angeles this month, may prove to be the deciding factor in determining the next Olympic marathon champion. Paavo Nurmi, the peerless Finn, stands suspended by the I.A.A.F.

CINCINNATI, July 12. -- Carl Hubbell kept the Reds entirely off the bases for the first six and two-third innings he pitched today, but it took a wild throw by Cincinnati's substitute shortstop in the ninth inning to land the Giants a 4-to-3 victory today, giving them one out of four in the series.

A stampede among hundreds of spectators of a fire in a four-story loft building at 275 to 281 Powell Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, who were showered with burning debris when a mysterious explosion blew out the front wall and collapsed the roof of the brick structure, resulted in injury to fourteen persons late last night.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- The Department of Agriculture today reported the number of young pigs on farms on June 1 as 50,093,000, a decrease of 3,758,000 since the same date of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12. -- An elaborately carved throne of stone, still retaining much of the orange paint applied more than 1,000 years ago, was one of the chief finds of the Eldridge R. Johnson Archaeological expedition of the University of Pennsylvania Museum in Piedras Negras, Guatemala.

Nicholas Perrotti, New Rochelle policeman, triumphed in the first and second rounds of the New York Municipal Golf Association championship golf tourney, which is being held over the Pelham Bay Park links. On Monday Perrotti took the medal after thirty-six holes of competition.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons, with homers by Carnegie, Miller and Detore, subdued the Reading Keys in the third game of their series, giving them an edge of two out of three games. The score was 7 to 5. The victors took second place.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., July 12. -- Frank Ryniec, 40 years old, was fatally burned early today when fire destroyed his home at 246 Lower Augusta Street here. His wife, Margaret, 36, was burned severely, but escaped with their three children, Ryniec died at the South Amboy Memorial Hospital.

Great South Bay fishermen are reporting a fine run of bluefish averaging from one pound and a half to two pounds, enough to entice the salt-water angler to some of the favored spots for a day or two of trolling at this time of year.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 12 (AP). -- William Gore of Newark, N.J., a musician and entertainer, died in a hospital here from injuries suffered in an automobile accident today on the Glens Falls-Gansevoort Road. Thre others were injured in the collision of the coupe in which Gore was riding and a truck.

John Ringling, who owns more and larger circuses than any man on earth, was reported in an afternoon newspaper yesterday to be ill in a private hospital in Brooklyn with an infection which had required the amputation of both legs.

ABOARD THE YACHT MARCON, Stonington, Conn., July 12. -- Dropping into this quiet harbor after an all day sail aboard the Myth II, Governor Roosevelt extended the olive branch tonight to New England followers of Alfred E. Smith.

LONDON, July 12. -- Prime Minister MacDonald told the House of Commons today that no pledge or even indication had been given by the United States that war debts would be reduced if reparations were abolished at Lausanne.

New York State, which has done no long-term financing since Sept. 15, 1931, when it borrowed $40,000,000 at the record low rate of 3.2289 per cent, is expected to consider plans soon for the offering of upward of $25,000,000 of bonds. It is understood that Controller Morris S. Tremaine will do no further short-term financing this year, but will sell longterm bonds.

Reduction of the salaries of city employes to a basis commensurate with the cost of living would effect a saving of $75,000,000 to $100,000,000 in next year's budget, Anton L. Trunk, president of the New York Real Estate Board, said in a statement yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 12 (AP). -- The Baltimore Sun says that the first rough draft of a treaty between the United States and Canada for development of the St. Lawrence River to provide a waterway from Duluth to the sea, has been completed and approved by President Hoover.

Advocating the creation of an International reserve bank to convert the remaining war debts "into a foundation for world recovery." J. H. Rand Jr., chairman of Remington Rand, Inc., told stockholders of that company at their annual meeting yesterday that the "friendly, co-operative spirit developed at Lausanne forecasts the successful solution of other economic world problems during the forthcoming conferences."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12. -- The first in a series of bridge tournaments in aid of the Southampton unemployment fund was held tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Supper was served. Mrs. Reginald Fincke has arranged the series with the aid of Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Mrs. William Robinson Simonds, Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Scores of bonus marchers settled upon, the grass of the Capitol grounds and slept tonight to bring more forcibly to the attention of Congress their demand for immediate payment of the bonus to needy war veterans.

LONDON, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- A smashing bowling achievement was recorded by Hedley Verity, slowmedium bowler of Yorkshire, in taking 10 Nottinghamshire wickets for 10 runs in a first-class county match concluded today at Leeds. Yorkshire won easily.

Plans for the merger of the United States Savings Bank of the City of New York into the Dry Dock Savings Institution were announced yesterday by Andrew Mills, president of the latter institution. The consolidation, negotiations for which have been under way nine months, would give the Dry Dock bank an uptown office.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The War Department appropriation bill, carrying a total of $396,078,513 and the last of the departmental measures yet to be passed, moved near final approval today when the House voted to accept a Senate amendment restoring 2,000 officers which the House had previously eliminated.

BERLIN, July 12. -- The Boerse was weak today, due to nervousness over the ratification of the Lausanne agreement in view of Washington's attitude and the increasing bitterness of the German election campaign. The death of Thomas Bata added another bear element.

Support for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket and for the Democratic platform's prohibition repeal plank was pledged yesterday on behalf of the Hotel, Restaurant, Club and Allied Industries Association Against the Prohibition Amendment at a meeting of the organization's executive committee at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The National Democratic organization in Washington struck back today at Secretary Mills for his speech last night in Boston wherein he criticized the Democratic record in Congress.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- The British, South African, Indian and Rhodesian delegations to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa all embark on the giant liner Empress of Britain at Southampton today, sailing for Quebec and the Ottawa gathering.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP). -- A young American opera singer, acclaimed less than a year ago at the Royal Opera House in Milano, Italy, will make her first American appearance by helping a mining village her birthplace -- buy a new fire truck.

The latest statement of the Federal Farm Board indicates an early end of the Government's experiment with " price stabilization." Of the vast stock of 329,000,000 bushels of wheat purchased by the board with public funds, at prices about twice those now prevailing, less than 30,000,000 remain on hand.

The Board of Estimate was warned yesterday by representatives of the Caldwell-Wingate Company, contractors, that any attempt to readvertise the contract for the new health, sanitation and hospitals building in the civic centre would result in immediate court action by the contracting company, which has made the low bid of about $3,000,000 for the work.

LIMA, Peru, July 12 (AP). -- Drunken mobs coursed through the streets of Trujillo looting and murdering during the period when the city was in control of the rebels, dispatches reaching here from the North declared today.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP). -- Homers by Whitney and Virgil Davis gave the Phillies five runs in the opening inning today, but Jim Collins and Watkins hit homers in the eighth and ninth frames, respectively, to give the St. Louis Cardinals the last game of the series, 7 to 6.

The Stock Exchange call loan rate continued at 2 per cent, no sign of a break from that figure being evident notwithstanding the liberal supply of funds at the lending table. Outside trades were done at 1, and Federals at 1/3@1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

Walter Stewart, left-handed pitcher of the St. Louis Browns, seemed to be harboring a fond notion that he was about to be the first American League pitcher to shut out the Yankees this season when along about the sixth inning at the stadium yesterday the thing began to prey on his mind, and presently it slipped right out of his fingers.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- In a statement to the Senate authorized by Secretary Stimson, Senator Borah. Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, today denied speeches made in the British Parliament and utterances of Premier Herriot to the effect that an understanding had been reached between the United States and debtor nations relative to a reparations agreement and reduction of the $11,000,000,000 war debt.

COPENHAGEN, July 12. -- The Norwegian Council of State has ordered a wider occupation of lands in East Greenland claimed by Denmark, it was learned here today, causing a sensation in a dispute that dates back to 1814 and has gone before the World Court for settlement.

PARIS, July 12 (AP). -- In an allnight session on the finance bill, broken only by a two-hour recess, Premier Herriot inferentially raised the question of Adolf Hitler's storm troops in Germany at one point in the debate.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- News and bearish views, combined with favorable crop reports, led to enough selling pressure today on the Board of Trade here to carry wheat and all other grain prices down with corn, near the lowest levels of the season, with new lows on oats and rye.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The last plank In President Hoover's economic relief program was approved by the Senate this afternoon when it passed the home loan bank bill without a roll-call and sent it to conference with the House, which has already approved the measure in a different form.

Mayor Walker's reply to the removal charges based on allegations sent to Governor Roosevelt by Samuel Seabury probably will be completed early next week, the Mayor said yesterday, and forwarded to Albany upon the Governor's return from his vacation cruise.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Thousands of coal miners from Southern Illinois today began converging on Springfield to protest the proposed basic wage scale, to be voted on Saturday. More than five thousand had reached that city this evening and many other delegations were on their way.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The depression is no excuse for the establishment of less than maximum reasonable railway rates to divert waterborne traffic from coastwise vessels operating between San Francisco and New York City, the Panama Canal steamship lines contended before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 12. -- All but one of the eight quarter-final brackets in the fortieth annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament were filled by seeded players at the conclusion of today's play at the Longwood Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Spencer's single and a wild throw to second by Appling, Chicago's shortstop, scoring the Senators catcher, today gave Washington a tenth-inning victory over the White Sox, 13 to 12.

Communist agitators made an unsuccessful attempt yesterday to storm the doors of the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, and disrupt a mass meeting of 10,000 garment workers gathered there to vote on the question of a general strike to break the deadlock in negotiations between the union and the jobbers.

Brooklyn Navy Yard workers, comprising about 3,600 in twenty-seven trades, feel that there has been discrimination against the yard by the government officials who compiled the naval work list for the ensuing eighteen mouths and are concerned over the possibility of many lay-offs because of lack of repair work in the next seven or eight months, according to Thomas Mahoney, secretary of the Metal Trades Council of the yard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The requests made by the Public Housing Conference, as reported in THE TIMES, would seem worthy of careful consideration. The motive prompting such research, deliberation and proposal by the conference for a housing plan can be regarded only as wholesome.

The most recent of the German language pictures to pay a visit to New York went on the screen of the Europa Theatre yesterday. It was "Brand in der Oper," which for the last half year has been heralded from various spots on the Continent and in England.

The stock market did not emerge from its familiar apathy yesterday; the day's changes were for the most part equally divided between, small fractional advances and small fractional declines. Domestic bonds made a general show of firmness, with numerous advances of 1 or 2 points.

Commercial insolvencies in June numbered 2,688, with liabilities of $76,931,452, a new high record for the month, according to statistics issued yesterday by R. G. Dun Co. The number for June, however, was the smallest for any month since December, 1931.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12. -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church asserted that the testimony given in the chancery receivership investigation by Harry G. Hendricks, who has been removed as receiver for the Earl Radio Corporation, was untrue. Chancellor Church's denial of Hendricks's allegations involving him was contained in a letter to Shelton Pitney, counsel in the investigation, which Mr. Pitney made public today.

The number of graduates from the Elementary junior high and senior high schools this year as compared with 1931 shows an increase of 4,675, while the girls had a larger percentage of successful graduates than the boys, according to figures made public yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education.

HAVANA, July 12. -- The expectation, that Havana University would be reopened next Fall was dissipated today when it became known that at a meeting yesterday of 118 members of the university faculty it was voted to suspend all efforts in that direction until political conditions on the island had returned to normal.

On an agreeably cool midsummer night the upper reaches of Washington Heights saw an outdoor per formance of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" last evening when, through arrangement with Sir Philip Ben Greet, various members of his company acted the Shakespearean company at the George Washington Stadium, St. Nicholas Avenue and 194th Street.

PLATTSBURG, July 12. -- The first issue of The Plattsburg Parade, published for the students of the Citizens' Military Training Camp, was distributed today to the 2,400 young men from all parts of New York. New Jersey and Delaware attending the camp.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The Senate tonight passed without record vote an unemployment relief bill to take the place of that which was vetoed yesterday by President Hoover.

A third action in litigation growing out of the sale of first mortgage bonds by S. W. Straus Co., Inc., investment brokers, was filed yesterday in Supreme Court in a motion for the appointment of a receiver for the Hotel Delmonico, which was financed by the Straus Company.

The St. Lawrence project is a strange mixture of law, politics, economics, diplomacy, engineering, finance and downright Yankee horsetrading. While the treaty waits, Governor ROOSEVELT'S intervention has brought the bargaining phase of the problem to the front.

Nat Duke, vice president in charge of traffic of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, testified yesterday at a hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission that railroads could not exist if they were not engaged in the warehouse business to meet the competition of other carriers.

BOISSEVAIN, Man., July 12 (Canadian Press). -- Filled with high hopes for the harvest, the people of Canada and the United States will meet Thursday at the imaginary line between their two countries to sow the seeds of an abiding peace in an international peace garden planned as a monument to more than a century of good-will and a pledge of their intention to live side by side without taking up arms against each other.

Mild realty trading in the metropolitan area was featured by the leasing to the F. W. Woolworth Company of a building to be erected at 1,348-50 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx. The lease involves the whole building and is for thirty years.

Rolling along on the crest of couple of homers, one delivered by Babe Ruth, the other by Frank Crosetti, the Yankees finished their series with the Browns at the Stadium yesterday by scoring their third victory of the five-game set by a score of 5 to 3.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- With aggregates of 103 out of a possible 105, a Scotsman and an Englishman led the 1,000 expert military gunners in the opening stage of the King's Prize today and will shoot for the National Rifle Association's bronze medal.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13. -- Henry Penn Burke, chairman of the American Olympic Rowing Committee, today announced that the Philadelphia Olympic squad, which leaves next Monday, will consist of twenty-two members, including fifteen oarsmen, two coxswains, two alternates, two officials and one coach.

A new issue of $25,000,000 Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston two-year 5 per cent notes will be placed on the market today by a banking group headed by the First of Boston Corporation and including the Lee Higginson Corporation, F.S. Mosley Co., Kidder, Peabody Co.; Burr, Gannett Co.; Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, Blake Brothers Co., Bankers Trust Company, National City Company, Goldman, Sachs Co. and Estabrook Co.

Formation of a large corporation in which realty owners of the garment and fur trades district around Pennsylvania Station might coordinate their resources and exchange equities for stock in the cooperative enterprise was suggested yesterday by Aaron Rabinowitz, president of the Spear Securities Corporation, as a possible means of stabilizing values in the district.

MAETERLINCK could not have found a better illustration of a double garden than the international garden which is to be dedicated today in Manitoba, stretching across the invisible border between the United States and Canada. In his book he tells how flowers have completed the conquest of the globe.

The Atlantic Apartments in Beach 66th St., Arverne, Queens, will be formally dedicated and opened by the Gold Theatre Corp., Max Gold, president, next Saturday at 8:30 P.M. The house is between Story and Swan Places.

Facts have a disconcerting way of knocking the props from under popular and even scientific beliefs. Of this the depression has afforded many examples. Welfare workers anxious about the health of the unemployed and their families have been agreeably surprised to discover that death has stayed its hand.

Play will start Saturday with a game between the Austin four and the Bahadurs, led by J.C. (Cocie) Rathborne as the first of the season's national polo championships, the Junior, opens at the Rumson Country Club, Rumson, New Jersey.

After an early decline that appeared to end the selling pressure which had caused a setback of $3 a bale in the last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered more than a quarter cent a pound yesterday and ended with net gains of 20 to 23 points, or $1 a bale or more.

While Summer heat has been accompanied by a lessened demand for shelter at free lodging houses for the unemployed. Salvation Army officials reported yesterday a large increase in the number of persons seeking food at emergency food stations.

With a Gubernatorial campaign imminent, Republican leaders in this State are again confronted with the cheerless prospect of a third ticket in the field to make more difficult, if it does not close to them entirely, the way to victory.

LONDON, July 13 (Canadian Press) . -- The Chancery Court gave permission today to counsel for H. W. Boardman to serve a writ on the Grand Trunk Railway, taken over by the Canadian National Railways, in the action by Grand Trunk first preference stockholders for compensation amounting to u37,000,000 ($131,350,000 at current rates).

Interrupted by a running fire of questions and allegations of inefficient and improper conduct of its business, Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., testified yesterday at the first New York hearing of the joint legislative committee to investigate the milk industry.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 13. -- A. A. Chapman, former confidential banking secretary to the late Thomas E. Mitten, Philadelphia transit operator, appeared before a Senate investigating committee today and repeated charges that William D.B. Ainey, chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, had received $150,000 from Mitten.

LONDON, July 13. -- The British and French Governments announced tonight an agreement between themselves that re-establishes the Anglo-French entente as a dominant force in European politics and is intended to set up a European "common front" in all but name and create something like a political truce among the chief European powers.

MIAMI, Fla., July 13 (AP). -- The Miami News today quoted the Rev. H. Dobson-Peacock as saying that New Jersey State police drove John Hughes Curtis to delirium by hanging a garment of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby over his head and thereby extracted his statements declaring that his reported efforts to negotiate with the kidnappers were a hoax.

MEXICO CITY, July 13 (AP). -- Carl Gilpin, president of the Gilpin air lines of Los Angeles, was killed and four passengers of the private airplane he was piloting here from Los Angeles were injured when the plane crashed into a mountain near Toluca tonight.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 13. -- Martin Schempp of Pittsburgh, flying a German-built glider, soared in the air this afternoon for seven hours, being forced to land to attend a dinner tendered to officials of the Soaring Society of America, Inc., and contesting pilots at the home of former Mayor J. Norton Wood.

LONDONDERRY, Ireland, July 13. -- Bar gold, estimated to be worth $70,000, has been recovered by divers from the liner Laurentic, which was sunk during the World War at the entrance of Lough Swilly while conveying gold to America.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., July 13. -- Jerome Lang, last year's winner, reached the semi-final round today in the annual invitation tournament of the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club, defeating Arthur Fowler, 6-2, 6-3.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The protective committee for prior preferred and preferred stocks of the Mississippi Valley Utilities Investment Company was authorized today by Judge Waller C. Lindley in the Federal District Court here to intervene in the recivership proceedings against that company.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Further bearings by the Radio Commission on the reallocation of domestic short-wave frequencies assigned to R.C.A. Communications, Inc., and the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, were opposed today by these corporations in replies filed with the court.

The money market continued stagnant in the matter of business and rate changes. The Stock Exchange call loan charge remained at 2 per cent, but Street business was quoted at 1 and Federals 1/8 @ 1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

The faulty memory of four prohibition agents who were unable to say who fired a shot that wounded Russell H. Whited, one of their number, last August during a raid on Braacker's Casino, 139 City Island, the Bronx, was responsible yesterday for Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard directing a jury to return a verdict in favor of Frank Ahearn, reputed lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schutz) Fleggenheimer, on trial for the shooting.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Prices of hogs here sagged gain today, the top and average quotations losing 15 cents, at $5.25 and $4.75, respectively, a hundredweight, the lowest since Tuesday of last week. The market has lost 25 to 30 cent in two days, but the ]oo;. is still 59 per cent above the low day in May and the average stands 50 per cent above that level.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 13 (AP). -- Rochester took the series from Jersey City, three games to one, with an 8-2 victory today behind the excellent hurling of Ira Smith.

The stock market awoke partly from its lethargy yesterday; practically all the list advanced, with numerous gains for the day of 2 to 3 points. This was no great enhancement. On a percentage basis, with prices at their present level, it was considerable, but the recovery must have been attributable to professional operators.

A broadside attack on the administration of President Hoover is made by Robert S. Allen in his book, "Why Hoover Faces Defeat," just published by Brewer, Warren Putnam. Mr. Allen was formerly chief Washington correspondent of The Christian Science Monitor and was co-author of "The Washington Merry-Go-Round," a volume concerning personalities and events in that city which was issued as an anonymous work.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- An investigation to determine whether transatlantic lines are receiving greater compensation on shipments to United Kingdom and European ports from the United States than on similar shipments from Canada, due to depreciated Canadian currency, was ordered today by the Shipping Board.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- An agreement on terms of a treaty to govern the development of a seaway from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean by way of the St. Lawrence River has finally been reached by the United States and Canada after eleven years of agitation.

An exhibition of arts and crafts from the island of Bali, in the Dutch East Indies, was opened yesterday afternoon on the terrace of the Empire Room at the Waldorf-Astoria. The show is a sort of prelude to Charles Trego's Balinese film, "Isle of Paradise," which will have its premiere at the Vanderbilt Theatre next Wednesday.
