More than 250,000 security holders of the Associated Gas and Electric System are being asked to help the company to meet $18,556,000 of short-term maturities of subsidiaries by subscribing on an average of $100 each to 4 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds of the New Jersey Power and Light Company at a 20 per cent discount.

MELBOURNE, July 13. -- The Australian Government has decided to institute the strictest investigation into a remarkable series of pension frauds throughout the Commonwealth, it was stated in the Victoria Legislative Assembly today by F.P. Jones, State Minister of Public Works.
ZLIN, Czechoslovakia, July 13. -- Experts are at a loss to explain the cause of the disaster to Thomas Bata's airplane, in which the shoe magnate was killed yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Members of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, who are asking themselves "which nominee for the Presidency will lead us into most constructive international policies," placed their program before President Hoover today.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Before 17,000 shouting fans, the veteran Jack Quinn today turned back the Cubs in the ninth inning with the tying run on third base, to give the Dodgers a 5-to-4 victory in the series opener.

There will be no attempt at interference with the manner of presenting opera of the Metropolitan Opera Association if that organization should decide to move to Rockefeller Center, it was declared yesterday by S.L. Rothafel (Roxy), who added that the Center was still hopeful that the Metropolitan would agree to move from its old quarters.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 13. -- Jack Kennedy, a former Nassau County policeman, who was shot from ambush in 1928 and who had undergone thirteen operations since, died at his home in New Hyde Park today, the police were informed by the widow.

TRUCKEE, Cal., July 13 (AP). -- A new gold rush to the Sierra was under way today at Lake Tahoe as news leaked out that a six-foot ledge of red quartz on the Chambers resort property assayed $20 a ton in gold and $2 in silver.

In ordering that a wider range of territory be taken over in East Greenland than the Myggbutta district, over which Norwegian hunters raised the flag in June, 1931, the Council of State is acting to protect Norwegian citizens and to strengthen the Norwegian case contesting the title of Denmark, which is to be argued before The Hague Tribunal.

ST. LOUIS, July 13. -- The Giants at no time today until the ninth inning developed any serious offensive against the wide lead built by the Cardinals with four first-inning runs, and lost the opener of the series, 6 to 2.

The suit of Michael P. Kosolopov against the Russo-Asiatic Bank, in which Mr. Kosolopov won a verdict of $173,000 in the Federal court in Brooklyn, only to see it set aside on the ground that the State courts and not the Federal courts had jurisdiction, was dismissed yesterday by Justice Burt Jay Humphrey of the Supreme Court in Queens.
CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the Reds, 3 to 2, today in the opening contest of a four-game series.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP). -- The Indians went on the warpath in the tenth inning today and took Lefty Grove and the Athletics into camp again by 7 to 5. It was their fourth consecutive triumph over Philadelphia and their second straight over the southpaw in this series.

The Willard Straight Post of the American Legion, which on April 6 in a telegram to National Commander Henry L. Stevens Jr., at Indianapolis, urged discontinuance of "all attempts" by representatives of the Legion "to coerce Congress" and of the "Washington lobby," has been temporarily suspended by the New York State executive council, it was learned yesterday.

Six hundred members of the American Bible Conference Association will sail today on what they term a "revelation cruise" to Bermuda and Halifax on the Anchor liner Transylvania. The trip will be under the leadership of Homer Hammon-tree.

Schedules in bankruptcy for Frederick Brown, real estate operator and philanthropist, who filed a petition in Federal court last month asking for the appointment of a receiver, were entered yesterday in his behalf by Ernest Gale, Bernays Falk, attorneys.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 13. -- The metropolitan open championship, which starts on the Lido course to-morrow, lost one of its star performers today with the announcement that Gene Sarazen, British and United States open titleholder and a considerable factor in recent metropolitan opens, would not play in the event.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 13. -- The fatal shooting of Z. Smith Reynolds, husband of the former Libby Holman, contained no official interest for the Forsyth County grand jury, which was dismissed here today. The jury took no action on the killing, which a coroner's jury decided was done "by a person or persons unknown."

PARIS, July 13. -- The stock market was highly irregular on the eve of the national holiday. The Bourse will be closed tomorrow for Bastile Day, and the mid-month liquidation will take place on Friday, after which the exchange will be closed again for two days.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had approved the listing of 300,000 shares of new $5 par value stock of the Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation and 809,173 shares of new $10 par value stock of the Murray Corporation of America.

ABOARD THE YACHT MARCON, off Cuttyhunk Island, via Woods Hole, Mass., July 13. -- A fifty-mile run of varied thrills brought Governor Roosevelt and his family crew on the Myth II into this little harbor tonight to drop the hook just as the last of the sun shot through a western bank of clouds.

LAUSANNE, July 13. -- From two capitals, London and Paris, came the surprising news tonight that the published Lausanne reparations treaty and the unpublished gentlemen's agreement, the authentic text of which has never yet been revealed, were not the only understandings reached by statesmen in the recent conference here.

MOSCOW, July 13 (AP). -- A dispatch from Khabarovsk, Siberia, published here today, said the Japanese had failed to fulfill their promise not to interfere with the operation of the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria. The railway is jointly owned by China and Russia.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 13. -- Colonel M.C. Rorty, former statistician of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, proposed before the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia, a way out of what he described as ''the vicious circle of debt deflation," a plan which he indicate was one of the "positive plans' now under consideration by President Hoover and one likely to receive the endorsement of the administration.

Under a plan of reorganization approved by the preferred stockholders' committee of the National Bellas Hess Company, Inc., and by the receivers for the company, acting on a court order signed by Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman in the United States District Court yesterday, the company, which was placed in equity receivership last April, will receive 300,000 shares of common stock in a new company, organized to carry on its mail-order business.

A new ballroom dance was demonstrated yesterday at the Dancing Teachers' Congress, now in session at the Hotel New Yorker. The teachers believe it will sweep over the country as one of the most popular ballroom dances of 1932. It is called the Earhart Hop, and is dedicated to Amelia Earhart, transatlantic flier.

The Italian liner Conte Biancamano, one of the popular liners in the Mediterranean trade, will leave New York for the last time on Saturday, marking the end of a long service here, and the beginning of what Italian Line officials call a new era Of Italian shipping.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- An agreement of the Pacific Coast-South and East Africa Lumber Conference under which member lines undertake to maintain freight rates, as agreed upon from time to time by a two-thirds majority of the conference on lumber and log shipments, was approved today by the Shipping Board.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The annual fair for the benefit of the Newport Hospital, given under the auspices of the Woman's Aid Association this afternoon on the hospital grounds, attracted many members of the Summer colony.

MARITIME law and regatta rules are up for discussion again. It happens every time the Riverside Yacht Club of Connecticut tries to run its Riverside -- Stratford Shoal overnight race for cruising yachts.

Although Mayor Walker has indicated that he does not plan to include "new matter" in his reply to the removal charges now pending against him before Governor Roosevelt, it was learned yesterday that he was considering putting a passage devoted to national politics in his answer.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- While bonus - demanding veterans continued to besiege Congress, resolutely declining to leave the city, President Hoover today sent to the Capitol a request for legislation to send the entire bonus army home.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 13 (AP). -- Ben White, veteran trainer, put over another smooth-looking youngster on the Grand Circuit program today at the Fort Miami track when Spencer McElwyn defeated a crop of 2-year-olds in the feature trot for that age.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 13 (AP). -- Colonel Luis Larrea Alba, who was Provisional President of Ecuador for two months last year, was imprisoned today when the government heard of a new military plot to make him dictator of the country.

Believing that prompt adoption of a suitable reorganization plan is the only way by which security holders and creditors can recover their investment and recoup their losses, the Chamber of Commerce of Chicopee, Mass., has formed an independent protective committee for the purpose of ending the receivership of the Fisk Rubber Company as quickly as possible.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 13. -- A four-year scholarship at Yale has been offered by that university for competition among the 2,400 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware in attendance at the 1932 Citizens Military Training Camp here, it was announced by Colonel George A. Herbst, Commander of Plattsburg Barracks.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Passage of a revised unemployment relief bill today in the House, by a vote of 296 to 46, cleared the way for probable disposal of this legislation so that the President may sign it tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- In connection with the St. Lawrence waterway project the United States in 1928 accepted as a "basis of negotiation," but with a number of important qualifications, a proposal by the Canadian Government for a division of work and costs summarized in the following "balance sheet":

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Clotho, by St. Germans, which sired Twenty Grand, qualified handsomely for the Empire City Derby by winwing the featured Bronxville Handicap at James Butler's Yonkers course yesterday. It was the second local appearance of the Whitney color-bearer.
Small residential structures again furnished the bulk of the realty turnover in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The international discussions of the Lausanne agreement and the domestic political tension intensified the bearish tendency on the Boerse today and most stocks declined in a restricted volume of trading. The losses averaged 4 per cent, with the greatest decline in Westeregeln Potash, which dropped almost 7 per cent.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 (AP). -- Porto Alegre is becoming a clearing point for government troops with whom the Federal authorities plan to wage vigorous warfare against the rebellion.
NEW YORK. The Minister from Finland, Leonard Astrom, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

The New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday a series of communications received by the committee on stock list regarding the Kreuger Toll Company and reported for the information of the governing committee of the Exchange, comprising the report of the committee of investigation at Stockholm, the petition of bankruptcy for the company and other information relating to the case.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 13. -- The newspapers here are warning Bolivia that the recent withdrawal of Paraguay from the Washington negotiations for a non-aggression treaty means danger of war and diplomats here express fear that the dispute over possession of the Chaco wilderness has reached its gravest stage.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13. -- Ohio Republicans prepared tonight for their platform convention, which is to open tomorrow afternoon, with Senator Simeon D. Fess in the role of temporary chairman and keynoter.

The Coney Island fire failed in one respect to equal the record of the first Lincoln Arcade fire, at Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, Jan. 30, 1931, in that no "simultaneous" alarm signaled by the numbers 9-9 was turned in. The 9-9 call summons all available apparatus in the greater city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There exists an erroneous idea that all bonus agitation is caused by veterans who have already borrowed 50 per cent of the face value of their adjusted-service certificates and who, having eaten half their loaf, now want the other half.

As departmental budget requests for next year's funds showed reductions from the current appropriations in most instances yesterday, Mayor Walker received a plan from Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan showing how the city could gain $4,000,000 a year in revenue by charging fees for elevator inspections, the filing of building plans and the maintenance of electric signs.

TRENTON, N.J., July 13. -- Railroads operating in New Jersey have filed appeals involving millions of dollars in tax assessments with the State Board of Tax Appeals. Hearing will be held in September.
CINCINNATI, July 13 -- A couple of Hawaiian lads who used to dive for coins in Honolulu Harbor bobbed up at Coney Island pool today with "United States Olympic timber" written all over them.

BOSTON, July 13. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd has accepted the chairmanship of the New England organization committee of the National Economy League. His new job, which, he says, is "non-political, non-partisan and non-salary," begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Senator Glass, long regarded as one of the most ardent Democratic drys, introduced in the Senate today a joint resolution proposing repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and sought unsuccessfully to push it through the Senate at once.

Neither Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, national chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, nor Mrs. John S. Sheppard, chairman of the New York division, would comment yesterday on the action of Miss Alice Chittenden, former president of the Women's National Republican Club, in resigning from the anti-prohibition body because of its endorsement of the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.
PITTSBURGH, July 13 (AP). -- The Boston Braves defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates in a double uprising at Forbes Field today, 5 to 1 and 10 to 5.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Monte Weaver held the Chicago White Sox in check today and the Washington Senators scored a 15-to-4 victory.

OAKLAND, Cal., July 13 (AP). -- The possibility arose today that Mrs. Helen Wills Moody would not defend her women's national tennis title this year. George Hudson, professional at the Berkeley Tennis Club, said he had received a letter from Lawrence Harper indicating Mrs. Moody might remain in Europe throughout August.

LONDON, July 13. -- Seven members of the British Cabinet are on the high seas tonight bound for the Ottawa Imperial Conference, which will atempt to lower the trade barriers among the nations of the British Empire.

With a view to relieving the unemployment situation, it has been decided to begin work at once on the massive flight of steps of Maine granite to lead from Amsterdam Avenue to the main entrance on the westward side of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Charges of undue foreign influence on the American merchant marine were made today by Representative La Guardia before the opening session of an investigation by the House Postoffice Committee into Postoffice Department finances.

Operations in the steel industry have been stepped up to a national average of about 16 per cent of ingot capacity, which means a return to the level of June, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This moderate expansion has been due to the resumption of activity at plants that were shut over the Independence Day week-end.
EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 13. -- Two favorites in the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Country Club for the Griswold Trophy were eliminated today.

PARIS, July 13. -- Mrs. Catherine Gordon-Ellis, adopted daughter of the late Frederick A. Whelan, former vice president of the United Cigar Stores Company, and wife of a French dentist, died soon after she had been admitted to the American Hospital in Neuilly early this morning.
DUBLIN, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- President de Valera entered the debate in the Dail late tonight with an eloquent exhortation to the Irish people to "stand firm."

Whereas the first entente between Britain and France -- the Triple Entente, to which Russia also was a signatory-related chiefly to imperial concerns in Africa and Asia, and Had a military background, the present entente is of an economic nature and relates only to Europe.

Anti-prohibition leaders in the Senate talked hopefully last week of an early change in the existing law. On the next test of strength they professed to believe that they would command a majority for the Bingham plan to legalize beer of 4 per cent.

Feeder brooks and streams of many of the principal river systems of Massachusetts will be closed to trout and other fresh water fishing beginning next Spring, the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Game has just announced.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 13. -- Walter Rothenberg, a member of the Winged Foot Golf Club and captain of the Lafayette College golf team, was the winner of the low-gross prize at the one-day tournament of the Westchester Golf Association today. The tourney was held at the Scarsdale Golf Club and attracted eighty-six entries, the largest turnout in Westchester one-day play this year.

The prediction that consumption of ferrous and non-ferrous metals has reached the minimum and that the composite averages of metals and pig iron and steel products and scrap will stand higher at the end of the year than they now do is made by The American Metal Markets.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Speaker Garner late today named House conferees to adjust the differences in the home loan bank bill after he and Representative Snell, the minority leader, had engaged in an argument on the floor that for a time threatened to disrupt the plans of leaders to adjourn Congress at the end of this week.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- About the time word of the new Anglo-French accord was received here today in press dispatches Secretary of State Stimson went to the White House for a conference with President Hoover. Whether they discussed the accord was not disclosed.

The effort to undo two generations of "blundering" in American family life by calling upon teachers in schools throughout the country to teach ''home-making" was characterized as "pathetic" by Dr. Benjamin C. Gruenberg of the Child Study Association in an address yesterday afternoon at the Conference on Education and Family Life in the Horace Mann auditorium of Teachers College, Columbia University.

LATONIA, Ky., July 13 (AP). -- Displaying marked improvement over her recent outing, C.E. Hamilton's Elizabeth Fox accounted for the featured Crescent Springs Purse today at Latonia. Second went to J.C. Ellis's Ellice, the favorite, while R. L. Baker's Squall finished third.
Owing largely to extensive dry sentiment in the State, Ohio, according to W.A. Julian, Democratic National Committeeman, will be a hotly contested battleground in the national campaign.

The strike threat of 27,000 garment workers to end the deadlock in negotiations between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and three employing groups was tempered somewhat yesterday by a series of conference at which consideration was given to the advisability of submitting the whole controversy to mediation.

LONDON, July 13. -- The stock markets were again uncertain today, with activity confined to British Government funds, which continued firm on investment buying. The industrials mostly were easier owing to lack of support. Even the textiles were lower after a firm opening.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP). -- The Red Sox took their first series of the year by scoring an 8-to-7 victory over the Tigers today to win three contests of the five-game series. The defeat dropped the losers to fourth place.

TRENTON, July 13. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, Superintendent of the State Police, refused to comment tonight on the charges made in Miami by the Rev. H. Dobson-Peacock that the hoax confession of John Hughes Curtis was obtained by driving the man to delirium.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- First tax payments under the revenue act of 1932, drafted to assist in bringing the government's budget to a balance, will be received by the Treasury Department soon after Aug. 1. For most of the manufacturers' excise, miscellaneous and stamp taxes the initial returns will cover the period June 21-June 30.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP). -- Crowning Glory, the long-striding, sleek bay colt, owned by Mrs. John Hay Whitney of New York, galloped dangerously near the 2-year-old championship of America at Arlington Park today.

COPENHAGEN, July 13. -- The Norwegian occupation of more territory in Southeast Greenland has created intense excitement in all Scandinavia. The Danish newspapers express astonishment at the step and regret that Norway, while the matter was in the hands of the World Court at The Hague has undertaken a new challenging action which will not help the friendly relations of the two Scandinavian countries.

Second-Grade Detective Harold Moore and Third-Grade Detective Thomas Riggs were promoted to first-grade detectives yesterday morning by Police Commissioner Mulrooney for their part in tracking down and killing Edward (Fats) McCarthy, Coll gang desperado, and the capture of two of his confederates at their hideout on Dorlyn Road, on the outskirts of Albany, Monday night.

Regarded as just another free show, bigger and more spectacular than usual, by most of the crowd of 150,000 which was at the resort yesterday afternoon, the Coney Island fire presented serious problems to 2,000 or more bathers whose clothing and money were destroyed in the burned bathhouses, and to 1,000 or more residents of the area who were left homeless.

The usual large audience which attends dance programs at the Lewishon Stadium assembled last night for the appearance of Irma Duncan and the Isadora Duncan Dancers with the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, Hans Lange conducting. Though the weather was threatening, the amphitheatre was filled to capacity and very few seats in the field remained unoccupied.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 13. -- Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today he did not contemplate selling any long-term State bonds until he actually needed the money for the purpose for which the bonds were voted. He said there had been rumors that the State might have to sell $20,000,000 emergency relief bonds this year, but he pointed out that it had until 1936 to complete the sale of the $50,000,000 bonds originally authorized.

BERLIN, July 13. -- While Baron Wilhem von Gayl, Reich's Minister of the interior, was on his way to confer with President von Hindenburg at Neudeck in East Prussia on what was to be done about the carnage in connections with the election campaign.

Was It House, or Howe? The Boston Herald has a wonderful secret which it is trying hard to keep. But, as if talking in its sleep, it mutters: "What a gorgeous exhibit an itemized bill of the telephone conversations that [Democratic convention] week between Beverly Farms and Washington, Chicago and Albany would be!"

With about 150,000 shares of B.M. T. common stock under its control, a protective committee headed by Elisha Walker, Bernard M. Baruch, Joseph P. Kennedy and Herbert Bayard Swope is prepared to demand the election of three directors to the corporation's board at the meeting scheduled for next Monday, so that it may take an active part in negotiating with public bodies for unification of all rapid-transit lines in the city.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13. -- David N. Jones of New York, former Columbia athlete, eliminated the top-seeded Keith Gledhill of Los Angeles to gain the semi-final round in the fortieth annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today, 6-1, 2-6, 7-5, 6-3.
BERLIN, July 8 (by mail) -- Personal appearances of Hohenzollern Princes at public functions have become the vogue in Germany under the von Papen Government.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, amounted to 213,100,000 kilowatt hours in the week ended July 9, as against 215,600,000 kilowatt hours in the preceding week and 245,800,000 kilowatt hours in the corresponding week last year.

Accused of shooting at two process servers as they were about to give him a summons to appear at a hearing on an action for an accounting of the funds of Local 125 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, Patrick J. Commerford, deposed supervisor of the local, "was held in $2,500 bail yesterday by Magistrate Hoekstra in Flushing Court for a further hearing July 26.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 13. -- An absorbing thirty-six hole final round is in prospect for tomorrow when Robert Moffett, former metropolitan junior champion, and Tommy Goodwin, the present holder, come together for the New York State junior crown at the Siwanoy Country Club.

Members of the Italian Olympic squad left New York City yesterday for their journey across the continent to Los Angeles. The party, composed of 106 athletes and twenty-six officials and coaches, the largest to arrive here en route to the Olympics, stopped off at Washington for a few hours in the afternoon.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on May 31 a net income of $8,296,540 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred and second preferred dividends to 93 cents a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the period, compared with $10,946,835, or $2.89 a share on the average number of shares outstanding during the preceding year.

The two most disastrous fires in the previous history of Coney Island were those that started in Dreamland Park early in the morning of May 27, 1911, making a clean sweep to the eastward, and the blaze that burned out Steeplechase Park and all the surrounding amusement enterprises on the morning of July 28, 1907.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 13. -- Although the issue will not be disposed of finally until after the American Olympic track and field tryouts have been concluded here Saturday, it appeared virtually certain today that no exemptions will be granted -- or asked -- in the make-up of the homebred athletic forces to be pitted against the rest of the world at Los Angeles.

Coney Island was swept yesterday afternoon by one of the most destructive fires in the history of the resort. Four square blocks at the western end were destroyed. Property valued at $5,000,000 was burned and more than 1,000 persons were made homeless.

LOS ANGELES, July 13. -- W.W. Hodkinson, founder and first president of what is now the Paramount-Publix Corporation, who "went fishing" seven years ago when he disagreed with the drift toward consolidation of production and distribution, is ready to return with a plan which, he asserts, will "save the picture business from complete disaster."
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 13. -- Twenty-two sloops took part in the fourth series of July races of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

J.L. Eysmans, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, testified yesterday before a hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission that, although the general policy of the railroad was to avoid voluntary storage of traffic, the keen rivalry and competition among carriers in the port of New York necessitated the inclusion of storage warehousing as an integral part of the railroad's transportation facilities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Reading Aloud" in today's issue has given me a rude shock. My wife and I have been spending every free evening reading aloud for more than ten years. We do not read the Victorian novelists, indeed, nor many novelists of any era for that matter, because you can't skip when reading aloud.
OTTAWA, Ont., July 13 (Canadian Press). -- The international rapids section of the St. Lawrence embraces the forty-eight miles of rapids and swift water between Chimney Point and Lake St. Francis.

Common stock of the United States Steel Corporation, amounting to 8,703,252 shares, was in the hands of 190,024 owners on June 30, whereas the total number of holders of such stock at the end of March was 186,981. The stock was owned by 156,239 persons at the end of June, 1931.

King cobra of Bronx Park, the record-breaker of the hooded family, lost its wrestling reputation to the king cobra of Sumatra yesterday morning in a twenty-minute bout before an excited audience in the Bronx Zoo. Many minutes passed before it again flexed the hood that hid its chagrin.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 13. -- A suit requesting the appointment of receivers for the General Gas and Electric Corporation, controlled by the Associated Gas and Electric Company, with headquarters in New York, was filed in the Court of Chancery here today by two stockholders, the General Utilities and Operating Company of Baltimore and Frank R. Kent, a Baltimore political writer.

"Farewell to Love," a play by Oscar M. Sheridan. English playwright, has been acquired for early Fall presentation by Arch Selwyn. According to Mr. Selwyn's office, a "prominent female star" will have the leading role.

The relief bill, which the President will soon sign, represents the best thought of Congress and the Executive as applied to the present set of facts. Chief among the legislators who have worked hard and intelligently to make the bill into law is Senator WAGNER of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although appreciative of your report of our primary contest, may I say that very little space was given in explanation of the motives that bring us into this campaign?

It will be surprising, indeed, if the United States does not capture both high jumping and pole vaulting honors in the Olympic Games. American hances in the broad jump and hop, step and jump, however, can be considered only fair.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper. Buyers' Operations Encouraging. Buyers are getting down to the actual business of writing orders in a rather encouraging fashion, according to reports in the apparel trades here yesterday. Many of the orders call for units which compare well with last year in both coats and dresses.

Representatives of savings banks in Manhattan and the Bronx attended liquidation sales yesterday and bid in properties offered by auctioneers. Most of the realty put up for sale consisted of small dwellings and tenement houses.

To Wall Street yesterday's spirited advance on the Stock Exchange, in the late dealings, seemed to be a reflection of the more hopeful attitude toward the market. Business was considerably more active than on the day before, the day's trading involving about 980,000 shares, compared with 700,000 shares.

A general strike of members of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, District Council 9, was started yesterday after working hours as a result of the failure to reach an agreement to replace the contract which expired on April 30, last, with the Association of Master Painters and Decorators.

Through the agencies caring for families utterly without income a great deal is known of their distress, their courage in meeting an unprecedented situation and their struggles to get on their feet again. Almost nothing is known of the thousands with reduced incomes who are somehow managing without resort to charity.

A burst of strength in domestic corporation issues, which quite eclipsed the gains in some sections of the foreign group, featured dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Although United States Government bonds closed generally higher, many issues failed to hold more than a percentage of their early grains through to the close.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13. -- Many members of the Garden Club of Southampton met this morning at Lenoir, the home of Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson. Mrs. Robert Waller, president of the club, presided.

The budget committee of the Board of Education announced yesterday that it would recommend suspension of the board's Summer school program for 1933 as another step in the interest of economy. The resulting saving to the city was set at $375,000.

In giving out the letter of Professor FRANKFURTER declining the proffered appointment to the Massachusetts Supreme Court, Governor ELY omitted a highly important part of it. This was the date. The letter was written, we understand, on June 29.

Amelia Earhart, transatlantic flier, set the wheels of her airplane to earth yesterday at 12:26:05 P.M., completing a transcontinental flight. Originally she had started out to beat the non-stop record set in June, 1929, by Commander Frank M. Hawks, but a forced landing early yesterday morning at Columbus, Ohio, set her back more than an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Dr. Victor A. Aimone, 45, medical officer in charge of Mount Alto Veterans' Hospital here, was shot through the heart and killed instantly in his office in the administration building at the hospital this morning. Frank Cassel, 40, of this city, a former patient at the hospital, was arrested and charged with the murder.

ALBANY, July 13. -- A boom for Mayor John Boyd Thacher 2d as Democratic candidate for Governor was started today by leaders of the Albany County organization. Edward J. O'Connell, county chairman, said he was writing to a group of up-State leaders of the party urging their support for Mayor Thacher's candidacy.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Advances in stocks and cotton helped today to strengthen the grain markets, and prices on the Board of Trade here moved up on outside and local buying. There was a better tone all around, especially at the close, since there was a subsidence of the pressure on all grains, which the light volume of trade had been unable to overcome.
DUBLIN, July 13. -- President de Valera gave notice in the Dail tonight of lightning retaliation for the new British duty on Free State produce.

PARIS, July 13. -- The Entente Cordiale has been resurrected, Premier Edouard Herriot told the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon after reading the text of the Franco-British "treaty of confidence." The gentlemen's agreement, whereby ratification of the Lausanne reparations accord is held up pending favorable action by the United States on war debts, is now completed, said the Premier, because France and Britain have promised to take a concerted attitude on intergovernmental debts.

CHICAGO, July 34 -- Prices of all live stock were set back today in the market here. Hogs declined 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds in a sluggish trade, the brunt of the decline hitting packing grades. The movement of packing sows, or lard hogs, has finally started, several weeks later than in other years.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- About 130,000 fingerprint records of appointees in the Federal service and applicants for appointment under Civil Service rules have been transferred from the Civil Service Commission to the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice.

The Bay Ridge branch of the Bank of Manhattan and Trust Company, 7,624 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, was robbed of $5,000 yesterday afternoon by three armed men who crowded employes and depositors into a rear room and rifled an open safe and the tellers' cages.

A method by which the late Ivar Kreuger obtained secrecy for at least one set of his market operations, together with evidence suggesting that his total stock purchases, as yet unestimated, were on a tremendous scale, became known yesterday as hearings continued before Henry K. Davis, special master in Federal court proceedings, to determine whether an American receiver should be named for the Kreuger Toll Company.

SULGRAVE, Northamptonshire, England, July 14 -- Ambassador Mellon led a pilgrimage of Americans and English today to the Washington Manor House in commemoration of the bicentenary of George Washington.

DUBLIN, July 14 -- Labor's allegiance to the de Valera government has been strained to the uttermost as a result of the President's announcement last night of retaliatory duties on British imports, and there is revived talk of an early general election.

PARIS, July 14 -- Premier Harriot, when asked by this correspondent tonight whether the remarks attributed to him by many newspapers last night regarding the Franco-British accord of confidence were true, said there had been no communique about the joint session of the finance and foreign affairs commission, which was not public, and that the words put in his mouth by the press were pure inventions.

LONDON, July 14 -- The tone on the Stock Exchange was better today, sentiment being helped by the rally in prices in the United States and progress in the war loan conversion scheme. Brokers reported only a slight increase in business, although the demand for British Government funds was greater and prices improved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whether we call it inflation or reflation, I am convinced that what America needs to lift her out of the depressed state is a liberal measure of that process. A timely resort to a liquefying treatment is as requisite for the maintenance of economic health as is a deflationary or hardening treatment.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $75,099,346, equal to $4.02 a share on 18,660,970 average number of shares outstanding during the period, comparing with $89,213,357, or $4.89 a share, in the first half of 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of what avail is it for a New York department store to spend thousands of dollars on advertising to entice customers if, when they arrive, there is no one to serve them?

MECHANICSVILLE, Md., July 14 -- Twenty-five members of a traveling carnival were wounded early today when a shotgun attack was made on men, women and children by unidentified men, said by police to have lost heavily at games of chance conducted at carnival booths during the past three days.

ABOARD THE YACHT MARCON, Sippican Harbor, Mass., July 14 -- Slipping into this blue-watered cove tonight at the wheel of the Myth II, Governor Roosevelt announced that he would ask Lieut. Gov. Lehman to take over his annual tour of inspection of State institutions.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 14 (AP) -- Bit by bit Sheriff Transou Scott added to his evidence in the Smith Reynolds death mystery today, but there was no indication a solution was near.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Two companies of marines showed up at the Capitol late this afternoon to go on guard duty against the "bonus marchers," but returned within ten minutes to their base at the Washington Navy Yard after causing a flurry of excitement.

Action favorable to mediation of the differences between the Internaional Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the three employing groups developed yesterday as the union members showed that an overwhelming majority had authorized heir officials to call a general strike if that step were deemed necessary.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 14 -- Mrs. Marshall Field, who has opened the grounds and gardens of Caumsett, her Summer home at Lloyd's Neck, near Huntingdon, several times this Summer for charity, will entertain on Saturday night with a large dinner and country circus for the benefit of the Long Island Biological Society.

MONTREAL, July 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals won their fifth straight victory when they took the opener from Jersey City today, 6-3, before 4,000. Claset gained his twelfth triumph of the season, though taken, out for a pinch hitter in the seventh. Boone hit a homer for the visitors over the right field fence with none on in the eighth.

A driver and his helper were kidnapped by three hijackers yesterday at Grand and Elizabeth Streets and ordered to drive to Brooklyn, where their truck containing $15,000 worth of cigars and cigarettes was stolen. Then they were taken to the Bronx by automobile and chased into a vacant lot, while the bandits escaped.

James Sinclair, chairman of the National-United Kingdom and the North Atlantic Freight conferences, said yesterday he had asked the United States Shipping Board for an opportunity to appear at the hearings of the board on the complaint of Pacific Coast lumber shippers on shipping rate schedules complicated by the differences in United States and Canadian money values.

Fulfilling expectations and at the same time providing a batting barrage for the entertainment of 4,000 devotees of cricket, the Australians, following up their almost unbroken string of successes in Canada, yesterday made their New York debut at Innisfall Park.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 14 -- Robert Eaton of Norwich, an 18-year-old flier, came near tying the American glider record for distance today in the national soaring contest here. Eaton, outdoing his competitors, soared to Millerton, Pa., a distance of ten miles, nine-tenths of a mile short of the national mark.
These orders were issued yesterday: Pensioned. On their own applications: PATROLMEN -- Patrick N. Walsh. 48th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 14, 1902.

TORONTO, July 14 (Canadian (Press) -- The design of Great Lakes freighters will undergo complete revision upon completion of the St. Lawrence waterway, shipping experts believe. Lake boats are not equipped for salt water. Their long, open decks with many hatches are not regarded as practical for ocean use.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In his letter to THE TIMES concerning the lack of public interest in municipal affairs Mr. Ackerman seems to strike the keynote of what is actually necessary before there can come a reorganization and reformation of local government.

Experiments of publishers and booksellers seeking to stabilize their industry have not thus far met with striking success, but there are signs of wholesome changes in frank discussion of their problems. When individuals and firms consult the Joint Board of Publishers and Booksellers about proposed publications in which they believe, and accept adverse decisions gracefully for the good of the whole trade, the outlook immediately becomes better.

PARIS, July 14 -- The "gentlemen's agreement" by which the principal powers concerned in the Treaty of Lausanne agreed not to ratify that treaty until each had obtained a satisfactory settlement of its own debts, and a covering letter by Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, to the government of France follow:

The speed James Mattern and Bennett Griffin found necessary to sustain in their attempted round-the-world flight to beat the record set by "Wiley Post and Harold Gatty caused their crash in Russia, Mattern said yesterday, when he and Griffin broadcast to America from Berlin after flying to the German capital from Moscow as passengers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 -- Opening the Presidential campaign in Ohio with an address before the Republican State Convention tonight, the Secretary of War, Patrick J. Hurley, declared that the "new deal" to which Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt pledged himself and his party in his acceptance speech at Chicago was merely a new deal from the old deck of William Jennings Bryan.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 14 -- Charges that Henry Perl, police justice of the village of Island Park, shared a $50 fine with two other officials were made today in a confession signed by Police Sergeant Fred Barth, Seward G. Spoor, Assistant District Attorney, announced here today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Washington Senators ran their winning streak to six straight games today by downing the St. Louis Browns in a twelve-inning battle, 5 to 4.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 -- Members of the Newport Garden Association met this afternoon at Hammersmith Farm, the home of the vice president, Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss. The speakers were Mrs. Gordon Abbott of Boston and Mrs. Ernestine Terry of Springfield.

TOLEDO, July 14 (AP) -- In one of the fastest races of the Toledo meeting May E. Grattan, driven by C. Earl Pittman, accounted for the Free-for-All Pace, feature of tonight's Fort Miami program, in straight heats. The third heat was won by Marvin Childs's Calumet Adam.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Norbeck farm relief bill was killed today by the Senate, which only yesterday had dispatched it to the House for final action.

GENEVA, July 14 -- A test of the new accord between Britain and France, so far as it relates to disarmament, is to be made immediately by the delegation from the United States to the world disarmament conference.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company reduced purchase money obligations and unsecured notes payable by $4,171,387 in the first quarter of this year and since that time has paid off the entire amounts, which were $1,378,765 of the former obligations and $4,890,000 of the latter, or a total of $6,268,765, according to the company's report for the twelve months ended on March 31, which was issued yesterday.
LATONIA, Ky., July 14 (AP) -- The greatly improved Major Lanphier, from the stables of F. and C. LeBuz, annexed the Silverton Purse today at Latonia.

PARIS, July 14 -- The International Federation of Business and Professional Women opened its conveitnon here today. Its board of directors will decide tomorrow whether to endorse the proposed amendment to the Pact of Paris formulated by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler that "would enable parties to the pact to inculcate joint measures of non-intercourse against any signatory nation threatening hostilities."
SILVER BAY, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt was credited by State Industrial Commissioner Frances Perking tonight with selling the idea of "industrial stabilization" to the country.

Holders of raw sugar continued yesterday to make it difficult for refiners to obtain sufficient stocks to meet requirements and forced the price 5 points higher on the day to 1.10 cents a pound. At the same time, a group of leading refiners announced that they would advance the price on refined sugar 15 points to 4.15 cents, effective this morning, the broadest advance of the year.

WEYMOUTH, England, July 14 -- King George, as the senior Admiral of the British fleet, was aboard the royal yacht Victoria Albert in supreme command when sixty ships of the home fleet steamed out of Weymouth Bay for today's naval manoeuvres, every ship cleared for action.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A list of all the loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was requested today by Senator Couzens, chairman of a special Senatorial committee authorized to inspect the loans and report to the Senate such facts as it may deem advisable.

Indications that a spirited controversy will ensue at Los Angeles prior to the start of the Olympic Games over the question of Paavo Nurmi's status and that he will not be reinstated, at least by the International Amateur Athletic Federation Council, were disclosed yesterday upon the arrival of a delegation of Swedish athletes in New York City en route to California.

The National City Company will offer today a new issue of $30,000,000 Consolidated Gas Company of New York 5 per cent debentures, due on July 15. 1957. The debentures will be priced at 94 to yield about, 5.44 per cent. Although the formal offering will not be made until this morning, the bankers reported yesterday that heavy advance orders were in hand.
NEW YORK. Williamson S. Howell Jr., First Secretary of the American Embassy in Paris, is arriving on the Europa and will be at the Ritz-Carlton.

Appearing at the stadium yesterday with the idea of showing just how they have managed within recent date to elevate themselves into second place, the Indians did remarkably well. In fact, they revealed such totally unexpected talents that they trampled all over the Yankees, who, having an exceedingly bad day of it, crashed down to defeat in the opening brush of a three-game series, 11 to 3.

An increase of $7,499,800 in gold earmarked for foreign account, the largest such movement since the outflow of gold came to an end last month, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Against this loss the receipt of $1,742,100 gold from Canada was reported, bringing the net loss for the day to $5,757,700.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- President Hoover and leaders in Congress were warned today by a committee representing nine principal American commodity exchanges that grain farmers of the nation faced the possibility of heavy penalties and a breakdown of marketing machinery during the heavy movement of the crops this Summer unless the tax on futures trading was reduced.

It was again the bond market which yesterday gave evidence of uniform trend. In the list of home securities on that market, the upward movement was positive and general. Among railway bonds particularly, advances of 2 to 5 points were unusually numerous.

With the arrival of some of the British copper executives here en route to the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, which starts next week, it was learned that they would advocate a tariff on imports of foreign copper into Great Britain.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 14 -- Semi-final positions in the women's invitation tennis tournament being staged in conjunction with the fortieth renewal of the Longwood Bowl event were gained by two unsceded players at the Longwood Cricket Club courts today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I reinforce the suggestion of your correspondent James Connell, who, in his letter of June 27, made practical application of the advice contained in your recent editorial, "A Vacation at Home" for children who cannot go to outdoor camps?

An employers' strike for better "pay," unique in strikes, was voted last night in the garment industry by the Allied Dress Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The organization, which comprises about 300 of the 2,300 dress contractors in the metropolitan area, pledged themselves to close their factories and remain closed until a minimum price schedule is agreed to by the dress jobbers, or wholesalers.
The Belair Stud's Pardee, a 3-year-old son of Sir Galahad III, sprang a surprise yesterday when he beat a band of the smartest sprinters now in training at Empire City.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 14 -- Theodore M. Brandle, New Jersey labor "Czar," was rebuffed today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor when he sought to make an explanation to organized labor's supreme tribunal of the many accusations that have piled up against him in this State in the last few years.
LONDON, July 14 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

A test of the constitutionality of an ordinance to prohibit street meetings of atheists and clergymen without permits was set in motion last night when Charles Smith, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Atheism, was summoned to appear in West Side Court next Tuesday following a meeting held in Columbus Circle.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The government was urged today to take the lead among "large-scale organizations" in putting into effect the five-day week in a report to President Hoover by the Council of Personnel Administration, of which Thomas E. Campbell, president of the Civil Service Commission, is the chairman.

Henry P. Talmadge, 85 years old, retired private banker, won an award of $879,195,88 yesterday when a jury before Federal Judge Harland B. Howe of Vermont, sitting temporarily in this district, returned a verdict in his favor in his suit against the United States Shipping Board.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Hoover warned Europe today against presenting a united front to the United States on war debts, and asserted that this government had not been consulted in the negotiations of the Lausanne reparations treaty.

MOSCOW, U.S.S.R., July 14 (AP) -- Vyacheslav Molotoff, President of the Council of People's Commissars, warned the Ukrainian Communist conference in a speech published here today against neglecting agriculture for the sake of industrial development.

After too long a silence Miss GERTRUDE STEIN, most original of American authors, speaks with most miraculous organ. She enriches Hound and Horn with a masterpiece entitled "Scenery and George Washington: a Novel or a Play." Strictly speaking, it is neither.

Several fishermen who came bach to town last night, following a trip to Beach Haven, N.J., reported on the off-shore fishing there. They said that in Little Egg Harbor it had been especially good during the last few days.

PLATTSBURG, K.Y., July 14 -- Extensive preparations have been made to entertain on Saturday hundreds of friends and relatives of the 2,400 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware attending the Plattsburg Barracks Citizens' Military Training Camp.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 14 -- Sheriff Transou Scott marked time today on his investigation of the recent fatal shooting of Z. Smith Reynolds, 20-year-old husband of the former Libby Holman, musical comedy singer, and son of the late R.J. Reynolds, tobacco manufacturer.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 14 -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia and Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., today reached the final of the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament for the Griswold Trophy at the Shenecossett Country Club.

Charging that two Italian vice consuls participated in the Fourth of July riot on Staten Island in which one Fascist was killed, Girolamo Valenti, editor of the anti-Fascist daily La Stampa Libera, telegraphed yesterday to Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. requesting a Congressional investigation into Fascist activities in the United States.

Arthur Train, whose novel "Princess Pro Tem" is published today by Charles Scribner's Sons, believes that during the next few years readers of books will seek relief from the depression in fantasy and adventure.

PARIS, July 14 -- Within two hours of each other America received from across the Atlantic two texts, the first, the Franco-British accord of confidence, later the "gentlemen's agreement" among France, England, Italy and Belgium. It is understandable here that the United States should be disturbed by these publications which unfortunately bear in their titles the words "gentlemen" and "confidence," which so often are used in shady connections.

Bonds on the Stock Exchange exhibited further strength yesterday under the leadership of railroad and industrial issues. Public utility loans eased in the late dealings, following a rapid run-up of prices on the previous day. Foreign loans were irregularly higher in dealings which dropped below $2,500,000.

How promptly and well, and at the same time sympathetically, this community cares for its citizens in times of sudden disaster was once more shown during and after Wednesday's devastating fire at Coney Island. Though the area was jammed with people on one of the Summer's hottest days, not a life was lost; no child went astray; no fire victim lacked thoughtful and intelligent aid from the city authorities.

TOKYO, July 14 -- The League of Nations commission of inquiry held a final conversation with Foreign Minister Uchida today and will return to China immediately to complete the drafting of its report, a task for which access to embassy archives in Peiping is essential.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14 -- Riding with fine team work and a persistent energy that kept them on the ball from the opening period to the close, the United States Army team, which will try for the national junior, championship, starting Saturday at the Rumson Country Club, today won the Meadow Brook Cup final.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 14 -- After being out of competition for several weeks, shelved by a sprained ankle sustained in a baseball game, George Voigt, one of the country's leading amateurs and Walker Cup nominee, returned to the golfing wars today apparently none the worse for his lay-off.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks reached a new high or low point for the year. The ratio of reserve for the System as a whole, which reached a new low figure last week, remained unchanged. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

General Plutarco Elias Calles, Secretary of War and former President of Mexico, spent part of the afternoon yesterday in New York en route to Mexico City with Senora Calles, who recently underwent a major operation at Boston.

The part played by the French Government at the Lausanne conference was praised yesterday by Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle. French Consul General, in a brief address at a reception to members of the French colony in New York marking Bastile Day.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- The Athletics ended their losing streak by scoring seven runs in a, seventh-inning rally to overwhelm the Detroit Tigers, 9 to 2, today.

The Salvation Army reported yesterday that gifts in kind, received during its current United Appeal for $600,000 with which to continue emergency relief, have been larger than at any time in its history.

Four damage suits for a total of $10,000,000 brought against the Coca-Cola Company by the Pepsi-Cola Company, Happiness Candy Stores, Inc.; the Mirror, and Loft, Inc., were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 -- Miss Alice Warner of the Greenwich Country Club won low gross honors with an 89 in the one-day medal play tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Country Golf Association, played over the course of the Greenwich Country Club today.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange opened yesterday at levels higher than the closing figures of Wednesday, but the advance of more than 30 points in the two days eliminated much of the short interest, and when a reaction developed in both stocks and grain, the prices ran back and closed near the bottom with losses of 20 to 22 points.

As a feature of the baby-costume fete to take place tonight at the Sands Point Bath Club, a "baby" parade will be held in which members and their guests, arrayed in garments of their infant days, will march, around the swimming pool terrace and on to the main dance floor, where awards will be made for Various costumes.

The metropolitan area of New York, and many other parts of the country sweltered again yesterday. But it was not as hot as all that, the Weather Bureau pointed out, for although the mercury rose to 88 degrees by 4:15 o'clock in the afternoon, that mark had been reached twice before this year.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- The . Phillies rained singles upon Pitcher Carroll of the Reds in the fifth inning today, greeted Ogden who relieved Carroll with Lee's triple on his first pitch and thereby built the foundation for an 11-to-6 victory.

Total bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the country amounted in the last week to $4,148,239,000, or $476,288,000 less than in the preceding week and 41.9 per cent below last year, according to R.G. Dun Co. In the same week last year the decline from the preceding week was $453,762,000.

CINCINNATI, July 14 -- Clarence (Buster) Crabbe of Los Angeles pulled in ahead in the 1,500-meter free style test at the Olympic trials at Coney Island pool this sizzling afternoon, but a freckled-faced youngster from Florida was right on his heels all the way.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 14 -- Although well seeded in the draw today for heats, favorites in the battle for places on the American Olympic track and field team face the keenest kind of a fight to survive the preliminaries tomorrow.

Thursday, July 14, 1932. Easy but quiet conditions pervaded all sections of the money market, business remaining upon a small scale at levels which showed no variation from Wednesday. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 per cent. while Street trades went at 1, and Federals at 1/8@1/4.

BELFAST, Friday, July 15 (Canadian Press) -- Police charging with drawn batons were required to break up a melee between rival political factions here last night, as a result of which five persons were confined to hospitals with injuries today.
LONDON, July 14 -- Gilbert Frankau, the author, married Miss Susan Harris at the Register Office this afternoon. It is Mr. Frankau's third marriage.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Looking to prompt action on the St. Lawrence waterway project, a subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee will hold hearings on the treaty during the adjournment of Congress. This will enable the full committee to proceed quickly after Congress reconvenes in December.

The names of 2,029 youthful residents of New York, New Jersey and Delaware, who are the successful candidates for the August group of the Citizens' Military Training Camps, were announced yesterday in an order issued by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 14 -- In a competition that was exceedingly close, the gray gelding Gray Knight, owned by Anthony and George Rives of Cobham, Va., and ridden by the former, was awarded the novice saddle horse championship, the only title event decided at the opening day of the ninth annual horse show of the Fairfield Hunt Club which began this morning on the club's grounds.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Hoover has sent a letter to Governor Meier of Oregon suggesting that a test suit be started in the Federal courts to ascertain the application of the anti-trust laws prohibiting joint agreements involving the lumber industry in Oregon and Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the Kellogg pact was being ratified the Senate Foreign Relations Committee reported: "Each nation is free at all times and regardless of the treaty provisions to defend itself, and is the sole judge of what constitutes the right of self-defense and the necessity and the extent of the same.

In a sudden and unexpected reorganization of the Southern Pacific Company's management announced yesterday, A.D. McDonald, vice chairman of the executive committee, was appointed president to succeed Paul Shoup. Mr. McDonald will have charge of operations of all the company's railway and steamship lines, thus for the first time since the company's early years concentrating this jurisdiction in one office.

A general sales tax whereby a large number of persons pay a small but certain amount for the support of the government is advocated by Calvin Coolidge in an article published in the current issue of Collier's Weekly today. Mr. Coolidge sees a grave threat to the whole structure of American democracy in the excessive taxation of a comparatively small number of the wealthy.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Insistence by the House on full publicity for all loans made hereafter by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation again deadlocked the $2,122,000,000 unemployment relief bill today, after the Senate and House conferees had reached an agreement on all its other features.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- Governor Ely. who put the name of Alfred E. Smith before the Democratic National Convention, continued silence today on his attitude toward the party's Presidential nominee, but he warned against any attempts to interpret his stand.

Plans for refinancing of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company, aided in the course of the day by an order from the Public Service Commission, appeared yesterday to call for the passing of control from the Associated Gas and Electric Company to other hands.
The Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity expects to save $800,000 on its budget for next year, according to its tentative estimate filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate.

MANCHESTER, N.H., July 14 (AP) -- The Right Rev. John B. Peterson, formerly of Somerville, Mass., was installed today as Catholic Bishop of New Hampshire at St. Joseph's Cathedral with William Cardinal O'Connell, Archbishop of Boston, presiding.

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- Assis Brasil, the Brazilian Ambassador, formally offered to the Argentine Foreign Minister today Brazil's good offices to bring about a renewal of diplomatic relations between Argentina and Uruguay.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 -- The text of Secretary Hurley's address to Ohio Republicans tonight was as follows:

Dry Goods Jobbers More Active. With an increase in the number of out-of-town dry goods wholesalers here this week, buying in the primary markets took on a more active tone, according to reports yesterday. Staple goods to cover immediate needs were ordered in fair quantities and jobbers operated more liberally on various Fall lines.

While city officials were investigating yesterday the causes of the fire which wiped out four square blocks of amusement places and homes in the heart of Coney Island on Wednesday, plans were put under way for the immediate rebuilding of the 1,000-foot stretch of the boardwalk which was destroyed and for the reconstruction as soon as possible of the ruined area.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during June was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 320,783 bales of lint and 46,680 of linters, compared with 332,439 and 50,178 in May this year and 356,674 and 61,796 in June last year.

Corporation Counsel Hilly, at a hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission, denounced the present electric-light rates as designed to promote the increased use of current by large business consumers at the expense of the small residential user.

Werner Jarvinen, winner of the Olympic discus championship for Pinland in 1906, has sent three sons to Los Angeles. And the official engraver may just as well inscribe the name of Jarvinen on two first-place medals right now. For Matti is almost a certainty in the javelin throw and Akilles in the decathlon.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- The first organized difference of opinion on the floor of the Northern Baptist convention since the sessions began Tuesday came today on the question of an appropriation for the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

From its national headquarters the American Legion has disowned responsibility for a law which will cost the public $100,000,000 during the present fiscal year for cash allowances to veterans in no way injured or disabled in the war. This is the act of July 3, 1930.

Sedgwick Harvey of the Salem-Crescent A.C., holder of the National A.A.U. junior featherweight championship, knocked out Andy Blasco of the International Y.M.C.A. in one of the special bouts on the card of amateur boxing contests at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Confusion over the program in the closing days of Congress increased tonight as the conferees on the home loan bank bill announced a deadlock and said they would have to ask their respective houses to decide between the Glass currency expansion plan and the Goldsborough price stabilization proposal.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 14 -- Senator Hull of Tennessee tonight attacked the tariff and trade policies of the Republican administration in a speech at the University of Virginia Institute.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Dazzy Vance, trying for his tenth victory of the season at Wrigley Field today, lost the decision to Guy Bush, but pitched great ball for seven innings. The Cubs triumphed, 4 to 1, scoring three of their runs off Babe Phelps in the eighth.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 14 -- A spectacular brand of putting by Tommy Goodwin, holder of the metropolitan junior golf title, enabled him to vanquish Robert A. Moffett, Princeton star, in the 36-hole final round match of the New York State junior championship at the Siwanoy Country Club today.

Taking cognizance of complaints that have been heard in Wall Street for some days, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday directed that no member "shall hereafter 'fail to deliver' against a short sale."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Resumption of the purchase of government securities on a scale somewhat below the level maintained before last week when acquisitions were virtually suspended was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in its weekly statement.

BERLIN, July 14 (AP) -- James Mattern and Bennett Griffin returned to Berlin today on their way home. They came by regular passenger plane from Moscow to be greeted by a cheering crowd at the Tempelhof Airdrome. Records were made of the reception there and were broadcast later from Berlin by radio, the fliers briefly telling the story of their mishap.
PARIS. July 14 -- Bright, sunny weather favored the traditional Bastile Day military review which passed before President Lebrun this morning on the Esplanade des Invalides.

Magistrate Ford in the Yorkville Court yesterday held Norman Walker, 46 years old, of 356 West Thirty-fourth. Street, business manager of the Broughton Institute of Orthodietetics at 134 East Forty-seventh Street, in bail of $1,000 to await action of the prand jury on a charge of grand larceny.

Through a quiet reassignment by Mayor Walker of terms of service in the Sanitation Department two days ago, Dr. William Schroeder, the Mayor's personal physician, friend and traveling companion, received a new six-year term as head of the Sanitary Commission at $22,500 a year, it was revealed yesterday.

Suggestions designed to aid dairy farmers by eliminating cut-price selling of retail milk in the New York City market were outlined yesterday at the second of the New York hearings of the joint legislative committee to investigate the milk industry. The hearings are being held at the Bar Association Building.
Several flats and taxpayers were included in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

A payment of $15,000,000 will be made today by the German Government against the credit of $125,000,000 extended to Germany in November, 1930, by a syndicate of bankers headed by Lee, Higginson Co. The credit was to have matured next , November but arrangements were made last April for prolonging it for one year.

A plan of selective distribution designed to strengthen the relationship of manufacturers and wholesalers and to restrict the number of competitive outlets through which mills are now selling was offered yesterday by the associate membership, composed of producers, of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at a conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PARIS, July 7 ((AP) by Mail) -- Tailored chiffon frocks with the texture of tissue paper and the trimness of a soldier's uniform have made their bow in the fashion world with the first hot days in Paris. Made of the filmiest fabrics, they are stitched and pleated with the firmness once accorded only to broadcloth.

The Petroleum Distillation Corporation has been formed by the Atlantic Refining Company, the Standard Oil companies of New Jersey and Indiana and the Foster Wheeler Corporation to acquire certain oil-distillation patents of these four companies, it was announced yesterday.

Holders of odd lots, or less than 100 shares, of the common stocks of forty-eight representative American corporations numbered 2,257,637 at the end of 1931 and were 88 per cent of the total of 2,565,250 stockholders in these corporations, according to an analysis prepared by De Coppet Doremus, odd-lot dealers on the Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Friday, July 15 -- Prime Minister MacDonald late last night invited President de Valera of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State to come to London to discuss the dispute over the land annuities, and early this morning it was announced that Mr. de Valera would take the first available mail boat today to keep the appointment.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- The Giants batted all the way around against Dizzy Dean in the seventh inning today, reaching the half-way point in their season's schedule with their thirty-fifth victory and their third in eleven battles since leaving home. They won by the score of 6 to 3, evening the series at one game each.

A further decline of $29,000,000 in total loans and investments in the week ended on Wednesday was reported yesterday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City. The banks showed a drop of $71,000,000 in investments against a rise of $42,000,000 in loans.
BUFFALO, July 14 (AP) -- The Newark Bears took a stronger grip on first place by winning both ends of a double-header from the Bisons today, 6 to 3 and 6 to 5.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Florenz Ziegfeld is gravely ill at a New Mexican sanatorium and constantly under a physician's care, his wife. Billie Burke, who is now playing in a radio studio picture, said here yesterday. Mr. Ziegfeld is not in immediate danger, she said.

A total of $97,554 has been disbursed by The New York Community Trust for charitable purposes during the first six months of 1932, the highest on record since the establishment of the trust in 1924, according to a tabulation transmitted to Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the trustees' committee, by Thomas Williams, chairman or the distribution committee, and made public yesterday by Ralph Hayes, director of the trust.

BERLIN, July 14 -- No post-war conference involving German interests has been followed so swiftly by such a devastating sense of national disappointment than that which less than six days ago was concluded at Lausanne and was supposed to put an end to reparations.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The task of drafting a statement of policy upon which member organizations may unite in vigorous defense of the Eighteenth Amendment during the coming political campaign was placed upon a committee today by the Nation Prohibition Board of Strategy.

After indicating the scope of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, and referring to some of the obstacles yet to be surmounted both in and out of Congress before the engineers can set to work, a correspondent of THE TIMES at Washington reports that "in the face of all these uncertainties officials would not attempt to predict when construction would be begun."
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 14 (AP) -- Peace negotiations with the revolutionaries who seized control of the State of Sao Paulo were reported to day to have been successful.

W. Averell Harriman, aviation promoter and son of the late Edward H. Harriman, railroad builder and financier, was elected chairman of the Union Pacific Railroad board yesterday. He also becomes chairman of the Oregon Short Line Railroad, the Oregon Washington Railroad and Navigation Company and the Los Angeles Salt Lake Railroad, subsidiaries of the Union Pacific.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senator Norris, Independent Republican from Nebraska, charged President Hoover today with a desire to halt the Federal Trade Commission's investigation of the power industry.

An irregular decline on the Stock Exchange late yesterday reflected the financial community's change of heart after an early display of confidence had put the whole list up sharply. So far as the important stocks were concerned, the price changes were negligible.

A list of 133 prominent Jews outside of the United States is published in today's issue of The American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune. The journal describes the list as "Our Foreign "Who's Who, being the first roster ever printed of outstanding Jews in lands other than the United States."
LONDON, July 14 -- The British Government spent today trying to correct the impression that the new Anglo-French entente represented a "united front" on the question of war debts.

Not Dead Yet. Our glib prophets of the speedy end of the capitalist system would do well to read what Lord SNOWDEN said in Parliament a few days agro. As a former Chancellor of the Exchequer he knows something about capitalism.

BUFFALO, July 14 (AP) -- Maxie Rosenbloom, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as world's light heavyweight champion, outpointed Lou Scozza of Buffalo in a fifteen-round title bout tonight. Rosenbloom weighed 175 pounds, the class limit; Scozza 173.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14 -- Mrs. Amory G. Hodges gave a luncheon today at the Meadow Club. Her guests were:

Great Britain and France are now making haste to assure the world that their agreements are simply to the effect that they will not do anything important in Europe without consulting each other. It is rather a pity that they did not consult each other about the form and time of their announcement of purpose.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- S.W. Labrot's Tred Avon, the little gray horse, cantered home first today in the featured Glen Ellyn Stakes at one mile at Arlington Park, and had one length and a quarter to spare over Late Date.

A complete investigation of the circumstances surrounding the shooting of Prohibition Agent Russell H. Whited last August during a raid on Braacker's Casino, 139 City Island Avenue, the Bronx, and of the testimony of witnesses, including Waited and three other agents, all of whom failed to identify Frank Ahearn, reputed lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, as their assailant, was ordered yesterday from two Federal sources.

The recently formed General Committee for the Protection of Real Estate Bondholders, of which Samuel Seaboury is counsel took a hand yesterday in suits over the reorganization of the Hotel Delmonico, 502 Park Avenue, when George Trosk, associated with Mr. Seabury, obtained permission in the Supreme Court to attend a private hearing on the litigation next week.

A committee of forty subcontractors has taken over the work of completing the $530,000 bathing pavilion in Jacob Riis Park, in the Rockaways, Queens, because of financial difficulties encountered by Robert J. Murphy, Inc., general contractors, and will endeavor to finish the contract by Aug. 1, it was learned yesterday.

With no reference in any of the speeches made to the reservations contained in the national prohibition plank adopted by their party at the Chicago convention, the Republicans of the Fifteenth Assembly District at the regular monthly meeting held last night at the clubhouse, 122 East Eighty-third Street, adopted a resolution in favor of "immediate repeal" of the Eighteenth Amendment.

LIMA, Peru, July 14 -- Three member of Congress were accused by the Minister of Government today of connivance in the recent rebellion in Northern Peru, and they will be tried despite strenuous efforts in Congress to prevent it.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,417,000,000, an increase of $40,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,465,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
