The United States liner Leviathan will arrive today from Bremen, Cherbourg and Southampton. Among her passengers are Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State, now a judge of the World Court. He is accompanied by Mrs. Kellogg.

A broad arcade promenade, about two stories high and nearly 500 feet in length, is one of the unusual architectural features included in the plans of the proposed new opera house in Rockefeller Center, it was learned yesterday.
GENEVA, July 15 -- The Council of the League of Nations granted today the Lausanne conference's request that it convoke a world monetary and economic conference.

A suit to compel trustees of the estate of the late Mrs. Mary Lily Flagler Bingham, widow of Henry M. Flagler. to save the Florida East Coast Railway from "destruction as a going concern by forced sale on foreclosure" has been brought in Supreme Court here, it was disclosed yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- Among dinner hosts tonight were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, who entertained at Old Trees for Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Gould Jennings of Fairfield, Conn., and for Mr. and Mrs. George B. Post of Bernardsville, N.J., who arrived today to pass the week-end with them.

The executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation approved yesterday an offer for the acquisition of the Rio Grande Oil Company. The proposal, which will he submitted immediately to the stockholders of Rio Grande Oil, contemplates the payment of approximately 495,000 shares of the common stock of Consolidated for the assets of Rio Grande.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- In the Hempstead Cups polo tournament first-round game on Hitchcock Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, the Camels, comprising three members of the Phipps family and John R. Fell Jr., defeated South Shore. 19 to 10.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Stock Exchange was dull today, with most sections less cheerful. British Government funds were easier in early dealings, although the tone improved later, and some losses were recovered.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The decision of the League of Nations to call the world monetary and economic conference will remove the parley from the controversy aroused by the Lausanne conference, according to Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador.

Announcement that the plan, proposed early in May by the Actors' Equity Association, to give free matinee performances of outstanding theatrical productions for the unemployed is "dormant at the moment" is made in the July issue of the Equity magazine, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Domestic politics and international questions growing out of the Lausanne conference dominated the Senate debate today in the lull between conference reports, and as a result the pages of the Congressional Record will be filled with campaign utterances that can be circulated to the electorate at the taxpayers' expense.

Further evidence of improved financial sentiment was to be found yesterday in the slow hut substantial advance on the Stock Exchange and in the uniformly higher range of quotations for important commodities. Nowhere was there any striking upturn in price, but the gains were well distributed, indicative, it seemed, of a more hopeful attitude generally toward all the markets.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Crude petroleum production in the United States in 1931 amounted to 851,081,000 barrels, a reduction of 5 per cent from the preceding year and the lowest annual total since 1926, according to the Commerce Department.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 -- Federal planes bombarded the front lines of the Sao Paulo rebels today and four wounded rebels were taken prisoner in the first skirmish of the revolt, according to dispatches received here.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, CAPE YORK, Greenland, July 15 -- On June 29 we cast off from the wharf at Brigus, Nfld., and proceeded on our voyage to Cape York, Northwest Greenland. Our purpose, with all the material on board, was to erect a monument at Cape York to the memory of Admiral Robert E. Peary, discoverer of the North Pole.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 15 -- The Public Service Commission was asked today by a committee of minority stockholders of the Metropolitan Edison Company, supplying electricity in the Reading and Eastern district, to investigate the financial structure, transactions and operations of the company and its holding corporation, the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

The management of the B.M.T., headed by Gerhard M. Dahl, has made a truce with the powerful group of stockholders, led by Bernard M. Baruch, which has been opposed to its policy in the negotiations for rapid transit unity, it was indicated yesterday.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 15 -- Governor Roosevelt of New York anchored his yawl Myth II about a half mile off the Eastern Yacht Club at 10:45 o'clock tonight, after a day of varied sailing conditions.

QUEBEC, July 15 -- Representatives of the Irish Free State reached Quebec tonight on the steamship Laurentic on the way to Ottawa, the first overseas delegation to reach Canada for the Imperial Conference.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Dry voters were urged tonight by the National Prohibition Board of Strategy to support candidates for Congress and State Legislatures who favored retention of the Eighteenth Amendment and were opposed to modification of the Volstead act.

Seventeen steamships will leave today for foreign ports, with 9,000 passengers, of whom 5,500 will go to Europe on eight liners. Sir Charles Tertius Mander, former Mayor of Wolverhampton, sails tonight for England on the Cunarder Aquitania, with Lady Mander, after visiting friends in the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Completely dispelling the jinx the Browns have held over them, the Washington Senators today defeated St. Louis for the second time in the current series, 8 to 7, and increased their winning streak to seven games.

Dr. DAVID SNEDDEN of Teachers College, formerly Commissioner of Education for Massachusetts, assumes to look back from the year 1950 and to prophesy in retrospect. By that time we shall he living, he dares to say, in a "clean, well-governed city," to which press and camera and wireless speech and television bring "heartening accounts of a fairly prosperous country."

CHICAGO, July 15 -- July wheat at 45 cents a bushel in the first hour of business on the Board of Trade here established today a new low for that month and was within 3/8 cent of the extreme low price for a future here.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over an unusually wide range and ended 17 to 19 points higher than on Thursday. The highest temperatures of the week in Eastern sections of the cotton belt, following more than a month of rainy weather, made shorts uneasy, and active covering by several professional operators ran all newcrop deliveries except October above the 6-cent level at one time.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- For the third time in three months governors of most of the Federal Reserve Banks conferred at the Treasury today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recommendation of the budget committee of the Board of Education that, the 1933 Summer schools be suspended seems to me to be unsound economy, to say the least, especially at a time when Summer jobs, for either pupils or teachers, are scarce.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 15 -- Establishment of the five-day week in the government service would be a "great economic and social achievement" and the forerunner of the shorter week in private industry, in the opinion of the legislative council of the American Federation of Labor, which is holding its semi-annual session here.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has made an offer to acquire the minority class A and B shares of the Pan American Foreign Corporation on the basis of $14.64 in cash and 5,435/10,000 of a share of its own capital stock for each share of Pan American Foreign.

LONDON, July 15 -- Prime Minister MacDonald and President de Valera failed tonight in their endeavor to avert the tariff war that now seems certain as a result of the contention of the government of the Irish Free State that no more land annuities need be paid to Britain.

JONES BEACH STATE PARK, L. I., July 15 -- A 15-year-old girl from Miami Beach, Fla., stole the show at the Olympic swimming and diving trials in Zach's Bay today as sixty-four of the foremost women aquatic luminaries of the country contested for positions on the American team before 20,000 persons at this immaculate public beach.

Officers and actors employed by Loew's, Inc., and its subsidiary, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, who earn more than $1,500 a week, will have their pay cut 35 per cent under a general salary reduction which will become effective Monday, it was announced yesterday.

NEW YORK. McClure Meredith Howland has gone to Rome to visit his sister, Countess Guerino Roberti. He will return in September and will go to Bernardsville, N.J., to be with his mother, Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce today informed officials at Washington that a "serious situation resulting in possible death and bloodshed will result inside of forty-eight hours if something is not done" about methods used in prohibition raids here.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 15 (AP) -- Though Calumet Ann's victory in the Hotel Fort Meigs Trot was one of the major features of the evening, another was the splendid triumph of Estrellita, a Toledo pacer owned by William Hoist and George Brice, in the 2:17 class pace -- opening event on tonight's Grand Circuit program at Fort Miami track.

New revenues amounting to more than $2,000,000 a year will be collected by the Fire Department through establishing fees for some of its services, taxing certain forms of fire insurance and increasing the present fees of the department, Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Reading Railway and the Lehigh Valley today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission reduced rates on anthracite coal from the Schuylkill, Lehigh and Wyoming coal fields in Pennsylvania to Pennsylvania points in an effort to overcome motor-truck competition.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- Capable twirling by Fred Fussell and timely hitting by Ollie Carnegie enabled the Buffalo Bisons to down the league-leading Newark Bears today by a score of 6 to 5. It was the first setback for the Bears in seven starts.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Hoover cut his own salary 20 per cent today. At the time it was anannounced that Vice President Curtis and the nine Cabinet officers would return 15 per cent of their annual pay to the government.

Philip D. Hoyt, First Deputy Police Commissioner, and Joseph Johnson, formerly Commissioner of Public Works in Manhattan, are being mentioned prominently as possible appointees to the $17,500 vacancy on the Sanitary Commission caused by the resignation last March of Charles S.Hand, It was revealed at City Hall yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 15 -- George Fissler of the New York A.C. placed on the United States Olympic relay swimming team today, leading five others to down a field of forty and qualify for a chance to win Olympic honors.

OTTAWA, July 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Governor General will open the imperial conference in Ottawa Thursday. Privy councilors, Senators and members of Parliament, together with guests from overseas countries, will be admitted to the galleries of the House of Commons for the opening only.

Inadequate police protection and laxity of magistrates were held part ly responsible yesterday by Dr. Philip I. Nash, president of the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce, for con ditions which made possible the disastrous fire at the resort last Wednesday.
BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Red Sox, 4 to 2, today in eleven innings, repeating their performance of yesterday, "which also went two extra innings.

BUFFALO, July 15 -- The largest flying boat in America is being constructed for the navy in the plant of the Hall-Aluminum Aircraft Corporation. Officials here declare it to be second in size only to the Do-X.

Joseph Castaldo, who according to George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, is the successor of Ciro Terronova, once known as the "artichoke king" of the Harlem and Wallabout Markets, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the income tax law and concealing assets in bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York replied today as follows to Girolamo Valenti, editor of La Stampa Libera, a New York anti-Fascist journal, who had requested a Congressional investigation of Fascist activities in the United States:

The steady upward trend of municipal bond prices this week, accelerated by the meagerness of new offerings, Is expected to be further aided next week by the comparative scarcity of new financing. Only $6,966,064 of State and municipal issues has been listed for award next week, comprising thirty-eight issues.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Allotments of $42,315,392 were made by the War Department today for continuing work on river and harbor improvements along lines previously laid down for the fiscal year. They will be followed by additional allotments of $17,684,608 when bids for contemplated work have been received and the amounts required for the projects are definitely determined.

The salt water fisherman these days may be found contemplating one or two trips. If ha is thinking of offshore fishing and a chance of getting tuna he is most likely planning a trip down the New Jersey coast, for the boats at Beach Haven have been, coming in with good catches.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 15 -- Two world's records were surpassed and another was equaled today in the first day's program of the final American Olympic track and field trials at Stanford Stadium, staged before a crowd of 12,000.

The country generally is in the middle of the midsummer lull in trade and industrial activity, according to reports received by business reviews. One of the more favorable aspects for the week is the continued rise in the prices of foodstuffs. At the same time industrial activity has continued to go to new low levels.

PARIS, July 15 -- The tone on the Bourse was exceptionally strong today, although trading was light. The improvement was ascribed to a favorable impression left by the various international accords published this week. The dollar rose to 25.51 1/4 francs, which is near gold par.

Conversations looking to an affiliation or merger of the men's furnishing stores of two of the largest clothing manufacturers in the country, Fashion Park Associates, Inc., and Hart Schaffner Marx, have been carried on for several weeks by officers of the two corporations, it was announced yesterday.

Representatives of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union will hold a private conference this afternoon at the Hotel New Yorker to discuss the question of mediation as suggested by George W. Alger, impartial chairman of the cloak and suit industries, when a deadlock occurred in negotiations for a new working agreement.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The peaceful siege of the Capitol, staged for several days by bonus-demanding veterans, continued its listless way today, but Capitol officials and Washington police exchanged sharp words about it.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers won a heavyhitting eleven-inning contest from the Athletics, 11 to 10, today to even the series at one game apiece.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan in Special Term in the Bronx awarded a total of $24,250 damages yesterday to fourteen members of Local 125. International Union of Operating Engineers, in their $100,000 suit accusing their own officials of blacklisting them so that they were unable to obtain work.

One of the largest audiences seen at the stadium concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra since the opening of the season listened to the orchestra under Willem Van Hoogstraten in the stadium last night. The first part of the program was devoted to Sibelius's first symphony.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The trend of the market here for hogs was reversed today. Prices ruled steady to 10 cents higher than yesterday, the top advancing 10 cents to $5.20 a hundred pounds, with the average up 5 cents at $4.65. Action also was better, smaller houses becoming good buyers when they realized that prices here were relatively lower than at points in the East.

Statistics which will be presented to the eleventh quadrennial World's Sunday School Association to be held in Rio de Janeiro, July 25-31, to which delegates from all over the world are now on their way, show that the total enrolment of the 330,874 Sunday schools on the nine continents is 35,309,318, an increase of 2,294,366 in the last quadrennium.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- The upturn in Giant affairs seemed definitely established today when the itinerant Terrymen took the lead in the series with the Cardinals, 2 games to 1, by virtue of a 12-to-4 victory which featured homers by Lindstrom and Ott and a scintillating all-round performance by Pitcher Fred Fitzsimmons.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 15 -- By the unanimous vote of eight resident taxpayers, a village to be known as Upper Brookville became incorporate tonight at an election at Wolver Hollow, the Summer home of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin.

CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- Outhit and outpitched, the Phillies nevertheless made smart fielding count for all it was worth to defeat the Cincinnati Reds today, 4 to 3, in twelve innings. The Reds had fifteen left on bases.

NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP) -- Five men were fatally burned and four others were missing after fire from exploding gasoline storage tanks today swept the oil tanker Rawleigh Warner in the Mississippi River above here.

It seemed to be the general sentiment of the Senate yesterday that $58 a page is too much to spend on printing political speeches in the Congressional Record. On the question before the Chamber -- which was whether Secretary HURLEY'S Columbus campaign harangue should be printed, in the log of Congress -- Senator ROBINSON of Arkansas implied that the matter wasn't worth 58 cents a page to anybody, including the readers of the Record.

As Wall Street judged the market, yesterday's moderate advance on the Stock Exchange was another reflection of the better feeling engendered by the preparations to adjourn Con- gress soon. A factor which also weighed heavily with the speculative fraternity was the continued improvement in commodities.

DUBLIN, July 15 -- While President de Valera was on his way to London today the Dail, by 68 votes to 57, passed through all its stages the emergency tariff bill that had been introduced as a reprisal against Britain for the imposition of the 20 per cent ad valorem duty on the farm produce of the Free State.

The first default on a publicly held German dollar bond issue occurred yesterday when payment was not met on the maturing issue of $10,000,000 Saxon Public Works. Inc., 5 per cent guaranteed notes. The default was on only $7,000,000, however, since the obligor holds $3,000,000 of the issue bought from time to time for the account of its sinking fund.

The semiannual statement of the Tri-Continental Corporation issued yesterday shows that the investment trust has improved its cash position by about $1,500,000 to $9,442,785 since the end of 1931, with the present total amounting to about 37 per cent of the total net assets.

The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation yesterday paid off in cash the $9,060,000 remaining 3 per cent gold notes which were due, chiefly out of funds that had heen provided by the Chase National Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company and practically every banking institution in Rochester.

The gold storks of the country sustained yesterday the largest single day's gain since the cessation of the gold outflow early in June, as a result of the release from earmarking of $16,476,200 of gold. The day's net gain was $16,992,200 because, in addition to the large decrease in earmarked gold here, $516,000 of the metal was received at San Francisco from China.

PARIS, July 15 -- One more of the past week's many misunderstandings was cleared up today when Premier Herriot declared to inquiries that his reported words linking the Franco-British accord and the question of the international debt situation entirely misrepresented what he had said.

LAKEHURST, N.J., July 15 -- At the naval air station here a new device to simplify the docking and undocking of airships -- a telescopic, mobile mooring mast -- is nearly ready for test. Built of fabricated steel on designs supplied by the Bureau of Aeronautics, United States Navy, at Washington, the mast can reach up like a giant finger 160 feet into the air.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of New Jersey, announced last night that Chairman James A. Farley of the Democratic National Committee had accepted an invitation to address the Democratic State Committee of New Jersey at a meeting to be held at Spring Lake on Thursday.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Appealing is the device of the Roosevelt press agents for Garnering the votes of the owners of canary birds and brown dogs. They have let a breathless world know that, upon hearing over the radio the announcement of Governor Roosevelt's nomination, a brown dog, habitat Brooklyn, and by a stroke of genius named Brownie, seized hold of a rug and waved it triumphantly on high.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 15 -- In case Macdonald Smith, the Carnoustie Scot, hopes to retain his title as metropolitan open golf champion, it will be necessary for him to put together a pair of great rounds tomorrow, when the field plays its final thirtysix holes over the Lido Country Club course.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, national chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, speaking at a meeting held at the new Southampton High School this evening, declared that the Republican prohibition plank would launch the country upon "an experiment more uncertain and confusing than the Eighteenth Amendment itself."

MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- Aquiles Cruz, chairman of the Board of Arbitration and Conciliation, and Gregorio Cruz, an aide, resigned today because of charges by Minister of Industry and Commerce Abelardo Rodriguez that they had failed to comply with the law by deciding within forty-eight hours as to the legality of strikes on the Southern Pacific Railroad of Mexico and the Mexico City street car system.

A great crusade should be aroused in this country in the interests of religious education. Dr. Walter Scott Athearn, president of Butler University, Indianapolis, Ind., asserts in his book "The Minister and the Teacher," published recently by the Century Company.

The broad offer of the Atlas Corporation, a general management investment trust, to exchange its shares for those of almost every active fixed investment trust, which was made public yesterday, aroused an outburst of protest from heads of the latter group.
Owen Madden, ex-convict and reputedly one of Broadway's leading racketeers, a Sing Sing prison inmate only ten days, has applied for release on parole, it became known yesterday.

Coast Guard vessels from the Cape May (N.J.) station were busy yesterday searching in the vicinity of Absecon Light for the 25-foot sailing boat Darling, which had been reported early in the morning by the master of the Dollar liner President Monroe to be abandoned about fourteen miles off the light.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 15 -- A new name will be inscribed upon the historic Longwood Bowl as the result of the defeat of two favorites in the semi-finals of the men's singles at the Longwood Cricket Club courts today.

MONTREAL, July 15 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals won their sixth straight game and their second of the series when they beat Jersey City today. 5-3. Bill McAfee, Royal pitcher, playing right field for Shiver, hit a homer with two on in the seventh to decide a struggle.
CONWAY, Ark., July 15 (AP) A fist fight between Representative Heartsill Ragon and Frank Bird, a Little Rock attorney, enlivened a political rally and picnic at Mount Vernon yesterday.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- Great Britain pondered President Hoover's letter to Senator Borah today, in which he declared the United States would not be pressed on the debt question by any combination in Europe, but the general attitude seemed to be that the question was cleared up by the official explanations here yesterday.

PLATTSBURG BARRACKS, N.Y., July 15 -- Athletics at the Citizens Military Training Camp from now an will occupy an increasingly important role in camp activities, according to the announcement today by Colonel George A. Herbst, post commander, of dates for the regimental tracK and field, boxing, tennis and swimming championships.

MANILA, Saturday, July 16 -- Governor General Theodore Roosevelt, in his first message to the Philippine Legislature, delivered this afternoon, pointed out economies already accomplished, amounting to 6,500,000 pesos (about $3,250,000), and stressed the necessity of further efforts to guarantee a balanced budget.

VATICAN CITY, July 15 (AP) -- The Congregation of the Holy office today placed on the Index Expurgatorius "The History of Europe in the Nineteenth Century." by Benedetto Croce, the noted anti-Fascist philosopher. Catholics henceforth are forbidden to read the work by the man who so vigorously opposed ratification of the Lateran treaties.

Continuing its campaign against congestion and fire hazards in public schools, the Emergency Committee on School Overcrowding, of which George Dyson Friou, Brooklyn attorney, is chairman, wrote to Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman yesterday, asking his cooperation in the removal of thirty-three frame school buildings in Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Richmond.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The criticisms of the United States district judges for appointing the Irving Trust Company as receiver in bankruptcy rather than individual receivers are not based on any lack of efficiency on the part of the trust company.

Tropic heat that set in Tuesday over many sections of the country continued unabated yesterday. The fourth day of the wave shattered records for the date in parts of the South and West, sent the mercury near or above the 100 degree mark over most of the nation and caused eighteen fatalities.

Almost 100 men and women who assembled yesterday at the regular Friday afternoon session of the bodyand-soul clinic in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie heard the preliminary plans of Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, to resist the disestablishment voted on June 27 by the church vestry, when it decided to restore St. Mark's to strictly canonical worship.

Favorable progress in the Salvation Army's campaign for $600,000 has provided needed funds for its four free fresh-air camps for underprivileged children, all of which now are filled to capacity, it was announced yesterday after the arrival of thirty boys and girls from the Cherry Street Settlement at the Army's Bear Mountain camp.

Signs of a turn to better conditions are seen in certain fields of business. In the numerous concerns listed by the Industrial Relations Section of Princeton University, in its second report on company loans to unemployed workers, there is a strongly optimistic feeling.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 15 -- After more than eight hours of police questioning regarding the beating earlier in the day of Mrs. Valeria Hizenski of Syosset, mother of a county detective, Hyman Stark, 20 years old, of 10 Suffolk Street, Manhattan, one of four men arrested for that attack, died tonight in Nassau Hospital, where he was taken after being stricken ill in police headquarters.

Domestic corporation bonds surged upward again yesterday on the Stock Exchange in moderately active trading, while foreign loans were irregularly lower and United States Government bonds generally lower. As measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES averages, the best improvement occurred in industrial bonds, with utility and railroad bonds following in the order named.

The rough-riding Indians, who have been tearing through the East at an alarming rate of speed, were brought up sharply at the Stadium yesterday. They crashed full tilt into Vernon Gomez, the singular Castilian, whose rare faculty for doing the unusual at the most unexpected moments so inspired his fellow-Yankees that they routed the distinguished Wesley Ferrell inside of four rounds and went on to win, 8 to 5.

The exhibition of American painters at the Knoedler Galleries will continue, along with "Fine Prints of Six Centuries," until the end of September. The show contains, embedded in much mediocrity, six canvases which should be looked at with thought by any one interested in our artistic past -- and the hints it may hold of the future.

An investigation was ordered yesterday by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to determine whether charges by representatives of retail cleaners and tailors warranted an application to the Supreme Court for the appointment of a referee and a motion for dissolution of the Metropolitan Cleaners and Dyers' Trade Association.

BURLINGTON, N.J., July 15 -- The first regular infantry unit of the United States Army to serve in France said farewell to an old commander and greeted a new one this afternoon in a ceremony on the parade grounds at Camp Dix. The Sixteenth Infantry of the First Division, stationed here for Summer manoeuvres and to aid in reserve and citizens' military training activities, still numbers some World War veterans among its active personnel.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S obvious intention to urge the nomination of Lieut. Gov. LEHMAN as his successor ought to be conclusive. The wishes of a Presidential candidate are usually heeded by party managers, at least in his own State. Them have been, it is true, reports that the Democratic organization in this city intended to favor some other man for the Governorship, and up the State one or two other possibilities have been brought to public notice.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 15 -- Mrs. Robert W. Lovett of Boston, favoring repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, was the speaker this afternoon at a luncheon at the Maplewood Hotel, Pittsfield. About 120 women were present. Miss Laura Dwight of Williamstown presided.
LONDON, July 15 (Canadian Press) -- The second GentlemenPlayers cricket classic, like the first, was drawn at Lord's today at the close of the three days of play.

Richard Pending's Ned O., first in the Columbia Purse feature on the Empire City card yesterday and clearly the best horse in the race, was disqualified in favor of Mrs. Kathleen Jesberger's Colossal, which was beaten a head by Ned O., after the latter had come from last place to first with a great show of speed and courage.
PARIS, July 15 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

A committee representing various prohibition organizations has been meeting in Washington to lay plans for the coming campaign. So far as a national ticket is concerned, the choice has not been easy. It is plainly out of the question for them to endorse Governor ROOSEVELT, leading a party committed to repeal.

Another victory, the second of their United States tour, rewarded the efforts of the Australian cricketers when they encountered another picked eleven of the West Indian cricketers of New York before a crowd of 2,000 at Innisfail Park yesterday.

Twenty peddlers arraigned before Magistrate Greenspan in Yorkville Court yesterday were reprimanded and nineteen first offenders were fined $5 with the alternative of two days in jail. James Cioffe of 209 East Seventy-sixth Street was fined $2.
DUBLIN, July 15 -- President Eamon de Valera stood up, holding out his hand in welcome and smiling down at your correspondent -- for he is an exceptionally tall man.

The taking of testimony on the application of the New York Central Railroad for a 40 per cent rise in commutation fares was concluded yesterday at a joint hearing of the Public Service and Transit Commissions. Spokesmen for the city and various Westchester communities opposing the application will argue next Wednesday for dismissal of the application.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 15 -- Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney will spend the weekend with her mother, Mrs. Vanderbilt, and her sister, Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, at The Breakers.

No change was perceptible in any section of the money market, either in the way of business or rate variation. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and business accommodation were all steady and unchanged from Thursday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- The rupture of diplomatic relations between their countries has brought the people of Argentina and Uruguay closer together than they have been in several years. Newspapers, public men and organizations in each country are trying to outdo one another in expressions of admiration.

MADISON, Wis., July 15 -- Seven Wisconsin utilities companies were ordered by the State Public Service Commission today to cease, payments of dividends on common stock pending a formal hearing, when the companies will have an opportunity to show cause why a final order should not be issued to prevent such payment.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Unemployment relief legislation, over which House and Senate conferees had been deadlocked, was pushed through the House today and was ready for the Senate soon after Senate conferees yielded on the point in dispute -- the policy of full publicity for all loans advanced by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WESTFORT, Conn., July 15 -- Championship honors among the saddle ponies rested today on the acatly turned shoulders of the little chestnut mare Blue Sky, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Alien Tobey of Southhold, L.I., the competition being one of the featured numbers of the second day of the ninth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.
ALBANY, July 15 -- Twenty up-State leaders have endorsed the candidacy of Mayor John Boyd Thacher 2d for Governor, Edward J. O'Connell, chairman of the Albany County Democratic Committee, said today.

Charges of "fraud and collusion" in the sale to the city Department of Sanitation in 1931 of thirty snow loaders were made yesterday by Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial in an affidavit submitted to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins in opposing a suit by the N.P. Nelson Iron Works, Inc., to compel the city to pay $93,250 due on the loaders.

BERLIN, July 15 -- President Hoover's letter to Senator Borah explaining that the United States refuses to allow reparations to be linked with the inter-allied debts holds no surprises for most German political observers. The President's stand is the same as that which has been taken by the von Papen government as well as the recent Bruening government.

BOSTON, July 15 -- Scientists from all parts of the United States will set up instruments near Fryeburg, Me.; Conway, N.H., and near-by towns in preparation for the total eclipse of the sun on Aug. 31, visible in the United States only in New England.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Without an opposing vote the House late today passed the Bacharach bill lowering the rate of interest on adjusted service certificates and making immediately available the 50 per cent loan privilege on all certificates issued in the future.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Without an opposing vote the House late today passed the Bacharach bill lowering the rate of interest on adjusted service certificates and making immediately available the 50 per cent loan privilege on all certificates issued in the future.

The United States liner President Roosevelt arrived yesterday from Hamburg, Havre and Southampton commanded for the last time by Captain George Fried, whose many rescues at sea have made him known to the entire world. Captain Fried bade farewell to his crew and took his effects ashore to await the arrival of the new liner Manhattan, which he is to command.
PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) -- A brilliant bit of pitching by the veteran Remy Kremer allowed the Pittsburgh Pirates to even their series with the Boston Braves today, 1 to 0.
ALBANY, July 15 -- When Governor Roosevelt returns to Albany next week he will find several State matters demanding his attention.

BERLIN, July 15 -- With almost complete abstention of the investing and speculative public from the Boerse today, transactions in the stock market were confined mostly to room trading. Disappointment over the "gentlemen's agreement" and the situation in domestic politics caused bearish tendencies.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 15 -- Formal approval has been given by the State Banking Department to the merger of the Dry Dock Savings Institution and the United States Savings Bank of the City of New York.

Fire in the subcellar of the threestory vacant building at 139 Broadway, between Cedar and Liberty Streets and diagonally across from the Equitable Building, could not be reached yesterday afternoon until after holes had been drilled into the walls of adjoining buildings, through which hose lines were laid.

The Imperial Economic Conference meets at Ottawa next week. Most of the delegates other than those from Canada are at sea. Their Governments must be almost equally at sea as to what is likely to be accomplished. Even cheerful Mr. THOMAS, Secretary of State for the Dominions, admits that the reconciliation of conflicting interests seems "insoluble," and is forced to take refuge in rhetoric about "our kith and kin" and "blood of our blood."

Emanuele Grazzi, Consul General of Italy in New York, issued a statement yesterday in connection with rioting following the memorial ceremonies at Garibaldi House, Rosebank, S.I., on July 4. He declared also that Nobile Giacomo di Martino, the Italian Ambassador at Washington, was not present at the Garibaldi ceremonies.
Twice do the faithful seek their reward at the gates of Heaven: on the way in and on the way out-Old Spanish Proverb.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 15 (AP) -- An unidentified man who asked directions for reaching the Reynolds home a few hours before the fatal shooting of Smith Reynolds, husband of Libby Holman, was sought today by Sheriff Transou Scott.

Basing its application on the charge that $50,000,000 of German bonds belonging to the International Match Corporation were stolen by the late Ivar Kreuger, the Irving Trust Company, trustee in the match company's bankruptcy, instituted proceedings in Federal Court yesterday to safeguard payment of $1,500,000 interest due on the German securities.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 15 -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia won the fourteenth annual women's invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Country Club today by defeating Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., 7 and 6.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 15 -- Robert Walker, or Huntington, as he sometimes called himself, pleaded with County Judge William L. Barnum today for a life sentence to Auburn prison, rather than a sentence for one year, and won.

Officials of American steamship lines report that American travelers are patronizing ships of the merchant marine this year more than ever before. It is the first time in the history of American shipping, they say, that any apparent "patriotic spirit" in travel has shown itself by increased bookings.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Silvio Coucci, aboard Max Hirsch's Swift and True, and Hank Mills, on Prose and Poetry, staged another instalment of their rivalry today in the $2,500 added Lake Shore Claiming Stakes at Arlington Park, with the former gaining the decision.

Hardware Sales Above Estimates. With the seasonal demand for Summer goods declining, jobbers and retailers of hardware turned attention to Fall merchandise this week. According to wholesalers, the volume of Summer business was above expectations and retailers feel more confident of future trade.

Fourteen Argentine athletes arrived in New York City yesterday aboard the M.S. Eastern Prince on their way to the Olympic Games at Los Angeles, where they will join a squad of twenty-oneteammates who landed here two weeks ago. A delegation of Swiss competitors also came here on the S.S. Aquitania.

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and now a Justice of the World Court, arrived yesterday with Mrs. Kellogg on the United States liner Leviathan. Mr. Kellogg, who had been away for three months, said he had found no war clouds over Europe, that Europe's troubles were purely economic and that the nations abroad were "getting back on their feet again."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The revolutionary government of Chile headed by Carlos G. Davila, former Ambassador to the United States, as Provisional President, has formally approached other governments for diplomatic recognition.
ALBANY, July 15 -- Governor Roosevelt has approved the purchase of a site of 700 acres at Coxsackie, Greene County, where a $1,250,000 institution for delinquent minors will be constructed.
LATONIA, Ky., July 15 (AP) -- The featured White Villa Purse, at five and a half furlongs, was captured by Chuck B., from the Serenata Stock Farm Stable, today at Latonia.
NEW YORK STATE, with fifty-two broadcasting stations, is now in the lead, with California second by virtue of its forty-three transmitters.

WITH the great Whig name of Stanhope most of us are vaguely familiar. By an effort we may remember that the first Earl Stanhope married Lord Chatham's aunt, Lucy Pitt, that the third Earl married Hester, sister of the younger Pitt, and that her daughter.

KNOEDLER GALLERIES -- Summer exhibition of American painters including John Singer Sargent, Theodore Robinson, J.F. Murphy, H. Dudley Murphy, A. Harrison, Childe Hassam, George Oberteuffer, A.H. Gorson, Dwight Tryon and Ernest Lawson.

WANTAGH, L.I., July 16. -- Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman formally opened the new Wantagh spur today. The spur, a three-mile stretch of highway connecting the Southern State Parkway with the Jones Beach Causeway, lies entirely in the village of Wantagh and was constructed at a cost of $1,500,000.

AT NO other season of the year is the motor car so like a human being in its reaction to the weather as when Summer's heat becomes intense and continuous. It is for this reason that there is special value now in a car maintenance program which many motorists habitually ignore.

Although two of the three employing groups involved in the controversy with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union have shown a conciliatory attitude toward mediation, the position of the third group brought union leaders yesterday to the belief that a general strike of 27,000 garment workers this week is inevitable.

HAVERHILL, Mass., July 16. -- Word reached here today of the drowning at Lake Sebago, Me., this morning of Frederick P. Liberty, aged 46, president of the George B. Leavitt Shoe Company of Haverhill and Farmington, N.H.

IN his preface Signor Barbasetti is at pains to point out that after teaching at the Italian Fencing Masters' School in Home and the Austro-Hungarian Central Fencing School in Vienna he was a private instructor in Paris. He implies that personal observation and experience in countries with different psychological backgrounds have enabled him to expound an unbiased theory of his art.

BERLIN, July 16. -- The government made public tonight its ordinance establishing a Federal "voluntary labor service," which is so experimental in scope, quantitatively so limited and generally contains so little innovation that there is wonder why so much fuss was made about it beforehand.

CASTING is under way for the a No. 2 company of "Of Thee Sing." According to present booking schedules, which do not necessarily hold good in the Fall, the troupe will open in Cleveland the week after Labor Day and spend another six days or so in Detroit before beginning an indefinite stay in Chicago.

FAITHFUL copies of eighteenth-century English furniture, including unusual pieces rarely found in this country in Colonial days, are now being made. Especially noticeable are chairs. tables and cabinets which duplicate originals on which Chippendale lavished his art of carving, many disclosing his predilection for the "Chinese taste."

BERLIN, June 25. SUMMER has come in -- and how! It has laid its warm hand on the German theatre and just about squashed it into unconsciousness. There wasn't much life left in it by late Spring, but the advent of June did it in completely.

While firemen still sprayed the soggy ruins of the section of Coney Island which was destroyed in Wednesday's conflagration, a small riot occurred yesterday at the Emergency Home Relief Bureau when persons who said they were destitute but had not suffered in the fire demanded that rent checks be given to them as well as to the fire victims.

MONTREAL, July 16 (Canadian Press). -- The Montreal Royals won their seventh straight victory when they beat Jersey City, 7 to 6, in twelve innings today in the first game of a double-header. Walker's double, scoring Gautreau, broke up a long contest which lasted 3 hours 40 minutes.

Fair progress was made in all departments of the listed bond market yesterday except in the case of United States Government bonds, which closed unchanged to 22-32 point lower. Railroad bonds led the advance in domestic corporation issues, with utilities and industrials next in line.

SPOKANE, July 16. -- The unemployment situation has revived one of the romantic and picturesque industrial activities of the Pacific Northwest this year-placer gold mining. It is estimated that nearly 3,000 men and women are panning the gravel of streams in Eastern Washington, Northern Idaho and Western Montana this Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The White House late tonight stood in the centre of a huge isolated area, shut off by police from both automobile and pedestrian traffic, after an attempt by veterans wanting the bonus to establish a picket in front of the Executive Mansion had been frustrated.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 14 -- There is not a great deal of breast-beating or flag-waving in Oklahoma over the Democratic repeal plank, but there is a universal feeling that this State will return to the Democratic column in November with an overwhelming vote.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Dr. Harmodio Arias, President-elect of Panama, will be met at Quarantine by officials of the United States and Panama Governments upon ,his arrival in New York tomorrow on the steamer Quirigua of the United Fruit Line.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- For the first time since yacht racing started on July 4, the squadron of the West Hampton Country Club, which races on Moriches Bay off the Speonk Shore, had the lightest of Summer breezes to drive a fleet of fifty yachts over the usual triangular course.

THE Ottawa conference may mark an important stage in the evolution not only of British economic policy but also of the British Commonwealth. The place of its meeting and the conditions under which it has been convened show clearly -- even dramatically -- how far this evolution has already proceeded.
In the heroic songs of Iceland there is a quatrain which runs in English:

ABOARD THE YACHT MARCON, Portsmouth, N.H., July 16. -- A fair southeast wind sped Governor Roosevelt around Cape Ann today to bring him into a quiet little harbor below this city. Tonight he sat aboard the Myth. II, with his 300-mile cruise from Port Jefferson, L.I., ended.

The steamship Lurline, which is to be launched at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow at the Fore River Yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., is the last of three passenger vessels constructed there for the Matson Oceanic Service.

Men with settled tastes do not give in easily to the new order of things. A reader of The Week-end Review petulantly inquires: "Can you or any of "your readers explain why it has be"come impossible to buy any pipe with "a round-bore mouthpiece?" He agrees that the fan mouthpiece is probably more convenient for smokers whose natural denture has in the course of time yielded to manufactured symmetry.

THE most disturbing circumstance in connection with crime in recent years, both in this and in other countries, is the increasing number of youthful criminals. The New York City Police Commissioner, in his report for 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Chandler's letter in THE TIMES relative to your editorial on Professor Ripley's observation with respect to truck competition overlooks several important factors. In the first place, every time the railroads have developed a good idea to merchandise their transportation services the Interstate Commerce Commission has proceeded to throw a monkey wrench into the works and stop the machinery.

THE sale of the Chester Beatty collection of Western manuscripts had an inauspicious beginning. The first portion sold at Sotheby's last month brought the unexciting total of u23,053. To this should be added the u3,500 for which were bartered privately the six leaves from the eighteenth-century English Psalter by W. de Bralles.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 16 -- Messages of condolence came from all over the nation today to the family of Mrs. Daisy Alien Story, former President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution, who died here yesterday of a heart attack.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 16. -- The course of the Hoover Administration during the economic crisis was criticized by speakers at the round-table discussions today of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

In an address, read by Prince George, before delegates to the Ottawa conference at a Canadian Day dinner in London. I DO not think I exaggerated when I say that the eyes not only of the empire but of the world will be turned to Ottawa. But while we recognize the difficulties we must not allow misgivings to overwhelm us; failure is unthinkable.

BLACK ROCK, Conn., July 16. -- In the regular Saturday series race among the Atlantic class boats of the Black Rock Yacht Club sailed today only two of the five starting boats finished, three being disqualified for rounding the wrong buoy. John Field's Margot was the winner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Transportation men are always interested in the views of W.H. Chandler, director of the Traffic Bureau of the Merchants Association, some of which are expressed in his communication to THE TIMES dealing particularly with the competition between the railroads and the trucks.

THE recent decision of the Norwegian Government to occupy another narrow strip of barren Greenland coast revives an old controversy and may serve to hasten a long-awaited decision of the Permanent Court of International Justice at The Hague, to which the dispute was referred last year by Denmark.

CATHERINE THE GREAT is one of those rulers seemingly doomed to remain a vague impression in the minds of most people. She lived on after the French Revolution got under way and after the United States had become a nation, yet in many ways she seems as remote as Mohammed or the Great Cham.

The trans-Channel debate of the past week between London and Paris on the point of whether the AngloFrench accord provides for a united front among our debtors in any future negotiations with Washington concerning the war debts owed the United States seems to partake olfactorially of the nature of a red herring.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Money in circulation increased $216,000,000 during June, according to figures issued by the Treasury today. The increase was attributed largely to banking difficulties and hoarding.

PARIS. EVERY day -- and practically every hour -- of the Grande Semaine was packed with sartorial interest. Each day at the races has a fashionable character all its own. All the most elegant Parisiennes turned out in special frocks for the course des haies (grand hurdle race) at Auteuil; in fact, that was the most typically French event of this big week.

Suit to recover $50,000,000 of German Reich bonds that the late Ivar Kreuger allegedly stole from the International Match Corporation in 1931 when he was its president was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the corporation.

HAMILTON, Ont., July 16 (Canadian Press). -- Two more Canadian records were broken and another tied today in the final program of the Canadian Olympic track and field trials as young Bert Pearson, Hamilton, led the way by recording a brilliant triumph in the 200-meter dash to add to his record smashing 100-meter victory yesterday.

One hundred and twenty-five day students of the New York University School of Commerce, Recounts and Finance have been named on the honor roll. Professor Gerald E. Se-Boyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing of that division, announced yesterday.

EXCITABLE, forgetful and just plain absent-minded cinema patrons are responsible for an interesting department in the big Broadway motion picture house. It is the Lost and Found booth. Of the hundreds of thousands attending the three major cinema palaces monthly, more than 2,000 lose something.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Should not the Englishman and his wife mentioned in THE TIMES editorial who enjoy reading aloud to each other be called artists instead of a hero and a heroine? Certainly they are alert to beauties unfathomed by the crowd and have learned delightful use of leisure.

The women's New York State golf championship, inaugurated for the first time two years ago, will occupy a chief place on the calendar of sports this week as the third annual tourney begins tomorrow at the Yahnundasis Golf Club, Utica.

THE founding of Plymouth is so encrusted with myth, so much a part of the generality of every child's common school education, that it is literally thought-stopping to try to think of it in any other than two standardized ways.

MEMBERS of the de Valera Government apparently have heard about the "Forgotten Man." They would have him be the Governor General of Ireland, but the more publicly they forget him and snub him, the more prominent he becomes.

The only additions last week to the list of issues called for redemption in July, before their maturity dates, were improvement bonds and notes of various municipalities. They increased the total of calls for this month to $26,116,000, compared with $8,851,000 in June and $91,670,000 in July, 1931, for corresponding weeks.

RADIO, many have prophesied, would prove the long-sought royal road to learning. On its flowery paths of ease one might, it was anticipated, be carried to whatever skies of knowledge one desired at the mere turn of the dial.

The "gentlemen's agreement" reached by the international oil companies at their recent conference here to act as a unit in dealing with the problems of the oil industry outside of the United States has been confirmed by them at the conference now going on in Paris, according to reports reaching oil circles here.

JUST as in Spring a young man's fancy follows Tennyson, so in Summer it seeks the solace of laughter. The one does not necessarily imply the other, for that way lies cynicism. But July and August are the months for Palm Beach suits and light comedy, and in recent years refrigerated theatres.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field were hosts tonight at Caumsett, their estate at Lloyds Neck, Cold Spring Harbor, at one of the largest and most brilliant benefit entertainments given on the North Shore in many seasons. The large sum realized from the subscription will go to the Long Island Biological Society of Cold Spring Harbor.
