There is a plain recourse for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, now that Speaker Garner has prevailed over its objections to publishing full information about the loans it makes to banks. If Chairman Meyer will spend a few hours in his home city -- shuttling between City Hall and the Stock Exchange -- he can learn the newest devices in setting up account dummies.

TODAY. 4:30 P.M. -- WEAF -- The American broadcasters have extended an invitation, and are hopeful that Sir Walter Layton, director of the Economic and Financial Section of the League of Nations, will be at the microphone in London to discuss the Lausanne Conference.

LONDON, July 8 -- The University of London, less then 100 years old, is now addressing itself to the great task of providing a worthy and dignified home of its own, conveniently located, which will be the focus of its manifold activities and a visible symbol of the pursuit of learning in a great city.

WITH the recent formal invitation to Turkey to join the League of Nations and her acceptance on the same day, the number of countries in the League was increased to fifty-six. Only the following twelve-States remain out of the League though they are eligible to join: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica. Ecuador, Egypt, Hedjaz. Iceland, Iraq, Nepal, Tibet, Russia and the United States.

DURING their last extended safari into the African jungle Mr. and Mrs. Martin Johnson lugged cameras and microphones along with them and made a picture which they have called "Congorilla." Under the auspices of the Fox Film Corporation it will have its first Dublic presentation at the Winter Garden this Thursday evening.

In a market that was both colorless and lifeless, stocks moved hesitantly yesterday, advancing cautiously in the first hour and then losing their gains to end the brief trading period with negligible price changes on the average. The inaction and indecision caused disappointment after Friday's lively advance in many sections of the Stock Exchange list.

WE are so accustomed to think of ourselves as belonging to nations that it surprises most of us to learn that the very idea of nationality is extremely modern. It is so modern that, though Dr. McIlwain's book ends about the time America was discovered, it was not born yet, and lies outside the book's province.

THIS young man wanted to go to Mexico. Ever since his childhood he had been haunted by a glamourous, alluring vision of a strange, mysterious land in which possibilities, picturesque, sinister, thrilling, romantic, thronged everywhere.

BUFFALO, July 14 -- Local reaction to the nomination of Governor Roosevelt for President presents some interesting details of the feeling which divided the State delegation at Chicago. The Erie County Democratic party was reorganized last year under the direction of a leader specially appointed by the Governor.

LONDON. THE strange, dramatic career of the former Emperor of China, now the Regent of the Japanese-controlled State of Manchukuo, is being followed with particular interest by a brilliant and scholarly Englishman whose life for seven years was linked with his.

LAKE PLACED. -- Summer sojourners here in the heart of the Adirondacks who missed the third Olympic Winter Games of last February will nevertheless be able to obtain some of the tang of the festive "white season" by attending ice carnivals to be held late this month and in August.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP). -- The Pirates defeated the Boston Braves in a double-header today. 2 to 1 and 9 to 8. The second game, a thriller in which Boston called upon five pitchers, was won in the tenth inning.

THIS book, written by the anatomist to the Zoological Society of London, is a hard blow to those who like to read human qualities into the behavior of the lower animals and, conversely, dislike to read subhuman qualities into the behavior of the human race.

LAUDE M. MOYE, known as "Pie Plant Pete." was so successful with his hill-billy songs at WTAM, Cleveland, that he is now piped over the land wires to New York at 8 A.M. for distribution to WEAF's network of ten stations.

LONDON, July 16. -- After a quiet, opening the stock markets strengthened today and closed cheerful. Trading in British Government funds was light, but the tone was firm. Gains by the internationals featured the industrial section. Cables and Wireless rallied sharply in anticipation of a favorable report by the company.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A milling, angry throng of 6,500 former service men, nearly half of the Bonus Expeditionary Force which has been encamped here for six weeks demanding payment of their adjusted service certificates, threatened for two hours today to run riot through the Capitol.

Jose Maybla, 60-year-old Colombian, who insisted that he had come to New York from San Francisco merely to sell 1,560,000 acres of his native land to the International Mining Corporation, was arrested yesterday by Bernard J. Connolly, Secret Service agent, and held in bail of $5,000 by United States Commissioner Cotter for removal to San Francisco on a counterfeiting charge.

Whether the recent rise of commodity prices is temporary or a development of real significance, it is at least a welcome change. For many months the continued decline of values in the wholesale markets has been one of the most discouraging factors in the business outlook. Purchasers have been reluctant to make new commitments, believing that by waiting they could obtain still better bargains.

JUNE production of passenger cars and trucks in the United States and Canada is estimated at 190,600 units, according to the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce. This is 1 1/2 per cent below May production and 26 per cent under June of last year.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 16. -- A veteran English marksman, despite rain and mist, recorded the next to the highest total ever scored in the classic King's Prize competition today to win the blue riband of Empire marksmanship.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 16 (AP). -- The international chess masters tournament began here today, with Dr. Alexander Alekhine of France, world's champion, among the sixteen, competitors.

Featherweight woolens and worsteds have a prominent place in early Fall dress fashions, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe of the Tobe Fashion Service. In addition to use for dresses, the report points out, these fabrics will also be important for the suit-frock, dress and jacket or three-piece ensemble.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Several unusual artistic projects of quite diversified character have been planned for the forthcoming weeks. This season, the fact is promises to outrival its recent predecessors in the number and variety of musical events, to say nothing of art exhibitions and theatrical performances.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 16. -- Twenty-two cruising yachts between 25.6 and 41.2 feet on deck, reported to the Riverside Yacht Club tonight and started the second annual race out around Stratford Shoal and return, a distance of fifty miles. The start was off Little Capt in Island at 9:39 P.M.

HAVANA, July 16. -- Although the Department of War and Navy yesterday denied reports of mutinies aboard the cruiser Patria and the gunboat Yara earlier in the day, the local press this afternoon is permitted to report that a communistic plot to seize the vessels had been nipped in the bud by quick action of the authorities.
LOS ANGELES, July 16. -- Here's the lowdown from the Olympic village kitchens:

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 16. -- The final American Olympic try-outs were concluded today in the Stanford Stadium as another series of brilliant track and field performances furnished broken and equaled world's records.

JONES BEACH STATE PARK, L.I., July 16. -- America's Olympic stock in the women's aquatic category soared to a new high today as two world's records were broken on the final day's trials for positions on the United States swimming and diving team.

ONE does not associate the august composer of "The Creation" with the tinkling frivolities of music-boxes. Yet it seems that Haydn lent his genius to the little musical clocks that adorned the boudoirs of eighteenth-century Germany as well as to symphonies.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 16 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings won a double-header today from Reading, 8 to 1 and 6 to 0. behind effective pitching by Bud Teachout in the first game and Ray Starr in the second to win three of four in the series.

TOKYO, June 23 -- War between Japan and the United States is possible only if one of two contingencies should occur, one being that Japan should interfere in the affairs of the Western Hemisphere and the other that America should attempt to prevent Japan's peaceful expansion in Asia, said Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, formerly Foreign Minister of Japan, at a welcome dinner to Ambassador Joseph C. Grew last night.

FOOLHARDINESS could go no further than to attempt an explanation of the motives of the younger generation, the young men under 30, in selecting for study and investigation this or that type of picture. We who see our 30s in far and dim perspective have enough to do with attending to our own reasons for selection and our own analyses of preference without poking our antiquated noses into the private affairs of our juniors.

PARIS, July 15 -- Every country went to Lausanne with well-defined objectives. That was what made it what Premier Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain called the most difficult negotiation he had ever taken part in.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- An unusual increase in imports of foreign commodities into the United States in June and an even heavier decline in shipments abroad gave this country an unfavorable balance of $6,000,000 in last month's trade.

Things begin to look bad for Marianne. M. LEON DAUDET spent the other Sunday in a village of La Crau in Provence -- a happy, noisy, full, enormous Sunday. From Aries, Avignon, Nice, Nimes, Marseille, automobiles brought Hawkers of the King in hundreds, "husky, in duck and linen suits, carry"ing little flags adorned with fleurs-de"lis."

WINGDALE, N.Y., July 16. -- The American Federation of Labor, represented willy-nilly in the person of wing Levitt, was placed on trial before a proletariat court at p Unity, where it is revolution of prosperity that one is supposed to see lurking "just around the corner."

Two ocean liners arriving here yesterday brought 105 European athletes who will represent five countries, Germany, Austria, Czechoslovakia. Latvia and Norway. in the Olympic Games at Los Angeles. The first four delegations came on the Europa and the Norwegians on the Tonsbergfjord.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 16 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. Norman V. Peale announced today that he had accepted a call from Marble Collegiate Reformed Church of New York City in preference to one tendered by the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Los Angeles, the largest church in his present denomination.

THEOPHIL WENDT, English conductor, will direct the second group of Toscanini Fund concerts of the Musicians' Emergency Aid. They will occur Tuesday afternoon at 1:30 in the chapel of Hunter College, Thursday night at 8 in the Riverside Church, and Friday afternoon, July 22, at 3:30, in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York.

A new record for the Empire City Derby was set yesterday by James Butler's Apprentice, ridden by Earle Sande, and victor by a head in one of the most thrilling renewals of the big feature of the Empire City meeting.

GLEN COVE, N. Y., July 16. -- F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation, was the principal speakers tonight at the formal opening of Morgan Memorial Park, the thirty-acre shore-front recreational centre and bathing beach dedicated to the people of Glen Cove and Locust Valley by J. P. Morgan in memory of his wife, who died at their East Island home a few years ago.
OSTEND, Belgium, July 16. -- The International Sugar Congress broke up today without tangible results. A statement issued after the final meeting said:
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The chief features of the Relief and Home Loan Bank bills passed by Congress today were as follows: The Relief Bill.

FOR the benefit of those transport and limited commercial license holders who find it impossible to obtain the ten hours of flying time required in each six months' period for renewal of Pilots' licenses of these classes, the Department of Commerce has made a ruling which will make it easier for them to maintain their active flying status.

A declaration by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in favor of the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Herber H. Lehman for Governor is believed to be imminent by friends of Colonel Lehman. Mr. Smith, it is generally known, is committed to his candidacy and has been withholding public expression of his views merely because he has been awaiting a proper time to make it.

IN a fine spirit of wifely devotion and of appreciation of her husband's ability, success and good qualities. Mrs. Bennett sends forth this little biographical memorial of the famous flier whose untimely death four years ago was an incalculable loss to American aviation.

Frank Haubold, competing or the Swiss Turn Verein of Union City, N. J., successfully defended his title as national A.A.U. all-around gymnastic champion last night at the City College gymnasium, defeating Alfred A. Jochim, a teammate, for the second year in a row.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The downward course of wholesale prices continued throughout the United States in June. The month ended with an average drop of three-fourths of 1 per cent below the preceding month, according to Labor Department figures made public today.

ST. LOUIS, July 16. -- Carl Hubbell, number one on Bill Terry's pitching staff this year, twirled a five-hit game today to assure the Giants of their third straight victory over the Cardinals, a 4 to 1 decision which was Hubbell's tenth of the year.

THE International Contest for Singers, held last month in Vienna, has announced the distribution of prizes. The first prize of 4,000 schillings was divided among five contestants, the second of 3,000 between two. The winners of 1.500 schillings each are Cleo Elmo, Italian dramatic soprano, and Edward Bender, Polish bass.

DENVER, Col., July 16. -- In an impressive ceremony, amid the merry laughter of "pioneer" belles and gay young men, and at a cost of $250,000, the famous Central City Opera House was brought to life tonight after a silence of fifty years. The attraction was "camille."

BAR HARBOR. -- All Bar Harbor is lifting up its eyes unto the hills this week, for on the summit of Mount Cadillac on Saturday the ceremony of dedicating the new mountain highway will take place. This highway, just completed, has been built by the United States Government as a part of the development of Acadia National Park.

AMONG the newer forms of insurance no classification calls for greater technical knowledge on the part of underwriters or greater care in preparing the policy than aircraft and air insurance generally. The insurance companies are frank who admit that while they have experts who know all about most types of insurance, they have been pretty much at a loss to establish rates and the types of coverage they will give in aviation.

THE famous Thompson Trophy Race, won last year by the late Lowell Bayles in a Wasp-powered Gee Bee super-speedster, is likely to be the best free-for-all in the history of the National Air Races this year at Cleveland.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 16. -- Falling darkness and icy winds halted an all-day search of the Cordillera region for the missing Pan-American-Grace Airliner. Planes of the Chilean Air Service, headed by Director Merino, aided by the United States Military Attache, Captain Ralph Wooten, who flew his own plane to Mendoza at noon, found no traces of the lost craft.
IF there had been any such thing as the Olympic Daily News and Commercial Advertiser in those days, the headline would have run: "Local Boy Makes Good: Coroebus Wins Olympic Crown."

BUFFALO, July 14. -- Reduced taxation in local governmental units has been given the emphasis of a national topic this year inasmuch as both of the major Presidential candidates have urged that home-rule economies are most important in meeting the conditions of the times.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The home loan bank bill, including the Glass temporary inflation measure as an amendment, was finally adopted by both Houses of Congress tonight after the House had receded, by 120 votes to 114, from its hitherto unalterable opposition to the Glass amendment.

Congress adjourned yesterday, with the President and Speaker John N. Garner fighting to the last. Each of the distinguished antagonists appears to believe that he has the right and the popular side of the unemployment relief legislation argument which has engaged them for weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A gross reduction of more than $1,000,000,000 in the appropriations for the fiscal year 1933, compared with the same period of 1932, was set forth today as among the accomplishments of the first session of the Seventy-second Congress.
BERLIN, July 26. -- The twenty-year 300,000,000-schilling loan of the League of Nations to Austria was characterized in German political Circles today as "political usury."

RELATIVITY in many lines of thought has become the order of the day. Professor Einstein having demonstrated that many of the fixed concepts of physics should be revised as relative, investigators in other lines of science have thought it well to question whether or not the fixed concepts of their, perhaps even more abstract, sciences should not be similarly revised.

THAT amiable character actor, Jean Hersholt arrived in town Wednesday morning prepared to make a personal appearance at the Capitol if it killed him -- which he though it probably would. At noon he delivered himself at the Warwick to meet the film writers and his fellow personal - appearance makers across the luncheon table.
VIENNA, July 15. -- The sigh of relief with which the great powers of Western Europe generally have greeted the results of the Lausanne Conference were only partially echoed in Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- China, it is understood here, is extremely uneasy about the report which the Lytton commission will make to the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Business activity continued for the most part unimproved over the low levels of recent weeks in our markets abroad covered by the current weekly survey by the Commerce Department. Some improvement was reported from Canada.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Is there any worse hate today in Europe than shown in the American Colonies by the following letter?
TATE, Ga., July 16 (AP). -- A seventy-ton block of marble will be raised 100 feet from its bed here Monday and started to New York to be used in the construction of the Bronx County Court House.

That taxation of chain stores is a menace, but that it is not likely to become sufficiently burdensome to cause serious injury to the chains, is the opinion expressed by Baker, Weeks Harden, stock brokers, as the result of a study of the chain-store business by their statistical department.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 16 -- A colorful crowd of several thousand persons lined the Parade Grounds here this morning for the Visitors' Day Review of the 1932 Plattsburg Barracks Citizens' Military Training Camp Regiment, at the invitation of Colonel George A. Herbst, post commander.

VIENNA, JuJy 16. -- Baron Otto Guttmann was sentenced to a year's imprisonment at hard, labor without privileges tonight on charges of having cheated at cards, his term to be followed by deportation to Hungary, his native country.
Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. BASE CAMP, Nanga Parbat, Kashmir, July 10 (By runner to Astor, July 15). -- We have reached the decisive moment in our present route up Nanga Parbat.
CHICAGO, July 16. -- Man o' War has sent a new champion to the American turf to carry on for him. It's Gusto, a grandson of the superhorse. And he's the new 3-year-old champion of the year.

TOLEDO, July 16 (AP). -- A spectacular accident in which Worthy Armstrong, driven by Stepro, plunged through the rail on the top turn in the third heat of the first division of the twenty-one class pace, featured the early events on tonight's program of Grand Circuit racing.

A steady stream of pilgrims. Italians and Italian-Americans, from the five boroughs and scattered parts of the country, many carrying huge candles and enormous bouquets of roses, poured into the gray stone Roman Catholic Church of Maria Santissima del Monte Carmelo, on 115th Street near the East River, last night.

TOKYO, July 16. -- The visit to Japan of the Lytton inquiry commission of the League of Nations, which is being brought to a close tomorrow, has proved disappointing to its members, particularly to those who sympathize deeply with the ideals of the League.
The main question before the Imperial Economic Conference is whether it is possible, by voluntary agreement, for the politically decentralized empire to arrive at an economic consolidation.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 16. -- A large dinner dance took place here tonight at the Orienta Beach Club. The dinner hosts included Mr. and Mrs. C.B. Lyman, Mr. and Mrs. B. H. Cooney, Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sichel, Mr. and Mrs. R. A. Sossong, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Pope, Mr. and Mrs. G.A. Schoenwald, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Roy and Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Crosett.

THE announcement that the United States and Canada have agreed upon the outline of a treaty, to be signed "at an early date," governing the improvement of the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes Waterway has brought again into the public eye one of the most intricate problems which has ever arisen in North America in connection with the utilization of a natural resource.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 16. -- A sharp protest was made today by the executive Council of the American Federation of Labor against what it interpreted as an attempt by the United States Civil Service Commission and Postmaster General Walter F. Brown to gag several hundred thousand government employes in the expression of their opinion on political matters.

As a result of a month's steady improvement in wholesale commodity prices, which made the sharpest gain since July, 1929, confidence of consumers in quotations is being restored so rapidly that the stocking up of goods may soon begin, according to the officers of several large industrial corporations.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Resorts along the shores of Lake Champlain are filling with guests, in spite of the prediction that it would be a poor season in this section. Renewed interest in boating, particularly motor-boating, has brought more than the usual number of racing craft up the Hudson from New York and through the Champlain Canal into Lake Champlain.

PARIS, July 2, 1932. THE unveiling of the monument to Debussy in the Champs-Elysees on June 17 was the occasion of a great concert of his works. Toscanini came to Paris especially to conduct "La Mer." He was the hero of the festival.

NEW types of planes for the military and other government services have been delivered of late and are in service or on the testing field. The first of the flying boats for the Coast Guard, delivered by the General Aviation Corporation, is a twin-engine monoplane with Wasp engines, mounted on the upper wing, and driving pusher propellers.

BAYSIDE, L.I., July 16. -- Three races were sailed under the auspices of the Bayside Yacht Club today. The first brush was for the Junior Snipes and was won by Salty, the property of T.S. Clark. In the Gull Class, the first home was Slopoke, owned by E. Culhane.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 16. -- Two men, passengers on an east-bound Long Island Railroad train, were injured critically this afternoon and other passengers were thrown into confusion when fragments of a missile flew through the open windows of the crowded car after the object had smashed against the side of the third coach while the train was between Floral Park and New Hyde Park.

MEXICO CITY. July 16 (AP). -- Clarence McElroy, an American aviator who was lost for nineteen days in the deep Mexican jungle, will be brought back to Mexico City from the little town of San Geronimo by airplane tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Amended regulations were issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today to clarify the application of the tax of 4 cents a gallon on lubricating oils.

DETROIT. IT has ceased to be a secret that the popular-price class of passenger automobiles is to have a new member entered by one of the oldest motor-car companies. The company is Hudson, and on July 28 it will introduce a new Essex, not just a revised model, but an entirely different type.

A POPULAR life of the courageous and eloquent Georgian who became Vice President of the Confederate States was much needed. The career of an extraordinary character has not been neglected, but most of the volumes that deal with it are not sufficiently biographical, containing more letters and speeches than narrative.

Sub-way construction and operation in New York, considering the special conditions which rapid transit must meet, are more efficient than in such great European cities as London, Paris and Berlin, according to Aaron I. Raisman, designing engineer of the Board of Transportation, who has just returned from an extensive European tour.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 16. -- By making the same kind of a finish that Gene Sarazen staged at Fresh Meadow in the national open, Olin Dutra, strapping California professional, who has been barnstorming throughout the East, brought his tour to a brilliant close today by annexing the metropolitan open golf championship, succeeding Macdonald Smith.

Charging false representations in the sale of stock of the Schulte-United Five-Cent to One Dollar Stores. Inc., and demanding damages of $636,964 on 477 claims assigned to them by stockholders, Charles H. Morris, Ralph B. Van Wormer and Clinton W. Gray filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court against David A. Schulte and other directors of the company, as well as against the United Cigar Stores Company of America.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- By nearly the two-thirds vote which is necessary for approval of submitting a constitutional amendment to the States, the Senate late today agreed to consider Senator Glass's resolution proposing a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment, with the saloon barred and control of liquor given to the States.

WHITE ZOMBIE" is the strange title for a picture produced in Hollywood by Edward and Victor Hugo Haperin which will be released by United Artists. The "living dead" of Haiti, stories of which have been trickling back to these shores for years, provide the background.

OTTAWA. THREE hundred and nineteen years ago Samuel de Champlain, seeking a new empire for France, beached his canoe on the south bank of a broad river at the foot of a tall cliff, not knowing that before him was the site of a future capital city.

WITH weather that was too warm for comfortable shopping in many sections, retail trade during the week showed more effect from the usual seasonal lull. Local stores, however, reported fair activity on a number of different items.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 16 (Canadian Press). -- Eagerly awaiting the arrival of imperial conference delegates and their wives, social Ottawa is putting last-minute touches on preparations for their entertainment. While it has been emphasized the conference is primarily a business meeting, much of the social activity of a parliamentary session will be revived in the capital during the weeks of the conference.

A new settlement of Greeks is growing up rapidly in the neighborhood of the new Greek Cathedral in Seventy-fourth Street between First and Second Avenues. Some time ago the parishes of two orthodox Greek churches, Holy Trinity in East Seventy-second Street and the Church of the Annunciation in East Fifty-fourth Street, decided to unite and the new cathedral was the result of the union.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16. -- Serving with tremendous speed and covering the court well, David N. Jones of New York, the former Columbia athlete, will have his name inscribed on the historic Longwood Bowl as a result of his victory today over Jack Tidball of Los Angeles, 6-3, 6-4, 6-1, in the final round at the Longwood Cricket Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorial on the railroad which Cincinnati built and owns was interesting even though you spoke of the Cincinnati Southern, whereas the name is the Cincinnati Southern. You may not know the whole story.

For large banks to keep cash equivalent to 60 per cent or more of their total deposits may be commendable under some conditions, but it is not helping the present situation in which there are borrowers who have a legitimate demand upon their bankers for temporary help, according to David Flynn, president of the First National Bank of Princeton, N. J., which numbered Woodrow Wilson among its depositors.

An injunction to restrain the New York Stock Exchange from enforcing its recent ruling limiting so-called unit or "package" sales of stocks was asked in the Supreme Court yesterday by the investment firm of Pirnie Simons Co., Inc., one of the firms sponsoring unit sales.

Picking themselves up with great alacrity after having been dropped on Friday, the Indians put on a rather remarkable display of their recuperative powers at the Stadium yesterday by crushing the Yankees in the final game of the series, 8 to 1.

PEACEDALE, R.I., July 16 (AP). -- Professor Irving Fisher said tonight he regarded as "economically sound" a proposal that he government act to stimulate business recovery through use of stamped money.

TOPSFIELD, Mass., July 16. -- Macalway won the classified pace in the closest race at the Mohawk Circuit meeting today and established a new mark of 2:09 in the second mile. G. W.S. was the best of a small but select field of 3-year-old trotters.

ATLANTA, July 14 -- The nomination of Roosevelt and Garner was precisely in line with the hope and belief held in every part of the country except the East. All the while, Georgians and other Southerners knew that the New Yorker would be named and that the chances vastly favored Garner as his associate.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP). -- A campaign against importation of steel has been started by Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio industrialists, it became known tonight.

When they realized that, in a double sense, the Democratic campaign was off to a "flying" start, the Republicans went into hasty action themselves. Following the opening address of Secretary MILLS at Boston, two other Republican speeches were spread on the record of last week.

IT would appear that the Royal Society of Literature, which musters on its rolls many distinguished names, has for some time been concerned with re-establishing or we might say rehabilitating, those who have become for this generation forgotten men of letters.

IN maturity of style, no less than in the grasp of the subject-matter, "Artemis Weds" represents a great technical advance over Cicely Farmer's first novel, "The Bending Sickle." There is nothing pretentious in the present book, there are no digressions or sociological inquiries to retard the action of the story; yet Miss Farmer has contrived at the same time to present a more than usually compelling picture of English society in the years since 1925.

An opening field of sixty entries was diminished to less than half as play began in the Metropolitan Public Parks tennis championship yesterday on the Central Park courts. Divisional leaders from. Manhattan, Kings, Hudson, Westchester, Bronx and Queens are represented in the tournament.

LONDON, July 16. -- Plainly annoyed at the breakdown of yesterday's Anglo-Irish conversations, the British Government tonight issued a statement attempting to place all responsibility on President de Valera.

BEING of a serious turn of mind, Mr. Nicholson, the English naturalist, sets the amateur bird student a number of purposeful tasks. To Mr. Nicholson the popular pastime of recognizing birds and compiling lists is a futile pursuit.

IN this "Iron-Man" civilization of ours, the Summer camp has so far been an unalloyed blessing to the American boy. Its two months bring the annual restoration to physical vigor and wholesome attitudes which is the inalienable right of our young people in their early and middle teens.

Final adjournment of this session of Congress has been accompanied by unusual expressions of relief throughout the country. It is felt that a Congress which began well soon came to lose public confidence by delays and working at cross-purposes, until it adjourned amid a general belief that it has not deserved well of the Republic.

Truly Warner Company, Inc., which was organized in 1902 as a small firm and was built up to one of the largest hat and shoe selling companies in America, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court, listing liabilities of $860,446 and assets with a book value of $1,068,860.

The annual report of the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America for the fiscal year ended on May 31 shows that appropriations for special reserve aggregating $58,535,906 were made during the year from capital surplus by reducing the stated value of all classes of stock, of which $51,061,334 was used in write-offs, besides $3,093,171 net loss on sale of securities which was charged to earned surplus.
CAMP DIX, N.J., July 16 -- The first section of army reserve officers assigned to Camp Dix, N.J., having completed their course of training, the second section moved into the camp yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 16. -- The first Olympic record for the 1932 international games has been broken.

ATLANTA -- Dr. Joseph Klein has been commissioned by the Thomas E. Watson Memorial Association to make a statue of Watson for the Capitol of the State of Georgia. Dr. Klein has executed portraits of Clark Howell, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, and Mayor James L. Key of Atlanta.

The hot wave which set in Tuesday and in four days took a nationwide toll estimated at seventy-five lives abated yesterday throughout most of the country. The Middle West and Southwest still sweitered with temperatures ranging at points beyond 100 degrees.

While the decline in dollar volume was quite general, the chain systems during the half-year period made a more favorable showing than did the department stores, analyses here during the week indicated. For the six months, 500 department stores reporting to the Federal Reserve Board showed a decrease of 23 per cent.

LONDON, July 15 -- The astonishing series of contradictions, misstate- ment and denials that have issued from the government this week in connection with the Lausanne agreement and its aftermath can be explained only when one remembers that Britain has a coalition Cabinet.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 16. -- Captain Thomas Phillips of the army, who was injured in the national gliding and soaring meet here last year, returned today to witness some of this year's contests, thus keeping his word to be back, given when he was thought to be dying in a local hospital last year.
HARBIN, June 14 -- In a rude peasant hut about 100 miles north of Harbin I met the man upon whom the Chinese rely to save Manchuria for China -- General Ma Chen-shan.
THE multitude of voters who eavesdropped on the national political conventions found much to write about. They penned, penciled and typed thousands of letters to the broadcasting stations.

SOME time ago a European writer and illustrator, one H -- M --. published in this magazine an article on America. The man had interviewed himself on shipboard while entering New York harbor and had reported his impressions of the country before seeing any of it except a dim shore line and two or three channel buoys.

PARIS, Sunday, July 17. -- Premier Herriot, replying to the Nationalist leader, Louis Marin, made a short declaration to the Chamber of Deputies early this morning regarding the Lausanne agreements and the Franco-British accord.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The first session of the Seventy-second Congress adjourned sine die, at 11:26 o'clock tonight. The end came as the climax of another day of storm not this time between Congress and President Hoover, but between the two houses themselves.

A this season of the year New York is highly interesting to those in any way affiliated with fashions. While people who will wear them are at the seaside or in the mountains acquiring golden tans, those who create them are busy launching Autumn styles.

KAROL SZYMANOWSKI lives in the fabulous little village of Zakopane, in the foothills of the Carpathians a few miles out of Cracow. If you hire or borrow an automobile, the horses will jump and shy and you will disturb the traffic that carries logs and foodstuffs -- carts driven by men in gorgeously embroidered trousers and slippers with gay-colored puffs.

Recognizing the need for preserving morale among the unemployed. as well as providing the essentials of life, the Salvation Army has included an appropriation for "insurance against social unrest" in its current united appeal for $600,000, the minimum amount necessary to continue its emergency relief throughout the city.

EVER since they were discovered the nature of the cosmic rays has been, in dispute. What are they? Gamma rays, like those of radium but much "harder" and penetrating, super X-rays, in a word, argues Millikan. Fast corpuscles like electrons, say Bothe and Kolhorster, two of the leading German authorities.

PREPARATIONS are under way for the publication of a magnificent "Vatican Memorial Series," illustrated with drawings and water-colors by Vernon Howe Bailey. The text will be written by Mgr. Enrico Pucci. and the preface by Comm. Nogara, director of the Pontifical Galleries and Museums.

PARIS, July 16. -- Without difficulty Premier Herriot's Government obtained permission from the Chamber of Deputies today to issue treasury bonds to the value of 2,000,000,000 francs [about $80,000,000] for the needs of the treasury during the coming months.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 16. -- Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson of Dallas, Texas, will lead the American women's Olympic track and field team, and such assistance as she may need against the foreign invasion will be provided by fourteen other young women.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Plans are rapidly maturing for the third Flower Show of the White Mountains Garden Club, which will be held at the Maplewood Casino on July 28, from 1 o'clock until 10 P.M. Mrs. John W. Gulder of Littleton is in charge of entries, which close at 8 P.M. on July 26. Mrs. Timothy N. Ansberry of Bethlehem, a former club president, is chairman and Mrs. Guider vice chairman.

I SEE by the papers that the Palace, for some time the only remaining stronghold of unadulterated vaudeville In this country, has just started upon a combination policy of variety and motion pictures. Possibly this policy will be a temporary one, lasting through the Summer only; at all events, there has been some talk of reviving the glories of old-fashioned vaudeville.

Encountering still another eleven representing the West Indian cricketers of New York, in the third match of their United States tour at Innisfail Park yesterday afternoon, the Australians were held to a draw for the first time, after having placed to their credit both games on Thursday and Friday.

WASHINGTON. THE rapid rise in prices for hogs during the past month has directed national attenion to that branch of the live stock industry which normally contributes about 13 per cent of the cash income from farm products of the United States.

TO the race that boasts the distinction of being the oldest in Europe, and that produced Ignatius de Loyola and Saint Francis Xavier, belong many of the present-day writers of Spain. The most eminent of these is the mystic and philosopher, Miguel de Unamuno, who was born in the teeming industrial city of Bilbao.

Endorsement of the trade acceptance system as a substitute for the open book accounts widened here last week as preliminary steps in the organization of local and national committees to further the project were completed by the American Acceptance Council.

THE summer play schools of the Child Study Association which have just opened, although originally planned to provide for underprivileged children kept in the city during the hot months, are now widening their scope to accommodate other children also.

Copyringht, 1932, by The Chicago Tribune. ROME, July 16. -- The Rev. James Cox of Pittsburgh launched his campaign for the Presidency of the United States here today as the candidate for the "Jobless" party. He had an audience with Pope Pius XI yesterday and this afternoon flew to Munich, whence he will continue by air to Cologne, Paris and Cherbourg.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., July 16. -- Charles Kear of Stratford, Conn., and Miss Dorothy Duggan of Greenwich, Conn., six times winner of the women's metropolitan archery crown, were the leaders at the close of the first day's rounds in the men's and women's open events in the third annual tournament, sponsored by the Westchester County Archery Association at Woodlands Park today.

THE brief stories told on these pages today reveal the progress made by the Hundred Neediest Cases of 1931 in the six months that have elapsed since the twentieth annual appeal was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Christmas.

The offering and quick sale last week of more than $70,000,000 of new public utility bonds, debentures and notes, the largest volume of securities of this classification marketed in one week in more than a year, was a direct result of the virtually uninterrupted improvement in utility bond prices on the Stock Exchange for many days.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- A gigantic super-banking machine, capable of throwing nearly $5,000,000,000 to the Support of the nation's credit structure in the present business emergency was the main accomplishment by the first session of the Seventy-second Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- Paraguay's Chaco delegates today bought tickets to return to Asuncion next Saturday on the steamer Southern Cross, after informing Chairman, White last night their government had reaffirmed its decision to withdraw from the negotiations with Bolivia.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Without committing itself to support either political party, the Northern Baptist national convention adopted a "dry manifesto" today, and added praise for President Hoover.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16. -- An audience of 5,000 persons at Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, tonight acclaimed the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Strawbridge Clothier Chorus in the premiere of Henry Hadley's cantata, "Belshazzar."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Discovery of an ancient American Indian religion that centred around a "Redeemer," resembling the redeemer idea in Old-World religions. was announced today by the Smithsonian Institution.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange has adopted a resolution praising the services to the Exchange of its former president, the late Frank K. Sturgis, who died several weeks ago. Mr. Sturgis was president of the Exchange from 1892 to 1894.

While the share market failed to confirm yesterday the most hopeful conclusions that had been drawn from the general advance of the day before, the bond market maintained its firm position and closed the week with a display of quiet strength.

With the St. Lawrence waterway now figuring prominently in the news, reports come that the great river between the United States and Canada harbors some 2,500 motor boats, and that these craft are doing yeoman work among the resorts of the Thousand Islands.

Many assistant pastors will preach today in churches where the pastors are on vacations. Not a few pastors as an economy measure are having the assistants remain on duty rather than engaging prominent clergymen from elsewhere. In some instance the pastors are curtailing vacations.

AT this season of the year the lure of beaches, lakes and mountains is at its maximum, and many find difficulty in determining whether they should go to one or the other on their holiday. In event of such doubt it is suggested that in Maine will be found all three.

CAN we afford to provide secondary education for every one? There is undoubtedly a short-term and a long-term answer to the question. From the long-term viewpoint if society decided to sacrifice sufficiently in the way of other economic goods, there is little question that secondary education could be provided for every one.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 16. -- Minister of Finance Zanartu today flatly refused to consider the quotas for Chilean nitrates proposed at the London nitrate conference, and he indicated the reopening of ruthless competition between the producers of synthetic and natural nitrates would be preferable to acceptance of the proposed quotas.

LONDON, July 8. -- The conference on disarmament at Geneva, and the one at Lausanne on the problem of German reparations have not had the quality of really attracting public attention in Great Britain. Politicians, bankers and other groups of people with special interests, have followed events there closely, but the British, public generally refused to become excited on these occasions.

RUMSON, N.J., July 16. -- With a short, angled drive from the east side boards as the final bell sounded George H. (Pete) Bostwick scored the twelfth goal for the Bahadur polo team at the Rumson Country Club today and by the margin of that single goal the team rode through to the semi-final round of the national junior championship, victors over Austin by 12 to 11.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Something of considerable Importance has happened in the South.

TOPEKA, July 14. -- Now that both national conventions have recorded their proceedings for the pages of history, the Kansas political picture is beginning to take shape, although it is true that until after the Aug. 2 primaries the picture may remain as fantastic as a futuristic painting.

CINCINNATI, July 16. -- President Herbert Hoover is a three-to-two favorite among University of Cincinnati Summer session students. His majority was due largely to feminine support. Only 52 per cent of the men favored a second term for him.

MILWAUKEE, July 14. -- For nearly fifty years the La Pollette family has been so strong politically in Wisconsin that to stand in its way was to be blown over in the big wind. The eldest La Follette, known as "Fighting Bob," since his graduation from the State university, spent virtually his whole life as a public officeholder.

PANAMA, R.P., July 13 -- Latin Americans are second to no other people in reverence for useless red tape and arbitrary enforcement of petty regulations against foreigners and foreign ships, especially American, and little concession has been made to the commercial airplanes that have brought fast mail and passenger service to these countries from Mexico to Argentina.

LONDON. FOR some unknown reason the question of characters in fiction has been attracting unusual attention lately. Arthur Wellings predicts that if the novelists' habit of putting each other into novels persists they will soon have to park their guns in the hotel cloakroom before they can be admitted to the annual dinner of the Authors' Society.

ROME, July 15 -- Now that France and Germany have reached an agreement on reparations, which was considered by many to be an insoluble problem, the thoughts of Italians are turning increasingly to Italo-French relations, about which optimistic forecasts have repeatedly been made, but which have shown only slight symptoms of progress in recent years.

James Strange Alexander, who retired Jan. 1, 1930, as chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company, died at his home, 440 Park Avenue, soon before noon yesterday of a heart attack in his sixty-eighth year. He was taken ill last Sunday and had apparently been making satisfactory progress toward recovery.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The furthest-reaching unemployment relief program ever undertaken by the United States was ready for President Hoover's signature this evening with final passage of the $2,122,000,000 relief bill which occupied Congress's closing days.

The American Diamond liner Black Hawk sailed yesterday, on a voyage to Antwerp. Officials of the line expect it to be the fastest passage to that port ever made by a cargo vessel. The second of six freighters being rebuilt by the company since the Black Diamond fleet was purchased from the Shipping Board last year, the Black Hawk underwent sea trials last week and attained a speed of 15.78 knots.
BUFFALO, July 16 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons gained an even split with the league-leading Newark Bears today by taking the first game, 9 to 8, before dropping the second, 8 to 7.

OTTAWA, July 14. -- Bent on adding to the world's knowledge of the origin of winds and weather, on advancing the study of such matters as meteorology, terrestrial magnetism and auroral phenomena, scientists of a dozen nations are moving into the Arctic and Antarctic fringes of the earth as part of the program of the second International Polar Year.

Modernization of equipment will prove an important means to enable railroads to compete with rival forms of transportation, and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is in a position to extend credit to the railroads for such expenditures, it is said by F.H. Shepard, director of heavy traction of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
NEW YORK. Friedrich W. von Prittwitz-Gaffron. the German Ambassador, is at the Ambassador.

Hyman Stark, the 20-year-old prisoner who died in the Nassau County Hospital Friday night after more than eight hours of police questioning, strangled to death as a result of a fractured larynx. District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards of Nassau County announced last night.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- With aviation day and the golf tournament a week behind, the Summer colony at the Greenbrier and cottages is actively engaged in preparations for renewed social activity during the open tennis championships for the State of West Virginia, which commence tomorrow and will continue throughout the week.

The offer to exchange shares of the Atlas Corporation, an investment trust of the general management type, for those of twenty fixed-investment trusts appeared yesterday to be the first gun in a new outbreak of the long feud between the sponsors of each of those two classes of companies.

LOUISVILLE, July 14 -- Fear of a drastic curtailment of the common and high school terms for 1932-33 was partially allayed this week, when Professor James H. Richmond, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, announced that the per capita allowance for each school child would be $7.

OF the ten countries of South America at least seven have suffered either revolution or the menace of revolution during the last two years. Some of them have added more than one violent governmental turnover to the lengthening list of American revolutions.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- Mrs. Henry Asher Robbins gave a dinner tonight at Asher House for the Rev. Dr. Theodore Sedgwick, rector of the American Church in Rome, Italy, and Mrs. Sedgwick, who are passing several days with Mrs. Robbins and her daughter, Mrs. Theron R. Strong.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 16 -- Linn Boyd Benton, who on July 1 retired as general manager of the American Type Founders Company of Jersey City, a position he had held since 1896, died last night at his home, 107 Crescent Avenue, Plainfield, of a cerebral hemorrhage, in his eighty-eighth year.

TORONTO, July 16 (Canadian Press). -- By breaking even in today's double-header Toronto won the three-game series with Baltimore, two to one. They won the second game, 2 -- 1, after losing the first, 5 to 2.

LATONIA, Ky., July 16. -- Head Play, purchased at the Lexington yearling sales last Fall for the proverbial song, proved a handy winner of the Cincinnati Trophy, which had its thirty-first running today. The My Play colt, owned by Mrs. William Crump, wife of the trainer of the J. W. Parrish Stable, ran coupled as an entry with J.W. Parrish's Isaiah.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 14 -- What is the depression costing Delaware? Even an approximate answer to that question is almost impossible when one considers the numerous factors involved and the extent to which all individuals and business in general have been affected.

ALBANY, July 16 -- The journey that General George Washington and Governor George Clinton and a group of fifteen mounted officers took through Mohawk Valley 149 years ago, will be depicted in a week's celebration which starts at Schenectady Monday morning and ends at Utica next Saturday.

In the course of a lecture, followed by an exchange of views which allowed me to meet in New York some men particularly well informed in regard to foreign politics, the same question was put to me which I had already heard almost everywhere on my journey in America:

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Manager Max Carey for the third time this season was banished from the field today by an umpire, but his Dodgers evened the series with Rogers Hornsby's Cubs by taking the final game, 6 to 4, before a crowd of 10,000.

In another section of THE TIMES today will be found a report on the cases which last Christmas were considered the neediest. A most cheering record it is by contrast with that of last December. Some of the hundred have already been so far restored to a state of self-help that the allotments for the year are not all needed for them and the balance is turned over to other cases.

GENEVA, July 15., -- Those Geneva Circles best acquainted with both American and European psychology sympathize with President Hoover in the difficult alternatives they see him now facing, alternatives intricately involving the war debts and disarmament.

THE recently arranged exhibition at the Newark Museum of types of paper and metal money and objects of barter used as a basis for exchange in this country during the lifetime of Washington furnishes an interesting sidelight from the past on the gold standard and the problems of a stable currency in a period of chaotic economics.

With many buyers in the wholesale market, Fall activity entered its full swing here last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Retailers exhibited confidence in the fashions presented in recent showings, and as a result the allotments for purchase of Fall ready-to-wear are on a par with those of last Fall.

CINCINNATI, July 16. -- Sixteen-year-old Danny Zehr of Fort Wayne, Ind., flashed out in Coney Island pool today as the answer to a coach's prayer for a back-stroke artist, and as the most sensational recruit of all among those chosen for the United States Olympic swimming team.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., July 16. -- All records for this season went by the board today as ninety-four yachts started in eight classes in a championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association off the Island Heights Yacht Club.

Angry apprehension has been aroused in public utility circles by the action of the Wisconsin Public Service Commission in ordering seven companies to suspend common dividends until it can be determined whether their payment is justified and in calling upon the Wisconsin Telephone Company to disclose the salaries of executives of American Telephone and Telegraph, the parent company, and of Bell System's auxiliaries.

TO me Mussolini appears, ten years after he seized power, more passionately interested in the constructive rebuilding of Italy than in destroying his enemies. He appears to be limiting his victories to his own country. Furthermore, he possesses two characteristics lacking in most recent dictators and without which there really is no greatness.

ST. LOUIS. July 14. -- When the Republican and Democratic National Conventions wrote into their platforms the planks that some persons believe mean the end of the Eighteenth Amendment, they threw shivers into certain Senatorial candidates who, avowedly dry in years past, are now engaged in trimming sails to meet the situation.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- A rush of selling by hedgcrs and liquidation by commission houses and traders long of wheat in the pit demoralized the market for that grain on the Board of Trade here in the last half-hour of trading today, depressing prices to the low marks for all deliveries on the crop.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 14. -- Called into session to fit a boom-time tax rate to a depression pocketbook, the Indiana General Assembly has succeeded in getting into a snarl over reducing its own pay, splitting over disposal of the $24,000,000 Highway Commission fund, and paving the way for repeal of the State prohibition laws.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16. -- A big tri-motored all-metal Ford plane of the Pan-American-Grace Line, due at Mendoza, Argentina, at 7:55 A.M. with six passengers and the southbound United States mail, had not been heard from at nightfall. It was feared the craft was lost.

THE New York police are delighted with their radio system, which has been in operation almost five months. Culprits und criminals already realize that when the call "All police cars listen" goes on the air, the long arm of the law is reaching after them with lightning speed.

GUAYAQUIL, July 13. -- President-elect Neptali Bonifaz, who is to take over the government Sept. 1, has issued a manifesto in which he emphatically denies that he is a Peruvian. The Opposition charges that years ago Senor Bonifaz admitted his Peruvian nationality.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended July 9 increased substantially over those of the preceding week but remained well below the corresponding week last year, according to the current survey of domestic business conditions by the Commerce Department.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 16. -- Harry Pownall, driving James B. Walker's bay stallion General Hanover, won the free-for-all-trot and pace in straight heats and established the season's record, also a double heat record, by winning in 2:10 and 2:10 1/2 beating Christie Mac, former New Jersey champion, and Calumet Bank.

The third annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday over the west course of the WestChester Country Club, Rye, N.Y.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Occasionally the repealists have paused in their frenzied activities sufficiently to remind the prohibitionists that they too regard the return of the saloon with utter abhorrence. While it is safe to say that the general attitude of the populace is for unequivocal repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, it may be added that the return of the saloon is equally distasteful.
PARIS, July 7. -- The post-Grande Semaine season with favoring weather, warm but not oppressive has kept an unusual number of Parisians in the city.

NEW LONDON, Conn. -- As a part of the Governor's Day program today the Summer horse show of the Connecticut cavalry units, now in camp at Niantic, will be held at Camp Cross. Governor Cross and staff will attend. The entries will be handled by Major Philip S. Wainwright.

The widely accepted theory that overproduction, created by excess capacity in manufacturing plants, is mainly responsible for the current depression is challenged in a special bulletin by the National Industrial Conference Board, released for publication yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., July 16. -- Citizens here were stirred anew today by the news that Major Andrew McCambpbell, State Prohibition Administrator, had sent a report to Washington exonerating the Federal dry raiders who figured in two clashes here this week without visiting this resort village for an investigation.

SAILS are drawing, sheets are taut, the lee rail is awash, the man at the tiller is feeling his boat, urging her along, taking advantage of every favorable slant of wind. When she responds to his coaxing he is happy, when she hesitates he is sympathetic.

IT is Mr. Dunlap's good fortune to be both a newspaper man and a radio amateur. He, therefore, approaches his subject as a journalist and as one who has made an intensive study of electrical communication. The result is a book unique in form and treatment.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to reflect the nervousness of traders over the unusually high temperatures in the southeastern section of the cotton belt, and after an easier opening the list made gains of 2 to 5 points on the day.
BOSTON, July 14 -- This is the bare record of the strangest murder case in the history of Suffolk County and one of the strangest in the history of the United States.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16.-- Miss Rose Grosvenor Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Davis, whose engagement to Henry Sanford Jr. of New York, recently was announced, was guest of honor with Mr. Sanford at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomay Jelke at Eagle's Nest tonight.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 16. -- The question of whether the United States will rise to the great opportunity provided by the Lausanne accord will be the central point of discussion at the annual session of the Institute of Politics beginning here on July 28, according to Dr. Harry A. Garfield, chairman of the institute and president of Williams College, who announced the program today.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 16. -- Cab Walier of Syracuse, N.Y., professional driver, took the lead in the Finger Lakes Outboard championships today, scoring in all four Division II events to compile 1213 points.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 16. -- Thirty sloops took part in the fifth race of the July series of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today. All three classes got off to a fair start in a fresh winds from south-southwest.

ONE frequently hears that American and European gramophone owners differ chiefly in their attitudes toward the mechanical side of their hobby. In the early days of the automobiles suburban owners gave one the impression of having bought cars in order that they might spend Saturday afternoons pulling them apart and Sundays struggling to put them together again.

In the Canadian Prairie Provinces all crops continue to make good progress, according to the Bank of Montreal. Last week rains again were general, and as moisture is ample, except in a few districts in Saskatchewan, warmer weather is flow required.

CHICAGO. WHEN the New York dance field becomes concerned with its own problems and adopts the attitude that nowhere else in the world are its difficulties and its accomplishments duplicated, it would do well to turn its face westward and survey other scenes.

HOW shall we got jobs for 10,000,000 persons? The business depression lingers and we cannot continue to support this army of unemployed indefinitely. What to do about it? Depression is a hard school but it forces sharp thinking.

BOSTON, Juiy 16 (AP). -- As Governor Roosevelt neared the end of a week's yachting cruise along the New England shore tonight Democratic leaders started plans to turn into political action the enthusiasm aroused in party ranks by the Presidential nominee's visit.

Mrs. Florence Carroll, 40 years old, of 145 West 120th Street, was shot accidentally in the right shoulder early this morning by one of several policemen pursuing a gunman who, holding a pistol against the head of a motorist, was on his way to give himself up at the West 123d Street station.

THE travel books illustrated in color published in London by the A. C. Black Company (and for which Macmillan's are the American agents) are so well known to all lovers of "color books" that a new volume in the series, now numbering forty-five titles, is hardly in need of praise.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH but one other completed picture to his credit, yet bearing a reputation in Hollywood almost comparable to that of D. W. Griffith at the height of the master's career, is the unique and paradoxical position of Rowland Brown, who this week finished direction of RKO-Radio's "Liberty Road," a story of prison camps.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Trading was dull on the Boerse today, with so little business that the narrow price fluctuations had little meaning, but the general tendency in both stocks and bonds was firmer than that of yesterday. Brokers believe the Lausanne agreement will go over until next year and are not disposed to feel much enthusiasm for any more conferences.

HAMBURG, July 8. -- The 20,000-ton cruiser Salamis, which never had a gun mounted and has been for fourteen years a fixture in the port of Hamburg where it was built on a pre-war order from the Greek Government, has gone to sea for the first and last time, bound for Bremen, to be broken up.

To the Editor of The New York times: In response to the letter of "Michael" requesting that I supply data supporting certain statements made in my previous letter in relation to Confederate bonds and the European World War debts due the Government of the United States, I am very glad to send such information as I have at hand, taken from authentic records.

Despite a heavy withdrawal of crude oil from stocks in May, the statistical position of the industry remained rather weak because of additions to stocks of gasoline in the season when substantial withdrawals should have been made, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y.. July 16 -- Its first week of Summer training completed, members of the old Seventh New York Regiment -- now the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard -- prepared for a festive day tomorrow at Camp Smith, where dinner reservations have been made for 1.400 guests.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- The Athletics overwhelmed the Detroit Tigers, 14 to 3, today, the victory being Grove's thirteenth of the year to end his losing streak of three in a row.

THERE is a disarming permanence about agriculture. Tremendous economic and social changes lie hidden in the simple fact that in this country, at least, food is readily available day after day, year after year.

NEWPORT. -- Golfers and golfing enthusiasts among the members of the Summer colony are to have plenty to interest them this week. It is golfing week, with the sixth annual invitation tournament of the Newport Country Club scheduled for the last three days.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 16. -- Bresking 49 out of a possible 50 targets. Fred Dickerson won the High Scratch Cup at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. F. Wise captured the High Handicap Cup in a shoot-off with four other gunners.

Public utility circles were perturbed yesterday over the implications of the action taken by the Wisconsin Public Utility Commission in ordering seven companies to cease payments of dividends on their common stocks and in requesting the Wisconsin Telephone Company to supply lists of salaries not only of that company but also of the American Telephone and Telegraph, Western Electric and other Bell System headquarters companies.

LOWELL SHERMAN is bestowing his educated villainies this week on "What Price Hollywood" at the Mayfair. He comes of an acting family. His father, John Sherman, was a theatrical producer, associated for many years with the Baldwin Theatre in San Francisco.
A SERIOUS situation confronts New York with respect to her municipal hospitals. They are overcrowded and are likely to remain so. We shall be fortunate if the conditions do not become worse.

Dr. William Schroeder Jr., just appointed by Mayor Walker to a new full term of six years as chairman of the Sanitary Commission, announced yesterday a plan for obtaining new city revenues which he estimated would bring in between $8,000,000 and $10,000,000 yearly.

The conclusion of Mr. SAUERWEIN, set forth in his article on this page last Sunday, that he was able, in his investigations while traveling through the United States, to detect no "actual revolt against society" as a result of the hard times, can hardly have impressed readers as an unexpected discovery.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14 -- When George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, addressed the Kiwanis Club of Birmingham a few days ago, he wore an immaculate suit of cotton. His necktie, socks and belt also were made of cotton.

ASBURY PARK. -- As the Summer season gets into full stride, charity affairs engage the attention of sojourners on the North Jersey shore, a number of such events having been arranged for the coming week.
Cheerful news for duck hunters and those interested in the water-fowl conditions in some of the Northwrest sectors is contained in two items of correspondence.

To the Dramatic Editor: As one who lives in the provinces and is intensely interested in the theatre, I would like to join the discussion of Mr. Carstens, who bewails the lack of opportunity to see the really great artists of the stage because he can't get to New York, and of "B.W., who feels we have the cream of the profession in the motion pictures and should he grateful.

SHANGHAI, June 19 -- The proposal that the Central Government shall legalize the sale of opium and tax the drug heavily in order to raise the $60,000,000 needed immediately to finance the anti-Communist military drive, is bringing a chorus of condemnation from Chinese newspapers.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16. -- Gavolo, aged black gelding owned by Doc Bodenweiser of Newark, and Adara, brown mare owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange, triumphed in the feature events at the special matinee program today.

DUBLIN, July 16. -- Shouts of "Don't surrender!" "Sinn Fein forever!" and "Up Republic!" greeted President de Valera of the Irish Free State Council today when he landed at Dun Laoghaire after a fruitless mission to Prime Minister MacDonald in London.
PALO ALTO, Cal., July 16 (AP). -- Protests from many quarters grew out of the extension of the qualifying lists in the field events.
Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, returned yesterday on the North Germen Lloyd liner Europa in a rather optimistic mood concerning financial conditions in Europe.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 16. -- Prince Charming II, the veteran bay gelding from the Warfield Farms of Port Chester, N.Y., capped a fine string of victories in the ninth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club today by winning the hunter championship.

SHANGHAI, June 19 -- The proposal that the Central Government shall legalize the sale of opium and tax the drug heavily in order to raise the $60,000,000 needed immediately to finance the anti-Communist military drive, is bringing a chorus of condemnation from Chinese newspapers.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16. -- Gavolo, aged black gelding owned by Doc Bodenweiser of Newark, and Adara, brown mare owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange, triumphed in the feature events at the special matinee program today.

DUBLIN, July 16. -- Shouts of "Don't surrender!" "Sinn Fein forever!" and "Up Republic!" greeted President de Valera of the Irish Free State Council today when he landed at Dun Laoghaire after a fruitless mission to Prime Minister MacDonald in London.
PALO ALTO, Cal., July 16 (AP). -- Protests from many quarters grew out of the extension of the qualifying lists in the field events.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17. -- Breaking its race week for a day, the Larchmont Yacht Club held a series of special races this afternoon, and with a spirited southerly breeze 105 craft went through their paces around triangles on Long Island Sound.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The agreement reached at Lausanne was a constructive step and we should at least make an effort to further the good which has been done there. It does not help to hear a lot of self-satisfied Senators and Representatives open their mouths about secret agreements and other impertinent matters.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor for the last five years of the University Methodist Church at Syracuse, N. Y., who has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, will begin his pastorate here on Sunday, Oct. 2. He is only 34 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP). -- Paul Wolf, described by police as "a local character with no address," was questioned at Lancaster tonight in what was apparently an attempt to wreck the Duquesne, a Pennsylvania Railroad express train.

The Glass bill to extend the national bank-note circulation privilege to all United States Government securities carrying a coupon of 3 3/8 per cent or less, which was passed by the Senate last week as an amendment to the home-loan bill, would provide national banks with a handsome source of profit, Wall Street bankers said yesterday, but nevertheless they were unanimous in condemning the measure.

ALEXANDRIA BAT, X.Y., July 17 (AP). -- A statement by Robert Gibson, an Alexandria Bay stock broker, that he heard a prohibition agent threaten to "come back and wreck the town" was made public here today by G. H. Savage, secretary of the Chamber of Commerce.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx drove home runs No. 37 and No. 38 today and the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the Tigers, 4 -- 3.

In an effort to reduce the "moral and physical hazards" that have arisen from the growing use of tenements and converted dwellings for lodging house purposes, a committee of experts representing civic and realty organizations has begun a survey of conditions in such houses.

An immediate settlement of the $6,500,000,000 war debts still owed to us by European nations through a cash payment in place of the existing fifty-five-year schedule of payments was urged last night in a radio talk over the National Broadcasting net-work by Walter Lippmann, special editorial writer of The New York Herald-Tribune.
NEW YORK. Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, who has been at the Pierre, will leave today for an extended motor trip.

ROCHESTER, N.T., July 17 (AP). -- Newark continued its victorious road trip with a victory over Rochester today in the opener of the series, 5 to 4. Dixie Walker put the Bears ahead with a home run in the first with Neun on base.

The public schools should not be curtailed by retrenchment policies in the system until every other measure of economy in the city's budget has been exhausted, in the opinion of a committee authorized by representative of twenty-five civic organizations to compile a list of specific recommendations by which waste could be eliminated without injury to the schools.

There are questions in religion which cannot and must not be answered plainly, the Rev. A. Robert George of Manchester, England, declared yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, because of the inability of questioners to appreciate the boundless connotations of the answers.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A round 500 laws were enacted by Congress during the session ended last night. They were chosen from 18,000 bills introduced, one of the bumper bill crops in history.
THE baseball fan was in the throes of setting a new record for the running high dudgeon. It was apropos of cricket.

You wouldn't recognize the oid Palace this week. Its screen is given over to the first full length film ever to play there-this the excellent animal picture, "Bring 'Em Back Alive" -- and on its stage are only six acts. Thus, for the time being at least, the policy of the former First Music Hall becomes indistinguishable from that of Loew's State and most of the other variety theatres in the metropolitan district.

A contract bridge team, made up of David Burnstine, Howard Schenken., Richard Frey and Charles Lochridge, won the benefit match held last night at the New York Athletic Club, the receipts of which were to go to the American Olympic Fund, by a total of 1,300 points.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 17 (Canadian Press). -- A permanent secretariat designed to continue into the future "what few tottering steps may be taken in Ottawa" should be one of the features emerging from, the imperial conference, in the opinion of John Bromley, president of the British Trade Union Congress, who arrived here today.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 (AP). -- Attendants posted amid domes and minarets of Aimee McPherson Hutton's Moorish castle at Lake Elsinore today kept the evangelist in the complete seclusion her physician said was essential for her recovery from a fractured skull.

The cry of "Kill the umpire!" nearly became more than a figure of speech yesterday afternoon when a free-for-all fight ended the game between the Ascension Parish team of Washington Heights and the Panama Cubs of Harlem in the North Meadow of Central Park and some one tried to bite the umpire, Walter Carroll, to death.

BERLIN, July 15. -- The revelation of the "gentlemen's agreement" and the Anglo-French pact gave something of a shock to the confidence expressed after the first announcement of the Lausanne decision. This supplementary agreement is taken to postpone ratification of the Lausanne decision until next year at the earliest, which would certainly increase the already sufficiently serious obstacles to ratification by the Reichstag.

BUENOS AIRES, July 17. -- There has been a decided improvement in Argentina's internal economic situation in the last two weeks as a result of the money put into circulation from the so-called patriotic internal loan, although the total subscribed so far is only one-third of the amount sought.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 17 (AP). -- Although it took nothing away from the convincing character of his performance, comparison of the official hand-timing with "camera clock" figures cast doubt today on the world's record credited to Bill Carr in his conquest of Ben Eastman in the final American Olympic 400-meter tryout yesterday.

An important Seventh Avenue lease has been closed by Lewis R. Schwartz, as broker, in the rental for a term of seven years of the first floor in the building at 480 Seventh Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-sixth Street, to the Allied Compensaton Service, Inc. The aggregate rental represents about $22,500.

KATONAH, N.Y., July 17. -- Two of his brothers assisted as deacon and subdeacon and a third brother, Patrick Scanlan, editor of The Brooklyn Tablet, was seated in the congregation when the Very Rev. Arthur J. Scanlan, president of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Theological Seminary at Dunwoodie, celebrated today the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination at a jubilee mass in the Church of St. Mary of the Assumption here.

The outstanding facts in last week's financial panorama were the check to the decline in staple prices (whether temporary or not), the fall in the foreign exchanges, the rise in bond prices, and a growing belief that European markets have been buying here.

PARIS, July 17. -- President Hoover's statement of his attitude on the war debts has produced in certain circles in Paris a reaction like that produced in similar circles in Washingtor. by the news that ratification of the Lausanne agreement had been made dependent on a new debt settlement with the United States.

When one goes through the books on his shelves, casting out unwanted volumes to make room for new, he is often surprised to find that his literary tastes have changed. In a public library the business of weeding out little-used books reflects the trend in wider preferences.
