CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- A great demonstration in defense of prohibition has been called by the drys of Chicago. Its program embraces day and night sessions for eight days beginning July 24 at the camp ground in suburban Des Plaines.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Coe gave a large reception with music this afternoon at the Apple Trees. The hostess sang a group of early American songs and ballads of the period between 1860 and 1870. She called the group "Mirthful Miseries," in allusion to one of the songs, a quaint lament of a young girl whose parents could not afford to go out of town for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Gallery listeners in the Seventy-second Congress may have sighed for the good old days of fire and brimstone oratory, but they may take it from William Tyler Page that "oratory enacts no laws."

The proposal to erect a New York State Merchant Marine Academy on the tip of Throgs Neck, the Bronx and thus divide the present site of Fort Schuyler between such an institution and the city, is opposed by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, in a letter to Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War, made public yesterday at the Park Association headquarters.

A sharp decline of 75 per cent in building contracts awarded during the first half of this year in the New York metropolitan area is indicated in figures just compiled by L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F.W. Dodge Corporation. The construction industry analysis was prepared by Mr. Schnitman for the Building Conditions Committee of the New York Building Congress.
The shades of night were falling fast on the Harlem yesterday when the Yankees and White Sox finally contrived to conclude a long and nard fought double-header before a crowd of 30,000.

The basic problem of civilization is moral, not scientific, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, asserted yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. The present economic tragedy, he declared, should teach us that if the motive for which our improved tools and technique are put to use is "selfish acquitsitiveness" rather than public welfare, then the economic chaos will be all the deeper.

While buyers proceeded rather cautiously on Fall ready-to-wear lines during the week, a fair amount of business was placed. Interest was centred upon apparel for between seasons and early Fall. The four-piece ensemble, consisting of three-quarter coat, skirt and hat, with a harmonizing sweater blouse, was quite popular.

LONDON, July 17. -- Public opinion in the United States must under no circumstances overlook the vital importance to the American people of the Lausanne convention signed on July 8. This document opens a new epoch in modern history and is the first long definite step toward rebuilding a world broken by the great war, a world whose economic, financial and industrial system has been hanging in the balance.

The Associated Gas and Electric System, which on Jan. 1 faced some $42,000,000 of maturing notes and bank loans due in 1932, has reduced its obligations by about $30,000,000 by a series of unusual financial measures.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 17. -- The American glider record, established last year by Hawley Bowlus, was broken twice in quick succession today when Jack O'Meara, representing the American Soaring Society of New York City, landed at Endicott Airport, fifty-five air-miles from Elmira, and later Martin Schempp of Pittsburgh landed southeast of New Milford, Pa., sixty-five miles away.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- President Hoover will sign the $2,122,000,00 unemployment relief bill Tuesday as it came to him from Congress, which had revamped the measure to meet the objections raised when he vetoed an earlier enactment.

PARIS, July 15. -- After a slight hesitation caused by fears of a fresh government crisis, the Bourse plainly recovered its optimism. The chief impression here of results from the Lausanne conference is the feeling of relaxed tension, after fears of grave complications which had become manifest among the financial public.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians took both games of a double-header from the Boston Red Sox today by scores of 5 -- 4 and 8 -- 6. Cleveland now has won twelve out of its last fourteen games on the road.

Field Marshal Lord PLUMER, who died in England on Saturday, was one of the five army commanders "whose names," said Sir DOUGLAS HAIG in his final dispatch of the World War, "have become household words throughout the length "and breadth of the empire."

The Salvation Army's united appeal for $600,000 for the immediate needs of its emergency-relief and institutional-aid activities increased the fund to $555,810.70 with last week's contributions, it was announced yesterday. The largest contribution of the week was that of $10,000 by the employes of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 17. -- Levi Casey of the Los Angeles A.C., four times national champion in the hop, step and jump and runner-up for the Olympic title in 1928, was dropped from the American Olympic team today and replaced by Sol (Happy) Furth of the Millrose A.A. of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- Mrs. John Garner will "putter about the home place," in Uvalde, Texas, while her husband goes on a fishing vacation, but when he goes campaigning for the Vice Presidency she wants to go along.

The army and the navy competed yesterday afternoon to rescue four Sunday fishermen off the New Jersey coast when fire on their 47-foot cruiser, the Johannah T, compelled them to put on life preservers and leap overboard. The actual rescue was accomplished, however, by an unheroic fishing boat, the Fidus of Sheepshead Bay.
Jack (Kid) Berg and Kid Chocolate are ready for their fifteen-round bout, which will feature the card at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City tonight.

An increase of 52,887 in the number of depositors and a gain of $23,335,550 in deposits in the first sir months of this year is revealed in figures released by the Savings Sank Association of the State of New York. The increase in deposits includes accrued dividends.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 17. -- Led by President Woodrow Wilson of the class of 1879, Commander-in-Chief of the military and naval forces of the United States, 5,807 alumni and undergraduates of Princeton University participated in the World War, according to figures announced today in "Princeton in the World War," a complete record of the activity of Princetonians in the conflict which has just been published.
John H. McCooey, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, after twenty-three years is relegating to subordinates the routine duties of the leadership, his friends disclosed yesterday.

Dr. Harmodio Arias, President-Elect of the Republic of Panama, who will take office Oct. 1., arrived yesterday on the United Fruit steamship Quirigua on a private visit and will remain in this city until Thursday morning when he will go to Washington.

ALGONAC, Mich., July 17. -- Gar Wood sent his current Harmsworth Trophy defender, Miss America X, six times over a St. Clair River course today, and estimated the highest speed attained "under wraps" at around 100 miles an hour.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., July 17. -- Amassing a total of thirty-three points, the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York City, the national champions, won the Atlantic Division A. C.A. canoeing team championship and the Yonkers C.C. point trophy on Lake Sebago today.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- The incipient Giant winning streak bumped into Pat Malone and Charlie Root, a pair of veteran Cub aces, today and the double-header opening the series was a double triumph for Chicago 3 to 1 and 8 to 2.

HAMILTON, Ont., July 17. -- Canada's team for the Olympic Games at Los Angeles will number about 120 men and women, the Canadian Olympic Committee announced after a meeting that wound up in the early hours today.

LONDON, July 17 (Canadian Press). -- Sir Granville Ryrie, Australian High Commissioner to Great Britain, issued a long statement today in answer to a pamphlet entitled "The Menace of Ottawa" that was distributed among members of the House of Commons July 8 by Sir Edmund Vestey, a director of the Union Cold Storage Company, Ltd.
CHICAGO, July 17. -- Headed by Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the Dallas cyclone, sixteen girls will seek the women's Olympic track and field championship for America at Los Angeles next month.

Making their first appearance on the historic grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston for the fourth match of their New York series, the Australian cricketers, defeating an all-New York fifteen by a margin of 15 runs and 2 wickets, yesterday scored their third victory notwithstanding the fact that for half an hour toward the close of the game considerable rain fell.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 17. -- A three-goal attack in the final five minutes of play just fell short of tying the score as the Sands Point polo team howed to Winston Guest's Templeton quartet, 14 to 13, in the weekly high goal exhibition game, at the Sands Point Club today.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- More than sixty members and their wives were at the Clambake Club today for the first ladies' day of the Summer. The next ladies' day will take place on Aug. 14.

Fire Commissioner DORMAN has followed the example of other departmental heads in suggesting a number of possible new sources of city revenue. Many of them seem reasonable enough. Neighborliness is one thing, but the section of the charter requiring the Fire Department to fight fires along the Hoboken and Jersey City waterfronts without compensation might well be reconsidered.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reports orders received in the second quarter of 1932 as $20,343,216, comparing with $20,388,658 in the first quarter, making a total of $40,731,874 for the first half of 1932. Orders received in the June quarter of 1931 were $44,827,759, and amounted to $74,928,169 for the first half of 1931.

WASHSMGTON, July 17. -- The public interest requires government control over the holding companies as well as over public utilities in the opinion of the Federal Power Commission which published today a preliminary report on the results of a year's study of this type of company.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In Congress and with some economists a fallacy is repeated frequently that by issuing more money, or putting out more credit, prices may be raised.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Wheat prices are down to the lowest in years, because of liquidation and general absence of good buying support. At no time in years has the speculative buying power in all markets been so light and there is no indication of an immediate pronounced return of confidence and a broadening in the speculative buying.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been much criticism of the Congress, particularly with reference to the matter of leadership as related to party responsibility in connection with majority membership. There is failure to give consideration to the constitutional basis for membership in the Congress.

Nassau County police and the District Attorney's office, conducting two separate investigations into the death of Hyman Stark, the 20-year-old prisoner who died of a fractured larynx after eight hours of questioning by the police last Friday, began yesterday efforts to fix the responsibility for his death and opened an inquiry into the use of alleged third-degree methods.

A new X-ray apparatus, which takes "snapshots" of the heart and other internal organs in one 120th of a second, or about twenty times as fast as the ordinary radiograph, is being tested by the New York Hospital, preparatory to installation in the new centre the hospital will open at Sixty-eighth Street and the East River, on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Monday, July 18. -- Kaye Don, noted British speedboat pilot, broke the world's water speed record at Loch Lomond early this morning, making an average speed of 117.43 miles an hour over the two-way course, in Miss England III.

There are no real crime waves, but there is a constantly increasing supply of young criminals produced by "broken homes," Dr. John Rathbone Oliver, associate in the history of medicine at the Johns Hopkins University, asserts in his book "Pastoral Psychiatry and Mental Health," recently published by Charles Scribner's Sons.

A party which included Gordon Palmer and Charles E. Kugler sailed with Captain Graham J. Parker of Parkertown, N.J., on the Albatross, and fishing recently in Little Egg Harbor, accounted for fifty-nine weakfish, two kingfish and thirteen fluke.

DUBLIN, July 17. -- The Irish Free State and the British Governments refused to budge an inch today, with the result that the two nations rushed headlong into a tariff struggle that grew more bitter every hour.

New York and other large cities today are like Jerusalem was during the life of Christ when He wept because He was seemingly unable to save a reluctant people who were unaware of His visitation, the Rev. Charles Michael Smyth declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

In an effort to prevent a threatened walkout of 27,000 garment workers this week Acting Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who had been mentioned frequently as a possible mediator in the cloak and suit controversy, yesterday sent a telegram to the three involved groups calling a conference for 2 o'clock this afternoon in the offices of the Cloak and Suit Commission, 132 West Thirty-first Street.

TRENTON, N. J., July 17. -- President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt are essentially alike, Charles Solomon. Socialist Senatorial candidate for the United States Senator from New York, declared in an address here tonight at the dinner of the Socialist party of New Jersey.

SOUTHFIELDS, N.Y., July 17. -- The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, dedicated this afternoon an outdoor chapel at the Lutheran Boys' Camp at Lake Stahahe in Harriman State Park here. The chapel, named in honor of Dr. Trexler, was built by the boys themselves in the midst of a natural forest.

The "myth of rugged individualism" must be replaced by planned control of the resources and machinery of the world if conditions are to be improved, the Rev. Sidney Lovett, chaplain-elect of Yale University, said yesterday in a sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in the July Atlantic by H.A. Batten, vice president of N. W. Ayer Son, entitled "An Advertising Man Looks at Advertising," is a refreshing exhibition of honesty and good sense amid the heaped-up insincerities and buncombe of advertising literature.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Washington Senators made a clean sweep of their four-game series with St. Louis today by overwhelming the Browns, 9 to 2.

Modification of the Delaney plan of financing new subway construction by the use of four-year bonds is under consideration by Mayor Walker in an effort to achieve a substantial reduction of the debt service charges in the 1933 budget. From official circles yesterday came guarded admissions that several schemes had been drawn to "adapt" the plan to the city's present economic condition.
The German and Austrian Olympic teams were greeted yesterday by Mayor Walker, who wished them success at Los Angeles.

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- Three freight piers were destroyed and twenty-five freight cars wrecked late today in a fire which swept the Clinton Street docks of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The loss was estimated at more than $1,000,000.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., July 17. -- An airplane crash near White Roe Lake Mountain today resulted in fatal injuries to Russell North of Middletown, N.Y., the pilot.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 17. -- Continuing his consistent placing in the final heats of the Finger Lakes outboard championships on Lake Seneca today, Cab Walier, Syracuse professional, captured high-point honors in the two-day regatta with a grand total of 2,379 points.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 17. -- The first election in which Missouri will choose its entire Congressional delegation from the State at large has drawn a field of almost 100 aspirants to the national House who will enter the primaries Aug. 2.

CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., July 17. -- There is "a vast difference" between the Republican and Democratic planks on prohibition and the two parties' candidates as well. Fred A. Victor, State superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New York, declared in an address today at the Presbyterian Church here.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 17. -- Forty-nine men and women who came here today by automobile and train from Philadelphia, New York, Washington, and other cities to distribute religious literature were arrested by police under orders of Superintendent Fred T. Trafford on charges of distributing pamphlets without a license.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 17 (AP). -- The Bisons grave the Baltimore Orioles a double trouncing today, 6 to 5 and 8 to 2.

SHANGHAI, July 17. -- The thunder of artillery, the rattle of machine guns and the crackling of rifles are being heard in five separate districts of China, where major military engagements have occurred during the week-end. The total killed in all the battles exceeds 10,000.

BUENOS AIRES, July 17. -- As darkness closed down again over the blizzard-swept Andes tonight "with no news of the Pan-American-Grace Line plane which left Santiago, Chile, early yesterday morning, little hope was held out that any of the three members of the crew or the six passengers would be found alive, even if they were not killed in the accident which presumably forced the plane down.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 17. -- Although placing third with Spray in today's race for International Star Class sloops, hold off the Seaside Park Yacht Club, Cliff Grover clinched the right to represent the Barnegat Bay fleet in the international championships at Southport in September.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 17. -- A paper chase held today by a group of the young set of Lenox added variety to Berkshire week-end events. In the company who followed Berkshire Hunt and Country Club trails were Misses Kate and Lee Wood Oglesby with their guests, Misses Lee Wood Shaw and Roselle Peters; also Elizabeth L. Fenno, John Butler Swann, Arthur Patten and John Fenno.

Notables who will sail tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa include the Marquess of Milford Haven, Countess of Granard, daughter of Secretary of the Treasury Ogden L. Mills, Bernard Baruch, banker, and Mrs. Baruch, Colonel Hugh L. Cooper and Mrs. Cooper, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Simon, Thomas A. Morgan, R.E. Gilmer.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Despite lessened business in 3931, "invisible exports" from the United States which benefited other countries totaled almost $1,000,000,000, Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, stated tonight in a talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

PITTSBURGH, July 17. -- When steel demand and production dropped to a low level in the early days of July the trade admitted its inability to determine whether the drop was due to influence of the midyear inventories July 1 and the national holiday or represented a new low pace for the Summer.
The withdrawal of major league support from two clubs, Hartford and Bridgeport, resulted yesterday in the collapse of the Eastern Base-ball League.

Figures of the Department of Correction do not bear out the theory that crime increases to a great extent in times of business depression, Commissioner Richard C. Patterson Jr. declared in his annual departmental report to the Mayor, made public yesterday.

Typographical Union 6 voted 593 to 10 yesterday to reject the proposal to arbitrate the union wage scale made by the committee representing the Publishers' Association of New York City. The union voted down the proposal on the ground that it was too vague, and further that the publishers' committee had sought the intervention of the international president of the union.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Undismayed by the failure of Congress to approve immediate payment of their bonus certificates, more than 18,000 former service men today prepared to "dig in" for a siege which, they declare, will last until 1945, unless the bonus is paid before that time.

"Chrysalis." the third new play to be given "during the summer season by Lawrence Langner's New York Repertory Company, will open to-night at the Country Playhouse, Weatport, Conn. Rose Porter is the author of "Chrysalis," which has been staged by Theresa Helburn.

The necessity for finding the "silver," which he said must form the lining of the enveloping "clouds of pessimism" of the current depression, was the topic of the sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. Alien Clay Lambert, new pastor of St. Thomas Lutheran Church, 175th Street and Topping Avenue, the Bronx.

A change of the voting system in New York City to permit the election of members of a City Council by the proportional-representation method was urged yesterday by James Marshall, chairman of the New York County Republican. Advisory Committee, in letters to Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, chairman, and Samuel Seabury, counsel of the legislative committee investigating the City Government.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 17. -- Ireland will enter the Imperial Economic Conference opening here Thursday with no high hopes of concluding trade agreements with Britain, but centring its activities upon independent agreements it hopes to conclude with dominions in the empire.

HAMPTON BEACH, N. H., July 17. -- A crowd estimated to number 50,000 persons gathered from various parts of Northeastern New England today to hail Governor Roosevelt as the Democratic candidate for President. From Maine, Massachusetts, Vermont and, of course.

Republican leaders in the city believe that the chances of the party's getting control of the City Administration would be hindered, rather than helped, by the removal of Mayor Walker at this time, it was disclosed yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 17. -- After losing the first game, 9 to 2, the Dodgers piled up three runs in the ninth and won the nightcap from the Cardinals, 8 to 5. A crowd of 9,500 watched the double-header.

LURAY, Va., July 17. -- President Hoover rested today at his Rapidan River mountain camp. He arrived from Washington, in the middle of the day after pausing on the road to assure aid for victims of an automobile crash. With him was Commander Joel T. Boone, White House physician.

At a meeting of the Massachusetts Democratic State Committee Mayor CURLEY described himself as "a self-effacing volunteer worker in the ranks of the Democracy." Governor ELY conversed cordially with his recent adversary, but neglected the opportunity to say anything about his present feelings or his future course in regard to the Democratic national ticket.

Unqualified cooperation has been given to the staff of the Citizens' Budget Commission in its initial surveys by the offices of the Mayor and the Controller, and if the city continues, "as we hope and believe it will," to give such cooperation, it will have a "very satisfactory" effect on the 1933 budget, Peter Grimm, chairman of the commission's board of trustees, said yesterday.

RUMSON, N.J., July 17. -- Another game decided by a single goal brought the national junior polo championship down to the semi-final round today when the United States Army piled up an early lead over Aiken and then just managed to stand off a great last-period rush of the losers. The score was 9-8.

TOLEDO, July 16 (AP). -- Three volunteer firemen were killed and twelve others injured tonight when their truck overturned three times while answering an alarm in Adams Township. The dead are Archie Dennis, driver of the truck: A.S. Northrup and Orville Reynolds.

With Congress adjourned, the next vexing question at Washington is how to persuade or compel the massed veterans to adjourn. Their presence and purpose at the capital have been a spectacle both unprecedented and humiliating. The public has observed it all these weeks with surprise and with something of alarm.

A nursing service that began when a little child thirty-nine years ago led a nurse from an east side settlement to a top - floor tenement home, where a mother was dying for lack of medical or nursing care, yesterday announced that it was now caring for its millionth patient.

CINCINNATI, July 17 (AP). -- Hod Ford, former Redleg, led the Boston Braves to a double victory over Cincinnati today, 5 -- 3 and 3 -- 1. Ford drove in three runs in the first game and two in the second.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 17. -- Frederick Gade's thirty-foot sloop Mumsey, representing the Cruising Club of America, finished first in the Riverside Yacht Club's fifty-mile overnight race out around Stratford Shoal and return but was disqualified by the race committee at a meeting tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- As an automobile leaps ahead on the open road and slows down when winding through heavy traffic, the human voice changes velocity as it flashes from city to city over long distance telephone wires.

Mrs. Florence Carroll, 40 years old, of 145 West 120th Street, who, while sitting on the steps in front of her home was struck in the right shoulder by a stray bullet fired by one of several patrolmen in pursuit of a fleeing gunman early yesterday morning, was in a serious condition last night at Harlem Hospital.

A nursing service that began when a little child thirty-nine years ago led a nurse from an east side settlement to a top - floor tenement home, where a mother was dying for lack of medical or nursing care, yesterday announced that it was now caring for its millionth patient.

CINCINNATI, July 17 (AP). -- Hod Ford, former Redleg, led the Boston Braves to a double victory over Cincinnati today, 5 -- 3 and 3 -- 1. Ford drove in three runs in the first game and two in the second.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 17. -- Frederick Gade's thirty-foot sloop Mumsey, representing the Cruising Club of America, finished first in the Riverside Yacht Club's fifty-mile overnight race out around Stratford Shoal and return but was disqualified by the race committee at a meeting tonight.

Continued hot weather lured another Sunday throng to the seashore yesterday. Although overcast skies in the morning had threatened to cut down resort attendance, noon found the sun shining brilliantly and started a rush of traffic shoreward that taxed transit facilities to the utmost.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The number of illiterates in the United States on April 1, 1930, was 4,283,753 or 4.3 per cent of the 98,723,753 persons who were 10 years old or over in the population

The world-wide "war" against Christianity which began, in Russia will, through the aid of religious indifference in Europe and America, cause in time the literal destruction of civilization, declared the Rev. William H. Dunphy in his sermon yesterday morning as guest preacher at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in commenting today on the record of Congress said there was some doubt whether the taxation act would produce the necessary revenues. His statement praised Congress for its work, especially its devotion to legislation aimed to preserve financial stability and encourage economic recovery.

In the last hours of the session of Congress, Speaker GARNER made it abundantly clear that he is ready to carry into the Presidential campaign his argument with Mr. HOOVER over the clause in the unemployment relief bill which requires the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to publish monthly full data concerning all its loans, including those to banks.
BERLIN, Monday, July 18. -- Fifteen persons were slain and many scores injured in seven bloody political affrays in various part of 'Germany this week-end.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 12 (AP) (By Mail). -- Private capitalistic enterprise will be permitted within the collective economic system of Chile as long as it is not incompatible with the State system, individuals and companies in business have been advised by Carlos Davila, president of the governing junta of Chile's new Socialist republic.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP). -- Three Eastern riders and one from the Far West qualified today for the American Olympic cycling team.

The joint committee on unemployment, newly organized under the leadership of Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church, announced yesterday that it would "make a drive for a special session of the Legislature to vote emergency unemployment relief and launch a constructive program" for such relief.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Midsummer quietness and high temperatures all over the country were not conducive last week to increased activity in business, and buying was confined to immediate requirements of seasonal goods. The chief activity was in wholesale and retail sales of Summer apparel for women.
If there is one thing certain about the Lausanne conference it is that reparations are definitely ended, said Sir Walter Thomas Layton, British economist, is a talk broad-cast iron London yesterday.

LONDON, July 17. -- British investors lost at least u50,000,000 [about $177,000,000 at the current rate of exchange] in the Kreuger collapse, it is indicated by a new report of the British protective committee.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- An irregular movement of live-stock prices made an unsettled feeling last week in the trade. There were sales of choice steers at $9.75 a hundredweight early, with a reaction later. Prices of hogs, sheep and lambs, which had advanced freely in the previous week, were depressed materially, with a small upward reaction late last week.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Beatrice Snipes of Columbia, S.C., 35 years old, surrendered to Charlotte police late today and calmly told them how she had fatally shot a South Carolina officer near here after he tried to arrest her husband. She then forced the officer's companion at the pistol point to get out of his automobile, in which she drove to this city.

LONDON, July 15. -- The continuing weakness in sterling has been ascribed here to numerous factors, but a new and interesting influence has recently arisen in the shape of demand for dollar exchange by British interests who are buying American securities.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers humbled the Senators here today, 8 to 6, and 2 to 1, breaking a "Washington winning streak which had reached nine games.

Buyers Concentrate on Fall Goods. The large number of retail buyers in the local apparel markets yesterday turned their entire attention to Fall merchandise and gave indications of staying longer and shopping more carefully than in previous seasons, resident offices reported.

The new liner Manhattan will leave Camden, N.J., for her sea trials on Saturday, carrying a large group of shipping men who are eager to see the first performance of the largest American-built liner and the first passenger liner for the Atlantic service built in this country since 1897, officials of the United States Lines announced yesterday.

DUBLIN, July 18. -- Without a division, the Senate today passed the second reading of the emergency duties bill, giving the Executive wide powers to impose prohibitive tariffs on British imports. The Senate recessed until Wednesday, when the final stage of the bill will be taken up.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The treaty between the United States and Canada to govern the development of the St. Lawrence waterway into an ocean lane and great power project was signed at a simple ceremony in the State Department at 10 o'clock this morning, thus bringing to a conclusion diplomatic negotiations extending over eleven years.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Officials of the Sanitary District today expressed regret that the treaty with Canada for the St. Lawrence waterway, limiting diversion at Chicago according to the 1930 Supreme Court decree, had been signed, and called it "unfair to the Middle West and to the United States."
CHICAGO, July 18. -- Reports of expanding industry from almost every section of the country today proved a cheerful note for the public in general and the financial communities in particular.

THE failure of Frank Wykoff to qualify in the 100-meter event must have been a terrific shock to native Californians. The breezy citizens of that area considered the Fast Male from Glendale the speediest stepper in spiked shoes. But the judges called three men ahead of him at the tape and the moving pictures made it four. So perhaps the Californians were mistaken, though this seems hard to believe.

Strength in United States Government bonds, especially issues bearing the lower coupons, which are affected by the provisions of the home-loan bill, featured the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Domestic corporation bonds were moderately steady, and foreign loans, although averaging slightly lower for the day, developed several strong spots.
The American University Club of New York is negotiating to take over the property on the northeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street and Park Avenue as a site for its proposed club-house.

Financial and utility circles expressed satisfaction yesterday with the position taken by the Federal Power Commission in its preliminary report asking Federal supervision of holding companies and by the stand of the Alabama Public Service Commission, which ruled that no unearned dividends could be paid and that management fees could not be paid by Alabama utilities without first satisfying the commission that the services were reasonably worth the fees.

ALBANY, July 18. -- Governor Roosevelt opened a drive today to harmonize the Democratic ranks in Massachusetts and came home this evening prepared for a series of important political conferences and to attach a mass of accumulated governmental routine.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 18 (Canadian Press). -- The major contingent of delegates to the imperial conference will reach Ottawa tomorrow. Two special trains carrying the delegates from Great Britain, Northern Ireland, India, South Africa and Southern Rhodesia are scheduled to reach here at 9:45 and 10:10 in the morning.

The Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie resounded with denunciations of Bishop Manning for three hours yesterday afternoon after the rector, Dr. William N. Guthrie, admitted a meeting which his body-and-soul clinic had originally planned to hold outside in the square.
NEW YORK. The American Ambassador to France and Mrs. Walter E. Edge, who are at the Ambassador, will sail on the Leviathan today to return to Paris.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 18. -- One of the strongest fields to assemble for a tennis tournament in this country this season will gather here tomorrow for the first annual invitation tournament to be staged by the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club at its new Long Island home.

BUCHAREST, July 18. -- The official final results of the general elections are still unavailable but semi-official statements indicate that, as was generally expected, the National Peasants' party had won by a big majority in the Parliament over the King's "personal regime" of Dr. Nicholas Jorga.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- In a rough and tumble fight, Johnny Jadick of Philadelphia retained his junior welterweight title by winning the ten-round decision from Tony Canzoneri of New York, at the Phillies' ball park tonight, before a crowd of 8,000.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 18. -- Joseph B. Sweeney, 62 years old, Ohio State Commander of the Spanish War Veterans, died today at his home. He had been suffering from heart trouble for more than a month.

Walter E. Edge, United States Ambassador to France, will sail tonight on the Leviathan of the United States Lines to return to his post in Paris. Also on board will be Harvey H. Bundy, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D.C. Oreson N. Neilsen of the Department of State and P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marina Company, and Mrs. Franklin and Joseph Messick.

GENEVA, July 18. -- With the arrival of Premier Herriot of France this day was spent in Franco-American, Franco-British and Anglo-American talks on the contents of the resolution with which the disarmament conference will sum up its achievements before taking a vacation.

In one of his rhapsodies W.H. HUDSON dreamed of searching for snakes in all parts of the world, " the entire globe to be explored in " quest of serpents, from the hot " tropical jungles and malarious " marshes to the desolate, windy roof " of the world."

Governor ROOSEVELT has plainly indicated an intention to take personal charge of his Presidential campaign. He has already asked Lieutenant Governor LEHMAN to take over part of his work. Having selected at Chicago his own National Chairman, he will next determine where the main party headquarters are to be located and who is to man them.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks, announced yesterday that two grants totaling about $1,400,000 for the construction of State parkways in Queens, Nassau and Putnam Counties would be asked from the Federal Government's $2,122,000,000 relief appropriations.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Miss Bunting, racing in the colors of John Marsch of Chicago, easily accounted for the winners' end of the $3,540 Lake Forest Stakes, feature of the Arlington Park program today, leading from start to finish.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., July 18. -- The setting off of tear-gas bombs in the People's Bank of Hawthorne shortly after noon today forced two armed robbers to retreat, but not until they had shot one employe in the right shoulder and injured a second by shooting through a window over her head.

Whatever may have been Wall Street's expectation, the adjournment of Congress did not produce any rally on the Stock Exchange. As a matter of fact, stocks lost ground; the net decline in fifty assorted stocks was $1.34. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 612,000 shares, compared with 808,000 shares on the last full five-hour day of last week.

BOSTON, July 18. -- Eighteen new industrial plants were established in cities and towns of the State, exclusive of Boston, during June and provided employment for nearly 1,000 persons, the Massachusetts Industrial Commission announced today.

Nearly every day some prohibitionist or some repealist attempts to forecast what President HOOVER'S speech of acceptance will have to say on the liquor question. The New York superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, unlike the Drys on the " national board of strategy," does not wait for that.

QUEBEC, July 18. -- Expressing the belief that the forthcoming imperial conference at Ottawa will set an example to the whole world in breaking down obstacles to commerce, and in aiding a revival of agriculture, industry and trade, Stanley Baldwin, former Prime Minister of Great Britain and leader of the British delegation to the Ottawa conference, arrived here tonight on the liner Empress of Britain.

Varied Paper Money. Reference in the news columns of THE TIMES yesterday to "seven different kinds of paper money in circulation" may have roused curiosity. Four or five are easily remembered, but it is harder to identify all seven.

Acting Governor Lehman, by interceding yesterday in the controversy between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and three employing groups, obtained a promise from union leaders to withhold the call for a strike of 27,000 garment workers pending further negotiations, and thus paved the way for a possible settlement of the differences on which the various factors have been hopelessly deadlocked.

John and Augusta Joneschat sold to Conrad and Anna Imhof the three story six-family frame flat on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 101 Zabriskie Street, near Sanford Place, Jersey City. The buyers gave in part payment a two-story frame dwelling, 145 Manhattan Avenue, Jersey City.

An American General once said of a French Ambassador that " which" ever way he crosses the Atlantic " he goes home." This was notably true of Ambassador JUSSERAND. No foreign envoy of recent times has been more at home here, and none has been more widely beloved and honored by our people.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The death of Jean Jules Jusserand caused genuine and widespread regret in official and unofficial circles in Washington, where he had made many deep and lasting friendships during the twenty-three years that he served the French Republic as Ambassador.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 18 (AP). -- Rochester's war clubs beat a merry tune today to the extent of seventeen hits, good for fourteen runs and a victory over the Newark Bears, league leaders, 14 to 6.

Heated words were exchanged yesterday by Magistrate Overton Harris and Arthur F. Driscoll, attorney representing Samuel G. Steinhardt in Tombs Court in a summons proceeding. It was the second hearing before Magistrate Harris on a charge brought by Mrs. Amelie Maxwell of 415 West Twenty-third Street, that Mr. Steinhardt, her former attorney, was withholding from her about $24,500 in bonds she had entrusted to his care.

Formation of two more committees to deal with questions pertaining to trade acceptances was announced yesterday by the American Acceptance Council. The first is a trade acceptance market committee that will deal with open-market practices and rates, and the second is the technical committee on trade acceptance uses.

DALLAS, Texas, July 18 (AP). -- John Nance Garner's sharp thrusts at President Hoover for what he called "legislation for a select clientele" brought forth cries of "pour it on" from an enthusiastic Texas crowd which greeted the Speaker and his wife at the train here today.

Thousands of children have lived for a comparatively short time in the Children's Village, near Dobbs Ferry, during the eighty years of its existence. They have come from broken homes, from unsuitable guardianship, have been runaways from institutions or transfers, from hospitals, or have come from the courts as delinquents.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18. -- The second regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week brought out 184 craft today and the four 12-meter sloops heading the large fleet had their best race of the Summer. Horace Havemeyer's Mouette won by 1 minute and 7 seconds from W. A.W. Stewart's Iris, but that margin hardly told the tale of a struggle over 19 3/4 miles.

The Port of New York Authority made public yesterday a letter addressed to the Board of Estimate in opposition to the $150,000,000 bridge over the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street which the North River Bridge Company plans to construct with private capital.

Typographical Union 6, which voted 593 to 10 on Sunday to reject the proposal to arbitrate its wage scale made by the Publishers' Association of New York City, wrote the newspaper publishers yesterday asking for another conference.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 18. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor announced today that it would adhere to its nonpartisan political policy during the Presidential campaign, but voiced deep disappointment with both the Republican and Democratic platforms.

If it had been expected that the adjournment of Congress would be followed by rapid recovery in the markets, the hope was disappointed yesterday. The stock market, at any rate, opened the week with no fresh stimulus from the news of Saturday night, drifted idly and uncertainly, and ended with perhaps more advances than declines.

Fred A. Britten, ranking Republican member of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, has brought suit for $46,987 against members of the stock brokerage firm of Harriman Co. Mr. Britten charged false and fraudulent representations in the sale to him of 3,000 shares of Southern Dairies Corporation B stock, between April, 1928, and November, 1929.

HAVANA, July 18. -- Little hope is held out for the recovery of Facundo Bacardi vice president of the Bacardi Company, rum distillers, of Santiago, Cuba, who was gravely wounded last night in the Rialto Cafe, Santiago, by the accidental discharge of a revolver belonging to Jose Leon, a policeman.

QUINCY, Mass., July 18. -- Sliding smoothly down the ways, the $8,500,000 passenger liner Lurline, third of three sister ships built at Quincy for the Matson Navigation Company, was launched today at the Fore River plant of the Bethlehem Ship-building Corporation, Ltd.
OTTAWA, July 18. -- Premier Bennett issued the following statement today in announcing the signing of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty between Canada and the United States:

To the Editor of The New York Times: This afternoon, at my country home in Westchester, while entertaining some friends, I picked up THE NEW YORK TIMES and read of the death of Lord Plumer, the commander of the Second British Army, which in the World War held the Ypres salient against all that the might and the valor of the German armies could do to flatten it out.

LONDON, July 18. -- The stock markets opened the week generally dull. British Government funds were easier, although the undertone remained confident. There were few features among the industrials, with business quiet and quotations slightly below Saturday's levels.

ST. LOUIS, July 18. -- Stepping to the mound in a relief role for the second time within twenty-four hours, Joe Shaute, who had won only one game all season until yesterday, pitched the Dodgers to a triumph over the Cardinals today, 7 to 4, for his second consecutive victory.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- Winning their third straight by taking the opening game of the series with St. Louis today, the Athletics also administered the eighth straight defeat suffered by the Browns. The score was 8 to 1, lifting the Mackmen back into second place over the Cleveland Indians.

The Democratic national campaign of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and Speaker John N. Garner may be run from one central headquarters in this city and the idea of having branch headquarters at Chicago and at Los Angeles or San Francisco may be abandoned.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP>. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation went about its business today of considering bank, railroad and industrial loans, leaving for tomorrow, or later, the problems created by the relief bill which hurtled through Congress at the last minute.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 18. -- Charles M. Chisholm who, while a Major in the ordnance department of the United States Army during the World War, supervised the manufacture of munitions, died yesterday at his home here, 125 North Maple Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Herman Bell held the Cubs to six singles in his first full-length pitching Job of the season today, and the Giants, with the able aid of five errors and twenty hits, soothed the sting of their double defeat in yesterday's series opener by winning a 13-to-3 decision.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 18. -- A report that Arthur Griffin, manager of the Disputada Mining Company, had seen an airplane over Las Condes Valley Saturday shifted the fruitless search today for the missing Pan-American-Grace air liner. There has been no trace of the plane since its radio was cut off Saturday morning while giving the position of the craft on a flight from this city to Mendoza, Argentina.
The heat wave shifted over Sunday from the Eastern to the Western cotton States and relief in Georgia caused a decline of 10 to 14 points in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Retail food prices showed an average decrease of about 1 per cent in fifty-one cities on June 15, as compared with May 15, and were 15 1/2 per cent lower than on June 15, 1931, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Cardinal Hayes will arrive this afternoon on the White Star liner Olympic, which is due to dock between 5 and 6 o'clock at Pier 59, at the foot of West Eighteenth Street. The vessel left Southampton, England, last Wednesday, the Cardinal going on board at that port.

RYE, N.Y., July 18. -- Mrs. Thomas A. Hucknall, member of the Woodway Club and one of the dominant figures in Connecticut golf affairs, tied with Mrs. George Hite of Apawamis in the first eighteen-hole round of the annual three-day medal play championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association today.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates' extra-inning winning streak was snapped by the Phillies today, 5 to 4, in eleven innings. It was the first time the league leaders have surrendered in an extra-inning contest since May 9.

TOKYO, July 18. -- Prefectural Governors, summoned here for a week's conference on rural distress, reported today on the conditions in their districts, each describing acute poverty and inability to meet obligations amounting in many cases to virtual insolvency over wide areas due to the collapse of agricultural prices.

On the application of the Huntington Specialty Company of Huntington, Pa., a creditor to the extent of $405,801, Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday appointed the Irving Trust Cornpany and Henry Schniewind Jr. receivers in equity for the Susquehanna Silk Mills, silk manufacturing company, with offices at 149 Madison Avenue and mills in four States.

Herbert R. Foshay, 54-year-old vestryman of St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, Mamaroneck, N.Y., who resigned as postmaster of that city in 1926 after a shortage of about $1,200 in the postoffice funds had been discovered, was sentenaced yesterday to a year and a day in Atlanta Penitentiary for robbing the mails of $35 last April while he was still in the employ of the postoffice as a clerk.

The second of the itinerant exhibitions to be launched by Robert Ulrich Godsoe in shops and hostels about town for the benefit of the art-hungry public and the food-hungry artists opened yesterday at the Franklin Towers Hotel, 333 West Eighty-sixth Street.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 18. -- While the American Olympic team received its second day of complete rest, four stars who failed in the final trials were selected today for the dual meet between the United States and the British Empire at San Francisco on Aug. 14.

TORONTO, July 18 (AP). -- The International League will not object if the Toronto Leafs wish to transfer some of their Sunday home games to Albany, as had been suggested since the Eastern League collapsed and left the latter city without league baseball.

Where to find an outstanding party man to take charge of the Eastern campaign headquarters of the Republican National Committee to be established in this city, will be one of the most difficult problems, in the opinion of prominent Republicans, that will confront Everett Sanders, Republican National Chairman, when he conies to this city, probably today, to make preparations for the Eastern campaign to re-elect President Hoover.

NORFOLK, Va., July 18 (AP). -- Asserting the future of $2,000,000,000 in undeveloped water power in Virginia to be at stake, Attorney General John R. Saunders today asked leave to intervene in behalf of the State and as a "friend of the court" in the Appalachian Power Company's action to enjoin the Federal Power Commission from interfering with its hydroelectric development on New River.
BERLIN, July 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Dr. Thomas Arkle Clark of the University of Illinois, first dean of students in an American university, died today at his home in Urbana, after six months of illness with an intestinal disease. He was 70 years old. He was appointed dean of undergraduates in 1901.

Burglars spent all Sunday night opening seven safes in the sixteen-story building at 74 West Forty-sixth Street and left early yesterday morning with more than $60,000 worth of jewelry and precious metals, besides doing more than $3,000 damage.

Occasionally when anglers get togather and swap stories one of them will relate how he took his young son or brother fishing for the first time. He will describe the youngster's reactions, and though the day might have ended with the boy's taking only an eight-inch trout, still the expedition will always stand out as an experience worth remembering.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 18. -- Only one of the eight seeded players did not reach the third round of play in the women's annual invitation tennis tournament of the Essex County Club which opened today.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The Boerse opened sluggish and depressed today and the small volume of trading sent stocks down on an average of 1 per cent. When it became known that the government had forbidden open-air political demonstrations moderate recovery set in, but with transactions ebbing further the closing was listless.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 19. -- For the first time since the Japanese extended their military control to the Great Wall of China fighting has broken out in the Province of Jehol, which lies to the westward of South-western Manchuria.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Reciting the recent occurrences at Alexandria Bay, N.Y., where prohibition agents conducted a raid in "brutal fashion," Representative La Guardia called upon Attorney General Mitchell today to order the use of violence discontinued in prohibition enforcement.

MANILA, July 18. -- Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate, said today he would use to the limit of his power, if necessary, party pressure to force the balancing of the budget and to effect a complete government reorganization. He held that the present crisis was a blessing in disguise since it afforded an opportunity conclusively to demonstrate their ability to manage the affairs of government under unfavorable conditions.

New York cricketers, with fifteen in the field, again failed in their attempt to check the Australians in the second encounter with the tourists at Livingston Park, S.I., yesterday, when indifferent batting, coupled with the deadly bowling of L.O'B. Fleetwood-Smith and Arthur Mailey, resulted in the defeat of the home team by 80 runs and 5 wickets.

Without much ado, another contingent of American athletes set forth last night on the journey to the Coast to take part in the Olympic Games. Cheered on their way by relatives and friends, the members of the swimming, fencing, gymnastic, weight-lifting and field hockey teams departed on a seventeen-car special from Pennsylvania Station.

Business activity in June declined to a new low level for the depression and contractions in several major fields were greater than seasonal, according to the report of the Conference of Statisticians in Industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

PARIS, July 18. -- The International Oil Conference, which is seeking to reach an agreement on controlling world production and exports, announced tonight the discussions had progressed to a point where a text for the conciliation of the various points of view was being drawn up.

LOCH LOMOND, Scotland, July 18. -- A re-check of the figures today showed that Kaye Don, in his second record-shattering run on the waters of Loch Lomond this morning, established the world's speed-boat mark at 119.81 miles an hour with Miss England III.

Charges of abuses in the administration of the disabled veterans preference law, made by H. Elliot Kaplan of the Civil Service Reform Association. have led to the formation of a committee of civic groups to consider what steps shall be taken, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Business men who dug deep into their pockets for funds to bring the Republican and Democratic National Conventions to Chicago reported today that original outlays were in many cases returned tenfold.

BERLIN, July 18 (AP). -- In its emergency decree today banning outdoor political demonstrations the government "reserves all further measures to itself and will not hesitate in case of need to proceed severely against groups working with explosives and firearms, even to the extent of standing up against a wall and shooting those caught with firearms or explosives."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- President Hoover, in a letter to Senator Steiwer, Republican of Oregon, today, said each Federal Land Bank had agreed to pursue a "humane" policy with regard to mortgages on farm property.

Two games will mark the resumption of tournament polo today at the Rumson Country Club, Rumson, N. J., the first opening the Herbert Memorial Cup play while the second will be one of the semi-final matches in the national Junior championship.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Rates which the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered effective in April, 1931, on merchandise in containers were suspended today by the commission because of the competition of trucks with the railroads.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- A plank never acted upon by the Republican convention, endorsing development of inland waterways, has been inserted in the party platform by the national committee.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- A11 live stock gave way under pressure today. Hogs ruled steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than on Saturday and showed losses of 10 to 20 cents since last Friday. The top price was $5.05 and was paid sparingly, with few above $4.90.

After a holiday of almost three weeks' duration, the first-nighters, whose ranks at present are rather slim, assembled last evening at the Masque Theatre to inspect something called "The Chameleon," which admitted -- nay, boasted -- of having been brought over from the Hungarian.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 18. -- Brought out bit by bit from the lips of a score of reluctant policemen, a sordid recital of third-degree methods was unfolded this afternoon and tonight at the John Doe inquiry here into the death of Hyman Stark, 20-year-old suspect in the beating of a detective's mother, after he had been questioned for eight hours in the Nassau County Police Headquarters last Friday.

LIMA, Peru, July 18 (AP). -- The government announced tonight that a revolutionary movement occurred at Huaraz, capital of the Department of Ancachas, south of Trujillo, yesterday and was definitely smashed within a few hours. Late last night loyal troops recaptured the city from rebels, headed by Major Lopez Mindreau.

Publication of the text of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Waterway treaty, signed at Washington yesterday, reveals the scope of the agreement about to be submitted to the appropriate legislative bodies of the two countries for ratification, Canada and the United States.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Many members of the Garden Club of Southampton met tonight at Ballyshear, the home of Mrs. Charles E. Van Vleck Jr. Mrs. Robert Waller, president of the club, presided. There was a showing of lantern slides of many varieties of roses, which had been lent for the occasion by the American Rose Society.

Lou Gehrig exploded his twenty-second borne run of the season at the Stadium yesterday, Tony Lazzeri and Joey Sewell contributed additional circuit clouts, the Yankees made it three in a row over the White Sox, 6 to 4, and all would have been very serene on the east bank of the Harlem but for a mishap to Babe Ruth which may discommode the Ruppert forces for some time.

Joseph C. Monier and Clifford M. Story, who traded as R.H. Hooper Co., cotton brokers, until June 18, 1930, when they were suspended from the New York Cotton Exchange, filed suit yesterday in Federal court against the Guaranty Trust Company for damages of $1,549,040, which they assort they sustained because the bank, with which they had an account, declined to honor three checks which they had signed.

The Civic Repertory Theatre, again under the direction of Eva Le Gallienne, has postponed its reopening until November, when it will start with a revival of Molnar's "Liliom," featuring Miss Le. Gallienne and Joseph Schildkraut. As one of its new plays next season the group will offer Eleanor Holmes Hinckley's "Dear Jane," based on the life of Jane Austen.

Sebastiao Sampaio, Brazilian Consul General in New York, yesterday received a cable message from Dr. Roquette Pinto, acting president of the National Coffee Council of Brazil, authorizing him to transmit to the coffee trade of the United States the following statement of Dr. Pinto on behalf of the council:

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Senate and House officials will be guilty of malfeasance and liable to removal if they refuse to make public the reports of loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Representative Rainey, Democratic floor leader, stated today.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Acting after political clashes throughout Germany had taken a toll of twenty dead and more than two hundred wounded yesterday, Chancellor Franz von Papen's Cabinet issued an emergency decree today reinstituting the ban on all outdoor demonstrations and parades that it had lifted when it sanctioned the wearing of political uniforms after having taken office early in June.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Carrying an equivalent of the average interest rate of .40 per cent, a new Treasury bill issue of $75,923,000 will go into effect on Wednesday, when virtually the same amount will be retired.

BERLIN, July 18. -- (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). Elihu Lewin-Epstein, Zionist leader and one of the founders of the Palestine colony of Rehoboth, died today at Baden Nauheim after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

A. Harry Moore, Governor of New Jersey, on his way to Pine Camp. near Carthage, N.Y., where he will review today the 112th Field Artillery Regiment of the New Jersey National Guard, in training there, conferred in this city yesterday with a banking group regarding the sale of $42,000,000 bonds of the Delaware River Joint Commission, the agency that operates the Philadelphia-Camden bridge.

Three directors of the International Match Corporation, examined in private last Wednesday by James N. Rosenberg, counsel for the Irving Trust Company, trustee in the International Match bankruptcy, were questioned regarding the efforts of the directors to safeguard the assets of the company, it was shown yesterday when the transcript of their testimony was filed with Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- The first tennis tournament of the season was played on the Casino courts this afternoon. It was a junior mixed doubles match, which had been arranged during the morning by Mrs. Lewis G. Morris. There were eight pairs.

OTTAWA, July 18. -- If the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa is a success from the viewpoint of Great Britain, Canada and the other British Empire countries, it will mean inevitably a material loss of the trade which the United States now has with Canada.

PARIS, July 18. -- A decree of divorce was granted here today in the action brought against Luis Mercelino de Aguirre by the former Virginia Clayton Willys, daughter of the retired automobile manufacturer and former United States ambassador to Poland.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- The preliminary work of the Republican campaign to elect twelve Central States Senators was started today by Senator L.J. Dickinson of Iowa, who stopped off here for a few days before returning home.

John J. Robinson's Renaissance, 3-year-old son of Master Charlie and Humanitarian, which ran so well as a juvenile, was the surprise winner of the Brevoort Claiming Handicap, feature at Empire City yesterday. At 4 to 1, he scored by half a length over Frank E. Brown's Condescend, which landed the place over E.R. Bradley's Cambal by two lengths.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 18. -- Bequests totaling $95,000 are made to charitable institutions in the will of Mrs. Adele G. Schiff, widow of Mortimer L. Schiff, New York banker, which was filed today for probate with Surrogate Leon D. Howell. Mrs. Schiff died on July 7, at her country in Oyster Bay, L.I.

KANSAS CITY, July 18 (AP). M.W. Borders Sr., representing the Federation of American Business, told a congressional committee today that the Federal Government has developed into a "bureaucratic octopus" that is competing with its taxpaying citizens to the extent of hundreds of millions of dollars annually.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The following is the text of the American-Canadian treaty providing for the construction of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence deep waterway:

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Plans for 870,000,000 financing for the three Insull operating companies in the Chicago area. Commonwealth Edison, Peoples Gas and Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, have been completed.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The State Department, in a statement today, reviewed the history of the negotiations concerning the St. Lawrence development and then in an interpretation of the treaty, said:

Inquiry into the death of HYMAN STARK from alleged maltreatment by Nassau County detectives began before a Supreme Court Justice yesterday. We must wait for the exact facts in this particular case. Illegal and brutal methods of the police are everywhere denied by the police.

LATONIA, Ky., July 18 (AP). --Sensational riding on the part of R. Finnerty injected considerable punch into the Latonia program today. The triple was unusual in that each of the trio was saddled by Clyde Van Dusen and each carried the colors of the Dixiana stud of Charles T. Fisher, Detroit sportsman.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Bonus Expeditionary Force was in high good humor today over a situation which has developed whereby, veterans here said, the government is financing for them a large-scale "tourist and recruiting service."

New York's "finest" tried to be actors yesterday, but the stage settings were wrong from start to finish, the audience was completely out of sympathy with the plot and the show had but a fifteen-minute run. It was stopped by a barrage of bottles, fruit, the latter fairly ripe, and anything else that happened to be handy.

RIVE HEAD, N.Y., July 18. -- Former County Judge John R. Vunk of Suffolk County, who was appointed a Supreme Court justice by Governor Roosevelt on July 9 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Lewis J. Smith of Nassau County, was sworn in at the Suffolk County Court House here this afternoon by Supreme Court Justice John B. Johnston of Brooklyn.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 (AP). -- The Federal forces of President Getulio Vargas began today a minor offensive against the rebels of Sao Paulo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One hesitates to disagree with Mr. Burlingham. He is usually right. I fear, however, that he misses the strongest objection to the automatic designation of the Irving Trust Company as receiver for bankrupts.
GENEVA, July 18. -- A special assembly today unanimously declared Turkey a member of the League of Nations, inviting her delegate, Kemal Husnu Bey to take a seat.

TORONTO, July 18 (AP). -- The Toronto Leafs' pitchers went to pieces in the seventh inning today and Jersey City won the opener of the series, 7 -- 2. Four hits, three bases on balls and a wild pitch enabled the Skeeters to score six runs off Liebhardt and Cantrell.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Among the principal provisions of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty signed today are the following:

A re-definition of the term "best-sellter" and a drastic revision of present book-trade practice with respect to "best-seller lists" were advocated yesterday by M. Lincoln Schuster of the publishing firm of Simon Schuster.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Bullish weather and crop reports from the Canadian Northwest, as well as from North Dakota and Russia, fell flat on the wheat market here today. The September position declined fractionally early to a new low mark for the season, while the other futures equaled the bottom levels of Saturday.
Jack (Kid) Berg received the decision over Kid Chocolate in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night.

Otto Wissner, a pioneer piano manufacturer of Brooklyn, died Sunday at his home, 356 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of two weeks. He was in his eightieth year. Mr. Wissner came to this country from Germany when a lad and after learning the piano manufacturing business in Manhattan he opened a repair shop and salesroom at Fulton and Court Streets, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Investigation of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty by a subcommittee of the Foreign Relations Committee promises to make this project and the power question leading issues of the Presidential campaign, in the opinion of Senators who discussed the ramifications of the treaty and its political aspects today.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 18. -- The 20 per cent reduction in production costs made in the exhibitors' drive to "deflate Hollywood" is not enough, David Barrist of Philadelphia, chairman of the board of directors of the Motion Picture Theatre Owners of Pennsylvania, Southern New Jersey and Delaware, declared in a report to that body in confereace here today.

As the Police Department asked for a 1933 budget increase of $1,294,190.94 yesterday and the Citizens Budget Commission at the same time voiced strong opposition to the suggestions for new city charges on real estate to obtain new revenue, it appeared certain that additional disputes between the administration and the real estate groups would develop over next year's budget.

Two more contingents bound for the Olympic Games reached New York yesterday when the Irish representatives arrived aboard the Baltic and the athletes from Denmark disembarked from the steamship United States.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 18. -- Extensive preparations are being made here to welcome Moses G. Hubbard Jr., New York State commander of the American Legion, who will arrive at Plattsburg Barracks on Sunday to inspect the 2,400 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware attending the 1932 Plattsburg Citizens' Military Training Camp. Mr. Hubbard is coming here at the invitation of Colonel A. Herbst. post commander.

R.H. Aishton, chairman of the Association of Railway Executives, conferred last night in the Biltmore Hotel with a subcommittee of the association headed by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, on a proposed draft of reforms designed to reduce competitive waste in the railroad industry.

Ramsey County, Minn. Award of a new issue of $500,000 Ramsey County (Minn.) City Hall and Court House bonds, Series C, dated Aug. 1, 1932 and due from 1933 to 1952, was made yesterday to the Guaranty Company of New York and the First Securities Corporation of Minnesota at their joint bid of 101.62 for the bonds as 4 1/2s.

PARIS, July 18. -- The Bourse continued today the favorable trend of Friday, stocks closing at the highest prices of the day after a session of uninterrupted steadiness. The market was favorably impressed by Parliament's authorization of treasury borrowing as well as by the prospect of a relatively long period of political tranquillity due to adjournment for the Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Calvin Coolidge's article in Collier's, from which you have printed extracts, reveals the wisdom of silence. One who knows his limitations and is silent is wise. Mr. Coolidge's wisdom, however, has given way to the large reward offered for his opinions -- opinions that demonstrate a narrow vision and an outworn interpretation of history and economics.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The number of marriages in the United States in 1031 was 1,060,095, as compared with 1,128,572 in 1930, and the number of divorces last year was 183,695, as compared with 191,591 the previous year.

A slight improvement in employment opportunities for women was reported yesterday by the Salvation Army. Most applicants for lodging at the Army's institutions, it was said, now succeed in obtaining positions before completing a two-week stay.

The Australian cricketers concluded their New York engagement of six days with a decisive victory, the fifth in the series, over a team of fifteen representing New York on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston Park before a crowd of 1,500 yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Newspaper men in the opinion of Alfred P Sloan Jr., should lead the country to an economic recovery by first facing unpleasant facts and then proposing remedies.

Allotments announced by the War Department for improvement of rivers and harbors in the next fiscal year show a decrease for the First New York District of nearly 44 per cent from total allotments for the year ended June 30, 1932, Colonel Gustave R. Lukesh, district engineer, said yesterday.

MARSEILLES, Ill., July 19 -- One man was killed with shotgun slugs and twenty-two others were shot and wounded this afternoon in a battle at the Marseilles Dam of the Illinois Waterway between unemployed unionists and open-shop workers. Four hundred men participated in the fight, it was said.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 19 -- Ward Campbell, vice president, secretary and treasurer of the Morris County Savings Bank and vice president of the First National Bank of Morristown, died at his home, 61 Miller Road, today. Mr. Campbell, after suffering a severe, fall two years ago, had been in failing health, and only for brief periods had he been able to attend to his duties.

ALBERT SHAW and WALTER PAGE, both graduate students of Johns Hopkins University, founded each a monthly periodical -- The Review of Reviews and The World's Work. Their merging, though now dictated by economic conditions, cannot be thought an ill fortune.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 19 -- Louis Bender, president of the Temple Israel Congregation of Freeport, was found head in his automobile sales-room early today under circumstances that caused to police to list his death as a suicide.

After holding within a narrow range for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved and closed at the top at gains of 11 to 13 points. Trading in the morning was the smallest in some time, but high temperatures in the Southwest and a return of showery weather in the Southeast, following last week's unusual heat wave, tended to restrict professional selling.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Further publicity regarding stock market transactions and regulation either of the New York Stock Exchange or of the corporations listing their securities on the Exchange were urged today by Chairman Norbeck of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- Fewer than fifteen of the forty-eight States do not intend to take full advantage of the Federal relief act, under which they may borrow for direct unemployment relief and for public works from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Before the first out in the first inning today three Giant runs rolled home on Melvin Ott's seventeenth home run of the season, but eventually the Cubs triumphed in the ninth, 5 to 4, on Hack's single, English's sacrifice and Cuyler's single, to win three games out of four thus far in the series.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 19 (AP) -- Rochester added another victory over Newark today, 6 to 2, bunching hits off Johnny Welch and Al Mamaux in the first four innings. Neither team scored after the fourth.

It is the impression of most adult Americans, certainly of parents of girls and boys ready for college, that the course there costs a lot of money. Books about college life have had something to do with the current feeling. The boys have cars and the girls go to parties and dances.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Hoover will be notified formally of his nomination for President in ceremonies here between Aug. 8 and 15. Representative Snell, chairman of the notification committee, conferred with the President today and said the exact date had not been decided upon, although it might fall upon the President's birthday, Aug. 10.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -- President Ortiz Rubio has ordered the Department of Communications to take over and operate the Southern Pacific Railroad of Mexico pending settlement of a strike that has paralyzed business on the West Coast for three weeks, according to an announcement today by H.B. Titcomb, president of the line.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 19 -- James J. Tunney, former world's heavyweight champion, student of Shakespeare and traveler, made his debut as a political stump speaker today at a Democratic women's outing at Columbia. Major Tunney is mentioned as a prospect for the nomination for Congressman at large from Connecticut.

The efforts of the leading bankers and insurance company heads of New York, comprising the membership of the two Interborough noteholders' committees in favor of pressing a settlement of transit unity here, were attended by rallies in nearly every security of the Interborough and Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Companies yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 19 -- Ottawa flagged herself today with the colors of all parts of the British Empire in honor of the delegations from those several States of the Commonwealth who arrived this morning at the Dominion capital.

Jehol, a province in Eastern Inner Mongolia, into which Japanese troops are now being sent, has, since 1929, been politically a part of Manchuria. This change in relationships was effected by General Tang Yu-lin, the Governor of the province, who recognized the authority of Marshal Chang Tso-lin in Mukden rather than that of Marshal Chiang Kai-shek in Nanking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon reading an editorial entitled "Canada and New York," I desire to disapprove the statement "that millennial result, in fact, cannot be attained here for several years," in reference to the making of hydro-electric power on the St Lawrence "available to millions of people at reasonable cost."
PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) -- The first-place Pirates and the Phillies divided today's double-header.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Rabbi Samuel Bloch of Temple Emanu-El, Youngstown, Ohio, who became ill while attending the annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America here recently, died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which broke all Atlantic records on her maiden voyage in 1929, completed three years of service this month and officials of the line announced yesterday that she had carried 147,890 passengers, or an average of 2,498 for each of fifty-five round trips between Bremen and New York.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP) -- The County Board of Supervisors today denied the petition of Charles Chaplin, film comedian, for a $6,000,000 reduction in the tax valuation of securities listed in his name. The decision upheld the $7,668,578 valuation of the County Assessor.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Expenditures by the departments and bureaus of the Federal Government for the 1932 fiscal year, which closed June 30, amounted to $2,567,491,292 and were $94,804,108 under the budget estimates, according to figures made available at the Treasury today.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 19 -- The Kansas Public Service Commission ruled today that the 40-cent city gate rate charged by the Cities Service Gas Company to more than 100 cities and towns in the State should be reduced to 29 1/2 cents a thousand cubic feet. The opinion was rendered after an investigation and hearing begun on Oct. 1 last and continued until three weeks ago.

American creditors of the Kreuger Toll Company are to begin an investigation to determine whether ground exists for legal action to recover $33,500,000 in German bonds believed to have been hypothecated in Sweden by the late Ivar Kreuger, it developed yesterday.
