Higher prices were registered in a majority of the wholesale markets yesterday, the grains, cotton, coffee, sugar and hides scoring good size gains. Moderately lower prices were found in cocoa, rubber and silk. Other staples were firm.

An exhibition of color reproductions of modern paintings will be on view on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art through the Summer. This show, which opens to the public today, is an amalgamation of four exhibitions which the museum has been circulating in New York City high schools during the past season.

Three European Olympic squads left New York City last night for Los Angeles and the Olympic Games. They were the Swiss delegation, which arrived Friday on the Aquitania; the Austrian group, which the Europa brought on Saturday and the Danish unit, which reached here Monday on the United States.
ST. PAUL, July 19 (AP) -- A new economic era was visualized tonight by a landlocked empire in the signing of the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes waterways treaty.

Paul H. Douglas, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, has finished a new book, "The Coming of a New Party," which analyzes the records of the older parties and their leaders and offers a program for liberals. It will be published soon by Whittlesey House, with a foreword by John Dewey.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- There is no mention of the St. Lawrence Waterway in the officially printed text of the Democratic party platform, it developed today, and although the resolutions committee of the national convention adopted a plank endorsing the project, when the platform was voted on by the convention, it did not mention the St. Lawrence.

BERLIN, July 19 -- The Boerse was so listless today that not even the late downward movement could make real headway and operations virtually duplicated those of yesterday. Losses among stocks were generally about 1 to 1 1/2 per cent. There were some fractional temporary advances.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 19 -- A petition to Governor Roosevelt requesting that District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards of Nassau County be superseded in his John Doe investigation into the death of Hyman Stark, 20year-old third-degree victim, was being circulated in Mineola today, as Mr. Edwards prepared to conclude his investigation before Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink tomorrow and rush any evidence of crime before a special grand jury on Thursday.

NORFOLK, Va., July 19 (AP) -- Constitutionality of the Federal Water Power act, as it is construed as giving the Federal Power Commission control over projects on non-navigable streams, was attacked today by counsel for the Appalachian Electric Power Company.

Much has been said in recent years about enhancing the functions of the Vice President. Without any warning, but doubtless after deep thought, Mr. GARNER is attempting to enhance the importance of a candidate for Vice President. In this pleasing task he sometimes seems to forget that he is not actually running for President; that he is not the "fit timber to deal with HERBERT HOOVER" that was selected at Chicago.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 19 -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks set the pace in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's oneday competition at the Pelham Country Club today when she carded a gross of 80. She was far ahead of the field, an 86 by Mrs. T.J. O'Reilly of Crestwood being the next best score.

SHANGHAI, July 19 -- The Chino-Japanese clash in Jehol is causing alarm in Chinese governmental circles, which fear that it may be used as a pretext by the Japanese for carrying out repeated threats to oust Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang from Peiplng on the ground that he continues to foment and finance the Manchurian disturbance.

Salvation Army leaders took issue yesterday with Colonel Robert I. Rees of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in connection with his recently expressed opinion that probably 25 per cent of the unemployed constituted the so-called "unemployable" group and about 35 per cent were composed of the "unstable or nomadic employe," leaving 40 per cent "who are the backbone of the country."

Yesterday's markets reflected little except what might be called the atmosphere of midsummer inertia. That has pretty much been the rule for this season in the majority of past years, but there have been some marked exceptions. Last July's stock market was violently unsettled by events abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- China is feeling a fresh outbreak of Asiatic cholera, more than 700 Chinese having fallen victims to the disease in eight cities, official reports to Washington revealed today. More than 500 of these deaths occurred in Shanghai, Tientsin and Nanking alone.

The Citizens Budget Commission completed and forwarded to Mayor Walker yesterday its first study on budget economy, a long document that suggested in delicate language that savings could be effected in the $247,000,000 set aside yearly for mandatory salaries if city employes would volunteer to take vacations without pay and otherwise reduce their incomes to conform with present conditions.

The same small group of men and women who for fourteen years have gathered at the grave of former Mayor John Purroy Mitchel on the anniversary of his birth made their annual pilgrimage yesterday afternoon to Woodlawn Cemetery. The grave of Mrs. James Mitchel, his mother, who always had been present at the services and who died on April 12, is beside that of her son.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 19 -- Quick action by firemen and the six servants employed in the historic Bolton Priory by Frederick Hobbes Alien, its present owner, saved several valuable paintings and many rare books when a fire partially destroyed the south wing this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A new regulation pertaining to the disputed feature of the estate tax law relative to transfers made in contemplation of death was issued today by David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, with the approval of Secretary Mills.

ALBANY, July 19 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the Democratic candidate for President, made clear her position on prohibition today. A personal dry, she said, she favored repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Americans Under Other Flags. Due to the depression and the immigration laws, more aliens left the country last year than entered it. Americans continue to be astonished at any picture of this country as a land of emigration.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Paraguayan delegates to the Chaco negotiations left for New York today, planning to sail for home Saturday.

The vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, through Hollis Holley as spokesman, said yesterday that its decision to close the church on July 31 to the body-and-soul clinic which was installed there ten years ago under the direction of Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, would not be affected by the protest meeting held in the church Monday afternoon by Dr. Cowles and his patients.
LONDON, July 19 -- Andrew W. Mellon, United States Ambassador, will sail on the Majestic tomorrow on a visit home, which it was announced today, has no political significance.

The daily average gross crude oil production of the United States for the week ended on July 16 was 2,154,850 barrels, compared with 2,152,550 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 2,300 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

UTICA, N.Y., July 19 -- Miss Helen Hicks, women's national champion and defending State titleholder, was the only player in a field of forty-six to break 90 in the qualifying round of the third annual New York State women's golf championship today at the Yahnundasis Club.

Aside from minor irregularities in United States Government issues, the bond market on the Stock Exchange moved generally forward yesterday. One of the features of the day was the marked improvement in several hitherto neglected foreign loans, which were up 1 to 9 points.

BERLIN, July 19 -- A formal petition for the installation of a federal commissioner for Prussia was filed with the government of the Reich today by Hans Kerrl, National Socialist president of the Prussian Diet.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 19 -- About 5,000 striking textile workers and unemployed men, in roving automobile bands today forced more than 100 factories in the Northern Piedmont section to close. The raiders operated on a forty-mile front from Highpoint, visiting Kernersville on the north and Lexington and Thomasville on the south.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The people generally, like THE TIMES, are concerned over what is to be done about the bonus marchers now swarming in Washington.

The directors of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association, at the close of a meeting yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building, made public a report by Robert Daru, former Deputy Assistant District Attorney, for a committee of the association, appointed last March to make an investigation of reports of the continuous practice of "third degree" methods by the police of this city.
TORONTO, Ont., July 19 (Canadian Press) -- Toronto defeated Jersey City, 6 -- 4, in a loosely played game today to even the series at one victory each. Errors paved the way for three Leaf runs.

New evidence for the existence of the neutron, nature's ultimate neuter unit of matter, which, unlike the electron and proton, possesses no electrical charge, is presented in the current issue of Nature, British science weekly, by Irene Curie, daughter of Mme. Curie, co-discoverer of radium, and F. Joliot, both of the Curie Laboratory, Institute of Radium, Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- The use of trade acceptances to the extent of $15,000,000,000 during the next few months as a means of "pumping life blood into the channels of trade" was urged by Irenee A. du Pont of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in an address today before the Board of Directors of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.
A summary of appropriations at the recent session shows that Congress met the demand for a balanced budget and brought the Government's current expenditures into line with its estimated income.

BERLIN, July 19 (AP) -- Hans Kerrl, President of the Prussian Diet, in his letter to Chancellor von Papen today urging federal intervention in the State and interpreted as expressing the official Nazi viewpoint, wrote:

In preparation for the next general unification conference, to be held at City Hall within a week, the Transit Commission conferred yesterday for two hours with spokesmen for the B.M.T. The only announcement about the conference was that it had dealt with many phases of pending unity plans.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 19. -- Play in the Wheatley Cups tournament got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today when William Reynolds's Smithtown polo team downed the Wanderers, 12 to 8, in a first-round engagement on Hitchcock Field.

ALBANY, July 19 -- Declaring that the court would be departing from established precedents if it upheld an injunction obtained by proprietors of the Stillwell Theatre, Rosekay Amusement Corporation, and Windsor Circuit Corporation, against Sam Kaplan as president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, the Court of Appeals today reversed injunctions obtained by the theatres and dismissed the complaints.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Exhorting the Bonus Expeditionary Force to remain in Washington until the government pays the veterans the full value of their adjusted compensation certificates, General Smedley D. Butler, retired officer of the Marine Corps, told the ragged and partially fed bonus army tonight that those who wore the uniform and then failed to stick together were "no damned good."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Local government in metropolitan areas, with its consequent cost to the taxpayer, naturally presents a problem to tax man's ingenuity. At the outset two inflexible forces clash -- the natives who resent innovations, and the transplanted city resident who thinks he has realized his dreams of a perfect government because he helps to run it by taking a greater interest in local affairs.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -- Exploration parties seeking the plane in which Clarence McElroy and his passenger, Roy Gordon, crashed three weeks ago in the mountains in the State of Oaxaca located the smashed craft and the body of Gordon, president of the Honduras Aviation Company, last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 19 -- From far-flung sections of the country came four sturdy youngsters today to show themselves worthy claimants to the National Public Links golf crown, won last year by Charles Ferrara of San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today prepared for an avalanche of applications for loans by States under the unemployment relief bill after receiving unofficial notice that probably thirty States will apply immeliately for funds.

The International Paper and Power Company reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net Joss of $399,567, after interest, depreciation and other charges. This compares with a net profit of $593,561 in the corresponding period of 1931, equivalent to 65 cents a share on the company's 7 per cent preferred stock.

North Carolina, which went for President Hoover in 1928, will be carried this year by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, Robert R. Reynolds. Democratic nominee for United States Senator in that State, asserted yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Woodward.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 19 -- The Canadian Olympic committee decided tonight four boats will speed over the Olympic course at Long Beach, Cal., bearing Canada's colors.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 -- Getting away to a good start over the 19 3/4 mile course to Greenwich Point and Oak Neck, Henry B. Plant's 12-meter sloop Clytie today turned the tables on Horace Havemeyer's English-built craft Mouette at the third regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week and defeated her by 1 minute 56 seconds.

A smothering midsummer heat wave encompassed most of the nation yesterday, sending the mercury up close to the 100-degree mark in many States and to a maximum of 87 degrees in the metropolitan area. Ten more persons died and hundreds were prostrated, according to reports to The Associated Press, adding to the casualty list of the last week's wave, estimated at almost 150.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Hot and dry weather in the American and Canadian Northwest was reported today to have caused more or less damage to the new Spring wheat crop, and the trade was more inclined to take the bull side for a turn.

Clarence Bishop Smith, a member of the law firm of Haight, Smith, Griffin and Deming of 27 William Street, died suddenly yesterday at Washington, Conn., where he had gone to recover from an operation. He was 60 years old.
MANCHESTER, Mass., July 19 -- The seeded list which escaped unscathed on the opening day's play of the annual women's invitation tennis tournament at the Essex County Club was upset twice today.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Leaders of the Illinois Manufacturers' Association and the Mississippi Valley Association announced today that they would go before the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee to oppose confirmation of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty as a "sell-out" to Canada.
A somewhat saddened trout fisherman from Pennsylvania was in town yesterday. His favorite stream had not been spoiled, nor had any of his own theories on angling been shattered.

Business failures rose in all except the wholesale and banking groups for the week ended July 14, according to Bradstreet's. This increase was somewhat offset by liabilities practically unchanged from the preceding week. Failures increased in every section of the country except the Pacific Coast, and were particularly marked in the Middle Atlantic district.

Although the main body of stocks made no headway in either direction yesterday, the net result was something of a stand-off. Trading was much less active than on the day before; the total turnover was 465,000 shares, compared with 612,000 shares on Monday.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 -- The annual dinner and flag oficers' dance was held tonight at the Larchmont Yacht Club here.

Dr. Harmodio Arias, recently elected President of Panama, who arrived in New York on Monday for a three weeks' vacation in this country, was officially received by Mayor Walker in a brief ceremony at City Hall yesterday afternoon. Before a battery of motion-picture cameras and photographers, the Mayor congratulated the President-elect and wished him a successful term of office.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 19 -- Sir Henry Thornton, president of the Canadian National Railways since 1922, has resigned his position, according to an announcement this afternoon by Dr. Robert J. Manion, Minister of Railways and Canals.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 19 -- Armed conflict between Paraguay and Chaco has started in the disputed Chaco region, President Salamanca has won an oath from Bolivian crowds to "defend" their country at any sacrifice and foreign capitals have been notified of "Paraguay's aggression."

Owen (Owney) Madden, ex-convict and alleged Broadway racketeer, lost his fight yesterday to obtain release on bail from Sing Sing. The Court of Appeals in Albany ruled that he must remain in prison until it hears his appeal in October, or until the State Board of Parole passes on the alleged violation of his parole.

Six seeded players gained the quarter-final round of the junior singles in the second day of play in the annual Long Island Tennis Centre tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney ordered yesterday an investigation into a charge made by George Kazamek, 22-year-old student in the law school of St. John's College, Brooklyn, that he was beaten by Detective Dennis Sheehan of the Vanderveer Park Precinct last Friday and later was locked up on a charge of disorderly conduct because he refused to sign a statement that Sheehan had acted in self-defense.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was surprised to read in this morning's NEW YORK TIMES the news of the success of the National Peasant party in the recent elections, under the title: "King Badly Defeated in Rumanian Elections."
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 19 -- Fleet McKylo won the Class A pace with two of the miles clocked in really fast time as the Bay State circuit opened a two-day program today.

The volume of acceptances in this country dropped $226,810,988 to $747,248,362 in the first half of the year, according to the semi-annual report by Robert H. Bean, executive manager of the American Acceptance Council. In June the amount fell $40,166,388, leaving the total at the end of the month $621,124,625 below the figure a year before.

The production of zinc throughout the world in June amounted to 70,293 short tons, against 74,165 tons in May and 93,807 tons in June, 1931, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Production in June averaged 2,343 tons daily, the lowest in many years.

Representatives of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, which controls the Alabama Power Company, are planning to meet the Public Service Commission of Alabama as soon as possible to clarify certain details of the commission's order with respect to utility depreciation and dividend policies and to indicate their willingness to collaborate in arriving at sound bases for regulation.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- The flag of one more nation rose in the Olympic village today as the tricolor of France was unfurled to the breeze.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP). -- Playdale, from the French Lick Springs Stable, raced to a new track record for a mile and three-eighths in capturing the featured Ravinia claiming purse, $2,500 added event, today at Arlington Park.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19 -- The second in a series of bridge tournaments to aid the Southampton unemployment relief fund took place tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Supper was served. In charge of the arrangements for the series are Mrs. Reginald Fincke, Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Mrs. William Robinson Simonds, Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 19 -- About 800 "hunger marchers" from various parts of Indiana paraded here this afternoon to the State House, where the Legislature is in special session for tax relief, bearing a red flag and banners demanding the release of Tom Mooney and to Theodore Luesse, an Indiana Communist now at the State Penal Farm.

While on their way to work early yesterday morning Harry Weissglass and his wife Sophia, both 49 years old, of 926 East 172d Street, the Bronx, were so brutally beaten by two men in front of an apartment house at 1,482 Southern Boulevard that the woman died of a compound fracture of the skull four hours after her admission into Lincoln Hospital.

Mercer County, N.J. A new issue of $1,112,000 Mercer County (N.J.) road, bridge and improvement bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1932, and due from 1934 to 1955, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including the National City Company, Bankers Trust Company and the First National Company of Trenton.

The outlook for the American novel is a cheering one, according to Grant C. Knight, Associate Professor of English at the University of Kentucky, whose book "American Literature and Culture" has been published recently by Ray Long Richard R. Smith, Inc.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 19 -- James H. Van Alen of New York and Newport played a surprisingly close match against Bryan Grant of Atlanta today in the opening round of the first annual invitation grass court tennis tournament at the new country home of the Crescent AthleticHamilton Club.

Frankie Petrolle, younger brother of the famous Fargo Express, pounded out a victory over Bat Battalino of Hartford, former feather-weight champion, in the main bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Stadium last night. The battle was viciously contested and was witnessed by a crowd of 5,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19 -- Loyalist infantry from the States of Parana and Rio Grande do Sul stormed the rebel positions south of Sao Paulo, according to a government communique today, penetrating disaffected territory through the town of Itarare.

RYE, N.Y., July 19 -- Although she took an 8 on a par-3 and a 9 on a par-6 hole at the Westchester Country Club today, Mrs. George Hite of Apawamis was two strokes ahead of the field with one round to go in the third annual fifty-four-hole medal play championship of West-Chester and Fairfield Counties.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP). -- John W. Dyar. 57 years of age, a Detroit capitalist, a director of the Truscon Steel Company of Youngstown, and an official in several other companies, shot and killed himself this morning in his home on Lincoln Road, Grosse Pointe.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 19 -- A police alarm was broadcast throughout New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania today in the search for Louis Albert Jackes Jr., 21 years old, a junior of Princeton University, who has been missing since last Wednesday night.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- The Athletics slugged their way to two victories over the Browns today, 9 -- 8 and 16 -- 6. The Mackmen had a total of twenty-nine hits in the two games.

Driven to despair by the plight of his wife and seven children -- the youngest a baby of two weeks -- Domenico Sica, 54 years old, of 175 Concord Street, Brooklyn, attempted to commit suicide about 10 o'clock last night by jumping from the Manhattan Bridge into the East River, 158 feet below.

RUMSON, N.J., July 19 -- The Bahadur polo team rode through to the final round of the national junior polo championship today at the Rumson Country Club and for the third time in a row in the tournament the game was settled by a single goal, Bahadur turning back Sands Point by 7 to 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I agree with many editorials in THE TIMES hut not with the recent one which makes it appear that reading a book aloud and likewise listening thereto are things to escape if possible, or, if unescapable, to be heroically endured.

Playing with a revamped outfield, while the wounded Babe Ruth spent the day at home mending a damaged leg, and drafting Vernon Gomez into service, despite the fact that the young man was still suffering slightly from illness, the Yankees rolled right on to another victory at the stadium yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 19 (AP). -- Winning his fourth successive game, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine today continued to lead in the international chess masters' tournament. Dr. Alekhine, who is world's champion, defeated Dr. Voellmy of Switzerland.

The scale committee of the Publishers' Association of New York City announced yesterday after a meeting at their headquarters, 280 Broadway, the publishers would accede to the request of the scale conference committee of Typographical Union No. 6 for another conference on a new agreement between the newspaper publishers and the union to replace that which expired on July 1.

HELENA, Mont., July 19 (AP) -- In the first eleven precincts to record totals for today's primary election in Montana, Governor J.E. Erickson polled more votes for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination than his three opponents combined, or 462 to 361.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19 -- William H. Vanderbilt, vice president of the Casino Theatre Company, and Mrs. Vanderbilt were present at the theatre tonight for the opening of the third week of the season, when the Casino players presented "There's Always Juliet," with Edith Barrett and Tom Powers heading the small cast.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Accusing President Hoover of fostering "wicked and vicious extravagance," Senator McKellar asserted today that the appropriations made by the recent Congress were $9,156,829,627.22, or nearly twice the estimate of the Senate and House appropriations committees.

ALBANY, July 19 -- New York City will receive $346,953 as its share of the latest distribution of motor fuel tax, Thomas M. Lynch. Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, announced today in making public the figures of the apportionment for the three months ended June 30.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 19 -- Two men are known dead and six are missing, believed drowned, as the result of the premature explosion of a charge of dynamite which blew to bits the drill boat America at Chippewa Bay, near here, today. Nine others, seriously injured, are in hospitals here and at Brockville, Ont.

ALBANY, July 19 -- A detailed program for drastic reduction in State expenditure was pledged today by Governor Roosevelt as a drive to enlist the aid of civic and business organizations in framing a smaller budget was started at the Capitol.

Following all-day conferences yesterday of jobbers, contractors and union representatives involved in the controversy over a new working agreement for the cloak and suit industry, It was indicated that an amicable settlement might be reached when the various groups meet Lieut. Gov. Lehman this morning in mediation to avert a strike of 27,000 workers.

In anticipation of successful completion by Aug. 15 of the plan of Saxon Public Works, Inc., to give holders of its 5 per cent notes that went into default on July 15 new 6 per cent notes due in 1937, the bankers obtained yesterday unlisted trading privileges for the new issue on the New York Curb Exchange.
NEW YORK. Mrs. George U. Harris of Tuxedo Park gave a luncheon for Mrs. Prentice Cromwell yesterday at the Central Park Casino.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 19 -- Flashing a brilliant brand of golf over the Leewood Golf Club course, Ian B. MacCallum, with a 74, three over par, led a field of 71 in a Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament today.

Seligman, Lubetkin, Strook Co. have announced the dissolution of their firm as of June 30, last, and the formation, effective yesterday, of Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc., to conduct a general investment business, specializing in real estate securities.

ALBANY, July 19 -- One of the most important decisions handed down by the Court of Appeals today was the appeal of S. Sheldon Meyers, appellant, against Credtt Lyonnais. The court agreed with Mr. Meyers that the statute of limitations did not bar him from maintaining an action on a contract which accrued in Russia in 1918 in favor of a Russian citizen against the defendant, a French bank having a branch in Petrograd.

The proposed bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street would not interfere with navigation and it would promote the usefulness of a great area west of Eighth Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Fifty-seventh Street, Francis Lee Stuart, consulting engineer and vice president of the North River Bridge Company, which proposes to construct the span with private capital, declared yesterday in reply to a letter sent to the Board of Estimtae by the Port Authority.

TRENTON, N.J., July 19 -- State Treasurer Middleton today announced reduction of the interest rate on State funds held by banks from 1 1/2 to 1 per cent, effective on Aug. 1. It will be the second reduction in a little more than a year, the first having been made on July 1. 1931, when the 2 per cent rate, which had been in force for twenty-nine years, was cut to 1 1/2 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to Mayor Walker, Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., approves the proposed removal of MacMonnies's group "Civic Virtue'' from City Hall Park and opposes its erection in any other park.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 19 -- Airplane pilots employed by the Hollywood motion picture studios, assistant directors and script clerks, scenic artists and costumers and a group of allied employes informed the executive council of the American Federation of Labor today that they had formed a strong organization and asked the federation's assistance in negotiating contracts governing their crafts.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 19 -- Society turned out in large numbers tonight at the opening performance of Henry Hull in "Springtime for Henry" at the Huntington High School Theatre. The play was presented by the Charles Hopkins company.

Correcting the Congressional Record is frequently done by Senators and Representatives. Before their remarks are printed they have an opportunity to revise the stenographic report. But often, blunders more or less serious get by and into the daily embalming of Congressional debate.

OTTAWA, July 19.-- Steel men of Great Britain and Canada who have been trying to reach some trade agreement of mutual benefit in anticipation of the Imperial Economic Conference have evidently had a much greater success than the cotton manufacturers of the two countries, whose efforts to reach a similar objective completely failed last month.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Unperturbed by the fact it was "Sam Rice Day" and Washington was paying tribute to the veteran outfielder. Detroit today fell on the Senators for the third time in a row, defeating them, 3 to 2.

ALBANY, July 19 -- Governor Roosevelt decided today that his campaign for election would be conducted by the State organizations themselves, working in cooperation with the national headquarters in New York and a large advisory committee.

BESSEMER could hardly have foreseen the effect of his paper "On the " Manufacture of Malleable Iron and " Steel Without Fuel," read before the British Association for the Advancement of Science in 1856. He was primarily interested in cannonmaking as the result of the Crimean War's exigencies.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company for the first half of 1932 amounted to $80,210,498, comparing with $141,180,091 for the same period of 1931, a decrease of 43 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. Second-quarter billings were $42,334,099, against $37,876,399 in the first quarter and $79,220,290 in the second quarter a year ago.

Liberal arts colleges throughout the country should train young men and women to take an active interest in local, State and national politics, placing special emphasis upon international relations, Dean J.B. Johnston of the University of Minnesota declared yesterday in an address to Columbia University Summer school students at Teachers College.

Money market was quiet in tone and unchanged in quotation. Stock Exchange day loans were 2 per cent, street trades at 1 and Federal funds at 1/3. Supply was good, but demand light. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

PEIPING, July 19 -- Fighting between Japanese and Chinese troops, which broke out yesterday in the Manchurian Province of Jehol, grew more fierce today after the Japanese said they had learned that the Chinese soldiers killed Captain Gonshiro Ishimoto, a Japanese liaison officer, whom they captured yesterday.

SAM JONES of the White Sox was taking his ease in his Inn. Squire Sam has been in the American League since 1914 and has pitched for six different clubs in the circuit. He has been in four world's series. He pitched a no-hit game for the Yankees against the Athletics, back in 1923.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The recent bullish situation in the hog market has been reversed by late developments and prices dropped 10 to 25 cents today, as the result of larger receipts than expected and slower demand.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- On the heels of the signing of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty with Canada this capital saw plenty of evidence of wide acclaim for the project, particularly in the States of the North Central West, but at the same time was reminded that thorny disputes are ahead in the path of ratification.

A fete called "In A Chinese Garden" with a special Chinese setting and menu will be given tonight in the Sea Grill of the Casa del Mar Beach Club. Some of those who will give dinner parties are Mr. and Mrs. James C. Brady Jr., the Misses Ann and Isabel Jennings, Mr. and Mrs. James W. Hannigan, Mr. and Mrs. William Lowery, Mr. and Mrs. A. Hamilton Cooke and Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Cunningham.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 19 (AP) -- Federal bonds, aggregating $200,000 were set by Judge Louie W. Strum today for three defendants under indictment for defrauding Almours Securities Inc., an Alfred T. Dupont firm, of $131,000.

Money market was quiet in tone and unchanged in quotation. Stock Exchange day loans were 2 per cent, street trades at 1 and Federal funds at 1/3. Supply was good, but demand light. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

Roger Q. Williams, who flew the Atlantic with Captain Lewis A. Yancey in 1929, will try it again, this time with the world's distance record as a goal and with a woman flier, Miss Elvy Kalep, Estonian transport pilot, as co-pilot. Miss Kalep and Mr. Williams outlined their plans, which call for a non-stop flight about Aug. 15 from Floyd Bennett Field to Athens or beyond, yesterday at the former's apartment, 65 East Fifty-fifth Street.

NOGALES, Ariz., July 19 (AP) -- Edmond Pissater, English fruit grower, of Mazatlan, to whom a report was attributed that the railway strike on the west coast of Mexico had brought the spectre of starvation to several hundred persons, was barred from Mexico today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If any one would propose to construct a dam near the outlet of the Niagara Rivar, undoubtedly there would be a tremendous protest, because such a dam would destroy the wonderful Niagara River rapids, though such a dam would develop a tremendous water power.

PALO ALTO, Cal., July 20 -- Assigning himself to the handling of the 400-meter relay team and naming seven active assistants to coach most of the other events, Lawson Robertson, head coach, today laid the groundwork for tuning up the American Olympic track and field team for the games.

Moderate gains on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the better feeling in Wall Street. Transactions involved a total of 627,000 shares, compared with 465,000 on the day before. Many of the more prominent issues were up anywhere from 1 to 3 points on the day and the average of fifty selected stocks, computed in the usual way, showed a net appreciation of $1.40.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 20 -- Einar Storm Trosdal, identified with shipping from the South Atlantic and Gulf ports to Europe, died this morning from the effects of carbon monoxide gas. He was discovered in the garage at his home here seated in a closed sedan, the motor of which was running.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- A pulled achilles tendon, if not the International Federation, may keep the great Paavo Nurmi from competing in the Olympic Games. It was a very worried Nurmi who abstained from all work today in an effort to ward off any ill effects from a leg injury that has been bothering him for some time.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Alexander Stillman, son of the New York banker James A. Stillman, and his mother, Mrs. Fifi Stillman McCormick, bride of young Fowler McCormick, each were in freakish airplane crashes tonight. Neither was seriously hurt.

NEW YORK, The Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation and Mrs. F. Trubee Davison gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino, and afterward took their guests to a theatre. In the party were Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lee, Mrs. Artemus L. Gates, Mrs. Lewis Douglas, Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont, Miss Margery Peabody, Thomas Gammock and John McCloy.

Having lost his fight to obtain release on bail, "OWNEY" MADDEN must remain in Sing Sing, unless the Parole Board releases him earlier, until the Court of Appeals in the Fall hears his formal appeal from a recent unanimous decision of the Appellate Division holding him subject to the board's jurisdiction.
BERLIN, July 20.--The Presidential decree appointing a Federal Commissioner for Prussia, dated at Neudeck, where President von Hindenburg is on vacation, reads as follows:...

Although one out of six marriages in the United States ends in divorce, recent studies of marriages of couples who met while attending coeducational institutions indicate that not more than one in seventy-five results in failure, Dr. Paul Popenoe, director of the Institute of Family Relations at Los Angeles, said last night in an address to Columbia University Summer School students at Teachers College.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Proceedings to determine whether foreign carriers have entered into any combination, agreement or understanding to exclude the Dollar Steamship Lines from membership in the Japan-China and Straits-Bombay Conference were instituted today by the Shipping Board.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 20 -- Standing within a point of victory after one of the prettiest exhibitions of tennis the local season has witnessed, Bryan Grant of Atlanta defaulted to Dr. Eugene H. McCauliff of Yonkers today in the invitation grass court tennis tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

A mystery concerning the ownership of about $50,000,000 in German bonds of the issue connected with the late Ivar Kreuger's German match concession developed yesterday as inquiry into the affairs of the Kreuger Toll Company continued before Henry K. Davis, special master, at 140 Nassau Street.

CARMEL, N.Y., July 20 -- After hearing an address by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., the Putnam County Republican Committee, at a meeting held in the court house here this evening, recommended a 10 per cent cut in the salaries of all county and town officials, elected and appointed, beginning Sept. 1.

Domenico Trombetta, editor of the local Italian newspaper Il Grido della Stirpe, was held without bail yesterday for the Richmond County grand jury on a charge of homicide in the fatal shooting of Salvatore Arena, a Brooklyn painter, after Trombetta had pleaded not guilty when arraigned before Magistrate Bridges in West New Brighton court.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 20 (Canadian Press) -- Terms of the agreement between the Dominion of Canada and the Province of Ontario as to the Province's share of the cost of the St. Lawrence seaway and waterpower project were outlined today by Premier Bennett and Premier Henry.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 20 -- Jack Mackie Jr., former New York State amateur champion, and Joe Weiner of Inwbod repeated their victory of last year by leading a field of forty-three teams in the second annual amateur best-ball tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Lido Country Club today with 144 for thirty-six holes.

Two Chinese, who were arrested in Chinatown last Monday on disorderly conduct charges, following the bombardment with, tomatoes, turnips, eggs and other edibles of detectives of the Narcotic Squad and motion pictures actors filming of a pseudo raid in a building in Doyers Street, were found guilty yesterday at a hearing by Magistrate Harris in the Tombs Court.

ORDINARILY Raymond L. Ditmars starts his stories by reaching into an old, battered suitcase, hauling out a linen bag, extracting there-from a writhing, twisting snake and sounding off with "Now this snake, gentlemen, belongs to the genus Pituophis and is a nice, gentle, useful colubrine," and so forth.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, daughter of John D. Rockefeller and once Chicago's wealthiest woman, has encountered financial reverses, according to Edwin D. Krenn, her close business associate for ten years.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- With the opening-day of the Olympics exactly ten days hence, advance ticket sales passed the 1,300,000 single admissions mark today, thereby exceeding all attendance marks of the modern games.

LONDON, July 20 -- The sequel to the latest German upset is being awaited with some anxiety in London, where there is considerable speculation as to whether President von Hindenburg and Chancellor von Papen have not "bitten oft more than they can chew."
MANCHESTER, Mass., July 20 -- Only one Easterner remained in the field as the semi-final stage was reached in the annual women's invitation tennis tournament of the Essex County Club today.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- Chuck Klein hammered his way out of a batting slump with two homers and a triple, while the Phillies defeated the first-place Pirates again, 6 to 2, today.

After a talk with Senator BORAH, a Washington gossip of The World-Telegram, has set down the latest version of what The-Man-Without-a-Party expects to do in the Presidential campaign. He will make some nation-wide radio addresses "on any subject which interests him."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Future greats of sail and sea had their innings afloat today in the seventh annual junior regatta sailed under the direction of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Eighty-two craft, with the interclub down in size, were manned by boys and girls, all under 18 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Herbert Hoover's first public utterance on the Great Lakes deeper waterway project after his nomination for the Presidency in 1928 was in his speech of acceptance at Palo Alto Aug. 11, in which he referred to the farm-relief possibilities inherent in the streams of the United States and urged the Great Lakes-Gulf development of the Mississippi and a waterway from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation expedited today plans to meet the expected avalanche of requests for loans from the States when the President signs the $2,122,000,000 unemployment relief bill.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 20 (AP) -- H.V. Jenkins of The Savannah (Ga.) News and Press announced here today that manufacture of newsprint and other paper from pine pulp will begin in a few days.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Whether steps taken to balance the budget for the present fiscal year have accomplished their purpose probably will not be known until the middle of November, and likely will not be made public until President Hoover submits the estimates for the 1934 budget to Congress, Treasury officials said today.

BERLIN, July 20 -- The control of Prussia passed into the hands of the Federal Government today when president von Hindenburg issued an emergency decree appointing Chancellor von Papen Federal Commissioner for Prussia with full authority to depose its acting government, headed by Otto Braun, Premier, and Dr. Carl Severing, Minister of the Interior, both Socialists.

DUBLIN, July 20 -- The de Valera Government was forced tonight to summon a special meeting of the Dail for Friday to consider several recommendations that the Senate made today when it passed the emergency duties bill through its remaining stages.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20 -- The sixth annual invitation golf tournament at the Newport Country Club will open tomorrow afternoon with the playing of the qualifying round. This will be followed by two days of match play.

The Cities Service Company reports for the twelve months ended on June 30 gross earnings of $36,722,723, compared with $48,812,303 for the preceding period. After interest and expenses, the net available to dividends and reserves was $22,909,742, against $34,053,652.

About 200 descendants of the twenty-three original patentees of the town of New Harlem, most of them from the Far and Middle West, held a "town meeting," the first time since, Colonial days, within its ancient boundaries yesterday to revivify the town corporation, which they declare was dormant but never dead, and take the first step on a road which they hope will bring them millions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20 (AP) -- The government announced today that the Brazilian Ambassador at London had signed an agreement with the financial house of Rothschild for prorogation and amortization of the L1,000,000 obligation of the Banco de Brasil, of which one-half already had been paid.
BERLIN, July 20 (AP) -- Dr. Franz Bracht, Mayor of Essen, named Deputy Commissioner for Prussia today, is 54 years old and a native of Berlin, although his family originated in Westphalia.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Cleveland ended a successful road trip by defeating the Red Sox, 8 to 1, today, having won fourteen of seventeen games played on the road and taken four out of five in their present series.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A group of about 200 of the radical element of the Bonus Expeditionary Force defied police orders and marched to the White House this morning. The police, for the first time since the army of veterans arrived here, were forced to display tear-gas bombs and scout cars equipped with other arms before the marchers were dispersed and sent straggling back to their camp.

A lioness escaped from the wild animal arena in Luna Park, Coney Island, while yesterday afternoon's "ballyhoo" was in progress, and roamed through the north end at the park for more than ten minutes before keepers armed with iron prongs and boat hooks succeeded in driving her back into her cage.

With a finals provided by screeching fire apparatus brought to the scene, by a false alarm, ground was broken yesterday for the new Feeral court house, which will rise thirty-two stories above Foley Squar, Courts Pearl Street from the Supreme Courts Building, after a ceremony at which Mayor Walker and seven others delivered addresses.

Though the Seventy-second Congress stands adjourned, its spirit will go marching on all Summer. No fewer than twelve investigations, all authorized at the last session, are either in progress or soon will be. Of these, six were initiated by the Senate and five by the House, while one is a joint undertaking.
ALBANY, July 20 -- The text of the Power Authority's report today to Governor Roosevelt on the St. Lawrence negotiations was as follows:

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20 -- Mauricio Cardozo, former Minister of Justice of Brazil, arrived by airplane today from Porto Alegre, in rebel territory, with full powers, it is said, to negotiate peace on behalf of the Frente Unica (United Front) party of Rio Grande do Sul.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Radio Division of the Department of Commerce was abolished and its duties transferred to the Federal Radio Commission by an executive order issued today by President Hoover. His action was authorized by the economy act of the legislative appropriation act which he recently signed.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 21 -- The Japanese view with concern the forthcoming military conference summoned to Peiping by Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang, former war lord of Manchuria, which will include such leaders as Han Fu-chu, Governor of Shantung, and Shansi and Suiyuan generals.

Asserting that it lies within the power of the bankers to make a "great and important contribution toward improvement in present business conditions" by means of "a more lenient credit attitude, particularly in regard to small enterprises," the banking and industrial committee, known as the Owen Young Committee of the Fourth Federal Reserve District, Cleveland, took its first step yesterday for renewed use of credit in that district.

ALBANY, July 20 -- A group of farm leaders called on Governor Roosevelt today and while indicating a friendly attitude toward him as candidate for President, said they would not go on record for either candidate -until after President Hoover had made his acceptance speech.

Franco Georgetti of Italy, four times national motor-paced champion, returned to titular competition at the Coney Island velodrome last night, defeating six-other starters to win a forty-mile paced grind.

The repeal of prohibition in Finland, which went into effect last April after a referendum, has been both financially and morally beneficial to the country and is generally hailed as a forward step, according to Urho Toivola, Finnish editor, who is revisiting this country to see the Olympic Games.

The railroads of the country united yesterday in issuing a statement addressed "to the American public" in which they described their condition as serious, pledged themselves to avoid all preventable waste through excessive competition and asked popular support of their efforts to ameliorate their present situation.

BERLIN, July 20 -- The Boerse was little disturbed by the government's measures in Prussia, although the action came as a surprise to financial circles. A certain nervousness was noticeable, but, as there were hardly any substantial offers, prices almost held their own.

Mayor Walker announced yesterday that he would speak on budget economy at 6:30 tomorrow evening over WEAF, addressing his department heads at City Hall in a speech that will be broadcast for the benefit of 130,000 city employes and any other persons interested.

Asserting that the rate now paid by the city to private hospitals for the care of city cases is less than half the cost of such cases, the directors of the Beekman Street Hospital have appealed for an increase, according to an announcement yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president.

The Commerce Department's classified statement on origin and destination of gold imported and exported during June, in which the exports exceeded those of May and rose to the largest figure of any month, on record excepting last October, indicates that the month's exports of $226,116,680 went to ten different countries, while the imports of $18,394,738 were received, sometimes in relatively small amounts, from thirty-two separate countries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20 -- Members of the Southampton Players opened tonight their second production of the season, "Crazy American," a new drama by Charles R. Walker, before a large audience in Parris Memorial Hall. The play was directed by Henry Codman Potter.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- Lefty Grove pitched the Athletics to victory today over the St. Louis Browns, 8 to 5, giving his team its sixth straight triumph. He registered his fifteenth triumph of the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES today the report of the committee representing twenty-five organizations and submitted to the Board of Education is announced. It is highly probable that one measure of economy in administration, that is not entirely obvious has been overlooked in this report.

RENO, Nev., July 20 (AP) -- Clyde D. Souler, attorney for John Wanamaker 2d, said here today that Mr. Wanamaker would not press his divorce action against Mrs. Wanamaker until the injunction at Norristown, Pa., had been settled.
Primo Carnera returned to Ebbets Field, where he was defeated by Jack Sharkey last year, and registered a seven-round victory over Jack Gross of Philadelphia last night.

Lodewick Vroom, formerly general manager for Gilbert Miller, declared yesterday that he, instead of the Erlanger Theatrical Enterprises, would henceforth operate Erlanger's Theatre in West Forty-fourth Street. Mr. Vroom, who opened his offices there yesterday, said he was representing a group of people who obtained the house from Vincent Astor.

Medical and dental service on the instalment plan, based on the same principles applied to the purchase of an automobile or a radio, has made tremendous strides during the last six months with the medical and dental professions in this city as well as with the public, it was revealed yesterday by Thomas R. Gardiner, president of the Mutual Professional Plan, Inc., of 33 West Forty-second Street.

More Woe for Commuters, Next to paying for "drinking water" on one's first trip abroad, or furnishing one's own soap, in Paris hotels, perhaps the most painful separation of currency from its owner is that collected by a conductor from a commuter who has forgotten his monthly ticket.

The Citizens Budget Commission's first communication to the Mayor is a model of diplomacy. If there is any mailed fist, it is concealed in the softest of gloves. Mr. WALKER has been insisting that a substantial part of the cost of local government is beyond his control because of mandatory legislation.

NEOLA, L.I., July 20 -- A "third degree" which went too far had a dramatic sequel in a crowded court room here today when Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink held thirteen members of the Nassau County Police Department to be criminally involved in the death of a prisoner suspected of beating and robbing a detective's mother

John Golden, theatrical producer, will be permitted to lease the Royale Theatre in West Forty-fifth Street for twenty-one months under a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Collins. The court heard an application by Philip J. Dunn and Mr. Golden, receivers of the Royale, Majestic and Masque Theatres, in the foreclosure suit by the Continental Bank and Trust Company against the Theatre Zone Realty Company and others, for permission to make the lease.
The fourth exhibition at the Eighth Street Gallery opened last night with what is described by the proprietor as an "informal festival," featuring singing, dancing, verse and dissertation.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- A rousing farewell was tendered the homewardbound Dodgers by the Cardinals in the final game of the series today when the home club walloped five Brooklyn pitchers for a total of twenty-two hits to win the deciding game of the series, 16 to 5.

ALBANY, July 20 -- The Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal yesterday of the Public Service Commission in the application of the New York State Electric Corporation, petitioner for a writ of certiorari against the Public Service Commission.
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 20 -- Twenty-four sloops took part in the sixth race of the July series of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today.

Democratic State organizations will be required to carry the heavy responsibility and bear the brunt of the battle to elect Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt President of the United States. A new departure in the organization of a national campaign of either of the major parties, this was the outstanding feature of a campaign plan which, following approval by the Governor himself, was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Representative Snell, Republican leader of the House, replied today to Representative O'Connor of New York, who, in a speech in the House July 12, declared that "the Republican campaign will be financed out of the Treasury of the United States and an investigation will prove it."
LONDON, July 20 -- On the eve of the Ottawa Imperial Economic Conference the British people are looking across the Atlantic with faith and hope that are almost like a prayer.

With Babe Ruth and a delegation of Australian cricketers seated in a box on the mezzanine floor as interested spectators, the Yankees finished their business with the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday in a manner that caused Manager Joe McCarthy to express deep regret that the Chicagoans really had to leave town so soon.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- Following a Cabinet meeting at which were considered Washington's offer of mediation and other, phases of the diplomatic conflict with Uruguay, Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas stated emphatically today that Argentina would not accept an offer of the good offices from the United States or any other country, but would insist on settlement in accordance with the Treaty of Montevideo of 1889.

COPENHAGEN, July 20 -- The foreign political committee and the Greenland committee of the Danish Rigsdag received a report today concerning the notes exchanged between Denmark and Norway since the new Norwegian occupation of Southeast Greenland.

Anecdotes of some widely known persons who have crossed on the Mauretania are related by Captain S.G.S. McNeil, retired master of this famous ocean liner, in his book, "In Great Waters," published today by Harcourt, Brace Co.
GENEVA, July 20 -- The text of the adjournment resolution presented to the disarmament conference today follows:

A survey of national advertising as comprising a large group of major industries reveals that newspapers continue to lead, generally by a substantial margin, in the advertising appropriations, it was announced yesterday by the bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, 370 Lexlngton Avenue.

UTICA, N.Y., July 20 -- Favorites including Miss Helen Hicks, defending champion, went into the quarter-finals of the New York State women's golf tourney today at the Yahnundasis Golf Club, with Miss Hicks registering two one-sided victories.

Although a final settlement which would end the long dispute over a new working agreement for the garment industry was not reached last night after an entire day spent by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in an attempt to bring the various groups together, leaders in the industry were admittedly "hopeful of a satisfactory outcome" at a conference to be held Saturday.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation is prepared to increase its bid of $18,000,000 in its per cent preferred stock for the Richfield Oil Company of California, which has been in receivership since January, 1931. This fact became known when it was learned that H.R. Gallagher, president of the Consolidated, left here last Sunday by airplane, arriving in Los Angeles on Monday morning.

The surplus of imports over exports, shown in the trade report for June, was the first monthly "import excess" since August of last year and the thirteenth since the war -- eight of them having occurred in 1923 and 1926. Last month's result is associated with British protective tariffs and restrictions on importations by other European countries.
Frank E. Brown's Condescend, winner of four races in a row at Jamaica last Spring, won for the first time since that sequence when he annexed the Richmond Purse, feature yesterday at Empire City.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 20 -- The United States will lose an important part of its large market in Canada for iron and steel products if the tentative agreement between the British and Canadian industries is ratified by the Imperial Economic Conference.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 20 -- Captain John Wanamaker 2d of New York and Philadelphia was restrained from getting a Reno divorce by a preliminary injunction issued here today by President Judge J. Ambler Williams in the Montgomery County court.

MONTREAL, July 20 (AP) -- Reading captured the final game of the series with Montreal today, 4 -- 3, giving the Keys three out of four in the series. Al Shealy held the Royals to four hits, one of which was a home run by Roettger with one on.

MEXICO CITY, July 20 -- Clarence McElroy, the American, flier, is recovering from his injuries, suffered when the plane he was piloting crashed in the State of Oaxaca out June 7, according to Dr. A. Good man, sent by the United States Consul here to San Geronimo to examine Mr. McElroy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No clearer insight into the realities of the political situation has been furnished the voters than by your editorial on Roosevelt's Chicago speech. Attacking the same inherent weakness in Roosevelt's appeal. Secretary Hyde called attention to the fact that the Governor's vague talk about "reforestation" as an aid to employment has not been based on any New York State performance.

The seventy-five community trusts in the United States now administer charity funds approximating $37,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday when representatives of twenty banks comprising the trustees' committee of the New York Community Trust met at the Bankers' Club to inaugurate the trust's tenth year of operation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Hoover, according to some Republican leaders, will support the party's declaration on prohibition in his speech of acceptance and will not attempt to interpret the plank so as to win the favor of the drys. Leaders who have discussed it with him.

The price of copper abroad was sent again yesterday to a new low price at 4.55 cents a pound c.i.f. base European ports, by Japanese producers who previously had been quoting 4.65 cents. As a result, Copper Exporters, Inc., the cooperative selling agency abroad for many producers, lowered its figure on special offerings from 4 7/8 to 4.70 cents a pound c.i.f. European ports.

The International oil companies, which control about 75, per cent of the production in Rumania, and all independent producers there except a few small concerns controled by French interests, have agreed to reduce their production to demand or by approximately 25 per cent, according to reports reaching here yesterday from the Paris conference.

The joint hearings before the Public Service and Transit Commissions on the New York Central Railroad's application for a 40 per cent rise in commutation fares, in progress for nearly eighteen months, ended yesterday with spokesmen for Westchester communities refusing to commit themselves to a compromise on a 25 per cent increase.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- President Hoover was asked today by a New England joint conference on re-employment to consider calling a national conference which would effect an organization sponsoring the flexible workday and week as a partial solution of the unemployment problem.

The New York Central Railroad has begun to spend the first instalment of a $4,399,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to carry forward its west side track improvement plans, it was revealed yesterday.

John Nogrady, St. John's College star, and Ernest Koslan, N.Y.U. freshman, gained the semi-final round of the junior singles in the annual Long Island Tennis Centre tournament by registering triumphs in quarter-final matches at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A glance at the fire-blackened ruins of several blocks at Coney Island confirms the general opinion, often expressed but seldom put into public protest, that there is too much flimsy wood construction at this and other beach resorts.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 20 -- In a pronouncement bristling with criticism of Industry for Its failure to introduce the shorter work week on a national scale, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor decided today to ask President Hoover to call a conference of representatives of labor and industry to work out a plan for the early adoption of the five-day week and the six-hour day for the nation's 50,000,000 wage earners.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 20 (Canadian Press) -- Officially opening the daily Montreal-Ottawa air service, established for the duration of the imperial conference, a party of prominent Canadian Manufacturers Association officials from Montreal arrived here today after a trip of 1 hour and 10 minutes.

Twenty-five properties in Manhathattan and the Bronx were put up at liquidation sales yesterday. This was the longest list of forced sales in many weeks. Banks, especially savings institutions, participated in the auction proceedings and protected their liens by bidding in the offerings in which they held an interest.

The Board of Estimate should make an independent investigation of rapid-transit unification before making even a tentative agreement on the price to be paid for B.M.T. and Interborough properties, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, declared yesterday.

A Connecticut angler tells a story to illustrate some of the well-known characteristics of the black bass. Fishing at Lake Saltonstall, near New Haven, during the last few days, Lyerit Russell was reeling in, what he thought was a good-sized bass, when suddenly through the water dashed another that hit the plug in a desire to see what was proving so tempting a bait.

RYE, N.Y., July 20 -- After a discouraging start, in which it appeared she had thrown away her chance, Mrs. John Lapham of Woodway made a grand finish in the fifty-four, hole medal play championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties today to win the Mrs. I.M. Wheeler Trophy with two strokes to spare.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Postmaster General Brown signed an order today modifying the transient second-class rate of postage on newspapers, magazines and other publications entered as second-class matter when mailed by others than the publishers or news agents in accordance with the recent act of Congress.

Figures on travel compiled by the United States Shipping Board for last year show a decline of nearly 20 per cent in the number of persons who traveled to or from United States ports on domestic or foreign ships, as compared with the previous year's figures.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- With Carl Hubbell, their pitching mainstay, submerging the Cubs' attacks, the Giants completed their Western wanderings with a 9-to-1 victory today. The triumph also was featured by Mel Ott's eighteenth homer of the year, another by Shanty Hogan and three substantial drives by Hubbell himself.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP) -- Holman Williams, a rangy youth from Detroit, provided a major upset in the preliminary tryouts for the American Olympic boxing team tonight when he eliminated Richard Carter of New York, holder of the national A.A.U. 126-pound title.

ALBANY, July 20 -- President Hoover's policy of "ignoring" New York State in the St. Lawrence waterway negotiations was sharply attacked today by the Power Authority in a report to Governor Roosevelt that imputed bad faith on the part of the administration.

Leasing of store space featured the dealings in business quarters reported by realty brokers yesterday. Shops on Madison Avenue, Park and Fifth Avenues were involved in the contracts. Stores in the produce section were rented and office space also was signed for by a number of firms.

Miss Dorothy Paris, who opened a gallery at 61 West Eighth Street last Spring, to assist in the sale of the work of young American artists, introduced her latest exhibition last night with a "festival of art" for which there was an admission charge of $2, to forestall the closing of the gallery.

The first exhibition of silks ever sponsored by the Silk Association of America was held yesterday for the benefit of buyers, stylists and fashion representatives at the headquarters of the association, 468 Fourth Avenue. The-Fall collections of 40 manufacturers were represented in the showing, which will be continued today.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 20 -- The heads of the delegations of all the empire countries represented at Ottawa have been in joint conference and in executive sessions with their own countrymen throughout today, making the final preparations for the opening of the British Empire economic conference tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- After dropping three straight to the Tigers, the Washington Senators today defeated Detroit. 4 to 1, in the fourth game of the series.

The gypsy fortune tellers did a fair business at Golden City Park, Canarsie, yesterday, but none of them could answer questions regarding the whereabouts of Mary Demetri, daughter of one of them, who disappeared with, her father and his family late Monday or early Tuesday.
TORONTO, July 20 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Toronto in both games of today's double-header, 5-4 and 2-1, to take the series, three games to one.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- Dispatches from La Paz and Asuncion report enthusiastic street demonstrations in both Bolivia and Paraguay demanding a formal declaration of war in the Chaco region, whence other dispatches indicate a state of war already exists.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Federal prohibition forces will be reduced by 6 per cent, or about 150 agents, during the current fiscal year, Amos W. W. Woodcock, head of the dry bureau, announced today.

PARIS, July 20 -- The Bourse weakened slightly today, stocks showing moderate losses all along the line, although there was decided resistance and closing quotations generally were not the lowest of the day. Unfavorable foreign news, particularly from Germany, was blamed for the weakness.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Public Service Company of Northern Illinois and the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company filed today an application, with, the Illinois Commerce Commission for an amendment to orders issued in May granting them and the Commonwealth Edison Company authority to issue $70,000,000 of bonds.

LONDON, July 20 -- British Government funds resumed their upward movement today, but German bonds slumped heavily on news of the dictatorship in Prussia. The stock markets generally started strong, but weakened, later on disturbing news from the Continent.

ROME, July 20 -- Foreign Minister Dino Grandi, four other Ministers and eleven Under-Secreteries of State were relieved of their posts this morning when Premier Mussolini decreed sweeping Cabinet changes. These changes had been announced as imminent several times before but had been postponed because it was feared they might give an erroneous impression in the present delicate phase of the economic crisis that harmony was lacking in the government.

DETROIT, July 20 -- The five-day week for all city employes became effective this morning, when Mayor Frank Murphy signed the ordinance passed, 6 to 2, by the Common Council last night. All salaries were cut 14.5 per cent from today.

LATONIA, Ky., July 20 (AP) -- Nituma, one of the ranking 2-year-old fillies of the Kentucky circuit, and Head Play, generally regarded as best among the colts, hooked up for the first time today in the Sparta Purse, with honors going to the filly. Nituma' races for Sewell Combs, member of the State Racing Commission, while Head Play is the star of Mrs. W. Crump's stable.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricane Four was eliminated from the Hempstead Cup's tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today when his team bowed to H.W. Shaffer's Vipers, 13 to 11, in the first-round engagement of the annual twelve-goal handicap tournament.

Sultry heat radiating through a clear sky from a dazzling sun continued the heat wave yesterday in the metropolitan area and, with some exceptions; the rest of the country. At least twenty-one deaths from the heat were recorded throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- State Department officials expressed regret today at the apparent misinterpretation in Argentina on the United States' extension of its good offices for settlement of the diplomatic differences between that country and Uruguay.

Aside from irregularly lower prices for German bonds, with the losses only a point or two, reflecting the declaration of martial law in Prussia, the bond market on the Stock Exchange gave a generally good account of itself yesterday.

Decision of the German Government to set up a temporary military rule in Prussia has two obvious motives. One is to put an end to the violent political clashes which have already resulted in a long and really appalling list of deaths and casualties.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Bullish crop comments from the American and Canadian Northwest and strength in Liverpool, while resulting in an upturn of 1/2 cent in the early trading today, failed to increase speculative interest on the Board of Trade. Scattered buying by commission houses was insufficient to carry prices above the offers.

Chesapeake Ohio. The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $8,766,967 after taxes and charges, equal to $1.14 a share on the $25 par common stock, against $11,841,284, or $1.55 a share, in the same period last year.
In a letter to stockholders of the Jewel Tea Company, M.H. Karker, president, urges a reduction in government expenses, with a view to reducing the tax burdens on corporations and individuals.

Plans for extensive educational and scientific exhibits in the buildings of Rockefeller Center were outlined yesterday by the Rockefeller interests after an announcement in Washington that President Hoover had signed a bill authorizing the entry under bond of foreign goods for such purposes without prepayment of customs duty.

The stock market pursued yesterday its familiar program of narrow movement in prices, but the trend this time was upward and advances ranging from fractions to 3 or 4 points occurred in many shares. Home bonds were also strong, with fairly numerous gains of 1 to 4 points, especially in railway securities.
With temperatures in producing sections the most moderate in some time and the weekly report favorable, prices on the Cotton Exchange receded 8 to 11 points yesterday.

RUMSON, N.J., July 20 -- By the convincing margin of 8 to 2, the team of the United States Army, which is apparently gathering momentum as the season progresses, rode over Templeton and into the final of the national junior polo championship today at the Rumson Country Club.

Retirement of large amounts of bonds, debentures and preferred stocks of subsidiary companies and substantial write-downs in the cost of the general portfolio and of holdings in subsidiary and affiliated companies are the principal changes reflected in the report of the United Founders Corporation, for the six months ended on May 31, sent to stockholders yesterday.

In honor of the 122d anniversary of the independence of their country more than 250 citizens of the Republic of Colombia attended yesterday afternoon a reception at the Hotel Ambassador given by Dr. German Olano, Colombian Consul General at New York.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 20--The candidates of the Second Battalion have shown the efficiency of their citizens' military training camp training with the rifle by all qualifying for marksmanship badges by making scores of 56 or over out of a possible 75.

NICE, July 20 -- Maurice Maeterlinck has sworn out a warrant charging embezzlement against Andre Gasiglia, one of the Riviera's most prominent lawyers and a former Cabinet Minister and civic leader, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Citizens of America from coast to coast are paying special taxes on things they eat, drink, wear or burn, a survey revealed today, the trend in perhaps half the forty-eight States being toward modified sales taxes.

MONTREAL, July 20 -- A protective committee has been formed here and is requesting deposits of the bonds of the Northwestern Power Company, Ltd. This action follows non-payment of the interest that was due on July 2 on the company's 6 per cent first-mortgage sinking-fund convertible gold bonds, Series A, of which approximately $10,000,000 principal amount is outstanding.

Edward W. Rollfs of Leonia sold to the Elward Holding Corporation of Palisade Park the three threestory six-family brick flats on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 249-253 New York Avenue, near Griffith Street, the three-story frame flat and the onestory brick garage at 160-162 New York Avenue, corner of Franklin Street, and the two-story brick taxpayer in the rear, 32-54 Franklin Street, Jersey City.
The full text of Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink's memorandum at the conclusion of the John Doe hearing into the death of Hy man Stark follows:

Apparel Orders Encouraging. Operations of retail buyers on Fall merchandise in the local apparel markets during the week were encouraging, with the new dress lines meeting with general favor, it was said among resident offices here yesterday.

It is now 106 years since the Government acquired the fifty-two acres at the end of Throgs Neck for a military reservation. Not until 1856 was Fort Schuyler completed. It is a casemated structure of granite, with opening's for heavy guns. As a fortification it is obsolete.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A conference is planned here next week between Democratic Senators and James A. Farley, chairman of the party's national committee. Senator Harris of Mississippi has requested Mr. Farley to meet with the Senators before they return home to consider the St. Lawrence treaty and other issues in the Presidential campaign, particularly methods to assure harmony within the party on the prohibition question.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The determination of the Chinese Government to "resist with all the forces at our command" the Japanesa invasion of Jehol Province in Inner Mongolia, 'Which started Monday, was announced today by the Chinese Legation here.

The New York State branch of the National Economy League, which aims to cut down government expenditures, beginning with the money being spent for veterans' relief, was organized yesterday at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO July 20 -- Ten days ago fresh pork loins were quoted at 20 to 21 cents a pound, while the same weight averages today were obtainable in carlots at 10 to 10 1/2 cents. Packers generally reported a slow demand for fresh meats as the result of the extremely hot weather.

HIGH POINT, N.C., July 20 (A.P) -- A committee of strikers voted tonight to reject an offer of hosiery mill owners to restore the wage scale effective until about ten days ago, reduction of which resulted in a general shutdown of industry here. They agreed to demand the higher scale in effect April 1.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The joint board of engineers of the United States and Canada, in making its final report on the improvement of the international section of the St. Lawrence River, expressed the unanimous opinion that the two-stage plan, provided for in the treaty for the seaway to the Great Lakes is practicable and feasible from an engineering point of view.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 20 -- Louisville's four-man team won the Harding Cup in the qualifying round of the national public links tournament today and medalist honors went to a California schoolboy, Joe Nichols, who was runner-up last year to Charles Ferrara of San Francisco.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- Rochester and Newark broke even in their series at two games each as the Bears trimmed the Red Wings today, 6 to 2.
