CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Hilena, a fleet miss born in the hills of West Virginia, was a surprise winner of the Arlington Lassie Stakes, worth $25,230, richest juvenile stake exclusively for fillies, at Arlington Park today.

Indications of increasing stability in the steel industry tend to offset the disappointment arising from the slow recovery from the mid-year shut-downs, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. The national average of ingot production is estimated by this publication to be about 16 per cent of capacity, the same as in the week before.

ALBANY, July 20 -- New York State will not seek to borrow from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for unemployment relief funds under the bill passed in the closing days of Congress, Governor Roosevelt said today.

GENEVA, July 20 -- A resolution backed by the United States, France, Great Britain and Italy and containing their first unanimous pledge to reduce substantially their air, sea and land forces was submitted today to the general disarmament commission this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- Washington regained fourth place in the American League today by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 4, in the closing game of the series.

Last Fall Bailie THOMSON of Glasgow, an enthusiastic Scottish Nationalist, was in Canada preaching-Scottish independence. Some day soon, he said, the Scotch should March on Edinburgh and reopen that Scottish Parliament adjourned without day at the fatal moment of the Union.

The four-party consolidation plan for the Eastern railroads as announced by the Interstate Commerce Commission holds out promise for "many economies" and comes extremely timely to the pledge to reduce competitive wastes made public by the railroads on Wednesday, it was said last night by Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio.

Building trades workers in this city have met with a revolutionary change in their employment status which results from changed conditions in real estate ownership and management, declares David Shapiro, secretary of District Council 9, Brotherhood of Painters, in a report to his national organization.

Thursday, July 21, 1932. The only change of any significance was the widening quotation for time money to I 1/4 @ 1 1/2 per cent from 1 1/2, with a little ninety days' done at the Inside figure. Except for a like quotation for sixty-day money in several weeks at this time a year ago, this was the lowest rate for a number of years.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The open season for hunting wild ducks and geese has been extended from one to two months for the coming Fall by President Hoover at the recommendation of Secretary Hyde.

STILLWATER, Minn., July 21. -- A toast, probably his last, to thirty-three fighting former comrades of Civil War days, men with whom he rallied around an old bottle of wine at dozens of annual reunions, was the tribute paid tonight by the "last man" of the Last Man's Club.

JERUSALEM, July 21. -- An ugly situation appears to be developing between Bedouin squatters and Jewish farmers in the northwestern section of the valley of Jezreel. Already there have been several encounters, mostly in land disputes.

The scale committee of the Publishers' Association of New York City and the scale conference committee of Typographical Union 6 were unable to break the deadlock over a new agreement on wages and working conditions at a conference yesterday afternoon.

Securities of a new kind of investment trust, in the form of collateral trust bonds, are being offered by the United States Securities Corporation, of which Wellington Bull is president. The bonds are to pay up to 7 per cent as earned and are to mature in thirty years.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 21. -- Miss Josephine Cruickshank of Santa Ana, Cal., twelfth ranking woman tennis player in the country, today scored a well-earned and surprising victory over Mrs. Lawrence A. Harper of Oakland, Cal., who ranks third nationally, to gain the final round of the annual invitation tournament of the Essex County Club.

PEIPING, Friday, July 22. -- Japanese military authorities announced at Tientsin today that if the Japanese army clashed with Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's army in Jehol province, Manchuria, "the Japanese garrison at Tientsin will have no other course but to attack Peiping, Chiang Hsiaoliang's base."

DETROIT, July 21 (AP). -- The touring Australian cricket team, ran up a score of 313 runs for four wickets before it declared its innings closed against a team, of local players today. The visitors then retired the Detroit side of sixteen for 88 runs.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP). -- Bareball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today approved the suspension of Bill Dickey, New York Yankee catcher, who was declared Ineligible until Aug. 4 and fined $1,000 for breaking Carl Reynolds's jaw.

Universites and colleges in large cities throughout the country are often forced to divide student residents in their dormitories according to their ability to pay instead of into academic or social groups, Herbert E. Howe, director of Earl Hall, Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon in an address before the Students' Housing Conference at Teachers College, Columbia University.
CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP). -- The sour taste in vinegar promises to save the leather industry from tremendous annual losses due to mold.

Reporting a sharp improvement in its operations, compared with the first quarter, the Chrysler Corporation's statement for the second quarter, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $1,186,052 after taxes and other charges, equivalent to 27 cents a share on the common stock.

TOKYO, Friday, July 22. -- Allegedly fearing that Manchukuo designs to deprive him of valuable opium revenue from Jehol Province, which is said to be the financial mainstay of his military forces, Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang is sending troops, planes and tanks toward Jehol.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Sean T. O'Kelly, speaking for the Irish Free State's delegation to the imperial economic conference, said in part:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 21. -- About ninety persons attended the golf dinner at the Newport Country Club tonight. The event marked the closing of the first day's play in the annual invitation tournament of the club. The guests included those who had competed in the qualifying round, members of the club and members of the tournament committee, of which Richard Van Nest Gambrill is the chairman.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Of four Canadian rowing championships decided on the opening day of the 1932 Henley regatta today, only, one was captured by a Canadian club. This distinction fell to a junior crew of the Don Rowing Club, Toronto, which won the junior 150-pound four-oared event.

A suit in behalf of bondholders who bought from S. W. Straus Co. the $1,350,000 issue secured by a first mortgage on the sixteen-story apartment house at 875 West End Avenue, to compel the Straus interests to return the property to the bondholders, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

SHANGHAI, July 21. -- The tenseness between Japan and China over Jehol Province of Inner Mongolia increased today as it was reported that most of Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's army of 170,000 was moving toward Jehol from Peiping, while a large detachment of Japanese troops left Mukden, Manchuria, for a secret destination.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 21. -- Plans were formulated today by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor for an aggressive campaign for the restoration of the pay and privileges taken from Federal employes through the passage of the economy bill.

More than 1,000 pending padlock cases in which the Federal Government has served complaints on bartenders and employes of speakeasies in this district and not on owners are likely to be voided as the result of a ruling handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

TRENTON, N.J., July 21. -- Republican candidates for election to the 1933 Legislature pledged themselves at a conference here today to support the party's national ticket, but decided at the same time to make their own campaigns on the platform adopted by the State convention rather than the one ratified at the Chicago gathering.

BERLIN, July 21. -- There will be for the present no new Prussian Cabinet succeeding the ousted Ministers to whom Adolf Hitler objected and whom Chancellor Franz von Papen's government held guilty of carelessness and negligence in having permitted the Hitlerites and Communists to shoot each other and innocent bystanders in political riots in the Prussian streets.

ALBANY, July 21. -- Arriving here fresh from a long conference with former Governor Smith, Lieut. Gov. Lehman was looked upon today at the Capitol as the man who might reunite the political interests of Governor Smith and Governor Roosevelt.

In preparation for the general conference early next week of representatives of the two transit companies, the city and the Transit Commission, representatives of Interborough security holders conferred yesterday with the Transit Commission.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- The address of the Earl of Bessborough, Governor General of Canada, opening the imperial economic conference here, follows:

The Restaurant Marguery, one of the centres of Park Avenue social life, in the Hotel Marguery, at 270 Park Avenue, was raided shortly after 7 o'clock last night by five Federal agents, who made three arrests and confiscated two bottles purporting to contain gin and whisky.

The Bowery Savings Bank, which opened a branch office at the north-west corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street last October, is providing for further expansion of this branch by leasing space in adjoining property to the north, it was learned yesterday.

The first issue of "Babies; Just Babies," a new magazine edited by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the Democratic Presidential nominee, and her daughter, Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, and devoted exclusively to the interests of young mothers, will be released on Sept. 15, Mrs. Roosevelt announced at her town house, 49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The upward trend in bond prices on the New York Stock Exchange continued yesterday, all classifications showing gains. Upturns were recorded in rails, industrials, public utilities and foreign obligations, as well as in United States Government issues.
It was the ice-water. There was too much of it. And when the last echo of the bats quivered in slow death in the thick layers of heat waves on Travers Island yesterday, the score-board snowed:

A sharp criticism of the decree issued by the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil, on April 28 putting into effect a plan by which the State will issue promissory notes in respect of the service on a large part of its external debt, was made yesterday by the Institute of International Finance through its director, John T. Madden.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Open-market purchases of United States Government securities were continued by the Federal Reserve Banks on a restricted scale in the week ended yesterday, according to the Reserve Board's condition statement issued today.

LONDON, July 21. -- The opening proceedings at Ottawa,, in the opinion of a majority of London's newspapers, justify confident hope that before the delegates separate they will be able to achieve agreements of the greatest value to the empire and to the whole world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of last Sunday published an article by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, which deserves the attention of every one, although it contains some contradictions.

Financial markets were generally cheerful yesterday. The slow and deliberate recovery in stocks continued. Athough consisting mostly of fractional advances, it affected the whole list; there were few declines. No halt occurred in the gradual rise of domestic bond prices, which has now continued, virtually without interruption, since the beginning of the month.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Intensive warfare, which has existed for years between organized labor and machine-gun gangsters, is held responsible for the murder at Shawano, Wis., today of Patrick Berrell, vice president of the Teamsters' International Union, and Willie Marks, former Moran gangster.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- President Hoover will open his campaign for re-election with his speech of acceptance here Aug. 11, according to an announcement today by. Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, who, with other leaders, conferred with the President on issues to be stressed and the plan of campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Corporation taxes collected during the 1932 fiscal year amounted to $629,566,115, a decline of $396,826,583 as compared with 1931, while individual income taxes amounted to $427,190,681, a drop of $406,457,216, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 21. -- The well-laid plans of seven bank robbers were amiss in two particulars today and as a result two alleged members of the gang are being held by the police and the branch office of the Perth Amboy Trust Company lost only $700, instead of $50,000.

BOSTON, July 21. -- The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission, on Eastern rail consolidation represents a victory for the Governors of five of the New England States (all except Rhode Island) and was hailed here as such tonight by the Chief Executives or their representatives.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP). -- The Browns broke their losing streak of eleven in a row by taking the final encounter of the five-game series with the Athletics today, 5 to 3.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The way was cleared today for the offering of $70,000,000 of securities by Commonwealth Edison, Peoples Gas and Public Service Company of Northern Illinois when the Illinois Commerce Commission at Springfield amended an order issued on May 25 authorizing the issuance of bonds for that amount.

The new Dutch Colonial house on the south side of Colonial Avenue between Murray Avenue and Weaver Street in the Maple Hill development at Larchmont has been sold by the builder, Antonio Rodrigues, of Rodrigues Brothers, to Frederick L. G. o Weckman.

More than a score of members of the New York City Secretaries Conference toured the Palisades Interstate Park yesterday as guests of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. They returned home late last night apparently impressed by the work accomplished by the commission and determined to direct facilities of the park to the attention of many city dwellers who might enjoy them.

King Albert of Belgium, speaking before a microphone installed for the occasion in his Summer palace at Laeken, addressed American radio listeners yesterday by means of transoceanic short-wave communication and extensive networks in this country on the occasion of Belgium's celebration of her day of independence.

Wearing the uniform of a guard of an armored car crew, a man bustled into the main offices of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company at 165 Broadway last Saturday forenoon, asked for "the money for the United States Trucking Corporation," received $56,325 in cash and disappeared, giving the police one of the most brazen robberies in the history of the financial district to work upon.

The semiannual reports of the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., and the Broad Street Investing Company reveal the changes in the personnels of these investment trusts resulting from the acquisition by the Tri-Continental Corporation of controlling interest in the Broad Street Management Corporation, which in turn managed both trusts under contract and controls Capital Administration.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 21. -- While a grand jury considered indictments against policemen accused of beating a prisoner to death, State troopers arrived here today to help District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards in the guilty to justice.

Differences over the admissibility of evidence between Chairman Milo R. Maltbie and Commissioner George R. Van Namee almost broke up the Public Service Commission hearing yesterday on the reasonableness of the charge made by the telephone company of 25 cents a month for the use by subscribers of the "French type" of telephone instrument.
OTTAWA, July 21. -- The speech of Sir Atnl C. Chatterjee, representing India at the imperial economic conference here, follows in part:

Word was received from Washington yesterday that the War Department had approved the Long Island State Park Commission's application to erect a 2,000-foot suspension bridge across Great South Bay between Conklin Point and Captree Island.

LATONIA, Ky., July 21 (AP). -- Billy Champ, which Edward Haughton recently purchased from the Warm stable, made good at the first asking for his new owner when he romped off with the Point Pleasant Purse, feature at a mile and a sixteenth today at Latonia.

With the completion of the United Fruit Company's expansion program calling for six new liners by February of next year, the line will maintain a regular fortnightly schedule between San Francisco and New York with a record time of passage in the intercoastal passenger trade eastbound, it was announced yesterday.

The preservation of Carnegie Hall as a centre of music and art and its availability to the public are assured, according to Robert E. Simon, president of the Carnegie Hall Corporation, who announced yesterday that a series of free organ concerts will be given daily during the noon hour, beginning on Monday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The way to solve the problems of local government in Westchester and Nassau Counties is to take advantage of the special constitutional provisions by which the Legislature may provide forms of government for these counties, subject to approval by their electors.
PARIS, July 21. -- The United States Davis Cup team opens its tennis series with Germany tomorrow to settle which nation will play France next week in the challenge round.

That intention to break "foolish precedents" which Governor ROOSEVELT proclaimed in his speech of acceptance to the very convention which had nominated him is plainly followed in the Democratic plan of campaign for 1932. The precedent has been that Western, far Western, and sometimes even Southern, headquarters are set up.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, a pioneer organization for prohibition reform, will remain neutral between the major parties in the campaign this Fall, Pierre S. du Pont, chairman of the executive committee, stated today.

ALBANY, July 21. -- Stressing the value of public health to the nation, Governor Roosevelt indicated his belief in his regular weekly radio talk on State finances tonight that only by a drastic and dangerous reversal of policy could the budget of the State Health Department be reduced to any extent.

MANAGUA, July 21. -- Enrique Fernando Sanchez Salinas, a member of a prominent Leon family, who had been held captive six weeks by Sandinistas, arrived in Managua yesterday from the northern department.

Police Lieutenant John W. Kenna, who was questioned during the magistrates' courts inquiry on reported bank deposits of nearly $250,000, was promoted to captain yesterday, by special action of Commissioner Mulrooney.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Former Premier Stanley M. Bruce, representing Australia in the Imperial Economic Conference, spoke today, in part, as follows:

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (AP). -- Captain Pie Traynor and Lloyd Waner returned to the Pittsburgh line-up today and celebrated the event by getting together in the ninth inning to score the run that beat the Phillies, 3 to 2.

Retail Collection Index Off. The index of retail collections for June based on the reports of twenty local stores showed a decrease for the month of 2.88 from June, 1931, and a drop of 2 for the six-month period as compared with the corresponding period in 1931, the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press.) -- N.C. Havenga, finance Minister of South Africa and head of his country's delegation to the Imperial Conference, spoke today at the opening of the conference, in part, as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 20, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,438,000,000, an increase of $21,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,485,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- Many members of the Summer Colonies in Southampton, East Hampton and West Hampton attended the recital of Willard Fry, baritone, this afternoon at the studio at Wayside, the home of his uncle, Marshall Fry.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The State Department refused today to be drawn into a controversy with the New York Power Authority over the St. Lawrence waterway treaty and said that, like the Power Authority, it was willing to have all the matters at issue presented fully before the Foreign Relations Committee so that Congress and the country could decide as to the merits of the treaty and the method of its negotiation.

UTICA, N.Y., July 21. -- With only a mild upset in the elimination of Miss Bea Gottlieb of Great Neck, L.I., by Miss Frances Snyder, Rye, the women's New York State golf championship moved into the semi-final round today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 21. -- Clifford Sutter of New Orleans and Biyan Grant Jr. of Atlanta, finalists in the national intercollegiate singles championship, were eliminated from the invitation doubles of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today in the opening round.

Modest gains on the Stock Exchange yesterday were ascribed to the widespread belief that there would be a pick-up in business in advance of the Autumn season. In other words, there is a feeling that trade and industry will expand to some extent before the Summer is over.

Virtual agreement between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers on differences affecting a new working contract on which the two groups have been deadlocked in the four-cornered controversy involving jobbers and contractors as well was announced last night after an eight-hour conference.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- President Hoover signed into law today the gigantic Federal relief plan that masses $3,800,000,000 in one coffer for invigorating business, increasing employment and relieving destitution.

Any plan coming from New Hampshire is likely to have a rock bottom and to be thought through with granitic common sense. Hence there is a predisposition in favor of a proposal which, at the instance of Governor WINANT, was presented to one of the most impressive gatherings -- public officials, employers, labor leaders, college presidents, economists and social workers -- ever gathered in Boston.

One of the largest outright sales of a fee in the Grand Central Zone in several weeks was announced yesterday. The deal will mark the passing of several old buildings and the appearance of a new combination store and office structure on Forty-second Street.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21. -- In the fourth regatta of the Larchmont race week Henry B. Plant's 12-meter Clytie evened the score with Horace Havemeyer's Mouette today by defeating her by 2 minutes and 36 seconds over their 19 3/4-mile triangular course.

OTTAWA, July 21. -- Currency stabilization as an essential factor to economic recovery was emphasized by the representatives of Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and India at the opening of the Imperial Economic Conference here today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21. -- With Earle W. Hopping leading the attack; the Eastcott polo team, took two goals on handicap from the Cyclones tonight and made them last to carry it into the second round of the Hempstead Cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club. The score was 11 -- 6.

BERLIN, July 21 (AP). -- Dictatorship held the State of Prussia under control today and although there were stirrings of opposition it appeared that the people would wait peaceably for the Reichstag elections to voice their opinions. In Berlin and the Province of Brandenburg, both under military rule, business went on as usual.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The full text of the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission approval of the four-party plan of consolidation of Eastern railroads is as follows:

Bank clearings were slightly higher in the last week than for the preceding week, the total at twenty-two leading centres in the United States aggregating $4,189,330,000, against $4,148,239,000 in the preceding week. The decline from the corresponding week a year ago was 42 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The two-fold problem of intergovernmental debs and disarmament was stressed today by Silas H. Strawn, chairman of the American Committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, in a letter concerning the Lausanne reparations agreement sent to the members of the committee.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Evergold, which races for Patrick and Richard Nash, flashed through a thunderstorm today to win the $2,500-added Dundee Stakes, top event at Arlington Park.
READING, Pa., July 21 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles took the opening game of the series from the Reading Keys tonight, 14 to 10.

DUBLIN, July 21. -- The products selected for the new tariffs against Great Britain under the emergency duties bill include coal, electrical goods, boots and shoes and cement. When the measure receives the Governor General's assent, probably tomorrow after a special meeting of the Dail, the Executive immediately will issue orders imposing the new increased duties.

RYE, N.Y., July 21. -- Mrs. Thomas Hucknall of the Woodway Country Club turned in the low gross score of 88 in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association today over the course of the Apawamis Country Club, eighty competing.

BERLIN, July 21. -- Chancellor Franz von Papen, in his capacity as Federal Commissioner for Prussia, will discuss the Reich's dictatorial assumption of power over the State and the ousting of its officiating Cabinet with the heads of the federated States in Stuttgart Saturday.
PARIS, July 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of Prance shows the following changes in francs:

Pledges having been received from the Pearl Assurance Company, Ltd., an English corporation, that it will conform in its announced policy of writing fire insurance throughout the United States to the standards of conduct set up by rating organizations, State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick gave the move his approval yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 21 (AP). -- The spirit with which the municipal golfer takes his game was shown by six extra-hole rounds today in the eleventh national public links golf tournament.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Selling of wheat, which the trade attributed to Federal Farm Board interests, and hedging pressure more than offset the effect of lack of rain in the Spring wheat area and prices on the Chicago Board of Trade closed today unchanged to 1/8 cent lower.

PARIS, July 21. -- Preliminary test flights were made, today on the new Farman stratosphere monoplane with Lucien Coupet piloting. High altitude flights, however, could not be attempted for several months, it was announced.

LONDON, July 21. -- The opening proceedings at Ottawa, in the opinion of a majority of London's newspapers, justify confident hope that before the delegates separate they will be able to achieve agreements of the greatest value to the empire and to the whole world.

OTTAWA, July 21. -- United States trade with the British Empire, taken as a whole, will not be greatly affectad by the agreements foreshadowed at the opening of the Imperial Economic Conference here today.

OTTAWA, July 21. -- Nearly 100 delegates to the Imperial Conference from the various parts of the British Empire have availed themselves of the privilege of free liquor permits. The Provincial Government of Ontario has decreed that those officially connected with the various delegations need not pay the usual $2 for a permit.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Gregory Sutton left the Plaza yesterday for Bar Harbor.

Playgrounds on School Roofs. Rooftop playgrounds are something of a novelty in the public school system of New York. One sponsored by the Community Councils was opened on Wednesday on the roof of Public School 31, Monroe and Gouverneur Streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Representative John D. Clarke writes to THE TIMES that the Farm Board has made a bad mess of things, could well be abolished and, "if we could evolve * * * a fair price for milk for our milk producers, another great step * * * would be taken.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Representatives of the neutral Pan-American governments who have been assisting in efforts of Bolivia and Paraguay to draft a non-aggression treaty covering the disputed Chaco region appealed to those two countries today for peace in that region.

The Railroad Credit Corporation authorized additional advances of $500,000 to railroads at its monthly meeting here yesterday. This organization collects revenues from the freight surcharges which took effect on Jan. 4 and lends them to railroads to meet interest charges.

MEXICO CITY, July 21. -- Striking workmen of the Southern Pacific Railroad of Mexico were ordered back to their jobs today after the National Board of Arbitration and Conciliation had decided that the walkout was legal.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- The address of L. E. Emerson of the Newfoundland delegation at the Imperial Economic Conference here today follows in part:

Wall Street, in anticipation of the heavy amount of new financing that is expected to be done by the United States Treasury on Aug. 1 in connection with the projected relief operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, engaged yesterday in figuring out, roughly at least, the probable amount of the borrowing and the terms.

Nine scientists, authors and research workers give their opinions on the motives for international conflict in "The Causes of War," a volume submitted for presentation to the World Conference for International Peace Through Religion and just published by the Macmillan Company.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the wake of the Congressional achievements in government economy there exists a distressful situation in the ranks of a certain group of Federal employes.

GENEVA, July 21. -- Premier Mussolini, as Italy's new Foreign Minister, was behind the most significant of several significant moves by the various powers in a sharp debate in the general commission today over the resolution registering the agreements reached in the first phase of the disarmament conference.

A series of twelve free band concerts, known as the Toscanini Fund Band Concerts, will be given during August in four New York parks, it was announced yesterday by Harry Harkness Flagler, chairman of the special committee of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, which is administering the fund raised at the benefit concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last April.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (AP). -- Amateur boxing stars of the nation, bent on securing places on the American Olympic team, resumed activities tonight in Quarter - final matches.

A series of agreements has been concluded between the Chinese Government and subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation which will give the American group an important additional share of the telephone and telegraph communications business in China.

Many will see a sequence to Signor GRANDI'S displacement as Italian Foreign Minister in the new statement of Italy's attitude toward disarmament made public at Geneva yesterday. The day before it had been understood and, indeed, explicitly reported that the Italian Government was in hearty agreement with Great Britain, France and the United States in approving the resolution laid before the Disarmament Conference.

BUENOS AIRES, July 21. -- In anticipation of adverse effects on Argentine trade from any dominion preference agreement at the imperial conference in Ottawa, Argentina has taken the initiative in seeking reciprocity tariff agreements with the United States and other countries with whom she maintains important commercial relations.

Alfred S. Jarvis of Tenafly, N.J., captured the Long Island Tennis League boys' singles title by defeating Lyman W. Crossman, Barnard School sophomore, in the final at the West Side Tennis Club. Forest Hills, yesterday. The doubles championship was also decided, the crown going to Gerard B. Podesta and Crossman, the team that recently carried off the Eastern boys' doubles laurels.

Handcuffed to a guard, Sidney Balizer, 28 years old, a self-made lawyer through a six months' law correspondence course, appeared before Judge Albert Frankenthaler in his private chambers at the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday morning and for one hour unsuccessfully pleaded his case that the court order the Municipal Parole Commission to fix a definite term on his sentence.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- The first of a series of bridge parties was held at the Maidstone Club this evening under the sponsorship of the women's committee. More than sixty members were present for dinner and bridge.

Price changes did not exceed six points in any one position on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, fluctuations in some deliveries being limited to 3 or 4 points, the smallest of the season. Although improved prices of securities had a steadying influence, favorable weather over most of the belt caused enough liquidation to leave the list 3 to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

Fire protection within the city's schools is solely under the jurisdiction of the Board of Education, and the Fire Department has no authority to order the demolition of old school buildings, whether they are judged to be fire hazards or not. John J. Dorman, Fire Commissioner, has informed George D. Friou, chairman of the emergency committee on school overcrowding.

The Yankees made a good many frantic gestures at the Stadium yesterday, even going so far as to call in the renowned and still maimed Babe Ruth to do a little pinch-hitting, but it all availed nothing.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The Bonus Expeditionary Force faced enforced disbandment late today when General Pelham D. Glassford, the Superintendent of Police, made public a letter from the District of Columbia Board of Commissioners ordering him to evacuate the marchers completely by noon of Aug. 4.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 21. -- Fourteen tennis players of prominence, three of them ranked in the first ten, signed a telegram which was forwarded today to the Sea-bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club petitioning the club to pay the expenses of those competing at Sea-bright "for the duration of the tournament."

Criticism of the methods of financing the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation are contained in an opinion made public yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The opinion supports the order issued last week, which made possible the refinancing of the company, but which provided that no dividends should be paid on the common stock until the discount paid by the company on an $8,500,000 bond issue shall have been amortized.
Bluefish, tuna, weakfish and broadbill swordfish form four of the species to which the salt-water enthusiasts are devoting most of their attention at present.
SOMETHING should be said for Primo Carnera. The ponderous Primo did his best to put a little action in the current boxing campaign. He deserves that much credit. He knocked a fellow down.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When an individual becomes so ill mentally that he cannot be allowed his freedom, society puts him away and tries to heal him, after seeking out the possible cause of the disorder and removing it. Well, the world is ill, mentally, but there is no other world wherein it may find asylum, or no other agency to which it may look for relief or healing.

OTTAWA, July 21. -- The sun that never sets on the British Empire was especially kind on the occasion of the opening here today of the Imperial Economic Conference by the Earl of Bessbarough, Governor Seneral of Canada.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- The address made today by Stanley Baldwin, leader of the London delegation, before the Imperial Economic Conference follows:

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Another step in the protracted contest between cooperatives and the Chicago Board of Trade was near today with, indications that the board would be found guilty of violating the Grain Futures act by refusing Clearing House privileges to the Farmers' National Grain Corporation.

Supreme Court Justice Black directed a verdict for $25,000 yesterday in favor of Miss Louise Squire, actress, against the F. W. Woolworth Company because her scalp was scarred permanently when a waterwave comb purchased in a Woolworth, store exploded when she was drying her hair with electricity.

J. H. Louchheim's Uncanny, leader from start to finish of the Tarrytown Stakes, feature at Empire City yesterday, showed such speed of foot over the fast track that he hung up a new record of 1:44 4-5 for the event, which now is run at a mile and seventy yards.
ALBANY, July 21. -- Complete accord between Republicans and Democrats on State relief plans is being maintained, Governor Roosevelt stated today after a long conference with legislative leaders.

ROME, July 21. -- Premier Mussolini today again took possession of the famous Hall of Victory, the Falazzo Chigi, from which for many years he directed the affairs of the Italian nation until he transferred the offices to the Palazzo Venezia.

Negotiations have been completed for the connection of Washington D.C., with the extensive network of electric power lines covering the wide territory from Niagara Falls to Cape Cod and from the St. Lawrence and upper Connecticut Rivers to Baltimore and surrounding territory.

It is cheering to note that New York State may decide not to apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan to be expended on unemployment relief. Unlike some of her more hard-pressed or law-bound or less resourceful neighbors, she is apparently able to care for her own, even if some straitened municipalities have to stretch out their arms toward Washington.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 21. -- The newly formed Williamstown Riding Club will present a horse show next Wednesday for the benefit of the Town Welfare Department. There will be eleven classes and entries will close on Saturday. Officers of the association are: President, William Scott Cluett; vice president, Miss Frances H. Dwight; secretary and treasurer, Willard Evans Hout.

An application for the listing of 58,700,000 first-mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due in 1956, of the New York Steam Corporation, which have been traded in on the New York Curb Exchange since they were issued, several months ago, has been made to the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., July 21. -- Sidney Noyes, young Yale star who played so well in the Metropolitan open last week, was still in fine form today, as he demonstrated by winning the qualifying medal in the annual Westchester Country Club invitation tournament for the third year in succession.

Democratic difficulties in Massachusetts, regarded as the State in which sentiment, for former Governor Alfred E. Smith is strongest, are being ironed out successfully, according to information received here yesterday. Governor Joseph B. Ely, who placed Mr. Smith in nomination at Chicago, is expected to run for reelection as part of the, program to bring harmony between the factions.

LOS ANGELES, July 21. -- The German Olympic team, third largest of all the foreign delegations, rolled past the gates of the Olympic Village today as several thousand persons gathered outside the portals to welcome it. In four huge buses the athletes swept into this unique athletic colony, preceded several hours by the American track and field squad, the Czechoslovak contingent and a group of Canadian swimmers.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21. -- Veterans Day was observed by the members of the 107th Regiment, New York National Guard, in their Summer encampment at Camp Smith here today. More than 800 former soldiers of the regiment, now members of the Seventh Regiment Veterans Association, including several officers of prominence, attended the drill and exercises featuring the day and ate mess with the present members of their old companies.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Consolidation of all Eastern railroads, except those of New England, into four great systems was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today in the most far-reaching decision ever handed down by the commission. The lines involved number about 300.

OTTAWA, July 21. -- R. B. Bennett, Prime Minister of Canada, today was elected president of the Imperial Economic Conference of the nine States within the British Empire whose delegates have assembled at Ottawa to devise some system of trading among themselves with greater mutual benefit than they now enjoy.

The United Hebrew Trades, said to represent 200,000 organized wage earners in the city, sent a telegram yesterday to Governor Roosevelt endorsing the proposal of Socialist leaders for an immediate special session of the Legislature to enact a program of unemployment relief.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- The text of the address made today by Premier Richard B. Bennett of Canada before the Imperial Economic Conference follows:

On the eve of Mayor Walker's radio appeal to civil employes, which is expected to contain a plea that the workers voluntarily refund part of their salaries to the city treasury. The Chief, the civil service employes' newspaper, came out yesterday with an editorial rejecting the suggestion.
OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Former Premier J. G. Coates, leader of New Zealand's delegation to the Imperial Economic Conference, spoke in part as follows:

Fred (Dixie) Walker's double in the eighth inning, the third of three hits by the Newark outfielder, scored Red Rolfe and Johnny Neun and enabled the Bears to overcome Jersey City, 6 to 4, in the opening contest of a four-game series at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- A sharp contraction in the movement of hogs throughout the West, with the eleven markets receiving 33 per cent fewer today than a week ago, stimulated demand and advanced prices 10 to 25 cents, light and medium weights showing the most strength.

The criminal division of the United States Attorney's office disposed of 1,233 cases during the fiscal year that ended June 30, George Z. Medalie, Federal Attorney, announced yesterday, explaining that when he took office in February, 1931, 1,295 cases were pending and that now the calendar was virtually up to date.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman in dissenting from the majority approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the four-party rail consolidation plan today declared that the people of the country now "have little time or money to spend on railroad consolidation plans."

OTTAWA, July 22 -- A flat demand that Great Britain admit Australian foodstuffs on a preferential system which would exclude the products of non-British countries was made at the Imperial Economic Conference here today by S.M. Bruce, former Premier of Australia and leader of the Australian delegation at the conference.
GRIFFIN, Ga., July 22 (AP) -- The recent death of a Negro convict was charged today to Captain P.H. Randall, county convict warden, in an indictment for involuntary manslaughter.

LONDON, July 22 -- The stock markets were cheerful today. British Government funds improved further on brisk buying for conversion purposes. Cables and Wireless was about the only weak feature, that stock being influenced by yesterday's meeting of the company.

With the final of the junior championship this afternoon at the Rumson Country Club, Rumson, N.J., the first of the season's national polo titles will be decided. In this match, to start on the clubhouse field at 4 o'clock, the United States Army will be meeting Bahadur in the climax of the tournament which started last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In a series of rulings on the revenue act of 1932 the Internal Revenue Bureau held today that when two or more shares of stock are transferred under one certificate the stock transfer tax will be levied on the face value of the certificate and not on the value of each separate share of stock so covered.

Unfortunately, Colonel GREENE'S next annual report as State Superintendent of Public Works is not due for another six months. It will be hard for followers of the intrepid Colonel to wait to hear what he has to say about the recent decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of Perlmutter v. Greene.

Azor Ali, 36 years old, a native of Calcutta, India, told a story to Thomas B. Dyett, Assistant District Attorney, yesterday that may quash a hold-up indictment against a fellow-countryman, Sultan Ali, 33, of 227 East Ninety-eighth Street, in the Tombs under $10,000 bail, awaiting trial.

Barnes Named by Engineers' Group. The Association of Consulting Management Engineers has appointed Nathaniel Waring Barnes as executive secretary and has opened an office in 122 East Forty-second Street, Harold V. Coes of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., president of the association, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Dr. Harmodio Arias, President-elect of Panama, was the guest of President Hoover at luncheon today at the White House.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 -- The Brazilian Olympic team continued to operate in the coffee business today. Required to sell 50,000 bags of coffee in order to pay their way to Los Angeles, the sixty-nine Brazilian athletes had only disposed of enough when they reached here this morning to permit twenty-four athletes -- oarsmen and track and field men -- to disembark from the government auxiliary, the steamship Itaquice, this evening.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs were overcome today in their first attack of the important "first-place" series, Pittsburgh increasing its lead over the Cubs to three and one-half games with a 3 -- 1 victory.

Although new bond financing this week amounted to only $27,806,000, against last week's total of $81,977,750, it compared favorably with the volume during the weeks immediately preceding. One of the features this week was the continuance of new public utility financing, with the offering of two issues aggregating $22,500,000.

The bodies of two unidentified men, gagged with adhesive tape and their hands tied behind their backs, who had been slain by gunmen, were found at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning on the old Lett farm off Fresh Meadow Road near the Auburndale Road in the rural section between Flushing and Bayside, Queens.
RYE, N.Y., July 22 -- Arthur Vreeland Jr. of Ridgewood, former New Jersey junior champion, provided one of the high lights in the Westchester Country Club's Invitation golf tournament today.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 22 -- Following a conference today between Governor Ely and James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and chief Roosevelt campaign manager, they issued a non-committal statement revealing that Governor Ely and Governor Roosevelt would meet for a conference in Albany next week.

Further gains in the prices of commodities and foodstuffs, coupled with indications of a more general stability in leading industries and in retail trade, were the principal business features of the week throughout the country, according to the mercantile agencies.
Wholesale markets yesterday followed the sharp rise in security values. The grains, cotton, provisions, sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk all showed substantial improvement in prices.

The comparative scarcity of highgrade State and municipal bonds, which had the effect this week of pushing up prices still higher, will not be relieved next week, as the calendar of new issues up for award will total only $6,931,149. This week's total was $6,966,064.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Topics of the Times "France Drinks More Tea" again raises the question which has puzzled me for years: "Why is America such a poor tea-drinking country?" The answer is, I believe, that few Americans have really tasted good tea.

Police and private detectives yesterday searched in Canada, Mexico and this country for two men who, posing as uniformed armored car guards of the United States Trucking Corporation, obtained last Saturday morning from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 165 Broadway, $56,325 which was intended for deposit with the Federal Reserve Bank.

PARIS, July 22 -- Though the oil conference continues to maintain the strictest secrecy, oil circles here understand that an agreement has been reached among the Americans, Anglo-Dutch and Rumanians to raise the price of oil 20 or 25 per cent on the world market, probably on Oct. 1.
MADRID, July 22 -- A mysterious sea tragedy came to light today when the steamship Luis I entered the port of Almeria towing the sailing ship San Antonio, which had been employed in fishing.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 22 -- After having its efforts rebuffed for the past four years, the Harvard Club's baseball team slammed its way to a 16-to-7 triumph over the Yale Club at the Rockaway Hunting Club diamond today. The contest was the sixteenth between the two clubs in a series begun in 1916.

BERLIN, July 22 (AP) -- The Reichstag Committee on Safeguarding the People's Righis, which is the only standing committee still functioning, held a meeting today, but the National Socialists, the Nationalists and other parties supporting the Prussian dictatorship remained aloof.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- The subscription dance to be given at the Clambake Club tomorrow evening under the direction of the dance committee will be preceded by several dinner parties.

Benny Leonard, former lightweight champion of the world, registered another victory in his come-back campaign by defeating Eddie Shapiro, rugged Bronx battler, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Coney Island Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The attitude of about 500,000 shareholders in the Eastern railroads toward the four-system consolidation plan approved yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission was looked upon here today as the determining factor in the consummation of that vast plan.

Mayor Walker told the city's 147,000 employes in a radio address last night that their next year's pay must be cut 8 1-3 per cent or the city would face "embarrassment, if not a defunct condition." The pay cut, which he asked them to accept voluntarily, would be in the form a deduction of a month's pay from their 1933 salaries, and would amount to $26,000,000.

The commission, headed by Grover Whalen, which undertook to make the celebration of George Washington's Bicentennial by the city a self-sustaining operation admitted yesterday through its vice chairman and executive, Leopold Phillip, that the public response during the last twelve weeks has been so disappointing that the commission still owes Sears, Roebuck Co. most of the original cost of $80,000 for the model of Federal Hall in Bryant Park.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- With a ladies' day gathering of 5,000 watching with entire approval, the Phillies welcomed the Dodgers today by trouncing them, 9 to 5, in the first game of the series.

The $2,000,000,000 Federal relief bill will make available within a short time large sums of money for model apartment developments here, it was revealed yesterday. After a study of the provisions of the measure, realty interests and housing experts characterized it as "the biggest step forward in years" in the movement to eliminate New York's slum districts.
WALDENBURG, Germany, July 22 (AP) -- Chancellor von Papen telegraphed the police here today to take special precautions to protect Adolf Hitler because there wag a plot against his life.

The railroads gave every indication yesterday of considering the problem of consolidation in the East with the promptness shown by the Interstate Commerce Commission in announcing its four-system plan on Thursday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 22 (AP) -- Libby Holman Reynolds, widow of Smith Reynolds, whose fatal shooting two weeks ago is still legally an unsolved mystery, has asked his uncle, W.N. Reynolds, to be executor of his estate.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Germany bluntly told the disarmament conference today that she would no longer undertake to continue to participate in it unless before its second session opened in January she got her demand for "equality with regard to national security and the application of all the provisions of the treaty."
Several important regulations have been announced along with, the establishing of the sixty-day open, season for ducks, geese, brandt and coot this year.

Taking the General Postoffice here as an index, it appeared yesterday that Federal postal officials had underestimated the shrinkage in first class mail volume as a result of the recent increase in rates. The expected loss was 8 per cent, but Postmaster John J. Kiely reported yesterday that there was a decline of almost 30 per cent in the volume of first-class mail in Manhattan and the Bronx.

PARIS, July 22 -- The stock market was generally stronger today. The government's firm hand in Germany and its apparent ability to control the situation quieted fears in that respect on the Bourse. Wall Street's continuing improvement also affected the market here favorably.

Although the oil conference in Paris with the Rumanians adjourned yesterday with companies representing about 10 per cent of the crude oil production of Rumania not agreeing entirely to the proposals looking toward a restriction of production, cable reports from Paris emphasized that the international oil companies and a majority of the independent producers of Rumania were in complete accord.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Plans for the reception here of Captain Wolfgang yon Gronau and his crew of three, who are winging their way from Germany, were under consideration today by prominent Germans.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 -- In a second-round match of the Hempstead cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, the Vipers, led by Philip Iglehart, turned back the United States Army No. 1 team in a closely fought match on Waterbury Field.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In a new bill filed in the United States Court of Claims the Aluminum Corporation of America has petitioned for a judgment against the government in the amount of $682,588.73, with interest since 1924, for aluminum furnished to the navy and other departments.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 22 -- With the defending doubles champiens, Mrs. Marjorie Gladman Van Ryn of Philadelphia and Miss Josephine Cruickshank of Santa Ana, Cal., leading in games by 4 to 3 in the first set against the Misses Sarah and Mianne Palfrey of Brookline, Mass., in the final round of the Essex County Club's invitation tournament, a heavy shower today forced postponement of the match until tomorrow.

During the last few days commuters on the North River ferryboats have been wondering what the small vessels anchored at points where traffic is heaviest in the main channel and where anchoring is generally prohibited are doing. These vessels are carrying on the work of the Coast and Geodetic Survey and are manned by United States Army Engineers making a comprehensive survey of the tides and currents of the harbor.

At Albany and at Washington Mr. JAMES W. WADSWORTH Jr. was an engaging and a powerful figure. A brilliant youth was succeeded by a rich maturity. In his two terms in the Senate he became one of the best-informed and most influential personages there.

Reversing its own decision of last December, the Circuit Court of Appeals now holds that complaints under the "padlock" provisions of the Volstead act must be served on the owners or proprietors of alleged speakeasies, not merely on their employes.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Jack A. Werner, 28-year-old Deputy Sheriff of Cook County, was killed by machinegun fire late tonight at Eighty-first Street and Calumet Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Bacharach bill signed yesterday by President Hoover, reducing the rate of interest on loans made to veterans on bonus certificates, and enabling them to borrow on certificates immediately after receiving them, will cost the government $359,000,000 to $384,000,000, according to the Veterans Bureau.

In their report for the first six months of this year E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. show a balance for common stock of $10,962,167, or $1.01 a share on 10,878,989 shares, the average number outstanding in the period. This income includes the company's equity in undivided profits or losses of controlled companies not consolidated, and it compares with $24,809,160, or $2.24 a share on 11,052,174 shares, in the corresponding period of 1931.

With the seven defendant banks raising no objection, the injunction sought by the Irving Trust Company as a preliminary to legal action to recover $50,000,000 of German bonds which figure in the International Match Company bankruptcy was granted yesterday by Federal Judge Mack.

Continued ease in time money, with all dates quoted at 1 1/4 @ 1 1/2 per cent, carried over from Thursday, when this rate was made for the first time in years, represented the interesting development of the day. Trades in ninety-day funds at 1 1/4 were reported. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 per cent, with the usual concession obtaining in street market.

UTICA, N.Y., July 22 -- Playing a brilliant up-hill game over a rain-soaked course, Miss Frances Snyder of the Apawamis Club, Rye, provided a startling upset today when she defeated Miss Helen Hicks, national champion and defending title-holder, in the New York State women's golf championship, 1 up, in a 19-hole semi-final match.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Pratt will sail today on the Berengaria to remain abroad for the rest of the Summer. They will be in Glen Cove for the Autumn.

Books are seldom illustrated nowadays. Children's books have found apt illustrators, but novels go forth in quiet covers and without even a drawing of the heroine for frontispiece. Their gaudy jackets are the only remaining evidence that art and literature once went hand in hand.

COWES, Isle of Wight, July 22 (AP) -- The United States six-meter fleet today won the fourth race of the series for the British-America Cup to sweep the regatta and successfully defend the international Yachting trophy.
LIST, Island of Silt, North Frisian Islands, July 22 -- Captain Wolfgang von Gronau hopped off here at 11 A.M. today for his third transatlantic flight to the United States.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 -- Driving through rain into a partial clearing, Horace Havemeyer's racing sloop Mouette took the fifth twelve-meter class contest today of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week. It was her third triumph of race week.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Orders to evacuate more than 2,000 members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force quartered in partially demolished buildings on lower Pennsylvania Avenue were rescinded today by the District of Columbia Board of Commissioners after General Pelham D. Glassford, Superintendent of Police, had warned that "bloodshed and riot" would follow execution of the command.

No one with a spark of historical imagination can fail to be impressed by certain aspects of the Imperial Conference at Ottawa. It is a living demonstration of the peculiar and continuing power of the British Empire. Under the new title of the British Commonwealth of Nations, it preserves much of its old prestige and glamour in holding together peoples and governments representing so vast a portion of the earth's surface.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The contention of Chicago interests that the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway treaty with Canada will destroy the usefulness of the Illinois waterway was declared to be "without basis of fact" by Major Gen. Lytle Brown, chief of army engineers, in a memorandum prepared for Secretary Hurley and made public today.

All of the markets responded yesterday, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, to the overnight announcement that the Interstate Commerce Commission had approved the four-party railway consolidation plan for the Eastern section of the country.

Crops in the prairie provinces have continued to make satisfactory progress and wheat cutting is expected to be general in Manitoba in the first week in August, says the weekly crop report of the Bank of Montreal. The report says in part:

OTTAWA, July 22 -- N.C. Havenga, Finance Minister of South Africa and the leader of his country's delegation at the Ottawa conference, today supplemented his plenary session speech of yesterday by a further detailed statement of what his governmen desires from the rest of the British Empire, particularly Great Britain.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., July 22 (AP) -- Friends of Maurice Chevalier in Hollywood were surprised to learn of the suit for divorce which he has filed in Paris against Yvonna Vallee, his former dancing partner. They said the couple always appeared happy and that when Chevalier left here three weeks ago for Paris there was no intimation of difficulty in his domestic life.

DUBLIN, July 22 -- While Deputy McGilllgan was attempting during a special tariff meeting of the Bail Eireann today to discuss the proceedings at Ottawa, where the Free State delegation yesterday joined in sending a message of loyalty to King George, he was repeatedly interrupted from the government front bench.

LA FAZ, Bolivia, July 22 -- The government sent a circular cablegram last night to all legations abroad giving a resume of events since June 19 when a Bolivian detachment arrived at Lagun Chuquisaca in the centre of the Chaco region, where it reported abandoned huts were found, indicating that the Paraguayans were advancing.

Realty trading in New Jersey yesterday centred in Plainfield and North Plainfield, where deals were announced involving residential properties with large plots. Plans for two dwellings there were announced.

UTICA, N.Y., July 22 -- Public bequests of $975,000 were made by Mrs. Ella M. Burke of Cleveland, widow of Stevenson Burke, according to appraisal of her estate made by State Transfer Tax Appraiser Fred J. Graff in Surrogate's Court here. Mrs. Burke, 89, formerly was a resident of Clinton.

OTTAWA, July 22 -- Like Washington, Ottawa has its lobbyists. Although not approaching in number or diversity the group that President Hoover recently characterized as "the locust swarm," legislative and other representatives of Canadian interests liable to be affected by the outcome of the imperial conference are decidedly in evidence around this capital.

OTTAWA, July 22 -- South Africa and Australia startled the Imperial Economic Conference here today with suggestions for greater preferences from Great Britain which would give them a large part of the meat trade now held by Argentina.

A nose finish over a slow track featured the Spur Purse, which had the place of honor on the program at Empire City yesterday, James Butler's Awake, making his first start, in almost two years, being nipped at the finish by P.M. Walker's Brown Pet, the 8 to 5 favorite.

Preliminary to a conference on a new wage and working agreement that will be held by the scale committee of the Publishers' Association of New York City and the scale conference committee of Typographical Union 6 at 11 o'clock this morning at the publishers' headquarters, 280 Broadway, the union scale committee conferred yesterday afternoon at its headquarters, 24 West Six-teenth Street, with its international president, Charles P. Howard.
Following is the transcript of Mayor Walker's address to city employes, made last night at City Hall, asking them to accept a deduction of one month's salary from their 1933 pay:

Citing the policy of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as a "practical application" of the formula of stimulating enterprise "from the top down," the committee on unemployment of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, in a report submitted to the council's officers yesterday, declared it could see little hope for "the people at the bottom of the economic heap" under such a policy.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The problem of finding two new directors for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has been complicated by the fact that one of the men frequently mentioned for a post, Wilson Mills of Detroit, is ineligible.
HOLLYWOOD, July 22 -- Florenz Ziegfeld, musical comedy producer, died tonight at a hospital here.

An itemized and all-inclusive summary of the rights and privileges conferred on World War veterans by Federal and State legislation is contained in the August issue of the American Legion Monthly, published today. It shows that a great variety of benefits, ranging from issuance of adjusted compensation certificates to 3,800,000 ex-service men and women to veterans' preference in civil service positions and certain minor tax exemptions have been conferred.

New York City will borrow $5,000,000 next Wednesday under the $151,000,000 revolving fund credit from a city-wide group of banks and banking houses. The amount is required for current running expenses and will be repaid from tax collection for the second half of 1932, which will become delinquent on Nov. 30.

If Germany had won the war, conditions there would have been far worse than they are now, in the opinion of Joseph Hergesheimer, who recounts in a book called "Berlin," just published by Alfred A. Knopf, his experiences on a trip to Central Europe.

Perhaps it was just embarrassment that caused Patrolman George Gerhard to refuse to smile yesterday afternoon when he voted with Sergeant Peter King and Patrolman John Higgins to award fourth prize in the baby parade at Public School 84 to Rita, the 10-months-old daughter of the "Amsterdam Avenue delicatessen lady."

An indebtedness of $25,000, incurred by the League of New York Theatres in its early efforts to curb ticket speculation, has been reduced over a period of a year and a half to $5,000, it was learned yesterday. The recognized ticket brokers who benefited through the league's regulations at the time of its organization have voluntarily met payments on the note, although they were not legally obligated to do so.

A voluntary petition in bankruptcy was filed in the "Federal court here yesterday by the Electric Management and Engineering Corporation, service company of the National Electric Power group The petition was signed by A.E. Burns, vice president, and submitted by Francis L. Archer, attorney, of 44 Wall Street.

Revival of the world nitrate cartel, which lapsed a year ago after having functioned two years in all markets outside of this country, seemed assured yesterday, when tentative agreements for division of the international markets were reached in London by representatives of ten European countries and Chile, producers of natural and synthetic nitrogen products.

The first feeling of any conversant with the matter, regarding the Commerce Commission's decision on the "trunk-line railway mergers," is relief that the ten-year deadlock has been broken. This does not exclude a sense of irritation that decision has been so long deferred.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Most of your readers will agree with the position you take toward the socalled "B.E.F." as expressed in the editorial of July 18 "A Left-Over Duty." Your editorial in issue of July 15 "An 'Item' of $100,000,000" is also commendable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If one party can elect its candidate for the Presidency, together with a majority in each House of Congress, it will be beneficial to business generally. Many of the present difficulties have been caused by a lack of coordination between the executive and legislative branches of the government.

Outstanding among numerous suburban real estate deals announced yesterday was one involving the purchase of acreage in Nassau County by the Long Island State Park Commission. The Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., broker in the transaction, reported that contracts had just been signed for the sale to the park authorities of more than twenty-two acres of vacant land on the south side of Jericho Turnpike at the intersection of Glen Cove Road in Westbury.

FORT ERIE, Ont., July 22 (AP) -- After a slow track had caused postponement of two races on the opening card of the Grand Circuit meeting today, Bertha Patch, black mare sired by Burton Patch, and driven by Vic Rowntree, won the Clifton Stake, closed to Canadian-bred 2:15 pacers.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration, announced yesterday that, as a result of a series of conferences with President Hoover and Secretary of Labor Doak, Ellis Island will be transformed next week into a virtual prison under armed guard to take care of the large criminal element passing through the Island, and to separate it from the regular immigrants.

Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, in a statement issued yesterday in answer to the charges of George D. Friou, Brooklyn attorney, that many public school buildings were "antiquated firetraps," quoted from a report of Walter C Martin, superintendent of school buildings, which asserted that there were no conditions in the structures which were "hazardous or in any way dangerous to life and limb."

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Equipoise, 1932 handicap champion of the American turf, faces the hardest, race of his career tomorrow in the mile and a quarter Arlington Handicap for a purse that may total $28,800.

GENEVA, July 22 -- The Fascist-Socialist fight which is going on in Germany and elsewhere in Europe flared hot between Italian and French deputies here today in a meeting of the Interparliamentary Union, which is discussing peace and other world problems.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 22 -- The Berkshire golf team championship will be determined tomorrow in an Interclub match at Stockbridge. Ten clubs will be represented by six men each. Miss Louise Edey of New York and Miss Bertha Pagenstecher, who is a guest of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Rice, registered at the Stock-bridge Club. Also there were Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Clark, W. Warner and Arthur W. Clark of Philadelphia.

A patrolman and a motorist were seriously injured, and five other policemen and their six prisoners slightly hurt when a patrol wagon from the Bronx bound for Night Court was in collision with an automobile at Park Avenue and Ninetieth Street last night.

Not since CHARLES CURTIS was nominated as Mr. HOOVER'S running-mate in 1928 has politics presented so edifying a spectacle as FRANK HAGUE'S Democratic rally at Spring Lake Thursday in honor of Governor ROOSEVELT. Mr. CURTIS expressed his satisfaction in sharing party honors with one who, the night before, he had said was "not even a Republican."

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 22 -- After swallowing two tablets containing the wrong amount of strychnine Major George R. Koehler, a regular army instructor attached to the National Guard quarters at Camp Moore, arrived unworried in his quarters at 9:15 o'clock tonight unaware of the fact that New Jersey and New York State police had made a widespread search to warn him against taking the tablets.
BERLIN, July 22 -- Chancellor von Papen left for Stuttgart tonight to attend a significant conference of the Premiers of the German Federated States especially summoned there to meet him tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was theoretically in a position today to give financial aid to any distressed community in the United States, but legal technicalities threatened to delay activities for several days at least.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday net earnings for the quarter ended on June 30, including equities in the undivided profits or losses of subsidiary and affiliated companies, not consolidated, of $5,326,377, equivalent after preferred dividends to 7 cents a share on the outstanding common stock.

The Public Service Commission, by a vote of 4 to 1, ordered the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation yesterday to charge to surplus rather than to operating expenses all sums paid for advertising and other expenses of the Hudson Valley Electrical League.

Although two of the groups involved in the controversy over a new working agreement for the cloak and suit industry have arrived at an almost complete settlement of their differences, the two other factors, the jobbers and contractors, remained outside the fold yesterday, giving only slight hope that the threatened strike of 27,000 garment workers would be averted.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., was speeding back eastward by train last night to appear this morning at the Bar Assocation Building and give his testimony in the suit of the Cleveland Motion Picture Exhibitors Association against his organization and its entire membership, including the major motion picture companies, and against the Cleveland Film Board of Trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 22 -- Unable to withstand the rapidly mounting tide of sentiment for compulaory unemployment insurance, evidenced by a flood of communications from local unions, city central labor bodies and State Federations of Labor, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor abandoned today its traditional opposition to the proposal, which has been denounced by labor leaders since the day of Samuel Gompers as "the dole."

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Democratic leaders here expect James A. Farley to visit the capital early next week for campaign conferences. He is expected to utilize the experience of some of the veteran Congressional chieftains, among them Senators Harrison of Mississippi, Connally of Texas and Hull of Tennessee.

LONDON, July 22 -- Michael Beary, the noted Irish jockey who recently won the Irish Derby on Dastur and is one of the best known figures on the British turf, has, according to The Daily Express, played an important role in attempts to effect an Anglo-Irish settlement.

RAIFORD, Fla, July 22 (AP) -- Complete exoneration of Florida prison officials and employes in the recent deaths of two convicts was voted here tonight by the Board of State Institutions. The prisoners were Harold Bradley and Frank Powell.
LONDON, July 22. -- From all available indications, Britain's L2,000,000,000 war-loan conversion operation is assured of success.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 22 -- Gregory S. Mangin defeated David N. Jones, winner of the Longwood Bowl, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, to reach the semi-final round of the invitation singles of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today, the decisive victory coming as a marked surprise.

In His Wife's Name. The name of the Democratic Presidential nominee is generally conceded to have been a political asset. Admirers of THEODORE ROOSEVELT are now shown to include many who think that the Governor is a son of the Colonel, and a few who think the nominee is T.R. himself.

A sharp rally in railroad bonds, resulting in gains of 1 to 10 points for a long list of issues, as the aftermath of the announcement by the Interstate Commerce Commission of its approval of the consolidation of Eastern lines into four systems, featured dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Hoover today signed the home loan bank bill, the last of his reconstruction measures aimed to stimulate industry and expand credit facilities.

BASE CAMP, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir, July 16 (By Runner to Astor, July 22) -- Fritz Wiessner and Felix Simon, who set out to establish Camp 5 and make a final exploration of the approaches to Nanga Parbat's sky-scraping summit, have returned to report favorably on the route around Rakiot Peak and up the ridge between that peak and the North Peak.
AKRON, Ohio, July 22 (AP) -- The coroner returned a verdict today that H.L. Boehm of New York City died of a heart attack induced by the heat.

Arthur Hawley Scribner, president of the publishing house of Charles Scribner's Sons, who died at Mount Kisco, N.Y., on July 3, left $150,000 to Princeton University and bequests of $5,000 each to the New York City Missions and the Skidmore School of Arts at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., it was revealed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

LAKE CITY, Minn., July 22 (AP) -- Two Plainview men were arrested today for questioning about the deaths of Louise Frigge, 22, who with Frances Polikowski, 22, was last seen Tuesday night when they went for an automobile ride.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, July 23 (AP) -- An agreement providing transpacific radio service between China and San Francisco, and including Honolulu and Manila, was signed today by the Ministry of Communications of the Nanking Government and the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company of California.

Further evidence of Wall Street's hope that the late Summer will witness a trade and industrial revival of some scope was seen yesterday in the extension of Friday's advance on the Stock Exchange. Business picked up sharply; there was a turnover of 1,448,000 shares, compared with nearly 925,000 shares on the day before.

BUDAPEST, July 22 -- The police announced today the arrest of three important Moscow emmissaries, including the chief of the Communist International for Hungary, Emmerich Sallay. Together with a number of other Communists who were trying to reorganize their party in Hungary, they were seized in a raid on the secret Communist headquarters here.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 22 -- Mayor Russell S. Randall was elected president of the Municipal Utilities Association of New York State today in the closing hours of its two-day convention here. He succeeds Floyd A. Clayton of Ilion.
Rumors of several real estate transactions pending in the midtown section of Manhattan were current yesterday, none of which, however, could be confirmed.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 22 -- The Nassau County grand jury, after two days' investigation into the death of Hyman Stark, an east side thug arrested last Friday on suspicion of beating and robbing a Nassau County detective's mother, handed up indictments tonight against a number of members of the Nassau County Police Department.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 22 -- Turned down in their request that their expenses be taken care of for the duration of the tournament, thirteen lawn tennis players of prominence today withdrew heir acceptances of invitations to play in the annual grass court fixture of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club which starts Monday at Seabright, N.J.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Given a smart ride by Bobby Jones and with the track to his liking, W.K. Coe's Llandaff romped off with the winner's share of the featured $4,280 Highland Park Claiming Stakes at Arlington Park today.

PARIS, July 22 -- Germany held its own against the American Davis Cup team in the interzone final today when Baron Gottfried von Cramm outsteadied Frank Shields, while Daniel Prenn bowed to Ellsworth Vines'e withering play.
