OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 22 -- At the crack of the starting gun fired from the lawn of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club on Centre Island, eleven seaplanes and amphibians took off in rapid succession here this morning on the first leg of the second annual seaplane cruise of the Aviation Country Club of Hicksville.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson gave a dinner tonight at the Crossways for Mrs. Ernest Iselin and Francis Henry Balfour Byrne, who are visiting them. Among their other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips B. Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, Mrs. Charles E. Miller, L. Systems Heemskersk and A. Hamilton S. Post of Baltimore.

In sympathy with an improved stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday and closed at gains of 9 to 10 points. For a time fluctuations continued limited under light business, but the better feeling in financial quarters stimulated buying from several directions.

American colleges and universities instead of "excluding large numbers from the privilege of higher education" should refuse to admit only those applicants whose failure may be predicted with relative certainty and to whom preventive or curative measures cannot be applied, Professor Floyd B. O'Rear of Teachers College, Columbia University, asserted yesterday in an address before Columbia University Summer School students at Teachers College.

HYDK PARK, July 22 -- Governor Roosevelt arrived here tonight prepared to discuss international affairs tomorrow with Owen D. Young, who will stop for several hours at the Governor's home on a motor trip to Van Hornesville.

The Federal Government, which has succeeded in padlocking only one of three places of unquestioned social prominence it has sought to close during the last several years, will go once more through the formality of filing a complaint against what prohibition agents describe as a "high-hat" resort, Arthur H. Schwartz, Assistant United States Attorney, in charge of the prohibition division, revealed yesterday.

WINDSOR, Ont., July 22 (Canadian Press) -- After dismissing a Border Cities sixteen for 94 runs at Kennedy Stadium today, the touring Australian cricketers gave a great batting display by hitting up 425 runs for the loss of six wickets in two hours and a half.

A GREAT light is shining through the gloom. In one of Anthony Trollope's novels of English life in the Victorian Era a Member of Parliament, exercising the right and privilege of cultured Englishmen in those days, rises in the House of Commons and graces his speech on a great problem with a Latin quotation, to wit:

Bishop William T. Manning, who is spending the Summer at Southwest Harbor, Me., will offer a prayer of dedication today at the opening of a new mountain road on Mount Desert Island. The ceremonies will be attended by Charles Francis Adams, Secretary of the Navy; Admiral William B. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations; Joseph Dixon, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, and Governor William Tudor Gardiner of Maine.

MELBOURNE, July 21. -- The Commonwealth and State governments are cooperating in the plan to get the unemployed off the dole and back to work. This has been made possible by the adherence of the governments to the promise of economy contained in the Premier's plan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a Denver dispatch to THE TIMES statements were made about the Denver public school system that are not in accordance with the facts. For instance, this statement:

While a gypsy band and rhythmic gypsy chanting vied with the crash of a roller coaster and the swish of captive airplanes, Ronaldo, darkeyed son of Pete Sockloff, Canadian gypsy king, and Mary, daughter of Steve Demetri, Russian gypsy leader, were married last night on the canvas of the outdoor prize ring at Golden City Park, Canarsie.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Visiting golf and tennis players who are competing in tournaments this week-end were the guests of honor at dinners this evening at the Maidstone Club and the Devon Yacht Club. There also were more than 200 residents and their house guests at the Maidstone dinner dance.

With producers and refiners cutting the "garment to the cloth," rational operation in the oil industry should return a fair profit under present conditions, according to a discussion of the economic conditions in the oil industry by Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in that organization's quarterly publication.

MANILA, June 20. -- A combination of political and military events has brought into the news frequently in the past year the name of Corregridor Island, the "Gibraltar of the Pacific." The proposal that the fortification here should be turned over to an independent Philippines, which was made by Senator Hawes, emphasized the military position of this strategic post.

Seldom can a Presidential campaign have started off with such a rush as the present one appeared to intend. It was like the rapid speeding up of an electrically driven car compared with steam propulsion. For this early drive toward the election, Governor ROOSEVELT'S flight to Chicago with his speech of acceptance in his hand was largely responsible.

Dr. Burdette G. Lewis, well-known economist and Commissioner of Correction during the administration of the late John Purroy Mitchel, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Equitable Assessment Association, which was recently organized to study realty values and the tax system of New York City, with a view toward establishing a more scientific and equitable basis for assessments.

The torture and murder of the two men whose bodies were found Friday morning in an unfrequented lane in Bayside, Queens, may have resulted from their participation in anti-Soviet activities in Ukrainian political circles here, according to a theory held yesterday by Queens detectives after the identification of one and a clue to the identity of the other.

PARIS. THE first authentic Paris Fall hat fashions are restoring the left profile -- including a generous expanse of hair -- to its former style supremacy. Women did not take enthusiastically to the straight, pulled-down hats pushed by the modistes last Spring; they found that the asymmetrical angle was apt to be more becoming as well as more individual.

LAKE PLACID. -- Aiding those less fortunate than themselves -- in previous seasons perhaps a more or less perfunctory pleasure for members of the Adirondacks resorts colonies -- has this season won unmistakable interest, and at all principal centres throughout the region committees are now at work arranging for benefits to take place during August.

TOKYO, July 23. -- Japan is withdrawing the expedition she sent early this week to Chaoyang, Jehol, to try to rescue Gonshiro Ishimoto, head of an official Japanese mission, who was captured by Jehol soldiers.

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Color reproductions of modern paintings, including painting fifty years ago; Cezanne and the Post-impressionists; twentieth-century painting (1) Matisse, Derain, Bonnard and others; twentieth-century painting (2) Picasso and cubism, futurism, abstract design and super-realism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To one who has sincerely enjoyed and made a study of the articles on prohibition reform as they have appeared in THE TIMES, it is surprising how much loose thinking is indulged in by 99 out of 100 citizens as to how and when the Eighteenth Amendment may be repealed.

If Bolivia and Paraguay cannot agree about their boundaries in the Gran Chaco, it is not surprising that others know little of the topography of the region and whether it invites development. To parts of it Argentina and Brazil have title. The Gran Chaco is sometimes spoken of as west of the Paraguay River and east of the Andes.

While the principle of the six-hour working shift in industrial plants is still in the experimental stage, a greater possibility now exists for its general adoption in industry than at any time in the past decade, according to comment in management circles yesterday following the request of the American Federation of Labor during the week that President Hoover call a general conference on the subject.
Theatregoers must have noted with surprise that on the Danish Olympic team there was no long-distance soliloquizer.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Bullish sentiment is increasing slowly in the wheat trade, but the market lacks breadth, while profit-taking and hedging sales offset buying by commission houses and the local element. The finish on the Board of Trade today was unchanged to 1/8 cent higher, the action being disappointing to the trade because of the strength in Winnipeg.
BERLIN, July 23 (AP). -- One Reichsbanner member was killed and fifteen Nazis and Communists injured at Bunzlau last night during an affray in front of the Trade Union headquarters.

The "creeping" advance of the bond market on the Stock Exchange continued in the two-hour session yesterday, with trading active for a Saturday. United States Government bonds pointed high, led by the lower coupon issues now eligible for use by national banks in temporary currency expansion as a result of the signing of the "home bank bill" by the President.

PARIS. STANDING near the door of the great Picasso show at Galeries Georges Petit, it was impossible not to overhear the voice of the advancing audience, especially as it spoke, for the most part, one's own American tongue.

SHANGHAI, July 22. -- One of the greatest tasks of reconstruction the world has ever known is about finished -- the rebuilding and repopulation of the Yangtse Valley in China, where 23,000,000 persons were made homeless and starving by the floods of last year.

SINCE there is no American ballet comparable to the traditional European organizations in which American-born and American-trained ballet dancers may appear, it is gratifying to know that when they travel overseas they are able to find themselves.

LONDON. OUT of the apparently interminable discussions which have been going on for months past, both in and out of Parliament, on the question of the Sunday opening of cinemas, there has been evolved one suggestion of real importance to the future of the British film industry.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- All the world knew today that Florenz Ziegfeld was dead, except his mother. She may never know. The white-haired old woman, so idolized during his lifetime by the Broadway producer that even his last hours found him telegraphing and telephoning to her home here from what proved to be his deathbed, has been unconscious for weeks.

LONDON. THE personality of a nation is a striking thing. A people lives, behaves and reacts like an organism, and, when highly civilized, like an individual. National reactions may differ widely, a fact that is particularly noticeable during a crisis which brings a country within an ace of death or ruin.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23. -- The annual invitation golf tournament at the Country Club came to a close this afternoon and many of the players remained for the week-end. They were among the guests at the subscription dance given at the Clambake Club this evening, which was preceded by a number of dinners.

ALTHOUGH this little book was written especially to meet the particular queries concerning evolution which would naturally be asked by the first man to be met on the street -- assuming that he were at least casually interested -- it actually serves a much wider public.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Chicago Board of Trade, principal grain marketing agency of the United States, was ordered suspended today for sixty days by a Federal commission composed of the Secretaries of Commerce and Agriculture and the Attorney General.

Strong representations have been made to the special committee engaged in the task of recodifying the constitution, by-laws and rules of the American Kennel Club regarding the present method of awarding championship points.

NEWPORT. -- Members of the Summer colony of this city are to have an opportunity to assist in no less than five benefit affairs that have been announced for the present week. These will start tomorrow night when there is a carnival opening at King Park on the southern harbor front, under the auspice of the local post of Veterans of Foreign Wars.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 23. -- The Montclair A.C. went into a tie with the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club for first place in the Eastern Athletic Club League by beating the new mooners, 7-4, today. This marks the third year that the nines have closed their drives in a deadlock. A play-off series will be held in September.

HOT SPRINGS, VA. -- With the arrival of scores of prominent visitors to witness the annual Virginia State open tennis championships which begin Monday on the Casino courts here, the advent of tennis week has been the signal for a gay program of social and sports activities.

MAYOR WALKER'S recent appointment of his personal physician, Dr. William Schroeder Jr., to a new sixyear term as chairman of the Sanitary Commission has again attracted attention to a branch of the municipal government which has important functions and is required to meet next year a condition imposed by the United States Supreme Court's mandate prohibiting the dumping of garbage and refuse at sea.

OTTAWA, July 22. -- What with the effects of the Hawley-Smoot tariff, the lower price level and the general reduction in the public's buying power, trade between Canada and the United States has shown an extraordinary recession in the last two years.

OUT of the Imperial Economic Conference now under way at Ottawa is expected to come an answer to the question in the minds of many Americans: Is the United States to continue selling about 17 per cent of all its export commodities to Canada?

LONDON. HUGH WALPOLE has been giving the readers of John o' London's Weekly a detailed account of the genesis and growth of his "Jeremy" stories. He began writing them during the last year of the World War, in the idlest possible manner, with nothing in his head save "a passionate desire to escape from the then intolerable Russia and all its works."

The ten city-operated ferry lines buffered a net operating loss of $1,984,904.24 in 1931, the largest loss of any year of ferryboat operation in the city's history, it was shown by the annual report of the Department of Plant and Structures submitted yesterday to Mayor Walker by Commissioner Albert Goldman.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States has entered a secondary League of Nations. The matter is, of course, the St. Lawrence deep-waterway project.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For several reasons which are quite obvious, churchgoers should be relieved from a condition that has existed probably as long as churches have been built as they are today. I refer to the foul air they are forced to breathe during services at all times of the year.

A MORIBUND Maine harbor town, with a sailing ship or two decaying in its yards, and its burying ground filled with gravestones to the memory of men who were lost at sea, furnishes the background for this solid and unpretentious novel by Ruth Blodgett.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 23. -- R.L. Miller, 21 years old, emerged the winner today from the greatest field that ever competed in a national public links golf tournament.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 23. -- Reading is the favorite pastime among 470 representative Weatohester County residents, with bridge a close second, moving pictures third and the legitimate theatre fourth, the Westchester County Recreation Commission announced today, making public preliminary findings of a survey carried on for the last year by the commission in collaboration with Columbia University experts.

Hope for improvement in the serious water situation in Jerusalem is seen in an announcement by the High Commissioner, Sir Arthur Wauchope, that the concession previously held by a British firm had been terminated and immediate steps were being taken to float a loan to meet the cost of a new water supply which will be undertaken by the government.

A storm of protest was aroused last week among property owners and taxpayers in general by the suggestions of various city department heads to impose tolls amounting to millions of dollars for special services to bolster up the city budget.

THE merits to be found in Professor Fairchild's survey of the romantic movement in English poetry are obvious. Professor Failchild is an able lecturer and he has succeeded in carrying over an informal, vigorous, direct classroom manner into his prose style.

IT was the wish of Kipling's "auld Scots engineer" that some one would arise to give the world the "song o' steam." Change "song" to "saga" and the job has been most excitingly accomplished by Captain S.G.S. McNeil, recently retired from the bridge of the S.S. Mauretania of the Cunard Line.

That progress in the unification at the Eastern railroads will depend largely on the attitude of the managements of the four trunk lines in this region is indicated by the fact that virtually all the important railroads included in the allocations announced by the Interstate Commerce Commission last week are already in control of the trunk lines.

LONDON. CONSIDER the detective of fiction. Or, on the other hand, it may quite easily be that you prefer not to consider the detective of fiction. In that case the blunt truth is that you may as well retire into plumes and armor without further ado.

THOSE colleges in the past which have been notably successful in luring Gothic towers and heavily endowed chairs from the check books of multi-millionaires have, by and large, been the older and more conservative institutions. In the long hoped for post-depression days will there be a radical change in tne type of beneficiary of educational giving?

IN the search for greater speed in regular air transport, greatly improved designs have been the result of a period of somewhat fallow years for the manufacturers. Something of the meaning of increased cruising speeds for the economics of air transport is reflected in another column.

New zoning standards placing a premium upon group or neighborhood planning rather than emphasizing restrictions upon individual plots is urged by Arthur C. Holden of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

A lone robber, who grained entrance on the pretext that he wanted to rent a vacant store, held up Alfred G. Crowe, treasurer of the Fox Academy of Music, a motion picture theatre at 126 East Fourteenth Street, yesterday morning, forced him to open a safe containing $1,200, the previous day's receipts, and escaped after knocking Crowe unconscious with his pistol butt.

BUCHAREST, July 22. -- The Rumanian elections, which for the second time have given the National Peasant party more than 40 per cent of the votes cast which were needed to return them to power, closely resembled those of five years ago which put this party in office for the first time.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Little business improvement from the quiescent conditions in foreign markets of the last several weeks was shown in the weekly survey of the situation abroad made public today by the Department of Commerce. The survey, based on radio and cable reports from department representatives, mentioned some increased activity in rural Canadian Provinces, with somewhat improved farm prospects.

THE voyage of the Brazilian adventurers tops everything in the seagoing tales of Olympic expeditions. Our athletes in the past had some exciting cruises on the high seas, but they never had to peddle Kansas corn or Idaho potatoes to raise money for their landing fees in a foreign port.

The thorny issue of disarmament is now asking the trains of one of the most intelligent and sympathetic conferences that have ever assembled. That it will make some important contributions to the attainment of its purpose may be confidently expected, but they can hardly be conclusive.

LOS ANGELES, July 21. -- So successful was California's experiment of last Winter in establishing State work camps for the unemployed that Governor Rolph has been urged to set aside $500,000 for the operation of similar camps next Winter.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., July 28 (AP). -- The film colony which gained many of the stars made famous by Florenz Ziegfeld paid tribute to him today. Some of the individual tributes follow:

Kaye Don's spectacular performance in lifting the world's speed record to 119.81 miles an hour on Loch Lomond provided the past week's outstanding development in motor boating and raised Great Britain's hopes for the Harmsworth Trophy races, to be held at Detroit from Sept. 1 to 5.
Surrogate James A. Foley will hold a hearing tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock to determine the status of twenty-nine persons out of the 1,622 claimants to the Wendel fortune.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 23. -- Funeral services were held here this afternoon for Leon H. Kibbe, a member of the New Britain Trade School faculty, who died at the home of his parents here Thursday night. He was in his thirty-fourth year. Mr. Kibbe was graduated from the Sheffield Scientific School of Tale University in 1923.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Uncle Sam's International Cash Book, just issued by the Department of Commerce, shows:

OTTAWA, July 23. -- A triple alliance by Canada, Australia and New Zealand to force Russian competition out of the British market is one of the outstanding developments that has emerged in the past twenty-four hours at the Imperial Economic Conference in session here.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- Earl Averill did his best to win a game for Wes Ferrell today, but the White Sox rallied in the twelfth to defeat Cleveland, 6 to 5 Ted Lyons went the route for the winners.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP). -- Jack Burns's home run with the bases filled in the fourth inning gave the St. Louis Browns a 5-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the first game of a double-header today. In the second game the Tigers turned, the tables, winning by 9 to 4.

HARBIN, June 22. -- Long before gangsterism got its start in America, it was a big business in Manchuria. But like its American relative, Manchurian racketeering registered its greatest strides during the past decade. To the Manchurian, a gangster is a "hunghudze."

Fred (Dixie) Walker's single to right in the ninth inning drove in two tallies and climaxed a three-run rally that enabled the Newark Bears to gain a 7-to-5 verdict over Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday for their second straight victory of the series.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's battling Pirates took one of the season's stormiest ball games from the Chicago Cubs today, 11 to 8, to increase their first-place lead to four and one-half games. Bickerings among rival players and between players and umpires dragged the wild struggle through 2 hours and 28 minutes.

A housing shortage which will become more marked unless home construction meets increasing demands exists now in Bergen County, Charles H. Plenty, president of the New Jersey Bankers' Association, told the Hackensack Rotary Club last week. He said the county has a home vacancy of only 3 per cent, considered less than normal in ordinary times.

SEA ISLE CITY, N.J., July 23. -- Mrs. Catharine Reynolds, 45 years old, of 352 Wolf Street, Philadelphia, was found slain late today in her bungalow at Strathmere, a seashore resort two miles from here.

Except for an advance in those United States Government issues upon which additional circulation privileges have been bestowed by the rider to the Home Loan bank act, the security markets produced no noteworthy incidents yesterday. Business on all of the Exchanges was typical of a Saturday in this midSummer season.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 23 (AP). -- Although thirteen of the original entries struck for more sustained hospitality and withdrew when it was not forthcoming, the Seabright invitation tennis tournament starting Monday will have a full quota of stars, both in the men's and women's divisions.

ALBERT COATES, who will conduct the Stadium concerts for four weeks, beginning Tuesday night, offers three works unfamiliar to Stadium audiences on his first and second programs. Vaughan Williams's "The Wasps" was arranged in 1925 from music written sixteen years before to accompany a performance of Aristophanes's comedy.

IN a sense the neutron is not only a discovery but an intellectual creation. When one billiard ball hits a second, we do not expect the second to display more energy than was imparted to it. Yet some- thing like this happens when the nucleus of a lithium atom is bombarded with the alpha particles of radium.

Figures to show that in a period of ten hours 1,852,500 automobiles are driven recklessly over the 13,000 grade crossings of the New York Central Railroad were issued by the company yesterday. The survey indicated an average of 1,315 motor vehicles for each crossing, or a total of 8,547,500 which used the crossings in the period.

GEORGE BANCROFT, whose screen works are usually of the rough and ready school, goes in for prizefighting in the most recent of the series. It is "Lady and Gent," a story about a boxer and his girl who leave the cabarets of Broadway and take up residence among the flowers of Main Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of your correspondents, in a letter appearing in your issue of July 10, finds fault with the repertoire of the Metropolitan Opera. This is always a ticklish problem for the management. Some want more Verdi and Puccini, while others want more Mozart, and still others will be satisfied only with Alban Berg.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 23 (AP). -- While a distinguished group of men prominent in public life looked on, a silken ribbon across the new Cadillac Mountain Highway in Acadia National Park was severed at noon today, officially opening the road to travel.

JERUSALEM, July 22. -- Dozens of dainty oil bottles imported from Cyprus before 1,000 B.C. and hundreds of juglets, lamps, bowls and pitchers, some of striking form and finish, are among the finds in the last tomb explored in the Necropolis of Mizpah, the fortress that existed from the time of King Asa of Judab until its capture by the Assyrians.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 23. -- Breaking fifty straight targets, R.H. Helsel won the High Scratch Cup at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- Accepting the challenge of the commission in Washington, the Chicago Board of Trade announced tonight that it would resist the order to suspend operations for sixty days.
IT was not that Warren William wouldn't talk. That would have been a paradox indeed for the garrulous hero of "The Mouthpiece" and "The Dark Horse." It was not even the heat, so much.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of former Ambassador Jusserand removes from the scene one of the world's great statesmen -- for he was immeasurably more than a diplomat, and his influence extended far beyond the borders of France and the United States.

The recent flaring up of activity within the public service commissions of several States, which has resulted in the issuance of stricter and unprecedented orders affecting hundreds of utility operating companies, has been due directly to the discovery of serious abuses which led to the receivership of several large holding company systems and to the suspicions of the commissions that other similar lapses may have occurred.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- An inter- national conference dealing with all questions involving the world's economic recovery, including a probable revision or cancellation of Europe's debts to the United States, was urged by Senator Borah, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, in a speech tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

RYE, N.Y., July 23. -- "A Night in Hollywood" was the feature of a dinner dance tonight at the Rye Bath and Tennis Club, here. The guests of honor included stage and screen stars. The club was decorated to represent a movie set and Japanese lanterns were placed around the open-air pavilion.

TEN years ago Great Britain and Ireland signed what was welcomed by the world as a permanent treaty of peace. By a supreme triumph of reconciliation, it seemed as if a bitter feud that had lasted for eight centuries had been brought to an end.

ESTABLISHMENT of the American University Club at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, as indicated by the purchase of that property by the club interests last week, marks an important change in that section of the avenue on the border of the Grand Central zone and also strengthens the stability of the locality as a club centre.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The house committee of the Taconic Golf Club at Williamstown, of which William T. Floyd is chairman, has arranged for a series of Saturday night dances while the Williamstown Institute of Politics is in session.

VIENNA, July 12. -- The bitter hostility of one exiled royal house toward another despite the proverbial comradeship in adversity is revealed in the interesting statement in this weeks "Sonn-and-Montags Zeitung" of an anonymus Austrian legitimist monarchist who has Just returned from Steenockerzeel.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 23. -- With rows of signal flags flying from her red, white and blue funnels and guest list representing nearly 300 leaders in government and industry, the 24,000-ton liner Manhattan, new queen of the American merchant marine, started down the Delaware River this afternoon amid the shrill whistles of harbor craft for her final sea tests before she enters the New York-Hamburg service of the United States Lines.

PRAGUE, July 12. -- Eger, in Bohemia, was the scene of a comic battle of flags recently. The occasion was a Catholic congress attended by many Germans from the Reich. The Czechs refused to allow them to bring their own religious banners, but permitted the display of the Reich black, red and gold flag on condition that every fourth flag should be the Czechoslovak ensign.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 23. -- Estimating that traffic on Connecticut highways will increase 22.5 per cent in four years ending with 1935, the Department of Motor Vehicles, concluding a study of its survey of 1931 traffic, offers in a report issued today a series of definite recommendations which are held to be essential to meet requirements expected to develop.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Opening matches in the annual tournament for the famous Seabright Bowls will get under way at the courts of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club at Rumson tomorrow, promising Summer sojournets on the North Jersey coast spectacular entertainment for the entire week.
SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 23. -- Well-filled entry lists in all classes sailed through a reefing southerly breeze today in the annual Rodman Wanamaker regatta on the Island Heights course.

HYMAN STARK, drug peddler and burglar, dies of brutal police treatment in a Nassau County police station, and his death focuses the attention of the nation once again on the third degree. Defenders and enemies of the practice of using physical violence or mental torture to force information from criminals renew the debate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- While officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company maintained silence today on the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for unification of the Eastern roads into four trunk systems, the belief grew that they would fight vigorously any attempt to give up its holdings in New England railways, as recommended by the commission, while the New York Central is permitted to remain there.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 23. -- College enrolments will be materially affected by the depression and will show substantial decreases in September, in the opinion of Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men at Rutgers University.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23.-- Deveraux, bay horse owned by J.B. Gilligan of South Orange, today won the Class A trot at Weequahic Park. Driven by Paul Vineyard, Deveraux won the third and fourth heats of a grueling struggle in which three heats were trotted in better than 2:11.

BANGOR, July 21. -- That potato raising in Aroostook County is a gamble is clearly shown by the record. There have been years when the farmers made so much money that they could afford to send their sons and daughters to college, wear fur coats and diamonds and invest in trotting horses.

UTICA, N.Y., July 23. -- Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo succeeded Miss Helen Hicks as women's golf champion of New York State today by defeating Miss Frances Snyder of Rye, 8 and 6, in a thirty-six-hole match at the Yahnundasis Club.

The sharp contrast between the nation's established needs for steel, and the per capita output since 1929 indicates that a rise in steel production cannot be deferred much longer, according to the report of a survey by the magazine Steel. If anything like the modern standard of living is to be maintained in this country, the publication declares, a higher rate of steel activity will be needed than the average for the last three years.

BERLIN, July 23. -- The Boerse continued exiremely quiet today, but prices kept on moving up slowly on small orders. Rheinische Braunkohlen led the market. In view of the small volume of business the upward price movements are regarded as no indication of the general market situation.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- By far the larger part of the $10,000,000 Federal relief requested by Governor Emmerson for Illinois will be expended in Chicago and Cook County, where 130,000 families are on the relief list. The question how to utilize this money most effectively has been raised by Dr. Martin H. Bickham, superintendent of the special work division of the Illinois Free Employment Service.

A meeting will be held in New York next Tuesday to perfect the organization of a National Economy League. Its nucleus is the committee, composed largely of ex-soldiers, which petitioned Congress at its recent session to reduce Federal expenditures for veterans' relief by drawing a line between disabilities resulting from war service and those having no connection with it.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- With the resort season at its peak, the Pocono Mountain resorts of Pennsylvania are busy with the preparations for the events of the coming two weeks, the feature of which will be the two days' horse show to be held in the "Arena in the Clouds," Mount Pocono, under the auspices of the Pocono Mountain Horse Show Association.

LAVENO, Italy, July 7, 1932. A CALL, on Albert Coates at Lago Maggiore, upon his return from Russia and just before his departure for New York to conduct a four-week season at the Lewisohn Stadium beginning July 26 revealed that Russia is attacking its musical problems in earnest.

Not only did Florenz Ziegfeld glorify the American girl, as the advertisements of his "Follies" productions proclaimed, but he also assisted on their way to stardom many entertainers who have achieved success in the theatre, the radio and motion pictures.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 23. -- The sloop Weetamoe, owned by Frederick H. Prince, today outdistanced Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie in a special race around Boston Lightship, sailed under the auspices of the Eastern Yacht Club.

LOS ANGELES, July 23. -- California's nine-year vigil is nearly over. The games of the tenth Olympiad will open in the magnificent Olympic Stadium on Saturday as more than 2,000 athletes from thirty-eight nations compete in the fourteen-sport program.

LONDON, July 14, 1932. SIR THOMAS BEECHAM'S arrangement of Handel's music (mostly from "Ariodante") for the new ballet, "The Origin of Design," given by the Camargo troupe, showed once more the adapter's rare tact in translating old wine into new bottles.

PARIS, July 23 (AP). -- Despite his objections, Jean Borotra, who insists that he is too old for such things, will be drafted for one of the singles roles in the Davis Cup challenge round to supplant the ill Lacoste, while the great Henri Cochet will carry the other, leaving Borotra to team with his old partner, Jacques Brugnon, in the doubles.

MIAMI, Fla., July 21. -- Motor across the State of Florida from east to west and nearing Tampa you will notice a small town, recognizable by its tall water tower, its electric plant, a sizeable motion picture studio and numerous smaller buildings, some of which blazon from their bare walls the name, Sun City.

After being delayed by log for six hours, the White Star liner Laurentic arrived yesterday afternoon from Montreal with 500 Canadians, including seventy-five Mayors from the Province of Quebec, on an eight-day cruise as part of the fourteenth an- nual convention of the Union of Municipalities of the province.
HYDE PARK, July 23. -- Owen D. Young and Governor Roosevelt conferred for an hour and a half today on the international situation and its relation to the Democratic campaign and policies.

Scoring a total of 45 1/2 points, Germany carried off the honors, considered by team achievements, in the ninth Olympic Games, held at Amsterdam in 1928. The United States was runner-up with 39 points, while Holland, with 34 1/2 points, took third place.

Spokesmen for one-fourth of the world are meeting at Ottawa to tighten the economic bonds which tie together the British Empire, the biggest institution on the face of the earth. That makes the Imperial Conference something which the rest of the world finds well worth watching.

The upward movement of prices in the local commodity markets, which has been gaining momentum and attracting increased public interest for more than a month, continued for the most part last week. The outstanding exception, to this advance was sugar, which met with a slight setback over the period, but this was offset by the enrolment in the movement of some staples which had previously lagged, notably coffee and cocoa.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23. -- District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards said today that the Nassau County policemen who have been indicted on criminal charges resulting from the death of Hyman Stark would be placed on trial as promptly as the law's technicalities permitted.

When the railroad managements of the country united on Wednesday in an appeal to the public for a change in regulations to give them equality with other forms of transportation and in return pledging a reduction in competitive waste, they had no idea that the Interstate Commerce Commission was then preparing to hand down its decision accepting the railroads' suggested modification of the Eastern consolidation program.

HAVANA, July 21. -- Unless the government, rules that automobile ownera may pay the annual license fee in quarterly or semi-annual instalments, more than 25 per cent of the motor vehicles in Cuba will be withdrawn from service, according to an estimate published by El Mercurio.

PARIS, July 23. -- American and British oil producers reached an agreement today with Rumanian producers that is understood to go far toward curtailing the price war among the interests involved and to open the way toward increasing prices and limiting production in Rumania.

That Franklin D. Roosevelt is the strongest candidate for the Presidency the Democratic party has nominated in the last twelve years, is the view put forward in a study of the Governor's character and career contributed by Claude Moore Fuess to August Current History.

Bondholders of the New York United Hotels, Inc., owner and operator of the Hotel Roosevelt, who dissented from the plan of reorganization instituted several months ago are entitled to have a receiver appointed for sufficient funds of the hotel to pay the interest on their coupons when due.

THIS careful, clear and extensive study of the relations between money and politics, of how much money political parties use in Britain, Germany and France and what they do with it, has much interest and value for Americans.

THIS week Andrew W. Mellon arrives in this country and undoubtedly will report to President Hoover what he has been doing during the last three months that he has been Ambassador to the Court of St. James. When he went to England last April he denied that he had any mission while there that related to the debt question.

FEW Europeans know the United States so well as Professor Bonn. He spent several years in this country as lecturer and exchange professor and has traveled extensively over many parts of the United States, from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

TWENTY years after the first appearance of Lewis Carroll's immortal "Alice" the publishers conceived the idea of gratifying the public appetite with a facsimile edition of the original manuscript. The earlier title was retained, so that unlike the regular edition, and in harmony with its manuscript character, the book was called "Alice's Adventures Underground."

A YEAR ago our budget was unbalanced, trade was declining and we were rapidly approaching one of the most critical financial situations our country ever had to meet. When the National Government appealed to the electors last Autumn they were obliged to impose great sacrifices on the people, but by an overwhelming majority the electors affirmed the government's policy.

EVERY time a man loses a job today a new peddler is born," said a Park Row jobber who sells to hawkers at present patrolling city streets by the thousand. "In this year of the depression peddling has become a major industry."

A general advance in wages of 10 to 20 per cent to solve the problem of reduced per capita unit consumption of merchandise, resulting from the increased wearing qualities of products available in the lower-price brackets, was advocated yesterday by Sidney H. Scheuer of Scheuer Co., textile consultants and brokers.

Some of those who have spent their vacation fishing in Canada recently, and especially those who have visited Jasper National Park with a rod and reel in their equipment kit, have been rather enthusiastic in describing their trips.

WHEN Coroebus won the first Olympic championship in 776 B.C. there was inaugurated a series of contests which continued without a break for nearly 1,200 years. Wars, floods, famines and all the ills to which mankind is heir came and went in those ancient days, but there was no interruption in the Olympic Games.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 18. -- Properly speaking, Southern Rhodesia is not a British dominion but a self-governing colony. From self-government to dominion home rule is only a short step, however, and Rhodesians regard their country as quite the equal of the neighboring Dominion of South Africa.

COPENHAGEN, July 23. -- The Permanent Court of International Justice at The Hague will render a decision Thursday on Norway's counter-appeal in her dispute with Denmark over the recent Norwegian occupation of a strip of coastalterritory in Southeastern Greenland.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edmund L. Baylies sailed yesterday on the Roma for Genoa. Mrs. Baylies will remain abroad throughout next Winter.

HORATIO ALGER is dead, but life, which can be spelled with a large L, has not forgotten Alger's technique of the success story. Consider Chee-Ak, which is the name of the sturdy young Eskimo who figures as the hero of "Igloo," at the Rivoli.

A shorter working week, if adopted by industry all over the country, would permit two or three men to be employed on the same job and would do much to end the depression, Richard Waldo, economist and president of the McClure Newspaper Syndicate, declared yesterday in a radio broadcast over the WEAF network of the National Broadcasting Company.

CHATTANOOGA, July 21. -- Three candidates for Governor, each disclaiming any connection with or obligation to the Lea-Horton-Caldwell treasury-looting regime, are stumping Tennessee today in a campaign of cross-currents that make the Democratic primary of Aug. 4 a baffling puzzle to political prognosticators.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- Equipoise, America's big horse, went down in defeat at Arlington Park today.
Following Friday's recovery, prices on the Cotton Exchange receded yesterday about 15 points and ended at losses of 9 points on the day.

COMMERCIAL air transport, both here and abroad, is again undergoing changes, and again Europe, and especially Great Britain, is borrowing from American experience in flying long distances with, pay loads. Imperial Airways has ordered eight 120-mile an hour monoplanes from the Armstrong Whitworth company.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the large subscription costume dance tonight at Windemere in First Heck Lane. The guests wore fancy dress of wide variety. Later in the evening prizes were awarded for the most comical costumes.

The Yankees and Red Sox wore down the better part of a crowd of 20,000 at the Stadium yesterday, but those who managed to survive the six and a half hours of royal entertainment felt themselves well enough repaid for their endurance and fortitude.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 23 (AP). -- A resolution to nullify the votes of Negroes "herded" to the polls in the Aug. 4 Democratic Gubernatorial primary was adopted by the State pri- mary board today after a stormy ses- sion marked by fist fighting in the aisles
DANZIG, today, is a Free City. And the people of that city are as happy in their freedom as a broken-hearted widow is in hers.

THE late period of unexampled prosperity in the United States which culminated in 1929 was marked by the advent of a peculiar state of mind of the public. This may perhaps be best designated as "common-stock consciousness." An epidemic of popular preference for the junior securities of all sorts of corporations occurred.

There is an urgent necessity at the present time to evolve some practical method whereby a large proportion of the vacant space now existing in factories and industrial plants may be put to some profitable use, points out Robert S. Harnsberger in the current number of Building Investment.

Beware of Cats! Some time ago a cat got into my child's perambulator in the storeroom. My wife aired the mattress, but the child took seriously ill, and only recently, after several doctors could not diagnose the case, we took the child to a hospital.

SUMMER homes fashioned from old barns or country mills often present opportunities to use diverse types of furnishings with charmingly picturesque effect. Here, in unassuming surroundings, odd chairs and tables that might appear shabby or out of place in a sedate Winter dwelling may take on a halo of beauty.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass. -- The very busy and interesting activities of Provincetown's art colony this season will come to a climax with the eighteenth annual "regular" exhibition at the Provincetown Art Association Gallery from Aug. 7 to Sept. 5.

To the Editor of The New York TImes: George W. Wickersham, writing in THE NEW YORK TIMES, is to be commended for discussing one of the major social problems of American life -- what to do about crime.

Announcement was recently made of the organization of the Bureau of Architectural Relations, the purpose of which is to stimulate a greater appreciation of architecture and the allied arts on the part of the people generally. The organization intends to book illustrated lectures, informal discussions and radio talks by architects, interior architects and landscape architects, on the plan, design, construction and equipment of houses and various other types of buildings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22. -- The fact that Governor Pinchot has within three weeks called upon two members of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission to defend themselves against charges at public hearings has served to emphasize that the old enmity between the Executive and the commission had merely been temporarily submerged in talk of unemployment relief and other pressing matters.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- Senator Borah, under demands for apology from Representative Crump for having made public charges that the Tennessean's "political machine" was distributing Red Cross flour in exchange for votes, maintained today there was justification for the accusations.
OTTAWA, July 23. -- In the first three days of its existence the Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa has raised more questions than can be answered in as many years.
FLORENCE. BRUNO CICOGNANI, although he has never succeeded in winning a wide public, has been greatly esteemed in Italian literary circles ever since he published his novel "La Velia" in 1921.

LOS ANGELES, July 21. -- There will be a State primary late in August that promises to be unusually fervid. More than five hundred candidates are officially entered in the primary lists, and the ballot in Los Angeles County will be one of the most cumbersome and complicated ever presented to a harassed electorate.

BERLIN, July 23. -- Prussia's battle for an injunction temporarily restraining Chancellor von Papen from further acts invading her sovereignty until the whole complex constitution- al problem involved in the Reich's assumption of the State government can be fully argued began today before a special tribunal of the Federal Supreme Court in Leipzig.

DETROIT. THAT a realignment is taking place within the automobile industry is a conclusion which is inescapable in Detroit these days. As a result, competition in the popular price field is expected to be keener in 1933 than ever before.

According to the nineteenth seminnual survey of the real estate sitution by the National Association of teal Estate Boards the great lack mortgage money supply stands out as the predominating feature. The survey was based on confidential reports received from member boards in 358 cities of the United States and Canada.

BERLIN. THE great surprise of the German elections in the Autumn of 1930 was the sudden growth of the Hitler party. It came as a shock to many who were considered good judges of German political opinion.

The general attitude in city departments yesterday indicated that the city's employes were disposed to accept as necessary the month's deduction in pay from their 1933 salaries that was asked by Mayor Walker in his radio address Friday night.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The text of Senator Borah's radio address tonight was as follows:

Give the Car a Chance. AT periodic seasons of the year articles suggesting to car owners what they should do to keep their automobiles in good running condition appear on this page. William Ullman contributed such an article last Sunday.

JUDGE ALBANO is magistrate of the Third Criminal Court, Newark, N.J., and in this book he writes about the varying phases of that court's work, illustrating them constantly with reminiscences of his own observations from the bench.

HAVANA, July 20. -- The district known as Las Yaguas, where some 8,000 indigent folk have constructed homes of palm leaves, will not be closed, according to announcement of the Department of Health. Complaints of insanitary conditions led to the appointment of a special health officer to oversee the district, since to close it would be to leave these families without shelter.

Dean Frank H. Sommer of the New York University School of Law announced yesterday that thirty-six students of the school registered in the first and second year classes were winners of honors for the school year 1931-32.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 21. -- After a week of tense uncertainty some 25,000 North Carolina school teachers have been assured that they will not be subjected to further salary cuts at this time, and reductions which had already been ordered for State institutions and departments have been rescinded.

IT is five years since Miss Mayo included caste in her celebrated survey of the Indian scene. By many Indians her indictment was fiercely resented, and we welcome, therefore, a book which, within a reasonable length and in understandable language, gives an account of this Indian phenomenon as it appears to an Indian scholar who uses terms to which no Indian can take objection.

WITHIN a short distance of Coney Island, with its bustle and bathing beach crowds, is the quieter bungalow cottage community just beyond the onefamous Brighton each and the great hotel of that name. This bungalow centre occupies the areas union which several years ago stood this Manhattan Beach and Oriental Hotels, On the site of the Oriental Hotel has recently been built a group of stucco homes adjoining the Manhattan Beach baths.

SKIRT lengths fail in three classes; daytime, on an average of ten inches from the floor; late afternoon, ankle length; evening, floor length, sometimes dipping a bit toward the back. A few whimsical trains are seen.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 23. -- State Senator J. Griswold Webb, a member of the State Aviation Commission, enjoyed his first glider flight so much today that he may have set an endurance record for the current contests here.

TWO coupe models are now in production to complete the 1933 line of Graham sixes introduced in June. The models, a two-passenger coupe and a four-passenger rumble seat coupe, have the same streamline design used on the other Graham cars.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 23. -- Mrs. Whitfield Painter, who, as Marjorie Morrill, won the Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament three years ago, repeated her 1929 triumph today, defeating Miss Josephine Cruickshank of Santa Ana, Cal., 9 -- 7, 8 -- 6, in a closely contested final round match.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- Harry Earl, theatrical and circus showman, died yesterday of peritonitis at the John B. Murphy Hospital.

RICHARD BENNETT has definitely joined his three daughters -- Constance, Joan and Barbara -- in the golden hills of Hollywood. His latest film characterization may be seen at the Paramount this week in "Madame Racketeer."

WHEN the American innocent goes abroad in these latter days he lacks the cock-sureness which distinguished American travelers of even fifteen or twenty years ago, and which may be said to have found its first notable expression when Mark Twain walked into his first Italian art gallery and discovered that he did not like very many of the pictures.

LONDON, July 23. -- The stock markets were fairly cheerful today, although some profit-taking occurred in British Government securities. The internationals eased slightly except Brazilian Traction, which improved on reassuring news from Brazil.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 23 -- Thirty-one sloops took part in the seventh regatta of the July series today off the Fishers Island Yacht Club in a light southwest wind which failed for about a half hour and freshened again, bringing the sloops home on time.

WASHINGTON. AN unimpressive dark brown building at Pennsylvania Ave- nue and Nineteenth Street in the northwest district of Wash- ington, where for seven years Her- bert Hoover worked as Secretary of Commerce, now houses the largest banking institution in the history of the world.

HUGH FORD, inactive in recent seasons, and Harry Askin, for years manager of the late John Philip Sousa's many tours, have been drawn into some sort of producing association. While they have several plays under consideration, they have tied up only one -- this "A Night in June," the work of Adelaide Matthews, who used to write them in collaboration with Martha M. Stanley.

HAVANA, July 21. -- Presidential decree No. 479, of April 19, providing for the compulsory registration of foreigners residing in Cuba will become effective on Monday and the registration must be completed with in sixty days.

HERE are mysteries without solutions -- stories of ghosts and apparitions, of witchcraft, diabolism, satanism, sorcery, voodoo, of all the dark and forbidden lore that men have dabbled in from time immemorial. The tales collected in this anthology are with a very few possible exceptions, frankly fictional, but they are written from the standpoint of a belief in occult forces not recognized by science.

THE development of international air navigation, whether in regular scheduled transport or in casual private travel, has had to steer a course between Scylla and Charybdis. On the one side lies the danger of regulation so stringent, and preservation of national prerogatives so careful, that international flying will be swathed in red tape and stipulated out of existence.

SITTING in the studio of a broadcasting company, surrounded by every evidence of the machine age. Norman Thomas posed for a drawing and stressed the failure of our present economic system to solve the problems which modern conditions have brought about.
CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP). -- Durocher hit into a double play to silence a ninth-inning chance to whip the Cardinals today, but the Reds went on to win by 3 to 2 in eleven innings.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., July 23 (AP). -- Ordered out of the Everglades by 200 irate white residents after an episode that involved a Filipino and a white girl, thirty members of a Filipino colony near Canal Point evacuated today.

PAUL GREEN'S folk fantasy, "Tread the Green Grass," has had to wait three years for its first production. On Friday night, July 15, the Department of Drama at the University of Iowa, under the supervision of Professor B.C. Mabie, achieved the particularly difficult task of carrying over into the theatre the widely diverse elements that together make this play one of the most original and stirringly imaginative works yet written by an American dramatist.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- America, according to a report of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, is ready for a building boom.
LEXINGTON, Va., July 23 (AP). -- Henry St. George Tucker, member of Congress from the Tenth Virginia District, died at his home here tonight.

The convening of the Imperial con- , ference and the bright outlook for crops have produced a greater buoyancy of spirit in Canada with respect to the future than has been evidenced for a long time, according to the summary of current conditions prepared by the Bank of Montreal.

KEEN interest was aroused last week by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a letter written by King Albert of Belgium to his Prime Minister, M. Renkin, during the Lausanne conference. In a statement dealing with the reparations settlement Dr. Butler quoted from the letter and made this comment:

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23. -- Ira L. Terry of Flushing was the winner of the free-for-all, second division, trot at the matinee of the Nassau Driving Club today driving his bay gelding Trumpet. Calumet Author, Henry Seaman's fast stepper, was next.

In The New Republic Professor JOHN DEWEY considers temperately the " Prospects for a Third Party." They are not immediately bright. At their recent conference in Cleveland the delegates of the League for Independent Political Action, of which he is chief, decided to support the Socialist candidates this year as nearest in aims to the League.

ADMITTEDLY of greater interest to the student of English poetry than to lay readers, the early poems by Alfred Tennyson, which his grandson here brings together and publishes for the first time are, nevertheless, of interest as showing the growth of a poet's mind.

A number of retail cleaners and dyers in the five boroughs have offered to appear before Assistant State Attorney General Edmund C. Collins for questioning about conditions in the industry in Greater New York, it was announced yesterday. As a result he will question several tomorrow at the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

TORONTO, Ont., July 23. -- The gold-mining industry, now tne greatest single producer of new wealth in Ontario, made another record of production in June, exceeding the figure for May by more than 100,000, the Provincial Department of Mine reports.

IT is rather significant of unemployment in musical America that before departing from the United States for Russia and adjacent territories this writer was asked by a rather prominent musician and teacher of this country, whose pupils are dropping off, to find out whether there were any positions open to musicians of accomplishment and reputation in Russia.
OTTAWA, July 23 (Canadian Press). -- Garden parties, dances and receptions have been arranged to provide recreation for delegates to the Imperial Conference.

ORDINARILY it is a simple process, usually only a formality, to obtain the sanction of the New York courts for a change in name, but occasional applicants get into difficulties and have their petitions denied. The latest of these unfortunates is Edwin M. Kelly, who recently asked the courts to change his name to Kellett on the ground that there is general antipathy to the Irish, especially if they are named Kelly.

ON the boarding-house veranda this Summer many a rocking chair flaps forlornly, robbed of its wonted seasonal occupants. Here and there under azure skies even the country club occasionally languishes with greens unshorn.

HOLLYWOOD. THE preparation, of Noel Coward's "Cavalcade," one of the most ambitious and important of this season's offerings, is being rushed at Fox with the assignment of Clive Brook to the leading role and the arrival of Captain Reginald C. Berkeley from London to do the adaptation.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The recent re- vival of the slot machine business in Cook County was held today a factor in the slaying last night of Jack Werner, 36 years old, intimate friend of Sheriff William D. Meyering. Werner was killed by machine gun bullets as he was driving his automobile at Eighty-first Street and Calumet Avenue.

WHY do thousands of people visit Lewisohn Stadium to hear the New York Philharmonic-Symphony concerts when they can sit at home, avert traveling to the scene and hear the radio music without distraction? Even Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor of the orchestra, sees in radio "a close approximation to the ideal situation in which a listener can enjoy his easy chair, light his pipe and devote his whole attention to the beauty of sound."

In a special report made public yesterday, the joint committee on foreign exchange restrictions, composed of representatives of fifteen foreign trade associations, calls for immediate, action to correct exchange conditions and prevent "the paralyzation of our foreign trade."

GENEVA, July 23. -- The first world disarmament conference ended its first phase today. Its general commission adopted, forty-one to two, Germany and Russia dissenting and eight nations abstaining from voting, a resolution registering the maximum general agreement reached in the first six months and laying down a program of work during the recess, which is limited to six months.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 16 amounted to 504,094 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 84,144 cars more than in the preceding week, 253,895 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 424,177 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23. -- Adopting resolutions calling for the immediate payment of adjusted compensation certificates and the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment "as a means of ending the widespread lawlessness and disrespect to law," the annual convention of the Nassau County American Legion adjourned here tonight.

The "man who ran the war and gave orders to Pershing" has completed the story of his experiences as Chief of the General Staff, U.S.A., and in it he reveals what went on behind the scenes in Washington.

After a four-hour conference, an agreement was reached yesterday in the Bar Association Building that, it was said, would result in the dismissal of the suit of the Cleveland Motion Picture Exhibitors' Association against the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, Inc., its membership of the big motion picture companies, and the Cleveland Film Board of Trade.

Despite the financial plight of the farmer, the Department of Agriculture reports that last year he spent more money than ever before in wiring his buildings and buying electric labof-saving machinery. He paid the power companies $46,187,000 for electricity. Today 1,000,000 farms -- about 10 per cent of the total -- are electrified.

The uniting of the country's 20,000,000 stockholders and 10,000,000 bondholders in an association whereby they could exercise the rights and privileges accruing to them in the management and direction of the business represented by their investments is a plan of Louis Guenther, publisher of The Financial World.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 23. -- Joseph W. Kitchell, 37 years old, real estate broker, 299 Fifth Avenue, New York, married Mrs. Eleanor Sheldon, 32, of New York, daughter of Harris Rubin, today in the Town Hall, Justice of the Peace J.J. O'Brien officiated.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 23. -- United States rowing stars took the honors at the historic Royal Canadian Henley regatta, concluded today, capturing the senior singles and senior eights and having a total of eleven victories.

Jimmy McLarnin is training diligently for his ten-round bout with Lou Brouillard, former welterweight champion of the world, to be staged at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, Aug. 4. The contest will be the feature event of the boxing card arranged to aid the $6,000,000 drive of the Daniel Frohman Foundation for the Actors' Fund of America.

THE second unit of the limited dividend apartment development of the City and Suburban Homes Corporation at Celtic Park, Queens, which is scheduled for occupancy on Aug. 1, contains 114 suites and 406 rooms, bringing the total number of apartments in the first two units to 231.

IT may appear strange that the history of the Second Empire and the personalities of its creators. Emperor Napoleon III and Empress Eugenie, should attract, time and again, the attention of our historians and biographers. For there is, it seems to us, no epoch more distant, psychologically speaking, from our time than this period.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- A rousing ninth-inning finish today produced the two runs necessary for Washington to down the Athletics, 6 to 5.

A change in the tariff rate basis, coupled with the sharp reduction of ad valorem rates outlined by the United States Tariff Commission in its recent report on the conversion of rates from a foreign to domestic value base, "would play right into the hands of importers," in the opinion of Dr. Arthur L. Faubel, secretary of the American Tariff League.

To the Editer of The New Yorte Times; In the issue of THE TIMES of July 10 there appeared an article by Olin Downes about the music of the Caucasus. It was a most refreshing article. Here was a straightforward description of the music of the cradle of the white race, music so simple yet so inspiring.

While there were fewer buyers in the market last week than during the corresponding period of 1931, due in part to the delay of many wholesale openings, a larger representation is expected in the market this week, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

James Butler's Apprentice, winner last week of the Empire City Derby, canfirmed his superiority over the Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret again yesterday, for he defeated the son of Flying Ebony, this time by half a length, in the featured Knicker-bocker Hanaicap.

A greater and more beautiful city is to rise from the shell-blasted ruins which are all that remain of the larger part of those sections of Shanghai lying to the north and east outside the International Settlement.
Real estate in the Borough of Manhattan assessed at $876,652,350 was conveyed during the first six months of 1932. Of this amount, $134,644,300 was transferred in foreclosure sales.

BOGOTA, July 20. -- Colombia's disjointed railway system, owned almost entirely by the National and State Governments, has been one of the problems facing the present administration, which has pledged reorganization and business administration of the lines.

LAST Thursday a transatlantic radio broadcast brought the voice of another king into American homes. For years he has occupied a place of his own in American hearts, for Albert of Belgium, whose slow, careful phrasing came through the loud-speakers last week, has visited the United States twice -- once as king in 1919 and thirty-four years ago when he was heir to the throne.

IN the same picturesque and unconventional style with which he entertained readers of "Through Oriental Gates," James Saxon Childers in this new book tells of further wanderings in the Far East. Beginning in Saigon, in French Indo-China, he describes his visit to the ruins of Angkor.

PARIS, July 13. -- Each Summer, just after the Grande Semaine, the British Embassy gives a garden party, which draws all the leading figures of government, diplomacy, letters and art of the capital. This brilliant function followed close on the heels of a dinner and evening reception given in honor of the new President of the French Republic, of which we spoke last week.

While Florenz Ziegfeld's last -- and Borne say his greatest-production "Show Boat," was playing yester day to the laughter and applause o a Broadway audience, plans were be ing prepared for bringing East the body of the producer, who died unexpectedly Friday night in Hollywood Cal., after an attack of pleurisy.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Benedict Fitzpatrick's interesting lesson on the significance and importance of the name of Kelly, which was printed in THE TIMES recently, points a moral not intended by Mr. Fitzpatrick. It is that the man, the clan or the nation that "muscles in" on the rights of others soon or late has to pay the piper.

WORKING backward, the Lener Quartet now gives us Brahms's Second string quartet, the A minor (Opus 51, No. 2), which, on four records, is contained in Columbia Masterworks Album No. 173. So far as European lists show, they have not as yet recorded the first of this pair, but it has been generally understood for some time that the intention is to have the three, played by this group, in the series eventually.

Gene Phillips, the defending champion and first seeded player, and Ted H. Crabtree, seeded No. 6, gained the third round as the annual Staten Island men's tennis singles championsnip tournament opened yesterday at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I. Sixty-four are entered in the competition.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- Falling before the relentless batting fury of the phillies twice today the Dodgers dropped the entire threegame series and at the same time established their longest losing streak at the season, five games. A crowd of 12,000 watched the home club win by 10 to 2 and 16 to 5.

Stocks continued yesterday to reflect the more cheerful frame of mind in Wall Street. Although trading was slow, the market extended its recent gains slightly and there were few indications of the usual Saturday profit-taking. The total turnover on the Stock Exchange was about 369,000 shares.

RYE, N.Y., July 23. -- With a finish reminiscent of his feats of a few years ago, when he was winning tournaments steadily, Maurice J. McCarthy Jr., former Georgetown star, today came from behind to grasp victory in the Westchester Country Club's Invitation Tournament, defeating William J. Tobin, a veteran golfer, but one who takes part in few tourneys.

The Olympic swimming trials held at Jones Beach last week proved to be one of the most spectacular events of its kind ever held, not only from the standpoint of competitive interest, but as a means of giving many thousands an opportunity of seeing the stellar women swimmers of the nation perform.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Tariff adjustments to restore American foreign trade, as advocated in the Democratic platform, will be necessary to realize hopes of great benefits from the St. Lawrence deeper waterway, Senator Hull declared today.

THE Country Club of Brookline celebrates in this handsomely made large octavo volume, designed by William Dana Orcut and produced by the Plimpton Press, the fiftieth anniversary of its birthday. As the story of the first fifty years of the first country club in this country -- perhaps also in any country -- the book is unique in its socially historical significance.

CRACKS in the broadcasting structure of the United States are seen by O.H. Caldwell, former Federal Radio Commissioner, who warns that sound engineering principles are being waved aside as more stations are allowed to share the ethereal channels originally assigned exclusively to lone but powerful stations.

LONDON, July 9. AS I came away from "Evensong," by Edward Knoblock and Beverley Nichols, I was glad that I had not yet read Mr. Nichols's novel upon which the play is based. For in the play there are signs of divided purpose which a brilliantly subtle and coherent performance by Edith Evans does much to conceal, but which, I felt intuitively, a knowledge of the book would have emphasized.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Second Lieutenants of the army who were graduated from the Military Academy in June received their first assignments to stations by War Department orders today.
BAR HARBOR -- The dedication of the mountain road yesterday brought visitors from afar as well as from all parts of the Northeast.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- With his $125,000,000 home loan bank bill just put on the statute books, President Hoover today could find that most major points in his economic program were granted by a Congress which may approve others next Winter.

WARSAW, July 22. -- With the warm July temperature harvesting of grain began earlier than usual this year. The crop is 15 per cent larger than last year's and prices, it is feared, will be accordingly lower. The calamity of good crops looms over Polish agriculture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the decision arrived at by the European powers concerning the war debts, it seems inevitable that the question whether the United States will accept a further scaling down of the $11,000,000,000 claim we hold against those countries must be determined.

The long-drawn-out debate over furloughs and salary cuts and other controversial features of the Federal economy bill, which took effect July 1, tended to obscure its provision for reorganizing the executive departments. Congress is now definitely committed to the policy of grouping executive and administrative agencies of the Government in accordance with their "major purpose," reducing their number by consolidation, and segregating regulatory functions from administrative functions.

PORTLAND, Ore. July 21. -- Unless there a decided change in expressed public sentiment before the November election, Oregon may again go into the Democratic columns when "it comes to casting the Presidential ballots. The nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the terse but expressive Democrats platform were both well received here and seemed to add fuel to the fires of revolt against the Hoover Administration that have been smoldering for almost two years.

FALMOUTH, Mass., July 23 (AP). -- Miss Elizabeth Fenner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D.C. Fenner of 1 Fifth Avenue, New York, and Thomas Baxter Gresham 2d of Baltimore were married today at the Moors, Summer home of the Fenners.

Predicting that Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt would be elected by a greater electoral college majority than any Democratic candidate for President except Woodrow Wilson in 1912, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared yesterday that he regarded no State, no matter how strongly Republican in past elections, lost to the Democratic national ticket this year.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that the index number of wholesale prices for the week ending July 16 stands at 65.0 as compared with 64.8 for the week ending July 9.

MOSCOW, July 21. -- There is a rising conviction among responsible American business men and engineers who have studied conditions in the Soviet Union that the United States is passing up a reliable and valuable market in refusing to trade with Russia and to give it credit terms.

That highway trucks should operate on express rates rather than freight rates is the opinion expressed by E.A. Houser Jr. of the K. S. Trucking Company, in comment on the declaration of policy made by the Association of Railway Executives last week.

ROME, July 22. -- Abolition of German reparations has caused a distinct reawakening of confidence in Italy. The general impression is that though it is futile to expect prosperity to return overnight, it is now definitely possible to foresee brighter times ahead.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 23. -- F.W. Estin continued winning in the Interclub class races of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association today when he took first place in the invitation regatta of the Sayville Yacht Club. Estin sent his Flying Cloud over the 13 1/2-mile course 11 minutes ahead of H.A. Bonyun's Typhoon, which was later disqualified.

LOS ANGELES, July 23. -- Along with their training chores, America's athletes are going in for literature -- international competitive rules mostly-in a very large way at the Olympic village these days.

LAUGHTER is the radio comedian's prop. There was a day when no visitors were allowed in the studio when comedy acts went on the air. Today guests are welcome. Even the Rudy Vallee orchestra, which always shunned visitors, beckoned a crowd to surround the microphone when two jokesmiths were recently added to the hour of broadcasting.

AMONG the Times Square habitues who are carefully surveying the oncoming theatrical semester is William A. Brady, alert and jaunty despite his almost seventy years. The patriarch of Broadway producing managers, he has been surveying approaching theatrical seasons, here and on the Pacific Coast, for about half a century, sometimes with optimism, sometimes with a marked degree of pessimism.
The University of California crew that will represent the United States in the Olympic games at Los Angeles will resume training tomorrow on the home course, the Oakland Estuary, at Berkeley, Cal.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23. -- Two squalls, one overlapping the other, struck the racing craft of Long Island Sound today in the last regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.

MRS. JOHN N. GARNER is "going campaigning" with the Democratic candidate for Vice President. Many a man has discovered a perfect secretary -- and then has married her. The process was reversed in the Garner family; Mrs. Garner married and then became her husband's perfect secretary.
BERLIN, July 22. -- Almost a fortnight after the termination of the Lausanne conference Germany suddenly discovers that in all the hullaballoo about it the Saar Basin has been completely overlooked.
WASSERKUPPE, Germany, July 23. -- Guenther Groenhoff, Germany's champion glider pilot, was killed today when the Fafnir, the glider with which he had set the world's record, crashed.

While few tangible evidences pointing definitely to a revival in business were noted at this time, a symposium of opinions of leading executives in major lines, gathered by THE TIMES during the week, indicates a general belief that underlying conditions are on a sounder basis and that sentiment has gained.

BOSTON, July 21. -- Why did the Republicans of the nation open their campaign with a meeting in Boston's historic Faneuil Hall, addressed by the man who had acquired greater prestige than any other party leader at the Chicago convention, and held almost immediately after the Democratic convention had named the present Governor of New York as its candidate for the Presidency?
