Owners purchasing property and paying for it by the monthly plan on principal and interest are sometimes puzzled to ascertain just how long it will take to complete the payments. An easy method of solving the problem is given in a recent issue of The Seattle Real Estate Board Bulletin as follows:

THE Limited Editions Club, according to a statement issued with the announcement of the club's publications for 1932-33, is not in the least worried about the depression. Indeed, in so far as the club's own affairs are concerned, there is no depression.

Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, an- nounced yesterday that Eastern head- quarters for the Presidential cam- paign would be established at the Waldorf-Astoria soon after Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Benjamin Reath Riggs of Philadelphia, first secretary at the legation at Ottawa, has been designated first secretary of the legation at Berne.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Fifty-five yachts, the largest fleet that has taken part this season in a race on Moriches Bay, crossed the starting line off the Speonk shore in the weekly regatta of the yacht racing squadron of the West Hampton Country Club today.
THE opening statement of the 1932 edition of "Facts and Figures of the Automobile Industry," annual statistical publication of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, reads as follows:
RUMSON, N.J., July 23. -- For the seventh time in ten years, the junior polo championship of the country rests with the United States Army.

NEW ORLEANS, July 21. -- Mississippians have heard many strange campaign cries and seen many political sights and wonders, but the spectacle of a candidate for Congress crying "Balance the budget with beer" has taken them all aback. It appears to most of the voters of this ardently dry State, where moonshiners pursua the old craft with the old artistry and sell the mellowed corn at the old prices, almost as a miracle.

SUMTER, S.C., July 22. -- It has become increasingly apparent during the intervening weeks that South Carolina's immediate concern with the liquor question was far from ended when her delegation, voting under the unit rule, gave its full strength to the unequivocally wet platform of the Democratic party.

OTTAWA, July 23. -- Although dominated thus far by discussion of tariff preferences to facilitate the exchange of products within the British Empire, the Imperial Economic Conference was preparing today to grapple with two subjects of equal if not greater importance.

THERE is no question about it -- girls are going to adore the Autumn styles. The mode seems designed for young things, for the cigarette silhouette has climbed into the saddle and probably nothing will unseat it this Fall.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- The team of Manuel Alonso and Dr. Eugene McCauliff recorded a smashing 3-6, 6-3, 6-4 triumph over Ernest Jonklaas and Charles Watson of Cedarhurst and established itself as a favorite to win the Maidstone Club's fifth annual invitation two-day doubles tennis tournament which began today.
LOS ANGELES, July 23. -- The Olympic Village, a colony that sprawls over the hilltops some six miles from the centre of Los Angeles, is unique in all sporting history.

FOR those who cannot afford a trip abroad and a motor tour through France, much the same result may be attained by driving northward into the Province of Quebec. Two days of easy rolling will take the New York motorist to Montreal and another day will land him in the city of Quebec.

Until Nov. 8 the chief business of American citizens is choosing a President. Meanwhile everything they say and do bears on the main point. There was a slackening in campaign activity last week, due to the adjournment of Congress -- which had become a mere political forum -- and to the fact that President Hoover has not yet made his speech of acceptance.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- While General Hines, chief of the Veterans' Administration, maintained today that the exodus of bonus marchers in the past forty-eight hours had left only 3,500 of their number encamped here, both the police and the leaders of the "B. E. F." maintained that those still here total more than 20,000.

AVERITABLE encyclopedia of broadcasting has been compiled by the Federal Radio Commission from a questionnaire sent to every broadcasting station in the United States. The answers disclose what is called the first fair picture of American broadcast- ing based on actual facts and figures, not hearsay and guesses, as heretofore.
DUBLIN, July 23. -- With nothing in sight on which to base hope for reopening of negotiations, the Irish Free State assumes tonight that Its economic war with England will begin on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- The task of exploring pathways of economy and starting huge new enterprises is keeping the Federal Government high-keyed as never before at the end of a session of Congress.

LATONIA, Ky., July 23. -- Ridgeview, 4-year-old filly which races under the colors of the Ridgeview Stock Farm, scored a surprising triumph in the fifteenth running of the $5,000 added Enquirer Handicap, which featured the card at the Latonia track today. Playtime was second and Lady Couvin third.

WILLIAM McNALLY has chosen for the scene of his novel, "House of Vanished Splendor," a very romantic section of the Upper Mississippi Valley, a section which is rich in historical interest and color, but one which has received very little attention from writers of fiction in general.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Dances, especially tea dances, will start on July 30 at this resort with jazz music and will be daily events thereafter. The activities reach their heights weekly on Saturday nights.

BOSTON. July 23. -- Armed with pitching of exceptional merit and effective batting, the Giants took two games from the Braves today, sweeping the first half of a four-game series by scores of 3 to 2 and 9 to 0 and climbing to sixth place by virtue of Brooklyn's double setback in Philadelphis.

THIS is a proud day for Canada, for in its capital city are gathered delegates from throughout the British Empire, empowered to speak for one-quarter of the earth's population and instructed to cooperate in determining a plan by which this great empire may continue its leadership among the nations.

Frank J. Sprague, father of modern electric traction, the commercial electric motor, the electric elevator and other epoch-making inventions that contributed largely to the growth of the modern electrical industry and rapid transit systems, will be honored tomorrow night on his seventy-fifth birthday with a meeting of appreciation and tribute at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, in the presence of several hundred internationally known engineers, educators, industrialists and inventors.

THERE have been a great many books published on dogs, but very few of as much practical value as this volume, since it tells clearly precisely the things that the average dog owner -- especially the new dog owner -- wants to know.

With many States and municipalities announcing their intention of borrowing from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the opinion voiced in municipal banking circles yesterday indicated that no fear is entertained that the corporation will enter into direct competition with the bankers.

PLATTSBURG BARRACKS, July 23. -- The annual track meet at the camp here, where 2,400 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware are receiving their Summer military training under the supervision of Colonel George A. Herbst, camp commander, was held this afternoon.

SELDOM it is in these melancholy days that a man may have two great triumphs the same week. And more unusual is the fact that the triumphant one is a statesman; which gives a clue to his identity, for we have a habit of terming foreign, officeholders statesmen, withholding that dignified label from our own politicians until they are dead.

An expedition through the areas of the lost Maya civilization in Mexico, Guatemala and Honduras, to take sound and Technicolor motion pictures of the Indian successors of the original Mayas and to explore the sites of ten ancient cities and the hitherto unexplored basin of the Usumacumta River in Tabasco, will start from here about Sept. 1, in charge of Lawrence T.K. Griswold, Boston archaeologist, it was announced yesterday.
The Long Island open golf championship, an event in which Macdonald Smith has been the outstanding performer for the last three years. will hold the centre of the stage during the coming week.

OMAHA, July 21. -- There is an air of good feeling plainly observable in the Corn Belt, somewhat modified, perhaps, but unmistakable, and it is justified. This section's chief marketable commodity and greatest producer of cash income, meat on the hoof, has just staged a remarkable comeback right at a time when many people had begun to wonder if there was any more ready cash left in the World.

Ninety-one women golf players are entered in the annual women's New Jersey Shore championship tournament, play in which is scheduled to start tomorrow morning at 8:30 o'clock over the Deal Golf Club's links.
DALLAS, Texas, July 23 (AP). -- Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Fergruson, former Governor, assumed a lead over ROSE S. Sterling, incumbent, in a partial tabulation from the Democratic primary.

TWO States claim Andrew Jackson's birthplace. In Union County, N.C., stands a monument which is visible expression of the belief of partisans of the North State as to the spot of Jackson's nativity. In Lancaster County, S.C., is another monument which marks a spot where the South State contends Jackson was born, and now a project is under way for improvement and landscaping of that monument.

LOS ANGELES, July 21. -- Officials of the Olympic Games ruled that it is proper to call the event itself the "Olympiad." Lexicographers went straight up and turned a double flip and their protests could be heard far out at sea. Since the days when the appetites of hungry lions were whetted by tender victims of the "thumbs down" rule, "Olympiad," they said, meant the period between the games.
Price trend in the wholesale markets yesterday was irregular. The grains were fractionally higher, but cotton lost some of Friday's advance. Other articles were steady.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Bank debits outside New York were lower in the week ended July 16 than in the preceding week, when month-end influences caused a sharp advance, but the week's total was about up to the June average, according to the Commerce Department's current survey of domestic business conditions.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. TACOMA, July 23. -- Like the rest of the nation, Tacoma is struggling with the grave problem of feeding a growing army of unemployed. Out of many futile attempts to solve it has grown the Unemployed Citizens' League, an organization watched with interest by all and with anxiety in some of the more conservative circles.

As a result of a talk before the transport section of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, delivered earlier in the week by W. Irving Glover, Assistant Postmaster General in charge of air mail, it was disclosed yesterday that the air transport operators of the country have decided to initiate an era of cooperation, rather than intensify keen rivalry, to realize more fully the opportunities of air transport from a self-supporting angle.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- Arthur W. Cutten, financier and grain trader, in a signed article published today said that one-third of the value of the domestic wheat, corn and oats crops goes "into the pockets of those who grow fat at the farmers' expense."

COLUMBIA, has spent a good four months preparing the screen play of "Washington Merry-Go-Round," and now has it about ready for production. The story represents a three-cornered collaboration of Maxwell Anderson, the playwright; Eugene Thackeray, once Washington correspondent for the defunct New York World, and Jo Swerling, scenarist.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- President Hoover will soon hold a conference on plans for decreasing unemployment through shortening the hours or days in the working week. The President today issued the following statement:...

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23. -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes advanced into the semi-final round of the Wheatley Cups tournament today by defeating the South Shore polo team, 16 to 9, on Hitchcock Field of the Meadow Brook Club.
Considerable activity in sales of property in the various subdivisions in and around Long each under the management of Joseph P. Day has been noticeable during the last few weeks.

RETAIL trade in the week maintained its recent level fairly well. The principal activity was reported on dress accessories. Early testing out of furniture promotions brought an indifferent response. Similarly, on forerunners of August fur coat sales reports varied.

The ultra-dry, the ultra-wet and all intervening degrees of political opinion on the prohibition question are likely to be represented in the roster of candidates whose names will appear on the Republican ticket in this State at the election this Autumn.

Announcements of bonds to be retired before their maturity dates made last week consisted entirely of foreign and municipal loans, none of which were called in their entirety. The total for July is now $26,120,500, compared with $9,102,000 in June and $98,776,500 in July, 1931, for corresponding weeks.

THE return of graphic art to problems of book illustration is now well established and cannot be too eagerly greeted. The problems resemble to an amazing degree those of architecture, but the freedom of the illustrator is far greater than that of the architect, and this is no less, a danger than an inspiration.

MR. HARDING, in such works of his as "Fads, Frauds, and Physicians." "The Degradation of Science," and his present latest volume, occupies a unique place in American social literature. He is the surgeon of the ailing body politic.

BANGOR, Me., July 21. -- Time was when a man who was handy with an axe was worth good wages in the Maine woods, but today the ability to chop down a lot of trees in a given time is of no great advantage. Maine still cuts hundreds of millions of feet of logs, but most of the harvest is small stuff for pulp; it is sawed, not chopped, and anybody can use a saw.

MADRID, July 22. -- While France, through the Anglo-French entente, has again demonstrated her political strength, Spain, to the south, is fighting, without drums or accompaniment, to gird herself for the future. As large as France and with half her population and a better strategic position, Spain is, nevertheless, looking for a new orientation to save her from utter dissolution.

PARIS, July 23. -- Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn made short work of Daniel Prenn and Gottfried von Cramm today, defeating them in three straight sets and putting the American Davis Cup team in a position where it is virtually certain of winning the interzone final and meeting the French next week in the challenge round.

On the Forty-second Street frontage of the well known American Theatre, which is now being torn down, a single story taxpayer building will be erected. The remainder of the large theatre plot, having a frontage of 49.4 on Eighth Avenue in the middle of the block and 150 feet on Forty-first Street, will be used for open air parking space.

STOCKHOLM. ON the delightful lakes and inlets encircling this city of wooded islands and peninsulas, over which the midnight sun casts a twilight glow through the short Summer nights, are thousands of beautiful motor boats.

LONDON, July 21. -- Although the British railways are in the doldrums, with both passenger and traffic freight fallen off seriously and still decreasing, a concerted campaign is being now carried on to help business and to recover some of the road's lost prestige.

Sun-worship may not be the most inspired of religions, but it is thoroughly natural on a planet that draws most of its benefits from the sun. At this time of year, when the solar rays are pitilessly direct and the asphalt pavements scorch the feet that tread them, the sun is not always in the highest favor.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- Secretary Hyde announced today the apportionment to the States of the $120,000,000 provided under the relief bill for Federal aid highway work.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 23. -- Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., and Clifford Sutter of New Orleans, will meet at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the final match of the men's invitation lawn tennis tournament at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, having come through the semi-final matches today.
ST. LOUIS. July 24 (AP) -- The Browns and the Tigers split the second of their three straight doubleheaders today, Detroit winning 6 -- 2 and losing 10 -- 7.

Although failures in the textile industry for the second quarter of the year set an all-time record, positive signs of a healthy credit condition are evident, the National Credit Office reports today. Indebtedness generally is at a low point and well within the safety zone, merchandise stocks are much below even a reasonable demand and accounts receivable indicate a fair degree of liquidity, the report stated.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP).-Six newspaper winners of merit prizes for the last year were announced here yesterday at a session of the National Editorial Association. The association makes the awards annually.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Pounding five Red Sox pitchers for eighteen hits, the Washington Senators today trounced Boston, 12 to 6. Al Thomas turned in the victory for Washington, though he had to quell an eighth-inning Boston rally which netted four runs.

NEW YORK. Sheldon Whitehouse, United States Minister to Guatemala, and Mrs. 'Whitehouse, who have been visiting his mother, Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse in Paris, will arrive today on the Bremen. They will go to Newport, R.I., for the rest of the Summer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In some of the recent contributions to your columns on the subject of international debts, there has been much discussion of the unpaid Confederate debt, of which an interesting historical review was given in the letter of Mr. Wilbur Bates in your issue of July 17.

Preparation for the establishment of the spirit of God in all forms of industry was urged yesterday upon the members of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fiftysixth Street, by the Rev. Frederick K. Stamm of Brooklyn, guest preacher.

JACKSON, Miss., July 24 -- King Cotton, who has ruled the South's economic life for decades, has been dethroned. Many Southerners are exulting in a new-found freedom from the whims of the cotton market and the disadvantages of an almost universal policy of one-crop production.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- Rigidly enforced economies in municipal government have helped to place Philadelphia on a financial footing which, considering the general economic situation, is regarded as being more satisfactory than for some time past.

MONTREAL, July 24 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals took both ends of a double-header from Buffalo today, 2-1 and 3-2. Shiver hit his sixteenth home run with one on in the nightcap to give Walter Brown his twelfth victory of the season. Claset won his thirteenth victory in the opener, allowing only two hits.

PITTSBURGH, July 24. -- Production of steel ingots last week was at an unchanged rate, 15 to 16 per cent of capacity, and the trade is more confident that the low point in demand has been left behind, but hopes for a marked improvement in September rather than for any important gain in the next few weeks.

International affairs form the high spot of the Movietone and the Metrotone newsreel program at the Embassy Theatre this week. One subject shows the signing of the Lausanne pact ending Germany's war reparations and another introduces Stanley Baldwin arriving in Canada at the head of the British delegation to the Empire Conference at Ottawa.

The recently formed Italian Line, consisting of three former lines, N. G.I., Lloyd Sabaudo and Cosulich, has carried a total of 14,935 passengers eastward on the last ten sailings, Captain Giuseppe Cosulich, director in charge of passenger traffic, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- General business and industrial conditions continued unfavorable in June, activity in industries decreasing by slightly more than the usual seasonal decrease, accompanied by a considerable reduction in factory employment and payrolls, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly review of the business situation.

The present personal fortune of President Hoover is estimated at $700,000 in an article entitled "The President's Fortune," which appears in the August issue of Fortune, a magazine, published today. His fortune in 1914, when he retired from active business, is placed at $4,000,000 in the same article.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Hot weather was against heavy marketing of live stock at all leading markets last week, although Chicago receipts of cattle'were within 780 of the previous week and 4,500 short of last year. Receipts of hogs dropped about 12,000 and receipts of sheep declined 18,000, yet supplies were ample for all trade requirements.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24. -- Eusebio Ayala, President-elect of Paraguay and former Minister to the United States, in a pessimistic interview with the Asuncion correspondent of La Nacion of Buenos Aires, described the Chaco situation as extremely grave, with Bolivia deliberately provoking a war because she knows her military strength is vastly superior to Paraguay's.

Mexico does not need any interference from this country, but what she does need is our cooperation and sympathy, the Right Rev. Frank W. Creighton, Bishop of Mexico, declared yesterday morning in a sermon as guest preacher at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Columbia University, Mexico, he told the congregation, should be left alone while she works out her own plan of social and political culture and ideas.

LONDON, July 24 -- Public ownership of the Bank of England and the establishment of a national investment board, which besides exercising control over new public issues could learn the reason for foreign loans and so insure that the money is not employed in armaments, are among the far-reaching proposals adopted by the executive of the British Labor party.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 24 -- F. Slade Dale's Vixen in the international star class and Bud Vail's Sand Flea in the junior catboat class were the victors in today's contests in the weekly Sunday regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association at the Seaside Yacht Club.
JAMES J. CORBETT knocked out John L. Sullivan in 1892 and held the world's heavyweight championship until 1897, when Ruby Robert Fitzsimmons laid him low at Carson City.

READING, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles took two games from the Reading Keys today, 8 to 7 and 8 to 5, to win the series, three out of four. Baxter Jordan made two homers for the Orioles, while Bell and Legett hit circuit blows for Reading.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- After analyzing the Republican and Democratic prohibition planks, the American Federation of Labor's National Committee for Modification of the Volstead Act today advised voters to pay little attention to them, "in view of the refusal of party leaders themselves to adhere to party declarations."

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has written the introduction to an edition of "Alice in Wonderland" which has just made its appearance as one of the titles of the Jacket Library, published here at 15 cents each by the National Home Library Foundation.

MANAGUA, July 24 -- Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, chairman of the United States Electoral Mission to Nicaragrua, who will supervise the Presidential election in November, completed his organization with the arrival today of the following navy and marine officers:

PRINCETON, N.J., July 24. -- Five hundred and fifty-two undergraduates of Princeton University, representing three foreign countries, thirty-five States, one dependency and the District of Columbia, were recipients of honors during the past academic year, it was announced here today.

The onrushing Yankees and the Somewhat faded Athletics crossed paths for a single game at the Stadium yesterday and, so far as the already aeverely ruffled champions were concerned, It was more than enough to demonstrate that in the short space of about nine more weeks a new club will reign supreme in the American League.

NEWTON, N.J., July 24 (AP). -- Fatally injured in an automobile accident today, Theophilus Current, 25 years old, of Sparta, got up from the operating table at the Newton Memorial Hospital, told the doctors and nurses, "I want to go home," and fell dead after walking about the room.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 24 -- The session of the Institute of Politics for discussion of international affairs and this year devoted in particular to the world crisis will open Wednesday at Williams College for the registration of members.

A Successful Mediation. Prevention of the threatened strike in the garment industry was scarcely expected until its announcement on Saturday. All the week the reports had been of an immovable deadlock between the union and the employers.

OTTAWA, July 24 -- Canadian textile manufacturers have informed Premier Bennett of Canada that, regardless of any concession he may have in mind to make to Great Britain in return for preferences that may be granted by the mother country to dominion exports, there must be no sacrifice of the Canadian textile industry.

In the August number of The American Legion Monthly there is a summary of laws enacted in behalf of ex-soldiers. Its purpose is "to acquaint the World War veteran "with the rights and benefits which "have been provided for him by Federal and State legislation."

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- The capital's disheartened and disrupted Bonus army was in full retreat today, only a fragment of its original strength remaining to tent for the last time on the old camp ground along Pennsylvania Avenue. That fragment must abandon camp by midnight tomorrow or face eviction unless leaders succeed in enjoining the authorities in court.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP). -- When Americans open the hay fever season after Aug. 1 with a salvo of sneezes forty-eight of their kind will be doing their best by science.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 24 -- For the second week in a row the gallery at the Sands Point Club's weekly high-goal exhibition, match watched fast, well-played polo today as the Hurricanes of Stephen Sanford turned back Roslyn, 14 to 11.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- America's Olympic boxing team was completed today in a riot of leather gloves that saw two champions, one of the A.A.U. and the other of intercollegiate rating, defeated.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- Clarence McElroy of Medaryville, Ind., arrived in Mexico City by plane this afternoon, following his rescue after wandering seventeen days in the woods in the State of Oaxaca, where his plane crashed in a gale on June 27, causing the death of Roy Gordon, president of the Honduras Aviation Company.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 24 -- Operations of the Federal Farm Board are termed a "tragic government adventure" In marketing, in a brief filed last night with Representative Joseph B. Shannon, chairman of the Congressional inquiry into the government's activities as a competitor in business.

Four English radio scientists are on their way to the Arctic to count the electrons in a thimbleful of air 130 miles above the North Pole, says the Associated Press. These electrons control the electrical conductivity of air and so affect the electrical radio waves.

In an address to a mass meeting at International House, built by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as a residence and club for students of all nationalities attending institutions in New York, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, said last night. "It is already evident that the last stand of capitalism will be in the highly nationalistic form of Fascism with all that Fascism implies of danger to world peace."

The price of forsaken ease must be paid if the organized church is to last as long as religion and Christianity, according to the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church of New York City in his sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth, Avenue at Twentyninth Street.
CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP) -- St. Louis won a double-header from Cincinnati today, 7 to 3 and 1 to 0. Si Johnson battled four Cardinal pitchers in the thirteen-inning second game.
The First Division polo team defeated the Freebooters at the Fort Hamilton Reservation yesterday, 7 to 6. A crowd of 2,500 persons witnessed the battle, which was entertaining throughout.

Tariff walls erected by creditor nations were held largely responsible for the world economic crisis yesterday by Pierre-Etienne Flandin, former Finance Minister of France, in a speech delivered in Paris and re-broadcast here by the National Broadcasting Company network.

OTTAWA, July 24. -- When the currency questions committee of the Imperial Economic Conference here begins its work this week two important proposals that will be laid before it are for the creation of a super-empire bank and for the remonetization of silver.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Assurances that the Chicago Board of Trade would remain open were renewed today by Peter B. Carey, president of the organization.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 24 -- Benjamin Natkins, 58 years old, former president of Nedick's Orange Juice Company of New York City, was found dead today in the cellar of his home on the Washington Valley Road in Mendham township. Coroner Stephen L. Chapman of Morristown, who investigated, recorded the case as a suicide.

CLEVELAND, July 24. -- Cleveland's city administration faces the problem of paring an operating budget of $17,604,000 because of a falling off in tax collections. The budget does not include the city's schools or sinking fund.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- After listening to tales of a series of robberies in roadhouses and restaurants along the Lincoln Highway near Langhorne, George Candelet, aged 14, of this city, who has been working at Penn Valley Park in his vacation, evolved a plan of action should he ever face a bandit.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 24 (AP) -- Rochester and Toronto divided a twin bill today. The Red Wings won the first game, 6 to 4, and lost the second, 5 to 3.

WARSAW, July 24. -- The efforts of Foreign Minister Zaleski of Poland at Geneva to make Rumania join the Polish-Soviet non-aggression pact having failed, the Polish Government has decided to sign the pact with the Soviet Union without Rumania.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 24 -- An impromptu team consisting of Elbert Lewis and Henry Culley of California annexed the Maidstone Club's fifth annual invitation men's doubles tourney, which, had an unfortunate termination on the club's grass courts today.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 24 -- Hesitation resulting in a moderate volume of trading featured the cotton market last week. The unwillingness of traders to undertake new commitments led to narrow price fluctuations with the result that the maximum spread of price amounted to only 17 points and the net decline, for the week was only 9 points, or less than 50 cents a bale.

LONDON, July 22 -- The improvement in sterling this week arose partly from sales of foreign currencies against purchases of gold, and partly from moderate support of the exchange from New York. It is believed that the low point of sterling has now been touched, and that only narrow fluctuations will occur for some little time.

BOSTON, July 24. -- The Dollar Line steamer President Van Buren, inbound from a world cruise via New York, docked here today with several dented plates on the port bow, stanchions of the skeleton deck rail bent inward and plating at the shear line crushed for several feet from a collision in fog early this morning somewhere off Chatham in Nantucket Sound.

Although the market showed a gain in activity last week, the peak of the buying season is anticipated during the next two weeks. Higherprice merchandise is expected to sell tetter at that time. Retailers for the most part were chiefly interested in ready-to-wear for back to college and school promotions.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Declaring that unemployment is the most pressing national problem and that the army of jobless may reach 13,000,000 next winter, the American Federation of Labor, in its monthly survey of business, urges national coordination to relieve the situation.

Jerome Selman sold to the Wegman Holding Company the two three-story frame flats on a plot 54 by 106 feet at 194-196 Jackson Avenue, northeast corner of Wegman Parkway, Jersey City. The property is assessed at $51,300 and was taken over subject to three mortgages totaling $41,000.

A request has been sent to Mayor Walker by the Fifth Avenue Association asking him to call a special meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment immediately to consider making a formal request to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of sufficient amount to permit the city of New York to continue to work on the Tri-borough Bridge and to start construction on the East River-Thirty-eighth Street tunnel to Brooklyn and Queens.

"The Harbor Light," Owen Davis's latest play, will be given its first professional performances during the week starting tonight by the Lakewood Players, Skowhegan, Me. The plot of the play, which is said to be in a vein similar to Mr. Davis's "Icebound," deals with three generations of a family.

The jury calendar is now so congested in the Municipal Court that a negligence case must wait seventeen months for trial and a commercial case must wait six months, according to the annual report of conditions in the Municipal Court made public by the New York County Lawyers Association.

LONDON, July 24. -- The building by Italy of naval vessels about which France and the rest of the world know nothing has been proceeding for some time, according to an article by Hector C. Bywater, British naval expert, in The Daily Telegraph.

Effective protection of home markets for farmers of the United States should be a permanent policy of the future, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt declares in an article on "Restoring Purchasing Power," included in a volume called "Government -- Not Politics," published today by Covicl, Friede.

Ernie Schaaf and Paulino Uzcudun will clash in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at the Madison Square Garden Bowl tonight. The battle is the first of a series of heavyweight elimination contests arranged by James J. Johnston, vice president in charge of boxing at the Garden.

CHICAGO. July 24 -- Hardening of wheat prices in many leading countries of the world, with statistics becoming more attractively bullish, has brought about a more constructive feeling in many quarters with the belief that prices arc due to work irregularly higher.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 24 -- Gerard B. Lambert's sloop Vanitis today turned the tables on Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe and beat her by 3 minutes and 20 seconds, actual time, in a race held under the colors of the Corinthian Yacht Club.

MIAMI, Fla., July 24 (AP). -- A party of scientists and photographers, led by George Vanderbilt of New York, left here by boat today to take pictures of scientific and native methods of catching large game fish in tropic waters of the West Indies.

Whenever a Presidential nomination comes after a contest there are always rumors of patronage deals. Usually the fact confounds the rumor, as was sharply demonstrated by WOODROW WILSON in making his Cabinet and other appointments. Again it was proved that politicians who lend support to a candidate on the vague promises of his campaign managers are lambs for the shearing.

In a statement reviewing yesterday the terms of the settlement by which the cloak and suit industry, through the mediation of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, avoided a strike of 27,000 workers, the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union disclosed that the union had conceded a flat wage reduction of $5 a week or about 10 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 -- Major James Doolittle left Newark Metropolitan Airport this afternoon with Miss Anne Madison Washington, the great-great-great-grandniece of George Washington, for Providence, the first leg of their flight to Kittery. Me., which will be the starting point tomorrow morning for their dawn-to-dusk cruise over points visited by Washington during his career as explorer, soldier and statesman.

MINEOLA, L,I., July 24. -- Thirteen Nassau County policemen were to appear tomorrow before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson to plead to indictments resulting from an investigation into the death of Hyman Stark, victim of a "third degree," which ended tragically.

Formation of a protective committee for holders of the 7 per cent series A preferred stock and cumulative convertible preferred stock, $3.50 series, of the National Public Service Corporation, now in receivership, was announced yesterday. The committee comprises William de Krafft, New York; George N. Lindsay, New York; Edgar C. Rust.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Due to the non-payment of taxes, the local governments of Chicago are in financial straits. The financial liabilities of these tax-spending bodies are about the same in total today as they were last Jan. 1, although the form has been changed.

The meeting of the first International Recreation Congress in Los Angeles this week is an appropriate preface for the Olympic Games. Behind these contests are the activities of millions. The Olympic victories are won on thousands of playgrounds around the world.

Dazzy Vance, with a great deal of help from Hack Wilson, Johnny Frederick, Tony Cuccinello and Glenn Wright, broke the five-game losing streak of the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, and the Carey athletes celebrated their first day at home, after a long road trip, by defeating the Phlllies. 5 to 4. About 6,000 saw the contest.

DENVER, July 24. -- Denver's tax collections have been only three-fourths of 1 per cent below normal in the administration of Mayor George Begole, who was elected a year ago last month. This, coupled with fewer appropriations and a rigid economy program, has placed the city and county of Denver in a reasonably sound financial condition in spite of the depression, according to William McGlone, Manager of Revenue, and W.H. McNichols, City Auditor.

The trout fisherman from Pennsylvania who found himself in New York for the Summer months without a chance of getting back to his home State for another opportunity at some of his favorite brown trout made several suggestions.
BERLIN, July 24. -- The drift of the German comment on the disarmament conference may be epitomized in one word -- tragi-comedy.

To the Editor of the New York Times. Much has been said and written regarding the chaos in the taxicab industry. We have heard that this condition was recognized by leaders in the industry and by city officials, and that steps were taken to put the industry on its feet.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A marked improvement in business sentiment is more apparent than for months. Many factories throughout the Middl West and West are increasing operations and taking on more help. With, a greater number of workers employed the disposition is toward continued betterment, as seen by many trade leaders.

WOBURN, Mass., July 24 (AP). -- A group of cottagers at the Silver Lake section, after a struggle with the police today, forcibly took from them the body of a drowned companion and raced to a hospital five miles away in a futile hope that his life might be saved.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 24. -- A special session of Congress to modify the Volstead act as a means of unemployment relief will be called by Governor Roosevelt as one of his first official acts if elected President, according to his son, James Roosevelt, who spoke today at a clambake of the Worcester Democratic Club at Paxton.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 24. -- With indications at hand that Argentina would remain neutral in event of a war with Paraguay, Bolivia rejected today the invitation of the neutrals in Washington to confer on a peaceful settlement and to resume negotiations for a non-aggression treaty.

DALLAS, Texas, July 24. -- Demonstration anew of the political power of James E. and Miriam A. Ferguson and a demand for resubmission of the prohibition question were revealed as highlights of yesterday's Texas Democratic primary by tabulations made today.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- The Ameriran Davis Cup team received no thanks from France for routing the Germans today from the flowery seting of Roland Garros Stadium in the Bois de Boulogne. Through the three-day series the voluble French galleries were decidedly pro-German. and there is no reticenec about French tennis fans showing where their sympathies lie.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 24 -- Unusual gliding conditions tempted so many pilots into the air today that plans to announce trophy and record awards at the closing banquet of the third annual national soaring contest had to go by the board.
MOSCOW, July 24. -- The Soviet Government today took another step toward liberalized policies when it promulgated a decree extending the rights of the Artisans' Cooperative Associations.

Last week's recovery on both stock market and bond market at least suggested the regaining of financial poise and a willingness to respond to any development of a potentially hopeful character. There have been such developments. The government's weekly "index number" of staple prices has been virtually stationary during the past ten weeks.

Despite reports "that Tammany and its up-State allies are opposed to the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman for Governor and the renomination of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, friends of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, expressed belief yesterday that Colonel Lehman would be named to head the State Democratic ticket and that Senator Wagner's renomination was virtually certain.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 24 -- Playing the best tennis he has displayed on grass this season, Clifford Sutter of New Orleans today won the invitation lawn tennis tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club by defeating Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

General Mills, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on May 31 reports a net profit of $3,891,200 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and minority interest, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $3.93 a share on the 639,525 no-par common shares outstanding on that date.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Senator Borah's proposal for an international conference to discuss means of bringing about business recovery was regarded here today as offering an opportunity for Europe to ask the United States to include war debts on the agenda of the coming economic and monetary conference under the League of Nations.

What one especially likes about the gods of the Massachusetts Democratic machine is their magnanimity in defeat. They are such good losers that even, their opponents must admire them. If their position has been misunderstood, that is because they are thoughtful men, accustomed to deep silences.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company has reorganized its operating schedules from a basis of three eight-hour shifts daily to four six-hour shifts, operating six days a week, with a view to providing employment for a larger number of workers, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, July 24. -- Governor Roosevelt motored home in the twilight tonight ready for an active week, to be marked by two major events, the deception of Mayor Walker's reply to the charges against him and the visit of Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts on Wednesday.

"The Eighteenth Amendment will not be repealed overnight, if at all," the Rev. A. D. Batchelor, metropolitan district superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, declared yesterday in an address at Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, West New Brighton, S.I.
HIGH POINT, N.C., July 24 (AP). -- Peace officers mobilized today in answer to the challenge of striking hosiery workers who threatened violence if the Diamond full-fashioned mill opens tomorrow.

The Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn, doing welfare work in Brooklyn and Queens, cared for 2,328 families from Jan. 1 to July 1, according to a report just made public by that organization. Of these cases, 1,462 were new to the organization this year.
EVARTS, Ky., July 24 (AP). -- Seven persons were wounded, three seriously, in an outbreak here late last night for which officers today could advance no motive.

SEA ISLE CITY, N.J., July 24. -- The New Jersey police, Investigating the slaying of Mrs. Catharine Reynolds, 45 years old, in her cottage at Strathmere, near here, requested the Philadelphia police today to search for James Kees, 53 years old, for questioning in connection with the crime.

The address on the Lausanne agreement and the war debts which Mr. BORAH made over the radio on Saturday evening showed him at his independent best. He boldly disagreed not only with the Administration but with his own past position respecting the war debts.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- Argentina is watching with real anxiety the efforts of Australia and South Africa at Ottawa to obtain tariff and other concessions which will enable them to increase their shipments of meat to British markets because any such increase could be only at the expense of Argentina.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES's approval of the New Hampshire plan of re-employment as a means to end the depression should go a long way toward dissipating a panicky feeling that has been hinted at in high places in the last few weeks.

RYE, N.Y., July 24 -- W. Roy Manny, who had been, sailing the ten-meter sloop Synthetic and this Summer joined the interclubs with Poppy, gave an exhibition of sailing to windward on Long Island Sound today.

The church should encourage young people to live their own lives to develop individuality, the Rev. C. Lloyd Lee, assistant pastor of the Broadway Methodist Episcopal Temple, at 174th Street, told the congregation there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has notified Senator Hull that he will be here Tuesday to confer with Senators and House members on issues to be stressed in the campaign and other subjects, such as the St. Lawrence waterway and its relation to hydroelectric power development.

A quality of showmanship as hard to define as personality distinguished FLORENZ ZIEGFELD. Every one who often witnessed the series of entertainments which made him famous felt the " difference," but it was not easy' to name it. He has received and deserved credit as the originator of a special kind of extravaganza, but a mere adaptation of French or German girls-and-music shows is not true creation.

The United Booking Office, which, as recently announced, will conduct the theatrical booking business now operated separately by the Shubert and Erlanger interests, will begin operations on Monday, Aug. 1, with offices in the New Amsterdam Theatre building, 214 West Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Fourteen new State chairmen started intensive organization in their territories last week of the drive to reduce governmental spending, sponsored by the National Organization to Reduce Public Expenditures, it was announced today by George W. Rossetter, president of the Chicago Association of Commerce and general chairman of the campaign against tax waste.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- The Olympic Village was a hubbub of activity today, but it was not the athletes who furnished the excitement. Instead it was some 10,000 of the curious who flocked to the bungalow colony to spend the day in the bright sunshine outside the village walls.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland indians halted a pair of ninth inning rallies today to take both games of a double-header from Chicago, 9 to 7 and 9 to 6. The Indians' two victories enabled them to supplant the Athletics in second place.
Members of Portugal's Olympic team arrived in New York City yesterday on the French liner De Grasse and left early last night from Pennsylvania Station for Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- The United States is retaining its leadership in world trade, despite the dollars-and-cents falling off in exports and imports.
In line with Governor Roosevelt's proposal to relieve unemployment throug'h reforestation, the Governor and other State officers provided work last week for 100 men in the reforestation areas.

NEW ORLEANS, July 24. -- Varying reductions in the salaries of public school, Sewerage and Water Board and Police Department employes and a slight decrease in operating expenses of the city's public units have been effected by officials to keep New Orleans on the right side of the balance sheet.

NEWPORT," R.I., July 24 -- The fleet of thirteen planes of the Aviation Country Club landed here today in the course of the annual cruise of tHe club, which began last Friday at Oyster Bay and ended there this afternoon. The fliers had come from Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., in an hour and ten minutes.
BERLIN, July 24 -- One week from today Germany will again go to the polls. It will be her fourth national election this year, every one held to decide the same issue.

OTTAWA, July 24 (AP). -- An axiom of the British milling industry -- "buy in the cheapest market" -- today presaged another conflict in the Imperial Economic Conference here. It appeared as a specific barrier against the virtual demand from two of Great Britain's most important Dominions for higher tariffs against foreign countries in general and Russia in particular.

The active cooperation of the stage hands in a revival of the campaign to introduce Sunday performances in the legitimate theatres of the city was pledged yesterday at the monthly meeting of Theatrical Protective Union 1, held in the Knights of Columbus Hotel. About 700 members were present.

The Newark Bears triumphed over Jersey City in both ends of yesterday's double-header at West Side Park in Jersey City, winning by 13 to 1 and 6 to 5.The double victory gave the visitors a clean sweep of the four-game series.

LONDON, July 24 -- Senator Borah's address on debt revision was hailed here as an event of the highest importance, although Great Britain is still in the dark regarding how this "conversion" has been brought about.

PARIS, July 22 -- The rise of dollar exchange in terms of francs appears to be a consequence of repurchasing by speculators who had sold the dollar during recent months. This "bear covering" proves that the fears mistakenly entertained some weeks ago, concerning the stability of the dollar, have now been dissipated.

Confident that the city's civil employes will fall in line with his proposal that they surrender a month's pay in 1933 to save some $26,000,000 in the budget for that year, Mayor Walker and his executive aides will begin today to put the finishing touches on a plan to cut down the debt service item of the same budget by a slight modification of the Delaney plan of financing new subway construction with four-year bonds.

OTTAWA, July 24 -- Problems of imperial preference and better empire markets for British products gave place today to shining silk hats and accompanying sartorial splendor as delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference joined in the observance of a typical British Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Secretary Mills will offer for subscription tomorrow, at par and accrued interest, through the Federal Reserve Banks two new issues of Treasury notes totaling $650,000,000, both dated and bearing interest from Aug.1, at which time there will be a maturity of $227,631,000.

The often repeated charge that religion is an opiate must be met by the Christian church, not with a complacent denial, but in a mood of "humble self-searching" which "faces the large truth which lies behind that conception," Professor Halford E. Luccock of Yale Divinity School asserted yesterday morning in a sermon at James Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Amassing a total of 44 points, the Washington Canoe Club upset all predictions by capturing the national canoe-paddling team crown and the Yonkers Canoe Club Point Trophy in the third annual national championship regatta, staged in Washington Channel today.

John Grier Hibben, former president of Princeton University, accepted the chairmanship of the Motion Picture Research Council just before sailing for Europe. The group, which includes many prominent educators, has spent several years studying the influence of motion pictures on the health, attitude and conduct of children ani adolescents, and plans to start a campaign on behalf of wholesome films.

The eighty-fifth anniversary of the arrival of Brigham Young and his followers at Great Salt Lake and the founding of Salt Lake City by the Mormons was celebrated as Pioneer Day in the three Churches of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints in the metropolitan area yesterday morning and last night.

PARIS, July 24 -- The American team won its way to the Davis Cup challenge round today when Ellsworth Vines beat Baron Gottfried von Cramm in the first match of the final singles play with Germany, 3 -- 8, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3. The United States thus gained the three points out of five needed to win the interzone final.

Three goals received by handicap provided the margin of victory for the Squadron C polo team of the 101st Cavalry In Its 9-to-6 triumph over the Governors Island four before 3,000 at Governors Island yesterday.

With colors flying and field music blaring, the Seventy-first Infantry, New York National Guard, set out for Camp Smith, Peekskill, yesterday afternoon for two weeks' field training. Colonel Walter A. De Lamater, the commanding officer, accompanied his men.

Nothing is more distinctive of the last half century than the growth of governmental philanthropy and the coincident decline of private charity, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of Halifax, N.S., said yesterday morning in a sermon in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixty-ninth Street east of Broadway.

BERLIN, July 22 -- The conflict between the Reich Government and Prussia induced temporary weakness in stocks on the Berlin Boerse in the middle of the week, but in general it had little effect on prices. The market continued inactive and irregular; some stocks show advances on the week's trade, others declines.

CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP). -- Libby Holman Reynolds, widow of Smith Reynolds whose fatal shooting at Winston-Salem is still being investigated by county authorities, has gone into seclusion to escape "the morbidly curious," her father said today in a statement denouncing the "selfseeking motives" of North Carolina authorities.

RUMSON, N.J., July 24 -- Displaying surprising power, the Austin polo team overwhelmed Winston Guest's Templeton quartet at the Rumson Country Club today, 15 to 7, to gain the final of the Herbert Memorial Cup tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The American electorate cannot be "befuddled" by the old-time protective tariff slogan in the present national campaign, Senator Connally of Texas said in a statement issued today through the Democratic National Committee.
SALZBURG, Austria, July 24. -- Sponsors of the Salzburg music festival opening on Saturday, anticipate a slim attendance for the first few days.

For the first time since the World War a rifle meet, a German "Schutzenfest" with hundreds of German, Austrian and Swiss contestants wearing badges, medals and feathered Alpine hats, opened yesterday afternoon in the Bronx.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- After two hours of wrangling, the French Tennis Federation today announced the team of Henri Cochet, Jean Borotra, Jacques Brugnon and Christian Bousus would represent France in the Davis Cup challenge round against the United States this week-end.

HAVANA, July 24. -- Terroristic activities and clashes between the police and enemies of the government in Havana in the last twenty-four hours resulted in the death of Captain Carlos Garcia Sierra of the national police and the serious wounding of three policemen by a bomb explosion and the shooting down of Colonel Esteban Delgado, prominent Oppositionist, by the authorities.

Bright skies lured another big Sunday crowd to the near-by coast resorts yesterday. Although a brisk northwest wind tempered the heat, beaches again were thronged with bathers, and police were kept occupied in unraveling traffic snarls and restoring lost children to anxious parents.

The need for a national economic council, familiar with the ways of business, to supplement existing political machinery, is discussed by Julius H. Barnes, as chairman of the board of the National Chamber of Commerce, in an article published today in the July issue of The Harvard Business Review.

BERLIN, Monday, July 25 (AP) -- Germany spent its first week-end with Prussia and Brandenburg under a virtual dictatorship, and up until 2 A.M. today no deaths had been reported in political clashes. Last week-end almost a score were killed and about 100 injured in various disturbances.

An international contract bridge tournament, expected to exceed in number of players any previous contest of the kind, will be held this Fall under the auspices of the American Legion to raise funds for unemployment relief and for the Legion's War Memorial in, Paris, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Meeting a withdrawal of foreign balances amounting to $425,000,000 from May 4 to June 29, the Federal Reserve Banks at the end of June nevertheless had $942,000,000 in gold in excess of their legal requirements, the Reserve Board disclosed today in its monthly review of financial conditions.

FARGO, N.D., July 24 -- Prospects of a bountiful crop in North Dakota this year, after three successive years of crop failure, especially in the western portion, has created a feeling of optimism which ignores, for the present, the hardships that must follow in liquidating the debts of the drought period.

BOSTON, July 24 -- After losing a hard-fought battle to the Braves, 4 to 3, in the first game of a doubleheader today, the Giants jolted Ed Brandt off the hill before the second out of the nightcap's first inning, getting four runs, by which margin they eventually won, 7 to 3.

ZURICH, July 15. -- That Remain Rolland, the French author and peace advocate, is being used by Communist elements in Russia and other countries for the purpose of promoting another "united front" manoeuvre is intimated in a letter sent to M. Rolland by Frederich Adler, secretary of the Socialist International, which has its headquarters in this city.

The granting of a permanent injunction in Jersey City yesterday, restraining Federal prohibition agents from maintaining a twenty-four-hour watch at a brewery in Harrison, led to a tightening of enforcement activities in North Jersey, which resulted in a double raid on a "beer drop" and cellar brewery in Union City.

The first ten railroads to report had net operating incomes of $3,585,000 in June, against $6,994,000 in June, 1931, a decline of 48.7 per cent, and against $8,666,000 in June, 1930, a fall of 58.6 per cent. Their net operating incomes in May were about $4,391,000, against $7,587,000 In May, 1931, a drop of 42.1 per cent.

HILLSBOROUGH, Cal., July 25 -- The third of the concerts given in the Woodland Theatre at Hillsborough by eighty-five members of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra took place yesterday afternoon, Bernardino Molinari conducting.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Babe Ruth delivered a pinch-single that scored two runs in the eighth inning today and put the Tanks ahead, and Lou Gehrig trumped it by sailing his twenty-fourth homer of the season over the wall in right centre, but a homer by Mule Haas with one on base and one out in the ninth finally won the game for Philadelphia, 8 to 7.
Ship owners and operators who have found their craft to be "white elephants" in times of depression can no longer abandon them in the Port of New York with impunity, army engineers said yesterday.

Jimmy McLarnin, who will meet Lou Brouillard, former welterweight champion, of the world, in a ten-round bout at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 4, visited the home maintained for aged veterans of the stage by the Actors' Fund of America at Englewood, N.J., yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- Competitive bidding appeared here today between the Consolidated Oil Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California for the Richfield Oil Company of California, which has been in the hands of receivers since January, 1931.

Holders of Arnold Print Works first mortgage 6 per cent sinking fund bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1941, have been notified of the formation of a committee to represent their interests in cooperating with the company in the adjustment of the sinking fund. The committee comprises George B. Bacon, Robert S. Byfield, Marshall Forrest and Samuel M. Jones.

This city has yet to decide what its attitude should be toward the opportunities afforded by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Banks, railroads and other largescale private enterprises have been served for some time, but the recently enacted Federal relief bill extends a helping hand to States, municipalities, limited-dividend corporations and other public and quasi-public agencies in need of funds for "self-liquidating" public works, housing, and direct unemployment relief.

One thousand shop chairmen of cloak makers unions affiliated with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union voted unanimously yesterday afternoon at Webster Hall, East Eleventh Street, to ratify the agreement arranged through the intervention of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, whose efforts averted a strike of 27,000 cloakmakers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 25 -- The legislative committee on revision of the election laws, of which State Senator Walter W. Westall of this city is a member, will recommend to the Legislature in January adoption of a permanent registration system similar to that now used in Massachusetts and Michigan Senator Westall declared here today.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP) -- Railroad labor, with a half million members unemployed, is organizing battle lines to oppose the merger of Eastern railways into four systems.

The literature about Presidential candidates, pro and con, begins to multiply. "This Man-Roosevelt," by Earl Looker, which Brewer, Warren Putnam will issue soon, is said to be an "Intimate biography," in which the author has drawn "a warm, human portrait of Governor Roosevelt as a man, husband, father and friend."

It would be impossible to write a history of aeronautics and ignore ALBERTO SANTOS-DUMONT, Who has just died in his native Brazil. He stands out not because of his technical contributions but because of his enthusiasm and imagination and a courage that amounted to recklessness.

Brisk advances in stocks and bonds occurred on all the securities markets yesterday, marking the fifth successive day of gains. The rally was attended by a rising volume of trading, involving a greater number of issues than in many weeks, and occasioned a feeling of widespread optimism throughout Wall Street.

The English-bred gelding Papyrcgraph, a son of the Epsom Derby winner, Papyrus, which came to this country only to meet defeat by Zev, won again at Empire City yesterday to gain his sixth consecutive victory. He has a perfect 1932 record since his seasonal debut at Aqueduct resulted in a victory.

The bodies of a man and a girl, tentatively identified by the police as John Angerano, about 35 years old, of 51 Catharine Street, and Rose Friedman, about 18, of the Inwood House, a shelter for girls at 225 West Fifteenth Street, were found last night in a furnished room they rented on Sunday evening at 59 Nassau Street, Brooklyn.

Michael Mariconda, business agent of the cloak and skirt makers' union, crossed Mott Street last evening opposite his home at 302 and waved to his wife, who was at the window of their apartment on the sixth floor. She waved back and then bustled into the kitchen to put the finishing touches to the supper which was steaming on the stove.

Popularity of the cruising yacht races this Summer is shown in the Bayside Yacht Club having twenty-seven, entries so far for its Block Island contest, which will be started on Friday. Twelve schooners, six yawls, five sloops and four ketches have been named, twelve never having competed in this annual event, which will be sailed for the twelfth time.

The labor committee of the League of New York Theatres and a delegation from Theatrical Protective Union 1, headed by its president, James J. Brennan, held another joint meeting yesterday in the course of their negotiations or a new contract covering wage scales and working conditions for stage hands to supplant the present agreement, which will expire on Sept. 1.

Substantial shrinkage in net value of assets of Harrison William investment trusts, including the Shenandoah Corporation, the Blue Ridge Corporation, Central States Electric Corporation, American Cities Power and Light Corporation and Electric Shareholdings Corporation, are shown in the interim reports for the six months ended on June 30.

An agreement to arbitrate the wages of printers employed in the newspaper composing rooms was made last night after a six-hour conference between negotiating committees representing the Publishers' Association of New York and Typographical Union 6.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The von Papen Cabinet won a distinct pre-election victory today when the Federal Supreme Court at its special sitting in Leipzig declined to grant the deposed Prussian Government a temporary injunction restraining further removals from the Prussian Government or to restrain Chancellor von Papen himself from further intervening as Reich commissioner in the internal administration of Prussia.

TRENTON, N.J. July 25 -- Albert C. Middleton, State Treasurer, reported today that State deposits of $22,537,119 were in nearly 400 New Jersey banks and trust companies on June 30 last. Most of the money was in Trenton banks for convenience.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on July 20 shows decreases for the week of $145,000,000 in loans and investments, $144,000,000 in net demand deposits and $40,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $12,000,000 in time deposits, $20,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and of $22,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- With national banks inquiring as to the workings of the new money expansion law, the offices of the Controller and the Treasurer said several minor points of law remain to be threshed out before the new currency could be issued.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mayor Cermak announced this afternoon that he had made arrangements to obtain $2,500,000 with which to pay school teachers and other School Board employes. His announcement, which indicated an early pay day for the employes to whom the board owes more than $20,000,000 in back salaries, followed a conference at the Chicago Club with Loop bankers.

FREDERICK KEPPEL, being no Scot, could believe that Mr. CARNEGIE'S hearing for the first time a great organ in America made such an impression upon him, having known in his native land only the singing of the Psalter and the playing of the bagpipes, that he became an ardent lover of the organ.

ALBANY, July 25 -- The value of a more friendly attitude toward Russia as an aid to international trade revival and to provide the United States with an extra weapon in international political negotiations is being suggested to Governor Roosevelt by a group of advisers, it was said today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A flood of applications and inquiries relative to employing the authority of the Glass-Borah amendment to the Home Loan Bank bill, by which national bank currency may be expanded $995,000,000, was reaching the Treasury today.

BERLIN, July 25 -- According to the first message received from the German Andes Expedition from Huaraz, Peru, its four members, Dr. P.H. Borcher, Edwin Schneider, H. Hoerlin and Herr Bernard, ascended Huascaran, the highest mountain in Peru, breaking the spell of this peak, 6,800 meters high (about 22,000 feet), which never had been ascended before.

Controller Berry, who has remained silent thus far on Mayor Walker's pay-reduction plan, is contemplating issuing a statement this week in which he is expected to point out how more of the taxpayers' money can be saved in other quarters, without affecting the standard of living of those in the lower brackets on the city payroll.

The first national meeting of the National Economy League, formed with the aim of obtaining drastic cuts in the payment of compensation to "non-disabled veterans," is to be held today at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Ernie Schaaf, Boston's hope to succeed Jack Sharkey as world's heavy-weight champion, defeated Paulino Uzcudun, durable Basque, in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night.

New construction contracts awarded in the metropolitan area for the first half of July totaled $5,601,600, as compared with $8,479,000 for the first half of June, $18,580,300 for the entire month of June and $62,870,400 for June, 1931, according to figures compiled by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

BUFFALO, July 25 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons had an easy time setting the Toronto Maple Leafs back in the opener of the series tonight by a score of 7 to 2. Slim Brewer had his foes blanked until the ninth, when they clustered three of their nine hits for their only scores.

Arthur J. Beckhard, producer of "Another Language," will test two plays next week in Summer theatres not far from New York. One is the melodrama, called "Tiger Hour," by Edwin L. and Albert Barker, which will have its first performance on Tuesday evening at the Croton River Playhouse, Harmon, N.Y.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 28 -- The Daily Telegraph, which yesterday published a charge from its naval correspondent, Hector C. Bywater, to the effect that Italy has under construction fourteen warships, the existence of which until now remained unknown to the outer world, today publish ea an official denial of the story from Captain A. Iachino, the Italian Naval attache in London, and a retort by Mr. Bywater.
DUBLIN. July 25 -- The Anglo-Irish trade war was carried a step further tonight with the announcement of the Irish Free State's reprisal duties against Great Britain.

Residential properties continue to furnish the bulk of real estate trading in the metropolitan area. Trading opened for the week yesterday with mild activity in small houses in Manhattan and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator Borah's radio speech Saturday night urging an international economic conference which would discuss the revision or cancellation of war debts, reparations and disarmament was his first move in an extended drive to mass public opinion behind such a meeting of the world nations.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The will of Mrs. Katherine Medill McCormick of Chicago, who died in Versailles, was filed for probate today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court by her son, Robert R. McCormick of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary Mills announced tonight that the subscription books for the current offering of $325,000,000 of two-year 2 1/8 per cent Treasury notes maturing on Aug. 1, 1934, and the same amount of four-year 3 1/4 per cent Treasury notes maturing on Aug. 1, 1936, were closed at the close of business today.

LONDON. July 25 -- The news that Germany, which at first appeared suspicious of the "European confidence pact" concluded at Lausanne between Great Britain and France, had decided today to accept the Anglo-French invitation to join, was conveyed by the German Charge d'Affaires, Count von Bernstorff, who this afternoon called at the Foreign Office here with the formal notification of his country's adherence.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 25 (AP) -- The Florida Racing Commission today granted State permits to six new horse tracks and fourteen new dog tracks to operate during the coming Winter. Three horse tracks and six dog tracks were operated in Florida last Winter and their licenses are still in effect.

BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, July 25 (AP). -- All available wrecking crews and equipment tonight were searching the wreckage of forty Big Four railroad freight cars believed to contain the bodies of between ten and fifteen train riders.

In a Lockheed-Orion monoplane, piloted by Major James Doolittle, transcontinental record-holder, Miss Anne Madison Washington, greatgreat-grandniece of the nation's first President, traversed yesterday, in less than seventeen hours, the route of all the travels her ancestor had crowded into a lifetime.

PARIS, July 25 -- The Bourse showed firmness today in very light trading. Speculators seemed to be holding off pending the results of the German elections, but the improvement in Wall Street at the end of last week and favorable news of today's opening of the London Stock Exchange stimulated the market here somewhat.

The catalogue of courses for the academic year 1932-33 of the New York University College of Fine Arts includes an announcement of a newly Instituted Division of Mural Painting. Classes will be held at the Midtown Centre, 250 East Forty-third Street.

Favorable weather in producing sections and further heavy liquidation, believed to represent government-financed cotton, more than offset a strong stock market yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved off 10 points, closing 1 to 3 points lower than on Saturday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 25 -- Albert Horton of Williams, Clark Andrews of Yale, and George Foster, former Yale player, were among the seeded stars to gain the third round of the men's singles in the Lake Placid Club's Invitation tennis tournament, which opened today.

President H.J. Burlington of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission has expressed the opinion that a salt-water fishing license fee of 50 cents or $1 would benefit the salt-water angler. He contends that those who paid such a fee would be glad to do so if they realized that it would mean the further developing and protecting of their sport.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 (AP) -- Warfare was suspended today by the Federal and Sao Paulo Armies in homage to Alberto Santos-Dumont, the South American "father of aviation," who died in Sao Paulo.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- A light run of hogs today resulted in active buying by packers and shippers, and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents. Receipts here were the smallest for a Monday since August, 1928, and cooler weather also had some effect. Today's top was 15 cents higher at $5.15, while the day's average was up 15 cents to $4.65.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 25 -- The "third degree," which resulted in the death of one of four young prisoners suspected of raiding the home of a detective's mother, brought the deputy chief and twelve members of the Nassau County Police into court here today to answer criminal charges.

LATONIA, Ky., July 25 (AP) -- Restored to good standing Saturday, the veteran jockey, Jake Heupel, made an auspicious return to the saddle today when he booted home Max Hirsch's At Top in the North Bend Purse at Latonia. Willie Pool, reinstated at the same time, finished second on Tea Tax in the opening dash.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 25 -- Frank M. Goeltz of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., provided the upset of today's play in the North Jersey men's singles tournament by eliminating Edward T. Tarangioli of New York, seeded No. 3, in three hard-fought sets, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25 -- The music lovers of the Summer colony filled the main gallery of the Art Association this evening to enjoy the recital for two pianos given by Jacques Fray and Mario Braggiotti. It was the annual benefit concert of the association.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., July 25 -- Plunging fully clothed into St. Regis Lake near here today, Walter Drurey, superintendent of Sunwood Farm, the Valley Force (Pa.) estate of Mr. and Mrs. F. Woodson Hancock. Jr., gave his life in an attempt to save Woodson, his employer's 11year-old son from drowning.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Faced by the need for an unemployment survey of the country in order to administer properly relief loans to States, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today "drafted" Fred C. Croxton, assistant director of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 Per cent for the best names. Friday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

BUFFALO N.Y., July 25 (AP) -- Hollyrood Dennis today won the 3-year-old trot, feature of the Grand Circuit card at Fort Erie and the performance advanced another notch the prospect for the Hollyrood Farm candidate capturing the $60,000 Hambletonian to be run at Goshen within a fortnight.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- John Marsch's fleet 2-year-old filly. Miss Bunting, today won the $2,500 added Lake Villa Claiming Stakes, featured race on a card of eight at Arlington Park. Miss Brilliant, from the stable of R. C. Schwarz, was second, and Mrs. M. B. Price's Gloritone was third.

DEAL, N.J., July 25 -- Miss Martha Parker of Westchester Hills, champion of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, and Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of the Old Country Club tied at 83 to share the first-round leadership in the fourth annual New Jersey shore championship, a fifty-four hole medal play tournament which began today.

The newly organized Joint committee on unemployment, of which Bishop Francis J. McConnell is chairman, opened its drive yesterday for a special session of the Legislature to provide funds for the immediate relief of 100,000 families in the State, who, according to the committee, are facing destitution.

WARSAW, July 18 (by mail) -- Several murders with accompanying press revelations have disclosed to the astonished inhabitants of Warsaw that for several years the merchants of certain markets have been under the terror of racketeers.

A survey of the estate of the late Florenz Ziegfeld, who died Friday night in Los Angeles, is now being made by J. Arthur Leve of the firm of Chadbourne, Stanchfield Levy. Meanwhile, Mr. Leve declined yesterday to reveal the value of the estate or the exact date when the will would be filed in the Surrogate's Court of Westchester County.

OTTAWA, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- Little effect upon the Winnipeg grain market is expected from the suspension of the Chicago Board of Trade, according to representatives of Canadian grain interests, who are acting as "observers" at the imperial economic conference.

THE king was in his counting-house, counting up the deficit. That was King George I of Greece and he was wondering how his country was to provide a fitting stadium for the first of the modern Olympic Games at Athens in 1896. In that crisis an Alexandrian merchant, M. Azeroff, reached into his pocket and hauled out 1,000,000 drachmas, saying in effect: "Build yourself a nice stadium and keep the change."
