MONTREAL, July 25 (Canadian Press) -- When Wolfgang von Gronau brings his seaplone down on the waters of the local harbor, he will be the first man ever to terminate a heavier-than-air Atlantic journey in this inland port. Only once has Montreal been an Atlantic air terminus, the R-100 having tied up here in the Summer of 1930.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25 -- High tribute to the United States for its efforts to help Nicaragua was paid by President Moncada at a banquet given on Saturday night by the President in honor of Major Gen. R. C. Berkley, who is in command of the United States Marines in this country.

A brief declaring that New York is entitled to the benefits of its natural advantages over other ports has been sent to the Interstate Commerce Commission by W.H. Chandler, manager of the traffic bureau of the Merchants' Association, in reply to the efforts of Southern ports seeking to level the geographic differences by changes in freight rates, according to a statement made by the association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- White House visits by two leading officials of railroads today led to the belief that immediate action may be taken toward carrying out part of the consolidation of four Eastern railway systems.

Although "nothing but a thorough overhauling of our economic processes will ultimately cure the present ills or prevent the future recurrence of them,'' music can do much to renew the courage of those suffering from the depression, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said yesterday in a dedicatory address at the first of a series of free midday organ concerts at Carnegie Hall.
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador, Juan Francisco de Cardenas, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Within the space of three business days, or since last Thursday, time money rates were again shaded 1/4, all maturities being quoted 1@1 1/4 per cent, with a small amount of ninety days' lending at the bid, lowest rate on record. The market was quiet, offerings being considerably in excess of the demand, which was light.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Executives of the Pennsylvania Railroad held no conferences today with the company's directors and it was said that none was contemplated in advance of tomorrow's meeting of railroad presidents in New York.

Mayor Walker's answer to the allegations advanced against him by Samuel Seabury and others, on which hangs the question of whether the city's Chief Executive shall be removed from office, is to be forwarded to the printer today and sent to Governor Roosevelt at Albany as soon as possible thereafter, it was announced at City Hall.

OTTAWA, July 25 -- British organizations, including the Federation of British Industries, are seeking through representatives attending the Imperial Economic Conference to extend film production within the empire, it was learned today.

DALLAS, Texas. July 25 (AP) -- "Ma" Ferguson, with her husband directing the show, will battle it out with Governor Ross S. Sterling in another campaign for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination -- equivalent to election in Texas.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 --The Olympic Village population climbed toward the l,500 mark today as nearly 300 athletes from eight nations checked in at the administratior building headquarters.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- That the Chicago Board of Trade may avoid the sixty days' suspension imposed Saturday by Attorney General Mitchell and Secretaries Hyde and Lament under the provisions of the grain futures act, was pointed out today In their reply to what they termed "misleading" statements by the president of the Board of Trade.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 26 -- Japan's "strong man" in Manchuria, Lieutenant General Shigeru Honjo, has been ordered to give up his command of the united armies there and return to Japan.

Operations of the National Public Service Corporation and its subsidiary, the Seaboard Public Service Company, two of the Samuel Insull Eastern properties petitioned into bankruptcy two weeks ago, will be continued for the time being under their present managements, according to a report submitted yesterday to Irwin Kurtz, Federal referee in bankruptcy by the Irving Trust Company, trustee.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP). -- Tens of thousands of fezzed Shriners today took possession of San Francisco -- a city decorated on all sides with flags and bunting, imitation obelisks and oriental rugs in honor of the convention and "national demonstration of optimism" here of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

James Roosevelt, son of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, denied yesterday that he had said that it was his father's intention, if elected, to call a special session of Congress to amend the Volstead act.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The invasion of Jehol by the Japanese has caused an increased determination to resist the Japanese occupation of Manchuria with all the resources of China, said Dr. Quo Tai-chi, the newly appointed Chinese Minister to Great Britain, who is here on his way to London.

An atmosphere of unmistakable cheerfulness pervaded financial markets as the week began. The forward movement in bond prices continued yesterday at an accelerated pace; the stock market followed suit, with many advances of 2 to 3 points, in which all of the railway shares participated.

Wholesale markets were buoyant yesterday, sharp price advances being registered in a number of leading staples, including rubber, hides, silk, sugar, cocoa, coffee andbutter. Moderately lower prices were found in the grains and cotton. Elsewhere the undertone was firm.

The formation of a cooperative selling agency for copper producers outside of the United States was seen yesterday as a probability in an announcement by interests close to the Anaconda Copper Mining Company that conversations recently had taken place between Anaconda officials and those of Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, which "have resulted in maintaining and strengthening the close and cordial relations existing between these two big producers."

BOSTON, July 25 -- Employment is on the increase in New England, especially in textiles and shoes, according to reports reaching the New England Council which indicate a return to work of at least 20,000 employes in the last few weeks.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25 -- Two distinct upsets in the women's singles marked the opening today of the forty-fifth annual invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, one of the East's net classics.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 25 unless specified:

A new insurance policy to cover shipments of currency, bullion and securities has been drawn up and put into effect by a pool of fifteen leading American stock fire insurance companies. The purpose is to cover these shipments on a moment's notice, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Continental Insurance Company.

HAVANA, July 25 (AP) -- Three well-known Cuban feminist leaders, Dr. Ofelia Dominguez, Dr. Berta Dardet and Senora Rosa Arredondo, were imprisoned today in connection with anti-government "terrorism" over the week-end.

Up the Weary Road. Commissioner MULROONEY and the heads of the police in counties adjacent to New York emphasize in their training schools politeness in dealing with the public. Yet every Monday morning, when New Yorkers gather to resume business after the week-end, tales of petty police tyranny are often to be Heard.

PARIS, July 25 -- Commenting this evening on Senator Borah's speech, Le Temps says that "his declarations indicate the existence on the other side of the Atlantic of an effort at adaptation to the political and economic necessities of the present time, if not of a new spirit."

Bond prices surged forward on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than a fortnight. Railroad bonds led the rise with gains of 1 to 9 points, with all other groups, industrial, utility, foriegn loans and United States Government issues averaging substantially higher for the day.

OTTAWA, July 25 -- The United States faces a loss of about 25 per cent of her anthracite coal shipments to Canada under a proposed arrangement between Canada and Great Britain by which the Dominion would increase her purchases of anthracite from the mother country.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- The fate of two United States explorers and their Canadian guide, missing in Labrador for about a year, was indicated today when a body was tentatively identified as that of Fred R. Connell Jr. of Glen Ridge, N.J.

CLARKSVILLE, Ark., July 25 (AP) -- Efforts of 500 union miners to halt non-union operations in the Johnson County coal fields caused disorder today that resulted in injuries to a mine boss and mobilization of National Guardsmen.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Timid longs were fair sellers of grain futures today as the result of the government committee deciding against the Chicago Board of Trade in the controversy regarding the right of the Farmers National Grain Corporation to membership in the clearing house.

BALTIMORE, July 25 (AP). -- With the bases full and one out in the ninth inning Pipgras went to the mound in the opening game of the series today to stop a Baltimore rally and give Jersey City a 5-to-2 victory.

PARIS, July 25 -- "I ask that I be killed" was the request of Paul Gorguloff, who went on trial today for the assassination last May of President Doumer. He said he wanted to "leave this earth," for which he predicted disaster.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- James Kees, 53 years old, was captured after a chase in South Philadelphia tonight and held on a warrant issued by Prosecutor T. Millett Hand of Cape May County, N.J., charging him with the murder of Mrs. Catharine Reynolds, who was found slain in her cottage at Strathmere, near Sea Island City, N.J., on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The committee of neutrals in the Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay refused to take the Bolivian note sent last night as a termination of the efforts for peace, and in a telegram today to La Paz asked Bolivia to make a declaration analogous to that of Paraguay, that she would not make an armed advance in the disputed region.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 25 -- The William K. Vanderbilt Museum, overlooking Northport Harbor, which houses thousands of specimen gathered in all parts of the world, will be opened to the public and to students on certain days each week, it was announced from an authoritative source today.

Max Thomashefsky, who was connected with the Yiddish stage in the United States for more than thirty-five years, died Sunday in the Israel-Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of three months. He was 60 years old. His funeral will be held at the Schwartz funeral parlors, 312 Fifth Street, at 2 P.M. today.

John C. Hegeman, president of the Hegeman-Harris Company, builders, who are erecting the new American Embassy in Paris, returned home on the Conte Grande yesterday after an extended tour through Europe.

Follow Thru. the 45-foot speed cruiser chartered by Charles (Buddy) Rogers, former motion picture actor, from Laurence Schwab, theatrical producer, was destroyed by fire yesterday while moored to a float near Duffy's Yacht Landing, Eightieth Street and the Hudson River.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Charged with invading a beach cottage on the Charles W. Maury estate in Noroton Saturday night to cook supper on an outing, Mrs. Stewart Scott, of 22 Benedict Place, Greenwich, wife of the former Yale football player and water poloist, and Miss Virginia Snyder of Purchase Street, Rye, N.Y., were taken in custody today by Darien (Conn.) police.

President Hoover, using the crisis growing out of the economic depression as his vehicle, might have become another Mussolini, in fact, "the world's greatest dictator" but "chose to remain the servant of his people," according to Dr. Walter Friar Dexter, president of Whittier College, who makes this assertion in a book entitled, "Herbert Hoover and American Individualism," which will be published today by the Macmillan Company.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25 -- A group of prominent women in the Summer colony, headed by Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien, will serve on the patroness committee of the eleventh annual Boys' Club dinner dance to aid the William CareyCamp In Jamesport, L.I.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25 -- Mickey Walker, Rumson, made short work of Salvatore Ruggirello, tall and lean Italian, at Dreamland Park tonight, knocking him out in 1:10 1/2 of the first round of a scheduled ten.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every week we hear or read of newproposals to relieve the effect of the depression by government expenditures in some form. Many of these proposals are advocated by persons of such intelligence and apparent understanding and responsibility as to give pause to those citizens who would otherwise raise their voices in protest.

BERLIN, July 25 (AP). -- Chancellor von Papen and two of his Cabinet colleagues -- Baron von Gayl, Minister of the Interior, and General von Schleicher, Defense Minister -- were present today at a meeting of the Reichstag Committee on Safeffuarding the people's Rights.

The slightly musty parable of the postman who went hiking an his holiday is pleasantly confirmed by the current show at the Art Students' League. The exhibition consists of work by students in the Summer school, done in off hours and without benefit of faculty criticism.

HORNELL, N.Y., july 25 (AP). -- A bullet hole through a clergyman's hat today added another chapter to the story of the minister's old and isolated hilltop home. Several other tenants have fled from the dwelling in terror, of what State troopers call a "phantom rifleman."

Pronounced strength, in the share market yesterday reflected again the latest revival of confidence in Wall Street. There may have been other explanations for the extension of the advance on the Stock Exchange, but the general impression was that the upturn was prompted by interests that are speculating heavily on an early reversal in market trend.

EUREKA, Cal., July 25 (AP) -- The bodies of four men and two women were recovered and those of three boys sought today as the victims of a motorboat upset at the mouth of Eel River, south of here, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On July 21 you published a letter signed by Robert Chipman Hull which attributes to an employe of the Bureau of Forest Nurseries of the Conservation Department certain statements which reflect upon the efficiency and competency with which this bureau, and the department are administered.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A group of about 150 radical members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force engaged in a series of street fights with metropolitan police and plain-clothes detectives today and for almost an hour kept downtown Washington in turmoil.

The Insurance Brokers' Association of New York in a letter sent to members asserted that it is fighting the proposal of stock casualty insurance companies to put into effect a reduction in compensation commissions. The letter said:

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Funds reverting to the Treasury through the 20 per Cent voluntary salary cut for President Hoover and the 15 per cent reduction for Cabinet officers will go into the general fund and will be available for any governmental purpose, it was stated at the Treasury today.

Prince Friedrich August of Prussia, fourth son of the former Crown Prince of Germany, a fair-haired young man, 21 years old; arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to "see America." He was met by his brother, Prince Louis Ferdinand, 24 years old, taller and dark, who has been working in the automobile business in Detroit.
The provisions of the Wagner relief program recently enacted by Congress and approved by President Hoover were explained by Senator Wagner last night in an address over radio station WOR.

Four hold-up men, one wearing the uniform of a New York City policeman, halted an armored truck belonging to P. Lorillard Co. at Second Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. While three of the bandits compelled the driver and his helper to get into an automobile the other robber drove off with the truck, which contained $25,000 worth of cigarettes being taken to a Brooklyn pier for shipment to Los Angeles.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 25 -- With the largest entry in history, the annual New Jersey centre championship tennis tournaments for juniors and boys started today on the courts of the Montclair A.C.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The German Government has notified the British and French Governments it is willing to take part in the open interchange of views on European questions mentioned in the English and French declarations of July 13. Germany thereby officially joins the consultative pact concluded by Great Britain and Franca during the Lausanne conference.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 25 -- Word from Lunenburg, N.S. today that Captain Angus Walters was eager to receive a challenge to the schooner Bluenose's championship of the North Atlantic tonight brought a reply from Captain Ben Pine of the Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud that he was just as eager to issue the challenge.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25. -- The vast cold silence of the polar regions has settled over Southwestern Argentina, which has been buried under a blanket of three and four feet of snow by one of the heaviest snowfalls in many years, putting an end to all activities and enforcing idleness and hunger.

Refusing to grant a delay so that American creditors might start injunction proceedings, Federal Judge Mack ruled yesterday in favor of immediate payment to two Swedish banks of $1,005,000, interest due on $33,500,000 in German bonds owned by the Kreuger Toll Company that had been pledged with the institutions as collateral.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Five thousand employes of the Federal Department of Labor were notified today that for the next forty-eight weeks they will work only five days a week.

Another demonstration that this is a dangerous year for the "ins" has been given by the Democrats of Texas. The probability now is that Governor STERLING will maintain his poor second place to Mrs. FERGUSON in Saturday's primary, and that these two, as in 1930, will contest in the run-off for the nomination for Governor.

Nine persons were formally recognized as being within the fifth degree of kinship to Ella V. von E. Wendel, the last of her line and heir to the Wendel millions, by the executors of her estate, at a hearing yesterday before Surrogate James A. Foley for the purpose of deciding the status of twenty-nine of the 1,622 persona who have laid claim to the estate.

TOKYO, July 25 -- Having finished a book in which he expounds his principles, the leader of the Farmers' Death Band, which attacked the Tokyo power stations while naval officers and military cadets were assassinating Premier Inukai on May 15, surrendered to the Japanese gendarmerie at Harbin yesterday and is being brought to Tokyo by air today.

LONDON, July 25 (Canadian Press) -- Newspapers of Great Britain are debating the efficiency of Stanley Baldwin's work at Ottawa, following Lord Beaverbrook's attack on the leader of the British delegation in The Sunday Express.
ALBANY, July 25 -- A ninth reprieve for Benjamin (Cockeye Benny) Gordon was granted today by Governor Roosevelt.

Following complaints that persons in easy circumstances were drawing from $10 to $20 weekly from the payroll of the emergency unemployment relief funds through the solicitude of the Brooklyn Democratic organization, the Emergency Work and Relief Administration dropped four of those specifically named yesterday, according to Lawson Purdy, chairman of the administration.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The Boerse began the week with a decided upward movement, due largely to an optimistic interpretation of the political outlook at home, which explains the return of the public as buyers. The verdict of the Supreme Court in declining to grant an injunction in Prussia, the absence of disturbances yesterday and Senator Borah's speech on war debts combined to bring back investors who bought briskly.

LONDON, July 18 -- Sufficient time baa now elapsed to enable one to gauge the effects on British public opinion of President Hoover's naval disarmament proposals. While there is general agreement as to the sincerity and boldness of the American plan, it is felt to be open to grave objections.

Nobody imagines that, as a sequel to the Federal Commission's notice of sixty-days' suspension after Aug. 8, the wheat market on the Chicago Board of Trade will actually be closed down. It is, in effect, a manoeuvre to assert and emphasize the "trading privileges" of the Farm Board's affiliates.

OTTAWA, July 25 -- The heads of the delegations of the nine British countries represented at the Imperial Economic Conference began their real working sessions today without an agreed-upon plan of procedure. There is the broad notion that they have come to Canada to help each other out of their common trade depression, but that is no plan.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 25 -- Jack Shaw and Mike Izzo, amateur and professional combination from the Plandome Golf Club, tied with Henry Picoli and Jimmy Hines of the Hempstead Country Club for the honors in the amateur-pro tournament held at the Garden City Country Club today as a prelude to the annual Long Island open championship, which starts tomorrow.

LONDON, July 25 -- The feature of the stock markets today was renewed demand for British Government funds. Strong buying caused the 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan to advance beyond u100 for the first time in history. The 5 per cent war loan also was strong.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 25 -- Favorites in both divisions came through without difficulty as the New York State junior and boys' clay-court tennis championships opened today, with the junior tournament reaching the third round and the boys' meet going into the semifinals.
LONDON, July 25 -- More than L1,000,000,000 of Britain's 5 per cent war loan had been converted to 3 1/2 per cent by the middle of last week, it was announced officially today.

According to an Associated Press dispatch from Poona, Sir TEJ BAHADUR SAPRU, who resigned from the Consultative Committee, and a colleague are at Poona, where Mr. GANDHI has been imprisoned since January for giving the All-India Nationalist Congress the signal for another campaign of civil disobedience.

OTTAWA, July 25 -- A drive to reduce the competitive position in the British Empire of more than 1,000 United States branch plants in Canada is under way at the Imperial Economic Conference here, it was disclosed today.

PARIS, July 26. -- The Paris Bourse reacted favorably today to Wall Street's strong showing yesterday, stocks rising all along the line. It is felt in financial circles here that the slow rise on the New York Stock Exchange is of great importance. Senator Borah's radio address also is favorably received here as testifying to a weakened opposition against a new war debt settlement, and it helped to improve the atmosphere on the Bourse.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 26 (AP). -- Selection of riders and horses for the United States Olympic equestrian team was announced tonight by Colonel C. L. Scott, manager of the Army's equestrian squad.

LAKE PLACID CLUB, N.Y., July 26. -- Clark Andrews of New York will play Hobey Hyde of Hartford and Albert Horton of Williams will meet J. R. Gow of Hartford tomorrow morning in the semi-finals of Lake Placid Club's invitation tennis tournament by virtue of their respective victories today over Gordon Tweedy of New Haven, George Foster of Bridgeport, Erdman Harris of New York and Charlie Lockhart of Pittsburgh.

OTTAWA, July 26. -- There are many sensational rumors about the corridors of the Chateau Laurier tonight to the effect that Stanley Baldwin, leader of the British delegation, is to make a startling statement tomorrow at the Imperial Economic Conference.

Smarting under the derision sometimes directed at the present drug store, with its soda fountain, book shelves, toys and other miscellaneous merchandise, a group of pharmacists met yesterday afternoon and organized the League of Registered Pharmacists, through which they hope to restore the profession to its former dignity.

The forty-story Lefcourt National Building, occupying the former site of Temple Emanu-El on the northeast corner of Forty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, was put into foreclosure yesterday in a suit by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for non-payment of two mortgages aggregating $6,000,000, interest of $116,000 due since last November, and city taxes for the first half of 1932, amounting to $130,000.
MOSCOW, July 26. -- Two Soviet icebreakers steamed out of Archangel today, bound on perilous explorations in the Arctic wastes to fulfill the Soviet's role in the second international polar year.

The mixed Summer show which opened at "Walter P. Chrysler Jr.'s Cheshire Gallery on Monday can only be described as trivial. Miron Sokole, Christopher Clark and Sterling Blazy must be excepted from this blanket indictment (they are serious painters with an obvious interest in their craft), but the exhibition as a whole is pervaded by that specious pseudo-refinement which is the pernicious anemia of art.

VIENNA, July 26. -- General Vladimir Glesl, former Austra-Hungarian Minister to Serbia, revealed today the dramatic story of Europe's last hours of the "Golden Age," ended by General Giesl's rejection at Belgrade of Serbia's reply to the Austrian ultimatum.

In an economic sense Cuba has her back against the wall. She can no longer count upon enormous profits from the production of sugar. Restriction of that crop is now the policy. Tobacco is another crop that is not doing so well as in the old days. In the news recently there have been items indicating that Cuba has decided to make a campaign of self-help.

NEWARK, N. J., July 26. -- A single by Johnny Neun with, the bases full enabled the Newark Bears to defeat the Reading Keys this afternoon in the tenth inning by a score of 3 to 2. It was Newark's sixth consecutive victory.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Receipts of hogs today, which were well above expectations, were the largest here for a Tuesday with one exception since May 10. Prices dropped 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight, with Monday's advances erased. Packing sows, which comprised about half of the receipts, showed the most loss.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Former Senator Atlee Pomerene of Ohio was appointed by President Hoover today as one of the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the President announced, will succced Eugene Meyer as chairman of the board which manages the affairs of the big government corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The death of Caleb Powers, recalled to South Trimble, Clerk of the House of Representatives, vivid memories of the stormy period following the assassination of William Goebel.
BUENOS AIRES, July 26. -- The Argentine Foreign Office has begun diplomatic conversations with Brazil, Chile and Peru to unite them in efforts to prevent war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

Adoption of a universal agreement by the nations of the world to eliminate double taxation is needed if a "crushing burden" is not to be imposed on international commerce, Mitchell B. Carroll, director of the study of the allocation of profits for the Fiscal Committee of the League of Nations, declared yesterday afternoon in a symposium on taxation law conducted by the Summer session of the Law School of Columbia University.

OTTAWA, July 26. -- Demands for a more elastic formula to govern the amount of empire labor and material which must be in manufactured articles to entitle them to preferential tariff rates within the empire were injected suddenly into the meeting of the Committee on Promotion of Trade within the Empire at the Economic Conference today.

ALBANY, July 26. -- Mayor James J. Walker of New York telegraphed Governor Roosevelt today that his reply to the charges against him would be in the Governor's hands within a few days, thus probably forestalling a demand by the State Executive that the Mayor speed up his answer.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

RUMSON, N. J., July 26. -- The United States Army polo team, winner of the national junior championship, met defeat today at the hands of the Austin quartet in the final match of the Herbert Memorial Cup handicap tournament, 11 to 7.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "Railway Consolidation" you say, "It is only after, eighteen months' delay that the commission has brought itself into general agreement with the plan."

GENEVA, July 26. -- Informed circles here expect the report of the League of Nations Far Eastern Inquiry Commission to be of such a nature that it will be hard for Japan to accept; and indications are that it will lead to a breach between Japan and the League.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., July 26. -- You remember during the war when we would read that the Liberty bond issue had been over-subscribed. Well, the other day Congress voted that they was going to loan folks something like $2,000,000,000, well you talk about a thing being "oversubscribed," why the whole issue was spoken for before sundown.

MONTREAL, July 26. -- At the adjourned meeting here today of holders of first mortgage twenty-five-year sinking fund gold bonds of Fraser Companies, Ltd., of which about $8,202,000 is outstanding, the plan of reorganization, as amended, was approved. At a recent meeting of holders of 6 per cent notes, certain amendments to the original plan were submitted and adopted, and as a result two motions, one for the amendments and one.

Bishop Manning was assailed yesterday by Monroe Douglas Robinson, nephew of the late Theodore Roosevelt, in a letter he sent to the Bishop after reading the Biahop's public approval of the action of the vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie withdrawing the use of the church from the body-and-soul clinic.

The effectiveness of the Lausanne conference on German reparations could be gravely impaired, thereby causing great damage to the interests of the American people, if this country followed a course similar to the one followed by the French Government in 1931 after President Hoover announced his proposal for a moratorium, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said yesterday upon his return to the United States from his annual visit to Europe.
With her pennants flying from stem to stern, and all harbor craft signaling a noisy welcome, the new United States liner Manhattan arrived yesterday from sea trials off the Atlantic Coast.

Details of the unusual mechanism and new devices to be used to achieve spectacular effects in the two theatres under construction in the Radio City section of Rockefeller Center were revealed yesterday by the Rockefeller interests with the announcement of the awarding of contracts for the stage equipment to Peter Clark, Inc., of New York.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 26 (AP). -- A decision, upholding the legality of the State's pari-mutuel law which permits betting "while the sun shines" was handed down today by the Illinois Supreme Court. The day-light provision of the act was aimed at curbing dog-racing wagering, without interfering with horse-race betting.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP). -- Pat Malone started the second Eastern invasion of the Chicago Cubs today by holding the Boston Braves to five hits and giving his team a 7-to-2 victory. It was his tenth victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- An opinion that the "mutual advantages" of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty with Canada were now being recognized in New York State was expressed by former Senator Allen of Kansas during a call on President Hoover today.

THERE was some surprise when the British Olympic contingent checked in at Los Angeles. They had no field men with them. Not a single hammer thrower or "pole jumper," as they still call them in jolly old England. It will make no difference in the results at Los Angeles, for the British have few field men who could even put up a brisk fight for a snappy third place in Olympic competition.

An intensive movement to educate commercial, agricultural and labor interests in this country, as well as the government itself, concerning the economic problems which have tended to destroy international trade, is being considered by several business associations, including the American Manufacturers Export Association, the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce and the World Trade League, it was announced yesterday by James D. Mooney, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, in charge of overseas operations.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Applications from banks for authority to issue new national bank notes under the Glass-Borah amendment to the home-loan bank bill, by which national bank currency may be expanded $995,000,000, continued to flood Controller Pole's office today, with every indication of a heavy issue of this type of paper currency.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26. -- The brilliant victory of Manuel Alonso over the veteran R. Norris Williams 2d stood out prominently among today's results in the forty-fifth annual invitation tennis tourney of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricked Club, as play progressed to the quarter-finals in the men's and women's singles and both those divisions were cleared of foreign invading stars.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 26. -- Denying that the State socialism of Chile was in any way connected with, communism or bolshevism, the Central Bank issued today a report asserting that, "allowing for a certain amount of uncertainty concerning the manner in which the government intends to intervene in regulating economic activities, the business situation, in general does not seem to have been seriously affected by the recent revolutionary changes."

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26. -- Formation of the Princeton Sports Managers' Club, with a membership of the twenty-three undergraduate managers of Princeton athletic teams and the graduate manager of athletics was approved at a recent meeting of the board of athletic control of Princeton University, it was announced today.

New York City's assessed valuations, which have teen climbing steadily year by year, will be reduced drastically, probably to the extent of $1,500,000,000 or more, to ease the burden on the city's taxpayers, it was said in authoritative quarters yesterday.

Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd was unanimously elected temporary chairman of the National Economy League when it was organized yesterday, with the endorsement of President Hoover and Governor Roosevelt. The league will fight governmental extravagance, beginning with the elimination of the annual payment of approximately $450,000,000 to Spanish-American and World War veterans who suffered no disability in service.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of July 1, 1932, shows the following principal changes during June. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

WILLIAM GREEN of the American Federation of Labor should have thought twice before he raised the cry of "gag rule" against the recent action of the United States Civil Service Commission forbidding electioneering by or in behalf of government employes in the classified service.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 26. -- State troopers halted a gold rush on State property here today, but not until treasure-seekers had carried away with them gold and silver coins of an estimated value of $1,000 to $3,000.

Continued case in time money, some trades in which were made at 1 per cent for ninety days, as on Monday, represented the only development of interest in the day's market. Other dates were bid 1, offered at 1 1/4, but there were no takers. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 per cent, outside trades at 1, and Federals at 1/8.

Renting of bouses in Manhattan was reported on a wider scale yesterday. Although confined largely to the west side, this type of trading showed a noticeable improvement over the last few weeks, when residential leasing was limited almost entirely to outlying suburban areas.
Daniel Frohman and William Muldoon sat yesterday in Philadelphia Jack O'Brien's gymnasium and spoke of the past.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is pretty difficult to see why anybody in the State of New York, outside of the immediate territory where the construction money will be spent, should favor the creation of a 27-foot waterway in the St. Lawrence River.

The daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,205,850 barrels, compared with 2,154,850 in the preceding week, an increase of 51,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The most important changes included increases of 47,550 and 8,100 barrels, respectively, in the average daily outputs of Oklahoma and East Texas.

MONTREAL, July 26. -- Captain Wolfgang von Gronau, accompanied by his co-pilot, a wireless operator and a mechanic, arrived here tonight at 7:06, E. S. T., aboard his Dornier-Wahl flying boat, completing his third transatlantic flight. He intends to remain two days in Montreal, the first being spent in rest and the next day in overhauling his machine.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 26. -- The trials of 102 Finnish Fascists, members ot the Lapuan organization -- a nation-wide anti-Communistic association-who are charged with instigating and commanding the Mantsala revolt in March, which aimed at the overthrow of the present Cabinet, started today in Abo.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 26 (AP). -- Playing in a steady rain from the fourth, inning, the Buffalo Bisons finally got an 8-to-4 decision over the Toronto Maple Leafs in eight innings today. With three Toronto runners home, men on second and third and two out a deluge stopped the game in the ninth.
NEWPORT, July. 26. -- The fourth week of the Casino opened tonight when the Casino Players presented for the first time "Hobson's Choice" before a large audience.

The grains and cotton, which had been moderately lower on Monday, turned sharply higher yesterday. Coffee, sugar, rubber, hides and butter were others to show improvement. Firmness pervaded other sections of the wholesale markets.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 26. -- The final bridge tournament of a series for the benefit of the Southampton unemployment fund was held tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Luclen Hamilton Tyng. Later in the evening supper was served.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement of the railroads is doubtless of great interest to millions throughout the country. As one of these millions, it appears to me that one subject has not been properly considered in the railroads' efforts to regain, and to increase, the patronage of the public at large-speed.

KIEL, Germany, Wednesday, July 27 (AP). -- Captain Mueller of the rescue steamer Therese Russ reported when he put in here early today that most of the German naval cadets of the ill-fated training ship Niobe were trapped at their desks at a between-the-decks classroom and went down in a twinkling.

In advance of the dividend meeting of the United States Steel Corporation, the stock market showed little animation yesterday. Transactions on the Stock Exchange involved a total of about 1,500,000 shares, or a trifle fewer than on the day before.

There was sure to be a wealth of proposals at the Ottawa Conference. Union upon them will be hard to attain. The United States, having slammed the door in Canada's face, can't complain of any Canadian returns of the courtesy. Canada, too, is looking out for Number One.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26. -- Arthur Sellers, chief deputy coroner of Philadelphia County and Republican nominee for Congress in the Fourth Pennsylvania District, stood before a mirror in his home here this afternoon and shot himself through the heart.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps and Miss Barbara Phipps will sail tonight on the Bremen and will go to London. After a visit there with the Countess of Granard, sister of Mrs. Phipps, they will go to Scotland for the shooting season.

DALLAS, Texas, July 26 (AP). -- Mrs. Miriam A. (Ma) Ferguson continued to dominate the struggle for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination today as late returns from Saturday's primary increased her lead over Governor R. S. Sterling, running for re-election, to 93,000 votes.

LONDON, July 26. -- Professor Elliot Smith, commenting on the discovery of a prehistoric skull in South Africa, said today the information was not definite enough to form a confident opinion on the precise significance of the discovery, although it suggested the possibility that another skull of Rhodesian man had been found.

A general stoppage of all workers in the cloak and suit industry will begin at 10 o'clock this morning, it was announced last night by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union. Arrangements for the stoppage were concluded last night at a meeting held in Beethoven Hall.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP). -- Bombarding Carroll for eight runs in the first two innings, the Phillies defeated the Cincinnati Reds today. 10 to 5.

Retail and manufacturing failures were lower for the week ended July 21, according to Bradstreet's, while increases were shown in the wholesale and jobbing and commercial service lines. Banking and financial failures were unchanged from the preceding week.
Discussing the possibilities of the hunting season in his section of New Brunswick, C. T. Summerson writes from Tabusintac that the black duck should be plentiful this Fall.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP). -- Fezzed, uniformed Shriners' painted the town red, yellow, green and purple in opening their fifty-eighth annual convention here today.

NORFOLK, Va., July 26 (AP). -- A young woman who booked passage on the Old Dominion steamer George Washington under the name of "Constance Fox" and who disappeared from the vessel last night while on her way from New York to Norfolk, phoned Mrs. J. Henry Callister in Brooklyn, according to the police here.

OTTAWA, July 26. -- Estimates obtained on the basis of commodities involved in negotiations under way at the Imperial Economic Conference here indicated today that the principal stake of the United States in the conference is about $50,000,000 of her normal trade with Canada.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- When President Hoover delivers in Constitution Hall his speech of acceptance at 8:30 o'clock on the evening of Aug. 11, the anniversary of the notification of his nomination in 1928, it will be heard throughout the country over two radio hook-ups and also will be transmitted to the insular possessions and around the world through a short-wave broadcast.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Issues of the Democratic campaign and questions of organization were discussed today by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, with a group of Senators and House members. The consensus of opinion expressed was that economic issues should be brought prominently to the front and that the Hoover Administration should be held responsible for present conditions and attacked as failing to provide legislation to solve the economic problems.

PLATTSBURG, N. Y., July 26. -- Company H of the C. M. T. Camp tied up the series being played to determine the baseball championship of the camp this afternoon by defeating Company A by a score of 13 to 4.

The new theatrical producing firm of Abbott-Dunning, Inc., the officials of which are George Abbott, Philip Dunning and Joseph P. Bickerton Jr., will present its first attraction, tentatively called "Exit," at the Morosco Theatre on Sept. 19. Before coming to Broadway the play will have a week's engagement in Newark.

Reports from a number of the larger cities, published on Monday in THE TIMES, show that salary reductions, similar to those proposed by Mayor WALKER, have been the rule in 1932. In Chicago the municipal government has trimmed its payroll by an estimated $15,000,000.

It is one thing to be the boss of a State, but quite another to be undisputed boss. Every day this difference is borne in on HUEY P. LONG. Hardly has he finished a fight than it is time to begin another. A few weeks ago he was grappling with insurgents in the Legislature.
OTTAWA, July 26. -- The imperial economic conference at Ottawa is evidently determined to feel its way very slowly and carefully before taking any drastic action, concerning Russia.

James Butler scored his eighth victory of the Empire City meeting, making more secure his place as the session's leading money-winner, when his Awake got home first in the featured consolation claiming handicap yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 26. -- Another sweep for favorites in both divisions marked the second day's play in the New York State junior and boys' tennis championships today, with both divisions reaching the semi-final round of singles and doubles.

LONDON, July 26. -- The stock markets were cheerful today. Purchasing of the war loan for conversion purposes continued, the price rising above u102. The 3 1/2 per cent conversion loan also was again popular.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 26. -- Thwarted in his attempt to capture the metropolitan open title by Olin Dutra's spectacular finish, Walter Kozak set out in the Long Island open championship today firmly resolved to set such a blistering pace as to insure himself against a similar happening.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- The wheat market was more active today than in some time, and prices advanced sharply under improved Eastern, foreign and local buying. No material selling pressure developed, and what the trade has regarded as Federal Farm Board selling was lacking.

HAVANA, July 26. -- Three members of an armed band were killed early this morning near Colon, Matanzas Province, in a gun battle with a squadron of soldiers sent out to capture them, according to General Herrera, chief of staff of the Cuban Army.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 26. -- Darkness with only a waning moon making a pattern of iron bars on the floor of my cell. Quiet broken only by a cough or the sound of a fellowprisoner twisting in her narrow bed. My next door neighbor a woman of the streets and in the cell opposite me a sad young girl found guilty of keeping a speakeasy.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- With Jockey P. Remillard doing the riding, J. W. Y. Martin's Dark Hope staged a thrilling finish to win the Glencoe Stakes, $2,500 added feature, at Arlington Park today.

OTTAWA, July 26. -- The committee on currency questions of the Imperial Economic Conference organized today by the significant election of H. H. Stevens, Canadian Minister of Trade and Commerce, as its chairman. Mr. Stevens is the outstanding advocate of the remonetization of silver in the Ottawa Government.

Events of the past few days have cleared the way for an expression of the will of the German people in the election of the new Reichstag next Sunday. Most of the wild rumors set afloat last week have got their quietus. There is to be no restoration of the monarchy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is announced by the Port of New York Authority that it is actively seeking a loan under the recently enacted Federal relief bill to carry on the construction of the proposed New Jersey-midtown vehicular tunnel.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26. -- The body of Mrs. Muriel Thoma of Berkeley was found today in Pyramid Lake, Nev., a few hours after an Indian had recovered the body of Dr. Roger M. Jones, her fiance and formerly Associate Professor of Greek at the University of California, but now of Baltimore.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 26 (AP). -- The Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company and its receivers today filed an answer in Chancery Court to the foreclosure suit begun recently by the Peoples-Pittsburgh Trust Company of Pittsburgh.

LONDON, July 26. -- Leaders in the Church of England, the free churches and Judaism in England have rejected the appeal of George Lansbury, the leader of the Parliamentary Labor party, to intervene or mediate in the Anglo-Irish dispute.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 26 (Canadian Press). -- A syndicate of Canadian banks tonight moved to guard this city from further damage at the hands of its unemployed.

BERLIN, July 26. -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt von Schleicher, Minister of Defense, announced tonight in a talk over a nation-wide radio hook-up that the German Government was absolutely determined to reorganize the army so as to obtain a certain degree of security, which he said Germany lacked more than any other nation in Europe.

KIEL, Germany, July 26. -- The sailing vessel Niobe, training ship of the German Navy, struck this afternoon by a sudden gale in the Baltic Sea off the island of Fehmarn, turned over and sank within a few minutes.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 26. -- Chief of Police Morris Grossman was summarily dismissed today by Mayor Frank Frankel for alleged failure to obtain evidence against gambling on the Boardwalk. He had been chief since Jan. 1, 1930.
WASHINGTON, July 26. -- After twenty-two years of service in the House, Representative John Q. Tilson of Connecticut, former Republican floor leader, has decided to resign.

PARIS, July 26. -- The heavy, muffled voice of Paul Gorguloff, on trial for the assassination of President Doumer, kept interrupting witnesses today as one after another, half a dozen alienists described his mental state. Yesterday Gorguloff had a full opportunity to tell his own story and show what kind of a man he was.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The administration, according to all indications today, plans to let the issue raised by Senator Borah of debt revision, conditional upon a general European reorganization, rest for the present, and make no new move in the situation.

The ten-year expansion program of the Boy Scouts of America has been endorsed by President Hoover in a letter made public yesterday by Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive. The letter, sent to Walter W. Head, president of the Boy Scouts of America, expresses the President's gratification at the acceptance of his challenge to the Scouts two years ago.
National Economy League. Organization of the National Economy League was completed yesterday, with Admiral BYRD as chairman and a distinguished group of members on the advisory council.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 26. -- Miss Martha Parker of Westchester Hills assumed a five-stroke lead in the women's New Jersey shore golf championship today, virtually assuring her the title which Miss Helen Hicks failed to defend.

Angelo De Dominico, a 15-year-old Brooklyn baker's apprentice, was shot and wounded, probably fatally, yesterday afternoon while asleep in his home at 6,814 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn. His assailant, who was not identified, escaped.
TOKYO, July 26. -- Two hundred farmers and fishermen and seventy small industrialists appeared at Premier Saito's residence today and demanded interviews on farm relief.

Three men, one of them Tony Centanni, 18 years old, of 231 Mill Street, Paterson, were held without bail for a further hearing on July 29 on homicide charges in connection with the death of Tony's father, Alphonse, 49, in his home at 37-23 Thirteenth Street, Long Island City, Queens, when they were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Dreyer in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON. July 26 (AP). -- In his statement in The Congressional Record revealing his purpose to resign from Congress, Representative Tilson said the "legitimate necessary expenses" of a member of Congress required his entire salary and made it impracticable to lay aside anything for his family.
SHANGHAI, July 26. -- A prospect of default on Chinese Government debt payments was revealed in a statement today by T. V. Soong, the Minister of Finance.
Evidence of the continued demand for small homes on Long Island was given yesterday in reports from brokers of the purchase of sites in Flushing and in Suffolk County for residential development.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate voted $3,OOO,000 yesterday for home and work relief for August and withheld action on an appropriation for September on the ground that it could not tell what the city's financial condition might permit in another month.

The question of arbitration in the working contractual dispute between Typographical Union 6 and the Publishers' Association of New York City is to be submitted to a referendum of the entire membership of the union, it was announced at 1:30 this morning following a joint meeting of the union's scale conference committee and executive committee.

JACKSON, Mich., July 26. -- The Rev. A. G. Larkey, assistant chaplain at Michigan State prison for four years, was discharged today by Warden Harry H. Jackson following the opening of an investigation into charges that he had appropriated to his own use the funds of prison inmates.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company ended its fiscal year on June 30 with a deficit of $831,749 before any deduction for the full 5 per cent rental on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee stock, which is payable only if earned, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday.

If the city and State must curtail the Queens trunk highway system as originally projected, they should build one or two of the three major roads in their entirety rather than partly complete both, John J. Sullivan, Commissioner of City Planning, said yesterday in criticizing the highway plans offered by Arthur W. Brandt, State Commissioner of Highways, and Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 26. -- Mark Stuart, young Fox Hills star, captured the premier honors today in a one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association, with a 75 over the Rockville Country Club course, leading a field of 110 players.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 26. -- A goal by William Ziegler Jr. on a shot from the side enabled the Great Island polo team to defeat the Princemere quartet, 9 to 8, today in a hard-fought contest on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

ALBANY, July 26. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman prepared today to begin his three-day State inspection tour tomorrow in .a drive to win the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination. At the same time Edward J. O'Connell, Albany County chairman, wrote to State and National Chairman James A. Farley that Mayor John Boyd Thacher of Albany was formally a candidate for Governor and would not accept a lesser place on the ticket.

Members of the Fire Department are being coerced into agreeing to Mayor Walker's pay cut proposal. Deputy Controlled Frank J. Prial charged yesterday. Mr. Prial, who is editor of The Chief, civil service employes' newspaper, expressed his opposition to the cut even before it was formally made by the Mayor in his radio address last Friday night.

The Runnymede Realty Corp., Max Levine, president, gave a mortgage for 56,000 to George H. Furman to be paid oft by Jan. 15 next, on 20-24 Division St., subordinate to first mortgages aggregating 550,000.

Whether because the recent pace of recovery was deemed somewhat too rapid, or because of doubt concerning the Steel Corporation's quarterly earnings and the directors' action on the company's preferred shares, the general recovery in stocks halted yesterday.

A new literary publication to be devoted in the main to chronicling the affairs of the 15,000 employes of the Department of Sanitation, the brain child of Dr. William Sehroeder Jr., chairman of the department will begin publication in September, if all goes well; or, to be more exact, if enough of the employes subscribe to it at $1 a year.

Thomas Patrick Morris, A thin, 52-year-old Scotsman, suffering from angina pectoris, told Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday a story which, if accepted, will bring back to life the wealthy Wendel family, supposed to have become extinct with the death of Miss Ella Virginia von E. Wendel on March 13, 1931.

ALBANY, N. Y., July 26. -- Governor Roosevelt received assurances of his strength in the "West as he prepared today for an impromptu conference tomorrow to aid in solidifying support in the industrial East.
LOS ANGELES, July 26 (AP). -- Justis F. Craemer of Orange Cal., was elected president of the National Editorial Association today.

FORT ERIE, Ont., July 26 (AP. -- Rain halted Grand Circuit racing ten day after the first heat in the fifth event. The 2:13 trot and a trotting event for 3-year-olds were unfinished and were added to the closing day's card tomorrow.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 26. -- On the eve of his eightieth birthday, George Foster Peabody philanthropist, educator and public servant, walked through the grounds of his Saratoga Springs estate, Yaddo, and reaffirmed his belief in the fundamental principles of democracy.

The first day of the Western invasion at Ebbets Field yesterday was a pronounced success for the Dodgers. While 10,000 fans cheered, the Carey athletes staged uprisings in both games to come from tehind and win. They took the opener, 12 to 6, and the nightcap by the closer margin of 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- In an effort to prevent the evacuation of about 3,000 veterans from government property on lower Pennsylvania Avenue near the Capitol, Walter W. Waters, commander-in-chief of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, pleaded long but in vain tonight with Secretary Hurley and General Douglas Mac Arthur, Chief of Staff.

Complete texts of the orders handed down recently by the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin and an explanatory letter of David E. Lilienthal, one of the members of the commission, indicate that preliminary studies were conducted in the case of each of the seven companies which the commission ordered not to pay any common dividends until the laws of the State had been complied with.

Discovery of a $650,000 defalcation by an employe was announced yesterday by J. S. Bache Co., brokers of 42 Broadway, one of the country's largest wire houses. The theft, one of the largest in the brokerage field in recent years, is substantially covered by insurance, it was said.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- The Farmmers National Grain Corporation, sponsored by the Farm Board, reported today a "substantial increase" in its trade during the year ended July 1. The increase, the annual report disclosed, was particularly noticeable in the cooperative's direct marketing program.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 26. -- While attorneys for the thirteen policemen indicted in connection with the death of Hyman Stark were pushing plans for their defense. District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards announced that further charges against the defendants would be considered by the Nassau County grand jury on Friday.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A new and intensified nation-wide campaign to effect further economies in Federal, State and local governmental expenditures in the next twelve months was begun today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
Andrew W. Mellon, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, arrived yesterday from London on the Majestic for a brief holiday. He was accompanied by his 25-year-old son, Paul.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Efforts of Republican journalists and spokesmen to create the impression that the forces which brought about the nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt are akin to those that dictated the nomination of William Jennings Bryan in 1896 are grounded on shallow knowledge of history or are made for a purpose and with small consideration for truth.
SHANGHAI, July 26 (AP). -- The Chinese postal blockade against Manchuria had tied up postal service today and appeared to have widened the breach between Japan and China over the Northern area.

The New York Central and the Pennsylvania were among the railroads to report yesterday substantial decreases in earnings for June and six months. The New York Central reported a decrease of $10,806,000 in June gross and a decrease of $3,589,000 in net operating income for the month.

The chief executives of the four Eastern trunk lines met yesterday in the Pennsylvania Station and made a preliminary survey of the differences between the plan of consolidation they submitted last October to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the plan which the commission issued last week.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Approval of a two-year loan of $5,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which on Feb. 25 approved a loan of $2,300,000 to the same system.

Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, Inc., agents for the American Scantic Line, said yesterday that he had long favored a cartel of international shipping companies, and now believed that the time was near when such an arrangement would be necessary for the advance of shipping business.

Eva and Emanuel Drucker of Brooklyn sold to Firovanti O. Miniutti the four-story nineteen-family brick apartment house on a plot 40 by 105 feet at 228-230 Stegman Street, near Jackson Avenue, Jersey City. The property is assessed at $49,300 and was taken over subject to two mortgages totaling $53,000.

The intellectuals and the intellectual arts of Soviet Russia are in a "peculiarly dangerous position under a proletarian dictatorship which encourages and makes effective the habits or the masses," Waido Frank asserts in his new book, "Dawn in Russia," published by Charles Scribner's Sons.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 26. -- The oil industry appears to be making more progress toward reaching a profitable basis than any other big business of the country. This is reflected in a growing interest, at advancing prices, in the shares of leading oil companies listed on the New York Exchange.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- The Grain Stabilization Corporation of the Farm Board opened negotiations today for the sale of 8,250,000 pounds of the coffee obtained from trades of wheat in South America.
BERLIN, July 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, July 26. -- The Chicago Board of Trade's directorate voted unanimously this afternoon to appeal to the Federal courts from the order of the Grain Futures Commission to close its trading in futures for sixty days. The directors authorized not only the immediate filing of a petition in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago, but the carrying of the appeal to the Supreme Court if necessary.

The "short short story" is about to attain the dignity of an annual anthology, which the "short story" won more, than a decade ago. "Short short stories" are narratives not exceeding 1,500 words in length. The new volume, which will be called "The Best Short Shorts of 1932," will be published in the Fall by G. P. Putnam's Sons and will be edited by Lionel White and Paul Anderson.

An indictment charging murder, first degree, was handed up by the Richmond County grand jury at St. George, S. I., yesterday against Domenico Trombetta, editor of Il Grido Delia Stirpe, a weekly Italian newspaper, and organizer of the Lictor Federation of America.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Amended regulations on the electrical energy tax, issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today, established definitely that municipal electrical light plants must tax the consumer and make returns to the government just as privately owned plants.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26. -- Two young gunmen held up a girl clerk alone in the office of Joseph M. Reicher, wholesale jeweler, at 207 Market Street, today, handcuffed her to her chair and escaped with diamonds and other jewelry valued by Reicher at about $15,000.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 26. -- The second of two concerts arranged by Victor Harris, conductor of the St. Cecilia choral in New York and a resident here, for the directors of Guild Hall will be given Aug. 5. A quartet of mixed voices will present Liza Lehmann's arrangement of "In a Persian Garden," and Mrs. Harris "will conduct.

LOS ANGELES, July 26. -- Tentative line-ups of the two American relay teams for the Olympic Games were named today by Head Coach Lawson Robertson. The sprint quartet will consist of Bob Kiesel, Emmett Toppino, Hec Dyer and Frank Wykoff in that order, while the 1,600-meter four will be composed of Ivan Fuqua, Ed Ablowich, Arnold Adams and Karl Warner.

Refinancing of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation was completed yesterday as a result of the private placing of $13,500,000 two-year collaterally secured notes of the company, due on Aug. 1, 1934, by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, Hayden, Stone Co. and J. W. Seligman Co.

Last week The Main Line Daily Times of Ardmore, Pa., added a bitter reproach to that of many cities for New York's lack of spirit. In prosperous times New York bore up under such criticism bravely. There was plenty of it. New York "ran things," or tried to.

BUBLIN, July 26. -- The opening of the trade war with England had a prompt sequel this afternoon that darkens and embitters the outlook. Following a three-hour session of the Executive Council, Gerald Dempsey, a Captain in the illegal Irish Republican Army, who was sentenced on July 14 to three months in prison for contempt at court, was released from Mount Joy prison by order of the government.

Seventeen athletes from Great Britain, comprising the swimming and boxing teams, arrived here aboard the Majestic yesterday and today will entrain for Los Angeles and the Olympic Games. Jules Ladoumegue, French runner, who is ineligible for the Olympics, was another arrival here, coming on the Ile de France.
BERLIN, July 26. -- It is now clear that Sunday's election is likely to result in greatly strengthening the forces of reaction in Germany.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 26. -- Four favorites, including Richard Hebard of White Plains, top-seeded player, advanced to the semi-final round of the annual junior New Jersey centre tennis championship tournament today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 27 -- Victory for the Consolidated Oil Corporation in the competition for purchase of the Richfield Oil Company of California was virtually assured here this afternoon when the $22,250,000 tender was formally accepted by the joint reorganization committee representing Richfield creditors.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 27 -- Although his game fell considerably below what it was on the first round of the Long Island open championship, Walter Kozak, young Engineers Club professional, managed to cling to the lead he established yesterday, when he scored a 68.
LOS ANGELES, July 27 (AP). -- American chances of capturing the major share of Olympic rowing honors on the beautiful new course at Long Beach are especially bright this year.
PARIS, July 27 -- A sentence of death was passed today on the Russian exile, Paul Gorguloff, who on May 6 assassinated President Doumer.

KIEL, Germany, July 27 -- The loss of the German naval training ship Niobe, which went down yesterday in the Baltic Sea with sixty-nine cadets, officers and members of her crew, according to the official report, remains a mystery to all naval experts, including the rescued officers.

NYACK, N.Y., July 27 -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman, after a day spent in inspecting State institutions in Rockland County, was informed this evening at a dinner here that the Rockland County Democrats would back him for the Governorship.

OTTAWA, July 27 -- The dominions, negotiating jointly at the Imperial Economic Conference to present a united front program of demands to Great Britain, have reached their first agreement It is on the question of butter exports to England.

Necessity, or an empty purse, Has evolved a new kind of travel, which an article in the August Harper's styles "Fourth Class Travel, American Style." In point of cost, travel by airplane is ranked first, train second and bug third. The fourth and cheapest is in somebody else's automobile.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- The Yankees, after being held to four scattered hits by Oral Hildebrand in the first game of today's series-opening double-header and losing, 2 to 1, made twenty-one safeties in the nightcap, only to be beaten, 12 to 10, when Eddie Morgan's homer over the right-field fence off Pipgras broke a tie score in the eighth.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Approval of a series of twelve postal cachets, marking anniversaries of incidents connected with the activities of George Washington in and about New York, both as President and as Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army, was announced today by Postmaster General Brown.

Some confusion of judgment, especially regarding the Steel Corporation's report and dividend action, appeared in yesterday's market at the start. On United States Steel preferred, what was evidently professional pressure was applied; the price fell 4 points.

Mrs. Evelyn H. Ward of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, who is suing her husband, Ralph D. Ward, vice president of the Borden Products Company, for separation, was charged with disorderly conduct in "Yorkville Court yesterday by her maid, Mrs. Ragnild Stange.

Texas stands up for Speaker GARNER, nobly defiant of opinion in this part of the country. The eagerness with, which Republican newspapers have seized upon and exploited some of Mr. GARNER'S speeches or his way home has been noted and proudly resented by his admiring fellow-citizens.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Repeated rumors of preparations by Bolivia for an armed advance against Paraguay in the Chaco led the committee of neutrals, headed by Secretary Stimson, to send a message to La Paz today again asking Bolivia not to carry out any hostile act which might aggravate the situation and render ineffective the good offices of the neutrals in the controversy between the two South American countries.

DUBLIN, July 27 -- Former President Cosgrave's party made the first peace move in the economic war with Great Britain when Senator Count ban introduced a motion tills afternoon in the Senate, directing that "the government as trustees of the nation, reopen forthwith direct negotiations with the British Government with a view to a settlement."

LONDON, July 27 -- The Polish pianist, Arthur Rubinstein, married Mrs. Amelia Munz, daughter of Emil Mlynarski, conductor of the Warsaw Opera, at the Register's office today. Ruth Draper and the Polish Ambassador were among the witnesses. After a reception at the home of the Marchioness Cholmondely the couple left on a wedding trip to Venice.

Work in 1,500 garment shops was temporarily suspended yesterday by order of tie joint board of the Cloakmakers' Union to enable the union to put into effect the provisions of the new collective agreement arranged through the mediation of Lieut. Gov. Lehman, and to organize non-union shops which have slipped out of the union's control.

All charges made by Reuben S. Adler, bondholder, in a suit based on the default of the bonds of the Hotel Madison, 616 Madison Avenue, were denied in an answer filed yesterday in Supreme Court by counsel for S. W. Straus Co., which placed the securities on the market.

The fact that Warwick Deeping's novel "Old Wine and New" still appears on best-seller lists has not deterred this author from working on a new novel, which Alfred Knopf will publish in the early Fall. It deals with a working man's tragedy and is one of the first novels to be based on the depression.

Speaking to a throng of Summer school students that jammed the gymnasium, of Columbia University Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, declared last night that the breaking down of the barriers Between the nations was the "chief job of the generation now coming on the stage of this world."

BOSTON, July 27 (AP). -- The Braves and Cubs shared a double-header today, Boston taking the first, 2 to 1, in a pitchers' battle between Bob Brown and Charley Root, and the Cubs the nightcap, 4 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 27 - Capitulation of the bonus expeditionary force to the Treasury in its efforts to evict them from condemned Federal building's was announced tonigh by Walter W. Waters, commander of the veterans.

LOS ANGELES, July 27. -- Olympic track and field officials, holding their first clinic today in preparation for the championship battle starting oh Sunday, compromised on innovations by banning all use of starting blocks but approving, semi-officially, the new Kirby photo-electric timer, used successfully this season in the American championships and final tryouts.

DEAL, N.J., July 27 -- Miss Martha Parker of Westchester Hills and Miss Jane Brooks of Rockland were tied today at the end of the fifty-fourhole New Jersey Shore women's golf championship with totals of 250. As a result they will meet tomorrow morning to play off the tie.

PARIS, July 27 -- The Bourse again today followed Wall Street's trend of yesterday. As in New York, the upward course was halted by profittaking and so quotations here showed slight losses generally. The reductions might be ascribed also as due partly to apprehension caused by General von Schleicher's belligerent address in Germany yesterday.

In the unfamiliar role of coffee, merchant the Federal Government has invited bids on 62,500 bags of its surplus. This is a small part of the supply it acquired in August, 1931, when it "swapped" with Brazil 25,000,000 bushels of wheat for 1,050,000 bags of coffee.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- La Nacion's correspondents at frontier points report that Bolivia has mobilized between 12,000 and 14,000 men in the disputed Chaco, region, with headquarters at Villamontes. where Colonel Toro is Commander-in-Chief. Colonel Toro was a member of former Provisional President Galindo Blanco's junta.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Ambassador Mellon began a series of conferences with ranking government officials today after his arrival from London for a leave of absence of a few weeks. He was received for discussions by President Hoover and Secretaries Stimson and Mills.
The latest title for the forthcoming George Abbott-Philip Dunning play, previously called "Lilly" and "Exit," is "Lilly Turner." It is scheduled to open at the Morosco Theatre on Sept. 19.

The Federal grand jury, after a delay of almost a year, returned an indictment yesterday against Vasile D. Murgulescu, formerly a clerk in the Rumanian Senate, who escaped from Governors Island on Sept. 17, 1931, after he had been brought here from Sing Sing prison to answer questions concerning the smuggling of aliens into the United States.

LONDON, July 27 -- British funds improved further today in the stock markets, but the chief attention was paid to Victory bonds, the conversion issue remaining around the overnight levels. Exchange returns for the week ended yesterday had a favorable influence, while the reduction to 1 1/2 per cent in the bank rate is generally expected tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP). -- The Washington Senators came back today to take the second game of a series with the St. Louis Browns, 9 to 3, Weaver allowing the Browns only two hits in the six innings he pitched and Marberry holding St. Louis to one safety during the rest of the contest.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 27 -- Miss Virginia Pierce, recently crowned women's Vermont State golf champion, survived the first round of match play in the fourth annual invitation tournament of the Green Mountain Girls Golf Association of Manchester today defeating Miss Margaret Weatherwax of Albany, N.Y., 1 up.
NEWARK, N.J., July 27 (AP). -- Scoring five runs in the eighth to break a 2-2 deadlock, the Reading Keys snapped the Bears' six-game winning streak tonight, winning 7 -- 2.

LATONIA, Ky., July 27 (AP). -- Form players took another terrific thumping today when Colonel R.L. Baker's Brush Down, outsider, upset their figures in the Clifton Purse, a mile, and seventy yards affair for 3-year-olds and upward.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Governor Roosevelt held a harmony conference today on the front porch of the Executive Mansion with Governor Ely of Massachusetts, who fought for Smith at the Chicago convention and is the only one of the candidate's chief opponents who has not declared his support of the ticket.

LOS ANGELES, July 27. -- The signal honor of taking the Olympic oath of amateurism and sportsmanship for the assembled athletes of the world at the opening ceremonies of the games on Saturday has been conferred on a United States Naval Lieutenant, George C. Calnan.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- More than $5,500,000,000 was subscribed for two issues of long-term Treasury notes totaling $650,000,000, Secretary Mills announced tonight. The issues are both dated Aug. 1. One of them was oversubscribed twelve times.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- Huddled together without shelteer and with little food, in the hills above Gaiman in the Chubut territory, the Irish and Welsh colony there has taken refuge from the flood waters of the Chubut and Chico Rivers that have filled the valley, which is nine miles wide.

Among the passengers sailing today for the Channel ports on the White Star liner Majestic are Sir Charles Wright, Lieutenant L.J. Fiennes, Air Attache of the British Embassy at Washington, and H. Nizamettin, Turkish Vice Consul at New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the death of Rene Bazin the French Academy has lost one of its Finest and most distinguished men of letters, master of an exquisite prose style, delicate painter of strange and familiar landscapes, sympathetic interpreter of human nature in humble circumstances and tragic crises.

RYE, N.Y., July 27 -- Young Leonard Martin, former metropolitan champion, scored a par 72 at Apawamis, his home club, to lead a field of 119 for the low gross prize in the oneday tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association today.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- Smead Jolley led the Boston Red Sox in a scoring riot today that submerged his former White Sox mates, 15 to 5, for the second Boston victory in a row. Jolley hammered a home run in the fifth with two on base and wound up the day with two doubles, a single and a walk.

Soviet Russia's exports and even the "dumping" of her products on the world's markets have not reduced the level of the Soviet worker's consumption, Joseph Freeman asserts in his hook, "The Soviet Worker," published yesterday by Liveright, Inc. Mr. Freeman, co-author with Scott Nearing of "Dollar Diplomacy," was one of the editors of The New Masses and has written much on Russia.

DETROIT, July 27 (AP). -- Buck Marrow, newest of Tiger recruits, made his debut as a starting pitcher in the second game of a double-header, with the Philadelphia Athletics today. He lost, 4 to 0, but his performance was at least on a par with those of three regulars who pitched in the opener, which the Mackmen won in slam-bang fashion, 13 to 8.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP). -- Buzz Arlett drove out his forty-fifth home run of the season as Baltimore took both games of a double-header from Jersey City today. The scores were 7 to 5 and 7 to 2.

The New York Stock Exchange has approved the listing of new $1 par common stocks of Remington Rand, Inc., and Servel, Inc., and the new $3 par stock of Electric Boat Company. The new shares are to be exchanged share for share for the present no-par issues.
