OTTAWA, July 27 -- India, like South Africa, "does not subscribe to the theory of a self-contained British Empire" and will not join in any agreements at the Imperial Economic Conference here that might jeopardize Indian trade with non-British countries.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 -- Federal troops are advancing steadily against the Sao Paulo rebels under cover of a heavy bombardment, the government announced today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment "More Woe for Commuters" ignores the underlying facts, which could readily have been ascertained by inquiry of the officers of the Long Island Railroad.

The North German Lloyd pier at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, was the scene of a novel traffic jam for forty minutes early this morning when 10,000 persons gathered on the pier to see the liner Bremen pull out for Europe and were plunged into almost total darkness because of a mishap to the pier's lighting and power system.

Jim Fitzsimmons, who went "West to condition Faireno for the Arlington Classic, signalized his return to the Empire City course yesterday by saddling Pardee, stablemate to Faire-no, to win the Melrose Claiming Stakes, feature at the Yonkers course.

THE United States appears to have an even chance of taking the Davis Cup for an ocean trip. Vines vs. Cochet will be the high spot of the program. Cochet was in poor form at Wimbledon, where Vines was going at top speed, but Cochet fighting on French soil to retain the Davis Cup will be another player.

Patrick J. Commerford, deposed "supervisor" of Local 125 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, finally appeared yesterday at 39 Broadway before Referee Carroll Hayes, who is taking an accounting of the financial affairs of the local.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 -- Three women players, ranted No. 7 or better in the national list, were the victims of quarter-final round upsets today in the singles division of the forty-fifth annual invitation tennis tourney at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

One of the largest of sales in the midtown section of Manhattan was closed yesterday when the Retail Department Stores of America, Inc., of which M.J. Whitman is president, purchased from Walter J. Salmon the northwest corner of Forty-second Street and Sixth Avenue and the southwest corner of Forty-ninth Street annd Broadway.
PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP). -- The Reds nosed out the phillies, 4 to 3, today to even the count in the series at one game each.

AMHERST, Mass., July 27 (AP). -- A world demand for gold, and not overproduction, greater efficiency, extravagance, prohibition, or our form of government, Professor G.F. Warren of Cornell University said today, is the cause of the present economic depression.
Housing deals involved properties in Jersey City, Union City, North Bergen, Kearny and Bayonne. A feature of this activity was the number of resales reported.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- The international amateur boxing bouts at Soldier Field between a picked team of German champions and the Chicago Golden Gloves winners ended in a draw tonight each team, winning four fights. The production was the second of the international series.

KANSAS CITY, July 27 (AP). -- Led by the "Wheat Queen" of Kansas, who minced no words and displayed a muscular arm that wields a shovel, a group of grain farmers vehemently demanded abolition of the Federal Farm Board and freedom from governmental interference with agriculture at the Shannon House hearing here today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On behalf of the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association, Inc., permit me to state that the Mayor's proposal to city employes to accept a cut of 81-3 per cent in their salaries will not meet with the approval of those teachers.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Plans for an investigation of the operations of the Federal Farm Board since its creation three years ago were disclosed to President Hoover today by Senator McNary, Republican, of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, during a conference at the White House.

The Retail Chemists Corporation, owner and operator of the Whelan Drug Stores, and a subsidiary of the United Cigar Stores Company of America, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court, listing liabilities of $10,635,000 and assets of $5,613,465.

The city's real estate assessment rolls in 1933 must be cut $3,000,000,000, or double the amount Mayor Walker proposed, if any appreciable relief is to be afforded the taxpayer, and even then, the slash must be aecompanied by a substantial reduction in the 1933 budget or a higher tax rate will defeat its purpose, business and civic leaders and city financial officers declared yesterday in criticizing Mayor Walker's economy program.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP). -- The New England Power Association reported today for the second quarter of 1932 consolidated gross earnings of $12,406,514, a decrease of $1,175,484, or approximately 8 1/2 per cent, from the corresponding quarter of 1931. After payment of preferred dividends of $1,001,027, the second quarter balance available for reserves and common dividends was $1,175,172, against $1,749,367 in the corresponding quarter of last year.

BERLIN, July 27 -- The forthcoming elections are casting shadows on the Boerse, which was extremely quiet all of today. Prices declined slowly and insignificantly. Electric stocks held their own on small buying orders.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 27 (AP). -- Affidavits telling of alleged attempts to corrupt the jurors who convicted Colonel Luke Lea of Nashville, his son, Luke, Jr., and Wallace Davis of Asheville last August of violating the bank laws, were followed quickly by a denial the defense sponsored them as a petition for a new trial for the three men was argued here today.

Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, who on Tuesday was chosen temporary chairman of the National Economy League at its organization meeting here, Announced yesterday that he would start in about three weeks on an air tour of the nation to speed the formation of local organizations of the league for a solid front in the war against governmental extravagance.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 27 -- A recital in four language groups will be given Friday evening, Aug. 12, at Guild Hall here by Vanda Nomicos, wife of David Oliver Shoemaker.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 27 -- The twelfth annual session of the Institute of Politics, a forum for discussion of international problems, will be opened here tomorrow by Dr. Inazo Nitobe, who will make the convocation address on "International Cooperation."

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 27. -- Mayor Frank Frankel, who dismissed Chief of Police Morris Grossman from office yesterday for alleged failure to stop Boardwalk gambling, was warned by District Attorney Elvin Edwards today that if he does not clean up the gambling situation "the District Attorney's office certainly will."

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- Tred Avon, Maryland filly, raced to victory down the stretch at Arlington Park today, winner by a length and a half in the Arlington Matron Handicap that was worth $10,975. Eight of the fleetest fillies and mares in America started.

To judge from the action of the stock market yesterday, Wall Street looked upon the United States Steel Corporation's dividend action and income report as incidents that had been discounted to a large extent. Stocks moved idly to and fro in the first two or three hours of trading and it was not until the wheat market began its sharp advance that the market on the Stock Exchange got into action.

Sheet music was the first big source of income for song writers and publishers. Phonograph records followed, and then radio became a "small tight." It is still bringing in something, but does not yield enough to balance the losses from decreased sales of sheet music, records and the greatly reduced income from talkies, theatres, restaurants and ballrooms.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 27 -- A Liberal party plebiscite will be held on Sunday for the interior of Nicaragua and 'on Aug. 7 on the East Coast to select delegates to the National Liberal Convention, which will nominate candidates for President and vice president.

The first twenty-six railroads to report for June showed yesterday net operating incomes of $8,103,000, against $20,151,000 in June, 1931, a drop of 59.8 per cent, and against $23,193,000 in June, 1930, a fall of 65 per cent. Their net operating income in May was about $8,878,000, compared with $19,783,000 in May, 1931, a decline of 55.1 per cent.

PARIS, July 27 -- After an exhaustive discussion of the effects of the new low rates instituted several months ago, the North Atlantic steamship conference declded today before it closed its two-day meeting here to retain them indefinitely.

The proprietor of a chain of cleaning and dyeing establishments in New York who refused to heed a suggestion that he raise prices recently found sewn in the neckbands of two garments he received at one of his stores chemicals which, if immersed in gasoline, would cause an explosion, Assistant State Attorney General Edmund C. Collins disclosed yesterday.

The nearly completed international nitrate trust, in which the Guggenheim interests are represented, was denounced yesterday as a "military alliance" directed against "the efficiency of our national defense and the protection of our agriculture," by F.P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- When appraised of developments in Pontiac, Melvin A. Traylor, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, declared today there was no doubt that runs on Chicago banks were caused by false rumors spread by radicals.

Although 10,000 bales more of government-financed cotton were sold yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply in the last hour and closed at the top, 13 to 16 points higher than on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Trade in wheat broadened today, and opposition to a further advance was swept aside as houses with Eastern and foreign connections became aggressive buyers. Prices advanced sharply to new high marks on the current movement, the July selling at the best figure since June 17.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 27 -- The profits of machinery should go to the workmen whom that machinery replaces, Hugh Frayne of the American Federation of Labor told the delegates to the convention of the State Allied Printing Trades Council today.

Duluth, Minn. Wallace, Sanderson Co. will offer today a new issue of $250,000 city of Duluth (Minn.) 4 1/4 per cent bonds, maturing on Jan. 1, 1935 to 1944. The issue will be priced to yield 3.75 to 4.10 per cent. The net bonded debt of the city is officially reported as less than 2 1/2 per cent of the actual valuation for purposes of taxation.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, CAPE YORK, Greenland, July 27.--The schooner Morrissey, with Captain Bob Bartlett in command, brought the members of the Peary Memorial Expedition to their destination here on July 14. The day was perfect, and no sooner was the schooner made fast to the foot of the glacier than the party started for the summit of the cape to find a site for the monument.

BERLIN, July 27 -- The political sensation in Germany today was undoubtedly the radio speech made by Lieut. Gen. Kurt von Sehleicher last night, in which the Minister of Defense frankly proclaimed the intention of the Reich to meet the inconclusive results of the Geneva disarmament conference by reorganizing the German Army, regardless of the limitations imposed by the Treaty of Versailles, so as to obtain for the nation the security, that is now lacking.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Copper Dickey are leaving tomorrow to visit Mr. and Mrs. Ira Barrows in East Hampton, L.I.

LOS ANGELES, July 27. -- With each passing day, as the opening of the tenth Olympiad approaches, word conies out of Olympic Village and from the practice fields of the exploits of some new figure to elevate him to the position of a favorite and bring about a revision of the form charts.

MADRID, July 27 -- With most of the business men of Madrid and many other cities of Spain in sympathy, 30,000 enthusiasts crowded into Madrid's giant bullring this afternoon and shouted vociferously when orators told them that granting Catalan autonomy would he equivalent to giving Catalonia complete liberty and would destroy the Spanish nation.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 27. -- State police denied today that third-degree methods had led to the suicide of Mrs. Elsa Eckert, 30 years old, whose body, with that of her 5-year-old daughter, Muriel, was found last night in a locked automobile in a tightly-closed garage at the rear of their home.

A search for assets of the Kreuger Toll Company based on clues furnished by law suits filed against it here has been undertaken by the American creditors who are seeking the appointment of a Federal receiver to cooperate with the liquidators handling the affairs of the corporation in Sweden, where it is bankrupt.

Jack Quinn, veteran of many baseball wars, added another unique achievement to his varied record in the Dodgers' ninth-inning victory over the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday. He pitched one ball and went into the records as the winning pitcher.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- The usually staid audience at the Colon Opera went wild with enthusiasm over Lily Pons's performance of Lucia last night and gave her an ovation seldom seen here. The musical critics, having exhausted adjectives in praise of her performances last season, declare she has firmly won a foremost position as one of the greatest sopranos of the age.

An advance in wheat, based upon reports of a farmers' strike by which the grain was being withheld from the market, produced a sympathetic rise on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in the late dealings after the general list had fluctuated nervously in the first three or four hours of trading.

Leasing of store space featured the business rental transactions reported by brokers yesterday. Retail shopping space was taken by clothing firms, women's wear and other concerns in various parts of Manhattan. Some dealings also were noted in office quarters, several contracts for one or more floors being included in the day's list.

Thomas Patrick Morriss, whose claim, if allowed, will make him the rightful heir to most of the Wendel fortune of $30,000,000 or more through being the son of John Gottlieb Wendel, spent yesterday on and off the witness stand before Surrogate James A. Foley while evidence corroborating him was put in and other evidence contradicting him was promised.

Further evidence of the beginning of a movement of gold from Europe to New York was provided yesterday by the action of the foreign exchange market and by reports of large selling orders for foreign currencies in this market not yet consummated. Sterling broke one cent, bringing the level to $3.53 3/8, the lowest since March 7, and the franc cables closed at 3.917-16 cents, off 1/4 point, the lowest since last Dec. 2.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27 -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon followed by bridge today at Claverack House, her place in Halsey Neck Lane, for Mrs. William Bayard Van Rensselaer of Albany, who is visiting her. Mrs. Barber's son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas as H. Barber Jr. of Mulberry Corners, Woodbury, L.I., and the latter's sister, Miss Helen Iselin Goodridge, will arrive Saturday to pass several weeks with Mrs. Barber.

A new proceeding for the release of Mrs. Mabel Hunt Slater, wealthy philanthropist, from Craig House, a sanitarium at Beacon, N.Y., and to have her adjudged sane was filed in Supreme Court yesterday in her behalf by her brother, Paul Hunt of Boston, on the ground that she never had had a fair bearing as to her mental condition because she never had appeared at an inquiry into her sanity.

LONDON, July 27 -- Mrs. Alfred Charles Bossom, American wife of a noted architect, her son Bruce Bossom, 21, and Count Otho Erbach-Fuerstenau, 23, were killed near Farnham, Surrey, tonight, when a hired airplane which Bruce Bossom was piloting crashed in a field.

SAN JOSE, Cal., July 27 (AP). -- A strange story of revenge which led a 20-year-old youth to kill his aunt and attempt to slay his uncle, a wealthy Manila importer and exporter, to avenge an alleged wrong to his father, was told by San Jose authorities today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 27. -- Mrs. Clem Seely, who protested her innocence of speeding to the point of going to the House of Correction to start a thirty-day term rather than pay a $25 fine, has decided that prison life is not so rosy after all. The clubwoman, who proclaimed that she was "fighting for a principle," gave up today and requested her husband to post bond.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27 (AP). -- The man who will become chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today promised there would be no politics in it so long as be is at the helm.
LONDON, July 27. -- F.S. Smythe, the young leader of the successful British Himalayan Expedition to Mount Kamet, is planning an expedition to the second source of the River Ganges next year.

Former Supreme Court Justice M. Warley Platzek, who died on July 20, left a large part of his estate to religious, charitable and public institutions, according to his will which was filed for probate in Surrogate's court yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestions made by Judge William P. Wiener of the City Court of Queens are worthy of serious consideration.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the beat names. Tuesday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The first loan to a State by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for immediate unemployment relief was granted today to Illinois, which received $3,000,0000. Otherwise the State's relief funds would have been exhausted this month.

Three revues, five musical comedies and a number of foreign plays are included in the list of productions which the Shuberts plan to make on Broadway during the coming season, according to announcement by them yesterday.

An attachment for $50,000 against the property of Mrs. Lottie. Robbins. Polsky, who has been bookkeeper and office manager of the Metropolitan Fireproof Warehouse, Inc., for eleven years, disclosed yesterday that she is charged with having shared to that extent in more than $100,000 alleged to have been diverted from the corporation by Lawrence S. Morris, secretary and general manager.

Negotiations are under way for the transfer of Paramount's motion picture studio in Astoria to A.C. Blumenthal, wealthy theatrical and film broker, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Blumenthal would use the studio to produce motion picture versions of plays presented on Broadway by his wife, Peggy Fears, it was further learned.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27 -- Despite the unsettled weather those interested in the old port day's celebration this afternoon and early evening went through with their program as scheduled. The afternoon found many members of the Summer colony at the fete for the improvement of Washington Street, on the harbor front, which was one of the first of the Summer colony streets of the city back in Colonial days.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Extra fares charged for passage on de luxe trains received the official approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission today in an announcement of the results of a protracted study of this form of transportation.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the letter which appeared in THE TIMES advocating the use of Conservatory Lake in Central Park for a swimming pool for children.

The American people's total annual expenditure for alcoholic beverages has remained virtually unchanged under prohibition, although the working class is spending less and the professional and business classes more than they did before the passage of the Eighteenth Amendment, Dr. Clark Warburton has found in an investigation of "the outlaw alcoholic beverage industry," the results of which were made public yesterday by the Columbia University Press.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The proposal which Senator Borah recently made for an international conference at which war debts and reparations would be on the agenda was discussed by the Senator with Secretary Stimson at Woodley, home of the Secretary of State, last night.

A plea to fur manufacturers who have contractual relations with the Furriers' Joint Council, and to wholesalers, retailers and the public, to scrutinize the source of fur manufacture as a guard against Communist activities in the industry, was made yesterday by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in a statement issued by the council.

The belief was expressed yesterday by Republican leaders here that General Edward Martin, the Republican leader of Pennsylvania, was the most likely candidate for the post of Republican Eastern campaign manager. Former United States Senator David Baird of New Jersey is also a possibility.

The establishment of a training school for young women dental hygienists as a part of the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic, a six-story $3,000,000 structure completed last year at 422-28 East Seventy-second Street for free treatment for children, was announced yesterday by Dr. John Oppie McCall, director of the clinic, who will be director of the school.

A lightning bolt disfigured the imposing 400-foot tower of the Riverside Church at Riverside Drive and 122d Street about 6:30 o'clock last evening at the height of a thunderstorm that caused property damage in other parts of the city but brought relief to New York's millions from the steaming humidity that had lasted most of the day.

PARIS, July 27 -- Defense Minister von Schleicher's speech in Berlin yesterday, Senator Borah's campaign for arms reduction as a collateral of debt reduction and certain recent London newspaper articles interpreting the Anglo-French consultation pact to which Germany has just adhered, have combined to cause a flurry in many quarters in Paris concerning the immediate future.

Deliberate devaluation of its currency by this country while in the position of a creditor nation with a favorable balance of trade and huge gold reserves would be profoundly disquieting both at home and abroad, according to a review by the New York Trust Company, which points out that no country in the past has ever voluntarily abandoned the gold standard.

Charges that the Amtorg Trading Corporation had sold $200,000 worth of Persian rugs in this country within the last two months at 20 per cent below the actual importation cost were made yesterday by A.E. Andon, Oriental rug dealer and chairman of a committee of rug importers formed three weeks ago to protest against the alleged Soviet "dumping."

Every year Mr. C.E. RIGHTOR of the Detroit Bureau of Governmental Research prepares for the National Municipal Review a report of the bonded debt of the leading cities of the United States. This year's tabulation, the tenth of its kind, affords a timely opportunity to compare the growth of local debts during the past decade, President HOOVER recently declared that of a total governmental indebtedness of $30,600,000,000, local debt comprised $12,600,000,000.
While emphasizing the "air of cheerfulness" in the steel industry, The Iron Age in its weekly review, published today, points out that there has been no measurable change in the volume of business.

FARNHAM, Surrey, England, July 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Alfred C. Bossom, killed today in a plane crash with her son, Bruce, and Count Otho Erbach-Fuerstenau, before her marriage was Emily, daughter of Samuel G. Bayne, president of the Seaboard National Bank of New York.

An arbitration decision against the late Florenz Ziegfeld became known yesterday. By a two to one vote. Reva Reyes, who had been engaged for a principal role in the Ziegfeld production of "Hot-Cha!" and had played the part on the road before she was replaced by Lupe Velez, received seven weeks' salary.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--"Whispering campaigns" in various sections designed to start runs against banks are being vigorously investigated by the Secret Service and agents of J.W. Pole, Controller of the Currency.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27 -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church, shorn of his powers following disclosures in the Earl Radio Corporation receivership, was declared "wholly unfit to discharge the duties of his office" in a report to Chancellor Edwin R. Walker in Trenton today by Charles L. Carrick of Jersey City, advisory master conducting the investigation into chancery receivership practices.

A recent act of Congress, the Department of Agriculture announces, will protect water-fowl on all waters of the District of Columbia. The provision of the former law which permitted shooting on parts of the eastern branch as well as in some sections of the Virginia side of the Potomac River, within the District, has been repealed.

White Wings' Gazette. The various names proposed for the Sanitation Department's new publication are wholly inadequate. It should be called either "Ashes to Ashes" or "Dust to Dust," it doesn't make much difference which.

The Federal Government is about to drop nearly all of its income tax investigations of city officials with large bank deposits, for lack of evidence on which prosecutions could be based, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Goldman Band, in the series of the Daniel Guggenheim memorial concerts, played to an audience of more than 10,000 on the Mall in Central Park last night under threatening weather conditions. The first part of the program was devoted to several new works, two of which were heard for the first time here, with the composers conducting.

PARIS, July 27.--A new and strong warning to France that American cooperation with Europe was impossible without disarmament was conveyed today by Ambassador Walter E. Edge during a visit to Premier Herriot, according to reliable sources.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- George Washington's favorite battle sword and Benjamin Franklin's cane have come to a final resting place together in the custody of the Smithsonian Institution. A catalogue issued today of the institution's sword collection, prepared by Theodore T. Belote, curator of history of the United States National Museum, lists both relics.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 (AP) -- The War Ministry announced tonight that General Waldomiro Lima's 8,000 federal troops swung to the north 125 miles above Itarare today and defeated a rebel force, capturing an entire battalion of 353 Paulistas.

Mrs. Loretta E. Kelly, 40 years old, a grandmother, who was suspected of participation in thefts of more than $163,000 from Russeks on Fifth Avenue in the last five years, was sentenced to a penitentiary term of not more than three years by Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 27. -- Trial of the thirteen members of the Nassau County Police Department, originally scheduled for Aug. 15, was set today for Aug. 22, when it was discovered that the code of criminal procedure provided that fourteen days following the beginning of a special term be set aside for the paneling of jurors.

Interest in the United States Steel Corporation's report for the second quarter is naturally divided between earnings in an extremely unfavorable period and the directors' decision, notwithstanding the deficit, to pay the regular preferred stock dividend.
PONTIAC, Mich., July 27 - A campaign of false rumors directed against a number of banks and bearing signs of having radicals at its source was revealed here today.

The National Republican Club, which in its years of existence has been host to many notables, from Presidents of the United States down, added another name to its long list of guests of honor last night -- that of Sam Goldstein, taxi driver.

Abe Wagner, east side bootlegger who was mentioned as a possible suspect in the Lindbergh baby kidnapping last March but was never found by the police, was shot dead by New York gangsters in Minnesota last Monday, his mother announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 27 -- Increased preferences on tobacco in the United Kingdom will be sought by Canada at the Imperial Economic Conference here while a British lobby watching the conference proceedings is working for large preferences to Great Britain in Canada on chemicals and allied products, it became known today.

Owners of the Wheeler Shipyards, Brooklyn, whose 40-foot Cabin cruiser exploded at Ithaca, N.Y., last year, killing one person and injuring four others, were relieved of all liability by the decision of Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers a in Admiralty Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Discovery of the foundation document of Artaxerxes I, in which the Persian Emperor records his completion of the magnificent Hall of a Hundred Columns, the greatest of the splendid palaces at Persepolis, was announced today by Dr. James Henry Breasted, director of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

In a letter admirable for its gravity and its irony County Chairman O'CONNEL notifies Chairman FARLEY that the Albany County organization proposes the nomination of Mayor THACHER for Governor, and that the Mayor will not be a candidate for any other office.

On May 2 Chancellor WALKER of the New Jersey Court of Chancery ordered, on application of the State Bar Association, an investigation of the receivership appointments and allowances of Vice Chancellor CHURCH. They were under suspicion of feeing unethical and damaging to the interest of creditors.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Amidst scenes reminiscent of the mopping-up of a town in the World War, Federal troops late today drove the army of bonus seekers from the shanty village near Pennsylvania Avenue in which the veterans had been entrenched for months.

On behalf of American creditors of Kreuger Toll, notice was served yesterday on the New York Trust Company to withhold payment on a balance of $21,455 in the account of Ivar Kreugrer's Swedish-American Investment Company, in accordance with an injunction granted to the creditors recently by Federal Judge Mack.
NICE, France, July 28. -- Michael Arlen, the novelist, escaped with bruises when the car he was driving overturned in a collision with another at a hidden corner here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The roster of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was completed by President Hoover today with the naming of Charles A. Miller, a Utica banker, to the remaining vacancy. Mr. Miller will be elected president of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The St. Louis O'Fallon Railway Company made a slight gain in its long-standing controversy with the Interstate Commerce Commission today when a preliminary report by P.S. Conway, examiner, urged a slight decrease in the finding of excess earnings by the railway from 1920 to 1923, inclusive.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, Miss Edith Cram and John S. Cram Jr., who were at the Fierre, returned yesterday to their home, 9 East Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP). -- After it had been decided tonight to hold off drastic action in the Anacostia camp until tomorrow, one blaze after another started in huts where the veterans were, and it was determined to let the troops complete the destruction.

Prohibition, is a success and there is not 1 per cent of the drinking done in the united States that there was formerly, according to an article by Henry Ford on "My Views on Liquor and the Law," published in the current issue of Collier's Weekly. Mr. Ford denies that prohibition is responsible for crime and contempt of law.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- William Hashka's war record lay tonight in a looked trunk in his windowless room in his brother's basement flat on Chicago's southwest side.

According to reports from near-by and easily accessible points, the salt water angler can be fairly certain of enjoying the week-end, as conditions and catches for the most part have been extremely favorable.

THE HAGUE, July 28. -- Under the presidency of Mineichiro Adatchi of Japan the World Court today heard the Norwegian petition for a declaration regarding the sovereignty of the territory in Southeast Greenland, now in dispute between Norway and Denmark.

In announcing that the directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had omitted the declaration of the regular preferred dividend, Eugene G. Grace, president, said yesterday that the directors were encouraged by the widespread improvement in sentiment, but had decided to follow a conservative policy with regard to the company's cash position.
A large part of yesterday's suburban realty activity centered in Westchester County, where brokers reported sales of vacant properties and sites improved with residences.
LONDON, July 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
It was announced at a dinner last night at the Bayside Yacht Club, Bayside, L.I., that six additional entries had been received for the club's Block Island race, making a total of thirty-three craft.

After stretching their new winning streak to five games by trouncing tie Cardinals for the fourth straight time in the opener at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers battled into the tenth inning, only to lose the second game, 8 to 6. The score of the first was 9 to 6.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 28. -- Without an Olin Dutra to come roaring from behind to snatch the honors from him, as it happened in the metropolitan open, Walter Kozak, young Engineers Country Club professional, today romped off with the Long Island open golf championship succeeding Macdonald Smith as the district's standard bearer.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The correspondence between Dr. William N. Guthrie, rector of the Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, and Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, whom he installed in the church ten years ago at the head of a body-and-soul clinic, developed into a controversy yesterday after the physician said the rector had agreed to stand with him in his insistence on continuing the clinic despite the request of the vestry to remove it from the church.

OTTAWA, July 28. -- The system of interconnecting commercial treaties that the members of the British Empire are seeking to erect among themselves was advanced today with the announcement that negotiations between Canada and South Africa had reached a point justifying the belief that a trade agreement would be concluded within a fortnight.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Purchases of government securities by the Federal Reserve Banks were cut to $5,000,000 for the week ended yesterday, according to the Reserve Board's weekly condition statement issued today.

CLEVELAND, July 28. -- Babe Ruth jumped back into the regular Yankee line-up today, blasted two homers over the right-field wall and drove home seven of the runs by which the McCarthymen stampeded the Indians for a 10-to-1 victory, their first of the trip.

The decline in wholesale trade and chain Store sales in the New York district in June from May was at much the same rate as in the correspending time last year, while in department store sales the drop was somewhat sharper, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve agent in New York.

THE heavy firing is about to start in the Stade Roland Garros at Auteuil and the big battle for the Davis Cup may not be decided until Sunday at sundown. The stage is set for a thrilling climax, with Henri Cochet to hold the French fort and lanky Ellsworth Vines to come sweeping forward in a last desperate attack that will mean final victory or defeat.

The decline in bank clearings reported this week from leading cities, while sharp from the totals of the preceding week, was only half of the comparable drop a year ago. The amount reported was $3,545,587,000, a decrease of 40.5 per cent from the corresponding week last year and of $650,000,000 from the preceding week.

OTTAWA, July 28. -- Two more cards were placed face up on the Imperial Economic Conference table today when Stanley Baldwin, leader of the British delegation, presented a statement plainly intimating to the dominions that in his opinion they were lagging behind the United Kingdom in the mutual exchange of trade benefits and H.W. Moffatt, spokesman for Southern Rhodesia, filed a request that Britain help his country by buying more of its cattle.

LONDON, July 28. -- Some satisfactory dividend statements today helped to maintain the cheerful tone in the stock markets. British Government funds again were active, the war loan still being bought for conversion purposes.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 28 (AP). -- Judge J.H. Clement started an investigation today into charges of attempts to bribe the jurors who convicted Colonel Luke Lea; his son, Luke Lea Jr., and Wallace B. Davis of violating the banking laws.

"Authoritative quarters" are given as the source of the information that assessed valuations throughout the city will be sharply reduced next year, perhaps to the extent of $1,500,000,000. Some lessening of the burden on the taxpayers had already been forecast.

The total accumulated cost of the city's public school plant soon will reach $500,000,000, according to the annual and financial statistical report of the Board of Education. Figures made public yesterday by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board, showed about $160,000,000 spent for school purposes during 1931.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The scene of the opening battle today in the attempt of the authorities to evict the bonus veterans from property belonging to the Federal Government was the south side of Pennsylvania Avenue, between Third and Sixth Streets. Northwest, extending southward as far as Missouri Avenue.
NEWARK, N.J., July 28 (AP). -- After tying the score with two out in the ninth, the Bears snatched a victory from the Reading Keys in the tenth inning today, 2 to 1.

Radio scientists are looking forward to the approaching total eclipse of the sun to solve some radio mysteries which have been puzzling experts. The path of the eclipse will cover parts of New England and Canada.

KANSAS CITY, July 28 (AP). -- Replying to what he termed "the loud squawks" of the grain trade, Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture, declared today that American grain prices under the Farm Board have been higher than those enjoyed by producers elsewhere in the world.

The twenty-three-story building at 180 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street, has been purchased by the Belcort Realty Company, Inc., for investment, it was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker in the deal.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 28. -- A new "Paraguayan attack on a Bolivian fort," was reported to Secretary of State Stimson in Washington by the Bolivian Government tonight.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 (AP). -- James Francis Burke, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, in a statement today said that "no more amazing evidence of Democratic desperation has been furnished than the comments of Democratic leaders on President Hoover's appointment of ex-Senator Atlee Pomerene to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation."

SEABRIGHT N.J., July 28. -- Four times on the threshold of victory and needing only one point to triumph over Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, the veteran Manuel Alonso faltered today in the men's singles semi-finals of the forty-fifth annual Sea-bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club invitation tennis tourney and Mangin gained the right to oppose Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York in the final tomorrow.

ALBANY, July 28. -- The case of Mayor Walker assumed a dominant place in the campaign plans of Governor Roosevelt tonight as he began a study of the Mayor's reply. He received the reply from Mr. Walker's messengers this afternoon.

The first ffifty railroads to report for June showed Let operating income of $12,468,000, against $41,688,000 in June, 1931, a drop of 70.1 per cent, and against $54,869,000 in June, 1930, a fall of 77.3 per cent. Their net operating income in May was about $11,212,000, against $36,816,000 in May, 1931, a drop of 69.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Flames rose high over the desolate Anacostia flats at midnight tonight and a pitiful stream of refugee veterans of the World War walked out of their home of the past two months, going they knew not where.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- President Hoover was asked today to intervene in the strike of miners of the Consolidation Coal Company of West Virginia with a view to bringing about a new wage agreement between miners and company.

ALBANY, July 28. -- Possibility of saving almost $2,000,000 in the care of prisoners through readjustment of criminal statutes, particularly those affecting fixed minimum sentences, was put forward tonight by Governor Roosevelt in his weekly radio address on State finances.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28. -- The Federal troops have recaptured the town of Barreiros from the Sao Paulo rebels after a bombardment of five days and the town of Areias has been invested, according to a government communique today.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP). -- Kim McKeithan, former Duke University star, made big first start for the Philadelphia Athletics today and was knocked from the box in the third inning of the series final, which went to Detroit, 4 to 2.

To the editor of The New York Times: We are going into a national election like a man worrying because he it ruined and can't have what he wants to drink, while he disregards entirely the fact that the home he is living in is sinking in quicksand.

Two officials of leading transatlantic steamship lines predicted yesterday that shipping companies would be forced to increase passenger faces "before very long" despite the fact that the conference in Paris on Wednesday voted to retain the pressent reduced schedule.

PARIS, July 28 (AP). -- France begins its defense of the Davis Cup against the United States tomorrow in Stade Roland Garros, with the outcome more uncertain than in any of the previous six meetings between the two countries for the historic tennis trophy.

The demand of investors in municipal bonds for more precise information regarding the financial status of borrowing communities, instead of taking the good credit of municipalities for granted, emphasizes the need for a rigid system of tests. Gaylord C. Cummin of the Municipal Securities Service, Boston, declared in an address yesterday before the Institute of Urban Problems, Pennsylvania State College.

MONTREAL, July 28 (Canadian Press). -- Holders of the first-mortgage sinking-fund gold bonds of Restigouche Company Ltd., subsidiary of Fraser Companies, Ltd., meeting here today approved the plan of re-organization of the Fraser Companies as submitted with the amendments accepted by holders of Fraser securities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the letter of Edmund Platt concerning Dr. Harold G. Moulton's study of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence waterway, it must he understood that the latter's criticism la directed against the navigation project as a whole and not necessarily against the canalization of the St. Lawrence River.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28. -- A calico ball took place here tonight in the auditorium of the Naval Training Station for the benefit of the Newport Army and Navy Y.M.C.A. About 1,000 persons were present.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The ordering out of troops to evict bonus marchers from government property was a step taken only after officials had made every effort to maintain order without the use of military forces.

BERLIN, July 28. -- A week ago yesterday the German Government, under the provocation of a series of political riots that had left a record of 100 dead and more than 1,200 injured, ousted the Socialist-Centrist-Democratic Government of Prussia, put Berlin and its environs under a state of emergency and proceeded to administer the State under "the guardianship of the Reich" without Parliamentary aid, as it was already administering the Reich itself.

Out of Kansas that bringeth all things comes a marvel and a portent, a wind of destiny, a blizzard of a woman and stateswoman that makes MARY LEASE look like Kitty Flyaway, heroine of OLIVER OPTIC'S "Poor and Proud." Mrs. IDA WATKINS, a widow with a strong right arm as well as a strong head, runs a 4,500-acre wheat farm at Sublette, in Southwestern Kansas, on the Santa Fe.

Wilbur J. Carr, Assistant Secretary of State, and Mrs. Carr will sail tonight on the Holland-America liner Rotterdam, which leaves for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam. Others on this ship will be Judge Mortimer Patterson of the County Court of Nyack, N.Y.; George A. Blake, chief counsel of the Public Service Corporation of Newark, N. J., and A.P. Vander Burch, assistant passenger-traffic manager of the Holland Line.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- June factory sales of automobiles in the United States, including foreign assemblies from parts made in the United States and reported as complete units, amounted to 183,092 vehicles, of which 160,103 were passenger cars, 22,754 trucks and 235 taxicabs, the Census Bureau announced today.

WASHINGTON. July 28 (AP). -- Long-legged Brigadier General Pelham D. Glassford, retired, chief of Washington police, who cajoled, jollied, threatened and fed the bonus army for two months, sees little sunshine through the cloud of tear gas spread today by troops.

TOLEDO, Ohio. July 28. -- The Willys Overland Company In the first half of July snowed a 93.8 per cent increase in shipments over the same period of the previous month, and a gain of 46.6 per cent over the first half of May, according to an announcement today by H.B. Harper, vice president in charge of sales.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The declaration of principles written by Joseph Pulitzer on his retirement as publisher of The St. Louis Dispatch on April 10, 1907, to serve as a "platform" for that paper, is not a trademark and may not be registered as such, according to the Patent Office.

OTTAWA, July 28. -- Definite plans for the remonetization of silver at a fixed ratio to gold throughout the British Empire, with a view to stabilize commodity prices, have been laid before the Imperial Economic Conference for consideration by a special committee on currency and related financial questions, which met for the first time today.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The Federal troops came out today and cleared Washington proper of the members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force. The cantonments, the "forts" in the unused Federal buildings, the huts that the men themselves had built, were evacuated by the veterans when they found themselves faced with tear-gas bombs, bayonets and tanks.

Fireman 1st Grade Thaddius Connolly of H. L. 32 died July 27 in the discharge of duty, from injuries received while responding to a special call, May 18. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 4,323 Bruner Av., the Bronx, at 9:30 A.M., Saturday, July 30. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Mount Pleasant, N.Y.

The vigorous upward movement in the stock market yesterday-which may have immediately embodied either rapidly increasing financial reassurance, or the driving-up of prices preparatory to speculative profit-taking, or both -- carried many active shares 3 to 6 points higher and, what was equally Interesting, brought total transactions to the largest figure of any day since last December.

The new collective agreements between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, on one side, and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association, arranged through the mediation of Lieut. Gov. Lehman, will be signed this morning at 10 o'clock in the office of George W. Alger, impartial chairman of the cloak and suit industries.

Terming himself the victim of political misrepresentation, and insisting that his entire official life would bear the closest scrutiny, Mayor Walker filed with Governor Roosevelt yesterday his answer to the removal charges pending against him as the result of allegations first made by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee.

LOS ANGELES, July 28. -- Paavo Nurmi, the greatest footracer or all time, winner of seven Olympic races, tonight was barred, definitely and finally, from competing in the 1932 games, less than three days before he was to have begun his fourth quest for Olympic honors.

Mayor Walker, in two appendices to his answer to the charges against him, devoted some 5,000 words in outlining what was equivalent to a plea of the statute of limitations and a reminder of the 500,000 majority he received in the 1929 elections. He also replied to charges filed by James E. Finegan.

OTTAWA, July 28. -- A British drive for the Canadian trade in machinery and electrical supplies, in both of which categories the United States sold to Canada in 1930 goods valued at more than $100,000,000, is under way behind the scenes of the Imperial Economic Conference here, it became known today.

LATONIA, Ky., July 28 (AP). -- Upsets marked today's card at the Latonia race track. Polly's Folly, paying $22.30, and Mount Rainier, returning $16.18, annexed the second and third dashes, respectively; but the real surprise came when F.H. Carpenter's Dunny Boy romped off with the Vovert Run Purse.

Rafael Sabatini has transformed an old mill on the banks of the River Wye in Herefordshire, England, into a combined dwelling, a place to work and a fishing lodge. Mary Austin, now that she has turned over to her publishers, the Houghton Mifflin Company, the manuscript of her autobiography, is spending the Summer in Santa Fe, N.M., devoting her talents to the making of jams and pickles.

Tammany, which voted against the nomination of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President at the Democratic National Convention, endorsed Governor Roosevelt and his running mate. Speaker John N. Garner, last night, at a meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee in Tammany Hall, held particularly for the issuing of the party call for the primary election on Sept. 20.
WASHINGTON, July 28.--Walter W. Waters, titular commander of the "Bonus Expeditionary Force," declared tonight that "no matter what may happen from now on, the B.E. F. will carry on."

PRAGUE, July 28. -- The will of Thomas Bata, Czechoslovak shoe manufacturer, leaves to his widow his shares in the Zlin shoe works, worth $1,000,000. To his only son he left $900,000 in shares in the Bata concerns.

Mrs. J.E. Nagle's 3-year-old colt The Crane, which has been racing in good form recently, accounted for the Sleepy Hollow Purse at Empire City yesterday when he scored by a nose over the Pine Tree Farm's Regal Flag, which placed second.
Joseph P. Day was the guest speaker at the woekly luncheon meeting of the Perm Zone Property Owners' Association held yesterday at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

(Copyright, 1932, by The Chicago Tribune). LIMA, Peru, July 28. -- With considerable data confirming his belief that cosmic rays are electrical, Professor Arthur H. Compton sailed today for Havana on the steamer Santa Clara with Mrs. Compton and their son to continue his studies in Mexico and Northern Canada.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP). -- Walter Stewart proved today he still retained, his mastery over the Washington Senators when the St. Louis Browns defeated Walter Johnson's team, 6 to 4, in the third game of the series.

The "modification" of the Delaney short-term bond financing policy is in the process of revision, it became apparent yesterday, with the savings in the coming tax budget from it hardly likely to amount to more than $12,000,000. No more than this can be saved in that way without endangering the 5-cent fare, it is contended by the city's financial experts.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP). -- Grantham's home run off relief pitcher J. Elliott with two men on base in the ninth gave Cincinnati a second triumph over the Phils today, 7 to 4.

With the Giants plunging resolutely in reverse there was still no checking the singular pennant flight of the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday, where for the second successive afternoon the home athletes went down to a double defeat.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff of the army, declared late tonight, upon returning to his office at the War Department after ousting the bonus veterans from government property, that the situation presented had been of the most serious character and that President Hoover had delayed to the last possible moment before ordering strong action.

A process for the extraction of pure Vitamin D directly from cod liver oil has been perfected at Columbia University by Professor Theodore F. Zucker after ten years of research and experimentation, it was announced yesterday at the university.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 28. -- Governor A. Harry Moore announced here tonight that Princeton University, through its acting president, Dr. Edward D. Duffield, had accepted his request that it conduct a non-partisan investigation of the New Jersey State government.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 28. -- Work on the stretch of Highway Route 4 between Grand Avenue, Englewood, and River Road, Teaneck, having been completed, the entire route from the Washington Bridge at Fort Lee to the Broadway Bridge, Paterson, was thrown open to traffic this morning when Jean Van Wagner, daughter of Mayor Karl D. Van Wagner of Teaneck, cut a tape stretched across the highway.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 28. -- Max Marston of Philadelphia, five times winner of the Shenecossett men's invitation tournament, today served notice on a field of more than 100 golfers that he means business in his quest for permanent possession of the second Shenecossett trophy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28. -- There was a large attendance tonight at the recital by Miss Mary Ledgerwood, contralto, and Cornelius Van. Vliet, cellist, in the Colonial Auditorium of the Southampton High School, under the auspices of the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion.

"Only as a Last Resort." In making its unemployment relief loan, $3,000,000, to Illinois, the Reconstruction. Finance Corporation issued a warning to other States applying for similar aid that it would expect them to meet their needs so far as possible from their own funds, private as well an public, calling upon the Federal agency only as a "last reaort."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 28. -- The police are seeking tonight racketeers believed responsible for the bombing early this morning of a three-story office and club building conducted by Vincent Martino, 31 years old, former Georgetown University athlete, now a ward politician, at 2,418 Atlantic Avenue, in the heart of the downtown business section.

LOS ANGELES, July 28. -- The biggest migration to California since the Forty-niners wrote an imperishable story of man's courage in braving the perils of the unknown has made Los Angeles the cosmopolitan capital of the world.
OTTAWA, July 28 (Canadian Press). -- The statement submitted today to the Imperial Economic Conference by the United Kingdom delegation follows:

The Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringren rail-road holding system, suffered a loss of $11,940,000 from the sale of securities between Jan. 1 and June 30, according to a report issued yesterday. This represented the sale of 46,200 shares of Pere Marquette Railway common stock to the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and also probably some of the 215,000 Erie common shares and 167,300 Nickel Plate common shares optioned to the C. O.

The parks of New York City will never reach as high a point of development as State parks until city magistrates can be compelled to cooperate and impose adequate penalties on park offenders, Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, told 250 members and guests of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., at Jones Beach State Park yesterday.

Although early gains were partly canceled by profit-taking, Wall Street was tremendously impressed by the performance of the share market. Transactions on the Stock Exchange involved a total of 2,735,000 shares, the largest turnover since December, 1931.
The name of Colonel William J. Donovan, already put forward as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, received support from two organizations yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 28. -- Lieut. Gov. Lehman declared Governor Roosevelt to be fitted in every particular for the task of national leadership in an address before Tompkins County Democrats here tonight. The Lieutenant Governor reviewed the social and material progress of the State under Governors Smith arid Roosevelt and expressed the belief that the Democratic nominee "is going to be elected by the greatest vote next November."

ALBANY, July 28. -- In between conferences with economists and with party leaders of other States, Governor Roosevelt today put in a second day's work on the address on the Democratic national platform which ha will deliver over the radio from here on Saturday night.
DUBLIN, July 28. -- President de Valera dashed tonight any hopes of early negotiations with Great Britain.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 28. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of the Round Hill Club, Greenwich, won low gross in the one-day medal play tournament, over the course of the Innis Arden Golf Club, Greenwich, today, with an 84.

Payments by life insurance companies to policy holders and beneficiaries in New York State in 1931 amounted to $517,000,000, according to a survey in The National Under-writer, which estimates that if the payments had been equally divided among all persons in the State, each would have received $40.90.

PARIS, July 28 (AP). -- A decree made public tonight bars from Prance "dubbed talking films," unless the process of post-synchronization into the French language is done in French territory. American film interests described the order as a serious blow to the American film Industry in France.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 28. -- Delegates td the convention of the New York State Allied Printing Trades Council considered today a resolution urging virtual banishment of advertising from the air, and after some discussion referred the resolution back to the resolutions committee for further consideration.

The National Steel Corporation reports for the six months ended on June 30 a net income, after all charges and Federal tax, of $1,153,799, equal to 53 cents a share on the 2,156,832 no par capital shares outstanding. This compares with net earnings of 53,459,376 or $1.60 a share for the corresponding period in 1931.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- Statements made by the American Vigilant Intelligence Federation that George E. Powers, at one time candidate for Borough President of Queens, was believed to have been involved in communistic activities to foment bank runs were denied today by Mr. Powers.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- Aided by a break which cost Epithet ten lengths, Mrs. John D. Hertz's Pair-bypair today accounted for the $2,500 added North Shore Handicap at Arlington Park.

BERLIN, July 28 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler's threat in a speech last night that democracy in Germany must die within a few days was followed up today by a strong call for Kaiserism from Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, leader of the Nationalist party, which, with Herr Hitler's National Socialists, is dedicated to putting Germany back in her "place in the sun."

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28. -- Mike Phipp's Camels quartet and William Ziegler's Great Island polo team ginned the final of the Hempstead cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today by registering victories in the semi-final round of the annual twelve-goal tourney.

PARIS, July 28.--Premier Edouard Harriot summoned the German Ambassador, Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, to the Quai d'Qrsay today to explain to him vigorously that the French people are considerably disturbed by the terms of Lieut. Gen. Kurt von Schleicher's radio speech Tuesday evening, in which he gave notice that Germany would arm, if necessary, contrary to the provisions of the Versailles treaty, and also attacked France.

Staid Bryant Park was magically transformed last night by means of a few beach umbrellas and Kleig lights into the courtyard of Ko-Ko's official residence, and later the same beach umbrellas turned, the very same Bryant Park into Ko-Ko's garden, all through the magic of Gilbert and Sullivan music and lyrics of "The Mikado," which was performed on the steps of Federal Hall by the Savoy Comic Opera.

The probability tHat former President Calvin Coolidge will aid President Hoover in his campaign for re-election was indicated yesterday when Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said that he would visit Mr. Coolidge Saturday and Sunday at the Coolidge homestead at Plymouth Notch, Vt., and expected to discuss the political situation with him.

Money market was quiet and without change in quotation, Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 per cent, and Street trades at 1, and Federals 1/8. Maturity money was quoted 1 1/4 @ 1 1/2, for all dates, but demand was light. Acceptances and commercial paper were steady.

DEAL, N.J., July 28. -- Miss Jane Brooks, young golfing star from Nyack, N.Y., today won the women's New Jersey shore championship at the Hollywood Golf Club when she defeated Miss Martha Parker of Westchester Hills in an eighteen-hole play-off after fighting her way into a tie for first place at the conclusion of the regular fifty-four holes of medal play.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The extraordinarily heavy oversubscription to the government's latest offering of 2 1/8 and 3 1/4 per cent notes indicates a ready market for Treasury issues, which may lead to the flotation of a long-term bond issue before the end of the year, according to officials.

A memorial mass meeting, attended by more than 500 persons, was held under the auspices of the Jewish National Fund of America and of the New York Zionist Region at the Hotel Astor last night, as part of an annual world-wide commemoration of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the death of Dr. Theodore Herzl, founder and leader of the Jewish movement for the rebuilding of Palestine as the Jewish National Home.

Governor Roosevelt is no "high pressure Executive," does not work hurriedly but accomplishes his work easily and therefore shows no signs of nervous or physical strain, Earl Looker writes in a Biography of the Democratic Presidential candidate, "This Man Roosevelt," published today by Brewer, Warren Putnam.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 28. -- Dr. Harry A. Garfield and Mrs. Garfield gave a reception this afternoon at President's House, Williams-town, for the lecturers, round-table leaders and 300 members who have arrived for the Institute of Politics. Among their guests were Dr. and Mme. Inazo Nitobe of Tokyo, M. Pierre Lyautey of Paris, Professor T.E. Gregory and Arnold Toynee of London and Dr. Luigi Villani of Rome.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 28. -- Marco Hecht and Ernest Koslan brought the New York State junior doubles championship to the metropolitan district by scoring a straight-set victory over Leonard Patterson and Gerald Phipps of Santa Monica, Cal., in the title final today, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 28. -- The full text, except for appendices, of Mayor Walker's reply, as made public here by the Governor, to the charges pending against him follows:
LOS ANGELES, July 28. -- Fourteen new world's track and field records, including Frank Wykoff's classic time of 9.4 seconds for 100 yards, made at Los Angeles in 1930, are due to be put on the books.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- In a far-reaching decision the Federal Power Commission today ruled in effect that power-site valuations must be based on the cost of the properties.

What had long been feared has now come to pass in Washington. The "Bonus Army," after weeks of defying decency, has broken out into violent defiance of the law and the public authorities. Its settling down at the capital was from the first a scandal.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP). -- Germany was awarded the Winter Olympic Games of 1936 at the opening meeting of the international Olympic committee today. The town where the international contests will be held was not decided upon. The 1936 Olympiad was awarded to Berlin at the last meeting of the committee.

WASHINGTON. July 28. -- Through rates agreed upon by the American Hampton Roads, Yankee and Oriole Lines covering shipments between Pacific Coast ports and London, Hull, Leith, Dundee, Liverpool, Manchester, Avonmouth, Cardiff, Glasgow, Belfast, Dublin, Londonderry and other United Kingdom and Irish ports and Hamburg, with trans-shipment at Philadelphia, were approved by the Shipping Board today.

Not only because campaign funds are low this year will there not be, so far as the Democratic party is concerned, "the usual waste and lost motion." In the opinion of ALFRED SMITH, writing reminiscently on such matters in The Saturday Evening Post, the "businesslike administration" given the National Committee for the last three years by Chairman RASKOB and Mr. SHOUSE will greatly improve conditions.

Benny Leonard, former lightweight champion of the world, scored the most impressive victory of his comeback campaign when her outpointed Billy Townsend, hard-hitting young welterweight from Vancouver, B.C., in the main bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Stadium last night.

A first victory for Thomas Patrick Morris in his fight to establish himself as the son of John Gottlieb Wendel and rightful heir to most of the $30,000,000 Wendel fortune was indicated yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a Southern business man and have been coining to New York for years on business. I confess my dislike for all this talk about the radicalism of the South and the association of Governor Roosevelt with that term because we favor him.

Before children go to school they can think of enough questions to make their unfortunate parents feel hopelessly inadequate in mind and knowledge. At the age of 8 they supply information to the less lucky members of the family who do not happen to be in the third grade.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 (AP). -- Brazilian regulars continued their gigantic circular movement around the rebels of Sao Paulo today, Minas Geraes troops capturing the railroad junction town of Sao Joao da Boa Vista, almost 100 miles due north of Sao Paulo City.

PARIS, July 28. -- The general tone of the stock market was steady today. International stocks as well as French industrials and banks made slight gains. Such leaders as Rio Tinto, Royal Dutch, Suez Canal, Pechiney and Credit Lyonnaise closed stronger.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 28. -- While District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards was preparing to present to the grand jury when it convenes tomorrow evidence of alleged perjury by some of the thirteen indicted members of the Nassau County Police Department, the recently organized defense committee was making plans to raise $25,000 to pay legal and other expenses in connection with the trial of the men.

James E. Finegan, former fusion candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, who filed charges of official waste and extravagance against Mayor Walker several weeks ago, called yesterday upon President Hoover to investigate the source of the "rumor" that the Federal Government had built up no cases against city officials for violation of the income tax laws.

The statement issued Wednesday by Mrs. Pauline Wagner of 19 Rutgers Place that her son, Abe, east side bootlegger, had been killed in St. Paul, Minn., by New York gunmen last Monday, remained without official verification yesterday.

Invigorated by fresh optimism, the Security markets made another broad advance yesterday. The day's transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 2,735,635 shares, which represented the heaviest trading since Dec. 18 of last year.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,434,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,496,000,000 compared with the corresponding week of 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a friend and comrade of Enrico Malatesta for thirty-five years, may I correct the statement that he ever received or would have accepted aid if it had been offered by the Fascisti? On the contrary, I know he would have died before accepting aid from those arch foes of the principles for which he fought for more than sixty years.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles scored eight runs in the third and fifth innings on three hits to take tonight's game with Jersey City by 9 to 6.

The first of the federal aid projects made possible by that portion of the $2,122,000,000 unemployment relief und assigned to New York got under way yesterday when Frederick Stuart Greens, State Superintendent of Public Works, advertised for bids on a $1,500,000 contract to pave Grand Central Parkway in Queens and Northern State Parkway, its extension in Nassau County.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings won a close game from the Bisons under the lights tonight, 5 to 3.

LOS ANGELES, July 29. -- At 3:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon [7:30 New York Daylight Saving Time] Vice President Charles Curtis, representing President Hoover and the nation, will formally open the tenth revival of the Olympic Games.

A small but select field teed off at the picturesque Hudson River Country Club, Greystone-on-Hudson, N.Y., yesterday, to play the first eighteen-hole round in the sixth annual fifty-four-hole Sweetser Victory Cup Tournament commemorating the great achievement of the Siwanoy ace in winning the British amateur championship at Muirfield in 1926.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Speculative unterest contracted in the wheat market today, and local and outside longs took profits as a result of the upturns of nearly 7 cents within ten days. These factors more than offset the strength in stocks, and the finish was 1/2 to 5/8 cent net lower.

BRUSSELS, July 29. -- Ultra-modern fortifications for Belgium's eastern frontier, patterned after the strong fortifications that Prance has built up since the "World War in Alsace and Lorraine, are called for in the program outlined today by the Minister of National Defense in an interview with a writer for the newspaper La Libre Belgique.

Edgar Rickard of 42 Broadway speaking as financial agent for President Hoover, characterized as "sneer rubbish" and "campaign gossip" yesterday recent reports concerning large shrinkages in the President's personal fortune.

Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany, in his first address over the radio to American listeners last night, sought to set at rest any fears entertained by his auditors that he or his colleagues favored a German dictatorship. He declared emphatically that neither he nor his Ministers would lend support to any such movement.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA., Inc. CAMP. TWO, NANGA PARBAT, Kashmir, July 21 (by runner to Astor, July 29): -- The fine weather with which this expedition has been favored has broken at last, and Fritz Weissner, Felix Simon and I have been held up here four days by storms.

A long-term lease of the Standard Oil Company's waterfront property at the foot of East Tenth Street has been taken by the C.O. Rudolph Warehouse Company, it was announced yesterday. This was the first deal involving an industrial property to be negotiated in some time, according to Harrison S. Colburn, broker, who arranged the lease.

As Governor Roosevelt plunged yesterday into a detailed study of the reply of Mayor Walker to the removal charges started by Samuel Seabury, the belief grew in informed quarters here and at Albany that the next important move in the case would be the fixing of a date for a public hearing.
Municipal Salaries Up, Expenses Down. The latest cost of living statistics illumine the current controversy over proposed reductions in the salaries of municipal employes.

OTTAWA, July 29. -- An increase in the Canadian duty on American anthracite from 40 to 75 cents a ton in response to overtures from the United Kingdom delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference appeared as a possibility today. American observers here were inclined to discount the idea of any such drastic increase, but believed there might be a rise of 15 cents a ton.
ST. LOUIS, July 29 -- (AP). -- The Washington Senators pounded three Brown pitchers today and took the final game of the series with St. Louis, 10 to 6.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 29. -- Governor Pinchot is willing to move the "bonus army" through Pennsylvania, but not to Johnstown or any other city within its borders.

The Neptune Association anounced yesterday that its committee on wages and working conditions had received assurances from the United States Shipping Board that the present wage scale and working conditions would be continued by Shipping Board lines.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- James W. Ford, a Negro, of New York, Communist candidate for Vice President, was arrested with thirty-five others today in a police raid upon a meeting of alleged radicals among the bonus marchers.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- The Chicago Board of Trade filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today asking for a review of the Federal Grain Commission's order issued July 23 closing the grain exchange for sixty days.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- A sweeping investigation by a District of Columbia grand jury was ordered today by President Hoover into charges that ringleaders in the bonus army riots were not ex-service men but Communists and other radicals.

ALBANY, July 29. -- Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and leader the Roosevelt pre-convention camaign, will accompany Governor Roosevelt on his campaign, trips, it was learned tonight after a dinner conference at the Executive Mansion.

BERLIN, July 29. -- Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador, who called on Foreign Minister von Neurath after the address on the radio by Lieut. Gen. von Schleicher Tuesday night, departed in no doubt that the German Government was squarely behind the utterances of its Defense Minister, a semi-official bulletin today revealed.

PARIS, July 29. -- Louis Germain-Martin, French Finance Minister, was reported today to have been selected by Premier Herriot as Ambassador to the United States. It was said he would go to Washington soon to replace Ambassador Paul Claudel for negotiations on war debts.

TEXARKANA, Texas, July 29 (AP). -- Representative Wright Patman of Texas, leader of the fight for cash payment of the veterans' bonus, denounced President Hoover today for ordering the evacuation of the bonus marchers from government property in Washington and suggested that the President "use the army to drive the international banking lobby from the capital city."

Appointment of Jeremiah Milbank, banker and philanthropist, as Eastern campaign treasurer of the Republican National Committee was announced yesterday by Everett Sanders, national treasurer, and J. R. Nutt, treasurer.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Washington was quiet tonight for the first time since more than eight weeks ago, when the vanguard of the Bonus Expeditionary Force arrived here.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Little gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. In the party were Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Wagstaff 2d. Mr. and Mrs. J. Stewart Barney. Miss Estelle La Branche and Albert Granger Jr.

TOKYO, July 29. -- Referring to Nanking's complaint that Japan was appointing an envoy to Manchukuo, officials here said today the special envoy being appointed to head the Japanese administrative organs In Manchuria was not accredited to Manchukuo.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- In order to acquaint the thousands of tourists who will visit Canada and other foreign countries this year with the various customs regulations, so that unpleasantness at border ports may be avoided, the Customs Bureau today issued a statement as to the rules of entry.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Two hundred women, and children, the final remnant of the "family unit" of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, were "evacuated" today from the shelters in which they spent the night after the rout of the veterans yesterday by armed troops.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 29.--A move to prevent the use of the word "union" as a trade-mark in such a way as to deceive or mislead the public was approved today by delegates to the New York State Allied Printing Trades Council at the closing session of their convention here.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- While the ragged horde of veterans began straggling today toward a proffered haven at Johnstown, Pa., W.W. Waters, their Commander-in-chief, issued a national call for volunteers to join a "khaki shirt" movement to "clean out the high places of government."

Although, one of the three employing groups in the cloak industry reached a final settlement with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union yesterday by signing a contract in accordance with the recommendations of Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, serious difficulties over the proposed settlement arose in the other organizations.

Twenty-three replacements for the routed bonus army in Washington marched out of Madison Square at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon behind a battered flivver and an American flag, after hoarse veterans had spent three hours in the hot sun appealing for men and funds to carry on the bonus war.

PEIPING, July 29. -- The Feiping Military Council, meeting here in an atmosphere of gravest anxiety, has suspended its sittings while an important session of the Political Council has been opened to discuss the threatening situations in Jehol and North China.

Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the S.S. New York, following a European journey. The former champion's pilot brought bacK sword that Schmeling has received several offers to box in this country, and that he positively will appear in a bout in September.

PARIS, July 29.--America was swept aside in the opening singles matches of the Davis Cup challenge round today when Jean Borotra, playing inspired tennis, beat Ellsworth Vines and Henri Cochet overcame Wilmer Allison's gallant bid for victory.

Mr. JAMBS FRANCIS BURKE, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, finds the principal discharge of his functions, so far as the public is informed, in the issuance of statements, manifestoes, proclamations, or whatever these singular documents ought to be called.

The criticism of Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, that New York's magistrates, through their laxness in dealing with offenders, are largely responsible for the uncleanliness of the city's parks was termed "obviously exaggerated" yesterday by New York's Chief Magistrate, James E. McDonald.

A general spirit of optimism throughout the country is evident in the weekly reports of conditions and sentiment gathered by the reviews of trade and industry. Improvement has been noted in the cases of many small Industrial plants and there has been a greater amount of wholesale buying. Bradstreet's says in part:
