Favorites fared poorly yesterday at Empire City, where the meeting will close today. In the fourth race, which had the place of honor, M.J. Miles's Anna V.L., the Messenger filly from Weather Love, won at 15 to 1 in a field of nine.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29. -- Only cooperative action among the nations in the present crisis can save the economic system which "now functions with every last ounce of strength it possesses," and if it goes to ruin "with it goes western civilization," Dr. Wilhelm Roepke, Professor of Political Economy at the University of Marburg, Germany, warns in a sixty-five page volume entitled "What's Wrong with the World," just published by Dorrance and Company of this city.
READING, Pa., July 29 (AP). -- Pounding out four homers tonight, Reading trimmed Jersey City in the series opener, 9 to 8. Bell, Bennett, Krueger and Richbourg hit for the circuit.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walton Goelet entertained this evening with a dinner.

LATONIA, Ky., July 29 (AP). -- The popular Eton blue silks of C.V. Whitney flashed to the front today when Blot, a 5-year-old son of Peter Pan and Stigma, accounted for the Carrollton Handicap at the Latonia track.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Members of the committee that will seek the deposit of underlying securities of the Chicago Elevated Lines in order that the elevated and street-car properties may be merged into the Chicago Local Transportaion Company were announced today by Halsey, Stuart Co., reorganization managers.

PARIS, July 29. -- The market remained firm during a calm session of the Bourse today. Most of the leading stocks finished slightly higher than yesterday's closing quotations, but for the first time this week the trend failed to follow closely that of the New York Stock Exchange.
Nine creditors of the National Electric Power Company filed claims aggregating $19,000,000 yesterday with Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy.

Declaring he was always glad to see evidence that citizens of the country were trying "to think their way through the present difficult situation" instead of merely complaining about it, Governor Roosevelt has written Milton F. Hutt, foreman of the surface lines shop of the B.M.T. at Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, thanking Mr. Hutt for several suggestions he offered recently for bettering present-day economic conditions.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP). -- The story of the bonus riots in brief facts and figures, with many of the latter estimates:

LONDON, July 29. -- The financial community had a pleasant surprise today when the Great Western Railway declared a dividend of one-half of 1 per cent on its ordinary stock, despite the slump of u1,163,000 in gross receipts for the half year.

In a letter printed in another column an ex-soldier raises certain questions pertinent to the present discussion of Federal expenditures for veterans' relief. We are not in a position to comment on his third point -- namely, the advice given by the Veterans' Administration to exservice men regarding settlement of their claims.

Influenced by the strength of the stock market and by unfavorable crop reports from many sections east of the Mississippi River, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered partly yesterday and ended at gains of 2 to 6 points. Following the setback of nearly a dollar a bale late on Thursday, the October delivery rose 13 points, but again met contracts above the 6-cent level.

LOS ANGELES, July 29. -- Preferred dividend requirements on the Consolidated Oil Corporation's 8 per cent preferred stock for the entire year were earned in June, Harry F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, announced today upon his arrival here in connection with the acquisition of Richfield Oil of California.

OTTAWA, July 29 (AP) -- Frankie Parker, 16-year-old sensation of the tennis courts from Milwaukee, and George Lott, American Davis Cup veteran, today entered the final round of the Canadian championships. They will meet tomorrow for the title.

Both wind and tide were fair yesterday for twenty-eight craft that set sail in the Bayside Yacht Club's twelfth annual race of 225 miles from Little Neck Bay out around Block Island and back. Last night they were footing fast through the Sound under a northwest breeze of fifteen knots, some with their rails down.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 29. -- Leaving little doubt as to the outcome once he began his masterful play in the second set, Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York today defeated Gregory S. Mangin of Newark to gain his second leg on the men's singles bowl in the forty-fifth annual Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club invitation tennis tourney.

Lovers both of peace and prowess can find a common meeting-place in the great Stadium at Los Angeles, where today begin the great Games, Here is to be found international amity, yet competition among the nations. There is rivalry, but it is the rivalry of peace.

LONDON, July 29 (Canadian Press). -- Acting favorably on the appeal of E.R. Croft from the Supreme Court of Canada today, the judges of the judicial committee of the Privy Council upheld the validity of the Canadian statute which says that as far as Canadian vessels are concerned, Canadian territorial waters extend for twelve marine miles from the coast.
OLYMPIC VILLAGE, Cal., July 29 (AP). -- Queer place, this village! A village so strange that even Hollywood goes to it, a reversal of the usual procedure.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 29 (AP). -- Down the winding valley where the great flood spent its fury in 1889, ragged, weary remnants of the bonus expeditionary forces are straggling into Johnstown tonight for "further orders."

These orders were issued yesterday: Salary Contribution Opinions Sought. The following is promulgated for the information and for the cooperation of all members of the uniformed force of the Fire Department:

Twenty-one students from thirteen American colleges will sail today aboard the Hamburg-American liner St. Louis to spend a year in Munich, Germany, under the direction of the University of Delaware, which is establishing a department at the University of Munich like the one it has maintained at the Sorbonne in Paris for nine years.

LOS ANGELES, July 29. -- Well fortified at the shorter distances and retaining its perennial preponderant strength in the field events, the United States appears certain of gaining major honors as the athletes of the world await the opening of the track and field section of the Olympic program Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Suggestions that Foreign Minister Zalles of Bolivia, through conferences with the Chilean Foreign Minister in Santiago, had obtained what amounted to Chilean acquiescence in a war between Bolivia and Paraguay over the Chaco were discounted tonight by Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal, the Chilean Ambassador to the United States.

HAVANA, July 29. -- Policemen this morning shot Antonio Lopez Rubio, 28 years old, who ignored a command to halt when discovered entering a building which had been under guard since dynamite was found there yesterday.

While speculative operations ton the advance were again pressed with considerable vigor yesterday, the security markets at times showed some signs of fatigue. Business on the Stock Exchange was smaller by more than 600,000 shares than on Thursday, but it was still well above the recent daily average.

Editorial comment, gathered yesterday by The Associated Press, on the expulsion from Washington yesterday by troops of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, was practically unanimous in expressing the opinion that President Hoover was justified in his course.
A Republican, a Democrat, a Socialist and a Communist addressed a noisy audience of perhaps 1,200 in the auditorium of the New School for Social Research last night at 66 West Twelfth Street.
PARIS, July 29. -- The French market is virtually closed to American films by yesterday's decree requiring that all "dubbed" films be vocalized in France, according to producers' agents here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the twenty-fifth annual flower show of the Southamptor Horticultural Society and the Carder Club of Southampton, which opened today in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.
Further light on the prospects of the duck season is cast by official Canadian, statistics that have been gathered from various sources in the breeding ground areas of the Dominion.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- The White Sox defeated Boston, 4 to 3 today for the only home team victory in the four-game series.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reports for the quarter ended on June 30 a consolidated net profit of $1,572,097 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, minority interest and other charges, equivalent, after dividend requirements on 10 the 6 per cent preferred stock, to 10 cents a share on the 5,610,511 no-par shares of common stock outstanding.

FISHERS ISLAKD, N.Y., July 29. -- In a spanking breeze blowing out of the west twenty-six sloops look part in the eighth regatta of the July series of the Fishers Island Yacht Club today, providing the most exciting race of the season.

BUDAPEST, July 29. -- The trial, sentence and execution today of Emmerich Sallay and Alexander Fuerst, Communist leaders, constitutes a record, even for the swiftly moving Budapest military court. The court already has tried and sent to death ten persons since it was formed after the railway wreck at Biatorbagy last November.

Raymond D. Little, 52 years old socially prominent and former Davis Cup tennis player, whose family for many years has been identified with printing and book manufacturing in this city, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself through the mouth with a shotgun ii the bathroom of his apartment at 48 Park Avenue.

About 50 per cent of the new State end municipal financing, totaling $10,443,272, scheduled for award next week will be accounted for by a single issue, that of $5,000,000 State of Missouri 4 1/2 per cent highway bonds, due from 1952 to 1956, up for sale on Thursday.
John and Helen Smith sold to the Orivard Corner, Inc., a battery of fifty-five one-car garages on a plot 88 by 175 feet at the northwest corner of Cator Avenue and Ludlow Street, Jersey City.

Bond prices continued their upward sweep on the Stock Exchange yesterday, led by railroad issues, many of which advanced 1 to 5 points. Industrial bonds pressed forward, but utility issues, on the average, made slower progress. Leading foreign loans averaged high despite the setbacks in Austrian Government issues in the light of developments in that country's finances.

Stock Exchange call money, maturity funds and business money markets were all quiet and unchanged in quotation. Money was in good supply for every class of accommodation, but as demand was slight nothing outside of the routine requirements of the day was reported.

Pressing relentlessly on toward a goal which, for a reason clear to nobody, seems to be mostly of their own choosing, the Giants tossed off the final game of their long series with the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday and then faded out with a great sigh of relief.
PITTSBURGH, July 29. -- Three Volpe brothers, prominent in the underworld and bootlegging, were slain by imported gunmen in a flareup of Pittsburgh's gang warfare this afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, July 29. -- With the battlelines drawn for the fight on the Nurmi case, delegates to the congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation discovered this morning that the matter had summarily been taken out of their hands by the action of the federation's council in secret session last night.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 29. -- President Eamon de Valera of the Irish Free State will share the estate of his mother, Mrs. Catherine T. Wheelright, who died here June 12, with his half-brother, the Rev. Thomas J. Wheelright of West End, N.J., according to terms of her will which was probated here today.

ELIZABETH. N.J., July 29. -- Mrs. J.E. Fleming of Raritan Valley had both the best gross score and the low net at the Suburban Golf Club today in a tournament held by the Women's New Jersey Golf Association. She came home in 39 for a gross of 85 and a net of 76.

The capital readjustment plan of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company was declared operative yesterday by the readjustment committee. G.A. Biddle, secretary of the committee, said more than two-thirds of all classes of stock had been deposited and that stock would be received until Aug. 22.

The Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad operated at a loss in June, according to a statement issued yesterday. The Southern Railway reported a net loss after taxes and charges in May and the five months. The Virginian had a decline in net income after taxes and charges in May.

Governor ROOSEVELT began his latest radio talk on State finances with a homely comparison to point the moral of the entire series. Substantial savings have already been effected at Albany; the State is far ahead of this city in that respect. Some further administrative economies may be brought about, notably by reductions in the payroll.

CLEVELAND, July 29. -- Maurice Maschke, Republican county leader and former national committeeman, late today was indicted by a special grand jury on a charge of embezzlement with a count for grand larceny, in connection with $570,382 shortage in the county treasury.

In the outline of the plan of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation it is stated Incidentally that the resources of the Association of Community Chests and Councils are at its disposal to aid in administering the fund. This association has country-wide information on community resources and can offer expert local personnel in the allocation of relief.

Princess Julia Cantacuzene, grand-daughter of President Grant, will sail today for Europe on the French, liner Ile de France. C.G. Bowers, Jean Tillier, general manager of the French Line in America, and Mrs. Tillier are also to sail. Others are Willis H. Booth, Judge Harry E. Sprague.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 29 -- Although not entirely unexpected the news that the International Amateur Athletic Federation had decided to suspend Paavo Nurmi created extraordinary disappointment here and many today still clung to the hope that the congress would reinstate him.
Empire City Entries. FIRST RACE -- Purse $800; claiming; maiden 2-year-olds; five furlongs.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP). -- Discarding his blue uniform for cool civilian attire for the first time in many strenuous days and nights, Pelham D. Glassford, police superintendent, absented himself from the bonus-disturbance scene today and calmly faced President Hoover's criticism of his administration.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Soldiers patrolled the charred ruins of camps occupied until yesterday by the "bonus expeditionary force" in silent contrast tonight to the intensive fighting of twenty-four hours ago when with tear gas and the threat of fixed bayonets they routed more than 10,000 bonus seekers from their make-shift hovels.

The Austrian Government has defaulted, technically at least, on the service on its League of Nations loan, issued to investors In the principal financial centres of the world in 1923 in the amount of $126,000,000, of which $25,000,000 was placed in the United States.

Mayor WALKER'S answer to Governor ROOSEVELT consists, like all Gaul, of three parts. One is a stump speech about the Republican "plot" to remove him from office and about the malevolence and dishonesty of Judge SEABURY. This is irrelevant surplusage and may be ignored.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The columns of THE TIMES have been full, lately, of letters, editorials and special articles hammering home the necessity for government economy. I think we are all pretty well with you on that point, but I should like to see the whole discussion get a bit more specific.

LONDON, July 29. -- The stock markets were dull today, with little business done. British Government securities were depressed by the continued weakness of sterling, while German and Austrian bonds declined heavily on disturbing news from Central Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--The State Department received today the official invitation to the United States to be represented at the International Monetary and Economic Conference called under the auspices of the League of Nations.

PARIS, July 29. -- Redfern opens the Paris Winter fashion salons by abolishing the waistline in a slim but not fitted princess silhouette. Big sleeves are continued with squaretop puffs to the elbows, then tight to the wrists.

OTTAWA, July 29. -- Indications at the imperial economic conference here today were that there would be a compromise between Great Britain on one side and Canada and Australia on the other on the demand of the latter two for a total embargo by Great Britain on Soviet exports.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- A match race between Playdale and Annimessic, the first of its kind in the Chicago racing district this year, occurred at Arlington Park today in the Lakeview Claiming Stakes at one mile and a half.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 29. -- Mayor Walker, after a hurried trip from New York City in a special car, arrived at the bedside of his brother, George Walker, who is ill in a private sanatorium in this village, today. With Mayor Walker during his visit with his brother were his sisterin-law, Mrs. George Walker; Dr. William Walker and two nieces, Dorothy and Helen.

The National Employment Exchange, organized twenty-one years ago with the backing of John D. Rockefeller, J.P. Morgan and other financiers as a charitable enterprise devoted to finding jobs for the unemployed, may be closed as the result of a decision handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- How the United States reluctantly sent troops to Siberia in 1918 under constant pressure of the Allies for intervention is disclosed in detail in a volume on Foreign Relations of the United States, entitled "Disintegration and Foreign Intervention" in Russia, published by the State Department today.

Communities of the State of New Jersey had collected, on Dec. 31 last, 69.60 per cent of the 1931 tax levy, According to figures made public yesterday by Walter R. Darby, State Commissioner of Municipal Accounts. This compared with 72.936 per cent of the 1930 levy collected on Dec. 31, 1930.

LOS ANGELES, July 29. -- Menus for the foreign athletes have proved quite a problem for H.O. Davis, director of the Olympic Village. Prepared for all sorts of fantastic food requests, Mr. Davis was very much surprised when the vistors arrived with requisitions for regular American food.

Possibly because speculative Interests were becoming more cautious, trading on the Stock Exchange was less active yesterday than in the excited operations of Thursday. However, the tone of the market remained strong and the trend was upward most of the day.

Savings tanks and insurance companies holding mortgages on a long list of Manhattan and Bronx properties again were active yesterday at liquidation sales involving the mortgaged holdings. Auctioneers conducting forced sales on about twenty parcels of real estate in the two boroughs struck down the liquidated properties to representatives who offered bids for interested parties.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- President Hoover today observed a custom of years' standing when at luncheon he partook of bread similar to that being served on the training tables of athletes of the nations gathered in Los Angeles for the Olympic Games.

Charles V. Vickrey, president of the Golden Rule Foundation, has left on a transcontinental automobile tour on which he will confer with committees in several large cities to discuss the observance of Golden Rule Week, from Dec. 11 to 18.

Mayor Walker's proposal of a voluntary cut in the salaries of city employes received its first serious setback yesterday. It became known that the sentiment among the members of the Uniformed Firemen's Association was against the plan. The association includes in its ranks virtually the entire personnel of the Fire Department.

B.G. De Sylva, who is co-author with Laurence Schwab of the forthcoming "Humpty Dumpty," will journey to New York from California next week to help prepare the production. He will bring with him the completed score by Nacio Herb Brown and Richard Whiting.

MONTREAL, July 29. -- Difficulties of the newsprint companies operating in Canada were regarded as increased when cable news was received from London that Lord Beaverbrook had withdrawn his plan of reorganization for Price Brothers Co.

OTTAWA, July 29 (Canadian Press). -- Captain Wolfgang von Gronau, transatlantic flier, arrived here today from Montreal with the statement that "if there were a good organization it would not be difficult to make the northern circle route from Europe to America a regular service."

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Senator Harrison opened the weekly Democratic national radio campaign tonight with the statement that the Hoover Administration had waited "two long years after the economic collapse" before offering a program to meet it.

OTTAWA, July 29. -- Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the dominion delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference today something about the improved financial situation of the United Kingdom. At least one dominion has interpreted this as a hint that Great Britain is planning to do something to help them by reduction of their debts to her.

The New York Stock Exchange firms of Rhoades Co. and Williams, Nicholas Moran will consolidate on September 1 under the name of Rhoades, Williams Co., it was announced yesterday. The new firm will conduct a general commission business in securities, and will continue as specialists in several leading issues on the Exchange.
LONG BEACH, Cal., July 29. -- America's eight-oared racing crew will make its opening bid for a second successive Olympic championship against formidable opposition.

The stockholders of the Aeolian Company and toe American Piano Corporation have approved the merger of these two companies into a newly formed organization to be known as the Aeolian American Corporation, according to a joint announcement yesterday by William H. Alfring and George Foster, presidents, respectively, of the two companies.

Four armed men entered Finkenberg's furniture store, 2,279 Third Avenue, at 124th Street, yesterday morning, and after, shooting and seriously wounding a Negro employe who surprised them in the hold-up escaped with $2,300 of a $6,000 pay roll.

BERLIN, July 29. -- The Boerse opened irregular today, but improved in the course of trading until there was a fairly uniform advance in which the usually less active stocks benefited. Confidence in the stability of the present government is growing, but in view of the approaching elections today's rise was attributed to the speculators.

Nearly 5,000,000 automobiles of American registry entered Canada in 1931, a decline of about 10 per cent from the previous year's figure, it was announced yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, a vice president of the New York Automobile Club. The exact figures for the two years were 4,909,989 and 4,410,520.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not to the principle of economy involved in the Mayor's proposal that many are opposed. Municipal employes should at this time, in a general way, contribute to a reduction of the 1933 budget. But it is the means to this end suggested by the Mayor that are objectionable.

Sharp criticism of the turn of events in the government's handling of the bonus seekers in Washington was expressed here yesterday by Representative La Guardia, the Communist party in New York, Norman H. Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, and by the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners.

Eight American directors of the late Ivar Kreuger's International Match Company are to be sued for general neglect of their duties as directors and trustees and on the specific ground that they paid dividends from capital, according to an announcement made yesterday to the Federal referee, Oscar Ehrhorn, by James N. Rosenberg of counsel for the Irving Trust Company, as Federal receiver and trustee in bankruptcy.

THE phone kept ringing and the recurring question was: "Who won the tennis matches abroad?" The answer, of course, was melancholy, verging on the morbid. The French fired with both barrels and did horrible execution. In this sad moment, what should be said?

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial agitating repeal of the law on disability allowances to veterans shows how absolutely unfamiliar you and others in lucrative positions may be concerning the position of the men who are in the majority of cases receiving this stipend from the government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., July 29. -- Too bad about this affair in Washington. Personally, I think the whole idea, of this pilgrimage was ill advised, and no doubt did their cause harm, but they have their side of it too.

Residents of New York City evidently are becoming better able to stand hot weather, since deaths from sunstroke are far fewer than they were thirty years ago, Dr. Shirley W. Wynne. Health Commissioner, announced yesterday. He urged, however, that the common hot weather precautions be observed, warning that the usual peak season for heat prostration and sunstroke deaths is at hand and that too much exposure to the sun is harmful.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 29. -- The 2,400 young men of the Citizens' Military Training Camp here returned this morning from their overnight hike and entered the homestretch in the four-week training period. The Twenty-sixth Infantry Band played as the young men marched back into their company streets.

From the mass of evidence offered to Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday as proving untrue the claim of Thomas Patrick Morris to filial kinship with John Gottlieb Wendel and ownership of most of the $30,000,000 Wendel estate emerged testimony that Wendel was a penman with two differing scripts and that the signature on the will produced by Morris "seemed familiar" to a man who knew both styles.

Patients of the body-and-soul clinic, conducted by Dr. Edward S. Cowles, in St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bouwerie used the period of the clinic yesterday afternoon for a mass meeting, at which they decided to continue their use of the church on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays despite the notice served by the vestry on June 28 that yesterday was to be their last day.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Predicting default of the Aug. 1 interest payment on the 54,200,000 first mortgage bonds now outstanding against the Hotel LaSalle, a bondholders' protective committee, headed by Francis E. Manierre, has been formed, and has requested owners of bonds to deposit their securities with Halsey, Stuart Co. immediately.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP). -- Jack Saltzgaver, Newark second baseman, pounded out a homer in the eleventh inning to give the Bears a 10-to-9 victory over Baltimore in the first game of the series today.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--A nine-point program looking to business recovery along a broad front was submitted to the nation today by President Hoover in making known what he is doing to make immediately operative the far-reaching relief program of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP).--Vice President Curtis late today bestowed upon Amelia Earhart the Distinguished Flying Cross voter her by Congress for being the first woman to fly alone across the Atlantic Ocean.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Predicting default of the Aug. 1 interest payment on the 54,200,000 first mortgage bonds now outstanding against the Hotel LaSalle, a bondholders' protective committee, headed by Francis E. Manierre, has been formed, and has requested owners of bonds to deposit their securities with Halsey, Stuart Co. immediately.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP). -- Jack Saltzgaver, Newark second baseman, pounded out a homer in the eleventh inning to give the Bears a 10-to-9 victory over Baltimore in the first game of the series today.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--A nine-point program looking to business recovery along a broad front was submitted to the nation today by President Hoover in making known what he is doing to make immediately operative the far-reaching relief program of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 29. -- With the awarding of commissions and prizes to students, the first section of the Camp Dix citizens' military training course, which has featured Signal Corps work, closed this afternoon, with ceremonies conducted by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, and witnessed by many visitors.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 29. -- No perjury indictments will be sought at present against the thirteen members of the Nassau County Police Department who have already been indicted on charges ranging from manslaughter to assault in connection with the death of Hyman Stark, District Attorney. Elvin N. Edwards announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- While some of the Senators who are in Washington expressed the view, privately, that the Federal Government acted hastily in evicting the veterans from government property, the only one to speak out was Senator Black, who was a Captain of field artillery during the World War.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- An expedition from the Naval Observatory has established a base in Maine for observation of the total eclipse of the sun Aug. 31, the Navy Department announced today. Construction of a tower for the sixty-five-foot telescope and other structures for astronomical apparatus has been started, at the base, which is between Limerick and Limington, Me.

VENICE IT takes a fine connoisseur to recognize all, or even the best known, varieties of wine. Ask him into a cellar, blindfold him and put him to the test. It is a thing that is still being done in the cool recesses dug under the hills of Champagne or of the Rhine.
AFTER five months of intensive deliberation, the First General Conference for the Limitation and Reduction of Armaments, as it is officially designated, has adjourned until Jan. 29, 1933.

Motor vehicle registrations increased from 10,500,000 in 1921 to 25,800,000 in 1931 and the average license tax fee advanced from $11.71 to $13.34, according to a report on "The Taxation of Motor Vehicle Transportation," the completion of which was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

BERLIN, July 30 -- The von Papen Government threw its weight into the campaign tonight with a manifesto summoning Germany to the polls tomorrow and a ringing radio plea by the Chancellor that his government be maintained in office "to lead in building Germany anew and stronger."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 30 -- Serious objections to President Hoover's proposal to reduce "defense" components of armies by one-third and criticism of the national defense act of 1920 were voiced at the Institute of Politics today by officers of the Foreign Policy Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who has believed for nearly twenty years in the possibility of an American ballet, as distinct from the so-called dance concert or dance recital, I found much that was stimulating and provocative, if not much that was encouraging, in John Martin's survey of the factors for and against such an institution in THE TIMES of July 24.

LONDON As in previous years, J.B. Priestley has shrewdly timed the appearance of his new novel for the "dead season" -- the period when a new book has comparatively few competitors for the attention of the press and the public.

PARIS THE Academic Francaise and the Sorboane have locked in mortal combat. M. Brunot, aged doyen of the Sorbonne and a great grammarian, has analyzed, with severity, the grammar published by the academy and has declared it full of errors.

VIENNA, July 12, 1932 THE composer of "Schwanda, der Dudelsackfcifer," Jaromir Weinberger, has just completed a new opera, the libretto for which was written by Milos Kares, who based it on a story by Bret Harte. The opera, the scene of which is laid in the California gold fields at the time of the great gold rush, is called "Die Leute von Poker Flat" ("The People of Poker Flat").

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision handed down yesterday in the Wendel case, recognized nine more fifth-degree claimants to the estate, and ordered counsel for the estate, which has conceded these relationships, to submit a motion to strike out the names of about 1,800 other persons who claim relationship in more remote degrees.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 30 -- Fast harness races today at the fair grounds provided some blanket finishes. Harry Pownall of the Nassau Driving Club captured two of the six races, scoring with Austin Verity's bay gelding Peter Laconda, which beat Calumet Arthor and Trumpet in 2:10 1/2 and 2:10 1/4.

The flaring up of an old quarrel after they had been drinking resulted in the strangling in the Hotel Richmond, 70 West Forty-sixth Street, early yesterday morning of Florence Miller, 32 years old, by her roommate. Jean White, 28, according to the police.

THE large exhibition of Childe Hassam's paintings, drawing and etohings still open at the Guild Hall, East Hampton, appears to be having the success any exhibition of Mr. Hassam's work deserves. The Leonard Claytor Gallery, which is sponsoring it, sends in word that the attendance runs to 150 a day.

ALBANY, July 30 -- Stressing economic issues as the keynote for the Presidential campaign, Governor Roosevelt in a radio speech tonight called for the lowering of trade barriers through tariff revision to make cancellation of war debts owed the United States unnecessary.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- The primary election to be held in Missouri next Tuesday brings to a close the greatest free-for-all battle in the recent political history of the State.

THOUSANDS of miles from the show mart of the world -- Broadway -- which he had helped make famous throughout the globe, in a hospital in Hollywood there died a week ago Friday a genius -- Florenz Ziegfeld.

HALL JOHNSON, whose Negro choir will sing at the Stadium concerts Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, has commented on the reasons for developing his organization and the manner of group singing in the following interesting paragraphs:

BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- Today's news from both Bolivia and Paraguay indicates that a state of war already exists in the Gran Chaco without formal declaration and that both republics are on a war footing, the mobilization and supplying of armies taking precedence over everything else.

Except that its velocity was lower, yesterday's share market differed little from those of the previous few days. Representative issues in all sections continued to plod ahead, many of them reaching the highest level of the current movement. Transactions on the Stock Exchange approximated 910,000 shares, which was at the rate of more than 2,200,000 shares for a full five-hour day.

LONDON. WHILE the British Empire is turning "a new page of history" in trade relations among the dominions, plans are also afoot to link the far-flung empire by radio. England has completed plans to build a forest of masts to hold aloft a monstrous cobweb of wires at Daventry so that wave lengths can be quickly juggled to reach all parts of the world.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 30 -- A declaration of war is only a question of hours, according to reports from the Bolivian-Paraguayan frontier, where actual hostilities commenced several days ago.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Although there were isolated signs of improvement, little change appeared in the condition of most of our foreign markets covered by the current weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.
Even in these days of abundant catches of bluefish there is one just reported by Ned Schafer that takes a place well at the top of the list.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 30 -- Everett Sanders, President Hoover's campaign chief, arrived in Plymouth this afternoon to be the guest of former President and Mrs. Calvin Coolidge over the week-end. Mr. Coolidge, with a chauffeur, drove the forty miles to Rutland to meet Mr. Sanders, who came to Vermont by train.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 30 -- The renomination of Governor Cross has become almost a certainty in the last few days, the Governor having, after some hesitation, given his consent to run again. His decision was made known to party leaders after several conferences.

Dispatches from Ottawa have paid much attention to American branch factories in Canada. Great Britain is seeking a larger market for her manufactures in the Dominions. She encounters competition not only from their industries but from goods made by American producers operating through subsidiary organizations.

LONDON, July 30 -- A company headed by Lord Essendon, chairman of the Furness Withy shipping interests, was formed today to operate the vessels of Lord Kylsant's once gigantic Royal Mail fleet running between England and South American ports and through the Panama Canal.

LOUISVILLE, July 28 -- Two court decisions this week will make it necessary for both major parties to choose their nine candidates for Congress at a State-wide primary from the State at large. Three judges of the United States Court, Judge Charles Moorman of the United States Court of Appeals; Judge A. M.J. Cochran and Judge Charles I.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Hoover reorganized the Shipping Board today under the terms of the economy act by reappointing three of the present members, including T.V. O'Connor of New York, the present chairman.

Broadcasting of the speech delivered by Ambassador Mellon at the dinner of the American Society in the Savoy Hotel, London, on July 4, caused a garbled version to reach this country. Following is the text of the address as delivered:

SHANGHAI, July 30 -- A new Chino-Japanese crisis of the utmost gravity was precipitated late today when T.V. Soong, the Finance Minister, announced that the Chinese Government was withholding payment of the Japanese portion of the Boxer indemnity due tomorrow, amounting to about $150,000.

The appeal made ten days ago to Interborough Rapid Transit Company holders asking for the deposit of 7 per cent and 6 per cent notes with two committees headed by J.P. Morgan and Charles Hayden was clearly undertaken to obviate funding the issues at their respective Sept. 1 and Oct. 1 maturities so that the resumed unification proceedings might go through uninterrupted by any considerations other than the value of the property.

A last we are to have expert testimony on prohibition enforcement. Izzy Einstein, the merest whisper of whose name was once enough to make the boldest scofflaw blanch with terror, has written his reminiscences, which will be published this Fall by Frederick A. Stokes Company under the title "Prohibition Agent No. 1." Izzy has a record of having arrested nearly 5,000 boot-leggers and beer-runners.

REFLECTING the gain in sentiment and the rise in security and commodity markets, retall trade showed more life during the week in this and, according to reports, in other sections of the country. Some of the higher-class stores here remarked on the improvement, while at the same time price promotions put on new vigor.

A heavy increase in the number of buyers visiting wholesale apparel markets here last week brought only a small rise in the volume of buying, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Retailers, according to the report, are placing small orders and intend to depend upon manufacturers to supply replacements on short notice later in the season.

American Bank Note Company and subsidiaries -- Quarter ended June 30: Net income after depreciation, Federal taxes, foreign subsidiary preferred dividends, 561,056, equivalent to 68 cents a share on 89,913 6 per cent preferred shares, compared with $976, or 1 cent a preferred share for the preceding quarter and $128,984, equal after American Bank Note preferred dividends, to 9 cents a share on 652,773 common shares, for second quarter in 1931.
OTTAWA, July 30 -- A proposal to create an empire economic court, with, its seat in London, will be laid before the, Imperial Economic Conference, it was reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- Vice President Curtis, before a throng of 100,000 persons which filled the Stadium in Exposition Park, proclaimed open today the tenth modern revival of the ancient Olympic Games.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Strolling down a road, a group of tall oaks caught my eye. Two of them were dead, and on the well-kept grounds of a country club!

WILL there ever be any new shows of consequence in New York? This question has been asked, and with more than a trace of irony, several times of late by skeptical minded folk who contemplated the unparalleled -- in recent years, at least -- inactivity of the current Broadway theatre.

The cow that produces less than 250 pounds of fat cannot make a profit for the dairyman, believes E.J. Perry, extension dairyman at the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, who bases this contention on present milk prices and the cost of running a dairy farm.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- One young man who sat on the sidelines in the Olympic Stadium today and watched the others parade was Gene Venzke of the New York A.C., the man who was hailed four months ago as a certainty to make the team.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 30 -- Under a brisk northwest breeze that dipped lee rails, 111 boats sailed today in the Riverside Yacht Club's annual regatta of the Long Island Sound championship series. The wind was too much for W.L. Gillespie's Class R sloop Live Yankee and her mast snapped off just after she crossed the finish line.

VIENNA, July 29 -- Scorning the proverbial warnings against looking into the mouth of gift horse, the Austrian parties passed the week subjecting the teeth of the gift horse from Lausanne to critical examina- tion and for the most part passed such disparaging remarks that acceptance or rejection of the loan probably will be postponed until September.

AS evidence of the success of air transport in the face of depression, witness the five months' figures for this year as compared with 1930. In the period under, consideration, which does not include the heaviest passenger months of the year, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce reports that the scheduled air lines flew 19,535,579 miles as compared with 9,690,474 in 1930 and 14,331,544 miles last year.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Ladysman, from W.R. Coe's stable of New York, won the Arlington Futurity as the Arlington Park Jockey Club's gala Summer racing season came to a close today. The race had a gross value of $54,010 and the purse to the winner was $38,010.

BERLIN, July 20 -- The American who would intelligently interpret the results of the German Reichstag elections on July 31, without getting lost in a maze of German parties and other aspects equally un-American, must first grasp the fact that, for all there are more than a score of tickets on the German Reichstag ballot, the fight really turns on just one issue: the "national movement," as it is called in Germany, against democracy.
WASHINGTON THE growing agitation for modlfication of the prohibition law has focused attention again on the question, "What is intoxicating?"

RYE, N.Y., July 30 -- Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's chestnut gelding His Elegance, Which was shown in the hunter class by Miss Caral Gimbel of Port Chester, was adjudged the champion hunter of the second annual horse show of the Westchester Country Club today.

COLLECTING match-box labels is a hobby taken just as seriously by some people nowadays as postage stamp and coin collecting. One evidence of this is the existence of a match-label collectors' club, which has members in six European countries and circulates about 20,000 labels a year.

IT is hardly an exaggeration to say that there are no purely factual books dealing with Russia since the revolution. Even statistics about the Soviets take on a white, pink or red color according to the person who gathers them or presents them.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the greater part of July continued on the smallest scale in eight years, but in the last week of the month the volume increased to such an extent as to swell the week's total of sales to the largest since February and bring the month's total up to slightly above that of June.

FOUNDED as The Daily Universal Register on Jan. 1, 1785, and changing its name to The Times three years later, England's most famous newspaper is now nearly a century and a half old. It is not the least remarkable of British institutions that have survived from the nineteenth century into the twentieth.

MUNICH SINCE American public libraries are models of their kind, a description of the new library which has been built as an adjunct of the Deutsches Museum of Munich may prove of interest. The Munich library places at the disposal of the people means of teaching themselves natural science and technology, in the conviction that such knowledge in our age is indispensable not only to the manufacturer and engineer, but to every artisan and laborer.

The Sandy Hook pilots have served notice on steamship companies that they will no longer take the responsibility of caring for visitors at sailings who "forget" to leave the ship before it sails, it became known yesterday with the sailing of the French liner Ile de France.

NO reader who has discovered the four volumes of "The Tale of Genji," which preceded "The Lady of the Boat," can fail to approach this new volume with keen anticipation. He will find no descent from the high artistry of "The Tale of Genji," "The Sacred Tree."

LATONIA, Ky., July 30 (AP) -- Suntica, owned by Willis Sharpe Kilmer, Binghamton, N.Y., scored an impressive victory in the $5,000 added Latonia Oaks, the thirty-sixth running of which featured the getaway program today at Latonia.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30 -- William Zeigler's Great Island polo team, comprised of Shaw Robinson, Gerry Smith, Lieutenant McDonald Jones and Walter B. Eaton, conquered Michael Phipps's Camels, 17-12, today at the Meadow Brook Club in the final round of the Hempstead Cup's tournament, the club's annual twelve-goal competition.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Bank debits, outside New York, for the week ended July 23 maintained the level of the preceding week, which was about equal to the June average, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

At the close of the busiest week on the Stock Exchange since the latter part of February, the share and bond markets yesterday extended their recent gains in spite of the usual Saturday realizing sales. The markets were still under the spell of the new optimism which has seized the financial community.

Communities throughout the country have launched waterfront improvements as part of their programs for unemployment relief, it is reported, and particularly on the Pacific Coast are endeavors being directed toward the construction of harborage facilities for small pleasure craft and commercial vessels.

The whereabouts of Greta Garbo Swedish film star, which has been puzzling hundreds of cinema enthusiasts in New York during the last week, was cleared up yesterday when she sailed for Gothenburg in the Gripsholm of the Swedish-American Line without being interviewed on photographed.

IN a recent issue of V.O.K.S., the official Soviet publication dealing with cultural matters and the cultural relations of the Soviet republics to other countries, there appears a survey of music conditions in Russia -- as seen through official eyes. The following excerpt deals with opera:
LONDON, July 30 -- A newspaper controversy is raging throughout England over the attack on the modern boy by C.H. Blakiston.

MOSCOW, July 29 -- The most important, event of the week here was the decree allowing petty tradesmen and artisans complete freedom to make what they want and to sell where they want and at what price they want. The decree follows the lines of the previous decree allowing peasants to trade freely in open markets, selling their excess grain and buying whatever goods are available.

IN the wake of considerable advance discussion comes the new Essex car, now on display in New York and throughout the country. Offered In the lowest-price field, the new cars, designated the "Terraplane" models, are issued as "a new type and kind of automobile."

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 30 -- A contingent of 1,400 C.M.T.C. youths from New York, Delaware and New Jersey will arrive here tomorrow to spend thirty days in drilling, shooting and hiking as students in the basic and infantry courses. The New York detachment will leave the Pennsylvania Station in a special train at 1:10 P.M., Daylight Saving Time.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Two foreign service officers who have been attached as experts to the American delegation at the disarmament conference in Geneva, have been assigned to diplomatic posts in Europe, now that the conference has recessed for several months.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 23 were 501,130 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 2,964 cars fewer than in the preceding week, 241,351 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 418,171 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Widely known headmasters of famous American schools take issue almost violently with the estimate of modern youth expressed by Cuthbert Blakiston, headmaster of Lancing College, England, in the speech he delivered before the British Medical Association last Thursday.

QUITE as strong as the human urge to travel is that other urge -- likewise human -- to tell every one all about it. That explains the postcards from Buffalo and Long Beach, where X marks the spot. That explains, also, the letters describing the Bay of Naples and the Baron on the S.S. Paris.

LONDON THE square mile which forms the ancient core of the gigantic area of urban and suburban London -- the old city of London, as distinct from the administrative county of London -- has been rebuilt time and again, but it has never undergone a more spectacular rebuilding than it has witnessed since the war.

BOSTON, July 28 -- In the report of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the trunk lines consolidation plan no part of the country is more interested than New England, even though that interest as yet is more indirect than direct. Ever since the transportation act was passed in 1920 with its consolidation provisions the future of the New England railroads has been a subject of discussion and investigation.

JOHNSTOWN, Fa., July 30--Leaders of the bonus army evicted from Washington were concentrating their tattered followers here tonight and trying to turn the veterans' crusade into a sort of Fascist movement which all "American citizens, loyal to the ideals of the Constitution," would be eligible to join.

STOCKHOLM SWEDEN is liquidating IVar Kreuger and, with him, some of its fondest illusions. Perhaps it is also liquidating a too expansive and optimistic epoch in its economic history. The Swedes are undertaking the unpalatable task calmly and stoically, frankly recognizing their mistakes, receiving foreign criticism on the whole in a fair and dispassionate spirit, adapting themselves realistically to the new and deflated circumstances, determined to regain whatever prestige they may have lost abroad.

President Hoover's action in calling out troops to expel the bonus army from Washington was characterized yesterday by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, as "a bad case of nervous irritation." He spoke at a picnic in Ulmer Park, Brooklyn, attended by about 15,000 members of the Socialist party in Greater New York.

On returning to this country after six years' absence one of the things that strike me most is the extent to which ideas and theories about planned economy and the right of labor to share the profits of capital, which formerly were regarded as subversive or visionary -- in a word, Bolshevik -- are now being discussed and seriously considered here.
Our idea of the right man in the right place is Calvin Coolidge as chairman of the advisory committee of the National Economy League.
OXFORD England, July 30.--H.G. Wells today took the almost unheard-of step of criticizing King George in a public speech.

Better sentiment regarding business was evident throughout the United States and Canada this month, according to the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. People in general, the report points out, seem to realize that there have been no detrimental influences which would cause a return of the former pessimistic feeling and, as soon as confidence is fully restored, a rush of orders can be looked for from commodity buyers.

LOS ANGELES has done itself proud and the Olympic Games now officially under way will be, unless all signs fall, the greatest set of international games in athletic history for competition, crowds and color. So much the better. We hate something to atone for in Olympic annals.

Somewhere above 50,000 feet the stratosphere begins -- a region very different from our stormy troposphere. Gales and violent changes in temperature give way to gentle breezes and intense cold. The blue sky is transformed into a darker canopy in which stars glitter by day.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 -- It is indicated that Pennsylvania will presently be in the thick of the fight against the direct primary system. The quietly gathering strength of the opposition was indicated when, without any previous campaigning, state Senator Leroy E. Chapman introduced a bill to repeal the law that has been in effect for twenty-six years.

OTTAWA, July 30 -- Neither the United States nor Argentina nor Denmark nor any other foreign country need feel that it must shut up shop because its business with the British has been shut off by Empire agreements at the Imperial Economic Conference here.

Refunding of bonds in July, before their maturity dates. increased sharply over the previous month, the total being the largest since February. Compared with a year ago, however, it was only about 25 percent of the amount then retired. Last month's total was $26,120,500, and compared with $9,102,000 in June; $98,776,500 in July, 1931, and 41,891,500 in July two years ago.

ONE regrets that Mr. Whipple called his book "Scandalous Princess," for Theresia Cabarrus, who was in turn La Marquise de Fontenay, Mme. Tallien, the mistress of Barras, to mention the most important in the long line of her amours, certainly was far from scandalous by the time she married Prince de Chimay.

Steadily gathering momentum, the wave of price advances which first broke out in the commodities, the bond market and a few scattered places in the common stock list has spread steadily over the entire stock list in the last three weeks, producing a rally the equal of which has not been seen since the first upturn after the great collapse of prices in October, 1929.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to reflect a strong stock market and the better feeling in trade and financial circles. All business was transacted at a slightly higher range of prices and the list closed at the top at gains of 4 to 6 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was the custom not so many years ago in the rural sections of New England to bury the dead in a home burial plot. In some places a lone grave may be found in the corner of an orchard or pasture, usually with brown stone head and foot markers, without inscription.

IRVING BERLIN, one hears, is preparing a musical piece for production late next season. One of the few safe bets in this soidisant business is that its producer will be Sam H. Harris. Incidentally, "Face the Music" will go on tour in the Fall with its original cast if the union, taking the times and current trends into consideration, will consent to a reduction in the number of stage hands deemed necessary for the road.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., July 30 -- The Suffolk American Legion convention, holding its annual session at the Plant Hotel here, went on record this afternoon as being opposed to the immediate payment of the bonus to veterans.
BERLIN, July 30--For the fourth time this year Germany will go to the polls tomorrow to decide her future course, this time in a Reichstag election.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., July 28 -- In contrast to last year, Northwestern Minnesota presents a cheery agricultural aspect. There is an excellent crop in prospect. Wheat has already been harvested, and there are reports of from twenty to thirty-five bushels to the acre.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (AP) -- The first champion of the 1932 Olympic games is Rene Duverger of Franca who tonight in the lightweight division of the weight-lifting contests broke the 1928 Olympic record by lifting a total of 715 pounds.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 30 -- Frankie Parker, Milwaukee's boy wonder of the tennis courts, again was the master of George Lott today as he defeated the American Davis Cup veteran in the final round of the Canadian championships. The score was 2-6, 6-1, 7-5, 6-2.

The management by the Continental Bank and Trust Company of the Fox Theatre property in Brooklyn after the Flatbush Avenue and Nevina Street Company, the owner, had defaulted on a $6,000,000 bond issue, was upheld by Supreme Court Justice Schmuck yesterday when he denied an application by Louis Grocco, a bondholder, to oust the trustee and to have a new trustee appointed.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30.--There was plenty of interest to the weekly regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the West Hampton Country Club sailed on Moriches Bay off the Speonk shore today. Not only was the weather ideal for the racing of small craft, but an excellent fleet started that included two visiting Star yachts from Narragansett Bay.

WHEN Marquis de Lafayette fitted, out a ship and sailed from Bordeaux bound for Georgetown, S.C., where he and eleven companions landed on April 24, 1777, to stir new hope in supporters of the Revolutionary cause.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau today issued regulations classing newspapers as industrial plants and not subject to the tax on electrical energy when the electricity is used in printing newspapers.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- One of the most colorful of the many dinners given this evening was that by Mr. and Mrs. E. Magawly Banon of New York at their Summer home, Lily Pond Park. The event was in honor of their house guest, Miss Fanny Washington, a great-great-grandniece of George Washington.

A refreshing optimism swept over the country last week to the accompaniment of rising commodity prices, a marked but uneven expansion in trade and industry and buoyant security markets. Reports received by THE NEW YORK TIMES from Federal Reserve centres reflect a general growth of confidence and hope, all striking a conservatively cheerful note.
LONDON, July 29 -- The annual visit of P.A.S. Franklin, American ship-owner, to England was the signal for the annual crop of rumors of impending mergers in the North Atlantic shipping trade.

ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) -- A loss of about a billion dollars to farmers of America on their last year's grain crops alone has been written into the records of the Congressional Committee conducting hearings into government operations in business, as blamable upon the agricultural marketing act.

LONDON ONE of the most important members of the royal household is little known to the British public. He is Richard Hewlett, "superintendent of the wardrobe" -- in other words, chief valet to King George.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Many sports events will engage White Mountain visitors in the coming week. Today at the Waumbek, Jefferson, there will be an exhibition golf match between Leo Diegel, Canadian open champion who played this week at Lancaster and Jefferson, and the trick shot artist, Johnny Farrell, who comes annually to tour this region.

The advance in the stock market, which last week rounded out an almost continuous recovery of three consecutive weeks, had the effect of reviving financial hopefulness. This is natural, when the business community is still in the habit of regarding the stock market as a barometer of economic trends and, more particularly, when we have learned in the two past troubled years how greatly financial apprehension may be aggravated by a prolonged decline in stocks.

Chairman SANDERS of the Republican National Committee begins well. A chairman who didn't talk at all would please many of us. Remembering his immediate predecessor, Saint SIMEON FESS, one may fairly assume until the contrary is shown that Mr. SANDERS won't keep the gates of his speech aswing; and that when he does open his mouth he will keep his foot out of it.
Popular interest his been aroused in England by the phenomenon of a "silent zone" in gunfire, which came to notice in connection with the recent review of the fleet by King George.

FRANCES PERALTA, formerly soprano with the Metropolitan Opera Company, will sing Leonora in "Il Trovatore," at an open-air performance by the Puccini Grand Opera Company at Federal Hall, Bryant Park, next Thursday evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After serving the best interests of the United States and his own country for twenty-three years Ambassador Jusserand was recalled. That recall, which caused sincere grief in both countries, has remained a diplomatic mystery.

The month-long race meeting at Saratoga, which for years has been one of the high points of the Jockey Club turf season, will begin tomorrow and, before its conclusion on Sept. 3, approximately $350,000 will have been distributed to horsemen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From all parts of the country the cry of excessive taxation is being raised. Yet comparatively nothing seems to be heard about the heavy toll of unseen taxes imposed on the people of the United States by industry.

An appeal to Republicans throughout the State to nominate for Gov- ernor Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse as a "fighting candidate" has been sent out by the Marvin-for-Governor Club of Onondaga County, with headquarters in the Yates Hotel of that city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your tribute to Senator Wagner for his conscientious and highly in- telligent work in framing the bill which will finally bring Federal relief to the unemployed, you say: "And Senator Wagner had the great satisfaction of inducing Mr. Hoover to relax his once firm refusal to ugree to a relief fund for distribution, on any tetms, to States and municipalities."
DUBLIN, July 30--Making his first appearance in any Irish farming district since the trade war with England began, President Eamon de Valera received an enthusiastic reception at Limerick tonight.

For the first month since March gold holdings in the United States increased in July, confirming the state- merits made by bankers in mid-June that the heavy withdrawals had ended. Imports at New York aggregated only $7,298,600, compared with $23,322,500 exports, but offsetting the loss was a net decrease in earmarked gold of $56,236,600 and the receipt of $8,796,000 at San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Taking up the protest of residents of Alexandria Bay, N.Y., against the conduct of Federal agents in liquor raids there July 12 and 14, Colonel Amos W.W. Woodcock, Prohobition Director, in a review of the case today based on investigation, upheld the agents except for "some unnecessary damage to property, for which they would be required to pay."

Final arrangements for rifle and pistol matches to be held in the various army corps areas all over the country during the next two months have been nearly completed, according to an announcement in the current issue of The American Rifleman, official magazine of the National Rifle Association of America.

NEWPORT -- The young people of the Summer colony appear to be coming into their own this year in the line of sports. More appear on the tennis courts of the Casino each afternoon, there are a few breaking into the game of golf, but a popular diversion this year is horseback riding.

MITCHEL FIELD, the Army Air Corps post at Garden City and Rempstead, L.I., is known to every aviation enthusiast in the country. Up to 1927 it was not only the military flying post for the district but was used continually by commercial filers, especially at night.

With the Western railroads casting about for a czar to solve their problems, with the oil industry achieving the most complete cohesion in its recent history and with steel producers significantly laying plans for a more aggressive "institute policy," it is apparent that cooperation, in the place of unbridled competition, has become the order of the day.

WHATEVER else is to be said, one is safe in the statement that J.B. Priestley can always be relied upon to turn out something that is good narrative. The author of "Angel Pavement" and "The Good Companions" has narrative "sense" -- a thing not possessed by all novelists.
EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 30 (AP) -- The victorious surge of Louis P. Stoner, 22-year-old Hartford golfer, came to an end today in the semi-final round of the Shenecossett invitation tournament.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelby Carter are leaving today for the opening of the racing season at Saratoga Springs. Afterward they will go to Newport, returning later to Villa del Raggio, Convent, N.J., for the late Summer and Autumn.

With a view to checking the decline in exports of American automobiles, which has resulted in the loss of more than 80 per cent of the market for cars abroad, leaders of the automobile industry have decided to sponsor aggressively a wide program of tariff reforms in order to destroy barriers which have restricted international trade.
PARIS, July 29 -- No jury ever had the task of trying on a capital charge a stranger prisoner than Paul Gorguloff, who on Wednesday was condemned to death for the assassination of President Doumer.
MANILA, July 30 -- Any one who makes even a superficial inquiry into the Philippine independent movement among the Filipinos themselves finds it a howling wilderness of contradictions.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- California has already begun to put its bouse in order for the convivial guest who is expected to arrive with the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Initiative petitions have been placed on the ballot for the coming election for two measures to meet the situation created by the passing of Volsteadism.

MANILA, June 26 -- Direct economic pressure has brought about in the Philippines what no amount of wise counsel and disinterested effort could accomplish -- a definite attempt to reorganize the governmental machinery on a scale better adapted to the revenues of the country.

Whatever the outcome of the contest for the Presidency, Democrats are confident that they will control the next Senate. Political observers are inclined to agree with them. The odds are on their side. Even though President HOOVER should be re-elected, there is no doubt that a strong tide against legislative "ins" exists in the country.

IN this abort book six distinguished economists gather at the bedside of a sick world, diagnose its ills and suggest remedies for its recovery. Though their prescriptions vary from Dr. Keynes's regimen of high feeding to Dr. Stamp's policy of low feeding and from Dr. Blackett's Planning Pills to Dr. Salter's International Elixir, they are in general agreement concerning the malady from which the patient has been suffering.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 30 -- The suggestion is made in the will of Paul B.J. Brorstrom, filed here today, that the village of Great Neck purchase from his estate the Theodore Roosevelt Rock Memorial, which Mr. Brorstrom built in 1918. The provision is made that the memorial be priced at $5,000 and the money be placed in trust to complete it.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Sunday, July 31 (AP) -- The Rengo (Japanese) News Agency today said Japanese headquarters here had announced conclusive proof that the noted Chinese General Ma Chen-shan had been killed northeast of Hailun.

The German Reich will vote today in what is called the most important election held since the nation became a republic. Some observers see as the real issue the fate of the republic itself, with a return to monarchy hanging in the balance. It is entirely possible that such a view represents an exaggeration.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- This will be "racketeers'" week in Bar Harbor with the international maritime tennis tournament occupying the centre of the social stage. It will be played, of course, on the courts of the Bar Harbor Club, where there will be a large gallery to watch the contests between British and American naval officers, and between officers and civilians.

THE "conjure-man" in Dr. Fisher's first mystery novel is a native African, a King in his own right, who has come to America, and after taking a degree at Harvard has settled in Harlem, where, for a consideration, he is prepared to reveal the past and foretell the future of those who wish to consult him.

FRANCE has been celebrating this Slimmer -- by a representative exhibition of his work at the Petit Palate in Paris -- the centenary of the birth of Gustave Core, whose modest Ambition it was to illustrate with his single arm the master-works of all the world's greatest writers from Homer to Victor Hugo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Coates, representing New Zealand at the empire conference in Ottawa, spoke of a large exportation of mutton and lamb from his country to the British market. When I heard mention of this, it occurred to me that the word mutton is seldom heard in the United States.

"AGAIN AND AGIN'." EVER since the good old days went over the hill to the poor house, there have been moist eyes and plaintive hopes for their return. People with little else to do have gazed upon the horizon, watchful for signs of the reappearance of what once were thought to he normal times.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- Recognition of the need for adequate regu lation in handling dangerous cargoes Was urged before the American Association of Port Authorities here today by Billings Wilson, assistant general manager of the Port of New York Authority.

Increased offerings of public utility bonds featured the new financing in July, resulting in the month's total of flotations exceeding slightly that of the previous month. New bonds aggregating $141,061,000 and one stock issue of $1,000,000 accounted for all the issues marketed.

DETROIT. JANUARY is a long way off, but the month will see the biennial sessions of forty-four State legislalures, and the automobile industry is already on the alert, extremely busy. Motor executives are concerned about the prospect of legislation, which they fear will place even further restrictions on motordom.

More than $2,000,000,000 annually has been taken out of circulation through the enforced idleness of 650,100 traveling salesmen, Fred M. Lewis, former vice president of the National Council of Traveling Salesnen's Associations and one-time president of the Textile Travelers' Association, told THE TIMES yesterday.

RADIO, a young industry, has most of its inventors still guiding and watching over its destiny, they are tireless in their efforts to give it greater magic. Last week, however, radio lost one of its pioneers, Reginald Fessenden, who contributed more than three hundred inventions to the science of wireless.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 30 -- There will be a new women's singles bowl in competition in the annual Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's invitation tourney next year, for today Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley defeated a rival Californian, Miss Josephine Cruickshank of Santa Ana, 6-4, 6-3, to take permanent possession of the present trophy.

Highway trucking must stand on its own feet and not be "kept alive and stimulated" by the taxpayers, it is contended by Edward S. French, president of the Boston Maine Railroad in a recent article in The United States Investor.

PRESIDENT HOOVER, in advocating the furlough plan calling for a five-day week for Federal employes and, in effect, suggesting a similar course to all large employers of labor, reinforced a movement that will extend well beyond the present emergency.

THERE is plenty to think and talk about in the new styles -- not that the changes are radical at this early stage of the Autumn output. (Paris is yet to be heard from regarding its Winter inspirations.) Many tendencies heralded last Spring have become actual trends, and if you recollect what they were, you will do your daily dozen with added energy, for hips must be reduced to a minimum and diaphragms flattened.

THIS is a book which may be taken from either of two points of view. One can read "Through the HawseHole" as a true narrative of adventure into distant seas in pursuit of a hazardous trade, or as the biography of the rise of an island Silas Lapham.

FOR a long time nations believed that they could remain isolated from each other and become immune against the contagion of the world crisis. Experience has proved the contrary, and it is to be toped that they will now agree to look straight at the results.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Walter W. Waters, commander of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, returning to the capital tonight from a secret mission on which he had departed in the afternoon, announced that he had acquired a wooded tract of land in Maryland about twenty miles from the District of Columbia for the establishment of a colony for the veterans.

BERLIN, July 29 --The German Labor Office's mid-July figures show that seasonal demand for labor has already ceased and that unemployment has again taken an upward trend. Barring an unexpected world turn toward prosperity, it is already certain that Germany's army of jobless men and women will keep on increasing into the Winter and there are experts prepared to forecast that the government's estimate of a peak of 6,000,000 is going to prove too low.

Declaring that the Republicans were repeating their "whispering campaign" of 1928, with Governor Roosevelt. Democratic nominee for President, as the target this year instead of former Governor Alfred E. Smith. James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee charged last night that false stories of Governor Roosevelt's physical and mental health were being circulated throughout the country.

Lower rates for both call and time loan funds featured the changes in quotations in July on the two local Stock Exchange money desks. Call-loan rates on the New York Stock Exchange, after carrying over at 2 1/2 per cent into the first week, a rate unchanged since Jan. 8, were reduced to 2 per cent on July 7 and remained so to the end of the month.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 30 -- Bobet, owned fey S.L. Raynor of Freeport, captured the cabin cruiser 35-mile handicap race which was a high light of the Great South Bay regatta, conducted by the South Shore Yacht Club off here today.

The City Administration has given no serious consideration to the program for new revenues submitted to the Mayor by several of his commissioners, it was disclosed yesterday. One suggestion was by Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission, that a "sewer rent" tax be charged property owners on a basis similar to the water taxes now paid.

ON Aug. 1 some 250 scientists of thirty-three nations will officially begin a systematic study of the earth's magnetism, atmospheric electricity, earth currents, auroral displays, weather and that intangible electrical mirror which is known as the Kennelly-Heaviside layer and which makes It possible for us to send radio messages around the world.

WHAT do all the Summer theatres mean? There have never been so many of them throughout the country as this season; I have counted between thirty and forty, as compared with little more than twenty only two or three years ago.

WOODBURY, L.I., July 30 -- One of the most colorful of the season's outdoor parties on the North Shore was the Spanish fiesta given tonight at Ben Robyn Farm by Mrs. Alicia du Pont Glendening in celebration of her birthday.

ONE of the most important pieces of legislation passed by Congress during the session, just closed was the emergency relief and construction bill. The new law directly affects the fortunes of the man in the street and has introduced, in the machinery of law-making, a note of humanity.

IN the heart of what used to be the Great American Desert, where the Colorado rushes out of its mile-deep canyons on its way to the Gulf of Lower California. American engineers are well along in the second year of what has been described as "a work ranking with the greatest ever attempted by human hands."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The prospective insufficiency of the $300,000,000 authorized for Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to States for immediate and urgent relief work under the unemployment relief act created the probability today that these relief loans will be apportioned entirely on the basis of what States have done for themselves.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Lady Margaret won the saddle horse championship at the fourth annual show of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club today. The victor, a chestnut mare, owned by Dr. Ogden M. Edwards of Donerail, Ky., showed well to score a popular triumph.

A FEW weeks ago Professor A. H. Compton reported in The Physical Review that, contrary to Professor Millikan's findings, the cosmic rays vary in intensity with the latitude, a phenomenon best accounted for by supposing them to be electrons, which, under the influence of the earth's magnetic attraction, tend to collect around the Poles.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 28 -- Apparently when, outside influences are unable to make the lot of Arkansas unbearable with criticism outside interference is injected to add to the gayety of things. This time it is the scheduled visit of Sen- ator Huey Long in the interest of Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway's re-election.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 30 -- County Judge Cortland A. Johnson declared in an interview today that although he is opposed to police brutality he is a believer in the maxim of the famous New York police chief, the late William S. (Big Bill) Devery, that "there's a lot of law in the end of a nightstick.

The National Steel Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that several changes have been made in the collateral deposited as security for its sinking fund gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due in 1956. The demand mortgage bonds of the Great Lakes Steel Corporation have been increased from $30,000,000 to $38,000,000, while the $2,000,000 mortgage bonds of the Hanna Furnace Corporation and the $6,000,000 of the Michigan Steel Corporation have been withdrawn.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- Vanitie, Gerard B. Lambert's big white sloop, evened the honors today with Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe in the second of the series of races for Arthur Curtiss Jalias's Constellation Cup as she crossed the line off Brenton's Reef Lightship nearly ten minutes ahead of the Weetamoe, which took the first race yesterday.
