LONDON, July 20 -- A spate of documents of an intriguing nature has come out of the Lausanne conference -- pacts, conventions, letters of confirmation and what not. In this labyrinth of diplomacy the public may well ask to be told the meaning of all these declarations, notices, promises and explanations.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Manchurian and Shanghai questions have gone into history, and what we would like to know now concerns the future.

Roadside Quotations. Why not have beautiful thoughts from the great poets painted on roadside signs and rocks to inspire the passing motorist? Who could object to thoughts such as "Go forth under the open sky and list to Nature's teachings" or "Full many a flower is born to blush unseen and waste its sweetness on the desert air"?

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Efforts of Governor Rolph to sound out members of the Legislature as to the expediency of calling a special session resulted in the rather curious charge by a State Senator that the Governor's canvass of the members was a misdemeanor.
CRUSADE FOR THE ANEMONE," Princess Bibesco calls this sensitive group of essays, inspired by a Journey through the Holy Land and presented in the form of a series of letters.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y. -- The Thousand Islands Country Club Invitation Golf Tournament opens tomorrow and continues throughout the week. The semi-finals for men and women competitors will be held on Thursday, and the finals on Friday.
CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- The Athletics wrested second place in the American League away from the indians with a 7-to-2 victory today. The triumph gave Philadelphia a half a game advantage.

Deceived by demagogic politicians into the belief that their immediate bonus demands are for simple justice, the collection of ex-soldiers and others who have "occupied" Washington for the last few weeks attempted Thursday to defy a government order of eviction and were bloodily dispersed by troops called out by President Hoover.

THE proposal advanced at the imperial conference in Ottawa for a great bank to serve Great Britain, the dominions and the British colonies is a reminder that the distinction of being the world's oldest central bank belongs to the Riksbank of Stockholm, which has a continuous history going back to 1668.

IF the Democrats win next Fall's national election the Roosevelts will join the Adamses and the Harrisons as the third American family to contribute two members to the Presidency. In the case of the Adamses the honor came early. The Harrisons took a little longer.

SHANGHAI, July 11 -- Alarmed at the increasing frequency of largescale strikes and other labor disturbances, the Chinese Chamber of Commerce of Greater Shanghai has sent a petition to the Kuomintang party headquarters in Nanking, asking for official assistance.

ASWEEPING vindication of the movies both as a classroom tool and, within limits, as a form of childhood recreation, has just been issued by the British Commission on Educational and Cultural Films, after a two-year inquiry.

Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Conte Grande for a rest, during which he will consult the immigration authorities in Rome upon a plan he has conceived to repatriate alien seamen stranded here.

SOUTHAMPTON -- The round of activities and diversions which was planned for the entertainment of many house parties now at various estates in the colony promises to continue throughout the coming week. The most eagerly awaited event of the Summer, the annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament, opens tomorrow afternoon on the courts of the Meadow Club.

TOKYO, July 7 -- The 1932 "Report on Progress in Manchuria," issued by the South Manchuria Railway Company, which in former years recorded the peaceful spread of Chinese colonization and Japanese enterprise, owes its chief interest to its narrative of the events which in the past nine months have wrenched Manchuria and China apart.

Residents of the Bronx, In the area served by the Olinville. Kingsbridge, Estabrook, Fairbanks and Halifax telephone exchanges, have filed with the Public Service Commission a complaint against the 10-cent rate on calls to and from points in Manhattan south of Fifty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday toy Lesser Lesser, counsel for the Northeast Bronx Alliance of Civic Associations.

PARIS, July 20 -- The Due de Richelieu and his wife, the former Eleanor Douglas Wise, who have lived much in New York, usually spend a part of each year at their Chateau du Haut-Buisson, near Ferte-Bernard, in the Sarthe.

THE conference at Ottawa among the nine States within the British Empire has once more raised the question of tariffs and world trade. The extent to which our own exports may be affected by decisions reached at this round-table meeting has still to be determined.

PARIS, July 30 -- With the full consciousness of having done their utmost and having laid a sound foundation for future work, the United States delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva left Paris for home today. With the exception of Ambassador Hugh Gibson, who returned to his post at Brussels, all sailed on the Leviathan this evening from Cherbourg.

TOKYO, July 8 -- A suicide epidemic causing the deaths of seven men and five women startled the public of Tokyo during the past week-end. Three cases of "shinju" or double suicide of lovers occurred; two young women died together; the others passed out singly.

Mrs. Theresa H. Kann, 34 years old, daughter of the late Herman Rawitser, who was a prominent woolen merchant of this city, was found dead yesterday morning in her bed in her apartment at the Hotel Lombardy, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Sixteen men have been killed by drinking wood alcohol in the latest poison-liquor outbreak that started last Wednesday on the lower east side. Three died yesterday. The police and prohibition authorities were making a hurried but careful search of the area for the source of the poison.

A fight with domestic interests over attempts to introduce American valuation as the basis for assessing duties on foreign merchandise was forecast here yesterday by importers who expect that Congress at its next session will be asked to write a new valuation provision into the present tariff law.
BUFFALO, July 28 -- Opinion in this locality is pronouncedly critical of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty. Comparatively few Buffalo voices, however, express any alarm over the effect on the city.

Control of the patents for the hydrogrenation process for the manufacture of oil products has passed to fifteen leading refining companies in the United States. This became known when it was announced that stockholders of the Hydro Patents Company, which controls these patents in the United States, had elected a board of directors composed of representatives from these oil-refining companies.

The threat of a strike in the garment industry was renewed yesterday by the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, in the event a satisfactory disposition is not reached tomorrow by the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association on the question of relationship of Brooklyn contractors.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 30 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's radio address here tonight is as follows:

PITTSFIELD, Mass -- The annual golf tournament at the Wyantenuck Club, Great Barrington, is to start on Wednesday and will continue through Saturday. This is always the first major tournament in the Berkshires and seven hundred Invitations were sent out.

LAKE PLACID -- Certainly no other week of this season, and probably none in any preceding season, has been so featured by carefully scheduled recreation and entertainment as that upon which the Adirondack and Champlain Valley regions are now entering.

That unsettled conditions existing in the American cotton industry are being prolonged through the persistent selling of cotton by the Farm Board or cotton cooperatives and the failure of the Farm Board to outline to the trade a definite policy as to its future disposition of some 3,500,000 bales of cotton which it either owns or controls is said to be the opinion of virtually the entire trade.

VIENNA, July 12, 1932 THE recent festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music here presented the latest works of the contemporary schools in two orchestral and two chamber music concerts. Some of the public compared the austerity of these works with the splendor of the classic concerts which had preceded.

GREYSTONE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 30 -- Trailing Maurice McCarthy Jr. by two strokes going into the last round of the Sweetser Victory Cup tourney today, John E. Parker Jr., captain of the Yale golf team, put on a brilliant finish at the Hudson River Country Club to win the event by one stroke.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Dickinson, keynoter at the recent Republican National Convention, challenged Governor Roosevelt in a radio address today to explain the "new deal" he promises.

THE life and voyages of Sir, Francis Drake as we know them have the qualities of breathless adventure, courage and swift, decisive action that are peculiarly appealing to young readers. There have come down to us, too, indications of a very likable personality.

The second dead heat of the season on the Jockey Club tracks occurred yesterday at Empire City when James Butler's Apprentice and William Woodward's Pardee finished so close together that the judges decided on a tie. The only other starter, Mr. Butler's filly Star Fire, was five lengths back of the pair which waged so bitter a battle for the victory.
MEXICO CITY, July 3D -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President of Mexico, resigned tonight as Minister of War and Marine, his resignation being regretfully accepted by President Ortiz Rubio.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- The Phils checked the rush of the Pittsburgh Pirates by defeating them in both ends of a double header today before 18,000 fans. The scores were 7 to 4 and 13 to 3.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- Against the strongest and most widely representative challenging array of athletes ever assembled, the United States track and field team will start the defense of its world's championship tomorrow on the newly laid cinder path and carefully groomed infield of the Olympic Stadium.

PARIS, July 30 (AP) -- France has committed herself to allow debt revision negotiations with the United States to lie dormant until sentiment in America is more favorable and possibly until the Presidential election is over, it was learned on high authority today.

THE refusal of the German Supreme Court at Leipzig to grant the ousted Prussian Government a temporary injunction restraining Chancellor von Papen from further intervention as Reich commissioner in the internal affairs in Prussia is the opening incident in what seems sure to become a bitter constitutional quarrel.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- With the city cleared of the bonus marchers and the troops withdrawn, an order was issued to the police by the Dis- trict Commissioners late today to check any attempt at further invasions of the capital.

READING, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- The Reading Keys won a double-header from Jersey City tonight, capturing the first game by a score of 8 to 5 and the second by 11 to 10. By winning Reading supplanted the visitors in sixth place in the International League race.

OTTAWA, July 28 -- Sean T. O'Kelly, head of the Irish Free State delegation at Ottawa and Vice President of the Executive Council of his government, takes exception to the article by P.W. Wilson in THE NEW YORK TIMES of last Sunday on the British-Irish controversy so far as it concerns the land annuities.

ARRANGING the comers of a room so that they are usefully occupied and as attractive as possible is always a test of a decorator's skill. Because of the need today to utilize all of the space in our homes we find both professional and amateur decorators giving the corner more thought than formerly and, as a result, improving on some of the devices of the past.

Dividend announcements by corporations in July, as in previous months this year, continued to refleet the drastic decline in company earnings and were replete with reduced and omitted payments to shareholders. Disbursements voted by 710 corporations to stockholders aggregated $134,577,492, compared with payments of $220,390,702 by 1,091 corporations in July, 1931.

DETROIT, July 30 -- Phillips's single, Pipgras's neat bunt and a ringing one-base hit by Combs put over the seventh-inning tally which enabled the Yankees to eke out a 5-to-4 victory over Detroit in the series opener today. It was their second triumph in six games played since leaving home.
BERLIN July 30 (AP) -- With bloodshed and blistering oratory, Germany today closed the campaign for tomorrow's Reichstag elections.

Several churches will hold their last services today until after Labor Day. Some of the congregations doing so will join in union services at near-by churches that are not to be closed for the Summer. After today the congregation of the Second Presbyterian Church will unite with that of the Central Baptist Church.
The tennis scene will shift to Long Island this week, with the Maidstone Club courts at East Hampton being the setting for the annual invitation tournament.

IN this tall volume the Sandars Reader in Bibliography at the University of Cambridge and typographical expert of The London Times has essayed a new and difficult task. He has collected and selected materials to show the format and the changes in it of English journals from their beginnings as pamphlets in the seventeenth century, their progress to biweekly, triweekly, daily, morning and evening.

IT is perfectly obvious that the general public will not continue to patronize the airlines unless the service is really convenient and appreciably faster than surface transportation. Furthermore, when the word "faster" is used it must be clearly defined as the actual elapsed time between centres of population, rather than the running time of plane versus train, which is so frequently emphasized when comparative figures are presented.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colonies in Southampton, East Hampton and West Hampton attended the horse show today at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. There was entertaining throughout the day at various estates for week-end guests.

THE deadly seriousness of E. Tietjens is appalling. So also is his undeniable cocksureness that the gospel he brings is the only gospel that can save the world. It is his very own theory, his own discovery, his one ewe lamb and therefore he loves it and believes in it beyond everything else in the whole gamut of man's knowledge.

BLACK ROCK, Conn., July 30 -- John Field's Margot won the Atlantic Class event in the sixth Saturday race of the Black Rock Yacht Club today, beating Norman J. Gaynor's Wawbeek 2d by one minute and nineteen, seconds.

EACH generation is able to look back upon the published wisdom of past ages and smile out of its superior knowledge or sophistication. There are ideas and forces current in our own time that will surely afford amusement to a later society.

LOS ANGELES THE exhibition which Leila Mechlin of the American Federation of Arts has organized at the Los Angeles Museum, as a sort of side show for the Olympic Games, is notable principally for its size and cosmopolitan character.

IN these columns last Sunday were shown a map and story devoted to the various ways of reaching Montreal and Quebec. In themselves these cities constitute motoring meccas of the first magnitude, but other localities in the Province of Quebec also offer superlative attractions, scenically and historically -- Murray Bay, the spectacular Saguenay River, Lake St. Jean, Laurentides National Park and the worldrenowned Gaspe Peninsula.
RYE, N.Y., July 30 -- A representative group from Westchester County attended today the Horse Show on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club here.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The first annual Hague regatta will be held on Aug. 18 on the Trout House beach at Hague on Lake George, under the auspices of the Association of Private Camps. It will consist of swimming races, diving contests and canoe events, and is open to all camps on the lake.

ROME, July 29 -- The announcement of plans already under way for a great exhibition oof modern architecture to be held in Milan next year is awaited with particular interest by Italian architects because the project is expected to mark a determined effort to break away from traditional forms and to recover the ground separating Italy from other countries in the vanguard of recent architectural developments.
LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- Olympic Stadium, which is the hub of the tenth Olympiad, is the most colossal structure of its kind in the world.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox reached three of the Washington Senators' hurlers for ten hits and an 8-to-5 victory today in the series opener. Milt Gaston also gave ten hits, but kept them scattered.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney made public yesterday the report of the committee on regulation of motor handbrakes, appointed by him early last year to devise a standard test. Simultaneously he issued a general order amending the departmental manual of procedure to establish a brake testing practice in accord with the report.

The New York Credit Men's Association, affiliated with the National Association of Credit Men, proposed yesterday that the United States take part in an immediate international conference having as its object "the expansion of commerce, the revival of business and the return to normalcy."

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Chicago's position at the junction point of the projected St. Lawrence Seaway and the Lakes-to-Gulf waterway, now nearing completion, gives it a particular interest in the treaty signed with Canada for construction of the former enterprise.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, Governor General of the Philippines, expects to return to this country about the middle of September to assist in the campaign for the re-election of President Hoover, it was learned yesterday from friends here.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index for the week ended July 23 stands at 54.2, unchanged from the preceding week. This continues for the second week the record low of the depression made in the week ended July 16.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Illustration Declining" was most timely. Why not a return to the beautifully illustrated popular magazine -- and so to the illustrated novel? We have popular magazines with illustrations in them, but are the latter beautiful? And the "teen" ages are the biggest buyers of thege magazines.

For about a year before Mr. ZIEGFELD died the advanced guard in musical entertainment had been running after a more agile style of showmanship. "Three's a Crowd" and "The Band Wagon" were less imposing than Mr. ZIEGFELD'S pageants, but they suited better the wry mood of the day.

DETROIT, July 28 -- The signing of the St. Lawrence seaway treaty has received unanimous approbation in Detroit, not only because manufacturers of export goods have been advocating the improvement for the last twenty years, but also because all business interests are convinced that completion of the waterway will increase greatly the prosperity of the raid-West section, which buys heavily of Detroit and Michigan products.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest THE TIMES editorial "The New Hampshire Plan." It so happens that in my book "The Price of Peace," recently published, I discussed the subject of a shorter workday and arrived at the conclusion that such action appeared to be fundamentally unsound and should be resorted to as a temporary expedient only. I said:

COMMERCIAL education, the man in the street will tell you, is mainly concerned with bookkeeping, shorthand and typewriting. Yet this is far from the view of the hundreds of business men, economists and teachers from some forty countries who have been deliberating its problems in London at the Triennial Congress of the International Society for Commercial education.

THIS is the first rendition in English of one of Flaubert's early works, his most personal novel. The translation deserves nothing but praise. And "November" is a finished product of the master as a young man. It is welcome in its own right as well as for its autobiographical import and the evidence it gives us as to Flaubert's genius striving toward ultimate expression.

THE Art Bulletin, an illustrated quarterly, published by the College Art Association of America, contains three scholarly and exhaustive articles by specialists in several fields. James J. Rorimer of the Metropolitan Museum discusses a fourteenth century Catalan tomb, from the Monastery of Santa Maria de Bellpuig de Las Avellana, near Lerida, which was presented to the Metropolitan Cloisters by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in 1928.

DETROIT, July 30 -- Henry Ford, 69 years old today, predicted a bright future for America, with fewer large cities, a land populated by happy, industrious people who will have "one foot in industry and the other firmly established in the security of the soil."

Should Governor Roosevelt decide to remove Mayor Walker from office, Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, would succeed him automatically and serve as Mayor until midnight of Dec. 31, 1933, and there would be no election of a Mayor next November.

Direct radio telegraph communication between the United States and Hungary was successfully begun yesterday with an exchange of greetings between President Hoover and Admiral Nicholas von Horthy, Regent of Hungary, according to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

More commodities on local Exchanges advanced in the last week than in any previous week this year. The outstanding grains were made in the coffee market, stimulated by the revolt in Brazil, but there were also gains in sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and silver, with wool tops alone lower.

OTTAWA, July 28 -- The Parliament of Canada unquestionably will give its approval to the St. Lawrence Waterway treaty with the United States if and when that document has received the approval of the United States Senate. The government, of course, is committed to the project and it has a commanding majority in both houses of Parliament.

TEACHING of reading as a college as well as a grammar school subject was advocated recently before the Institute for Administrative Officers at the University of Chicago by Professor William S. Gray of the School of Education at the university.

CLEVELAND, July 28 -- A thirty-six-year-old, water tower that failed to function on the night flames destroyed the Eilington Apartments here and killed twelve residents is Exhibit A before a committee of city officials and citizens, which is struggling this Summer with the problem of raising funds to improve the Cleveland Fire Department.

TORONTO, Ont., July 30 -- For the first half of this year British Columbia shows total mineral production of a value of $14,336,000, according to figures presented by W. A. McKenzie, Minister of Mines for the Province. The report makes special mention of the increased output of gold which rose to $1,881,137.

NEW YORK'S budget is receiving widespread attention for the first time since the consolidation of the Greater City in 1898. It is provoking intense interest and intelligent discussion, for the times are unusual and we are face to face with realities.

LONDON, July 30 -- Stocks were irregular in extremely quiet trading today. British Government securities rallied after a heavy start and closed with small gains. The internationals reflected the improvement in Wall Street by advancing all along the line.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- Amid the roar of cannon, the crashing of bands and the liberation of thousands of pigeons which soared high above the lofty Stadium ramparts beneath a benign welkin, the tenth modern revival of the ancient Olympic Games was officially declared open today by Vice President Curtis in Exposition Park.

RICHMOND, July 28 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt's stand on prohibition in the present campaign is wetter than Alfred E. Smith's was four years ago and the Democratic prohibition plank of 1932 is to that of 1928 as the Mediterranean Sea is to the Desert of Gobi, but nobody down this way expects Mr. Roosevelt to lose Virginia in November.

TORONTO, July 30 (Canadian Press) -- Montreal defeated Toronto, 7 to 2, in the first game of today's double-header. The Royala bunched three hits and a walk for four runs in the fourth to drive Ray Walker, former Baltimore pitcher, from the box.

The precipitous downward flight of the bewildered Giants was still functioning with a smoothness excruciating to behold at the Polo Grounds yesterday when the Reds, occupants of last place in the National League, race arrived on the scene and forthwith helped themselves to the opening encounter of a four-game series.
MALDEN-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 30 -- The second and fourth son of the former Crown Prince of Germany are having a pleasant time here on the estate of their grandfather's friend, Poultney Bigelow.

Dr. Philip A. Brennan, one of the Brooklyn representatives on the Board of Education, announced yesterday a plan he will present to the budget committee of the board this week for the reorganization of the three teacher-training colleges which also would provide additional accommodations for pupils now overcrowding the high schools, as well as financial relief.

Calls on the Salvation Army for relief during July were only slightly less than the demands made during the Winter when distress was at Its peak, according to a statistical report issued yesterday by the organization which supplied nearly 100,000 lodgings and 500,000 meals in the month ending today.

All eyes are fixed on the German election today for reasons that are obvious. Some of them are general and international. It is thought that determination of the future government and attitude of Germany is what all Europe is waiting to know before quite daring to draw a breath of full confidence.

WATCH HILL, R.I. -- Members of the Misquamicut Golf Club held the first costume ball of the season here last night, in place of the regular Saturday night dinner dance. The costumes worn were of pirates and Indians. The program called for Captain Kidd and his crew and the band of original Watch Hill inhabitants, the Misquamicut chiefs.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 28 -- An 81-year-old man who traveled about the United States as a vagrant, but who had 49 $100 notes and 100 $20 notes in oilcloth wallets pinned to his underclothing, died in St. Vincent's Hospital here this week without spending the wealth he had hoarded.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- German reparations, debts owed the United States and tariff rates are specifically excluded from the scope of the coming monetary and economic conference of the League of Nations in the invitation to the American Government to attend and participate in preparations for the conference.

ARMIES are again on the move in China. Generals who fatten on the civil disorder have reorganized their forces; Communist divisions have taken to the field. After several months of comparative quiet, fighting has been reported in five different areas.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- As State police, volunteer "MPs" and Johnstown police patroled highways tonight to maintain order, leaders of the B.E.F. discovered Communists in the camp and ordered them removed. State troopers were reported on the streets of Johnstown.

IN the same sensitive and luminous style that distinguished "A Childhood," Hans Carossa continues his novelized record of Juvenile adventures and impressions in "Boyhood and Youth." The narrative, patently autobiographical like its predecessor, possesses similar qualities of poetic delicacy and restraint.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The wheat market made a poor response to bullish crop news today, and the action of the last two days disappointed operators, who were looking for a straightaway advance. Prices held inside a range of about a cent and closed within a fraction of the bottom at net losses of 1/8 to 1/4 cent.

A solution to the problem of unprofitable pricing in industries, through enforced publicity, either by agreement or by law, of all pricing operations affecting stockholders, labor and the consuming public, was offered here yesterday by Paul T. Cherington, business consultant.

PARIS, July 30 -- Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, in a long, exciting match, defeated Henri Cochet and Jacques Brugnon this afternoon in the Davis Cup challenge round doubles by 6-3, 11-13, 7-5, 4-6, 6-4. France now holds a 2-1 lead on the American team, which lost both singles yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whenever a political campaign is about to begin, the voters prepare for a flood of oratory, in which certain words will be bandied about, the meaning of which will be none too clear, even to the orators themselves.

Stores are making strenuous efforts to increase the effectiveness of their advertising and to make substantial reductions in their publicity expenditures by various economies, according to an analysis of such expenses released yesterday by the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
GENEVA, July 29 -- For Geneva seeding time has now begun.

OTTAWA, July 30 -- Negotiations between representatives of Canadian and British textile interests on the demand of the British for increased preferences on their exports to the Dominion have reached a deadlock. At the same time progress was reported in negotiations on the Canadians' demand for a larger share of the British lumber market.

MEXICO, spoken for through the eloquent voices of American writers who have formed one of the notable publishers' garlands of recent years, continues to be presented as one of the most appealing countries beyond our borders.

IN these three long short stories -- in the form, by the way, of the Henry James whom she once made her apprentice model -- Willa Cather returns, quite literally, to the scenes of her childhood -- to the Western country of "O Pioneers" and that nostalgic poem of "April Twilights" written from a train window on the Burlington route.
The Communist party, at its headquarters here accepted responsibility yesterday for the demonstration that resulted in the bonus army riots in Washington.

PARIS, July 29 -- The French Government is again giving serious consideration to that eighteenth century device for replenishing a depleted treasury -- the national lottery. It was last discussed, out finaly rejected as a way out of financial difficulties, in 1925 and 1926 when the rapid fall in the value of the franc threatened national bankruptcy.

IT is only natural that the last two years should have seen a number of changes in policy on the part of companies here and abroad. What had come to be regarded as regularly established series, such as the complete Baireuth Festival sets, failed to be continued and the sponsors of these made no secret of their reasons.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 30 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club's nine defeated the Montclair Athletic Club by 7 to 5 in the first of a three-game series to decide the Eastern Athletic Club Baseball League championship today. The teams finished their regular season in a tie for first place.

BERLIN, July 16, 1932 WITH the echoes of the Furtwangler-Baireuth collision still reverberating through the land, the German press and public have begun to wonder and to speculate about Toscanini. What is the Italian master's relation to the matter, what his attitude?

OTTAWA, Out., July 30 -- Determined to obtain some tangible benefits for the Canadian farmer from the Imperial Economic Conference, Prime Minister Bennett, in apparent defiance of the grain trade, is insisting upon a preferred position in the British market for about 80,000,000 bushels of the exportable Canadian wheat surplus, according to those close to the administration here.
DALLAS, July 28 -- Texas is still a bit bewildered by what happened in last week's Democratic primaries when there was cast an amazing three-to-one vote for resubmission of the Eighteenth Amendment.

CHICAGO. AS the exhibits program of the World's Fair develops it becomes more and more apparent that the automobile will be in the exposition's spotlight more than any other product of this industrial age.

WASHINGTON PAPER currency of high denomination has notably increased in the last three and one-half years. In outstanding $100, $500, $1,000, $5,000 and $10,000 notes the net gain has been $732,198,550.
St. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox won a twelve-inning game from the St. Louis Browns today, 3 to 2.

BALTIMORE, July 30 (AP) -- A double by Buzz Arlett in the ninth with the bases loaded grave the Baltimore Orioles a 7-to-6 victory over the Newark Bears today. Arlett hit two doubles and his forty-sixth homer of the season during the game.

Admiral PRATT'S article, "Our Naval Policy," in the July Naval Institute Proceedings, should be studied by extremists on both sides of the naval controversy. The article is a sane and well-balanced discussion of the strength and maintenance of the United States Navy. Admiral PRATT does not take his stand with the "build now" group, whose zeal, he says, sometimes does the country harm.

A committee of railroad presidents is considering a plan put forward by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, and Robert P. Lamont, Secretary of Commerce, to use Reconstruction Finance Corporation funds for the repair of track and the many thousands of pieces of railway equipment now out of order.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- With its original $500,000,000 fund depleted severely by tussling with the woes of agriculture, the Farm Board has turned its face from stabilization to more active development of cooperatives and to finding foreign markets for large American, stores of wheat and cotton.

HARTFORD, July 28 -- Whether Connecticut has a special session of its General Assembly on relief legislation as an added attraction for the Fall campaign, it now seems fairly evident that the regular biennial session next January will be the scene of many proposals and some contests for a broad reorganization of the State's machinery for raising revenue.

ALL of us are familiar with those cartoons in which, let us say, the concourse of a railway station is presented not only as a whole, still less as an impression, but in meticulous detail that leaves nothing to the imagination.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 30 -- Upon being notified at a meeting today of the International Baby Chick Association that he had been expelled from the organization, G.A. Norman of Knoxville, Tenn., drew a pistol and fired at Reese V. Hicks of Kansas City, secretary.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 -- In the wooded valley that crouched at the joining point between the River Cladeus and the River Alpheus the ancient Greeks encamped in tents outside the walls of Olympia to await the start of the Olympic Games. And almost 2,600 years later Californians encamped today outside the massive Olympic Stadium that juts 106 feet upward toward a clear blue sky.

TORONTO, July 30 (AP) -- An Ottawa dispatch to The Mail and Empire said today it was learned on good authority that a public loan of from $150,000,000 to $200,000,000 would be floated by the Bennett Government this Fall to meet the costs of unemployment relief and the Canadian National Railway's deficit for 1932.

Propelled by steady though not heavy buying, the bond market on the Stock Exchange made further gains in the brief trading period yesterday, with railroad bonds show ing about the best strength. Gains of from 1 to 6 points were scored by a representative list of rail issues with only a comparatively few infrequently traded issues showing declines of any consequence.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company and nineteen of its officers and directors were named defendants yesterday in a suit for $30,000,000 filed in United States District Court by the Trophy Towers Sales Corporation, which charged that the merger in 1930 of the defendant corporation and the Autostrop Safety Razor Company ruined its business of selling double-edged razor blades in slot machines.

DODGE CITY, Kan., July 28 -- The annual catch-as-catch-can match between budget makers in Kansas counties and municipalities and decreased valuations has received more attention from taxpayers in recent weeks than the opening salvos of the national campaign.

DETROIT, July 30 -- While on his way from Ottawa to Chicago today. Captain Wolfgang von Gronau, the German aviator, was forced to bring down his seaplane at Lake St. Clair early this afternoon because of a defective water pipe. A launch towed his craft to the Trans-American Air Line dock here.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 31. -- Tributes were paid to the 2,400 young men of the citizens' military training camp here this morning in farewell sermons by camp chaplains.

BALTIMORE, July 31 (AP). -- Buzz Arlett, Baltimore's heavy slugger, pounded out three home runs during the afternoon, but the Newark Bears took both games of today's double-header. After winning the first game, 12 to 5, Newark went ten innings before taking the nightcap, 4 to 3.

BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Out of all the figures and percentages and welter of argument surrounding yesterday's Reichstag election there appeared one point of general agreement, and that was that General Kurt von Schleidher, the "mystery man of politics," has definitely become the real boss of the Reich.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 31 (AP). -- B.E.F. leaders expressed alarm over the food situation as registration at Camp McCloskey tonight showed 6,000 men, women and children encamped there.

LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., July 31. -- This was a one-man town and Samuel Insull was the man. That is the prevailing sentiment among the 3,873 residents of Libertyville, home of the once-powerful utilities magnate for over a quarter of a century.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP). -- The Washington Senators evened the series with the Chicago White Sox by winning a hard hitting game, 8 to 5, today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31.--Entertaining today in the Summer colony included a party at the Clambake Club, several picnic parties at Bailey's Beach and luncheons and dinners at homes. Among the luncheon hostesses were Mrs. Thomas Ridgway, Mrs. William Goadby Loew, Miss Julia A. Berwind, Mrs. Robert Kelso Cassatt, Mrs. Edward V. Hartford and Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss.

Seemingly having made a momentous overnight decision, the Giants served blunt notice on the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday that they had no immediate intention of ousting the Cincinnatians from last place in the National League pennant race by smacking down Dan Howley's pack in both ends of the afternoon's doubleheader.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 31. -- Seven Hackensack youngsters at 4 o'clock this morning equaled the record of eight Brooklyn boys in what is known as the wagon-shoving endurance contest, and then went on to make another world mark.

PITTSBURGH, July 31. -- The reversal toward optimism in steel-trade sentiment, which began nearly three weeks ago, has been much commented upon in the last week, all observers agreeing that the change is marked and is virtually universal. It is held to be all the more significant by its not having been produced or encouraged by larger steel orders.

The appointment of Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, to head a mobilization of welfare and relief organizations of the country into a coordinated unit to obtain adequate support for all local welfare and relief work during the coming Winter was announced yesterday by J. Herbert Case, president of the Association of Community Chests and Councils.

LONDON, July 29. -- London bankers and business men are unquestionably beginning to take a hopeful view of the financial outlook. They are encouraged to do so by what is considered the really wonderful improvement in British credit since the national government came into being, by the assured success of the war loan conversion, by the cheaper cost of borrowing which it foreshadows, and by the Lausanne agreement.

Sir Josiah Stamp, in an address rebroadcast from London yesterday, announced that the success of the conversion of the $10,000,000,000 5 per cent war loan now seemed assured, with only 4 per cent of the investors, representing 2 per cent of the loan, demanding repayment.
HARBIN, July 31 (AP). -- Jajanese military headquarters here have received further details of the killing in action of General Ma Chen-shan, the Chinese hero of the battle of Nonni River.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 31. -- Miss Jean Moorhead of Mattituck, L.I., this afternoon was awarded the trophy for the champion hunter of the Brookville Charity Horse Show, having shown her chestnut gelding My Bachelor to win three blue ribbons before entering the final competition.

Changes of vital benefit to owner and the building industry in generals and which will totally eliminate many present practices are embodied in the proposed new building code, points out Colonel George H. McCaffrey, director of research of the Merchants' Association, under whose auspices the new code is being drafted.

The appointment of Frank C. Walker as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, chairman. The post had been vacant since the resignation of James W. Gerard last Spring. Since the meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Chicago, Mr. Walker, who was treasurer for the pre-convention Roosevelt organization, has been acting as assistant treasurer.

The aggregate business of 285 joint stock and seventy-three mutual fire and marine insurance companies authorized in New York State, summarized in the seventy-third report of the New York State Insurance Department, headed by Superintendent George S. Van Scnaick, shows that there was a decline of $9,460,526,069 insurance in force at the end of 1931 as compared with, the end of 1930.

OTTAWA, July 31.--An added test of some already rasped tempers at the Imperial Economic Conference was given today when N.C. Havenga, Finance Minister of South Africa, made a sharp retort to Thursday's statement by Stanley Baldwin, leader of Great Britain's delegation, to the effect that the United Kingdom had already done more to help the trade of the dominions than they had done for her.

MONTREAL, July 31 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals took both ends of a double header from the Toronto Leafs today, 7-6 and 8-0. A crowd of 12,000 saw the Royals take their ninth victory in the last ten games and their sficth straight.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31. -- Bolivian troops attacked Fort Boqueron in the disputed Chaco region today, according to reports from Paraguay, and at 6:30 o'clock this evening a battle for its possession was still raging.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 31. -- Mayor Eddie McCloskey, who invited the bonus army here against the wishes of the Chamber of Commerce, has given this quiet mill town its biggest thrill since the flood of 1889, when the waters of the Conemaugh River swept down into the valley as the ragged veterans are doing now.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 31. -- Bolivian troops overwhelmed a Paraguayan force at Fort Boqueron, in the disputed Chaco region, at 1:30 P.M. today, according to reports here tonight.

PARIS, July 22 (by mail). -- A vogue for little wraps has taken Paris by storm. Feathers, fur, velvet, wool, ribbons and even straw are used to make the abbreviated coverings which are the rage in the fashion world. Sports, street and evening clothes have all adopted the mode.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 31. -- Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, leaving here this afternoon for Chicago, after a 24-hour visit at the Summer home of former President and Mrs. Calvin Coolidge in Plymouth, indicated that Mr. Coolidge probably will take some part in the Hoover campaign.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP). -- Bump Hadley and Bob Cooney, pitchers for the St. Louis Browns, each withstood three Boston pitchers and the Browns took both ends of a double-header, 13 to 2 and 7 to 3, from the Red Sox here today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31. -- Scoring another victory over Gerard B. Lambert's sloop Vanite off here today, Frederick Prince's Weetamoe retained possession of the Constellation Cup offered several years ago by Commodore Arthur Curtiss James as a perpetual trophy to the Narragansett Bay Regatta Association.

HAVANA, July 31. -- Colonel Rosendo Collazo, former Senator from Camaguey and one of the leaders of the ill-fated revolutionary expedition that attempted to set out from Atlantic City for Cuba during the revolt last August, was gravely injured early this morning when the automobile he was driving overturned on the Central Highway near Madruga, Havana Province.

PARIS, July 29. -- The decrease for the second successive week in the Bank of France gold reserve, amounting for the past week to nearly 100,000,000 francs, attracts much attention. The prevalent explanation is that the bank probably took advantage of the high dollar rates to sell exchange, and drew for that purpose on gold balances held in New York.

Love of Christ and love of one's fellow-men in a Christian fellowship that transcends all racial, social and cultural differences is the church's best means of persuading an unbelieving world that it has something real to offer, the Rev. Adam Burnet of the Westbourne Church, Renfrew Street, Glasgow, Scotland, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, July 31. -- The cotton market here was rather nervous and erratic last week and, although trading was mostly sluggish, some periods showed considerable activity, particularly in the second half of the week, when sharp upturns in stocks and wheat stimulated trade buying and short covering.

DETROIT, July 31.--Babe Ruth's thirtieth homer of the year and his fourth in four games crested the Yankee uprising which wiped out Detroit's early lead of six runs today and eventually landed the McCarthymen a 12-to-8 victory for their second straight here, maintaining their first-place lead of eight games over Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Secretary Mills, replying today to Governor Roosevelt's radio speech of last night in criticism of the administration's fiscal policies, said that the outlook for restoration of prosperity was dark unless deflation is halted. This country's "greatest single economic problem today," Mr. Mills said, "is to arrest deflation and expand credit."

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 31. -- Dudley Kirkton Morris, 42 years old, Democratic leader of Sea Cliff, shot and killed his wife, Abby, 45, and then himself this afternoon in a private room of the North Country Community Hospital here. Mrs. Morris had been taken to the hospital twelve days ago suffering from cancer.

NOROTON, Conn., July 31. -- Commodore Paul H. Smart's Firefly today won the final race of the Spring series among the Star Class boats of the Noroton Yacht Club, leading Argro, owned by John Nickerson Jr., at the finish by 25 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- Attacking last night's radio speech of Governor Roosevelt, Senator Smoot, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, asserted today that the Democratic Presidential nominee was "attempting to deceive the American people by use of cunningly devised phrases and 'weasel words.' "

PARIS, July 31. -- France, by a score of 3 to 2, today retained the Davis Cup for the sixth consecutive year as Jean Borotra defeated Wilmer Allison of the United States, while Ellsworth Vines turned back Henri Cochet, giving the challengers their second point.

Desire for wealth, worship of success and love of ease are the three "bandits" that have robbed American life of its beauty and fineness, the Rev. Walter F. Whitney declared in a sermon yesterday at the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.
BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 1.--The German election, the results of which were being assembled and calculated as this was written at 4 o'clock this morning, has resulted in a stalemate.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 31. -- A call for the nation-wide organization of semi-military units of "khaki shirts" was issued by Walter W. Waters, commander-in-chief of the bonus expeditionary force after a hasty visit to about 6,000 of his followers encamped on a hill outside of this city.

Christian honesty consists of not merely telling the truth and meeting one's obligations but also in giving truth its chance to perform good works for men, the Right Rev. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, said in his sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel of Columbia University.

This week is moving week at the Central Park Zoo and Head Keeper Robert Hurton and his assistants lave much work to do, but out of the welter of less mundane things the problem of the howl of the timber wolf has taken priority.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much has been written of late about the depression, and comments have been in a more or less pessimistic vein. It is true that the manufacturing industries are either at a standstill or are operating at a loss. However, that is no reason why one should despair of the future.

The Republican organization of the Nineteenth Congressional District has designated William L. Carns, a lawyer with offices at 165 Broadway, as candidate for Representative to run against Representative Sol Bloom, Democrat, who is slated for renomination.

Three more producers who expect to offer plays on Broadway during the corning theatrical season have made known their plans. Standish O'Neill intends to bring forth two plays, "The Poor Fish," by Charles de Lima, and "Tiger Dove," by Leota Boehm.

Bids on construction of the foundation of the third section of the west side express highway, extending from Thirty-eighth Street to Forty-eighth Street, will be received today at the office of Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., July 31. -- in a plea for faith in a time of distress, the Rev. Dr. J. Stuart Holden of London, preaching this morning before 1,200 attendants at the fifty-second Northfield general conference, said that "though hell is night, God is nigher."

READING, July 31 (AP). -- The Reading Keys split even in today's double-header with Jersey City, winning the first, 11 to 8, and dropping the seven-inning nightcap, 15 to 10. Heavy batting featured both.

What Wall Street calls the "creeping recovery" in stocks and bonds has been so continuous that, while domestic bond "averages" have risen since the end of May some 10 1/2 points, or slightly over 20 per cent, the average of stocks has been advanced since July 8 nearly 13 1/2 points or (the previous valuations being very low) 40 per cent.

Orders placed last week showed that buyers were more confident of the new Fall merchandise. The ready-to-wear market showed encouraging activity. Coats and wool dresses for early Fall promotions were purchased. The coat buyers concentrated their attention on coats in the retail ranges between $48 and $78.

BERLIN, July 29. -- Uncertainty over the outcome of the Reichstag election, to be held on Sunday, did not appear to affect the Berlin markets last week. As in the week preceding the election of 1930, the Boerse held firm throughout the week.

DUBLIN, July 31. -- In a pouring rain which made the narrow mountain paths dangerous. President de Valera climbed with 50,000 pilgrims today to the summit of Croagh Patrick, 2,500 feet above Clew Bay, where St. Patrick is believed to have banished the snakes from Ireland.

Two armed men forced the clerk at the Hotel Martinique, Broadway and Thirty-second Street, at 6 A.M. yesterday to open the cashier's cage. He was then tied and gagged. The hold-up men pried open the strong box in the safe with a crowbar and escaped with $4,250 in cash and checks.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Red Cross motor corps and other units searched the city and countryside around Washington today for the scattered families of the bonus army to afford free transportation to their homes.

Shouts and Whispers. Chairman FARLEY has already discovered and denounced "a whispering campaign." It is the report, the rumor, the insinuation, which he declares that Republicans are passing from mouth to mouth regarding Governor ROOSEVELT'S health.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Increased activity among manufacturers and trade interests in one section is being reflected in others. Sentiment has been changed most decidedly in favor of improvement in general business, due in a measure to the advance in securities, grains and live stock prices.

Mutual savings banks of the United States gained 72,468 new accounts in the first six months of 1932, bringing the total to a record of 13,432,139, despite unemployment and decreased individual earning power, according to figures announced yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks through its executive Secretary, John W. Sandstedt.

The Work Relief system of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration has been able to operate, during the period between Nov. 1, 1931, and June 1. on a ratio of 15 per cent for materials and maintenance and 85 per cent for relief wages of needy unemployed persons, according to a study made public yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the administration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the discussion of the constitutional amendment proposed by Senator Glass in lieu of the present Eighteenth, there is one point which, so far as I am aware, has not been mentioned but which seems to me of material, if not cardinal, importance.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc. WASHINGTON, July 30. -- "State regulation has broken down" is a comment frequently heard because easily made. Yet this criticism, with its generous country-wide application, is not so easily backed up with facts of equally wide application.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 31. -- A company of 200, including Merrill-Cuyler wedding guests and week-end visitors, attended the first subscription dance of the season at the Lenox Club last night. It was arranged by the house committee, of which David T. Dana is chairman.

Reductions greatly outnumber increases among the higher-ranked poloists in the new list of handicap ratings announced by the United States Polo Association yesterday. These ratings were decided upon at the midyear meeting of the association's handicap committee last week, at which J. Watson Webb, veteran internationalist, presided.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, winner of the Seabright Bowl yesterday, heads the list of eight seeded players who will compete in the seventh annual women's invitation Gold Cup tournament which starts on the Maidstone Club Courts tomorrow.

Nine entries have teen received thus far for the Star Class international championship regatta to be held on Long Island Sound off Southport, Conn., from Sept. 16 to 23, it was announced yesterday by T.D. Parkman.

Special developments must, for the time being, supplant the usual indices of business and trade in a survey of general conditions and sentiment, according to the American Bankers Association Journal. Certain happenings of the last few weeks may some day be looked back upon as milestones on the road to recovery, It says.

The entire 1932-33 schedule of the Columbia Pictures Corporation will be exhibited in the theatres of the R.K.O. circuit under the terms of an agreement made public yesterday by the two companies. The Columbia product includes forty-eight feature productions, as well as its short subjects.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The text of the Federal Reserve Board's order, issued, today, authorizing federal Reserve Banks to make direct loans to individuals, partnerships and corporations under the terms of an amendment to the Federal Reserve act enacted at the recent session of Congress follows:

LOS ANGELES, July 31. -- With all the splendor of its setting, the radiance of the weather and the brilliance of the performances, the opening day of competition in track and field in the tenth modern Olympiad was one of grief and disaster for a half dozen or more athletes of world renown, who were found wanting in the crucible of as stiff an inaugural session as the games have known since their revival.

From the beginning of the invasion of Washington by the veterans the men most blameworthy were members of Congress who not only cringed before the political threat but inflamed it. And now, at the end of the humiliating and disastrous experience in Washington, some of the same politicians are behaving much worse than any of the ex-soldiers.

BERLIN, JULY 31 (AP). -- The police of Berlin reported today that during the night they had dealt with thirty-four street rows, in which one person was killed and 287 were arrested. The trouble arose mainly between hostile party men tearing down each other's posters.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The aftermath of the Bonus Expeditionary Force disorders and evacuation of last week, when the use of Federal troops was required to oust the men from the capital, will occupy the attention of official Washington during the next few days, as the grand jury tomorrow begins an investigation of the elements entering into the tragic events.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- No negotiations are in progress between the United States and French Governments on armaments, and none are in immediate prospect, State Department officials said tonight. Paris reports that such negotiations are expected soon to begin were characterized in informed official quarters here tonight as "pure speculation."

The creation of a new political party to represent the interests of the workers, the farmers and the consumers of this country is advocated by Paul H. Douglas, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, in his book "The Coming of a New Party," published today by Whittlesey House. Professor John Dewey has written a foreword to the volume.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 31. -- Tommy Hitchcock's Sands Point quartet defeated Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes, 12 to 10, today in a hard hitting, closely contested polo match at the Sands Point Club. The winners lined up with Robert Lehman at No. 1 and Hitchcock at No. 3, while Eric Pedley and Lin Howard, California stars, held down the No. 2 and back positions, respectively.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- No instructions have yet reached the Japanese Embassy here for the return to Tokyo of Ambassador Debuchi, it was said at the embassy late tonight.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- High-grade steers have become relatively scarce. The few that arrived at Chicago last week met ready sale at $9.50 to $9.75 for heavies, and $9.25 to $9.50 for yearlings, the season's top. The average of all steers for the week was $8, an advance of 25 cents for the week, butchers' stock and feeding steers dropping 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Authorization was issued to the Federal Reserve Banks today by the Federal Reserve Board to make direct loans to individuals, partnerships and corporations for a period of six months, beginning tomorrow, under an amendment to the Federal Reserve act enacted by the recent session of Congress.

Economic and moral recovery in the United States today can be effected through three essential channels, namely the correcting of crooked politicians and citizens, finding new and able leaders and thinking our way out of the present difficulties squarely and fearlessly, the Right Rev. John Newton McCormick, Bishop of Western Michigan, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S announcement on Saturday evening that he is going to cut the flourishes and the highfalutin out of his campaign speeches must have fallen gratefully on the ears of a multitude of listeners-in. With the radio now at the candidates' command, it should be feasible to make simple and straight-forward appeals, with the air of merely inviting people to sit down and reason together.

BUCHAREST, July 31. -- Former Premier Maniu today told a deputation of the National Peasant party he was ready to resume leadership of the party after almost two years of retirement from public life. His decision opens the way not only to resumption of the party chairmanship, but to the Premiership of the present Peasant party government.
BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 1. -- Election day did not pass off without numerous rows between the National Socialists and the Communists in many parts of Germany.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. OTTAWA, July 31. -- It is no secret that the British delegation to the empire economic parley is dissatisfied with the general offer made by Canada, and certain of the other dominions, that in return for a natural commodities market in Great Britain the dominions will permit the mother country to compete with certain "reasonably efficient" domestic industries.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 31 (AP). -- Bertrand H. Snell, Republican leader in the House and since 1914 Representative from the Thirty-first New York District, will be opposed this Fall by Colonel Kenneth Gardner of Saranac Lake, a World War veteran and member of a New York admiralty firm.

JEDDA THE HEDJAZ, July 31 (AP). -- The government of powerful Ibn Saud, ruler of much of Arabia, announced tonight it had subdued a rebellion among the Bedouin tribesmen, killing 360 rebels, including the Bedouin leader, Ibn Rafada.

In a brief to be filed today with the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission, Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly not only voices the city's opposition to the request of the New York Central Railroad for a 40 per cent rise in commutation fares, but also asks that the schedules in force before May 1, when a 25 per cent rise became operative by agreement, be restored.

The new liner Colombia, being built at Newport News for the Colombian Steamship Company will be launched next Saturday with Mrs. C.H.C. Pearsall of Babylon, L.I., wife of the vice president and general manager of the company, acting as sponsor, it was announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, July 31. -- The text of South Africa's reply at the Ottawa conference to the British statement on empire trade follows:
BOSTON, July 31. -- Governor Ely's long-waited statement throwing his support to Franklin D. Roosevelt and John N. Garner and announcing his own candidacy for re-election was made public tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Smith gave a large reception this afternoon at their home in Ox Pasture Road for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. William C. Durant. Tea was served on the terraces overlooking the gardens.

The five-story building at 140 West Seventy-seventh Street has been leased by Hannah Blum to Maria Dorn for three years from Sept. 1, 1932, the rent to be $3,500 for the first year and $3,600 for each of the last two years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of us have looked upon Senator Borah as being occasionally erratic but always able. His outpourings have at times led us to fear the effect of his statements on the peoples of Europe as well as of his countrymen.

A statement charging that city contractors on grading, curbing and concreting work are violating the State labor law, which became effective Sept. 23, 1931, and provides for an eight-hour day and five-day week on public works, by working their men six days a week and more than eight hours a day, was issued yesterday by Edward L. Hannan, international secretary-treasurer of the International Union of Pavers.

With the solemnity required in these matters, National Chairman SANDERS has at last announced the designation of Senator HEBERT of Rhode Island as "Eastern Republican Manager." It is a mouth-filling title. By rights it should mean the high and exclusive command of all Republican operations addressed to carrying those States commonly referred to as Eastern.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 31. -- C. Tracy Barnes of the Piping Rock Country Club, Locust Valley, L.I., today defeated E.L. Beard of Flushing, L.I., 1 up, in the 36-hole final match of the Shenecossett Invitation Golf Tournament for the Marston Shenecossett trophy.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 31. -- A rebuttal to Mayor Walker's reply to removal charges will be filed by Samuel Seabury with Governor Roosevelt within the next few days, it was announced here today.

Glancing through a somewhat technical article in a serious magazine, it was startling to find an accurate description of persons with whom the article had nothing to do. The paragraph was so vivid, the characterization so lifelike, that it seemed incredible that it did not apply to a group of gentlemen easily recognizable.
PARIS, July 31 (AP). -- Franco-American negotiations seeking an acceptable formula for reduction of armed forces, with a special eye on the French Army, are expected to be opened very soon.

Two more deaths were ascribed yesterday to the effects of drinking wood alcohol, bringing the total to eighteen in five days. Most of the deaths as well as a number of alcohol poisonings were reported from the lower east side.

NANKING. July 31 (AP). -- To raise funds to meet foreign and domestic loan obligations pending a settlement of the Chino-Japanese-Manchurian customs dispute, the Nationalist Government today ordered an increase in customs duties on certain commodities effective tomorrow.

The religious services at l'Eglise du Saint Esprit (Protestant Episcopal French Church, at 114 East Seventysixth Street, were confined yesterday morning to observance of the 641st anniversary of the foundation of the Swiss Confederation.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- Many prominent persons, including Governor Roosevelt, have taken boxes for the racing meeting of the Saratoga Association which opens tomorrow. The list of bondholders follows:

A call to Catholics to exercise a personal censorship of the theatre to keep offensive plays off the stage was sounded by the Rev. Robert E. Woods in his sermon yesterday morning at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
LONDON, July 31. -- Lord Essendon, chairman of Furness Withy Co., emphatically denied tonight that his company had bought the White Star Line, as had been rumored in New York.

The Salvation Army's United Appeal for funds with which to continue its emergency relief and institutional aid activities in the city has brought in a total of $575,432.98, assuring attainment of the minimum goal of $600,000, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Constructive sentiment is developing in all lines, particularly in the stock and bond and commodity markets. All made good advances last weeK and held nearly all of them, but grain markets, especially wheat, have not shown strength in the last few days.

CAMP SMITH, PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 31. -- To the tune of the "Old Gray Mare," two regiments of National Guardsmen encamped at this post marched past Governor Roosevelt in review today as a rain squall swept the plateau above the Hudson to clear away later with a rainbow arching the eastern sky as the review ended.

CLEVELAND, July 31. -- The second largest crowd ever to witness a major league baseball game filled the Municipal Stadium today to watch the Philadelphia Athletics defeat the Cleveland Indians, 1 to 0. The official attendance was announced as 80,285, of which 76,979 were paid admissions.

BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The German people brought to an end a bloody election campaign today with a forthright refusal to entrust the fate of the nation to any one of the twenty-one political parties of the Reich -- not even to the Nazis of Adolf Hitler.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Congressional committee which has been holding sessions in Kansas City for the purpose of obtaining information concerning the competition of government enterprise with private business has revealed the fact that such competition already exists in relation to ninety-four different lines of business.

A flapping window shade led to the discovery in a cold-water flat on the second floor at 220 West 104th Street yesterday of a murdered woman, a man who had committed suicide and a new counterfeiting plant used to turn out spurious $5 banknotes of unusually good workmanship.
BAYSIDE, L.I., July 31. -- Favored by a northwest wind, the fleet of twenty-eight auxiliary sailing craft in the Bayside Yacht Club's annual race out around Block Island and return made fast time.

Two old friends, boon companions for many years, were brought together last night in the Coney Island police station after a separation of two days. The two were Anna Froustet, 15 years old, and food.

BERKELEY, Cal., July 31. -- Development of X-ray apparatus which requires a current of only 15,000 volts to produce radiations with the energy of about 1,000,000 volts was announced at the University of California today.
Mayor Walker, if removed from his present office by Governor Roosevelt, intends to be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, it was learned yesterday on unimpeachable authority.

HARBIN, July 31 (AP).--Rengo (Japanese) News Agency dispatches from Chinchow today said the Japanese had executed two air raids over Jehol and were threatening more bombardments in the last Manchurian province dominated by the Chinese.

In yesterday's Magazine Section of THE TIMES Warden LAWES looked at education from a Sing Sing point of view. In his care are hundreds who might have been useful members of society if only they had been brought under wholesome family or social influences in childhood and early youth.

If the firemen persist in their present inclination to oppose a voluntary pay cut, they are likely to find themselves ranged squarely against the policemen on this stirring issue. They want "more information" before deciding finally. They would prefer a "complete program" of economies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The illuminating article on the Confederate debt by Judge John Bassett Moore in THE TIMES of July 25 was additionally interesting to those who remembered an incident of the long ago, which happened when the learned judge was 4 or 5 years old.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 31. -- North Shore society crowded around the oval today on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Davis, where the Fifth Annual Brookville Horse Show was held for the benefit of the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau at Mineola.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (AP). -- Rudolf Jsmayr, a lawyer of Munich, sent the flag of Germany to the top of the flagpole in the tenth Olympic Games today in winning the weightlifting championship for middleweights.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings gave the Bisons a double beating today before an overflow throng of about 19,000.

A North Atlantic air-mail flight, probably in August, seems to be assured by the agreement between the Government of Newfoundland and a citizen of Minneapolis, who has selected BERNT BALCHEN as pilot of the plane. From that city the start is to be made.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Former Senator Henry C. Hansbrough of North Dakota today joined Senator Norris, insurgent Republican of Nebraska, in supporting Governor Roosevelt for the Presidency.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP). -- The monthly report on business conditions in this district by the Federal Reserve Bank stated that there have been apparent signs of improvement in several lines of trade and industry, indicating largely replacement demand.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 31. -- With mills all over the State employing more workers, many working full time and a few operating night shifts, yesterday closed the most encouraging week in Rhode Island industry in two years.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- The Rev. Dr. Howard Chandier Robbins, former dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in New York, has accepted an appointment as special preacher at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, on Rittenhouse Square here, for the coming Winter, it was announced today by the Rev. Floyd W. Tomkins Jr., minister in charge.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- With the ardor and interest of turf followers not perceptibly dampened, the inhabitants of this town in the foothills of the Adirondacks and thousands of visitors eagerly await the opening tomorrow of the thirty-day meeting of the Saratoga Association at the famous old course which has seen so many champions in the past.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP). -- The Braves batted out a 7-to-2 victory over St. Louis at the expense of Dean in the second game of a double-header today after Paul Derringer had shut out the tribe, 7 to 0, in the opener.
BUENOS AIRES, July 31 (AP). -- Stories of mounting defense funds came out of Bolivia and Paraguay today in the heat of their new argument over their ancient boundary dispute in the Chaco territory.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31. -- The country's finances occupied official and public attention last week in preference to all other public questions, following the discovery that the budget put into effect thirty days ago with an announced surplus of 12,000,000 pesos ($3,000,000) will produce a deficit variously estimated at 80,000 to 100,000 pesos.

Despite the threat of rain early in the evening, a large audience turned out last night at the Lewisohn Stadium for the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Albert Coates, and of Paul Robeson, Negro baritone, now appearing in the revival of "Show Boat."

With 32,000 fans crowding the stands at Ebbets Field yesterday the Dodgers stopped their winning ways long enough to lose the first gams of a double-header with the Cubs, 6 to 3, but staged a seventh inning rally to capture the nightcap, 5 to 4.

Organization, of business men and women throughout the country to aid in the campaign for the election of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democratic nominee for President, will be undertaken immediately by the Roosevelt Business and Professional League, Jesse Isidor Straus, its chairman, announced yesterday after consultation with James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP). -- The Harvard College Observatory and the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary joined today in a word of caution to the public who will be watching the eclipse of the sun Aug. 31. After every eclipse oculists treat numerous cases of injured eyesight, due to looking at the sun without proper protection, the announcement said.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "New Biographies for Old," Lytton Strachey is quoted as describing the old style biography as being "those two fat volumes with which it is our custom to commemorate the dead -- who does not know them, with their ill-digested masses of material, their slipshod style, their tone of tedious panegyric, their lamentable lack of selection, of detachment, of design?"

NEW HAVEN, July 30. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 60.9, Which compares with 60.8 a week ago, 60.2 two weeks ago, 59.6 three weeks ago and 59.6 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; the average of June 18, at 59.3, was the lowest.
TORONTO, Ont., July 31 -- The Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., this evening issued the following statement in connection with bond interest due June 1 and postponed until tomorrow:
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Redmond Cross will give a dance Sept. 24 at their home in Bernardsville, N.J., to introduce to society their daughter. Miss Emily Redmond Cross.

Copyright, 1932. by N.A.N.A., Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. MANILA -- Only freedom will meet the hopes of the Filipinos, whether or not it comes in the guise of independence, according to the political philosophy of Manuel L. Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate.

Fishing in Jasper National Park in Western Canada seems like going a long way from home to a metropolitan angier, but the splendid sport to be found in the Maligne and Medicine Lakes is, according to all indications, attracting a number even from eastern localities.
GARY, Ind., July 31. -- Industrial Northern Indiana, its steel plant furnaces dark part of the time, has turned to the hoe for employment and food.

FORDHAM JOE McCLUSKEY will step out against those fast foreigners in the steeplechase trial at Los Angeles today. The black-haired lad from the Bronx is practically our lone hope against those landloping Finns in a distance event.

ALBANY, July 31. -- A drive in which, he will seek to portray President Hoover as a sponsor of unsound ''radical" experiments in government and himself, the so-called "radical," as a supporter of practical measures for rehabilitation was mapped by Governor Roosevelt tonight.

In its annual economic and industrial review, made public yesterday, the Department of Research and Economics of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America defined protective tariffs as "a form of international warfare and as such contrary to the principles of Christianity."
At least nine new plays, several of which are scheduled for Broadway, will be tested this week by Summer theatrical groups.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Trial of the government's suit against Appalachian Coals, Inc., and 136 coal operators of four States for alleged violation of the Sherman anti-trust law began before a three-judge Federal court here today.
HUTCHINSON, Kan., Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Board of Trade announced today that it had denied membership to the Hall-Baker Grain Company, a trading unit of the Farmers' National Grain Corporation.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Cal., led the eight seeded players who advanced through the first round of the annual "Women's Invitation tournament on the Maidstone Club courts today. Miss Jacobs had little difficulty in winning from Miss Florence Le Boutillier of Westbury, L.I., in straight sets 6-2, 6-1.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The electro-photographic "camera clock" shows Eddie Tolan gained the decision over Ralph Metcalfe for the Olympic 100-meter championship by two inches, Gustavus T. Kirby, American member of the board of judges, told The Associated Press tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The Prince of Wales dedicated at Thiepval today Great Britain's monument to 73,413 of her men who fell during the World War on that greatest of battlefields, the Somme, and who still lay unidentified in their trench and shell-hole graves.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The seventeenth, annual race meet and championship regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association started informally today. Thirty boats raced, but the result of the regatta, which was held under the auspices of the Unqua-Corinthian Yacht Club, will not count in the yacht racing championship of the South Shore.

When Captain Henry A.T. Candy, master of the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania, saw his ship made fast safely at Pier 59, North River, yesterday forenoon, he ended his fortyfive-year career of roving the seas under sail and steam.
BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- Post-election riots in Germany resulted in four deaths and many lesser casualties today.
