TORONTO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- After losing eight straight games the Toronto Leafs defeated the Montreal Royals, 4 to 2, in the second half of today's double-header. They lost the first, 3 to 0, when Curly Ogden pitched a two-hit game.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Judge Hand's decision in the employment agency case, recorded in THE TIMES, should receive the approbation of all those who feel that employment work should have a professional standing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Before an opening day throng of more than 12,000 Chicago turf fans, Big Brand scored over Cathop by a neck in the feature race at one mile and a sixteenth at the Hawthorne track today. Crystal Prince saved the short end of the purse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1.--Congressional investigation of the bonus army riots was demanded by Senators McKellar and Shipstead this afternoon as more than a dozen witnesses gathered at the court house where the District of Columbia grand jury is beginning an investigation to place the responsibility for the disturbance.

The punching power with which he hopes to conquer Lou Brouillard, former world's welterweight champion, in their ten-round bout for the benefit of the Daniel Frohman Foundation of the Actors' Fund of America Thursday night at the Yankee Stadium was placed on exhibition yesterday by Jimmy McLarnin, Vancouver welterweight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- The defeat of Wilbur F. Coen Jr. of Kansas City, Mo., No. 14 in the national ranking, by 20-year-old John McDiarmid of Fort Worth was the lone upset recorded today as thirtytwo players participated in the opening round of the forty-second annual invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

When the massive iron gates of the Federal Reserve Bank swung open yesterday morning, admitting those having business at the bank, the usual group was augmented by a number of persons who had read that the day marked the bank's entrance into the business of making loans to corporations, partnerships and individuals, as newly authorized by Congress and the Federal Reserve Board.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1. -- Eighty-three wrestlers from sixteen foreign countries started a seven-day campaign for Olympic championships in the Auditorium today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The first record of the 1932 Olympics to fall today was the program sale mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A barrage of twenty-three hits, including nine doubles, a triple and a home run, placed the Phillies within seven games of first place in the National League as they won their third straight from the Pittsburgh Pirates, league leaders, today.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Paris is talking of little else today except the extraordinary Davis Cup incident and decision, which cost Wilmer Allison his match and the United States the cup itself.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- The results of yesterday's balloting for the new Reichstag disappoint party organs generally, even the Rightist newspapers sorrowfully admitting that expectations of a national Germany remain unfulfilled and that the outcome only duplicates that of the Prussian election last April.

The body-and-soul clinic conducted by Dr. Edward S. Cowles, psychiatrist, was locked out of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerio yesterday, in accordance with a decision taken on June 27 by the corporate body of vestry, church-wardens and rector, to restore the church to the canonical worship prescribed by the Book of Common Prayer and the counsel of Bishop Manning.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- By awarding Babe Ruth four bases on balls today, the Tigers prevented any enormous scoring on the part of the Yankees, but thanks largely to Lou Gehrig's run-driving, the McCarthymen took their third straight from Detroit, 6 to 3, making their road record show an even break in eight games played.

Union Square early last night was the scene of a large but orderly Communist demonstration, in which between 10,000 and 15,000 spectators and avowed workers for the Soviet cause packed the north end of the park.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Elaborate ceremonies will mark the conclusion of the four-week training period of the Citizens' Military Training Camp here tomorrow and afterward the 2,400 young men who have completed the course will leave for their homes on special trains.
THE Davis Cup remains In La Belle France. Vive la republique and all that sort of thing! Lafayette, we were not there.

Mrs. Jennie Cromwell, wife of William Nelson Cromwell, lawyer, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,527,075 gross and $1,478,746 net, of which $1,444,691 was in securities. Mrs. Cromwell also had owned 960 shares of the Monmouth Securities Corporation worth $401,904, which she transferred to her husband six weeks before her death.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Barefoot and dressed only in army slickers, 1,400 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware stood at "retreat" tonight as their first military experience in the month of training they entered today as students of the Citizens' Military Training Camp here.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- Governor Roosevelt made plans today to return to his more active schedule of exercises, interrupted for several weeks by activities in connection with the convention and its aftermath.

Viewed as evidence or their confidence in the public utility structure of the country, the principal banking institutions in New York and Chicago have within the last three days extended accommodations of $90,000,000 to companies that had important bond and note maturities to meet.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- It may be said on indisputable authority that the present German Cabinet is thoroughly content with the outcome of yesterday's election, indecisive as it was from some other points of view, and is prepared to carry on with every confidence that when Parliamentary authority is needed for its acts that authority will be forthcoming.

CHAMBERLAIN BROWN'S SCRAP BOOK, a mixture of all forms of amusement, in two acts and twenty scenes. Sketches by Mr. Brown. Staged by Charles Schoffleld and Robert Lively. At the Ambassador Theatre, twice daily and on Sunday nights.

Sign of the Season. Every four years at about this time a certain name appears in the political news. The date-line is sometimes Washington, sometimes a point in the farm belt. The subject of the article, though a "Lincoln Republican," has decided to support the Democrats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: People deeply interested in the success of New York's great public power project, as well as those in the West who have at heart the development of the great waterway, may well resent the Federal Administration's gratuitous affront to New York.

The "back to the land" movement for food, which has made such progress recently in Indiana, is flourishing in New York State as well. Five thousand industrial gardens are now yielding food supplies to 5,000 unemployed families in more than forty manufacturing communities, it was reported yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, which has been sponsoring a State-wide relief gardens system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Former Senator Atlee Pomerene, inducted into office today as chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, pledged that no partisanship or favoritism would be displayed by that organization.

The monetary gold stock in the United States was swelled yesterday by $10,947,400, compared with a rise of $16,390,700 for all of last week, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. The principal increase was of $7,512,800 through the release of metal held here under earmark for foreign account.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Boston Braves went down to defeat, 4 to 2, today before the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the agricultural situation appeared less discouraging than a month ago, with "a number of changes that may mean the steady decline in farm prices has been "The general landslide of prices appears at least to have leveled out for checked."

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1. -- Maj. Gen. Smedley D. Butler, who the ragged bonus marchers secretly hope will undertake to lead a nation-wide organization of "Khaki Shirts," advised them today to go home, for the time being.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1.--A renewal of protests over assessments against the property of wealthy residents of this part of Long Island, was indicated here today with the opening of the assessment roll for 1932, which showed little change from the valuations placed last year on properties in the general plan of equalization.

Interest in financial markets over the holiday had concerned itself with conjecture, first as to whether the week would begin with the expected reaction after the long recovery, second as to how, if at all, markets would be affected by the German elections.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- United States exports to France, which already have suffered many serious checks, were curtailed again today by two important measures. The Franco-Belgian import tax convention went into effect, giving Belgium a reduced transfer tax rate and thus permitting her to undersell competitive United States products, particularly copper.

The New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that hereafter members could "not absorb as an expense the cost of the shipment of securities to customers or correspondents." Heretofore, the general policy has been to include these costs, including postage and registration, in operating expenses.

TOKYO. Aug. 1 -- In addition to Mr. Dubuchi, three other Ambassadors, Isaburo Yoshida of Rome, Torikichi Obata of Berlin and Koki Hirota of Moscow, are coming to Japan on leave, from which it is expected that only Mr. Hirota will return.
ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP) -- August and railroad workers in Eastern New brought encouraging news to factory York.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- Billings Wilson, assistant general manager of the Port of New York Authority, explained before the general convention of the American Association of Port Authorities here today the rapid development of freight handling and distributing facilities in the port and told the convention that trade moving through the port would "saturate every facility" unless new methods and facilities were constantly provided.

The rebuttal to the defense of Mayor Walker in removal proceedings, which Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, plans to submit to Governor Roosevelt in connection with the removal charges against Mayor Walker, probably will be sent to Albany today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Miss Jane Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope, was guest of honor at a dinner dance tonight, given by the Misses Peggy and Polly Easton, daughters of Dr. and Mrs. Charles D. Easton, at the latter's Summer home on Price's Neck.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The Bourse was strong today, demonstrating a favorable reaction to the German elections, the results of which had. been discounted in advance. Substantial gains were made in many securities, including the Young loan, which rose 21 francs.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Miss Laura Bragg, the director of the Berkshire Museum at Pittsfield, and its trustees gave their annual midsummer reception tonight at a private view of eighty-eight modern paintings by fifty artists of twentyone countries.

DURHAM, N.H., Aug.1 (AP) -- A warning to farmers against the "propaganda which is being circulated by the grain trade and many other handlers of farm products under the old system" was uttered tonight by Carl Williams, vice chairman of the Federal Farm Board.

Fingerprint records served yesterday to identify the man known as Robert Sanborn, who was found dead on Sunday in a flat at 220 West 104th Street beside the body of a woman known as Rosemary Sanborn, whom he had shot and killed before he put the automatic to his own head.

Governor ELY'S declaration that he will support the national ticket and be a candidate for re-election is at once frank and adroit. Veteran politicians like "Honey FITZ " and Senator WALSH could come into the Roosevelt camp at once. The disappointment and anger felt Toy so many Massachusetts Democrats over the defeat of their idol are not subject to such summary treatment.

To help young people to understand the coming solar eclipse, Isabel Martin Lewis, astronomer at the United States Naval Observatory, has revised her book, Astronomy for Young Folks." The new edition, with an appendix called "The Story of Eclipses," has just been Issued here by Duffield Green.

Professor LASKI recently uttered a lament over the political lethargy of American, college students. To him it seemed almost inexplicable that they do not take an active and flaming part in public affairs, as do their fellows in Europe and South America and to a lesser extent and in different ways in England.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- Chancellor von Papen told The Associated Press today that ha would not attempt government by coalition in Germany, but would present his ministry to the new Reichstag late this month and defy the members to oust it.

Buyers Here More Encouraged. Retail buyers in the market here yesterday showed a greater degree of optimism than at any time this year, executives of buying offices said yesterday. While retailers have not abandoned their cautious attitude, they were said to be impressed with the turn which events have recently taken and feel that the Fall will prove a better business period.

Wallace D. McLean, executive vice president of the Morris Plan Company of New York, announced yesterday consolidation of the advertising and public relations departments of the Morris Plan Corporation of America and of the Morris Plan Company of New York.

JEDDAH, Arabia, Aug. 1 -- The short-lived terror of the desert sheik, Hamad Ibn Rafada, chieftain of the Bill tribe, who for the past two months has been leading a revolt against the King of Hedjaz, is ended.

M.S. Szymczak, Controller of the city of Chicago and acting Mayor in the absence of Mayor Cermak in Europe, conferred with bankers here yesterday on his plans to market a substantial block of the city tax anticipation warrants. Funds are required primarily for the payment of salaries to school teachers.

The talents of NEWTON D. BAKER, who was in official charge of the recruiting of our great citizen army in the World War, are now put at the country's service in mobilizing the largest citizen army of relief. It is wholly an army of volunteers, serving for the most part without pay or expectation of any reward except the satisfaction of seeing their neighbors in better state.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Prohibition and "bossism" are the leading issues in Missouri's primary tomorrow to nominate a candidate to succeed Senator Hawes, Democrat, who has announced his retirement, and to name party choices for Congress and other State offices.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Rube Walberg bested Wes Ferrell in a bitter pitching duel that was not decided until the ninth inning today as Philadelphia made it three straight over Cleveland, 1 to 0.
Several apartment houses and business structures were included in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- William Woodward, chairman of the Stewards of the Jockey Club, saw his colors first in the Saratoga Handicap and the Flash Stakes as the thirty-day Saratoga meeting opened today, thus gaining a double which is the first of its kind.

By Telegraph to the Editor of The New York Times. WIANNO, Mass., Aug. 1 -- I notice in THE TIMES today that Secretary Mills asks of Governor Roosevelt if he does not know that "this country has been undergoing the most drastic and devastating deflation ever witnessed."

HAMILTON, Ont., Aug. 1 -- W.C. Dunford's Boscobel raced to a nose victory over G.H. Ellis's Bushman in the mile and a sixteenth of the Civic Holiday Handicap, feature at the Hamilton track today. Prince Peter was third.

Charlotte M. Fixel, former actress, was declared yesterday by Surrogate John P. O'Brien to have been the common-law wife of Abraham L. Erlanger, and as such entitled to assert widow's right to half of the estate.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 1. -- After describing the treatment of the bonus army in Washington as "brutal, stupid and altogether unnecessary," Governor Pinchot refused a request today that the veterans' camp at Johnstown be supplied with tents and cots by the Pennsylvania National Guard.

Although the advance on the Stock Exchange was arrested yesterday, the market developed no acute weakness and the general results were satisfactory to Wall Street. The composite averages showed no net change of consequence in either direction.

The New York State Conservation Department, through the office of Commissioner Henry Morgenthau Jr., has announced that the experiments conducted at the Long Island Game Farm, near Port Jefferson, L.I., since last Spring, have "achieved a considerable initial success."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The value of privately owned taxexempt property in Westchester County last year was greater than the value of property owned by any single governmental unit, according to a recapitulation of tax-exemption figures filed here today with the Board of Supervisors by Clerk Fred L. Merritt.
CATSKILL. N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Paul Quattrocci, who was Jack (Legs) Diamond's "number two man" during the reign of the late gangster in Greene County, died early today after a lingering illness.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Jim Stroner's homer in the eighth inning with the bases loaded gave the Baltimore Orioles a 13-to-10 victory over the Newark Bears tonight in the final game of their series.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The other morning was awakened to greet a policeman, who handed me a traffic summons, my first one in twenty years. I had parked my ear in front of the house over night. Later I joined the big parade at 151st Street to pay the fine, and in the afternoon put the car up for the Summer in a friend's garage outside of the city.

Twelve men, two of whom were sentenced last month to serve five years each in Atlanta Penitentiary as leaders of a bankruptcy ring that wrecked the Mercer Merchandise Company and swindled creditors of $750,000 in 1930, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of concealing $75,000 assets in the bankruptcy of the Euro-American Corporation, which had offices at 60 East Fourteenth Street.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Aug. 1 -- Searchers striving to find pretty Evelyn Sanford, 17, a high school graduate who was apparently kidnapped near her farm home Saturday night, obtained a clue today indicating that she had been forcibly carried off by two men in an automobile.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The voters of Kansas, one of the first States to outlaw the liquor traffic, will have an opportunity tomorrow in the biennial primary to express their sentiments indirectly on the Eighteenth Amendment. The prohibition issue will be up for the first time since 1914.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The Heim Winter silhouette shows a gradual fullness beginning a little below the bust in the high-waisted models. There are, however, many normal-waisted costumes with straighter effects. Some have wide-topped sleeves. More fur is used on the lower sleeves, with elbow emphasis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Katsuji Debuchi, the Japanese Ambassador, was authorized by his Foreign Office today to return to Japan for a leave of absence and arranged to leave here on Aug. 19. He will sail from San Francisco on Aug. 25 on the steamer Chichibu Maru.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, will begin tomorrow a series of conferences that are expected to result in an agreement of the party leaders throughout the State on candidates for Governor, Senator and the other offices on the State ticket.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 1 (AP).--Seven hundred unemployed Canadians, including scores of women, met in an abandoned garage here today and passed resolutions criticizing President Hoover and demanding emergency relief "at the expense of the rich."

Adoption of regulations to halt the practice of unjust cancellations and returns in the garment industry was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Trade Relations of the Credit Clearing House. B.H. Lerner, executive director of the bureau, said the regulations constitute an important and constructive step by the dress industry in defining indefinite terms which have caused confusion and misunderstanding nn the past.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Once more the administration spoke today in an effort to spike reports that President Hoover's Rapidan camp in Virginia was costing Uncle Sam money.

The water-colors of Joseph Pennell placed on view yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries are strikingly un-American in feeling. The small scale, the delicate, almost precious touch, the tonal palette, as well as the low horizon and panoramic sweep, recall English watercolor of the eighteenth century and, naturally, the Dutch.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Plans have been completed for the annual Boys' Club dinner dance, in aid of the William Carey Camp in Jamesport, L.I., which will take place on Friday at Canoe Place Inn. Several divertissements will be given during the evening by members of the junior committee, which is headed by Miss Rita Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell, who will be a debutante this season.

The play that was more or less presented at the Provincetown Playhouse last evening was the sort of thing that should only be shown to a small group of very, very indulgent friends. Even as a parody "The Devil's Little Game" could only add to tha dismal feelings that the world has accumulated through the years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A loan of $1,289,120 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The Great Western had applied for $2,000,000 with which to meet equipment obligations and pay taxes and interest on its bonds.

Economics is everybody's business in the world of today, according to G.D.H. Cole, British economist, whose book, "Economic Tracts for the Times," a study of present-day conditions, is to be published today by the Macmillan Company. Mr. Cole, who sometimes turns to the writing of detective stories for recreation, discusses in his new book unemployment, the financial crisis, tariffs and finally explains why be himself is a Socialist.

Largely as a result of a substantial return flow of funds from other districts and a reversal in the gold movement, the excess reserves of New York City members of the Federal Reserve System increased to more than $100,000,000 again, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions in this district by the Federal Reserve Agent in New York.

A syndicate represented by Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co., realty brokers, is among the applicants for aid from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to rebuild the lower east side, William H. Wheelock, president of the firm, said yesterday. Action on the application is expected in about two months.

Domestic bonds of all classifications moved substantially higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with German loans making by far the best showing In the foreign list. Many domestic railroad issues were pushed up 1 to 12 points in heavy dealings.

Arthur Hopkins is planning an Immediate presentation of "The Master Melody," a comedy by Barton MacLane, an actor, "The Master Melody" was not included in the producer's announcement of his plans, printed in Sunday's dramatic section of THE TIMES.

The threatened strike of 12,000 workers in the garment industry was averted yesterday when the board of directors of the Merchants' Ladies' Garment Association, the jobbers group of the cloak and suit industry, after an all-day meeting at the Hotel New Yorker, agreed to sign a contract with the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union in accordance with the agreement brought about last week among the various factions by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Weekly reports on stocks of grain in Toledo warehouses have been discontinued.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 1 -- Details of the capture of Fort Toledo Saturday were made public here today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 1 -- Interest payment was defaulted today on the bonds of three Canadian newsprint companies, Price Bros. Co., the Abitibi Power and Paper Company and the Lake St. John Power and Paper Company.

SPRINGFIELD, Pa., Aug. 1 -- William Condon, Cornell University football player, was among the winners in the opening of the men's Eastern States clay court tennis championships on the Idle Hour courts today. Condon, playing from the Hill Top Club of Philadelphia, took a three-set match from A.W. Warner of Wilmington, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Duer duPont Breck will give a dance tonight at the Small Point Beach Club, Small Point, Me., to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Susan Cony Breck, Miss Breck will be introduced in New York during the Winter.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- The Ziegfeld Follies may not pass into the limbo of theatrical productions. Billie Burke, wife of the late Florenz Ziegfeld, today indicated that she might take up the career of the famous glorifier of girls.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland and Walter W. Waters, leader of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, will confer at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Governor's office in Annapolis concerning the Chief Executive's refusal to sanction the establishment of a permanent colony in Anne Arundel County near Waterbury.

A week after Immigration Commissioner Edward Corsi had established conditions resembling a prison on Ellis Island to prevent the escape of deportees and possible trouble among the criminal element, a man disappeared mysteriously Sunday night, apparently escaping under the very noses of the guards.
The New York Stock Exchange has received notice that the Aug. 1 interest on the following issues is not being paid:

GODERICH, Ont., Aug. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Perfect weather, a fast track, thousand-dollar purses and a large entry list today served to make the civic holiday race meet of the Goderich Trotting and Pacing Association a record-breaker, A crowd of over 4,000 saw the races.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- The Canadian Government tomorrow will place before the British delegation to the Imperial Economic Conference a set of revised proposals worked out by Prime Minister Bennett and members of his Cabinet during the week-end. The Canadians hope the proposals will lead to some agreement between Canada and the United Kingdom, regardless of what else the conference may accomplish.

An old confidence game, which, according to police, has cost relatives and employes of travelers thousands of dollars in the last several months, won the attention of the United States Government yesterday when a Federal grand jury handed up an indictment against three defendants under the mail-fraud statute.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1. -- Walter W. Waters, the momentary Mussolini of the "Khaki Shirts," is enjoying the realization of a "noncom's" dream.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Real disarmament cannot come unless there is a "new deal" in Europe along economic and political lines, Lieut. Col. C.G. Mettler, district ordnance officer of the Second Corps Area, told the Institute of Politics today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug 1 (AP). -- A fine pitching exhibition by Bill Gould stopped the Rochester Red Wings today after they had taken the first four games of the aeries and the Bisons won 2 to 1. Gould allowed only five hits and the sole tally off him was unearned.

After a survey lasting more than three weeks, friends of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday that they had started a campaign to obtain for him the Republican nomination for Governor. Meredith Strong, Superintendent of Buildings and Offices in Queens, who made the announcement, said temporary headquarters of the "Harvey for Governor" campaign had been opened in the law offices of Samuel D. Jones at 120 Broadway.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Conewago, the Yankee defender, scored today in the opening race for the historic Canada's Cup. The Rochester Yacht Club's eight-meter sloop won from the Royal Canadian Yacht Club challenger, the Fire-designed Invader II, by a margin of thirty-five seconds after an eighteen-mile race over a windward and leeward course.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The expectation that President Hoover would call a national parley of business and labor leaders to discuss means of spreading the five-day week and probably also a shorter working day was expressed tonight after a White House conference.

A protest has been filed by the Central Mercantile Association with Borough President Levy of Manhattan against establishing a gas and parking station on the block fronting on the east side of Seventh Avenue between Nineteenth and Twentieth Streets.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 1 -- Sir Guy Mac, 2:04 1/2, the chestnut trotter owned by Mrs. Charles F. Adams of Farmingham Centre, Mass., smashed three records in the opening heat of the classified trot to blaze the way for Grand Circuit speedsters as they began a five-day race meeting at Rockingham Park this afternoon.

Granting that Mayor WALKER intends to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor if he is removed from his present office, and even crediting the prediction that Tammany would support his candidacy, it is most improbable that the Mayor could be nominated.

Influenced by the strength In the stock market and by over-Sunday rains in sections east of the Mississippi River, values on the Cotton Ex-change advanced yesterday to the highest levels of the last three weeks. At prices above 6 cents a pound for the October delivery, the market ran into contracts, while sales of governmentfinanced cotton were estimated at above 10,000 bales.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 2 -- Marshal Chiang Kai-shek, head of the Nanking Government, has apparently determined to intervene vigorously in the situation in North China, where the Japanese threaten to attack the forces of Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang both in Jehol Province and in Tientsin and Peiping.

The hopes of the taxicab industry for a stabilization of rates, preferably on a higher level than at present, received a setback yesterday when it became known that Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly had submitted to Maurice Hotchner, chairman of the Board of Taxicab Control, all opinion holding that the board had no power to fix minimum rates.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1. -- Equaling the world's record in an almost dead-heat finish with his team-mate. Ralph Metcalfe, stocky little Eddie Tolan of the United States won the Olympic 100-meter sprint title today as another series of sensational performances enthralled a crowd of 60,000 in the huge stadium here.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 1 -- Hollis College, debt free, was conveyed to a self-perpetuating board of trustees today, on the ninetieth anniversary of the college, attaining the goal set eighty-six years ago by Charles Lewis Cocke, the first President.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1.--The immaculate stretch of velvet turf in Olympic Stadium, the background against which the world's greatest track and field performers are competing in the tenth Olympiad, presents a continual moving picture of color and animation that is sufficient in itself to rivet the eye and the attention of the spectators when there is a lull in the program.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1 -- Mme. Sun Yat-sen, the widow of the revolutionary founder of the Kuomintang party, issued a statement today championing Harold R. Isaacs, the American editor of The China Forum, who Has been warned by the United States Consul General here to cease his sharp attacks on the Nanking Government on pain of losing his immunity to Chinese prosecution.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Information that Mayor Walker was considering running for the Democratic nomination for Governor if he should be removed from office came as a distinct surprise here today, although aides of both Governor Roosevelt and Lieut. Gov. Lehman professed to be unworried by the threat of the Mayor's entrance into the State political picture on a possible "vindication" issue.

The Reichstag election was a disappointment if we assume that the primary purpose in the voting was to produce a parliamentary majority capable of governing. But the outcome was neither indecisive nor disappointing if we take it that the principal issue was HITLER.

A small fire followed by the explosion of pent-up fumes yesterday in the subcellar paint shop of the Ritz Tower, forty-one-story apartment hotel at Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, cost the lives of seven firemen and resulted in injuries to thirty-one persons. firemen followed him, dragging hose. About thirty firemen were in the subcellar, the basement, on the ladder in the shaftway or on the stairway leading to the subcellar when the first explosion occurred.

A polite invitation to the United States to attend a world economic conference has been presented by the British. Our Government is assured that reparations, governmental debts and "specific " tariff rates, "as distinguished from tariff policy," will be excluded from discussion.

The result of the poll on Mayor Walker's "voluntary" pay cut plan n the Department of Sanitation, announced yesterday by Chairman William Schroeder Jr., showed that 14,998 employes voted yes and fiftyfive voted no. Dr. Schroeder said that when the poll was taken 189 were absent on sick leave, 198 were absent for other reasons, and 2,085 were on vacation.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- The Imperial Economic Conference will resume its negotiations tomorrow after a threeday recess, still desperately determined to accomplish something but with a handicap that did not exist when the sessions began on July 21.

The Chicago and New York banking syndicate holding an option to buy an issue of $18,000,000 Commonwealth Edison Company first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, series G, is exercising its option and will make a formal offering of the bonds in a day or two, it was announced yesterday.

Although returns due yesterday from manufacturers under the new Federal excise levies were described as coming in "satisfactorily," there was no heavy rush of payments. It was said at the offices of Collectors of Internal Revenue here. No estimates were made at either office of the volume of taxes represented or the number of returns filed.
LONDON, Aug. 1.--The first definite link between the ancient civilizations of India and Babylonia has been found in the Tigris Valley by excavators of the University of Chicago Oriental Institute.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Business at the recreation parks operated by the Westchester County Park Commission has increased to such an extent during the past month and prospects for August are so good that employes may not have to take thirty-day furloughs to enable the commission to keep within its operating budget, according to an announcement here today by Chief Engineer Jay Downer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The week-end deluge of political speeches and statements prompted a declaration today by Senator Hull, Democrat of Tennessee, taking to task two Republicans, Secretary Mills and Senator Smoot of Utah.
HARBIN, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Manchuria faces losses of tens of millions of dollars by floods which have followed torrential rains.

No one need expect, because the Federal Reserve is now authorized by law to discount notes "for any individual, partnership or corporation," that there will forthwith be inconveniently large-scale absorption of Reserve Bank credit for that purpose.

FAIRLAWN, N.J. Aug. 1 (AP). -- Covered by a layer of chocolate bonbons, a dynamite bomb was delivered by parcel post carrier today to the home of Mrs. Mary Dell Vennery at 133 Lincoln Avenue, and but for the suspicions of her daughter. Rose, a school teacher, might have carried out its death-dealing mission.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A charge that Bolivian attacks on Paraguayan forts in the Chaco region violated Articles X and XI of the League of Nations Covenant was cabled to the League Council today by the Paraguayan Foreign Minister.

The Republicans for Roosevelt Repeal League, made up of Republicans who are supporting Governor Roosevelt for President on the prohibition issue, was organized yesterday under the leadership of Mrs. Edward Wylde. Headquarters were opened in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Market values, as gauged by 240 representative stocks, appreciated more In July than in any other month since June, 1931. The extent of the gain, so far as these stocks are concerned, is shown in a compilation made. by THE NEW YORK TIMES, comprising twenty groups listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- William Mairs Duryea, riding Say When, won in the adult jumping class in the first of this season's series of invitation riding and jumping contests, held at the Riding Club. Mr. Duryea also rode Scott McLanahan's Bridget, which took second.

Addison H.Day, who will be 82 years old in November, began yesterday his sixty-fourth year as a regular commuter between Chatham, N.J., and New York. When he stepped aboard the train in the morning at his home town to come to his desk in the office of the Marine Midland Trust Company, at 120 Broadway, where he is an official, he started on his thirty-ninth commutation trip around the world, figuratively speaking.

COLON, Aug. 2. -- Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago, returning from a scientific expedition to Peru that took him to the top of Mount Misti, 19,000 feet high, to measure cosmic rays, said today that his observations would be of great value in determining the nature and origin of the cosmic ray.

Those who have examined the daily statements of the Treasury since July 1, hoping for evidence of a balanced budget, have thus far been disappointed. At the close of business on July 28 the Federal Government had received $77,000,000 and had spent $337,000,000.

Bathing in the waters adjacent to New York City must be ended entirely some day if adequate facilities are not provided for the disposal of the city's ever increasing volume of sewage. Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, warned yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 3 (AP). -- A dispatch to the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency from Mukden today said small bandit raids in the neighborhood of Yingkow had caused 300 extra Japanese police to be sent there from Port Arthur.

Bond prices turned reactionary yesterday on the Stock Exchange, particularly in domestic corporation issues, several of which received setbacks of 1 to more than 5 points. In the foreign loans bonds of the German group held their ground fairly well, with a few issues losing 1 to 3 points for the day.

An eighth-inning pinch double by Johnny Frederick at Ebbets Field yesterday brought Hack Wilson and Tony Cuccinello racing over the plate to give Max Carey's fast-rolling Dodgers a 4-to-2 victory over the Cubs in the final game and three of the four games of the series.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2. -- In competition so close that it was necessary to decide the victor on points. France was declared winner early today over Italy in the team foil finals of the 1932 Olympic Games. Italy was the 1928 champion.
BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- Because of the foreign exchange control laws, the Deutsche Bank und Disconto-Gessellschaft will be unable to repay in dollars its 6 per cent $25,000,000 loan maturing Sept. 1.

The Associated Gas and Electric System has cut its refunding requirements, which were about $42,000,000 as the year began, to less than $2,000,000 at the present time, as a result of the latest measure undertaken to meet the note maturity of a subsidiary.

If Governor ROOSEVELT sticks to his rule that he will respond to no attack "except from the gentleman who is running against me," he may never have an opportunity to come to personal grips with the President during the campaign. In 1928 Mr. HOOVER never mentioned Mr. SMITH'S name; it was as if he had no idea who was his opponent.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Farmers have a right to peddle any produce which they have produced themselves in any city or village in the State, according to a ruling promulgated today by Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

Cooperation between China and Japan is essential to the welfare of both countries, George S. Sokolsky, writer on affairs in the Far East, asserts in his book "The Tinder Box of Asia," to be published today by Doubleday, Doran Co.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 2. -- The A B C powers, Argentina, Brazil and Chile, are reported here to have prepared a note to send to Bolivia and Paraguay on the Chaco dispute, but decided not to send it because Brazil objected that it was too strong as regards the Bolivian position and too favorable to Paraguay.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Errors behind him cost young Bill Chamberlain his first start for the Chicago White Sox today against Washington. The score was 4 to 1, with the young southpaw yielding only four hits ill eight innings. Not a run was scored on him that was not helped along by poor defensive play.

HINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 2 (AP). -- The opening day of a series of sailing contests between East and West ended with the salt-water sailormen of the Hingham Tacht Club a scant quarter of a point ahead of their fresh-water challengers from Detroit.

To exhaust the sum of $31,570 in the sinking fund, the Chase National Bank as successor trustee is inviting tenders for the sale to it at prices not exceeding par and accrued interest of Consolidated Coal Company of St. Louis general mortgage thirty-year 6 per cent sinking fund gold bonds.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Seventyseven boats sailed in the first championship regatta of the seventeenth annual race meet of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, held under the direct auspices of the Babylon Yacht Club today. The number would have been larger had not the Star Class craft raced over a special course off Bay Shore.

While the time for the exchange of Pacific Gas and Electric preferred and common shares for San Joaquin Light and Power preferred shares has not been extended officially, stock of the latter company is still being accepted by the Pacific company beyond the Aug. 1 date set.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 3.--Commander Waters of the B.E.F. issued a statement soon after midnight this morning advising the members of that organization to return to their respective home States. This statement was issued after a series of late conferences and was the third one which Waters had, made during the evening.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP). -- In a battle of booming distance drives, the Phillies defeated the Pirates today, 11 to 6, and made a clean sweep of the four game series over the league leaders.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Liquidation by Eastern and local longs, with hedging pressure, crashed the wheat market today and the finish was at the bottom at net losses of 2 cents.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John M. Conyngham have arrived at the Plaza from their home in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

Gross crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 2,137,500 barrels daily, compared with 2,205,850 in the previous week, a drop of 68,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 59,900 barrels and 14,900 barrels, respectively, in the daily outputs of Oklahoma and East Texas were among the important changes.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The government must remiburse Isadore Rabinowitz of Paterson, N.J., an army field clerk in the Adjutant General's Department, for $2,124.40 he claims to have spent to recover from an attack of pneumonia which followed twenty-four hours of continuous duty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Grain exports from the United States last week amounted to 1,007,000 bushels, compared with 761,000 the previous week and 5,591,000 during the corresponding week last year. Commerce Department figures today gave the following comparisons between last week's exports and those the week before: Wheat, 594,000 bushels, against 321,000 last week and 4,790,000 last year; barley, 143,000 against 314,000; corn, 54,000 against 75,000; oats, 216,000 against 51,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A blockaid campaign for raising funds for unemployment relief, similar to the campaign recently conducted, in New York City, was set in motion throughout New Jersey today at a meeting of 200 representatives of New Jersey municipalities in the Assembly chamber at the Capitol here.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 3. -- The Daily Express estimates that up to July 31, the last day for the holders of 5 per cent war loan bonds to obtain the conversion bonus of u1 per u100, the amount offered for conversion into the new 3 1/2 per cent loan was u1,500,000,000 out of a total of u2,087,000,000.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Unleashing a complete reversal of form after losing the first set, Gregory S. Mangin of New York, No. 11 in the national ranking and holder of the national indoor title, registered the first major surprise of the forty-second annual Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament today, turning back Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara, Cal., eighth ranking player in the national list, 1-6, 6-1, 9-7.

TEHERAN, July 19 ((AP) by Mail) -- The venerable Bengali poet, Sir Rabindranath Tagore, has made a triumphant Journey through Shiraz and Ispahan to this Persian capital, where he was welcomed outside the grates of the city (always a great honor) by a representative of the Shah and other distinguished persons.

HELSINGFORS, Aug. 2. -- Important cooperation has started between the Carnegie Institution of Washington and the Geological Commission of Finland with a view to solving the riddle of primary rock. The Carnegie Institution has undertaken, a series of determinations of the radium in Precambrian rocks which may help to determine their ages.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2. -- Prime Minister Bennett of Canada, as president of the Imperial Economic Conference, made a brief statement to the assembled correspondents of the British Enpire and foreign countries today and then volunteered to answer their questions.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 2. -- A wholly new plan by which the aggregate air forces of the world now numbering 18,000 airplanes and 200,000 men, would ultimately be reduced by at least 80 per cent was presented to the Institute of Politics today by Edward P. Warner, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Aeronatuics, and now editor of Aviation.

The hard training grind will end today for Jimmy McLarnin, hardhitting Vancouver welterweight, and Lou Brouillard, former world's champion, who are to clash tomorrow night in a ten-round struggle at the Yankee Stadium, under the auspices of the Aram A.C., in the interests of the Daniel Frohman Foundation for the Actors' Fund of America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- An upward movement in business was noted today by the Department of Commerce.

The council of the Actors' Equity Association took action yesterday against what it termed "revues in the guise of vaudeville" when it ruled that the production of Chamberlain Brown's "Scrapbook," which opened at the Ambassador Theatre on Monday night, was to be classified as a revue instead of a vaudeville entertainment and that, under the circumstances, the Equity members in the show would have to give their two weeks' notices of termination of contract immediately.

Plans for the Republican campaign in the East for the re-election of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis were discussed yesterday by Everett Sanders, national chairman, and Senator Felix Hebert of Rhode Island, Eastern campaign manager.

Approximately one hundred communities in Florida which have been permitting their taxpayers to turn in bonds of the respective communities in lieu of payment of taxes in cash must abandon this method at once, as a result of a decision just rendered by the Circuit Court of Appeals.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Forewarned by District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards of Nassau County, the proprietors of all gambling concessions along the boardwalk of this resort, whose wide-open games of chance recently led to the dismissal of Chief of Police Morris Grossman by Mayor Frank Frankel, voluntarily closed their places of business tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Art exhibits from the United States entered in the Olympic fine arts display received the lion's share of awards in the judging completed today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Victor Cumming of 400 East Fifty-seventh Street of the marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Dorothy Cumming Elliott, former stage and screen actress, to Allan McNab, British artist, last Wednesday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edward Henry Emett, pastor of the Manhattan Congregational Church, in the presence of relatives and close friends at Mrs. Cumming's apartment.

The political career of Ramsay MacDonald, Prime Minister of England, is an outstanding illustration of the "pathetic" predicament of the Liberal in modern society since the World War, Professor Carl Becker of Cornell University declared yesterday afternoon in an address to Columbia University Summer session students at Teachers College.

Adam returned to Harlem yesterday bringing a new Eve. With them came Noah, Cain, Moses, several prophets and priests, and a group of wingless angels. The Lord stopped off in Chicago, his native city. The cast of "The Green Pastures" had come home.

Beer Wine and Spirits. Various estimates have been made of the amount of intoxlcating liquor illegally produced and sold in the United States. The latest is contained in a survey made by Dr. CLARK WARBURTON, published by the Columbia University Press.

A force of 100 engineers, fitters and shipyard men has been engaged since Monday morning in raising the two funnels of the new United States liner Manhattan fifteen feet because it was discovered on the trial trip before coming to New York that the funnels were not high enough to throw off the poisonous gases and soot that comes up from below.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes advanced to the final round of the Wheatley Cups polo tournament by touting Bobby Strawbridge's Vipers, 15 to 8, today in a semi-final match, of the annual tourney on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

Work was started this week at the foot of Fourteenth Street, Hoboken, on the new New York terminal of Seatrain Lines, Inc., and will progress rapidly to be ready for use when the company's two new vessels emerge from the builder's yards late in the Fall, officials of the line said yesterday.
ASUNCION, Aug. 2 (AP). -- President Jose P. Guggiari called upon the army to "achieve deeds of prowess" in a proclamation today called forth by the Chaco boundary conflict with Bolivia.

Walter Edward Webel Jr., 22 years old, of 543 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was shot and killed near his home yesterday by Deputy Sheriff Vincent Glynn, nephew of former Governor Alfred E. Smith. Glynn told the police that he was attempting to serve an order of arrest in a contempt of court action on Webel.

THE 1,500-meter trials will be run off today at Los Angeles. There's an Olympic event that it would be good to win. The final, not the trials. It's the nearest thing on the Olympic program to our standard mile.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Captain Wolfgang von Gronau, German aviator who has flown the Atlantic three times by the northern route, arrived in Chicago this afternoon and received an enthusiastic greeting by 5,000 persons gathered in Grant Park.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict gave a luncheon today at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club for Mrs. Edwin S. Cramp. Her other guests were Mrs. Edward L. Keyes and her daughter. Mrs. Joseph Du Vivier of Paris; Mrs. Joseph K.T. Van Pelt, Mrs. George Arents, Mrs. Robert J. McKeon, Miss Dorothy Schieffelin and Miss Laura Worthington.

The Hotel Victoria at the northeast corner of Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue was sold yesterday for $1,000 above mortgages totaling $3,858,917. The twenty-two-story structure, one of the best-known hotels in the midtown section, changed ownership in an action brought by Frances Spiegel against the Max Kurzrok Realty Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Threats against Haden Clarke by Captain W. N. Lancaster, former British Army flier, when the latter learned of a growing attachment between the young writer and Mrs. J.M. Keith-Miller, his flying partner, were charged in the prosecutor's opening statement today as Captain Lancaster went on trial for murder.

A revised plan calling for inclusion of further material on virtually all of the accusations he has made against Mayor Walker caused Samuel Seabury to redraft yesterday parts of his rebuttal of Mr. Walker's defense in removal proceedings. It had been expected that the rebuttal would be sent to Governor Roosevelt yesterday.

Oversubscription of the issue of $18,000,000 Commonwealth Edison Company first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, Series G, was indicated in advance of the public offering of the bonds today, resulting in bidding for the bonds at a premium. Dealers were reported to have more orders for the bonds than they are able to fill, as allotments were small.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Boston Braves rallied in the ninth inning today to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 3, in the last of the five-game series. A double by Wally Berger, Fred Leach's single and Wes Schulmerich's fly, all made off Dean, put over the winning tally.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2. -- Bo Lindman of Sweden, led in the modern Pentathlon, competition, tonight after the first event of the five-day program, a 3,000-meter equestrian steeplechase which furnished thrills and spills for 500 spectators.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The United States commission investigating the claims of British inventors against the United States Government in respect to war inventions began its sittings in the offices of the Privy Council today.

Following Monday's advance to the highest quotations in three weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday in sympathy with outside markets. Selling pressure at the opening put values a dollar a bale lower at one time. A loss of a quarter cent from last week's high levels attracted enough demand to steady the tone in the last hour, leaving quotations 12 to 16 points off on the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: W.W. Waters has issued a call to every citizen to join a movement to take the government away from the moneyed powers, by legal means, and return it to the common people, whose government it should be.

To the Editor of The New York times: I knew when I read THE NEW YORK TIMES report on General Smedley D. Butler's harangue of the destitute war veterans and others of the "bonus expeditionary force" in their squatters' camp at Washington that the government had to choose between rout of the B.E.F. and eventual loss of control of the nation.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The value of military students to the nation, first as good citizens and secondly as men trained for national emergencies, was impressed upon 1,400 students from New York, New Jersey and Delaware at camp here this afternoon when they were mustered into the training camp organizations with the administration of the C.M.T.C. oath.

JOHN BUCHAN in his description of the British advance in the vicinity of Thiepval in France, where the monument was dedicated on Monday bearing the names of 73,413 unidentified soldier dead, said that these words were true of every man of them as they entered the conflict: As gentle and as jocund as to jest Go I to fight. Truth hath a quiet breast.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club won the low gross honors today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, one-day tournament at the North Shore Country Club, outstroking three of the district's leading links stars in doing so.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug, 2 (AP). -- Two youths, holding a capitalist and an orphanage superintendent as captives, were trapped by police in a Richmond bank today as they sought to collect $7,500 in ransom money.

The monthly index number of average commodity prices, compiled by Dun's Review as of Aug. 1, calculates increase of 2 3/4 per cent in the price average. This is the second largest recovery reported for any month since 1929, the largest being the 2 7/8 per cent advance of last October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A loan of $4,575,000 to the Wabash Railway Company by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to pay, in part, bank loans now due was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Two of the eight seeded players in the Maidstone Club's seventh annual women's invitation tournament fell by the wayside in the second round today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- United States Senator William E. Borah, of Idaho, stopped off in Chicago today, en route to Minneapolis, where he will make a speech tomorrow night. Replying to questions, he said he would not support the Republican Hoover-Curtis ticket or the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On behalf of the board of directors of Beekman Street Hospital I wish heartily to endorse the petition filed by the United Hospital Fund with the Board of Estimate and Apportionment of New York City asking for an increased appropriation for the care of the sick poor in private institutions.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Germany still suffered today from election tension, and in seven cities and towns there were outbreaks of political violence.

In the absence of any new developments, activity in all financial markets slackened yesterday, and the trend of prices was reactionary. To Wall Street this brought no surprise, considering that the recovery in stocks had lasted almost uninterruptedly nearly four weeks and the recovery in bonds two months.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- After a weak opening the market rallied on the Bourse today and most of the closing prices were above yesterday's final quotations. Neither the technical changes affecting the market here nor uncertainty regarding the German political situation influenced trading unfavorably.

An important business lease in the shopping district centring in Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street was announced yesterday. Nelson-Hickson, Inc., women's wear firm, was the lessee, taking extensive store and upper floor space in the Heckscher Building, southwest corner of the avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, for a long term at an aggregate rental of nearly $800,000.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 2. -- Following receipt of contradictory instructions from Walter W. Waters, their commander, members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force tonight were determined to stick it out here.

The late Chancellor SEIPEL was the ablest political leader produced by post-war Austria. Though his name is connected with a party and a special interest -- he was the organizer and leader of the Catholic peasant element against the Socialist influence dominant in "Red" Vienna -- he served his country faithfully and well.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The United States formally accepted today the invitation to attend the International Monetary and Economic Conference of the League of Nations on terms laid down in the invitation. Thus negotiations on debts owed to this country, German, reparations and tariff rates will be barred, but the silver problem will be included in the discussion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eli Benedict writes enthusiastically and ideally about the recent Coney Island fire. Confirming his opinion that there is too much flimsy wood construction at beach resorts, no one, whether prompted by zeal for certain building materials or by personal reaction after years of fire-prevention and fire-protection experience, would gainsay such opinion.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- In the lead from start to finish. Invader II, Royal Canadian Yacht Club challenger, today evened the Canada's Cup series at one race each. Invader finished the twenty-one-mile triangular course with an advantage of fifty-seven seconds over the defending Conewago of the Rochester Yacht Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- Continuation for another year of the national agreement between the American Federation of Full Fashioned Hosiery Workers, with its 22,000 members, and the Hosiery Manufacturers' Association was insured today when the union's national executive board and national conference board, at a joint meeting here, decided not to send in a notice to terminate the peace.
LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The celebrated Oldoway skeleton, which, had been believed by some scientists to be the oldest known specimen of true man, was declared today to date from a fairly recent period.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Aug. 2. -- The monastery of Villanova College was virtually destroyed today by a stubborn fire which ate its way through an art collection valued at upward of $500,000 and resulted in injuries to fifty-three persons, including firemen, two women spectators and a student.
ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- The names of 150 students who have won Cornell scholarships from the State were announced today by the State Education Department, following an examination June 20-24.

READING, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Reading trounced the Montreal Royals in two games tonight to retain their hold on sixth place in the International League. The Keys chased Gowell Claset in the first frame of the opener, which they won, 7 to 2. The second game was won by 9 to 2.
OTTAWA, Aug. 2. -- Twelve men and two women demonstrators were jailed today after conflicts between the police and Communists following an interview between their leaders and Prime Minister Bennett.

Wholesale market prices were irregular. Grains and cotton declined sharply while on the other hand better prices appeared for coffee, butter and printcloths. Metal prices were firm with zinc showing a small advance. Other price changes were of a minor nature.

In the dry statistics of the census figures on women's occupations, one may discover an accurate, living picture of social trends during the last decade. The first large fact -- that there are eleven million women earning a living outside the home in this country -- sheds a broad ray of light on conditions changed greatly in ten years and altered beyond recognition in twenty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Economy measures of the government were reflected in a reduction of $47,773,000 in general expenditures during July, the outlay of $198,773,771 for the month representing the cost of operation of the various departments and bureaus, and being one of the few classes of expenses which may be curtailed.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) . -- Vancouver surgeons, by performing what is believed to be the only operation of its kind ever done in Canada, are credited with saving the life of 9-year-old Billy McGillivray, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McGillivray.

A resolution to suspend ail work, beginning tomorrow morning, in about 75 per cent of the shops in the men's clothing industry in New York City and vicinity was adopted last night at a meeting of the shop chairmen and members of the executive boards of the local unions of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

There appears to be no abatement in the good results the off-shore fishermen have been having recently. It is rather strange, too, in what have been described conservatively as dull times, to find that so many of the boat captains are finding that they are making bookings covering practically every day of the week.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 2. -- W. D.B. Ainey, chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, resigned today rather than face a Senatorial investigation into charges of gross misconduct in office.

After the Federal Reserve Bank had turned away individuals applying for direct loans to save their homes and aid their small industries, a plan was being evolved yesterday which would extend the facilities of the central bank's new credit program to prospective borrowers ineligible for direct loans, it became known yesterday in banking circles.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 2. -- Captain A.F. Amory of the trawler Seagull, one of three vessels trying to locate and recover approximately $6,000,000 in gold, silver, jewels and money in the sunken steamer Merida, reported today that the craft had been found. He said sweeping operations had revealed the vessel about ten miles off Winter Quarter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Eleven army units will march in silence when they go parading in the future. Their bands are to be muted by the governmental economy program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Bolivia was asked to agree to a suspension of hostilities with Paraguay in the Chaco on the basis of the status quo ante and to consent to submit the controversy to arbitration, in a note by the committee of neutral diplomats forwarded to Foreign Minister Gutierrez at La Paz tonight.

Borrowing's of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange on security collateral declined $1,974,352 in July to a new low record of $241,599,943. The figures were a surprise in Wall Street, where the sharp rise in the value of stocks and bonds in the last month had been attributed to bullish speculation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Former Governor Edwin P. Morrow of Kentucky announced in a statement tonight that because of ill health he would not be the Republican candidate for United States Senator from that State.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 2. -- Mrs. Bernice Rogers Weber, wife of Robert Weber, for the past five years a counterman in a lunch cart here, today received notification from England that she is to receive $6,000,000 of the $15,000,000 estate left by Edward Weil, a former Houston (Texas) capitalist, who is believed to have died in a detention camp abroad following the outbreak of the World War in 1914.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- An entertainment is being arranged for the benefit of the Middletown unemployment fund and the Sunshine Society of this city. It is to take place at Dudley Place, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Delafield Phelps. on tha afternoon and evening of Aug. 20.

An old Injury came back yesterday to cost Billy Patrolle, Fargo, N.D., ring veteran, his scheduled chance at the world's lightweight title bout against Tony Canzoneri, the champion. During a workout at the Pioneer Gymnasium Petrolle twisted his left arm in such a manner as to splinter a bone near the elbow in two places.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Aug. 3. -- A severe blow to the campaign of Marshal Chiang Kai-shek against the Communist armies in the Yangtse Valley has been dealt by the desertion of two of his divisions which were operating against Red armies to the west of Hankow.

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- A vast amount of material for addresses in the Presidential campaign is being assembled by Governor Roosevelt, it was learned today, with the program calling for at least six or seven major speeches in various parts of the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Heavy oversubscription for the Treasury's offering of 2 1/8 per cent two-year notes and 3 1/4 per cent four-year notes, dated Aug. 1, was announced today by Secretary Mills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The War Department gave approval today to plans of the Department of Docks of New York City for a modification of the bulkhead line of the East River betwen East Houston and East Fourteenth Streets, Manhattan, so as to accommodate the East River Drive as recently laid out by the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania personally appealed to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today to expedite an immediate relief loan of $10,000,000 for the State. No immediate action was taken, however, and the Governor was requested to return Thursday accompanied by two members each of the Pennsylvania Senate and the Assembly.
Captain S.G.S. McNeil, retired master of the Mauretania, will sail on the Cunarder this afternoon, for England. Others sailing are:
BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The monthly wage basis established on Monday for the Delaware Hudson Railroad's 2,850 train-service employes will have the effect of distributing work more equitably than is possible under the standard agreements, L.F. Loree, president, said yesterday.

There seems always to be in the matter of nominating a Governor of New York a preliminary silly season. Impossible candidates are gravely mentioned. Men as obscure as those whom WILLIAM J. BRYAN used to name as fit for the Presidency are urged in various parts of the State.

Henry Cohen, formerly a bank teller in the midtown branch of the National Bank and Trust Company of New York, was indicted yesterday as an embezzler because a Federal grand jury did not believe, his story that on April 29 last an armed man forced him to pass $11,800 through the cage of his window.

MONTREAL, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press). -- The Theatre Francais, one of Montreal's few surviving links with the glamorous days of the old melodrama, was destroyed today by fire from which a motion-picture audience of 300 escaped only through the presence of mind and courage of the manager and a few aides.

Primo Camera, Italian ring giant, scored the third straight ring triumph of his current American campaign at the Queensboro Stadium last night at the expense of rugged Hans Birkie, Californian, in the ten-round feature bout. The huge Venetian, however, failed to impress a crowd of 3,000 as a heavyweight title threat, and, in fact, failed to convince many that he was entitled to the decision.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. MANILA -- The hopes and fears of Filipino political leaders regarding independence and their doubts of the effect of a plebiscite after a few years of economic dislocation are expressed by Juan Sumulong, Opposition leader, a man of political ability and perspicacity.

A reaction that had long been forecast overtook the stock market yesterday, causing a moderate setback in prices, but no observable diminution of optimism. Business on the Stock Exchange approximated 1,440,000 shares, compared with 2,107,000 on the day before.
Mayor Bill Smith excused himself for a moment last evening as he noticed the sunset shadows lengthening in the cobbled streets of Hardluck-on-the-River, down at the foot of East Tenth Street.

In a final brief, filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission, in support of its pending application for a 40 per cent rise in commutation fares, the New York Central Railroad asserts that even that increase is not compensatory.

Rogers Hornsby, manager of the Chicago Cubs, was released last night, it was announced by William L. Veeck, president of the club. Charlie Grimm, first baseman of the team, took charge of the club in Philadelphia, where the Cubs open a series today with the Phillies.

Arthur J. McQuade, 24 years old, of 725 Riverside Drive, objected last night when Patrolman Charles Klika, on duty at the corner of Fifty-fourth Street and Broadway, asked him to move his car from the pedestrian crossway at the southwest corner, where, according to Kilka, he had parked it.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 2. -- The chestnut horse Josedale, 2:05, called the greatest cripple on the Grand Circuit since the days of Walter Cox's Abbedale, scored a straight-heat victory over a classy field In the 2:16 trot to feature the second day's big-time racing at Rockingham Park.

It may in time develop to have been the beginning of the long-awaited August push and then again it may only have been the Reds, but whatever the reason, the Giants finished their current business with the Cincinnatians at the Polo Grounds yesterday with another smart, concise victory.

The aggregate of new financing in the United States in the first seven months of this year was only $336,636,000, despite the increased activity in July, when new financing totaling $94,209,000 was done, according to figures announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of National Statistical Service, Inc.
GENEVA, Aug. 2. -- The League of Nations received and immediately forwarded to Bolivia today an offer from Paraguay to arbitrate the conflict over the Chaco region.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2. -- While the strictest secrecy was being observed by Canadian officials concerning the proposals now being whipped into shape by experts for presentation to Great Britain at the Imperial Ecoiomic Conference here, it was learned they would embody an offer to divert to the United Kingdom from $50,000,000 to $60,000,000 of Canada's purchases from the United States.
Money market remained dull, call rate continuing at 2 per cent, with outside funds loaning at 1 per cent. Time loans, bankers' acceptances and commercial paper rates unchanged.

Leopold A. Bernheimer of this city, who died on July 26 at Central Valley, N.Y., left bequests totaling $15,300 to twenty Institutions in his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

The large unfinished gray building that has stood forlornly at the northwest corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-second Street for the last eight years soon may join its smart apartment-house neighbors. Sumner Gerard, attorney, who yesterday bought the erstwhile Hudson Towers at a foreclosure auction sale for $200,000, believes that the building, planned as a de luxe hospital, sanitarium and hotel, may be converted into a multifamily structure.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 2. -- While taking a revolver from a desk drawer to place on a bedside table for protection last night, Lieutenant Joseph Francis Dahlgren, an instructor in French and German at the Naval Academy and acting curator of the academy's museum, seriously wounded himself in the chest and was in a critical condition today at the naval hospital here.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens asked Controller Berry yesterday to give "immediate attention to the matter of acquiring title to streets in Queens." In a public statement, he denounced the controller for "failure to advance title acquisition proceedings, thereby delaying more than $2,000,000 worth of public improvements in the borough and necessitating the recent dismissal of 100 engineers of the Queens Sewer Bureau."

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- Throughout the political campaign which culminated in Sunday's election there was a strong disposition among the spokesmen of the parties of the Right to follow up the German success in virtually wiping out reparations at Lausanne by promising to the voters some further scaling down of German debts.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Colonel Bennett C. Clark, son of the late Speaker Champ Clark and an avowed opponent of prohibition, early today was leading Charles M. Hay, veteran dry, and Charles M. Howell, Kansas City organization candidate, for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in scattering early returns from yesterday's primary election in Missouri.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Outstanding in the stock markets today was the recovery in German bonds following a favorable reception of the election results. Considerable interest was taken in British Government funds, but there was less business.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2. -- Running the greatest 800-meter race in the long history of sport, Tom Hampson of Great Britain upheld the 16-year-old tradition of British supremacy in this classic test of speed and endurance today when he raced the distance in the world record time of 1:49.8 to give his country her first championship in the 1932 Olympic Games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Mills and at least one other member of the administration have called one or more meeting: of certain railroad officials to urge them to accept loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the repair of rail equipment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug 2. -- A new track record was set here today for the two-mile steeplechase course when Stephen Sanford's Dark Magne got home first in 4:11 4-5, reducing by a fifth of a second the mark established by J.E. Davis's El Kantara in 1924.

The cause of the fire and the two terrific explosions that shattered the subcellar of the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, on Monday, took the lives of seven firemen and injured thirty-one other persons, mostly firemen, was still a mystery last night.

The Liquid Carbonic Corporation, for the twelve months ended June 30, reports a net profit after interest, depreciation and Federal income taxes of $533,921, equal to $1.56 a share on the 342,406 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compares with a net profit, after similar charges and reserves, of $977,368, or $2.85 a share on the capital stock, in the preceding twelve months.

The second step toward a nationwide interdenominational move to interest young people in a program to curtail crime has been taken by a group of members of the Methodist Episcopal Church South at a conference now in session at Junaluska Lake, N.C., it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William F. Sunday, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Aug. 2.--Mrs. Annie W. Fisher, a widow, of Lyndhurst, N.J., who is touring England with her daughter, Kathleen, and her sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Welsh of West Fiftyfifth Street, New York City, told an amazing story of love and fraud in the Oxford police court today when she charged a well-educated man, Robert Arthur Cooper, with obtaining money under false pretenses.

When the trustees of Fanny R.G. Ely sold to Eva Rachmel the five-story and basement tenement house at 314 Delancey St. for $8,000, they took back a purchase money mortgage for the full purchase price, payable July 29, 1937, at 6 per cent monthly, the buyer also agreeing to deposit with the trustees every month one-twelfth of the annual real estate taxes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- I expect no further trouble from Twenty Grand," was the frank declaration here of Dr. Phillip J. McCarthy, veterinarian who came from Philadelphia to complete an examination of the hero of last year's racing which has not competed since last Fall.

A five-story, fifteen-family flat at 403 East Seventy-seventh Street has been sold by the Frank G. Wild estate to Mrs. Anna Frejka, who intends to renovate the structure. The seller took back a three-year $13,000 first mortgage at 5% per cent. The lot is 25 by 100 feet.

The testimony of George Murnane, a partner in Lee, Higginson Co., American bankers for the late Ivar Kreuger's International Match Corporation, given at a private hearing last Tuesday before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, federal referee in the bankruptcy of the International Match Corporation, was filed yesterday as part of the record by Nathan Katz of counsel for the Irving Trust Company, trustee for the bankrupt corporation.

The Bank for International Settlements as trustee for the Austrian Government International Loan of 1930 issued a formal statement yesterday announcing that owing to restrictive measures taken in Austria, it has not received in foreign currencies the instalments due on July 1, 1932, and Aug. 1, 1932, so that technically, at least, the Austrian Government has defaulted on the issue.
