BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- An anti-climax after the political excitement of recent months was evident at today's session of the Boerse, where business shrunk even below yesterday's volume. Those who in anticipation of a rise covered yesterday, were anxious to be rid again of their engagements, which resulted in a moderate decline in the price level.

Despite unfavorable business conditions and unemployment, the general health of the industrial populations of the United States and Canada during the first half of 1932 reached the highest level ever attained in the Winter and Spring of any year, according to a resume issued yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

On the cover of "Accident Facts," 1932, published by the National Safety Council, are pictures of an airplane in flight, a crowded bathing beach, the stacks of an industrial plant, an automobile rounding a curve, an oncoming railway train and a rustic house in a garden.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2. -- Lured by le procession of record-breaking performances attendant upon the first two days of competition and with the unsurpassed Southern California brand of balmy weather continuing to old forth, another huge crowd of 5,000 spectators sat in the Olympio Coliseum today as Tom Hampson of England led a crack field home in the 800-meter run in the world-record-breaking time of 1:49.8.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 2. -- Serious trouble for Japan in an area which has been comparatively quiet since the Japanese drove the army of Chang Hsiao-liang out of Southern Manchuria last January, is reported in dispatches received here from Mukden.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The rebel government controlling the State of Sao Paulo announced this afternoon that heavy fighting was going on between federal and rebel forces on the northeastern front in the vicinity of Queluz and Barreira.

The results of the poll of the city's firemen on Mayor Walker's proposal that they, with the rest of the city employes, give up a month's salary in 1933 are expected to be known tonight. The ballots will be in the hands of Fire Commissioner Dorman this morning, and the counting of the ballots will begin at once.

More than 500 persons of varying political sympathies gathered in Town Hall last night under the auspices of the recently formed Joint Committee on Unemployment, of which Bishop Francis J. McConnell is president, to listen to speakers discuss unemployment and the eviction of the bonus army from Washington.
Small flats and dwellings composed the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). -- My Dandy, the old one-eyed star of the Reichert Brothers' Stable, liked the sloppy going at Hawthorne today and captured the top race by a margin of five lengths over Annimessic.

Hall Johnson and his Negro choir were the assisting artists at last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Albert Coates at the Lewisohn Stadium. In last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES Mr. Johnson, speaking of the aims of his work, analyzed the racial idiom as becoming most apparent when done in "the real Negro style and by a group.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 2. -- Senator George McGill and Governor Harry H. Woodring were renominated by the Democrats of Kansas by wide majorities on the face of returns tonight from the State's primary election.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A new policy of peace for the Western Hemisphere was laid down in impressive circumstances today when the American nations joined in an identic note to Bolivia and Paraguay declaring that they would not recognize territorial gains in the disputed Chaco region won by force of arms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The State Department was taken completely by surprise today by publication of reports from Berlin that some German Government officials felt Germany should try to have German private debts scaled down at the coming international monetary and economic conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Shipping Board approved an agreement today between the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company and the Gulf Pacific Line covering through shipments of canned goods, canned salmon, dried fruit, beans and rice from Pacific Coast ports to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, with transshipment at New Orleans.

An explanation of a report that Harold R. Isaacs, American editor of the Shanghai English language newspaper The China Forum, had been warned that extraterritorial protection might be withdrawn from him was contained in a letter received yesterday from the State Department by Representative Fiorello H. La Guardia.

That moneys advanced by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to provide employment for railroad maintenance forces should not be subject to interest charges was informally suggested in railroad circles yesterday. This, it was pointed out, would enable the railroads to repair the large amount of equipment now out of order without increasing their fixed charges.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- The announcement of his plans for a ten-day inspection tour of the State, to begin early next week, is expected to come from Lieut. Gov. Lehman tomorrow, and it would not surprise his friends if he placed himself formally in the open as a candidate for Governor at the same time.

Jimmy McLarnin, Vancouver welterweight, tonight undertakes his first ring encounter against a southpaw in the interests of charity. He is to battle Lou Brouillard of Worcester, who formerly held the world's 147-pound title, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Yankee Stadium, under the auspices of the Aram A.C., and for the benefit of the Daniel Frohman Foundation for the Actors' Fund of America.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Count von Bernstoff, the German Charge d'Affaires in London, has informed the British Foreign Office that his government intends to avail itself of the new European consultative pact to open negotiations in London on the demand for full German equality in armament made by Defense Minister von Schleicher in his radio address a week ago.

The referendum called for yesterday by officials of Typographical Union 6 to determine whether the rank and file of the members are in favor of submitting to arbitration the differences on the scale of wages existing between the Publishers' Association of New York City and the union aroused considerable criticism in the various chapels in the city's newspapers, which indicated a negative vote on the ballot in its present form.

Money market was dull, at quotations which showed no change in their array for day loans, maturity money, or business funds. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 per cent, while street trades went at 1, and Federals at 1/8. Maturity money was quoted 1 1/4 to 1 1/2.

William J. Pender, former guard in the United States Trucking Corporation's armored car service, who walked out of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company at 165 Broadway on July 16 with $56,350, was arrested early yesterday morning at Selma, Va. He still had $54,605.

Of more than local interest is the dramatic resignation of W.D.B. AINEY, veteran chairman of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, on the eve of a Senatorial investigation. Only a little over a month ago a man named CHAPMAN, formerly secretary to THOMAS E. MITTEN, the Philadelphia traction magnate, accused Mr. AINEY of receiving $150,000 from Mr. MITTEN over a six-year period.

Meeting the New Taxes. As the first of the month bills come in, people who intend to Pay them all if the money holds out see varying effects of the new taxes. For themselves, they know that if they mail out checks in the usual way, each bill paid will cost a nickel.

The "boy friend" telegrams cited by Samuel Seabury as proof that Mayor Walker and Senator Hastings of Brooklyn attempted to help in financing the Equitable Coach Company were reproduced yesterday in Mr. Seabury's rebuttal, together with Mr. Seabury's interpretation of the cryptic terms contained.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3. -- Before a crowd of 85,000, the largest ever to view a track and field meet from the time of the ancient Greeks down to the present, the United States today enjoyed its mightiest day of triumph in the Olympic Games.

Opposition to Mayor Walker's proposal for a reduction of 8 1-3 per cent in the pay of all civil employes in 1933 gained additional impetus yesterday when the Magistrates' Courts Officers Association voiced objection to "the too-evident coercive methods" used in polling city workers and pledged its support to the Civil Service Forum, which has gone on record against the proposed salary slash.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. - Loyalty to the new boss of the Cubs and best wishes for the departing manager as he prepared to leave for the West were expressed today by members of the Chicago National League team.

DUBLIN, Aug. 3. -- The De Valera Government this afternoon met the Opposition's peace overtures in the Senate with by far the most outspoken speech yet made in either house since the trade war with Great Britain began.

Drop in Furniture Sales Volume. August furniture promotions in retail establishments, throughout the city continued disappointing from a volume standpoint this week. With few exceptions stores found that unit sales trailed from 10 to 20 per cent behind the figures for similar events last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Robert P. Lament resigned as Secretary of Commerce, today and the appointment of Roy Dikeman Chapin of Detroit as his successor was announced immediately afterward by President Hoover. Mr. Chapin is chairman of the board of the Hudson Motor Car Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- Four Brooklyn terminal companies filed a joint injunction suit in the Federal District Courf here today seeking to have the Pennsylvania Railroad restrained from putting into effect its proposed "store-to-door pick-up and delivery freight" plan which was scheduled to begin operating on Sept. 15.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- Lieut. Gen. Kurt von Schleicher, Minister of Defense and credited with being the real power behind the von Papen Government, was quoted by the newspaper Zwoelf Uhr Abendblatt today as expressing frank admiration for Adolf Hitler and declaring his movement must be used, "because it is fired with faith."

Old fishermen of New York, who like to stand around New York docks and talk to youngsters about "the old days," were compelled to take a back seat yesterday when the harbor had a run of mackerel. No one knows how these things get about, but early yesterday morning the dock at the United States Quarantine Station on Staten Island was a hive of excitement.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Volette, the daughter of Dis Donc, which set a new track record at Arlington Park, bore the colors of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney to victory in the Schuylerville, feature today and one of the Saratoga Association's best known tests for 2-year-old fillies.

The Charles Broadway Rouss Building, a landmark in the mercantile district downtown, is again to become a centre of sales activity. The ten-story building at 549-55 Broadway has been leased by M. Martin Kallman, industrial engineer, who will operate the structure as the Manufacturers' Sales Service.

READING, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Reading's Keystones, who will become the Albany Senators, dropped their farewell games as representatives of this city in the International League to Montreal tonight, 11 to 7 and 10 to 4.
PARIS, Aug. 3. -- Maggy Rouff shows the widest shoulders in frocks yet seen, tapering to a slender, normal waist but broadened at the hips.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3. -- Senator Borah declared tonight that if reparations and war debts were not discussed at the coming International Economic Conference, no settlement of monetary problems could be achieved.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 3. -- With a south, southwest wind sweeping across Great South Bay from the ocean front, the Corinthians taking part in the seventeenth annual race meet and championship regattas of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association were confronted with a rolling sea off this port today.
DETROIT, Aug. 3. -- Roy D. Chapin's rise has been closely associated with growth of the automobile industry.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- A memorandum setting forth the needs and desires of the United States Government, which it is hoped the French Government will be disposed to meet, should be ready for presentation by Ambassador Edge at the Foreign Office tomorrow as his first step in negotiating a new Franco-American trade treaty.
Trout fishermen not only like to sit about the fire and enjoy a pipeful, but most of them are constantly seeking some slightly frequented spot, no matter where, to enjoy their sport.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Phil K. Wrigley, who succeeded to the holdings of his late father, William Wrigley Jr., in the Chicago Cubs, has taken a "hands-off" policy in the appointment by William L. Veeck, president of the club, of Charley Grimm as club pilot.

The text of Senator Borah's speed at Minneapolis last night, as received by the Columbia, Broadcasting System, was as follows: Ladies and Gentlemen -- It is a great pleasure to be greeted by this magnificent audience. I am sure it manifests your interest in the great problems which are presented to the American people from the standpoint of international affairs.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 3. -- Martial law for the vicinity of the Dixie Bee mine, in Vigo County, south of here, was ordered by Governor Harry Leslie late today, on the heels of a battle between union and non-union miners yesterday which resulted in the death of one union picket and the wounding of eight other miners, four to a side.

Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, who won a host of readers and the Pulitzer Prize for 1932 with her best-selling novel, "The Good Earth," turned momentarily from fiction to fact yesterday after her arrival in New York from China.

HINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 3. -- The Detroit team of 22-meter boats, racing a team from the Hingham Yacht Club, had a lead of a point and three-quarters today at the conclusion of the third race. The Fraeth, Detroit, won the morning contest and finished second in the afternoon, while the Dodo II, Hingham, finished second in the morning and was the afternoon winner.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange erased Tuesday's losses yesterday and moved forward in heavy trading, which aggregated $11,667,000. Domestic corporation bonds led the advance, with many issues up 1 to 5 points for the day. United States Government bonds were irregularly lower in dull trading.

Text of Seabury's rebuttal to Walker's defense, pages 10,11,12. Characterizing Mayor Walker's plea that ten of the fifteen removal charges against him are "outlawed" as one that no person "is obliged to make if he is willing to meet issues on their merits," Samuel Seabury completed yesterday his rebuttal of Mr. Walker's recent defense, and forwarded it to Governor Roosevelt.

Details of how he forged records of study credits for backward students in the City College of the City of New York four years ago on which, he said, they obtained State Regents' certificates allowing them to take up professional studies were revealed yesterday by Jules Ross, 28 years old, a former student at the college, in a confession to Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney.
Cooperation in solving their present perplexing problems is being sought by realty interests in Long Island and Westchester.
Yesterday's downpour, which washed out the local major league baseball games, was received with varying reactions by the clubs concerned.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The Bourse showed a heavy tendency today. After a strong resistance in the early trading, quotations generally ended below yesterday's final prices. The reaction was expected, however, as the Bourse has been paralleling Wall Street's showing, which was decidedly poor yesterday, according to views here.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 3 (AP). -- The tangled and tragic love affairs of Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller, Australian flier, with Captain W.N. Lancaster, former British Army aviator, and Haden Clarke, young writer, were recounted in the witness chair by her today in Lancaster's trial for the murder of Clarke.

The sale in the city of so-called "Veterans' Association bonus relief buttons," for the ostensible purpose of raising funds to aid the members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, was ordered investigated by the police yesterday by Magistrate Dodge in West Side Court.

Despite predictions to the contrary, the directors of General Motors Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock due at this time. Although the announcement was not made until after the close of the stock market, information was current in Wall Street soon after midday to the effect that the regular rate would be ordered.

Substantial changes in the portfolio, particularly in the complete sale of railroad securities and the purchase of many new industrial blocks, is shown in the report of the Sterling Securities Corporation for the six months ended on June 30. This investment trust, a member of the Atlas Corporation group, reports a net asset value for convertible first preferred stock of $34.95 a share on June 30, against $42.99 on Dec. 31.

To the outlander the voice of the Kansas people in Tuesday's primaries has no siren sound. The prime Sunflower hero, lord of the air and shepherd of the goats, the great Milford medico, JOHN R. BRINKLEY, had no part in that battle of the booths.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Reinstating of recently sold-out lines of long wheat, which was credited by pit gossip to Eastern account, turned a weak market into a strong and advancing one today on the Chicago Board of Trade. At the high point the market had more than regained half of the 5-cent decline sustained in a five-day straight drop.

Average daily electric power production in the week ended July 30, adjusted for seasonal variation, was 213,800,000 kilowatt hours, as against 213,000,000 kilowatt hours in the week ended July 23, and 244,200,000 kilowatt hours in the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Walter W. Waters, national commander of the remnants of the Bonus Expeditionary Force, now concentrated at Johnstown, Pa., held a series of secret conferences today with representatives of a "prominent national organization" which Waters reported had offered to help work out plans for opening bonus camps in every State in the Union.

Economic issues may be most important in this Presidential campaign. But wherever, for any reason, prohibition figures in a contest, it seems to be absorbing most attintion. That was true of the two national conventions, where the only debate was over prohibition, though the clouds of the industrial depression lowered over the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- While the first printed proof of President Hoover's speech of acceptance lay upon his desk, two of his personal aides conferred at length today with Everett Sanders, chairman of the Republican National Committee, concerning arrangements for the notification ceremonies on Aug. 11.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Overcoming an advantage rolled up by his opponent, Charles M. Howell, in Kansas City, Colonel Bennett C. Clark, outspoken wet, tonight swept into an increasing lead for the Democratic nomination for Senator as belated returns from yesterday's Missouri primary were tabulated.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- The purchase of $1,024,000 long-term New York City bonds as an investment for State sinking funds was announced today by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. The bonds will yield from 5 1/4 to 5 3/4 per cent, having been bought from private sources at large discounts, the prices ranging from 80 to 87, according to Mr. Tremaine.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Pittsburgher returned to good racing form today by cantering home first in the Pine Gate Purse over one mile and a sixteenth. The 4-year-old son of In Memorian-Wistaria ran the distance over a slow track in 1:48 4-5 to beat Evergold by six lengths.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Conewago, the Stephens designed eight-meter defender of the Canada's cup, ran away from the challenging craft, Invader II, of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, today, to take a two-to-one lead in the series.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 3. -- All is quiet today along this resort's gambling front. Behind the lines, however, the operators of games of chance along the boardwalk, who put up their shutters last night in the face of threats by the local police and District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards, were preparing to start a legal offensive with the resumption of business as their objective.

The disappearance three weeks ago of Russell H. Lucas, former controller of the Fidelity Investment Association of 120 Broadway, was announced yesterday. The police, at the request of relatives, have been vainly seeking the missing man since July 18, four days after he disappeared.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Business was small on the London Exchange today. Because of the unfavorable news from Germany, Austria and Wall Street the early firmness was not maintained, most sections showing an easier tendency.

A suit to foreclose a balance of $492,500 due on a mortgage for $600,000 on the office building at 264-68 West Fortieth Street was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the New York Life Insurance Company against the Masro Realty Corporation, Samuel Friedenberg and others.

THREE good men and true: an Irishman, a Frenchman and a German. The Irishman is James Archibald McLarnin, the chap with the cherubic, countenance, the bland smile and the destructive right fist. James fights infrequently and the report is that soon he will abandon fighting altogether, like James Joseph Tunney, and go in for higher things. But he has an engagement at the Yankee Stadium this evening and, weather permitting, he will keep it.

Investigation of conditions in the cleaning and dyeing industry in Greater New York City in the last two weeks disclosed conclusive evidence of racketeering, John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, declared yesterday in a statement issued at his office, 80 Centre Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With regard to THE TIMES editorial "Many False Alarms," I would suggest that the reason for the increased number is the new fire-alarm boxes themselves. Before the new boxes were installed, in order to turn in a fire alarm, it was necessary to break a glass cover, open the door of the box and turn a handle.

With the opening of "The Man Who Reclaimed His Head," which he will present in association with Arthur Hammerstein at the Broadhurst Theatre on Sept. 8, L. Lawrence Weber will start upon an active production schedule.

HAMILTON, Ont., Aug. 3. -- Mrs. H. Pyne's veteran racer, Storm, at home in the sloppy going, defeated Mrs. George Fox's Happen by a neck in the featured contest on the closing card at the Hamilton track today. The Seagram Stable's Dark Mission finished third.

The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the twelve months ended on June 30 shows gross income of $23,821,214, against $46,953,106 in the preceding year, expenses of $6,315,230 against $10,092,760, and net income of $17,505,984, against $36,860,346 the year before.

The Grand Central Terminal echoed with the shouts and songs of 1,600 young men of the metropolitan area who returned in two sections of a special train at 6 o'clock last evening from the citizens' military training camp at Plattsburg, N.Y.

A collection of 150 letters of HENRY JAMES, not previously published, is included in a book by ELIZABETH ROBINS, just out in England. Miss ROBINS ties the letters together with some narrative, gives her own and others' opinions of the London theatre of the '90s and relates stories of the Ibsen discussions of the time.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- A large audience filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players presented their third production this season, "Six Is Company," a new play by Eleanor Chilton and Herbert Agar. The play was directed by Henry Codman Potter.

With a challenge from the Knickerbocker Yacht Club of Port Washington for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup, the Larchmont Yacht Club yesterday set Aug. 19, 20 and 21 as the dates for the races, which will be held on Long Island Sound off Larchmont.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 3. -- The ousting of the Bonus Army from Washington with Federal troops and "prosperity under the Republican regime" were scored, today at two meetings, one of the local chapter of the Disabled Veterans of the World War, and the other, a gathering of ex-service men after that organization had adjourned.
MANILA, Aug. 3. -- Repeal of the Philippine press gag law was voted down, 14 to 1, in a House committee today, presumably in a test ballot to determine the committee's sentiment.

Wall Street quickly regained its confidence yesterday after an hour of uncertainty the afternoon before. After a display of irregularity in the morning, the general list on the Stock Exchange turned strong simultaneously with an expansion of trading activity.

The recent tentative ruling of State insurance Commissioner George S. Van Schaick restricting the field covered by marine insurance, which with modifications may be made permanent, was discussed yesterday at a meeting in the State Building, attended by more than 100 executives representing casualty, fire and marine underwriters.

The Standard Oil Company of California reports for the quarter ended on June 30, net profit of $3,986,302 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, Federal taxes and inventory revaluation, equal to 30 cents a share on the 13,102,900 shares of no-par capital stock.

Edward N. Lee of the New York A.C. set a new Richmond County A.A.U. mark in the one-half mile free-style invitation event, feature of the swimming meet conducted by the Richmond County A.A.U. at the Midland Beach pool, Staten Island, last night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The annual garden party of Emmanuel Church was held this afternoon at Harbour Court, the home of Mrs. Nicholas Brown. Mrs. Brown was in charge of the flower table. Assisting her were Mrs. Harold Brown and Mrs. William B. Bristow.

WILLAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 3. -- Specific methods of bringing about disarmament occupied the attention of the Institute of Politics today. The proposals took a wide range, from that of the United States joining the League of Nations or becoming an associate member on special occasions
Samuel Seabury's replies to the chief contentions of Mayor Walker's recent defense against removal were expressed in the following manner yesterday in Mr. Seabury's rebuttal:

General Mario Garcia Menocal, former President of the republic of Cuba, arrived unexpectedly yesterday on the French liner Lafayette, and heightened the mystery of his arrival by declining to say what his plans might be and where he would stay while in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A committee of the Radio Commission, composed of Commissioner Thad H. Brown, Dr. C.B. Jolliffee, chief engineer, and James J. Baldwin, secretary, tomorrow will inspect the New York City office of the commission, formerly the office of the radio division of the Department of Commerce, which has just been merged with the commission.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Reduction of Germany's private debts, which run to nearly $300,000,000 a year, may be sought in private negotiations, but apparently the government does not intend to raise this question at the projected world economic conference in which the United States will participate.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The State Department of Banking and Insurance shows in its semi-annual report that in the six months ended on June 30 there was a decrease of $35,000,000 in withdrawals of bank deposits, compared with the preceding six months, and a marked reduction in the number of bank closings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not safe to assume that because Governor Roosevelt had the astounding plurality of nearly 725,000 in 1930 the Democrats will have a walk-over in the coming election in this State, either for the national or the State ticket.

Six of the seven firemen who were killed Monday, when two explosions wrecked the subcellar of the Ritz Tower Hotel, will be buried today after joint funeral services -- the first in the memory of Fire Department officials -- are held at 10 o'clock this morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The National City Bank, after refraining for several years from issuing its own currency against United States Government bonds carrying the circulation privilege, has decided to resume this practice under the new Federal Home Loan Bank act.

One of the greatest obstacles to the return of better times is the "tremendous burden of taxation now being carried by the people of this country," James W. Wadsworth, former United States. Senator, declared last night in a radio talk over a National Broadcasting Company network.

BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Boersen Zeitung, ultra-Rightist newspaper, said today that the government was considering a new emergency decree, this time directed chiefly against the National Socialists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Ted Lyons, distinguished veteran member of the White Sox pitching staff, was in rare form for the Yankees' series opener today, holding the McCarthymen to six hits while Chicago overcame Charlie Ruffing's stubborn resistance to win in the tenth inning, 3 to 2.

ADOLF HITLER must have spent considerable time yesterday plucking the petals of General VON SCHLEICHER'S interview trying to decide whether the Minister of Defense loves him or loves him not. When the General refers to the Hitler movement as something that must be used because "it is fired with faith," the impression is that HITLER is greatly loved.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- An attempt of more than 100 unemployed men and women to hold a mass meeting here tonight in defiance of the refusal of Police Chief William Miller to permit a public demonstration in the city streets was broken up by fifty policemen after an exchange of blows that lodged two unemployed men in the hospital.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3. -- The avalanche of record-breaking performances in the tenth Olympiad has caused widespread comment here as the reason for so unprecedented an eclipse of the figures in the books.

ROME, Aug. 3. -- War is exalted by Premier Mussolini as giving "the seal of nobility to peoples" in his concluding exposition of Fascism for the Encyclopaedia Italiana, which was published today in his old newspaper, Il Popolo d'Italia. Perpetual peace, the Premier says, is impossible.

M.S. Szymczak, Controller of Chicago, who has been conferring with New York bankers this week regarding the sale of Chicago tax-anticipation, warrants, issued a formal statement yesterday before his departure for Albany, outlining the city's financial condition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today made available at the request of Governor White of Ohio $852,662 for furnishing relief and work relief in Lorain, Mahoning, Stark and Summit Counties. The loan is to be repaid with interest at the rate of 3 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3. -- The Waterbury camp, the site for which in Anne Arundel County was given last Sunday to the Bonus Expeditionary Force by Mrs. Maude Edgell, was abandoned today in accordance with Governor Albert Kitchie's orders. Within two hours after State police had ordered them to leave, some forty campers, including several women, were on their way out of Maryland in a State truck and dilapidated automobiles.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Detroit made it seven victories out of twelve games against Washington this season by beating the Senators, 2 to 1, in a series opener today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Two sculptured marble heads of Roman workmanship have been unearthed near Corinth, Greece, by the archaeological expedition of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens. Announcement of the finds, which were made last June, was made here today for the first time, by Professor Edward Capps of Princeton University, chairman of the managing committee of the Athens school.

Breaking away from the mildly reactionary influences which had brought about Tuesday's moderate decline, the stock market advanced yesterday with more energy than it has displayed at any stage of the current upswing. The rise was the widest since February, the net gains in individual market leaders running from 1 to 7 points.
BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Boerse continued quiet today. Prices declined little, 2 per cent at the most.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Seven or eight thousand years ago in what geologists call modern times a race of negroid cannibals lived in Palestine, burned the bones of their dead after burial and devoured the bodies of their enemies.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Grafton Smith of Hamilton, Mass., who is now at the Waldorf-Astoria, will give a dinner tonight at the Central Park Casino for Miss Anita Shields of Philadelphia, Pa., whose marriage to Alastair MacLean of Argyleshire, Scotland, will take place Saturday at the home of Miss Shields's sister, Mrs. Robert Livingston Clarkson, Oyster Bay, L.I.
S.S. LEVIATHAN, Aug. 3. -- After six months of arduous but productive labor the general disarmament conference has finished the first stage of its work and adjourned for a short period.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- A series of disturbing incidents has occurred in East Prussia, where the Hitlerite storm detachments seem to have got out of hand and are indulging in reprisals against individuals who have incurred their dislike.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Francis (Rusty) Nash confessed tonight, police announced, that he was the slayer of 17-year-old Evelyn Sanford, whose body was found today buried in the basement of an unoccupied house in Freesoil.

Considering the hesistant character of the share market in the early dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the recovery in the afternoon furnished an impressive contrast. The advance was, in many respects, the most vigorous of the entire movement extending ever the last four weeks, whether measured by the net results or the velocity of the upswing in the last two or three hours of trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Port of New York Authority applied today for a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan of $75,600,000 to build the proposed Thirty-eighth Street vehicular tunnel to New Jersey.

Sentiment in the steel industry remains cheerful in the face of a further decline in pig iron production, a slight drop in steel ingot output and a recession in the price of heavy melting steel scrap at Pittsburgh, according to the "weekly review of The Iron Age.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The will of Forrest F. Dryden of Bernardsville, former president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, and son of John F. Dryden, its founder, was filed with the Secretary of State here today, after being probated in Prerogative Court.

Ralph Richards, a nimble-witted criminal who escaped with three other men from the Eastview Penitentiary, Westchester's model prison, on July 16, was mortally wounded and taken prisoner with two companions last night at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-second Street a few minutes after the three had committed a $12 hold-up.

A new issue of $5,500,000 Southern Indiana Gas and Electric Company first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds, series due in 1957, will be offered publicly today by Drexel Co. and Bonbright Co., Inc. The price will be 93 1/2, to yield more than 6 per cent.

The Swedish firm of Kreuggr Toll, which was the keystone of the late Ivar Kreuger's $1,000,000,000 organization and which is in bankruptcy in Sweden, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack to be represented here before him on or before Aug. 25 to answer an American bankruptcy petition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Senator Moses accused Governor Roosevelt today of proposing to reduce tariffs sufficiently for the European debtors to make a large enough profit to pay the United States about $300,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway Company will receive its fifth loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation under an authorization by the Interstate Commerce Commission today approving a three-year loan of $753,500.
S.S. LEVIATHAN, Aug. 3. -- The situation is much improved for the accomplishment of something substantial at the second session of the disarmament conference, which will possibly convene in January.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 3. -- The Bonus Expeditionary Force began to disintegrate late tonight a few hours after their national commander. Walter W. Waters, ordered them to go home and Mayor Eddie McCloskey, their genial host, told them they were no longer welcome in Johnstown.

Members of the Far East Steamship Conference said yesterday that the statement of M. Ascher, president of the New York Freight Forwarders and Brokers' Association Inc., on Saturday, to the effect that the conference had issued rulings inimical to American trade, was "misleading" and that the conference had not yet adopted any definite schedule.
ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- In accord with a program of seeking to harmonize all elements in the Democratic party, Governor Roosevelt expects to have John J. Raskob as a luncheon guest here tomorrow.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Three hundred volunteers, anxious to set service against Bolivia in the Gran Chaco, almost swamped the first transport carrying troops to the scene of the conflict when the ship started up the Paraguay River today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The reaction of citizens in many communities throughout Nassau County to the indictment of thirteen county policemen following the death of Hyman Stark, New York gangster, was expressed here tonight with the formation of a central committee to lay plans for the defense of the men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial beginning, "In an economic sense Cuba has her back to the wall," and the article therein cited, "Cuba's Economic Isolation," by William L. Schurz, in the August Current History, are among the most candid statements of Cuba's problems that I have seen in recent years.

Plans for the city and State campaigns were discussed yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, in conferences he had with city and up-State leaders. The principal up-State leader to visit Mr. Macy's office at 100 East Forty-second Street was State Senator George R. Fearon, majority leader in the Senate, and frequently mentioned as a possible candidate for Governor.
HARBIN, Manchuria, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Twenty-one days of uninterrupted rains have converted North Central Manchuria into a vast lake and brought about a national disaster.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3. -- Robert Pearce of Cushing, Okla., won the Olympic bantamweight championship and Herman Pihlajamaki, Finland, law student, captured the featherweight crown in the finals of the catch-as-catch can wrestling matches tonight.

"Oh, my dear boy, a play is always a gamble," said a matron languidly but wisely last night on the stage of the Bijou Theatre. She was speaking one of the lines assigned her in "Page Pygmalion," which had the temerity to ruffle the calm of the midsummer theatre by opening there, and she was giving voice to what everybody knows is a self-evident truth.

The World War was less an isolated episode than the opening phase of a universal convulsion like the Thirty Years' War or the French Revolution. Frank H. Simonds asserts in a new edition of "Can Europe Keep the Peace?" just published by Harper Brothers.

An appeal for active cooperation and financial aid in carrying out a "gigantic" new schedule of activities preparatory to an extensive campaign for prohibition this Fall was issued yesterday from the office of the Allied Forces from the headquarters of that organization, 419 Fourth Avenue.

One of the favorite themes of Congressmen discovering conspiracies is the alleged abuse of tax refunds. The Treasury has been accused of defeating the purposes of Congress by authorizing large repayments, of playing favorites in the exercise of its discretionary powers, of making large concessions to rich corporations in return for contributions to campaign funds.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 3. -- A Forsyth County jury today began an investigation into the death of Z. Smith Reynolds, 20, who was fatally shot on the morning of July 6 at his home near Winston-Salem. Sheriff J. Transou Scott, who has been investigating the shooting since it was first reported to authorities, testified for more than two hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Little use has been made of the authority granted in the home loan bank bill for the issuance of national bank currency against which has been pledged with the Treasurer of the United States 3 per cent, 3 1/2 per cent and 3 3/8 per cent government bonds, it was reported at the Treasury Department today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 3. -- The long-delayed list of Canada's demands from and offers to Great Britain on which the success of the Imperial Economic Conference almost entirely depends is ready.

Dairy Industry Realty Corporation of New York, Kenneth Gebbie, vice president, sold to the Hoboken Land and Improvement Company the two-story concrete factory building on a plot 200 by 100 feet, comprising the entire Monmouth Street frontage extending from Fourteenth to Fifteenth Street, Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- A refunding issue of Treasury bills of $75,000,000, to be dated Aug. 10, maturing on Nov. 9, was announced today by Secretary Mills.

Evidence of a fight in the Twenty-second Assembly District against the leadership of James J. McCormick, Deputy City Clerk, and veteran Tammany official, who testified before the Hofstadter committee that his income in tips for performing civil marriages averaged $16,000 a year, appeared in Washington Heights yesterday with announcement of the organization of a new Democratic club.

TOKYO, Aug. 3. -- Alarm over new outbreaks by insurgents prevails in the cities and towns along the entire main line of the South Manchuria Railway, all stations being guarded and curfew regulations enforced, according to dispatches to newspapers here.

Wholesale markets were buoyant yesterday, sharp price advances being registered in every section. The grains, cotton, rubber, silk, hides, dairy products, coffee and other staples showed substantial gain. Coffee was easy, sugar steady.
The complete text of Samuel Seabury's reply to Mayor James J. Walker's answer to the charges filed against him follows:

Thomas Patrick Morris's claim to the $30,000,000 estate of Miss Ella von E. Wendel was called a "scheme" yesterday by Charles G. Koss, one of the executors, as John M. Harlan, his trial counsel, continued to pile before Surrogate James A. Foley evidence to show that Morris's story of meetings with his purported father, John Gottlieb Wendel could not have taken place as described.
After a slight decline in early trading yesterday prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered a dollar a bale and ended 9 to 11 points higher than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Although condemning the manner in which it said stock was obtained, the Interstate Commerce Commission today discontinued its investigation into purchases of stock of the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway and of stock of the St. Louis-San Francisco by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway.

Charges by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens that Controller Berry had "failed to advance title acquisition proceedings" in Queens and thus had "delayed $2,000,000 worth of public improvements" were characterized yesterday by Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial as "absolutely untrue."

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 4. -- Widespread Chinese attacks in the last two days in the most densely settled portion of Manchuria are the most serious challenge to Japanese control of that province since the Nonni River battles in November.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Aug. 5. -- The situation in Manchuria and North China grew more grave today as the Japanese concentrated more troops at Chinchow, whence they are in a position to strike either at Jehol Province or North China, and the renewed widespread attacks on South Manchurian cities by irregulars continued unabated.
Several apartment houses were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday. There were two resales of properties recently in foreclosure.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- George Earnshaw outpitched Walter Stewart today to win his sixteenth victory of the year as the Athletics defeated the Browns, 6 to 2. Both hurlers were wild, however, Earnshaw passing seven and Stewart six. The game, which opened the series, was featured by seven double plays.
DETROIT, Aug. 4. -- Roy D. Chapin intends to sell his optimism to America in his new position as Secretary of Commerce.

A partly completed national survey, made during the last two months by the American Society of Civil Engineers, shows that hundred of projects for State and municipal public works in the fortyeight States, amounting to a total of more than $2,250,000,000, have been suspended because of lack of funds or the difficulty of marketing securities at reasonable interest.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 4. -- A Forsyth County grand jury this afternoon returned true bills charging that Z. Smith Reynolds, 20-year-old heir to the $15,000,000 R.J. Reynolds tobacco fortune, was murdered by Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, the former Broadway "blues" singer, his wife and Albert (Ab) Walker, 20, his boyhood friend and secretary.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production in the week ended July 30 shows a sharp rise over the index for the preceding week, standing at 67.9, as against 56.7 for the preceding week. The index for the corresponding week of 1931 was 94.7.

Butter. Receipts, 14,902 packages. The position was very well sustained yesterday morning at Wednesday's advance with most of the support coming from statistical and speculative st'.ength of sentiment rather than from active open market buying. The commodity and securities markets in general are still showing advances and added strength has developed in the butter market as a whole on the basis of the favorable statistical position and the general optimism.

For the rapid upward sweep of stocks in yesterday's earlier hours, under the largest transactions of this year, there were two evident explanations. With some recent developments kept in mind, especially the abrupt turn of the international gold movement in this country's favor, prolongation of the rise meant restored financial confidence.
He that is first in his own cause seemeth just; but his neighbor cometh and searcheth him. -- Proverbs xviii, 17.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- British Air Force pilots were valued at $10,000, the cost of their training, and infantrymen at $250 by an attorney in pressing claims today before a United States commission based on the invention by Lieut. Col. Henry Newton, a Briton, of his six-inch trench mortar bomb and fuse.

"It's smart to be poor" might be a good slogan for these times. So many have been forced to economize that to be canny is almost to be fashionable. Experts in shrewd buying boast of their skill. One young business woman remarked: I have several friends who simply haven't been touched by the depression, and I feel rather sorry for them.

Public utility and industrial issues led the advance in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with railroad bonds, although heavily traded, showing a smaller percentage of gains for the day. In the foreign group, German loans were strong. United States Government bonds were lightly traded and finished with minor irregularities.

The practice of spreading work by the establishment of the five-day week and shorter working hours is becoming more and more prevalent among American, business and industrial concerns, it is revealed through answers to a questionnaire to 1,718 businesss executives in various sections of the country by the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc.

Proposals that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation advance the $26,000,000 necessary for completion of the triborough bridge, as well as funds to initiate the model housing program for Manhattan and Brooklyn formulated by the State Board of Housing, have been laid before the R.F.C., it was learned yesterday on the arrival of Senator Robert F. Wagner in New York.
Leasehold deals constituted the bulk of the realty activity in Manhattan reported yesterday. Several leases were given back to the property owners by the lessees.

HINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 4. -- The Detroit team of 22-meter boats triumphed over the Hingham team by finishing in first and second places this afternoon in the fourth and final race of the series in spite of having been disqualified in the morning contest.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- A lake dwelling dating from the ninth century B.C. as been found in a bog in Ireland by two young Harvard scientists, Hugh O'Neill Hencken and H.L. Movius, who have been excavating for the National Museum of Dublin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Bill Dickey returned to the Yankee line-up after a month's absence today and made his presence felt by hitting a homer and three singles in the course of the 15-to-3 triumph by which the McCarthymen evened the count with the White Sox in the current series.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Rallying late in the third set, Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York, 1931 Wimbledon champion, today defeated diminutive Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta to avert a surprise that would have surpassed in magnitude the upset registered by David N. Jones of Brooklyn over Berkeley Bell of New York as the singles play in the Meadow Club's forty-second annual invitation tennis tourney reached the semi-finals.

Reports from 167 Class I railroads to the Bureau of Railway Economics showed that their combined net operating income in June was $12,653,000, against $50,618,000 in June, 1931, a drop of 75 per cent. Their decline in net operating income for May was 71.3 per cent, which compared with a drop of 48 per cent in April and one of 30.5 per cent in March.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Newark and Toronto divided a double-header today before 6,000, the Leafs taking the opener, 6-4, with a late drive and the Bears scoring in the nightcap, 3-0. Don Brennan recorded his fourteenth triumph and limited the Leafs to two hits.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Contending that such devices as the "penny heart" games on the boardwalk here are games of skill and not games of chance, former City Judge Morris Vogel, counsel for some of the 100 concessionaires who voluntarily stopped their operations two nights ago, started proceedings today looking toward an injunction permanently restraining Mayor Frank Frankel, the local police and the District Attorney's office from interfering with them.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 4 (AP). -- On a swelling tide of votes from Shelby County in which Memphis lies, Hill McAlister, State Treasurer, rode into the lead late tonight in unofficial returns from today's Democratic Gubernatorial primary.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, headed by Harvey D. Gibson, announced yesterday that it had appropriated $361,000 from its funds to provide work for the unemployed during August. Of this sum, the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau will use $346,000 for wages of men and women on emergency work projects and the remaining $15,000 will go toward direct relief of the needy in Harlem.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Cabinet approved today the text of the Hindu-Moslem settlement, which will be published soon and which is described as so fair that it will satisfy nobody.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 4. -- American bankers and their "highpowered" bond salesmen, who disposed of billions of dollars in Latin-American bonds to the public, were sharply criticized at the Institute of Politics today, but they found defenders who blamed "the greed of the public" for higher returns as the cause of the issuance of the securities ] now in default.

Joseph T. Yates, superintendent of the Third District of the United States Lighthouse Service, announced yesterday that plans for changing lights and signals in New York Harbor and the Hudson River had been approved in Washington and that workmen in the service would begin on the changes immediately.

Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia and Norman H. Davis, former Undersecretary of State, who have been attending the disarmament conference as members of the American delegation, will return today on the United States liner Leviathan with other delegates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The grand jury investigation of the B.E.F. evacuation disorders neared a close today with, the appearance of District Commissioners Luther C. Reichelderfer and Herbert B. Crosby.

The Giants and the Cardinals running neck and neck for a position which neither club expected some four months ago it would have to occupy, crossed paths at the Polo Grounds and immediately set about drawing the lines a trifle tighter.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Man Is called upon, to fight his greatest battles in times of peace. Brig. Gen. Howard L. Laubach, commander of Camp Dix, said in an address today to more than 1,300 newly enrolled members of the Citizens' Military Training Camps on the parade grounds here.

ELLEN BROWNING SCRIPPS was born in London a few months before Queen Victoria came to the throne. But though a mid-Victorian in the middle years of her life, she became the most modern of women through her early American transplanting: an equal suffragist, a temperance reformer, a practical protagonist of free speech, a keen sharer in business enterprises and a generous nourisher of the sciences.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- In its first adverse decision on appeals by States for unemployment relief aid, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today declined to lend money at this time to Pennsylvania.

Continental Shares, Inc., the holding company-investment trust once dominated by Cyrus Eaton and his associates in Cleveland, has given up its right to have its shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange by discontinuing its registrar in New York.

Plans for the first section of the underground passageways, trucking tunnels and the sunken plaza in the middle block of Rockefeller Center were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings.

Governor Roosevelt, who is carrying forward his study of the rebuttal filed Wednesday by Samuel Seabury, has determined upon speedy action on the removal charges against Mayor Walker, it was reported in informed quarters here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4. -- Canada told the British delegates to the Imperial Economic Conference today what special tariff preferences or free list entry she was willing to grant on manufactured articles imported from Great Britain and what she demanded in return in the way of preferences in the British market for primary products exported from the Dominion.

The storm and rain of Wednesday somewhat shattered an exceptionally fine stretch, of offshore fishing, but the weekly round-up, nevertheless, is replete with encouraging news for the salt-water angler.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4. -- Italy, Japan, Finland and the United States shared the spoils of Olympic competition in the fifth session of the track and field program today as two more world's and two Olympic standards were added to the landslide of falling records before a crowd of 65,000 in the Stadium.

Reminders of our coming blessings, the speakers' bureaus of the major political parties, are in the act of organization. Except the national candidates and a few speakers of the first distinction whom people may be curious to see, why should there be much physical circulation of orators?

Boston, Mass. The city of Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would be in the market next Monday with an additional issue of $2,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes, dated Aug. 9 and due on Oct. 4. The city is authorized to borrow up to $35,000,000 against future tax collections, and has already borrowed less than $30,000,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Damage estimated at 56,000,000 was caused this evening by a spectacular fire near Twenty-second and Sangamon Streets, which destroyed the Quincy Grain Elevator and most of the plant of the Omaha Packing Company. Half the city's fire apparatus was concentrated at the scene.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The Trillora Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N.J., scored handsomely with its hunters and jumpers during the first two sessions of the annual Monmouth County Horse Show, which opened this morning on the grounds of the Rumson Country Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The happiness and thrill of gay and soothing music for the sick and weary! What do these words mean to you? Can you imagine what they mean to our hot, crippled, restless, blind, unfortunate friends in the great hospitals?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Tariff walls bricked up higher and other trade-control measures made stricter -- thus have many nations tightened already tight markets in 1932.

The Government of the United States, for what in said to be the first time in the history of Federal Court in this district, yesterday took advantage of a provision of the law, which, in the opinion of legal experts, permits a Federal judge to impose as many sentences on a recalcitrant witness as are required to make him tails before a grand jury.

To, the Editor of The New York Times: Representative Black in his letter to THE TIMES again calls attention to the chilling attitude of President Hoover toward Governor Roosevelt with respect to the matter of negotiating the St. Lawrence Canal treaty.

SEAGIRT, N.J., Aug. 4. -- A delegation of about 3,000 Democratic men and women from nine New Jersey counties gathered today at the Little White House, the Summer home of Governor A. Harry Moore here, to celebrate the season's second Governor's Day celebration.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- John J. Raskob and Vincent Astor, two outstanding representatives of "big business" in the Democratic party, told Governor Roosevelt today that they would aid him in his fight for the Presidency.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4. -- Clare Brett, 4-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Brett of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, is expected to have normal sight again as a result of an operation so delicate that it is said to have been performed only once before with success.

Among the observations of Winston Churchill, British statesman, on journeys through this country in 1929 and this year, as recounted in an article in Collier's Weekly today, was "a new and surprising fact" that the United States, although theoretically dry, has become an exporter of liquor.

MADRID, Aug. 4. -- Former King Alfonso took 8,000,000 pesetas, or about $700,000, in cash out of Spain with him on the hasty midnight ride when he left the country with a revolution behind him. This became known today with the arrest of a Portuguese, Carlos Almeda, head of a gang running money out of the country in the face of exchange restrictions.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Making his weekly radio address on plans for economy in State administration, Governor Roosevelt detailed tonight his reasons for seeking suggestions from the public on cuts in the next budget.

With an enormous investment demand converging upon preferred stocks, prices rose sharply again on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in the most active market that has been witnessed since last December. The total turnover was 3,522,000 shares, as compared with 2,400,000 shares on the day before.

Holders of 5 per cent serial gold notes of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, due on Aug. 15, have been notified that there still remain outstanding $747,000 principal amount due on that date whose holders have not accepted a previous exchange offer, under which they could receive Northern Pennsylvania Power Company first and refunding mortgage gold bonds.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. George Arents gave a luncheon, followed by bridge, today at Meadow Beach, her-residence on the ocean, for Mrs. Edwin S. Cramp, who is passing the week with her.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4. -- Miss Ellen Preiss of Austria became the individual women's foils champion of the Olympic Games tonight by defeating England's entrant, Miss Heather Guinness, by 1 point after they had fenced off a tie. Each had won eight matches and lost one.

An application by Vladimir Heifetz, cousin of Jascha Heifetz, for an injunction against Isa Kremer, folksong singer, and the London music publishing firm of Chappell Co., Ltd., to restrain them from publishing a volume of songs called "The Album of Jewish Folksongs," was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Shientag, who directed an early trial of the suit.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- His candidacy for the Governorship was announced today by Lieutenant Governor Herbert H. Lehman, and immediately afterward a warm endorsement came from Governor Roosevelt, who predicted victory for his associate in the contest for the Democratic nomination and later at the polls.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- Official warning was given tonight that unless political disorders entirely ceased within eighteen hours, the German Government would issue a Presidential decree providing more drastic penalties for cases of armed assault and the possession of illegal weapons than the law now permits and special emergency courts would be instituted to deal with such offenses.

The Swedish company of Kreuger Toll, through which the late Ivar Kreuger held his $1,000,000,000 structure of industries, banks and holding companies throughout the world, was adjudged bankrupt in America yesterday and the formal order will be signed today.

A settlement of a dispute between the heirs of C. Albert Stevens, member of the Stevens Point, Hoboken, family, and the estate of his widow, who later became Mrs. May Brady Harriman, was set forth in a suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against Mrs. Carolina E. Wittpenn of Bernardsville, N.J., sister of Mr. Stevens and widow of H. Otto Wittpenn, once Mayor of Newark.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Playing in his first State amateur tournament since 1929, when he won the title, Maurice J. McCarthy Jr., young metropolitan area star, matched par almost stroke for stroke today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the ninth renewal of the events.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Gar Wood will have more than just Kay Don to battle aganst when they meet in Detroit in September in competition for the world's water speed record.

Mayor Walker will officiate tomorrow afternoon at the opening of the $530,000 bathing pavilion at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways, according to an announcement yesterday by Park Commissioner Benninger of Queens. The Mayor will be introduced by Mr. Benninger and after his address the Police Department Band will give a concert on the open-air terrace of the pavilion.

Five hundred and eighty golfers, only three fewer than a year ago, have entered for the sectional elimination rounds of the national amateur championship which is to be held at the Baltimore Country Club during the week of Sept. 12.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The Canada's Cup, premier international yachting challenge trophy for fresh water, was successfully defended today by the Rochester Yacht Club's eight-meter sloop Conewago, which won the fourth and deciding match of the series from the challenger, Invader II, of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto.

Tammany Hall was the largest single American contributor to the Cuban revolutionary junta in America, organizer of the revolution against Spain, which culminated in the Spanish-American War, the American occupation of Cuba and the establishment of the Republic of Cuba, Horatio S. Rubens, only surviving member of the junta, reveals in his book "Liberty," an account of Cuba's struggle for independence, published today by Brewer, Warren Putnam.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- The first definite step toward negotiating a new Franco-American trade treaty was taken today when Walter E. Edge, United States Ambassador, delivered a thirty-page memorandum to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs setting forth the requirements of American commerce and proposals of the United States Government for reciprocal concessions to France's exports.

Gandhi and Albert Schweitzer are the leaders of a new ethical attitude on the part of mankind, a return to the old philosophy of "reverence," Professor H. Richard Niebuhr of the Yale Divinity School declared yesterday in an address to Columbia University Summer session students at the Horace Mann Auditorium, Teachers College.

Quiet strength pervaded all sections of the wholesale markets yesterday. All staples started the day in a carry-over of the upward price movement of Wednesday, but later realizing sales canceled a good part of the improvement. Grains were steady at the close, cotton was slightly lower; provisions, sugar, coffee, rubber, hides and silk were higher. Metals as a group were strong.

Passenger traffic on the city's nine ferry lines for the first half of this year fell 2,319,604 below similar traffic for the first six months of 1931, while vehicular traffic fell 240,439 and ferry revenues dropped $210,015.78 for the first half of 1932 as compared to the same period of 1931, according to figures made public yesterday by Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

Reflecting the great extent to which the volume of trading has been swollen by public participation in the last few days and the consequent increase in brokerage commissions, the price of memberships on the leading exchanges scored the widest advances of the year yesterday.

No Radical Changes at Openings. The current Parisian openings have been devoid of any outstanding development that will cause a radical revision of the early Fall styles in better dresses, it was reported yesterday by Morris Kallman, executive director of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP). -- A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. David Selznick today. Mrs. Selznick is the former Irene Mayer, daughter of Louis B. Mayer, head of the Metro-Goldwin-Mayer motion picture studios. The Selznicks have another child, a daughter born last Fall.

Intercession between Bolivia and Paraguay two years ago was an offer of good offices coupled with an appeal to reason. The settlement then brought about has not stood the test of time. Today the nineteen nations of the Pan American Union reinforce their appeal for peace in the Chaco region with a hint of serious consequences.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Aug. 4. -- Roger Q. Williams, accompanied by Mrs. Elvy Kalep Miller, who is to accompany him on his projected flight to Greece, arrived unexpectedly at Captain Harry M. Jones's hangar here tonight.

As a part of a rounded program designed to hasten the economic recovery, a powerful pool is being organized to strengthen prices of agricultural staples. The project is a private banking enterprise thus far, but it has the active encouragement, if not the sponsorship, of the administration in Washington.

Powerful anti-aircraft searchlights stationed in Bryant Park will sweep the city skies next Monday night and every night thereafter up to Aug. 27 as part of an exhibition of modern military equipment to be staged in connection with the New York City George Washington Bicentennial celebration.
New York brewers are demonstrating their faith in the legalizing of real beer for the American public by importing hundreds of new barrels made in Germany and shipped from Hamburg and Bremen.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 4. -- Racing fully up to expectations and clearly demonstrating his superiority in every heat, Ankabar, 2:01 1/2, owned by H.J. Schmoeger of Peoria, Ill., and driven, by Hug Parshall, romped off with the $10,000 Marshall House Stake trot, the feature race of the third day of Grand Circuit racing, this afternoon.

Alfred H. Maurer, internationally known artist, committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself from a door-casing on the third floor of his home at 404 West Forty-third Street. His body was discovered more than an hour later by members of the household.
Jimmy McLarnin, Vancouver welterweight, was knocked cleanly off his perch as foremost challenger for the world's welterweight title last night by a persevering southpaw.

George E. Roberts, vice president of the National City Bank and a delegate to the gold conference of the League of Nations, upheld the negative position in a radio debate last night over Station WOR on the question "Shall We Split the Gold Content of the Dollar?" A.C. Peters, director of the World Trade League of the United States, Inc., defended the affirmative.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The law moved rapidly today and sent Francis Nash, confessed killer of 17-year-old Evelyn Sanford, on his way to a life term in prison twenty-four hours after the girl's body was found buried in the cellar of a vacant house.

Three factors entered into the victory of BENNETT C. CLARK over the Missouri Democratic organization in the contest for the Senatorial nomination. The lesser were personal ability and the good fortune of being the son of the late Speaker. But it was his forthright stand against national prohibition which attracted Democratic voters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The invitation of the Spanish Government for American participation in the fourth International Radio Telegraph Conference at Madrid, opening Sept. 3, has been accepted by the State Department. President Hoover today appointed delegates and their technical and advisory staff.

A complete reorganization of the personnel and methods of the city's Sanitation Department, and stricter enforcement of ordinances against street litter are urged by Nathan Straws Jr., chairman of the antilitter committee of the Twenty-third Street Association, in recommendations he has submitted to the association along with an endorsement of the campaign of the Harlem Board of Commerce for cleaner streets.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- There was more activity in the stock markets today, and the tendency was firm everywhere, due to favorable American news. Business was better in British Government funds, with no further selling pressure, yesterday's intervention by the government changing sentiment.

Mayor Walker's plea that the city employes voluntarily yield a month's salary to the city in 1933 has been rejected by the city's Fire Department. The firemen voted against the proposition in a ratio of twenty to one, and if the city wants the month's pay it will have to go to Albany for the authority to get it.

New Yorkers in the bonus army in Johnstown were informed yesterday, in a telegram from Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, that, the same relief being given by the city to the homeless and hungry here will be given to the members of the bonus army who can prove one year's residence in the city, when and if they return.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- Lucien Lelong abandons the bulky sleeves and shoulders in favor of youthful silhouette frocks with long slim sleeves and skirt fullness, often accentuated at the side or centre front.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Mary Roberts Rinehart, author and playwright, described as "critical" today the condition of her husband, Dr. Stanley M. Rinehart, who was brought to a hospital here Saturday after collapsing at a Summer camp at Little Moose Lake.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- The market's trend was sharply higher during an active session of the Bourse today. Wall Street's rise yesterday inspired a wave of optimism and renewed confidence. Although the Bourse failed to advance quite as far as the New York Stock Exchange, such international stocks as Rio Tinto and Royal Dutch made gains almost in proportion to their rise in New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I just enjoyed the privilege of being invited to join the discussion on disarmament, held under the auspices of the Williamstown conference, and find in my mail THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 24 containing R. Fulton Cutting's interesting article on "Disarmament and Railroad Control."

Patrolman Rowan Kelly of the West Forty-seventh Street police station was congratulated at the line-up in Police Headquarters yesterday for the arrest of Anthony Scalise and George Gregory and for shooting Ralph Richards, who led a jail break at Eastview Penitentiary on July 16, in a chase after a holdup Wednesday night at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

Thousands of persons from Staten Island to the Bronx, from obscure residents of the lower east side to men high in the city's official life, with almost 2,000 firemen from a parts of the city, paid homage yesterday to six of the firemen killed in the explosion and blaze at the Ritz Tower Hotel at requiem services in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Downtown Gallery at 113 West Thirteenth Street has been trying since Summer began to close for the vacation season, but business has proved too brisk. Mrs. Halpert, the proprietor, has just installed a new show which is scheduled to remain until Oct. 1, when the opening Autumn exhibition will be announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit during the week ended Aug. 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,416,000,000, a decrease of $18,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,445,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Playing for the first time under the leadership of Charley Grimm, the Chicago Cubs crushed the Phillies, 12 to 1, with two big innings in the series opener today.

H.H. Raymond, president of the Colombian Steamship Company, will leave today for Newport News, Va., to attend the launching tomorrow of the new liner Colombia, the first of two ships being built for the Colombian trade by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 4. -- The convention for the amelioration of the condition of the wounded and sick of armies in the field and the convention relating to the treatment of prisoners of war were proclaimed by President Hoover today and became effective for the United States.

The Manufacturers' National Committee on Government, composed of shipbuilders, railroad men, founders and representatives of other lines of industry, was organized here yesterday for the purpose of offsetting "the government's continual encroachment on the domain of private business."

TUCKER PRISON FARM, Ark., Aug. 4. -- Four convicts were killed and three wounded today in a break from the stockade at Camp No. 2 and in a gun battle between the fugitives and officers in a field. One hundred and five prisoners refused to take part in the break.

With 11,000,000 already unemployed, hundieds of factories are making even more use of labor-saving devices and power to reduce their payroll, according to Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, who made that assertion at the formal opening of Wonder Honse, a modernized reproduction of a Norman cottage in the auditorium of John Wanamaker's yesterday afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- Two hundred unemployed persons marched on City Hall today and were dispersed by police reserves. One man was arrested.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Playing the best tennis she has shown in this country since her arrival two weeks ago from England, Miss Joan Ridley today fought her way through the quarter-finals in the Maidstone Club invitation tournament by defeating Miss Sarah Palfrey of Brookline, Mass., 0 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Kid Chocolate, the Negro flash from Havana, successfully defended his junior lightweight championship in the Chicago Stadium tonight, defeating Eddie Shea, Chicago challenger, in a ten-round battle before 5,500 spectators. The verdict of the two judges and Referee Phil Collins was unanimous.

Extending its recent advance in the heaviest trading of the year, the stock market gave yesterday what was considered the most encouraging response thus far to the pervasive optimism in "Wall Street. The net gains were less impressive than on other days in the recent past, but the turnover was enormous, measured by present-day standards.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4. -- A rise of 60 cents a ton in the Canadian tariff on anthracite coal from the United States, to facilitate British anthracite exports to Canada, will be requested by the British delegation to the Imperial Economic Conference here if the delegates yield to the pressure of lobbyists for British coal interests who are active behind the scenes at the conference.

Anna Skigam and Abraham Finkelstein, proprietors of paint shops, who were arrested on Wednesday night on a charge of selling denatured alcohol which killed two of twenty-six persons who have died recently from poison liquor, were held in bail of $2,500 each for hearings yesterday in Homicide Court.

MANILA. -- The economic depression has already paved the way for Philippine independence because it has reduced the export of sugar, copra and hemp, says Rafael Alunan, Secretary of Agriculture and Natural Resources in the Philippine Cabinet.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. Walter Belknap James was hostess for a meeting of the Newport Garden Association this afternoon at Rockhurst, her residence. There was a large attendance of he members, who were greatly interested in the address of Mrs. Eloise Luquer, national chairman of the conservation committee of the Garden Club of America, who was guest speaker.

On an April evening six years ago, Isidore Renner, jeweler, of 132 Rivington Street, shoved his fist through a plate glass window of his shop to raise an alarm when four armed men attempted to rob his store. Yesterday afternoon Renner did exactly the same thing, and again frustrated a robbery.

VIENNA, Aug. 4. -- The main committee of the Austrian Parliament made it evident today that the provisions of the Lausanne agreement affecting Austria, if adopted at all, would be adopted only with amendments not likely to be acceptable to France.

Operations of the Radio Corporation of America for the second quarter of this year resulted in a net loss of $283,818 after taxes, charges and reserves, contrasting with a net income of $1,072,184 in the same period last year. Whereas no dividends were paid in the 1932 period, there was a deficit of $228,353 after Class A and B preferred dividends a year ago.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4. -- The field hockey game between India and Japan, held this morning in Olympic Stadium, drew only a handful of spectators, but those who turned out were rewarded with an exhibition of team play such as is not often seen in any branch of sport.

Copyrighted, 1932, by The Associated Press. ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Governor Roosevelt outlined informally today the general principles which will serve as guide posts in forming his recommendations for the regulation of the nation's public utility industry.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Washington Senators rallied in the tenth inning today and bombarded two Detroit pitchers for two triples, two doubles and a single which netted five runs and won a bitterly fought game, 14 to 11. It deadlocked the series at one game each.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians used twenty-two innings to beat the Boston Red Sox twice today. They won the first without much trouble, 8 to 2, but had to come from behind twice to take the second, 8 to 7, in thirteen innings.
