CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 4. -- Alfred Holman, the father of Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, informed late today of her indictment at Winston-Salem, N.C., for the murder of her husband, Z. Smith Reynolds, said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is Implied in THE TIMES editorial on the moral equivalents which students find for revolt that such moral equivalents are good. That may not be so. The charge of intellectual immaturity so often brought against the American college student is founded precisely on that attitude which assumes that the college period is a grand and glorious four-year holiday.

Bank clearings reported from leading cities for the week ended on Wednesday increased $1,394,732,000 from the preceding week, reaching an aggregate of $4,940,319,000, according to R.G. Dun Co. The figure is 28.6 per cent below the total for the same week last year, while last week's figure was 40 per cent under.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The American Legion Handicap, feature today, saw its tightest finish since it was inaugurated, when lour horses drove past the judges only noses apart but with the Sage Stable's Microphone on the front end.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- A cottage owned by William Eustis on Oak Island Beach on the north side of Fire Island Inlet at a point due north of Point Democrat was almost washed out to sea by an unusually high tide accompanied by a steady south by southwest wind early today.
Coventions in New york. Though August is a dull month fraternally, the Merchants' Association reports that fifteen conventions and trade exhibitions will be held in this city, before Labor Day.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. John D. Chapman of the Greenwich Country Club led a field of fifty-three contestants in the one-day tournament of the Women's Weatchester and Fairfleld County Golf Association today by scoring a 92 over the Wee Burn Country Club course.

The principle of a plan to insure payment of the war debts by offering in exchange surplus American products to the debtor nations in value equal to the several debt payments has put forward by Mark O. Frentiss, advertising counsel, who said his proposal so far was distinctly a bid for constructive suggestions which might aid in perfecting such a program.

NEW YORK. Miss Mary Pearsall Field will return from Europe Aug. 19 on the Mauretania and after a few days at the Plaza will go to Lenox, Mass., for the marriage of her niece, Miss Marjorie Lila Field, to Lieutenant Helm George Wilde, U.S.A.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Federal Reserve Banks continued the purchase of government securities on a restricted scale in the week-end of yesterday, with acquisition of $5,000,000 in the open market, bringing total holdings to $1,846,000,000, or $1,165,000 laregr than a year earlier, according to the board's condition statement issued today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4. -- Despite the efforts of nineteen American nations to prevent war between Bolivia and Paraguay, an official bulletin posted at Tarija, in the Bolivian section of the disputed Chaco, carries an announcement today from Colonel Pena, commanding the Fourth Bolivian Division, that he has begun a heavy artillery bombardment in the Pilcomayo sector of the disputed Chaco region.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The only proposal that has come from the Republican party regarding the foreign debts is Senator Borah's program for cancellation, Senator Ashurst asserted today in replying to Senator Moses's criticism of Governor Roosevelt on the debt question.

SAM BREADON started it. Sam owns the Cardinals, and in 1925 with great regret, he removed Branch Rickey from the managership of that club. The Cardinals were away down yonder in the lower reaches of the National League, and slipping further day by day. So Sam called Branch Rickey in and said:

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 4. -- Vowing vengeance on President Hoover at the polls next November and planning vaguely for a march on Washington, next December, two-thirds of the nondescript horde of bonus marchers were riding the cushions homeward tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Dumping of rubber shoes into the United States by producers in Japan and Czechoslovakia was charged today by representatives of the American rubber industry in a hearing before F.X.A. Eble, Commissioner or Customs.

The application by Samuel Seabury, Charles H. Tuttle and Herman Oppenhelmer, representing bondholders of the Hotel Delmonico, Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, for a temporary injunction restraining S. W. Straus Co., Inc., from carrying out a reorganization of the financial structure of the hotel, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Collins.

Preliminary to the adoption of a more aggressive policy of cooperation to overcome unsettled conditions in the steel industry, Robert P. Lamont, who resigned on Wednesday as Secretary of Commerce, has been chosen to head the American Iron and Steel Institute, which represents about 95 per cent of the steel producers of the country.

Directors of the National Dairy Products Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, thereby placing the stock on a $2 annual basis against $2.60 previously. The reduction in the dividend, Thomas H. McInnerney, president, said, was in line with reduced prices generally and the narrower margin of profit.

Francis Joseph O'Doul, with some aid from the rest of the Dodgers, yesterday afternoon defeated the Pirates in both ends of a double-header. The Carey crew for the first time this season rose above the 500 mark in the standing.

Loans and investments by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City jumped $239,000,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, compared with a gain of $32,000,000 the previous week. The principal increase came in investments, which were up $230,000,000, of which United States Government securities accounted for $217,000,000, in connection with the Aug. 1 financing, and other securities $13,000,000.

Leasing of store space constituted the feature of the business, rental market, according to reports received from brokers yesterday. Retail shopping quarters were taken in various parts of the city. Several store rentals in the Bronx were listed, and some activity also was noted in the garment district.

DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Carl Williams of the Federal Farm Board said today that the board, engaged in the stabilization of the cotton market, expected to dispose of 1,150,000 bales of cotton in the coming fiscal year with the same absence of price disturbance that marked its sale of wheat.

The temple that was built in praise of George Washington in Bryant Park was the background last night for open-air Italian opera. A troupe that styled itself the Puccini Grand Opera Company presented "Il Trovatore" in the first of a series of ten successive Thursday evenings of grand opera.

DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Carl Williams of the Federal Farm Board said today that the board, engaged in the stabilization of the cotton market, expected to dispose of 1,150,000 bales of cotton in the coming fiscal year with the same absence of price disturbance that marked its sale of wheat.

The temple that was built in praise of George Washington in Bryant Park was the background last night for open-air Italian opera. A troupe that styled itself the Puccini Grand Opera Company presented "Il Trovatore" in the first of a series of ten successive Thursday evenings of grand opera.

When JULIUS MILLER submitted his revised plans for the West Side Motor Highway to the Board of Estimate in the Spring of 1927, he estimated that it would cost about $11,000,000. As officially sanctioned in the Fall of 1928, the cost was set at $13,500,000.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Buffalo won twice from Baltimore today to supplant the Orioles in second place. The Bisons scored in the afternoon, 5-4, clouting Glen Liebhardt, pitching his first game for Baltimore, for nine hits in seven innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- More than 600,000 persons have lost their jobs since the first of June and 11,023,000 were out of work in that month, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today in his monthly analysis of unemployment.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced at one time yesterday to the highest figures of the week, the market met cotton above 6 cents for the October delivery as on each improvement recently. A reaction in securities in the last hour and active liquidation of government-financed cotton not only wiped out all the earlier gains but closed the list at the bottom at losses of 5 to 9 points on the day.

Governor Roosevelt assured the Hungarian people of his sympathy and friendship in a recent interview with Paul Nadanyi, political editor of the Amerikai Magyar Nepszava, a Hungarian daily newspaper published in this city. Mr. Roosevelt told his interviewer that he was in sympathy with all efforts to straighten out difficulties or injustices that might have arisen from the Treaty of Versailles or from other treaties that were negotiated after the World War.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 4. -- Government hospitalization for war veterans suffering from non-service disabilities was attacked by members of the medical profession here today before the Congressional committee headed by Representative Joseph V. Shannon, which reopened its investigation into government competition with private business.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. The following tables show for various items the highest and lowest points reached thus far in 1932 and in a series of years past.

POINT O' WOODS, L.I., Aug. 4. -- For the first time in the history of Great South Bay yachting the cruising fleet of the Yacht Racing Association crossed to the Fire Island side of the bay and held a championship regatta, off here today. In honor of the occasion, 103 boats came to the starting line, the largest fleet that has raced in the present series.

The question of wage arbitration between the Publishers' Association of New York City and Typographical Union 6 has resulted in a breach between Austin Hewson. president of "Big Six," and Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, it was revealed yesterday in a statement by Mr. Hewson.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Buffalo closed its series with Baltimore today by splitting a double-header. The Orioles won the first, 9 to 2. and the Bisons took the second, 10 to 1.

A recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange carried the October delivery to 6.06 cents a pound at one time yesterday, but the market ran into an increased supply of contracts again and the list closed 5 to 9 points higher than on Thursday.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Between the United States' acceptance of the invitation to the world economic conference on condition that neither war debts nor tariffs be discussed and Senator William, E. Borah's insistence that both these matters as well as disarmament be dealt with, the French have, decided that the best course is to wait and see what happens.

While their car, parked in the middle of the avenue with the engine running, held up traffic outside, five gunmen held up the branch office of the Savings Bank of Richmond Hill at 120-08 Liberty Avenue, Queens, just before noon yesterday, obtanied $9,100 and escaped.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5. -- The British Government, as represented at the Imperial Economic Conference here by seven of its Cabinet Ministers under the leadership of Stanley Baldwin, will definitely not accept the proposals of the Canadian Government for further reciprocity in trade.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- After Gregory S. Mangin of Newark had upset Clifford S. Sutler of New Orleans, Sidney B. Wood of New York, 1931 Wimbledon champion, also waged an uphill battle today to conquer David N. Jones, also of New York, and qualify with Mangin for tomorrow's singles final in the Meadow Club's forty-second annual invitation tennis tourney.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Libby Holman Reynolds knew tonight that she had been indicted for murder, but a hide-and-seek game as to her whereabouts continued.

The carrying of firearms by peace officers engaged in serving civil processes was condemned strongly by Magistrate Mark Rudich in Brooklyn Homicide Court yesterday during the arraignment of Deputy Sheriff Vincent Glynn, a nephew of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, on a charge of homicide.

With official figures of the Fire Department showing approximate agreement yesterday with the poll taken by the firemen themselves on Mayor Walker's proposal for one month's service without pay next year, Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial ridiculed the entire plan as a failure which he said would be made more apparent when Sanitation Department employes had a real chance to express their views.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in July aggregated $19,318,502,525. This was a decline of 12 per cent from the preceding month, and of 44.4 per cent compared with July, 1931. It was likewise the smallest total in more than fifteen years.
DUBLIN, Aug. 5. -- President Eamon de Valera got u2,000,000 [about $6,960,000 at yesterday's rate] for a tariff "war fund" from the Dail Eireann tonight by his "mechanical" majority of 58 to 43.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- There is still a possibility, although a very faint one, that Prime Minister MacDonald will consider approaching the United States for a reduction of the war debts before the Presidential election in November.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Red Sox matched hit-for-hit with Cleveland today but lost their third straight of the series, 7 to 2.

The American delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva returned yesterday on the United States liner Leviathan. The members were disappointed in some respects by the outcome of the negotiations, but cheered nevertheless in the belief that the final resolution of the conference pointed to definite limitations and "real reductions" when the international representatives convene again in January.

In line with its policy to Improve fishing and hunting in the State during the coming years, the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game is conducting an elaborate distribution of ringneck pheasants within its boundaries.

Although trading was less active on the Stock Exchange yesterday, prices continued to advance and new maximums for the movement were recorded in many of the leading issues. The volume was 2,684,000 shares, compared with 3,522,000 on the day before.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 (AP). -- The political fate of Senator Alben W. Barkley, keynoter and temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention, will hold major interest tomorrow, when Kentucky votes, after a primary campaign in which prohibition was the major issue for the first time since adoption of the Eighteenth Amendment.

It is a common remark that the Presidential campaign has thus far been rather languid. One experienced observer of American politics recently said that he never knew a time when enthusiasm in either party, whether for its platform or for its candidate, was so lacking, as at present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one caught in the catastrophe at the Ritz Tower, and who had ample opportunity to watch the work of the Fire and Police Departments, I wish to compliment you upon the concise, accurate job of reporting done by your paper.

Production of steel ingots in the United States in July was 792,533 tons, the lowest for a month for which there is a comparable record. Compared with the previous month, July showed a decrease of 104,742 tons, while the drop from July, 1931, was 1,095,047 tons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Reports of pledges since the first of the year to spend $44,600,000 on property improvement and labor were announced today by the home modernizing committee of the Department of Commerce.

Bennett Griffin and James Mattern, who crashed in Russia in July while attempting to set a new record for flying around the world, returned yesterday on the United States liner Leviathan still modestly surprised at the enthusiastic reception given them in European cities, and expressing wonderment that any one should be praised for cracking up "a perfectly good ship."

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A young Buffalo player, Mike Fareo, who left the caddy ranks only last year, provided the major thrill of the tenth annual State amateur golf tournament today as he battled Maurice McCarthy Jr., metropolitan ace, to a standstill only to lose on an extra hole.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Dave Harris, utility outfielder of the Washington Senators, blasted the hopes of Tommy Bridges, Detroit right-handed hurler, for a perfect game today after Bridges Had retired twenty-six men in order.
RENO, Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Julia Calhern, the former Mrs. Lydig Hoyt, who was known on the stage and the screen as Julia Hoyt, began a suit today for a divorce from Louis Calhern, the actor.

The "Public Welfare Medal" established in memory of the late MARCELLUS HARTLEY has been awarded by the National Academy of Sciences to Dr. WILLIAM H. PARK. When he was cited for an honorary degree by New York University a few years ago he was called a " living link between science and the common life."

BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Because the worst of the recent political disorders have occurred in East Prussia, Rudolf Diels, counselor to the Prussian Ministry of the Interior, was appointed special commissioner today with orders to proceed to Koenigsberg immediately to investigate the situation.

PARIS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Henrl Cochet and Marcel Bernard will sail next Wednesday on the liner Champlain for the United States to compete in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills, L.I., Sept. 3-10.

MONTREAL, Aug. 5. -- Mrs. A.M. Hall's Kingbird scored by a neck over T. Jerfita's Relline in the onemile race which held the feature position on the card at Dorval Park today. Light Nun was a close third.

TAYLORVILLE, III., Aug. 5. -- John B. Colegrove, 65 years old, facing one to three years in prison since his recent convictiion in connection with the $1,500,000 failure of the J. B. Colegrove Co. State Bank, of which he was the head, was kidnapped from his home here by three men tonight.

In its plea for giving up the Delaney plan of financing new subway construction the Citizens' Budget Commission cuts to the kernel of the problem, of retrenchment. If any are still unaware of the burden which that ingenious device loads upon the taxpayer they may learn the facts from the chairman's latest letter to Mayor WALKER.

If householders in Westchester and Long Island hope to preserve their shrubs, lawns and trees they must join battle against the increasing insect pests. Not only the Japanese beetle but the newer Asiatic and Oriental beetles are appearing in force for the first time in the metropolitan area, it was said yesterday by C.H. Zimmer, supervisor for the Department of Agriculture in its fight to control the Japanese beetle in New York.

SEAGIRT, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Governor and Mrs. Moore shed a tear or two here today in their Summer home, known as the Little White House, when "rioting" broke out on the Camp Moore parade ground and an infantry platoon from the New Jersey National Guard encampment threw tear gas candles to disperse a crowd of hooting "strikers."

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The framework of a detailed program for regulation of public utilities and power projects to be offered to the nation in a campaign speech was reviewed today by Governor Roosevelt in conference with his experts in the field.

Mayor Walker announced yesterday that he would go to Washington next week to seek, on behalf of the city, a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to complete the Triborough Bridge and other public works that may be decided upon as the most pressing.

Encouraged by the aggressive banking plans to strengthen the price situation of agricultural staples and by reports of heavy foreign buying of American securities, the stock market extended its recent advance widely and on a broad front yesterday.

The preparation of Mayor Walker's reply to the rebuttal filed with Governor Roosevelt on Wednesday by Samuel Seabury was being rushed yesterday at the Mayor's apartment in the Hotel Mayfair. Mr. Walker announced that he hoped to send it to Albany on Monday, the time set by Governor Roosevelt in acceding to the Mayor's request for permission to a surrebuttal.

The Rev. Conrad.E. Schroeder, for the last four years pastor of the Lutheran Church, Mineola, L.I., will be installed as superintendent of the Bethlehem Lutheran Orphan and Half Orphan Asylum, which is at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., at a public service which will be held tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in St. Luke's Lutheran Church, Forty-sixth Street, west of Eighth Avenue, Manhattan.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5. -- Bill Carr did it again.

Domestic corporation bonds moved forward again yesterday on the Stock Exchange, although the gains were not so impressive as on the days immediately previous. Utility bonds showed the best average rise for the day. Foreign loans were irregularly lower, while the United States Government bonds were irregularly higher, in light trading.

HUDSON FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Blaming labor trouble, John P. Gamble, general manager of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, announced this afternoon that the Fenimore mill of the company will be closed. The machinery is expected to be dismantled and shipped away.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Listen, an 8-year-old black mare, imported three years ago from England, was the bright star of the second day of the annual Monmouth County Horse Show, winning a championship, four blue ribbons and a second prize, in addition to which she carried off the S.L. Herbert Cup for her owner, Miss Sylvia White of Shrewsbury, N.J.

A substantial gain in the volume of new financing this week over the two weeks immediately preceding, is believed to presage increased activity in the marketing of new bond issues this month. This week's total of new financing reached $31,430,000, the heaviest since the week ended on July 15, when issues aggregating $81,977,750 were put on the market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES publishes in a news item, "Lays Our Depression to Idle Machinery," a report of an interview with Walter Clark, consulting: management engineer of Paris and New York. Mr. Clark notes the fact that machinery, even in good times, is partially idle in this country.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 5. -- Pep II, owned and driven by E.L. Chase of Baltimore, won the first ten-mile heat of the Miles River speedboat trophy race today in the feature of the opening day's program of the Miles River Yacht Club's annual homecoming regatta.

The forward trend in commodities prices was resumed yesterday after the interval of Thursday's irregularity. Grains, cotton, provisions, dairy products, metals, rubber, silk, hides, coffee, sugar and cocoa all scored good-size gains. There were no recessions reported in any section.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Mirror, morning tabloid, which has been under the same ownership as The Chicago Tribune and The New York Daily News, suspended publication with its early bulldog edition today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The committee of neutrals rejected today the Bolivian proposal to arbitrate the Chaco dispute witty Paraguay on the basis of present military positions, and in a note to La Paz repeated the request for arbitration or some other peaceful method of solution on the basis of the status quo ante.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Division staff officers of the New York National Guard arranged today to begin shifting tomorrow 2,100 out of 6,300 guardsmen who are to be moved between State camps and armories.

Whether criminal negligence was responsible in the deaths last Monday of seven firemen in the fire and explosion in the Ritz Tower apartment hotel in East Fifty-seventh Street will be considered Monday at a conference of officials in District Attorney Crain's office.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Playing almost perfect par for the last nine holes, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Baltusrol, holder of the New Jersey women's championship, led her nearest opponent by three strokes to win the low gross event of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club today.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The eighteen hours specified by the German Government last night as the period wherein political disorders must cease have more than passed, but the threatened decree increasing the penalties for rowdyism and even including the death sentence for extreme cases has not been issued.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One or two of your correspondents have commented recently on alleged repudiation of bonds issued by the State of Florida. This State has never repudiated, scaled, readjusted, defaulted nor delayed payment of any part of her public debt, either principal or interest.

Staten Island was nearly deserted yesterday. That is, the interior of the island was almost depopulated while all along its shores the populace sat angling for mackerel. And those who were not on the shore were out in all manner of craft hauling in the fish.

In denying the request of Pennsylvania for a $10,000,000 advance on an eventual loan of $45,000,000 for unemployment relief the Reconstruction Finance Corporation laid down a sound premise and precedent. The $300,000,000 assigned by Congress for use in the States is to " supplement" State and local relief and not to be used in lieu thereof."

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The Economist believes the United States has passed the crisis. The leading article in the current issue of that periodical is headed "The Long Lane," and remarks that the past year has placed before the United States the "deepest depression and the biggest economy ordeal in her history."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colonies in Southampton, East Hampton, West Hampton and Quogue attended the annual Boys' Club dinner dance in aid of the William Carey Camp in Jamesport, L.I., which was held tonight at Canoe Place Inn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Seven camp sites for members of the Bonus Expeditionary Force have been offered in as many States. Walter W. Waters, commander of the bonus marchers, announced today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Through a heavy rain which started just before the race, Mrs. Emil Denemark's Miss Marr came from behind to win the Rose of Sharon Purse, top event at Hawthorne today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- With the Reconstruction Finance Corporation rushing toward completion its organization to handle loans for self-liquidating projects, it was learned in unofficial quarters today that action may be expected on such advances within a week.

After an exchange of correspondence between Austin Hewson, president of Typographical Union 6, and Howard Davis, acting chairman of the Publishers' Association of New York City, arrangements were made for a meeting at 10 o'clock this morning between the scale conference committee of the union and the publishers' committee to discuss future plans for ironing out the differences between the two factions regarding the question of a new scale of wages.

A Chicago and New York banking syndicate in a few days will exercise its option to buy $20,000,000 Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company first and refunding mortgage 6 per cent gold bonds, series C, and will offer them early next week at a price reported to be around 98.

The Mayor of Salisbury, England, Councillor J. Sidney Rambridge, arrived on the Cunard liner Aquitania yesterday, bound for Salisbury, Md., where he will be chief guest of honor at the city's bicentennial celebration beginning next Monday and lasting through the week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Reports of a $30,000,000 pool in wheat spread over the trading floor of the Chicago Board of Trade today, but neither confirmation nor denial was forthcoming. Arthur W. Cutten, veteran trader credited with directing the pool, was silent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Exports of merchandise from the United States in June amounted to $114,274,918, a drop of $72,801,771 from the corresponding month of 1931, the Commerce Department announced today. Imports were valued at $111,410,900, a decrease of $62,044,147 from June, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Reduction of the personnel of the New York office of the Federal Radio Commission appears probable today following a visit of inspection by Commissioner Thad H. Brown, Charles B. Jolliffe, chief engineer, and James W. Baldwin, secretary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcement that the representatives of the former Allied Powers and Germany have reached an agreement materially reducing reparation payments brings the United States one step closer to the question of a reconsideration of the war debts.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Charley Grimm experienced the sadder side of managerial life today when the Phlllies hammered the offerings of three Chicago pitchers for fifteen hits and a 9-to-2 victory as the Cubs played their second game under their new pilot.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Sterling exchange on New York declined further today from $3.49 3/8 to $3.47 1/2, which caused a dull tendency in British Government funds and the assented war loan declined to under par, but the closing prices were above the lowest of the day.
LONDON, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Sussex defeated Northamptonshire by six wickets in a county cricket match concluded at Hastings today.

The swinging balance of a pair of Police Department scales that came to rest at weights between nine and ten carats when testing the stones of a diamond bracelet brought new hope yesterday to Robert C. Nelson, convicted and sentenced as a receiver of stolen jewelry and out on bail since Thursday pending the hearing of his appeal.

A $45,000,000 model housing enterprise for the lower east side, to be undertaken by a corporation of limited profit under the terms of the State Board of Housing, with funds to be sought, at least in part, from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was outlined yesterday by Robert W. Aldrich Rodger of Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Unable to decide whether their quarry was a robber or a maniac, Adams County officers searched through the farmlands around Natchez today for some trace of the man who riddled the body of Miss Jane Merrill, aged and wealthy recluse, with bullets and ransacked her home.

To start immediate inflation of their currencies is the best measure that gold-standard countries could take to aid in rapid economic recovery, in the opinion of Dr. Gustav Cassel, Swedish economist, whose book, "The Crisis in the World's Monetary System," has just been published by the Oxford University Press.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Lawrence Harper of Oakland, Cal., No. 3 in the national ranking, stopped the onward rush of Miss Joan Ridley, English player, in the semi-finals of the Maidstone Club's seventh annual Women's Invitation Gold Cup tournament today and will meet Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Cal., ranked No. 2, in the final tomorrow.

A man with, a just claim but no money for legal expenses need not feel that justice is out of his reach so long as the Legal Aid Society continues to function. For fifty-six years it has been acting in behalf of poor clients. Last year, it is stated in the annual report, more than 40,000 applied for legal assistance.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Contrary to expectation, the Bourse snowed a slight weakness today. It was believed the market would follow Wall Street's buoyant tendency, as it has been doing lately, but transactions were few, with speculators generally waiting to see whether the New York market would consolidate the gains there.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer Jr., who went to Bermuda shortly after their marriage, are returning today an the Monarch of Bermuda. They will go to Newport for the rest of the Summer. Mrs. Tailer is the former Miss Florence Baker.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the time of the last solar eclipse observable in New York City I caught a phenomenon that may be a source of interest to the lay observer in the track of the New England eclipse occurring on Aug. 31. It can easily be found, and as I have never seen it mentioned anywhere, I would be glad to be checked up on it.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5. -- With each succeeding day the panorama of the Olympic Games unfolds on a wider scale to take in more and more territory in an area of 100 square miles, until one now feels the need of sevenleague boots or an airplane to take in all the sideshows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- In keeping with his principle of informality, Speaker Garner has been notified of his nomination for the Vice Presidency in a letter sent by Senator Barkley of Kentucky, temporary chairman of the Democratic National Convention.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Reports that a pool with financial backing of $30,000,000 was or had been formed to operate in the grain markets were not confirmed today, and the trade was inclined to make light of the rumors. Arthur W. Cutten refused to comment on the alleged pool, of which it was said he was to be the manager.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5 (AP).-- Veterans defended the present system of hospitalization for service men before the Shannon house committee today as representatives of bankers, commission men and dyers increased the volume of complaint against government competition.

Long Island University has decided to cancel its football schedule for the coming season. The Federal tax on gate receipts is responsible, mainly, for the decision, which was announced last night by Tristram W. Metcalfe, acting head of the university. In place of football, Long Island University will concentrate on basketball and intramural sports.

Star-grazing and providing the means for others to do so had been for years the source of Arthur F. Nursey's livelihood. And, as if in accordance with some unwritten universal scheme, it was star-gazing that resulted in his death late Thursday night in Bellevue Hospital.

The advisory council and the general membership of the Association of Railway Executives will meet here next Wednesday to discuss the Federal Administration's proposal that the railroads increase employment by, borrowing from the Reconstruction, Finance Corporation to finance repairs to equipment.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds checked a ninth-inning surge of the Boston Braves today and gained a 3 to 2 verdict.

NEWPORT, R.I., .Aug. 5. -- A busy round of week-end entertaining in the Summer colony began today One of the larger of the parties was the tea given by Miss Katharine Cortazzo at the Viking. Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward gave a luncheon at Claranden Court in honor of their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Replogle of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Governor Roosevelt favors the same kind of tariff as the "competitive" Underwood bill, which placed "practically all the products of the farm, field, mines and ranch" on the free list, Senator Moses charged today.

David Getzoff, 45 years old, an exconvict known on the east side as "Dufke," died in Gouverneur Hospital at 4:30 A.M. yesterday, two hours after he had been shot in the back of the head at East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

Analysis of the substance found sewed in the seams of garments recently sent to a cleaning establishment showed it to be an explosive which if immersed in water would have wrecked the plant, according to a chemist's report submitted yesterday to Edmund C. Collins, Assistant State Attorney General. Mr. Collins is investigating conditions in the cleaning and dyeing industry throughout the city.

The Grant Studios at 114 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, has replaced its portrait show, which it held in July, with a group of oils, watercolors and sculpture. The feature of the new exhibition is a roomful of "thumbbox" sketches by Ernest Meyer, one-time pupil and associate of William Merritt Chase.

COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday .... 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday .... 2 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper. Regular Lines Seen Gaining. Consumer resistance to special promotion based chiefly on price increased during the week, it was remarked yesterday in retail circles here. Customers are tending to fill in on some of their current needs, following delayed buying earlier in the Summer.

The new cabin liner Manhattan, built at the plant of the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden for the United States Lines, will sail at 3 o'clock this afternoon with 250 travel agents, officials of the line and newspaper men for a 200-mile trip to sea.

East River Drive. The War Department has been kind to New York lately in a number of its decisions. When the city wished to build 1,000-foot piers in the Hudson, the department agreed to the necessary change in the pierhead lines on both sides of the river.
Strength in prices of non-ferrous metals continued yesterday in virtually all markets. Copper was higher both here and abroad, while zinc and lead improved further in the domestic markets.

Bond and note issues amounting to $10,330,107 will come up for award next week, representing the requirements of thirty-four municipalities and one State. This total is a decline of about $500,000 from that of this week and compares with the weekly average for the year to date of $20,586,765.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Seated at his desk in the Marine Barracks here this morning, Captain L.I. Gover directed a dress parade of marine reserves by radio at the Great Lakes Naval Station in Chicago. The orders were executed, reports from Chicago said, with the same precision and snap as if they had been given by an officer standing in front of the troops.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 5. -- The thorny question of revising the peace threaties occupied the attention of the Institute of Politics today. There was general agreement that the treaties need revision in certain particulars, because failure to revise them might lead to war.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 5 (AP). -- A desire that the trial of his daughter, Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds, be held at the earliest possible date was expressed tonight by Alfred Holman.
James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will begin Monday a series of conferences with State chairmen which will be continued until every State has been represented.

The crux of disarmament, said NORMAN H. DAVIS, in his shipboard dispatch, to THE TIMES on Thursday, is "how to reduce and limit world armaments without reducing the relative security of any one nation." It has never been quite fair to stress the fact that more than a dozen years after the nations had pledged themselves to reduce armaments there are more soldiers in the world than before the World War.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 5. -- In all probability Northam Warren's Eina is the winner of the association special prize cup in the regatta sailed under the auspices of the Sayville Yacht Club off here today. The craft scored its fourth straight victory in the seventeenth annual race meet and championship regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

A further improvement in business sentiment throughout the country is noted in Bradstreet's weekly review, based upon reports from fifty-five leading cities. Optimism has "permeated to the smaller centres and undoubtedly can be taken as an encouraging factor," says this agency.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5. -- Wielding a blade lightning swift, but striking often in the same place, Gustavo Marzi, Italian student who has been fencing twelve of his twenty-three years, today won the individual foils championship of the Olympic Games.

In connection with the Swedish bankruptcy of Kreuger Toll through which the late Ivar Kreuger held his $1,000,000,000 organization, and which Federal Judge Mack decided on Thursday to adjudicate in bankruptcy here. Judge Mack said yesterday that he saw no necessity to name a receiver during the interval until the American creditors elect a trustee in bankruptcy.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- After a Federal investigation begun nearly two years ago, announcement was made here today of the indictment of three officials of three New York chemical concerns, charging conspiracy to distribute ether unfit for anesthesia to hospitals and surgical supply houses.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Returns from yesterday's primary made it appear certain tonight that Hill McAlister, Democratic State Treasurer, and John E. McCall, Republican of Memphis, will contest for the Governorship in the November election.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 5. -- The special session of the State Legislature, which has gone through six weeks without any decisive action on unemployment relief, probably will adopt a program of new taxation to provide funds for the needy next week.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Taking both ends of their double-header with the Toronto Leafs before 7,000 today, the Newark Bears Increased their wide advantage in the pennant race and clinched the series four games to one. The scores were 6 to 3 and 10 to 9, the latter game going nine innings although it was scheduled for seven.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Two sharply conflicting theories as to the earliest true men were advanced here today by eminent scientists, but both were promptly and vigorously disputed.

Jersey City lost both ends of a double-header to the Rochester Red Wings yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City, giving the visitors the series, four games to two. The first battle went fourteen innings, the Red Wings taking the verdict, 7 to 6, on Riley's three-bagger and a long fly by Pepper.

(Copyright, 1932, by The Chicago Tribune). JUAN LES PINS, France, Aug. 5. -- Canes were swung by hands that had never brandished anything more deadly than a cocktail-shaker and brickbats were propelled by dainty bangled wrists as the "Pajama Coast" rose up in revolt last night against the municipal authorities.

Bowling the Cardinals over with a grand flourish, the Giants hung up their fifth straight victory at the Polo Grounds yesterday and swept majestically past the world's champions into sixth place. They now lead the world's champions by a full game and are three games back of the fifth-place Robins.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Republican defense has apparently narrowed down to two main assertions. One, that the administration cannot be held accountable for the depression, it being due to economic factors. And two, that the depression is the result of the war, the implication, being that depressions always follow wars.

Discussions relative to the sale of long-term bonds of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation and a corresponding reduction in the company's bank loans are being carried on between bankers and representatives of the company's new board of directors, composed largely of Rochester citizens.

DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Carl Williams, vice chairman of the Federal Farm Board, told the American Institute of Cooperation today he was confident that interest collected on more than $400,000,000 loaned to cooperative organizations would more than offset any losses.
Mournfully but firmly our realist neighbor, The Herald Tribune, says: An able and tested public servant like Mr. LEHMAN cannot be beaten by a second-rater, even in a Presidential year.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 5. -- A request for the arrest of Libby Holman Reynolds was dispatched tonight to Newcastle County authorities at Wilmington, Del., by Sheriff Transou Scott, with the suggestion that the former Broadway singer might be found at the home of a friend in Montchanin.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Reclassification of all positions in the Westchester County Government, with the exception of department heads, under a plan of appointment and promotion for merit, instead of political influence, was recommended in a report made public here today by the budget committee of the County Board of Supervisors.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns went ten innings today to take the second game of the series from Philadelphia. 9 to 8, each side using three pitchers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The estate of Florenz Ziegfeld, New York theatrical producer, is divided between his wife, Ethelbert Appleton Ziegfeld, known on the stage as Billie Burke, and their daughter, Patricia, according to the will, filed here today.

Reversing its decision of Tuesday, the council of the Actors' Equity Association at a special meeting yesterday morning reclassified Chamberlain Brown's "Scrapbook" as vaudeville and "decided not to assume jurisdiction over this production." Consequently, Equity will not interfere with the two-a-day schedule of performances, including the announced showing tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The annual waste in New York State forest and wood working industries if converted into lumber would amount to about 100,000,000 board feet, or enough to make a solid train fifty-five miles long, according to a survey of non-utilized wood in that State made under the auspices of the Department of Commerce.
Paul Claudel, French Ambassador to the United States, is sailing today for France on the motorship Lafayette of the French Line. Others sailing on the ship include:

Lovell Hall Jerome, who was familiarly known in the customs service here for many years as "the Colonel," and is one of the last surviving officers of Indian warfare of the early 70's, will observe his eighty-third birthday today at his home, 829 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Government officials learned with gratification today of the coming appointment of Secretary Lamont as "czar" of the steel industry, a title disliked by the steel men, but which government experts say must be lived up to if the industry is to be safely stabilized.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 5. -- Unleashing in two heats the irresistible speed that has made him the season's outstanding pacer to date, Zombro Hanover, 2:00%, owned by H. Stacy Smith of Newark, N.J., and driven by Will Crozier, won the $10,000 Parker House stake, the feature of the Grand Circuit program today at Rockingham Park.

Further details of how the new State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N.Y., is to be utilized as a controlled research laboratory for the study of delinquency and the behavior problems of boys in general were announced yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Centre, which is to cooperate in the project.

An extensive "energy survey," tracing the industrial and agricultural development of the United States during the last 100 years in terms of production, employment and energy expended, is under way at Columbia University. It is being made under the joint auspices of the university's Department of Industrial Engineering and the Architects' Emergency Committee of New York, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter Rautenstrauch, head of the department.

NOTE the cast of characters at the Olympic Games. A Swedish preacher, Johann Richthoff, won the heavyweight wrestling championship. A croupier in a French gambling house, Louis Hostin, won the Olympic title for weight-lifting in the light heavyweight class. Another French winner in hoisting gross tonnage was Rene Duverger, a dancing instructor. A schoolmaster, Tom Hampson, won the 800-meter final for Great Britain, and a British railway worker won the 50,000-meter walk.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 5. -- The evacuation of Camp McCloskey, where nearly 9,000 bonus marchers reassembled after being driven out of Washington, struck a serious snag today. When night fell about 1,200 men and women from Eastern States were stranded on short rations awaiting the completion of arrangements for their transportation home.

PORT COLBORNE, Ont., Aug. 5 (Canadian Press). -- When the Great Lakes' largest freighter, the Lemoyne, steams into this port tomorrow preparatory to the official opening of the WeHand Canal, she will carry the greatest cargo of grain ever moved on the lakes.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5. -- Lieutenant Richard Mayo, the United States's surprise contender for the modern Pentathlon honors of the tenth Olympiad, maintained his lead today, but three Swedish competitors were within striking distance after the fourth event, the 300-meter free-style swim.

After a midday pause which reduced the volume of trading substantially, the share market resumed the advance in vigorous fashion, in the late dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Measured by final results, the showing was fully as satisfactory as that of the day before.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A challenge td the supremacy of Top Flight as best of the sex was delivered here today when Willis Sharps Kilmer's Suntica, winner in the West of the Kentucky, Arlington and Latonia Oaks, scored in the eighth running of the Test Stakes in the gamest sort of fashion.

The estate of Alexander Smith Cochran, philanthropist and former president of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers, was appraised yesterday at $41,682,901 gross and $38,977,237 net by Transfer Tax Appraiser James J. Fleming of Westchester County.
SAN PEDRO, Cal., Aug. 5. -- The United States took the major share of honors today as eight days of Olympic yacht racing got under way.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Captain W.N. Lancaster's anguish at hearing that Haden Clarke had succeeded him in the affections of Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller was described to the jury today in a diary read at the former British Army flier's trial on a charge of murdering his rival.

A collection of contemporary German graphic art never before shown in this country will be placed on view at the Roerich Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, next Monday. The exhibition will include works of internationally known artists in black and white.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5. -- Canada's strong position on the "empire content" requirement, qualifying products of foreign branch plants to preferential tariffs in the British Empire, was the subject of heated discussion between representatives of Great Britain and Canada at the Imperial Economic Conference today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 4 -- With primaries near and elections not so very far away, political interest in Arizona is growing more intense. But interest in issues is overshadowing that in the personalities of candidates. Several petitions for important changes in laws have been circulated.
THE story is told of one inmate of an insane asylum adjacent to a golf club saying to another after watching three men in a bunker:

IN the vast sunny spaces around Uvalde, in Texas, the Speaker of the National House of Representatives exchanged the gavel for the fishing pole, the other day, and became a child of nature. Beside an unspecified creek beyond the horizon he ceased, for the moment, to be the Congressional leader and the Vice Presidential nominee of his party.

SHANGHAI, July 15 -- Because of the unruly conduct of students, which has resulted in repeated mobbing and personal injury of Cabinet officials, the Nanking Government has forcibly closed two of the largest universities in the country, and had ordered a complete reorganization of faculty and student bodies before they are reopened.

BUFFALO AMERICAN provincial art and folk sculpture, as a comprehensive collection, representing so much of America's most genuine art expression, has temporarily abandoned its more immediate field of discovery in New York and vicinity for a visit in Buffalo.

The willow scab fungus and the Dutch elm disease are two fungous diseases which have been found in this country recently, Dr. E. Porter Felt, director of the Bartlett Tree Research Laboratories, says.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- In the most stunning upset recorded to date in the Tenth Olympic Games, Jarring Jim Bausch of Kansas, 20O pounds of compact sinew and muscle, came through a formidable field today to win the decathlon championship for the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Democratic registration for the California State primary Aug 30 is considerably more than double the party primary vote two years ago. Registration figures from all but six of the State's fifty-eight counties prove the situation.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- The City Council here and the State Legislature will prepare separate programs of new taxation next week. Under a new law the Council may tax anything not taxed by the State.

SHANGHAI, July 12 -- Agitation has been begun for radical changes in the Shanghai district courts, which are successors to the old mixed and provisional courts. The agreement between the Chinese Government and the powers, under which the district courts were established in February, 1930, expires on March 31 of next year, "unless extended additional period upon mutual consent," according to the wording of the agreement.

DOWN in Atlantic City, where they haven't seen many shows lately, but where they continue to live in hope, the first American performance of "Domino," Marcel Achard's play in adaptation by Grace George, became something of a civic event last Monday evening.

The political situation in Germany, not at all clarified by last Sunday's parliamentary elections, does not augur well for the settlement of the issue of intergovernmental war debts. Instead of bringing a definite party situation, the results of the vote left the situation as difficult as before.

Nothing during the week seemed to interest the public so much as faint indications of a return toward prosperity. Is it the real or the false dawn? A people, straitened by adversity and no longer trustful of the judgments of its financial and political leaders, is not yet sure.

As a substitute for Mayor Walker's "unfair, unscientific and unjust" plan for a reduction in the city payroll. Justice John F. Hylan of the Children's Court in a statement yesterday advocated the immediate appointment by the Mayor of a commission to "investigate and tabulate the unnecessary and overlapping jobs and activities which clog the city budget" with a view to their elimination.

Two youthful brothers attempted to hold up a policeman in civilian clothes and his young woman companion as they were sitting in a parked automobile in a lonely neighborhood in the Pelham Bay Park section of the Bronx late last night. The policeman shot and killed one of his assailants and with the help of the girl overpowered the other.

DETROIT IF anything materializes out of the numerous rumors of mergers in the automotive industry, the gen- eral public will be no more surprised than Detroit motor executives. They give little credence to any of the widely predicted amalgamations.

ANNAPOLIS, Aug. 6 -- The new fourth class at the Naval Academy will be the smallest for years. Academy officials state that its final strength will be about 325. For a number of years, new classes have averaged about 600.

LOOKING backward to Chaucer, and to some degree anticipating the Elizabethans, but in no wise measuring up to their gigantic stature, stands the figure of John Skelton, priest and poet. The date of Skelton's birth is generally placed as 1460.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 6 -- The steamer Colombia, a passenger-cargo craft of 5,500 gross tonnage, was launched today before a throng of visitors. She is the first of two to be built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company for the Colombian Steamship Company.

Modification of the city's economy plans by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee in the event of Mayor Walker's removal by the Governor was viewed as a certainty at City Hall yesterday as the Mayor's pay cut plan continued to weaken under attack.

SOME day there is likely to be a new sort of cable secluded far beneath the waves of the At- lantic. Today the cables carry high-speed dots and dashes. The new line will rush spoken words along the ocean bottom. Then, if something happens in space to bombard radio's words with static, the voices may be switched through the sea where the tide ebbs and flows twice every twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Bank debits, outside New York, for the week ended July 30, declined to the smallest total reported this year, according to the weekly survey of business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Contrary to tradition and general expectations, Distributors Group, Inc., has decided not to sell from the portfolios of the two series of North American. Trust Shares the common stocks of seven companies, including three railroads on which dividends have been passed since the trusts were formed ten months ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was rather surprised to read Olin Downes, writing from Berlin, "The orchestra played about 300 times as well as that of the Metropolitan." This is a bit harsh, rather unjust, and ridiculous for a critic to go to that ratio of comparison.

MAID OF ATHENS" is full of contrasts between ancient and modern Greece. Its characters run the gamut all the way from Greek peasants to visiting American millionaires and members of the British Embassy; and the color and atmosphere of Athens, plus the mingling of a bizarre group in an unusual setting, give the novel a romantic fascination.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- A report which is expected to play an important part in the negotiations now under way toward a Franco-American commercial treaty was published today by the Under-Secretariat of National Economy.

The value of all listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange rose $4,861,279,888 in July, from $15,633,479,577 on July 1 to $20,494,759,485 on Aug. 1, an increase of 31.1 per cent, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price for a share rose from $11.89 to $15.58.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Frank Teague's letter to THE TIMES a few days ago, with reference to the so-called New Hampshire plan and its concomitants, was of the essence of common sense. Now that millions of people are literally at the very edge of the abyss of complete destitution, all sorts of plans are coming to light for alleviating the monstrous situation.

BLIND flying, which under the regulations of the Department of Commerce which will go in force on the first of the year, must be part of the equipment of every transport pilot flying passengers on scheduled planes, has proved of great value to the operation of one of the most difficult air routes in the world: that between Tampico and Mexico City, which is flown once daily in each direction by Pan-American Airways.

The National Municipal League announced yesterday its tentative program for the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the association to be held at the Willard Hotel, Washington, on Sept. 19, 20 and 21. Murray Seasongood, president of the league and former Mayor of Cincinnati, will open the meeting with an address on "Paying for Local Government During Depression."

NEWPORT. -- With mid-August at hand it appears as though the music season for the members of the Summer colony here was well advanced, though there have not been as many recitals this Summer thus far as there have been in the past.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Bonus Expeditionary Force has just begun to fight, "not for a few paltry dollars promised by our government" but "against the most dangerous precedent ever established by a president in time of war or peace," Walter W. Waters, national commander of the remnants of the B.E.F., said today.
SHANGHAI, Aug. 6 -- A sudden movement has started for annexation of a large section of territory in China proper south of the Great Wall to the new State of Manchukuo.

Governor Roosevelt announced yeserday at Hyde Park that he had summoned Mayor Walker to appear in the Executive Chamber in Albany next Thursday at 1:30 P.M. to answer at a public hearing the removal charges filed against him. Almost immediately the Mayor issued a statement here saying that he would be there "on the minute" and personally cross-examine witnesses who may appear against him.

John H. McCooey, Democratic leader of Kings County, will return from Bretton Woods, N.H., tomorrow to investigate reports that a number of his friends have subscribed $100 and more each for an autobiography which the veteran leader disclaims as unauthorized.

Under present financial conditions, with the 5-cent fare imperiled because of impending changes in the Delaney plan of financing subway construction, unification of all rapid transit lines is the only way to prevent a general fare rise, according to a statement issued yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The Rochester Red Wings defeated the Newark Bears, 7 to 4, in the series opener today.

BERLIN THE series "Klassikerder Kunst," published by the Deutsche Verlagsanstalt, Stuttgart, has this year brought us a particularly fine and interesting volume dealing with the great Italian master Leonardo da Vinci.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- With 255 boats going to the starting line, exceeding by one last year's record fleet for the opening day, Marblehead race week began today under ideal conditions. Clear skies and a spanking southeast racing breeze resulted in fast times for boats from some fifteen yacht club.

OMAHA, Aug. 4 -- The great North Central farm belt is full of minor prophets. Some cry one thing and some another. They are continually leading movements to get something from Congress or from the Legislature, or to finance some undertaking, or to do something for themselves.
Official positions of importance were accorded to a number of New York State realty men at the recent convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Cincinnati.

THE official designation of a new director for La Scala, Italy's lending opera house, in Milan, will not be made until the nomination of a new board of directors some four months hence. But sources of information here and in Italy seem to leave little doubt as to who the new incumbent will be.

DANNEMORA. "YOU can't possibly miss it," said the man at the railroad station. Nor indeed, the hill ascended, could one; for Clinton Prison dominates this little village, on the fringe of the Adirondacks, much as feudal castles used to dominate the clustered hearth of medieval vassal and liegeman.

Reduction of expenditures is the problem before municipalities today, points out A.J. Swenson, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board, who adds that assessed valuations have nothing to do with expenditures and should not be brought into the question.

A STAGE-STRUCK young man who had a two-line bit and was assistant stage manager in a piece called "Give Me Yesterday" was striving very hard a year or so ago to gain the attention of the play's producer, Charles Hopkins.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Simple ceremonies in a colorful setting have been arranged for the notification of President Hoover on Thursday of his renomination for the Presidency, according to an announcement made today by the Republican National committee.

QUTNTO MAGANINI, conductor of the New York Sinfonietta, recently offered a reward to any one who could find the orchestral score of Louis Moreau Gottschalk's "A Night in the Tropics." The composer, one of the first American symphonists, died in South America after conducting the first performance of the work.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The ceaseless search for ancient man will be carried on more smoothly and intelligently in the future as a result of the decisions made this week at the Congress on Prehistoric and Protohistoric Science.

BEFORE the Summer ends, the word "stratosphere" will probably become familiar to all the newspaper readers in America. No less than five groups of aeronauts, two by balloon and three by airplane, plan ascents into this frigid and mysterious region of the sky.

WITH the World War much of the glamour that had been Poland's for over a century vanished or was measurably modified by the realities of the Paris peace conference. These realities, in turn, were transfigured in accordance with the impressions made on the world by the conflicting propaganda through the maze of which the nation was striving to develop her new status.

THE very name of Canada's Maritime Provinces suggests the sea, and a glance at the accompanying map will show to what extent the salt water embraces these popular touring grounds. No part of Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Island and Prince Edward Island is far from a shore line.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has filed an application with the California State Railroad Commission for authority to acquire stock in the Pacific Public Service Company, now owned by the Standard Oil Company of California and the Pacific Lighting Corporation which hold joint control of the company.

MR. MAXWELL'S latest book is a study of a type of philanthropist which is unfortunately rather uncommon in this snatch-and-grab world; but which, in spite of its many unusual virtues, is redeemed into credibility by some very prosaic everyday faults.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 6 -- No attempt will be made by motion to dismiss the indictments against the thirteen members of the Nassau County Police Department who are to be tried for the killing of Hyman Stark, Charles R. Weeks, one of their attorneys, announced here today.

Proper knowledge of the property upon which a loan has been made is advised by Gerhard Kuehne as a means of assuring the mortgagee that the security is satisfactory to protect the lender's interests. He points out, however, that it often is impossible to avoid difficulties which arise from mismanagement of the property, diversion of funds by the owner or depreciation of the security resulting from natural and uncontrollable causes.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 6 -- The last large contingent of the Bonus Expeditionary Force said good-bye to this grateful little mill and mining community today, and now the story of how their departure was engineered can be told.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 6 -- Albert Walker was freed on bond today, and assurance was given that Libby Holman Reynolds would come here within a few days to surrender on the indictment charging her and Walker with the murder of her husband, Z. Smith Reynolds.

RICHARD ARLEN is the outstanding alumnus of "Wings.'' From what is described in the scenario as obscurity he jumped -- along with Mr. Rogers, the orchestra leader -- into fame. Nobody had heard of him much before that particular picture was produced, although he had been around quite a bit before.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Severe condemnation of government intervention in business by valorization schemes intended to stabilize commodity prices united a group of economists today at the Institute of Politics.

PARIS ANOTHER "picture of the year" has opened in Paris -- G.W. Pabst's "L'Atlantide," the talking version of Pierre Benoit's famous novel of the same name. This is the second truly important film of 1932 for France, though it does not bear comparison with "Les Croix de Bois" in any other way than importance.

Increased employment and an end to wage-cutting in the paper, box-board and paper-box industries are indicated in a survey completed last week by W. Clement Moore, economist for the industries mentioned. Executives of 21 per cent of all factories reporting in the survey stated that they have in mind hiring a considerably increased number of employes in the Fall and Winter months.

The Summer slump in business was less noticeable than usual this year, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, pointed out in a monthly review of business conditions prepared yesterday for the association's 25,000 members.

The largest touring party to come to the United States from the Netherlands since the war arrived yesterday on the Holland America liner Statendam to spend a week in New York. The party was led by J.P. G. Sabel, president of the Dutch Travel Club and Dr. Jan Zuyderhoff.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- Jim Bausch of Kansas registered the most stunning upset of the Tenth Olympic Games when he came through a formidable field to win the decathlon championship today.

Butter. Receipts, 13,576 packages. The market closed the week in firm position, with prices fully supported under the general bullish sentiment prevailing. Friday's quotations were nominally unchanged yesterday, with very limited street business, and exchanges both here and at Chicago were closed.

PARIS IT is idle to speculate upon the probable innovations to be revealed by the now imminent Paris couture collections, when we shall so soon be able to see for ourselves what they really are. One sartorial fact, however, is already established, that is the vogue for the velvet evening gown.

WELLAND, Ont., Aug. 6 -- Empire leaders stressed the historic significance of the event as Cnanda's great Welland Canal, permitting passage of the largest Great Lakes vessels to Lake Ontario, was dedicated this afternoon. The largest freighter on the lakes, the Lemoyne, carried a record cargo of wheat through the great locks today.
HAVANA, Aug. 6 -- The resignation of Manuel Marquez Sterling, Cuban Ambassador to Mexico, has been accepted by President Machado, according to an announcement today by the Department of State.
MADRID, Aug. 5 -- With revolutions in Brazil, rumblings in Chile and a tentative war between Bolivia ind Paraguay this week, Spain is watching South America with interest and understanding.

TO make the potential gangster a good citizen by catching him young and then studying and, if possible, removing the factors that drive him toward crime is the object of an experiment which has just been undertaken by the State of New York at its Reform School at Warwick, Orange County, in cooperation with the Columbia Medical Centre of New York City.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4 -- The Oneida Indians now live in Wisconsin, but they still are a tribe of the Six Nations of New York, whose council meets at Onondaga. Thus it has happened that Buffalo is the centre from which proceeds most of the historical data and legal counsel in an interesting case relating to land titles.

A lion-hearted Columbia University Club crew unleashed a stirring finish which enabled it to come from behind and arm me the senior four-oared shell with coxswain metropolitan title yesterday. The race was a high light of the metropolitan championship regatta, held on the Harlem River under the auspices of the New York Rowing Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tariff will be one of the political issues this year, or it should be. Apparently the advocates of freer trade have ignored one of the most convincing arguments made by John Stuart Mill ("Principles of Political Economy," Book III, Chapter 17, Section 4) nearly 100 years ago when he wrote: "* * * the only direct advantage of foreign commerce consists in the imports.

AMERICA has witnessed a right-about-face in immigration. Because of technological processes, because of the absence of free economic land, and because of an increasingly significant unemployment problem, we have had to abandon the welcome mat at our door and almost change the sign of "entrance" to "exit."

TAYLORVILLE, Ill., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Though his death had not been definitely established, two men were charged in warrants today with kidnapping and slaying John B. Colgrove, former president of the defunct J.B. Colgrove Co. State Bank.

PARIS, July 26 -- The long-studied and much-agitated plans for restoring Longwood, on St. Helena, where Napoleon died, seem finally about to be put into execution. The Society of the Friends of St. Helena has now 500,000 francs (about $20,000) at its disposal, and is only awaiting authorization from the Ministers of Foreign Affairs and Fine Arts to begin.

THE July issue of the Yale University Library Gazette is an entertaining number whose articles are mainly devoted to a description of some of the riches of the library. First of these is a sketch on the journals and letters of George Eliot.

WHILE woodcuts are always with us, they have, in common with other graphic media, their dormant periods. Recently they have hibernated in the chill of solander boxes devoted to collectors' specialties, and are now wakening from this unnatural seclusion to take an active part long familiar to them.

PARIS, July 18 THE Paris theatrical season has been showing signs of coming to an end even earlier than usual and the hot weather has precipitated its closing -- with the result that by now there is very little left that is artistically worth seeing, and there is not likely to be anything new of importance until October.

Councilor J. Sidney Rambridge, Mayor of Salisbury, England, and Wade H. Insley. Mayor of Salisbury, Md., were guests at a luncheon in their honor on the lawn of the Mount Vernon reproduction in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, under the auspices of the Maryland Society of New York.

THE Lausanne conference and the German elections have thrown into flux the political pattern which Europe has assumed during recent years. The tentativeness of the reparation settlement, the fog which surrounds the Anglo-French agreement and the failure of any German group to attain a clear majority in the Reichstag conspire to inject uncertain elements into the existing situation.

LONDON, July 29 -- General von Scleicher, the chief of the Reichswehr, and not Herr von Papen, the Chancellor, enjoys in the British press the distinction of being described as the master of the German situation. Public interest is fickle, and in this country today Schleicher is watched, while Dr. Bruening, not so long ago the "one and only" German statesman, is now thoroughly forgotten.

WARREN POINT, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Phil Perkins and Bobby Cruickshank combined a best ball of 66 to equal Johnny Golden's course record at Eimwood Country Club today and defeat Gene Sarazen, United States open champion, and Golden by 3 and 2 in an exhibition match for the benefit of a Paterson charity.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- With one of the best fields in the history of the tournament entered, the Eastern grass court lawn tennis championship got under way at the Westchester Country Club today.

HOMO AMERICANUS, despoiled by racketeers, weighted down by taxation, impoverished by the shrinkage in security values, confronted by waste in government and with a general grouch on the political and financial leaders of the land, will find both interesting and illuminating these maxima on public affairs from the pen of a candidate for the Presidency.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Charged by the police with having admitted that he sent threatening letters to J.P. Morgan, Henry Ford and Mayor Jerome T. Congleton of this city, Fasquale Monaco, 19 years old, of 236 Oliver Street, was held in $10,000 bail by Acting Judge Thomas F. Guthrie in police court here today.

Health Commissioner Wynne issued a warning to food dealers throughout the city yesterday against spurious badges being presented by unauthorized food inspectors. Dr. Wynne requests all food dealers to demand that any person claiming to represent the Health Department produce his official identification card.

SAINT SATURNIN is the country home of the Colombes, and the entire action of this novel is laid there. The book opens with the death of gentle old Mme. Colombe and thereafter concerns the relationship between the mind-de-luded husband who survives her and his three children.

SOUTHAMPTON -- There is every indication that the unusually gay series of social and sports events attendant upon the annual invitation tennis tournament, which closed yesterday at the Meadow Club, will continue throughout the closing weeks of the season.

Adequately trained young men are needed now more than ever by American industries to assist in solving new economic problems, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, declared yesterday. There is no reason, Mr. Watson said, why young men, college-trained and others, who are seeking to enter business, should feel discouraged.

MALVERN, England, Aug. 6 -- Bernard Shaw, watching the English premiere of his latest play, "Too True to Be Good," here today, expressed surprise that the American critics failed to identify one of its chief characters. He admitted that Private Meek is a faithfully drawn and unmistakable portrait, complete in every detail, of his very good friend, Colonel T.E. Lawrence of Arabia, now Aircraftsman Shaw.

It was reported a few days ago that the first definite link between the ancient civilization of India and that of the Tigris Valley had been discovered in the unearthing of a city less than a hundred miles northeast of old Babylon -- on the borders of Persia, at that time the home of the Elamites.

Stating that the move to put men "back on the road" was bound to grow and would be a fruitful source of business recovery, a prominent manufacturer here said yesterday that numerous complaints had reached him of retailers who, through the operation of their resident offices, are denied the opportunity of seeing merchandise lines other than those the buying office wishes to be seen.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Wes Schulmerich and Ray Kolp were the heroes today as the Braves and Reds divided a double-header Boston won the first game, 4 to 3, with a spectacular four-run rally in the ninth, but were shut out, 3 to 0, by Kolp in the second.

THE Shuberts, thinking things over, have decided to change the title of their forthcoming revue from "The Greenwich Village Follies" to "The Passing Show," which means that "The Passing Show" name will be affixed to one of the season's earliest entertainments.

Tamed legions of molecules of petroleum are carrying forward the automobile industry, according to Dr. Gustav Egloff, research chemist of the Universal Oil Products Company, Chicago. These molecules are reformed and disciplined by means of the process known as cracking oil, explains Dr. Egloff.

ROME, Aug. 5 -- The sudden and belated arrival of intense Summer heat again has given rise to rumors that the Pope is about to leave the Vatican to spend the vacation he usually takes from the middle of August to the middle of September in the papal villa, Castel Gandolfo.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- Although the Imperial Economic Conference was not in session today, with most of the delegates away attending the opening of the Welland Canal as guests of the Canadian Government, experts for the various delegations continued at work, studying the trade reciprocity proposal submitted by the respective dominions to the United Kingdom, and seeking to clear the road for possible definite action upon resumption of the conference on Monday.

THE Catalan statute lies on the long dark table before the Deputies of Spain -- dynamite enough to blow the place to pieces, all done up in the form of black words on white paper. For a year and a half it has hovered in the background, a portent of trouble that must be faced.

CAIRO, Aug. 5 -- Yet another military desert drama traveled its course to an abrupt conclusion this week with the death on the battlefield of Sheik Hamad Ibn Rafada el Awad, his two sons and his principal lieutenant, Sheik Mahmoud Abou Toukeika.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Plans for New York State's exhibit at the World's Fair next year were disclosed today by members of the advisory committee of the State's commission.
