TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Nathan Mayo, head of the Florida Prison Bureau, said today he had dismissed two prison guards and that two others had quit as a result of his investigation of deaths and reputed brutality at convict camps.

LAKE PLACID -- Many lovers of golf are here for today's finals in the Barksdale invitation tournaments, one for men and the other for women, which, sponsored by the Westport Golf Club, have for the third year been brought to a successful conclusion with a large field prominent amateur players taking part.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The blue waters of Lake Ontario were gently ruffled by a breeze from the southwest today as American and Canadian yachtsmen began the 150mile handicap race to Cobourg, Ontario, by wya of the Yorkshire Islands.

BLIEVING that Canadian methods of handling grain in bulk have attained a higher degree of efficiency than those which have been used by other countries, Mr. MacGibbon has written this detailed and very careful exposition of those methods and of the extensive organization and interests involved in the grain trade.

News was received here yesterday by mail from Pollensa, Mallorca, in the Balearic Isles, of the death by drowning on July 22 of William A. Brewster of Boston, a Harvard honor man and graduate of 1927, when his yacht capsized in a storm with four guests on board.

The $530,000 bathing pavilion at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways representing the city's effort to emulate the State's development at Jones Beach State Park was opened officially yesterday afternoon by Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly and Park Commissioner Albert C. Benninger of Queens.

ON Broadway or in the prov- inces, when the feature film is boring and the two-reel comedy more distressing than amusing, there is always one bright spot on the program. It is the news reel, with its bits of life that put to shame the sugary romance and the slapstick effusion between which it may be sandwiched.

Tennessee Democrats struck a deadly blow at what is known as the Lea-Horton machine in the nomination for Governor of State Treasurer MCALISTER of Nashville. For months the State's troubles, growing out of the collapse of banks and other enterprises controlled by former Senator LUKE LEA and ROGERS CALDWELL, allies of Governor HORTON, have been spread on the public records.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The issuance of a Presidential decree providing for severer penalties and special emergency tribunals to deal with the political rioting in Germany has been indefinitely postponed, there having been a decline in disorderly street manifestations.

Modernistic architecture of recent German school buildings represents the crystallization of a new spirit in German education, Professor Nickolaus L. Engelhardt of Columbia University pointed out recently to students in the Columbia University Summer session.

WITH the addition of two more volumes of The Journals, the publication of Boswell's private papers approaches completion. Fourteen volumes from that rich store recovered by Colonel Isham from Malehide Castle have now been issued; four more will probably suffice to present in its entirety one of the most fascinating records of self-revelation which any human being has left to posterity.

The new United Fruit liner Veragua, a turbo-electric vessel built by the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corpora- tion at Fore River, will make her first appearance in New York harbor today. Delivery of the ship was made at the shipyards after sea trials off the New England coast that officials of the company and of the builders pronounced successful and satisfactory in every way.

VIENNA, Aug. 5 -- The death of former Chancellor Ignaz Seipel this week was an event before which all other developments in Austrian politics, interesting though some of them were, paled into insignificance. It was not only that he was Austria's greatest, perhaps only, post-war statesman.

IN the very first chapter of this book the author tells us that Eyliffe Van Maarden is planning to kill Roger Sombert. Later on we are told how the murder was done and how the murderer took every possible precaution to cover up his tracks.

In letters to Secretary of the Treasury Mills and to Secretary of Labor Doak, Representative La Guardia, it was learned yesterday, urges the Cabinet members to support his suggestion to place all departments of the Federal Government on a five-day-week basis, believing it would force industry, banking and business to do likewise and result in additional employment.

LONDON, July 19 AT the end of this month theatrical England will set out on its annual pilgrimages into the countryside. At Canterbury the Old Stagers, the most venerable and distinguished amateur company in England, will give, in addition to their own original Epilogue, revivals of "Mr. Wu" and of Benn Levy's "This Woman Business."

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was not so very long ago when we had to pay 10 cents for sending a letter, and with no guarantee of delivery nor as to the time it would take in transportation. In England the cost of a "two-sheet" letter was 45 cents.

A PRE-ELECTION series of non-partisan radio talks and round-table discussions which will bring leading authorities on governmental and political problems before the microphone will be inaugurated on Sept. 6. The broadcasts are being presented under the auspices of the Committee on Civic Education by Radio of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education and the American Political Science Association.

THE plastic and musical arts of the U.S.S.R. are long since following their own ways, technically in no way inferior to the West, yet setting tasks for themselves of which the West is ignorant. Perhaps the whole great difference between Western art and art in the U.S.S.R. consists in a clear demand for ideological content, for conscious concurrence with the tasks of socialist construction.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Confined to a wheel chair for the last four years and regarded as helplessly crippled by wounds received in an attempted jail break in 1928, Harry Baxter, a convict serving a life sentence, in the State prison here, has been tunneling his way to freedom through walls of steel and concrete for the last three months.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave a dinner for more than fifty guests at Beaulieu this evening.

THE LAKE GUN" was probably the last of Cooper's writings to appear in print during his lifetime. It was published in a miscellany of the time, "The Parthenon," in 1850, and reprinted in an anthology, "Specimens of American Literature," in 1866.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4 -- Naturally, the decision of James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo to become a candidate for Representative in Congress from the Thirty-ninth District is the most conspicuous political event in Western New York at this stage of the campaign.

HOLLYWOOD THE town, which is always seeking something new and sensa- tional, returned this week to the first principles of motion pictures and was amazed at the results. "Bird of Paradise," which has been made by nearly every company under one title or another, reached the screen at an RKO-Radio preview and is now regarded by the industry as the type of film that will bring audiences back to the theatre.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6 -- Authorities here have been unable to locate Libby Holman Reynolds, but belief was expressed today that she may be aboard the yacht of a prominent Wilmington family in Chesapeake Bay.

THERE can be no question that the Julian Shaughnessy, who purports to write this "story of one man's life," is none other than Mr. Sullivan him- self. The realization that the two are identical makes it easier to accept the book as an autobiography, yet an autobiography which has about it much of the penetrating analysis that one expects in a good novel.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the ball which was given, tonight at the Meadow Club for the visiting tennis players as a conclusion of the annual invitation tournament.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES a grave injustice has been done, not alone to Cotton Mather, but to that great expression of the human mind in the domains of theology and morals, New England Puritanism; of which Cotton Mather was the perfect flower.

Mr. WALTER J. KOHLER, again the regular Republican candidate for Governor of Wisconsin, will make his first campaign speech' at Beaver Dam on Monday night. His address will toe preceded by "an old-fashioned torchlight parade." Antiquarians will jump at this revival of a bygone form of political illumination.

This Department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, c., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- A strike of about fifty caddies at the Lawrence Brook Country Club, near here ended today in a temporary armistice after a threatened free-for-all fight on the first fairway had been quieted with the arrest of five caddies by two State troopers.

Appropriately rounding out a week of rising prices and of reviving optimism, the share market established itself yesterday at the highest level of the current movement. Excited advances occurred in many stocks and the volume of trading was uncommonly heavy on the Stock Exchange.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- A slender young American Army officer with plenty of heart but not enough leg power crumpled today in the last event of the Olympic Games Pentathlon, a heartbreaking cross-country run, and America's finest bid for this championship tottered before the iron men of Sweden.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Equipoise and W.R. Coe's Ladysman divided the honors today before 10,000 persons when the former was a galloping winner of the Wilson Stakes to confirm his place as best in the handicap division, while Ladysman spreadeagled a crack field in the United States Hotel Stakes and won by four lengths.

Despite new forms of competition, the railroads dominate in transportation, E.G. Buckland, chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and president of the Railroad Credit Corporation, said last week in a speech before the Railway Accounting Officers' Association at Buffalo.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Hunt have returned from Europe and are at Cedarhurst, L.I., for the remainder of the Summer.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Peter Daylight's victory in the Class B event to carts went to four gruelling heats today before being decided. It featured a six-class program at the weekly matinee.

ONCE more Paraguay and Bolivia are flushed with the fever of war. More than a century ago the seeds of today's quar- rel were sown and for more than fifty years the two countries have been at the sword's point. Their quarrel is over the division of the Gran Chaco Boreal -- an immense area of swamps, plains and dense jungle, the frontiers of which touch Brazil, Paraguay, Argentina and Bolivia.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 49,816 shares in July despite the steep ascent of stock prices in the greater part of that month, and on Aug. 1 stood 181,388 shares above the low mark of 2,000,211 on June 20 and 3,408,101 shares under the high total of 5,589,700 on May 25, 1931, the greatest amount since tabulations have been kept.

WHEN the United States entered the World War the administration was not entirely clear in its own mind what our part in the struggle should be. Obviously our entrance placed at the service of the allied cause a practically unlimited supply of money and material.
"Beer? Who said beer? Let's talk about cheese, instead. All right, we'll compromise: we'll make it cheese and beer."

NICE ONE writer who will never again write for the screen is P.G. Wodehouse! The father of Jeeves, that peerless "gentleman's gentleman," just finished serving eighteen months in the Hollywood studios, so he should know what he is talking about.

BOOKS on Mary Wollstonecraft multiply -- proof that appreciation of her work and character increases with time, the severest test of human values. It is now 135 years since she died. Not many people are remembered with interest so long as that, and fewer still are those whose fame grows after the first century has passed.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Archmere, the estate of John J. Raskob, former Democratic National Chairman, at Claymont, Del., six miles north of Wilmington, has been sold to the Premonstratensian Fathers of St. Norbert College, Depere, Wis., it was announced today by T.B. O'Toole, a local real estate man, who said he negotiated the sale.

Buyers in the market are encountering difficulty in finding merchandise suitable for selling now and for the next few weeks, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. So much attention has been expended on the development of wool dresses that it is hard to obtain desirable silks in the new colors for immediate delivery.

THE grain in retail trade noted as a result of improved sentiment was fully maintained during the week. Volume was reported somewhat better than last month's average. Demand did not appear to centre upon any particular kind of merchandise, but took in a number of articles which were wanted to meet ordinary needs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Bonds valued at $600, alleged to have been stolen in Boston, were recovered here when Ruth Lamar, 23, of 35 East Thirty-eighth Street, New York, and her husband, William Lamar, 24, of Boston, attempted, it is alleged, to dispose of them.

FRANKLIN is supposed to have flown a kite in a thunderstorm, to have drawn sparks from a key attached to the string and thus to have proved the identity of electricity and lightning -- a question about which philosophers were as much concerned in the eighteenth century as we are about the nature of the cosmic rays.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- After two desperate combats the Cubs triumphed over the Phillies in both ends of a double bill today before 20,000 persons. The scores were 10 -- 9 in the first tilt and 10 -- 8 in an eleven-inning second battle.

Several melees marked the activities yesterday of men's clothing workers on the third day of the general suspension of work called by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America "to remedy the deplorable sweat-shop conditions that have come into existence in the industry since the depression."

THE celebration this year of the two-hundredth anniversary of the birth of David Rittenhouse, the famous Philadelphia clock-maker and astronomer, has focused attention on one of the most remarkable men of Colonial times.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Astronomers predict the best shower of shooting stars in several years after midnight next Thursday.

THE Albertina Rasch Dancers will be introduced to the Stadium audiences Tuesday and Wednesday nights. The public will see for the first time a group of seventy-five dancers and soloists, representing a national school of the dance created and established by Mme. Rasch, in an elaborate choreographic program expressing the American idiom in an indigenous synthesis of music and the dance.

PARIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Paris fashion talk for the Fall has developed into two good-sized battles. Lined up in one skirmish are the designers, waging a war between the thorax and the hips. On another front are the dressmakers and the manufacturers.

IN somewhat the same spirit that we Americans are honoring the Father of our Country, the Azorians -- inhabitants of that archipelago of "sea-grown, mountains" which constitute Europe's westernmost outpost and appear on the map as a cluster of nine dots -- are about to honor, not the father of their isles but the finder of them.

MIAMI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Testimony that the body of Haden Clarke, young writer, was bruised and bore no powder marks and that Captain W.N. Lancaster had threatened to "get rid" of him, was introduced today in the prosecution's effort to prove that the British flier killed Clarke because of jealousy over Mrs. Jessie M. Keith-Miller, Australian aviatrix.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- The most dramatic episode provided within the Coliseum today was not anything that transpired on the track or the field, but came immediately before the beginning of competition in the afternoon session with the staging of the Olympic victory ceremony for the 5,000-meter run.

Fossils and Floods. It is true that fossils of marine origin may be found practically everywhere on earth, and it is true that practically all parts of the earth have been submerged under prehistoric seas. But all parts of the earth's crust were not under water at the same time.

Prices advanced vigorously in virtually all sections of the listed bond market on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's two-hour trading period. The best gains were by domestic corporation issues, many of which were bid up 1 to 5 points. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of ten leading foreign loans made a new high mark for the year.

RONALD COLMAN, whose last picture was "Arrowsmith," is back at work again. With King Vidor to direct, he is making "Cynara" for Samuel Goldwyn. Notified on his European trip that the play had been bought for him, the actor paid a visit to Robert Gore-Brown, who wrote the book and was co-author of the play.

LIBERTYVILLE, Ill. THE collapse of Samuel Insull's public utility empire, causing heavy losses to thousands of large and small investors, has a special significance for this community, which was dominated materially and spiritually by Mr. Insull.

VIENNA TO be at home in the world of motors and structural steel requires a special kind of training, the development of which is an essential characteristic of education in our times. Despite their many differences in outlook, we find today that Communist educators in Soviet Russia, Socialist educators in Vienna and more conservative educators in Hitler-inclined Prussia, are all at work upon promising developments in technical training for the average boy and girl.

WHO LOOKS AT A KING. THREE years ago H.G. Wells wrote a book, "The King Who Was a King." A week ago yesterday Mr. Wells criticized King George for departing "from his proper political and social neutrality" to take part in the crisis of last Autumn which resulted in the overturn of the Labor Party and the substitution of a National Government.

James J. McCormick, Tammany district leader and Deputy City Clerk, through his counsel, Robert S. Johnstone, obtained permission yesterday from Judge Donnellan of General Sessions to inspect the minutes of the grand jury which in February last returned two felony and two misdemeanor indictments against him for accepting "tips" from couples he had just married in his office in the Municipal Building.

Led by United States Steel preferred, in which obviously there was a frightened retreat by bearish speculators, the share market extended its advance widely yesterday. In many respects, it was the most spectacular market witnessed since the rise started on the Stock Exchange a month ago.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, historic starting point of so many of the great flights of the last five years, is extending its activities in both directions. Its spacious concrete and steel hangars, with their wide apron, and the constant improvement of its runways attest its modern spirit.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Dabbler o'Dingle o'Pinegrade, the noted Sealyham terrier from the Pinegrade Kennels of Frederick C. Brown of Armonk, N.Y., was pronounced best dog in the fifteenth annual show of the Kennel Club of Atlantic City, which was held today at the Atlantic City airport under the most favorable auspices.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- There has been a truce to Germany's party strife since last Sunday's Reichstag elections, and it is no mere figure of speech. It has been duly ordained by Presidential decree under that clause of the German Constitution -- Article XLVIII -- which provides against emergencies endangering law and order.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Rushing into the lead a second after the start, Faireno, winner of four important stakes this year, galloped to an easy victory in the $25,000 added Hawthorne Handicap today.

IN the year 1703 the great Manchu Emperor, K'ang-hsi, erected his first country seat near the little town of Jehol, in the land of the Harchin Mongols, outside the Great Wall. Thus he laid the foundation to the famous Summer Palace, China's Fontainebleau.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's proposal, made at Chicago, for the use of men in reforestation projects has met with considerable partisan criticism, and it has seemed justifiable that, as one acquainted with the technical side of the problem, I might attempt to clarify the subject.

MARSEILLES, July 29 -- One grand avenue of thrills, soldering in France's famous Foreign Legion, will henceforth be closed to adventurous Americans. Enlistment officers are keeping a sharp lookout for Americans with a distinct eye to weeding out those sons of Uncle Sam who wish to take a fling at that romance in the raw for which the Legion stands in the minds of youth since generations.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics were able to get only five hits off George Blaeholder today, but they were effective enough to give the Mackmen a 4 to 2 victory over the St. Louis Browns.

PARIS IT does not always happen in France that a change of majority brings a change in policy. More than once in recent years the electorate has been amazed to find that what it voted against still goes on and that what it voted for does not eventuate.

A WEEK ago there was started a significant cooperative effort by a group of rival concerns, some of them bitter competitors. General Air Express is its trade name and it consists of an interline agency in which seven air lines are using single manifests and way bills for reciprocal shipment of freight over 17,000 miles of airways.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Last Sunday Paris provided an illustration of how international sports matches may be as unsuccessful as international conferences in improving international relations.

WINDOW-SHOPPING expeditions in New York never fail to reveal something of interest. A recent stroll down Madison Avenue brought a trick bag to our attention (illustrated). It is quite the most entertaining thing: within its slender contour it conceals a cigarette case, built into the outer wall of the bag and hidden even when the flap is lifted.
ALBANY, Aug 6 (AP) -- Vince Barton's home run over the right field wall with two men out in the ninth inning tonight gave Albany's new International League team a 2-1 victory over Buffalo.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 2 -- Manuel V. Domenech, the Insular Treasurer, has reported to Governor James R. Beverley that Puerto Rico collected revenues in excess of estimates during the fiscal year which ended June 30. Actual collections were $12,662,000, exceeding the estimate by $662,000 and almost $1,000,000 in excess of the revenues of the previous fiscal year.

MOSTLY, only those enjoy reading about finance who are her devotees in either theory or practice and so are on intimately understanding terms with all her aims and methods and significance. Those who are not thus familiar with her holy of holies are apt to look askance on books about finance and to consider them bitter pills to swallow.

An part of the general movement to end the chaotic conditions in the cotton and textile industries, a syndicate composed of the principal cotton mill interests is being formed with powerful banking support to purchase the 3,000,000 bales of cotton held either directly or indirectly by the Federal Farm Board.

In the country it is auction time. Now that the Summer folks have appeared with their eccentric ideas about value, the auctioneer is taking up his stand on the front porch and is flinging Household goods to the highest bidders. Most country auctions are second funerals; they bury all that is left of one branch of the family.

PARIS THERE are few characters in history so romantic, so appealing and so mysterious as the son of Napoleon -- he whom we have called the King of Rome, whom the Austrians know as the Duke of Reichstadt, and whom the poets have baptized as the Eaglet.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 6 -- According to reports received by the Ontario Department of Mines, the revised figures of production from the gold mines of the Province for the first half of 1932 not only confirm but show an increase, compared with the recently issued cumulative monthly statement.

MANILA, July 6 -- The disposition of the various entities within the Philippine government to meet a new fiscal condition is demonstrated in the estimated costs and requests for appropriations submitted to the budget office by the bureaus and divisions.

THE eagle with outspread wings is the only familiar thing about the new quarter-dollar just placed in circulation in commemoration of the bicentennial anniversary of George Washington. The standing Liberty which has adorned the obverse or face side of the quarter since 1916 has given way to a left profile bust of the first President of the United States.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Drives for funds for the various hospitals will soon begin -- for the Memorial Hospital at North Conway, the Littleton Hospital, which is holding its committee meeting at the home of Mrs. John G.M. Glessner at Littleton to discuss plans, and for the Morrison Hospital at Whitefield.

It may be a little too early to single out the heroes and heroines of the Olympic Games at Los Angeles, but the performances of Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson certainly have won for herself and the United States signal honors during the past week.

THERE were 268 violations of the air commerce regulations during the second quarter of 1932 which came to the attention of the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce. The department collected fines amounting to $1,025, the major part of which was for penalties assessed before the three months' period.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Aug. 6 -- All Arkansas is invited to a huge homecoming celebration planned for Bill Carr here Aug. 24, and so is Ben Eastman, his sturdiest rival in the 400-meter run that made history at the tenth Olympiad in Los Angeles yesterday.
If it hadn't been for a deer Harold Hartogensis would have caught his trout. It happened this way, he says, writing from Stony Creek, N.Y.:

PITTSFIELD -- The Lenox Dog Show is to be held next Saturday on Mrs. Molly Covington Hanna's farm and will be an outstanding sporting event of the Berkshire season, with more than 500 dogs on exhibition. Miss Elizabeth L. Godwin is president, John Matthews, treasurer, and Frederick S. Dela- field, secretary, of the Lenox Kennel Club.

BAR HARBOR -- These are the days when everybody's calendar is full to overflowing and the Summer resident of Bar Harbor wonders how he may arrange his time to do all the things he wants to do in this short month of August, into which so many of sport and social activities are crowded.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 6 -- "Citizenship" has been the big discovery made by several hundred young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware who came to the Infantry C.M.T.C. at Camp Dix a week ago to learn something of the art of war.

The Fall will see much attention given to knitted sportswear, and the English influence, strongly evident in all sports fashions for Fall, is par ticularly prominent in this merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion and merchandise counselor.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The New Bedford Standard-Mercury announced today a consolidation of The New Bedford Evening and Sunday Standard with The New Bedford Daily and Sunday Times. The new papers will take the titles of The Standard-Times and The Sunday Standard Times.

Announcement that Charles B. Noonan of Schenectady had been substituted for Frank H. Crosswaith as the Socialist candidate for Lieutenant Governor was made yesterday at the State headquarters of the party, 7 Bast Fifteenth Street. Mr. Crosswaith, a Negro, declined the designation in order to run for Representative in the Twenty-first Congressional District in Harlem, where there is a large Negro population.

POLICE have discovered that the incoming emergency calls can be speeded by connecting the telephone direct with the radio transmitter. This enables all police cars to hear the conversation between the dispatcher and the citizen reporting the burglary, hold-up or whatever it may happen to be.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 -- It is business rather than sentiment which has brought together at the Ottawa Economic Conference representatives of all the nations in the British Commonwealth. It is business more than sentiment which has developed in Canada, particularly within the past year or two, a disposition to buy products of the British Empire.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- A rangy, powerful youngster from Monroe, N.Y., who came back from almost certain defeat, tomorrow will carry the colors of the metropolitan area into the final round of the annual State amateur golf tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- The international character of the dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay has diverted public attention from the fact that a war of much more serious proportions already exists in Brazil. The fact that the Brazilian trouble is a civil war detracts only from its international importance.

THE year 1932 has cut deeply through the whole system of American education. In cross-section is revealed its fundamental strength and weakness. Economic forces are compelling educator and public to examine carefully the blocks with which the structure has been built.

HARBIN, July 10 -- Taking advantage of the uncertain state of affairs here since Sino-Japanese hostilities were carried into North Manchuria, kidnapping gangs have become increasingly active, and at least attempted kidnappings are almost a daily occurance in Harbin and vicinity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Hoover went to his Summer camp on the Rapidan this afternoon, where, before his return, probably Monday, he will complete the revision of his speech accepting the Republican nomination for President. The notification ceremonies will take place Thursday night in Constitution Hall.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Retaining its first-semester position during the second term. Sigma Alpha Mu led the twenty-one Rutgers fraternities in scholarship during the past academic year with an average of 79.316, it was announced today by Luther H. Martin, registrar.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 4 -- North Carolina has just witnessed the completion of a textile strike which furnished a sharp contrast to two strikes in 1929 that attracted the attention of a large part of the world to this State. With the Governor acting as chairman of the board of arbitration, the latest textile strike ended in a settlement which is expected to furnish a precedent for future disputes.

I CANNOT myself see any permanent upward trend except through the solution of some of the problems, if not all, coming to us from the great war. I cannot see any upward rise in the price of farm products or the restoration of confidence, which is necessary to the rebuilding of our economic prosperity.

Several prominent pastors will return from their vacations to preach in their own pulpits today and on subsequent Sundays as an economy measure. In other years these churches have engaged visiting clergymen of distinction to be the guest Summer preachers.

MERLE JOHNSON has prepared a revised edition of his "American First Editions" to be published on Oct. 1 by the office of The Publishers' Weekly. Forty names have been added to the list of American authors whose first editions are being actively collected.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- The unprecedented record-making in track and field has so absorbed every one's attention that the remarkable success of the United States in two other fields has not caused the stir that it would otherwise. Following the surprising victory of the American wrestlers in winning the catch-as-catch-can team championship, Joseph Levis of New York placed second yesterday in the individual foils bouts.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- One hundred and three yachts started in the final regatta of the seventeenth annual race meet and championship regattas of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association today. The race was managed by the Bellport Bay Yacht Club and the course was a triangular one off the clubhouse.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 -- An order barring officials from confiscating The Public Press and interfering with its sale was refused by Federal Judge Paul W. Guilford today. The judge held that the Minnesota law permitting action by injunction to suppress alleged obscene publications is valid in parts, despite a decision by the United States Supreme Court holding one section of the act unconstitutional.

There could be no doubt in the mind of any one who listened to last week's conversation in business circles that revival of hopefulness about the financial outlook has begun. It could not be said to reflect a marked change in the business situation. Production and consumption of goods continue very low; perhaps they were last month at the lowest since the prolonged reaction of trade began.
The burden of responsibility attached to maintaining an imposing winning streak proved a trifle too much for the Giants yesterday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Henry B. Plant's twelve-meter sloop Clytie, champion of Long Island Sound last year, struck her old gait today in the Stamford Yacht Club's fortieth annual regatta in the Sound association championship. Over an eighteen-mile triangle she defeated Horace Havemeyer's Mouette by 2 minutes and 33 seconds.

GEORGE ARLISS, who has been having a vacation in England, will return to the United States some time this month. His next picture, to be called "The Adopted Father," will go into production at the Warner Brothers' Burbank studio in September.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To me, as a former inmate of one of the State's largest penal institutions, two recent issues of THE TIMES contained items of peculiar emphasis. One was the report of Governor Roosevelt's radio talk on prisons and the other Warden Lawes's article on the shortcomings of our educational system.

With the release of the last patient yesterday from the Lying-in Hospital at its present location, Second Avenue and Seventeenth Street, preparations are being made for the moving of that institution to the new site of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College Association at York Avenue, Sixty-eighth to Seventieth Street, overlooking the East River.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Changes will be made in the electoral votes of thirty-two of the forty-eight States for the 1932 election, eleven States gaining votes and twenty-one losing them.

The modern biographer unites the functions of anatomist, diagnostician, cross-examiner, detective, spy, alienist and judge, Claude M. Fuess, author of "Daniel Webster" and "Carl Schurz," asserted recently in an address in the contemporary literature symposium being conducted in the Columbia University Summer session.

RED BANK, N.J. -- Bridge enthusiasts will have their innings during the coming week. The national championship tournament of the American Bridge League opens tomorrow night at the convention hall here and play continues every day throughout the week.

MADRID, July 15, 1932 ANOTHER important step for the future of music in Spain has just been taken with the decree of the Ministry of Public Instruction (published in the Gaceta de Madrid of July 12), which gives practical effect to one of the cardinal reforms introduced by the republic last year, but which had remained thus far a dead letter.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 6 -- With Harry East leading the attack with seven tallies, the Burnt Mills polo team advanced into the final round of the Wheatley Cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club by routing David Evans's Smithtown quartet, 13 to 5, on Hitchcock Field today.

WASHINGTON Aug. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 30 amounted to 510,687 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 9,557 cars more than in the preceding week, 251,131 cars fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 409,094 cars fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

MARC CHADOURNE is a novelist. His "Cecile de la Folie" won the Prix Femina in 1930. Undoubtedly he has brought to his "China" a novelist's imaginativeness, a keenness for personalities and an almost photographic impressionability for the high spots.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 6 -- The Maryland Yacht Club's eleven-year quest for the Miles River Trophy, the Chesapeake's most coveted speedboat prize, ended today when E.L. Chase drove his Pep II to a clean sweep of the three-heat 1932 series of the Miles River Yacht Club championships.

Only a few bonds were called last week for redemption in August before their maturity dates, but those announced for future months included a large industrial and two large foreign issues. The total for August is now $56,019,000, compared with $25,941,000 in July, and $113,754,000 in August, 1931, for corresponding periods.

LONDON GENERALLY speaking." remarks J.C. Squire, when reviewing in The Sunday Times the late Edward Marjoribanks's "Life of Lord Carson" (Gollancz), "I think that people's lives ought not to be written until they are dead."

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The plan of the Deutsche Lufthansa for regular airplane service between Europe and South America has made such progress in recent months that the first test flights probably will be made early next year. A 6,000-ton steamer will be stationed in mid-Atlantic between Gambia, Africa, and Natal, Brazil, for a refueling station.

The rebuttal filed by James E. Finegan last Thursday with Governor Roosevelt to the answer of Mayor Walker to the charges of misfeasance against him was made public yesterday. The document includes five pages, contains nine allegations, five denials and asks for opportunity to submit proofs of charges originally made.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Winning her first leg on the Gold Cup in the Maidstone Club's seventh annual women's invitation tournament, Miss Helen Jacobs, seeded No. 1 in the tournament and No. 2 in the national ranking, turned back the determined Mrs. Lawrence A. Harper of Berkeley, Cal., 6 -- 3, 6-- 1, today in the final.
